column2: If a large number of homeowners who have oil burners wait until December or January to find out the hard way wherther there really is a fuel oil shortage and convert to coal, they will suffer also from a lack of coal, M.R. Grover, assistant to the president of Anthracite Industries, 405 Lexington Avenue, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Donald M. Nelson, obviously fighting mad and ready for a showdown on his administration of the war production program, asserted today that "from now on any one who crosses my path is going to have his head taken off."

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The greatest battle fought in Western Europe since the fall of France took place today around the sleepy little English Channel port of Dieppe, France, and United States troops and bombers were in it.

Directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company maintained unbroken yesterday the company's twenty-one-year dividend record by a declaration for the regular quarterly payment of $2.25 a share on A.T. capital stock.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 19 -- John P. Lynch, former Stratford (N.J.) justice of the peace, was convicted at 7:42 o'clock this evening of first-degree murder in the ambush slaying of George C. Miller, Clementon policeman.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces have recaptured the walled city and port of Wenchow on China's east coast, only 600 miles from Japan, a Chinese communique said today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Aug. 20 -- The 10,000-ton Australian cruiser Canberra was lost in the Solomon Islands battle, it was disclosed today by Prime Minister John Curtin.

Saunterers along a certain narrow street have a way of stopping short at a little shop that has a big sign emphatically lettered in black: "Honey Ice Cream." This placard -- it seems especially appealing when the thermometer is high and the humidity more so -- is an unspoken invitation to weary pedestrians.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Costs of living in large cities rose 0.4 per cent between June 15 and July 15, the second month of general price control, Secretary of Labor Perkins announced today.

UNITED STATES RANGER HEADQUARTERS, Somewhere in Britain, Aug. 19 -- Uncle Sam's Rangers, who have been taking lessons in rough-and-tumble slaughter from their British counterparts, the Commandos, went along to Dieppe today on a field trip to practice, on live Germans, what they had learned.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The outcome of the battle that the British Navy fought last week in narrow enemy-infested Mediterranean waters to take supplies to Malta was officially disclosed today by the Admiralty.

GARY, Ind., Aug. 19 -- The American Federation of Teachers today elected John M. Fewkes, physical education instructor at Tilden High School, Chicago, as president of the federation to succeed Dr. George S. Counts, professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, who has headed the organization since 1940 and declined re-election.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, Aug. 19 (UP) -- A young United States soldier broke into the staff room of a movie theatre today, shot and seriously wounded an usherette and then committed suicide. The soldier's name was withheld.
OTTAWA, Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- Canadian troops who participated in the Allied attack at Dieppe today suffered severe casualties, Defense Minister James L. Ralston announced late tonight.

The report of the Electric Power and Light Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months to June 30, issued yesterday by Joe H. Gill, president, shows a consolidated net income, after expenses and charges, of $8,030,294. This compares with a consolidated net of $5,811,994 in the twelve months to June 30, 1941.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Silver Star for exceptional gallantry in action has been awarded to Major Frank D. Sharp of Salem, Ore., and his crew of eight men whose Flying Fortress battled twenty-three Japanese fighter planes over Burma, the War Department disclosed today.

To New Yorkers in this weather the prospect of cooler homes and offices next Winter sounds more like a promise than a threat. But the proposal to shut off the hot water, except for a few hours in the night and morning, is something else again. Even in this land of modern conveniences it is likely that a majority of the adult population grew up in homes where running hot water was a luxury.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Administration officials who are drafting a new anti-inflation program for President Roosevelt were reported today to have prepared an Executive Order establishing a seven-member Economic Stabilization Authority, with broad powers to coordinate Federal policies on prices, wages, taxes, savings and credits.

THE last this observer heard of Professor Moe Berg, late instructor of languages in the bullpen at Fenway Park, he was heading southward to spread good-will in the Latin-American countries. He can talk to them in their own languages.

Digging into cellars, attics and back rooms, employes of the United States Rubber Company offices in Rockefeller Center yesterday came up with many rare and almost extinct musical instruments as well as modern ones, to be turned over to United States soldiers, sailors and marines now being held prisoners in Japan.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 19 -- "Two Against Tomorrow," a story of the last days of the siege of Bataan, has been purchased by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer from its author, Peter Viertel, who is now in the United States Marine Corps. The studio has assigned the property to Edgar Selwyn for production.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Aug. 20 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique early today:

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 19 -- Alejo Russell of Argentina and Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Ecuador walked off the stadium courts in victory late today after providing three hours of exciting tennis that had the gallery cheering until dusk at the Longwood Cricket Club.

OTTAWA, Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King tonight announced a new manpower policy that, by curtailing or eliminating non-essential civilian activities and restricting the right to seek employment, will require every Canadian citizen to "make his most useful contribution" to the war effort.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 19 -- Committeemen of the Aluminum Workers of America (C.I.O.), led by their president, Nicholas A. Zonarich, sent a telegraphic demand to the War Labor Board tonight for an "immediate explanation of its decision refusing pay increases to employes of the Aluminum Company of America."
Sales of properties in Manhattan on all-cash terms were reported yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- A Federal grand jury's investigation of charges that confidential naval information was published by The Chicago Tribune, The New York Daily News and The Washington Times Herald ended today with a decision that no violation of the law had been disclosed.

A stock-selling fraud through which thirty-six persons interested in aiding the Allied cause were said to have been cheated of $75,000 was charged to Harvey H. Hevenor, a former bank president, in a Federal indictment yesterday.

VICHY, France, Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- A total of 4,000 Jewish refugees in occupied France and 4,000 others in unoccupied France have been arrested and deported to Polish Silesia "as a lesson to Jewish accomplices of terrorists and black market traffickers," the German-operated Paris edition of the Paris Soir reported today.

One of the proposals growing out of the recent Book Mobilization Conference, that of naming a "Victory Book for the Month" which would be featured as such through the retail book trade, has been approved by the executive committee of the Book Mobilization Committee.

LONDON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Commando forces and tanks of the Western Allies invaded and lambasted Germany's coastal forts at Dieppe today and withdrew as planned after achieving an all-day assault on the enemy shore of the English Channel, something Adolf Hitler never dared to try.

Because of numerous postponements, the girls' Eastern grass courts invitation singles tennis tournament at the Richmond County Country Club, Staten Island, was cancelled yesterday. Competition in the doubles, however, was started, with the field moving into the semi-finals.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, at El Alamein, Egypt (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The last man grimy Tommies expected to see in the choking dust and debris of the desert battlefield was Prime Minister Winston Churchill, and when Mr. Churchill, smiling, puffing on his black cigar and giving the "V" sign, appeared at a brigade headquarters, one Londoner shouted:

In the face of protests by tenant organizations and some landlords against the hot water rationing and fuel conservation program that Mayor La Guardia has reported will be put into effect soon for apartment houses, the Real Estate Board of New York has called a meeting for today of owners and managing agents of residential buildings to discuss the situation.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Aug. 19 -- Less than forty-eight hours after the burial of A.J. Barber, real estate broker and business promoter, his brother and associate, Louis Barber, a 67-year-old attorney, plunged to his death from the twelfth floor of the Hotel Sterling today.

More than $18,000,000 worth of war bonds and stamps were sold in July by thirty-four non-grocery chain store companies reporting to the Institute of Distribution, John P. Nichols, general manager, reported yesterday. Only six companies filing complete reports for the period failed to reach the campaign quota that had been set as 4 per cent of total July sales. One store reached 32 per cent, Mr. Nichols said.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 19 -- A sentence of three years in a Federal penitentiary was imposed here today by Federal Judge Thomas F. Meaney on Frederick W. Bilgeshouse, 30 years old, of 218 Fifiteth Street, West New York, N.J., who had been convicted by a jury July 31 of having violated the Federal sabotage statute.

Nineteen student nurses, members of the senior class of the New York Medical College, Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals, pledged themselves to Army-Navy duty as future members of the Red Cross First Reserve in a ceremony held yesterday afternoon at New York Chapter Red Cross headquarters, 315 Lexington Avenue.
Following is the address of Governor Lehman, temporary chairman of the Democratic State Convention:

The decision of the Federal Reserve Board to reduce reserve requirements of member banks in this city and Chicago, effective today, produced yesterday a much firmer tone in the government bond market, particularly in bills, certificates of indebtedness, notes and in the short-term bonds.

Production of petroleum in the United States last week averaged 3,893,450 barrels daily, a decrease of 77,000 barrels from the 3,970,450 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 145,050 barrels below the recommendation of 4,038,500 daily by the Office of Petroleum Coordinator for August.

Nine men who drifted on two life rafts for forty-eight days in the Atlantic after their ship was torpedoed and sunk by a German submarine told their story at an East Coast port yesterday. Among them were seven Norwegians, a Dane and a Swede.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Department stores, stocking up for the day when civilian production will be curtailed sharply, have on hand an average supply of nearly five months' merchandise.

The very last thing in the world that one would call Mrs. Roosevelt is a weather vane. She is a lady of very firm convictions. But a First Lady who moves around the country so much and so fast may become, without meaning to, a weather map and the publication of weather maps has been banned by the censors.

The latest attacks by German submarines on Brazilian shipping have brought one of our best friends in South America to the point of a formal declaration of war. If this declaration comes, it will mark the beginning of Brazil's second war with Germany. She was the only one of the South American nations to enter the First World War on the side of the allied nations.
The proposed rationing of hot water and heat is being "lapped up" by the landlords, but what about the tenants?

THIRD ARMY HEADQUARTERS SOMEWHERE IN LOUISIANA, Aug. 19 -- Thousands of troops of the Third Army, the "Army of the South," forded muddy bayous and pushed through the tangled slash pine forests of Louisiana today in a continuation of country-wide manoeuvres which are 'topping off' the training of many of our combat divisions.

Robert J. Murray, president of the New York Cotton Exchange, leased a terrace apartment in River Edge House at 33 East End Avenue through the Herbert McLean Purdy Management Corporation, the latter disclosed yesterday.

The clandestine anti-Gestapo, pro-German Army radio station calling itself Gustav Siegfried Eins last night described wild confusion among Elite Guards in Paris when they heard the news of the Dieppe raid, said the Columbia Broadcasting System's short-wave listening station, which recorded the broadcast here.

MOSCOW, Aug. 19 -- Today's Soviet communique reports no significant changes in the general situation oh the Stalingrad and Caucasian fronts. It is clear that General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock is making a tremendous effort to advance both wings of his forces and that the situation for the defenders is graver than it has been at any time since the first German attempt to rush the Don-Volga defenses failed.

" Somewhere I'll Find You," the last picture which Clark Gable made for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer before he joined the Army, will have its Broadway premiere a week from today at the Capitol. Lana Turner has the feminine lead in the film, which stars Gable as a newspaper correspondent in the Philippines during the Japanese invasion.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 19 -- The convention of the State Federation of Labor sent an appeal to the people of India today, asking them to abandon the "ill-timed and ill-advised" civil disobedience campaign launched by the Indian Congress under the leadership of Mohandas K. Gandhi and "not to play into the hands of your enemies."

A FIELD DRESSING STATION, BRITISH SOUTH COAST, AUG. 19 (U.P.) -- Dead-tired and battered, Commandos from the French coast streamed into this dressing station tonight for treatment of arm, leg and face wounds they brought back from Dieppe.

Replacement of General Sir Claude Auchinleck by General Sir Harold Alexender is plainly a continuation of Mr. Churchill's long search for a man to match the fighting spirit of Rommel. The test of battle alone will show whether Alexander is that man. Preparations by both sides in the desert indicate that the test is near.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The War Production Board expects to see President Roosevelt's shipbuilding goal for this year, 8,000,000 deadweight tons, surpassed by about 10 per cent.

Reflecting increased sales, which amounted to $27,109,707 for the fiscal year ended with June, compared with $22,330,492 a year before, earnings of the American Agricultural Chemical Company exceeded those of the previous year despite substantially larger taxes, according to a report issued yesterday.

The appointment of food wardens on a block plan basis probably would be the most effective way to diffuse nutritional information among urban low-income groups, according to a study made by Earl L. Koos, sociologist, and Ruth E. Thoreson, nutritionist, among sixty-one families in the Kips Bay and Yorkville areas, near Cornell Medical Center.

Lists of new rentals released yesterday by renting agents showed continuance of the demand for apartments in buildings on the West Side. The names of Laurence Lustig, Max Asher, Nathan Goldstone and Samuel Morey were added to the tenant roster of the Majestic at 115 Central Park West, according to Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., the agents.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Bears gained considerable ground toward mathematical certainty of their seventh International League pennant in eleven years as they galloped to a double victory today over the last-place Red Wings.

BOSTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- A death toll of sixteen men in the crash of an Army transport plane against a mountain in Peru, Mass., on Saturday was revealed in the official casualty list made public today by the First Service Command.

THE Pacific has always been the ocean of incredible voyages. At some date in the prehistoric past, the Polynesians, who sewed their ships together with coconut husk fiber, presumably brought the sweet potato to the South Sea Islands from Peru. That must have been the most hazardous voyage ever made, for it necessarily involved a two-way crossing of 5,000 empty miles of ocean in a vessel that didn't have a single nail in it.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- There was a surprise today when the Brookmeade Stable's Very Snooty captured the $5,975 Albany Handicap by a length before 8,382, the biggest weekday attendance of the meeting. Although he led almost all the way, the son of Psychic Bid had to survive a claim of foul that the stewards deliberated long and carefully.

William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, submitted a report, dated Aug. 13, to Mayor La Guardia yesterday calling attention to "irregularities" that he ascribed to the New York Pathological and X-Ray Laboratory of 509 Fifth Avenue and to Julius J. Brosen, clerk in charge of the Manhattan Marriage License Bureau.

Detectives patrolling the Harlem area yesterday arrested six Negro youths charged with being members of a gang of thirteen muggers who attacked Ann Coleman and her brother, Charles, Sunday on the roof of a tenement at 567 Lenox Avenue.

The Eastern seaboard and the major industrial centers such as Detroit and Pittsburgh have distanced the Pacific Coast in placing bombardment insurance with the War Damage Corporation, according to well-informed insurance circles.

It is formally announced that our Army is going to the dogs. But do not be dismayed. In that respect, as in mechanizing the forces, we have followed the example of the Germans, who have overlooked no means of increasing military efficiency. The dog's keen senses and his capacity for disciplined obedience have made him a useful servant of man in many of the pursuits of peace.

SCHENECTADY, Aug. 19 -- Housed in a special building with three-foot concrete walls which make it resemble a bomb shelter, a machine which will speed electrons to energies of 100,000,000 volts, and which will produce X-rays of the same power, is being constructed here.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 -- Henry J. Kaiser returned home today to try to get the West Coast aircraft industries united on his big cargo plane building program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Treasury officials suggested today that a "pay-as-you-go" income-tax collection proposal might be modified so as to cancel part, but not all, of the taxes on 1942 income falling due next year.

Notice of a motion for a Supreme Court order restraining Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, from demolishing old Fort Clinton in Battery Park, which housed the Aquarium, was served on Mr. Moses yesterday through Russell L. Tarbox, assistant corporation counsel.
HAVANA, Aug. 19 -- Cuba went into mourning today as the bodies of her first war victims were brought to Havana.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- States of the Atlantic Seaboard will be divided into four areas for the purposes of fuel-oil rationing this Fall and Winter, under a plan which the Office of Price Administration has drawn up and submitted for the special War Production Board sub-committee, which is to be named by Donald M. Nelson.
LONDON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten's combined operations headquarters communique:

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- While American Rangers charged German positions at Dieppe today two squadrons of United States Flying Fortresses soared at high altitudes over a Nazi fighter base at Abbeville, France, forty miles away, smashed runways, fired the airdrome and fuel storage tanks and reduced the base's buildings to rubble and fragments.

Chairmen of the 119 units of Bundles for Britain in the city are being urged to organize all apartment houses in their districts to expedite the collection of properly processed tin cans, Mrs. Wales Latham, president of the organization, said yesterday at the opening of a branch office at 21 West Forty-sixth Street.

Historic meetings, fighting pacts and ringing declarations are all very well as symbols and promises of action. But the bravest words and gestures do not take the place of acts, and all the drama they express and imply does not produce the thrill of a single daring deed.

VICHY, France, Aug. 19 -- Chief of State Marshal Henri Philippe Petain today received Chief of Government Pierre Laval in conference and the latter conferred with Admiral Francois Darlan as chief of land, air and sea forces.

Modern, mechanized global war has produced so many innovations -- among them battles at sea in which the opposing surface fleets were never within sight or range of each other -- that the civilian population should be prepared by now to accept almost any change in governmental or social rules and customs that accompanies the new type of international conflict.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, yesterday told the opening convocation of students in the course on international administration that the United States must begin now to gain an understanding of the conquered peoples of the world if any program for their rehabilitation is to bring about a lasting peace.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 19 -- Mrs. J.B. Balding and Mrs. Thomas Rudel, both of Cedar Creek, tied for low-gross honors with identical scores of 40, 42 -- 82 in the one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association over the Lakeville Country Club course today.

DETROIT, Aug. 19 (AP) -- A three-run homer by Rudy York and another four-bagger by Ned Harris enabled the Tigers to crush Cleveland, 6 to 1, in a twilight game today and cut the Indians' advantage over the fourth-place Browns to half a game.

Action on the proposal to cut by 50 per cent the contribution of dress manufacturers to the promotion fund of the New York Dress Institute will be taken within the next few days by the three producers' associations, it was stated here yesterday.

Despite continued attempts to get a compromise candidate, the contest between Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., backed by State Chairman James A. Farley, and Senator James M. Mead, backed by President Roosevelt, seemed last night to be certain to be carried to the floor of the State convention, which opened earlier in the day in the grand ballroom of the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 19 -- Today was hot as Army and Navy censorship permits admitting. In the yards of the Kaiser-operated Oregon Shipbuilding Corporation, Evelyn Dishman, 17, doffed long leather gloves and helmeted welding hat. She kept on her leather jacket under which she wore a blue sweater, and said she was not warm in spite of the jacket.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Office of Price Administration is contemplating an amendment to existing maximum rent regulations which would forbid the sale of dwelling rental properties in defense rental areas except under terms prescribed by the agency.

LOUISVILLE, Aug. 19 -- Striking Reynolds Metals Company employes, 2,000 of them according to C.I.O. strike leaders but about 100 according to company and A.F.L. representatives, received an ultimatum tonight to return to work on schedule tomorrow or be displaced permanently.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- Better war news from Western Europe and continued lack of hedging pressure sent wheat prices soaring today on the Board of Trade, with shorts covering freely on the way up. At no time were prices as low as yesterday's finish, and the bulge reached 2 cents a bushel before the aggressive buying let up.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- Nazi propagandists were busy tonight trying to make it look as if the attack on Dieppe was an attempt at an invasion, which they had beaten off.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Eight Pittsburgh runs in the sixth and Vince DiMaggio's fourth-inning homer toppled the Reds to their sixth straight defeat today, 9 to 2.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 19 -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Bromley and Mrs. John N. Blakeley entertained with a large luncheon today at the Gideon Putnam for Mrs. Ferdinand Roebling, Mrs. V. Vassar Baker, Mrs. William G. Cavanagh, Mr. and Mrs. Warren Wright, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bragg, Mr. and Mrs. D. Walter Mabee, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Small Moore and Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Salmon.

Net earnings of steel companies dropped sharply in the first half of 1942, although production was breaking all previous records, and went to the lowest level for any six-month period since the first half of 1939, according to a survey by the American Iron and Steel Institute.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- Flensburg, a Baltic port of Prussia, not far from the Danish border and a site of submarine and shipbuilding yards, was bombed last night by Royal Air Force squadrons.

What the well-dressed soldier will wear -- whether he's on duty in tropical jungles or bleak tundra country, or somewhere between -- is on view at the New York District Quartermaster Procurement Planning Office, 521 Fifth Avenue, but Major Francis K. Duffy, officer in charge yesterday, pooh-poohed the idea that there might be a special American commando uniform for raids like the historic foray around Dieppe.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Although he has been totally blind seven years, Julius Acosta Jr. is one of the most accurate plane spotters of the Civilian Defense Council's organization here.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 -- Lieut. Gen. John L. deWitt announced tonight a new procedure for excluding from vital areas of his Western Defense Command persons deemed "dangerous or potentially dangerous" to military security.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The troops who attacked the German fortifications at Dieppe returned tonight as the men of Combined Headquarters, who planned the attack, intended they should. They came back as heroes should, to admiring throngs who cheered them.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Jersey City and Buffalo divided a twilight-arc double-header tonight, the Bisons taking the opener, 5 to 0, with the Little Giants coming back to annex the nightcap, 4 to 2. The split decision evened the series at two games apiece but left the visitors with a 12-10 margin in the season's set.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- British commentators and editorial writers and the British populace seem tonight to share the common belief that the Dieppe raid is an investment that will yield high dividends. In modest homes and in drawing rooms, in hotels and pubs, the British people tried to answer the question: "What does the raid mean?"

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Mort Cooper pitched his fifteenth victory of the season tonight as the Cardinals punched out a 5-to-1 decision over the Cubs. Enos Slaughter and Walker Cooper hit home runs for the Cards.

HARTFORD, Aug. 19 -- Eight men and four women members of a Federal court jury listened all day to defense lawyers' arguments why they should acquit the Rev. Kurt E.B. Molzahn, of Philadelphia, of the government's accusation of espionage conspiracy, and this evening indications were that much or all of tomorrow would be devoted to further summations, with the case probably going to the jury on Friday after Judge J. Joseph Smith's charge.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Athletics pounded three Washington pitchers for twelve hits and defeated the Senators, 8 to 0, tonight before a crowd of 6,000. Roger Wolff gave nine hits in scoring his shut-out.

Boston pitching was of such tempting softness at Ebbets Field yesterday that Pete Reiser impishly batted right-handed in his last turn at the plate -- and singled through the box. The mayhem perpetrated on the Braves was simply horrifying as the Dodgers slammed nineteen hits, five of them doubles, for an 11-1 victory.

Although "Priorities" vacates the Forty-sixth Street on Sept. 5, another variety bill will follow on its heels, opening there Sept. 15. The new show, untitled as yet, will contain such diverse personalities as Harry Richman, Gracie Fields, Bert Wheeler, Johnny Burke and The Bricklayers.

Acting Secretary of State Sumner Welles has written a very significant letter on the subject of shipments of food to Greece This letter, addressed to the president of the Greek War Relief Association, doubtless because of the natural pressure of military news, has not, we believe, received the public attention it deserves.

Although the Federal regulations covering the taking of migratory birds were announced a short time ago, the New York State Conservation Department has supplemented the rules as they apply specifically to Fall duck hunting in the Empire State.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 -- The West Coast dimmed out tonight for the duration of the war. In advance of the midnight deadline for compliance with a proclamation of Lieut. Gen. John L. de Witt, Western Defense Commander, non-essential lights along the whole coastline and, in some areas inland for 150 miles, were extinguished and essential lighting was shielded to prevent an upward glow.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 19 -- Many younger members of the Summer colony served as hostesses this afternoon at the Beach Club at the fourth in a series of entertainments for service men stationed in this vicinity. Thirty soldiers and members of the Coast Guard were guests of honor at the party, which included swimming, beach games, supper and dancing.

Despite heavy losses, Russian troops have renewed strong attacks on the Rzhev and Vyazma fronts, northwest and southwest of Moscow, the German High Command said yesterday, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 19 -- A curfew for the entire Federal District was decreed today by the police. Bars and coffee houses must close at 8 P.M., theatres and other amusements at 10 P.M., and persons must be in their homes by 11 P.M.

Governor Lehman, as keynote speaker at the opening session of the Democratic State Convention in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, urged yesterday the continuation of the Democratic administration in Albany as a protection for the party's social gains in the last twenty years.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- The stock markets today were quieter than on the preceding two days and the tone was firm.

BOSTON, Aug. 19 -- United States troops equipped with machine guns, rifles and gas masks, took possession at 8 o'clock tonight of the S.A. Woods Machine Company in South Boston, a shell-making plant which became so ensnared in a labor controversy that President Roosevelt ordered the War Department today to assume control of its management.

Vice Chairman Joseph T. Sharkey of the City Council and six Councilmen conferred yesterday with Mayor La Guardia in an effort to obtain a compromise on his proposed amendments to the McCarthy Salary increment Law.

BOSTON, Aug. 19 -- Flanked by a crowd of 38,814, the second largest gathering of the year at Fenway Park, the Yankees and Red Sox dealt each other some lethal blows today. But the world champions, past masters at this sort of thing, dealt the last one and so came off with an even break in the double-header that still left them leading Joe Cronin's pursuers by eleven and a half lengths.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- William S. Farish, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, told the Senate Patent Committee today that the United States got far more from Germany out of the long controverted patents pool between Standard and I. G. Farbenindustrie than Germany ever received from us.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Chicago national amateur tournament put on a golf show at the Knollwood Club today entitled "The Rout of the Favorites" and at the finish only Wilford Wehrle of Racine, Wis., still was in the title running.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 -- A sweeping reorganization of the Securities and Exchange Commission, designed to streamline its efficiency while effecting war economies, was announced today by Ganson Purcell, chairman.

In his first direct comment on union affairs since he entered government service two years ago, Sidney Hillman, President Roosevelt's special assistant on labor matters, declared yesterday that peace between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations was an essential part of the national unity needed to win the war.

Rushing to the defense of their women workers, personnel executives in Eastern aircraft factories said yesterday that they had no intention of segregating women, from men workers and, what's more, they didn't think the women took their jobs too lightly.

Commandos who tested Hitler's "Western Westwall" in the Dieppe area must have been met with a murderous crossfire from batteries emplaced in the beaches and cliffs, judging from an unauthorized inspection I made of that area last year.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 19 -- A list of things the Hitler government wants to know about war production in the United States -- including facts about a 3,000-horse-power airplane motor -- was read to a mixed jury in Federal Court here today just before the government rested its case against Herbert Karl Friedrich Bahr, charged with being a Nazi spy.

With sales already running about 35 per cent under a year ago, principally as a result of stricter credit regulations and diversion of excess consumer income into war bonds, installment furniture retailers are planning to take on new lines in a desperate effort to prevent further volume losses which are expected, due to shortages of merchandise such as radios and appliances.

More than 90 per cent of the manufacturers in this area who are required to file applications under the Production Requirements Plan for their allotments of materials for the fourth quarter of the year have done so, according to estimates made yesterday at the regional office of the War Production Board here.

The appointment of H.T. Frushour as general manager of the New York zone of the Pennsylvania Railroad to succeed J.A. Appleton was announced yesterday. Mr. Appleton has been appointed chief of the rail division of the transportation corps of the Army on the staff of Major Gen. Charles P. Gross. He will be stationed in Washington.
LONDON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- A communique from headquarters of the United States' Army in the European theatre of operations:
MOSCOW, Aug. 19 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- A first step toward a program of meatless days was taken here today when the annual convention of the International Stewards and Caterers Association adopted a recommendation of its war effort committee for "meatless Tuesday" menus for its 2,100 members located in twenty-one cities.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- An American submarine has sunk a Japanese cruiser or destroyer in the Western Aleutian area, a Navy communique disclosed today.

Men's clothing manufacturers are starting to run into bottlenecks in materials for civilian use, and in some instances Fall orders are being held up because of scarcities of needed fabrics and trimmings, it was reported here yesterday.

Wall Street was discussing yesterday the hairbreadth margin by which Dillon, Read Co. succeeded with their daring secondary distribution of capital stock of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana despite the refusal of the New York Stock Exchange to allow its members to participate.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 19 -- After the war there should be sincere cooperation among all nations, particularly among China, the United States, Britain and Russia, without which it will be impossible to preserve world peace, declared Dr. Quo Tai-chi, former Minister of Foreign Affairs, in a speech officially released today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- An unrelenting anti-submarine campaign is being waged off South America's Atlantic Coast, where United States, Brazilian and British planes were reported to have attacked at least seven undersea raiders in the last seventy-two hours, sinking one and probably two of them.

The seizure of twelve more Germans and four Italians by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents on Tuesday night was revealed yesterday at FBI headquarters in the United States Court House in Foley Square. The enemy aliens have been taken to Ellis Island for further investigation and possible internment.

Relief Wings, an organization for aiding the evacuation of ill and wounded civilians in case of enemy attacks, assigned its first emergency ambulance plane to La Guardia Field yesterday. The plane was donated to the organization by Cornelius V. Whitney and is the first of several to be assigned to posts throughout the nation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that it would soon lift the March, 1942, price ceilings on five important dried fruits and raisins by some 15 per cent above the packers' level. This increase will be passed on to some extent to the consumer, but even at the higher prices civilians are not likely to see much of the crop.

The stock market experienced yesterday a difficult time in charting any definite course under the weight of profit-taking, but still it managed virtually to hold its position. The volume of business on the Stock Exchange remained above the half-million-share mark, but there was not an unduly large employment of buying power, for the lower-priced issues continued to attract the greater portion of interest.

Representatives of veterans' organizations, carrying banners urging the nomination of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for Governor, paraded last night near the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn, scene of the Democratic State Convention.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 19 -- There was intense excitement in all parts of France today, according to reports reaching here following the action at Dieppe by forces of the United Nations. From the so-called free zone the only news available legally was from German sources: nevertheless, thousands of listeners to foreign broadcasts soon spread the word that at last an important demonstration had been undertaken.

Yale, so rich in collections, has a new treasure. Robert Vincent of this town, sometime a sound engineer for the Radio Corporation of America, has given to the university the assemblage of phonograph records of distinguished persons that he has been forming ever since he was a boy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The State Department announced today that 2,058 of the 16,000 United States citizens who enlisted in the Canadian armed forces before Pearl Harbor nosy had been transferred to United States Army or Navy units.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Norma Shearer, screen actress, and Martin Arrouge, 28-year-old former ski instructor at Sun Valley, Idaho, applied today for a marriage license. Miss Shearer, who gave her age as 38, is the widow of Irving Thalberg, film producer who died in 1936.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Aug. 20 -- Russian troops have given up Krasnodar, a railroad and river city of the Northwest Caucasus, to overwhelming German assault forces now pressing down toward the Black Sea naval base of Novorossiisk, less than sixty miles distant, a communique disclosed today.

LONDON, Aug. 19 -- While the Dieppe raiders were still fighting for their initial toehold on the European coastline this morning, the British radio gave the first of a series of hourly warnings to the French people that this was not an invasion and that they should keep clear of the battle zone.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- At least four of the twenty-eight persons indicted on July 23 on charges of conspiring to impair the morale of the armed forces will be arraigned tomorrow in the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Comdr. James Joseph (Gene) Tunney, Navy director of physical training, asked the sports world today to "lay off" athletic stars who have been called to the colors.

A German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press last night reported a German High Command special bulletin claiming that the Allied forces that attacked the French coast near Dieppe were "destroyed without the calling up of reinforcements of important strength."

For the first time in the present war an enemy surface raider in the Atlantic has sunk a United States merchant vessel, the Navy disclosed yesterday. Announcing the arrival at an Atlantic port of ten survivors of a medium-sized ship sunk by torpedoes and shell fire, the Navy gave the first official confirmation of recent reports that a heavily armed German raider was loose in the South Atlantic.

Proposed plans for consumer rationing of meat were attacked yesterday by Joseph Cohn, counsel and executive director of the Meat Trade Institute, Inc., 270 Broadway, in telegrams sent to government officials in Washington.

Inexpensive fur coats, designed for double-duty use, were on view yesterday at the Autumn showing of the Jaeckel budget shop, 10 East Fifty-seventh Street. Calling its selection of thirty garments "duration durables," the salon featured simple lines, with emphasis on roominess.

Twenty-six persons were injured, none seriously, when an empty bus struck a bus filled with fifty passengers and sent it careening into an automobile at Eastern Boulevard and Westchester Avenue, the Bronx, shortly after 6 P.M. yesterday.

July marked a turning point in advertising linage, especially in newspapers, according to figures in Printers' Ink, out tomorrow. The index of newspaper advertising in that month, showing an increase for the first time this year, was up 6.5 per cent, compared with June and 0.6 per cent, compared with the corresponding month of last year.

Twenty-six persons were injured, none seriously, when an empty bus struck a bus filled with fifty passengers and sent it careening into an automobile at Eastern Boulevard and Westchester Avenue, the Bronx, shortly after 6 P.M. yesterday.

July marked a turning point in advertising linage, especially in newspapers, according to figures in Printers' Ink, out tomorrow. The index of newspaper advertising in that month, showing an increase for the first time this year, was up 6.5 per cent, compared with June and 0.6 per cent, compared with the corresponding month of last year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- An appeal to Americans to stop thinking in terms of group advantage and concentrate on the country's welfare was made tonight by Secretary Wickard, in a radio speech which warned that the United Nations were still losing the war and that all the resources and energy of this country must be thrown into the effort if we were to turn the tide.

BOMBAY, India, Aug. 19 (U.P.) -- Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of India's Moslem League, was reliably reported today to be seeking an interview with Mohandas K. Gandhi in hope of reaching an agreement to settle the current Indian impasse.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Beginning tomorrow, Class 1-B, the Selective Service designated for registrants considered fit for limited military service only, will be eliminated, national headquarters of the Selective Service System said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- President Quezon of the Philippines Commonwealth Government, exiled to America by the Japanese occupation of his native land, celebrated his sixty-fourth birthday today, heartened by messages of congratulations from President Roosevelt and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, who promised the early delivery of his people.

WITH THE CANADIAN RAIDING FORCE, Returning From Dieppe, Aug. 19 (Delayed) -- For eight raging hours under intense Nazi fire from dawn until a sweltering afternoon, I watched Canadian troops fight the blazing bloody battle of Dieppe. I saw them go through this biggest of the, war's raiding operations in wild scenes that crowded helter-skelter one upon another in crazy sequence.
TEMPLE, Texas, Aug. 20 -- The Commando raid on Dieppe yesterday and our painful but definite progress in the Solomon Islands forecast the "shape of things to come."

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 -- "Grapes of Wrath" in reverse disturbs California today. Caught in a labor shortage, the fruit industry would welcome "Okie" or oligarchist. Men are needed for the orchards; women for the canneries.

Back in 1907 Walter Johnson pitched his first major league game. In 1927 Babe Ruth set his record of sixty home runs in one season. Behind the plate in Johnson's debut and also there when Ruth smashed No. 60 was Billy Evans, one of the greatest umpires in history.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- After more than an hour's debate today the Senate put over until Monday consideration of the bill to permit absentee voting in Presidential and Congressional elections of members of the armed forces within the continental United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Through three orders issued here today the Office of Price Administration relieved the current "squeeze" on retailers of men's and boys' work clothing and at the same time reduced the pressure on manufacturer's margins by lowering ceiling prices on specified fabrics used in the garments from 1/4 to 1 cent a yard.

With Townsend Harris High School students winning first place in the recently announced Regents scholarship awards, it also was learned that only about 50 per cent of their teachers, who were in a large measure responsible for the students maintaining their high scholastic averages, would be appointed to other positions after the school is officially closed on Aug. 31.

William S. Farish has made it plain in his testimony before the Senate Patent Committee that the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey got far more by its agreement with the Inter-essengemeinschaft, the German chemical monopoly, than the Department of Justice would have us believe. His list of laboratory achievements based on German discoveries and the immense fighting power that they have given us cannot but impress any fair-minded reader.
Prices of stocks fell off yesterday as did the volume of business as the market stumbled around without any strong leaders to help chart a course.

There are three advance signs of impending Autumn in the City of New York -- a "new silhouette," a bonnet show by Bendel, and an epidemic of articles about good grooming. For give a woman the faintest premature whiff of cool air and she immediately sees herself swathed in simple, irreproachable elegance -- perfectly poised, perfectly coiffed, perfectly clothed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- During the week ended Aug. 15 average prices for commodities in primary markets reached the highest level since October, 1926, as measured by the Bureau of Labor statistics wholesale price index of 889 series.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- The National Food Distributors Association, opening its fifteenth annual convention and exposition here today, was told that the war presented a challenge to the dehydration branch of the food industry. The speaker was Joseph Pardieck, Pacific Coast dehydration veteran, who warned that quality must be kept intact "during these trying days of priorities and food shortages."

The Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation is completing negotiations for the purchase of the former country estate of the late Otto H. Kahn in Morristown, N.J., it was learned yesterday. Title to the property is due to pass from the estate to the Allied Chemical at a meeting of their representatives this week in New York.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 20 -- Mrs. Frank J. Holleran of the home club won low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association when she carded 39, 41 -- 80 over the Round Hill links today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- President Roosevelt conferred with United Nations military leaders and asked Congress to appropriate funds to pay the Pennsylvania gift tax of $195,000 on the P. A. B. Widener art collection which will go to the National Art Gallery.

MOSCOW, Friday, Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- German forces have stormed across the Don River northwest of Stalingrad for the second time within twenty-four hours, the Soviet High Command announced today, and Russian defenders of the east bank, after wiping out the first band, "almost completely destroyed" the second.

Black Strong in Coats Black continues to lead in coat reorders, running at least as large a percentage as in initial business. In colors, the favored hues are brown, beige, blue and green. In fur trimmings, silver fox is outstanding. Active demand has also favored red fox, mink, Persian lamb and sheared beaver.

ROSLYN, L.I., Aug. 20 -- A landmark of this part of the North Shore, the six-foot iron fence enclosing the estate of the late Clarence H. Mackay, is being taken down and the segments, totaling 3,000 feet, will be moved to Schenectady to enclose a war production plant, it was learned today.

Reports of the new anti-inflation program which is being drawn up for the President by Judge Samuel I. Rosenman suggest that a typical Administration strategy is being considered. Instead of trying to mend the real causes of the breakdown in inflation control, it is proposed to plaster a new board, with a near, high-sounding name, on top of the existing boards and agencies.

Members of the Board of Estimate deferred action yesterday on a resolution calling for the dismissal of 197 additional city employes until Aug. 25, and at the same meeting the board authorized the issuance of $10,331,555 in serial bonds and tax notes as a planning fund to launch $312,603,000 of projects in a post-war improvement program.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- A spokesman for the S.A. Woods Machine Company revealed today that the government had taken over a second of its plants. He termed the seizure "unwarranted and purely coercive."

ABOARD A BRITISH NAVY GUNBOAT off Dieppe, Aug. 19 (Delayed) (AP) -- The American Rangers -- first actual United States units to participate in land operations on the Continent in this war -- proved their gallantry and won a victory in their all-important share in the record-breaking Dieppe assault.

Loss of two more British vessels to Axis submarines became known yesterday as the Navy Department revealed that a medium-sized British merchantman had been torpedoed in the Atlantic on June 13, and press dispatches from Willemstad, Curacao, reported that thirty survivors of a torpedoed British schooner had been landed there.

"I Live on Danger," a melodrama featuring Chester Morris, opens at the Rialto today and "Enemy Agents Meet Ellery Queen," with William Gargan and Margaret Lindsay in the lead roles, arrives at the Central.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- William Dudley Pelley, one-time leader of the Silver Shirts, who is under a fifteen-year sentence for sedition, and three more of the twenty-eight persons indicted for conspiring to impair the morale of the armed forces, pleaded innocent in Federal District Court today. They and eight others have until Sept. 20 to obtain local counsel and file motions attacking the indictment.

Increased renting activity in Essex House, 160 Central Park South, was reported yesterday by Oscar Wintrab, managing director, who released a list of sixteen new tenants as follows: Ira Jean Belmont, Anna Reinfeld, Charles Feltman, Adelaide C. Loeb, George I. Weissbaum, Richard Voltter, Philip J. Rudden, Lesser Segerman, Esther Rose, Henry C. Stevens, Isador Kaplan, Benjamin Grodin, Hugo Doob, Joseph F. Cohen, Sam Campe and Florence Auer.

ABOARD A MOTOR LAUNCH OF BRITISH NAVY, Returning From off Dieppe, Aug. 19 (Delayed) (AP) -- I have just watched the Royal Air Force and the Royal Navy smash German planes in the fiercest and most dramatic air and sea battle of the war in the west.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- The National Association of Retail Meat Dealers closed its fifty-seventh annual convention here today with the passage of a number of resolutions demanding government action on a series of controversial problems, ranging from the imposition of price ceilings on livestock to the abolition of all forms of crop control to the end that the nation might produce more abundantly to meet consumer and war needs.
The text of the State Democratic platform of 1942 follows:

Ray Robinson will seek to add Rube Shank of Colorado to his long list of victims when the pair clash at Madison Square Garden tonight. Robinson, the Harlem welterweight who has yet to lose a professional battle, is scheduled to travel ten rounds against the newcomer from the West in the top bout on the card.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed holdings of United States Government securities to be the highest on record, having increased $61,210,000 during the past week. Note circulation was also the highest for the year, while ratio of reserve was at the lowest.

On the sixty-fourth anniversary of his birthday President Quezon got cordial congratulations from Mr. Roosevelt, from General Chiang Kai-shek, from General MacArthur, his old "friend, comrade and adviser," and from other eminent persons. As soldier and as statesman he has served the Filipinos faithfully for almost forty-five years.

Wall Street was still deeply interested yesterday in the decision of the New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday, when it forbade its members to participate in a secondary distribution of stock of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana sponsored by Dillon, Read Co.

DETROIT, Aug. 20 (U.P.) -- The United States Rubber Company said tonight that it planned to start immediate production of "a tire sandal" designed to add 2,500 to 3,000 miles to the life of an automobile tire.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- The Westchester County Surrogate's Court pondered today the legality of a will that was written in letter form last March 6 by a United States Army captain while Japanese soldiers were surrounding him in a jungle somewhere in the Philippines.

The all-rail route via Mexico to Central America provides a means by which shippers may avoid the submarine menace and at the same time save as much as $25 a hundred pounds in war risk insurance charges, H. E. Chenoweth, commercial agent of the Mexican Government Railway System, declared yesterday.

EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 20 (U.P.) -- Bill DeCorrevont, the one-time boy wonder of scholastic football, was cast again today in the undesired role of a "bench warmer" as the college All-Stars started their final week of practice for a game Aug. 28 with the Chicago Bears.

The Lanson Realty Corporation has bought one of the last large tracts of land in Brooklyn consisting of more than an acre in the Flatbush section at the northwest corner of Linden Boulevard and Rogers Avenue. The seller was the Estate of Annie R. Gibson.
LONDON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- A communique from combined operations headquarters:

VICHY, France, Aug. 20 -- "It was certainly intended to be more than a raid," was the opinion expressed today in authorized circles on the United Nations landing that terminated yesterday after nine hours of heavy fighting in and about Dieppe.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- British destroyers that shepherded troops ashore near Dieppe yesterday proved that a large number of ships, given adequate air cover, can be maintained near the enemy coast, regardless of the defenses.

HAVANA, Aug. 20 -- Thousands gathered at the National Capitol this afternoon to witness funeral rites for the first Cuban war victims. Eight sailors killed when the Cuban merchant vessels Santiago de Cuba and Manzanillo were torpedoed and sunk -- whose bodies had lain in state in the Capitol since they were brought here yesterday -- were buried with military honors.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Aug. 20 -- The twenty-four room residence on the Cedar Knoll estate of Mrs. Margaret Emerson was destroyed by fire of undetermined cause this evening. Most of the furnishings also were burned or damaged by smoke and water and the total loss was estimated at more than $200,000 by Deputy Fire Marshal Peter Lynch of Port Washington.

LONDON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Frank O.D. Hunter, commander of the United States Fighter Command, issued a statement praising his pilots in the Dieppe action, which he called a "hell of a hot show."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Port battalions of the Army are being organized and trained to operate overseas ports to insure prompt handling of United States military equipment, Under-Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson said today.

Did the New Deal start out like other living things by being born, or did it just grow, like Topsy? Governor Lehman's keynote speech at the Democratic convention lends itself to both origins. Arguing for a Democratic Congress as well as for a Democratic Legislature in New York, the Governor said: "The New Deal had its birth in this State under Governor Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- President Roosevelt today returned to private management the Bayonne, N.J., plant of the General Cable Corporation, which was commandeered a week ago to halt a wildcat strike of 1,000 workers who were protesting the refusal of the National War Labor Board to grant them a general wage increase.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Secretary Wickard has reached the conclusion, a close associate said today, that some form of price-fixing should be adopted to stabilize farm, food and industrial prices in the interest of wartime economic unity and to prevent inflation.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 20 -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura took his place in the semi-final round of the Longwood Bowl invitation tennis tournament today with a decisive victory over Victor Seixas of Philadelphia at the Longwood Cricket Club.

John Wanamaker, New York, is now rearranging its selling departments in a move that will eliminate use of the fourth and fifth floors of the north building for selling purposes, it was announced yesterday by store officials. These floors, which are the two upper ones of this building, will be used for storage of reserve stocks.

MOSCOW, Friday, Aug. 21 -- A Soviet communique issued early today reported that more enemy tanks and men broke across the Don yesterday in the direction of Stalingrad from the river's loop, within which the fighting has been continuous for the last month.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Counsel fees estimated at $135,000 were granted today by Supreme Court Justice Gerald Nolan to Frank M. Gagliardi of this city and John E. Mack of Poughkeepsie and to their law firms for work in prosecuting a suit to enforce the statutory liability of stockholders of the defunct Westchester Title and Trust Company of White Plains.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 20 (U.P.) -- Federal authorities have ordered that all refugees who escaped to Switzerland from Axis-dominated countries since Aug. 11 be returned to the places whence they fled, the National Zeitung of Basle reported today.

SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 20 (UP) -- Allied landing parties, including United States Marines, mashed into the Japanese on the Solomon Islands behind a curtain of United States dive-bombers and had the Japanese "on the run from the start," a survivor of the 10,000-ton Australian cruiser Canberra reported today.

Now operating with considerable independence from the parent Penguin Books firm in England, Penguin Books of New York has issued the first of its new books. The publishers of the paper-covered volumes have shifted their editorial course toward titles of a more popular nature, have improved the format of the publications and have added a stiffer paper cover.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 -- The Widener art collection was collected by Joseph E. Widener and his father at a cost reputed to have been upwards of $50,000,000.
MOSCOW, Aug. 20 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The irony of it all sometimes makes Mrs. Blanche Noyes chuckle, but she is going right ahead with her job of obliterating hundreds of the safety air markers she spent six years getting set up.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The War Labor Board, preparing to defend its decision denying a general wage increase to 32,000 Aluminum Company of America workers against a C.I.O. strike threat, called today for labor compliance with its ruling.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Training classes for enlisted women in the Women's Naval Reserve will open Oct. 9, the Navy stated today as it disclosed that Oklahoma Agricultural and Mechanical College has been chosen as a third training center for the group. Recruiting for 1,600 volunteers, who will also be trained at the Universities of Indiana and Wisconsin, will begin Sept. 11.

A favorable turn in the retail charge account situation is likely during the last quarter of the year and may begin to be evident next month, according to views expressed yesterday by Edward Malloy, president of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York.

MEXICO CITY, Mexico, Aug. 20 -- The British American Equities Company of New York has leased 250,000 acres of oil properties for development and exploitation work in Northern Mexico to provide Monterrey, in Nuevo Leon State, with an additional 30,000,000 cubic feet of natural gas daily.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20 -- America's tin and scrap steel shortage may be overcome to the extent of over 1,000,000 more tons a year by a revolutionary process of salvaging tin cans developed by two Los Angeles men.

Not long ago I attended a concert at Lewisohn Stadium. As is customary on all such occasions, the orchestra began the program by playing "The Star-Spangled Banner," but scarcely a sound could be heard from the audience, which stood in mute and reverent silence as though at a funeral.

From the smoke of battle on the seven seas sailors of the British Royal Navy are receiving rest and recreation at a new woodland haven established on a rugged hillside in the Rip Van Winkle country of the Hudson Valley, seventy miles north of New York City.

A lot of "test tube fabrics" have arrived on the Autumn fashion scene and dispelled all fears connected with the wool and silk shortages. Although positive claims as to the comparative warmth-giving qualities of the newcomers are wisely awaiting their contact with chill breezes, a glance at their conversion into garments has given them fashion's unreserved approval.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, Aug. 20 -- Royal Air Force veterans who have gone out on countless raids with their own bombers in the last two years exultantly recounted at their mess today the remarkable performance of the United States Flying Fortresses at Abbeville and Rouen.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 20 -- Thousands of German nationals, possibly half a million or more throughout this country, are affected by a decree issued today by President Getulio Vargas, allowing only Germans with diplomatic status to leave Brazil.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 20 -- Representatives of the C. I. O. Aluminum Workers of America rejected today the War Labor Board's decision which refused a wage increase and voted to ask the local unions to authorize their president to call a strike if he believed it "necessary."

If a reminder is needed of the rapid expansion of the national debt, it is available in the current statistics of the government debt due within one year. This week, for the first time since the first World War financing, the total due within twelve months has topped $10,000,000,000, and in the year to come, these maturities will have to be "rolled over" in addition to the new money financing that must be done.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Mrs. Al Sabath's Alsab, prepping for the $80,000 American Derby; Aug. 29, carried 128 pounds to a sizzling triumph in a $5,000 added handicap for 3-year-olds at Washington Park today.

LONDON, Aug. 20 (U.P.) -- Allied planes and warships blasted out a clear path between England and the coast of France yesterday, and our shock troops fought a terrific eight-hour battle along the shores, but by an unlucky 1,000-to-1 chance a German patrol boat spotted the first landing party and spread an alarm that cost the Commandos heavy losses.

The Democratic party has nominated as its candidate for Governor a competent and conscientious public servant who is thoroughly familiar with the business of the State. Mr. Bennett is not a colorful figure. His name has seldom made the headlines until recent weeks.

The recent Commando raids on the Continent were not considered by the British people as an indication of the opening of a second front, according to Walter Nash, New Zealand Minister to the United States, who arrived by Pan American Clipper at La Guardia Field last night.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Running the fastest six furlongs of the meeting, the Brookemeade Stable's Mettlesome made it two in a row when he scored rather easily by two lengths in today's Volante Purse, run over a fast track before 8,235 persons.

Secretary of Agriculture Wickard's support of the provision was an important factor in enabling the farm bloc last year to write into the Price Control Act a prohibition against ceilings on farm prices at less than 110 per cent of "parity." Mr. Wickard now says that "the situation is different." He has reversed his stand and wants the 110 per cent ceiling repealed. In this change of view Mr. Wickard is to be congratulated.
The curtailment of big game fishing at Montauk has been emphasized by the dearth of news from the rod and reel contingent there.

Despite strong last-minute pressure from the national and State administrations, the delegates to the Democratic State Convention nominated yesterday Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for Governor by a vote of 623 to 393 for Senator James M. Mead, the candidate favored by President Roosevelt. On motion of Representative Michael J. Kennedy, leader of TammanY, the nomination of Mr, Bennett was made unanimous.
LONDON, Aug. 20 -- Business on the stock markets today was quiet. After a week's steady improvement in prices there was a pause on the industrial shares. Gilt-edge home rails showed few changes.

LONDON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- For the first time since June the Bank of England's condition statement, issued today, disclosed a decrease in note circulation of more than u4,000,000. An increase of about an equal amount was reflected in the bank's reserve.

The platform adopted yesterday by the Democratic State convention, shortly before its nomination of a candidate for Governor, speaks with more eloquence than is usually to be found in a document of this kind. It pays a richly deserved tribute to the "keen foresight and stout courage" with which the President led Congress and the country to such momentous decisions as the adoption of Lease-Lend in the critical days before Pearl Harbor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- During the week ended Aug. 19 member bank reserve balances decreased $56,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves rose from increases of $86,000,000 in money in circulation, $66,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks, and $11,000,000 in nonmember deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, offset in part by increases of $103,000,000 in reserve bank credit and $2,000,000 in gold stock.
Sale of five apartment houses in the Bronx was reported by brokers in four deals yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 20 (U.P.) -- Outnumbered Spitfires shot down four and damaged eight of twenty Messerschmitts over the desert yesterday, front reports revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- United States Marines who stormed at least three Japanese-held islands in the Solomons almost two weeks ago have "recently captured" those islands and are now engaged in "mopping up" remnants of the dispersed Japanese forces on them, the Navy Department revealed this evening.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 20 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, bluntly told a mass meeting of war workers here tonight that increases like the 11 per cent rise in real wages and 75 per cent in farm cash income since the war began in Europe "must not continue" if the fight against inflation is to be won.

President Roosevelt's disclosure that Joseph E. Widener had offered his art collection to the National Gallery of Art caused no surprise in art circles, since Mr. Widener announced in October, 1940, his intention of making this gift to the nation.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 -- Touching off a six-run explosion in the fifth inning that buried Marvin Breuer and tossed a ladies' day crowd of 16,956 into a mild delirium of joy, the Red Sox today subjected the Yankees to some more painful rear-guard fighting by winning the series final, 7 to 4.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Wendell L. Willkie announced today that he would leave within three weeks on a semi-official flying trip to the battle fronts of Russia and the Middle East. It was expected that he would confer with Josef V. Stalin, Soviet Premier, and would carry a communication to him from President Roosevelt.

WITH THE CANADIAN COMMANDO RAIDING FORCE, Aug. 19 (Delayed) (Canadian Press) -- Units of two infantry regiments, the Royal Hamilton Light Infantry and the Essex Scottish of Windsor, Ont., with a Calgary tank regiment carried the main attack of the Dieppe raid right into the town itself and battled the Germans through the streets to capture the main portions of the town.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 20 -- Yesterday's Allied action at Dieppe had its echo at Berlin today when one after the other the myths of stolid Nazi invincibility enunciated by the Reich Propaganda Services last night exploded from over-inflation.

The board of directors of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States took action yesterday on a threefold plea to Congress asking the continuance of the present $40,000 exemption of life insurance proceeds from estate taxes, a reasonable deduction for income-tax purposes of premiums paid by policy holders and the exemption from the Federal estate tax of life insurance proceeds earmarked by policy holders for payment of taxes on their estates.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Persons entering this country from abroad were warned today against discussing or disclosing information which might be valuable to enemies of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Rear Admiral H.L. Vickery, who is in charge of the Maritime Commission's ship construction program, told a House merchant marine subcommittee today that he was responsible for cancellation of a contract with the Higgins Shipbuilding Corporation of New Orleans for construction of 200 Liberty cargo ships and facilities.

ONCE again this landlubber is all at sea. That great stern gun of the Navy, Commander Gene Tunney, is the cause of it. This observer, wrapped up in a cardboard-bound book of several hundred pages entitled "Physical Training Program for Naval Aviation Pro-Flight Schools," was rudely interrupted by a copy boy who, under sealed orders, thrust forward a clipping with a note attached.
GREAT LAKES, Ill., Aug. 20 (AP) -- The sailors at this United States Naval Training Station, largest in the world, will meet twelve of the toughest football foes this season, it was announced today.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Four unearned runs in the first inning gave the Reds their first victory in seven starts today, a 5-to-3 triumph over Pittsburgh.

In order to prove their physical prowess and agility, 350 boys from 10 to 16 from West Side playgrounds gave an exhibition yesterday in the McCaffrey Playground, Forty-third Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Lake Superior Iron Ore Association reported today stocks of iron ore at furnaces and Lake Erie docks on Aug. 1 were 37,326,533 gross tons, highest for the date since the association began keeping records.

Earnings of the Borden Company from operations throughout the United States and Canada, and from the sale of its more than 100 products, amounted to $3,378,188 for the first six months of this year, Theodore G. Montague, president, announced in the semi-annual statement to stockholders yesterday.

Jacob Kalich will play opposite his wife, Molly Picon, in "Oy Is Dos A Leben" when that play with music, which he wrote with Joseph Rumshinsky, opens at the Molly Picon (formerly Jolson) Theatre on Monday, Oct. 12. The play is based on Miss Picon's eventful life and Mr. Kalich will portray himself.

HARTFORD, Aug. 20 -- After speaking for nearly six hours, James W. Carpenter, counsel for the Rev. Kurt E.B. Molzahn of Philadelphia, closed today the summation of the defense against the charge of espionage conspiracy.

If the President, Commander in Chief of the armed forces of the United States at war and dominant leader of the United Nations, had not decided to bring his power and prestige to bear in an effort to induce the delegates pledged to Attorney General John J. Bennett to support another aspirant for the Democratic nomination for Governor of New York, the convention of that party this week would have been an unimportant side-show.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Aug. 20 -- A board of Army officers, empowered to recommend exclusion from the West Coast combat zone persons whose presence here is adjudged to be dangerous or potentially dangerous to military security, has already begun to function.

The dwelling at 19 Bank Street, in Greenwich Village, has been sold by Stell Andersen, the well-known pianist, and Esther Morgan McCullough, the writer, to Jacob Lederer for investment. The buyer, who was represented by Hines Hines, Inc., brokers, owns the adjoining house at 21 Bank Street.

LONDON, Aug. 20 (U.P.) -- Stephen Horthy, elder son and designated successor of the Hungarian Regent, Admiral Nicholas Horthy, has been killed in air combat on the Russian front a Stefani news dispatch broadcast by the Italian radio reported today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Punching six runs across in the fifth inning, the White Sox scored an 8-to-5 victory over the Browns tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- A sharp battle in Congress is in prospect within the next two months over the proposal made yesterday by Secretary Wickard for repeal of provisions of the Price-Control Law prohibiting the establishment of farm price ceilings below 110 per cent of parity. The Secretary of Agriculture saw in such a course an aid to wartime food production and the prevention of inflation.

Bank clearings of $7,316,286,000 for the week ended on Wednesday were 10.1 per cent larger than the volume of the previous week and 16.9 per cent above the $6,260,953,000 total of the corresponding week a year ago, according to the report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Assertions by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey that the United States received more war benefits than Germany from the patent-pooling agreements of 1927 and 1929 between Standard and I.G. Farbenindustrie, Reich chemical trust, were challenged today as the Senate Patents Committee pursued its investigation into these relations.

Pledging himself to continue whole-hearted support of the war program of President Roosevelt, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. formally accepted last night the Democratic nomination for Governor of New York before a cheering audience at the closing session of the State convention at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

The McLaughlin bill, H.R. 7121, relating to "railroad adjustments," has been passed by the House and is now before the Senate. It has some excellent features, but it should not be passed in its present form. It has been disapproved by the Securities and Exchange Commission and is opposed by certain railway labor organizations. It should be opposed by all holders of railroad securities.

ARGENTINA is 2,300 miles long and has slightly more than 13,000,000 inhabitants. Economically, culturally and politically they are of vital importance in the Latin-American and world scenes. Mexico and Venezuela have oil, Chile has copper and nitrates, Brazil coffee. But the Argentines have ambition, industry and efficiency in addition to their wheat and beef.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 20 (AP) -- With Willie Turnbull riding his fourth consecutive winner of the day, Mrs. William Hodson's Fritz today won the fifth race at Narragansett Park, the best event on the card after cancellation of the original feature.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The Army, Navy and Maritime Commission, which award war contracts, were warned by Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, today to put them in areas of labor surplus if they wished to avoid serious delays in war production.

Mayor La Guardia's program for hot water rationing and fuel conservation in New York residential buildings was rejected yesterday by a virtually unanimous vote at a meeting of the city's leading realty owners and managing agents.

The German High Command reported yesterday that a Russian defense system between the Volga and the Don south of Stalingrad had been taken by storm in a bitter battle and that German attacks in the Caucasus "are gaining ground," according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

Big Jawn Mize was the only "spoil sport" among the Giants at Ebbets Field last evening as Whit Wyatt pitched the Dodgers to a 2-1 triumph and gave the National League leaders a seven-game advantage over the second-place Cardinals.

Clarence H. Low, chairman of the New York City Salvage Committee for the last seven months, at a meeting yesterday of metropolitan salvage workers in the Chanin Building auditorium, handed his resignation to Mayor La Guardia.
MOSCOW, Friday, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

DETROIT, Aug. 20 -- Housewives, teachers and office workers are flooding the offices of the Michigan Unemployment Compensation Commission with their war-work questionnaires, and extra clerks have been added to sort the incoming cards, officials said today.

Excess reserves of the member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City, which touched a low of $130,000,000 early this week, lowest level in more than five years, recovered to $180,000,000 as of the close of the fiscal week on Wednesday to show a net loss of only $15,000,000 on the week, according to the weekly figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 20 (Reuter) -- The working committee of the All-India Moslem League, in a resolution issued this afternoon after three days of debate, says it Continued on Page Eigh is willing to consider any proposals for the setting up of a provisional government of India provided the demand for "Pakistan" [separate Hindu and Moslem States] is conceded.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- President Roosevelt sent to Congress today a message announcing the offer to the National Gallery of Art of the paintings, sculptures and other works of art collected by the late Peter A.B. Widener and recommending appropriation of $195,000 with which to pay to Pennsylvania the State 5 per cent gift tax on the collection, the present value of which is estimated at $3,900,000.

ROANOKE, Va., Aug. 20 -- "It should no longer be necessary for the Treasury to come to every American, hat in hand, to ask for subscriptions for war bonds and at 2.9 per cent interest," said Secretary Morgenthau in an address here today during ceremonies designating Roanoke as the first "Treasury Flag city" in the war savings bond campaign.

GARY, Ind., Aug. 20 -- Resolutions calling for Federal support of an adult education program, salvaging the services set up by the WPA and making it a permanent program on a non-relief basis, was adopted today by the American Federation of Teachers.
LONDON, Friday, Aug. 21 -- It now can be revealed that British Commandos captured the Dieppe race course and converted it into a temporary landing ground for planes.
