WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- A possible first step toward eventual elimination of most "spectator sports" activities of service athletes was seen today in the cancellation of all competitive football schedules at schools of the Air Corps Technical Training Command.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- President Roosevelt withheld comment today on the New York Democratic Gubernatorial contest in which Senator James M. Mead, who had the President's support, was defeated decisively by Attorney General John J. Bennett, who had the support of James A. Farley, State chairman.

Rising in volume to a mark that almost triples that set a year ago, awards for engineering construction in the present week amount to $230,706,000. This is an increase of 15 per cent over last week, according to the Engineering News-Record, whose weekly survey shows that public work has climbed 261 per cent above a year ago and is 18 per cent higher than last week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Rangers of the United States Army, some of whom participated in the assault on Dieppe, will help train other American forces both in Britain and in the United States for similar operations on a larger scale. Under-Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson indicated today.

Union and company officials reported yesterday that more than two-thirds of the 600 women workers who went out on an unauthorized strike last Monday had returned to their jobs at the I.B. Kleinert Rubber Company plant, 20-09 127th Street, College Point, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (U.P.) -- Donald M. Nelson, in the first wide-scale housecleaning of the War Production Board staff, soon will dismiss up to ten of his forty-odd branch chiefs, it was learned today.
The text of the speech of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., acceping the Democratic nomination for Governor follows:

The junior division of banditry made its debut in Brooklyn yesterday on bicycles, staged a bold daylight robbery in one of the busiest sections of the borough and escaped with $28.25 in cash and a package of cigarettes.

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 20 -- Caustic political exchanges that caused a stir during Prime Minister John Curtin's visit to Brisbane are a sequel to the Opposition's recent determination to take its job more seriously. After months of strife and division it seems to have attained a larger measure of unity than lately seemed possible.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 20 -- LeRoy Ellsworth Grooms, 54-year-old engineer, groomed himself as an Army colonel and thereby violated Federal inpersonation statutes, the Federal Bureau of Investigation here charged today.

"Bourbon to buna and bombs" is the transition that is taking place in the chief product of the American Distilling Company, Russell R. Brown, president, declared yesterday in a report on the company's operations. The grain mashes from which bourbon and rye whiskies hitherto were distilled in the company's plant at Pekin, Ill., now are being turned into industrial alcohol, the basic material for synthetic rubber and smokeless powder.

In what the management described as "a unique and unforeseeable situation," the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad proposed yesterday that it return $5,054,443 cash raised through the sale of equipment trust certificates to buyers of the securities.

Members of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., employed on the day shift of the BMT division of the city's unified transit system at a mass meeting and rally last night in Arcadia Hall, Broadway and Halsey Street, Brooklyn, heard union leaders discuss a four-point program for negotiations with the Board of Transportation on wages, hours and working conditions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Department-store sales for the week ended Aug. 15 were the same as sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This compared with a decrease of 5 per cent from 1941 for the previous week. Sales for the latest four-week period were 2 per cent lower.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- Five hundred United States And Royal Air Force fighters swept over Northern France today in one of the greatest daylight attacks of the war, while American Flying Fortresses bombed the railway yards at Amiens in a follow-up to yesterday's pounding of Nazi installations while the Commando raid at Dieppe was being carried out.

OTTAWA, Aug. 20 (Canadian Press) -- Dominion Government deposits decreased $28,216,000 to $18,265,000 in the week ended yesterday, it was shown today in the weekly statement of the Bank of Canada. Notes in circulation increased $3,751,000 to $582,536,000.

A festive note was struck yesterday on Ellis Island, which often has been pictured against a gloomy backdrop, when public officials and associates in the Immigration and Naturalization Service met to honor Byron H. Uhl, district director, upon his completion of fifty years at that post.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- A long, detailed communique issued by Lord Louis Mountbatten's Commando Headquarters late tonight gave the first full picture of the huge attack by land, sea and air on Dieppe, France, one of the most strongly held ports of the Nazi-occupied English channel coast.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 20 -- Herbert Karl Friedrich Bahr, a young man who claims American citizenship because of the naturalization of his German-born father, put his life in the hands of a jury composed of six men and six women, all housewives and business men, here today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 20 -- Rehearsals were begun today for the classic Chinese drama, "The Sorrows of Plan," which will be given in English, with musical accompaniment, at the entertainment entitled "An Auspicious Autumn Festival" on the afternoons of Sept. 1 and 2 in the terraced gardens of Shelmar House, the home of Francis Hartman Markoe in Water Mill, for the benefit of United China Relief.

At the directors' meeting of Basic Refractories, Inc., yesterday, no action was taken on the dividend due at this time. In March and June the company paid 10 cent a share each, while dividends of 20 cents each were declared for the March, June and September periods of last year.

LONDON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Twenty-two unarmed men whose job was to look, listen and try to keep out of the way of bullets and bombs accompanied the Allied forces in the Dieppe raid yesterday just so they could tell the story to newspaper readers in words and pictures.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Senator Robert R. Reynolds of North Carolina, chairman of the Military Affairs Committee, asserted in the Senate today that Great Britain must grant immediate freedom to India before the world would be convinced of the "seriousness and good faith" of the United Nations.

Advertisers generally, who are now preparing their campaigns for the Fall and Winter, plan to use realistic newspaper, magazine and radio copy on about the present scale, according to T.K. Quinn, president of Maxon, Inc. Those with products to sell, such as food, cosmetics, beverages, paint and hotel services, contemplate continued activity and in some instances are looking for sales increases, he said.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- five-run uprising in the twelfth inning gave Philadelphia a 6-1 victory over Washington in the nightcap for a sweep of a double-header today. The visitors won the opener, 9 to 2.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Livestock markets failed today to show any reaction to the statement by Secretary of Agriculture Wickard that he would consider placing ceilings on prices of live animals if a satisfactory formula were presented to him. Hogs and sheep were higher and most types of cattle at least held steady.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- Business showed a brisk upward trend in the American Red Cross Milestone Club in Kensington today. It had been pretty good right along with kindly English ladies, Mrs. John G. Winant and other celebrities waiting on table for Yanks who stop off at the club during their leaves in London. But the upsurge was traced to the arrival of American Red Cross workers from across the sea.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 20 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces have recaptured the Kiangsi Province towns of Kweiki and Shangjao on the Hangchow-Nanchang railway, further weakening the Japanese grip on that vital communication line, the Central News Agency announced today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Grain traders placed a bearish construction today on a speech by Secretary of Agriculture Wickard in which he advocated elimination of the not less than 110 per cent of parity price ceiling on leading agricultural products as provided in existing laws.

About 90 per cent of the important offering of Persian lambs and broadtails offered yesterday by Lampson, Fraser Huth were withdrawn because of difference in price views between shippers and fur buyers. Attendance at the sale was good and manufacturers were said "to want goods," but the shippers pointed to higher import, freight and insurance costs, now representing about 30 per cent of current prices against a much smaller figure a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Retail food prices advanced in two New York cities and declined in one between mid-June and mid-July.

Renascence in government circles of talk of more stringent curbs on inflation had yesterday a retardatory effect on the cotton market, causing active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange to fluctuate indecisively and to close 10 to 13 points lower than Thursday's final quotations.

To avoid any tie-up of vital wartime communications, Federal agencies intervened yesterday in two telegraph labor disputes, while a third controversy ended in the signing of a collective bargaining agreement.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 21 -- Twentieth Century-Fox today announced the purchase of two new war stories for filming this Fall. The studio acquired "Tin Fish," a screen yarn by Jacob Nelson about the Navy's torpedo planes, and has assigned it to Walter Morosco for production in color.

A racket by which the government was defrauded of money, and relief recipients were cheated of the benefits of the Federal food stamp system, was charged in thirty-six Federal indictments yesterday to thirty-eight merchants operating shops in Harlem.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Price ceilings on livestock would "inevitably curtail seriously the future production of meat animals," representatives of livestock producing associations said today at a meeting called by the National Livestock Marketing Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Tony Musto, the stocky Chicogoan with the bobbing, crouching style, scored an upset ten-round decision over Lee Savold of Des Moines tonight. Musto weighed 199, Savold 190 1/2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The first large forces of American Marines moved out to the Southwest Pacific in May, it was officially disclosed today, gathering in New Zealand for action against Japan's island outposts.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- Dennis Cardinal Dougherty, Archbishop of Philadelphia, warned today that "alcohol caused national degeneracy" and called on all Catholic priests to wage relentless warfare against "the evil of drink."

FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 21 -Frank Joseph Johnson, 32 years old, a former convict, was held today without bail for action of the grand jury on a charge of murdering Mrs. Elizabeth Satterthwaite yesterday on a farm in Upper Freehold Township, where Johnson formerly was employed.

The first in a series of exhibitions to be held for and by men in the armed forces at the National Catholic Community Service branch of the USO will open tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock at 17 East Fifty-first Street. The exhibition will be held out-of-doors tomorrow and indoors for the remainder of the week.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Eleven Flying Fortresses of the United States Army Air Forces met a pack of twenty to twenty-five of the Nazis' Focke-Wulf 190's over the North Sea today. The American bombers did very well indeed in the twenty-minute battle that resulted, for all of them survived and six of the Germans' latest fighter planes were destroyed or shot down damaged.

The Public Service Commission reserved decision yesterday after a public hearing on a proposal by the Brooklyn Union Gas Company to change its billing methods so that consumers, beginning Nov. 1, would receive bills once every two months instead of once a month.

In spite of the rationing of "gas" and tires "uninterrupted church attendance should be provided for in the nation-wide campaign to maintain transportation for war workers and essential civilian needs during the war," said a statement issued yesterday by the Highway Traffic Advisory Committee to the War Department through its director, J. Truman Thompson.

GARY, Ind., Aug. 21 -- In an address at the closing session of the convention of the American Federation of Teachers, marking his inauguration as president, John Fewkes of Chicago, warned that "crackpots and inefficient teachers" would not be acceptable in the membership of the federation.

City Court Judge Rocco A. Parella and former Assistant United States Attorney George J. Mintzer were selected last night as the Republican candidates for two of the vacancies on the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District, which includes Manhattan and the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Following President Roosevelt's signature of the service dependents' measure today, the War Department said that it would begin payment of allowances soon after Sept. 1, the first checks to include sums accrued since June 1, and the Navy Department stated that it was "prepared to make payment almost immediately" on applications already approved.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, national selective service director, said today that the reclassification of married men probably would begin in October, and certainly by Christmas.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Days of heated argument, before the Senate Patents Committee, whether contractual relations between the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and the German I.G. Farbenindustrie constituted an international cartel came to a climax today with a Department of Justice spokesman sharply impugning the credibility of five Standard Oil executives, and one of them offering to meet the accuser outside.

A large town house in the Murray Hill section passed to new hands yesterday with the sale by the Estate of Mrs. William P. Douglas of the six-story limestone front residence at 57 Park Avenue between Thirty-seventh and Thiry-eighth Streets. The property is now assessed at $100,000, but the house alone is said to have cost $120,000 to build when it was erected in 1909.

Leaders of the American Labor party decided yesterday to persist in their decision not to accept Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee, as the Labor party candidate for Governor, but to name a candidate of its own.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Cubs exploded a five-run fifth inning today to beat the Reds, 6 to 3, in the opener of a four-game series.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Aug. 15 were 246,433,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, United States Department of the Interior. This represented a decrease of 542,000 barrels in the week, comprising decreases of 372,000 and 170,000 barrels in domestic and foreign stocks, respectively.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Pointing toward a climactic series with Brooklyn next week, the Cardinals won their seventh straight victory today, defeating the Pirates, 10 to 2, and cutting the idle Dodgers' lead to 6 1/2 games.
One new little worry has turned up for this department in a world that so obviously has no serious trouble on its mind. This time it is the umbrella of British-American war planes over Dieppe.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Now that the smoke of battle has cleared away, some points about the attack on Dieppe should be cleared up. Among the attacking forces there were a small detachment of United States Rangers, some units of British Commando troops and a handful of Fighting French, but Canadians made up the bulk of the troops who landed and who suffered the heaviest casualties.

Some 18,000 workers in the millinery industry have approved the union's recommendation to waive a demand for an increase in wages in order to encourage producer in the metropolitan area to cooperate to a greater extent with the Millinery Stabilization Commission in its efforts to strengthen the market here, it was announced yesterday by Nathaniel Spector, manager of the Joint Board of the Millinery Workers Union.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 21 -- International representatives of the C.I.O. Aluminum Workers of America submitted to the 32,000 rank and file members of the union tonight the issue of whether a general strike should be called in the essential war industry.

LONDON, Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- The Moscow radio said today that second front would be opened "soon, very soon," and it reported that underground forces in occupied France and Norway were ready to aid the Allied invaders.
PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 21 -- A communique from Pacific Fleet Headquarters:
The eight-room house on an acre of land at 117 Handsome Avenue, Sayville, L.I., was sold by Charles Rohm to Alfred P. King through G.A. and W.B. Robinson, Inc., brokers.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 21 -- The theft of ten pieces of jewelry valued at $20,000 from the Summer home of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Crocker on South Main Street here was reported today in a nine-State teletype alarm sent out by the State police of the Riverhead substation.

Seeing the recent motion-picture, "The Pride of the Yankees," brought back poignant memories of the immortal Sultan of Swat, Babe Ruth. It no doubt brought back thrilling memories to his many fans who sat out in Ruthville and watched their idol perform super-human diamond feats.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- If the country is serious about paying for the war and preventing inflation, considerably more money must be collected under the pending tax bill, and virtually all from individual taxpayers, than the $6,200,000,000 contained in the House draft of the measure, Senator George, chairman, of the Finance Committee, said today.

AMERICA was built by refugees. But as 40,000 of them poured into this country between June of 1940 and March of 1941, at a time when the great interventionist-isolationist debate was clouding our collective judgment and fraying our nerves, the refugees became much more of a problem than they had ever been in the great days of Ellis Island.

The thousands of volunteer workers enrolled by the various local defense councils are doing a marvelous job of rooting out and collecting the materials so sorely needed by America's war industries. Too often, however, the salvage committees are discovering that red tape and burdensome restrictions, perhaps useful at the time of their adoption but now a serious obstruction to the war effort, have stymied the collection of important quantities of waste materials.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Operators of motion-picture and legitimate theatres have been told by the War Production Board that the board wants to keep all theatres open during the war as a morale factor, but that as the war progresses "we should realize this will become increasingly difficult."

LONDON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Allied raid on Dieppe "looked like a suicide mission" to four American Rangers attached to Lord Lovat's Commandos, but, as Corporal William R. Brady of Grand Forks, N.D., put it today: "Damned if we didn't make it."

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Pilot Officer Donald Joseph Curtin, 24 years old, of 208 Alexander Avenue, the Bronx, won the Distinguished Flying Cross on his first combat flight with the Royal Canadian Air Force, it was announced here today.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 21 -- Mordecai I. Fruchs and M.K. Frank, downtown scrap iron dealers, have been ordered by Judge Robert M. Gibson in United States District court to produce their books for inspection by the Office of Price Administration on Tuesday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 21 -- The War Minister, General Eurico Gaspar Dutra, today issued a proclamation stressing the gravity of Brazil's situation and declaring the army was ready to repel aggressions of those who, "using criminal methods, destroyed Brazilian life, sinking harmless coastwise ships in Brazilian seas."

This notion to promote gridiron meetings between Fordham and Manhattan and Columbia is being propounded with a diligence which may lead some people to take it seriously. It should be soberly weighed and then heaved onto the scrap heap.
BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Army announced tonight that at least seven fliers had been killed in the crash of two medium bombers near Harding Field, Army air base here.

A father whose son has been missing since the fall of Bataan arose yesterday at a manufacturers' salvage rally and donated twenty-four machines to the Knit Goods industry's campaign to raise 1,000 tons of scrap metal.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 21 -- Mohandas K. Gandhi has written to the Viceroy, the Marquess of Linlithgow, it was disclosed today. This breaks an eleven-day wall of silence by Mr. Gandhi, who has been held strictly incommunicado at the Aga Khan's palace at Poona since his arrest at Bombay.

A "Second Front" in religion will be advocated by clergymen tomorrow in their sermons in churches of the New York area. Pastors and visiting preachers will urge more of "a crusading spirit" if the war is to be won by the United Nations, and they will condemn "Religious Isolationism."

All physicians and nurses must be militarized for the duration, because in no other Way can the abnormal present and future conditions created by the total war be met adequately. This would not be a socialized, State or communistic medicine; it is simply and plainly total-war medicine, a grim necessity created by total war, which the medical profession must not accept as an imposition but demand as its active, effective and sincere contribution to victory.

Retail trade-here, while active this-week, suffered by comparison with the' extremely high sales totals of the corresponding week last year. Department store volume was estimated as running about 7 per cent under' I91, 'with apparel specialty shops having an even larger decrease.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Indians returned to the victory column tonight with a 3-to-2 victory over the White Sox behind the five-hit pitching of Mel Harper. Two Chicago errors helped the Tribe to its opening pair of runs in the second and a hit batsman in the fifth forced in the winning tally.

A newspaper campaign on furs intended to help retailers and manufacturers sell more garments of ranch-bred mink and silver fox has been started by the New York Auction Company, Maurice Cantor, president, announced yesterday. This is the first time, he said, that any auction company has gone directly to the consumer in an effort to benefit the entire fur industry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- President Roosevelt said today that Wendell L. Willkie would make his trip to Russia and the Near East as a personal representative of the President, a symbol of American unity in the prosecution of the war.
BOSTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The commercial bulletin will say tomorrow of the Boston wool market:
The six-story warehouse building on a plot 75 by 100 feet at 88 Sandford Street, Brooklyn, was sold by the American Tobacco Company to H.M. Field, Inc. tenant of the premises for the past five years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- American railroads hope to move more than 1,000,000 barrels of oil to the Atlantic seaboard daily this Fall and Winter, W.E. Callahan, manager of the tank car division of the Association of American Railroads, said here today.

DETROIT, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Successive home runs in the fourth inning by Barney McCosky and Rudy York gave the Tigers the opener, 4 to 1, of a four-game series with the Browns that may determine final occupancy of an American League first division berth.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The text of the statement of President Roosevelt in regard to Axis crimes in occupied countries was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Senators split today on the significance of the nomination of John J. Bennett Jr. for Governor of New York. Most legislators begged to be excused from commenting on the victory scored by James A. Farley, who had backed Mr. Bennett.

In demanding on the floor of the Senate that Britain must grant "immediate independence to the 370,000,000 people of India" before the world will be convinced of the "seriousness and good faith" of the United Nations Senator Reynolds of North Carolina spoke irresponsibly.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 21 (Reuter) -- Tonight's Chinese communique included the following:

Reporting on five years of steadily diminishing industrial strife, the State Mediation Board set forth yesterday its conviction that "mediation pays social dividends in the form of community peace and industrial stability."

The first profit for a twelve-month period since that ended on Dec. 31, 1931, was reported yesterday by the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company, which is in proceedings for reorganization under Section 77B of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

Any hot water and fuel conservation program made necessary by war shortages should be applied generally to the areas affected, and should be carried out "by Federal and not local order," the Real Estate Board of New York yesterday suggested to Mayor La Guardia.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 21 -- A force of United States Marines of the Pacific Fleet landed on Makin Island in the Japanese-held Gilbert group on Monday, destroyed all installations there and withdrew "with only moderate losses," a Pacific Fleet communique said today.

DETROIT, Aug. 21 -- Construction of an addition to the Chrysler Corporation tank arsenal was halted today when 475 American Federation of Labor members went on strike in a jurisdictional battle with the C.I.O.

Preparations for landing the 1,451 passengers arriving here next week on the Swedish diplomatic exchange liner Gripsholm were announced yesterday by Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port, at the Custom House.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The text of President Roosevelt's letter to heads of government agencies and departments directing them to refrain from public debate criticizing each other and controversy over policy questions read as follows:...

The appearance of the first issue of railroad securities since July 16 featured a smaller total of new bond offerings here this week for public subscription. Three bond issues with an aggregate face value of $3,917,500 were marketed, more than half in a single rail issue.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- The Illinois Federation of Retail Associations today urged the two big national retail trade groups to obtain United States help in alleviating the shortage of help in department stores.

A protest against enactment of legislation to prohibit payment of brokerage or contingent fees by producers to any broker or appointed agent in any negotiations or contract with the government has been filed in Washington with the Senate Naval Affaiirs Committee by Julius Perlmutter, managing director of the National Association of Merchandise Brokers, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Distinguished Service Medal, the Army's highest award for non-combat service, has been conferred on Colonel Theodore Wyman Jr. of Kingston, N.Y., for "exceptionally meritorious and distinguished service" in the direction of emergency construction at isolated and widely separated points in the South Pacific area.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- All steel and zinc, as well as many grades of lumber, are denied to civilian industry, no matter how essential, by a new War Production Board listing of scarce materials, published today. Scrap materials, including iron and steel and rubber scrap, are also included in this "insufficient for essential needs" category.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 (AP) -- Tony Lupien, rookie first baseman for the Boston Red Sox, drove in five runs tonight to lead the Sox to a 7-to-5 victory over the Athletics before 9,388 at Shibe Park.

Ray Robinson scored a fast knockout over Rube Shank, Colorado lightweight, in their scheduled ten-round battle at Madison Square Garden last night. The Harlem welterweight, who has never met defeat as a professional, registered his thirty-fourth consecutive triumph when he stopped the Westerner in 2 minutes and 26 seconds of the second round.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

Those were rattling good stories in yesterday's newspapers of the Commando raid on Dieppe. The war correspondent has come back. It is sensible of the authorities to let him see for himself and to tell what he sees. And war has become many more kinds of "hell" than it was in the days of Bull Run Russell, Archibald Forbes and our own MacGahan.
A boom year is in store for blouses, according to all indications. An independent career lies ahead of the garment that so long was dependent on the rest of the ensemble.

OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 21 -- Women shipbuilders are creating confusion in the ranks of the Boilermakers' Union at the plant of the Moore Drydock Company here. The famous old shipyard is now seeing the day when men are voting whether women will be accepted in the union and allowed to work beside them in the yards.

Following a second conference yesterday with Mayor La Guardia on compromise amendments to the McCarthy Salary Increment Law, Vice Chairman Joseph T. Sharkey of the City Council reported that progress had been made toward reconciling the differences between the Council and the Mayor.

Debt liquidation is removing a large part of the threat of high war-time income to our price structure, according to a statistical survey in the current issue of The Exchange, magazine published by The New York Stock Exchange.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Aug. 22 (U.P.) -- Allied medium bombers made their second straight attack yesterday on the Maobisse area of Japanese-held Timor Island, shooting down one enemy Zero fighter and losing one of their own bombers, a communique issued by General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today.

Captain Leland P. Lovette, newly appointed director of the Office of Public Relations for the Navy, disclosed in Chicago yesterday that not more than five ships out of 2,000 convoyed in Atlantic coastal zones had been lost since May 14.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 21 -- The Paragon Stables' Liste won the $1,600 Worcester Purse at Narragansett Park today, leading Arnold Hanger's Ubiquitous to the wire by two and three-quarter lengths.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Senate acceptance of a House bill to permit absentee voting for Federal officeholders by members of the armed forces of the United States was indicated today when Senator George, who blocked action yesterday, said that he had obtained an agreement from Senator Green, Senate sponsor of the bill, to modify it to meet his objections.

Under a revived bullish interest in low-priced issues and a mild help at leadership from some of the rubber and steel stock, the stock market improved yesterday as much as a point. Final quotations were around the best of the session.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Workers in mines, mills and smelters producing Copper, lead, zinc and six other critical metals were urged today by Paul V. McNutt, War Man Power Commissioner, to stay on their jobs and he intimated that their wages would be raised if they did and that other employment might be refused them if they did not.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Talk of anti-inflation and of lowered price ceilings for farm products had relatively little effect today as a price-making influence on grains on the Board of Trade. There was a little selling of wheat futures early by professional traders, but the offerings were absorbed by brokers who frequently act for mills, and the market firmed up readily.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The newspaper column of Mark Sullivan became the vehicle today for President Roosevelt's gleeful evasion of comment on the Democratic nomination of Attorney General John J. Bennett for Governor of New York over the New Deal favorite, Senator James M. Mead.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- War spending by the Treasury is higher than that ever attained by any government, but official statistics showed today that American consumers were still spending more than the Treasury.

Nearly 400 delegates from Suffolk, Nassau, Queens, Brooklyn and Richmond attended the Second Judicial District Republican Convention yesterday afternoon in the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn, and conferred for four hours on nominating five candidates for the Supreme Court bench in the Brooklyn-Long Island district.
It was quite a show the Yankees put on yesterday at the Stadium for a ladies' day crowd of 10,024.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- German air defenses proved startlingly inept in the battle of Dieppe, and if the Allies had followed through with dive-bombers and parachute troops behind their perfect fighter screen, they might have turned the moderate success of their invasion rehearsal into a smashing victory, Allied observers said tonight.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 21 -- Lieutenant Gardnar Mulloy of the Jacksonville naval flying base and Miss Margaret Osborne of San Francisco advanced to the final round of the Longwood Bowl invitation tennis tournament today at the Longwood Cricket Club.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 21 -- Prince and Princess Irbain-Kahn Kaplanoff gave a luncheon today at the Beach Club for Mr. and Mrs. Jules J. Vatable of Lochgraeme, Islip, who motored here to spend the day with the hosts.

The former Rice Bakery plant at Park and Linden Avenues, Linden, N.J., has been purchased by the Tobacco Machine Supply Company from the McDonald Baking Company, an affiliate of Rice Bakeries. The building is a one-story structure on a plot of one and one-third acres, and affords 20,000 square feet of daylight space.

Blanket charges of profiteering and hoarding against waste material dealers were called unfair and unpatriotic by Price Administrator Leon Henderson in a letter to Charles M. Haskins, managing director of the National Association of Waste Materials, Inc., which he released yesterday as an answer to criticisms directed at the industry.

CONVENT STATION, N. J., Aug. 21 -- Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr., of Crestmont, New Jersey Association champion, captured low gross honors in the one-day golf tournament over the Morris County course today with a card of 43, 40 -- 83.

LAKEVIEW, L. Aug. 21 -- Herbert H. Green, 50 years old, a retired New York City fireman, killed himself with a pistol shot today after firing several shots at his wife, Estelle, 41, and wounding her as she fled from their home at 16 Parkside Drive, here, following a quarrel over Green's refusal to divulge the contents of a safe deposit box he owned, according to Detective Thomas Bonanza of the Nassau County Homicide Squad.

No new films arrive on Broadway today, but several revivals are scheduled to open. At the Little Carnegie, the "Gala Film Festival of Dance and Music," comprising short subjects featuring the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, Katherine Dunham, Carmen Amaya and Paderewski, will open for an indefinite run . . . "
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Jersey City and Rochester battled to a 3-3 deadlock tonight in a game that was halted at the end of the eighth inning because of dimout restrictions.

Safeway Stores, Inc., has leased from E.Q. Payne the one-story store building at 5600 Broadway in the Riverdale shopping district and upon completion of alterations will occupy it as a supermarket. Mark Groskin Company in cooperation with L.J. Phillips Co. were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The cost of living is still rising, Leon Henderson said today, because the prices of foodstuffs which the Office of Price Administration has no power to control are advancing at a rate which means a 30 per cent rise within the next year.
MOSCOW, Aug. 21 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:

The United States Government, through the Treasury Department, already has set up financial safeguards in Hawaii just in case of enemy invasion. These have taken the form of stamping United States currency in the Territory of Hawaii with an official "H" and of provision for deposits of United States Government and corporate securities held in the territory.

The will of Miss Frances T. Ingraham, who died on June 26, 1942, at the Mohawk Hotel in Brooklyn, filed for probate in the Kings County Surrogates Court, disposes of a considerable estate among relatives and religious and charitable institutions.
LONDON, Aug. 21 -- The stock markets finished the week quietly today. Gilt-edge securities had several fractional gains.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- President Roosevelt told his press conference today that good progress was being made in the development of plans to avert inflation and expressed the hope theft some action could be announced within two weeks.

The lull in advancing prices that followed the first imposition of price ceilings has now been broken definitely. Wholesale prices and the cost of living have advanced to new highs for recent years, with the former up 33 per cent and the latter 19 per cent since the outbreak of the war in Europe.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Lady Doverdale, the guest of Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin, addressed the workers at the Bundles for Britain shop here this morning on conditions and needs in Great Britain. Mrs. Sydney J. Smith of New York and this city is chairman of the local branch.
The Coast Guard, Third Naval District, is enlisting additional personnel for its sailing vessel patrol for offshore work, according to an announcement yesterday.
CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 21 (AP) -- M.B. Goff's Bostee, a 3-year-old filly, closed with a rush to take first money in the American Red Cross mile and one-sixteenth feature at Garden State Park today.

NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- "Rockland Riot," the twelve-act variety show to be presented tomorrow night at the Clarkstown Country Club in South Nyack by the Rockland County actors' colony for the benefit of Russian War Relief, is a sell-out.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 21 -- The police of Avellaneda City, south of Buenos Aires, announced today the arrest of eight persons believed to be the material perpetrators of the attack Aug. 2 upon Waldo Frank, United States author.

BELLEVILLE, N.J., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Defending champion Bill Samanchik of Passaic County was eliminated from the New Jersey public links golf championship today by Jack Spinnell of South Shore, L.I., in a second-round match at the Branch Brook course.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 22 -The Nazi bid for Stalingrad reached a critical stage early today with reinforced German troops trying to erect bridgeheads across the Don forty miles above that Volga city and attempting to exploit a wedge driven into Russian positions northeast of Kotelnikov below the Don.

Arriving at La Guardia Field aboard a Pan American Airways transatlantic clipper yesterday, Emanuel Rosen, director of the Immigration Service of the Joint Distribution Committee, asserted that about 1,500 Jewish refugees will have been evacuated monthly from Europe to the Western Hemisphere by the end of the year.
We all know that the civilian defense organizations in our city are doing a fine job, but I think they have overlooked one very necessary precaution.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 21 -- Assistant District Attorney Thorn Lord abruptly closed his cross-examination of Herbert Karl Friedrich Bahr in Federal Court here today when he obtained an admission from the man accused of being a Nazi spy that he had asked an FBI agent "how much do you think I could be punished?" directly after making the long detailed statement which is the principal evidence against him.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 21 -- Kwangfeng, important stronghold on the Hangchow-Nanchang railway, was recaptured by Chinese forces yesterday and the retreating Japanese garrison is being pursued northeastward along the railway, the Chinese communique reported today.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 21 -- Chess experts from many points in the United States began arriving today for the annual open championships of the United States Chess Federation which starts tomorrow at the Hotel Baker under the auspices of the Texas Chess Association.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Aug. 21 -- What is probably the world's first tank destroyer training center consisting of barracks, workshops, ranges and training ground for 39,000 men will be officially opened next month at Camp Hood, near Killeen, Texas.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- The Sugar Producers Association announced today opposition to a plan to revise coastwise shipping regulations to permit some foreign ships to carry Puerto Rican sugar and other cargoes to the mainland.
Natural and artificial gas manufacturers served 18,734,000 consumers on June 30, an increase of 647,000 from the same date a year previously, the American Gas Association has reported.
LONDON, Aug. 21 -- The cry for girls and still more girls has again gone out from the three women's uniformed services of Britain, it was disclosed today.

Not long ago a transport airplane which had flown nearly two million miles on a commercial American route before it entered the Middle East war ferry service came down with one engine burned out on a sand bar at the mouth of the Nyanga River on the west coast of Africa.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Tommy Goodwill of Briar Hills, who is studying celestial navigation preparatory to going into the Coast Guard, today steered the straightest course of any of the eighty-nine contestants in the second annual invitation golf tournament of the Hummocks Country Club.

After being in rehearsal for more than a month without a leading feminine player, "Strip for Action" finally has acquired Eleanor Lynn for the part. At least twenty-eight persons were interviewed before Miss Lynn was signed to complete the large cast.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 21 -- Although Edmond S. Webster of Mount Tabor, N.J., is 69 years old, he is not one to submit to robbery quietly.

When Hitler was preparing to invade Poland no one could have foreseen that three years later the war for Danzig would have spread to the last of the five great continents of the earth. Yet that is what is happening as Brazil, biggest of the South American republics, prepares to declare war on the Axis powers.

The State Liquor Authority made available yesterday copies of the price schedules filed for September as required by the newly enacted Hollowell law and scores of manufacturers', wholesalers' and retailers' representatives examined the lists at the Authority's headquarters at 420 Lexington Avenue.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- As word came from the United States today of President Roosevelt's warning that Axis nations would one day be compelled to suffer "fearful" retribution for their crimes against civilians in the occupied countries, news of fresh cruelties and oppressions leaked to London.

The University of Rochester, Rochester, N.Y., has received more than $300,000 from the late Mary M. Condon to set up a fund known as the John P. Munn Fund in memory of Dr. John P. Munn, former chairman of the board of trustees of the university, it was disclosed yesterday in the estate tax appraisal of Miss Condon's estate.

Legal proceedings designed to save the jobs of twenty-seven of the forty city high school teachers scheduled to be dropped on Aug. 31 under a recent Board of Education resolution to meet a budgetary deficiency were started yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court.

The disruption of an international cartel said to have controlled the molybdenum market from 1929 until the outbreak of war in 1939 was reported yesterday by the Department of Justice. The announcement was made with the filing of a consent decree enjoining the five principal American producers and distributors of molybdenum from future violation of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- President Roosevelt served grim warning today on the Axis invaders of Europe and Asia that they would be required, after the certain victory of the United Nations, to stand trial in the now-occupied countries for their "barbaric crimes," including the execution of hostages for acts of sabotage and violence committed by others, and that "fearful retribution" would come to all those guilty of such acts.

Adequate preparation for a special offering on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange changed yesterday the picture for common stock of the Hercules Powder Company. Shields Co. offered 5,000 shares, the balance of a 6,300-share block offered for ten hours by another firm over the Aug. 9 week-end, and saw it go "out the window" at a special commission of $1.15 a share in one minute.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 21 -- Industrial leaders must be the nation's first line of defense in the fight to prevent post-war unemployment, according to a report issued by the regional office of the National Resources Planning Board. The area covered by the report includes New York and New Jersey.

MOSCOW, Aug 21 -- Germany was able to launch her great Summer offensive against the Soviet Union only because she had help from ninety divisions of her allies' fighting men, the Red Army soldier realizes today as he watches for news from the west of a second front.

LONDON, Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- A Belgian Government spokesman disclosed today that twenty armed Belgian patriots recently overpowered German guards in a mine near Marcinnelle, in South Central Belgium, near the French border, and destroyed a considerable quantity of explosives.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- President Roosevelt ordered officials of every government department and agency today to stop bickering, criticizing each other over the economic war program, airing their disagreements in public, and thus contributing to the confusion of the man in the street. "Officials divert to quarrels with each other the time and energy they ought to be devoting to fighting the enemy," he bluntly said in the course of his order.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 21 (AP) -- The league-leading Newark Bears hung up a 2 to 1 decision over the Buffalo Bisons in the first game of a twilight double-header tonight, then played eleven innings in the nightcap before dimout regulations halted the game with the score deadlocked at 1-1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The British-American Combined Food Board described as "an immediate problem" today the allocation among the United Nations of needed food supplies, to be drawn from pooled stocks of the United States and the United Kingdom.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 21 (AP) -- Four suits involving sums which may run into millions of dollars were filed in United States District Court today against Frederick H. Prince of Boston and Newport and two holding companies in which he is the principal stockholder.

A program of educating all students in the last two years of high school throughout the State in the "importance of aviation in modern life" and in the present war was announced yesterday by the State Board of Regents, which met at the State Office Building, 80 Center Street.

The technical and scientific professions were requested yesterday by James M. Landis, Federal Director of Civilian Defense, to organize regional, State and local committees to provide technical advice and research on civilian protection problems.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- An additional 5,000 to 7,000 tank cars are likely to be made available to haul petroleum to the East Coast as a result of an order from the Office of Petroleum Coordinator today banning the movement of gasoline by rail in twenty Midwestern and Southwestern States.

Making a little go a long way is an honorable and old-fashioned art, long numbered among the lost in this prolific land. SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21 -- As many West Coast farmers despaired of getting enough Mexican labor to make much difference with this year's harvest, the California Processors and Growers, Inc., appealed to Lieut. Gen. John L. DeWitt today to detail soldiers to relieve the agricultural labor shortage.

Long Branch fishermen believe that the strip of sand along their section of the New Jersey coast is one of the best for surfmen who want to hook into a striped bass. Apparently the leading entry in the Governor's New Jersey fishing contest is in agreement, for he landed a 42 1/2-pounder there recently.

A resolution authorizing a committee to present to Mayor La Guardia and Chairman John H. Delaney of the Board of Transportation the demands of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., for better wages and working conditions on the city's unified transit lines was adopted last night at a mass meeting in Manhattan Center, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, and attended by day workers on the IRT and IND divisions.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 21 (U.P.) -- Balkan reports said today that an estimated 50,000 German troops had been moved by sea and air transport from Greece to the North African front and the island of Crete.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Ward Baking Company has been called for Sept. 29 to vote on a series of proposals including recapitulation of the preferred stock, the writing down of good-will and property accounts, and modernization of accounting practices.

OTTAWA, Aug. 21 (Canadian Press) -- Beef cattle producers today were guaranteed a "floor" under live cattle prices should they fall below the equivalent of wholesale beef prices fixed by the Wartime Prices and Trade Board.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Allied landing raid at Dieppe demonstrated, according to the opinion expressed by foreign military experts here today, that a second front can be opened in France -- granted a sufficient superiority of land-based planes, adequate transport and the proper element of surprise.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 21 (Reuter) -- Besides attacks on Tobruk, light bombers of the South African Air Force attacked objectives between El Daba and Matruh, it was reported here today. Two fires were started near El Daba and a small fire and numerous explosions were caused among motor transports in Sidi Haneish and Galal.

ALBANY, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Knickerbocker News said today that Richard D. Scandrett of Cornwall - on - the - Hudson, Republican candidate for Representative-at-large on the 1938 State ticket, has written a letter to delegates to the party's State convention asserting that Thomas E. Dewey, who is expected to win the Governorship nomination, "is a very substantially weaker candidate today than in 1938."

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in the Western Desert, Aug. 21 -- When a New Zealand patrol attacked and overran an enemy advanced position in the darkness of early morning, it brought back one wounded prisoner.

Heavy increases in gross and net returns for July and the first seven months of the year were reported yesterday by several railroads. Operating revenues of the Erie were the largest for that month in any year. Those of the Southern Pacific company were $41,320,000, against $26,432,800 in July, 1941.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Work on power projects scheduled to produce 2,200,000 kilowatts of new energy when completed next year and the year after was ordered stopped today by the War Production Board as it put into force a readjustment of the country's power expansion program.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21 -- A mass meeting of striking United Automobile Workers of America (C.I.O.) voted late tonight to return to work at the Vernon plant of the Aluminum Corporation of America at once and resume production of essential aluminum materials for aircraft builders and parts manufacturers.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 21 -- Members of the Bayonne Refinery Employes Association voted last night to appeal to the United States Circuit Court of Appeals against a decision of the National Labor Relations Board ordering dissolution of their organization on the ground that it was dominated by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

PEARL HARBOR, Aug. 21 -- A picture of battle-hardened United States Marine forces standing victorious on the beaches of the Solomon Islands with the remnants of the Japanese defenders hiding in the hills and jungles was painted tonight in a communique issued by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the United States Pacific Fleet and director of the Solomons campaign.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 21 (AP) -- United States and Brazilian airmen continued today their search off the 5,000-mile coastline for Axis submarines, including one that accosted the Godiva, a small coasting vessel, with demands for fuel and food.

Widener's wish thus to dispose of the collection formed over a long period by himself and his father, P.A.W. Widener, has been known for more than a year.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 21 -- Bert Jackson was in the Suffolk County Jail at Riverhead tonight, to which he was remanded after his arraignment here today before Police Justice George Hahn, on a charge of grand larceny arising out of a $10,000 stock deal.

Everett John Grady, vice president and director of Ruthrauff Ryan, Inc., has leased a large suite in 863 Park Avenue through Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton. This was one of many apartment rentals reported by brokers yesterday over a wide area. Another lease, announced by the Leslie Apartments in Forest Hills Gardens, L.I., was that of James S. Wallington, radio announcer.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Adequate supplies of fabrics for the production of men's work clothing arc assured under terms of an order, M-207, issued today by the War Production Board.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- The Petroleum Coordinator's office announced today that a production rate of 4,066,500 barrels daily of all petroleum liquids had been set for September.

VICHY, France, Aug. 21 -- In an interview with the German paper Pariser Zeitung, published today, Jean Bichelonne, Vichy's Secretary of State for Industrial Production, announced that a second group of French factories was about to be closed under the government plan for industrial concentration.

New issues of municipal securities aggregating $34,118,500 are scheduled for award next week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. This compares with this week's total of only $2,106,297, and with the weekly average for the year to date of $23,420,470.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Full fields in both the $14,000 Saratoga Handicap and the $12,000 Grand Union Hotel Stakes have been named for tomorrow, the fourth Saturday of this race meeting which has made turf history by carrying on in the face of all transportation difficulties.

Travel Lines: Mashoes, N.C., is to have a new road, and youngsters who formerly went to school by boat will be able to go on foot. But over against the British publicity there is a temptation to put the paucity of information given out by Washington on United States military and naval activities.

KEESEVILLE -- Observance of Labor Day will be more this year than just another celebration. The occasion will mark the 100th anniversary of the construction of the ancient arch bridge -- largest keystone bridge in the country, spanning the Ausable River here a few miles above the point where it plunges through the rock-walled chasm on its way to Lake Champlain.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 22 -- The fortieth annual Piping Rock Horse Show, scheduled two weeks earlier than usual, Sept. 17-19, will benefit the Army Emergency Relief with gross receipts from this three-day sports and society fixture of the North Shore turned over to that fund.

Macy Co., enabling the individual taxpayer to pay his income tax within the year in which he receives the income, would seem to remove the most serious obstacles to the enactment of a workable withholding tax on current income.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Charles William Soltau, 33-year-old research engineer who tried to organize an Indianapolis unit of the German-American Bund four years ago, was arrested today on a charge of violating the Selective Service Act.

The Atlantic Refining Company announced in Philadelphia last week that James E. Moss, manager of operations of the company's marine department, had been appointed a member of a panel of consultants of the Merchant Marine Council of the United States Coast Guard.

By a stroke of the pen, the Federal Reserve Board has cut reserve requirements of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in this city and Chicago, and by so doing has given temporary relief in a situation which threatened to impair the ability of the institutions in Wall Street and in the Loop to continue their heavy purchases of government securities.

Gerhard Wilhelm Kunze, former national leader of the German-American Bund, and Dr. Otto Willumeit, head of the Bund in Chicago, who were sentenced Friday in the Federal court in Hartford, Conn., for conspiracy to violate the espionage act of 1917, will be brought here tomorrow for trial for conspiracy to violate the Selective Training and Service Act.

A total eclipse of the moon will be visible everywhere in North America next Tuesday except in the far West and Northwest. At 9:01 P.M. the moon enters the penumbra (the outer part of the shadow cast by the earth) and at 10 P.M. the umbra (the earth's inner shadow).
The establishment of the Fordham Bureau of Economic Research was announced yesterday by the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Shortly after the announcement of the declaration of war had been broadcast to the nation, this city's principal streets were filled with excited people, many of them shouting with joy over warfare against the Axis -- a condition that had long been desired by the average Brazilian, who is violently pro-democratic.

MORE verity dwelt in a bygone era's nickel novels than the disapproving parents who confiscated them on sight ever supposed. Our elders' denunciation of those lively narratives' lurid, if somewhat stenciled, violences seems sardonically comic now in the red glare of current everyday catastrophes.

SOVIET ASIA, the vast land mass between the Urals and the Pacific, between the Arctic Ocean and the borders of China and Afghanistan, is a vividly interesting subject for a book for two reasons. It contains an enormous variety of regions and cultures, the frozen tundra toward the Arctic, for instance, the pioneer Russian farm settlements, the old colorful oases of Inner Asia, with such romantic cities as Samarkand and Bokhara.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- The growing need for world understanding, coupled with the increased interest in international relations as shown by the activities of students during the last year, has led Colgate University to enlarge its International Relations Concentration for the coming year, Dr. Rodney L. Mott, director of the School for Social Sciences, announced today.

BIZET'S beguiling "Carmen" is coming to Broadway, escorted by an all-Negro cast and bedecked with all modern appurtenances. Lest the overseers of the Metropolitan Opera and the operatic faithful have any misgivings, Oscar Hammerstein 2d, the artistic guide of the pending production, offers advice to the contrary.

Although cotton textile exporters are finding it extremely difficult to do business under present conditions, they disclosed yesterday that they intended to remain in business, in the belief that there would be a world-wide shortage of cotton goods following the war despite the current tremendous production in this country.

LAKE GEORGE -- Pre-Labor Day social events of interest to visitors will include a recital by artist-pupils of Mme. Louise Homer, former opera star. Mme. Homer, wife of the writer Sidney Homer, is a resident of Diamond Point on Lake George.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- Although Britain lacked official notification of the fact, the news today of the Brazilian Cabinet's decision to declare war against Germany produced the deepest satisfaction in London as a decision toward which the Axis acts of aggression were likely to drive an increasing number of the remaining neutrals.

For the first time since the emergency began, educators representing every section of the country and all branches of learning, from elementary grades through the university, will gather in Washington this week-end to participate in a four-day National Institute on Education and the War.

IF, as the story goes, an ailing cow really started off the Minnesota career of the elder Dr. Mayo, it seems a peculiarly appropriate beginning, for the story of one of the world's greatest medical institutions is as American in one sense as a stake-an-rider fence.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The War Labor Board appealed today to striking Midwest truckers to return to work, saying that the dispute, which involves some ninety-six companies and about 10,000 workers, was contrary to the national agreement of labor unions not to strike during the war.

There is a new aristocracy in the world of motorists. Not so long ago the wheelbase of an automobile and its state of polish determined the social status of its owner. Today a little windshield sticker with an "A," "B," "C" or "S" is the sign of distinction.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- One of the most cheering notes in the war situation in the United States is the fact that even with all the fear of alien influence here, only a fraction of the nearly 1,000,000 Axis nationals have had to be locked within detention camps.

HERE is another Simenon double feature. The first of the two stories in it is "Death of a Harbor-Master," starring Inspector Maigret. In the opening chapter we find Maigret on a Cherbourg train leaving Paris.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 22 -- Play started today in the annual open championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation in the ballroom of the Hotel Baker, with eighteen experts from various sections of the country and Canada competing in one section for cash prizes and the Kirkland D. Holland trophy, won last year by Reuben Fine at St. Louis.

BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Army officially listed nine dead today in the air crash of two medium bombers as rescue workers continued searching the wreckage in the woods just north of Harding Field, near here.

The motion picture industry, by request of Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., will head the Treasury's $1,000,000,000 war bond and stamp drive next month. The campaign, designated as a "Salute to Our Heroes," will have as its slogan and theme, "Buy a Bond to Honor Every Mother's Son in Service."

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22 -- Sweet words as well as sunshine radiated today from Southern California, where 20,000 women work in the aircraft industry. Softening the Boeing blast made on Monday by Oliver West, executive vice president, officials of leading aircraft corporations spoke in behalf of the women workers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- For the first time in its history the United States now has a truly international military force, spread out all over the globe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Following a conference between President Roosevelt and Mayor La Guardia today it was announced at the White House that their discussion concerned only on war problems.

FROM the day when Euclid made geometry classic and Archimedes terrified the Romans with his engines of war to our modern era of Einstein theory and the bomb-sight, mathematics, theoretical and practical, has been an indispensable element of human culture.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- British-American plans for the vast air offensive against Germany, laid "through all the months of patient, strenuous work," were "at last beginning to ripen," Air Secretary Sir Archibald Sinclair said in a speech at Swansea tonight. The 1,000-bomber raids against the Reich would soon be "less infrequent," he asserted.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Scoreless in the first six innings of play, the Red Sox found their range suddenly today and belted the Athletics freely to win a double-header, 11 to 3 and 11 to 5.
Addressed to The Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, a personal request comes by way of prisoner-of-war mail from a flight lieutenant being held somewhere in Germany.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Karl Maust of Columbus, 1941 national open trapshoot champion, and John Vogel of Alliance, Neb., each shattered 100 straight targets in the second day of preliminary firing in the forty-third annual Grand American trapshooting tournament today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Atlantic City, with both soldiers and the civilians present, goes into the final weeks of the Summer season with a near-capacity crowd.

Quite honestly and outside the evasive black market there is proffered a means for motorists to get five-gallons-worth of automobile mileage for each four-gallon coupon torn from an A-ration book. Actually no extra fuel is involved and the saving comes from "splitting" the engine so it will run on half its cylinders.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 22 -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Ecuador qualified today to meet his erstwhile mentor at the University of Miami, Lieutenant Gardnar Mulloy, in the final round of the invitation tennis tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- A return of scattered liquidation in the corn market, which had depressed prices early in the week, resulted today in unsettling the grain markets on the Board of Trade and the close was about the bottom. Corn finished with losses of 1 1/4 to 1 5/8 cents a bushel, pressure from cash rouses helping the decline.

The time may come when severe merchandise shortages and a narrowing consumer goods economy will force major merchandising curtailment and the closing of many retail departments or stores, but it would be a mistake at this time for merchants to foster a policy of contraction in retailing, according to views expressed here last week by retail authorities.

Christmas mail for members of our armed forces serving outside the continental United States should be mailed by October, "the earlier the better," according to instructions by Third Assistant Postmaster General Ramsey S. Black published in The Postal Bulletin.

AT this time of year we normally expect a spate of preliminary announcements of forthcoming Fall publications. It would be an exaggeration to say that, instead of a flood, we have now no more than a mere trickle, but it is certainly true that, in comparison with prewar days, our literary output has greatly dwindled.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Representatives of the Treasury in new efforts to make the withholding tax of 5 per cent on personal incomes, as adopted by the House, more acceptable to the Senate and to employers who would be responsible for its collection at the source, laid simplifying proposals before a subcommittee of the Senate Finance Committee at a closed session today.

Japan for the first time had been presented with an important threat to her Southwest Pacific conquests.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 22 -- Saratoga, the 4-year-old bay colt rated by harness racing followers as one of the most consistent pacers in training, romped home on top in both heats of the Fon du Lac Junior Free-For-All Pace, which featured the program at the Roosevelt Raceway today.

NOTHING too solemn today. Listening to the new programs that have been coming along recently -- with the exception of "An American in England" and "Britain to America," noted here last Sunday -- you get the notion that the creative minds along Radio Row are marking time, waiting for the Autumn or perhaps only for a good idea.

So don't go passing cups of hot coffee over their heads at the table -- many scalds occur that way. Check up on electrical connections around the house -- youngsters can get their fingers in loose floor plugs, to name only one needless hazard.

QUITE early in life John L. Sullivan discovered that "when he hit a man the man went down." His strength, though great, was not the only reason. He also had, says Mr. Chidsey, "a natural genius for timing his punches."

To insure adequate nursing care for civilians, the State Health Department and the Health Preparedness Commission of the New York State War Council have undertaken the joint project of organizing community nursing squads whose members will be used for home nursing in emergencies.

IT has become very much the fashion to write about the future of the Netherlands East Indies and to decide what should happen to that part of the world. All the investigators of this problem prefer to be strictly democratic, but they have a bewildering tendency to overlook entirely the democratic aspects of the matter they are dealing with -- namely, that the Indies themselves should decide about their future in the first place.

After two nights and three days of conferences and more than twelve hours of intensive labor by a small group of its leaders, the State Convention of the American Labor party last night nominated Dean Alfange, Tammany organization Democrat, for Governor.

THE admirable Phaidon Edition series on sculpture continues. As has been true also of preceding volumes, the mast arresting feature of these books is the illustrative material. The large-format, full-page plates are of splendid quality, seeming almost to bring before one the pieces of sculpture themselves so vividly are they illustrated.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The White House announced today that President Roosevelt, by an oversight, failed to include China in the list of countries which Wendell L. Willkie will visit to explain the progress of the American war effort.

NEARLY half a score of big seaports along the Atlantic Coast fairly teem with ocean shipping. Grim platoons of tanks, guns and military transports are drawn up on the docks. Smoke-colored freighters, ensign at stern and a fluttering row of signal flags above the bridge, poke their way down the channel.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 22 -- A fleet of 337 freighters, largest to move a single bulk commodity in Great Lakes shipping history, now is hauling ore to lower lake ports, a report compiled by C.C. Lindeman, statistician for the M.A. Hanna Company, disclosed today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 22 -- Major Gen. Baron Karl August von Gablenz, a top official of the Reich Ministry of Aviation and one of the best known aviators in Germany, was killed instantly today when his service plane crashed near Berlin.

SWING: Britons last week got a look at genuine rug-cutting by experts. The occasion was the United States Amy's first all-Negro military ball in the British Isles. Seventy-five Ngro women from the African Church's Mission at a British port were among those who attended.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 22 (U.P.) -- A Central News Agency report said huge fires were raging at Kiangshan, where the Jap garrison was "showing signs of withdrawal as the Chinese rapidly pressed toward the town in a sweeping counter-drive in Chekiang."

GIRLS are beginning to dress up in the evening when their beaux are on leave. Even now at the end of Summer many of them tuck a dinner dress into their bags when they go to parties at the different posts. Throughout the Fall and Winter, benefit affairs for Army and Navy will call for evening clothes to complement the wartime uniforms of the men.

It has always been Joseph Stalin's principle to seek cooperation with the great powers of the West.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (U.P.) -- Merchant ship sinkings in American waters -- the East Coast, the Gulf of Mexico and the Caribbean -- are fewer now than at any time since early Spring, official Navy announcements indicated today.

Bittencourt, Brazilian Military Attache here and sen ior delegate to the Inter-American Defense Board, said tonight that the first task now confronting Brazil would be to defend herself and particularly the "bulge" which juts out to within 1,800 miles of the Vichy French base of Dakar, French West Africa.

The American public contributed last January in celebration of President Roosevelt's diamond jubilee birthday $3,908,310 to combat infantile paralysis and help those already stricken by it, shattering all records of previous years. This was reported yesterday by the Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday to Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

Late Summer is a period during which most city gardens lack bloom and color. The increasing shade from trees, mostly the vigorous growing ailanthus, as well as the shifting position of the sun, leaves densely shaded areas which earlier in the season were colorful with Spring bulbs, shrubs in bloom and annuals.

THOSE of us who were brought up on "The Arabian Nights" fondly think of a djinn as a benevolent servant conveniently endowed with the most useful of supernatural powers. Not so, however, the Tunisians, who live in constant dread of their malicious impulses.

HOW are the Eastern art colonies faring this year, with the nation deep in war? A quick tour of some of the principal centers establishes the fact that they have made the necessary adjustment and held to their respective Summer programs -- if not quite as usual, at least with determination and courage.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Wobbly but game, the Cardinals staggered through their eighth consecutive triumph today -- a 7-to-6 affair with the Pirates -- but Manager Billy Southworth called on four pitchers before the final out.

"NEARER THE EARTH" is the current winner of the Avery Hopwood award at the University of Michigan. It is a far cry from the brash and earthy realism of the recent winner, "Whistle Stop." For Beatrice Borst's book is the story of a girl who was undeniably a lady.

THIS morning's news is that Arturo Toscanini and Leopold Stokowski, who are to share the leadership of the NBC Symphony Orchestra, will be heard this Winter on Sunday evenings -- 5 to 6 P.M. -- instead of Tuesday or Saturday nights.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 22 -- During the week news came out of Oslo that the Interessen Gemeinschaft Farbenindustrie, better known as the I.G. Farben, had placed huge construction contracts in the south of Norway with a view to transferring much of its production from Frankfort on the Main to Norway -- where it is likely to be less hampered by R.A.F. bombings than in the Reich proper.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Seeds of the Russian dandelion, a quick-yielding rubber plant, are on the way to Argentina and Chile for experimental plantings after having been rushed half-way around the world this Summer from their native soil.

TROPICAL BUTTER -- Dairy specialists of the United States Department of Agriculture find that pure butteroil and skim-milk powder -- two dehydrated dairy products that contain all the food nutrients found in butter -- can be shipped to tropical countries, held for a year or more if desired and then made into good butter with the aid of a little cold water.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 22 -- Brazil's declaration of war upon Germany and Italy following the sinking by German submarines of five Brazilian ships forming part of a convoy in waters off the coast of Brazil came as a rude shock to those South Americans who imagined the war was taking place so far from their shores that it did not even distantly concern them.

Main floor and basement departments were busy in stores in the three major test markets of New York. Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. College shops were active, with a good call noted for dresses, coats, suits and furs.

Johnny Colan, West Side heavyweight, outpointed Al Boros of Bridgeport in the star bout of ten rounds at the Queensboro Arena last night before 2,000 fans. Colan, who weighed 178 1/4 to his rival's 195, floored Boros for a count of nine in the fifth round. Boros held frequently.

MONTEBELLO, Que., Aug. 22 -- United States youths grabbed three of the four places in the semi-final round of the Seigniory Club Junior Davis Cup tennis tourney today and only a strong comeback by Henri Rochon of Montreal kept the invaders from a sweep.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 22 -- Several events planned for the late season in behalf of various philanthropies are receiving the support of Summer colonists here.

A total of 159 schools and colleges in the United States now cooperate with the Tuition Plan in financing the academic careers of students, according to the annual report made public yesterday by Florence McConnell Rogers, president.

"FARMER'S GIRL" is an exact, business like narrative of life and work on a thousand-acre "all-sorts" farm in East Anglia from October, 1939, to the tail-end of last year. It is highly representative of present-day agriculture in England and particularly interesting in its suggestiveness of what, in all probability, will be the country's future land cultivation role.

Seven women, all college graduates who had held teaching, administrative and retail business posts, were sworn in yesterday morning as officers of the Women's Reserve, United States Naval Reserves, at the office of Naval Officer Procurement, 33 Pine Street.

RUMSON, N.J., Aug. 22 -- A "hillbilly" barn dance was given tonight at Harbourage, their Summer place, by Mr. and Mrs. J. Frederick Talcott for their granddaughters, Miss Joan Talcott of Rye, N.Y. and Miss Frances McMillan of Philadelphia.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Aug. 22 (Wide World) -- Off on a particularly perilous flight, Captain Arthur La Roe of Westfield, Army Air Force medical officer, put his thoughts on paper. NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 22 -- The Yale Plan of student preparation for war service has now been in operation since the opening of the accelerated Summer term on July 6 and has proven a complete success both from the standpoint of the 3,200 undergraduates and the university faculty, it was reported today by Yale authorities.
BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 22 -- Boston University's two-year curriculum experiment, started five years ago, has proved successful and will be continued in its present form, university officials said today.

FERDINAND V of Spain is remembered not only for promoting the expeditions of Columbus but for establishing the Inquisition within his realm. Just after Columbus embarked on his first voyage for the greater glory of Spain a mass exodus of Jews began from the country in which they were no longer welcome.

NAZI censorship of the Continent is as tight as a drum. But RAF Flier Claude Strickland sends regular cables to lush Hollywood starlet Maria Montez, the transatlantic apple of his eye. Weekly the screen actress receives messages of love from her flier-wooer, incarcerated somewhere within Germany-Dachau, according to latest reports.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Aug. 22 -- If any of Paul Dresser's candle-lights are still gleaming through the sycamores on the banks of the Wabash, they will be joined this Fall by lights which gleam from the campus windows of Indiana State Teachers College and schoolhouses throughout this region, for the significant trend in education in this area at present is night study brought on by the war.

NEWARK. N.J., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Tommie Byrne, young southpaw, registered his sixteenth victory of the season today as he limited the Bisons to five hits while Newark galloped to a 5 -- 1 decision in the opener of a scheduled twin bill.
