HANOVER, N.H., Aug. 22 -- As a preliminary to the study and devising of a general program that will eventually give to its undergraduates a sounder knowledge of American history and civilization, Dartmouth College next month will add an achievement test in that field to the aptitude and placement examinations to be given to all incoming freshmen.

SINCE Hitler's killers marched over the border more than a year ago Russia has produced heroes aplenty among her fighting regulars, her home guard and her guerrillas. Now there is another kind of hero, the soldier of the camera, who advances with the Soviet vanguard and retreats only with the last stubborn fighters of the rearguard.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- It was easy sailing for all but the trailers of a fleet of fifty-six competitors today in the twelfth special regatta on Long Island Sound, which was held by the Echo Bay Yacht Club. The last ones suddenly had heavy going, so much in fact that they could hardly be kept under control to cross the finish line. There were no mishaps.

Most of the proprietary bridge clubs have reopened, after having shut down voluntarily, "for repairs" or "during the hot season," following police raids made as a result of the shooting at the White House Bridge Association on Aug. 3. Under consideration by the managers is the formation of an association which would endeavor to protect the interests of the clubs.
CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Coming around on the outside in the stretch, Mrs. Ella K. Bryson's Mercury won the $5,000 added Walt Whitman Stakes for 2-year-olds at Garden State Park today.
MUSSOLINI the dictator does not like Ignazio Silone the novelist. This is understandable. Silone does not like Mussolini. In his novels he makes that masterpiece of bombast seem utterly ridiculous.

THE head of a model agency and several of his models, a photographer, a gangster or two, a catsup tycoon and his playboy son, a police inspector and a reformed amateur detective -these are the persons who play their parts in this tale of glamor and gore.

An incendiary bomb fountain pen of the type found in the possession of the Nazi saboteurs caught after landing in Long Island and Florida will be among new exhibits to be on display tomorrow at the Win-the-War show at Hearns Auditorium, Fifth Avenue and Fourteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (U.P.) -- Torture and mistreatment inflicted by Gestapo agents on prisoners in Norway, including Americans, was revealed tonight in eyewitness accounts made public by the Norwegian Embassy here.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 22 -- Swarms of newly hatched mosquitos, humming like a million tiny bombers, rose from the storm-flooded meadows in this area before dawn today, swooped down on sleeping residents of four counties and turned their beauty sleep into a weary torture of slapping, scratching and swatting.

Amid the turbulence of quarrels between Manager Mel Ott and Dixie Walker, a near fist fight between Muscles Medwick and Bill Werber, a drizzling rain and finally a downpour, the Dodgers yesterday walloped the Giants, 10 -- 5, to win in the eighth inning at Ebbets Field.

Business activity and mail orders increased in most of the wholesale markets last week, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. There were indications of volume surpassing last year in better coats and suits and better dresses.

Even in friendly quarters there is a disposition to describe Mr. Bennett's personality as lacking in color. An honest and capable and conscientious public servant but not exactly a glamour boy. When people speak of a colorful candidate they are thinking, naturally, only of the campaign.

ROCKFORD, Ill., Aug. 22 (UP) -- The Chicago Bears, polishing their offense for their contest with the college all-stars Friday night, scored in every quarter today to defeat the Camp Grant service team, 32 to 6.

MEET Oliver Twitchet. He is the official who that everything in Washington gets done according to the rules. He is the fellow who worries about the upstarts who want to win the war in a hurry. He is the coordinator of red tape who sees that records are kept straight, memoranda exchanged and protocols observed.

BOSTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The Braves and Phils split a double-header today, Boston winning the opener in ten innings, 2 to 1, and Philadelphia, copping the ngihtcap, 5 to 3, behind the six-hit pitching of veteran Si Johnson.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 27. -- Valdma Marl, a 3-to-5 favorite of the crowd of 20,000, won the $5,000 added Jeanne d'Arc Stakes for 2-year-old fillies today at Narragansett Park.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- A voluntary pre-induction training program using existing facilities of schools and colleges throughout the country to meet present and future needs for properly trained personnel in the armed forces was announced today by the War Department.

That Wall Street still does not feel quite right about the provisions for relieving railroads of their burden of debt contained in the bankruptcy law is evident from the current controversy about the McLaughlin bill. This bill provides even more drastic means for slashing railroad debt than does bankruptcy procedure.

There can never be too many ideas for gifts to men in the services, for besides all the members of one's own family who are in the armed forces there is always some other recruit to cheer. Packages from home make any day seem better at camp.

The long-awaited adjustment in the Revised Maximum Export Price Regulation, as it affects exporters of finished piece goods, will be announced by the Office of Price Administration within the next week or two, it was reported in the trade yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Donald Nelson, chief of the War Production Board, returned from a short holiday this week to present critics of the board's performances with a record of work accomplished and a promise that he would be completely ruthless from now on with any one who got in the way of war production.

Preliminary plans for the annual American Merchant Marine Conference, which will be held in conjunction with the sixteenth annual convention of the Propeller Club of the United States at the Waldorf-Astoria on Oct. 15 and 16, were discussed last week at a meeting of various club committees in charge of arrangements.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Shifting the emphasis from conventional patterns of international affairs instruction, the American University School of Social Sciences and Public Affairs will concentrate its resources on the problems and practices of international administration, it has been announced by President Paul F. Douglass.

The Sparks-Withington Company, manufacturer of radio and allied appliances, issued yesterday its report for the fiscal year ended on June 30. It showed a net profit of $679,845, after charges and reserves for Federal income taxes and a provision for war-time and post-war adjustments.

THE nineteenth festival of the International Society for Contemporary Music was given earlier this month at the University of California in Berkeley, and its sponsorship was one of its most significant features.

Dimout and blackout requirements are eliciting from the professional interior decorator many an ingenious idea for window treatment. The homemaker in search of smartness as well as protection may have imitation Venetian blinds, made of paper, for example, cream on the inside and black on the outside.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- The vanguard of a confident Republican party organization in the State began arriving here this afternoon for the opening of the Republican State Convention Monday.

WHEN Walter Damrosch's "The Opera Cloak" receives its world premiere during the second season of the New Opera Company, which opens Nov. 3, at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre, the stage direction will be assumed by Felix Brentano and the production will be designed by Eugene B. Dunkel. Dr. Damrosch will conduct this offering.

Until the government began distributing food for school lunches, around 9,000,000 youngsters in this country weren't getting even one square meal a day, according to the August issue of The Consumers Guide, a publication of the United States Department of Agriculture.

CORVALLIS, Ore., Aug. 22 -- Oregon State College will start its seventy-fifth year on Sept. 20 with a new president, Dr. August Leroy Strand, and two new degree curricula, one in business and the other in mining engineering.

Possibility of a "sit-down strike" on the part of liquor retailers in their dealings with wholesalers was seen in the trade last week following the release by the State Liquor Authority of September price schedules, the first filed by the suppliers under the Hollowell Law.

Your editorial "Training in Camouflage" caught my eye at once, I having been for many months in the Y.M.C.A. hut of our Camoufleur Section at Dijon, France.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- The Skytop Club will give its annual musical review "Skyrackets" at the Lodge on Friday and Saturday. The final rounds of men's and women's golf club championships will be played this week at Pocono Manor.

THIS war volume by Major Miksche, a Czechoslovak officer who fought in the Spanish civil war and is now with a detachment of Czechoslovak volunteers in England, is an outstanding exposition, accompanied with diagrams and timetables, of the methods of warfare practiced by the Germans in the campaigns of 1939- 1941.

A stalling disposition, promoted by the revival of anti-inflationary talk and by the approach of the next government's crop report, was in evidence yesterday in the cotton market. With volume restricted because of these factors, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange moved within a 9-point range during the dull session and closed with net losses of 5 to 8 points.

When the Democratic State Convention last Thursday nominated Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for Governor of New York, State Chairman James A. Farley won a decided victory over President Roosevelt, who backed Senator James M. Mead.

HAMILTON, Mass., Aug. 22 -- The ninth annual all-breed fixture of the North Shore Kennel Club, held on the Myopia Hunt Club grounds today, saw best-in-show go to the stylish whippet, Ch. Flornell Glamorous, owned by Mrs. George A. Anderson of Glen Head, L.I., and shown by Percy Roberts.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -The text of a statement by the Brazilian Embassy on Brazil's entry into the war against Germany and Italy follows:

TAKING advantage of a diminishing sense of humor on the Axis radio, the BBC seizes the initiative in the international war of wits and holds up for ridicule recent German and Italian military disappointments. On Mussolini's fifty-ninth birthday they quoted from Il Duce's new book, in which he writes: "It is better to be a lion for a day than a sheep for a hundred years."

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- After a bitter head-and-head drive all the way down the stretch, the long shot Can't Wait eked out a head decision over the Greentree Stable's Swing and Sway, who was odds-on at 9 to 20 along with his stable-mate, Corydon, to win the $14,200 Saratoga Handicap today before 13,969 spectators.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 22 -- Two local war work organizations -- the East Hampton Chapter of the American Red Cross, headed by Mrs. Samuel Seabury and Mrs. Daniel Tucker, and the Service Men's Club, of which H. Lewis Edwards is president, were the beneficiaries of a dinner-dance tonight at the Devon Yacht Club.

The refusal of an effective majority of the New York State Democratic Convention last week to forsake its pledge to nominate Attorney General John J. Bennett for Governor, and select instead Senator James A. Mead or some other candidate acceptable to the President, was a declaration of political independence as well as a tribute to the character of Mr. Bennett's sponsor, James A. Farley.

THE announcement last week that Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will cease to observe the sales terms of the year-old Department of Justice consent decree under an "escape clause," effective Sept. 1, was regarded by Hollywood observers as a strategic move rather than an actual immediate reversion to the old policies of block booking and blind selling which the decree outlawed.

A Turtle Bay garden party and street fair will be given in that area, Forty-eighth Street between Second and Third Avenues, on Sept. 15 under the auspices of the British War Relief Society for the benefit of the Merchant Navy Clubs in the United States for British Seamen.

JONESPORT, Me. -- Along the shores of Frenchman's Bay, "Down in Maine," life goes on in outward peace. Farmers still work the rocky soil for a modest subsistence and fishermen ply the island-studded waters off the coast. Weirs and lobster-pots dot the small bays, and vegetables, eggs and milk go their appointed rounds through Hancock, Sullivan, Steuben, Cherryfield, Columbia Falls and Jonesport.

GLANCING at the problems of Jack Lescoulie, the platter jockey, or maitre de records, of WNEW's "Milkman's Matinee," you suspect that things are not what they were on the 1 A.M. to 7 A.M. stretch. Once it was a matter of talking along and playing tunes the clients asked for and talking some more.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Blueberry Pie galloped to victory today in the $7,500 added Meadowland Handicap over Washington Park's turf course and established a track record.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Navy Department released today a congratulatory message sent by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, to Major Gem Alexander A. Vandegrift, commanding officer of the United States Marines in the Solomon Islands area. Admiral Nimitz said:

War does strange things, and not the least of these in our country is that it has caused a well-known educator to attempt a defense of a political, economic and cultural system for which during the past two and a half decades hardly any one in public life has had a good word.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 22 -- A large group of South Berkshire Summer colonists will be in charge of booths and stalls at the Ascension Farm School Bazaar, to be held at Stockbridge Town Hall and grounds next Saturday for the benefit of the Ascension Farm School in South Lee.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 18 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- American soldiers at New Delhi probably will not become homesick now that they have been shifted to brand new living quarters.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- Demands made by the armed forces upon the physicians of the country plus shortages in merchandising lines are restoring the drug store's pharmaceutical department to its old prominence, officials of the National Association of Retail Druggists said here today in discussing plans for the annual convention, Oct. 5 to 9.

At the end of what is frequently termed "the world's biggest excursion for a nickel," is Staten Island -- this year coming into new prominence as a vacation objective. Remembered by old-timers as a place of big estates and old-fashioned farms, the island retains wooded stretches and grassy uplands.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 22 -- So much stress is being laid at Vichy on the "correct" attitude of the population of Dieppe during the Allied Commando raid there Tuesday that it may be deduced that the Nazis and the Vichy authorities feared active civilian participation there, according to private advices reaching here today.

Russia and the Middle East -- two theatres of operations that are closely linked in the grand strategy of this war -- were still the principal battlefields of the global struggle last week despite spectacular Allied attacks at Dieppe and in the Solomons.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- The present and the past came to grips today in the quarter-final round of the second annual Hummocks invitation golf tournament, formerly known as the Green Meadow invitation, and the present, represented by young Douglas Ford, current New York State junior champion, came out on top.

The stringent measures of the new war economy have penetrated to the most remote corners of the Indian reservations. Beatty, has assumed a tremendous responsibility which it is meeting in a highly commendable manner.

Last week several formations of heavy American bombers lifted from their bases in England and roared over Occupied Europe to strike at German strong points and bases. The precision bombing of these craft from miles above the earth amazed British fighter pilots, who went along as escorts. What's more, all the Boeing B-17's returned.

Nat Baron, the former titleholder, had a difficult time in eliminating Bernard Seligman, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, as play began in the national open paddle tennis championships yesterday at the Parkchester Courts. Frank Barrardi, City Public Parks ruler, also was hard pressed before vanquishing Phil Rubin, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 4.
NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 10 (Delayed) -- This Virginia tidewater area, long a mecca for Summer visitors, is now a center of America's war effort.

ONE of the most important institutions that have developed within the field of the American dance, the dance project at Bennington College, last week completed its ninth Summer session. Since this year was, for obvious reasons, its most difficult, the record of its accomplishment is of particular interest.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Marine Corps announced today that it had adopted as a supplementary .45-caliber weapon, the Reising submachine gun which fires at the rate of 400-450 rounds a minute.

UNCLE SAM'S Army is having a tough time getting enough radio men. It is estimated that the Signal Corps -- nerve center of the Army -- within the next few months will need several hundred commissioned officers, several thousand non-coms and many thousand enlisted men skilled in radio operation and maintenance.

A survey of the coming Winter in Palm Beach reveals plans for assisting government workers on vacation furloughs to find quarters in the resort's hotels. And both the Mayor and the Town Manager of Palm Beach have been in Washington and New York recently consulting with officials on the problem of transportation for these future visitors.

The International Hydro-Electric System yesterday reported for the three months ended on June 30 a consolidated net loss of $23,551 against one of $189,585 for the similar period of 1941. For the twelve months ended on June 30 the net loss was $693,855, while for the preceding twelve months the system had a net income of $8,467.

IN "Natalie Maisie" Mr. Masefield indulges himself in writing one of the worst poems in the English language. It is a privilege of poet-laureates. They have all been at it some of the time from Shadwell through Wordsworth and Tennyson to Alfred Austin, who did it all of the time.

RETAIL trade showed more life in the week and consumer response to intensified promotions was improved. The prospect of inventory reporting, even if actual control is put off for six months, had led to price reductions which are tempting to customers.

ALBANY, Aug. 22 (AP) -- State tax revenues for July, the first month of the new fiscal year, fell off about 17 per cent below July, 1941, due mainly to restrictions on motor vehicle use. The drop amounted to $3,872,504.56, the Tax Department reported today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Five thousand of the 50,000 dogs in Westchester are qualified for "enlistment" as sentries in the Army, Navy and Coast Guard, Mrs. Marvin Preston, president of the County Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, said today in urging residents to relinquish their pets to the armed forces.

WHEELER WILLIAMS, the sculptor, raises the question: What is "modern"? This point comes up apropos of an article that appeared in these columns May 31. It was concerned in part with an address delivered by Mr. Williams at the annual dinner meeting of the National Sculpture Society, quotations from which were made, indirectly and from memory.

THAT man Saroyan is still at it without resistance from his fellow-playwrights or the actors. The Rialto Gossip column not long ago stated he is casting another of his great plays with the usual group of bartenders, taxi drivers and hat check girls, not through the customary agents, but at hack stands, night clubs and bars.
BOMBAY, India, Aug. 22 (AP) -- Political observers declared today that ungoverned violence might be tapering off, but non-violence was just beginning.

Letters containing specific recommendations of women qualified for appointment to policy-making boards in Washington, being delivered on official desks this week, will add momentum to a campaign to win more directive posts for the distaff side.

ISTANBUL, Aug. 22 -- Guerrilla warfare of Yugoslavia's General Draja Mikhailovitch and his 150,000 Serb Chetniks and Yugoslav regular troops burst with fresh violence recently along the coastline of Dalmatia and the heights of Montenegro, as well as in Bosnia and central and eastern Serbia, as large and powerful bands launched a series of attacks against the Italian Second Army garrisons and Croat Ustashi over an area of hundreds of square miles.

"HOW would it be, do you think, if I rode across Canada?" Mary Bosanquet asked her parents, one day in London in 1938. She knew nothing about Canada; her riding experience was limited to "hacking, horse shows and hunts"; her ready cash totaled eighty pounds; but her parents were willing and she was eager, and so, in the Spring of 1939, off she went.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that costs of certain special services and actual transportation costs may be added to the maximum prices for sales of beef and veal carcasses and wholesale cuts to the armed forces and the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation under an amendment to Maximum Price Regulation No. 169.
LONDON, Aug. 22 -- Although military and political events overshadowed economic thoughts in the last week, the future of the British commodity trade continued to attract attention.

As if to compensate for its reticence in making public information about the war, the Navy issued a 1,200-word press release yesterday through the Public Relations Office of the Third Naval District, 90 Church Street, telling all about the way the Duchess of Talleyrand has been entertaining ten young sailors at her "castle-like" estate on the Hudson River at Tarrytown, N.Y.

In the week just closed it has been evident that the war has been rising to a climax. The direction in which it swings in the next few months or weeks or days may determine its outcome. Nothing is to be gained, and everything could be lost, by failure to recognize the gravity of the situation in Russia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The War Production Board, pointing out that many newspapers were carrying only minimum stocks of newsprint, reminded publishers today that the agency's orders that relaxed inventory restrictions on newsprint would expire Sept. 30.

From the grand ballroom of the Hotel St. George, tucked away in the maze of quiet residential streets that is Brooklyn Heights, rumbled last week the first gunfire of battles to come in American politics. At issue in Brooklyn was the Democratic party's nomination for Governor of New York State.
Victory gardeners who live in suburban and country areas and are now confronted with the many problems that the canning season brings need have no regret if they are dependent on electric stoves.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Production of guns, tanks, planes, ships and other instruments of war increased 16 per cent in July, but was still 7 per cent short of the goal set at the beginning of the month, Donald M. Nelson declared today in his second monthly report to the country on the status of our effort to out-produce the Axis.

OWING to all-too-familiar causes, no more olive oil is being imported. California olive growers, in spite of extraordinary effort, can meet only about a tenth of the demand. And, while it is hoped that stocks of imports can be eked out until the middle of next year, prices -- about three times above normal -- are out of reach of most wartime pocketbooks.

LAREDO, Texas -- Near Government restrictions on the use of United States currency will affect tourists to Mexico this Summer and Fall. According to the Treasury in Washington, travelers, after they pass the Rio Grande, will have to use bank checks, travelers checks or other instruments of credit instead of United States currency.

IF, on Aug. 28, some patrons of Loew's State receive gifts, list it not as a minor aberration but merely as a commemorative gesture on the part of a grateful host. For on Aug. 29, the theatre will have reached its twenty-first birthday, which according to the management is justification enough for festivities.

A 302-pound woman who, the police charge, posed as an heiress worth $340,000,000 and casually presented her intended victims with checks ranging from $3,000,000 to $46,000,000 was under arrest in the prison ward of Bellevue Hospital last night on a charge of grand larceny.
The Joe Pye weed now makes the moist lowlands and the damp waste places glow with soft purple beauty. Weed it is called and weed it may be, but it has a history that goes back more than 2,000 years.

Those who have visited the Interstate Park area north of Dyckman Street Ferry in recent weeks have probably been impressed by the number of power boats cruising the Hudson off the Jersey shore.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 22 (AP) -- A plan for the opening of millions of square miles of virgin rubber tracts in Eastern Colombia has been put forward by the United States Government's Rubber Reserve Corporation, it was learned today.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: With a few days' respite from almost constant rains, one of the most important garden tasks is to go over the garden for a thorough clean-up: where mildew, molds -- or just plain decay -- are found, foliage or old flowers can be cleaned out, and sulphur dust or some similar fungicide applied.
OTTAWA, Aug. 22 -- Canada has been thrilled by the stories of the attack on Dieppe, in which Canadian units from Toronto, Montreal, Winnipeg, Windsor and Hamilton took a conspicuous part.

An initial enrollment of seventy students is indicated for the opening on Sept. 14 of the new Cardinal Farley Military Academy, at Rhinecliff-on-Hudson, N.Y. The new school occupies the former country home and estate of the late Levi P. Morton, vice-president of the United States in the administration of President Benjamin Harrison and Governor of New York from 1894 to 1896.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 -- America's hopes of winning the war and maintaining prosperity afterward lies in abandonment of the idea of a security economy, Thurman W. Arnold, Assistant Attorney General of the United States, told the National Institute for Commercial and Trade Organization Executives today in the final lecture of the annual week of study.

HARRY HARRISON KROLL has established himself as a regional writer of the South. The world of plantation-owners, share-croppers, tenant farmers is familiar to him, and he succeeds in presenting it to the reader.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Aug. 23 -- German troops driving relentlessly toward Stalingrad have succeeded in crossing the Don River southeast of Kletskaya and have rammed a wedge into Russian positions northeast of Kotelnikov in twin reverses for the Red Army, it was reported officially today.

The past week's arrivals of new issues from abroad include Dominican Republic's series issued on Aug. 15 to commemorate the coronation of the country's patroness, the "Virgin of the Highest Grace." In this group are 1/2-centavo gray- green, 1c deep green, 3c violet-red, 5c brown, 10c pink and 15c deep blue.

POINT O'WOODS, L.I., Aug. 22 -- Sixty-two craft participated in the annual regatta of the Point o'Woods Yacht Squadron today with the Cape Cod Class attracting the most entries, twenty-one. The small boats covered a four-and-one-half-mile triangular course in Great South Bay, while the larger ones sailed the distance twice.
THIS has been a busy fortnight in the London theatre, with six new productions. Although there was only one new play that was a good one.

CONWAY, Ark., Aug. 22 -- Hendrix College is meeting the pressing war demands by reinstituting a Summer session, liberalizing academic requirements, and raising the maximum for work permitted each semester by nearly one-third, college officials announced here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The New York Central Railroad today asked authority of the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to abandon its line between Van Cortlandt Park Junction, New York, and Getty Square, Yonkers, a distance of 3.1 miles.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- The war program announced by Sarah Lawrence College has been planned by a trustee committee, a faculty planning committee and the Student War Board with the common purpose of enlarging and redirecting the college activities to meet not only the demands of the war crisis but also the reconstruction period.

E.C. MILLS, former administrative chairman of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers and now general manager of the Song Writers Protective Association, is pessimistic concerning scarcity of new war songs, for which the President and other administrative heads have asked and which undoubtedly are needed today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Several luncheons were given in the track clubhouse today before the races. Among those entertaining were Mr. and Mrs. Parker Corning, Mr. and Mrs. William Woodward, Mrs. E. du Pont Weir, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth G. Reynolds and Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lustig.

Like the nation itself, American colleges are today confronted simultaneously by problems of both war and peace. The colleges are only now entering fully into their war activities. Their faculties are already depleted by the multitude of teachers who have entered the armed services and other national agencies.

In an effort to improve "employe suggestion plans," representatives of twenty-eight large companies with nearly 500,000 employes have organized a National Association of Suggestion Systems. Two meetings have been held and another is scheduled for early next Fall.

A nation-wide war-poster competition for both artists and photographers is announced by a sponsoring group comprising Artists for Victory, the Council for Democracy and the Museum of Modern Art. Offering eight $300 War Bonds as prizes, the competition closes on Oct. 15.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 22 -- Brazil's declaration of war on the Axis was communicated to the Argentine Government soon after noon today in a note that the Brazilian Ambassador, Jose de Paula Rodriguez Alves, delivered in person to the Argentine Foreign Minister, Dr. Enrique Ruiz Guinazu.

Activity in low-priced shares featured trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and resulted in deals of 180,410 shares, the heaviest for a Saturday since the first week-end in June. On Aug. 8 deals were 126,900 shares. Prices drifted narrowly and the market closed dull and mixed.

J.H. Lofland, a former official of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company and formerly general manager of the New England Steamship Company, has been named Coordinator for Ship Repair and Conversion, a joint office of the Maritime Commission and the Navy for expediting war work on American and other United Nations vessels.

SOUTH NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- Competing against a horde of mosquitoes for the attention of an audience of 3,000, Helen Hayes, Ed Wynn, Tilly Losch, Larry Adler and a dozen other Broadway stars performed tonight in an outdoor variety show for the benefit of the Russian War Relief Fund at the Clarkstown Country Club here.

The country's ship repair industry, which has a role in the United Nations' war effort second in importance only to actual shipbuilding, is now handling vessels for repair and conversion at the rate of more than 5,000 annually.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- This has been a crowded week. Events have followed each other so fast that many Londoners are not quite sure what day it is, let alone how they felt about any momentous happenings at any given time. Yet there is general belief that if this is the decisive Summer of the war, the seven days just passed were the fateful week.

WHEN war broke out, the great-granddaughter of Charles Dickens decided -- after some brief but illuminating experiments with other kinds of work -- that she would become a nurse: a real hospital nurse, no mere emergency assistant.

With prospects of the largest supplies of grain in history, the authorities in Washington are confronted by the question how to dispose of them so that they will contribute most to the war effort and at the same time reduce the inflationary threat, which is growing almost daily.

Community nursing squads -- so it is announced today -- whose members will be available for home nursing in the event of an emergency, are being organized by the State Health Department and the Health Preparedness Commission of the New York State War Council

Men of the Army and Navy have shown so much interest in the triptychs for religious services supplied by the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, Inc., that the organization is not only continuing but expanding its program in this field.

GREENC STLE, Ind., Aug. 22 -- In line with the idea of service which the Edward Rector Scholarship Foundation has had for more than two decades the complete educational facilities of the foundation have been offered to the United States Army Air Forces for the duration, De Pauw University officials announced today.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (U.P.) -- Fifteen Yuogslav guerrilla planes inflicted "many casualties" on the Axis garrison and a column of German troops in Banja Luka, a Bosnian city 160 miles west of Belgrade, it was reported today as a new surge of patriot activities in Western Europe followed the Allied raid on Dieppe.

The Western Electric Employes Association, representing 22,000 workers at the Western Electric plant in Kearny, N.J., appealed to the War Labor Board yesterday to review its decision denying any general wage increase to the company's workers.

Opposition to the proposal of the Office of Defense Transportation to curtail passenger bus service in Manhattan was registered yesterday by the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., in a statement issued by its international secretary-treasurer, Douglas L. MacMahon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Nearly 900 alien deserters from ships have voluntarily gone into service on vessels of the United Nations as a result of a four-month round-up of seamen illegally in this country, the Department of Justice and the War Shipping Administration announced today.

Next to the rose, queen of flowers, delphiniums are probably more universally popular than any other, and yet many a garden where they might well be enjoyed goes without them. One of the main reasons for this state of affairs is that they are not planned for far enough in advance.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22 -- After a campaign in which the war effort has been stressed, but with "Ham and Eggs" unforgotten, Californians will vote Tuesday at a primary election.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Jersey City defeated Rochester, 6 to 5, in the first game of a twilight-night doubleheader this evening and was leading, 1 to 0, when the second game was halted at the end of the fourth by dimout regulations.

THE BOOK - OF - THE MONTH CLUB'S book dividend for September and October will be "A Conrad Argosy," by Joseph Conrad, with a special introduction by William McFee and woodcut illustrations by Hans Alexander Mueller.

While retail trade here was active last week, dollar volume of sales suffered in comparison with the corresponding period a year ago, when consumer scare buying was strong. Department store sales were estimated as running about 7 per cent under 1941, while the drop for specialty shops exceeded that figure.

Thirty-nine young Naval officers have completed a three-month course in aeronautical engineering at the Daniel Guggenheim School of Aeronautics, New York University, and will take up duties as maintenance and repair supervisors with fighter aircraft squadrons both afloat and ashore, the Third Naval District announced yesterday.

BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, Aug. 22 -- A proposal that State, college and public school officials cooperate to inform young people of the advantages of the teaching profession has been made by Dr. Walter A. Zaugg, Professor of Education and director of the Bureau of Appointments at Bowling Green State University.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 22 -Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Barret of New York and Philadelphia gave a dinner and dance tonight at the Pot and Kettle Club for their son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. George V.W. Marston of New York, who have joined them at Mariposa for the remainder of the season.
College styles for young women showed strong military influence as displayed yesterday at a fashion show conducted by members of "the college board" at Gimbel Brothers.

LONDON, Aug. 22 -- The Upholder, Britain's leading submarine, whose captain was Lieut. Comdr. Malcolm David Wanklyn, V.C., D.S.O., has been lost, the Admiralty announced today. So distinguished was the vessel and its crew that the traditional brief statement of her loss was amplified with an official eulogy as follows:

MURRAY BAY, Que., Aug. 22 -The Manoir Richelieu is the scene of a round of parties over the week-end. Sir Frederick and Lady Williams-Taylor were hosts to their son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Pierrepont Perry of New York, who are here on their wedding trip.

Babe Ruth comes back to action today. So does Walter Johnson. And all roads will lead to the Yankee Stadium where these two immortals of baseball will once again be on exhibition, to revive memories of the past for the older generation and to give the younger generation a view of two heroes of the diamond whose exploits will be mentioned as long as baseball is played or talked about.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 22 (AP) -- An embargo on shipments of cash barley to Minneapolis, St. Paul, Duluth and Superior was ordered today, effective at midnight on Sunday, by Edward J. Grimes, grain marketing agent of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 22 -- Brazil has joined the long list of nations warring against the totalitarian countries. The declaration of a state of belligerence between Brazil and Germany and Italy was announced this afternoon.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22 -- Men who in other wars would have no chance for survival are recovering in the Mare Island Navy Hospital because of blood donations from persons living in many cases hundreds and thousands of miles away.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 22 -Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Barret of New York and Philadelphia gave a dinner and dance tonight at the Pot and Kettle Club for their son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. George V.W. Marston of New York, who have joined them at Mariposa for the remainder of the season.

PRIVATE DETECTIVE ANTHONY MARTIN of Los Angeles is sent to San Francisco on a wild goose chase. Since he is well paid for it, he does not mind being hoaxed, but when the man who sent him on the trip appears to be involved in a murder case the matter takes on a more sinister aspect.

Despite their objections to renegotiation of war contracts, business men generally were pleased last week to hear that the Army, Navy and Maritime Commission by inference were opposed to the flat profit limitation proposed in some Congressional circles.

Evergreens and conifers are most desirable in beautifying the garden, not only for backgrounds but for walk or driveway banking or when used individually to accentuate some definite point of attraction. They are also good in lower mass effect to soften a too harsh line of the house or as a much-needed screening.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Eastern Traffic Bureau, Inc., of 30 Church Street, New York, filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission an application to continue its operations as a Freight Forwarder of Package Goods between points of origin in the East to destinations in the South and West.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22 -- Many members of the Summer colony are actively interested in the benefit circus which will be given by the Newport Post of the American Legion to raise funds for the Army Emergency Relief Fund. The event will open tomorrow and continue through the week.

MOSCOW, Aug. 22 -- Russian resistance remains strong in all sectors and in the last twenty-four hours the situation on all fronts has shown no appreciable signs of serious deterioration. At Leningrad the defenders, now on the offensive locally, have scored further successes in a vital area.

PART of the fun of a vacation for a professional observer of films is (1) staying as far away as possible from motion pictures during the course of his sabbatical and (2) catching up on the new ones which came along while he was away.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22 -- A jurisdictional dispute between two A.F.L. boilermakers' locals which threatened to cause large numbers of welders to quit work at the Kaiser shipyards at Richmond quieted today on the surface to await government action.
LONDON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- United States Army Air Forces pilots, flying British Spitfires, took part in patrols over the Strait of Dover and Northern France this morning.
WHEN Fritz Kreisler was hit by an automobile about a year ago and lay unconscious in a hospital for many weeks, the pessimists predicted that he would never play the violin again.

"There are many anglers who have never visited Cuttyhunk and probably will not have the chance until after the war, but would enjoy reading and knowing more about this famous spot," says Dick Waterhouse in forwarding a description of the activities, as well as a brief history, of the island in outer Buzzard's Bay that has become synonymous in fishermen's minds with a striped bass.

Next Sunday the season's first field trial meeting for pointers and setters on the Canadian prairies will get under way. It will mark the ninth annual trials of the Saskatchewan Field Trial Association and will be held at Melita, Manitoba. The program will be made up of derby, all-age and championship stakes.

THE rubber raft measured 4 by 8 feet; it was taut, fragile and tricky; it had no sailing equipment, no provisions; it suddenly had a three-man crew who a few seconds before had watched their momentarily floating scout bomber sink in the Pacific.

James G. Blaine, chairman of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, said yesterday that nearly 100 neighborhood CDVO branches are now open throughout the city. Each is completely organized to carry on every kind of civilian participation in war work, he said, as this decentralization facilitates the enrolment of volunteers and enables defense instructors to work with small groups.

YOU can spend a pleasant and profitable hour or so just roaming through the galleries of the Metropolitan and noting the rearrangement necessitated by removal of many of the most valuable paintings to a place of wartime safety.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Four Japanese vessels have been sunk, one damaged and "possibly sunk," and a sixth torpedoed and damaged by American submarines operating in the Far East and in the North Pacific, a Navy communique revealed today.

With many of the best players in the armed services, the United States Lawn Tennis Association will conduct the national championships for the sixty-second and probably the last time until the war has been fought to a conclusion.

MONTEVALLO, Ala., Aug. 22 -- Alabama College, the State-supported institution for higher education of women, is devoting emphasis to expansion of its courses of training into fields of work for women for which there is increased demand because of war conditions.

MR. WRIGHT still has a way of telling a story and mixing in his philosophy that will appeal to as many readers as ever. Perhaps many more, wondering unhappily what the present wretched state of the world is all about, will find something to cling to in his credo.

THE poison, you may as well know at the beginning, is cyanide. Four deaths by it have occurred in New York with in a few days, and Inspector McKee is as nearly baffled as it is possible for him to be. One extremely vague clue leads to Westchester, and McKee follows it up only to discover another cyanide murder.

Among the many annual fixtures on the sports calendar which draw large attendances from society, one of the most colorful as well as impressive is the national amateur championship tennis tournament at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills. This year's tourney, to be held from Thursday through Labor Day, Sept. 7, has aroused unprecedented interest for several reasons.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The White Sox virtually stole a 3-to-1 victory from the Indians today. In the sixth inning, Chicago broke a 1-all deadlock with a pair of runs on two hits and three stolen bases.

NOVELS about the hardboiled career woman crop up rather frequently, but what distinguishes "Hang My Heart" from most of its competitors is that it pictures such a woman in her first, formative stages -- when the pattern of her future has only just begun to crystallize.
The adage, "after the feast, the famine," fell athwart the path of the Yankees yesterday to give the champions some anxious moments in their struggle with the Senators at the Stadium.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 22 -- After a meeting of civilian defense officials of seven States on the Atlantic seaboard at the Advertising Club of New York yesterday, the organization of the East Coast States Conference of Civilian Defense Directors was announced here today.

WHILE Peter Clancy and his ever faithful Wiggar are staying at a dude ranch in the Far West a horse opera is being filmed near by and Peter seizes the opportunity to learn something about the picture business.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- Efforts for cooperation of the United Nations in the war would be helped by creation of a Supreme War Council through which the Allies would share details of their program, Walter Nash, Minister for New Zealand, said on his return from a three-week visit to Great Britain.

MEN in the Arctic, cut off from human contact without even a letter for nine months at a time, builders working in the ceaseless wash of ocean waves, keepers going without sleep four or five days at a stretch as the split-second accuracy of a fog-horn tears at the nerves -- these are the men who have built and are responsible for the United States Light Service.

DURING the past year or two Old Bill Saroyan, the Armenian word man, has been conducting a rebellion against the American theatre. The theatre is dead, he says. The producers are no good and the audiences are pretty terrible. "I am opposed to practically everything in and connected with the present American theatre, including its methods, purposes and people," he says.

MIAMI EACH, Fla., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. George H. Brett, leader of the Army aviation forces smashing at the Japanese in the Australian area, promised only hard work, headaches and thanklessness to members of an officers' training class who were graduated from the Air Forces Technical Training School here today.

The American Army, which in less than two years had expanded from a peacetime strength of 500,000 men to a war force of sevral millions, with 10,000,000 soldiers the ultimate goal, last week was seeking new reservoirs of fighting man power. In Washington Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service head, warned that reclassification of 3-A -- men with dependents -- would start by Christmas, if not earlier.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 22 -- In the Corn Belt, reports of local meat shortages, possible rationing, or voluntary meatless days seem almost incredible. Supplies of meat animals on farms and ranches are the greatest in history. Sixteen per cent more cattle and seventeen per cent more hogs went to market the first six months of this year than a year ago.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 22 -- The aircraft carrier Independence, the second carrier to be launched since the United States entered the war, went down the ways of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation today in a private ceremony conducted in the presence of Secretary Frank Knox and other high Navy officials.

Declaring that a majority of the teachers who taught at Townsend Harris High School, which will close officially on Aug. 31, had not as yet obtained other positions, the Townsend Harris defense committee, through its chairman, James E. Flynn, charged yesterday that a Board of Higher Education committee, headed by Charles H. Turtle, had assisted only about thirty of the staff of seventy-five in finding employment.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (U.P.) -- Major Earl Johnson, commanding officer of 2,500 American women pilots, believes that women are just as good as men on most flying jobs, and sometimes better.

AT once strange, romantic, exciting and pathetic, A.E.W. Mason's new novel is a tale of England and Italy in the middle of the eighteenth century. The author has caught the flavor of the time, its curious mixture of the brutal and the exquisite, of cruelty and the love of beauty.
I read in THE TIMES of Aug. 14 that Representative Gearhart of California "hints patents block quinine substitutes," which is typical of the ill-founded attacks being made on our patent system.
PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 22 -Public willingness to accept the tax burden imposed by the war goes far beyond the conception of politicians or government officials.
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 22 -- A new X-ray tube which without shifting can send X-rays in different directions is claimed in a patent (No. 2,292,859) granted here to Thomas E. Allibone, Sale, England.

The six-story elevator apartment house for sixty-five families at 7101 Bay Parkway, in Brooklyn, has been bought by the Marbert Realty Corporation from Paul S. Hitlin, operator and builder, for cash over a first mortgage of $183,612 at 3 1/4 per cent, due in October, 1944, and held by the Public National Bank.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 23 -- Steel production in the nation last week slid off one point to 96.5 per cent of rated capacity. While furnace repairs have figured in on this, there is also evidence that scrap piles have declined, incoming supplies are lower in volume and scrap being received is, in many cases, of inferior quality.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 23 -- The masses in Brazil are applauding the war measure they demanded three days ago. Congratulatory telegrams are pouring in from a number of governments, evoked by the step Brazil took yesterday in declaring war against Italy and Germany.

Renewal of demands of government leaders for the adoption of more severe inflationary preventatives usurped the attention of the cotton trade during the latter part of last week, converting an active market into a hesitant one and turning prices of active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange downward after gains of the previous week had been increase.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23 -- Government agencies, including the United States Employment Service, are offenders against President Roosevelt's Executive order declaring against racial or other types of discrimination in war work, it was alleged today by the Bay Area Council Against Discrimination.

Net income of the American Smelting and Refining Company and its consolidated subsidiaries in the first six months of this year amounted to $14,828,177 before taxes, or $1,020,621 in excess of the $13,807,556 earned before taxes in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the semi-annual statement signed by Francis H. Brownell, chairman, and Roger W. Straus, president, and issued for publication today.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 23 -- Seventy-two craft were engaged today in the Long Island Sound championship regatta conducted by the Port Washington Yacht Club. Changeable conditions, from easy going to bowled-over hulls at the finish, made it a colorful and exciting competition.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Rear Admiral W.H.P. Blandy, in a broadcast from "somewhere in the Pacific" today, appealed to the workers in the nation's war plants to forego sympathetic strikes and jurisdictional union conflicts.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, Aug. 24 -- Colonel Blank's boys have done it again. Colonel Blank, whose name cannot be published because that information might one day be valuable to Japan, is a United States fighter plane commander at Darwin.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 23 -- Although Colombia's Federation of Workers has adopted a resolution favoring war on Germany, and although an editorial in the Liberal indicates such a possibility, the Tiempo does not favor a declaration of war now.

A campaign to educate the people on the need for salvage and to provide depots where scrap metals and other vital materials can be left was started yesterday by the United Jewish War Effort with the opening of depots at 1038 East 163d Street, the Bronx, 2364 Broadway, and 1617 East Sixteenth Street, Brooklyn.
In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES Walter J. Ruthenburg stated his determination to regroove his own tires because the Conservation Bureau forbade tire-repair people to do the job for him.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 23 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek has telegraphed officers and men of the Chinese expeditionary forces in India, ordering them, during their temporary stationing there, "to continue to conduct yourselves in a manner worthy of our great country and the traditions of the Chinese Army."

MIDLAND ARMY FLYING SCHOOL, MIDLAND, Texas, Aug. 23 -- The "Hell from Heaven" boys of the Army Air Forces are dropping scores of bombs from the "greenhouses" every day, each "egg" marked with Hitler's name or Hirohito's.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The two-man production staff of a plant at Bay City, Mich. -- a 60-year-old employer and his 79-year-old employe -- received a large American flag poster, official recognition as a labor-management production drive committee, and a letter from Donald M. Nelson today commending their efforts.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY, Somewhere in Britain, Aug. 23 -- The largest American convoy ever to cross the Atlantic in this war has arrived at many British ports with vast quantities of war materials and crack fighting units obviously eager to "get it over with."

Crossing the vast Amazon jungle in United States made military training planes, Brazilian Air Force pilots have arrived in Rio de Janeiro on a successful mass flight of 9,000 miles from the United States with forty-four new aircraft to replace German-built Focke-Wulf trainers, it was announced here yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 23 (AP) -- George L. Paxton, 30-year-old Texan who was shot down by Japanese fighters as he served with the American Volunteer Group in Burma, said today he thought the United States could wipe out Japanese air power in China by maintaining a force of 100 fighters and fifty bombers there.

The board of directors of the War Damage Corporation, Federal agency formed to provide insurance at low cost to American property owners against the risks of damage resulting from enemy attacks, has approved the extension of the so-called "bombardment" insurance to currency, securities and other valuable papers.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 23 -- Information from Russian staff officers on the performance of American equipment is proving valuable, according to Major Gen. Russell L. Maxwell, Commander of the United States Army in the Middle East.

JUST recently Ernie Hjertberg, veteran track and field coach, went by his seventy-fifth birthday breezing. A few days later he dropped by this desk, not to accept congratulations but to bemoan the lack of progress in the promotion of his great idea, the establishing of a web of neighborhood athletic clubs all over this country. It was recalled that Ernie had stopped by to present the merits of that scheme ten years or more ago.

The plants of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation, which was taken over by the Navy temporarily last Spring for failure to produce planes, are now turning out new types of dive bombers, some of which already have been shipped abroad.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 23 (U.P.) -- A Central News Agency dispatch from the Kiangsi front said the Japanese had applied the torch to all centers they had been forced to evacuate. Hardly one building was said to be standing in Shangjao and Kwangfeng, Western Kiangsi city abandoned by the invader last week.

City Court Justice Edward L. Kelly of Brooklyn, who in the primaries on Aug. 11 won the Democratic nomination for Kings County, judge, was killed at 10 P.M. Saturday in an automobile collision on the Montauk Highway, five miles east of Amagansett.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- The Republican State convention is scheduled to adopt here tomorrow a platform headed by a three-point world affairs plank pledging all-out participation in the war effort until final and complete victory, outlawing any thought of appeasement with the enemy and dedicating the party to the establishment of a more stable world once the war is won.

By liberal use of newspaper advertising Van Camp's, Inc., was able in six months to build up sales of its new macaroni product, Tenderoni, in all of the 135 markets where it has already been introduced to a point equal to or higher than the record set by the product it replaced, Van Camp's Pork and Beans.

The people of Great Britain have the greatest admiration for the Russian resistance to the German armies and complete confidence in the ability of the Red Army to withstand the Nazi onslaught, Richard Law. Parliamentary Undersecretary of State for Foreign Affairs, said last night on his arrival at La Guardia Field on a Pan American Clipper.

LONDON, Monday, Aug. 24 -- An independent army command has been established by the British in Iran and Iraq, which means that there will be a new force directly below the Caucasus, where the Germans are pressing hard against the Soviet armies. General Sir Henry Maitland Wilson, one of this country's stanchest leaders in the field, has been appointed Commander in Chief of the new force.

AT A PACIFIC AIRFIELD, Aug. 23 -- One American Army bomber pilot who helped pave the way for occupation of the Solomon Islands now has two Japanese Zero planes and the award of the Purple Heart to his credit as the result of one flight over the Guadalcanal area.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Brazil formally notified the British Government today of her declaration of war against Germany. The British and Russian press hailed the decision. There was a note of deep sympathy for Brazil in the Portuguese press which was regarded as significant and Madrid newspapers featured the news.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Foreign Office announced tonight that Argentina's position in the light of Brazil's declaration of war against Germany and Italy would be "fixed officially" tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- General liquidation developed last week in the corn market, and prices on the Board of Trade went to the lowest marks of the season on all deliveries. Selling was especially heavy in the September contract, which at one time was about 9 cents a bushel lower than a month ago and 3 cents under December.

Comes a moment in the life of every soldier when dinner seems only a dim memory and breakfast nothing but a distant prospect. For just before "Taps" sounds -- we have this on the word of a young man whose familiarity with Army regime stems from personal experience -- unmistakable hunger pangs are wont to set in with a vengeance.

Professor Karl Boemer, former head of the Foreign Press section of the German Propaganda Ministry, who was convicted of treason last year after he had indicated Germany's intention to invade Russia, has died from wounds received in fighting around Kharkov, according to a German Transocean news broadcast recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES last night.

ABOARD THE GRIPSHOLM, AT SEA, Aug. 23 -- Every Chinese woman belongs whole-heartedly to the largest women's auxiliary corps the world has ever seen. If it had a name it would be called the Chinese Women's Auxiliary Legion for the Hatred and Destruction of Japan in China.
Babe Ruth hit one of his greatest home runs yesterday at the Stadium -- a typical Ruthian wallop in the interests of freedom and the democratic way of living.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- The British Board of Trade's index of commodity prices for July, based on 1930 as 100, was 159.8, the same as for June. It compared with 153.2 for July, last year, and 98.1 for August, 1939.
VICHY, Aug. 23 -- It has been frequently said that gold has no longer any monetary role to play and that it is destined to lose its value. It, nevertheless, is eagerly sought everywhere.
VICHY, France, July 26 -- In this vacation season of 1942 in France the great problem of the hour is travel.

War news turned distinctly for the better last week and financial markets responded. Dispatches comprised the Navy's somewhat belated announcement of an American victory in the Solomons (though still with a hint at further fighting) and a direct attack of picked troops on Dieppe, the first demonstration in occupied Europe outside of air-bombing, and rather generally taken as a test of invasion possibilities.

Enforcing its determination to withhold public assistance from persons who will not work, the Welfare Department has dropped 407 families from home relief because employable members of the families refused to accept jobs in the city's new work relief program, Commissioner William Hodson disclosed yesterday.

Nomination of Dean Alfange for Governor by the State Convention of the American Labor party failed yesterday to cause a great amount of worry among supporters of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee. The consensus among the Democratic leaders was that the Laborites might have nominated a much stronger candidate and that Mr. Bennett received a "break" when Mr. Alfange was named.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 23 -- Members of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps stationed at Fort Des Moines are keeping twenty-two volunteers busy at two USO information booths here, pending the opening of two regular USO recreational centers for the Waacs.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 23 (AP) -- Something new in international diplomacy -- a combined Office of the State Department and the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs -- opens here tomorrow to smooth the path of "Good Neighbor" visitors in war-busy North America.

We are indebted to "A Constant Reader" from a Connecticut town for information on what Grandma is doing to help win the war. She is doing just what she was doing in peacetime, only more so. She is taking care of her grandchildren when their mother has something else to do.

ALBANY, Aug. 23 -- Criminal offenses in this State, including traffic violations, declined in the half year from 630,899 in 1941 to 497,138 in the first six months of this year, Correction Commissioner Lyons reported today. The decrease in motor vehicle violations and traffic infractions was 108,365, compared with 1941.
MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information's midnight communique:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- War expenditures constituted 31 per cent of the national income in the second quarter of 1942 as against 15 per cent in the fourth quarter of last year, demonstrating the progress of the war production program since Pearl Harbor, according to a report released today in the Survey of Current Business, a monthly publication of the Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that industrial activity increased further in July and the first half of August, reflecting continued growth in output of military products.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 23 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain and Chief of Government Pierre Laval have asked Fernand de Brinon, the Vichy Government's envoy in Paris, to "transmit to the German High Command in France their congratulations on the successful repulse by German troops and the rapid clearing of French territory" in connection with the Allied raid at Dieppe on Wednesday, according to a German D.N.B. news agency statement from Paris, received here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Fine pitching by Cecil (Tex) Hughson and Joe Dobson enabled the Red Sex to sweep a double-header with the Athletics in their Army-Navy Relief Fund program today, 2 to 0 and 7 to 0.

A check for $500,000, the first installment from the profits of "This Is the Army," was presented yesterday afternoon to Major Gen. Irving J. Phillipson, in charge of Army Emergency Relief, by Irving Berlin, author, songwriter and producer of the show.

HALF HOLLOW HILLS, L.I., Aug. 23 -- A special one-day benefit horse show was held today at Hunting Hollow Farms, the Half Hollow Hills estate of O.E. McIntyre. Members of the Smithtown Hunt and Meadow Brook Hunt cooperated to make a success of the show, which, because of tire and gasoline rationing, was confined mostly to Long Island entries.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 23 -- Mrs. Eliot Betts Hoadley and her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Lydig Hoyt of The Point, Staatsburg, N.Y., who are spending the season with Mrs. Hoadley, entertained with a buffet luncheon today at The Mallows, Mrs. Hoadley's home.

All too frequently men of the armed services are prone to look at ununiformed men of their own age or younger with disapproval. There is possibly some justification for a service man in his late thirties sitting down beside a lad in his early twenties in civilian clothes and wondering why he should have been singled out and the other not.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 23 (U.P.) -- Captain F.P. Bender of Brooklyn, N.Y., and Sergeant Arnold M. Thompson of Utah have reached safety at a United Nations base after having been shot down in flames during a bombing raid on the Buna area of Papua, New Guinea, in late July, it was learned today.

SOMEWHERE IN SOUTHERN ENGLAND, Aug. 23 -- While raids like that on Dieppe last week worry the Germans and test their coastal defenses, the British are quietly training their own ordinary army in landing operations under a hail of real bullets in numerous schools throughout the British Isles, some of which have already been used by United States troops and will be turned over to the Americans in increasing numbers.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- The stock markets here have quite recovered their air of jaunty confidence. The success of the United States forces in the Solomon Islands, Prime Minister Winston Churchill's visit to Moscow and changes in the military command in the Middle East were the principal strengthening factors, while the raid on Dieppe had a tonic effect.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 23 -- I.A. Horowitz of New York, Herman Steiner of Los Angeles, Abe Yanofsky of Winnipeg and Erich Marchand of St. Louis were tied for the lead with three victories apiece after completion of the third round today in the annual open tournament of the United States Chess Federation at the Hotel Baker.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 23 -- An accidental burst of machine gun fire from an airplane landing at Mitchel Field this morning sent bullets flying to a distance of more than two miles, some of them landing on the property occupied by Frank Rochilla of 36 Elm Avenue here.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 23 -- Searchlights swept the skies over Rio de Janeiro's harbor as protection against surprise attack tonight and police-car sirens shrieked as authorities carried out an intensive round-up of spy suspects on Brazil's first day of war.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Herman Barron of Fenway had a hand in all the prizes in the third annual pro-member golf tournament staged as a war benefit by the Elmsford Country Club today.

Shortages in basic materials and in labor supply are making it increasingly hard for companies engaged in war production to maintain output at present levels, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.

Mr. Hobby -- former Governor William Pettus Hobby of Texas, publisher of The Houston Post and husband of Director Oveta Culp Hobby of the Waacs -- came to town yesterday and in an interview revealed that he is impressed, but not in the least awed, by his famous wife.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Neil White of Tamarack, who migrated to the metropolitan district a few years ago after winning the Southern amateur championship, today succeeded Tommy Goodwin of Briar Hills as winner of the annual Hummocks invitation golf tournament, formerly the Green Meadow invitation.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
MOSCOW, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

By his reckless policy of rule or ruin Hitler has brought one more nation into the war against him. The courageous action of Brazil in declaring hostilities against Germany and Italy has an important bearing on the future course of the war, not only in itself but in what it symbolizes.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 23 -- After a conference between President Alfredo Baldomir and Foreign Minister Alberto Guani that lasted almost all night, Uruguay has decided to grant to Brazil all rights of nonbelligerency.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 -- With 4,000 women employed at the Santa Monica plant of the Douglas Aircraft Company, which for two months has been hiring them at the rate of two for every man taken, company officials have decided to provide a day nursery to meet the growing problem of caring for children whose mothers and nurses are both war workers.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Aug. 23 -- Reports this evening from the Northern New Jersey fronts bearing the brunt of the worst mosquito invasion in years, Bergen, Union, Essex and parts of Morris Counties, indicated that the Amazons of the species Culex pipiens (the female does the stinging) were still engaged in force dealing out modified torture to citizens not quick with the slap or insecticide.

Brazil as an active ally greatly improves the strategical position of the United Nations. It also adds 4,600 miles of Atlantic coastline to be defended by a nation with a negligible navy. It took courage for an exposed and vulnerable country to choose war, but the Brazilians apparently face the risks gladly.

Charles F. Hubbs Co., paper merchants, have purchased the building they occupy at 383-9 Lafayette Street, the southeast corner of Fourth Street, from the estate of S. Charles Welsh. A four-story and basement structure of heavy fireproof construction, the building was erected about thirty years ago from plans prepared for the Hubbs company, which has occupied it since.

VICHY, Aug. 23 -- The Bank of France's statement for July 23 shows an increase in credits accorded the market. Bills discounted rose 1,048,000,000 francs and the bank's purchases in the open market amounted to 971,000,000. On the other hand, ordinary advances to the State declined by 1,350,000,000 francs and special advances for the costs of German occupation, by 38,000,000.
LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Maple leaves flown from Canada were strewn today on the coffins of fifty Canadians who died in the Commando raid at Dieppe, France.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Thomas E. Dewey, the all but nominated candidate of the Republican party for Governor, will accept the nomination tomorrow night at 9:15 o'clock in a speech to be made to the State convention and over the radio soon after his nomination has become a fact.

DALLAS, Aug. 23 (AP) -- W. Lee O'Daniel was assured on the basis of unofficial election returns today of the Texas Democratic nomination, tantamount to election, for a full six-year term in the United States Senate.
Speaking of bass fishing, Carl Oestreicher writes from North Belgrade, Me., to describe some of the activity at Salmon Lake.

BOSTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Braves and the Phils split a double-header today, Boston taking the first, 3 -- 1, as Al Javery racked up his eleventh victory and his fifth in a row, while Rube Melton's four-hitter in the nightcap gave the Phils a 2-0 verdict.

The President's order to heads of Governmental agencies not to quarrel in pubic is a strange document. There can be no doubt concerning the existence of the evil which it seeks to end. The President is altogether right in asserting that public criticism by Government agencies of each other's views or policies lowers the prestige of the Government and "contributes only to the confusion of the public."

America's baby carriages will continue to provide style and comfort, government restrictions not-withstanding. While parents ponder over gasoline-less autos, their heirs can be transported in vehicles that meet a recent ruling which sets a six-pound limit on steel used in baby buggies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Conclusion of negotiations between the War Shipping Administration and the American Institute of Marine Underwriters looking toward the establishment of a basis for settling hull and cargo insurance where, by reason of the disappearance of the vessel, it is impossible to determine whether the cause of loss is of marine or war-risk nature, was announced today by the WSA.
MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 24 -- Both arms of a German pincer drive have advanced closer to Stalingrad, the great industrial city on the Volga, the Soviet High Command acknowledged today.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained unchanged at 107.2. The price increases and decreases occurred almost entirely in agricultural products. The most notable individual price rises were those in eggs, raw cotton, potatoes and butter.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- New York women are among those presiding at war bonds booths at the race track, which to date have brought in a total of $16,603.90 this month. Mrs. John Henry Rogan 2d of New York has been responsible for sales totaling $7,500.

DETROIT, Aug. 23 -- The vanguard of 2,500 lawyers from Mexico, Canada and the United States is here today to register for sessions of the American Bar Association's sixty-fifth annual convention opening tomorrow.

LONDON, Monday, Aug. 24 -- Two British Wellington bombers in daylight yesterday dropped from a great height to a level of about 4,000 feet over the German port of Emden, dodged through a gap in the clouds that covered the city and loosed their big bomb loads among buildings in the dock area.

Mike Priano, aquatic ace of the Flatbush Boys Club who holds the New York State pentathlon swimming championship, successfully defended his laurels yesterday in the Flushing Meadow amphitheatre. In four of the five events Priano showed the way to four other rivals, missing only in the 100-meter breast-stroke, where he had to be content with third place.

The American Communication Association, C.I.O., accused the War Shipping Administration yesterday of using "dilatory tactics" in handling a wage dispute between the union and eight major tank-ship companies.

VICHY, Aug. 23 -- The French Government has ordered several important fiscal measures affecting companies, with the aim of facilitating their use of a new technique in manufacturing substitutes which are urgently required at the moment.

Deploring the sham of people who wish to live as they please and at the same time set up certain limits for worshiping God, the Rev. Dr. Otto H. Bostrom said in his sermon yesterday at the Lutheran Church of Gustavus Adolphus, 151 East Twenty-second Street, that "the average man wants to live in the church very little, for he knows that there he must be restricted."

Battling both the Giants and the elements before a capacity throng of 34,022 at Ebbets Field yesterday, the champion Dodgers conquered both and steamed toward St. Louis last night with a five-game winning streak and a seven-and-one-half game lead over the second-place Cardinals.

FRAMINGHAM, Mass., Aug. 23 -- Best in show in the annual fixture of the Framingham District Kennel Club today was the Welsh terrier, Champion Flornell Rare Bit of Twin Ponds, owned by Mrs. Edward Alker of Great Neck, L.I. Rare Bit was shown superbly by John Goudie.

DETROIT, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Browns met the challenge today of the Tigers for a place in the American League's first division by sweeping a double-header, 2 to 1 and 4 to 2, before 50,758 spectators, who contributed $68,172 to Army and Navy relief.

THE oriental outposts of the British Empire that collapsed so quickly before the onrushing barbarian hordes were defended by a few brave men who fought and died handicapped and hamstrung by every conceivable obstacle. They were ill-trained, ill-equipped and badly outnumbered, and from first to last the yellow "apes in uniform" controlled the air, save for one brief interval when the A.V.G. pilots made their spectacular defense of Rangoon.
I happen to live in a large apartment building which probably will not be affected even if the Mayor's most recent pronouncement relative to fuel conservation should be given a try.

Declaring that the cultivation of the spiritual sources of democracy has "priority" among the responsibilities of the church today, the Rev. Dr. Henry Smith Leiper, Foreign Secretary of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, asserted yesterday that we in America have not yet sensed the degree to which democracy is threatened from within.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Declaring that "we can't win this war unless every one cooperates in furnishing money as they are cooperating in furnishing men," Senator Taft proposed tonight a 10 per cent retail sales tax on all except food purchases.
CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- With Claude Passeau and Lon Warneke taking the pitching honors, the Cubs shut out the Reds in a double-header today by identical scores of 3 to 0.

Mayor La Guardia, who indicated a week ago that the city would take formal action in "a week or so" to enforce hot water rationing in apartment dwellings, declared yesterday that "in all likelihood if regulations are necessary they will come from Washington, and in all likelihood they will be far more severe than those we have now under study."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Edgar G. Brown, director of the National Negro Council, today wrote to President Roosevelt protesting the discrimination against Negroes in administration of price and rent control and of rationing.
The war in China can never be seen clearly at any one time. For true perspective it must be viewed over a whole period. A perspective can be taken now.

Much has been printed about shortages of raw materials affecting production, especially of aircraft and vehicles of mechanized warfare. Not long ago Donald M. Nelson urged the Automotive Council for War Production to "make more and more with less and less."
Four new films will arrive at Broadway theatres this week. The schedule follows:...
LONDON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- An Air Ministry and Ministry of Home Security joint communique:

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The posthumous award of the Distinguished Service Cross to First Lieutenant Gerald McCallum of Ruston, La., of the United States Army Air Forces "for extraordinary heroism in action at Surabaya, Java, Feb. 25," was announced today.

Senator Robert R. Reynold's statement in the Senate on Thursday calling for immediate freedom for India before the world would be convinced of the "seriousness and good faith of the United Nations" was denounced as "a dangerous and peculiarly despicable form of sabotage" by Bishop William T. Manning, in a sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
