CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Cash oats continue in active demand, especially choice heavy grain, and the failure of leading markets in the Central West to accumulate a stock is commencing to affect the market. The harvest in the Northwest is nearing completion and a fairly liberal quantity of new grain is coming forward.

WEISER, Idaho, Aug. 23 -- Residents of this Western Idaho town of approximately 3,000 persons are tired of getting up early. So, effective Sept. 1, Weiser, the county seat of Washington County, is abandoning War time and returning to Mountain standard time.

The Socialist party, through Irving Barshop, executive secretary, issued a statement yesterday declaring that the American Labor party, by nominating Dean Alfange, Tammany Democrat, had given up its "one chance to be really independent and free of old party ties."
BUFFALO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- John C. Cullen of the Coast Guard, who reported the landing of four Nazi saboteurs on Long Island last June 13, today received the Army and Navy Union Medal of Honor.

William Saroyan has decided to withdraw, temporarily at least, from the Broadway scene. Final performances of "Across the Board on Tomorrow Morning" and "Talking to You" were given Saturday evening and the sign, The Saroyan Theatre, which subordinated that of the Belasco (where the plays opened last Monday night) was turned off.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Bishop Miguel de Andrea of Buenos Aires predicted today the ultimate fruition of the "humane and Christian objectives" of President Roosevelt as he laid a wreath on the Tomb of George Washington.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23 -- A certified check for $25,000 was presented today to Curtice Clark, president of the San Francisco Press Club, and John G. Robinson, treasurer of the club's national drive to send food and supplies to the men on Bataan.

College shops across the nation are bristling with this season's crop of pullovers and plaids, and many a girlish brow is furrowed over an impressive pamphlet called "Courses of Study." Simultaneously, on the bright-lighted counters of our emporiums appear an array of Puckish cosmetics for the young in heart.

Wholesale apparel markets were busier last week, but fewer buyers were in town for other departments, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 23 (AP) -- A medium bomber from Harding Field crashed on a wooded hilltop near Bogalusa, La., today killing six Army airmen and critically injuring another.

KEARNY, N.J., Aug. 23 -- Officials of the Western Electric Employes Association, an unaffiliated union representing 22,000 workers at the Western Electric plant here, announced tonight that their organization had refused to take part in ceremonies to be held Wednesday to mark the award of the Army-Navy "E" to the plant.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 23 -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura walked out of the Longwood Cricket Club stadium in triumph today, the first South American in history to win a men's major grass court tennis tournament in this country.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Liquidation by holders of September grain contracts swelled business on the Board of Trade last week to a daily average of about 16,000,000 bushels, an increase of about 3,500,000 compared with the preceding week.
In a manner befitting their lofty position as baseball champions of the universe, the Yankees put on a gaudy and gorgeous show yesterday as their contribution to the nation's war effort.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 23 -- A jury of six men and six women will begin deliberations some time tomorrow to decide the fate of Herbert Karl Friedrich Bahr, 29-year-old former Buffalo student, charged in Federal court here with conspiracy to commit espionage in the United States in behalf of the German Gestapo.

Radio broadcasts from Berlin, Rome and Tokyo, commenting in exactly the same tenor upon Brazil's declaration of war against Germany and Italy, sought yesterday to blame the United States for this latest addition to the enemies of the Axis.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Pressing hard on the heels of retreating Japanese, the Chinese recaptured Kiangshan and Huangchinpu today, thus broadening their hold on the Hangchow-Nanchang railway to more than 140 miles, the Chinese Central News Agency reported.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 23 -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura walked out of the Longwood Cricket Club stadium in triumph today, the first South American in history to win a men's major grass court tennis tournament in this country.

The plant at 111-19 Sussex Avenue, Newark, N.J., was sold by the American Tag Company of Chicago and Belleville, N.J., to the Columbia Engineering Company, which will use the first and second floors to manufacture engineering products and machine tools.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 23 -- Charles Laughton will play the title role in the screen version of Frederick Hazlitt Brennan's Broadway comedy of last season, "The Wookey," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer announced.

The world will find victory and peace only by accepting the Cross of Christ, which "gives us hope and strength and courage," the Roy. Dr. William F. King of the staff asserted at solemn mass yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Five New York City Park Department tennis championships were decided yesterday at Central Park, with the men's singles crown going to Aloysius Doyle. He rallied to defeat Vincent Paul, 7 -- 9, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2. Both men are from Queens.
JERSEY CITY, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Tail-end Rochester struck Jersey City's International League playoff chances a powerful blow today by handing the Little Giants a double defeat, 5 -- 2 and 6 -- 4.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Aug. 23 -- In a simple and brief ceremony Norma Shearer, film actress, and Martin Arrouge, ski instructor, were married here this afternoon in the Church of the Good Shepherd.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Jim Bagby's lean right arm kept the Indians in third place today as he blanked the White Sex by 1 to 0 in ten innings after Ted Lyons had hurled the Sox to a 3-to-1 victory in the first contest of a twin bill.

Dr. Kaufman Schlivek, head of the Eye Division of Mount Sinai Hospital, has leased an apartment in 955 Fifth Avenue through Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers, who also announced renting suites in 290 Park Avenue to Mrs. F.H. Stevens.
LONDON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The British Government has called up key milliners for service, increasing the labor shortage through the textile industries.

The regaining of self-confidence and the putting of "God back into our activities of everyday living" were urged in a sermon yesterday morning by Dr. Fred P. Corson, president of Dickinson College, Carlisle, Pa., at a union service of Brooklyn Heights Protestant churches at the First Presbyterian Church, Henry Street, near Clark Street, Brooklyn.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- The Silver Star, fourth highest military decoration within the gift of the United States Government, was awarded today by Major Gen. Carl A. Spaatz, commanding the United States Army Air Forces in the European theatre, to the two officers who led the Flying Fortress raids last week over France.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Bearish factors seem to be losing their influence as a major price-making factor in the wheat market, and while there were several selling movements last week based on anti-inflation and other reports emanating from Washington, the net effect was relatively small, and losses caused by professional selling were regained quickly when shorts tried to cover.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 23 -- Secretary of Agriculture Wickard's change of opinion in favoring 100 per cent parity for ceilings on cotton instead of his previously advocated 110 per cent was the signal last week for a moderate wave of liquidation in cotton futures following gains of as much as $1.50 a bale around mid-week.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- The softball teams of Lowell Thomas, Robert L. Ripley, Gypsy Rose Lee and Danny Kaye played ball this afternoon at a United Service Organizations benefit at Arbor Island Park here, and the townfolk never before saw the like of it.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Cardinals, still on their National League treadmill after many weary weeks of trying to catch up with the Dodgers, split a double-header with the Pirates today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 -- A standard form for reporting the financial condition of any firm or company probably will be adopted in Chicago on Tuesday at a meeting of a group representing Federal, State and private agencies, it was learned today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 23 -- Chile will make known tomorrow her position with regard to Brazil's belligerency with Germany and Italy, informed circles predict, explaining that Chile's reaction probably will be explained when the text of the note replying to the Brazilian communication is published.

A sequel volume to Prime Minister Winston Churchill's "Blood, Sweat and Tears" has been acquired by Little, Brown and will be published Oct. 21. To be called "The Unrelenting Struggle," the collection of sixty-seven speeches, broadcasts and messages will cover the period from Nov. 12, 1940, to Dec. 30, 1941.

An outdoor exhibition of forty-six paintings and sketches by soldiers and sailors was opened at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon on the sidewalk outside the National Catholic Community Service Center, 17 East Fifty-first Street, opposite St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Although many of the metal items shown last year were missing, trading at the New York Gift Show, which opened in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday, compared favorably with the 1941 level. By adding novelties of ceramics and wood, manufacturers generally were able to report that they had "nearly compensated" for the loss in volume brought about by stop orders on lamps and other merchandise requiring critical materials.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Clarence Doser of Scarsdale, playing with two partners from his home club, O.A. Krebs and Everett Noetzel, shared honors in the pro-amateur best-ball tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association over the west course of the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

CAMDEM, N.J., Aug. 24 -- Mrs. E.D. Jacobs's Sting Pal, one of the typical claims made by Trainer Hirsch Jacobs, broke on top and led every step of the journey to score by four lengths in the Lakewood Purse, mile and one-sixteenth headliner, at Garden State Park today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, Aug. 25 (U.P.) -- Edward J. Holloway, Minister for Social Services and Health, revealed in a speech at an Air Raid Precautions rally today that at least 1,000 persons had been killed and "goodness knows the number maimed" by enemy air raids on the Australian mainland since the war began.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 6 per cent last week under the corresponding 1941 week, according to the report yesterday of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. In the preceding week the decrease had been 8 per cent.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 -- District leaders of the A.F. of L. and the C.I.O. said today there would be no Labor Day parade this year and that work would continue without interruption in every war plant in the Bay area.
The semi-annual report of the American Insurance Company, Newark, shows total admitted assets on June 30 last increased to $33,869,221 from $32,605,786 a year earlier.

Graybeards, figuratively speaking, had their innings in the Yankee Stadium day be-before yesterday. They sat in grandstand and bleachers and saw a batter named Babe Ruth knock a home run off the delivery of a pitcher named Walter Johnson.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 24 (AP) -- State police dragged Mariaville Lake this afternoon for the body of William J. Kuczwalski, 43 years old, of 166 North Sixth Street, Brooklyn, an assistant district attorney of Kings County.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Thomas B. Sheridan, a new Democratic City Councilman here, joined today in a fight of the City Manager League for removal of City Manager Raymond J. Whitney who took office two and a half years ago as the first executive head of a "reform" proportional representation and city manager government in this community of 142,000 persons.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Saratoga began its final week of racing today with 7,777 persons present to see High Command capture the Negofol Handicap. Many of the delegates to the Republican State convention, including Senate Majority Leader Joe R. Henley, were at the track.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Secretary Morgenthau admitted today that the $815,000,000 August war bond quota, like the $1,000,000,000 quota for July, would not be achieved. Mr. Morgenthau denied, however, that this brought the prospect of the substitution of a compulsory plan any nearer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Armed for the first time with a reasonably complete picture of demand and supply, the War Production Board has set up a new system for controlling the flow of materials into war and civilian production.

DETROIT, Aug. 24 -- Robert E. Healy, member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, today told a section meeting on public utility law at the American Bar Association's sixty-fifth annual convention that our entry into the war had made necessary continued SEC enforcement of the "death sentence" provision of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

DETROIT, Aug. 24 -- An example of union slowdown tactics that are "sabotaging" the war effort was related to President Roosevelt today in a telegram sent by Walter L. Fry, proprietor of the Fry Products, Inc., which has contracts for canvas military equipment.
LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A communique of the Air and Home Security Ministries:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The immediate effect of the President's order to officials to keep from the public hereafter all knowledge of disagreements over facts and policies that may exist among them has been to close the public's best sources of government information.

VICHY, France, Aug. 24 -- Americans bent on traveling through Spain are being warned by the diplomatic and consular authorities here that United States currency and travelers' checks in dollars are no longer being accepted in Spain, it was learned today.

A banking group composed of A.C. Allyn Co., E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc., and the Union Securities Corporation submitted yesterday the highest bid on $33,950,000 of electric power and light revenue bonds of the city of San Antonio, Texas.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Buddy Kerr's eighth-inning single, which scored Connie Ryan from second base and capped a two-run Jersey City rally, gave the Little Giants a 5-to-4 victory today in the opener of a three-game series with the Baltimore Orioles.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- George John Dasch and Ernest Peter Burger, the two Nazi saboteurs who escaped the death chair, have been turned over to the Department of Justice by the Army and probably will be used as witnesses against their alleged accomplices.

Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange and its affiliate, the Stock Clearing Corporation, announced yesterday that the "night branch" of the latter company would be abolished "on an experimental basis" after the settlement of Sept. 1.

VICHY, France, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Laval Government has protested to the United States because American bombers blasted Rouen in German-occupied Northern France on Aug. 17, two days before the Dieppe raid, it was announced tonight.
SOMEWHERE IN EUROPE, Aug. 24 -- Late reports from Rome this afternoon indicate a noticeable increase of political tension there following Brazil's declaration of war against the Axis.

For many years the watchword of our national tax-makers has been "progressive." We have relied heavily upon the income tax to provide the Federal revenues, and have levied that income tax upon a very narrow base. In 1940 fewer than 4,000,000 persons paid Federal income taxes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- After hours of wrangling over the controversial poll-tax issue, lack of a quorum prevented the Senate from taking a vote today on a House-approved bill which would permit members of the armed forces stationed in the United States to vote by mail in the Congressional elections this Fall.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 24 -- After five rounds of the open championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation, Israel A. Horowitz of New York, Herman Steiner of Los Angeles and Erich Marchand of St. Louis are leading the field with five straight victories apiece.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 24 -- A mother of two sons in the Army and two more scheduled to enter military service soon was denied citizenship here today by Judge Walter L. Hetfield 3d because she "could not conscientiously pledge" to bear arms in the defense of the nation.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 -- Professing to see a threat of a return of prohibition immediately to urban centers in the United States through enactment of pending measures in Congress, hotel keepers and wine and liquor dealers have waged a vigorous fight in California to nominate candidates pledged against what is termed a "sneak" attempt to "railroad" dry legislation through while many voters are in the armed services.

Four American flamingoes, whose normal coloration is a strong shade of red, arrived yesterday at the Bronx Zoo as a gift of the Hialeah racetrack at Miami. They arrived in time, it was disclosed, to take part in an experiment now going on in the zoo which, if successful, will give them the distinction of being the first American flamingoes there that managed to stay red after exposure to life in New York.

WPB has ordered work to cease on projects to produce 2,000,000 kilowatts of electric energy because of "the necessity for diverting critical materials and equipment to the direct war program." There are to be total stoppages of power plants under construction or delays, lower priorities or none at all for some plants and higher priorities for others which are considered essential but which cannot be named because of their military importance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Charleston, S.C., with a 56 per cent rise led all cities in department store sales in July compared with July of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Stockton, Calif., was next with an increase of 36 per cent, while Niagara Falls and Fort Smith, Ark., were next with identical increases of 34 per cent.

Terence J. McManus, who was chairman of the committee to name Senator James M. Mead as Democratic candidate for Governor, sounded a brief eulogy last night over the four-day-old grave of his campaign. He spoke at a convention in Tammany Hall to name Democratic candidates for the Supreme Court bench in the First Judicial District.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 24 -- Since April, 1940, the German occupation has cost the Bank of Norway about 4,000,000,000 Norwegian kroner, it was reliably reported today from Norway. Moreover, other Norwegian banks have been compelled to accept in exchange for ready cash nearly 800,000,000 kroner of worthless German treasury notes.

Low priced issues continued to serve as the principal avenue of trading as the stock market entered neutral territory yesterday with a slight shift to the easier side. Changes in values seldom veered from fractions and the minor flurries of selling were almost balanced by demand which spread over a widely unrelated list of specialties.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The War Labor Board divided 4 to 2 today in ordering a 7 1/2 per cent general wage increase, retroactive to Feb. 24, for the 1,200 workers at the Norma-Hoffman Bearings Corporation at Stamford, Conn. Labor members dissented, contending that employes should be given the full ten-cent-an-hour raise asked by the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America (C.I.O.).
MOSCOW, Aug. 24 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

The Spanish-American War, the Boxer Rebellion and World War I did not prevent the national tennis championship tournament from going on, although in 1917 it was called the Patriot's Championship. Neither will the current conflict, and everything concerned with the title competitions, which get under way at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, on Thursday morning, is proceeding according to schedule.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 24 -- The joint Army-Navy production award for "accomplishing more than seemed reasonable or possible a year ago" was presented to the Bullard Company this afternoon while 5,000 employes of the machine tool firm cheered representatives of the nation's fighting forces.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Aug. 24 (AP) -- Reuben B. Robertson of Hamilton, Ohio, chairman of the Industrial Relations Committee of the National Association of Manufacturers, said today that intelligent leadership by industrial managers and intelligent cooperation by labor "will furnish a continuing drive in the battle of production and make it possible for our armed forces to destroy the gangster overlords of Germany and Japan."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The cost of selling cannot be added to the maximum prices for new fabrics under maximum Price Regulation No. 163, since the ceiling formula provided in that regulation has covered this item of cost, the Office of Price Administration today informed manufacturers of woolen and worsted apparel fabrics.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Members of the Inter-American Defense Board unanimously extended to Brazil today "a vote of adherence and friendship on the occasion of her declaration of war against the Axis countries."

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24 -- The Cardinals tonight gave the Dodgers a decidedly warm reception by taking the opening battle of the so-called crucial series, 7 to 1, behind the four-hit pitching of Southpaw Max Lanier.

LONDON, Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- The largest convoy ever to arrive in Britain recently brought twenty-two blond and brunette Red Cross field workers -- the vanguard of hundreds to be brought here to help make American doughboys feel at home.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Crude rubber, latex, reclaimed rubber and scrap rubber used in civilian products were placed under specific allocations control today by the War Production Board.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (AP) -- R. J. Thomas, president of the C. I. O. United Automobile Workers, said tonight that "nothing could be more calculated to create unrest among the millions of our workers engaged in defense industry than enactment of a sales tax."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Mayor John W. Fletcher of Unalaska near Dutch Harbor, concurred today in assertions by Delegate Anthony J. Dimond of Alaska that more than 20,000 Japanese were on Kiska Island in the Aleutians.
The six-story tenement on a plot 24.9 by 105.1 feet at 244 East Second Street, between Avenues B and C, was sold by the Central Savings Bank to a client of P. Zaccaro Company, Inc., brokers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- The Census Bureau reported today that the death rate from heart diseases has more than doubled during the last forty years, although the rate of deaths among persons less than 35 years of age attributable to heart diseases fell off.

LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The commander of the Fighting French Commandos who participated in the Dieppe raid Aug. 19, estimated today that the Germans lost 4,000 men, including flying personnel, in the day's action.

IF Commander James J. (Gene) Tunney of the Navy is still hot under his uniform collar over the "spectator sports" indulged in by men in the Army, Navy, Coast Guard and Marines, this confused civilian would like to point out that, with an exception in one direction only, the service men engaged in this competition are strictly following orders and acting in line of duty.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- Uruguay's land, sea and air forces were on the alert today, following President Alfredo Baldomir's announcement of Uruguay's "complete" indentity of views with Brazil in her war against Germany and Italy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- A greater voice in policy-making decisions regarding war production was demanded for labor as well as management today by representatives of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Federal Judge Robert N. Wilkin today signed a consent decree permanently enjoining William P. Markle of Houston, Texas, a steel broker, from violating price "ceilings" set by the Office of Price Administration.

Law-abiding yardages, in the new L-85 silhouette, conserving the draped ease and dramatic sweep of pre-priority days, characterized the second nonmovie collection of Adrian, Hollywood fashion designer, shown yesterday afternoon at Bonwit Teller.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Nelson Rockefeller, as coordinator of Inter-American affairs, will leave within a few days on a trip to Brazil, Chile, Peru and Colombia, his visit to coincide with Pan-American conferences that are scheduled in Brazil and Chile.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- H.G. Aldritt of Excelsior, Minn. cracked 100 straight targets today to take the lead in the Class A division of the forty-third annual Grand American trapshoot.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The midnight communique:

Two is a plant. Likewise a company, a manufacturing company. So a story, a prose-poem, on the front page of this newspaper showed us yesterday, describing the well-earned bays of two Michiganders of Bay City on the Saginaw. Before the war Jake Sparling kept a bit of a shop where he made pulleys and repaired machinery.

Forty-one survivors of a medium-sized United States merchant ship, torpedoed and sunk in the Indian Ocean late in June, reached the African coast after seven days in an open boat, only to be confronted by naked savages armed with big knives.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Aug. 25 -- German forces have reached the gates of the Grozny oil fields after a fifty-mile sweep down the Caucasus railroad and are pounding toward Stalingrad after having crossed the Don River in force to the northwest and wedged into Soviet defenses southwest of the city.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- Secretary Ickes has voiced support of Governor Tugwell's policies by reprimanding two Puerto Rican officials for criticizing the Governor, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The National War Labor Board notified the leaders of 10,000 striking Middle Western truck drivers today that the board "will take immediate action to terminate your defiance of your government" unless the transportation stoppage is ended at once.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The War Labor Board enunciated today a new principle of war labor policy applying equal pay for equal work to women employes of the Norma Hoffman Bearings Corporation, Stamford, Conn. The decision was immediately praised by Miss Mary Anderson, head of the Women's Bureau, as a "forward step" and she said she expected it to become standard policy in WLB decisions.

Among the apartment leases reported yesterday by various brokers operating throughout the city was one signed by Drs. Otto Lowenstein and Kurt Dressel for a ten-room and four-bath duplex maisonette in 863 Park Avenue. Warren Marks Associates, brokers, arranged the lease through Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., agents.

Negotiations for a new contract affecting 10,000 truck drivers were begun yesterday by the Merchant Truckmen's Bureau and a group of other truck owners' associations and three locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The Senate Finance Committee "tentatively" voted 9 to 7 today to tax the income from future issues of State and local bonds.
You are to be congratulated upon publishing Sir Stafford Cripps's up-to-date article on the Indian situation. May I underline his comments and your own?

This is the ninth day of Germany's supreme assault on Stalingrad. Nazi forces in great strength have forced a crossing of the Don elbow below Kletskaya and Nazi tanks are battering their way across the scant forty miles of plainland that separate them from the Volga stronghold.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 24 -- Many young matrons of the Summer colony, as well as several debutantes of this and recent seasons, are aiding Mrs. Casimir de Rham in the sale of tickets for the "imaginary fete" in behalf of the William Carey Camp of the Boys' Club of New York.

LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP) --Increasing hammer blows of Allied air power are beginning to make Germany doubtful of the outcome of the war, the R.A.F. stated tonight in its third booklet recording historical phases of the war.

Holding that the suit was not barred by the statute of limitations, and that "all the essential elements of a good cause of action are present," Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin denied yesterday a motion by directors of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., to dismiss a stockholders' accounting action for recovery of unspecified corporate funds paid to Willie Bioff and George E. Browne, convicted former labor leaders, between Jan. 1, 1935, and May 23, 1941.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 24 -- Thomas E. Dewey, nominated without opposition tonight as the candidate of the Republican party for Governor, pledged his own and his party's loyalty to the nation's Commander in Chief in wartime, but reserved the right of free criticism to maintain democracy on the home front.

Following recent charges that black market operations in steel were frequent throughout the country, the first action against such price evasions in the East was taken yesterday when a temporary restraining order was served against Greenberg Bros. Iron and Steel Corporation, 114 North Fourth Street, Brooklyn, after attorneys for the Office of Price Administration had charged that the corporation sold steel sheets at prices above the ceiling schedule.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The American Flying Fortresses proved their durability again today when, escorted by United States, British, Canadian and Polish fighters, they bombed the Nazis' western communications system, striking at Le Trait, on the Seine estuary midway between Rouen and Havre, and dropping heavy explosive missiles on the shipyards there, where U-boats are built.

Declaring that the 10 per cent sales tax on jewelry, in effect for the last year, had had little effect on sales volume over that period, Henry W. von Unruh, president of the American National Retail Jewelers Association, called upon members last night to support a general sales tax as their part in helping finance the war.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Colonel Frederick L. Devereux, organizer and first leader of Westchester County's 96,000 civilian defense workers, resigned today as County Director of Civilian Protection to become an active Army colonel serving as administrative officer of a new branch of the Ordnance Corps in Detroit under Brig. Gen. Donald Armstrong.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Forty-nine additional industrial plants have been selected to receive the joint Army-Navy Production Award in recognition of outstanding performance on war work, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, and James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy, announced today.
Have you a word with a subtle military connotation that Uncle Sam doesn't know about? Then G-2 is looking for you.

The report of United Wall Paper Factories, Inc., manufacturers of wall paper and incendiary bombs, released yesterday, shows a net profit of $551,002 for the fiscal year ended with June, compared with $325,974 earned in the previous fiscal year.

Few of the calls made by the Treasury on commercial bank depositaries in recent weeks have been small. Yesterday the Treasury issued another such notification of intention to withdraw funds from its war loan accounts with these banks that is one of the largest in recent weeks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The second World War is "intimately bound up with the future of the church," and is truly a crisis for Christianity, Archbishop Edward, Mooney of Detroit said today in an address before the opening session of the Inter-American Seminar on Social Studies convened here under auspices of the National Catholic Welfare Conference.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- Adolf Hitler's appointment of Dr. Otto Georg Thierack as Reich Minister of Justice was seen here tonight as yet another move toward tightening the Nazi party grip on Germany. It was also regarded as a further bit of evidence of Herr Hitler's anxiety over the reaction of the civil population in Germany to a military defeat.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 24 -- Confiscation measures against Axis assets in Brazil were enforced today as a reprisal for losses suffered through sinkings of Brazilian ships by Axis submarines.

Every day, on the radio and in the press, we hear of the urgent need of doctors for the armed, forces. Yet I know of several physicians whose applications for commissions have been rejected on account of some minor physical defects. Two physicians about 40 years old were rejected because they are a few pounds overweight.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 24 -- Representatives of the Jersey City Law Department failed today in an attempt to prevent members of the new Hudson County Tax Board from hearing appeals on 180 assessment cases, when hearings were held on that number of applications from this city and sixty from Hoboken.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- The Boston Symphony Orchestra has been dropped from the program of the Eastman Theatre here in deference to the demands of James C. Petrillo, head of the American Federation of Musicians. This was revealed today when the Civic Music Association made public the concert series for the 1942, 1943 season.

Beginning the new week with the same hesitancy that has characterized its activity since Secretary of Agriculture Wickard proposed lower ceilings on farm products in a speech last Thursday night, the cotton market yesterday finished with net losses of 6 to 9 points.

DETROIT, Aug. 24 -- Monopolistic abuse of patents has caused war materials shortages which will cost America and her allies thousands of lives, Thurman Arnold, assistant United States attorney general, told a sectional meeting today as the annual convention of the American Bar Association opened.

JOLIET, Ill., Aug. 24 -- The laundry industry is preparing to meet a wartime shortage of men capable of holding down supervisory positions by appealing for more women students to enter the school of laundry management of the American Institute of Laundering.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- The United States tanker Louisiana has been sunk, it was announced officially here today.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 24 -- Behind the story of a Burmese head hunter tribesman who lived for weeks on the outskirts of a Japanese troop center in Eastern Burma, sold chickens regularly to the Japanese commander, and meanwhile obtained detailed military information which he passed back to the British in Assam, lies an amazing tale of guerrilla organization in that area of Burma.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 -- An order was issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission requiring the dissolution of the American Power and Light Company and the Electric Power and Light Corporation, major-sub-holding companies of the Electric Bond and Share Company, because they were found to be "wholly unnecessary."

Amusingly whimsical and completely delicious are stubby candy sticks made to taste precisely like coffee 'n' doughnuts. Somewhat over an inch in length and averaging but six calories apiece, these are packed in a circular transparent box, each small piece wrapped in a shining twist of cellophane.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Aug. 25 -- Swiss police officials and representatives of refugee welfare organizations, meeting in Zurich yesterday, found a temporary solution to the thorny question of Jewish refugees flowing toward Switzerland as a result of harsher measures taken in France.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 24 -- A record-breaking crowd of 15,000 khaki-clad figures encircled the post baseball diamond today to see the world champion Yankees defeat the Fort Dix team, 4 -- 2, in an exhibition game.

The exchange liner Gripsholm, carrying the first consignment of United States diplomats and other American nationals from internment camps in Japan and elsewhere in the Orient, will arrive in New York waters this morning and dock before noon.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 24 -- Leonard Dreyfuss, State Director of Civilian Defense, announced today the appointment of an insurance advisory committee and called a meeting of the members for Thursday at the Downtown Club in Newark, when plans for insuring members of the Citizens Defense Corps will be discussed.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Prices ranging up to the $325 bid for a letter written by Abraham Lincoln to Louisa Drew, aunt of the late John Barrymore, were paid by buyers at a Federal court auction of the actor's effects today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Conscientious objectors who are confined in camps throughout the country are to be employed in emergencies resulting from enemy action in civilian defense activities, according to an announcement today by the Office of Civilian Defense.

Dr. Joseph Alexander, former Syracuse lineman and Football Giants ex-coach, will come out of retirement to coach the City College football squad this Fall, it was learned last night. He is to take the place of Benny Friedman, who received a leave of absence to enter the Navy.

Two shipments of bananas -- the first within three to four weeks -- reached the metropolitan area yesterday via truck from the South. Seven hundred stems weighing 24,000 pounds went on sale last night at the wholesale establishment of Sal Traina, 264 Washington Street, while 20,000 pounds reached two dealers in Newark.

The stiffest possible penalties were imposed on Werner von Clemm yesterday by Federal Judge James P. Leamy, and when he had been led United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa announced that he would move to have the prisoner's citizenship annulled.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Labor was asked to arrange its observance of Labor Day in such a way that the operation of industries, plants and mines will not be interrupted if a shutdown would be injurious to the war production.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 24 -- Herbert Karl Friedrich Bahr, 29-year-old German-born, American-educated engineer, was found guilty of being a Nazi spy by a jury of housewives and business men in Federal Court here today. He took the news with a blink and a dazed shake of his head.

In the first step in a program to broaden the scope of its activities, the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation has acquired the Holtzer-Cabot Electric Company of Boston, it was announced yesterday by Arthur O. Dietz, president of C.I.T. and A.R. Welton, president of Holtzer-Cabot.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 24 (U.P) -- Six months ago Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, now commander of United States Army Air Forces in China, stood on a Northern Burma air base with a cluster of American Volunteer Group pilots when a report came in that thirty Japanese planes were approaching.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve System announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 19: Increases of $845,000,000 in holdings of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, $742,000,000 in United States Government deposits and $192,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and decreases of $106,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks and $97,000,000 in balances with domestic banks.

Decision by various dress trade associations on the proposal of Julius Hochman, general manager of the Dressmakers Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, that the contribution of manufacturers to the promotional fund of the Dress Institute be cut 50 per cent will be forthcoming within a few days, it was reported yesterday.

PARAMARIBO, Surinam, Aug. 24 (Netherlands News Agency) -- This Netherland West Indies territory, which with British Guiana was the only South American belligerent area up to last Saturday, has welcomed Brazil's entry into the war. At the same time Brazil's war declaration has focussed attention anew on Vichy-controlled French Guiana.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Four of a group of thirteen Japanese fighter planes encountered over Eastern New Guinea were shot down by Allied airmen and others were damaged a communique announced today. One Allied plane was damaged, but returned to its base.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 24 -- Following is the text of the platform adopted here tonight by the Republican State Convention:

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 24 -- A young, well-dressed man, detected by an alert worker in the act of photographing a war vessel and ways at the New York Shipbuilding Corporation last evening, was sought today by city police and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 24 -- The Standard Oil Company announced today that it would appeal a recent National Labor Relations Board order outlawing three independent employes' groups that are now the bargaining agencies for 5,000 workers at the company's refinery here, in Bayonne and Jersey City.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 24 -- A sweeping reorganization of the administration of justice and judiciary procedure in the Nazi Reich was implicit in the appointment today by Adolf Hitler of Dr. Otto Georg Thierack, formerly President of the People's Court, to the vacant post of Reich Minister of Justice.

Sidney Hillman's union, the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, which was one of the founders of the American Labor party and which has been one of the party's chief financial supporters, may withhold its support of Dean Alfange, the party's candidate for the Governorship, it was indicated yesterday.

HACKENSACK, N.J, Aug. 24 -- The Bergen Evening Record, Bergen County (N.J.) daily newspaper, apologized today to Its readers for inflicting upon them so much material about a county political fight when every one should be helping to win the war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- The amount of electric energy produced for public use in the United States last month broke all records by totaling 15,762,924,000 kilowatt-hours. This, the Federal Power Commission reports, was an increase of 11.9 per cent over production in July, 1941.

VICHY, Aug. 24 -- The message from Rouen, published in a communique here tonight, was in the name of an organization in the occupied zone signing itself "The Friends of the Marshal" and was addressed directly to Chief of State Petain. It purported to relate the emotion of the Normandy population on learning of the American bombing raid of Aug. 17.

DETROIT, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Private John Pinchera testified at the coroner's inquest today into the death of John Duval Dodge on Aug. 13 that a patrolman dropped Dodge to the floor of the station on the night of his arrest and that Mr. Dodge's head struck the floor violently.

LONDON, Aug. 24 -- Declaring that he had been "refreshed" rather than tired by his long journey, which took him to Moscow and Cairo, Prime Minister Churchill returned tonight to London and to Ten Downing Street.

Foreign freight forwarders here expressed amazement yesterday over the announcement that the Maritime Commission had instituted an investigation into the industry's practices and operations. Inasmuch as the investigation is being confined to the New York operators and is reportedly based on a rate case several years old, it was generally asserted that the motive of the probe is undoubtedly "political."

MOSCOW, Aug. 24 -- The foreign-news pages of all Soviet newspapers recently have devoted considerable space to messages from New York correspondents describing a strong popular demand for the immediate opening of a second front.

Attorney General Francis Biddle announced yesterday in Washington that a Federal grand jury in Newark had indicted nine corporations supplying all of a special patented electric cable designed to resist flame, shock and water, and used in the complex wiring systems of the fighting ships of the Navy.

SEATTLE, Aug. 24 (U.P.) -- Senator Wallgren of Washington, before leaving for San Francisco today, said that Charles Clark, assistant counsel to the Truman commitee, was badly shaken up in the landing, crack-up of an Army bomber during a Senate Military Affairs Committee's tour of Alaskan Army and Navy establishments.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 24 (AP) -- Top aircraft industry executives met with Henry J. Kaiser today to Study his proposals for design and construction of giant cargo-carrying airplanes, but except for an aircraft pledge of cooperation with Mr. Kaiser and the government, results of the discussions were a war secret.

Fay Wray, motion picture actress, and Robert Riskin, scenarist and former writing partner of Frank Capra, were married in New York on Sunday afternoon, it became known yesterday. The ceremony was performed by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora in the St. Regis Hotel suite of Colonel William J. Donovan.

LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Increased air activity over the Egyptian desert and continued Axis efforts to get convoys across the Mediterranean led tonight to renewed speculation over the possibility of another offensive by General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel.

A United States of the World was proposed by the Rev. Daniel A. Lord at the opening session of the Summer School of Catholic Action yesterday morning on the Fordham campus to bring about a world-wide view of seeing "with God's eyes."

Japanese piracy (book publishing variety) will pay dividends to an Atlanta blood-donating center. The story goes back to 1937 when an enterprising Japanese publisher brought out an unauthorized edition of "Gone With the Wind." Unashamed, the publisher sent Margaret Mitchell a doll requesting that she be photographed with it for his advertising purposes.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Aug. 24 -- The continuation of Anglo-American air raids over Western Europe and the growing strength of American air power in the Middle and Far East may be said today to be the most encouraging advantages of the United Nations in the current months of crisis.

CHUNGKING, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The recapture of Linchwan, second biggest Japanese base in Kiangsi Province, was announced tonight by the Chinese High Command, while other Chinese forces smashed to within thirty miles of Nanchang, the invaders' main Kiangsi stronghold.

Having threatened the Democrats that it would put its own candidate in the field if they did not name a candidate to its liking, the American Labor party, finding its bluff called, decided that it had to go through with its threat. Having done very well as a parasite on other parties, the Labor party is now obliged to show what it can do on its own.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- An appeal to householders over the country to make thorough searches periodically in their homes for scrap needed in war industry was made tonight by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin yesterday and recorded here by The Associated Press:

SUFFERN, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- In an effort to do his "patriotic" bit to keep the Republican party in existence, Charles B. McPhillips, veteran Rockland County Democratic leader, announced today his resignation as Ramapo Democratic town chairman. He resigned also as Democratic committeeman from a district he represented thirty years.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Friends of Thomas E. Dewey substituted a sound motion picture of their candidate for the traditional nominating speech at the Republican State convention tonight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Arthur S. Barrows, one-time Indiana hardware retailer, was elected president of Sears, Roebuck Co. today. Directors announced also that net profit of the Chicago mail-order organization for the twenty-four weeks ended July 16 was slightly higher than that of the corresponding period of last year1 despite a 2.4 per cent decrease in sales.

Although national organizations are not likely to shoot from sprouts to striplings as quickly these days as they did a few years ago, it may be that the seed from a new group in Georgia may grow into a sturdy association.

Add to the week's opening "The Talk of the Town," which will arrive Thursday at the Radio City Music Hall. Cary Grant, Jean Arthur and Ronald Colman have the principal roles in this comedy-drama, which was directed and produced by George Stevens for Columbia Pictures.

Although national organizations are not likely to shoot from sprouts to striplings as quickly these days as they did a few years ago, it may be that the seed from a new group in Georgia may grow into a sturdy association.

Add to the week's opening "The Talk of the Town," which will arrive Thursday at the Radio City Music Hall. Cary Grant, Jean Arthur and Ronald Colman have the principal roles in this comedy-drama, which was directed and produced by George Stevens for Columbia Pictures.
The major baseball leagues have gone over the top in their contributions to war relief.

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 24 -- The government is paying wheat growers 4s a bushel at country sidings on the first 3,000 bushels of the next crop and 2s against the balance, which will be pooled. Minister of Commerce W.J. Scully said that on the new basis payment would insure a good living for at least 80 per cent of Australia's 68,000 growers, the vast majority of whom grew within the 3,000-bushel quota.

With Sam Jaffe almost certain to accept the leading role in "Franklin Street," due here Oct. 13, the go-ahead signal will be given on Thursday when rehearsals begin under George S. Kaufman's command. The sudden predicament of finding a suitable actor for this central role after Groucho Marx, for whom it was originally written, and Ed Wynn had excused themselves was something all concerned with the play had not anticipated.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Bears, thanks to the long-distance clouting of Joe Johnson, ended the winning streak of the Chiefs tonight as they pounded out a 5-to-2 decision in a game halted for an hour by the weather.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 24 -- A last-minute plea of John P. Lynch, 39 years old, former Stratford, N.J., Justice of the Peace, to escape sentence to the electric chair for the murder of George C. Miller, Clementon policeman, failed today. Judge Robert L. Warke sentenced him to die during the week of Oct. 4.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The Navy reported today the names of eleven men killed yesterday when a PBY flying boat crashed near Dahlgren, Va.

LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- The execution of thirty-five more Czechs Croats and Slovenes by the Germans and Italians was reported today. Axis threats that ten hostages would be killed for each anti-Axis assault in occupied Croatia also were reported.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24 -- Following is the text of tonight's speech by Thomas E. Dewey before the Republican State Convention accepting the Republican nomination for Governor:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Lord Halifax, British Ambassador just back from a seven-week trip to England, conferred with Secretary Cordell Hull for more than an hour today on what Mr. Hull described as "important matters."

Through its executive committee, which had gone on record in favor of nominating Senator James M. Mead for Governor on the eve of the Democratic State Convention, Tammany Hall pledged last night its "loyal, united and active support" to Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., who emerged as the nominee of the convention.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 24 -- The Argentine Government, by decree, extended to Brazil today the same rights of non-belligerency that were granted to the United States immediately after Pearl Harbor, and communicated that measure to the Brazilian Ambassador in a cordial note in which the Argentine Government expressed its "fraternal solidarity."

A funeral service was held yesterday for Mrs. Alice Duer Miller, noted American author, at her residence, 450 East Fifty-second Street, where she died Saturday after an illness of eight months, at the age of 68.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- Lord Halifax, British Ambassador just back from a seven-week trip to England, conferred with Secretary Cordell Hull for more than an hour today on what Mr. Hull described as "important matters."

ROSLYN, L.I., Aug. 24 -- Scoring a sparkling 30, four strokes under pair, on the back nine, Pat McGee of North Hills and Jack Mallon of the Garden City Country Club took first place in the weekly amateur-pro tourney of the Long Island P.G.A. with a 67 at the Engineers Golf Course today.
LONDON, Aug. 24 -- The stock markets gained a mild stimulus today from the entry of Brazil into the war on the side of the United Nations but this was offset by less favorable news from Russia.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Eighteen-year-old Lois Andrew obtained a divorce from George Jessel today, after testifying that the 44-year-old comedian was "too old for me and I am too young for him."
MOSCOW, Aug. 24 -- General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock's

Mead for Governor on the eve of the Democratic State Convention, Tammany Hall pledged last night its "loyal, united and active support" to Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., who emerged as the nominee of the convention.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 24 -- The Argentine Government, by decree, extended to Brazil today the same rights of non-belligerency that were granted to the United States immediately after Pearl Harbor, and communicated that measure to the Brazilian Ambassador in a cordial note in which the Argentine Government expressed its "fraternal solidarity."

A funeral service was held yesterday for Mrs. Alice Duer Miller, noted American author, at her residence, 450 East Fifty-second Street, where she died Saturday after an illness of eight months, at the age of 68.
LONDON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 26 -- The Duke of Kent, youngest brother of King George VI, was killed yesterday in the service of his country. He was 39 years of age.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- "Raider" battalions of United States Marines, made up of specially chosen, trained and equipped men, participated in the Aug. 17 attack on the Japanese-held Pacific island of Makin, in the Gilberts, and are participating in the offensive in the Solomon Islands, the Marine Corps disclosed today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 -- R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile, Aircraft and Agricultuarl Implement Workers of America, C.I.O., charged today that thousands of war workers in Detroit were being laid off several days each week because of an artificial steel shortage.

The General Aniline and Film Corporation announced yesterday in its statement of operation covering the six months ended on June 30, net income of $1,292,247 after all charges, including $3,626,616 provision for Federal taxes on income, computed at rates provided in the House Bill.

It is well that THE NEW YORK TIMES has brought the attention of its readers to the plight of the recently dismissed Townsend Harris High School teachers. Even without disputing further the merits of the Mayor's abolition of the school, one is puzzled to find justification for the failure to make proper use of its fine staff.

The White Sox have not beaten the Yankees at the Stadium all season, but they had yesterday's game all wrapped away until the string broke. That almost unheard of major league occurrence, two dropped outfield flies in one inning, enabled the New Yorkers to tie the score at 3-all in the seventh before Joe Gordon's two-run homer in the eighth settled things, 5 to 3.

Federal and State requirements concerning conservation of gasoline and rubber will be discussed today, tomorrow and Friday by bus operators, representatives of trucking companies and merchants who use trucks in New York City and nine near-by counties of the State.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 25 -- Valerie Hobson, British film actress, has been signed to a term contract by David O. Selznick and will come to the United States in January to make her first picture for him, the United Artists producer announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- A formal demand for "direct and effective representation" of organized labor on the War Production Board was made today upon Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman, by twenty representatives of major labor unions.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Rip Sewell allowed the Braves only three hits, all by Tommy Holmes, as the Pirates romped tonight to a 6-to-0 triumph. Jimmy Wasdell opened the scoring with a first-inning homer and a three-run fifth frame clinched the contest.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- President Roosevelt today evaded two questions concerning his possible support of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for Governor of New York on the Democratic ticket.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:
MOSCOW, Aug. 25 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Broomhall, British grain authority, issued today the following summary of foreign crop conditions:
LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Except that it is now quite fashionable to be a little shabby, the war so far has not brought many changes in the way the women of Britain dress in the daytime.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Trade associations gained a point with the Office of Price Administration today when that agency ruled that they may act for manufacturers or wholesalers in fulfilling the retail "notification requirements" of four OPA apparel regulations. The regulations are: No. 153 covering women's girls' and children's outerwear garments: No. 177 on men's and boys' tailored clothing: No. 178 on women's fur garments and No. 208 on staple work clothing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- General George C. Marshall, United States Army Chief of Staff, declared at a luncheon meeting of the joint Brazil-United States Defense Commission today that "our triumph is as inevitable as the sunrise."

Effective next Tuesday there will be twenty-eight stock issues traded in ten-share units on the main floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Emil Schram, president, made the announcement yesterday, listing sixteen issues now on the floor that have 100-share trading units and twelve issues now at Post 30, the inactive post, in ten-share units.

In the first step of an unprecedented campaign to end the enormous losses in man power caused by industrial and other accidents, the trustees of the National Safety Council, meeting at 71 Broadway, voted yesterday an initial appropriation of $250,000 to begin the work.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Light coastal forces fought four German flak [anti-aircraft] ships off Flushing, the Netherlands, last night and a torpedo from a flotilla leader hit a German ship which is believed to have sunk.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 25 -- Details of grandiose preparations for a "European Conference," scheduled to be held in Berlin about three weeks hence, for the purpose of "fixing the map of the new Europe" reached foreign circles here today where they are causing considerable "consternation."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- First-aid to survivors of torpedoed ships hereafter will come to them literally from the skies through the Navy Department and the American Red Cross.

The colony of Germans, Japanese and Italians on Ellis Island received another member yesterday when Alfons Hambacher, an ardent Nazi, was deprived of his acquired United States citizenship. The nullification of his certificate was accomplished at his own consent in Federal court, and immediately afterward the 42-year-old mechanic was surrendered to FBI agents for internment.

The moon shone down with a rare and exciting loveliness last night as the celestial paths of the sun, the earth and its satellite crossed in the star-laden heavens in a way to create a total eclipse of the moon, the first visible here since July 15, 1935.

The Labor party calls on the Federal authorities to protect the New Deal pro-labor legislation now on the statute books from the attacks by the National Association of Manufacturers and the anti-union bloc of Congressmen, such as Howard Smith and Clare Hoffman, under the guise of furthering the war effort.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- No more locally arranged air raid alarms will be sounded in Westchester County, the County Office of Civilian Protection announced today. All blackouts, alerts and civilian mobilizations in the future will be ordered by the State Office of Civilian Protection, and some involving new elements of surprise will be called after Sept. 1, the local office said.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25 -- The great American deserts have become training grounds for war. In the Mojave and Colorado deserts, glider pilots and tank troops were training this morning in the tactics of victory. Glider pilots use hot desert winds to soar on mighty thermals far above California peaks.

The diplomatic exchange liner Gripsholm, painted in the bright blue and yellow of neutral Sweden, arrived here yesterday carrying nearly 1,500 evacuees from Japanese-dominated lands of the Orient, the first exchange party to reach this country since Pearl Harbor.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 25 -- Thomas E. Dewey, in his first press interview here today as the 1942 Republican nominee for Governor, flatly rejected any compromise with Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. in the latter's campaign for re-election in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The War Labor Board today unanimously approved a 5 1/2 cent hourly wage increase for the 250,000 employes of United States Steel Corporation but split, 8 to 4, in favor of making the rise retroactive to Feb. 15 over the objection of the steel company.

Despite the additional 10 per cent reduction in coffee deliveries effective Sept. 1 the civilian population, even though suffering a total cut of 35 per cent in supplies, still has available enough coffee to provide eight cups a person weekly, Roberto Aguilar, managing director, Pan American Coffee Bureau, declared yesterday.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- The Republican State Convention, before it adjourned early this afternoon, gave to Thomas E. Dewey, its candidate for Governor, these running mates:

This is to remind the voters in the November elections that the men to be chosen will be our hired men. As such, we have not only the right but the sternest obligation to demand records of past performance as guarantee for future action.

SPOKANE, Aug. 25 -- The marriage-by-cable of Miss Eleanor Lucille Granlund in Spokane and Benjamin Vaughn of Libby, Mont., a soldier with the United States Army in Australia, was recorded today by County Clerk Frank C. Nash.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- Coming on powerfully in the stretch, the Brookmeade Stable's Pomayya made short work of her opposition in the fourth running today of the Diana Handicap, a mile and a furlong test restrected to fillies and mares.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -The seriousness of the fuel oil shortage in the Eastern States was re-emphasized today to New England officials and members of Congress as they conferred with Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chairman; Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, and officials of the War Petroleum Coordinator's office.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Warships and planes of the United States Navy, supported by Army bombers, were fighting today in a large-scale battle with a powerful Japanese fleet sent to strike a counter-blow at the bases in the Solomon Islands recently captured by American Marines.

Percy H. Johnston, chairman of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, will celebrate tomorrow his twenty-fifth anniversary with that institution. Mr. Johnston came to New York as a vice president and director of the Chemical Bank on Aug. 27, 1917, and became its president in 1920 at the age of 39.

Mrs. Maria Pennino, 64 years old, and her daughter, Lillian, 28, of 232 East Sixty-seventh Street, were injured a little before 9 o'clock last night when they were crushed against the guard wall of Central Park, at Fifth Avenue and Seventieth Street, as a horse drawing a hansom cab shied at a bus and bolted.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Navy announced today that a Navy plane with fourteen officers and enlisted men aboard was missing on a flight from Alaska to Seattle.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Archbishop Robert E. Lucey, Catholic prelate of San Antonio, Texas, said in an address today that part of the Catholic press of the United States had led Catholic opinion astray on certain questions of international ethics "by advocating an out-and-out isolationism."

A proposal that all retailers join in a fight to bring about the repeal of the Silver Purchase Act, thereby putting domestic silver on the open market, was made yesterday by William J. Cheyney, executive director of the recently organized Retail Credit Institute of America, at the annual convention of the American National Retail Jewelers Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Aug. 26 (AP)-- The Soviet Information Bureau's communique early today:

Campaign badges and buttons, dear to the hearts of political workers and small boys, cannot be made of shiny celluloid over a tin shell with a spring steel pin for the coming campaign, in the opinion of local manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- All supplemental gasoline rations will be re-examined by local rationing boards and deliberate violations of the rationing regulations which may be discovered will be the subject of prosecution, Paul M. O'Leary, deputy OPA administrator in charge of rationing, said today.
The first of 400 potential officer candidates for the Waves from the Third Naval District were interviewed yesterday at 33 Pine Street. From that number 195 candidates will be selected.

After more than twelve hours of questioning by the police of the Bronx and Queens, Sergeant Custode W. Caroppoli, a soldier assigned to Fort Totten, Bayside, Queens, was released at 6:15 P.M. yesterday and turned over to the military authorities after being exonerated of any criminal action in the death early yesterday of Mrs. Lottie Sabat, 30 years old, a domestic in the Bayside home of Eddie Dowling, theatrical producer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Miss Ruth Mitchell, sister of the late Brig. Gen. William (Billy) Mitchell, presented to President Roosevelt today a basket woven from the wrappings on Red Cross food packages as a gift from 360 British women in a German prison camp at Liebenau, Germany.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill, though home for only a few hours after his historic 15,000-mile flight, was up early today for a discussion with members of the War Cabinet on how to carry through the plans resulting from his visit to Moscow.

In an effort to force compliance by dress manufacturers in the use of "New York Creation" labels, Julius Hochman, general manager of the dress joint board, International Ladies Garment Workers Union, yesterday ordered a stoppage in any shop in which labels are not supplied for garments, beginning Sept. 1.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 25 -- Nine companies and sixty-one individuals in the glass container industry were found guilty today by Judge Frank L. Kloeb in Federal District Court of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 25 -- Ten years in a Federal prison was the sentence imposed this afternoon on the Rev. Kurt Molzahn, the 47-year-old pastor of Old Zion Lutheran Church, Philadelphia, who last Friday was found guilty of conspiracy to violate the peace-time Espionage Act.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 25 -- Former Italian Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza will leave tomorrow by air for Washington to take up active direction of the Free Italy movement which was formally founded at the recent congress held in Montevideo, Uruguay, by representatives of all the anti-Fascist Italians on this continent.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Aug. 26 -- A Japanese convoy was attacked yesterday by United Nations planes north of the southeastern tip of New Guinea, it was announced today by General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters. That general area has been the scene of increased activity lately, there having been a couple of combats there between United Nations and Japanese aircraft.

BURBANK, Calif., Aug. 25 (AP) -- From the windows of the sky grill at the Lockheed and Vega Aircraft Companies, Lockheed Field revealed today dozens of almost completed P-38 combat planes being wheeled over to a storage shed.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The National Electric Products Corporation, one of nine companies indicted on charges of conspiring to defraud the government in sales of insulated cable to the Navy, said today that the prices at which it sold the cable were in competition with other manufacturers, and the charge that it has made excessive profits is without foundation.

Peter Kessler, 44-year-old superintendent, of 550 West 168th Street, was shot and killed yesterday in his apartment by a patrolman after he had attacked his wife and stepdaughter, threatened to throw his 7-month-old baby into the furnace and finally charged at the patrolman, brandishing a butcher knife in each hand.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Five men and three women were tied today for the North American clay target championships at the forty-third Grand American Trap-shoot.

Today's only new film arrival is the Abbott and Costello comedy "Pardon My Sarong," which opens at Loew's Criterion. Appearing in support of the comedians are Virginia Bruce, Robert Paige, Leif Erikson and Lionel Atwill.

A group of scholars of worldwide reputation in science, philosophy and religion, together with authorities on the arts and literature and human affairs, will resume tomorrow at Columbia University an attempt launched in 1940 to clarify the basic cultural claims of democracy.

Net income of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended June 30 amounted to $1,345,703 after provision of $800,000 for contingences, $948,787 for Federal income taxes, and other charges. The income is equivalent, after preferred dividend requirements, to 14 cents a share on 486,122 shares of common stock.

This is to present Penelope the Pig, newly arrived in Manhattan to adorn the dressing tables of the young and whimsical. Penelope is pink, with rosy clover blossoms painted on her sides, and under her round back -- which comes off like a lid -- are three round bottles of preparations for milady's fingertips.

Mitzi Green, musical comedy and film actress, and Joseph Pevney, actor, were married here yesterday afternoon by Supreme Court Justice Morris Eder. After the ceremony, held in the jurist's chambers, the couple was cautioned by the justice not to "spoil" his record of thirty-five marriage "successes" in his twenty-three years on the bench.

Ornamentation, that "prodigal daughter" of a priority-conscious fashion world, really came into its own yesterday at a millinery showing of Saks Fifth Avenue. Previously welcomed as a subtle silhouette softener for fabric-hungry coats and gowns, it emerged on Autumn chapeaux in its natural role -- that of decorator, pure and simple.

Acting on the assurance of Deputy Mayor Rufus E. McGahen that the City Council would soon enact satisfactory amendments to the McCarthy Salary Increment Law, the Board of Estimate yesterday postponed until Sept. 2 its action on a resolution calling for the dismissal of 197 city employes in various departments.

Registrations of out-of-town buyers in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 706, which compared with 665 in the preceding week and 899 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 351 as against 281 for last Tuesday.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 25 -- Mrs. Robert A. Magowan, Mrs. John Hamilton Baker and Miss Charlotte McDonnell head a large committee of young society women arranging a supper dance to be held on Sept. 5 in the colonial ballroom of the Meadow Club for the benefit of local service organizations.

Mayor La Guardia still finds verbal communication with the newspaper reporters incompatible with the faithful performance of his duties. In response to questions after his hot-water broadcast last Sunday the Mayor said, "I'm sorry. Any time I get accurate reporting I will be very happy to make a statement."

Now that the Treasury has made known that its 2 per cent notes due on Sept. 15 and the RFC seven-eighths of 1 per cent notes, due on Oct. 15 are to be paid off at maturity, thus eliminating subscription "rights" of the holders for new issues, the already small premiums quoted on these issues in the open market declined further yesterday.

Whether or not Mr. Churchill brought encouraging news to Moscow, the remarkable fact is that he came back from seeing the Russians in the hour of their gravest reverses not only "refreshed," as he said, but definitely encouraged. The tenor of the London comment following his return confirms previous reports to Washington on the results of his spectacular jaunt to the crucial battlefields of Russia and the Middle East.

The cost of food took another spurt from the middle of June to the middle of July, attaining a level 17 per cent higher than that of a year ago. The advance, averaging 1.1 per cent, was fractionally less than that during the previous period (mid-May to mid-June) when a rise of 1.3 per cent was recorded.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Aug. 26 day, Aug. 26 (U.P.) -- United Nations airmen dropped eight tons of bombs yesterday on Japanese bases at Rabaul and Gasmata, on New Britain Island, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- President Roosevelt announced today that Federal action will be taken soon to stabilize wages and farm prices at their present levels.
New York City held its second surprise blackout and air raid drill in a month last night in a dramatic setting in which a full moon participated in eclipse.

Another widely known film actress to make the transition from Hollywood to Broadway is Wendy Barrie, who has been engaged for "The Morning Star," due at the Morosco on Sept. 14. Although this will mark her New York stage debut, Miss Barrie recently acted in a Summer theatre and before coming to this country appeared in the London production of "Wonder Bar."

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 25 (U.P.) -- It may now be revealed that Prime Minister Winston Churchill announced here on his way home from Moscow that "we are determined to fight for Egypt and the Nile Valley as if it were the soil of England."

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Earl Warren, Republican State Attorney General, who charged Governor Olson, a Democrat, with playing politics with the State's wartime safety, ran Mr. Olson a close race for the Democratic nomination in early primary returns tonight.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 25 -- Two sloops were tied for first place tonight at 15 points each, and two others had but one point less after two races had been sailed out on Long Island Sound in the class championship of the Atlantic craft.

Eagerly awaited, the Gripsholm is at last in port, about a month out from Lourenco Marques by way of Rio de Janeiro. Hers is a strange business, a ship of exchange between enemies, but she has also carried Red Cross supplies for American prisoners. Like the Drottningholm she is one of the few floating islands of safety in all the oceans.

The pay-as-you-go tax plan of Beardsley Ruml is gaining new supporters every day. This is the plan which calls for turning the tax clock ahead so as to provide that payments made this year on last year's income be regarded as taxes on the current year's income.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- President Roosevelt announced today that Prime Minister Peter Fraser of New Zealand would arrive here tomorrow for a series of war discussions. He revealed that he had invited Prime Ministers John Curtin of Australia and Jan Smuts of South Africa to come to the United States later in the year for similar discussions.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 25 -- The moon went into eclipse over Crosley Field tonight and took the Giants and Carl Owen Hubbell with it. While the astronomical show was going on overhead, Johnny Vander Meer was pitching the Reds to a 3-1 triumph that cut the Giants' third-place margin over Cincinnati to four games, snapped Hubbell's victory string after eight in a row and extended the New York losing streak to five.

The Fine Arts Federation of New York, which has opposed Park Commissioner Robert Moses's plan to demolish the Aquarium and reconstruct Battery Park, disclosed yesterday the prize winning designs in its competition for an "improved plan" for the rearrangement of this historic area of the city, with the restoration of the Aquarium to its original form as Fort Clinton.

Irrespective of all its many and complex subsidiary causes, the "War of Greater East Asia," as Japanese propaganda calls it, is first and foremost the direct result of a now successful effort by a military clique, known as the "Manchuria Gang," to seize power in Japan, oust the "capitalistic-democratic" government of politicians and Big Business, and erect a rule by modern Samurai analogous to that overthrown in the Meiji restoration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- On the eve of the twenty-second anniversary of the women's suffrage amendment, to be celebrated tomorrow for the first time in a world at war, Miss Marguerite M. Wells, president of the League of Women Voters, issued today a statement carrying a "text" for members of the league and calling on all voters to choose candidates for public office "in time."

Two Bronx boys playing a game in which a small express wagon was "towing" a bicycle down a slight incline on Laconia Avenue between 211th Street and Gun Hill Road, the Bronx, were killed yesterday when the express wagon went out of control and ran under a fuel oil truck, pulling the bicycle and the boy on it into the side of the vehicle.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Announcement by the Department of Agriculture late yesterday that returns indicated that an upward revision of 15,000,000 bushels had been necessary in the estimated yield of Spring wheat in four leading Northwestern States fell flat as a market influence on the Board of Trade today.

At midnight Aug. 31 Townsend Harris High School, the distinguished century-old preparatory department of the City College, will close until the dawn of a better day. Your paper has rendered worthy service in this major educational tragedy.

Outright divestment of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company from the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation system was recommended yesterday by the Public Utilities Division of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

American exporters of pharmaceutical supplies may find the Mexican market shut off in effect as a result of the recent decree by the Mexican Department of Health placing "arbitrary" price ceilings on those products, Walter Bomer, vice president of Bristol-Myers Company, declared yesterday.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Unless the wage stabilization program is enforced, the country faces a rapidly accelerating spiral of wage increases, Raymond S. Smethurst, counsel for the National Association of Manufacturers, told members of the conference on industrial relations of the organization today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The City Bank Farmers Trust Company, New York, asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to modify the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad reorganization plan so as to eliminate the proposed sale of $2,250,000 of new securities and instead allocate that amount in common stock to holders of general mortgage bonds.
