The Rheem Manufacturing Company, describing itself as the largest single manufacturer of steel drums, barrels and other industrial containers, registered 85,326 shares of $1 par common stock with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday. Blyth Co., Inc., were named to underwrite the sale of the stock, which would increase the amount outstanding to 400,000 shares.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Aug. 26 (AP) -A communique:

A definite upturn in export advertising by American manufacturers is expected now that the Treasury Department has approved the use of export advertising within proper bounds and permitted deductions of such expenditures for Federal income tax purposes.

Vic Dellicurti, Harlem middle-weight, and Georgie Kochan of the Coast Guard fought to a draw in the feature bout at eight rounds at the Queensboro Arena last night before a gathering of 4,000, The weights were 155 for Dellicurti and 159 for Kochan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- A small increase in the price of sugar was permitted today by the Office of Price Administration for an estimated six out of every 100 retailers in ten North Atlantic Seaboard States who have been selling sugar at less than 6 1/2 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Tax concessions to war bond buyers, representing the first move toward modification of Secretary Morgenthau's sales of war bonds on a solely voluntary basis, were included by the Treasury today in a program for the relief of debt-loaded individuals and corporations submitted to the Senate Finance Committee.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Aug. 26 -- The Russian High Command said today that the Red Army had made seven counter-attacks at one point northwest of Stalingrad, but it mentioned that industrial city for the first time in a communique, indicating that the 1,000,000 Germans who were smashing at the defense walls had made some progress.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25 -- The Dodgers lost everything tonight, including Manager Leo Durocher, Acting Manager Chuck Dresden, a lot of sleep and their second straight game to the Cardinals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The fast-stepping Browns beat the Senators in both ends of a twin bill tonight, taking the opener by 8 to 1 and the eleven-inning nightcap by 3 to 2. The first-game victory gave the Browns third place in the American League. St. Louis displaced the Indians, who lost two games to the Red Sox.

In the changing of fashion it is interesting to observe how the suspender is replacing the belt in male attire. That the suspender, and not the belt, was used in Elizabethan England is shown from the lines in Henry IV (the scene is after the hold-up in which Prince Hal and Falstaff participated): "Their points being broken, down fell their hose."
ROOTERS for big league baseball are feeling pretty good at the moment. Their favorite game made a big hit last Sunday. It was a triple in a pinch. It cleared the bases and won the game.

Fourteen hundred pairs of precious silk stockings were tossed aside yesterday with no lingering backward glances by the members of the Chain Service Restaurant Employes Union, all waitresses in Childs restaurants.

None of the offshore fleets operating from Long Island's south shore has reported any sizable catches of tuna. While they manage to take a few on their daily trips, they have not yet hit into anything resembling good fishing.

To meet the need of the wartime demand for quick transmission the Western Union Telegraph Company has developed a device which prepares an arriving telegram for automatic transmission to thirty-six cities simultaneously, the company announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Sterling J. Potter of Santa Monica, Calif., and Harry Nye of Chicago today duplicated their one-two finish of yesterday in the second race of the nineteenth annual International Star Class sailboat series.

A program of thirty feature pictures definitely scheduled by Twentieth Century-Fox for release in the 1942-43 season was announced yesterday by Thomas J. Connors, vice president in charge of sales. Mr. Connors said the company planned to increase its output to a total of between forty-eight and fifty-two features, provided the projected film conservation program does not cut too deeply into the studio's supply of film.

WITH UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCE IN CHINA, Aug. 19 (U.P.) (Delayed by censor) -- The first group of Chinese aviation cadets trained at the United States Army Pursuit School arrived today at this base on their way to Chinese bases, where they will resume training in American pursuit planes to prepare for action.

Promptly, and apparently in great strength, Japan has launched her expected counter-attack on our newly conquered base at Tulagi in the Solomons. For three days a large-scale air and naval battle has been in progress over the waters around Guadalcanal Island, occupied by our Marines.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Trading in the hog market was less active today, with small killers particularly showing a reluctance to buy at present levels. Prices, however, closed steady on all weights and sows.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 25 (AP) -- After Hank Sauer's two-run homer in the ninth had tied the score at 4-all, the Syracuse Chiefs nudged over a tenth-inning run which gave them a 5-to-4 victory, over the Newark Bears before 5,657 fans tonight.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- More than 100 boys who started for Kingston, N.Y., on the Hudson River Day Line steamboat Peter Stuyvesant today, were let off at the Yonkers city pier after being told that apples they had volunteered to pick in Ulster County were not ready for picking.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- The Phils outhit the Cubs today to help themselves to a 6-to-4 victory in the opener of a three-game series.

In Northern Scotland, that dour land of fighting men, the Duke of Kent was killed yesterday on active service on his way to Iceland. That the low-toned radio announcement of his death was a shock to his people there can be no doubt, because they held him in affection and respect.

SUPERIOR, Wis., Aug. 25 -- Edgar Lechner, University of Minnesota tackle last year, today joined the New York Football Giants, training here for their Eastern All-Army game Sept. 12 at the Polo Grounds for the Army Emergency Relief and Tribune Fresh Air funds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Now that the Brazilian street demonstrations in favor of the war and the absence of any important dissension in the army and navy of Brazil have been registered, official opinion here is confirmed that President Getulio Vargas is a statesman of the first order and the most effective architect of Western Hemisphere solidarity in Latin America.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today to amend the Social Security Act to make more money available to the Children's Bureau for "special needs of mothers and children arising from war conditions." Legislation to accomplish this was immediately introduced by Senator Walter F. George, chairman of the Finance Committee.

It has been pointed out that "the Army would rather have youth 18 and 19 than married men, contending they make the best possible soldiers," and that "Congress has refused to take any immediate action because * * * the proposed amendment (to draft 18 to 19 year olds) is loaded with political dynamite and should be avoided until after November elections."

Early in September, 1928, when the 25-year-old son of King George V and Queen Mary landed in Santa Barbara, Calif., on one of the cruises that took him tens of thousands of miles as a salesman of Empire, a cablegram was received from his father forbidding him to do any flying.

MOSCOW, Aug. 25 -- The people of Moscow are facing the crisis calmly. Nothing in the news is preventing them from snatching fiercely at the pleasures that high Summer offers. There is noticeably less nervousness and irritation and a greater desire to live fully than a year ago, when the few visitors to the Park of Rest and Culture had the rare experience of seeing kiosks piled with fruits and candy but without customers.

The Army Emergency Relief and Major League Baseball Equipment Funds became richer by $162,890.40 yesterday when checks for that amount were presented by Horace Stoneham, president of the Giants, to Colonel John Thomas Taylor of Washington, director of Army Relief, in a ceremony at the Giants' offices.

Military sources said last night that German armored forces attacking southwest of Stalingrad had broken through Soviet bunker positions seven and a miles deep, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by the United Press in New York.

CHUNGKING, Aug. 25 -- The Chinese press general this morning considers the puzzling significance of the large-scale Japanese withdrawals from the seaboard provinces. Greater air support for China and a general Allied counter-offensive are urged.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Denying that rising farm prices carry a threat of inflation, President Edward A. O'Neal of the American Farm Bureau Federation declared opposition today to the proposal of Secretary Wickard that Congress repeal the price control law provision prohibiting farm price ceilings from being established at less than 110 per cent of parity.
LONDON, Aug. 25 (U.P.) -- Dispatches received in London from Glasgow tonight said the crash in which the Duke of Kent was killed was not due to enemy action.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 25 -- Herbert Carl Bahr, 29-year-old former Buffalo honor student, who was convicted last night in Federal court of conspiring with the German Gestapo to commit espionage in this country, is being kept isolated from other prisoners in the Hudson County Jail, it became known here today.

An air raid warden's complaint against a superintendent who was off duty during the surprise city-wide blackout on July 31 and left hallway lights burning throughout the building was dismissed yesterday in Bronx Magistrates Court, but Magistrate Morris Rothenberg held the landlord responsible for an infraction of the War Emergency Act and fined him $25 or five days in jail.

Without detracting from the credit due to management and millions of patriotic workmen for the increased tempo of war production in July, "wildcat" strikes and jurisdictional walkouts continued to mount during the month, according to the findings of a survey made public yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers.

BOSTON, Aug. 25 -- The Red Sox swept their third doubleheader in three playing days at the expense of the Indians today, 4 -- 3, in eleven innings, and 5 -- 1, to total fourteen victories in their last fifteen starts. During the twenty innings the Indians were held to eleven hits as southpaws Ken Chase and Oscar Judd operated without relief.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTY ARMY, in Egypt, Aug. 25 -- That the enemy at last feels himself fully prepared to rupture the British lines in the Western Desert and crash through to the Nile delta is variously indicated here today. The desert full moon sheds light almost like day.
BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Fist-fighting broke out tonight in the Louisiana State Senate chamber with members of House and Senate engaging in the melee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The New York Foreign Trade Zone received only 136,860 short tons of merchandise during the calendar year 1941, as compared with 215,658 tons in 1940, but the total value recorded was $88,623,194, which was $5,192,194 greater, according to the annual report of the zone to the Commerce Department.

Using wagons, carts, baby carriages and anything else that would roll, about fifty children from 8 to 13 years old, led by "commandos," invaded the lower East Side from Clinton Street to the East River and from Rivington Street to Grand Street yesterday in an effort to collect anything of use to the government in its salvage drive.

Weakness penetrated yesterday into most sections of the stock market as the l7ist suffered one of its most widespread declines since the start of the month. From a technical viewpoint, the retreat was not regarded as a real criterion since much of the trading continued to center in the low-priced issues, and not a single pivotal stock was able to generate any volume of importance.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 25 (AP) -- The American Negro was advised today by one of his leaders, "This is not the time for the Negro to unduly press for advantages."

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- The features of an otherwise quiet stock market were the continued rise in gilt-edged issues and strength in the internationals. The demand for British funds kept the tone of the market firm. The 3 1/2 per cent war loan and the old consols each gained 1-16 point.

Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday intervened in the case of a 23-year-old father of four children, who is dying from a bullet wound inflicted by his wife, to force her to bring the children to their father's death-bed.

Workmen engaged in tests to improve the Long Island Lighting Company's capacity to distribute power from its Glenwood Landing generating station yesterday made a sizzling mistake which cut off electricity in Nassau and Suffolk Counties for one to three hours.

The strategic plans of the British and American Governments are hidden from us almost as much as those of the Axis. It is altogether necessary that they should be. We do not know, therefore, whether the military forces of the United Nations are planning to open a second front in the immediate future or whether they are not.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 25 (U.P.) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Central China armies have reached the approaches of two airfield towns in Chekiang Province from which Tokyo could be bombed and are preparing to storm Nanchang in Kiangsi, where 50,000 Japanese have converged for a stand, it was announced tonight.

For the fifth time this year the infant mortality rate in New York City has dropped below 25 per 1,000 live births, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins said yesterday in reporting the vital statistics for the week ended last Saturday.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- Sales of furniture stores next year canot be expected to equal more than 50 per cent of 1941 volume, John R. Trost, manager of the New York office of the National Retail Furniture Association, told Westchester furniture merchants here tonight By the end of 1943, he said, at least one out of every four, or about 5,000 furniture stores, will be out of business.

LONDON, Aug. 25 (U.P.) -- German Gestapo agents, waging a new reign of terror against patriots in occupied Europe, have executed at least 100 persons in the last forty-eight hours, it was reported tonight, and the Yugoslavs are striking back with a newly formed "execution corps" pledged to kill all traitorous public officials who help the Axis.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Jersey City made it two in a row in its three-game series with the Orioles today, winning by 6 -- 3, behind the six-hit pitching of Hugh East.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Former Senator James O. Eastland, a lawyer and planter, forged ahead to a good lead in Mississippi's Democratic Senatorial primary today. He will face either Senator Wall Doxey or Representative Ross Collins three weeks hence in a run-off for the nomination.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Wholesale potato prices rose above $4 a hundred pounds again today, the Agricultural Marketing Service reported. This was the first time since Aug. 6 that the market had reached this level, which represents the highest late Summer potato prices in a decade and longer, Department of Agriculture statistics showed.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Fresh Start won the Swansea Purse at Narragansett Park today, leading the Reynolds Brothers' Powder Bluff across the finish line by five and one-quarter lengths.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 -- German and Italian aliens of the West Coast, who have been subject since early this year to strict travel and curfew restrictions, may obtain temporary exemptions in certain cases, under a program announced by the Army today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The Senate, with a 47-5 vote, passed today and sent to conference with the House legislation designed to enable an estimated 4,000,000 service men and women on active duty here and throughout the world to participate in the election of Congress in November.

Seven months ahead of schedule, the mightiest battleship ever built will slide down the ways of the Navy Yard in Brooklyn tomorrow, it was announced yesterday by the Third Naval District headquarters here. She is the U.S.S. Iowa, first of six 45,000-ton battleships now under construction to reach the launching stage.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Representative Sasscer of Maryland has a sort or proprietary interest in "The Star-Spangled Banner," inasmuch as it was written in his Congressional district. But he admitted today that he would have "one hell of a time" singing it through, either in solo or chorus.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 25 -- Three of the leaders in the open championship tournament of the United States Chess Federation -- I. A. Horowitz of New York, Herman Steiner of Los Angeles and Abe Yanofsky of Winnipeg -- continued to sweep all before them today in the sixth and seventh rounds.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Combined net profits of fourteen major meat packing and allied product firms rose $3,000,000 in 1940, while combined sales increased $165,000,000, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- British bombers struck the Rhineland cities of Frankfort-on-the-Main and Wiesbaden in force last night, starting many fires. British fighters simultaneously attacked railway objectives in the Low Countries, destroying a number of locomotives.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- A Navy communique:

MOSCOW, Aug. 25 -- From a wide lodgment on the Don's left bank a powerful force of enemy tanks with strong air protection is advancing toward Stalingrad despite furious resistance. The Germans are straining every nerve to maintain the relentless vigor of their attack.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 25 -- It may be otherwise on the field, but on paper the Football Dodgers appear to have no worries concerning a first team this year. Mike Getto, who has taken over Jock Sutherland's title, duties and worries, has fifteen veterans available, salvaged from the squad that was coming along so smoothly until the war stepped in and took a dozen or more top-flight football stars.

FOR a long time the complaint has been heard in this country that politics and government offered insufficient attractions to men of education and ability compared with business and the professions and that the nation's affairs were too often entrusted to professional politicians distinguished chiefly by their devotion to party machines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Five million women will be added to the swelling total of feminine workers in the nation's war effort by the end of next year, Miss Thelma McKelvey of the War Manpower Commission said tonight.

TRENTON, Aug. 25 -- State Civilian Defense Director Leonard Dreyfuss and Arnold S. Vey, chairman of the New Jersey War Transportation Committee, warned today of "a complete breakdown of transportation for 1,200,000 workers, many of whom are engaged in vital war industries, unless immediate steps are taken to conserve automobiles.

Home owners must order immediately grates and other equipment necessary, for the conversion of oil burner furnaces to coal if they want to be certain of having the conversion job completed by the start of the heating season next month, Joseph C. Fitts, secretary of the Heating, Piping and Air Conditioning Contractors National Association, 1250 Sixth Avenue, said yesterday.

VICHY, France, Aug. 25 -- Administrative services of the French Senate and Chamber of Deputies, whose existence has maintained the shadow-life of Parliament since it was adjourned in July, 1940, will be abolished by a law to be issued tomorrow, it was announced officially here tonight.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 25 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho is considering a proposal to all countries of North and South America for the formation of a unit of the nations of these two continents, including Canada, according to a semi-official report here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Mgr. John A. Ryan, head of the social action department of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, told the conference's inter-American seminar on social studies today that legislators and rulers who desired to follow Catholic social teaching in setting up a new social order should adopt these economic policies:

Near-month liquidation spear-headed a sharp decline in the cotton market yesterday, causing active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange to lose all the gains made in the preceding session. General selling at the close left the list with net losses of 25 to 22 points.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 26 -- New Zealand troops routed an Italian division west of El Alamein, and United States bombers blasted at Axis shipping in Suda Bay, Crete, and on the Corinth Canal in Greece today as the Allies lashed out to break up General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's preparations for a new offensive in Egypt.

A woman, who said she was the Baroness Wilhelmina Oppenheim, 42 years old, a native of Savannah, Ga., and widow of Baron Francois Oppenheim of France, who died about, two years ago at Darien, Conn., was held in $300 bail yesterday in the Felony Court on suspicion of the theft of a rare book on Aug. 18 from Charles Scribner's Sons at 597 Fifth Avenue.

KEARNY, N.J., Aug. 26 -- The twin destroyers Glennon and Jeffers were launched at the yard of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company here this morning, the third and fourth vessels to go down the ways here since the company received the Army-Navy "E" award sixteen days ago.

The banking syndicate that on Monday won the award of $33,950,000 of electric light and power revenue bonds of the city of San Antonio, Texas, was enlarged yesterday to include Dillon, Read Co. and Kuhn, Loeb Co., thus bringing the total of major underwriters in the deal to five.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 (AP) -- A charge of assault and battery, with attempt to kill, which Mrs. Harry M. Barstow Jr., former Philadelphia beauty contestant, filed against her husband, a real estate man of Atlantic City, was nolle prossed in the Municipal Court here today.
LONDON, Aug. 26 -- The news from Russia, with the seriousness of the position of Stalingrad, kept the markets subdued today.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 26 -- As a result of play in the eighth and ninth rounds of the open championship of the United States Chess Federation at the Hotel Baker today, Abe Yanofsky of Winnipeg was forced back to third place.

Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., Republican nominee for reelection in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District, issued yesterday the following statement in reply to the assertion of Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, that he would not vote for him if he could vote from his farm in Putnam county:

Substantial changes in schedules and operating methods of bus companies in and around New York may be expected, bus operators were told yesterday at a meeting held at Police Headquarters under the auspices of the war transportation committee of the State War Council.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- A meeting between Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower and Prime Minister Winston Churchill on his return from Moscow via the Middle East again stirred speculation today on the opening of a second front and the selection of a generalissimo to command it.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- With the seasonal rebound in retail trade nearer, wholesalers of textiles this week found themselves the center of a demand for percales and other scarce cotton goods for civilian purposes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The business men of Spain were told today by Eric A. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, that they would commit economic suicide if they let Spain's workers go to work in Germany.

The calm that has been hanging over Egypt has been broken by the New Zealanders. The desert moon has reached its full, and the finest fighting weather of the year approaches. Rommel likes to fight on moonlit nights when his tanks can twist their way through British mine fields.

The surprise blackout in New York City Tuesday night was an unqualified success. Even the moon cooperated. This was the most realistic test of wartime conditions that the city has tried. In the one previous "surprise" blackout, last July 31, it was the Mayor who gave the orders; the Police and Fire Departments had advance warning, as did some of the air raid officials.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Aug. 27 -- On Aug. 11, on a seventy-mile front embracing the Kalinin and western zones in the directions of Rzhev, Gzhatsk and Vyazma, General Gregory K. Zhukoff and Colonel Gen. Ivan S. Koneff gave orders to their generals to open an offensive.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 26 -- Obtained for $2,500 early this Spring, Gleen Felkner's 3-year-old Albatross carried a claiming price of $4,600 today as he won the Narragansett Claiming Stakes at Narragansett Park.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information communique issued early today:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Breaking his long silence on the progress and conduct of the war, President Roosevelt plans three nation-wide radio addresses between now and Labor Day, the White House disclosed today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 26 --"One Hundred Girls and a Man," a story by Myles Connolly, has been scheduled by Universal as a vehicle for Robert Cummings and Michele Morgan, the studio announced today. Connolly has been engaged to write the scenario, and Henry Koster will direct the film, starting in November.
LUBBOCK, Texas, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Four flying cadets and a civilian were killed today in a collision of two planes over the Lubbock Army Flying School.

One statement by the President to his press conference this week was highly encouraging. He announced that you cannot stabilize wages without stabilizing farm prices nor can you stabilize farm prices without stabilizing wages. This is entirely correct. However long it may have taken the President to recognize this fact, it is a great gain that he has finally done so.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 26 -- A new outbreak of labor trouble at the Cornell-Dubilier Corporation plant here was threatened today when officers of Local B-1041 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A.F. of L., announced that 1,200 workers would meet Friday night to take a strike vote in protest against alleged delay by the National Labor Relations Board in certifying the results of an election held at the plant a month ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The setting-up of two permanent Catholic agencies for the study of social problems common to South, Central and North America was recommended at today's sessions of the Inter-American Seminar on Social Studies which opened here on Monday under the auspices of the National Catholic Welfare Conference.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Aug. 26 (U.P.) -- The Argentine merchant marine will open a new Pacific Ocean route to the United States by way of the Strait of Magellan, it was announced today. Starting next month the vessels will call at Valparaiso, Chile; Callao, Peru; Guayaquil, Ecuador; Buenaventura, Colombia; Balboa, Canal Zone; Manzanillo, Mexico, and San Francisco, Calif.

THE TIMES of Aug. 19 printed an account of the charges made before the Senate committee investigating patents involving a number of utilities, the General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company. Mr. Walker of the Anti-Trust Division of the Justice Department charged collusion of the utilities and the two companies mentioned to retard the development of fluorescent lighting.

Disregarding the vigorous protests of teachers groups, the Board of Education at its regular meeting yesterday voted to close five evening high schools, at an estimated annual saving of $35,000. However, Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, declared that adequate facilities remained for all students.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The first field to be explored by a special committee on concentration of production set up within the War Production Board will be the: industries engaged in producing essential civilian products in which metal is used, Joseph L. Weiner, deputy director of the Office of Civilian Supply and chairman of the newly appointed committee, told newspaper men today.

Your recent correspondent on fuel curtailment wrote from misinformation when she said that because many boilers had built-in water-heating coils the water is heated at no extra cost. The water comes cold in the coils and must be heated by transference of heat units from the boiler water and steam.
High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 -- A plan for a merger of the Lexington Water Power Company into the South Carolina Electric and Gas Company and the recapitalization of both, designed as a step in an overall program for distribution of the assets of the General Gas and Electric Corporation, a subsidiary of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Increased production in the poultry industry and adherence to the program of price control to prevent inflation were advocated yesterday by government officials at the annual exposition and convention of the Northeastern Poultry Producers Council at the Hotel New Yorker.

Efforts will be made to save waterfowl along the New Jersey coast this Fall that become covered with oil, according to an appeal sent to sportsmen's clubs by George C. Warren Jr., president of the New Jersey Fish and Game Commission. His letter is directed chiefly to those in Atlantic, Burlington.

A Presidential order to provide unallocated Treasury silver for use by industry and business will be sought soon, G.H. Niemeyer, president of Handy Harman, bullion dealers, indicated yesterday at the annual convention of the American National Retail Jewelers Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

OTTAWA, Aug. 26 -- Reorganization of the Canadian Information Service and the opening of offices in Washington and New York by a new information board was announced today by Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King. Charles Vining, head of the Newsprint Association of Canada, will be chairman of the board and F. Philippe Brais, until now Minister Without Portfolio in the Quebec Cabinet, will be vice chairman.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Secretary Stimson has ordered decentralization of personnel management in connection with the War Department's civilian employes.

The British Government spent 3,805,000 for press advertising between Sept. 1, 1939, and June 30, 1942, according to reports received by J. Walter Thompson Company from its London office. Samuel Meek, vice president in charge of international operations, said the largest portion of the appropriation, or 1,251,000, was spent by the National Savings Committee.

ON THE FRENCH-SWISS FRONTIER, Aug. 26 (U.P.) -- A round-up of all foreign Jews who entered France since 1936 has begun in the unoccupied zone despite an urgent plea from Pope Pius to the Chief of Government, Pierre Laval, for "moderation" in the treatment of Jewish and other expatriates.

In a report on a survey conducted by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People -- specifically directed at getting OPA Administrator Leon Henderson to revise price regulations -- it was said yesterday that shoppers in Harlem paid 6 per cent more for food than did residents of other sections.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- A direct statement by Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, outlining the adjustments his office is prepared to make to relieve the "squeeze" on distributors who will be handling the 1942 canned vegetable pack, was made to a group of food industry representatives who called upon Mr. Henderson today.

The recovery drive in prices of securities, stalled for several sessions, met yesterday its worst setback of the month when the stock market ran into a morning period of selling which depressed prices as much as 2 points. The severest damage was crowded into the first two hours, and then the pressure eased, and in the afternoon the list just drifted in dull trading.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 26 -- An unpretentious factory in Chengtu, with only a dozen workmen, recently received an order to build 153 models of the P-40 planes that won fame by defeating the Japanese Zeros. Also ordered were 153 model Flying Fortresses and 153 rubber-bandpowered model planes for Szechwan's 153 Peoples Education Institutes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Earl Warren, a leading figure among California Republicans, won the Republican nomination for Governor and also gave Governor Olson a hot battle for the Democratic nomination in yesterday's primary.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Bears turned on all their power, except the home run department, tonight in their final appearance before Syracuse fandom of the regular schedule and pounded out a 5-to-1 decision which prevented Syracuse from moving up a notch in the International standings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- President Roosevelt held his first conference today in the latest move to bring South Africa, Australia and New Zealand more closely into cooperation with the war efforts of the United States when he received the Prime Minister of New Zealand, Peter Fraser.

Changes in the business set-up of the Stillwater Worsted Mills, founded in 1909 and operating mills in Rhode Island, Connecticut and Virginia, will be made shortly, the concern announced yesterday. The name of the present company will be changed to the Harrisville Combing Company and the firm's plants engaged in manufacture of worsted yarn and cloths will be sold to a new organization, the Stillwater Worsted Mills, Inc.

A program to provide blood plasma banks for civilian casualties resulting from enemy action is now being carried out by the United States Public Health Service through the medical division of the Office of Civilian Defense, it was disclosed yesterday by Dr. H. van Zile Hyde, regional medical officer of the OCD.

The Hospital for Joint Diseases, 1919 Madison Avenue, gave three-fourths of the medical and surgical services it rendered to the community last year free of charge, according to the thirty-fifth annual report made public yesterday by Frederick Brown, president.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Oswaldo Aranha, the Brazilian For eign Minister, declared the people of Brazil face the war with "inflexible determination" in a message today to Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The citizens of South Bend, Ind., improved their knowledge and use of nutritive foods about 10 per cent as the result of a special Nutrition Week campaign, it was reported today by Paul V. McNutt, director of the Office of Defense Health and Welfare Services, on the basis of a special survey.

Provision of $11,380,255 for Federal taxes reduced the net income of the Sperry Corporation and its domestic subsidiaries for the six months ended on June 30, to $2,394,238 from $3,477,434 earned in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the semi-annual statement of Thomas A. Morgan, president, issued yesterday.

Out-of-town buyers now in the market here reported yesterday that retail trade was very spotty throughout the country, with some defense centers showing fantastic gains and other areas down as much as 18 to 20 per cent. As a result, the business being placed by buyers varies considerably.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, on the Front Near El Alamein, Egypt, Aug. 26 -- During the morning German shells have been bursting with their usual scream and dull thump along the screening ridges that hide the activities of the Australians in the coastal salient from the eyes of German artillery observers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- United States aircraft based on Guadalcanal Island have damaged six more Japanese ships, including two destroyers, and have repulsed what apparently was a smaller striking force of the powerful Japanese armada striving to dislodge our forces from their recently won bases in the southeastern Solomon Islands.
Arbitration was proposed yesterday as a means of settling a deadlock in contract negotiations affecting 15,000 truck drivers in this city.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Four dissenting employer members of the National War Labor Board charged today that the labor-public majority of board members had voted against the sanctity of a collective bargaining contract in making the five-and-one-half-cent-an-hour wage advance for 250,000 workers of the United States Steel Corporation retroactive to Feb. 15.

DETROIT, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Associate Justice Stanley Reed of the United States Supreme Court urged tonight in an address to the American Bar Association that the nation chart its war course carefully and that decisions then be backed by universal support.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The scramble for honors as top 3-year-old harness horse of the year became even more involved today as G.F. Benham's Cannon Ball beat both Colby Hanover, pre-Hambletonian favorite, and The Ambassador, Hambletonian winner.

When the Iowa was authorized by Congress three years ago she was expected to be the mightiest fighting ship afloat. The developments of this war, the rise of air power and the emergence of the plane carrier, may have modified that hope. Yet she slides down the ways in Brooklyn today -- a bulk of 45,000 tons of concentrated force, the heaviest warship ever launched.
LONDON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- After 800 men ineligible for military service had applied for jobs at his munitions plant in answer to a newspaper advertisement, Sir Edmund Crane today suggested that the Ministry of Labor work out a plan to utilize this untapped man power.

The man in uniform and his Uncle Sam are going to dominate every box of gifts shipped in or out of this country during the next year. A glance at the myriad offerings, which soon will be in the shops, in the New York Gift Show, currently at the Hotel Pennsylvania, has revealed an unlimited use of patriotic colors, military insignia and other symbols of a country at war.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 26 (UP) -- More than 1,000 Germans and Italians have been arrested in Rio de Janeiro and near-by States since Brazil declared war on Germany and Italy four days ago, it was reported today.
MOSCOW, Aug. 26 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 (AP) -- In an unusual contract, Thomas J. Watson, who was paid $462,519 as president and director of the International Business Machines Corporation in 1941, will forego any war profits earned in the future by the company from the manufacture of munitions, it was disclosed today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Pitching was decisive in a double-header between the Cubs and the Phils today and so Philadelphia won the opener, 3 to 2, in eleven innings and Chicago took the second contest, 3 to 0.

As the hour hand sped too quickly around the clock, Alman Harrington, 23-year-old electrician's helper, who is dying of a bullet wound inflicted by his 21-year-old wife, Anna, spent a few happy moments yesterday with his four small children, whom he had not seen since he was shot on June 23.

Stocks of gasoline in the United States at the close of last week were 80,443,000 barrels, a decline of 265,000 from the 80,708,000 a week earlier, the American Petroleum Institute announced yesterday. A year ago these supplies amounted to 81,194,000 barrels.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Ten officers of the Marine Corps, including one now a prisoner of the Japanese, have been promoted temporarily to the rank of brigadier general, effective Aug. 19, the Navy announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Price ceilings on hogs and cattle would be designed to bring them in line with ceilings on pork and beef. Uncontrolled livestock prices have advanced to a point where, Secretary Wickard has said, many packers are unable to sell processed meat at ceilings and avoid losses.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 26 (AP) -- James O. Eastland, lawyer and planter, ran 10,000 votes ahead of his nearest opponent for nomination to the United States Senate in yesterday's Democratic primary, which is tantamount to election. He will face either Senator Wall Doxey or Representative Ross Collins in a second primary three weeks from now.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Aug. 27 -- The Japanese have made another landing in New Guinea. This one is at Milne Bay, on the southeastern tip of the island, and United Nations ground forces already are in contact with the enemy there.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- The crewmen of the giant Liberator who flew Prime Minister Winston Churchill to Moscow might never have had that mission if they had arrived in Egypt two days sooner than they did late last month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, has notified the War and Navy Departments that the OPA will exempt from its controls prime contracts for completed combat materiel, such as planes, tanks and similar equipment, but this will not halt efforts in Congress to force that agency to keep its hands off parts and other items purchased solely by the government for the prosecution of the war.

There is more in a lemon than meets the eye. At least, that is the conviction of a certain chemist who tells of acrid oils concealed in the smooth yellow rind. When you split the fruit and squeeze the halves, he says, you inevitably release some of these oils, which, once freed, drop into the juice, making unpleasantly bitter what should be pleasantly tart.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- In celebration of the twenty-second anniversary of the national enfranchisement of women, open house was kept today by the National Woman's party at its headquarters on Capitol Hill. Members and friends met to recall the days of the suffrage campaign and rally their forces in the interest of the adoption of the pending equal rights amendment.

Last Spring New Jersey commemorated with fit rejoicing its Thirty Years' War with the mosquito tribes. The thirty years were completed. The war was not. Yet looking back to the time when New Jersey's 100,000 acres of freshwater swamp and 285,000 acres of salt marsh swarmed with these ferocious singers and stingers the long culicidal campaign has been surprisingly victorious.

Recent Selective Service announcements have practically brought the men's retail clothing business to a standstill, merchants revealed yesterday. Buying hesitancy, created by reports that married men will be drafted and older men classified, may curtail August sales more than the 20 to 30 per cent lag which was noted during the first two weeks of the month, they said.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 26 -- Referring to American successes against the Japanese in the Pacific, Lieut. Comdr. John Bulkeley, hero of "PT" boat exploits in the Philippines, declared "we're pitching now, instead of catching" in an address today at the launching of the latest craft of that type built by the Elco Naval Division of the Electrical Boat Company here.

MEXICO has had many revolutions. But the flavor of the common life changes very little over the decades. When Charles Flandrau wrote his charming, informal "Viva Mexico" about life on a coffee plantation, or finca, back in the high noon of Porfirio Diaz, the Mexican rhythm was summed up in the word "ahora," signifying not "now" but "in a little while."

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 26 -- The two-way tie for the lead between Bobby Mosbacher's Teal and Dan Mackenzie's Whim in the point scoring for the Atlantic Trophy, emblematic of the Atlantic Class sloop championship, was broken today like a lee shore wreck.

A millinery fashion show with manikins emerging from hat boxes will be conducted for the next ten days, excepting Sunday, in the window of Bloomingdale's at Fifty-ninth Street and Lexington Avenue from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M., according to announcement made yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Meatless days, the imposition of price ceilings on live hogs and cattle, and the ironing out by the Office of Price Administration of inequalities caused by taking Lenten prices as the basis for the ceilings put on meat at the retailer's level, are the measures with which it is proposed to end the meat shortage, it was learned today.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- The government today lifted its ban on the publication of The Daily Worker, Communist party organ, which had been in force since Jan. 17, 1941. With the notification to the management, however, went a warning that the ban could be reimposed if at any future date there were any systematic publication of matter calculated to foment opposition to the prosecution of the war to a successful issue.
Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark has come to Hampshire House from Cooperstown, N.Y.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Pete Center, husky Oriole right-hander, spoiled a special ladies' day honoring Representative Mary T. Norton today, as he pitched Baltimore to a 4-to-0 victory over Jersey city before a crowd of 25,853, of which 19,988 were women.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Leaders of organized labor appealed to President Roosevelt today to leave the wage stabilization authority in the hands of the National War Labor Board when he formulates his anti-inflation program designed to keep pay rates and farm prices at their present levels.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 26 -- The forty-third grand American trapshoot schedule was thrown out of gear when more than one-third of 770 marksmen, largest field ever to seek the class championships, failed to complete today's program before dark.

Tennis players from all over the country, some of them wearing the uniforms of the armed services, have gathered at Forest Hills, L.I., for the national championships, starting today at the West Side Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Senate Finance Committee rejected today by a vote of 13 to 3 the Ruml "pay-as-you-go" income tax plan, under which taxes on 1941 incomes would be canceled or "skipped" in order to put taxpayers on a current basis.
BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Red Sox won their ninth straight today as they defeated the Indians, 4 to 1, behind the three-hit pitching of Bill Butland.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- If Private Charley Smith of the air forces in Alaska wants to know how his former neighbors in Yonkers are spending their time or how his old classmates are doing with the Navy in the Mediterranean, The Yonkers Home News, a paper published exclusively for Yonkers service men, is almost certain to convey the information.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Paper patterns used for home dressmaking were brought under the general restrictions already ordered for ready-to-wear garments in a new limitation order issued today by the War Production Board. The pattern order, however, specifically states that the measurements to be applied by pattern manufacturers do not include the extra-severe restrictions ordered for wool garments.

Directors of the Electric Power and Light Corporation, at a meeting held yesterday, took no action on dividends on its preferred stocks, normally up for declaration at this time. The company had been making partial payments against arrears, the last disbursement having been made on July 1 at the rates of 35 cents a share on the $7 preferred and 30 cents on the $6 preferred.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- Test tubes bubbled away mysteriously in front of be-goggled Carol McLaughlin. A metronome ticked back and forth as 17-year-old Martha Pahnke dropped bicalcium phosphate into a container. And Jane Bradley, scales by her side, tested the strength and reaction of polycatalyst pellets, used to raise the octane rating of aviation gasoline.

WEST MILFORD, N.J., Aug. 26 -- The governing body of the First Presbyterian Church of this community came to the support today of the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Lewis Gaston Leary, in his long dispute with Police Chief Somers Stites of West Milford Township over how the American flag and the Christian flag should be placed on the pulpit in respect to each other.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- A Navy communique:

Major themes of the Boston Conference on Distribution, to be held Oct. 5 and 6 at the Hotel Statler, Boston, will be "Distribution's Part in Winning the War," "Post-War Adjustment of Business," and "Major Trends in Distribution," it was announced yesterday by Daniel Bloomfield, director.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) -- All interests bid actively today in the cattle section of the livestock markets and prices were strong throughout. Quality was improved over earlier days this week and choice steers brought $16.65 a hundredweight. There also was an active trade on stock cattle, choice yearlings and feeders going at $13.25 to $13.75.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 26 -- Many members of the Garden Club of Southampton attended the meeting of the organization held this afternoon at The Playhouse, the home of Mrs. R. Swift Maguire in Halsey Neck Lane. Mrs. John D. Beals Jr., head of the club, presided.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- The British Empire today mourned the Duke of Kent, who died in a burning plane on a wild Scottish mountainside yesterday with thirteen others who were with him on a mission to Iceland.

The book about the U.S.S. Lexington and the Coral Sea battle by Stanley Johnston, correspondent of The Chicago Tribune, originally announced for early September by Dutton, yesterday was set for publication Oct. 8. Announcing the book six weeks ago, the publisher put forward a contest for a better title than "Queen of the Flat Tops: the U.S.S. Lexington and the Coral Sea Battle."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- American photographers were urged today by Norman H. Davis, national chairman of the American Red Cross, to lend their talents to the recording of the work of the organization at home and abroad.

State Senator Thomas G. Brennan will ask Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter today to order a recount of the primary vote in the Sixteenth Senatorial District, in which Senator Brennan was defeated for the Democratic renomination by 288 votes by James G. Donovan.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- Anthony Pelleteri's La Reigh, 123 pounds and all, was a decisive winner of the $5,075 Adirondack Handicap today on a program which also marked the victorious return to competition of Colchis, who had been absent since the Kent Stakes at Delaware Park.

The tinted fingernails of Brooklyn's champion among early teenage jacks players had rough treatment yesterday afternoon. Time and again, they were scraped across a wooden surface, knocked against a stubborn jack and deprived of their former luster as their perspiring owner, Anna Geller, struggled to catch the coveted championship of Greater New York.

Following a final conference with Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday, Vice Chairman Joseph T. Sharkey of the City Council announced that the Council would meet on Monday at 1:30 to adopt amendments to the McCarthy Salary Increment Law.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Settlement out of court of the libel suit of James H.R. Cromwell, former United States Minister to Canada, against the New Masses, left wing publication, for falsely naming him as a member of "the Washington Cliveden set" of so-called appeasers was reported today by Jay Jerome Williams Associates, public relations advisers representing Mr. Cromwell.

In Chicago and New York yesterday the brokerage business labored to simplify its tasks, with retrenchment as the end-product. In Chicago the Securities and Exchange Commission worked with representatives of the financial industry to devise a single reporting form, so that the Federal and State Governments may be handled in one operation.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 26 (AP) -- The Army-Navy "E" banner was unfurled at the American Locomotive Company's plant today in ceremonies honoring its war production workers the third time within a year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Legislation designed to relieve War and Navy Department employes and other war workers from transportation difficulties arising from gasoline and tire rationing was filed in the Senate today by Senator Walsh, chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee, for formal introduction tomorrow.

Thomas E. Dewey, returning here yesterday afternoon from Saratoga Springs, where he was nominated by acclamation by the Republican State Convention as the party's candidate for Governor, contended that Republican ranks were more completely united than they had been for years and confidently predicted an "overwhelming" victory for himself and the entire State ticket in the November elections.

Dismissal of a stockholders' accounting suit against directors and former voting trustees of the Hecker Products Corporation was asked yesterday in Supreme Court by defendants on the ground that the issues raised in the suit had already been decided in another case.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The special House subcommittee investigating cancellation of the Maritime Commission's contract with the Higgins shipyard at New Orleans, La., today urged William L. Batt, vice chairman of the WPB, to try to find some way to utilize the plant and "salvage the government's investment."
JERUSALEM, Aug. 26 -- American Field Service ambulances have covered 300,000 miles of desert in Libyan battles since last May and have since been continuously active.

The report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries for the first seven months of this year, issued yesterday by Justin R. Whiting, president, shows a consolidated net income of $5,515,555 after taxes and other charges.

Since the outbreak of war the price of cotton has gone up over 100 per cent, and this rise has been almost entirely responsible for an advance of 50 to 70 per cent in the wholesale quotations for practically all textile fabrics, including sheets and pillowcases, towels, etc. Meanwhile, the carryover of cotton from previous crops is almost sufficient to cover our country's needs for another year.

After a six-day period in which no new sinkings by enemy submarines in the western Atlantic had been announced by our Navy, the loss of two ships was officially acknowledged yesterday. One was a medium-sized United States ship that was torpedoed and shelled in the Gulf of Mexico early this month; the other a small Dutch merchantman sent to the bottom in the Caribbean more recently.

New indications that the German-American Bund has continued its pro-Nazi activities through various social clubs since giving up its open, national organization were brought out yesterday in Federal Court. With the indictment of Fritz Streuer of Detroit. United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa announced that the Detroit unit of the bund had been operating for nearly a year as the Springfield Social Club.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- There was a lull in the air activity in this theatre last night and today, but that is not say there was no raiding by both British and Germans, for a day never goes by on either side without the dropping of a few bombs and the killing of a few persons.
SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Aug. 26 -- The Pacific "showdown" seems to be at hand.

Three new films will open today. The Radio City Music Hall will present "The Talk of the Town," a Columbia comedy-drama starring Cary Grant, Jean Arthur and Ronald Colman; the Capitol will bring in "Somewhere I'll Find You," a story about the Philippine invasion, co-starring Clark Gable and Lana Turner, and the Palace will offer "Give Out, Sisters," featuring the Andrews Sister, with the second-run "Wings for the Eagle" also on the program.

LIMA, Peru, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The residents of the little seaport of Lomas fled to the hills in terror last night when new earth tremors shook the village, which was rocked by a severe earthquake Monday and then swept by a tidal wave.

Having plunged the country into war, the military clique that has seized absolute control of the Emperor and the government in Japan is now busily engaged in converting that country into the typical one-party Nazi-Fascist State.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The story of a youth from Newark, N.J., who gave up a possible career as a Navy officer because he could not wait to be of service to his country was told today by Representative Robert W. Kean of New Jersey.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26 -- News from this western bank of the Mississippi tonight is of such a nature that considerable alarm doubtless will be felt in every Flatbush precinct.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Several times a week now, as for months past, great passenger airplanes land at points within the United States and the United Kingdom, discharging official observers and administrators of the war who are beginning or have just ended their assignments.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 26 -- Chuhsien, site of the biggest air field in China and the best base for bombings of Japan, is under attack by Chinese forces in the big drive against the Japanese invaders in Chekiang and Kiangsi Provinces.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 26 -- Douglas Ford, 21-year-old New York State junior champion, extended his year's conquests today by winning low gross honors in the fifth one-day tournament of the Metropolitan Golf Association, leading sixty-seven other contestants.

It was a long time coming, but the White Sox finally made it. They beat the Yankees at the Stadium yesterday for the first time there all season, and the Chicagoans could not have skimmed closer to the deadline, because this was their final fray in New York.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 26 (U.P.) -Chinese troops have captured Tunghsiang, thirty-seven miles southeast of the important railway center of Nanchang, where 50,000 Japanese troops are dug in for a last stand. This raised to fifteen the number of Kiangsi and Chekiang province towns from which the Japanese have been routed in five weeks.

Specialty distributors in the electrical goods fields are beginning to pass out of existence at the rate of ten to fifteen a week, as a result of the shutdown of sources of supply, reports here yesterday indicated. Frantic efforts to add unrelated lines as a source of revenue are enabling some distributors to keep going temporarily, while a substantial number have skeletonized operations and are maintaining a precarious existence on servicing.

LONDON, Aug. 26 -- Brig. Gen. G.M. Barnes, Assistant Chief of Ordnance, United States Army, in winding up today a three weeks' tour of gun, tank and other munitions plants in Britain, said of Allied weapons:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, charged today that "business-as-usual" policies of American Communications companies were delaying urgent war messages, and asked the Senate Defense Investigating Committee to hold hearings on the alleged failure to put the industry on a war basis.

A few weeks ago the War-Production Board announced its intention of forming an Office of Technical Development to test promising inventions in the light of industrial needs. Later came the news that this office would also act as a clearing house for the United Nations, with the result that industrial science and invention might be more effectively mobilized than ever before.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 (AP) -- Detroit defeated the Athletics twice tonight, capturing a 4-2 decision in a game under the arc lights after eking out a 1-0 verdict in a twilight contest.

Wednesday night, Sept. 9, has been chosen by Brock Pemberton for the premiere of "Janie" at Henry Miller's Theatre. The preceding evening will be devoted to a preview. After a brief illness Mr. Pemberton returned to his chores yesterday.

Consolidated net income of the Greyhound Corporation for the first half of 1942 was $2,245,420 after all charges and Federal taxes, it was announced yesterday. This was equal, after preferred dividends, to 77 cents a share on 2,792,075 average number of common shares outstanding in the period.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Senator Burnet R. Maybank, friend and supporter of President Roosevelt, won an apparently safe majority over Eugene S. Blease today as late unofficial returns were reported from yesterday's Democratic primary to name a United States Senator.

The author of our daily book review yesterday, in the swift completion of his appointed rounds, commented on a new book which deals harshly with the policies and management of our State Department in recent critical years.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 -- The International Hydro-Electric System filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan for its liquidation, little more than a month after such action had been ordered under the "death sentence" clause of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

Accompanying Department of Sanitation trucks on their collection of tin cans, Mrs. Guy Percy Trulock, chairman of the tin can division of the New York City Salvage Committee, made a personal inspection yesterday on the West Side to learn the problems and methods of collection in an effort to find ways to increase the number of cans collected.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Aug. 26 -- There is greater need now for considering the training of supervisors than for war workers, M.J. Kane of the War Manpower Commission told members of the industrial relations conference of the National Association of Manufacturers today.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 26 -- With gratifying results, the Giants expended on the Reds at Crosley Field today some of the pent-up fury they had accumulated in a tailspin that encompassed five straight defeats.

SHREVEPORT, La., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Four Army airmen were killed today when a B-26 bomber from the Barksdale Field crashed into a small farmhouse ten miles south of here, destroying it and burning a farmer severely.

Companies in the metropolitan district that have won prizes in the State-wide safety contest conducted by the State Insurance Fund will receive plaques and certificates at a dinner tonight at the Hotel Commodore, it was announced yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia, matching his comedy with that of Bud Abbott and Lou Costello, capped a day of war bond appeals by the movie comedians with a brief serious speech before 17,000 persons at the Mall in Central Park last night.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, speaking at a conference of the American Federation of Negro College Students at International House of Columbia University, 500 Riverside Drive, said last night that the wartime demand for manpower may help to solve the problem of racial discrimination in the United States.

The tedious debarkation of refugee passengers from the Swedish liner Gripsholm continued in Jersey City yesterday, and government officials expressed the hope that the ship might be cleared by tonight.

In a strong effort to break into the American market, the Pan-American Woolen Company, Buenos Aires, will start a $100,000 campaign, breaking in October in daily newspapers and leading fashion magazines. The campaign is being handled by David Steinfeld, director of the textiles and fashion division of Arthur Rosenberg Company, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- In an election year the House of Representatives, which must present its entire membership to the judgment of the voters, has virtually turned over to the Senate, only one-third of which must face the polls, the task of writing the 1942 tax bill.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Aug. 27 (U.P.) -- General Douglas MacArthur awarded three Distinguished Service Crosses today to United States Army Air Force officers for heroism in the air war over New Guinea and New Britain in April and May.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 27 -- The New Jersey branch of the Office of Price Administration has recommended to OPA's enforcement division in Washington that tighter controls be placed on the issuance and use of S gasoline ration books for motor trucks, it was admitted today by Nathan L. Jacobs, chief OPA attorney for this State.

Some of the furnishings of the former French liner Normandie, which is now being salvaged at her pier in the North River, were sold at auction yesterday with other abandoned, seized and unclaimed merchandise, at the United States Customs seizure room in the Appraiser's Stores, 201 Varick Street.

A West Side apartment house upon which the contractor is putting the finishing touches changed hands yesterday when the Bank for Savings sold the new six-story structure occupying the southerly half of the block front on the west side of Eighth Avenue, from Fifty-second to Fifty-third Street, to the Chain Building Corporation, Leo Silver, president.

FORT DES MOINES, Ia., Aug. 27 -- Only four of the four hundred and forty women who completed the first officer candidate class of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps failed to meet the final academic standards for graduation, it was stated today by officials of the Waac school.

Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff," in the original form of the music, but in the new orchestral version of Dmitri Shostakovich, will be produced for the first time in America by Leopold Stokowski and the New Opera Company in the Forty-fourth Street Theatre between Dec. 29 and Jan. 10.

Louise Stanley, actress, and Lieutenant Charles A. Munn Jr., U.S.N.R., were married on Tuesday evening at the home of the bride, 2 Sutton Place South, it was announced here yesterday. The ceremony had been scheduled for Monday and several hours before it took place the prospective bride announced that Lieutenant Munn's duties had necessitated postponement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Department store sales declined 3 per cent in the week ended Aug. 22, compared with the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. In the week ended Aug. 15 sales were the same as in the corresponding week of 1941.

WITH U.S. ARMY AIR FORCES, in China, Aug. 26 (Delayed) -- The old Burma Road terminus, Lashio, looked fresh and peaceful in the sunlight after a sudden rain when our American fighters and bombers arrived over it today.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Aug. 28 (AP) -- A communique:

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Owen D. Young, retired executive of the General Electric Company, joined yesterday in warning labor and industry that failure to raise required funds through the voluntary purchase of war bonds would make it necessary for the government to resort to compulsion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Three delegates from Soviet Russia, all actively engaged in their country's war effort and two of whom, a young man and woman, both lieutenants in the army of the U.S.S.R., have personally accounted for more than 450 of its Nazi enemies, arrived today for the International Student Assembly, which will open on Monday.

Although 6 per cent below the previous week, awards for engineering construction for the current week are 75 per cent greater in volume than in the corresponding period last year. This week's total is $217,798,000 according to the Engineering News-Record, which reports that in the present week public construction almost doubles its total for a year ago, gaining 98 per cent over the 1941 week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- House action on the bill to enable 4,000,000 service men and women to participate in the election of the new Congress was postponed today, largely because of absenteeism on the part of a majority of the membership.

Home owners from the vicinity of 150th Street between Seventy-sixth and Seventy-seventh Avenues, Flushing, Queens, met last night with city officials and with the owner of a tract where there is a large pond near that location, to work out plans for eliminating the pool, a danger to children in the neighborhood.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Whether some 100,000 football fans will flock to Philadelphia on Nov. 28 for the big Army-Navy game remains a problem for Secretary of War Stimson to solve.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The White House called in the top legal brains of the Administration today to discuss President Roosevelt's war powers to fix farm prices at levels less than the minimum directives of Congress in the Price Control Act, and thus avoid an estimated potential increase of $5,500,000,000 in the retail cost of food and clothing.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 -- All members of the present House delegation from California, including a half dozen sharply attacked by their opponents on "pre-Pearl Harbor" records, had won either re-election or their party nominations on the basis of late returns tonight from Tuesday's primary election.

Normal advertising expenditures and those necessitated by the numerous contingencies arising from the war program are deductible for income tax purposes, according to a clarifying explanation of the attitude of the Treasury Department and the Bureau of Internal Revenue, released yesterday by the Association of National Advertisers with the approval of the office of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 27 -- Shortage of labor, Royal Air Force attacks and the activity of Russian submarines in the Baltic are mainly responsible for a considerable decrease in German-Swedish commercial exchanges. The newspaper Aftonbladet revealed today that the quantity of German coal and coke delivered to Sweden in July had been 500,000 tons less than that for the corresponding period of last year.

Heralded by Assistant Secretary of the Navy Ralph A. Bard as a weapon that might some day "take part in that final climactic operation of all the war -- the invasion of the Continent of Europe or the islands of Japan," the 45,000-ton battleship Iowa, largest man-o'-war ever built, slid down the ways of the navy yard in Brooklyn yesterday morning.

We have still to defeat totalitarianism in our own minds as well as on the battlefield, according to an opening statement issued here yesterday on behalf of the Third Annual Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion in Their Relation to the Democratic Way of Life.

Although the Vichy radio quoted a German spokesman on Tuesday as declaring "the fate of Stalingrad will be settled before the end of the week," other German sources began yesterday to prepare for a possible postponement of the city's capture.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Aug. 27 -- In the quiet drawl of his native Missouri, Captain Herbert W. Underwood, commanding officer of the Naval Training School at Smith College, employed good old housekeeping terms today to describe preparations for the coming arrival of the first members of the Women's Navy Auxiliary to be mobilized for training.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 27 -- Ol' Dan'l Boone Davis became the hero of Brooklyn in the twilight at Sportsman's Park today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- President Roosevelt met with the Pacific War Council and talked with Governor Van Wagoner of Michigan, who assured him that Michigan's 5,000 war plants are doing a wonderful production job. William C. Bullitt, who reported on his recent special mission abroad, was his guest at luncheon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Secretary Knox has called into the Navy Department an investigator, unidentified for the present, to conduct an inquiry into the planning and production of invasion boats by and under the direction of the Navy's Bureau of Ships.
Many missionaries who returned home this week on the Swedish exchange liner Gripsholm have volunteered their services to the United States Government as war workers, it was disclosed yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- Talk of two shortages slipped into conversation in Chicago war industries today. One affects the civilian population, the other, women workers.

Announcement was made yesterday that five hotels on the New Jersey coast and one on Long Island were to be taken over for the quartering of military personnel. The Navy will get the sumptious Lido Club at Lido Beach, L. I., and the hotels Monterey and Berkeley Carteret in Asbury Park, while the Army has rented the Kingsley Arms in Asbury Park and the Essex and Sussex and the Monmouth in Spring Lake, N. J.

FORT DIX, N.J., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Dr. Herbert Kainer, who has written treatises on bone tuberculosis and taught advanced surgery in a Berlin hospital, is now an Army private dispensing pills and first aid to fellow soldiers at the Fort Dix Reception Center.

BAHIA, Brazil, Aug. 27 (U.P.) -- The Brazilian Government plans to evacuate all Germans from the coastal area on its northern "bulge," which is less than 1,700 miles from Vichy-controlled French West Africa, according to Lafayette Ponde, Security Secretary of the Northern State of Bahia.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 27 -- "Iron, copper, zinc and brass, tin-cups, hammers, nails and old auto-bodies -- all are mounting up at dizzy speed into metal pyramids as Cariocans build them in several places. In Rio de Janeiro, so far, thousands of tons of kitchen utensils are going to increase the metal reserves of Brazil and be converted into cannon to fight Hitler."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The War Labor Board, by unanimous action today, denied maintenance of membership and check-off changes to a union which struck in violation of labor's no-strike pledge to industry and President Roosevelt.

KARACHI, India, Aug. 24 (Delayed) -- Another batch of American pilots and their crews flew into Karachi this evening, swelling the ever-growing air strength of the United Nations in India and disproving the story believed in New York that everything has had to go to Egypt.

Georges Theunis, Belgian Ambassador Extraordinary to the United Slates, announced yesterday that he had received from the Belgian authorities in Leopoldville, Belgian Congo, a cablegram saying that 3,000 Greek refugees, most of whom are women and children, had arrived in Leopoldville recently.

A threatened strike of 15,000 local truck drivers drew nearer last night when union and employer representatives disagreed on a formula for settling their wage dispute through arbitration. A general stoppage when the present contract expires at midnight Monday would tie up the movement of vital war materials, including shipments for the armed forces.

The American Republics Trading Corporation, formed about a year ago to engage in exporting and importing heavy materials between the United States and South American countries, particularly the Argentine, has leased space on the sixteenth floor of the Time Life Building in Rockefeller Center for its first New York office.

A $60,000 gift by the women's dress industry of this city to the Greater New York Fund was made last night at a testimonial dinner to Adam L. Gimbel, president of Saks Fifth Avenue, at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Delayed in Hollywood by retakes of her new picture, "Keeper of the Flames," Katharine Hepburn will not be arriving in the Theatre Guild's production of the Philip Barry play, "Without Love," at the St. James the week of Oct. 5.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 -- R.J. Thomas, president, and other high officials of the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) sent a telegram to President Roosevelt today requesting a conference before the end of the week on "an imminent threat to continuity of key war production."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The Department of Agriculture will parallel the ceiling prices to be put on livestock by the Office of Price Administration with "floor" prices at about the level of parity, it was stated today.

The main contention of V.R. Emmanuel -- that suspenders (or braces, as we British call them) surpass belts as a means of holding up trousers is well taken; but he is in error as to some collateral facts. Points, in Elizabethan costume, so far from being galluses, were the tie strings of trunk hose; therefore more nearly related to the belt.
Today's lone new film arrival is "Just Off Broadway," a melodrama starring Lloyd Nolan and Marjorie Weaver, which opens at the Rialto.
Governor Lehman, who opposed Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for the Democratic nomination for Governor, announced yesterday that he would support Mr. Bennett and the rest of the State ticket.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 27 -- Mrs. Samuel Seabury was the speaker this morning at the Red Cross Rooms on Main Street, and Mrs. Elliott Maxwell presented pins to ninety-eight children, who for two months have been making articles in the Red Cross workroom for service and civilian use.

The report of the United States Guarantee Company made public yesterday, shows total admitted assets on June 30 increased to $20,549,703 from $19,448,797 a year earlier. Included in the assets are bond and stock investments of $15,214,036 which compared with $13,482,406 at the close of June, 1941.

With drastic regulations affecting every phase of intrastate trucking, whether by common carriers or private operators, becoming effective on Tuesday, the War Transportation Committee of the State War Council appealed to all truckers yesterday to cooperate in the effort to clarify the new rulings.

A new type of rectifying column to permit production by "highwine" distillers of 190-proof alcohol, the proof needed by war agencies, without the use of critical materials has been developed by the Schenley Distillers Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Carl J. Kiefer, vice president in charge of production.

The trade anticipates a very lively season in Christmas cards. The times are serious and millions of families have been disrupted for the duration. First thought goes out to the men at the front and in the camps. Next come the war workers, men and women, away from home.
MOSCOW, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:

The increase in juvenile delinquency since the war began is due to "restlessness" in youth seeking adventure, Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt said yesterday at a reception given for her by the Young Men's Vocational Foundation in Reuben's Restaurant, 6 East Fifty-eighth Street.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 27 -- All other measures in a desperate situation having failed at Crosley Field today, Manager Mel Ott resorted to the time-honored squeeze play and the Giants beat the Reds in the eleventh inning. The score was 2 to 0.

The American Export Lines Flying Ace, carrying fourteen trans-atlantic passengers, arrived at the marine base yesterday at La Guardia Field, establishing what officials said was a flying time record for the Westbound voyage. The new time, including stops and other delays, was twenty-two hours and twelve minutes, reducing the previous elapsed time mark by twenty-nine minutes.

The stock market negotiated yesterday its first general upturn of the week, but the volume was too light to make the advance a worthwhile affair. The war news admittedly had a place in the day's factors, as the dispatches from the Russian front turned better for the first time in weeks and the American successes in the Solomon Islands area were magnified.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 27 -- Five Norwegians were sentenced to death today by the German military court of Oslo and three others to five, three and two years' imprisonment, respectively, because they allegedly belonged to British-inspired patriotic organizations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Officials of the War Production Board said today that Donald M. Nelson, chairman, had not yet decided how the new priorities procedure would be instituted and that the effective date of the proposal has not been established.
