Several hundred parents attended a special term of the Queens Supreme Court in Jamaica yesterday to hear a clash of arguments over whether the Board of Education has the right to transfer children from a school in Forest Hills because of crowded conditions.

The Right Honorable Peter Fraser, P.C., Prime Minister of New Zealand, came to Washington just about a year ago. He is there again. He is an old friend. By way of welcome there is nothing much to say except that Americans like him and his countrymen even better than they did.
LONDON, Aug. 27 -- The stock markets were cheerful today on the news of the counter-offensive launched by the Russians and further details of the Battle of the Solomon Islands.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- American shipbuilders, engaged in the greatest merchant-ship construction program of all time as an aid to the war effort, will observe Labor Day by launching six 10,500-ton liberty ships named after leaders of organized labor, the Maritime Commission said today.

DETROIT, Aug. 27 -- The American Bar Association closed its annual convention today with an attack by the patent section on Assistant Attorney General Thurman Arnold's war-patent pronouncements and recommended legislation.

For many weeks the Treasury has made a practice of calling on its commercial bank depositaries for funds to be turned over to it on Mondays and Tuesdays, and then issuing another call for Thursdays and Fridays. Yesterday the Treasury followed this pattern by announcing that it would withdraw $145,642,000 on next Monday and a like amount on the following day from commercial bank depositaries throughout the country.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, Aug. 28 -- Fighting is in progress to push out the Japanese from the Milne Bay area on the southeastern tip of New Guinea, where they landed in force Tuesday night. No further details were made public by the United Nations headquarters spokesman today when he issued General Douglas MacArthur's communique, which said that "action between ground forces is developing."

The sinking of three Allied merchant ships by submarines in a single night recently in the Caribbean area was revealed yesterday when the stories of survivors who had been landed at an East Coast port were released by the Navy. More than thirty persons were listed as probably lost, including three passengers, one of whom was a woman.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Amateur Trapshooting Association's "noble experiment" of boosting the $10,000 Grand American Handicap from 100 to 200 targets appeared futile today as the unknowns took charge just as they have for the last forty-two years.

Formation of the American section of the Free World Association was announced yesterday by the association. Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, former United States Minister to Norway, is chairman of the new section, which will organize activities throughout the country to carry out the world-wide program of the association for victory and post-war justice.

Price-fixing operations by the trade and covering of short positions by local traders were met by hedging and New Orleans selling in late trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, keeping prices on an even keel after the market had been irregular earlier in the day.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Southern Association of Commissioners of Agriculture voted unanimously at a meeting here today to join the movement to hold the 1942 cotton crop in government loan until a 21.47-cent price is reached.

Definite indications that the dress industry is moving rapidly to protect itself against the threatened stoppage of work on garments not carrying Dress Institute labels were given yesterday when the sale of such labels was reported to have risen 500 per cent in the last two days over last week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The following table shows the distribution of major war supply contracts and facilities projects of the Army, Navy, Maritime Commission, Treasury and the British Empire by States, cumulative through June of this year:

Following discussions of the shortage of silver brought about by the Silver Purchase Act, which all week have dominated the annual convention of the American National Retail Jewelers Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, the association, at the closing session yesterday, went ahead with plans to seek the release of Treasury-held metal.

Resolutions pledging wholehearted support to Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, and assuring Edward J. Flynn of "unswerving support of his leadership" were adopted last night at a meeting of the Bronx Democratic County Committee in the Bronx High School of Science, East 184th Street and Crescent Avenue, the Bronx.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Bears are generally favored to beat the College All-Stars tomorrow night before 101,000 spectators in Soldier Field, but their owner and coach, George Halas, ventures an on-the-spot prediction that this year's game "will be a lot tougher than last year's."

Bemelmans the bon vivant, the wearer of pink glasses that looked on a part of the world that had a sort of pink aura anyway, is out for the duration. He will be, that is, after one more book about "the fat and easy life." This is "I Love You, I Love You, I Love You," bound in yellow with pink decorations and covered by a jacket in shocking pink.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 27 -- The Crown Zellerbach Corporation and subsidiaries reported today for the three months ended on July 31, first quarter of its new fiscal year, net profits of $1,803,147 after all charges, provision for Federal taxes and minority interest.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (U.P.) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board ordered Pan-American Aairways, Inc., tonight to show cause why present mail rates from New York to Europe and from New York to Bermuda should not be reduced. Pan-American received fifteen days to make its reply.

BETTY BAUR is an American, a graduate of Cambridge, a pianist, a sheet-metal worker in a New England plane factory, and has a husband in the Army. And that small budget of information is absolutely all her publishers have chosen, or been allowed, to make available about the talented author of an unusually good first novel, "The White Queen."*

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- A senatorial investigation into the extent of control of James C. Petrillo and his American Federation of Musicians over music in the United States and the effects of his restrictive orders on national wartime morale and welfare was called for today in a resolution offered by Senator Clark of Idaho.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- An aviation engineer battalion composed of Negro troops performed "exceptionally meritorious" service in New Caledonia immediately prior to the Battle of the Coral Sea, Secretary Stimson said this morning.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- Baseball's advisory council today announced a plan for division of world series receipts which would net the Red Cross and United Service Organizations $357,544 if the series went four games and $679,006 if it went the limit of seven contests.

If Russia is unable to hold back the Germans, the need in Great Britain for continued war relief contributions from the United States will be "enormous," Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the British War Relief Society and chairman of the board of the British War Relief Society, told a group of luncheon guests yesterday at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.

The item in THE TIMES telling of the "hell of a time" Congressman Sasscer says he would have trying to sing "The Star-Spangled Banner" in case it is to be sung by all members of Congress over a world-wide radio hook-up in observance of the 128th anniversary of the composition of the national anthem, on Sept. 13, is not such a trifling matter as might be supposed.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Not content with pitching a two-hitter, Hank Gornicki hit a homer and a single to score two of the Pirates' runs in blanking the Braves, 5 -- 0, today.

Playing with three partners in yesterday's invitation best-ball event of the Long Island Golf Association at the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing, Mal Galletta of North Hills clicked with one of them to capture low net honors.

BOSTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A revamped Cleveland line-up beat the Red Sox, 4 to 2, today and burst two Boston bubbles -- Pitcher Tex Hughson's run of eleven consecutive victories and the Red Sox string of nine straight triumphs.

The addresses made by Catholic churchmen and teachers at the Inter-American Seminar of Social Studies are a notable contribution to current thinking on the moral issues of the war and on the tremendous tasks of social reconstruction that will come after it.

The Board of Transportation held yesterday the first of a series of conferences with representatives of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O. affiliate, to discuss that organization's four-point program affecting the 34,000 employes of the city's unified transit system.

LONDON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Russians from the east and British and American Allies from the west are engaged in a whipsaw aerial pounding against German-occupied Europe, it became apparent tonight, with Soviet raids on Berlin and East German towns to which Ruhr and Rhineland industries have been moved, and continued attacks launched from Britain.

The Intercontinental Rubber Company yesterday reported for six months ended on June 30 a net income of $177,553 after all charges and taxes, equal to 30 cents each on the 595,832 capital common shares outstanding. This compares with $149,908, or 25 cents a share, for the similar period of 1941.

The leaders of organized labor have appealed to the President to leave the wage "stabilization" authority in the hands of the National War Labor Board. They do not want any other agency with power to veto WLB decisions. Their solicitude is not difficult to understand.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Eight States received more than half of the $80,338,688,000 in major war supply and plant contracts from the beginning of the defense program to the end of June, a War Production Board tabulation showed today.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 27 -- Plans for complete modernization of educational activity, employing motion pictures, pictorial magazines, mobile broadcasting units, public address systems, tabloid newspapers, and dramatic troupes, have been announced through the Political Training Board of the National Military Council.

Privates, noncoms and commissioned officers on furlough joined with the ranking amateurs in the civilian ranks yesterday to inaugurate the wartime national championships at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 27 -- As enemy concentrations pile up behind a screening front of artillery and infantry, attacks by British fighter and light bomber planes become more and more effective in spreading destruction.

Many WPA workers who have not the slightest chance of getting other employment are being dismissed daily. Most of these people are middle-aged or elderly. Even in normal times, no matter how capable they might be, they would be rejected by private employment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Prices in primary markets continued at the highest levels in nearly sixteen years in the week ended on Aug. 22, and the Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of wholesale prices remained unchanged at 98.9 per cent of the 1926 average.

Pat Collins, portrait painter and former pugilist, will put aside the palette and the easel this morning to join the Coast Guard. He will be sworn into the service by Chief Boatswain's Mate John Jorgensen at 1 State Street.

The delivery of two large packing cases at Borough Hall, Queens, yesterday for use of the civilian defense corps gave Borough President James A. Burke a real and not too pleasant surprise. The Borough President, who has been demanding that his corps be supplied with helmets and other necessary equipment for emergency work, expected to find in the packing case some equipment of this kind.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- A 30 per cent reduction in traffic fatalities in the country in July from the total for the same month in 1941 was reported today by the National Safety Council.

WITH UNITED STATES AIR FORCES, in the Suez Canal Area, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Stars and Stripes waved smartly in the breeze in front of a tent here today as the latest arrivals from the United States completed their first flag-raising ceremony.

The German High Command said yesterday that bitter Soviet counter-attacks west of Stalingrad against a far-advanced German spearhead had been repulsed and forty Russian tanks destroyed, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 27 -- In a series of dawn-to-dusk raids on enemy aliens throughout Northern New Jersey yesterday, Federal Bureau of Investigation agents visited 250 homes in a score of communities and arrested 100 Germans on Presidential warrants.
LONDON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 27 -- Bobby Mosbacher of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club over in Port Washington, L.I., today retained the championship of the Atlantic Class with the sloop Teal, but in a measure it was a hollow victory, though no fault of his own.

The Ruml pay-as-you-go plan for making current tax payments applicable to current income has unquestionably caught the interest and approval of a very large number of people. Thousands of small taxpayers like the idea of paying their taxes as they go along instead of having a year's debt to the Treasury constantly hanging over their heads.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- The United States Army's Flying Fortresses, escorted by Spitfires of the Royal Air Force, bombed the shipyards and dock basin at Rotterdam this afternoon, maintaining their record for the series of attacks against the Nazis in the past ten days of no planes lost.

LONDON, Aug. 27 (U.P.) -- Dr. Hans Drosch, German Consul General for the Ljubljana district of Croatia, "died suddenly" at the Slon Hotel in Ljubljana, private advices said tonight, and Yugoslav sources hinted he was poisoned by anti-Axis patriots.

Three records were broken yesterday by a special offering of 17,000 shares of United States Steel common stock on the New York Stock Exchange. Sponsored by Smith, Barney Co., the block involved the greatest money value of any special offering so far, was sold to more individual customers and was distributed through more firms.

ATLANTA, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Sandy Beaver of Gainesville resigned today as chairman of the Georgia Board of Regents and as Governor Eugene Talmadge's Chief of Staff, declaring in a letter to the Governor that he was convinced "that nothing can induce you to give up the political dictation which you have set up over education in Georgia."

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- For the second week in a row, Mrs. Frank J. Holleran of Round Hill today won low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association. She carded a 43, 42 -- 85 over the Hudson River Country Club course.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 27 -- Plans for a strike vote among 1,200 employes of the Cornell-Dubilier Corporation were shelved tonight after Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, had recommended that the board in Washington conduct a formal hearing into the circumstances surrounding an election last month in which an A.F. of L. union received the highest vote.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- A pricing method by which retailers and wholesalers of "seasonal commodities," including cold weather apparel items, toys and seasonal sporting goods, may establish ceiling prices was announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

An eleven-room apartment has been leased in 920 Fifth Avenue by Gerald Ritter, president of the Barbizon Corporation, according to Douglas L. Elliman Co., broker, and the Carpenter Realty Company, agents. Warren Marks Associates reported the rental of an apartment in 9 East Fifty-seventh Street to Robsjohn Gibbings, the decorator.

This Fall, for the first time, women are sternly faced with frozen fashions -- skirts and dresses whittled down to pencil slimness, and "fixed" that way by the uncompromising order of the War Production Board. But the terrifying L-85 evinces nary a tremor in the quiet city salon where silhouettes are made to order.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Madigama, from the Brandywine Stable of Donald P. Ross, one of the three executive members at Delaware Park, captured the richest race at the Spa today as the meeting went into its final three days.

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- The body of the Duke of Kent rested tonight in Albert Memorial Chapel of Windsor Castle and will remain there until the funeral. The funeral of King George VI's youngest brother, it was announced tonight, will take place in St. George's Chapel at Windsor.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 27 -- The Japanese are in general retreat from Chuhsien, where China's greatest airfield lies within bomber range of Japan, while their rearguards try to stem the Chinese assault, which has penetrated the outskirts of the burning city, military dispatches said tonight.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 27 -- I.A. Horowitz, New York State title holder, for the first time today met a slight reverse in the open championship of the United States Chess Federation in progress at the Hotel Baker, when, in the tenth round, he was forced to share a point with J.C. Thompson of Dallas, president of the Texas Chess Association.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 27 (U.P.) -- Plans to enroll Brazilian women in war work and train them in industrial and transportation jobs so that male workers might be relieved for military duty got under way today.
MOSCOW, Friday, Aug. 28 (AP) -The Soviet midnight communique:

Bank clearings of the major cities of the country for the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $6,232,341,000, a decline of $1,083,945,000, or 17.4 per cent from the volume of the preceding week, but 5.7 per cent above the $5,897,386,000 recorded in the comparable week last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

MOSCOW, Aug. 27 -- How far the war has materially affected Moscow's life cannot be computed statistically. No statistics are available that throw any light on health, food or family budgets. Nor is Moscow typical of any large part of the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 22 totaled 869,404 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 559 cars or 0.1 per cent more than for the preceding week, 30,384 cars or 3.4 per cent less than for the corresponding week last year, and 108,296 cars or 14.2 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 27 -- George Brent and Miriam Hopkins will appear with Bette Davis in the screen version of "Old Acquaintance," John van Druten's Broadway comedy of the 1940-41 season, Warner Brothers announced today. Brent will play the role of Preston Drake, which Hunter Gardner did in New York, while Miss Hopkins will be seen as Mildred Drake, Peggy Wood's stage character.

A drive to recruit a second battalion of automobile mechanics in the metropolitan area for the Army Ordnance Department was announced yesterday by the Automobile Merchants Association of New York, Inc. Eight county recruiting offices have been opened.
The younger generation of casters will have an inning or two to themselves tomorrow at the thirteenth annual boys' national casting tournament at Ventnor City, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The Office of War Information will begin a radio campaign on Sept. 14 "to inform the American people of the facts of the war effort of the United Nations." The agency described the campaign, which will continue through Oct. 26, as "the most important ever attempted thus far by the United States Government through the medium of radio."

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Officials of the C.I.O. Aluminum Workers of America said tonight that members in five of seven plants of the Aluminum Company of America had voted to reject the War Labor Board's decision denying their request for a general wage increase.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 27 -- Henry J. Kaiser's West Coast shipbuilding company and a Cleveland steel warehouse firm were enjoined today by a temporary writ issued by Federal Court on Office of Price Administration charges that OPA price ceilings on steel had been violated.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Donald M. Nelson, living up to his promise to reorganize the War Production Board for a more even output of war material, took away today from Army and Navy field officers their power to assign preference ratings to individual Army and Navy contracts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The Senate Finance Committee, acting at the request of Leon Henderson, the Price Administrator, voted by 13 to 4 today to eliminate the 5 per cent tax on freight charges adopted by the House. The tax would have produced $171,000,000 in revenue.

LONDON, Aug. 27 (AP) -- The Bank of England's weekly condition statement, issued today, revealed a decrease of 1,771,000 in note circulation. It was the second consecutive week that a loss had been recorded. The decrease was reflected in the bank's reserve which increased almost a similar amount.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, Aug. 27 (AP) -- A Davenport nurse identified only as Mrs. X has been barred from applying for a new automobile for the duration of the war because she attempted to obtain one through deceit, a War Rationing Board official said today.

Because of the many problems which will face retailers in handling their holiday business under wartime conditions this year, the Bureau of Smaller Stores of the National Retail Dry Goods Association will hold a special all-day forum at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Sept. 30.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The age at which skilled men may enlist in the Army has been raised from 45 to 50 years, Secretary Stimson announced today. Also today college students of 18 and 19 were warned that they might be called soon into the armed forces.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

LONDON, Aug. 27 -- A fleet of 5,000 air transports that could bring 1,000,000 men to Britain in fifteen hours and make a transatlantic round trip every four days or move 150,000 tons freight weekly each way was advocated today by E.C. Gordon England, chairman of the Engineering Industries Association.

The Chicago North Western Railway reported yesterday a net railway operating income of $12,120,243 in the first seven months of the year, against $9,717,282 in the same period last year, an increase of 25 per cent. The company is in bankruptcy and the Interstate Commerce Commission's plan of reorganization for it is before the United States Supreme Court for review at the behest of objectors.
C.D. Jackson, formerly general manager of Life, has been appointed administrative vice president of Time, Inc. Andrew Heiskell takes over his former position with Life.
Restoration of American history to its once prominent place in our institutions of learning was advocated in a number of important letters in THE TIMES recently.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Auto "graveyards" of the country have been feeding scrap metal to the steel industry at the rate of more than 400,000 tons a month for four months, Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chairman, said in a radio address here tonight.
Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, announced yesterday morning the appointment of former Assemblyman Herbert Brownell Jr. as his campaign manager.

Nathan R. Sobel, counsel to Governor Lehman, was named by the Kings County Democratic Executive Committee yesterday afternoon as the party nominee for Kings County Judge. Mr. Sobel replaced Justice Edward L. Kelly, who was killed last Saturday in an automobile accident near Amagansett, L.I.

Any previous notions about cotton as a purely Summer fabric were systematically broken down yesterday afternoon by the Cotton Textile Institute and the National Cotton Council at their Autumn and Winter fashion showing for the press in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 27 -- Colonel Edward R. Bradley and his sister, Mrs. Katherine Bradley Bailey, entertained at luncheon yesterday at the Trackside Restaurant for Dr. and Mrs. D. Philip MacGuire, Miss Beatrice Butler MacGuire and Stuart MacGuire.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 -- Holders of September wheat contracts continued today to liquidate and the discount compared with the December widened about 3/8 cent a bushel to 3 3/8 cents, the widest spread so far. Cash houses bought the September and sold the December but there was much out-right selling of the near-by future.

Earnings of the Bendix Aviation Corporation for the nine months ended with June rose $1,527,128 over the comparable period of the previous year, despite its provision for taxes, which were six times the net profit and $50,295,513 larger than the tax deductions for the period in the preceding year.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 27 (UP) -- Former Argentine President Agustin P. Justo's enrollment as an honorary general in the Brazilian Army created a sensation today. General Justo is expected to be a candidate for the Presidency in 1943, campaigning on a strong stand for the United Nations.

ALBANY, Aug. 27 -- Solicitor General Henry Epstein, Democratic candidate for Attorney General to succeed John J. Bennett Jr., called tonight on Thomas E. Dewey, Republican Governorship candidate, "to name the names of the incompetents" whom Mr. Dewey had declared should be swept out of public office.
The following article, the third of several, is by the former Tokyo correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who has just returned to this country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Development of natural resources, new industries and closer trade and labor relations among the peoples of the Western Hemisphere in their mutual interest was urged at today's sessions of the inter-American seminar on social studies by Secretary Wickard and officials of welfare, trade and labor organizations.

This week-end the nation's school leaders, representing every branch of learning from nursery through the university, will gather in Washington to develop a comprehensive program for education during the war crisis. Under the direction of Dr. John W. Studebaker the teachers will consider means of making education a more influential factor in the total war effort.

MOSCOW, Friday, Aug. 28 -- While General Gregory K. Zhukoff's offensive west of Moscow continued to meet with success by recapturing further populated points and breaking into one strongly defended position, the grim battle for Stalingrad grew in ferocity, according to reports released here early today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 27 -- Members of the Summer colony attended the annual entertainment and exhibition of handicraft given this afternon by the children of the Southampton Fresh Air Home for Crippled Children at the headquarters of the home for officers and members of the organization's board of managers.

The largest gain in capital investment in manufacturing for any year during the last sixteen was registered during 1941, when the increase was $5,900,000,000, the Conference Board reported yesterday. The gain, according to the board, was greater than the combined expansion from 1925 through 1929.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- The strong Japanese naval force that attempted to assault United States positions in the Tulagi area of the Solomon Islands has broken off the engagement and "appears to have withdrawn," the Navy Department announced tonight, and there has been no action in the main sea battle off the Solomons in more than twenty-four hours.

The thirty-two apartment building at 4306-12 159th Street, Flushing, L.I., has been sold by the Dardyk Realty Corporation to Cherubina Moramarco, who has conveyed it to Alice Sileo. The building is on a plot 100 by 106 feet and is assessed for $90,000, land and improvements.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) -- Ray Robinson of New York registered his 124th successive ring victory tonight by knocking out rugged Tony Motisi of Chicago in the first round of a scheduled ten-round bout in Comiskey Park.
Federal bureaucracy as a menace to agriculture was the theme of farm organization leaders who spoke here yesterday before representatives of farmer groups in eleven Northeastern States.

After having walked some 400 miles through enemy-occupied territory, a Gurkha, Havildar Singh Bahadur, has just reached the lines of the British Eighth Army, says an Indian Army observer in Egypt, according to a broadcast of the British Official Wireless yesterday that was recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 -- A 3,500-mile round-about transcontinental trip, punctuated by almost daily visits to Army, Navy and Marine camps, bases or military establishments, has shown some of the strengths and weaknesses of the country at war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Thanks largely to an increase in corporation net incomes, taxes in 1942 produced nearly $5,000,000,000 of State revenues, 10 per cent more than the 1941 figure, according to a census report today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 27 -- The circumstances that neither the Rumanian Government nor Marshal Ion Antonescu, the Premier, officially took cognizance of the death of Deputy Regent Stephen Horthy of Hungary or dispatched delegations to today's funeral have provoked considerable comment in diplomatic circles in Budapest, says a special dispatch to the Basler Nachrichten.

The return match between Cleo Shans, Los Angeles lightweight, and Maxie Shapiro of the East Side will headline the card at Madison Square Garden tonight. This pair, who engaged in a sizzling struggle in a preliminary bout on the Garden card two weeks ago, so thrilled the onlookers that Matchmaker Nat Rogers of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club elevated them to main-bout status as a natural procedure.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 -- Hector J. Dowd, an investigator for the War Production Board, disclaimed today all responsibility for the language used in a WPB press statement relative to a report of his investigation into charges that there was "a black market" in steel.

WATCH out! Five football games are coming along with a rush. Yes, sir, it's that late already. Recent gossip about fuel oil rationing for home heating gave householders a chilly reminder that Summer doesn't last forever. With football ready for the kick-off, Autumn must be hard at hand. "Good-bye, Summer, Goodbye," with music by Tosti.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 -- Henry J. Kaiser, whose company is accused by the Office of Price Administration of buying steel on "black market terms," denied tonight that it had violated OPA price regulations and said that to the best of his knowledge, "our actions were entirely legal."

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation reports in its statement covering the twenty-six weeks ended on June 27, for publication today, a consolidated net profit of $2,190,894, after $1,250,000 provision for Federal taxes on income and $3,100,000 reserve for foreign assets.

CHICAGO, August 28 AP -- Prices of hogs responded today to the possibility of price ceilings by dropping 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight. The top price declined to $15 from S15.10, which had been held for seven days. The decline was aided by the arrival of 1,000 head more than had been expected.

The sale of the Flushing Bus Terminal at 136-48 Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing, Queens, to Vincent Astor for use by the American Air Lines and the American Export transoceanic air line was announced yesterday by the Blackstone-Dasey Realty Company in Flushing.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, Aug. 29 -- Heavy fighting is progressing at Milne Bay, Southeastern New Guinea, where allied forces are seeking to push out a comparatively small party of Japanese who landed there on Tuesday night. This was announced in today's communique from General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28--The American people may be asked to observe one meatless day a week in the near future, to save shipping space needed for the movement of war weapons to fighting fronts, President Roosevelt said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Counsel for a stockholder of the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation charged today that the public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission had attempted to "whitewash" the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation in approving a plan for dissolution of its subsidiary, Columbia Oil.

Fred A. Poor, president of Poor Co., manufacturers of supplies for railroads, informed stockholders yesterday in the semi-annual operating statement that officers and directors are anxious to clear up accumulated class A dividends as soon as possible.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- Mr. and Mrs. John H. Rogan entertained at their annual party after the races yesterday for George H. Bull, president of the Racing Association, and John A. Morris, secretary-treasurer, and Mrs. Morris.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 28 -- With Summer waning fast the possibility of another Winter campaign in Europe is much discussed. The Tribune de Geneve, says the German High Command, is calling upon its Army for great efforts to spare it and the rear another Winter of war.
When the scribes gather to cast their ballots for the National League's most valuable player, Mel Ott is one they can't fail to consider.

As the magazine Asia points out in its current issue, this is an anniversary in China. One hundred years ago today the Treaty of Nanking was signed on the deck of a British battleship in the Yangtze River. Out of that treaty came the system of "extraterritoriality'' under which foreigners (Americans included) have now enjoyed for a full century special rights in China which have been humiliating to that country and destructive to its sovereignty.

May I give a few words of advice to the boys from 16 to 20 who to aspire to go into the Navy V-7 or V-5 courses for commissions as ensigns and to those who wish to join the Army Air Force as aviation cadets?

Japan claimed complete victory yesterday in both phases of the Solomons battle in an unusual nation-wide broadcast by Captain Hideo Hiraide, spokesman for the navy section of Japanese Imperial Headquarters, according to Japanese broadcasts recorded in New York by the United Press.

MOSCOW, Aug. 28 -- In the stress of battle during the early stages of what was at first called the Germans' Kursk offensive, which developed into an attack on Voronezh, little news was released of the fighting in the central Russian highlands between Kursk and the Don River.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UP) -- Nicholas Zonarich, president of the C.I.O. Aluminum Workers of America, deferred today until next week a decision on whether to call a strike in seven plants of the Aluminum Company of America, which produce most of the aluminum needed for the nation's war effort.

NEWTON, N.J., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Approval by Vice Chancellor Henry T. Kays of a compromise board of directors recently named for the Breeze Corporations, Inc., of Newark and Elizabeth, was delayed today when Eugene Garey of New York, as attorney, challenged the agreement under which the board was selected.

James B. Reston begins his argument in "Prelude to Victory" with an aphorism from Somarset Maugham: "If a nation values anything more than freedom, it will lose its freedom; and the irony of it is that if it is money or comfort that it values more, it will lose that too."

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Aleutian Islands were described today by Captain Leland P. Lovett, director of the Navy's Office of Public Relations, as being "a great natural rat trap" for the Japanese.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- W.W. Colpitts of Coverdale Colpitts, consulting engineers in New York City, has advised the Interstate Commerce Commission that he is withdrawing his application to be a director of the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad Company and the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad Corporation while continuing to be a director of the Pete Marquette and the Seaboard Air Line railway companies.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- With six named for the mile and three-quarters of the Saratoga Cup, and eleven for the Hopeful, the month-long meeting of the Saratoga Association will come to an end here tomorrow, an achievement in devotion to tradition, even though behind last year in the matter of business.

The United States Conciliation Service took steps yesterday to intervene in the threatened strike of 15,000 truck drivers in New York City. At the same time spokesmen for three locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, while insisting that the last thing they desired was a strike, held to their demand that Hugh E. Sheridan, impartial chairman of the trucking industry of New York City, act as arbitrator.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 28 (AP) -- E.C. Eastwood's Challamore today ran six furlongs in 1:11, the fastest sprint of the meeting, to win the $1,600 What Cheer purse at Narragansett Park. The favored Challamore, took the lead at the start and held it to win by three and a quarter lengths from the Brookmead Stable's Yarrow Maid.
WITH THE ARMY ON DESERT TRAINING MANOEUVRES, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Army will send a group of men into the California Desert next week, to give the new emergency K-2 ration its first test in the field.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Meeting competition not even remotely resembling that from which they suffered in St. Louis, the champion Dodgers today breezed to a 7-1 triumph over the sixth-place Cubs before a ladies' day crowd of 25,601 at Wrigley Field.

This year government officials are spiritedly urging housekeepers to cultivate the old-fashioned, domestic art of canning at home. They are making this plea in a spirit of conservation, anticipating a record national harvest. For victory gardens, fostered by single families or whole communities, are sprouting up where they never grew before, and farmers, working on a wartime basis, are energetically enlarging their crops to meet unprecedented goals set by Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 29 -- While General Gregory K. Zhukoff's offensive on the front west of Moscow continued to develop satisfactorily with the capture of more inhabited points, the great battle northwest of Stalingrad raged throughout yesterday without any further appreciable German gains, according to the Soviet communique issued early today.

Among the outstanding records of increased production in recent months has been the production of loud and denunciatory blasts by Congressmen, Senators, Government officials and others directed at various industries and individuals who are charged with having held up the supply of vital materials for their own selfish or shortsighted ends.
SCHENECTADY, Aug. 28 -- Forty "pioneer women," in slacks instead of mother-hubbards, have proved their worth in industrial engineering.

The writer just has returned from a canoe trip on the upper Hudson River which forms part of the Champlain Canal. It is believed that the attention of other potential vacationists should be drawn to a situation existing in the up-State waterways. Lock-keepers on the Champlain and Erie Canals have been forbidden to permit canoes to pass through the locks alone or with other vessels.

In last Saturday's NEW YORK TIMES there appeared for the entertainment of your readers a letter which hailed Fordham University as a football paragon, a paragon which exists in the minds of every Fordham fan.

BOSTON, Aug. 28 -- The Associated Industries of Massachusetts reported today orders booked by a combined group of Bay State industries during July showed a continuance of the decline from the peak achieved last April. The decline from June was about 10 per cent; that from the April peak has been approximately 28 per cent.

ALBANY, Aug. 28 -- Six big bound volumes, said to contain the names of 50,000 voters, were filed in the Election Bureau of the Secretary of State's Office this afternoon in behalf of Communist candidates for State offices.

MOSCOW, Aug. 28 -- The Russian air raids on Germany and East Prussia Wednesday night were on a greater scale than any others the Red Air Force accomplished since the war began, and as the communique showed they ranged over a wide area of Eastern, Northeastern and Central Germany.

The seasonal lull in new financing here was emphasized further this week by the flotation of only one issue of bonds for public subscription. Amounting to $1,000,000, this lone municipal issue compared with offerings of $3,917,500 in the preceding week, when there were three flotations, and with $38,491,000 for six offerings in this week in 1941.

The first Tri-State Savings Bank Life Insurance Conference will be held at New London, Conn., Sept. 11 to 13, it was announced here yesterday by the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York. Representatives of savings banks in Massachusetts, New York and Connecticut that are now participating in the issuance of savings bank life insurance will gather to map plans for the extension of the system under wartime conditions.

Leonora Corbett, co-star of "Blithe Spirit," and John F. Royal, vice president of NBC, will be married at noon today in Miss Corbett's apartment at the Hotel Pierre, it was announced last night. Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora will perform the ceremony. Mrs. Fred Bate will be the bride's only attendant. Mr. Bate will be best man.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 28 (AP) -- With the pennant excitement of the Brooklyn series still in their veins, the Cardinals took a twin bill from Philadelphia today, gaining a half-game on Brooklyn. The Dodgers, who trampled Chicago, 7 to 1, had their lead cut to five games.
LONDON, Aug. 28 -- The tempo of the Allied air offensive against Germany and German-held territory in Western Europe was stepped up a bit higher through last night and today.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 29 (AP) -- A Nazi armored spearhead northwest of Stalingrad was reported fighting for its life today against encircling Soviet mortar and anti-tank crews, while a Russian communique said the Red Army still was battling the Germans in the outskirts of Rzhev in the offensive west of Moscow.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Detroit made three runs in the fourteenth inning here today to defeat Washington, 10 to 7. Each team was forced to use four pitchers. Hal White was the winning hurler.

The Parks Department is going to have a dance contest for fox trotters, waltzers, rhumba artists and even jitterbugs. Elimination rounds will be held in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, on Sept. 8, on the Central Park Mall Sept. 9, in Poe Park, the Bronx, Sept. 10; in Forest Park, Queens, on Sept. 15, and McDonald Playground in Staten Island on Sept. 16.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- A plan to rehabilitate the art treasures, the manuscripts, literature and famous buildings of Spain and to encourage the movement of tourists from the twenty-one American republics to Spain after the war was outlined today by President Roosevelt, who said it was predicated on the Spanish Government's remaining neutral in this war, as this country hoped it would remain.

LONDQN, Aug. 28 (U.P.) -- Secret new anti-aircraft guns and a system of "defense in depth" will meet any large-scale resumption of German air attacks against Britain this Winter, it was disclosed today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 28 -- A 320-year-old cannon that once defended the bastions of La Rochelle, France, has been given by Mayor Stanley W. Church on behalf of this city to a scrap metal committee for melting into modern armaments, and tonight the Mayor's act drew protests from historians, one terming it "vandalism."

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 28 -- The mother of an ailing child whose diet requires bananas prompted an investigation this week that led to the issuance of a warning to two Newark produce dealers who had raised the price of the fruit above the March ceiling set by the Office of Price Administration, it was disclosed today by Nathan L. Jacobs, chief attorney for the OPA in New Jersey.

When Secretary of Agriculture Wickard stated recently that he now favored stabilizing farm prices in order to halt inflation it was hailed as a splendid example of a broad-minded reversal of policy. Unfortunately the Secretary qualified his opinion by suggesting that if the grower was found to need further compensation it could be handed him in the form of a subsidy.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- A Treasury compilation showed today that appropriations and contract authorizations for the war program now totaled more than $220,000,000,000.
This will be the last week-end for most of the trout fishermen in the State, as Monday will be the final day of the season in all but Rockland County, where the currain falls on Sept. 7.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null approved yesterday a certificate of incorporation of the United Seamen's Service, Inc., a new organization for assistance and relief to merchant seamen, sponsored by the heads of the United States War Shipping Administration, the National Maritime Union, and the Seamen's Union of the Pacific.

As George Stewart made a heroine for his novel "Storm" out of a near-gale that struck California, Edward J. Nichols has done a book in which the hero is an oil refinery. "Danger! Keep Out" is the story of the refinery's transition from a minor community enterprise to a large modern industry.
BOSTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Joe Dobson pitched his third shutout of the season today, blanking the White Sox with four scattered hits as the Red Sox took the opener of a two-game series, 4 -- 0.

TENAFLY, N.J., Aug. 28 -- Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches won low gross honors in the weekly one-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association over the Knickerbocker Country Club course today, when she turned in a score of 39, 39 -- 78.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 28 -- Rhyming ill with the Germans' loud public praise of the population of Dieppe for its attitude during the recent raid, second-hand reports received here from Dieppe via Paris show that the Germans actually shot eleven Dieppe civilians, in addition to imprisoning several hundred immediately after the raid.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Marshall Field, founder of The Chicago Sun, declared today that the suit against The Associated Press, "brought following a complaint filed with the Department of Justice by The Chicago Sun," would if successful "prove to be one of the most important strokes for freedom of the press in the history of American journalism."

A bull market reminiscent of World War I days developed yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. While gains of around $4 a bale later were halved, the cotton market experienced its sharpest rally in several years. Since the Fall of 1940 the price of the staple has more than doubled, and this advance always has reflected developments in Washington rather than supply and demand.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 28 -- Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler gave a dinner tonight at their home. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Harry Pelham Robbins, Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Higgins, the Duke and Duchess de Richelieu, Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Duncan Preston and Mr. and Mrs. John H. Morice.
The Home Owners Loan Corporation has sold the two-family house at 527 Sixty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, to a client for occupancy through Michael P. Curnin, broker. The co-broker was James Cotter.

CHUNGKING, China, Saturday, Aug. 29 -- Chinese troops yesterday recaptured Chuhsien and Lishiu and their major airfields, located about 800 miles by bombing flight from Japan, the Chinese Army Command announced today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- The power-scoring Chicago Bears, champions of professional football the last two years, swamped the College All-Stars, 21 to 0, before a record-breaking throng of 101,100 at Soldier Field tonight, thus upholding their reputation of never losing a game in four appearances in this annual pre-season classic.

Despite the honest differences that exist among them, one hundred scientists, philosophers and theologians are meeting on the common ground of scholarship and culture at Columbia University today. Leaders in their fields, these men realize that the democratic way of life can be preserved only through the combined efforts of all freedom-loving citizens, regardless of intellectual disagreements that may exist.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug 28 -- Faced with a drastic shortage of fuel oil which may hamper war production, New England leaders are trying to work out some plan to provide the much needed supplies before Winter comes.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 28 -- Alarmed at the prospect of spoilage of hundreds of tons of tomatoes from a bumper crop now reaching its peak in Hew Jersey and Eastern Pennsylvania, the Campbell Soup Company here issued an urgent appeal today for the immediate employment of 500 men and boys.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 (AP)--Walter Judnich's tenth-inning home run gave the Browns a 5-to-4 victory over the Athletics today after Glenn McQuillen had delivered a homer in the ninth that robbed the Mackmen of a 4-3 decision.
DETROIT, Aug. 28 -- The first bomber to roll off the Willow Run Assembly line now has a name, but the date of its premiere has not been disclosed.

Fluid milk distributors in New York City, faced with an automatic price rise next Tuesday of nearly half a cent a quart to farmers producing fluid milk and cream for the city's millions of consumers, are considering the institution of legal action which will be the first test case of wartime ceiling prices fixed by the Office of Price Administration, headed by Leon Henderson, it became known here last night.

Robert McLean, president of The Associated Press, issued the following statement yesterday on behalf of the board of directors of that organization, commenting on the government's anti-trust suit against it:
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 28 -- The United Steel Workers asserted in a statement today that man days lost by strikes in the first six months of this year amounted to only .09 of 1 per cent.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- The mother of June Morris, dark-haired, 17-year-old canteen worker, said today that a newspaper report that her daughter was engaged to the Hon. Gerald Lascelles, 18-year-old nephew of King George VI and son of the Earl of Harewood and the Princess Royal, was correct.

Retail trade this week continued to follow the pattern of the last few weeks, running about 5 per cent behind the comparative 1941 period. But store executives reported that, with the exception of furniture and hostery, business in general was fairly good.

KARACHI, India, Aug. 26 (Delayed) -- How the war has shaken up the world came home to the people of Karachi today when 1,500 Polish peasant women and children arrived on two ships. Their husbands and fathers are dispersed all over the Middle East in Polish legions or are prisoners in German camps or are dead.

Varying a little the slogan of the horse-leach, the Nazis in France are crying Give-up, Give-up. They demand the round-up in both the occupied and unoccupied zones of all the refugees, Austrian, Baltic, Czech, German, Polish, who have sought safety in France since 1936. Miners and farm laborers must be had in Silesia and Poland.

Edward P. Berger, 21 years old, a bespectacled, undersized machine operator with an obsession for punching and kicking his 3-year-old son and namesake and sometimes his wife, Catherine, when he is intoxicated, was sent to Elmira Reformatory yesterday by Judge Saul S. Streit in General Sessions.

KARACHI, India, Aug. 27 (Delayed) -- An American entering this gate of India finds himself caught between two fires -- British and Indian. Both sides have their case and they present it with such complete conviction and force that the neutral observer is bewildered. He has only a choice between black or white; take it or leave it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Repeal of the capital stock and declared value excess profits taxes, which have been under attack by business concerns for years, was voted today by the Senate Finance Committee on recommendation of the Treasury.

Little Phil Rizzuto, the half-pint shortstop of the Yankees, moved like two streaks of lightning at the Stadium yesterday, and this singular performance, along with Buddy Rosar's second homer of the year, which dropped like a clap of thunder in the right-field stand, was more than enough to sink Lou Boudreau's Indians, 3 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Representative Alfred L. Bulwinkle, Speaker pro tempore, said today that he would not summon a quorum of the House to return to Washington Monday for an effort to complete enactment of the bill designed to enable service men and women of the armed forces and auxiliaries here and abroad to participate in the November election.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 28 -- A new anti-Jewish statute for Bulgaria has been approved by the Council of Ministers. It is drastic in its confiscatory provisions and general prohibitions in regard to personal and commercial freedom. It creates a Commissariat for Jewish Affairs, which is empowered to put the law into effect.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, was invited today by Representative Fulmer, chairman of the House Committee on Agriculture, to take a trip with him into rural areas and find out what farmers were actually receiving for their product.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- An experimental plan for budgeting the use of materials by prime war contractors is being tried out by the War Production Board and, if successful, will be incorporated into the board's general program for controlling the flow of materials Amory Houghton, director general for operations, announced today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- The meat industry, the farmers, cattle feeders, packers and retail butchers, joined today in asserting that all other alternatives for reducing meat consumption should be exhausted before reviving the meatless days of the last war as proposed by President Roosevelt.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Federal Judge W. Calvin Chestnut ruled today that immigration officials may not return a deserting seaman to the site of his government-in-exile but must return him to his native country or allow him to remain in the United States.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 28 -- The caliber of the Russian resistance in the Stalingrad sector is not denied in Berlin military quarters, but the German High Command, it is said there, took all eventualities, even the prospect of a Russian comeback, into its deliberations when it launched its Summer offensive.

Well fortified in varsity talent but completely uncertain in reserve strength, the Brooklyn football Dodgers and the Green Bay Packers will fire away at each other at Ebbets Field at 6:15 this evening in an exhibition game which will open gridiron hostilities hereabouts.

Increases in non-residential building and in heavy engineering work during the first seven months of 1942 largely offset the curtailment in private residential building due to war restrictions, with the result that the total amount of building contracts awarded in the metropolitan New York and Northern New Jersey area was only slightly below the figure for the same period last year.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 28 -- The application of Mrs. Luethy Behmer of 8715 Third Avenue, North Bergen, for an annulment of her marriage to John Behmer, who killed their two sons on Jan. 12, 1941, was granted today in Chancery Court here on the ground that the husband, unknown to the wife, was insane at the time of their marriage.
FORT DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Representative Edith Nourse Rogers of Massachusetts, known as godmother of the Waacs, flew here tonight for a look at her girls and found them good.
Frank Parker, the highest ranking amateur tennis player in the country, made his first appearance of the year before an Eastern gallery yesterday.

ARTHUR KROCK calls book columnists, drama critics and movie reviewers the "chartered libertines of the press." To use a telling Americanism, they are always perfectly free to dish it out, but they seldom have to take it. When a reader complains by a letter, they can put the complaint into what Leon Henderson calls the "Dear Sir, You cur" file and forget it.

The proclaimed aims of the military clique that plunged Japan into the war and now proposes to bring whole earth under Japanese control sound so fantastic that the outside world might well be tempted to regard them as mere war propaganda or to question the sanity of their authors.

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 28 (UP) -- Documents showing that members of a subversive organization now under investigation planned to assist a Japanese invasion of Australia may be presented to Parliament next week, it was learned today.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 28 (AP) -- James F. Holderman, 32-year-old farmer from Morris, Ill., who has been shooting only three years, today won the forty-third Grand American Handicap -- highest prize in the clay target sport.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 28 (U.P.) -- Private William C. Blythe, 19, of Detroit, an Army deserter who enlisted five months ago to escape possible prison sentence for armed robbery, was shot to death today on a railroad train when he drew a gun on a military policeman returning him to Fort Knox.

TWILIGHT and evening star -- and a football game at Ebbets Field. The gridiron season is on and it's going to be more of a job than ever to follow the flight of the ball and untangle the players on the ground.

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee announced last night a grant of $25,000 to the Ose, the Jewish child care and medical aid agency in France, to provide for the rest of the year for 1,200 Jewish children who will be evacuated "from the danger zone which occupied France has become within the last few weeks."

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- The stock markets today were more active than for some time past. Supplies were small and most dealers found it increasingly difficult to meet buying orders. The weight of money seeking reinvestment kept the gilt-edge issues moving with rises 1-16 to 1/8 point.

Utility companies supplying manufactured gas are notifying all their customers that the War Production Board is limiting the new customers they can accept after Sept. 1, the American Gas Association said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Donald Nelson, production chief, who declared last week that he was going to get tough with anybody who got in the way of war production, received today the resignation of the head of his iron and steel branch, Reese H. Taylor, a dollar-a-year man.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- The coffin with the Duke of Kent's body, borne on a little Royal Air Force ambulance wagon, was driven through the Henry VIII gate at Windsor Castle today. It was covered with the Duke's personal standard which has flown during the past years wherever the Duke was in residence.

EDGEWATER, N.J., Aug. 28 -- A report today by Frank Ellis, president of Local 906, United Automobile Workers Union, C.I.O., that the Ford Motor Company was trying to sell the Edgewater assembly plant in a general policy of union "busting" was denied by W.K. Edmunds, plant superintendent, who characterized the allegation as an effort on the part of Mr. Ellis to gain publicity and a reputation as a union saver.

Dr. Eduardo Grove, first Chilean Minister to Canada, brings the cheering assurance to North Americans -- as all citizens of the United States and Canada are referred to in South America -- that his countrymen are "predominantly pro-United Nations and anti-Axis."
A spontaneous and tremendous public interest has developed in the pay-as-you-go income tax plan, Beardsley Ruml, its author, declared last night in a broadcast over a nation-wide radio network.

The complaint in the government's anti-trust suit against The Associated Press sets out that the AP is a cooperative association of newspaper owners incorporated in New York in 1900, which has its principal offices at 50 Rockefeller Plaza, and is engaged in the business of "collecting and distributing news, information and intelligence in interstate and foreign commerce."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Senate Finance Committee acted quickly today to approve the Treasury's proposal to eliminate the capital stock levies. The capital stock tax is $1.25 per $1,000 declared value of stock. The declared value excess profits tax, which is linked to the capital stock tax, operates when a company makes more than 10 per cent of its declared stock value in profits.

Mayor La Guardia denied yesterday that he had ever said that 100,000 workers would be employed at the new aluminum plant to be built here, and declared that the plant would not employ one-fifteenth of that number.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 28 -- Mike Cestone of Jumping Brook, winner of the metropolitan amateur honors in 1941 and apt to hold on to them for some time to come judging by the look of things, today shot a 75 for a partial hold on the qualifying medal in the Norwood Country Club's sixth annual New Jersey Shore amateur championship.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Expressing confidence that "The Associated Press will get justice in the Federal courts," Colonel Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune and an Associated Press director, today issued a statement regarding the government suit asking the Federal District Court for an order to force the news service to serve any newspaper willing to pay the cost.

LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 29 -- Another huge force of British long-range bombers, probably numbering at least 650, was believed to have smashed last night for the second straight night at German war factories, less than twelve hours after an American Flying Fortress assault on a French aircraft works.

More than fifty "pools" of small industrial plants have been formed in New York City to produce war material either as prime contractors or subcontractors, George A. Sloane, New York City Commerce Commissioner, said yesterday. Members of these pools were brought together and assisted by Mr. Sloane's department and the local offices of the War Production Board.
LONDON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

A destroyer, complete in every detail and with its complement of sailors aboard, made port in Times Square yesterday afternoon and came to rest in the cove formed by Boadway, Seventh Avenue, Forty-third and Forty-fourth Streets. It was a thirty-one-foot model of the 1938 series of destroyers, built to scale and lent to the Navy to be used as a recruiting station.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 28 -- Berliners have no time to spend in air-raid shelters unless it is absolutely necessary, authorities in the Reich capital have decided, and henceforth raids of "just a few planes" will call for a "limited alarm," with no compulsion to seek shelter and during which street and train traffic will continue uninterrupted, it was learned here today.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 28 (AP) -- Armed union men forced a halt in work on the Texas-to-Illinois oil pipeline near Cape Girardeau, Mo., B.E. Hull, general manager of War Emergency Pipeline, Inc., said here today, but he reported tonight that resumption of work tomorrow had been arranged.

German troops forced their way across several more mountain passes in the Caucasus and annihilated dispersed Soviet groups that stood in the way, the High Command declared yesterday, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 28 (U.P.) -- A special Federal court with three judges on the bench today upheld temporarily the OPA's rent ceiling orders in one of the nation's first cases involving contests of the OPA's powers to fix ceilings. The court ruled that Raymond Boyd, an aircraft welder, might remain temporarily at his home at a rent lower than the landlord asked.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Aug. 22 were 246,307,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, United States Department of the Interior. This represented decreases of 109,000 and 17,000 barrels in domestic and foreign stocks, respectively, in the week.

"War Service Sunday" will be observed Nov. 8 by the 8,000 congregations of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, the Rev. Dr. Stuart Nye Hutchison, Moderator of its 1942 General Assembly and chairman of the Presbyterian Wartime Service Commission, announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- With the famed bargain colt, Alsab, installed as top-heavy favorite, seven 3-year-olds were named today to start in the $79,400 American Derby at Washington Park tomorrow.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY ON DESERT TRAINING MANOEUVRES, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Whipping out the side door of a Douglas C-47 with all the precision of rapid fire, eleven Army parachute troopers put on an impressive demonstration of their specialty today within rifle shot of the California desert training headquarters.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Aug. 28 -- Twenty-one holders of a carload of college degrees sat in a Smith College dormitory today as tense as the greenest undergraduate. Gone was the assurance backed by master's degrees, former posts as deans of women and, in one case, a Ph.D.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 -- Corporate simplification proceedings under the "death sentence" clause of the Public Utility Holding Company Act were ordered today against the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and its subsidiary companies by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Cleo Shans, Los Angeles lightweight, punched his way to a ten-round decision over Maxie Shapiro of the East Side in the feature bout at Madison Square Garden last night.

Appointment of Harvey D. Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York, as American Red Cross Commissioner to Great Britain was announced yesterday in Washington by Norman H. Davis, national chairman of the American Red Cross.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 28 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today completed casting of William Saroyan's "The Human Comedy," with the assignment of Lionel Barrymore, Fay Bainter, Spring Byington and Dorothy Morris to leading roles. Mickey Rooney, Van Johnson, Gene Kelly, Marsha Hunt and Henry O'Neill already had been announced for the film, which Clarence Brown will direct starting next week.
BUFFALO, Aug. 28 (AP) -- Miss Winifred C. Stanley, Republican nominee for Representative at Large, regards more domestic women with a feeling akin to awe.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The official reports of twenty-four chaplains, now probably prisoners of the Japanese, added another chapter today to the chronicle of Bataan and Corregidor.

That is September peering around the corner, and according to present indications it is to be a pretty busy month in the theatre. As of yesterday, ten plays and musical works, plus an ice show, were scheduled to open between Aug. 31 and Sept. 30 -- all this opposed to last year's seven.

WINNIPEG, Aug. 28 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Pacific and the Canadian National Railways stated in crop reports issued today that wheat, oats and barley are heavy and of a good grade everywhere in Western Canada, Thirty to thirty-five bushels of wheat to the acre are reported from most districts, with occasional yield of fifty bushels, the Canadian Pacific said.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The obligation of schools and colleges to provide the pre-induction training needed by the nation's armed forces, leaving the Army free to concentrate on the specialized combat training required now as never before in history, was placed as a charge upon the educators of the country today and accepted by them at the opening of the National Institute on Education and the War.

Renting of apartments to out-of-town tenants is active, Sidney and Arthur Diamond, brokers, reported yesterday. They listed seven leases to newcomers to the city as follows: Joseph Alexander, Chadwick L. Rowe, Mrs. Kathryn Ahearn, Charles Gold, Mrs. Flora Lubelski, in 177 East Seventy-seventh Street, and David H. Millinger and Mrs. Edward S. Sykes Jr. in 170 East Seventy-seventh Street.

The Rev. James Z. Nettinga, who for the last two years has been pastor of the East Eighty-ninth Street Reformed Church, between Park and Madison Avenues, has accepted an appointment as secretary for young people's work with the board of education of the Reformed Church in America, 156 Fifth Avenue.

Dr. Harriet Van Buren Peckham, pioneer Brooklyn woman physician and widow of Dr. Stephen S. Peckham, scientist and historian, was fatally injured yesterday when she was struck by a taxicab in Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn. Dr. Peckham, who was 81 years old, lived at the Congregational Home for the Aged at 123 Linden Boulevard.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- Nine high-ranking Czech Army officers -- all members of the former Czechoslovak General Staff -- have been executed following sentence by the German People's Court at Prague, according to news reaching London today.

LONDON, Aug. 28 (U.P.) -- The Royal Air Force's devastating offensive against Germany this year has completely wiped out a total of about five and a half square miles of nine of the largest German cities and made at least 1,000,000 persons homeless, according to information from official and other reliable British sources.

The United States Government filed suit in the Federal district court here yesterday in a civil action against The Associated Press, charging it with violating the Sherman and Clayton anti-trust acts. Under the direction of Assistant Attorney General Thurman Arnold, who is in charge of anti-trust prosecutions, Charles H. Weston, a special assistant to the Attorney General, came here from Washington to file the 14,000-word complaint.
Electrical Wire and Cable Concern to Receive Double Award From the Treasury for Furthering the Innovation

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 28 (AP)--Torpedo planes of the Royal Air Force have slammed their steel fish at another Italian cruiser, the British command disclosed today, while the desert battle preparations of German and British armies went on behind a screen of minor actions.
MOSCOW, Aug. 28 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:

NEWARK, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Newark Bears moved closer to their seventh International League pennant in eleven years today by breaking even with the Baltimore Orioles in a twilight double-header. The visitors took the opener, 2 -- 1, while Newark charged back with a 6-3 decision in the second game.

Climbing 50 points in ten minutes, futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday vaulted to gains of 72 to 82 points from Thursday's closing quotations, equivalent to $3.60 to $4.10 a bale, one of the sharpest rises in several years.

Enforcement of trucking restrictions designed to conserve gasoline and rubber will be largely in the hands of State authorities, although the regulations will be jointly administered by the Office of Defense Transportation and the war transportation committee of the State War Council, it was disclosed yesterday.

The American Council of Dress Manufacturers, Inc., yesterday appealed to Mayor La Guardia to intervene in the current dispute between the New York dress industry and the union, in order to prevent the scheduled stoppage of work on Tuesday in plants not providing Dress Institute labels.

AT AN R.A.F. SPITFIRE BASE in the Desert, Egypt, Aug. 27 (Delayed) (AP) -- British Spitfires in the hands of crack Royal Air Force formations composed of British, Canadian, Australian, New Zealand, Argentine and Trinidad pilots have proved to be the masters of Messerschmitts during the past month in which the Allied fliers have been undertaking large-scale operations here, persons in close touch with the desert war said today.
The Treasury Department has set a September war bond quota of $160,000,000 for New York State and the drive will be launched here next Tuesday morning with a "million-dollar breakfast."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Blue Network, with the assistance of Orson Welles and William Bacher and stars of stage, radio and screen, along with nineteen popular dance bands, will sell war bonds for seven hours over the air tomorrow night, the Treasury stated today.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 28 -- I.A. Horowitz, New York State titleholder, clung to his half-point advantage in the open tournament for the championship of the United States Chess Federation today. After thirteen rounds he was leading with a score of 12 1/2 -- 1/2, with Abe Yanofsky of Winnipeg, 12 -- 1, in second place.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Manufacture of woolen lounging robes for men and boys was ordered stopped today by the WPB. The office ruled that manufacturers may use woolen fabrics they had on hand or in their possession on the date of the issuance of the order (L-130) but that when present stocks are gone they may not use cloth containing wool in robes, bath robes or beach coats.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Casting aside fears of strict government controls over farm goods prices that have fettered the markets most of the week, traders accelerated their purchases of butter, egg and potato futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange today and prices swung upward.

Prospects of a definite upturn for Fall in the demand for paper are beginning to fade rapidly and the industry is now reconciled to a steady decline in operations for the balance of the year, it was indicated yesterday. Some sellers are trying to keep alive a faint hope that there might be a sudden pickup next month but so far there have been no indications of any upturn.
Following is a list of all the defendants named by the government in its anti-trust suit against The Associated Press:

In providing food for wartime consumption the nation's farmers will go "over the top" this year, with production exceeding last year's yield by 9 per cent instead of the 5 per cent set up as the 1942 goal, M. Clifford Townsend, administrator of the Agricultural Conservation and Adjustment Administration, reported yesterday.

"The Puritan hated bear-baiting, not because it gave pain to the bear but because it gave pleasure to the spectators." Macaulay's Puritan has his modern counterpart in the Treasury. For the Treasury seems to object to the Ruml pay-as-you-go income-tax plan almost entirely on the ground not that it will do any harm to the Treasury's revenues but that it will benefit a small group of taxpayers.

RICHMOND, Calif., Aug. 28--As the Kaiser shipyards here sent a 10,000-ton Liberty ship into the water today twenty-four days after its keel had been laid, Henry J. Kaiser predicted that within a few months his yards would be launching 10,000-ton freighters on eighteen-day construction schedules.

LONDON, Aug. 28 (U.P.) -- Admiral Harold R. Stark, commander of United States Naval Forces in European waters, said today that the war would likely be "long and tough," and that the Allies should trim their sails accordingly.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 28 -- Brazil will carry on, help or no help, in fighting the Axis for what she considers her rights, Foreign Minister Oswaldo Aranha declared tonight at his first press conference since Brazil's declaration of war.

In John Kieran's column on home-run hitters appearing in THE TIMES last Sunday no mention was made of Jimmy Foxx, who has done some home-run clouting as part of his regular major league chores for the last eighteen years. Therefore I would like to take this opportunity to bring to light the greatness of a ball player who rarely is given the credit he deserves.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- A high government authority today cautioned the American press and the American public against interpreting the withdrawal of Japanese naval forces from the Solomon Islands area as a major victory for the United States.

While the United Nations bide their time in opening a second front there is much we can do at home to prepare ourselves for that crucial hour. For one thing, we could open a "special front" now -- a front that will depend neither upon time nor place for its successful execution.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 28 (AP) -- The Braves went hitless against Bucky Walters for five innings tonight, but in the sixth Bucky's first three walks loaded the bases and started a four-run rally that beat the Reds, 4 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Navy gobs eagerly asked "Where do we enlist?" this afternoon when three officers of the Waves appeared in their distinctive uniforms this afternoon at the Navy Annex in Arlington. Enthusiasm for the trim outfits, especially for the original hats, ran high not only among the press women present but among a class of sailors and their commanding officers who pushed into the room as the show ended.

Sam Boston, betting commissioner who allegedly played in high-stake gambling games with such figures as the late Arnold Rothstein, yesterday was ordered by Magistrate Richard McKiniry in West Side Court to refrain from "playing or betting at one time or sitting for money or property exceeding the value of $2.50."

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Department store circles here are looking for a Federal inventory control order at a fairly early date and on a more reasonable basis than that rejected by WPB Administrator Nelson Early in May.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The midnight Soviet communique:

The principal commodities assumed the leadership in the nation's markets yesterday and scored some outstanding gains, while the stock list managed to add meagerly to its recovery. The peaks in the commodities were not maintained to the close of trading because of profit taking, but at that the net advances were impressive.
Mayor La Guardia expressed his "hearty approval" yesterday of the pay-as-you-go Federal income tax plan proposed by Beardsley Ruml.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- President Roosevelt held two important war production conferences at the White House today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- A nine-point increase in the farm price level in the last month was reported to the Agriculture Department today while President Roosevelt and his aides were still seeking a definite answer to the legal question of whether the Commander in Chief, in time of war, could, in effect, set aside a Congressional restriction under which farm prices ceilings could not be established below 110 per cent of parity.

LONDON, Aug. 28 -- Expert accountancy is beginning to be just as necessary a knowledge for the British housewife as the more old-fashioned peacetime virtue of being able to tell a good piece of meat from a bad one or a tender bean from a tough one.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (U.P.) -- Liudmila Pavlichenko, a brown-haired, soft-spoken woman of 26, smiled a grim smile today and remarked:

For the protection democracy, the educational system should abandon the theory of the open mind in teaching controversial subjects and should be "partial" to the democratic side, according to one of the proposals submitted yesterday at Columbia University at the third annual Conference on Science, Philosophy and Religion.

washington aug. 28--an CPA regulation which allows retailers and wholesalers of the 1942 frozen fruit, berry and vegetables pack to pass on to consumers the exact amount--and no more--by which recently raise was issued here today....
I should like to suggest a rather elementary addition to the procedure adopted in blackouts here, whether practice or grimly necessary.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 -- Commodore Paul H. Smart of the Noroton (Conn) Yacht Club, won the fourth race of the world's Star Class annual championship series today off Chicago Harbor. With his son Hilary as crew, Commodore Smart represents the Central Long Island Sound fleet.
