CHICAGO, Aug. 28--Favorable war news from the Russian and Far Eastern fronts resulted today in a rather marked change in speculative sentiment, and with cotton strong there was persistent buying of wheat futures which disclosed a lack of selling pressure.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 28 -- Taking the offense at the outset and increasing the pressure as they went along, the Blues defeated the Whites, 20 -- 7, on old Yale Field today in the first All-Army intra-squad scrimmage under game conditions.

Completion of a Committee of One Hundred to arrange New York City's first wartime observance of Navy Day, Oct. 27, was announced yesterday by Commander Charles Hann Jr., U.S.N.R., general chairman of the New York City Observance Committee, by virtue of his office as regional vice president of the Navy League of the United States.

In the midst of riotous Summer bloom the dull days of Winter seem far away. Yet foresighted gardeners already are making preparations that those days, although dull, may not be flowerless. At this season many seeds and bulbs may be started for early bloom in the house.

CARSON CITY, Nev. -- Nevada's new museum and art institute will end its first year as a State institution open to the public on Admission Day, Oct. 31. Housed in the historic Carson City mint, the museum occupies a structure which first rose against the desert sky about 1866.
This week-end, for the first time since mid-June, dog-show folk will enjoy three excellent exhibitions in as many days within the limits of the greater metropolitan area.

The present method of calculating parity prices without including farm wages as a factor leaves the way open for "a tremendous inflationary movement," according to Edward A. O'Neal, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, who was here last week to attend several conferences of Northeastern farmers.
Five more garden clubs have announced that they have "enlisted" in the national Victory Garden Harvest Show movement -- proceeds to be for the benefit of the armed forces.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 29 -- Three hundred women attended the opening today of the fifteenth biennial convention of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae at the Hotel Robert Treat.

"My husband and I dearly love children; I have a lovely, light, airy room for them," reads one application to the New York City Committee on Child Welfare of the State Charities Aid Association, which is seeking 5,000 new boarding homes for neglected or dependent children in New York.

Japanese forces on the Chekiang-Kiangsi front began on Aug. 19 "a readjustment of their battle line to secure a more militarily advantageous position in readiness for future action," the press section of the Japanese expeditionary forces in Central China announced on the Tokyo radio yesterday, according to The Associated Press.

Summonses for violation of Police Commissioner Valentine's recent order requiring automobile headlights to be dimmed or shaded will be served starting Tuesday night, it was learned last night. Formal announcement is expected to be made today by Mayor La Guardia in his weekly broadcast.

THE handsome man who meets an untimely death is Rex Manners, who has just announced his engagement to lovely Sylvia Latham during a week-end party given by his stepmother, Mrs. Clare Manners. Were it not for a reluctance to condone murder, we might be tempted to call his death a timely one, for Rex was not a nice person.

AS the normally dull Summer season nears conclusion, retail trade has become subject to a number of war influences, and yet merchants are hopeful of better results within the near future. Men's wear buying has slumped off further on the draft announcements concerning married men and probably this news has also affected home furnishing promotions, though tighter credit regulation is no doubt the main factor.

THE new book by the author of the widely read "Address Unknown" is the story of the Nazi campaign against the Christian churches of Germany, and of the underground movement of resistance which has kept that campaign from success.

COEUR D'ALENE, Idaho, Aug. 29 -- Although the Nazis have specifically addressed their propaganda to the Indians of America ever since 1933, the descendants of this continent's original inhabitants are active in all phases of the war effort.

FARM SCHOOL, Pa., Aug. 29 -- The traditional three-year courses of study of the National Farm School of Bucks County have been supplemented by a series of one-year units designed to meet the needs of young men who desire to prepare themselves quickly for the production of vital foodstuffs, Dr. H. B. Allen, president, announced today.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Plans have been completed for the twenty-fourth annual Tuxedo Kennel Club dog show to be held at the local horse show grounds next Saturday. The show will be for the benefit of Dogs For Defense, Inc., and entries are being received from owners in all sections of the metropolitan area.
The national amateur tennis championships ran afoul of bad weather yesterday at Forest Hills and what should have been one of the most profitable days was washed out.

Those Star Class sloops that have won their right on points during the Summer to represent their fleets, will compete this week in the Atlantic Coast championship, which will start today out on Great South Bay off the Bay Shore Yacht Club.

War deprivations, some present and far more to come, raise the question of what constitutes a necessity. Most of the commodities which we shall have to do without or use sparingly did not exist at the time of the Civil War -- indeed, at the time of our war with Spain.

Most people buy their furniture ready-made. But if you are willing to go to the trouble of inspecting the possibilities of local woodworking shops and lumber yards, and will use your imagination and ingenuity, you are very likely to come up with some ideas for making your own pieces, or having them made. This can be a lot of fun, and can save money.

"NEW YORK? Absolutely unchanged, I tell you! Seven months and you can't tell the difference. Why, in Rio they told me in New York people are fighting over sugar. Imagine! I had visions of people storming warehouses, riots in the streets, a whole epidemic of tabloid sugar murders!"

Since higher taxes and overhead expenses are more certain than good sales of major home furnishings in the near future, controllers of many department stores are starting to clamp down on requests for additional buying appropriations by merchandising men, many of whom believe that anything in a warehouse is a good investment.

Crocuses, if put in at once, will be not only the start of a permanent planting but will also yield blooms this Fall. There is time for their bright blossoms to add to the shrubbery or garden border, the ground-covered planting under trees and the rock garden.

DOES any one want to buy a Japanese doll? Now wait a minute! This is a very special Japanese doll. It represents all the royalties received by Margaret Mitchell on more than 200,000 copies of "Gone With the Wind" in Japanese editions.

STUART, Fla. -- Jeeps patrolling the hard sandy beaches, long stretches of the highway skirting the ocean closed at night, the coastal blackout and the gas scarcity have almost killed the popular Summer pastime and minor industry of sea turtle egg-hunting in lower East Coast Florida.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- A program for production of the minimum number of storage batteries necessary for replacement in passenger cars, trucks, buses and other vehicles during the balance of this year was announced today by the War Production Board.

Prices on the New York Stock Exchange drifted yesterday without apparent direction and closed dull and mixed, with aircraft, oil and motor shares forming the firmest groups. Volume was only 137,490 shares, against 180,410 on the preceding Saturday.

Retail trade here continued to lag behind the high 1941 figures last week. The showing was slightly improved, however, and the loss which had been running around 6 to 8 per cent was reported cut to about 5 per cent. With the exception of furniture and other home furnishings departments, the showing was regarded as satisfactory by stores.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 29 -- There are 250,000 German soldiers and more than 300,000 German civilians in Norway, it was reported today from Oslo.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 29 -- Japanese forces in Kwangtung Province in South China are in flight before a new strong Chinese offensive forty miles north of Canton, Chinese dispatches said tonight as the High Command confirmed earlier reports that the valuable air bases at Chuhsien and Lishui in Chekiang Province had been wrested from the invaders.

In the interest of both the Treasury and the taxpayer no time could be more propitious for the adoption of the Ruml pay-as-you-go tax plan than the present. The Treasury would be permanently benefited because the plan would make possible the immediate introduction of a substantial withholding tax.

The Fall meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club at Aqueduct, which marks the return of racing to the metropolitan area, gets under way tomorrow and continues through Sept. 19. The popular Long Island track is offering approximately $250,000 in purse and stake money for horsemen to shoot at.

Ethelbert Smith said there was one thing that puzzled him about Winston Churchill's lightning business trips. Now the Prime Minister turns up in Washington, and now he is in Moscow, and before he has come back home he has visited Egypt on the way.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -The Senators squared their last home series with Detroit today, beating the Tigers, 4 -- 1, as Bobo Newsom scattered eight Bengal blows. Tommy Bridges was the victim of Washington's nine hits, as well as his own wildness.

LOS ANGELES. Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Army has made the Redskins bite the dust before and maybe it can do it again, but in advance of tomorrow's football season opener between Major Wallace Wade's Western Army All-Stars and the Washington Redskins of the pro ranks the service boys look like second best.

EVERY one, it is said, has a good book in him if only he could write it, and this is a very good book. It is genuine autobiography, a psalm of life that is still youth, sung full-throated by a Scottish lassie as the air that she breathes, joyous in its zest for experience and gayly triumphant over disillusions.

MONTICELLO -- As resorts in this area prepare programs for the Labor Day week-end, the New Concord Hotel at Kiamesha Lake is today concentrating on a successful conclusion for its A.A.U. swimming meet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The close relationship between the nation's school system and the needs of its air forces was presented to representatives of the teaching profession and commissioners of education from all parts of the country in addresses and through the medium or motion pictures at today's sessions of the National Institute on Education and the War.

CHUNGKING, Aug. 29 -- High official military and political circles in Chungking are generally agreed that Japan has been checked at the peak of her capabilities for aggression, with the initiative for major offensive action now being wrested from her grasp.

GREAT LAKES, Ill., Aug. 29 -- Benny Friedman, former University of Michigan All-America quarterback, tops a group of five officers who were named today as assistant football coaches of the Great Lakes Naval Training Station team.
The following editorial comment on the filing of a civil action against The Associated Press by the United States Government was published yesterday in the various papers cited:...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Prosecutions of wartime offenders have been speeded up during the last six weeks and have resulted in the conviction of fourteen persons charged with treason, espionage, sedition and similar crimes, Wendell Berge, Assistant Attorney General, reported to Attorney General Biddle today.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- The British feeling on India this week, as reflected in the press and public comments, seemed to be that the initial crisis caused by the outbreak of the Gandhi-led "nonviolence campaign" had passed. In London attention was being turned to the finding of some new way of settling the Anglo-Indian difficulties.

TO the question "Just what are you trying to do, Mr. Street?" James Street, author of "Tap Roots," "O Promised Land" and "The Biscuit Eater," said, "Well, what I'd like to do is write a really good book.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Authoritative government sources reported tonight that a special committee of the War Production Board had decided to impose coupon rationing of fuel oil in the Atlantic States and one well-informed official said that Oct. 15 had been selected for the starting date.

PEOPLE abroad, one gathers, have acquired a somewhat curious impression of the city of Chicago. They tend to picture it as a place where gangsters level guns at almost every corner and where vice and dirty politics run rampant.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Grave problems affecting organized labor and its full participation in the war effort were raised this week by government and labor itself. The solutions to the questions presented were by no means clear, but there seemed a desire among the leaders of government, industry and labor to work them out, amicably if possible, and to get on with the war against the Axis powers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Relations between Spain and the United States have improved considerably in recent months and there is an increasing prospect that General Francisco Franco, if left to himself, will not bring his country into the war, it was learned here today.
POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -All the Pocono resorts are preparing for an exceptionally busy Labor Day week-end.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Four Southern newspaper men, one the editor of a Negro weekly, were commended today by Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, for investigating and exposing false rumors of impending racial disturbances.

THERE is a chance that "Othello," with Paul Robeson, may come to Broadway in January, but not under Theatre Guild auspices. The date depends on Mr. Robeson's concert bookings. At present he is tied up until April 10, but Robert Rockmore, his adviser, is trying to rearrange his schedule so that the Margaret Webster production of the tragedy may be brought here sooner than next Spring.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Red Army, forcing the Germans to pay heavily for every inch of ground before Stalingrad, fought stubbornly today against strong Axis assaults while northwest of Moscow other Soviet forces advanced in the Kalinin sector and reported crossing a river.

COMMANDO! The very name of these rough and ready assault troops breathes decisive action and great deeds. Yet the Commandos, currently the most glamorous of the British fighting men, are only a small part of a great plan of combined operations which slowly but surely is etching a pattern for invasion on Western Europe.

Probably the showiest of all the garden's blooms is the oriental poppy and, believe it or not, it is the most agreeable of all flowers, providing it is not touched except during its dormant period, which is August.

Reorders increased in the wholesale market last week, and many requests came in to rush goods on order, according to the report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. The improved volume reflected a pick-up in retail business due to the brisk weather.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Navy made public tonight the following message sent by Major Ben. A.A. Vandegrift, commanding Marine forces in the Solomons, to the Marines who stormed Guadalcanal:

BOSTON, Aug. 29 -- Members of the Massachusetts Women's Defense Corps stand ready today for the last phase of their seventy-two-hour alert which started Friday morning when Army troops began practice manoeuvres "somewhere in New England."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Four Navy nurses who were captured by the Japanese on the island of Guam Dec. 10 came home to a belated Christmas today after traveling 20,000 miles over four oceans and spending six months in enemy prisons and detention houses.

For the fourth time in this war men study the northern skies for the first far shadow of the dark wings of Winter. In the lowlands of the North we may still feel heat, but all around the earth, in New England, in China, in Russia, in Norway, some trees are showing spots of Autumn color, and frost has touched the four-thousand-foot level, and below.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Tuned to the keynote "Free Labor Will Win," American labor, with government cooperation, is planning for Sept. 7 celebrations which will emphasize ways and means of clinching victory over the Axis.

The War Man Power Commission will meet with the American Management Association to discuss more effective employment at the Hotel Pennsylvania Sept. 29 and 30, the association announced yesterday. Practically every industry in the country is expected to be represented at the sessions.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Aug. 30 -- Last midnight's Soviet communique indicated that there had been no significant change on the vast Russian front in the last thirty-six hours.

Struggling along under playing conditions that were far from perfect, the usually flawless Yankees were guilty of some imperfect play at the Stadium yesterday, with the result that Lou Boudreau's Indians, making their farewell appearance of the year here, sent the world champions skidding down to defeat, 6 to 5.

The number of tons of freight moved one mile by truck in the United States in 1941 was 44,227,000,000, compared with 477,500,000,000 moved by rail, according to a chart and compilation prepared by H.E. Hale of the securities investment department of the Equitable Life Assurance Society.

UNCLE SAM and John Bull, now partners in a momentous enterprise, have issued booklets of advice for their young overseas representatives. John's is addressed to his airmen training in this country; Sam's to our fighting men in the British Isles. Comparison of passages chosen at random indicates that Sam and John have similar ideas of how a visiting fireman should conduct himself.

More than 400 of the automotive industry's top-flight engineers and technical experts drawn from all companies in the field for several months have been breaking down bottlenecks by pooling ideas, developments and inventions, according to the Automotive Council for War Production.
Richard A. Loederer, 23 West Forty-seventh Street, New York City, is working on a book of National Heroes of Latin America which includes the following men.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 29 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, inspecting American Army installations in India, has conferred the Silver Star on Colonel George W. Sliney of San Francisco and Captain Eugene P. Laybourne of Windsor, Col., United States Army Headquarters here announced in a communique, it was earned today.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Aug. 29 -- The College of William and Mary, second oldest of the nation, today once more is showing its ability to meet the exigencies of war. Through all the armed struggles of this country, from the Revolution to the present war, the college has kept its doors open, and now with its recently inaugurated "War Work Plan" it is stepping into active participation in the nation's current fight for freedom.

Paraguay's series, promised for release last April in commemoration of the founding of the "ciudad" (city) of Asuncion by Domingo Martinez de Irala, Spanish conquistador, in 1541-42, appeared on Aug. 15. "Asuncion-Ciudad" and the dates 1541 and 1941 are inscribed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The Senate Finance Committee, which is rewriting and perfecting the House tax bill of 1942, will probably be able to preserve the major portion of its draft throughout the legislative process. This has been the history of recent tax legislation, especially in an election year, when all seats in the House are before the electors to be filled and only one-third of those in the Senate are.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 29 -- Magnus Konow's International Frolic, Jay Lukens's Atlantic Hera, P.I. Patton's Herreshoff S boat Kandahar, Samuel Faile's Star Justa Star. Bill and Margaret Hornidge's 110 FainaII, S.E. Kay's fifth division Handicap boat Valkyrie and R.M. Ollinger's seventh division Sufi were the winners today in the New Rochelle Yacht Club's special regatta.
BOSTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Charley Wagner won his twelfth game of the season today as the Red Sox took advantage of the generosity of White Sox pitcher Lefty Jake Wade to beat Chicago by 4 to 2.
THE music of Vincent d'Indy seldom appears on our symphonic programs and it is equally rare on records. Yet he was a composer of distinction, and his music is eminently worth listening to.

PERCY MARKS'S new novel is an entertaining story about a young man who suffered from a kyphosis and a psychosis -- that is to say, about Terry Price who had a humpback about which he was so hypersensitive that he almost developed a hump on his soul.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 29 -- Always together in civil life, but separated when they entered the Army at Fort Dix in July, Privates George and Frank Koch, 22-year-old twins, of 878 Flora Street, were reunited yesterday at Camp Gruber, Okla., through the intervention of President Roosevelt, who acted in answer to a plea from the soldiers' sister, Mrs. James J. Mottley of this city, that they be assigned to the same camp.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., Aug. 29 -- The University of Notre Dame will be host Monday to fifteen prominent Latin Americans as the Inter-American Seminar arrives on the campus from Washington for a one-day session.

Declaring that "women and older men in the country will have to take over the burdens of war production and civic administration to release young men for combat duties," Carl F. Zaidler, 34-year-old Mayor of Milwaukee, now a junior grade lieutenant in the naval reserve, described yesterday his first visit to Milwaukee since his enlistment last April.

BERGENFIELD, N.J., Aug. 29 -- The 6-Month-old twins of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Bottjer of 18 Wilbur Road here are dead and Mrs. Bottjer, 34 years old, and her son, John, 4, are in a critical condition from gas poisoning in Holy Name Hospital, Teaneck.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- Candy manufacturers in increasing numbers are delaying their purchase of peanuts for confectionery until the present tangle over ceiling prices is remedied, it was learned here today at the offices of the National Confectioners Association.

URBANA-CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Aug. 29 -- The University of Illinois, noted for its research contributions in the various fields of transportation, has a long-range program well under way relating to problems of the skyways.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCE IN CHINA, Aug. 29 (U.P.) -- American bombers continued, an offensive designed to break up apparent Japanese plans for an invasion of Yunnan Province today, striking at two Japanese bases along the Indo-China border where supplies and equipment had been accumulated.

OFELIA lived with the twelve other members of her family in a hut close to the house where Gertrude Diamant took an apartment, on the outskirts of Mexico City. Indeed it was Ofelia who showed the foreign visitor the apartment in the first place.

The Nazi drive in the Caucasus and next Winter's house-heating problem in our parts have very ancient beginnings. Several millions of years ago, or maybe billions, the seas and the marshes of this planet swarmed, as they do to this day, with more or less passive and drifting forms of life, diatoms and algae, mostly microscopic, which the scientists call plankton from the Greek word for "wandering."
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Aug. 29 -- The 3-year-old Spiral Pass today whipped the highly favored Vagrancy and seven other fillies of the same age in winning the $12,400 New England Oaks at Narragansett Park.

One hears many complaints about the government's interference with business, but so far as the men's clothing industry is concerned it has taught manufacturers efficiency without affecting quality and, so far as its acquisition of Army uniforms is concerned, has proved itself the best buyer in the country, clothing contractors here declared yesterday.

A GREAT deal has been said and written lately about Mrs. Miniver, and the American public has been good enough to show a deep and sympathetic interest in all her doings. It occurs to me that this same warm-hearted public might be interested to hear more about the present situation and activities of her husband, Clem Miniver.

With a cast of 110 figure skaters headed by Bobby Specht and Miss Donna Atwood, the Ice Capades of 1943 will have its world premiere in Madison Square Garden on Friday night and thus will begin sixteen-day run there.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Aug. 29 -- At a recent meeting the trustees of Williams College voted to allow freshman eligibility on varsity teams for the duration of the war. This decision came as a result of a resolution passed by Gargoyle, undergraduate honor society.

Approximately 85 per cent of the present and future stocks of Irish flax are expected to be required by the armed services and, although there is little likelihood of any "sizable" allocation of linen yarns for export, the United States market may expect "first call," R.W. Charlesson, special representative of the Northern Ireland Ministry of Commerce, declared last week.

Byron H. Uhl, district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said yesterday that eighty passengers remaining of 162 taken to Ellis Island from the diplomatic exchange ship Gripsholm would probably be released this week-end.

The fourth article of the Atlantic Charter postulates access to the raw materials of the earth on equal terms to all nations. Nothing less than a world-wide mobilization of science and technology is implied because the raw materials themselves are worth little without the technical knowledge and skill demanded in their extraction from the earth and their utilization.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 29 -- W. Lee O'Daniel, denounced in Texas and over the country as an isolationist at heart if not in fact, has been nominated for a full six-year term in the United States Senate by Texas Democrats in a close run-off primary victory over James V. Allred.

Considerably quieter after the active buying of the previous session, the cotton market went yesterday through a process of adjustment, moving between gains of 16 points and losses of 10 points. Active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange reacted to early covering operations and late realizing.
The result of this year's New York State election on Nov. 3 will have nation-wide significance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Washington has been cooler and quieter this week. The coolness was partly attributable to the city's usual August break in the weather, but for the quietude President Roosevelt's "No public squabbling" order to his department and agency heads was undoubtedly largely responsible.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 29 -- Albert Spalding, violinist, is giving a recital at the Pittsfield High School Hall next Thursday evening as a benefit for USO and British War Relief. Mr. Spalding is donating his services.

MARK PATTISON, English author and rector of Lincoln College, Oxford, whose extraordinary distinction of mind and preoccupation "in the things of the intellect" made him an authority in his field, said Desiderius Erasmus, the Dutch scholar and historian, was born at Gouda about 1466, where he attended his first school, learning little else but the love of letters, which was the ruling passion of his life.

BERTRAND RUSSELL has been outlining in the current Fortnightly his plans for an international university as part of the world's post-war construction. He devotes a few pages of his article to the subject of historical textbooks.

NOW that Irving Pichel is permanently behind the cameras rather than in front of them, he finds that he breathes easier in the presence of his three stalwart sons. Not that they ever reproached him directly, but Mr. Pichel still remembers wryly the awkward period when they were going to public school and their companions would taunt them -- "Yah! Your father tried to kill Dick Tracy."

PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 29 -- A recommendation to every four-year college and university in California that it include in its curriculum a required "general survey course in the history of the United States" went out today from a State-wide conference of history professors held at Stanford University.

An increase in the number of tank cars used to bring oil to the East, from the present total of 62,000 to 80,000, would permit daily delivery of 1,045,000 barrels, or 4,976 carloads, on the basis of present efficiency, according to Railway Age.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP) -- After trying for six years, Harry Nye Jr. of Chicago won the world Star Class sailing championship today.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Aug. 29 -- Lieutenant Frederick J. Kidde, leader of a Marine Corps patrol whose exploits were mentioned in a dispatch from Guadalcanal Island in the Solomons yesterday, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Kidde of 80 Elm Street, Montclair.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 -- The Dodgers suffered from the well known Double-X today in the ninth inning when Jimmy Foxx drove in the tying run and Stan Hack singled across the crusher to give the Cubs a 4-3 triumph and set a Wrigley Field crowd of 14,557 cheering as if the Bruins had just clinched a pennant.

IN the last three months Hollywood's reputation for magnificence has gone kaput. The industry that once prided itself on its sublime disregard of costs, that complacently admitted tossing thousands around like pennies, now has become more frugal than a Dutch housewife and prouder of a ten-cent saving than a schoolboy of a new bank.

MUSIC CHARMS: Cows on the Suffolk County farm at Yaphank, L. L, are saic to give more milk since a radio was installed in the barn. Welfare Commissioner Richard T. Gilmartin claims they prefer soft, dreamy tunes. Swing music doesn't keep them contented, he said.

A new way of making three-dimensional X-rays which should expedite operations for the removal of bullets and shrapnel in advance base hospitals has just been developed at the New York University College of Dentistry by Dean Allen T. Newman and Drs. Milton and Edward Klein.

WITH August at an end most sponsors have completed arrangements for their Fall and Winter programs and the cheerful word is that a good and varied program of entertainment is in store for the listener.

Despite wartime restrictions, import trade is continuing at a satisfactory rate and operations under General Imports Order No. M-63, the principal regulation affecting the trade, are working more or less smoothly, it was reported by importers last week.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 29 -- A unique experiment in practical engineering which encompasses plenty of good, practical experience in the mechanics of surveying forests, railroads, creek beds and coal land, is included in the four-year course in civil engineering offered by the University of Kentucky College of Engineering.

An informal Fun Fair divided into twelve sections, each representing a separate effort in the home-front war services, will be given on the afternoons and evenings of Oct. 6, 7 and 8 at St. Thomas Episcopal Chapel, 229 East Fifty-ninth Street.

A Russian captain and two members of a crew of forty-three, who brought their damaged merchant ship through a six-day bombing and submarine attack in the Barents Sea about three months ago, gave some of the details yesterday of their experience which earned for the ship the Order of Lenin, and for them the titles of Heroes of the Soviet Union.

MADISON, N.J., Aug. 29 -- "Production goals" for individual students are established at Drew University, enabling the faculty at the end of the year to expect of each one results commensurate with his ability. The system is the outgrowth of five years of experimentation.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 -- For the first time since Pearl Harbor, a major California track has received permission from the Army for a racing meet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- One large Japanese destroyer has been sunk, another probably sunk and a smaller destroyer severely damaged by land-based American planes operating in the Solomon Islands, the Navy announced today.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- The way to quick and certain victory is through a successful invasion of the Continent and a march to Berlin. On that there is general agreement. It is upon the question whether any assault upon the Nazis' coastal defenses in Europe with the forces now at the disposal of the United Nations could succeed that the experts fall out.

CHIEF Inspector French has a new assistant, a young chap named Arthur Rollo, who is given the temporary rank of sergeant while working with French on the case with which this book deals. French would rather have Sergeant Carter, whose ways and whose worth he knows, but he takes Rollo and hopes for the best.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 29 -- Further discussions of the thorny problem of refugee relief in Switzerland were held today at a conference of Cantonal police authorities at Lausanne, attended by Dr. Edward von Steiger, Federal Councilor and chief of the Department of Justice and Police, and Dr. Heinrich Rothmund, chief of the Swiss Department of Foreign Police.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., Aug. 29 -- Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, in his first public appearance since his nomination last Monday night in Saratoga Springs, declared here this afternoon that the Republican party had its "greatest opportunity and greatest obligation" in the coming elections to preserve the two-party system of American government and unite the country behind the war.
THIS is a case history, elaborate and detailed, of how France's press and many of her politicians succumbed to the psychological campaign which Berlin waged against the morale of the French people.
The diction and pronunciation of radio speakers are of much concern to millions of listeners. There is all too frequently a slovenliness and a carelessness of delivery in men of supposed education.
NEW YORK has another art controversy on its hands; one of timely and more than usually widespread interest in view of the fact that it bears a direct relationship to the war effort.

A group of stars headed by Miss Helene Rains, national senior 220-yard breast-stroke and 300-yard individual medley champion, will compete in the swimming meet at which two metropolitan A.A.U. titles will be decided in the Concord Hotel pool, Kiamesha Lake, N.Y., today.

DETROIT, Aug. 29 -- Detroit may be boiling within, and there may be bitterness over union-management disputes, but one thing is certain. The women are in the war by virtue of milling machines and rivet guns.

THERE has been as much discussion of the economic reconstruction which must follow the war as there has been of the shape of political things to come -- and perhaps even more nonsense. Counsels of both perfection and despair have been frequent and clamorous.

MOSCOW, Aug. 29 -- One can make more mistakes in estimating what the enemy can do with or without more oil than in any other form of military prophecy if one questions Soviet oil experts on the subject.

Harry A. Morgan, vice president of the American Communications Association, marine department, announced yesterday that the union had been informed of the adoption of another of the union's proposed safety measures to minimize loss of life at sea.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's idea of catapulting fighter planes from convoyed merchant ships to combat enemy air raiders at sea has worked out with astonishing success, particularly on the route to Murmansk.

LONDON, Aug. 29 -- Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has asked his organization commanders and chaplains to allow American troops to participate next Thursday in the national day of prayer that is to be observed throughout the British Isles and wherever there are British stations.

Because of the price reduction in tickets for the coming season of the Metropolitan Opera Association, more applications for subscriptions have been received than at the corresponding period last year, it was announced by Edward Johnson, general manager.

A medium-sized American merchant vessel was torpedoed and sunk in the Caribbean about the middle of August, the Navy announced yesterday The entire crew of thirty-eight and the Navy gun crew of eleven were saved by the vigilance of the master of the ship, according to the United Press, which refers to him as a naturalized American, born in Denmark, who was formerly a heavyweight boxer and once "king" of a South Sea island.

VICHY, France, Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Vichy Government announced tonight that it had protested to the British through Madrid over what it said was the aerial bombing of a passenger train yesterday at Menars, near Blois, in which twentysix persons were killed and fifty-six wounded.

There is about 2,000 miles of travel in every thirty-second of an inch of tread on an automobile tire. That is to say, your tires wear down about the thickness of an ordinary rubber band every time your car clicks off another 2,000 miles.

SO your child is going to school. Have you checked up on his vision and his hearing, as well as his general health? Can he see the blackboard from a back seat, or does he need to sit in the front row? Can he hear normally no matter where he sits?

GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands, Aug. 14 (Delayed) -- Aug. 7, 1942, the largest force of Marines ever to engage in landing operations assaulted Guadalcanal, Tulagi and Gavutu, important Japanese bases in the Solomon Islands. The attack marked the first time in this war that American land forces have taken the offensive against the enemy.

The third annual rendezvous of senior scouts of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York opened yesterday afternoon on the grounds of Sailors Snug Harbor on Staten Island and will be continued today. Three hundred scouts with full camp equipment, representing every borough in the city, arrived on the grounds before noon and were greeted by Howard A. Flynn, Governor of Sailors Snug Harbor, and 600 retired seafaring men who make their home there.

To demonstrate the part that industry is playing in maintaining the American way of life during wartime an extensive exhibit will be held by R.H. Macy Co., Inc., early next year, according to an announcement yesterday by Jack I. Straus, president of the concern.

Along many lines the war is beginning to teach us the value of conservation; the great national habit of wanton waste is no longer considered something to boast about. Instead, we are urged to make this and that stretch to the utmost in use or wear, and where possible to supplement the things we must purchase with home-made substitutes.

New York City will mark on Wednesday the 153d anniversary of the founding of the United States Treasury Department with one of its biggest War Bond rallies, to be held on the steps of the Sub-treasury Building, on Wall Street. Mayor La Guardia, Federal officials and Hollywood stars will participate in the celebration, which will begin at 12:30 P.M.

Dropping the exploration of difficulties between husband and wife for the time being, the Lieferants in their new novel take a long look at a glamour girl who doesn't know which man to marry. She has pale gold hair and her name is Leda. One of her two suitors is Clyde, rich, handsome, a polo player, probably the most eligible young man in New York.

CLEVELAND, Aug 29 -- Temporary elevators built last, Fall at ports on the Upper Great Lakes to increase storage facilities will be unable to handle surplus grain stocks this year, shippers disclosed today.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi's movement of civil disobedience appears to be spreading underground after three weeks of surface demonstrations in which disorder, suppressed in India's big cities, continued to boil in the villages.

THE first chapter of this book bears the ominous heading "The Hundred and and Fiftieth Day Before the Execution." Succeeding chapters have similar headings but with constantly decreasing serial numbers.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 29 -- With a victory barrage of home runs the Giants today took their farewell of Forbes Field for the 1942 campaign and downed Frankie Frisch's Pirates in both ends of a double-header before a gathering of 5,212.

"THE UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT PRESENTS" -- When that credit title flashes on the screen of the Rialto Theatre in Times Square on Thursday night it will mark not only the arrival of "The World at War," first official film history of the present conflict, but the introduction of a new era in governmental war film activities.

At midnight tomorrow Townsend Harris High School, which for thirty-five years enabled exceptional students to graduate from high school in three instead of four years, will officially close. Though actually discontinued in June when its last class was graduated, tomorrow is the date designated by the Board of Higher Education as the time for its official demise.

Dog days are over, and here comes September. Not Autumn, yet; simply September, which can be as sweltering as mid-July and as chill as late October, and usually manages to be both. Flowers still bloom in September, but sumac and swampland maples give them the lie by turning a gorgeous Autumn scarlet.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 22 -- Lack of newsprint and advertising will shortly force this city's newspapers to cut down to eight pages, it was learned today. The dailies, which ran twenty to twenty-four pages last January, have already reduced to twelve and sixteen.

THE passing of Michel Fokine presents a paradox that nobody even remotely associated with the art of the dance will find it easy to accept, for so long as the ballet itself is alive, manifestly Fokine is alive. This is no mere theory, no article of faith; fact and practice demonstrate its substantial truth on every hand.

THE author, gathering material from old records and letters, from Daniel Boone's own writings, from museums and private collections and from visits to the Boone country which she knows well, has put together a convincing story of the great pioneer and his family.

IT is in the latter part of David O. Woodbury's book that the text lives up to the title. Moore, president of Skidmore College, declared today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Gasoline taxes collected in twenty-seven States in July were 18 1/2 per cent below the total of July, 1941, according to the Public Roads Administration of the Federal Works Agency.

As the third year of war came to an end news of our increasing participation in active battles was coming in from the South Sea Islands, the Channel coasts, the Egyptian desert, the dim highlands of China.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 29 (AP) -- The Orioles improved their playoff chances today by taking the measure of the Bears, 6 to 5, for their second victory in a series which has gone three games.

Sheridan, impartial chairman for the New York City trucking industry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Teaching of the realities of a global war, and the obligations of the peace to follow if the future is not to be the prelude to another and worse war, or a way of life hardly less tolerable than war itself, was urged at today's sessions of the Institute on Education and the War by Senator Thomas of Utah, and Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Aug. 31 -- General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters issued this morning a special communique announcing that the Milne Bay area, on the southeastern tip of New Guinea, where the Japanese had made a landing that seriously threatened all United Nations positions in New Guinea, was "rapidly being cleared of the enemy."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Bishop Miguel de Andrea of Buenos Aires disclosed today what President Roosevelt said when they met at the White House last week. The Bishop said:
LORAIN, Ohio, Aug. 30 -- Admiral Ernest J. King came home today to the city of his birth.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Although stocks of soft coal held by consumers throughout the country rose in July to the highest figure on record, many consumers have not acquired sufficient coal to protect themselves from transportation shortages this Fall and Winter, the Office of Solid Fuels Coordinator for War announced today.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Ten-year-old Richard Emil Glenn has the spirit and the fighting qualities of a United States Marine and he is all set to enlist as a "devil dog" in 1950.

A warning to American industry that "we are losing the war" and that we will continue to lose it until we unite unselfishly is sounded by Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, chief of the Army's Services of Supply, in an article in the September issue of the McGraw-Hill industrial magazine, Factory Management and Maintenance.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A special communique issued today reported that the Japanese had suffered heavy losses in the fighting at Milne Bay.

THE only airplanes Earl Walsh expects to see for a while will be Army bombers or pursuit planes flying overhead. He himself is grounded for the duration. For nine years Walsh traveled the country over, flying to San Francisco one week-end, whipping down to Baton Rouge the next and skipping here, there and elsewhere.

The democratic world of today is endangered by conservatism, by persons who are "sufficiently comfortable to be content with their lot" and who are opposed to any change until it is finally forced upon them, the Rev. Dr. Robert Russell Wicks, dean of the Princeton University chapel, declared yesterday morning in a sermon at the Riverside Church.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Aug. 30 (UP) -- General Douglas MacArthur awarded decorations today to fourteen United States Army officers and men for acts of bravery in Australia and over Japanese-occupied bases.

AN EAST COAST PORT, Aug. 30 (U.P.) -- Crewmen of a medium-sized American merchantman, who kept their helplessly drifting vessel afloat after a torpedo wrecked her engine room, told tonight of standing off with a deck gun the Axis U-boat that surfaced to finish the job with shellfire.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 30 (U.P.) -- Flood waters have inundated 60,000 square miles of the Japanese-occupied East China lowlands and 10,000,000 poverty-stricken, war-weary Chinese peasants there are being ravaged by epidemics, it was reported here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Federal Power Commission issued today the first of nine projected reports covering every section of the country, showing the differences in different communities in prices charged for specific amounts of domestic electric current and also indicating whether the charges are made by private or public utility services.

A German Transocean wireless dispatch directed to the United States reported under a Shanghai dateline yesterday that, as a thrust against this country, the Japanese would not permit repatriated aliens who would sail in September to take with them any more than they could carry at one time in ordinary-sized hand baggage.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 30 -- The Maritime Commission has taken over Mohannes, the estate of Kermit Roosevelt in Cove Neck, to be used as a rest or a convalescent home for merchant marine seamen who have suffered from shock and exposure when their ships were torpedoed, it was learned at Cove Neck today.

Tonight's scheduled premiere of "I Killed the Count" at the Cort has been put off until Thursday evening. After three consecutive previews last week it became apparent to interested bystanders that the running time of Alec Coppel's mystery comedy was twenty minutes too long.

The worshipers at solemn mass yesterday morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral were advised by the Rev. Thomas Donnellan, a Summer member of the cathedral staff, that in a choice between spiritual and temporal considerations they should always choose the kingdom of God first.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 107.2 to 107.4. Price changes occurred mainly in the farm products and foodstuffs groups. Increases in eggs, oranges, potatoes and poultry caused the foodstuffs index to rise 1.0 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UP) -- Senator Taft urged today the adoption of a uniform National Selective Service quota system so implemented as to make certain that no local board is forced to draft men with dependents into the armed forces while boards in other parts of the country may still have adequate reserves of eligible and fit single men.

The detailed regulations for the dimming out of vehicle headlights were made public yesterday by Mayor La Guardia as he announced that rigid enforcement of the rules by the Police Department would begin tonight. The regulations apply to street cars, interstate and intrastate buses and the city's franchised bus lines as well as to private motor cars and trucks.

DETROIT, Aug. 30 -- Walter L. Fry, president and general manager of S. Fry Products, Inc., which is engaged in making canvas military equipment under government contract, has sent a telegram to President Roosevelt relating examples of union "slow-down" tactics which he said were sabotaging the war effort.

NOVELS about the New York world of glitter, the swank, the rich, the famous and powerful, come in all shapes and sizes. Some of them, glossy and phony packages of outside-looking-in romance designed for the rental library trade and magazine serialization, glorify an apartment on Park Avenue and a bibulous evening in the bars of Fifty-second Street as if they were the finest possible culmination to the typical American success story.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- Fiddler Bill McGee sagged badly under the weight of two rescue jobs at Wrigley Field today and the Giants had to be content with a victory and a stand-off in a twin bill that attracted 30,809 fans.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Aug. 30 -- A strike of 1,800 employes of the Post Products Company entered its second day today in protest against delay in union contract negotiations, now in progress two months.

Charged with attempting to run down a patrolman who had threatened to give him a ticket for unnecessarily honking his horn, James Kelly, 42-year-old real estate broker of 135 Amersfort Street. Brooklyn, was held for the Court of Special Sessions yesterday on a charge of third-degree assault.

When the 300 trucks of the Department of Sanitation make their tin can collection tours on Wednesday there will be a woman volunteer worker on every truck, seated next to the driver, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his radio "Talk to the People" from City Hall.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 30 -- Like cornered monsters they lie helpless on the floor. Silvered and silent, the barrage balloons billow out as though impatient for release to protect convoys, coast factories and torpedo boats.

DENVER, Aug. 30 (AP) -- American pilots have returned to battle "time after time to overwhelm the enemy against tremendous odds" in the Pacific war zone and their stamina and courage are earning them the reputation of "the best pilots in the world."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Navy has announced the temporary promotion of 279 lieutenant commanders of the Navy to the rank of commander. Among them are the following:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (U.P.) -- The Department of Justice was asked tonight to investigate Representative Dies, chairman of the Committee on Un-American Activities, on charges of "shielding" Axis agents.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Aug. 30 -- In a continuation of the drive begun last May to rid Rockland County of gambling, State police yesterday raided the "Smith Place" in the unincorporated village of Tappan near here, arresting twenty-eight persons who were alleged to have bet on horse races.

Aroused by appeals from the East to "share your oil," Frank Phillips, general chairman of the petroleum industry committee for District No. 2, stated yesterday in Chicago that "this campaign discloses an astonishing misconception of the causes of the gasoline and fuel oil shortage in the East and utter lack of knowledge of the tremendous effort that the Middle West already is making to help solve the problem."

An accusation of the "flagrant misuse" of the New York City Civilian Defense Information Center at Pershing Square "by a private organization to advance its own interests" was made yesterday by Advertising Age, national advertising newspaper, with offices at 330 West Forty-second Street.

He seems to have asked them not only whether he has power to adopt a sweeping economic program without authority of Congress, but whether, in effect, he has power to suspend part of existing Congressional legislation.

The role of policemen in the war will dominate discussions at the three-day police war conference that will mark the forty-ninth annual meeting of the International Police Congress to be held here Sept. 21 to 23, it was announced yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Washington Redskins, with Sammy Baugh pitching in mid-season form, crushed the western Army All-Star football team coached by Major Wallace Wade, 26 to 7 as 55,000 watched in Memorial Coliseum today.
A variety of properties, including a business building, a taxpayer and apartments, have been sold by savings banks, according to reports of transactions made over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Joseph C. Grew, Ambassador to Tokyo for ten years, warned the American people tonight that war production and fighting spirit must be increased, and that unless we abandoned the hope of leading normal lives, "leaving the spirit of self-sacrifice to our soldiers and sailors," we risked the danger of a stalemate in the war with Japan.

ALBANY, Aug. 30 -- An intensive drive to prevent home and farm accidents will be started on Labor Day by the State War Council and State Department of Health by home and farm accidents while with seventy-five civic and service organizations participating.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 30 -- Although signs are multiplying at this steel center that the maximum possible production and distribution of steel products are being directed into channels where they will do the "most good at the best time," apprehension is mounting over the future effect of the current shortage of scrap metal.

With Doublrab, the country's champion sprinter, named for the $7,500 added Bay Shore Handicap, racing will return to Aqueduct today. Eleven are named for the seven-furlong sprint which heads an eight-race program scheduled to begin at 1:45 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Twenty-nine more industrial plants have been selected as meriting the joint Army-Navy Production Award in recognition of outstanding performance on war contracts. The Under-Secretary of War, Robert P. Patterson, and the Under-Secretary of the Navy, James V. Forrestal, made the announcement.

Over Africa, in certain seasons, sweeps a warm, wild wind toward the sea. Heavy with the pollen of exotic blossoms and the scent of aromatic grasses, it blows unceasingly out of the jungle land to the south. Its name is sirocco.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Syracuse and Jersey City swapped 4-0 shut-outs today before the second largest crowd in the history of the local park -- 12,351 fans.

The scholars who are devoting their knowledge and wisdom to the task of saving democracy are thinking in vain unless they learn to make themselves intelligible to the public, according to Professor Lyman Bryson, on leave from Teachers College to be educational director of the Columbia Broadcasting System and the Office of War Information.

One of the most expensive meals ever served in New York is scheduled for tomorrow morning when executives of the film industry, civic leaders and representatives of labor unions will "pay" $1,000,000 in war bond purchases at a "million dollar breakfast."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The Treasury is making every effort to put all available silver into urgent war work, Secretary Morgenthau said today. Substantial amounts of the Treasury's "free silver," he said, already are being delivered to war plants producing aluminum and magnesium.

VICHY, Aug. 30 -- The statement of condition of the Bank of France, dated July 30, shows no important variations in the credits accorded to the securities market. Thirty-day advances on bonds decreased 287,000,000 francs, but bills discounted increased 90,000,000.

The Yankees somehow never delay long in answering a challenge to their supremacy. They made a reply yesterday that more than satisfied a crowd of 50,398 as they walloped Del Baker's Tigers in a double-header at the Stadium. For the twin victories increased the lead of the world champions to eight games over the Red Sox, who were held to an even break by the Browns.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 110.2 on Aug. 18. This compares with 110.9 a fortnight before, 111.6 a month before, 106.4 a year before and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Johnny Vander Meer shut out the Phils by 2 -- 0 to equal his 1941 record of sixteen victories in the opener of a double-header today and the Reds added an 8-5 triumph with Ray Starr hurling.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The National War Labor Board ruled today on the wage petition of 4,000 employes in six plants of the Reynolds Metals Company, Inc., that "under the facts of this case any general increase is precluded by the national wage stabilization program."

The article "News Is Sadly Lacking on American Fighting" in THE TIMES of Aug. 23 echoes so strongly what I have thought about Washington's handling of war publicity that I am prompted to write my first letter to a newspaper.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Riding high on a surge which has brought them nineteen victories in the last twenty-two games, the Cardinals triumphed twice over the Braves today.
No day passes now without fresh evidence of the war coming to the back door. It is a quickening rhythm in the home, as well as on the battlefront. A small repair is needed in the heating system.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 30 -- Splitting a double-header with the Pirates, while the rampant Cardinals were taking two from the Braves, the Dodgers, who so confidently entered St. Louis last Monday with a seven and one-half game lead, tonight faced the disturbing fact that their advantage had been whittled to three contests.

Recent discussions in the editorial columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES have dealt with the question of property rights in patents and prompt the emphatic assertion that patents, as an indication of the inventor's rights to his inventions, are and should be property.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- An increase in the movement of cash oats in the Northwest and offerings of Canadian grain in the East tended to curtail speculative interest in this grain, but hedging pressure was less in evidence and when shorts tried to cover they found offerings rather light at times.

The Communist party line in the State and nation took a new turn yesterday at the State convention of the Communist party as demands predominated for the harnessing of the nation's war effort to a "centralized, planned national economic program."

Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands celebrates her sixty-second birthday today in England, where she has carried on her constitutional functions since May, 1940. It is the third time that she observes the day in exile. Twice before her faithful subjects in subjugated Holland celebrated the anniversary of the "Mother of Her Country" in defiance of the Nazi authorities.
Leases of furnished and unfurnished apartments with fourteen new tenants in the London Terrace development on West Twenty-third Street were disclosed in the latest rentals reported over the week-end.

Emphasizing that the duty of the Christian church is to put forward spiritual rather than material aid, the Rev. Charles H. Graf asserted yesterday morning at St. John's Episcopal Church, 218 West Eleventh Street, that renewed faith in one's self was the antidote for all the troubles existing throughout the world today.

Trading improved in nearly all wholesale markets last week, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Large numbers of ready-to-wear buyers were in town along with those attending the jewelry and gift shows.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Despite pronounced seasonal inactivity the stock markets here have not lost their quiet strength. Stimulated by further favorable announcements of dividends, industrial shares renewed their advance at the weekend, the index for that group reaching the highest point since the war started at 83.4, which also was the best since June 8, 1939.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The hapless Athletics snapped a nine-game losing streak today, rallying for two runs in the ninth inning to defeat the White Sox, 3 -- 2, in the second game of a double-header after losing the opener, 2 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Seven Japanese planes were shot down out of a total of twenty-four participating in two unsuccessful bombing raids last Friday (Washington time) on Guadalcanal Island, in the Solomons, the Navy Department announced today.
MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's midnight communique:

Twice in our century an illimitable war has been started by an attack on a state in Eastern Europe. This is neither coincidence nor accident. It is proof, if any were needed, that the second war is a continuation of the first and that the basic issues are the same. Likewise it is proof that those issues were not settled among the original antagonists.

CLERMONT-FERRAND, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Marshal Petain's address here today was his first political speech since he explained the circumstances of the appointment of Pierre Laval as head of the government last April. The speech was notable in that it departed from the Marshal's usual pessimism.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- Price ceilings on lard and other hog products, with no restriction on prices of hogs, have forced all leading meat packers to operate at a loss, it is reported, and brokers express the belief that unless there is a readjustment, it will be some time before the returns on pork products will cover the cost of the hog.

NOTTINGHAM, England, Aug. 30 (Canadian Press) -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Lord Privy Seal, told a youth rally here today that "in every land where the Nazis have gone in and in Germany itself there are countless, unnamed young heroes of liberty fighting the underground war."
The national amateur tennis championships made up for lost time in an unusually heavy schedule yesterday as 6,000 looked on at the West Side Club, Forest Hills.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Members of the Women's Reserve of the Navy, nursing blisters on their heels and aching muscles, were getting the Capen House shipshape tonight for the arrival tomorrow of their director, Lieut. Comdr. Mildred McAfee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- President Roosevelt will speak tomorrow in dedication of the new naval medical center at Bethesda, Md. The event will mark the 100th anniversary of the founding of the Navy's Bureau of Medicine and Surgery.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Bears clinched the International League pennant, their seventh in eleven years, as they divided a double-header today with Baltimore.

All Christians throughout the world desire the "utter destruction of Hitlerism" and are determined that complete and final victory over the Axis will be won by the United Nations, the Rev. Dr. Wesley Megaw, pastor of the Fort Washington Presbyterian Church, Wadsworth Avenue and 174th Street, declared yesterday, morning in his sermon.

Charging that drink and vice are "playing havoc" among the officers and men in the armed forces and are being looked upon by authorities as "worse than sabotage," the Rev. Dr. Stewart M. Robinson, chairman of the Committee on Chaplains of the Presbyterian Church of the United States of America, called upon the churches of the nation to participate in a renewed campaign to stamp out these evils.

Because of the recent slow trade in men's clothing, some local retailers will start their Fall promotional campaigns this week, although the majority of the programs will not break until next week. Contrary to expectations earlier in the year, stores are well stocked with wool goods and in some cases will have to carry over Summer-weight merchandise.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 -- An unwieldy long interest built up in September corn earlier in the season has been liquidated in a persistent manner during recent weeks and prices dropped last week to the lowest levels of the season before rallying.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (U.P.) -- The country faces a shortage of 50,000 school teachers for the coming school term. And before the school bells begin ringing in another week to end the Summer vacations the shortage may become more serious as the draft and defense plants take more male teachers and the Waacs and Waves make inroads among the women personnel.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- Russian bombers, lashing out at least 900 miles from the Eastern Front in heavy raids over Germany, set ninety-one fires in Berlin, Koenigsberg. Danzig and Stettin last night, the Moscow radio announced today. It warned the German people that they could expect long nights of terror from mighty Allied air raiding forces this Winter.

The statement of the Treasury's views on advertising in wartime, which has been prepared in consultation with the Association of National Advertisers, will have a wholesome effect in clearing up doubts that have surrounded that question. It was drawn up following a conference in Washington with the appropriate officials and has been issued with the approval of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- Cleveland and Washington divided a twin bill today, the Indians taking the opener, 3 -- 1, behind Southpaw Al Milnar's effective pitching and the Senators winning the nightcap, 2 -- 0, with the veteran Dutch Leonard on the mound.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Many steps were being taken, official sources related today, to clear President Roosevelt's desk of petty routine so he can concentrate on the war.

D.N.B., German official news agency, and the High Command said yesterday that powerful Russian smashes west of Moscow had gained some ground but declared the strongly fortified defense system of Stalingrad on the Volga had been deeply pierced, according to German wireless transmissions directed to the United States and recorded by The Associated Press.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 30 (AP) -- Nelson Rockefeller, whose peacetime duties as Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs have assumed new significance since Brazil entered the war, is on the way to South America to align a sailing-vessel fleet and rich raw-material areas with the war effort.

It is not surprising that last week's financial markets should have moved perplexedly up and down. War news was the governing influence, but it was difficult to guess which way the conflict, taken as a whole, was moving. The further Nazi advance in Russia was recognized in all the dispatches, but so also was the Japanese defeat in the Pacific islands.

Three years ago today gay bunting flew from every church steeple in Holland. Mansion and cottage alike were similarly decorated with the national colors and those of the House of Orange, and those same gallant colors were proudly worn over the heart of every man, woman and child in the land.

Local law No. 45 of 1936, commonly known as the McCarthy Increment Law, provided that civil service employes who had served at least one year in a position calling for an initial salary of $1,800 a year or less should be entitled to four annual salary increments of $120 each.

There has been a flurry of activity on Maine's lakes and ponds, with salmon, trout and bass reported being taken near the surface. Commissioner George J. Stobie, who visited Moosehead Lake a short while ago, reports good fishing in several sections of this area.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin yesterday and recorded here by The Associated Press:
MOSCOW, Aug. 30 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:
Their activity dictated largely by the ever-changing political sentiment over feasible inflation-arresting methods, cotton traders last week alternately bought and sold on developments in Washington.

AN AIR BASE IN ENGLAND, Aug. 30 (UP) -- The Flying Fortresses can take everything the Germans can dish out, and while they are taking it they can dump concentrated destruction in the laps of the Germans with phenomenal accuracy.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 30 -- The David and Goliath theme was re-enacted in a minor way today in the Y.R.A. championship regatta conducted by the Riverside Yacht Club when a Lawley Sixteen called Gamin beat her bigger and normally faster rivals in the handicap class.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 30 -- Through an announcement made this morning at masses at St. Joan of Arc Roman Catholic Church in Jackson Heights, Queens, Nassau County police established the identity of a woman who is in the Nassau Hospital here with injuries suffered when she was struck by an automobile in Lake Success, L.I., Friday night.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- A mysterious, Commando-style raid on the tiny island of Anticythera, between Greece and Crete, and twenty-four hours of intense air action against Sicily from Malta indicated today that the British were striking strongly once more for the initiative in the Mediterranean.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 30 -- A "gay nineties" revue, which will feature a pantomime entitled "The Life of Deborah the Debutante," by Mrs. Winston H. Hagen, will be given on Sept. 13 by members of society here to aid the local unit of the American Women's Voluntary Services.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (U.P.) -- The Navy Department announced tonight that a medium-sized British merchant ship was torpedoed by an enemy submarine in the Caribbean about the middle of August. Survivors have been landed at an east coast port.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Expenditures for gasoline used by civilian defense workers in the performance of assigned duties may be deducted as a contribution in computing Federal income taxes, but no allowance may be made for car depreciation, the Office of Civilian Defense noted today.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 20 -- Thirty-five women, among them co-eds, graying mothers, stenographers and housewives, begin moving this week from Stanford University classrooms into war factories to take over technical jobs which used to belong almost exclusively to men.

Long ago the Brooklyn Dodgers learned the potency of the Isbell-Hutson forward passing combination, but like the rest of the National Football League they have been unable to stop them. So, when Cecil and Don went to work for the Green Bay Packers at Ebbets Field yesterday the result was the same.
BOSTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- An old jinx hobbled the late-season drive of the Red Sox today as the American League's second-place ball club divided a double-header with the Browns.

VICHY, Aug. 30 -- Serious concern is still being caused by the problem of supplies. The new wheat crop was reached without having to reduce the bread ration directly, but the outlook for food supplies for the coming Winter is not very favorable.

MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 31 -- The Russian defenders of Stalingrad have hurled back all German attacks and struck counter-blows in some sectors, a communique said today, while the Red Army made new gains on the Moscow front and in a new offensive pushed back the German spearhead aimed at the Grozny oil fields in the Caucasus.

Predicting an "inevitable breakdown in Central Europe and in Japan," the Rev. Robert C. Carlson of the New York Avenue Methodist Church, Brooklyn, in a sermon yesterday morning at Trinity Baptist Church, 179 New York Avenue, Brooklyn, said he looked for "moral and spiritual sincerity on the part of the United Nations" after the war.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 30 -- Samuel Goldwyn has accepted the first treatment of a screen story by Lillian Hellman dealing with Russian young people in the Nazi invasion and has announced that he will produce it this Winter with Teresa Wright in the leading role.

FLINT, Mich., Aug. 30 -- Two union committeemen who appeared on picket lines at the Buick aluminum foundry yesterday were ordered barred from the plant today, pending an investigation to determine their loyalty.

In an effort to avert a strike of 15,000 truckmen, whose union contracts with the employers expire tonight, representatives of three locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F. of L., and of the Merchant Truckmen's Bureau will meet today at 11 A.M. to discuss arbitration procedure.

MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 31 (U.P.) -- The most optimistic reports in many weeks told today of Soviet successes, offensive and defensive, in many vital regions west of Moscow, before Stalingrad, and in the Caucasus.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 30 -- Following a conference this afternoon with officials of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation, Commissioner Irvin D. Shapiro of the United States Conciliation Service said that "circumstances are very favorable" for averting a general walkout among the 20,000 war workers in the company's five plants in this vicinity and of settling the dispute over job reclassifications that had already led to work stoppages by 2,000 employes.

The Chinese recapture of Chuhsien, the air base on the China coast, is more important for what it signifies in the larger strategy of the war in the Pacific than for its military consequences. All the evidence points to the conclusion that the sudden Japanese reversal can be attributed to withdrawal of Japanese troops for use elsewhere as much as to Chinese military successes.

The city's departments and agencies have submitted requests totaling $91,059,781 for the 1943 capital budget, the City Planning Commission announced yesterday. This includes $84,843,221 for pending projects and $6,216,560 for new ones.
Sales of private homes in Kew Gardens, Forest Hills and other parts of Long Island were reported by brokers over the week-end.

I should like to take issue with the report by Arnaldo Cortesi on Aug. 22. Your correspondent states that a majority of Argentinians "favor keeping out of war at all costs." Does this mean even at the cost of an Axis victory?

"Fabric substitutes" and fashion "limitations" mean entirely different things to French and American women, and a recent traveler from France, who left the Cote d'Azur in mid-July, yesterday furnished some interesting fashion footnotes to news stories of fabric shortages and severe clothing rationing trickling out of the quarantined vacuum of France.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 30 -- Mike Cestone, Montclair mail carrier, captured the sixth annual New Jersey Shore invitation golf tourney at the Norwood Club today only by the grace of good fortune.

AKRON, Aug. 30 -- Describing the War Labor Board as "a packed institution" composed of "politicians and appointed by politicians," William F. O'Neil, president of the General Tire and Rubber Company, declared today that production of tires for war use was no higher than before Pearl Harbor and perhaps less.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Treasury proposals for a new wartime tax on individuals, a "spending tax" calculated to yield $4,000,000,000 to $5,000,000,000 annually, will be laid before the Senate Finance Committee Tuesday, Chairman George said today.

VICHY, France, Aug. 30 (U.P.) -- British bombers have destroyed or severely damaged one-fourth of the buildings in the once-flourishing French Channel port of Havre during the past two years and all its industries are shut down, Mayor Pierre Courant of Havre asserted today.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 30 -- Coming from behind in spectacular fashion, Herman Steiner of Los Angeles, champion of the Pacific Coast, finished with a score of 16 -- 1 to share first place with Abe Yanofsky of Winnipeg, Canadian titleholder, in the open championship of the United States Chess Federation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 30 -- One hundred thousand German civilians, holding positions in various Reich departments in the former French capital, are being trained on Sundays in street fighting and other forms of partisan warfare, according to reliable persons who left Paris last Thursday and have now arrived here.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 30 -- Chinese soldiers are storming the suburbs of Nanchang, Japan's major base in Kiangsi Province for twenty-nine months, and have recaptured Lungyu in their eastward pursuit of the Japanese in Chekiang Province, the Chinese reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration has ordered into effect tomorrow a new ceiling price of 45 cents an ounce for imported bullion. The former price was 35.375 cents. A preliminary announcement of the increase was made on Aug. 22 by the State Department following negotiations with the government of Mexico, whence most imports come.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 30 (AP) -- A 16-yard field goal, booted before many spectators were in their seats, proved the margin of victory today as the Giants, Eastern Division champions of the National Football League, defeated the Cleveland Rams, 17 to 14, in an exhibition game.

Mrs. John Jacob Astor heads the executive committee for the dinner dance to be given in the Persian Room of the Plaza on Sept. 22 to commemorate the fortieth anniversary of the founding of the Navy League of the United States and to raise funds for the league's emergency war relief program.

From accountants, actors, advertisers, architects and artists to waiters, watchmen, wholesalers and writers a handbook for the citizen at war released yesterday by the Office of Civilian Defense has the answer to "What Can Do?"

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- Aliens who register as Germans, Italians or Japanese in error or involuntarily under the Alien Registration Act of 1940 now may rectify their records. Forms for amended registration are available at all field offices of the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
Five new films are scheduled to have local premieres this week. The program follows:

CLERMONT-FERRAND, France, Aug. 30 -- Despite difficulties the National Revolution of the "new" France would be carried through until unity was attained, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, the Chief of State, told war veterans of the French Legion here today on the second anniversary of the foundation of the Legion as the official political organization of the unoccupied zone.

The story of how the captain of a torpedoed Norwegian motor ship, who had abandoned a lifeboat in the belief that it was unsafe and ordered his crew to crowd into two other boats, was startled to find the abandoned boat two months later on exhibition in a boardwalk stall in Coney Island was released yesterday by the public relations office of the Third Naval District, 90 Church Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 -- The program of the National Defense Committee of the United States Chamber of Commerce will include military phases of the war, civilian and plant protection, measures to combat sabotage and espionage and other matters relating to coordination of the armed forces and trade and industry, it was made known today by Eric A. Johnston, president of the chamber.
