NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 30 -- Great Britain and the United States are missing "perfect" opportunities for whipping public opinion into a more war-minded state by their policies on news of the services, Miss Barbara Ward, foreign editor of The London Economist, declared today in an address before the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae here.

LONDON, Aug. 30 -- The Duchess of Kent, who buried her husband yesterday at Windsor, went today to the little parish church of Iver, Buckinghamshire, and joined the simple village folk who are her neighbors in mourning for the Duke.

Four 17-year-old Negroes were held in $2,500 bail each in Brooklyn Weekend Court yesterday on a charge of assualt and robbery growing out of the mugging Saturday night of Joseph Maraniss, middle-aged printer, on Lefferts Place between Classon and Fraklin Avenues.

Our conquest of the southwest Solomon Islands has lopped off the longest of the tentacles in which Japan hoped to grasp the whole Pacific world. Now, three weeks after the first landings, we are firmly established in the entire Tulagi area.
LONDON, Aug. 30 -- The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir Kingsley Wood, speaking at Dundee today, gave some facts about what was happening to incomes in this country under wartime taxation.
The Canadian dollar was lower last week, the only exception to an otherwise firm array of values for other foreign currencies.
The Canadian dollar was lower last week, the only exception to an otherwise firm array of values for other foreign currencies.

SOMEWHERE IN THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Monday, Aug. 31 -- Lieutenant Duncan Seffern of Manawa, Wis., reached this advanced operational base today after a 70-mile hike through dense jungles in an incessant tropical downpour, during which he went six days without food.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 -- The varying tactical theories that govern the use of our own and British bombers are exemplified by the raids now being made against Western Europe.

Facing a deluge of orders within the next thirty days, moving van operators warned the public yesterday to "move now or not at all." Added to an unprecedented volume of orders is a severe shortage of skilled furniture handlers, many of whom have gone into better paying war industry jobs.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Marketing of the second largest run of cattle here this year and of a total of 107,900 head in the twelve leading centers of the country today was cited by P.O. Wilson, secretary of the National Livestock Marketing Association, as proof of the harm being done by the talk of livestock price ceilings in Washington.
CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A communique issued by Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters:

The loss of three more United Nations merchant ships to enemy submarines operating on this side of the Atlantic was announced yesterday by the Navy. All three sinkings took place months ago. A small United States ship was sunk in April; a small British ship was sent to the bottom in June, and a medium-sized Dutch ship was torpedoed in June.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -In a move to make a larger volume of petroleum available to the Atlantic Seaboard States, the War Production Board today authorized an increased drilling of oil wells in Illinois, Southwestern Indiana and in Northwestern Kentucky.

Does Congress know dynamite when it sees it? If it considers the drafting of 18 and 19 year olds too loaded with political dynamite, can it consider the breaking up of homes by the drafting of married men, with and without children, any less politically explosive?
SAN FRANClSCO, Aug. 31 -- Assurance came today from Secretary Wickard that California would have the help of Mexican laborers in harvesting its sugar beet crop.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Randolph E. Paul, general counsel of the Treasury, attacked tonight the Ruml pay-as-you-go income tax plan on the ground that it would not, as claimed, put the nation's taxpayers on a current basis, but it would cancel several billions of dollars due on 1941 income, and favor the rich.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Willie Goggin and Carl Loeb Jr. of the Century Country Club carded a record ten-under-par 29, 33 -- 62 in the weekly pro-amateur tournament of the Westchester P.G.A. to take the honors over the Briar Hills course today.

Milk distributors for the New York City marketing area decided yesterday to petition Price Administrator Leon Henderson for increases of one-half cent a quart in the retail ceiling prices for milk and 2 cents a half pint for heavy cream to offset higher prices to the farmers which become effective today.

For the first time in years, Handy PIarman, local bullion dealers, failed yesterday to quote a price on silver at New York. Recently, the Office of Price Administration raised the ceiling price on foreign sliver from 35% cents an ounce to 45 cents and that of newly-mined domestic silver to 71.11 cents an ounce plus freight charges.
CAIRO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A British general headquarters and R.A.F communique:

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Going into the seventh inning at Wrigley Field today, the Giants had frittered away a 5-run lead and were trailing the Cubs, 6 to 5, in this play-off of yesterday's tie. Then there stepped from the seclusion of the dugout as a pinch hitter one James Walter Maynard, also known as Buster, from Henderson, N. C.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Aug. 31 -- Opening the Colonial Parliament in the presence of high British and American naval and military officers today, the Governor, Viscount Knollys, placed emphasis on the government's intention to "take every practicable step toward planning and executing a policy fitted for wartime without neglecting the normal welfare of the community.

Net profit of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and its subsidiaries for the twelve months ended with May, amounted to $11,023,372 after Federal taxes, including $9,925,166 estimated excess profits taxes and after providing $6,526,156 additional reserve for contingencies, according to the report made available under the Securities and Exchange Commission regulations.

LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 1 -German armored and other forces pushed early yesterday morning against the British southern flank in Egypt in the neighborhood of Qaret el Himeimat, the War Office disclosed in a communique issued shortly after last midnight.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in August was on a slightly slower scale than in the preceding month and second dullest month of the year. Sales for the month of 7,387,341 shares, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, were the dullest for a corresponding month in twenty-four years, or since August, 1918, and compared with 8,373,550 shares in July and 10,875,370 shares in the same month in 1941.

Following Mayor La Guardia's assurance yesterday that the sixty-seven Welfare Department employes dismissed earlier in the month would be restored to duty tomorrow morning, the City Council voted unanimously yesterday to amend the McCarthy Salary Increment Law.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 31 -- The stoppage of work in the near-by Fair Lawn foundry of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation, which began Friday and affected 2,000 men spread over three shifts, according to the company, ended at about noon today following a direct appeal to about 500 workers gathered in the yard by Federal Conciliator Irvin D. Shapiro.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The July level of employment in non-agricultural establishments reached a new high, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins reported today.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Sept. 1 (AP) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- The nation's 128 distilleries will be converted to production of war alcohol manufacture of whisky, gin when and other beverage spirits ceases in the United States on Nov. 1, and the conversion may be made even earlier, it was announced today by Matthew J. MacNamara, whisky conversion official of the War Production Board in an address before the National Alcohol Beverage Control Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Japanese people, who were told after the Battle of the Coral Sea that the United States Pacific Fleet had been annihilated, now were being warned to be prepared for new attacks by a "superior force" from America, the Office of War Information reported today.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Elmer Riddle won for the Reds from the Phils for the fourth time this season tonight, 8 to 1. A home run by Rookie Eric Tipton sent Cincinnati off to a two-run lead in the second frame.

The police began at one minute after midnight this morning to serve summonses to motorists, bus and truck drivers and trolley car motormen whose headlights or speed violated the new dimout traffic regulation.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 31 -- A novel "sitdown" demonstration was staged early tonight at the Park Works of the Crucible Steel Company in Lawrenceville by a group of shop committeemen of the C.I.O. United Steel Workers of America to prevent a general strike of about 3,000 workers at the war plant over grievances.

The American Bankers Association, which was prevented by wartime transportation difficulties from holding its annual convention in Detroit, Sept. 27 to 30, released yesterday summaries of speeches and committee reports that would have been made at the annual meeting.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Robert S. Peare, manager of General Electric Broadcasting, said tonight that KGEI, the G-E international short wave radio station in San Francisco, did not intend to enter a controversy over the making of musical recordings.

DETROIT, Aug. 31 -- All provisions of the new contract between the Ford Motor Company and the U.A.W.-C.I.O. have been agreed upon and approved by the National Ford Council of the union except those dealing with wages and the union's demand for the establishment of an impartial umpire system of handling grievances, union officials said today.

Out of the fighting that rages over the long Russian front one solid fact stands out The Russians still hold Stalingrad The Volga city controlling the vital artery of water communication in Central Russia is this year's main German objective. The Germans High Command announced that it would fall last week.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- A foreign diplomatic source who could not be quoted by name said today that he had received unconfirmed advices from the Continent indicating that Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Premier Mussolini would confer soon on the dual problems of campaigns in Russia and Africa.

William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, submitted a second report to Mayor La Guardia yesterday saying that he had found instances in which couples applying for marriage licenses had paid gratuities in excess of the legal charges in the Marriage License Bureaus in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- The belief that "the period of gradual exhaustion for the enemy has started" was expressed by General Wladyslaw Sikorski, Premier of Poland, in a statement issued on the third anniversary of the German attack on Poland that began the second world conflagration.
MOSCOW, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

KATONAH, N.Y., Aug. 31 - Development of a Norwegian sailors rest home on the property near here of the old Brookwood Labor College became a certainty today when Bedford town officials re- zoned the campus and college buildings for business use, according to Ray W. Aylesworth, counsel for the Norwegian Shipping and Trade Mission.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 31 -- Louis Norman (Bobo) Newsom, colorful and sometimes extraordinarily competent pitcher, today returned to the Dodgers, the club with which he began his checkered major league career thirteen years ago.

With nine banking groups competing for the business, a group composed of Kuhn, Loeb Co.; Smith., Barney Co., and Blyth Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of a new issue of $5,000,000 Potomac Electric Power Company 3 1/4 per cent first-mortgage bonds, due 1977.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 31 -- In shipyard and tank arsenal, women will probably be found hard at work before the war is over, but there is one place where they will not be employed. That is the steel plant.

Of the 2,220,000 raincoats sought by the Army early last month, the New York needle industries obtained contracts for 515,000, Colonel Thomas W. Jones, director of procurement of the Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot, disclosed yesterday, and said contracts for the whole order have been let.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 1 -- A new German wedge has been driven into Soviet positions southwest of Stalingrad, but the Red Army has continued to gain in a thrust against the enemy flank to the northwest, near Kletskaya, after overwhelming Italian forces, the Russian High Command announced today.

"Wake Island," Paramount's picturization of the United States Marines' stand at that Pacific outpost, will have its world premiere at the Rivoli tonight. The proceeds of the reserved-seat benefit showing will go to the American Red Cross and will be used to aid service men and their dependents. Featured in the film's cast are Brian Donlevy, Robert Preston, Macdonald Carey, William Bendix, Albert Dekker and Barbara Britton, who portrays the picture's only feminine role.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 31 (AP) -Long-range fighters of the Royal Air Force attacked Axis air and land communications in the rear of the desert battle area today, shooting up enemy transport in the Solum region after a night raid on Tobruk, in which United States Army Air Forces bombers took part.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- The filing of a State ticket by the Socialist party late today brought the number of candidates for Governor up to six. The Socialist ticket was filed through Irving Barshop, executive secretary, who said it carried 16,000 names.

Certain elementary and high schools in Manhattan and the Bronx were picketed yesterday by members of the Glaziers Union, Local 1,087 of the A.F. of L., in protest against the use of custodians and their helpers to repair broken windows in the schools.

The threatened strike of 15,000 truck drivers which was scheduled for last midnight was averted, at least temporarily, when employers and the union agreed yesterday to adjourn conferences looking toward an agreement until 1 P.M. tomorrow.

Racing returned to the metropolitan area yesterday with a victory for the King Ranch's 15-to-1 shot, Salto, in the $9,125 Bay Shore Handicap, which was witnessed by 15,609 persons, 7,165 of whom reached Aqueduct via railroad The result was just one of the surprises which studded a program during which $907,210 passed through the totalizator on eight races and the daily double.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31Smoking Pall Mall cigarettes will not prevent finger staining nor are Luckies toasted, the Federal Trade Commission asserted in complaints charging American Cigarette and Cigar Company, Inc., and American Tobacco Company vith misrepresentation in the advertising of their cigarettes.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 31 -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler opened the German Winter Help Campaign tonight by issuing a message to the nation calling for heavy sacrifices by the people, since the German soldier, engaged in the "most gigantic struggle of all time," has "endured privations that are scarcely imaginable."

HOUSTON, Texas, Aug. 31 (U.P.) -- A tropical hurricane with winds ranging to 100 miles an hour swept the Gulf coast of Texas from Galveston to Corpus Christi during the week-end causing property damage of many millions of dollars and killing at least three persons.

CHUNGKING, Aug. 31 (Reuter) -- Chinese troops, pressing forward in Chekiang, have recaptured Lungyu, on the Chekiang-Kiangsi railway, eighteen miles east of Chuhsien, airbase retaken last week. Dispatches from the front today said Lungyu fell yesterday morning after brisk fighting.

Even though the over-all appearance of the war news was distinctly brighter, the uncertainties on the domestic economic front, including the contemplated anti-inflation program and the many proposals advanced in the pending tax legislation, kept trading in the stock market at a minimum yesterday.

The Rural plan has ninny advantages. Conversation with tax experts convinces me that it has very few disadvantages administratively. From the standpoint of the taxpayer the advantage being fully paid up at the end of the year is enormous.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Red Cross supplies worth $8,000,000 have been distributed about equally between Russia and China since the war began, as part of a relief program which thus far has sent $60, 000,000 worth of supplies to 20,000, 000 war victims.

An exhibition of war poster paintings was opened yesterday at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue, to continue through Sept. 15. The project is sponsored by the Abbott Laboratories of North Chicago, Ill.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 31 Several of the younger members of the Summer colony, wearing Chinese costumes, will assist in the tea garden when an entertainment known as "An Auspicious Autumn Festival" will be given for the benefit of United China Relief tomorrow and Wednesday afternoons in the terraced gardens of Shelmar House, home of Francis Hartman Markoe in Water Mill.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 31 -- Official Japanese statements confirm evidence from other sources, which your correspondent is not at liberty to specify, that Japan's boasted "co-prosperity" in Southeastern Asia has everywhere meant a disastrous economic depression.

John R. Crews was re-elected Brooklyn Republican leader at a meeting yesterday of the Kings County Republican Executive Committee at county headquarters, 160 Montague Street Mr. Crews has served as leader since he succeeded Frederick J.H. Kracke in 1934.

NORTHAMPTON, Aug. 31 -- Clad in the natty uniform which is to be worn by all Waves, Lieut. Comdr. Mildred H. McAfee, who is on leave from the presidency of Wellesley College, reviewed this afternoon the forty women's naval reserve corps officer candidates at the Smith College campus.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Coupon rationing of meat to allow consumers not more than two and one-half pounds a week has been decided upon by the Food Requirements Committee, it was disclosed today by Secretary Wickard.

Tammany Hall, which stuck to the last to the standard of James M. Mead in the fight for the Democratic nomination for Governor, yesterday was the first organization in the city to unfurl a campaign banner for the nominee, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The White Sox, making their final appearance here this season, swept both ends of a double-header with the Athletics today, 3 to 1 and 5 to 0.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A nifty forward passer, Tommy Thompson, and an equally able receiver, Bob Priestley, teamed tonight to pace the Philadelphia Eagles to a 16-to-8 victory over the College All-Stars before an estimated crowd of 75,000 in Municipal Stadium.

Pointing out that Monday would be the nation's first war-time Labor Day, Mayor La Guardia appealed yesterday to New Yorkers to ease the demands on out-of-town transportation by finding their recreation within the city over the Labor Day week-end.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Tex Hughson became the first major league pitcher to win eighteen games this season when the Red Sox defeated the Browns, 8 to 6, today. However, Hughson was driven from the mound in the 5-run St. Louis ninth.

BERNE, Switzerland, Aug. 31 -- As the war enters the fourth year objective observers in Europe, not excluding some in Axis countries, consider that its end is conditioned today by factors that were not present when the Germans invaded Poland on Sept. 1, 1939.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Sept. 1 -- The Milne Bay battle has progressed to the point where today's communique from General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters speaks of it as a "mopping up" operation.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Declaring that enemy raids and mass sabotage in New York State are a probability, Governor Lehman told members of the New York Guard here today that they might see actual combat service within the State.

BETHESDA, Md., Aug. 31 -President Roosevelt dedicated the towering, white Naval Medical Center here today as a monument of America's determination to work and to fight for the defeat of "a few inhuman tyrants -- German, Italian and Japanese" -- who, he said, were already feeling the might of the growing Navy.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 31 -- An unprecedented deal for the purchase and distribution of "ten or twelve" already completed Paramount pictures by United Artists has reached final stages of negotiation and probably will be concluded late this week, Gradwell Sears, United Artists vice-president in charge of distribution, disclosed here today.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The Australian press and public acclaimed today the Allied victory in the Milne Bay entrapment and defeat of the Japanese.

OMAHA, Aug. 31 -- While there are still shortages of critical materials which are holding down production, America's existing plane plants will be able to build all the planes we need when they can get a good supply of parts, Glenn L. Martin said here today.
MOSCOW, Aug. 24 -- The Russian humorous paper Krokodil tells the following story about a Karelian cat that became a regimental mascot.

From a Washington dispatch printed in this newspaper yesterday it appears that the desk of the most overworked man in the United States has been cleared of a lot of small-potato stuff that never should have been dumped there. The President of the United States, any President, in ordinary peaceful times has more than enough to do in discharging his constitutional, political and social duties.

WITH THE RED ARMY, Near Rzhev, Aug, 31 (U.P.) -- American-built medium tanks and trucks have played a leading role in the Soviet offensive toward Rzhev. Soviet staff officers said that the American tanks had aided in the break-through that carried Russian forces into the northern outskirts of Rzhev.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (U.P.) -Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, accepted tonight the resignations of Reese Taylor and R.C. Allen, chief and deputy chief, respectively, of the WPB iron and steel branch.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 31 -- Characterizing the Solomons operations as a seesaw battle, Ta Kung Pao declared today that the action had affected Japan's strategy and at least had compelled her "to hesitate in her studied process of encroachment."

Nobody knows what Adolf Hitler thought he was starting when he ordered his troops into Poland three years ago today. Nobody knows whether he thought at all. He is a man of instinct and emotion, and maybe these sufficed. He could not have held back indefinitely, even if he had wished to do so.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 31 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Central China armies have seized Sungyang, thirty miles west of the recaptured air base town of Lishui, and have reached the approaches of Kinhwa, one of the last Chekiang air base towns remaining in Japanese hands, it was announced tonight.

In a beautifully fought match, distinguished by the boldness of the hitting and the variety of the strokes brought into play, Mrs. Marjorie Harshaw Vosters of Lansdowne, Pa., defeated Mrs. Patricia Canning Todd of Jackson Heights, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 9 -- 7, yesterday in the national tennis championships at Forest Hills.

CAMDEN, N. J., Aug. 31 -- Record pay-offs in straight wagering and the daily double pool were set at Garden State Park today when W. A. Connolly's Favorite Trap, at $166.70 for $2, combined with Mrs. Edward Haughton's Leo's Brandy, at $35.80, for a daily double return of $2,456.60 to holders of ten lucky tickets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve System announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Aug. 26: a decrease of $47,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans and an increase of $122,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills; an increase of $450,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and a decrease of $601,000,000 in United States Government deposits.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- After seeking vainly to get quick action on the bill to permit absentee voting this Fall by members of the armed forces, the House sent the measure to conference today.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Queen Wilhelmina was described as a "symbol'' of the Netherlands' fight for freedom by her followers, who likened her to William the Silent, who led the Netherlanders' fight for freedom almost four centuries ago, as she celebrated her sixty-second birthday here today amid a display of armed force and with congratulatory messages pouring in upon her.

The Japanese have taken another hard blow in their defeat at Milne Bay. Their landing was an attempt to retrieve in part their expulsion from Tulagi by establishing a new bridgehead for a two-way offensive against Port Moresby and eventually Australia itself. Now that they have been driven into the sea they have lost the initiative in the New Guinea area and the waters that wash its eastern shore.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 31 -- Ol' Dan'l Boone Davis, who had put out the Cardinal fire in St. Louis, stepped to the Forbes Field mound in the tenth inning today to extinguish an incipient Pirate blaze and help himself to his fifteenth triumph.
The six-story apartment house on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 545 West 146th Street was sold by Harry Stern to a client of the Kempner Realty Corporation, brokers.

WITH U.S. ARMY ON DESERT TRAINING MANOEUVRES, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Although American-made tanks already have given a fine account of themselves in North Africa, they would be no match for the models now being supplied to our Army, according to Major Gen. Jacob L. Devers, chief of the armored force.

The preparation of women to take ever certain production jobs and replace men for the armed services will be the immediate task of Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, newly named director of personnel and labor relations for the Todd Shipyards Corporation.

The New York Stock Exchange firm of Winthrop, Whitehouse Co. proposes to dissolve on Sept. 30, with many of the partners considering the joining of other firms while a few expect to retire from business. The firm was formed last December through the merger of the Eastern division of Winthrop, Mitchell Co. with Whitehouse Co.

An honor roll bearing 593 names, including those of three women, was dedicated yesterday by Mayor La Guardia and Welfare Commissioner William Hodson, at the Department of Welfare Headquarters, 902 Broadway, before several hundred persons.

A new issue of $33,950,000 City of San Antonio Electric and Gas revenue bonds, with coupon rates of 2 1/2, 2 3/4 and 3 per cent, due serially on Aug. 1, 1944 to 1972, is being offered today by an under-writing group headed by Dillon, Read Co. and A.C. Allyn Co., Inc., The Union Securities Corporation, and E. H. Rollins Sons, Inc.
Following is the text of an address made by President Roosevelt yesterday at the dedication of the Navy Medical Center at Bethesda, Md., as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Colonel Darryl F. Zanuck, vice president in charge of production for Twentieth Century-Fox, has received leave of absence without compensation at his own request to devote his full time to the Army, it was announced yesterday by Spyros P. Skouras, president of Fox, after a special meeting of the board. At the same time it was disclosed that Colonel Zanuck also tendered his resignation as vice president and member of the board.

A variety of proposals to aid the small business man, ranging from financial assistance to retraining of proprietors to prepare them for executive work in war factories and war agencies, will come before the Senate Committee on Small Business, which will start a series of hearings on Sept. 28, it was announced yesterday by Senator James E. Murray, chairman of the committee.

OTTAWA, Aug. 31 - Beginning tomorrow, all employment throughout Canada will be controlled by the government through the Director of National Selective Service working in cooperation with the Ministry of Labor and the National Defense Department.

After fairly substantial mill buying at midday had accounted for gains of as much as 21 points, or $1.05 a bale, the volume of hedge selling increased in late trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and the market closed unchanged to 6 points higher.

CHUNGKING, Aug. 31 (U.P.) -- United States Army fliers based in China have made four devastating raids on Japanese bases in Burma and French Indo-China in a 72-hour period without losing a plane, it was announced, today at Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters.
SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Aug. 31 -- The Japanese Broadcasting Corporation put on an interesting and instructive "news" program from Tokyo tonight.

Diatoms -- microscopic plants that float to and fro with the tides in aimless fashion and that are deemed delicious by the oysters that consume them -- flourish in wet weather. That is why, when the rains came this Summer, the oyster men rejoiced.

One thousand citizens of the Netherlands and their friends observed last night the sixty-second birthday of Queen Wilhelmina at a rally in the Hotel Astor. Similar celebrations were held in England, the Dutch West Indies and at various spots on the globe where free Dutch meet.

OTTAWA, Aug. 31 (Canadian Press) -- With home beef requirements cared for by purchases of the wartime Food Corporation, Canadian beef cattle exports to the United States this year to Aug. 27 totaled 120,232 head, the Agriculture Department reported today.

The New York Football Giants, fresh from their 17-14 victory over the Cleveland Rams at Akron, Ohio, in Sunday's exhibition game, arrived yesterday to begin the final phase of their preparations for the game with Colonel Bob Neyland's Army All-Stars. The contest will be held at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 12 and the Tribune Fresh Air Fund and the Army Emergency Relief will benefit.

"RILLY MITCHELL was right," say people like Major A1 Williams. "Billy Mitchell was wrong," says retired Brig. Gen. Henry J. Reilly. And so the contest rages over the prophetic air officer who tried throughout the Twenties and the early Thirties to warn the United States of the role that air power would play in the next war. But the truth is, as usual, a compromise: Billy Mitchell was both right and wrong.

Resumption of extensive advertising by Nash-Kelvinator, Detroit, "in the interest of the war effort, the future of its dealers and the protection of its name," was announced yesterday by the company. Full-page four-color copy will break in sixteen national magazines beginning this month.

In an effort to alleviate a shortage of experienced engineering personnel caused by the draft, Columbia University has started training fifty-five young women as engineering aides for the Grumman Aircraft Corporation of Bethpage, L. I., in the first such course ever given in this country in cooperation with an aircraft plant, it was announced yesterday by Professor Frank H. Lee of the University Drafting Department.

Richard A. Di Costanzo was selected last night as the Republican and American Labor party nominee for the State Senate in the Eighteenth district, Manhattan, to succeed Senator Charles Muzzicato, who has been nominated as the Republican candidate for Representative-at-large.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in its monthly review of credit and business conditions, estimates nation-wide sales of war savings bonds in August at $700,000,000, compared with $901,000,000 in July and with the announced August quota of $815,000,000.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Aug. 31 (UP) -- Whether Navy men should salute officers of the Waves has become a problem, according to their director, Lieut. Comdr. Mildred McAfee. She told tonight of two naval officers in Boston dodging around a corner as she approached and remarked that "apparently they didn't know whether to salute me or not."

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 31 -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, playwright and wife of Henry R. Luce, publisher of Time, Life and Fortune magazines, announced today that she had decided to seek the Republican nomination for Representative from the Fourth Congressional District, which embraces Fairfield County.

One good way of safeguarding the American people against undue optimism about the war would be to suppress all the newspapers and shut down the broadcasting stations. Here, for instance, is a straight warning from high official quarters in Washington not to suppose that our victories in the Solomon Islands are really important.

New financing in August was virtually at a standstill here, with public offerings of new bond issues the smallest for any month since January, 1939. There were no stock flotations for the first time since June, 1935.

Mayor La Guardia revived his plan for a "yardstick" power company under municipal operation yesterday when he asked the City Council to adopt a local law permitting the city to buy the Staten Island Edison Corporation at a price which he said would be between $14,000,000 and $16,500,000, the top limit.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- Hedging pressure at Minneapolis, reflecting larger offerings as the result of receipts of 1,016 cars of cash wheat, the largest of the season, unsettled the market on the Board of Trade today, and while there was fair support closing sales showed losses of 1/4 to 3/8 cent a bushel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Revision of high school programs, modification of college entrance examinations and other adjustments designed to correlate schools to the war, were adopted at today's closing session of the Institute on Education and the War.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Office of Price Administration announced the methods by which mail order houses can post ceiling prices for cost-of-living items under the General Maximum Price Regulation.

CAIRO, Egypt, Aug. 31 -- An Axis attack on the front that extends southward from the region of E1 Alamein was expected monlentarily all day yesterday. The tenseness that set in early last week in the forward positions of the British Eighth Army increased,

Basing its program on the theory that the draft age will be lowered to include 18 and 19 year olds, the Board of Education is preparing to revise its high school courses so they will be more in line with requirements set forth in Army manuals, Associate Superintendent Frederic Ernst, chief of the high school division, declared yesterday.

Anthony Cramer, a 42-year-old mechanic, was accused of treason yesterday in the first such indictment to be handed up here in this war. Cramer was one of the fourteen persons rounded up last June as "contacts" of the eight men who were landed on American shores by Nazi submarines.
LONDON, Aug. 31 -- The Germans tonight were reported to have executed or sentenced to death ninety-eight more persons in combatting the growing wave of opposition throughout occupied Europe.

Some folks still scoff at fairy tales and fables, but they haven't heard the story of Jimmy McCann, a 3-year-old lad who walked off with four lollipops and two war stamps yesterday, just because he remembered about the tortoise and the hare.

RIVERHEAD, L.I, Aug. 31 -- Robert H. Hairston of Melville, unanimously was elected chairman of the new Suffolk County Democratic Committee, at the organization meeting of the committee held in the County Court House here this afternoon.

No ceremony marked the official closing of Townsend Harris High School yesterday, although for thirty-five years it had permitted exceptionally bright students to complete their high school work in three years instead of the usual four.

According to German broadcasts directed to the United States, the German High Command declared yesterday that its assault forces had driven to within fifteen miles of Stalingrad from the south, and military quarters were quoted by the German Transocean news agency as having said that "the fighting for Stalingrad has entered its final stage." The Associated Press reported.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- A Federal grand jury indicted today two former officials of the War Production Board and three dealers in used machine tools for conspiracy to defraud the government and to interfere with the prosecution of the war.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Joseph C. Grew, United States Ambassador to Japan, and members of the embassy staff, it was learned today, had a ringside seat during the United States Army air attack on Tokyo by Brig. Gen. Doolittle and his aviators.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Aug. 31 -- President Getulio D. Vargas followed up today Brazil's entry on Aug. 22 into the war against Germany and Italy with a decree declaring a "state of war" throughout the country. The declaration is called for under Article 166 of the Constitution to put the country's resources on a war footing when it "becomes necessary that the armed forces be employed in the defense of the State."

A physician's glory is the number of lives he has saved, the number of persons lie has restored to health. A naval or military doctor in war time shares that glory, but he has also to face the fact that the men whose wounds or illnesses he is able to cure may be destined all the sooner for another gamble with death.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Cananea, claimed 'for $1,500 at Rockingham Park, today returned her third winning dividend to Owner-Trainer Sol Rutchick in the Saylesville purse for juveniles of $3,000 caliber at Narragansett Park. Tile 3-to-1 shot scored by a neck over Ample Reward, who had a length on Suntegra.

PASSAIC, N.J. Aug. 31 -- First Lieutenant Pascoe Deaton, bombardier on a B-24 flying fortress, met death with ten other members of the crew on Aug. 9 somewhere on the East African coast, the adjutant general's office of the War Department notified his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Deaton of 60 Lafayette Avenue, today.

BAY SHORE, L. I., Aug. 31 -- In the second race for the Atlantic Coast championship of the Star class of sloops, Eddie Ketcham of the Great South Bay fleet today took the point lead from Harold Halsted of Moriches Bay.

PROVIDENCE, R, I., Aug. 31 -- The National Federation of Music Clubs condemned today the action of James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, in prohibiting union members from making recordings for radio and other public use.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Reports from the Australian area encouraged the stock market today. Australian shares, chiefly bank and government issues, were marked up. British government issues were buoyant, the 3 1/2 per cent war loan gaining 1/8 to 106 1/2, which equaled the highest price touched this year.

Reporting the most successful renting season in several years, the Cruikshank Company listed yesterday among new apartment rentals fourteen leases in 200 West Fifteenth Street as follows: Dr. Gerhard Witt of Union Theological Seminary, Dr. Buck Luria, Janet Baird, Kathryn Dann, Arthur G. Lawson, Fice Mork, Herbert H. Brown, Dr. Maxwell Malament, Julia Evans. Mrs. Luella Beaumont, Vera Gladden, George L. Drum, Gerhard Tapken and Louise Van Bergen.

Asserting that a widely manufactured garment known as a "jive, juke or jeep coat" violated Limitation Order L-85, H.M. Brundage, Deputy Regional Director of the War Production Board, announced yesterday that the Regional Compliance Department had been instructed to prosecute vigorously this and all other violations of government orders.

It would be rash for any one at this moment in the absence of current information and evidence to prophesy in regard to the campaign in the Caucasus. It seems possible, however, to make certain estimates of the campaign in the East based on experience of Russia in the past.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Two officers who returned a bullet-riddled Flying Fortress to its British base after a battle with Nazi fighter planes over the North Sea -- and one who died before the plane landed and was the subject of a posthumous award -- received Distinguished Service Crosses today from Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, commander of United States forces in the European theatre.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores declined 13 per cent last week below the corresponding 1941 period, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline was sharper than had been expected but comparisons are with a period last year when retail sales were soaring.
In accordance with tradition, Labor Day is celebrated in them theatre with matinees. Divided into plays and musicals, the list of eleven for next Monday -- alphabetically arranged -- follows:

A hundred scholars adjourned a five-day effort on behalf of democracy with a declaration yesterday at Columbia University that the "intellectual confusion" of a generation still prevailed in their varied fields of knowledge.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The National Labor Relations Board criticized today an electioneering campaign of the International Association of Machinists (A.F.L.) based on the promise of premium pay for week-end war production, in violation of a pledge to President Roosevelt.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 -- A registration statement covering the issue and sale of 60,000 shares of common stock, 30,000 shares of producers common stock and 30,000 shares of preferred stock, all $10 par, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the newly organized Stillwater worsted Mills, Inc., Harrisville, R.I.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Resisting Treasury demands for sharp increases in corporation taxes, the Senate Finance Committee voted today to retain the combined normal and surtax rate of 45 per cent voted by the House, then approved a 10 per cent post-war refund and a ceiling of 80 per cent on the effective tax rate of any corporation.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Hog prices broke 25 cents a hundred pounds today, the largest decline in more than a month, as talk of meatless days and ceilings, smaller government lease-lend purchases and expanding receipts at major centers combined to unsettle the market.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 31 - The Rev. James Herbert Anderson, 34 years old, pastor of the Negro Mount Olive Baptist Church, East Orange, was arrested tonight on a charge of murder after, the police charge, he had shot and killed his mother-in-law and wounded his sister-in-law during a domestic quarrel here.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 31 (AP) -- The outlawed Irish Republican Army issued an manifesto today charging that the presence of United States troops in Northern Ireland was an act of aggression.

The Treasury's new proposal for a wartime "spending tax" will be laid before the Senate Finance Committee today. There will then be an opportunity to study its details. But as outlined in advance by Senator George, it does not look promising. The "spending tax," at a basic rate of perhaps 10 per cent, would be imposed, possibly on a graduated scale, on virtually all persons with incomes of more than $1,000 annually.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Bobby Coombs continued his mastery over Syracuse tonight for Jersey City as the two clubs concluded the season's regular play with each other in the Chiefs' final scheduled home game. He allowed seven hits and eked out a 4-to-3 decision, his fifth in six starts against Syracuse.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The War Production Board sad tonight that the conversion program under which liquor producers are shifting to the production of industrial alcohol for the war effort has been in progress for some time and is expected to be completed by Nov. 1.

Infuriated by routine questions in seeking the release of his ten-month-old daughter from the New York Foundling Hospital, 175 East Sixty-eighth Street, a 21-year-old father went berserk at 4:45 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the admitting room of the institution, stabbed the supervisor and a nun and fled in the ensuing panic. Four hours later he was taken into custody near his home, and early this morning was booked on a charge of felonious assault.

Representative William T. Pheiffer, Republican, announced yesterday to his supporters in the Fifteenth Congressional District that he would not leave Washington to campaign for re-election. He declared that since his election he had devoted all his time to representing his constituents in Washington, that duties on the "firing-line" have increased tremendously, and that his work for his constituents "can not, and shall not, stop for a political campaign."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- An interdepartmental committee has been set up to see that wage differences between copper mining and competing employments paying more are adjusted, Donald Nelson, war production chief, revealed today in a letter appealing to miners of copper and other critical materials to stay at their jobs.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Striking after the Japanese had repaired damage caused by American bombing raids, Allied fliers in two days of attacks hit sharply at the important Japanese air base at Myitkyina, in North Burma, it was announced today.

Add to the food campaign for peaches, broilers and fryers, which we have had since May, the present drive in behalf of cheese. The Agricultural Adjustment Administration wants us to eat as much cheese as possible. The idea of the new Victory Food Drive is to help ease the strain on certain commodities by using foods that are plentiful.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The Navy will mark Labor Day by launching or laying the keels of 150 naval vessels, an all-time record for simultaneous operations. The launchings and keel-layings, planned as part of a program arranged around the slogan "Free Labor Will Win," will take place in seventy-five municipalities in twenty-seven States.

The twelfth literary fellowship of a series sponsored by the Boston publishers, Houghton Mifflin, was awarded yesterday to Donald MacRae, chairman of the English Department of Central Washington College, Ellensburg, Wash.

Always a few Jumps ahead of the equinoxes, book publishers with the new month enter their Fall season. Each has a favorite he is grooming as a best-seller entry. Among the favorites here are a few titles that will make their appearance in the next four weeks.
OAKDALE, L.I., Aug. 31 -- As eager as a kid counting the days till Christmas, peppery Herb Kopf just can't wait to see how his new offense, known as the QT formation, is going to work.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Aug. 31 -- Communal field kitchens for German workers have finally been introduced throughout the Reich after a long period of hesitation on the part of the authorities, who feared unfavorable psychological effects of the measure.

James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, resigned last night as honorary chairman of the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League in protest against a boycott called by the organization against The New York Daily News. The boycott was announced last week by Professor James H. Sheldon, national chairman of the league, which claims a national membership of 2,000,000.

LONDON, Aug. 31 -- Coinciding with the announcement of the arrival in London of the New Ethiopian Minister, Professor Ayalla Gabre, came the news today of the departure of British troops from Addis Ababa, provided for under the military convention entered into at the beginning of this year.

WITH THE RED ARMY, Near Rzhev, Aug. 31 -- From where I am writing, on a little island of firm, birch-covered ground amid the swamps from which General Polianoff recently launched an attack on Pogoryaloe-Gorodishche, the bombardment of German positions east of Rzhev sound ceaselessly.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 31 -- As a compromise between file requests of government representatives and defense counsel, Federal Judge Thomas Meaney today set Nov. 9 as the trial date for nine companies and six of their officers on charges of conspiracy to defraud the government in the sale of insulated cable to the Navy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Class I railroads had an estimated net income, after interest and rentals, of $376,500,000 in the first seven months of 1942, a gain of 61.8 per cent from the same period in 1941, it was announced today by the Association of American Railroads.

SEPTEMBER arrives and with it begins the annual stretch drive of the major league pennant races. It is, without doubt, the toughest portion of baseball's long Summer grind. Tempers are short, nerves become taut, arras and legs are sore and weary.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's communique early today:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Hollywood launched September's $1,000,000,000 war bond drive from the steps of the Treasury today.

BELFAST, Aug. 31 (U.P.) -- American troops stationed in Northern Ireland were understood tonight to have been ordered to stay away from Belfast Wednesday night. The execution of Thomas Joseph Williams, 19, member of the Irish Republican Army, for killing a constable, is scheduled for that day.
One of the fishing triumphs of the past week, although they caught nothing, went to Harold Lentz of the Dover Fishing Club. Philadelphia, and his 13-year-old son, George.

Mrs. Frances E. Sneyd, young American wife of Henry Sneyd, a British munitions factory executive, arrived at the Marine Terminal at La Guardia Field yesterday on a Flying Ace of the American Export Line with her 18-month-old son, Stephen, one of the youngest of transatlantic flying passengers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- Hollywood launched September's $1,000,000,000 war bond drive from the steps of the Treasury today.

BELFAST, Aug. 31 (U.P.) -- American troops stationed in Northern Ireland were understood tonight to have been ordered to stay away from Belfast Wednesday night. The execution of Thomas Joseph Williams, 19, member of the Irish Republican Army, for killing a constable, is scheduled for that day.

Completion of the government's program for moving civilian agencies out of Washington to ease housing and office space shortages in the capital was announced here yesterday by Fred W. Vincent Jr., assistant manager of the Office of Decentralization Service.
BELFAST, Sept. 1 (U.P.) -- The government announced tonight that it had uncovered a plot for widespread violence by the outlawed Irish Republican Army.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- The war effort and the Cubs were the beneficiaries today of the Giants' 1942 farewell to Wrigley Field.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The C.I.O. sent word to the White House today that labor was opposed to "the naming of any czar or supreme dictator to regulate the economic affairs of the nation."

IVfarried men in New York CityI may be reclas:*ied by their draft[ boards before the end of the year, but they are not likely to be called until after 100,000 unmarried men, heretofore classified as 3-A because of dependents, have been re-i classified and inducted into the Army.

Robert Founier, 20 years old, a Puerto Rican of French descent, was impatient and unrepentant yesterday when he was taken into Felony Court to face the charge of having stabbed a nun and a woman supervisor in the New York Foundling Hospital with an icepick for refusing to turn over to him his 11-month-old child.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Office of Price Administration today established what it termed a "simpler and faster procedure" for handling retailers' applications for adjustment of their ceiling prices. The machinery providing for expedited handling of applications was set up in two companion actions:
Mecca Temple, opened about seventeen years ago under auspicious circumstances as a fraternal meeting-place and musical center, was bid in for taxes yesterday by the city.

CHUNGKING, Sept. 1 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops have captured a railway village eight miles east of Kinhwa, site of a "bomb Tokyo" air base, and the Japanese garrison there has fired the town and is counter-attacking in three directions in an attempt to escape encirclement, it was reported tonight.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Sept. 1 -Frederick F. Schock, president of the Hastings Square Hotel Company, owner of the Essex and Sussex Hotel here, said today that the hotel had not been taken over and that his concern had received no information that the Army intended to take over the hotel for military purposes.

The New York Central Railroad proposes to start court action to determine whether it should pay income and excess profits taxes for the New York Harlem Railroad, F.E. Williamson, president of both companies, announced yesterday. The N.Y. H. owns the site of and approach to the Grand Central Station.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- An average increase of 15.53 cents a ton in minimum prices at the mine for bituminous coal was authorized today under an order issued by the Bituminous Coal Division of the Interior Department. The increases, worked out on a regional basis, range from 5 to 30 cents a ton.

The statement in the letter, "General Eaker's Example," in your issue of Aug. 21 presents a Phil Kearny that does not accord with what his enemy said of him. From what they saw of him in the Peninsula and at Second Manassas, he always led his men, and with distinction. They never associated him with "Lead and I follow."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Treasury today set its September quota of war bond sales at $775,000,000 -- considerably lower than recent months -- but disclosed an intention to build up to a goal of nearly $2,000,000,000 in January.

With a national goal of a billion dollars in war bond and stamp sales to aim for, the motion picture industry swung into action yesterday and at 8 A.M. announced that the campaign was off to a $54,048,500 start, exceeding the first day's quota by $20,000,000.

September marks the opening of the saddle-shoe season. Country houses crackle with the friendly sound of hearth fires and college campuses wear the bright splashes of confetti-colored tweeds and shetlands.

The German High Command declared yesterday that Axis forces, breaking stiff Russian resistance, had reached the coast of the Black Sea below the Kuban River and had occupied the port of Anapa, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

The stock market followed yesterday a listless course. Traders looked upon the situation generated by the tax proposals and the projected anti-inflation program too complicated to hazard any definite market commitments. Trading was inaugurated on the Stock Exchange in ten-share units for a new list of thirty issues, but even this move did not help the volume to any extent, for the deals in such stocks only aggregated 1,870 shares.

FORT DIX, N.J., Sept. 1 -- Tonight was pay night at Fort Dix, but the merchants of Pointville were not there to reap the profits. The fifty or so stores and taverns in the community, surrounded on three sides by the reservation, were reminiscent of a ghost town except for the fact that the town was crowded with soldiers waiting for buses to take them to Trenton and Philadelphia.

Despite "indiscriminate" charges of "unconscionable" profits by manufacturers on war contracts, a study of the net income and tax figures of 125 of the largest arms contractors, covering the first half of 1942, shows that net income after taxes was 36. per cent below that of the first six months of 1941, according to the National City Bank in its monthly bank letter released yesterday.

William B. Cox, president of the New York Football Americans of the American League, said yesterday through The Associated Press that the league's club owners are so tied up with war work that the circuit would not operate this year and possibly not for the duration.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Syracuse Chiefs divided a double-header with the champion Newark Bears today, taking the nightcap by 2 -- 0 behind Clay Lambert's sparkling two-hit pitching after dropping the seven-frame opener, 10 -- 1.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 -- Aggressive buying of wheat futures here and at Minneapolis, which brokers attributed to mills who were removing hedges against flour sales, lifted prices to new high levels for the last six weeks on the Board of Trade.

In spite of the fact that the United States oil industry is producing several times the volume of 100-octane gasoline that military experts estimated in 1940 as the maximum war requirements of the country, The Lamp, official organ of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, in its current issue says that within a year today's capacity will be expanded to an even greater figure.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 (AP) -- President Manuel Avila Camacho told Congress in his annual message today that Mexico was in the war until "a peace worthy of our living in it" shall have been achieved and will not make a separate armistice or peace.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Mrs. Roosevelt forecast today a "very chaotic situation" unless the housekeeping burdens of the women who were going into war industries were lightened.

Nine Housing Authority groups in various parts of the country made known yesterday that they would open bids on Sept. 9 on new issues of Federal Housing notes. The issues aggregate $45,614,000 and range in size from $420,000 to $12,400,000.

Activity in the local cotton futures market felt yesterday the impact of late hedging operations and lost early gains. Under this pressure, exerted chiefly in the distant months, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 10 to 13 points below Monday's final prices.

Manufacturers indicated yesterday that the pending government order for 35,000,000 woolen and worsted fabrics, including 6,000,000 blankets, might create some complications if specifications on the blankets call for the use of all domestic wools, but they felt confident that the industry will fill the order.

James G. Blaine, chairman of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, congratulated forty Red Cross nurses at City Hall yesterday on their work in training volunteer nurses' aides as they received certificates of merit for the accomplishment.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Sept. 2 (AP) -t comuniqud:

A shortage of some types of high-grade meats and other food products already is being felt or soon will be felt here as a result of war conditions, it was reported yesterday by restaurateurs. In order to offset the possibility that such shortages may become serious, hotels and restaurants have begun a city-wide campaign to impress upon the public the need for food conservation.

Renting of new apartments continued brisk yesterday in various parts of the city. Among the new leases reported was that of Percy D. O'Connell, vice president of the American News Company, who rented an apartment in the new Leslie Apartments, 150 Greenway Terrace, Forest Hills Gardens.

Ten thousand purchasers of War Bonds will be granted free admission to the opening performance of the Ice Capades of 1943 on Friday night at Madison Square Garden. According to an announcement yesterday, the managements of the Garden and Ice Capades are giving away tickets to each buyer of a War Bond in the drive being conducted by Station WJZ.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The War Production Board is reported to be determined that the plan of Henry J. Kaiser, West Coast shipbuilder, for producing heavy cargo-carrying planes shall get a trial despite the alleged objection of the Army and Navy.

Forty thousand home owners in the East have responded to the government warnings of a fuel oil shortage this Winter and have converted their oil burner furnaces to coal, Lawrence B. Davis, director of marketing for Region No. 1 of the Office of Petroleum Coordinator, said yesterday.

CAIRO, Sept. 1 (U.P.) -- British troops have hurled back General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's new attempt to crash through to the Nile Valley, and United States tank crews are helping to hold the front line while American fliers battle Marshal Rommel's dive-bombers and pound incessantly at his ground forces, it was disclosed tonight.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's midnight communique:

Mayor La Guardia borrowed the words of a Rodgers and Hart song from "Garrick Gaieties" yesterday to describe the beauties of New York as he repeated his plea to New Yorkers to spend the Labor Day week-end at home.

Full cooperation in the projected meat rationing system just announced was promised yesterday by all factors in the food industry. Inasmuch as the effective date of the program is still indefinite, however, operators were generally reluctant to make any predictions with regard to details of its operations.

Professor Boris Furlan, Yugoslav refugee in this country who is under sentence of death by an Italian military tribunal, warned yesterday that Italy had a "very good army" and that it was dangerous to ridicule or minimize its strength.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 -- In the first specific ruling on the constitutionality of actions by President Roosevelt, by Congress and by Lieut. Gen. John L. DeWitt in connection with evacuation of Japanese on the Pacific Coast, a Federal court today held that the Army was within its rights in evacuating, and in keeping in protective custody, all American-born Japanese as well as Japanese nationals.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Bob Lemon broke a 3-3 deadlock with a home run in the final inning to give Baltimore a 4-to-3 victory over Jersey City in the opening game of a double-header tonight, but the Giants captured the nightcap, 6 to 3.

WASHINGTON, Sept 1 -- From sources in the agencies concerned with the fuel oil problem, who declined to be quoted by name, it was learned that a basic ration was contemplated which would permit heating homes to an average temperature of around 68 degrees, with supplemental rations to be issued on the basis of need.

Fashion dictators who feared a wartime trend toward dark and somber colors were reassured once again yesterday that American women are being led in the right direction. In its showing of new millinery, Franklin Simon went all-out for bright, dashing hues in one of the cheeriest collections yet to enter the Autumn scene.

LINDEN, N.J., Sept. 1 -- Taken aloft by Don Bernsdorff, a test pilot and veteran of the "Flying Tigers" of Burma fame, the first Navy fighter plane assembled at the Eastern aircraft diviison plant of the General Motors Corporation here was put through a series of tests at the recently completed flying field fronting State Highway Route 25 today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Senate and House conferees on the bill designed to enable men and women of the armed forces and their auxiliaries to vote in the November election agreed promptly today, much to the surprise of Capitol Hill, to recommend enactment of the measure as the Senate had rewritten it.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 1 -- The news broadcast from Tokyo today of the resignation of Russia-appeasing Shigenori Togo as Foreign Minister and the assumption of his post by Russia-hating Premier Hideki Tojo, in the opinion of some observers here, presages the long-expected Japanese stab-in-the-back attack on the sorely pressed Soviet Union.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- It is believed here that the crucial battle for Egypt has begun. Even if Marshal Rommel has merely lifted his fist without meaning to fight to the finish, the British are determined that he shall.

BACK in the days of the flying wedge and turtle-neck sweaters football was considered strictly an Autumnal pastime. But not any more. At the rate the gridiron sport has spread around the calendar of recent years the boys soon will be going at it hot and heavy on the Fourth of July.
ALBANY, Sept. 1 -- One phase of the two-part program approved today will provide pro-flight training for juniors and seniors in about fifty high schools.

To resist successfully the onslaught of the German and Italian troops under General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel the British Eighth Army cannot afford to retreat eastward more than twenty-five miles. Within that distance from E1 Alamein is the Amaria position, north of the tip of the Qattara Depression

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1 -- Strikes by timbermen and truck drivers in the Connellsville area of Fayette County threatened tonight to curtail delivery of coke to steel plants, but two other labor disputes in this region of intensive war production had favorable turns.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- A Selective Service directive issued today to all State chairmen ordered immediate action looking toward the goal of assuring that single men are called for military service before married men, regardless of the disproportionate nature of lists compiled by local boards.

Nine crewmen of a medium-sized British merchant ship were killed and her master was taken prisoner on board a German submarine when the ship was sunk several hundred miles off the northern coast of South America early in August, it was revealed yesterday. Forty-seven survivors were rescued after more than a week in lifeboats.
The former Landrine Building on a plot 45 by 140 feet at 719-21 Bergen Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., was sold by Mrs. Marie H. Lackey to a client of Cyrus Hoffman, attorney.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 1 -- A few hours after he had opened the annual session of Congress today, President Manuel Avila Camacho announced the appointment of former President Lazaro Cardenas as Minister of National Defense. At the present time General Cardenas is in command of the Pacific Coast defense zone.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- German air raiders confined their activity today to the bombing and machine-gunning of a southeast coast town. One bomb that fell near a road construction gang killed three men and injured others. A hospital was bombed in the same town and a soldier was killed and several other persons were injured.
The first nail in the coffin of Adolf Hitler was hammered in at 5:44 P.M. yesterday by Charles Laughton, the movie actor, before 5,000 persons attending a rally to sell war bonds in Times Square.
Sidney Wood's quest for the national tennis championship met with a checkmate in the third round yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- Formal objections to the Communist petitions nominating the party's State ticket headed by Israel Amster for Governor were filed this afternoon with the Election Bureau in the Secretary of State's office by Frank Pedlow, representing Herman F. Greene, county commander of the American Legion.

Of Hitler's message to the German people on the third anniversary of the beginning of the war it can at least be said that it lacks the exuberance of earlier pronouncements on this occasion. Two years ago he was almost jaunty when he spoke in the Berlin Sportpalast.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The disappearance of Shigenori Togo as Japanese Foreign Minister, with the taking over of his office by Premier Hideki Tojo, means the final domination by militarists of all the key posts in the Tokyo government and comes as a somewhat significant sequel to reports that new Japanese moves are in the offing in Asia.

In today's editorial you say: "One hundred years ago * * * the Treaty of Nanking was signed. * * * Out of that treaty came the system of 'extraterritoriality' under which foreigners (Americans included) have enjoyed for a full century special rights in China."

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- "What a thing! What does it mean?" It was with these words that American officers in Britain today greeted the news at their gathering places that whisky as well as gin making had been halted at home for the duration of the war.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 1 -- Victory but no bread was the reaction of Germans to Adolf Hitler's Winter help appeal yesterday as rumors of fresh cuts in the bread and fat rations Oct 1 deepened gloom over the prospects of the impending fourth war Winter, say persons who arrived here today from Berlin.

A decree enjoining the Sperry Gyroscope Company, Inc., from future compliance with certain agreements with organizations in Italy, Germany, Japan and France was filed in Federal court here yesterday. The decree, signed by Judge Samuel Mandelbaum, constituted final judgment in a suit filed at the same time by Samuel S. Isseks, who has charge of the local office of the Department of Justice's anti-trust division.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The first Army check under the new Service Men's Dependents Allowance Act was mailed today by the War Department to Mrs. Thelma Greer of 1203 East Forty-sixth Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Senate Finance Committee, in the face of an urgent appeal by Randolph Paul, general counsel for the Treasury, refused today by a 14-to-7 vote to eliminate the special depletion allowances for oil and gas wells granted in the tax bill as passed by the House.

Incensed over the suspension of the Directory of Contract Opportunities around which the Stanley Plan, designed to aid subcontracting, operates, the American Business Congress, composed of small manufacturers in this area, yesterday proposed to call protest meetings against the stoppage.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- The activity in the stock market slackened today with few changes in prices. Gilt-edge issues held yesterday's gains with the exception of the 3 1/2 per cent war loan, which lost 1-16, but the conversion 5s, which will be quoted ex interest, hardened to 105 1/8.

" Tobacco Road" will return to Broadway, from which it has been absent for sixteen months, on Sunday afternoon. Again it will be housed at the Forrest, where it accumulated most of its 3,180 performances. John Barton will be Jeerer Lester, playing the part for the first time on Broadway although he is a veteran of the road, having been seen steadily in the hinterland for the last five years.

Democratic State Chairman James A. Farley, who succeeded in nominating John J. Bennett Jr. as the Democratic candidate for Governor, over the opposition of President Roosevelt and other New Deal leaders, indicated annoyance yesterday over press reports which put him at the head of a movement, supposedly under way now, to line up anti-New Deal forces for the 1944 Democratic national convention.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Hu Shih, the Chinese Ambassador, has been recalled by his government and will be succeeded by Wei Tao Ming, former Chinese Ambassador to the Vichy government of France, it was learned authoritatively tonight.
TOLEDO, Sept. 1 -- The 300 women on the assembly line of the Army's famous jeeps paid almost no attention today to visitors at the plant of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc. They were too busy.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 -- It cost a relatively small group of Philadelphia business men, labor union representatives and social leaders $4,547,350 today to take Hedy Lamarr to luncheon.

Otto D. Tolischus, NEW YORK TIMES correspondent in Japan from January, 1941, until the outbreak of war, will do a full-length book analyzing Japan's policies and recounting his personal experiences. Mr. Tolischus returned last week on the Gripsholm after having spent six months in a Japanese prison.
Several homes formerly owned by Tri-Boro Gardens, Inc., in Astoria, L.I., were reported yesterday as having been sold through A.G. Walker and Associates, operating managers for the development.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Brig. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley, United States Minister to New Zealand, told reporters after a conference with President Roosevelt today that the people of New Zealand had come to "a full realization that the challenge by which liberty is confronted cannot be met by words."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Total assets of national banks on June 30 of this year were $45,000,000,000, which was $3,844,000,000, or nearly 10 per cent, more than a year ago, it was announced today by Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency. Loans and discounts, however, showed a decrease of $20,000,000 from June 30, 1941. Bank investments in Federal securities were up more than 30 per cent.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 1 -- Pointing out that he had urged the American Federation of Labor to forego the strike weapon on defense work more than two years ago, Louis P. Marciante today told the New Jersey State Federation of Labor, of which he is president, that "unions affiliated with the federation have made an enviable record in this regard."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Federal Power Commission announced today that it had filed a brief in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in a case which it asserted "has the most far-reaching relation to the basic question of the ability of the government to correct and control the admitted abuses of the entire electric utility industry."

METUCHEN, N.J., Sept. 1 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation and Army authorities opened this afternoon an investigation into the explosions and fire that destroyed a small building at the New Jersey Fulgent Company plant here today, took the lives of three men, sent two others to a hospital and caused minor injuries to an undetermined number of other employes.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Sept. 1 -- By taking the third race among the Star Class sloops for the Atlantic Coast championship, Harold Halsted, with this Chuckle V of the Moriches Bay fleet, today gained a 30-point tie with Eddie Ketcham and his Draco II of Great South Bay for the series lead.

An "all-out" scrap collection campaign was officially launched yesterday by the Building Trades Employers Association at a luncheon meeting in its clubrooms at 2 Park Avenue. The drive will be conducted by a committee headed by Christian G. Norman in cooperation with the industrial salvage section of the War Production Board.

Despite record-breaking production during the first half of this year, average corporate earnings were 30 per cent lower than in the 1941 period, principally as a result of greatly increased tax reserves and higher operating expenses, the division of industrial economics of the Conference Board reported yesterday.

Aqueduct's Fall meeting settled into its stride with yesterday's racing, apparently a handsome stride, for a surprising second-day gathering of 12,739 watched the eight races to send a total of $800,527 through the mutuel machines.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Although the Admiralty still is not giving out any figures on ship sinkings, it can be said authoritatively that the month just past was the most encouraging in the Battle of the Atlantic.

" Holiday Inn," which enters its fifth week at the Paramount today, joins "Northwest Mounted Police" as the only film to have played so long an engagement at that theatre. According to the management, the picture's total attendance of 575,000 persons constitutes a record for the four-week period.

Three men who pleaded guilty to conspiracy to reveal defense plans of the United States to Germany were sentenced yesterday by Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to serve fifteen years each in jail.

A battle is developing in the Egyptian desert which may well be the beginning of a major offensive to take Alexandria and the Nile Valley. At one point Rommel's troops have driven their tanks nine miles through British mine fields. This initial drive has apparently been checked.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Rear Admiral C.H. Woodward predicted today that Americans would soon fall into three groups, fighters, war producers and women, children, the aged and persons "absolutely essential" to maintain homes and national institutions.
MOSCOW, Sept. 1 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

The first specific allocations of a critical material to manufacturers of civilian goods started yesterday, when this system of distributing a commodity went into effect for all types of rubber, including crude, latex, reclaimed and scrap. This step is a forerunner of others that will be taken on certain critical materials, particularly imported ones such as hemp, as their shortage becomes acute.
Paul McNutt's warning to educators that they are preparing all boys for war service abroad gives new impulse to the question of language study and its place in the school curriculum.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Sept. 1 (U.P.) -- Bombardier Sergeant Earl W. Snyder of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., died with his hand clutching his bomb release and his head hanging over his bomb sight a split-second after he had sent his bombs down on the Japanese invasion fleet in Milne Bay, his comrades said today.

Since the outbreak of the war Jews in America have provided overseas relief assistance for 3,000,000 persons through the Joint Distribution Committee, supported mobilization of the 584,000 Jews of Palestine for the defense of the Middle East through the United Palestine Appeal and financed retraining and adjustment of refugees in the United States through the National Refugee Service, it was reported yesterday by the United Jewish Appeal for Refugees, Overseas Needs and Palestine.

Registrations of out-of-town buy-in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 820, which compared with 706 in the preceding week and 559 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 322 as against 351 for last Tuesday. During August, 3,208 buyers were recorded as against 3,713 in the same month of last year, a decrease of 13.6 per cent.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 1 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has scheduled "Homecoming," a screen story by George Oppenheimer, as a vehicle for Gene Kelly, Van Johnson and Marsha Hunt, the studio announced today. Oppenheimer's plot deals with a soldier-hero and a civilian worker and a girl they both love.

BOSTON, Sept. 1 -- The New England Council's revised index of business activity, released today, shows that slight decreases during July in the metal trades and the shoe industry were more than offset by other components and the index at the end of the month stood at a new all-time high.
This is in reply to the letter written you by Miss Joan Hansen about radio helping during blackouts.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday that sales of war savings bonds in August in the Second Federal Reserve District by issuing agents other than postoffices amounted to $111,902,000, compared with $196,561,000 in July. The latest figure is also slightly below the totals of May and June.
Several sales of East Side and downtown apartment, loft and office buildings have just been closed by banks as a further step in liquidating their realty holdings.

OTTAWA, Ont., Sept. 1 (Canadian Press) -- Untimely rains in Western Canada in the last week halted harvesting operations and increased the difficulties of gathering a very large crop, said the Dominion Bureau of Statistics in an official report today.

GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands, Aug. 15 (Delayed) -News ghering hereabouts is no City Hall beat. The success of the Navykarine Corps operations has given us six islands to cover. That means open water and small boats, which in this area add up to a game of hide and seek with Japanese submarines.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The National War Labor Board unanimously directed the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipbuilding division today to grant a maintenance of membership clause and a voluntary check-off, covering 50,000 workers in eight Atlantic Coast shipyards, to the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, C.I.O.

For the second consecutive month advertising linage in eight New York newspapers registered an increase in August, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures. The rise over the corresponding month of last year was 4.7 per cent, with five of the eight papers showing gains.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 1 -- The United States is contributing more than planes and guns to China's war effort.
