American dollars, raised by the United China Relief in the United States, are helping to sustain the welfare and morale of the Chinese people through various activities of relief and rehabilitation.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 1 -- Strong German armored columns, screened by dust clouds from British and American bombers, advanced yesterday afternoon in a northeasterly direction in the southern sector of the Egyptian front. These columns were harassed by British light mobile forces, but were able to push their way through British mine fields.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden today eulogized the courage of the Norwegian and Polish peoples for their unyielding attitude in the face of the most cruel aggressions and promised them that the day was ahead when they would drive the invader from their soil.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 1 -- Irvin D. Shapiro, mediator for the United States Conciliation Service, announced tonight that all shifts were in full operation in the plants of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation after a partial walkout had delayed work in the Fair Lawn foundry of the company from Saturday to Monday.

A man who was born when Van Buren was President, who sold newspapers on the Pennsylvania Railroad on June 21, 1871, and who regularly eats a steak at an 11 A.M. breakfast, had coffee and cake early last evening at the Mills Hotel No. 1, 162 Bleecker Street, and said there'd be a sort of party Friday night.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Sept. 2 -- Japanese ground forces fighting their way overland in New Guinea toward the big Allied base at Port Moresby have attacked Allied positions at Kokoda with increased strength and, as a result, ground fighting there has been intensified, General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today.

MOSCOW, Sept. 1 -- While the Germans' northern spearhead is in serious difficulties in the resilient and powerful Russian defense system before Stalingrad and strong pressure is being exerted on their left flank, a more dangerous Axis thrust toward the Volga now appears to be directed from the southwest, where a Russian communique admits some withdrawal after a wedge had been driven into the Red Army's lines by mechanized forces.

Japanese Foreign Minister Shigenori Togo resigned yesterday "for personal reasons" and his post was taken over by Premier General Hideki Tojo, according to a Japanese broadcast recorded in New York by The Associated Press. Mr. Togo was a former Ambassador to both Berlin and Moscow and had held the Foreign Ministry office since the formation of the present government last October, the broadcast added.

Herr Hitler begins the fourth year of his war by launching the expected drive in Egypt and issuing an appeal for the Winter help campaign calling upon the German people to make heavier sacrifices to match the "scarcely imaginable" privations the soldiers have endured.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP). -- The Senators tallied in the tenth inning to defeat Cleveland, 4 to 3, today behind the steady hurling of Alejandro Carrasquel. Jimmy Vernon's third single of the contest drove in the deciding run.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Federal restrictions governing the operation of taxicabs went into effect today, the code to affect the riding habits of the users of the more than 50,000 cabs in fleets throughout the country.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Sept. 2 -- German armored forces have driven into the area "southwest of Stalingrad," the front heretofore designated as northeast of Kotelnikov, wedging into the Soviet defenses in one sector and pushing the Russians back in another, the High Command announced today.

From surface indications, the New York Stock Exchange's experiment with ten-share unit stocks has been a success. Volume figures at this early date mean little. Possibly there were "courtesy" trades with the new specialists by friends on the floor. Possibly small traders, reading in the newspapers of the new system, preferred to risk a day or two of waiting to paying the odd-lot differentials.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 1 -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, commander of United States forces in the Far East, said today that there was a "good chance" that the Japanese would attack Siberia before Winter.
MOSCOW, Sept. 1 (U.P.) -- Russian newspapers noted the war's third anniversary today with editorials expressing confidence that the fourth year of the conflict would bring decisive defeat to Germany.

An investing syndicate has purchased from the Bank for Savings in the City of New York the nine business buildings and the adjoining theatre in the blockfront on the west side of Broadway from Sixty-fifth to Sixty-sixth Street.

The Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League yesterday made public a communication to James W. Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany, who resigned as honorary president of the organization over its decision to boycott The Daily News, defending its action as "voluntary, democratic and essentially American."
Furs with a long "life expectancy" in both wear and style were shown yesterday by Russeks, Fifth Avenue, in an Autumn collection of new coats.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Some parts of the country may have to get by this Winter with 25 per cent less fuel than they have used in the past, President Roosevelt warned at his press conference today.

Smaller trading units got their first trial on the main floor of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Volume in the twenty-eighth inactive issues was 1,870 shares, against 680 on Monday and 1,120 on Sept. 2, 1941, when the market was more than twice as large as it was yesterday.

Twelve new cases of infantile paralysis were reported in New York City last week, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins said yesterday. This was more than double the number for the previous week and half the total for the last month.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, U.S.A., who ten years ago as superintendent of the New Jersey State Police directed the investigation into the kidnap-murder of the Lindbergh baby, arrived today in Iran to reorganize the national police of this strategically important country.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Prices in all sections of the livestock market declined under the weight of comparatively large arrivals today. Hogs were steady on a few heavy offerings to 15 cents a hundred pounds down on lighter weights, steers were weak to 25 cents lower and Spring lambs lost 25 to 40 cents.

SEATTLE, Sept. 1 (AP) -- A bullet-riddled and patched four-motored bomber was back at its birthplace today with Lieut. Gen. George H. Brett after a fighting career which the General's aides said was probably without parallel in the Army.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1 (AP) -- Mort Cooper pitched his eighteenth victory tonight as the rampant Cardinals trimmed the Braves, 4 to 3, in a see-saw contest which saw St. Louis come from behind twice to remain three and a half games back of the league-leading Dodgers.

The foregoing will not appear in any classified advertising section, but it just about sizes up the situation at Columbia, which started football practice yesterday at Baker Field. Lou Little, beginning his thirteenth year as head man at Morningside Heights, was unusually cheerful and if one concentrated, he could detect just the slightest touch of optimism.

One of the brightest spots on today's war map is China. Four months ago Japan launched an offensive there which was "to end the China incident." It overran most of Chekiang and Kiangsi Provinces, captured all the airfields the Chinese had built in the hope of bombing Japan some day and closed China's vital trunk rail line except for a gap of twenty-five miles.

The Diamond Match Company reported yesterday in its statement covering the six months ended on June 30 consolidated net profit of $l,030,957 after $1,335,720 Federal. State and municipal taxes and other charges. The company states that no excess profits tax provision was required. Federal taxes are based on the latest information regarding the proposed Revenue Act of 1942, including House Bill 7378.
Thousands of Americans of Polish ancestry throughout the nation joined yesterday in memorial observances of the third anniversary of the German invasion of Poland.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Reds beat Philadelphia, 4 to 3, today in eleven innings to sweep the Phils' final four-game series here.

Formal offering will be made today by Kuhn, Loeb Co., Smith, Barney Co., and Blyth Co., Inc., of the new issue of $5,000,000 of Potomac Electric Power Company first mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds, due on Aug. 1, 1977, which was awarded to the bankers on Monday through competitive bidding.

From two different sources and almost simultaneously we have just had some interesting news about what the war has done to Mrs. Miniver's husband's income. Both informants are in a position to know what they are talking about.

The American Arbitration Association announced yesterday that the Brooklyn Eagle, Inc., had been sustained in a controversy with the Newspaper Guild of New York, arising out of the discharge of am employe. Hearings were held before John C. Pemberton, member of the national panel of arbitrators of the association, last week.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- Assuming the presidency of Colgate University today, Everett Case indicated that one of his first steps would be to have a special committee of faculty members work with him on a survey to see if the scope and pace of the institution's contributions to the war effort could be increased.

ALBANY, Sept. 1 -- The State War Council today approved the plan of pre-flight training submitted by Oakley Furney, assistant commissioner for vocational education in the State Education Department. The plan provides for secondary school instruction in the importance of aviation in modern life and the significant part which aviation is playing in the war effort, and aims to prepare selected students for employment in aviation occupations.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 -- The Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. reached the highest membership in the 236 years of organized Presbyterian in this country when the church year ended March 1, according to the annual report of the General Assembly, made public today.

Handy Harman, local bullion dealers, yesterday raised the official quotation on foreign silver at New York to 44 3/4 cents an ounce from 35 1/8 cents. The new price is the first change since Nov. 28, 1941, when the quotation was increased from 34 3/4 cents where it had been stabilized since June 17, 1940.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1 -- Pitching a five-hit game, Kirby Higbe, the speedball thrower from Columbia, S.C., today wrote a bright new page in the brief baseball history he has compiled since coming into the National League.

A long lease on two floors and basement space in 38 West Forty-eighth Street, in the Rockefeller Center district, has been signed by Murray Cohen, head of the Marco Polo chain of spaghetti restaurants, for a new unit. Empire Real Estate Company represented the tenant and Lehigh Management acted for the landlord.

The Japanese Government's announcements yesterday that Shigenori Togo had resigned as Foreign Minister, that Premier Hideki Tojo had assumed his post, and that the Premier planned to create a "Greater Asia Ministry" are typical of Japanese official language to screen impending major developments.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The resignation of Shigenori Togo as Japanese Foreign Minister and the assumption of his duties by Premier Hideki Tojo was regarded here today as a normal move by a dictator who wished to concentrate more power in his hands.

Preferred stockholders of the Empire Gas and Fuel Company approved its recapitalization at a meeting in Dover, Del., yesterday, 95,965 of 127,751 publicly held shares being represented. Holders of 74.8 per cent of the publicly held preferred shares assented.

LONDON, Sept. 1 -- A new technical corps of the British Army, the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers, will come in to existence officially on Oct. 1. The new corps includes the engineering side of the Royal Army Ordnance Corps, a large proportion of the maintenance engineering side of the Royal Army Service Corps and a large part of the mechanical maintenance section of the Royal Engineers.

The Treasury, despite its opposition, really agrees with the principle of getting the income tax payers of this country on a pay-as-you-go basis, according to a statement issued here yesterday by Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the board of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, treasurer of R.H. Macy Co., and adviser to the National Resources Planning Board.

Reference to the controversy concerning the proper position of the American flag published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 27, the following is an extract of House Joint Resolution 303, passed June 15, 1942:

No amount of argument can alter the fact that our national silver policy has become a national scandal. Our Government holds stocks of nearly 3,000,000,000 ounces of silver, most of which, in view of our huge gold reserves, are utterly unneeded for monetary purposes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- A pledge of unqualified support for all political candidates who support the policies of President Roosevelt was voted by the C.I.O. executive board today in a resolution calling its rank and file to a vigorous house-to-house campaign to elect a win-the-war Congress.
Every Spring one hears discontented folks say: "Seems as though there isn't any Spring any more." In a pettish Summer they say: "Seems as though there isn't any Summer any more."

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 1 (AP) -- United States military authorities, taking extraordinary precautions to avert trouble following the discovery of two illegal caches of arms and explosives allegedly intended for Irish rebel attacks on American and British soldiers, tonight declared this Ulster city out of bounds for the American Expeditionary Force.

ARLINGTON, Mass., Sept. 1 (AP) -- The Rev. Peter Duffee of St. Francis of Assisi Church of New York City was cited for bravery today for helping in the rescue of several persons from the Lafayette, the former French liner Normandie, when it burned at its pier.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 1 -- Strike threats against aluminum plants were declared tonight by the head of the 7,500-member Local No. 2, Aluminum Workers of America C.I.O., to be unauthorized and harmful to morale and the prosecution of the war.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 1 -- Mayor Stanley W. Church's recent gift of this city's 320-year-old French cannon to a scrap salvage committee was as unwarranted as would be a contribution of the Magna Carta, a New Rochelle taxpayer charged today in a Supreme Court suit to retrieve the relic for permanent display here.

Judging from many tested factors. the Fall fishing should prove active in Maine. The number of inquiries regarding suitable camps and lakes in the Pine Tree State as well as in Canada indicate that the great vacation time is not yet over for many Easterners.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- Asked at his press conference today for comment on the third anniversary of the outbreak of the war, Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, pointed to an editorial in The Baltimore Sun this morning as precisely stating his views.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 1 -- "The rising sun of Japan has already passed the noon hour and Japan has now moved from the offensive to the defensive stage," declared the government spokesman, Dr. T.F. Tsiang, today.

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick's resignation from her post as Regional Director of the National Labor Relations Board to become personnel and labor relations director for a shipbuilding corporation reminds one that the person who fills a job is often more important than the job itself.

Salvaging fats -- straining them into a scoured tin and carrying them off to the butcher -- is all very well with one obvious, though often overlooked, proviso. No fat should go out of the kitchen that might be put to some good function within it.

The football Giants held their first home workout of the season at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The playing surface was the same as of old, the uniforms were the same, but there was a startling difference in personnel. It almost was a shock to be able to recognize so few of the athletes.

The voice of American creation spoke last night when Bergdorf Goodman's gave the signal for the formal fashion season to get underway. This was the first showing by one of New York's great couture houses since the passing of the L-85 regulation.

Steel production, already short of capacity, may drop even lower this Winter unless there is an intensification of the scrap metal salvage campaign, Robert W. Wolcott, chairman of the American Industries Salvage Committee and president of the Lukens Steel Company, declared at a salvage committee luncheon at the Empire State Club yesterday.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 1 -- An old classic Chinese drama, "The Sorrows of Han," was given in the terraced gardens of Skelmar House, the home of Francis H. Markoe in near-by Water Mill, this afternoon. Produced in English, with musical accompaniment, the play was directed by Mr. Markoe, who also portrayed the role of a mandarin, Now Yen-shang.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 -- Twenty-five hundred freight cars filled with vital war materials stood idle tonight on the maze of tracks leading to this city's Delaware River piers as the result of a strike today of 300 to 400 waterfront car-loaders.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 31 (Delayed) -- S.D. Savarkar, president of the All-India Hindu Mahasabha -- the organization of Orthodox Hindus -- today left no doubt as to the seriousness of his convictions and intentions in his campaign for independence.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 2 -- Vincent J. Murphy, Newark Mayor, today was endorsed as a candidate for Governor in the 1943 election by the New Jersey State Federation of Labor at its convention at the Essex House here. Mr. Murphy, who was secretary-treasurer of the Federation, said: "If this be the will of the Federation, there is nothing more for me to do but accept."
LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Traders on the stock markets today were inclined to await developments in Egypt before opening new commitments.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 2 -- "I have failed in my mission and I am returning to Japan a bitterly disappointed man," said the former Japanese Minister, Tatsuo Kawai, who left Australia Aug. 16 bound for Lourenco Marques, Portuguese East Africa, on an exchange ship.

DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 2 -- Miss Vivien Kellems of Westport, a candidate for the Republican nomination for Representative in the Fourth Connecticut Congressional District, aimed a barrage of ridicule at the New Deal tonight at a forum for the several candidates seeking the nomination at the Darien High School.

SOMEWHERE ON THE FRENCH FRONTIER, Aug. 31 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Police have begun mass arrests of 13,000 foreign Jews in unoccupied France for deportation to labor camps in German-controlled Eastern Europe and the French people are aiding the Jews to resist seizure, it was learned today.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 2 -- Charles P. Taft, Assistant Director of Defense, Health, and Welfare Service, told the Veterans of Foreign Wars today that "most, if not all of the 4,000,000 men now in the Army will have seen foreign service by the time victory comes -- and many will not return."

BOSTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Ted Williams's thumping bat kept the Red Sox firmly on the victory path today as they swept a doubleheader from Detroit, 3 to 2 and 4 to 2, stretching their month-long spurt to twenty-two victories in their last twenty-six games.

There is one piece of postwar planning that might well be put aside for something more pressing and useful. It has to do with the dreadful punishments we are going to visit on the conquered nations when we have won the war.
The major part of the Federal income taxes are paid by the large and medium manufacturing, transportation or communication enterprises.

Russell Meehan, 21 years old, a chauffeur, of 1222 Wheeler Avenue, the Bronx, who pleaded guilty in Bronx County Special Sessions when charged with stealing a gasoline ration book from a passenger automobile, was sentenced yesterday to sixty days in the workhouse.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2. -- Continuing its policy of unabated application of the "death sentence" clause of the Holding Corporation Act, the Securities and Exchange Commission instituted today proceedings for corporate simplification against the Cities Service Power and Light Company and six of its subsidiaries.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- Complaints against the contemplated conversion of this city's historic French cannon into scrap metal came in crescendo today from historians and artists, but Mayor Stanley W. Church said at a conference with scrap salvage workers that there would be no surrender in his battle to have the relic converted into bullets.

In the discussion of "The Star-Spangled Banner" in your columns I have looked for some one else who stood before the Jeanne d'Arc Statue on the Rue de Rivoli on the morning of Nov. 11, 1918, to tell what happened there.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- The prepared text of the address tonight by Bishop Miguel de Andrea of Buenos Aires, Argentina, at a dinner for the sixteen Latin-American delegates to the Inter-American seminar was as follows:

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Sept. 2 -- Mrs. Ellen Lane, Long Branch's oldest resident, will celebrate her 100th birthday tomorrow at an "open house" at her home at 187 Hampton Avenue, where she lives alone and attends to her own housework.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Strikes in war industries caused a loss of 1,130,678 man-days work in the first seven months of this year, the War Labor Board reported today. A compilation showed that, on the average, eight out of every 10,000 workers were idle because of strikes in industries covered by the report.

A three-year contract, which will add an estimated $7,000,000 to the aggregate annual maintenance payroll of 4,000 loft, office and apartment buildings in Manhattan, was signed yesterday by the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations, Inc., and Local 32B of the Building Service Employes International Union.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- A special technical mission of industrial engineers, headed by Morris L. Cooke, was commissioned by President Roosevelt today to undertake the industrialization of Brazil for her own defense against the Axis powers and to give additional aid to the war effort of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The submarine threat to United Nations shipping off the Atlantic Coast of the United States is "not by any means solved," Secretary Knox told reporters today, but he asserted that there had been considerable improvement in recent weeks.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Germans are rushing large-scale reserves of aircraft, tanks and troops from areas deep in the rear for an all-out attack on the wavering defenses of Stalingrad, dispatches from the front said today as the Soviet command acknowledged a new break-through southwest of the city.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 2 -- Arky Vaughan's line single to right on a three-and-two pitch by Southpaw Clyde Shoun scored Peewee Reese from second base and provided the embattled Dodgers with a twelve-inning, 3-2 triumph over the Reds and Bucky Walters today.

Dr. Charles Muzzicato, who was renominated for the State Senate in the primary by the Republican and American Labor parties and later declined this nomination to accept the Republican nomination for representative at large, was faced yesterday with a Supreme Court suit which, if successful, would leave him as candidate for both offices.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- By a unanimous vote the War Labor Board tonight denied a general wage increase of 10 cents an hour to 1,750 employes of the Cambridge, Mass., and Edgewater, N.J., plants of Lever Brothers Company.

Responding to Mayor La Guardia's appeal for the purchase of War Bonds as an investment in the principles of human happiness laid down in the four freedoms named in the Atlantic Charter, a noon-hour throng of 6,500 workers in the financial district purchased $460,000 worth of bonds during a rally held yesterday under the joint auspices of the Treasury Department and the motion picture industry at the Subtreasury Building, Wall and Nassau Streets.
The five-story apartment house on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 2473 Davidson Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by Henry Goelet, operator, to an investing client of Abraham Berman, attorney.

A warning that a crisis in transportation will be reached by Jan. 1 and that a government ban on cross-hauling of certain types of civilian goods is inevitable was sounded yesterday by speakers at a meeting of the Shippers' Conference of Greater New York at the Commerce and Industry Association, Woolworth Building.

METUCHEN, N.J., Sept. 2 -- An Army investigation into the explosions and fire that claimed the lives of three men at the New Jersey Fulgent Company plant here yesterday was continued today and "will continue until we are completely satisfied as to the cause," according to Captain D.B. MacMasters of the Army Ordnance Department at New York.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2 -- While the Dodgers were battling tooth-and-nail in Cincinnati today, the Giants were hammering the everlasting daylight out of the Cardinals at Sportsman's Park to the dismay of 4,303 fans.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 2 -- United States and other Allied planes and British guns heavily bombed and shelled Axis forces in the Western Desert today.
CAIRO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A joint British Headquarters-Royal Air Force communique:
BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Seven Harding Field Army fliers were killed last night in the crash of a twin-motored bomber on an operational mission.

Joseph Gillespie, president of the Metropolitan Association of Employment Agencies, took issue yesterday with Senator James M. Mead, who had declared, Mr. Gillespie said, that New York City had 500,000 unemployed, of whom 75,000 were skilled workers.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Board of Visitors of the College of William and Mary adopted today a recommendation by Governor Darden that fraternities and sororities be prohibited from maintaining separate establishments for use as living and meeting quarters.

ONE of the things that have been puzzling this observer no little of late is the growing complaint of correspondents, editors and the like that the men conducting our war effort, both government officials and military authorities, are not giving out sufficient information.

IT'S too bad that Hitler didn't study ecology, which is the science that deals with the mutual relations between organisms and their environment. He would have learned from such a study that nature abhors totalitarianism even more than it abhors a vacuum. If the wolves, for example, had been sufficiently totalitarian to kill off all the herbivorous beasts, what would have happened to the wolves?

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Two government spokesmen -- Lord Woolton, the Minister of Food, and Clement R. Attlee, the Dominions Secretary -- voiced today their confidence in the United Nations war effort on the opening of the fourth year of the war against the Axis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission granted today authority for four modifications of the financial setup of the Colorado Southern Railway Company in accordance with the railway's plan of adjustment of extension of maturities and modification of interest charges which was filed with the commission in June.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The automobile of a United States Army officer was stoned today and two American soldiers in the forbidden streets of Belfast were angrily challenged, "Why don't you go home?" by crowds protesting the hanging this morning of a young Irish outlaw.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- A limit of $200 was placed by the War Production Board today on the amount of residential construction which can be carried through without specific authorization from that war agency. The former limit was $500. The changes are effective on Sept. 7.

The trim L-85 silhouette will parade through its first Fall softened with cascading fringe or shimmering with beads and complimented in large part with matching accessories, according to models shown yesterday by Milgrim's, 6 West Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Japanese interests in thirty American companies engaged in the importation of goods were seized today by Leo T. Crowley, alien property custodian. They included Mitsui Co. and Mitsubishi Shoji Kaisha, American subsidiaries of two powerful Japanese concerns which have exported raw materials to this country for many years.

LONDON, Sept. 2 (U.P.) -- A Budapest report broadcast by the German radio said tonight that Count Julius Karolyi, son-in-law of Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Regent of Hungary, was killed in an air accident at 5 P.M. today.

Seventeen-hour airline service between New York and Mexico City will be started by American Airlines tomorrow with a ceremonial flight of government and airline officials leaving La Guardia Field at 8 A. M. as a preliminary to the beginning of a daily flight each way starting Monday.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Something new under the labor sun appeared to be developing today in a strike called by an A.F.L. Federal labor union at the Columbia Conserve Company.

Townsend Harris High School instructors, now unemployed because of the school's closing last Monday, will receive special examinations prepared by the New York City Board of Examiners, which will enable them to obtain substitute licenses and make them eligible to teach in the city schools.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The White Sox rained base blows all over the lot and capitalized on Washington errors to sweep a double-header with the Senators, 8 to 2 and 7 to 6, today.

Because of their concern over the possibility of a ban on cross-hauling, some national advertisers are beginning to consider more concentrated distribution of their goods in areas adjacent to their main production centers. They are beginning to find that long shipments today are not only more costly than previously but also slower, particularly those from the East to the West Coast.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 2 -- David O. Selznick, United Artists producer, has purchased the contract of Robert Stevenson, director, from RKO. Selznick already held an agreement with RKO to borrow Stevenson for one picture a year and had announced that he would direct "Jane Eyre."

A revolutionary method in America's efforts to mobilize its women in the home, on the military front and, more recently, in the factory has been adopted by one of the country's largest war industries. It embodies a psychological approach to the problems of the wartime "factory girl," both on the points of dress and of morale.

Thomas J. Watson, president of International Business Machines, announced yesterday that he had accepted the chairmanship of a national campaign to raise $2,000,000 for war relief to be administered by the American Friends of Yugoslavia, 8 West Fortieth Street.
Motor vehicle traffic between New York City and New Jersey by bridges and tunnels decreased 33 per cent last month compared with August, 1941, the Port of New York Authority said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- The Carnegie-Illinois Corporation and four other subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation accepted today the War Labor Board's order affecting wages and working conditions of its more than 150,000 workers but sharply criticized the order, indicating that only the war caused acceptance.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 2 -- Herbert Karl Friedrich Bahr, convicted here of having conspired with German agents to commit espionage in this country, received today a thirty-year sentence from Federal Judge William F. Smith after government counsel had asked that the death penalty be imposed.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Charges that immorality and drunkenness were widespread in three British women's services, which have been voiced from time to time since the units were first organized, are officially denied in a White Paper to be made public tomorrow.

An agreement to begin negotiations this morning for a new contract in the trucking industry was reached yesterday afternoon by employers and union representatives in conformity with the proposal of Dr. John R. Steelman, director of the United States Conciliation Service, to avoid a strike of 15,000 truckmen in this city.

Gasoline stocks throughout the country at the close of last week amounted to 80,831,000 barrels, an increase of 388,000 over the 80,443,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum institute. A year ago these stocks amounted to 80,394,000 barrels.

A German Transocean news agency broadcast from Berlin recorded last night by THE NEW YORK TIMES suggested not only that persons in the Reich, contrary to law, were listening to British broadcasts, but also that such persons were being impressed by them.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Allied bombers of General MacArthur's command made a heavy attack on the Japanese airdrome at Buka, at the northern tip of the Solomon Islands, in a raid last night, unloading five tons of bombs along the runway and upon enemy installations, it was announced today.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 2 -- The War Production Board sent Paul R. Norgren today to the Connellsville area in Fayette County to investigate the strike of timber cutters and haulers which has spread to the Beehive Coke industry, the principal source of fuel supply for the steel mills in Western Pennsylvania.
PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 2 (AP) -- The Pasadena Business Men's Association voiced outspoken opposition today to a 1943 Rose Bowl football game. A resolution, unanimously adopted, said:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Members of the Pacific War Council discussed today the probabilities of an imminent Japanese attack upon Siberia, and heard from President Roosevelt an "encouraging" report on the relative airplane losses of American and Japanese forces in the Battle of the Solomon Islands.

LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 3 -- The Red Air Force and the Royal Air Force attacked the Germans simultaneously on Tuesday night, giving the enemy another taste of what war on two fronts can mean. The Russians unloaded their bombs over Warsaw, while the British concentrated their destructive efforts on Saarbruecken, center of an important German industrial region.

An old man sat slumped yesterday morning halfway down the flight of steps that lead to the Suffolk Street station of the BMT subway at Suffolk and Delancey Streets. Passersby paid little attention to him. He was shabby and he seemed to be drowsing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Concentration of production of bicycles in two plants officially designated by the War Production Board was ordered today by the war agency in revising its previous order limiting bicycle production.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 2 -- Madigama, a 4-year-old bay son of Gino, that races in the colors of Donald P. Ross's Brandywine Stable, showed smart speed to lead from the start and gain a length and one-quarter victory in the six-furlong Cape May Purse at Garden State Park today.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Federal Judge Wayne G. Borah ruled today that negro teachers in the public schools here must be paid salaries equal to those of white teachers where qualifications and experience were the same.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Sept. 2 -- Property valued at more than $100,000,000 in thirty companies has been taken over by the Brazilian Government for use in national defense.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Lon Warneke shut out Boston until the eighth inning today, then the Braves tied the score and went on to win in ten innings, 2 to 1. It was Warneke's fifth loss since returning to the Cubs.

By voting unanimously yesterday for the Council bill amending the McCarthy Salary Increment Law, the Board of Estimate provided for restoring the jobs of sixty-seven Welfare Department investigators dismissed last month, and removed the threat of dismissal for 197 other city employes in various departments.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 2 (AP) -- After coming from behind to win the first game 7 to 6, tonight, Baltimore dropped the second to Jersey City, 13 to 4.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Scoring four runs in the eighth without a hit, the Pirates tonight defeated the Phils, 5 to 2, before the season's smallest night crowd at Forbes Field, 3,712 fans.

Americans now should be steeling their minds and their moral sensibilities against the terror that will surely engulf Europe as the Nazis are slowly driven from the countries they have conquered. It is possible that the United Nations will begin actually clearing the Germans out of the fallen countries within the next two years.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- The Most Rev. Miguel de Andrea, Auxiliary Bishop of Buenos Aires, Argentina, declared here tonight that liberty, justice and democracy must triumph in the war, and upon these three principles must be based the post-war reconstruction.
MOSCOW, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Navy's 1942 varsity football squad, hard pressed for veteran material and practicing on a skimpy hour-a-day schedule, tomorrow will open its ranks to plebes for the first time in nineteen years.

As a result of curriculum changes made during the Summer, the New York City public schools, reopening Monday, Sept. 14, will be completely geared to do their part in helping win the war, Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, Thursday, Sept. 3 -- Chinese experts on Japanese affairs, in assessing the significance of the resignation of Foreign Minister Shigenori Togo, were generally agreed last night that it presaged "some bold move," but whether this meant imminent aggression against Siberia, as seemed to be the expectation of the average Chinese, these experts would not hazard a guess.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 2 (AP) -- A stirring ride by George Seabo, who got the mount when Ty Meloche was injured earlier in the afternoon, brought John R. Macomber's Side Arm home the winner of the $2,500-added Fall River Claiming Stakes today at Narragansett Park.

Mrs. Thelma Greer, wife of First Class Private Matthew Greer, now stationed in Washington, received the distinction yesterday of being the first soldier's wife in the country to receive a check from the War Department under the new Service Men's Dependents Allowance Act.

Japanese broadcasts recorded in New York yesterday by The United Press reported that the Tokyo shake-up, regarded in many quarters as presaging an attack on Russia, continued yesterday with the resignations of Shigeru Kawagoe, Foreign Office adviser and former Ambassador to China, and Vice Foreign Minister Haruhiko Nishi.

Habib Sabet, Persian representative of a number of manufacturing concerns in the Middle East, has leased space in the RCA Building at Rockefeller Center for an importing and exporting business. Mr. Sabet has his headquarters in Teheran, capital of Iran, and this will be his first office in the United States.

Although the yardage of sheets and pillow cases for civilian use to be offered by retailers next January in "white sales" will probably run only about 25 per cent below this year, the assortment of sizes will be narrowed appreciably, manufacturers and retailers asserted yesterday.

"The World at War," a feature-length documentary film tracing the ten years of war up to the attack on Pearl Harbor, will have its premiere tonight at the Rialto. Sponsored by the Motion Picture Bureau of the Office of War Information, the picture, which was written and produced for the government by Samuel Spewack, contains material from confiscated Axis films and also clips from newsreel libraries.
Surfmen along Long Island's south shore have been doing well at the Hamptons, confirming reports that bluefish have been taken near Shinnecock Inlet that weighed between three and four pounds.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, Sept. 1 (delayed) -- The tank battle that began last night and continued until dark was resumed at dawn today. There are no indications of a decision in this second phase but reports from yesterday's engagement indicate the British came out appreciably better than the enemy.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 2 (AP) -- A group of twenty-three salesmen for competing wholesale mercantile firms who traveled together to save gasoline and tires reached the end of their first tour of Florida today with reports that they had saved time and money and had done more business than they formerly did individually.

"A California carrot differs from a New York carrot." So declares the spokesman for a youthful concern in explaining that virtually every single vegetable is unique in itself. Plus a distinctive chemical composition, it has a myriad of tiny cells in which the very essence of its "personality" is stored -- its full flavor, its wholesome vitamin content, its bright, clear color.

Fuel oil deliveries to consumers in the New York metropolitan area probably will not be cut more than 10 per cent this Winter, E.S. Ferguson, regional rationing executive for the Office of Price Administration, said yesterday. In other sections of the eastern seaboard where gasoline rationing is now in effect, the cut may run as high as 25 per cent below the corresponding period of last year, he added.

To help women conserve materials without sacrificing any of the morale building quality which good clothes provide, a style show demonstrating how as little as $20 can buy a complete season's wardrobe was held last night at the Civilian Defense Information Center at Pershing Square.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Office of Defense Transportation today announced that the entire refrigerator car ownership will be handled as a single unit for distribution purposes hereafter.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York made known yesterday its latest figures on the volume of payments made by banks in the Second Federal Reserve District in August for new issues of government securities, figures which emphasized the rapid monthly increases in such payments.

OTTAWA, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Canada's $400,000,000 newsprint industry, supplying nearly three-quarters of the United States' supplies of newsprint paper, faced centralized control today as the Wartime Prices and Trade Board announced an allocation system under which production would be concentrated where electric power and manpower are most readily available.

A corps of New York City housewives, 225 strong, rose with the dawn yesterday, boarded 175 Department of Sanitation trucks, and took a peek into the "backyards" of their sleeping sisters. What they saw explained, in part, the lagging contributions to the tin can salvage drive.

Nearly 30,000 persons at the Stadium yesterday thought Hank Borowy, hurling the second game for the Yankees against the Browns, had achieved a no-hitter in his 6-0 victory. Borowy thought likewise, as did Buddy Rosar, Joe Gordon and all the other Yankees.

Although overburdened, bus transportation for war-plant workers in the metropolitan area appears to be adequate at present, a survey ended yesterday shows. There are, however, indications that short-haul bus transportation may become a serious problem soon.

The fourth group of newspaper men to go to Harvard as Nieman Fellows, the 1941-42 members, will leave a memorial to their months of informal study at the university -- a book of essays called "Newsmen's Holiday." It was a spontaneous idea and the fellows -- reporters, editorial writers, copy-desk men and news executives -- assigned each other to the subjects.

There are reasons to doubt whether a major Japanese drive will develop from the present brisk fighting at Kokoda in New Guinea. The enemy may wish to produce that impression, but it is more likely that behind the smoke of battle he is rearranging his defensive positions throughout the area.

Aqueduct yesterday had for its feature one of the best run steeple-chases of the year, with the dark brown gelding Good Chance from Lieutenant Paul Mellon's Rokeby Stables joining the long string of great fencers who have taken the Harbor Hill.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The responsibility of the tree nations of the world to take the initiative from the Axis Powers in waging and winning the war and building a new and better world order was presented by Supreme Court Justice Jackson in an address tonight before the International Student Assembly which opened a four-day session here.

The recall of the Chinese Ambassador to Washington, Dr. Hu Shih, is a shock. The Chungking Government could have combed the length and breadth of China without finding any one better fitted than Dr. Hu. His American friends had high expectations of him when he came here in his official position in 1938, and he more than lived up to what was hoped.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Dissolution of the Retailers Advisory Committee against inflation and its replacement by a central committee which will assure full participation by the merchants and their national retail trade association secretaries was announced today by Fred Lazarus Jr., its chairman.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Tommy Byrne, youthful Newark southpaw, chalked up his seventeenth victory today by blanking the Syracuse chiefs with five scattered hits, 1 to 0. Byrne has lost only four games.

A mother with four sons in the armed forces was facing eviction last night from a second-floor railroad flat in Woodside, Queens, but she was showing a brand of courage that will be difficult for any one of her boys to equal.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Senator Taft expressed the belief today that the Administration was waiting until after the November elections before requesting Congress to enact legislation permitting the drafting of youths 18 and 19 years old.

A move to compel the Board of Education to cancel or modify a plan to transfer pupils of the sixth, seventh and eighth grades from Public School 3, at 108-55 Sixty-ninth Street, Forest Hills, to other schools in that community and in Corona advanced another step yesterday when representatives of the objectors and of the Corporation Counsel's office filed briefs with Justice Joseph Fennelly in Queens Supreme Court.
A single stroke stood between Ladislav Hecht and victory over George Richards of Montebello, Calif., yesterday in the national championship at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (U.P.) -- A survey of food production figures revealed today that housewives will be unable to substitute poultry and fish for "red" meats as suggested by the food requirements committee.

Buildings on Fifth and Park Avenues continue to attract a large part of the new renters of apartments on the East Side. One of the latest leases was signed by Dr. Robert L. Craig, who took a suite in 791 Park Avenue through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Officers and men of the United States Coast Guard played an important combat role in the battle of Solomon Islands, the Navy Department revealed for the first time today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The War Production Board wiped out today its entire contracts distribution branch, set up to help small business get war contracts, and notified 174 employes of the branch that their government service would terminate Sept. 15.

Pronounced weakness in the near months, the result of continued liquidation and transferals, featured yesterday the downward movement in the cotton futures market. Losses were only moderate, however, and active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 10 to 17 points below Tuesday's final prices.

The Eastern railroads rejected yesterday the demands for increased wages and other proposals of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen, which had been in negotiation since June 23, and expressed their willingness to join the union in requesting the services of the National Mediation Board under the Railway Labor Act.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's communique early today:

In the campaign to obtain release of Treasury silver for use by industry, fifty local manufacturers of silver jewelry have formed the New York Silver Jewelry Manufacturers Association, it was announced yesterday. They have appointed three members to the industry-wide committee that is now being arranged for the silver fight.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Hugh Dalton, President of the Board of Trade, told the Manchester Chamber of Commerce today that Britain must reduce exports and distribute more home-manufactured products among her own people because they have been subjected to all possible cuts.

Representatives of the essential oils and allied chemicals industry joined yesterday in the industrial program of the War Production Board to salvage scrap materials for war production. They met at luncheon in the Hotel Pennsylvania under the chairmanship of Frederick J. Lueders, president of George Lueders Co.

Tuesday The Atlanta Constitution was 75. It commemorates the anniversary in an issue of 144 pages. In this, besides the full complement of news of the world, it reviews the history of the growth and prosperity of Atlanta. That is one of our magical cities, an obscure little village that kept surprising the census-takers and became the capital of a region.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- British officers and men taken prisoner in the attack on Dieppe will be handcuffed tomorrow afternoon, said a German communique issued today, and they will be kept manacled unless the British Government withdraws what the German communique described as a British order for the binding of German captives.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 2 -- Wendell L. Willkie stepped out of a plane onto the sun-baked Egyptian sand today to start his special mission to the Middle East, Russia, China and perhaps India.

The gloom that had hovered over the Schuessl_r household since lay 31, when Terry, a canary that smiled and sang operatic arias, flew away was dispelled yesterday with Terry's return. Not only were Mr. and Mrs. Henry Schuessler, their twin sons, William and Henry, and their daughter, Joyce, overjoyed but even the household pets, Butch, a turtle, Mickey, the cat, and Pete, a 15-year-old poodle. were happy that Terry was once again in their midst.

If the radio speech of Randolph E. Paul, general counsel for the Treasury, against the Ruml pay-as-you-go plan represents all that the Treasury can say against it, then the plan should certainly be adopted. For Mr. Paul's argument is utterly unconvincing.

Detailed plans for the campaign will be discussed today by Thomas E. Dewey, nominee for Governor, and the other candidates on the Republican State ticket. The conference will be held at the Dewey campaign headquarters, 41 East Forty-second Street.

Retail trade in out-of-town areas improved steadily this week, visiting buyers reported yesterday, but may still show an unfavorable comparison with last year because of the heavy gains made during that period. Back-to-school wear was an important item.

The Louisville Gas and Electric Company, Kentucky, reduced yesterday the quarterly dividend on the common stock with the declaration of 25 cents a share for payment on Oct. 24. Previous disbursements were 37 1/2 cents a share.
Private dwellings and tenement houses figured in most of the Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday.

GROTON, Conn., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Probate Judge Arthur P. Anderson ruled today that Peter Bennett Plant, 13, was adopted and was not the son of Constance Bennett, the actress, and the late Phil Plant, and so was not entitled to $550,000 of Mr. Plant's estate. Mr. Plant was the second of Miss Bennett's four husbands.
BAY SHORE, L.I., Sept. 2 -- Sailing an outstanding race throughout, Bill Picken, with his sloop Fo-Fo, today won the fourth contest for the Atlantic Coast championship of the Star Class.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Sept. 3 -- The threat to Stalingrad became even more acute yesterday. Striving with all his might to reach the city, General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock intensified his attack from the southwest, flinging 150 tanks into the narrow salient that was driven into the Russian lines on Monday.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- The migration from the London pavements toward the hop fields of Kent, a tradition of the past 150 years, found swarms of East-Enders flooding to trains across London Bridge yesterday.
At 12:01 A. M. today Police Commissioner Valentine set a record of having had the longest tenure of office of any Police Commissioner in the history of New York City.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The country's entire supply of cotton linters must be sold to the Commodity Credit Corporation under an order issued today by the War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Attorney General Biddle told Congress in a report today that thirty-six Federal employes had been discharged during the last year and that thirteen others had been disciplined for activities associated with alleged subversive organizations, but he declared that "sweeping charges of disloyalty in the Federal service" had not been substantiated in the $100,000 F.B.I. investigation ordered by Congress.

WASHINGTON, Sept 2 -- The Navy took steps today looking to the more rapid advancement of younger officers and giving the Bureau of Aeronautics representation in the higher ranks more in proportion with the importance of that service.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses received permission from the Board of Estimate yesterday to proceed with his plans for demolition of the Aquarium and the reconstruction of Battery Park.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 -- The West Coast has all the appurtenances of war -- except the fighting.

LONDON, Sept. 2 -- Some of the economic problems facing Germany as a result of the three-year blockade were described today by an official of the Ministry of Economic Warfare. The chief factors that have accelerated the problems are a combination of heavy fighting in the East, maintenance of the blockade in the West, dislocation through R.A.F. bombings and growing restlessness in occupied Europe.

The drive to sell $1,000,000,000 of war bonds in September which has just been launched by the motion-picture industry is a challenge to the home front. We need the money to provide the tanks and planes and guns with which the armies at the front are fighting back the challenge of the enemy.

A reawakened interest in securities of the public utilities brought some of the preferred issues of this group to the fore yesterday, but the main body of the stock market drifted listlessly. Scattered minor gains were strung through the list at the close of trading, with here and there an addition of major size.

Clarification of the procedure by which the postal authorities accept certain parcel post export shipments and then merely hold them pending the availability of shipping space was urged yesterday by speakers at the first Fall meeting of the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) --Lieutenant John J. Hyland Jr., 30, of Port Washington, L.I., was presented today a Distinguished Flying Cross by Secretary Knox for his achievements as commander of a Navy patrol bomber in the China Sea campaign.

CHICAGO, Sept 2 -- Buying of wheat futures by mills here and at Minneapolis rushed prices upward in the early trading to a new high for the last six weeks before profit-taking and a little hedging pressure developed and checked the upturn.

Postponed from Monday evening, Alec Coppel's mystery comedy, "I Killed the Count," will be presented tonight at the Cort by Frank Carrington and Agnes Morgan with the backing of the Shuberts. Production of this play was long delayed because of a resemblance to another script, a matter which Mr. Carrington says has now been straightened out. Mr. Carrington and Miss Morgan staged the play.

Plans are complete to have 4,000,000 adults and children in New York State start a wartime physical training program by Oct. 1, intended to "develop a citizenry fit to fight and serve on all fronts," Dr. Hiram A. Jones, director of physical fitness for the State War Council, reported yesterday.

With a salute to our gallant ally, Russia, Jay Thorpe opened its Fall custom-made collection. Throughout there were references to Russian styles past and present. However, it must be said that not more than the merest hint was visible. There was a suggestion of the Russian peasant blouse in a red crepe two-piece fastened down the side with gold buttons.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 2 -- William Norman Hudson, 26 years old, of 501 West Seventh Street, who on Monday refused to report to Selective Service Board 14 for induction in the Army, was posted today as a delinquent at the board's offices and notice of the action was sent to the United States District Attorney, Governor Charles Edison and Selective Service Headquarters in Trenton.
Mrs. Linville K. Martin, president of the Association of the Junior Leagues of America, is in town with "a lot of theme songs."

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Truck tire production was resumed at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company's Plant One this afternoon under an agreement providing for negotiation of the question whether the tire builders should work a six-hour day, or one of eight hours, as desired by the company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, demanded tonight that a representative of labor be put in a position of coordinate power with Donald M. Nelson, director of the war production program of the United States.

The first three years of the war were reviewed at a luncheon of the Overseas Press Club in the Belmont Plaza Hotel yesterday by Jan Ciechanowski, Polish Ambassador; Harold Beresford Butler, British Minister in Washington, and Douglas Miller, author and assistant to Elmer Davis, head of the Office of War Information.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept 2 (U.P.) -- Kinhwa, the capital of Chekiang Province, which has an air base within medium bomber reach of Japan, is about to fall to Chinese troops battering into its environs from three sides, a communique said tonight.

Lawrence Ottinger, president of the United States Plywood Corporation, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders here that the company's products had found their way into so many war uses that the company could not supply more than a fraction of the demand, despite a substantial increase in production facilities.

It is three years since Poland said a bold "No" to Adolf Hitler. It was the first "No" that Hitler had ever heard. In eighteen days of savage fury he believed he had stamped out Poland. Now in the fourth year of the war Poland, armed and steadfast, unconquered and indomitable, still confronts him.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 2 -- United States forces serving overseas now total more than 500,000 men, John J. McCloy, Assistant Secretary of War, disclosed today in an address before an encampment of Veterans of Foreign Wars here. "And like John Paul Jones on the Bon Homme Richard, we have not yet begun to fight," he declared.

Singing lustily and carrying souvenirs that ranged from salamanders to canned tomatoes and a home-made barometer, 275 Girl Scouts, the last contingent of 2,289 girls who spent their Summer vacations at four camps, arrived at Grand Central Terminal yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- America's shipyards delivered sixty-eight new cargo vessels and large tankers in August, the Maritime Commission announced today, giving the total as 753,600 deadweight tons.

A drive to enforce strict compliance with the provisions of the Selective Service Act has been begun in this city, it was disclosed yesterday. P. E. Foxworth, assistant director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, announced that his agents had picked up thirty- four men in raids Tuesday night and yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- The Treasury failed to present details of its proposed spending tax today and the Senate Finance Committee virtually marked time, although it did remove eight strategic minerals from the excess profits tax.

The German High Command said yesterday that German mobile units had reached the Volga River north of Stalingrad and repulsed several strong Soviet counterattacks, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 -- A Federal grand jury today indicted Charles F. Rohleder, a building contractor, and three of his employes on a charge of conspiracy to defraud the government in supplying $200,000 worth of materials for rehabilitating the Cramp Shipbuilding Company plant.

The action of the Albany County branch of the American Legion in seeking to bar the Communist party State ticket from the ballot was characterized yesterday by Earl Browder, general secretary, as the work of "fifth columnists" in support of what he called "Jim Farley's insurrection against the Commander in Chief of our nation at war."
CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 2 -- The Army-Navy "E" for excellent per formance in war production has been awarded to the Diebold Safe and Lock Company here.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 -- A blue-ribbon Federal grand jury, described as the first of its kind in the United States since Pearl Harbor, was called today by Judge George A. Welsh to investigate the activities of an alleged country-wide espionage and sabotage organization, apparently having its center in this area.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (U.P.) -- The Office of Price Administration authorized increases today in maximum prices for canned apples, applesauce, apple juice, cider and dried apples so that processors may cover increased raw fruit prices and other items which have risen over levels of last year.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 2 -- Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler entertained with a buffet luncheon today in the Colonial Room of the Meadow Club before the closing presentation of the festival in aid of United China Relief, given this afternoon in the terraced gardens of Shelmar House, home of Francis Hartman Markoe in Water Mill.

LONDON, Sept. 2 (U.P.) -- Fifty thousand Jews from Germany and Czechoslovakia have been thrown into the fortress at Terezin and several thousand who are ill or charged with "criminal" acts are in underground dungeons where they are "dying like flies," a Czech Government spokesman said tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 2 -- The draft boards of Atlantic County and State Selective Service headquarters are in disagreement over the deferment of non-essential employes of the public utility companies.

Men who married after Dec. 8, 1941, or even on a previous date when it appeared that they might soon be drafted will not benefit by the latest instructions to local boards from Selective Service headquarters in Washington, ordering the induction of all single men before married men are called, it was announced yesterday by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City draft director.

Mainbocher held an American wartime showing yesterday afternoon. It was a collection for women who are taking their war responsibilities seriously, for women are buying clothes to last them for the duration.

In spite of all of our modern methods of communication, the radio, the telephone and whatnot, rumors still are transmitted by the oldfashioned method of word of mouth. Yet they surely do get around in a hurry and distance is no obstacle.

Although the theatre has been having a protracted recess it has not got all the torpor out of its system yet. Quite a lot of it turns up in Alec Coppel's "I Killed the Count," which was acted on a competitive basis at the Cort last evening.

German and Rumanian forces dislodged Soviet troops from strongly fortified bunker positions near Stalingrad, and enemy installations in the city and shipping on the Volga were subjected to severe pounding from the air, a communique from Adolf Hitler's headquarters announced yesterday, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York.

LONDON, Sept. 3 (U.P.) -- Twenty-four American Air Force heroes were cited for gallantry in action today, five posthumously, by Major Gen. Carl A. Spaatz, commanding the United States Army Air Forces in the European theatre.

Continuation of the fight against Park Commissioner Robert Moses' plan for the reconstruction of Battery Park, involving the demolition of Fort Clinton, later the Aquarium, was promised lastnight at a dinner of the Fine Arts Federation of New York at the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street.

With both parents fighting bitterly over the custody of their four small children, Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan ruled in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday for the second time that the children were to remain with their father, Alman Harrington, 23-year-old electrician's helper, who is in critical condition from a gunshot wound inflicted by his 21-year-old wife, Anna, until he dies or recovers sufficiently to change the status of the case.

Col. Teddy from the Calumet Farm that bred Whirlaway captured the Pickwick Purse, richest race run at Aqueduct yesterday, but there was just as much comment over the showing of a 2-year-old, Blue Swords.

Best prepared for meat rationing, when it comes, are the sturdy democratic men, as Walt Whitman might call them, endowed by their Creator with, a liking for hash, both corned beef and roast beef, and such closely allied subsistence as hamburgers, frankfurters, stew and the like.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 3 -India will be saved by her army and not by the agitators who are seeking Indian freedom, General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, Commander in Chief in India, said in a broadcast from Delhi this evening.

WITH UNITED STATES FORCES, NEAR CAIRO, Sept 3 (AP) -- "I just want to say I'm damned glad to see you. God bless you and give 'em hell," Wendell Willkie told American troops today after looking over their big army workshops and repair facilities here.

A GULF COAST POPT, Sept. 3 (U.P.) -- The Navy said today that three seamen who stuck to their posts when a torpedo crashed into their medium-sized British cargo vessel had been killed in the first Caribbean sinking officialy announced this month.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Jitterbug dancers and the strange, voluminous garb that many of them affect are interfering with the progress of the country's war effort and the War Production Board intends to do something about it.

As a result of the Army's investigation into the celebrated air-marker hoax story last month, Colonel Dache M. Reeves has been relieved of his command of the First Air Ground Support Command at Mitchel Field, L.I., and Major Lynn Farnol, public relations officer of the First Air Force, has been relieved from active duty.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 3 -- Spain took a decided swing toward the Allied camp today when Generalissimo Francisco Franco summarily dismissed his brother-in-law, Ramon Serrano Suner, as Foreign Minister and replaced him with a known Allied sympathizer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Confidence in victory for the United Nations was expressed today by Peter Fraser, Prime Minister of New Zealand, as spokesman for the British dominion which has contributed more lives to the war effort proportionately than any other of the Allies.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he had asked James G. Blaine, chairman of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, to take over the New York City salvage campaign until a successor was named for Clarence H. Low, former director of the drive. Mr. Blaine said he would act as temporary chairman.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Chicago meat packing officials denied today that their companies had evaded the beef and veal price ceilings schedule which became effective July 13. They assailed the Office of Price Administration suits as "without merit."
Details of three loans to finance war production were made public yesterday.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Sept. 3 -- At Milne Bay the Australians made a most satisfactory haul of Japanese equipment, samples of which have been brought back to the mainland and are now undergoing examination by experts.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Here are some questions and answers concerning the Treasury's new tax proposal:

MADRID, Sept. 3 -- General Francisco Franco, Chief of the Spanish State, today ousted his brother-in-law, Ramon Serrano Suner, as Foreign Minister, General Jose Enrique Varela as War Minister and Colonel Valentin Galarza as Internal Minister in a sweeping Cabinet shake-up that gave him full control of the government and Spain's single political organization, the Falange party.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- President Roosevelt talked with groups of farm and labor leaders today about his new anti-inflation program which is to be announced on Labor Day.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 -- Amplifying the statements made today by Ganson Purcell at St. Paul, the Securities and Exchange Commission made public the text of a list of extensive proposed changes in proxy rules designed to place control of industries more securely in the hands of stockholders.

Prices at the silver fox fur sale held yesterday by the New York Auction Company, Inc., were softer by about l0 per cent compared with the previous sale, the company announced. There were 12,000 skins in the offering and the sale of about half of this number was completed yesterday.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 3 -Members of the Summer colony have responded to the "no benefit appeal" in behalf of the William Carey Camp which was launched here a fortnight ago by a group of young matrons and debutantes of recent seasons, headed by Mrs. Casimir de Rham.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Small detachments of Japanese troops have made new landings in the Southeastern Solomon Islands, the Navy announced tonight. These landing groups are being sought out and engaged by our Marines, the Navy said.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- During the last week of August the Bureau of Labor Statistics index of prices of nearly 900 series in primary markets remained unchanged for the third consecutive week at its 16-year record level, 98.9 per cent of the 1926 average.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- Business on the stock markets was small today. In the gilt-edge section the 3 1/2 per cent war loan declined 1/16 to u106 3/8. In the homerails London Northeastern improved slightly. The rayons were quieter in the industrials.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The United States concluded today, through exchanges of notes, agreements with four of the United Nations to formalize the arrangements for reciprocal aid against the enemy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -The American Newspaper Publishers' Association asserted today in a brief filed with the Supreme Court that "any tax or other exaction which falls directly upon the act of circulation is an unconstitutional restraint upon the liberty of the press."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -Petroleum Coordinator Ickes said today that the Government had requisitioned from the Midwest and Southwest all the remaining rail tank cars transporting gasoline there.
After an experimental ride yesterday in a Sanitation Department truck equipped with wooden tires, Mayor La Guardia decided that the rubber problem still was a long way from being solved.

To provide plywood planes and gliders on a mass-production basis for the United States Navy by making use of the facilities of a group of furniture manufacturers under the guidance of experienced aircraft executives, the American Aviation Corporation has been organized and is constructing a large assembly plant at Jamestown, N.Y., R.N. Webster, president and chairman of the board, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -Formation of four new armored divisions to give the Army a total of fourteen such units was announced today by Secretary Stimson.

MOSCOW, Friday, Sept 4 (UP) -- German forces assaulting the outposts of Stalingrad have pressed the Russians back somewhat in a new push northwest of the city and are attacking heavily in the depth of the Soviet defenses to the southwest, the Red Army command reported today.

Mayor La Guardia announced last night the streets where free parking will be permitted over the Labor Day week-end for the thousands of suburbanites whom he has invited to spend the holiday in the city.

"What's the use," Alice ruminated, "of a book without pictures or conversations?" And "what's the use," we meditate in a similar vein, "of a holiday without parties or celebrations?" Since it is obviously of no use at all, we have planned a festive, though meatless, menu for the eve of Labor Day -a Sunday night supper for a family plus friends.

All banks in the United States and its possessions will be closed on Monday, as will all securities and commodity exchanges in observance of Labor Day. All markets in Canada also will be closed. Here all plants vital to the war effort will produce on the holiday, however, and wherever possible, the usual Labor Day observances by labor organizations will be held tomorrow.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 3 -- Breaking with the "traditional" Falangist direction of his country, Generalissimo Francisco Franco, in a dramatic reshuffle of his Cabinet, this afternoon ousted his fanatically Falangist Ministers of Foreign Affairs, Interior and War, replacing them with younger men of monarchical sympathies.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A joint communique from British General Headquarters and the R.A.F.:

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 3 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops have driven to within fifteen miles north and twenty-five miles west of Canton, greatest port in South China, in a two-pronged sweep that carried through several more towns and wiped out all Japanese gains in Kwangtung Province since May 30, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- President Roosevelt told the youth of the world by radio today that "the Nazis, the Fascists and the militarists of Japan have nothing to offer to youth -- except death." A victory for the United Nations, on the other hand, he said, meant freedom, economic security and banishment of fear.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 3 -One of the many activities that continue to keep India in a disturbed state is illegal distribution of leaflets and pamphlets of an inflammatory nature.

Betty Jean Schwaeber, 13 years old, and her brother Henry, 10, children of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Schmaeber, gave a "Roosevelt broadcast party" yesterday while the President was broadcasting to the youth of the world. It was held in the Schwaeber apartment in Shelton Hall, 155-01 90th Avenue, Jamaica.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 -- Prices of wheat dragged slowly lower today on the Board of Trade on scattered selling induced more by lack of aggressive milling and other demand than by any material pressure. Final sales of futures were at about the bottom, with losses of 3/8 to 3/4 cent a bushel, the former on September.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (U.P.) -The War Production Board is preparing an order to reduce farm implement production drastically and concentrate all such output in a few small plants, it was disclosed tonight.

Wednesday's parade of the first contingent of American soldiers through London is reminiscent of May 11, 1918, when the first units of our World War Army marched over the three-mile route past Hyde Park and Whitehall, and were reviewed by King George in front of Buckingham Palace.

When the Dies committee submits a list of more than 1,100 Federal employes for investigation by the F.B.I. as possible members or affiliates of subversive organizations and the F.B.I. finds only two of this number, plus thirty-six reported from other sources, sufficiently involved to merit dismissal from Government service, it is clear that there is a difference of opinion as to the nature of evidence.

Convinced, according to close associates, that there is no prospect of a return to the era of lush living in which the renting of apartments at $10,000 or more a year was a common occurrence, Vincent Astor has reversed a century-old policy of his family and is selling a considerable part of his vast realty holdings in Manhattan.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- As Great Britain today entered the fourth year of the war the entire nation, including Prime Minister Churchill, knelt in prayer while, as far as possible, industrial activity was halted for fifteen minutes, beginning at 11 A.M.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 3 -J. Kenneth Bradley, Republican State and county chairman and national committee man, tonight declared his support for Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce of Greenwich for the Congressional nomination in the Fourth District, which embraces Fairfield County.

What may become the largest motion-picture deal in the history of the industry was put in motion yesterday when the rights to "Life With Father," one of Broadway's biggest comedy hits, were placed on the open market. Unusual restrictions were laid down by Oscar Serlin, producer of the dramatization by Howard Lindsay and Russel McKinley Crouse of Clarence Day's reminiscences of life in his father's New York home in the Eighteen Nineties.

In times of war the repair-man and the mending basket enjoy a sudden, unaccustomed popularity and conservation comes into its own. On every side, like toadstools after a rain, signs pop up with their optimistic messages of flats fixed, shoes remodeled and rips rewoven as good as new.
LONDON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- In the condition statement for the week ended yesterday and issued today the Bank of England reported an increase of almost 1,500,000 in note circulation.

An award of $2,500 for the best non-fiction book written by a working American newspaper man or woman was offered yesterday by the New York publisher, Alfred A. Knopf, 501 Madison Avenue. In announcing the terms of the contest Mr. Knopf, who has brought out the books of many newspaper men, took cognizance of the truism about all newspaper men having a book they want to write.

Every indication points to a record-breaking Labor Day week-end. The traditional surge of travel from New York City will begin today and reach its peak tomorrow, when thousands will depart. The influx of visitors is expected to set a new record.

Injunction actions to restrain twelve packing companies from continuing alleged violations of Office of Price Administration ceilings through the sale of low-grade meat at prices fixed for better qualities were begun yesterday in Federal courts in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

The Carnegie-Illinois Corporation and four other subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation have agreed, under protest, to submit to the order of the National War Labor Board raising the wages of their 150,000 employes. Under the board's order, wage rates are to be increased 5 1/2 cents an hour, retroactive to Feb. 15, 1942.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Special holiday candies were removed from the provisions of the General Maximum Price Regulation and placed under independent regulation by OPA today. The action was taken because the type of candy in question was not sold in volume in March.

At 12:01 yesterday Police Commissioner Valentine broke a record. He had served a longer time than any of his predecessors. Appointed Sept. 25, 1934, he has become the dean of New York Police Commissioners. Our old friend the dictionary tells us that "dean" comes from the Latin decanus, which means "a chief of ten.
