WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A proposal by Senator Gurney to draft youths of 18 and 19 drew criticism today in the Senate where Senator Bilbo declared that he preferred to draft married men before putting "tender-age boys" into the combat service.

The report of the United Engineering and Foundry Company for the six months ended with June, issued for publication today, disclosed a net income of $1,126,878 after all charges, including $3,720,000 provision for State and Federal income and excess profits taxes and $200,000 provision for war contingencies.

NEWARK, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Syracuse Chiefs improved their play-off hopes today by taking the measure of the champion Newark Bears, 4 to 1, in a game that was marred by the accidental beaning of Outfielder Joe Abreu in the eighth.

LONDON, Sept. 3 (U.P.) -- A United States naval attack near New Britain Island is likely when Vice Admiral Robert Lee Ghormley completes consolidation of United States positions in the Solomons, The Star reported today from Sydney, Australia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The War Department expects to double its present force of 300,000 women workers in civilian positions and thereby displace an equal number of men who will be released for military or other service, Secretary Stimson said today.

SHREVEPORT, La., Sept. 3 (AP) -- Six Barksdale field flyers, including First Lieut. Kenneth E. Reddy of Bowie, Texas, who was a co-pilot on the Tokyo raid with Brig. Gen. Jimmy Doolittle last April were killed last night when a B-26 twin-motored bomber crashed and burned in a wooded section seven miles from Little Rock.

CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 3 -- When Commonwealth Treasurer Joseph B. Chifley presented his first budget last year he provided for a year's outlay of 221,000,000 Australian, and the actual expenditure is reaching 319,000,000. Parliament had before it today Mr. Chifley's new budget, presented last night, calling for a total of 549,000,000 Australian -- roughly $1,950,000,000 -- of which war expenditures would be about 440,000,000; and even this estimate may prove inadequate.

AT THE FRENCH FRONTIER, Sept. 3 (UP) -- Germany was reported today, in advices from unoccupied France, to be seeking permission to station dive-bomber squadrons at Dakar. The demand was said to have been placed before Chief of Government Pierre Laval by Otto Abetz Adolf Hitler's emissary in France, last Thursday at a conference held at Nevers, just north of Moulins, in the occupied zone.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 3 -- Bobo Newsom today made a magnificent debut as a Dodger by white-washing the Reds on four hits as the league pace-setters beat them, 2 -- 0, and ran their winning streak to four games. The victory enabled Brooklyn to maintain its lead of four-and-one-half games over the Cardinals.

Following an all-day conference with his colleagues on the State ticket, Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, announced yesterday his first trip of the campaign, which he will start intensively early next month. Plans for the campaign were discussed at the conference and Edwin F. Jaeckle said he had received very encouraging reports from county leaders both in New York City and up-State.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 3 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has undertaken a sweeping revision of the "sadly prostituted" proxy device in order to "enable stockholders themselves to control the actions of management," it was disclosed today by Ganson Purcell, chairman of the SEC, in an address before the National Association of Securities Commissioners.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3 -- A fly ball that was lost in the sun allowed three Cardinal runners to cross the plate in the third inning today at Sportsman's Park, much to the embarrassment of Carl Hubbell. Tricky winds also swung two high flies out of Babe Young's reach in the sixth and they fell for doubles.
It is, indeed, high time that Congress begin to renovate its spirit, as you suggest in your editorial "The President and Congress."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 3 -Fred MacMurray will play the leading role in "Mistress Mary," a comedy which Robert Pirosh and Rene Clair are writing for direction by Clair, Paramount announced today. The studio has abandoned plans for production of "The Man Who Had No Private Life," an unproduced play by Otto Furth, which Clair was to have directed, and "Mistress Mary" will replace it on the schedule.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles gained ground in the International League play-off race by defeating Jersey City in both ends of tonight's doubleheader, Pete Center and Elmer Burkart won the opener, 5 to 4, with a six-hit job, while the Flock combed Bobby Coombs for eight blows.

The Army Specialist Corps will select some twenty to thirty business executives with extensive retail store experience from this area to attend a school for Post Exchange officers to be started on Oct. 1, it was announced here yesterday.

"In view of uncertainties in the immediate outlook occasioned by the meat price ceilings, directors of Armour Co. of Illinois decided to take no action on the $6 prior preferred stock at this time," the company announced yesterday. The last payment on the issue was $1.50 on July 1.

"Across the Pacific," a tropical melodrama produced by Warner Brothers which arrives at the Strand, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Humphrey Bogart is starred in the picture, which was directed by John Huston. Mary Astor and Sydney Greenstreet head the cast of supporting players.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The War Labor Board, hearing C.I.O. appeals for wage increases for General Motors employes beyond those recommended recently by its panel, was told today by Walter P. Reuther, vice president of the United Automobile Workers, that Unrest among the 225,000 unionists in that segment of the war production industry was greater now than at any time since the labor troubles of 1937.

LONDON, Friday, Sept. 4 (Reuter) -- "A great adventure in part nership," is how an editorial in The Times of London described today the two-way leas-lend agreement outlined yesterday in the notes exchanged between the United States and British Governments.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- While the departure from the Spanish Cabinet of Serrano Suner, Foreign Minister and brother-in-law of Generalissimo Francisco France, was regarded as possibly favorable news for the democracies, since Senor Serrano Suner was conspicuously pro-Axis, observers here tonight hesitated to express a definite opinion until it became clear to what extent the shake-up resulted from friction inside the governing Falange party.

WITH BRITISH NAVAL AIR FORCES in the Egyptian Desert, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Crack bomber pilots of the British Navy, dumping scores of tons of bombs on Axis lines, have inflicted heavy casualties on German troops and have smashed motor-transport columns in raids lasting through last night to early today.
BAY SHORE, L.I., Sept. 3 -With another sloop, but with his same sense of wind and course, Harold Halsted today won his third Atlantic Coast Star Class championship.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -Secretary Jones revealed today that the War Damage Corporation has insured property in the United States against enemy attack for $50,000,000,000 to $100,000,000,000. Mr. Jones, who is chairman of the company, made this report to the first directors' meeting today.

Hesitancy reigned yesterday in the cotton futures market as many traders shied from further commitments until the implications of inflation-arresting measures, which President Roosevelt is expected to outline in his Labor Day address, can be determined.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- A Navy communique:

The New York Football Giants yesterday shifted the scene of their operations from the Polo Grounds to Baker Field, where they continued preparations for their charity game with the Eastern Army All-Stars at the Polo Grounds a week from tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The new and better world order predicted by President Roosevelt as "the total victory" for which the United Nations were fighting "total war," was the subject of discussion at today's sessions of the International Student Assembly, not only by guest speakers, but by the students themselves.

The semi-annual statement of the Federal Insurance Company and its wholly owned subsidiary, the Vigilant Insurance Company, given out yesterday by Hendon Chubb, president, shows a consolidated net premium income of $5,636,195, compared with $3,811,280 for the first half of 1941, with a net underwriting loss of $2,516,001, against net underwriting income of $182,313 last year.

BOSTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The Red Sox, who have been winning games but gaining little ground in their stretch drive to catch the league-leading Yankees, shut out the Tigers, 2 to 0, today behind the four-hit pitching of Bill Butland.

Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht Jr. ruled unconstitutional yesterday a law passed by the State Legislature this year which restricted the right to perform marriages to ministers of religions "listed in the last preceding Federal census of religious bodies.

Heralded as setting a new high in figure-skating entertainment, the Ice Capades of 1943, with several international stars in the cast of 110, win have its world premiere in Madison Square Garden tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Treasury Department examples of how the proposed spendings surtax, refundable spendings tax and lower family exemptions in the income tax would affect incomes of $2,500, $5,000 and $10,000 a year are as follows, the lowered exemptions referred to being $500 for a single person, $1,000 for a married couple and $250 for each dependent:

Parks Commissioner Robert Moses was taxed yesterday with having struck below the belt in his attack on Pierce Trowbridge Wetter, whom he described to the Board of Estimate last Wednesday as a former Federal convict in Leavenworth penitentiary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The sinking of a Japanese light cruiser by United States submarines in Far Eastern waters, together with the destruction of four other vessels and damage to three additional ones, was reported in a Navy Department communique today.

ALBANY, Sept. 3 -- Denying a motion to amend an earlier decision of his court on the tangled affairs of Local 17 of the Hod Carriers and Common Laborers Union, Supreme Court Justice Bergan declared today that while the court would afford protection to the rights of a labor union member, unable to help himself, it will not attempt to run labor unions in detail.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Department store sales in the week ended Aug. 29 decreased 14 per cent compared with the like week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The decrease in the previous week was 2 per cent (revised). Sales for the latest four-week period declined 6 per cent.
Following is the text of an address made by President Roosevelt yesterday before the International Students' Assembly in Washington, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Labor's bid for a place on the War Production Board and an equal voice with Donald M. Nelson, the chairman, in directing the war production effort appeared to have been compromised today with Mr. Nelson's agreement that he would consider the appointment of two labor executives as vice chairmen.
MOSCOW, Sept. 3 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:

Pending appeals from L-135, under which the War Production Board has banned the use of steel springs in living room furniture after Nov. 1, manufacturers are going ahead with experiments on "ersatz" lines, they said yesterday. Samples shown to the trade thus far have not met with too good a response, but manufacturers have hopes of developing better models.

Nearly 100 negotiators, equally divided among employing truckers and A.F. of L. unionists, made a new approach to the city's trucking dispute by meeting yesterday in the Hotel New Yorker to carry out the formula proposed by Dr. John R. Steelman, director of the United States Conciliation Service, that they agree upon as many points of a proposed contract as possible and report back to him their seemingly insoluble differences.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- It would be a comforting thought if General Francisco Franco's sudden and peremptory dismissal of his brother-in-law, Ramon Serrano Suner, from the Foreign Ministry and presidency of the Falangist political bureau could be interpreted as indicative of a shift in Spain's diplomacy away from Axis influence.

Some complaints are beginning to develop among retailers that national advertisers who gauged their advertising schedules to their own production are overlooking the fact that retail stocks are still heavy in many lines and will last for months. At a time when retail sales are running behind last year retailers need the help of manufacturers' national advertising, even though the producers' output may have been cut sharply or stopped.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Parents and others wishing to send Christmas presents to Navy and Marine Corps men have about a month to do so, the Navy Department said today, and they might best send small, portable articles and avoid shipping food which might deteriorate in transit.

Record-O-Vox, Inc., a radio manufacturing concern, and Samuel Solat, its president, were enjoined yesterday from continuing the manufacture of radio sets in violation of priority regulations designed to save such critical materials as copper and aluminum for more important war uses.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 3 -- Under constant bombardment by British artillery, German tank columns fell back today from some of their newly won positions in the Western Desert. British tanks and armored cars immediately retook the abandoned strongholds.

A protest against the treatment of the Northern Railroad of New Jersey and its subsidiary, the Nyack Northern Railroad, in the Erie Railroad's bankruptcy proceedings was issued yesterday by Cameron Blaikie Jr., vice president of the Northern.

Douglas Southall Freeman, whose four-volume "R.E. Lee" won the Pulitzer Prize for biography in 1934, is off on another multi-volumed work to be called "Lee's Lieutenants: a Study in Command." Next month Scribner will bring out the first volume of the projected three, "Manassas to Malvern Hill.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- American doughboys in Britain in the last six months have maintained a better health record than the troops at home, Colonel Paul R. Hawley, Chief Surgeon of the United States Army in the European theatre, said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -Some small arms ammunition plants have been directed to curtail operations, the war production board disclosed tonight, because production of this type of munitions has been so abundant as to be out of balance with the over-all war program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Washington defeated Chicago twice today, taking the opening game, 3 -- 2, behind Sid Hudson's four-hit hurling and exploding for twenty blows to overwhelm the White Sox, 14 -- 0, in the nightcap with Rookie Scarborough on the mound.

BURBANK, Calif., Sept. 3 -- The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and its subsidiary, the Vega Aircraft Corporation, produced nearly as many dollars worth of aircraft and parts in the first half of 1942 as they delivered in all of 1940 and 1941, while production in July alone exceeded that for the whole of 1940, according to a letter sent today to stockholders by Robert E. Gross, president of Lockheed.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 3 -Crisis coincides with crisis. In Russia the Germans claim to have reached the Volga; simultaneously Field Marshal Erwin Rommel has attacked in Egypt; Japan again appears to be threatening Siberia, and in the South Seas a limited operation in the Solomons has become for both sides a continuing and expensive campaign.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- According to official information received here, there are no German troops in Dakar. Diplomatic circles are inclined to doubt that the Vichy government will consent to their going there. Moreover, it is doubted that the Germans will be inclined to force the issue as long as they are so involved on the Eastern Front.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, Sept. 3 -- The main armored concentrations of the British Eighth Army have held their original positions, which appear to be extremely strong. The center of their resistance is of their own choosing, and they are well protected by artillery.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The Office of Price Administration ordered today, effective Sept 8, that substantially the entire meat industry, with the exception of the retailers, already regulated, submit to licensing control. The step is designed to prevent the evasion of existing and forthcoming price regulations, it was explained.

LONDON, Sept. 3 -- New methods and new devices are making life "doubly dangerous" for Nazi submarine crews, A.V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, declared today at a luncheon of the National Defense Public Interest Committee here.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Sept. 4 (AP) -- United Nations bombers, blasting Japanese bases in the upper Solomons for the second straight day, damaged two enemy seaplanes and started large fires with four direct hits on fuel dumps, a communique announced today.

Mayor La Guardia called upon all employers yesterday to relinquish registered nurses eligible for military service and to replace them with ineligibles, as he issued a proclamation naming the first two weeks of this month as a drive to recruit 1,822 registered nurses for the First Reserve of the American Red Cross.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 3 -- With bomber planes of the United States Army Air Forces cooperating, British Empire light bomber aircraft made 20 per cent more sorties yesterday than on any other day since the war in the Middle East began.

CAIRO, Sept. 3 (U.P.) -- Wendell L. Willkie, on a White House-approved tour of Allied and neutral countries, said during a press conference today that "Nazism has reached the peak of its power and we now are seeing the beginning of its recession, although it will be a long war."

Your editorial "Inventions and the war" emphasizes admirably the need for greater coordination of scientific and technical research, both of which are important to the complete mobilization of our economy for the all-out war effort.

MOSCOW, Friday, Sept. 4 -General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock's drive against Stalingrad from the southwest was checked yesterday, but northwest of the city, after violent fighting, the defenders were pushed back. Announcing this news of the day's fighting, the midnight Soviet communique also reported further withdrawals before Novorossiisk, Black Sea port in the Caucasus.
MOSCOW, Friday, Sept. 4 (AP) -The Soviet midnight communique:

The thirty-three member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City lost $110,000,000 of excess reserves in the week ended on Wednesday, reducing the total to $265,000,000, according to the weekly figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The fashion parade, apparently stimulated rather than stifled by shortages and restrictions, was augmented yesterday by the Autumn collection of another leading couturier. Ornamentation, fabric manipulation and new silhouettes all conspired to make Henri Bendel's showing of gowns, suits and furs a notable addition to the current openings.

A total of $23,796,948 in War Bonds and stamps has been sold in New York State by means of the drive begun last Tuesday by the war activities committee of the motion-picture industry, Max A. Cohen, chairman of the State committee, announced last night.
LONDON, Sept. 3 -- Karlsruhe, important German rail junction and industrial center of the upper Rhineland, was set ablaze by British bombers last night in an attack of several hundred planes.

The appointment of Miss Eleanor L. Curnow, formerly associated with the administration of the work relief program of the Federal Works Agency in New York City, as executive secretary, and of Mrs. Lloyd B. Sanderson Jr., former secretary to Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, as membership secretary, of the Women's City Club of New York was announced yesterday by Mrs. Alfred Winslow Jones, president of the organization.

"Janie" has postponed its opening a day to next Thursday. Tickets for the Brock Pemberton comedy go on sale today at Henry Miller's, scaled from $4.40 to $1.10 for opening night, with a $3.30 top thereafter.

REKYJAVIK, Iceland, Sept. 3 (AP) -- The destruction of a German Focke-Wulf Kurier bomber near here last month was disclosed today with the award of the Silver Star to Second Lieutenants Joseph Shaffer, 24 years old, of Long Beach, Calif., and Elzae Shahan, 24, of St. George, W. Va., for "extraordinary heroism" in shooting the intruder down into the sea.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Proposals for a new $6,500,000,000 spending tax on individuals, of which $2,000,000,000 would be a permanent addition to the Treasury's revenues and $4,500,000,000 would be enforced savings returnable to the taxpayer without interest at the end of the war, met a cold reception from the Senate Finance Committee when presented today by Secretary Morgenthau.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 3 -- Wars of three centuries and events in New Rochelle's Huguenot history were reviewed before Justice Gerald Nolan in Supreme Court today in the battle of historians and artists to retrieve for posterity a 320-year-old French cannon that Mayor Stanley W. Church of New Rochelle recently donated for scrap.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 3 (AP) -- Simplification of regulations on new securities issues would encourage many corporations to finance "on their own," relieving government of that much of the burden. Albert H. Gordon, New York, member of the industrial securities committee of the Investmenti Bankers Association of America, today told the National Association of Securities Commissioners.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- Commissioning of 500 women of the Women's Auxiliary Corps (the Waacs) as third officers was announced today by the Army, their rank dating from Aug. 29.

A struggle waged for more than five years by Miss Helen Keller, a former novice in a Dominican convent at Orangeburg, N.Y., to clear her 32-year-old convict brother, Michael, of a robbery, gained its first success in General Sessions yesterday when Judge Saul S. Streit reduced a thirty-to-sixtyyear State prison term imposed on Keller in 1937, to ten to twenty years.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- The text of Secretary Morgenthau's statement to the Senate Finance Committee on proposals for a spending tax and other changes in the tax bill, was as follows:

Francisco (Pancho) Segura evened a score with William Talbert of Cincinnati yesterday and is now holding forth in the semi-final round of the United States tennis championship at Forest Hills. Bracketed with him is Frank Parker, the player who defeated the little Ecuadorean in 1940, the first time he appeared at Forest Hills with his two-handed drive.

Somehow the statements of Propaganda Minister Goebbels no longer ring with the same self-confidence. He has begun to plead with the German people. A large number of them, one gathers from his latest statement, now reveal an alarming tendency to be "unbiased and just" to the British, instead of keeping their hearts full of hatred, and recognizing that "the bourgeois era of false ideals about humanity is past."

Hearings on economic conditions in the candy and related products industry, on the basis of which the United States Department of Labor is scheduled to raise wage minimums, were begun yesterday at the Hotel Astor before a committee of fifteen representatives of the public, the employers and employes in the industry.
The offshore fishermen who had almost become resigned to a quiet year for tuna may find a surprise in the latest news from Freeport.

CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 3 -- Herbert V. Evatt, Australian External Affairs Minister, reviewing in the House of Representatives today his mission to the United States and Great Britain, said he had found that the Pacific theatre was being assessed as of higher relative importance than many authorities were at first disposed to give it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (U.P.) -Joseph B. Eastman, defense transportation director, said tonight that rationing of unreserved train seats is not being considered, but that priorities on rail travel will be instituted "wherever necessary."

The sharp decline in sales of consumers' durable goods on the installment plan since March, as a result of credit restrictions and product shortages, is shown in the fact that the volume of retail financing by sales finance companies has declined 57 per cent.

CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 3 -- Herbert V. Evatt, Australian External Affairs Minister, reviewing in the House of Representatives today his mission to the United States and Great Britain, said he had found that the Pacific theatre was being assessed as of higher relative importance than many authorities were at first disposed to give it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (U.P.) -Joseph B. Eastman, defense transportation director, said tonight that rationing of unreserved train seats is not being considered, but that priorities on rail travel will be instituted "wherever necessary."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 4 -- Seven thousand four hundred and fifty persons have been summarily executed in German-occupied countries since the German reign of terror began in August last year, according to a compilation made by the Goeteborg Handelstidningen today.

"Tobacco Road" opens tonight for a limited engagement at the Forrest Theatre, where it closed its record-breaking run of 3,180 performances sixteen months ago. John Barton will play the part of Jeeter Lester for the first time on Broadway, although he has portrayed the role on the road for the last five years.
CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 4 (AP) -- A United States Army Air Forces communique from Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Petroleum Coordinator's Office does not believe that gasoline rationing in the Middle West is the best way to relieve the shortage in the East, Ralph K. Davies, deputy coordinator, declared in a letter released by Senator Walsh, Democrat, Massachusetts, today.

CHUNGKING, Saturday, Sept. 5 -- American Sky Dragons, packing light bombs as well as machine guns on their fighting planes, carried out one of their most devastating sweeps all the way from Nanchang to Hankow Wednesday, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced last night.

There appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES recently a letter from a reader complaining of people sneezing in subways without covering their noses. Lest she become apprehensive of germs being spread in the summertime, especially from Aug. 15 until the first frost, let me assure her that the cause of most people sneezing at the present time is hay fever and not respiratory infections.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Sept. 4 -- Nelson Rockefeller, Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, listed some of the war efforts of the United States at a luncheon given for him by the Brazilian Commercial Association.

LONDON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Germany has announced Adolf Hitler's appointment of General Friedrich Hirschhauer as the new chief of anti-aircraft defenses for the whole country, and British sources said today that the step betrayed Nazi alarm over the growing destructiveness of Allied air attacks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The War Department plan to reduce the course at West Point from four to three years but at the same time give a wider field of training, received tentative approval today from the Senate Military Affairs Committee. Formal approval is expected early next week, with floor action following promptly.

Incoming and outgoing crowds jammed transportation terminals yesterday as thousands of out-of-town visitors arrived here for the annual Labor Day week-end and throngs departed for country, mountain and shore resorts for the three-day holiday.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- An order by Surrogate John A. McKenna of Rockland County filed here today directed that four trust funds in the estate of the late Daniel Carter Beard, Boy Scout commissioner, become immediately distributable. Mr. Beard died at his Suffern, N.Y., home July 11, 1941, leaving an estate recorded at more than $10,000 real and personal property.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- A British bomber captained by Pilot Officer Roy Charles Munson of Halsey, Ore., after carrying out its share of the bombing attack on Mainz last month, crashed in landing just over the British coast. Behind the award of the Distinguished Flying Cross to Pilot Officer Munson lies a story of skill, courage and determination which triumphed over great odds.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 4 -- The four societies of the Sheffield Scientific School and of the Engineering School of Yale University, at their annual elections tonight, chose eighty-four members from the class of '45. St. Anthony and Vernon Hall picked twenty-two each, York Hall and St. Elmo, twenty each. Those elected were:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Aug. 29 were 249,007,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, United States Department of the Interior. This represented an increase of 2,700,000 barrels in the week, comprising increases of 2,582,000 and 118,000 barrels in domestic and foreign stocks, respectively.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- Mayor Stanley W. Church revoked today his gift of New Rochelle's 320-year-old French cannon to a scrap salvage committee and said the city would comply with demands of historians and artists that the relic be preserved as a municipal treasure.
MOSCOW, Sept. 4 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman returned from an 18,000-mile tour of visitations to Catholic chaplains with the armed forces in the United States and Alaska in time to celebrate a solemn memorial mass yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral on the fourth anniversary of the death of Patrick Cardinal Hayes.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Sept. 4 (AP) -- If Bill Dickey can hold up three more seasons, a veteran of the New York Yankees' farm system predicts, the world champions will be able to unveil a successor so closely resembling the ace catcher nobody will know the difference.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4--An indictment charging treason against three men and three women, all Chicagoans and all naturalized citizens, was returned today by the Federal grand jury. It was the first time an indictment for this crime had been voted in Illinois.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- The government White Paper on conditions among the women's services in Britain, which was issued Thursday, has done more than allay public misgivings regarding the conduct of girls in the Auxiliary Territorial Service, Women's Auxiliary Air Force and the Women's Royal Naval Service -- it has opened new vistas of thought on what is to be done with this vast army of uniformed women once the war is won.

ONEONTA, N.Y., Sept. 4 -- Making his first public appearance up-State since his nomination, Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, opened his campaign today by making an informal tour of the Republican counties of Ulster and Delaware.

The appointment of Charles H. Silver, general sales manager of the American Woolen Company, as chairman of the Independent Citizens Committee for the Election of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, was announced yesterday. Mr. Silver will open headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore on Tuesday. He will work in close conjunction with State Chairman James A. Farley and the Democratic State Committee.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 4 (AP) -- A Navy plane crashed into the sea today about 1,000 yards off Beavertail, Jamestown, sinking almost immediately after its two occupants freed themselves from the wreckage.

Walter P. Reuther, vice president of the United Automobile Workers, tells the War Labor Board that "unrest" among General Motors employes is greater now than at any time since the labor troubles of 1937. The implication is that there win be "trouble" unless the board grants substantially what the union has asked.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 4 -- Some time ago a number of well known people of Palestine felt that some organized expression should be given to the main idea contained in Dr. Judah L. Magnes's article on Palestine and Arab union that was printed in local periodicals in June.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- Traders in wheat evened up today for the approaching Labor Day holidays and the scheduled announcement of the government's price-control measure during the period when the markets are closed. Scattered selling disclosed a lack of aggressive demand and the close on the Board of Trade was 1/8 cent a bushel lower to 1/4 cent higher.

The controversy in New Rochelle over the salvaging of historic war relics brings to light many problems relating to the public's lack of understanding of what total war really means. The moral indignation of people who probably were not even aware of the existence of historic relics shows how quickly the public can become emotional about a situation that should be viewed objectively and solely in the light of winning the war.

Looking for Trouble There is such a thing as looking too far ahead. It is predicated in the case of one candidate for high office in this State who is worried about post-war fascism. He is convinced that when this war is over we shall be confronted with a "vicious reaction" engineered by fascists and racial and religious bigots.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Submerging its domestic political aims in a common determination to win this war, the British Liberal party went on record today pledging itself "to pull together" with all parties in an all-out effort to achieve victory, but reserving its democratic right to fight for its own party ideals when the war is won.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Led by veteran Johnny Niggeling, who hurled four-hit ball, and by Vernon Stephens, who blasted his thirteenth home run of the season, the Browns defeated Cleveland, 4 to 0, tonight in the nightcap of a day-night twin bill. The Browns won the first game, 6 to 3.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4 -- The Board of Education threw its weight into the war effort today with a plan for 40,000 high school students to plug critical gaps in farm and industry labor.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he had asked the police and members of the City Patrol Corps to protect the cars of Labor Day week-end visitors to the city from theft or damage. The Mayor said the police would be particularly vigilant in protecting vehicles against stealing of gasoline or tires.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- President Roosevelt canceled all engagements today to devote full time to the preparation of his anti-inflation message to Congress Monday noon and his nation-wide radio speech on Monday night.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 4 -- German soldiers who show signs of cowardice in the fight against the Russians will be shot, a German Army captain warns, writing in the latest issue of the army weekly, Militaerwochenblatt. The article meant as a manual for all German soldiers on the Eastern Front, pays many frank if unwitting compliments to the valor, tenacity and general qualities of the Soviet soldier.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 4 -- The drawing of names for the September grand jury panel was interrupted today in Quarter Sessions Court by protests on procedure made by former Judge John Warren, who is counsel for Bayonne officials under indictment on charges of misconduct in office.

The Police Department may not arbitrarily restrict the area which strike pickets may patrol, under a decision handed down by Magistrate J. Roland Sala in Municipal Term Court, Brooklyn, yesterday when he dismissed disorderly conduct charges against two pickets.
MILWAUKEE, Sept 4 (AP) -- The Falk Corporation, manufacturer of gears, filed a $50,000 libel action in Circuit Court today against the United Steel Workers of America, C.I O., and three individuals.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4--Responding to an appeal by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, 150 newspaper publishers and editors pledged today their cooperation in a campaign to help bring out from every cellar and garret the scrap metal needed to keep steel production going at wartime levels.

Retail Trade Improves Slightly Retail trade here improved this week over the previous week and the decline from a year ago was cut from 13 per cent to about 9 to 10 per cent, according to store executives. The lag in home furnishings and in men's wear was chiefly responsible for holding down total volume. Back-to-school merchandise sold well, except that college wear has been affected. Women's ready-to-wear was active.

The sale of three large apartment houses in New Jersey through Harry T. Jenkin, broker, was reported yesterday. The Associated Company sold two of the houses as follows: The five-story house at 773-75 High Street, Newark, consisting of forty-one apartments and 100 rooms, sold at a reported price of $105,000.

The three-story apartment house at 23-10 Steinway Street, Astoria, L.I., has been sold by Mary J. O'Malley to Vincento Savarese through Stephen Dedesco, broker. The property was sold subject to a mortgage of $6,120. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

The offices of the realty representatives of Vincent Astor took on the appearance of boom days yesterday following the announcement that many of the long-held Astor properties in Manhattan were for sale and that Mr. Astor was in the market for income-producing real estate in other parts of the country to diversify his investment portfolio.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- "Scare" buying of liquor by the public under the impression that production of liquor would cease for the duration of the war was ill-advised, Matthew J. MacNamara, special consultant on conversion of distilleries to industrial alcohol production for the chemical branch of the War Production Board, said today.

The decision of Vincent Astor and his realty advisers to depart from the old Astor tradition of concentrating realty investments in Manhattan is a significant symptom. His new program involves selling many of his holdings here and replacing them with a diversified group of income-producing properties in various parts of the country.

"Moscow Strikes Back," the Russian documentary feature dealing with the Soviet counter-offensive on the Moscow front last year, which enters its fourth week at the Globe today, will be distributed nationally by Republic Pictures, it was learned yesterday.

A detailed account of German atrocities in Poland, with documentary evidence in the form of official papers, pictures, maps and eyewitness stories, makes up "The Black Book of Poland," publication of which was announced yesterday by the Polish Information Center here.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Bertram de N. Cruger, London representative of the British War Relief Society of America, on behalf of the American Labor Committee, sponsored by the American Federation of Labor, handed a check for $35,000 to Labor Minister Ernest Bevin to be used to add twelve new clubs to those already existing for girl munitions workers with temporary emergency hostel accommodations.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Chiefs moved nearer a play-off berth tonight by defeating the pennant-winning Bears, 9 -- 5, in a twilight battle. The victory gave the Chiefs the series, 3 games to 2, and whittled their deficit in the season's set to 12-10.

The enemy air-marker hoax recedes into history with the disciplining of the two officers apparently responsible for it. General Drum has relieved the commanding colonel of the First Air Ground Support Command of his post and has relegated the reserve major who acted as public relations officer to civil life.

LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Royal Air Force bombers attacked twenty-one target areas in Germany in August during twelve nights of raiding and also participated in five daylight raids over Germany and German-occupied territory, the weather making large-scale operations difficult at other periods, the Air Ministry said tonight in a summary.

What was declared to be the first air attack of the war on Budapest, Hungary's capital, was reported last night by the German Transocean agency in a wireless transmission to the United States recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The alarm lasted from 11:30 P.M. till 1:20 o'clock this morning, Budapest time, and bombs were dropped in and about the city, the German agency said.

For many years the big New York stores have made no extra charges for delivering purchases out of town or for wrapping purchases as gifts. Recently some of the stores have been charging for out-of-town deliveries and for gift wrappings, saying the change is the result of action by an association of which they are members and whose policy they fix.

A penthouse apartment in the building at 888 Park Avenue has been leased by Lieut. T. Suffern Tailer, U.S. Army, through Douglas L. Elliman Co. who also reported leases with Mrs. William H. Osborn in 111 East Eightieth Street and Joseph C. Palermo in 301 East Twenty-first Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept 4 -- RKO has acquired an optional right to film the life of Sister Elizabeth Kenny, Australian nurse who discovered a treatment for infantile paralysis, a previously announced deal between United Artists and the nurse having been permitted to lapse, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Coach Jimmy Conzelman pronounced his Chicago Cardinals in excellent condition today with the exception of Tackle Al Babartsky, who has a leg injury, as the squad embarked for Denver and a game there Sunday with the Western Army All-Stars.

The typical small retail dealer in about 75 per cent of the trades buys 80 per cent or more of his goods from wholesalers, while large retailers, regardless of trade, buy much of their merchandise directly from manufacturers, according to a survey of the buying policies of more than 2,600 independent stores released yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.,

SCHENECTADY, Sept. 4 -- Production of machine tools in this country during the past four years was greater than the total for the preceding forty years and this year's output will probably reach a value of $1,500,000,000, Tell Berna, general manager of the National Machine Tool Builders Association, declared here today at the General Electric Farm Forum.

CHICAGO, Sept. 4 -- America is on the road to air superiority, the requisite for victory, Captain E.V. (Eddie) Rickenbacker, World War ace and president of Eastern Air Lines, declared tonight in an address at the Army Air Forces Technical School here.

Featured by the largest flotation of municipal bonds since January, new bond issues offered for public subscription here this week surpassed any week's total in the last three months. Three issues were marketed for a total of $39,435,000, one amounting to $33,950,000. These compared with a single offering of $1,000,000 in the preceding week and with five issues aggregating $7,841,825 in the week ended on Sept. 5, 1941.

DEAL, N.J., Sept. 4 -- A $2,000,000 civil libel suit, accusing Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, Democratic leader of Hudson County, of making "false and malicious" statements against John Warren, Jersey City lawyer who led the legal fight resulting in the ouster of the Hague-dominated Hudson County Board of Taxation, has been started in Monmouth County Common Pleas Court by attorneys for Mr. Warren.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- William Fox, former movie magnate, contended in a petition filed with the Supreme Court today that he should be permitted to withdraw a plea of guilty to charges of conspiracy to obstruct justice because the United States Attorney General had agreed to this action and because the case against two alleged co-conspirators had been dropped.

An elaborate program has been arranged for the "Labor Salutes the Armed Forces," rally on the Central Park Mall tomorrow afternoon, sponsored by the New York State and Greater New York C.I.O. councils in cooperation with the USO.

A committee headed by Joseph Wilbur Murray of Holyoke, Mass., has sent a letter to stockholders of the Wickwire Spencer Steel Company asking that they sign proxies for the immediate sale of their stock at $19 or more a share in cash. The committee states that this is its first step in an effort to consummate the sale of the company.

Winning the nation-wide contest conducted by the American Jersey Cattle Club for members of 4-H Clubs and Future Farmers of America brought Robert Houston Jr., 19 years old, Tupelo, Miss., to New York yesterday on his first visit. He also will have the opportunity of seeing the bull calf, Elsie's Son of Victory, which is his prize in the competition. This pedigreed calf is at the Walker Gordon Farm in Plainsboro, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- President Roosevelt has prepared for issuance Monday the most drastic order affecting the everyday life of Americans in the nine and a half years since he became President -- a decree limiting all wages, salaries and farm prices in the United States, responsible sources said tonight.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Sept. 5 (U.P.) -- Allied medium bombers attacked a Japanese cruiser yesterday off Southeastern New Guinea with "unknown result." General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters reported today, leading to speculation whether the Japanese might be trying to make another drive against the world's second largest island.

Caution prevailed again yesterday in the cotton market, restricting volume. Active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 5 to 7 points higher than Thursday's final quotations, the force of liquidation and hedging in the final hour paring gains of 8 to 16 points made on fairly good trade and mill buying.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 4 -- Of 30,000,000 Chinese in the northeastern provinces 13,000,000 have become opium addicts as a result of a deliberate Japanese policy to poison the minds and bodies of the inhabitants of Manchuria since Sept. 18, 1931, according to Li Chung-king, a member of the standing committee of the Opium Suppression Commission of the Ministry of Interior, in a broadcast to Chinese in the occupied territories.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept 4 -- The Reynolds Brothers' Powder Bluff won the South Shore Purse at Narragansett Park today with a two and three-quarters length victory over Miss T. Hanley's Hopeville. It was Powder Bluff's second consecutive victory. Third place went to Jim Arthur's Shrimpie, three lengths back of Hopeville.

The German attack on Stalingrad has carried to the suburbs of that city on the Volga, while 400 miles to the southwest the Nazi Army of the Crimea has stormed across the Kerch Strait to the Russian-held Black Sea coast, the German High Command announced yesterday, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The mechanics of possible ceilings on live hogs have been discussed in a two-day conference between Office of Price Administration officials and producers, live stock commission men and packer buyers, OPA announced today.

Organized participation by school students in the New York City salvage campaign and an increase in the number of neighborhood depots to receive individual contributions of scrap material too small to warrant the sending of a junkman are among the salvage projects which will be worked out by the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, it was learned yesterday.
HAVANA, Sept. 4 -- Cuban armed forces today celebrated the ninth anniversary of the sergeants' revolt which placed Fulgencio Batista, now President, in command of the island.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 4 -- Francis P. Byerly, 52, a senior partner in the accounting firm of Price, Waterhouse Co., attached to its New York headquarters, was found dead early today in his car in the garage of his home in Bowling Green, near Media. Chief Ralph Howard of Nether Providence police said that Mr. Byerly had committed suicide by inhaling carbon monoxide from the exhaust of his car.

The only record-breaking track and field accomplishments these days come from war-torn Europe. Gunder Haegg, the Swede, is bettering world records with such regularity that it seems we are back in the old days when Paavo Nurmi was the hero of all track and field followers.

Popularity of the employes' Suggestion System of the Celanese Corporation of America was disclosed yesterday in a survey showing that about 40,000 suggestions were submitted at the company's two yarn producing plants in Maryland and Virginia in the last year and a half, and $21,000 has been distributed in extra compensation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The State Department has made the "most vigorous representations possible" to the French Government through the American Embassy in Vichy over the mass deportation of Jews from unoccupied France, it was announced today by the American Jewish Committee.

On the whole, I think that Mel Ott is doing a swell job with the Giants and that the club is one of the most improved teams in the major leagues today. However, a number of changes in the Giant pitching staff and relief squadron seem highly advisable.

Brilliant punting by Merle Hapes, Ole Miss fullback, highlighted a two-hour morning drill for the Football Giants at Baker Field yesterday as Coach Steve Owen's squad continued preparations for the benefit game with the Eastern Army All-Stars at the Polo Grounds next Saturday.

CANBERRA, Australia, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The flow of Australia's essential war requirements from the United States is gradually increasing, Prime Minister John Curtin said in a statement today. Planes, tanks, guns and equipment for the fighting forces make up more than half the lease-lend supplies received, he added.

ALBANY, Sept. 4 (U.P.) -- The State American Legion joined today a move to bar the Communist party from the November ballot. The drive, begun by the Albany County American Legion, suffered a reverse yesterday when Secretary of State Michael F. Walsh rejected a request to strike the party from the ballot.

New municipal securities scheduled to be awarded next week will consist chiefly of $45,614,000 of notes, comprising the offerings of nine public housing authorities in various parts of the country. Bids on these issues, which range in size from $12,400,000 to $420,000, will be opened on Wednesday.

Both the league-leading Dodgers and the third-place Giants rolled back home yesterday from their satisfactory invasion of the West prepared to tangle with each other in a three-game series at the Polo Grounds, which has a strong bearing on the National League race.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The Orioles suffered a serious blow to their International League play-off hopes when the Jersey Giants defeated them in both games tonight, 4 to 3 and 5 to 1.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 4 -- Four high Orthodox Church dignitaries of Czechoslovakia were executed in Prague this morning by Gestapo vigilantes following a "public" trial by the Special Tribunal in that city yesterday on charges of "hiding the murderers of Reinhard Heydrich," former Protector of Bohemia-Moravia, and of "having sheltered in the Charles Borromea Church of Prague enemy parachutists landed on territory of the protectorate."

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $427,801,463 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price a share of all listed stocks on Aug. 31 was $23.70, compared with $23.42 at the end of July.

An agreement to settle for $4,000,000 the proceedings brought against officials of the General Motors Corporation arising out of payments of bonuses from 1930 to 1940 became known yesterday when Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell signed an order setting Oct. 5 as the date for a hearing on the compromise.

CAIRO, Sept. 4 -- A slight move westward by the Axis desert forces yesterday was regarded here today as not highly significant. General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel failed to draw out the British by his early advance some distance east of the Allied forward positions.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 4 (U.P.) -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation entered the San Francisco home of Saverio Ariani, a former Chicago bank president, tonight and recovered $48,300 in cash and securities, declared to be part of the $155,000 with which he allegedly absconded eleven years years ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- A plan for regulation of wholesalers' and retailers' inventories of finished goods for civilians has been approved by the War Production Board, Donald M. Nelson, chairman, said today.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Sept. 4 -- The special committee appointed by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, to evaluate Henry J. Kaiser's proposal for building a fleet of cargo planes in his shipyards has not yet submitted its final report, representatives of committee members said tonight.

MOSCOW, Sept. 4 -- The Russian offensive in the Rzhev and Vyasma region has met not only with German resistance but with attacks from nature as well. Long, heavy rains, which in places stopped tanks and artillery completely, hindered the Russian operations.

This Summer Americans have discovered, somewhat to their own considerable surprise, that having a good time does not necessarily involve making a dash over the hills and far away. We have been busy exploring the greenness of our own back yards -- and finding it up to a delightfully high standard.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Sept. 4 -- Preparations were being made at Mount Holyoke College today for the training of 300 officers for the Waves while 900 other women of the Navy auxiliary are being trained at Smith. The Navy Department at Washington yesterday designated Mount Holyoke as the second of two training schools in the East for women of the Navy.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 4 -- By sixty-six votes to twenty-two the Chamber of Deputies decided today to request the Minister of the Interior to appear before it Sept. 18 to explain why the government has not taken effective measures "to suppress the activities of the German National Socialist party, which continues to function in Argentina under the name of Federation of German Welfare and Cultural Clubs."

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 4--Violent fighting has broken out again on the Egyptian front, where American tank crews have drawn their first blood, destroying at least six Axis tanks, and Allied bombers and artillery have destroyed thirty-nine other tanks and forced the German Afrika Korps to withdraw twice in twenty-four hours, it was announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- The War Production Board asked every State and city in the country today to do its share in a nationwide campaign to collect one-half billion pounds of waste fat a year.

AT AN ALLIED BASE IN AUSTRALASIA, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Lieutenant Duncan Seffern of Manawa, Wis., pilot of a bomber that ran out of gas on a flight from Townsville, Australia, to Port Moresby, New Guinea, has reached this base after tramping through New Guinea jungles for twenty days.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Sept. 5 -The defenders of Stalingrad held their ground today as the gigantic struggle for the city -- the greatest battle of the war -- moved inexorably toward its climax.

Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday that the construction of two public housing projects and one new city hospital had been slowed down because of inability to get priority orders on the necessary construction materials.

Formation of the Plastic War Production Association, a pool of plastics companies in this area with headquarters at 122 East Forty-second Street, was announced yesterday. The association, which has been certified by the War Production Board, will pool the engineering, research and manufacturing facilities of its members for the benefit of the various government branches placing war contracts.

The New York Life Insurance Company has sold the six-story apartment building at 1439-59 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, to the Beverly Gardens Corporation. The structure is on a plot 191 by 100 feet and contains seventy-two apartments. The Wiljack Realty Company was the broker in the deal.
LONDON, Sept. 4 -- Business fell off to small proportions on the stock markets today. Gilt-edged issues remained steady and home rails were in demand at gains of 1/8 to 1/4 noted.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Major General A.A. Vandegrift of the Marine Corps, who commanded the United States Marine forces in the capture of the Tulagi base in the Solomon Islands, has commended highly the Navy airmen who supported the attack in cooperation with Army and Marine Corps fliers.

"Labor Sunday" will be observed at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine with a special service tomorrow at 4 P.M. The address will be delivered by Dr. Spencer Miller, Road Commissioner of New Jersey and for many years labor relations consultant to the National Council of the Episcopal Church.

There is a good deal to be said for Greater New York as a place in which to spend a holiday. Or, rather, there was a good deal to be said until our worthy Mayor up and said it. As one reads the list of possibilities for the coming week-end one wonders why any one should ever go out of town.
DETROIT, Sept. 4 -- Thousands of members of the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) employed in automobile plants engaged in war production protested today against a Labor Day layoff.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 4 (AP) -- Chicago defeated Pittsburgh, 5 to 3, tonight as Hiram Bithorn held the Pirates helpless until the ninth when a single, walk and doubles by Vince DiMaggio and Maurice Van Robays were bunched for all of their runs.

Formation of a sponsoring committee to cooperate with the United States Civil Service Commission in its drive to recruit 1,000 stenographers and typists from the New York area for government jobs in Washington was announced yesterday by the American Women's Voluntary Services of Greater New York.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 4 -- The second-place Cardinals took a third-inning lead over Cincinnati tonight and stayed in front to win, 5 to 3, and gain a half-game on the idle Dodgers, who now lead the league by four games.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

One would think that such a document as the formal statement handed out by the third annual Conference on Science, Religion and Philosophy at Columbia University would be a model of the correct use of words, or that it would at least avoid incorrect usages.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 4 -- The Camden County Grand Jury, indicting seventy-five persons today in a drive on gambling, linked Edward Carroll, police lieutenant and head of a Camden city police division, with Marco Reginelli, notorious underworld figure.

Alejo Russell, the smiling, courteous Argentine star who has been winning American tennis galleries with his sportsmanship and grace in accepting defeat, furnished the big thrill of the national championships at Forest Hills yesterday.

The new tax proposals of the Treasury have these virtues: they would raise large additional revenues; they would increase the number of taxpayers; they would penalize spending and reward saving. Those are highly desirable objectives, but the method advocated is incredibly bad.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) -- President Juan Antonio Rios of Chile will arrive in Washington Oct. 22 on a state visit at the invitation of President Roosevelt, it was stated today by the Chilean Embassy.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 4 -"Repression with unswerving energy of all provocation or acts of sabotage" is the keynote of the policy in Spain to be followed by the new Spanish Minister of Interior, Blas Gomez Perez, according to a short address delivered by him on assuming office in Madrid today.

"Federal Funds" For the first time in several weeks, New York City banks short of reserves with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York as a result of heavy Treasury withdrawals from war loan accounts with these institutions and the further heavy withdrawals scheduled for next week, borrowed funds yesterday from banks which were better supplied.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 4 -- The story of a young man and a young woman with the wanderlust and $10,000 worth of railroad tickets and how they were balked by a technicality before they could take their first journey was related by the police today in announcing the solution of the theft of 933 long and short tickets from the International Ticket Company, ticket printers, of 50 Grafton Avenue here.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

ALBANY, Sept. 4 -- A service flag was unfurled in front of the Capitol this afternoon by Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, in honor of 3,400 men and women employes of the State now in the armed forces of the United States. The ceremony was held in spite of a drizzle.

The Axis is going to hold a big "European youth meeting" in Vienna soon to "answer" the speech which President Roosevelt made Thursday to the International Students Assembly, the Berlin radio said yesterday.

Israel Amter, Communist candidate for Governor, and Elizabeth Gurley Flynn, Communist candidate for Representative at large, will remain in the race, Simon W. Gerson, Communist campaign manager, announced last evening, following a conference of party leaders.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Slavic delegates to the International Student Assembly meeting adopted, independently, today a resolution calling for the opening without delay of a second front in Europe.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Casey, the humbled hero of "Mudville," is fighting for life in a hospital here. He is 80 years old, and the power which made him a terror to opposing pitchers is gone.

"Labor Sunday" will be observed tomorrow in the churches of the New York area, Monday being Labor Day. Commendation will be expressed from pulpits for the many thousands for whom the holiday will be foregone in the effort to speed up work in war plants.

The sale of war bonds by the motion-picture industry in its drive to raise $160,000,000 almost reached the $35,000,000 mark in the first three days of the campaign, it was announced yesterday by Max A. Cohen, chairman of the New York State War Activities Committee.

VICHY, France, Sept. 4 -- Shipbuilding, both merchant and naval, is continuing in France, according to announcements in thee press today. The newspaper de Depeche Brest today announces the launching of the first ship built in occupied France as having occurred last Wednesday.
One of this newspaper's veteran correspondents, Herbert Matthews, sums up the problems of a reporter newly arrived in India:

The Ruml tax plan should be regarded primarily if not exclusively as a psychological cliche -- certain stimulus resulting in certain response. To ask anybody from an imminent to an eminent taxpayer if he wants the plan adopted is equivalent to offering him cash or asking if he would like Mr. Morgenthau to cover all insurance premiums for the next few years.
New Yorkers got their first glimpse of the Ice Capades of 1943 in Madison Square Garden last night and emphatically proclaimed the new season's initial skating show an entertainment "must."

The War Department announces that troop movements in the United States during the first nine months of this war were three times what they were during an equivalent period after we entered World War I. But Secretary Stimson, in giving out this cheerful news, declined to speculate "on any comparison between the movement of troops abroad in the same periods in the first World War and the present one."

With fourteen named for the Babylon and thirteen for the Woodmere, Aqueduct will have its biggest day of the current meeting today when approximately $25,000 will be available in purses on the eight-race program. The Babylon is for 2-year-olds and the Woodmere for older horses, each carrying approximately $7,000, and each a sprint race.

RICHWOOD, W. Va., Sept. 4 -- A migration of mountaineer farmers to help harvest the tomato and peaches and other crops of upper New York State began today. The first thirty-three of almost 300 volunteers in the food-for-victory drive left by bus for Rochester and 250 will go Tuesday, accompanied by their families, on a special train chartered by the Farm Security Administration.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 4 (U.P.) -- Two bystanders were wounded tonight when members of the outlawed Irish Republican Army exchanged shots with police in an armored car on a Belfast street.

LONDON, Sept. 4 (Netherlands News Agency) -- A Rembrandt painting, "The Kindness of Emperor Titus," has been auctioned at The Hague for 300,000 Netherlands florins -- about $162,000 -- the German radio reported today.

WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 4 -- Miss Vivien Kellems said today she would not withdraw from the race for the Republican nomination for Congress in the Fourth District, a seat now held by Representative Leroy Downs, despite the fact that J. Kenneth Bradley, State central committeeman, wrote to her yesterday that he endorsed her opponent, Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce of Greenwich, for the nomination at the district convention in Bridgeport Sept. 14.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- A move to aid in recruiting 5,000,000 more women for war production by the end of 1943 was taken by the War Manpower Commission today with the appointment of a woman's policy committee consisting of twelve women leaders of labor, industry and public activities.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 4 (AP) -- In a fantastic Babe Ruth-like job of "calling his shot," Gunder Haegg took the world one-mile running record apart tonight with a blazing performance of 4 minutes 4.6 seconds for the cinderpath's most highly prized competition.

More than 500 employes of the Fultch Fish Market turned out yesterday morning to honor their fellow-workers in the armed forces and watch the dedication by Commissioner of Markets Daniel P. Woolley of a service flag hearing seventy-two stars.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4--The Navy Department moved today to establish personnel divisions in all shore establishments to coordinate all questions of industrial relations.
CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 4 -- This city's Board of Education decided tonight by unanimous vote to close Camden's public schools during January and February to conserve fuel oil.

In its first change of ownership in more than fifty-eight years, the four-story building at 49 Canal Street has been sold by the Wendel Foundation to 35 Canal, Inc. The parcel is 21 by 50 feet and is assessed at $16,000. It was sold through the Cross Brown Company and the Julius Bachrach Company.

The first extended undergraduate Summer courses given by Columbia University to enable men to complete their academic work before being called for military service have been completed by 800 students, it was announced yesterday by Edward J. Grant, registrar of the university.

Lieutenant George Stab, commander of a German submarine, was captured after his ship ran onto a submerged reef in seeking to escape from depth-bomb attack off the American coast on July 11, according to a broadcast from the anti-Nazi German radio station Gustav Siegfried I, which was picked up yesterday by The Boston Globe and transmitted from Boston by The Associated Press.

Fish that hop about on land to move from one pool to another and fish that stick their heads in the sand like an ostrich were among 250 exotic species displayed last night at a "pre-view" of the fiftieth annual exhibition of the New York Aquarium Society in the American Museum of Natural History.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Their nocturnal game with the Senators called off on account of weather, the Yankees tonight found themselves confronted with the rather laborious assignment of playing three double-headers on the next three days, a task which promises to tax even so elaborately equipped a pitching staff as the world champions possess.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- The Berlin radio, speaking in German, yesterday quoted Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda, as saying that German broadcasting has been built up as a huge weapon of war, with fifty-six transmitters busily telling Europe in twenty-nine languages what Goebbels thinks Europe should hear.
Eight workers at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn who designed or suggested improvements in existing machinery were honored yesterday at a brief ceremony.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 4 -- The systematic deportation of all German Jews eastward is approaching its end, and while no precise figures are available it is reliably learned here today that only an insignificant number of Jews employed in German war industries and considered irreplaceable are still in Germany.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 -- Three sales tax plans were discussed by the Senate Finance Committee today in addition to the spending tax which was proposed by the Treasury yesterday but failed to commend itself to most of the committee's members.

The Lerner Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday for the six months ended on July 31, net income of $825,610 after provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes at the rate provided in the Revenue Act of 1942 as passed by the House, in the amount of $1,484,566.

The most interesting political event of the week is the shake-up in the Spanish Cabinet. General Franco has replaced one set of key men by another set, of a different mind. Serrano Suner, symbol of the pro-Axis tendency within the ruling party, is out as Foreign Minister, and General Jordano, who held that post under Primo de Rivera and again in 1939, is in.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 4 (AP) -- Governor Darden, saying he had been advised indirectly that there were fraternities in some high schools of the State, declared today that in so far as his authority went, "I will seek elimination of them entirely."

Fish that hop about on land to move from one pool to another and fish that stick their heads in the sand like an ostrich were among 250 exotic species displayed last night at a "pre-view" of the fiftieth annual exhibition of the New York Aquarium Society in the American Museum of Natural History.

IN Hollywood Charles Coburn recently confided to a scout for this column that he had serious intentions of returning to the Broadway stage this Winter after an absence of five years. Bringing him back to these parts would be a comedy written by the late Don Marquis entitled "Master of the Revels."

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 5 -- President Ramon S. Castillo today reaffirmed Argentina's intention to abide by her policy of neutrality when he received a committee that delivered to him fourteen albums containing, it was said, one million signatures of Argentine citizens who approved of the isolationist attitude assumed by their country's government.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- The advantages of a robust handicap were demonstrated today when Joe Pittori of Hickory, Mount Vernon lawyer, and J.A. Lyons Jr. stepped off to a one-stroke lead over the field in the revival of the annual Leewood Golf Club invitation member-guest tournament.

Delegates to the American Kennel Club at their quarterly meeting this month will not be called upon to act on the amendment to Chapter 10-A, Section 1, which was proposed some time ago by the board of directors.

EVERY day new contrasts appear on battlefields of the world, and on the "home front," between the strategy and methods of World War I and of World War II. Nowhere is the contrast more striking than in the role assumed by the American college in the present national crisis.

SANTIAGO -- Chile has selected Nov. 1 as date of release of the promised series commemorating the founding of the University of Chile on Nov. 17, 1842. Printed at the Government Mint, the stamps will be valid for postage through Dec. 31, 1943, after which any unsold balance will be destroyed. The postal administration is considering installing a special postoffice at the university and according a first-day service for collectors.

How swiftly women are adapting themselves to the skills war industries demand is a story told in figures compiled by the United States Office of Education, showing a six-fold increase in their enrollment since February in engineering, chemistry, physics and production supervision courses.

A kidnapping case brings Eleanora Burke, a detective attached to the District Attorney's office, to the home of Dr. Amadeus Wyatt, a scientist who has for many years been conducting experiments to prove that environment is a more potent factor than heredity in the forming of character.

HAVANA, Cuba, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The arrest of a 31-year-old German whom Cuban police described as "one of the most important spies yet captured in America," was announced today. The authorities indicated he would escape the firing squad by becoming a government witness.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Here is the text of Secretary Morgenthau's statement in support of the Treasury's proposals for a spending tax:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- In a Labor Day statement tonight President Roosevelt warned of sacrifices of increases in wages, crop prices and profits, as well as in bodily comforts, for the purpose of winning the war.

The blue of the sky, the warmth of the wind, the lyricism of Mayor La Guardia and the bargains of department stores combined forces to overload the city yesterday with out-of-towners as the Labor Day week-end started on its gay way.

Police Lieutenant Charles O. Dannhauser and Patrolman Leonard P. Cooke were exonerated yesterday by Commissioner Valentine of having participated in the $100,000,000 city-wide gambling racket uncovered by Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Secretary Morgenthau warned in a statement today that unnecessary spending in the country had reached a point of "national danger." It cannot go on, he declared, without threatening the success of the war on the home front and therefore must be checked and brought under control promptly by "bold and resolute" action.

When my loaded wheelbarrow tipped over one day I decided something better was called for, so I bought a child's express wagon. We have hauled just about everything in this wagon. Flats and pots ride securely. Loam, earth, compost, manure, even mixed concrete go right into the steel body.

ALMOST simultaneously with the official warning by the United Nations that the Axis despoilers and oppressors of occupied Europe will be tried and punished, appears the second volume of the Polish Black Book. In it the Polish Government documents the unbelievably horrible treatment of the civilian population by the German Army and administration in Poland.

Under its plan for the promotion of closer educational and cultural relations between the Americas, Pan American Airways System announced yesterday that fifteen outstanding students from as many Latin-American countries had been selected to receive travel fellowships to enable them to study in schools and colleges of the United States during the academic year of 1942-43.

HERE is another collection of Bemelmans' engaging sketches in word and line, most of them culled from the smart magazines in which they first appeared. Like Bemelmans himself, they mosey all over the map, gay, irresponsible-seeming and neatly humorous.

FRESH cool breezes swept across the Blue Ridge Mountains and bright sunshine lay across the valley looking westward to Masanutten when, a few days ago, the first major contingent of dogs of war -- or the WAAGs, as they have been called elsewhere -- was formally inducted into the armed services of the United States at the Army Remount Station here, where the Skyline Drive begins its course southward.

The scrap heap, now beginning to tower on many a village green, invites the antiquarian to linger for a pensive moment. "Bring your scrap and cook a Jap," says a sign rising above a huge old iron caldron that reminds of the departed days of home-made soap.

A frank statement of policy regarding the future of motoring during the war period by the Administration would be welcomed by the nation's millions of car owners and drivers. Washington alone gives out information on automobile, gasoline and rubber supplies that can, or cannot, be made available for civilians.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 5 -- Two Army lieutenants stationed at Mitchel Field were killed instantly here this morning when an Army trainer plane piloted by First Lieutenant Jack R. Davies, 23, of Florence, S.C., crashed in a lot south of Garden Street and burst into flames.

BEFORE the First World War Dr. John Dewey said of Germany that it was "the modern state which provides the greatest facilities for general ideas to take effect through social inculcation. Its system of education is adapted to that end.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Sept. 5 -- The first of a new series of New Zealand mine sweepers will be launched Tuesday, indicating that the country's naval program designated to help win the Pacific battle is now fully under way. It is said here that when the full history of New Zealand's war drive is told naval construction will prove the major item.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Hubert W. Cox, 47, a war-plant worker who said he destroyed molds in anger over what he called union limitations to his production, was freed today of Federal charges against him.

Attorney General John J. Bennet Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, yesterday ended his two-week vacation at the American Legion Mountain Camp and will resume his duties in Albany Wednesday morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Flames swept through the destroyer tender Prairie, causing severe damage and killing two enlisted men, while she was tied up at a dock at Argentia, Nfld., May 27, the Navy said today. The vessel since has been repaired and is back in service.

Your editorial on "Luxuries and Necessities" was an interesting analysis of the lengthening distance that is increasing between the poles of need and desire, and it prompts a personal review of what might be called the soft-soap and candle-mold days of a not too distant past.

The serious shortage of scrap metal at the mills, where it is needed for conversion into the sinews of war, has led to government consideration of a subsidy for the collection of certain kinds of large-size scrap which is lying about the country in great quantity because the expenses involved in dismantling it and cutting it up have been greater than its money value, it was learned last night.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Sept. 6 -- Soviet Russian soldiers have hurled back German attempts to advance on Stalingrad by violent assaults of infantrymen, tanks and planes and the Russians are holding their lines firmly before the city, the Russians announced early today.

First Deputy City Clerk Philip A. Hines and three other employes of the office of City Clerk H. Warren Hubbard have resigned their posts, effective as of last Thursday, Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday at City Hall.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco's Cabinet changes, including the dismissal of his brother-in-law, Foreign Minister Ramon Serrano Suner, were considered tonight in European circles more and more an effort to strike some balance between dissident internal forces and to keep Spain on its present neutral course.

Shipyards and building basins all over the country, from the small cove plants to the giant yards turning out warships and cargo carriers, will mark Labor Day with the greatest exhibition of maritime production power in our history.
