A tendency to uniform mark-ups in departments affected by the Fall pricing order of the Office of Price Administration may develop as a result of retailers' inability to check last year's selling costs, store executives pointed out here last week.

Two shadows stretched across Hitler's Reich last week. One was the shadow of Red Army bombers, striking from the Russian steppes 1,000 miles east of Berlin. The other was the now-familiar shadow of the R.A.F., reaching out from British airfields 600 miles or more to the west of the German capital.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 5 -- Noteworthy contributions to the war effort, in addition to the job of preparing students for various branches of the armed forces, were made by Princeton University during the eight-week Summer term just completed, a survey of the activity of departments revealed today.

The Sanitation and Fire Department baseball teams will clash today at the Yankee Stadium in the sixth annual game in the Department of Sanitation Welfare Honor Relief Fund series. The Mayor's Victory Trophy will go to the winner.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- A United States destroyer, the Blue, and a small auxiliary transport, the Colhoun, have been sunk in action in the South Pacific during the last two weeks, the Navy Department announced today. There were "a few" casualties.

An hour and a half before he was to have been married, Nordino Di Girolamo, 25 years old, was found dead of illuminating gas fumes at 3:30 P.M. yesterday in an apartment he had rented for himself and his bride at 443 Shepherd Avenue, Brooklyn.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 5 -- Standardization of beer has driven down consumption 12 per cent throughout Germany during the past year, although percentages vary in different sections. North Germany is consuming 23 per cent less beer than formerly, while Bavaria, which set the pace for the Reich from time immemorial, curtailed her requirements by 11 per cent. East Prussia is the only section to register increased consumption.

Although the cotton textile industry for many years has made only haphazard stabs at research, it has recently become research- minded and is developing one of the best rounded and coordinated programs of any industry in the country.

PRESUMABLY, between blackouts and whenever other wartime duties permit, the art world ought to be promoting earnest speculation as to what the "new" art movement will be like. That a "golden age" is in prospect nobody need bother to deny, because the denial could not be proved, and weight of evidence remains, as of course it should, on the side of optimism as against pessimism.

OBJECTIONS by the government of Francisco Franco to the filming of Ernest Hemingway's "For Whom the Bell Tolls" have been unsuccessful, it was learned this week from an official source at the Paramount Studios.

A program is being launched this week by the New York State Department of Labor to assist employers in providing adequate eating facilities for added numbers of war workers, to educate employes in correct food habits, and housewives in what to provide for the war worker's lunch box.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The determined Browns went a long way toward assuring themselves of third place, their highest position since 1928, by beating the Indians, their nearest challenger, in a second straight double-header today.

Four clinics for the discussion of Office of Price Administration regulations covering the pricing of certain classes of Fall and Winter seasonal merchandise will be held for retailers on Wednesday and Thursday at the New York State OPA office, 535 Fifth Avenue, it was announced yesterday by Lee S. Buckingham, State OPA director.

On application of members of the American Legion, Supreme Court Justice Francis Bergan in Albany yesterday issued a temporary injunction restraining Secretary of State Michael F. Walsh from placing the State candidates of the Communist party on the ballot for the November election and issued an order directing Secretary Walsh to show cause why the injunction should not be made permanent.

ALBANY, Sept. 5 -- Deploring the wastage of human life and crippling caused by accidents, Governor Lehman today issued a proclamation starting on Labor Day "The Home and Farm Safety Campaign," to be directed by the State Department of Health and cooperating organizations. In his proclamation he said:

With a call for a number of highly qualified nurses from the New York metropolitan area, Dr. Addison Gorgas Brenizer of Charlotte, N.C., announced yesterday the formation of an Affiliated Unit, which when completed will operate a base hospital for foreign service with our armed forces.

A new social class is emerging and rising to dominance in Soviet Russia, composed not of proletarians nor the old, loyal Bolsheviki, but of the young production engineers in whose hands economic control and administration has been unified, Dr. Solomon M. Schwarz declares in a report on "Heads of Russian Factories" made public yesterday.

AN unoccupied house standing next to the one in which she is employed as governess terrifies Elizabeth Featherstonhaugh. She feels that there is something evil in this house, something that threatens her two small charges and herself.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5 (AP) -- President Philip Murray of the C.I.O. announced tonight that the United Steel Workers of America has signed a new contract with five manufacturing subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation.

Life, for Steve Owen, Jack Mara and the New York Football Giants, is full of surprises these days. Last week at Akron, for instance, a fellow approached Mara and informed the Giants' president that he would like very much to play for him. It was John Chickerneo, the blocking back of Pittsburgh fame.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 5 -- With brief and simple formalities the new $4,400,000 Charter Oak Bridge, over the Connecticut River between this city and East Hartford, was opened about 10:30 o'clock this forenoon, and by noon thousands of cars had passed the toll gates on the imposing connecting link in the Cross-State Parkway, which will be a part of the principal route between New York and Boston.

Charles Allen Jr. of Allen Co., investment bankers, acting with the approval of Terence J. McManus, referee appointed by the Supreme Court of the State of New York, has notified stockholders of the Wickwire Spencer Steel Company that a letter from Joseph Wilbur Murray asking for their proxies to sell the company's stock at $19 or more a share "is highly misleading, as we know of no one having made such an offer."

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 5 -- The bombing of Budapest and other parts of Hungary by the Russian Air Force last night, following recent Soviet air activity over German territory, was regarded here today as a significant development.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- Westchester and Connecticut police joined today in a hunt for a woman "Raffles" who has escaped with several thousands of dollars in cash and jewelry after "crashing" fashionable Saturday afternoon wedding receptions at three estates in this area during the last six weeks.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Sept. 5 -- Broadening of research facilities and projects, putting into practice its theory of an accelerated program of study for undergraduates in engineering and science, increasing the scope of the social relations program and adopting a practical method of reducing student mortality have been significant developments at Carnegie Institute of Technology during the last year.

WITH Autumn waiting in the wings, Broadway is feverishly preparing for the biggest theatrical season in years, quantitatively at least. After slogging along through several abysmal Winters -- the last one of unhallowed memory was so frail that the Critics Circle chose to overlook it entirely and gave no awards at all -- New York, like London before it, is discovering that amid the bustle and anxieties of war the people want to be entertained.

ART has a practical function in wartime. It works in the common cause. Although an artist may feel at loose ends in a period when the world is taut with action, he has something vital to contribute. He can pull together all the scattered details of war-making and give them an eloquent meaning.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 5 -- The four heats of the two feature events furnished four different winners at Roosevelt Raceway today as the trotters and pacers moved through their regular matinee session.

IN her new novel the author of "Oil for the Lamps of China" has brought her workmanlike intelligence and dramatic sense to play upon a fascinating and little-known field: the picturesque and unique agricultural industry of the California vineyards and the making of wine.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The Yankees' sweeping strides toward the inevitable clinching of the pennant struck a bit of a snag tonight as the annoying Senators held the world champions to an even break in a long session of twilight and nocturnal baseball.

NORMAL, Ill., Sept. 5 -- The morale of our students is going to be affected more by what educators do than by what they say. Dr. Francis W. Hibler, Professor of Psychology at Illinois State Normal University, warns school teachers and administrators now returning to their positions.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, Sept. 5 -- The story of an Italian "commando" raid that fizzled was revealed today when British troops returned to camp with fourteen Fascist desperadoes who were captured while they were shooing flies.
LONDON, Sept. 5 (UP) -- Berlin is moving up on the bombing "priority" list as the nights lengthen and the combined Anglo-American air strength grows, it was revealed today.

Successive Japanese defeats in the battles of the Solomon Islands, Makin Island and Milne Bay in New Guinea have jarred Tokyo's propagandists out of their smug complacency for the first time since the start of the war in the Pacific. Two abrupt shifts in Japan's home propaganda have occurred -- a new caution in claiming quick victory, and a new estimate of America's fighting power.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- The Liberal party pledged itself by an overwhelming vote today to continue its adherence to the national government, regardless of party lines, to aid in the prosecution of the war to a successful conclusion.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 5 -- Shippers will continue to move ore down the Great Lakes until ports at the head of the lakes are icebound, it was reported here today.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- A gathering of leading socialites and prominent dog breeders and fanciers this evening watched the final judging at the twenty-fourth annual exhibition of the Tuxedo Kennel Club in the Tuxedo Park horse show ring.
CAIRO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- A joint Middle East headquarters and Royal Air Force communique:

The disputed job reclassification at the Wright Aeronautical Corporation plants in and near Paterson, N.J., which led to a recent work stoppage by 2,000 employes and a threat of a walk-out by the 20,000 war workers in all five plants, will be studied by a technical expert of the Department of Labor, it was announced last night by Commissioner Irwin D. Shapiro of the United States Conciliation Service.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The shake-up in the Spanish Cabinet by Generalissimo Francisco Franco, Chief of State, who eliminated his pro-Axis brother-in-law, Foreign Minister Ramon Serrano Suner, and made other important changes, is taken here as showing the way the wind is blowing in Europe.

HALF ENGINES -- Professor Walter E. Lay of the University of Michigan's Automotive Engineering Department thinks none too well of the idea that gasoline consumption can be reduced by operating automobile engines on only half of the cylinders. Some fuel would be saved, he admits, but the durability of the engine and car would be reduced.

We reported in this department that last year Drs. Schroeder and Adams (Rockefeller Institute) had reduced high blood pressure with tyrosinase, the substance that causes peeled bananas to turn brown on exposure to the air, and that Dr. Irvine Page of Indianapolis had obtained similar results with extracts of pork kidneys.

An obligation is laid upon colleges and universities not only to fit students to take their place intelligently and effectively in the country's war effort but also to prepare them for the readjustment and reconstruction that are bound to come in the post-war world.

WITH THE ARMY ON CALIFORNIA DESERT MANOEUVRES, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Blue and Red Armies, starting a new exercise, engaged today in preliminary skirmishing and reconnaissance under a blistering desert sun. The problem, which began at 6 A.M. and is scheduled for three days and nights, promises to be as great a test of endurance as of tactics.

TAMPA, Fla., Sept. 5 -- James Elliott Mooney, president of the University of Tampa, frequently called "the keynoter for defense education in Florida," has prepared a ten-point program for war emergency educational training at the college level.

Negro church and insurance leaders will open a ten-day drive this morning to collect 100,000 signatures from residents of Harlem to a petition to Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, asking that the OPA establish a Harlem rent ceiling based upon January, 1941, rates to halt rises which, they say, are working a severe hardship on tenants in the overcrowded section.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 5 -- Several hundred members of the Summer colony attended the final supper dance of the season held tonight in the Colonial Ballroom and Oriental Room of the Meadow Club for the benefit of the local service organization.

I am convinced that owners of evergreens do not take the matter of Fall Watering nearly seriously enough, especially if plants have been set out within the last couple of years. Last year we had a late ice storm here in Philadelphia which resulted in high rhododendron casualties in the gardens on both sides of mine.

HOLLYWOOD. JULIEN DUVIVER'S name looms large in Hollywood today. As the director of "Tales of Manhattan," boasting a screen play by ten top-notch writers and acted by nine stars and twenty-eight featured players, M. Duvivier has started a trend toward the episode narrative.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 5 -- Wilson H. (Bud) Madden, playing with John M. Lashar of the Brooklawn Country Club of Bridgeport, Conn., took medal honors in the member-guest tournament of the Huntington Crescent Club with a score of 35, 37 -- 72 today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Wickard announced today that President Roosevelt had authorized a Commodity Credit Corporation loan and purchase program for the 1942 crop of rice at 85 per cent of parity, with a record crop in sight. The loan rates for all varieties, grades and milling qualities of rice will average about $1.05 a bushel. The crop marketing year began on Aug. 1.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Private Barney Rossi of Brooklyn came out of the desert today after a battle in which United States armored forces whipped a German tank outfit and, with true Brooklyn spirit, had this to say:

PEARL HARBOR, Sept 2 (Delayed) -- Two Pacific Fleet airmen forced down far from their carrier in the South Pacific rigged a sail from a parachute -- using an aluminum paddle as a mast -- sailed in a tiny rubber life raft for twenty-three days and reached a tropical island, but one of the men was drowned in landing through the surf.

Fifteen Senators sought renomination this year. If we have counted straight, it has been denied to three. Of these Bulow of South Dakota is the senior in service. He was first elected in 1930 and was supposed to be a fixture. He was beaten in a thin vote by Tom Berry, twice Governor, once before a candidate for Senator, famous in his State as a cowboy, also a successful sulky-driver, a popular and salty character.

Advocating a reappraisal of the college curricula, Dr. Everett N. Case, newly elected president of Colgate University, urged yesterday that greater emphasis be placed on the social sciences in the liberal arts institutions. He held that it would be unfortunate to swing too far into the technical or vocational fields, although at the moment colleges must do everything possible to aid in winning the war.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- The second front in the air became a reality through last night and today as American, British and Russian bombers pounded Hitler-dominated centers of Europe from two sides, leaving destruction and blazing fires in their wake.

A visitor in New York recently, Bill Sharpe has evidently returned to his desk in Raleigh, N.C., for he has forwarded two accounts that will be of interest to hunters. The first of these discusses the Holly Shelter Wildlife area hunt, Pender County, in his State, which will have open days next month for some 600 hunters.

RUMSON, N.J., Sept. 5 -- The supper dance tonight at the Rumson Country Club and the annual husband-and-wife tennis tournament which began today at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club, feature the holiday week-end here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (U.P.) -- The Special Rubber Committee headed by Bernard M. Baruch will recommend to President Roosevelt government purchase of "extra" tires and automobiles, a thirty-five-mile-an-hour national speed limit and expansion of the synthetic rubber program, it was learned tonight.
EASTON, Pa., Sept. 5 -- Lafayette College will go on a war-footing next Tuesday when the 111th college year opens and the unique accelerated program goes into effect.

This column recently reported a method used by a Chicago club to assure its members a chance to play bridge for an hour, or even a shorter period, when they drop in on their way home from work. This is accomplished by playing groups of four hands, instead of playing rubbers.

Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has notified all issuing agents in this area qualified for the sale of United States war savings bonds, Series E, that the bank has received inquiries from certain agents concerning their responsibility as the result of the delivery of bonds by them against checks which subsequently were returned unpaid.

Charley Gibbons yielded only one hit and struck out eleven as the Streaks beat the Saxons by 5 -- 1 in seven innings, to win the 18-year-old division championship of the New York City Baseball Federation yesterday at Ebbets Field.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Men who can make greater contribution to the war effort by remaining in vital aircraft industries will not be permitted to enlist in the Army without clearance from their local Selective Service boards, Robert P. Patterson, War Undersecretary, has notified the aircraft war production council.

WELL toward the end of his book Mr. Reves begins one of his chapters by remarking, almost as an afterthought it sounds, "These pages do not contain one single new idea." But it is not an afterthought and there is no attempt here to be coy, as the reader will instantly know from the profound sincerity and straightforward movement of the argument up to this point.

AT AN AMERICAN AIRFIELD, Somewhere in the Middle East, Aug. 30 -- A tour of aviation centers that have become the responsibility of the United States Army Air Forces in this theatre reveals impressive activity. It is expected within a short period the strength of the American contingents will have grown to the point where they will prove an ever greater menace toward the enemy.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 5 -- Wedged between desert mesas and the positions of the British Eighth Army, General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel used emplaced anti-tank guns and other artillery yesterday in a strong bid for what he apparently con tinued to consider a valuable position. Since he had failed to catch the troops of the British Empire off base, Marshal Rommel had drawn back, with the German Africa Corps still an intact fighting force.

Southbound express traffic on the East Side and West Side branches of the IRT division of the city subway system was halted for twenty minutes yesterday by two separate incidents that delayed several thousands of persons.
Labor Day week-end crowds that thronged the midtown shopping district during the day converged on the Times Square section last night, jamming the sidewalks and overflowing into the street.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 5 -- The Cardinals won their second straight game from the Reds today, 3 to 2.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 5 (AP) -- Jersey City clinched a berth in the International League's Governors' Cup series today by staging a thrilling four-run rally in the ninth inning to defeat the Newark Bears, 9 to 8, in the opener of a five-game series.

The Waterman Steamship Corporation announced last week that it had sent a telegram to Lindsay C. Warren, United States Controller General, protesting against a report that Mr. Warren made to Congress criticizing the steamship company and the Maritime Commission for a ship deal.

Thirty-one new and revised courses directly related to the national war effort will be offered at Brooklyn College during the Fall and Spring semesters, Mario E. Cosenza, academic dean, announced yesterday.

Trades unionists of Soviet Russia have rejected the liaison arrangement proposed by William Green, president of the A.F. of L., and are asking for direct representation on the Anglo-American Trade Union Committee to collaborate on the war, according to advices received here yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 5 -- From the First Lady of the Land, Senhora Darcy Vargas, to the lowliest citizen, the women of Brazil have answered the war call of their nation and are organizing into groups for home defense.

" WE could lose this war," wrote the Office of War Information in a recent review of the war situation. "To win a total war we must fight it totally. * * * As a nation we are not yet more than ankle deep in the war."

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Renewal of acts of violence and terrorism by the Irish Republican Army in Northern Ireland is not to be taken too seriously. Against the background of the World War the sound of gun duels, bomb explosions and running fights between self-styled revolutionaries and the police is feeble. Even against the narrower background of Ireland itself the recent I.R.A. activities are relatively unimportant.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The Congress started out to give the soldier, the sailor, the Marine, the Waac and the Wave, too, assurance that he or she could have a true citizen's part in the selection and election of the new Congress in November.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- Newell Mecartney, a Chicago attorney, has been arrested on charges of seditious activities and sending obscene and libelous matter through the mail. J. Edgar Hoover, head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, came to Chicago to make the arrest.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Sept. 5 -- There is a great demand for electric flashlights today because the coming blackout will soon absorb all stocks. Electrical stores have sent rush orders to the wholesale houses and in the meantime prices of these articles have shot upward.
LONDON, Sept. 5 (U.P.) -- Advices from the Continent tonight reported new conscript labor in Norway, but Yugoslav patriots made new gains against Axis troops and burned crops destined for Germany.

Admiral Emery S. Land, chairman of the Maritime Commission and War Shipping Administrator, announced last week that the Government would establish another rest home for seamen as a part of its plan to assure the rehabilitation of men suffering from shock and exposure as a result of torpedoing.

THIELLS -- With the passing of hot weather, the Autumn hiker comes into his own. He is the chap who likes a touch of crispness in the atmosphere when he ascends the long, steep trails that crisscross the Harriman-Bear Mountain sections of the Palisades Interstate Park.

Fritzie Zivic will have the chance to prove that he is Freddie (Red) Cochrane's superior on Thursday night when the pair clash in a ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden. The clash will head a card arranged for the benefit of the USO and promises to attract a crowd of 12,000 fans.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 5 (U.P.) -- A report by the semi-official Chinese Central News Agency today said that at least 21,000 young Chinese men and women had been massacred by the retreating Japanese in Chekiang and Kiangsi Provinces.

A few words ought to be said at this time about the latest fashion in education: the Post-War Planning Courses. So far the war has left its imprint upon education in a series of shocks and nervous changes. With the help of the Army we discovered first that the basic education was not good enough.

The ash trees and the elms have begun to spill their weary leaves in the country driveways. Not many, yet; but a foretaste. They scuffle underfoot with a sound that is at once melancholy and exhilarating. And already there is a thinning at the treetops, new patches of blue sky to be seen, particularly among the maples, where gray squirrels make their morning pilgrimages.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 5 -- For the first time in many years Connecticut Democrats and Republicans will hold their biennial nominating conventions in the same city. The Republicans will meet here Sept. 10 and 11 and Democrats Sept. 15 and 16.

BOSTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Phil Marchildon won his sixteenth game today as the Athletics came from behind to beat the Red Sox, 4 to 3.

Anybody who is laying long plans to have a good wool coat or suit made up to last as long as the Nazi army does will find plenty of strong, beautiful wool fabrics in the stores right now. The new Fall things are in and there's an immense variety in styles and colors.

ALBANY, Sept. 5 (U.P.) -- A "tremendous" response in Albany County to calls for help in harvesting a bumper Hudson Valley apple crop was reported today by Farm Bureau agents striving to alleviate an acute farm labor shortage.

The recent survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES of the condition of the teaching of the history of the United States showed a situation which was a surprise to college faculties, however much it may have been realized by the historians. The moral was obvious: our youth need more knowledge of their own country, and that moral is as true in times of peace as it is in days of war.

WAYNE, Pa., Sept. 5 -- Geared to the pace and needs of a nation at war, Valley Forge Military Academy will open its doors to the largest student body in its history next Saturday when the first of 575 members of the cadet corps will appear for training in a setting immortalized by the hardy Continentals of George Washington.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5 -- William P. Deppe of New York, an inventor of combustion engines, was rebuked today by the Third Circuit Court of Appeals for casting aspersions on the integrity of Circuit Court Judge Joseph P. Buffington, retired, other members of that tribunal and Supreme Court Justice Owen J. Roberts.

The arrest of three men on charges that they acted as agents of the Japanese Government and the seizure of 142 aliens, among them twenty-two women, was announced here yesterday by P.E. Foxworth, in charge of the local offices of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

LONG before the war came to this country American scholars were on the alert with measures for the preservation of cultural and historical material. Aroused by the reports of wholesale destruction of archives in Europe, the American Council of Learned Societies initiated a plan for microfilming significant manuscript collections in Europe and Latin America.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Much Fall planting lies ahead. Preparation of soil now in areas to be planted several weeks hence offers three distinct advantages: saves time later on in the busy planting season; gets the ground into better condition by giving lime and plant foods a chance to become thoroughly incorporated with the soil; permits the newly dug ground to "settle" before planting.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- Quite apart from current price ceilings troubles, the meat packing industry is frankly worried over the details of the proposed rationing program for consumers. Unless very carefully administered, the packers foresee dickering without end and possibly a very appreciable diversion of sales which normally pass through retail butcher store channels.
DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 5 -- Danbury Expositions, Inc., 1942 version of what would have been the seventy-third annual Danbury Fair, will open here today and continue through next Saturday.

Slide Rule and Bold Irishman were the surprise winners yesterday at Aqueduct, where 25,246 persons saw the running of the Babylon Handicap and the Woodmere Stakes. Slide Rule, a W.E. Boeing color-bearer, had been rather in eclipse because of his more famous stable-mate, Devil's Thumb.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 5 -- The Maidstone Club's only dance this season, a "Furlough Carnival," took place tonight at the Tennis House on Maidstone Lane. Many dinner parties preceded the dance.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 5 -Every player on both the Yale varsity and junior varsity football squads, including freshmen for the first time, is either a member of the Army, the Navy or Marine Reserves or has already applied for admission into some branch of armed service, according to a check just finished by the bureau of military information of the university.

I can sympathize with Congressman Sasscer, who was quoted recently in THE TIMES as complaining that he'd have a "hell of a time" singing "The Star-Spangled Banner" if and when members of Congress try to struggle through it on a world-wide radio hookup Sept. 13.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Appointment of an over-all food director independent of existing governmental agencies and with authority to enforce his mandates, is being urged upon the Administration by branches of the food industry, it was learned today.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 5 -- In an effort to learn the practical workings of American politics, 140 Williams College students will soon spend a week-end at home discovering just how the voters are reacting to the record of their Congress members and whether or not they stand a good chance of being re-elected.

Individuals are prohibited from mailing printed matter to European neutral countries, under an order issued yesterday by Postmaster Albert Goldman. The only persons authorized to send such matter, the postmaster said, are publishers or registered news agents, firms or organizations for which the material is printed or the publisher's distributing agency.

THE Promenade season has added two symphonies to its record of novelties -- Benjamin Britten's "Sinfonia da Requiem" and Alan Bush's Symphony in C. Both works have been suggested by contemporary events; neither seemed quite true to its subject.

FAR out on the Pacific Ocean the shot-torn remains of a Navy patrol plane crashed into the sea, while a triumphant Japanese formation wheeled off in search of other prey. Thousands of miles away in a Norfolk, Va., Navy housing unit a young woman, the mother of three children, read that her husband had been a member of the plane's crew.

In three years of war prices of commodities generally have followed a course similar to that in other international conflicts over the last 150 years. Although prices of important farm products generally are twice those at the beginning of hostilities, they are considerably below the peaks reached in the World War and the period immediately following.

THE happy news this morning is that soap operas aren't the only staple in the daytime radio diet of the ladies of New York, New Jersey and adjacent points. This is a pretty sensational statement, all right, but there seems to be some evidence.

FROM Mexico City, where the Ballet Theatre has been in residence since May, comes word of its final series of performances there before its return to New York for the October season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, was reported authoritatively today to have left to Army and Navy chiefs the final decision on Henry J. Kaiser's proposal to construct a fleet of cargo planes.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- At this time of year there is a stretch of Pennsylvania -- the eastern strip bordered by the Delaware River -- that brushes the haze of late Summer from its eyes and turns an eager face to Autumn.

A pointed word to American troops to "come on over here" to strike at Nazi-held Europe was heard, apparently from a United States Ranger who said he was from Jacksonville, Miss., in a prisoner-of-war broadcast over the Berlin radio last night.

POTSDAM, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- The teacher shortage in Northern New York is expected to result in the closing of several one-room school houses in remote rural districts, a survey of northern teacher colleges, district school superintendents and other educational institutions and educators shows.

FOUR hundred years before Christ, at the siege of Plataea, the Spartans used gas against the Athenians. They saturated wood with pitch and sulphur and burned it under the walls of the city to help in subduing the defenders.

SOME quickening of demand for women's apparel came along before the holiday week-end and retailers felt that this might lead to the increased activity to which they are looking for the Fall season. Home furnishing lines were still very quiet and men's wear clearances met with indifferent results.

IN its setting, modern Mexico, Baker's second novel is like her first, "A Sombrero for Miss Brown" Like it, too, this one is lively in its appreciation of the delightful country, the proud people and their vivid language and customs.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 5 -- Mrs. W.R. Flemming's mare Loveday, who is noted for late rushes, gave an exhibition of her specialty today as she came from far back to win the $5,000 added Mary Dyer Handicap at Narragansett Park before 25,000 spectators.

NORWAY fights on, at home against the invader by underground means and abroad openly through its official government, its seamen, fliers, soldiers and sailors. Keynote's new album is a tribute to the Fighting Men of Norway, containing half a dozen Songs of Norwegian Freedom (No. 114, three 10-inch records).

MANAGERS of the country's major symphony orchestras will hold their annual meeting this Wednesday and Thursday in Cleveland, that city having been chosen to honor the Cleveland Orchestra's forthcoming twenty-fifth anniversary season.

Both houses of Congress have now passed bills reinforcing provisions made by most of the States to insure that citizens shall not lose the right to vote because they are enrolled in the armed forces. The Senate went further than the House in stipulating that soldiers should not be deprived of the franchise in Federal elections because of their failure to pay their poll taxes.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- President Roosevelt today appointed H.B. Horton, treasurer of the Chicago Bridge and Iron Corporation, to the War Labor Board as an employer member.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- In a German attack, designed to coincide with the attempt to neutralize Russia by crashing through to Stalingrad at any cost, General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel is initiating his long expected move toward Alexandria and Cairo.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- The Larchmont Yacht Club's special regatta today, which opened the Labor Day week-end sessions, drew seventy-three starters to the Long Island Sound courses, and the sailing craft had fine, steady going around their varied triangles.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Sept. 5 -- In the light of the full harvest moon the second in the series of "Moonlight Serenades" will be given here on Sept. 19 at Claremont, the estate of Prince George Chavchavadze, Russian pianist. The proceeds of the concert, for which Prince Chavchavadze is in charge of all musical arrangements, will be donated to the Musicians Emergency Fund for their work in engaging musicians for Army and Navy concerts.

Whimsical apartment gardeners, as well as those willing to attempt growing horticultural oddities, may well acquaint themselves with the insectivorous, bug-catching Venus Flytrap. This plant is mentioned in literature often enough, but is grown by comparatively few gardeners.

CERTAIN good omens emerge from advance matter concerned with the New Opera Company's plans for its second season. One is that subscriptions for this second season, with the opening two months away, already total more than the company had in its coffers when it opened its doors for its first experience of trial, error and significant accomplishment last season.
On battlefields almost 3,000 miles apart the Wehrmacht last week pressed its pincers drive for conquest of the Middle East, one of the war's key theatres.

The Navy announced yesterday the sinking of a medium-sized British merchant vessel by a submarine that torpedoed it in the Caribbean area about the middle of last month. This brought to 456 the unofficial Associated Press total of United Nations' vessels announced sunk since Pearl Harbor.

MOSCOW, Sept. 5 -- On Dec. 4, 1941, the mercury in Russian thermometers dropped the equivalent of 20 degrees Fahrenheit. In the Smolensk railroad station seventy-three powerful locomotives refused to budge. Along the highways heading toward Moscow tanks and trucks were stuck as fast as if a giant thumb had pressed them into the ground and held them there so firmly that they lost the power to squirm and struggle.

LONDON, Sept. 5 (Canadian Press) -- Aston Villa and Derby County, who returned to league football last week for the first time since the start of the war, scored their second straight victories in Northern Section matches today.

Herman Steiner of Los Angeles, who shared first place with Abe Yanofsky of Winnipeg in the open chess championship at Dallas, was the only tourney player to win a game from I.A. Horowitz of New York, Empire State title-holder. Steiner and J.C. Thompson of Dallas, who drew with Horowitz, were responsible for the failure of the New Yorker to finish at the top in the annual competition of the United States Chess Federation.

HUGHIE CALL was a Texas girl who married a young Montana sheepman and went to his ranch as a bride. Now she can look back on twenty-five years or so of ranch life with mature perspective. Looking back, she finds it good, and she sets down her memories and her findings in a thoroughly readable book that is local history as well as autobiography.

A WHITE-HAIRED major general stood by a railroad siding, a quarter of a century ago this month, amid the sand, scrub oak and pine of Camp Upton, L.I. The United States had been in World War I a little more than five months. A train drew in, and out of it poured men whose faces reflected every national and racial strain in Europe.

Photography of the human emotions has never been given due consideration by the average amateur. It seems a bit paradoxical, for photography of the human species is perhaps more practiced than any other branch of the art of "painting with light."

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Sept. 5 -- Coves and valleys of this region are sending their sons in over-enlistment of a call for 160 seamen to replace the crew of the Asheville, 1,270-ton gunboat sunk by enemy action in March in the Java Sea.

Senator Robert F. Wagner, in a Labor Day address broadcast last night over a coast-to-coast network of the National Broadcasting Company, called for a greater recognition of labor in the policies of the War Production Board and for stabilization of wages, farm prices and the cost of living as steps toward victory in the war.

ALAN DEVOE, author of "Phudd Hill" and "Down to Earth," has written in "Lives Around Us" another book of nature studies of the same distinguished quality, in which scientific fact and keen observation of the living subject are conveyed through the medium of a style of great clarity, beauty and perception.

The bride is waiting at the church, and so is the bridegroom, who happens to be our old friend, Quinny Hite. But the best man is missing, and he has the license. That is all there is about the wedding. After that, Quinny starts for New York via the Staten Island ferry, falls overboard and wakes up in Chinatown just in time to be in at the beginning of a murder investigation.

WHAT used to be chiefly a circus stunt has today become standard practice for those who travel or fight in the air. Moreover, it is interesting to note from Dr. Zim's book that parachute jumpers from carnivals and circuses have made some extremely valuable contributions to the development of the science.

One commodity which war consumes rapidly is time. We are in the fourth year of a war that was let loose by Hitler in expectation of a traditional old German six-week victory. What is even more impressive, day after tomorrow will be nine months since Pearl Harbor.

RED CROSS libraries, consisting of books contributed to soldiers by people who want to make some slight return for what the soldiers are doing for them, help mitigate the rigors of Army life and especially of Army hospital life.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The War Labor Board said today that it would not consider the merits of a dispute involving the Post Cereal Products Company of Battle Creek, Mich., and the United Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employes of America, C.I.O., "as long as the strike continues."

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Fighting French headquarters here today, describing shocking scenes that marked the Nazi-inspired brutal round-up of Jews in Paris on July 14, declared Pierre Laval's anti-Semitic measures in unoccupied France had aroused violent opposition to his regime.

THE thousands of airplane spotters throughout the country, who for months now have maintained a lonely vigil on mountain tops lest an enemy aircraft pay a surprise visit, are finally coming in for some deserved recognition from the Army and radio.

" SPACE, TIME AND ARCHITECTURE," by Sigfried Giedion, the Swiss savant, was the result of his lectures as the Charles Eliot Norton Professor at Harvard. It is in summation an effort at leveling the effects of the inequalities of conflicting, contradictory tendencies that bewilder and confuse many people today who see only the apparent chaos around them, but Dr. Giedion believes there is a secret synthesis in our present civilization.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 5 -- An income tax, a real estate tax and increased customs duties have been proposed by the Finance Committee of the Assembly of Bermuda to meet a "serious diminution" of revenues derived from customs duties because of a heavy reduction in imports.

Despite efforts to bring war work here, New York City faces the immediate prospect of an increase in unemployment far beyond the present figure of 400,000, Dr. Meredith B. Givens, director of research and statistics of the division of placement unemployment insurance, New York State Department of Labor, predicted yesterday.

WITH the end of the vacation season, various responsibilities again close in on the distaff side of the family. Long shopping tours are involved in equipping young hopefuls for school. Summer paraphernalia must be stowed away and the domestic scene set for Winter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- A stiff revamping of the Selective Service procedure ordered earlier this week, and already under way in New York and some other States, emphasizes more strongly than ever the fact that Selective Service exerts a vital force not only on the war program but on the entire social and economic life of the nation.

The address made by Bishop Miguel de Andrea at the Chicago meeting of the Inter-American Seminar was as notable for its content as for the fact that the Bishop spoke as a distinguished and influential citizen of Argentina, the director of the Catholic Workers Center of Buenos Aires.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Plans of the Army and Navy to transport complete hospitals as well as all badly wounded men by air were described to the Aero Medical Association today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The United States prepared to ration meat to its citizens this week despite the assurance of the greatest production of the rationed items in the history of the country.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 5 -- Her conquests in the South Pacific area have failed to prove a treasure trove for Japan, writes Kung Teh-po, authority on Japanese affairs, in a recent issue of the Japan Review, a Chinese magazine published here.
WAYNESBORO, Va. -- Snappy Autumn nights are just around the corner and with their approach, heralding as they do the icy blasts of Winter, the fuel problem becomes more and more important.

YOU can take David Ormsbee's "The Sound of an American" in either of two ways, that of the corrupt and muddled death of the Third French Republic or as a pretty stark love story set against an impossible background, and from both attitudes you will fine plenty to arouse emotion and almost angry skepticism concerning this best of all possible worlds.

DAWN POWELL'S new book maintains and probably tops her record for writing very enjoyable books about very disagreeable people. Her wit is sharp, shrewd and biting, and it finds a pretty mark in the stuffed shirts, male and female, of "A Time to Be Born."
BOSTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- A ring dealing in stolen gasoline ration books in three Southern New England States has been broken, the OPA reported today in announcing more than fifty arrests.

BUFFALO, Sept. 5 -- American chemists mobilized for war will gather at Buffalo next week for the 104th meeting of the American Chemical Society. More than 4,000 chemists and industrialists will attend sessions of the eighteen professional divisions of the society, at which about 400 scientific papers will be read, dealing with results of the war work of chemists at university and industrial laboratories.

TUNING to Japan's feeble morning waves in the hope of finding out how the Mikado's world megaphone explains Nipponese thrashings in the Solomon Islands and at Milne Bay, one is surprised to hear that "American and combined Allied forces in the Southwest Pacific have met with a calamitous defeat at the hands of the mighty Japanese Navy!"

" WHEN you refer to the 'Annals' in the paper could you possibly avoid calling them monumental?" The professor made the request with an exaggerated testiness. "It's not pleasant when you've lived with a work most of your life, to have it described by a word that suggests a mausoleum."

A FEW years ago this book would have had but a cold reception from those who believe, with more sincerity than realism, that toy soldiers could have only a brualizing effect upon the young. If now it finds a deserved welcome, it should be not only because of its timeliness but because of its broader theme of steadfast courage, responsibility and sacrifice.

In line with its wartime efforts to train students in practical skills as well as to promote general morale, the Hunter College evening and extension division will offer in the Fall semester an enlarged program of courses directly related to the war, Professor Broderick Cohen, director of the division, announced yesterday.

The most exciting phase of home decoration at present is the cheerful task of making the most of what one has. Budget or no budget, practically all home decorators are in the same boat. Some things -- and their number is increasing -- are just not obtainable.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 5 -- Georgia will go to the primary polls next Wednesday after one of the longest and bitterest Gubernatorial campaigns in many years. The outcome of the struggle for the Democratic nomination will have a widespread effect in the South.

British stay-at-home people have learned a good deal this year -- more, I think, than in the earlier years of the war. We are confident of victory, but not yet, and not until we have made an immense effort, we and all the United Nations.

The Whitelaw Reid mansion at 451 Madison Avenue will be the setting on the night of Sept. 26 for the second Junior Officers Ball, patterned after the fete given there on June 6. The first dance was considered by its sponsoring group to be such a success that the decision was made to arrange a similar party.

Six thousand tons of steel rail, left imbedded in the city streets through abandonment of trolley lines, are being reclaimed by the War Production Board to augment the transportation facilities of Army and Navy establishments and industrial plants engaged in war work, it was revealed yesterday.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 5 -- Packed with more controversy than almost any other issue of the war is the question whether to draft 18 and 19-year old youths into the armed forces.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- American public and private schools have done an excellent job of informing their students about service opportunities open to them in the armed forces, according to Frederic A. Wyatt, director of admissions in Union College, who this week was called to duty as a lieutenant in the Naval Reserve.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- More than 5,000 tons of pure tin and 495,000 tons of steel vitally needed for the war effort will be recovered annually from tin cans by July 1 if American housewives and local collection agencies cooperate as they are expected to in the can salvage program, the War Production Board said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- About 100,000 domestic mechanical refrigerators which have been frozen in the hands of dealers and distributors since Feb. 14 were released-today or will be released in the next week by the War Production Board for sale to the general public, that agency announced today.

MOSCOW, Sept. 5 -- The battle for Stalingrad is violent everywhere, but the quintessence of violence has its fulcrum at a railroad station southwest of the city, where a furious and bitterly contested battle now is in its third day.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 5 -- C.I.O. aluminum workers at New Kensington voted today to give the Aluminum Company of America "until Sept. 15" to resume negotiations on wage increases denied by the War Labor Board.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- In a few days Parliament will reassemble after its long Summer holiday. Historic events have taken place since the members went on their holiday. Among them are the arrest of Congress leaders in India, changes in the High Command in Egypt and above all, Prime Minister Churchill's visit to Moscow.

BOSTON, Sept. 5 -- Eight months after Pearl Harbor, Boston University has contributed more to the nation's war effort than during most of the last war, a comparative survey of the contributions by students, faculty and organizations of both war classes revealed today.

Private gardens forming a mid-Manhattan rustic retreat, once part of a sixty-acre tract settled in 1677 and called Turtle Bay because of the peculiar rocky formation of its East River boundary, will be opened on the afternoon and evening of Sept. 15 for the Turtle Bay Garden Party and Street Fair, an elaborately designed fete arranged by the British War Relief Society to raise funds for British seamen in this country.

THERE are still some competent critics who have little use for detective fiction. Howard Spring, for instance, has lately made it known that he is not "much of a one" for detective stories. The horrible creaking of a machine, he says, goes all through them, for the one objective is "Who killed -- ?

CORTLAND, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, in a speech here this afternoon at the Cortland County Fair, paid tribute to farm youngsters throughout the State and country who are working at top speed to produce food for wartime needs.

Assumption of complete control over the flow of vital materials for the war program by the War Production Board this week will mark the first time that control of raw materials has received a chance to work, according to opinions expressed last week by business executives in close touch with the war effort.

The article by Sir Stafford Cripps in the Sunday Magazine starts from the implied premise, with which every one who wishes the defeat of the Axis will agree, that the primary need of the present hour is to achieve maximum unity among the United Nations in the fight for freedom.

HOLLYWOOD. HOLLYWOOD and Los Angeles were clusters of brilliant light spread far beneath the lonely house perched upon the side of the mountain. Encino and San Fernando paled into the distance. In the vast room the heavy man waddled to the cavernous easy chair and carefully lowered his 280 pounds into it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. -- In this grinding hub of the nation's mighty war effort we are hearing some ominous soundings. And if there is one thing the civilian population already has learned from the war it is that if you hear an ominous sounding it is always best to give heed and consider yourself forewarned.

IT is a common assumption that the "only" child is apt to be a selfish and unsocial brat, handicapped by his solitary status and by too much parental coddling, as the child with brothers and sisters is not. And there is nothing whatever in this idea, judging by the evidence of several studies.

The twentieth annual women's New Jersey State golf championship will be held over the Upper Montclair course from Sept. 14 through Sept. 18, in competition for the crown held by Mrs. Charles Whitehead of Plainfield since 1940.

On Friday afternoon the Plaza Art Galleries, Inc., will sell at auction eighteenth and early nineteenth century furniture, comprising the collection of Katharine Hartshorne of this city, a member of the American Institute of Decorators.
Close to three hundred new names have been added to the Metropolitan Golf Association's handicap list which was released yesterday.

HAVANA, Sept. 5 -- A Nazi agent engaged in transmitting information by radio concerning the entry and departure of vessels at the port of Havana has been arrested, Captain Mariano Faget of the national police said this afternoon. Police seized a short-wave radio transmitter and receiving set, and a mass of compromising documents in possession of the agent.

NARRAGANSETT, R.I., Sept. 5 -- Mrs. Joseph Warren Greene Jr. gave a dinner and small dance tonight at the Dunes Club for her daughter, Miss Edith Noyes Knight. Among the young people attending the party were Mr. and Mrs. Curtis Knight, the Misses Constance Knight, Barbara Rutherford, Margaret Campbell, Jane Campbell, Sophia Hazard, Mary Peace Hazard, Deborah Hunt, Avery Rogers, Patricia Champlin and Gaff Dawley.

The proposed excise tax submitted on behalf of the Treasury Department to the Senate Finance Committee last Thursday is probably as complex and severe a tax measure as was ever devised for the Federal government. It is a combination income-spending-enforced saving - sales - withholding tax. In effect, however, the main measure of the tax would be the taxpayer's personal, family and household expenses.

Although there were few buyers in the wholesale market last week, business generally was active and mail orders were heavy in many lines, according to the report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

The efforts of a sympathetic American Government to make Chinese seamen welcome and happy in the port of New York have brought giddy days of freedom to the philosophical Chinese seaman and acute headaches to government shipping officials and the shipping industry.

The mystery shrouding the existence of William Shakespeare was believed to be nearer solution with the announcement yesterday that a signature, ascribed to the Bard, had been discovered on the title page of a book of Anglo-Saxon laws printed in 1568.

Achievement of world unity in the post-war period by overcoming linguistic, political and geographic barriers will be studied in four free extension courses for adults to be given during the Fall and Winter by the Cooper Union Division of Social Philosophy, it is announced by Dr. Houston Peterson, head of the division.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (U.P.) -- The executive committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association today recommended that all rules governing intercollegiate sports be frozen for the duration of the war.

Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, will be the speaker at the world trade dinner, a feature of the twenty-ninth National Foreign Trade Convention, to be held in Boston, Oct. 7, 8 and 9, it was announced yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council, sponsors of the meeting.

In the face of considerable decreases in the number of prints entered in salons throughout the country, an actual increase of 25 per cent over last year's total is reported for the Champlain Valley International Exhibition, judged at Burlington, Vt., recently by J. Ghislain Lootens, F.R.P.S., F.P.S.A., of New York.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The left side of the Tigers' infield -- Third Baseman Pinky Higgins and Rookie Shortstop Johnny Lipon -- supplied five hits tonight to back Paul (Dizzy) Trout's four-hit pitching for a 4-2 victory over the White Sox.

Net earnings of Burroughs Adding Machine Company for the first half of 1942 were $1,600,445, equivalent to 32 cents a share for 5,000,000 shares of stock, including profits made by the parent company on sales of foreign subsidiaries and $90,523 received as dividends from subsidiaries abroad.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 5 -- Its curriculum adapted to meet special wartime needs, the postgraduate course for practitioners will be conducted by the School of Medicine of the University of Buffalo Sept. 21 to 26.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 5 -- Many important Indians with whom the writer has talked since his recent arrival in this country have expressed a desire that Washington intervene diplomatically or arbitrate to settle the deadlock between the government and Indian elements belonging to the All-India Congress or sympathetic to Congress aims.

Ted Schroeder and Frank Parker and Miss Louise Brough and Miss Pauline Betz, all of California, came through as expected to the final round of the national tennis championship singles yesterday at Forest Hills.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 5 -- A large decrease in the number of retail and artisan shops is reported today from Germany, where 65,200 shops, or roughly 8 per cent of the total number, have closed since the beginning of the war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (Science Service) -- A real plane performing acrobatics in the air such as occur in combat is fired at with real shells, that explode too, but don't worry, no one is hurt.
ALBANY, Sept. 5 -- President Roosevelt commended the white collar workers today for their contribution to the war effort.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 5 -- An undergraduate department of religion will be established in the liberal arts college of Drake University with the opening of the Fall term, Sept. 14, Dean Luther W. Stalnaker has announced.

DENVER, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Like any well-trained military force after an initial setback, the Western Army All-Stars today shook up their attack for their football encounter with the Chicago Cardinals tomorrow.

According to a Berlin broadcast that was recorded by The Asso ciated Press, the German High Command said yesterday that the commander of the Sixth New Zealand Brigade had been captured on the Egyptian front, along with several hundred other soldiers; that several armor-supported British attacks on the southern end of the line had failed and that a British destroyer had been hit by a torpedo from a German submarine in the eastern Mediterranean.

Civilian laborers are urgently needed in Hawaii, the United States Civil Service Commission announced yesterday. Interviews of applicants will be conducted from tomorrow through Friday in Room 915, Federal Building, 641 Washington Street, from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.

The New York Football Giants have lost only one All-Star game in the history of the club, but the most formidable array of selected talent they ever have faced will oppose them at the Polo Grounds on Saturday at 2:15 P.M. for the joint benefit of Army Emergency Relief and the Tribune Fresh Air Fund.

THIS book carries on the story of the gay crowd of high school graduates who were so intent on finding their futures in "Success in Reserve." So varied are their personalities that a whole series seems indicated, but this time it is Laura Lou, who bloomed out of shyness and obscurity into popularity, who takes the spotlight.

LOS ANGELES, Sept 5 (Netherlands News Agency) -- Eight months after the invasion of the Netherlands Indies Japan has made virtually no progress in winning the cooperation of the 70,000,000 inhabitants of the archipelago, and because of her harsh colonial policy will never be able to get the natives to accept her regime, according to Dr. F.H. Visman, former member of the Netherlands Indies Council.

"That's the most fascinating stuff I've ever read," she told the woman professor who had put it into her hands. The book was rather formidably entitled "Physiological Chemistry."

OGUNQUIT, Me. -- Though Indian Summer is just around the corner and frost will soon be on the pumpkin. Maine is eating strawberries these days. For the second local crop is on wayside stands and travelers take their pick of the luscious fruit, eating the berries as they are or carrying them away to be consumed later with sugar and cream.

Speedboat racing's black and white finish flag, which has appeared only infrequently this wartime season, and then at merely local events, will be taken out of the moth balls next Sunday at New Martinsville, W. Va., for what is undoubtedly the banner event of the Summer.

Off to a fine start in its engagement at Madison Square Garden, Ice Capades of 1943 will present the first of three Sunday matinee programs this afternoon. The colorful skating extravaganza, which will close its run at the Eighth Avenue arena on Sept. 20 will be presented nightly with the exception of Thursday, when the Garden will be the scene of the Freddie (Red) Cochrane-Fritzie Zivic fight for the benefit of USO.

A rally for the New York Victory Garden Harvest Show will be held on Wednesday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The show is to take place on Sept. 21, 22 and 23 at Grand Central Palace and the proceeds will be for the benefit of the armed forces.

The situation behind the two new Argentine stamps on a cover received in New York last week from Buenos Aires is one which involved the national pride of the Argentine people. The people had long been expressing ire because, in the numerical order of the denominations in the republic's 1935-39 series, a likeness of a bull, symbolizing cattle-breeding, is on a stamp between two stamps bearing portraits of noted Argentines.

The tiny Spleenworts are coveted but are not too easy for the amateur gardener to establish. Rusty Woodsia (Woodsia ilvensis), so called because of the rusty scales on the underside of the fronds, is far easier, thriving in sunny crevices.
