IN a symposium such as this little book presents one does not look for unity. Though the volume has an introduction by the Commissioner of Indian Affairs, and three-fourths of it is written by men employed at the present or within the past ten years by the Indian Bureau, still there are distinct divergences in the attitude toward Indian problems and in the suggested solutions.

SIR PATRICK HASTINGS is one of the most successful lawyers now alive in Britain. The fees he earns are so high that he probably is not allowed by the government to keep more than a fortnight's earnings each year for spending money, with the income tax at its wartime level.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Sept. 5 -- A certain highly placed American Army officer received a telegram the other day from an Australian veteran of the last war who is now operating what the Australians, true to the British fashion, always call a "lift" in an office building in one of the large Australian cities.
CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Eddie (Rochester) Anderson's Burnt Cork, a 2-year-old son of Mr. Bones, and Hyman Friedberg's Montsin shared honors before 25,000 at Washington Park today.

" YANKEE, DOODLE WENT TO TOWN," was the compliment paid by Air Marshal Sir Arthur T. Harris when Brig. Gen. Ira C. Eaker, commanding the United States bombers here, accompanied the first all-American bomber attack on occupied France in the plane with that name.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- On the eve of the plowing campaign this week the British Government announced lighting regulations for farms. The move was necessary as the program for a record production of wheat in 1943 entails extensive night work by British agriculture for the next eight weeks.
EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Sept. 5 -- Wheatley Hills members who picked Cherry Valley golfers for partners in the club's annual member-guest tournament, which began here today, made wise decisions.

WINE HARBOUR, the scene of Naomi Lane Babson's new novel, "Look Down From Heaven," bears a very strong resemblance to Rockport, Mass. A New England town on the seacoast, it has a number of native-born inhabitants who live there all the year round, city people with Summer homes on the Headlands and a quarry worked almost entirely by laborers from across the ocean, principally Finns.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., Sept. 5 -- In the words of President John J. Tigert, "the University of Florida has enlisted for the duration."

Problems of business and accounting which have their origins in the war emergency will be the principal topics at the fifty-fifth annual meeting of the American Institute of Accountants which will be held Sept. 28 to Oct. 1 at the Palmer House in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- The Port of New York Authority, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, the Shippers Conference of Greater New York, the Chamber of Commerce of Newark, the New Jersey Industrial Traffic League, the New England Traffic League, the Boston Port Authority and others, asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for a further hearing in proceedings involving increases in ocean-rail rates to the Southwest.

Business was generally good last week, with main floors and basements busy in the three major markets, New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 5 -- The United States will emerge from World War II with a school program more nearly adapted to "the practical and current life of the students," in the opinion of Dr. W.W. Charters, who retires Monday after fourteen years as director of Ohio State University's Bureau of Educational Research.

ONLY last Sunday this column was sounding a verbal alert on the pending approach of new pictures which would show the war in realistic terms. That was two-thirds wishful thinking and one-third foreknowledge of events, for, in the past week, two pictures have obligingly come along which meet on all counts the specifications solemnly laid down last week.

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 5 (UP) -- Rear Admiral Percy W. Foote, material procurement officer for the Navy in this area, estimated today that the United States must provide 10,000,000 fighting men -- and that half of them would be casualties.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Our war leaders have been more bearish about the United Nations' shipping problem than any other phase of the fighting effort, so the view of Secretary Knox expressed this week that the submarine menace "should not interfere with victory in the war" means, it is hoped, that we have turned the dark corner in the vexing problem of putting a ceiling on sinkings.

DACEY HAMILTON, aged 27, the mother of five children, came into the city room of a New York newspaper as the bells were ringing in the year 1918 and asked Urian Oakes, the reporter on duty, for a job. This is how Dorothy Van Doren's new novel, "Dacey Hamilton," begins, and offhand you'd say it doesn't make sense, that nobody applies for a job, even on a newspaper, at that strange hour of the night.

Scientists in general and physicians in particular will be disturbed by the correspondence which has passed between the postal censor and Dr. J. McKeen Cattell, editor of Science, and which appears in the current issue of that journal. That censorship in war is necessary no one will deny.

With the approach of Labor Day, retail trade in the New York area improved somewhat last week. Comparisons were with the five- day Labor Day week last year, making the percentage figures more favorable.

The large lecture hall in a Midlands factory is filled with an alert, intent audience. An American lecturer has just finished an hour-long discourse. From his seat on the platform the Mayor, his gold chain adorning his neck, rises to announce that Alderman Soandso will move the vote of thanks.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Americans will have as much or more meat, per person, under proposed government rationing than they had through most of the depression, but not as much as during the last war. This was shown to day by an analysis of meat trade statistics.

Unsettled by the report that President Roosevelt will ask for ceilings on farm products at "existing levels" the cotton market fluctuated nervously again yesterday, moving between losses of 25 points and gains of 8 points. Closing prices for active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 5 to 12 points below Friday's final quotations. Opening prices had been down 10 to 19 points.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5 -- The fully equipped newspaper plant of the bankrupt Evening Public Ledger, capable of printing 132,000 thirty-two page papers an hour, will go on the auction block in a trustees' sale on Sept. 15, 16 and 17.

MR. ANDERSON calls this new book about horses an ABC of thoroughbreds, and if the subject seems a little remote from today's most pressing matters, one has only to look at the record of the Russian cavalry, as he points out in his preface, to realize its importance in war as well as peace.

Free French Syria's new definitives for regular and air-mail postage reached New York last week. Instead of "Syrie" or "Republique Syrienne" being inscribed, the word "Levant" is used, this title dating from the seventeenth century.
CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 5 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command said today that severe fighting continued in the outskirts of Kinhwa and near-by Lanchi "with the Chinese steadily gaining the upper hand."
In the grand manner yesterday, Babe Young took care of the Brooklyn situation at the Polo Grounds.

Railway shares led the market on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and prices closed firmer in dull trading. The turnover on the Exchange was 145,270 shares, which was larger than at the preceding week-end, despite the absence of many traders for the holidays. Of the 416 issues traded, 170 rose, 88 fell and 158 were unchanged.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 5 -- The equipping of Mexico's first motorized division was completed today when General Salvador Sanchez, chief of the Presidential General Staff, received a large number of jeeps delivered to him by Tom L. Johnson.

THIS is War! Next to war the second largest industry in the country today is viewing with alarm. Prognosticators are on the wing. The economist looks up from his crystal ball and the politician peeks out from behind the eight ball to warn us that the offing is fraught with plight.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 5 -- Zaca Gray, a 3-year-old filly who races in the colors of Mrs. Anthony Pelleteri of New Orleans, scored a front-running victory in the six-furlong Colonial Handicap over the favored Level Best, champion filly of last season, at Garden State Park today. Taunt, shipped here from New York, was third.

The 1,148 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $65,276,941,820 par value as of Aug. 31, had a total market value of $62,720,371,752, according to a compilation by the Exchange issue yesterday. As of July 31 there were 1,150 issues, aggregating $63,992,198,940 par value, which had a total market value of $61,277,620,583.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- President Roosevelt declared today that the Federal service was facing "its severest test," and he expressed his confidence that the employes would make the most of their opportunities for distinguished patriotic service.

MARJORIE LAWRENCE, who has been absent from the concert and operatic field since a year ago June, when she was paralyzed from a vaccination, has recovered sufficiently to make her first public reappearance, Sept 24, at the moonlight musicale at Gulestan, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Leeds Stillman, in Plainfield, N.J. Prince George Chavchavadze, Russian pianist, will appear joinly with Miss Lawrence.

MARJORIE LAWRENCE, who has been absent from the concert and operatic field since a year ago June, when she was paralyzed from a vaccination, has recovered sufficiently to make her first public reappearance, Sept 24, at the moonlight musicale at Gulestan, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Leeds Stillman, in Plainfield, N.J. Prince George Chavchavadze, Russian pianist, will appear joinly with Miss Lawrence.
I read with great amazement the letter of D. Dem Dimanescu in a recent issue of THE TIMES under the title "Magyars Seek a Leader."
The dauntless spirit of British women today is strikingly revealed in this letter from my friend Mrs. Findlay, wife of the late Colonel Findlay of the "Buffs." She writes from Canterbury:

SEATTLE, Wash., Sept. 5 -- An educational program, born of necessity during the first World War and carefully nurtured through the lean years of the depression, today is the basis for the accelerated services of the University of Washington in the second world conflict.

ONE cheerful comment on soldiers' reading by Margaret Farrand Thorp in the article that begins just next door to this column is that soldiers frequently ask for "a good love story" but that the love story is often wanted not for relaxation but as a guide to conduct.

More than 1,000,000 Russian troops, aided by thousands of civilian volunteers, are defending Stalingrad with a bitterness unmatched in this war, German news dispatches declared yesterday, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

One of the first protests voiced locally by organized labor against the plan to freeze pay scales which President Roosevelt is expected to announce tomorrow was registered yesterday by the International Ladies' Handbag, Luggage, Belt and Novelty Workers Union (A.F. L.) in a telegram to President Roosevelt_ The telegram, signed by Samuel Reinlib, president of the union, read:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 (AP) -- Sociologists are expressing apprehension today lest the country cut too deeply into the undeveloped manpower reserves intended for tomorrow.

Samuel E. Runganadhan, one of the three advisers to the British Secretary of State for India, with headquarters in London, arrived yesterday aboard an American Export Airlines Flying Ace at La Guardia Airport, and declined to comment on the Indian situation because it was "highly complicated, involving many issues and currently exercising many minds."

It would seem that many persons will find themselves in a reminiscent mood today. Stayers-in-town, either voluntarily in response to the Mayor's plea or perforce for lack of "gas" coupons, will recall how they used to spend the long week-end in a far-flung vacation spot.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices decreased from 107.4 to 107.2. This decrease was caused mainly by changes in agricultural products. The continued rise in the price of eggs was more than offset by decreases in livestock, potatoes and fruit, causing the farm products, foodstuffs and raw materials groups to decrease slightly.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Allied ground and air forces continued to smash yesterday at Japanese units in the Kokoda area of Southeastern New Guinea, where the enemy has been attempting to push through a pass in the Owen Stanley Mountain range toward the important Allied base at Port Moresby, sixty miles to the west, a communique said today.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 6 -- With the exception of a temporary display of strength in the opening session, cotton futures were under water last week. The market drifted lower, influenced by uncertainty over the price-control measures that the President is expected to outline tomorrow and prospects that the next crop report may reaffirm a measurable increase in indicated production over last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, said tonight that in almost every plane "which carries to the enemy reminders of the growing strength of the United Nations, American women workers know there is a sample of their work."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Chairman George of the Senate Finance Committee pledged "very serious consideration" for the Treasury's spending tax proposal today, while Senator Danaher, Republican, of Connecticut, pressed his retail sales stamp plan as a method of raising billions in revenue now and avoiding a slump after the war.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 6 -- One of the metropolitan district's foremost juvenile equestrians, Dick Van Winkle of Montclair, N.J., captured the horsemanship championship to culminate the exceptionally well-attended Helping Hand Horse Show today.

The early Fall Red Cross campaign to train Queens housewives in home nursing, so that by the end of the year a minimum of 6,000 will have received instruction, starts next week, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. John H. Morris, chairman of home nursing for the Central Chapter of Queens.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 6 -- Senator Edward Bertram Johnston of the Country party, representing West Australia, was found drowned on the beach of a suburb of Melbourne this morning. It is believed he walked into the sea after removing his clothes, which were found a quarter of a mile away.

Traditionally, financial markets of the week before Labor Day are the most lifeless of a year. On the eve of the last Summer holiday, and a Monday at that, most people are out of town and nothing happens. There have been exceptions. The present European war began in that week, but markets rose on the news; what has happened since was imagined then by nobody.

The prospect of a new world, built from the inside by the people who live in it and not a product of international treaties or government restrictions, was pictured yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Lewis Seymour Mudge, of Phildelphia, Stated Clerk Emeritus of the Presbyterian Church, who preached in the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street
The player who had conquered every rival and won every major women's tennis tournament on grass this season met her Waterloo yesterday in the final of the national championship at Forest Hills.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- All trading in lard futures on the Board of Trade here last week was at the ceiling price of $12.90 a 100 pounds. While there has been talk of an upward revision in the ceiling there has been nothing in the way of official comment to confirm this belief.

The trend of prices of cotton last week reflected mainly developments on the anti-inflationary front. Movements were irregularly lower and relatively moderate, with traders inclined to mark time, pending the President's address today.
Four new films will have premieres here during the week. The schedule follows:

It was open nouse yesterday at City Hall. The front doors were not merely unlocked -- they were thrown wide open early in the day and kept that way until late afternoon, for the benefit of any Labor Day week-end visitors who cared to take advantage of Mayor La Guardia's order that the utmost courtesy be shown the city's guests.

It would be unwise to assume that the replacing in Spain of Serrano Suner by Gomez Jordana is a pro-Ally move. Spain is Fascist. The words of the dictator on several occasions are sufficient authority for that.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Senator Guffey, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, predicted today that the Democratic majority in the Senate would be increased by the November elections.

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 6 -- Under-Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal, in a broadcast from Pearl Harbor this morning at ceremonies in which he presented to the Pearl Harbor Navy Yard an "E" for efficiency, said he had made notes for his speech in a Navy patrol plane on a 1,000-mile flight over the Pacific.

A promise that the American Federation of Labor will "do everything humanly possible" to achieve organic unity with the Congress of Industrial Organizations was given yesterday by George Meany, A. F. of L. secretary-treasurer, in a coast-to-coast broadcast in which he said that establishment of a single, unified labor movement was the greatest patriotic contribution American labor could make at this time.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 6 (AP) -- For the moment at least General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's latest threat to Alexandria and the Nile valley has been dissipated by the blows of tanks, land troops and the Royal Air Force and the United States Army Air Forces.

A Pan American Airways clipper with twenty transatlantic passengers, mostly British and American Government officials, arrived yesterday at the marine base at La Guardia Airport, under the command of Captain Charles Goodwyn, carrying 1,164 pounds of mail.

THE date was Sept.7, 1892. The place was the Olympic Club in New Orleans. The parties of the principal part were John Lawrence Sullivan -- the great John L., the Boston Strong Boy -- and James J. Corbett of San Francisco. They met and they fought at that time and place. The result was the crashing fall of an idol and the crowning of a new heavyweight champion of the prize ring.

Since Brazil entered the conflict against two Axis Powers, scores of Germans and Italians have been arrested there and plans are being carried out to evacuate all Germans from the country's coastal areas. Brazil at war realizes the dangers of a fifth column and its Government takes no chances.

ALBANY, Sept. 6 -- Communist leaders charged here today that the American Legion was conducting a deliberate campaign of "terror and harassment" up-State against signers of Communist independent nominating petitions, which seek to put Israel Amter on the ballot as the party's candidate for Governor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Following are the texts of the Labor Day messages of William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations:

WEST MILFORD, N.J., Sept. 6 -- The long-standing dispute regarding the display of the American flag and the so-called Christion flag in the First Presbyterian Church was settled today by a compromise between the Rev. Dr. Lewis Gaston Leary, the pastor, and Police Chief Somers Stites.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, AustraZia, Monday, ept. 7 (PP -- A co?7?rTniqu. Northwestern sector: Reconnaissance activity only. Northeastern sector: Kokoda -- In cooperation with ground forces, Allied fighter units executed Three bombing and strafing attacks on enemy positions. Southeast New Guinea -- Allied heavy bombers, attacked an enemy cargo ship with unknown results.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Pirates came within sight of the first division by shutting out the Cubs twice today, 6 to 0 and 5 to 0. The Bucs now are only two games behind the fourth-place Reds.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The hard-hitting Cardinals swept a three-game series by beating the Reds, 10 -- 2, today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 6 -- Military heraldry in the Second World War, the grimmest conflict in history, has been taken over by the blithest spirits in Hollywood, the creators of Mickey Mouse and, Donald Duck.

The war came closer to the Polo Grounds yesterday and for a few moments the cheering, jeering crowd of 59,453 Giant and Dodger fans forgot the two baseball battles and stood with bared heads and muted voices.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Subdued cheerfulness characterizes the stock markets, which, weighing the favorable against the unfavorable or doubtful developments in the war situation, find more that's encouraging than discouraging.

Mrs. Dorothy Hall, amateur short-wave operator of Springfield Gardens, Queens, who in 1938 established communication with the isolated inhabitants of Pitcairn Island in the South Pacific, has received a government appointment to teach morse code operation to potential members of the Signal Corps, it was disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Several hundred Serbian prisoners were shot and killed by camp guards in July to prevent typhus from spreading, according to reports received here today by the Norwegian Telegraphic Agency.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Browns and the Indians split a double-header today, leaving the Browns with a four-and-a-half-game edge over the Tribe for third place. St. Louis won the first, 3 to 2, and lost the second, 6 to 5, for its only defeat in the six-game series.

VICHY, Sept. 6 -- The difficulties of the railroads in war time are well known, for they have to contend with damages to their lines, reductions in material and obligations arising from the German occupation.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Britain is fighting an "invisible war" that not only is having a tremendous effect on the United Nations' war effort but bids fair to have an unexpected effect on Britain's own social organization and health. It is a battle toward making this importing island self-sufficient in food.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 6 -- Prince and Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff gave a luncheon today at the Southampton Beach Club for Mrs. William J. Hutchinson. Also in the party were Mr. and Mrs. James Abercrombie de Peyster and Mrs. Crosby Tuttle Smith of Ridgefield, Conn., who are visiting Prince and Princess Kaplanoff; Mr. and Mrs. Jules J. Vatable of Islip, L.I., and Lawrence Smith Butler of St. James, L.I.
MOSCOW, Monday, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's midnight communique:
Workers can lead the way to world brotherhood, the Rev. Frank Curtis Williams declared in a sermon yesterday morning at Prospect Avenue Methodist Church, at Greenwood Avenue, Brooklyn.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., Sept. 6 -- The medalists in the annual Wheatley Hills member and guest tourney, Dr. Charles Robinson of the home club and Wesley Cotterell of Cherry Valley, advanced two notches closer to their objective today, taking Ed Warner and his guest, Charles Warner of Hempstead, into camp, 6 and 4, in the first round and then downing Rudy Mattis and his Garden City Golf Club partner, Dr. Gerald Harrigan, 3 and2.
LONDON, Sept. 6 (Reuter) -- One of the frankest Axis commentaries on the war thus far came tonight from Italian Colonel Balsco in a broadcast to the Italian people.

If a united attack is to be made on the evil forces of the world, then let the Christian Church march together with united heart and hand, the Rev. Gordon E. Bigelow, pastor of the First Baptist Church of Beverly, Mass., said yesterday at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Municipal expenditures for recreation are again on the upgrade because of the increasing needs of war workers and service men, the International City Managers Association reported today.

WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 6 -- Vivien Kellems, candidate for the Republican nomination to Congress from the Connecticut Fourth District, charged today that she had been threatened with personal reprisals by State Central Committeeman Frank Altschul of Stamford for her political attacks against Wendell L. Willkie, Samuel Pryor of Darien, former Fairfield County Republican leader; Clare Boothe Luce of Greenwich, another woman contender, and Republican State Central Committee Chairman J. Kenneth Bradley of Westport.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The first breech-loading rifle ever used in warfare is now in the Smithsonian Institution, and, according to correspondence of its inventor, a British officer in the American Revolution, could have been used to kill General Washington had the officer not elected to pass up a potshot at the American commander.

Mr. Jack Kirkland's tawdry play about Erskine Caldwell's pitiable people of Tobacco Road picked up Saturday night where it left off some sixteen months ago at the Forrest Theatre. There for a brief stay before taking to the road once more, the familiar sights and sounds of Jeeter Lester's barnyard commanded the absorbed and appreciative attention of a large audience.

Private Ora Foster of Rochester, Mich., thumbed a ride on an English country road the other day from a lady who turned out to be Queen Mary. Unaware of the identity of his hostess, Private Foster admitted that he did most of the talking. But if he had known who she was he would probably have talked just as freely.

RYE, N. Y., Sept. 6 -- In the only Eastern fixture of 1942 which showed an increase in entries over last year, the famous Welsh terrier, Champion Flornell Rare-Bit of Twin Ponds today repeated his victory of yesterday at Tuxedo to gain his thirteenth best-in-show award.

The Germans smashing with all their might against the outer defenses of Stalingrad are awed by the stony resistance of the city. They say of this industrial town sprawling along the west bank of the Volga what they said of Sevastopol -- that it is a fortress; but in this case they refer not to the improvised system of defense works flung around the place but to the iron spirit of the population.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Sept. 7 -- Novorossiisk, keystone of the Soviet Black Sea Fleet's operations since the fall of Sevastopol, was stormed and captured yesterday afternoon by German forces supported by Rumanian cavalry, according to a special communique issued by the Germans last night.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 5 (Delayed) -- Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the Moslem League, will arrive in New Delhi Monday, which will be the signal for some intense political negotiations aimed at breaking down his intransigent demand for recognition of Pakistan -- independent Moslem States -- before considering any communal -- Hindu-Moslem -- settlement.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Five million American women will rally to the clarion call of a wartime factory whistle before the dawn of New Year's Day in 1943. Such is the solemn prediction of the War Production Board, which envisages an American army of denim-clad daughters, serving their country as armorers, lathe-hands and aeronautical engineers.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 -- The New Rochelle Rowing Club led the out-of-town oarsmen in the fifty-first annual Middle States regatta by winning two sculling races on the placid Schuylkill River course today before 5,000 spectators.

BUFFALO, Sept. 6 -- A new process for extracting vanadium, an essential war material used to toughen steel armor plate and war production tools, that will assure the United States an adequate supply of this mineral was announced in a report made public tonight by the American Chemical Society, which opens its 104th meeting here tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, on his way to Omaha today, was told here of a report from New York that new pressure was being brought to get him to reverse his stand against "full collaboration" with Russia's workers.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, Sept. 5 (Delayed) -- Addressing American and British war correspondents in a tent somewhere in the Western Desert, Wendell L. Willkie gave his opinion that the German full-scale effort, begun last Monday, to crack British positions on the line that extends southward from the region of El Alamein had "definitely failed" and that as a result of that failure "the threat to Egypt has been averted."
Fighting grimly to shake off the Cardinals in their desperate struggle for the National League pennant, the Dodgers came a cropper at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

An eleven-minute air raid alarm was sounded for New York and other sections of the metropolitan area in the Eastern Defense Command at 2:26 o'clock this morning and the air raid defenses on this section of the East Coast went into action.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 6 -- The Chinese drive northward through coastal Chekiang Province has gathered momentum and the Japanese are being hit hard in the vicinity of the provisional capital, Kinhwa, which the enemy is trying desperately to hold, the Chinese High Command reported today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Senator Guffey made his forecast at the beginning of a week in which primaries and conventions in eleven States will bring the nominating season near a close.

The Rev. Dr. Arthur M. Sherman, in a sermon at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, declared yesterday that, while a military victory is a first step toward restoring freedom and security to all peoples, it will not solve humanity's problems.

The Christian churches are ready to support a voluntary national economic council, composed of employers' and labor groups, to bring about maximum production now and plan the post-war reconstruction if such an arrangement is worked out on a basis of cooperation for the common good, the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America declared in its Labor Sunday message.
MOSCOW, Sept. 6 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

With weather ideal for sightseeing, New York's thousands of Labor Day week-end visitors went eagerly about the city yesterday. They strolled along the famous avenues and streets, visited the Bronx Zoo, City Hall or the various museums, rode the Staten Island ferryboats, crowded the motion-picture theatres or joined New Yorkers at the beaches or the Giants-Dodgers baseball game at the Polo Grounds.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The country will observe Labor Day tomorrow not only under the impact of many warnings that it must further tighten its belt for a hard war but also with President Roosevelt's disclosure of a concrete program to that end.
BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 6 -- "And what do you have to eat in the evening, little man?"
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 6 -- Henry J. Kaiser, the West Coast shipbuilder, speaking over the radio tonight, declared that if any one thought he was not going to build cargo planes he was wrong.

ABOARD A.U.S. WARSHIP, in the Solomon Island Area, Aug. 28 (Delayed) -- Shot down over the sea by Japanese planes in an air battle near Tulagi, an American Navy pursuit pilot today is aboard one of his own ships again after spending two six-hour ordeals adrift alone in the Pacific Ocean, two days living on coconuts on an uninhabited tropical island and a week on another island, succored by the only two white inhabitants there.

As President Roosevelt has said, "there has never been a Labor Day as significant as this one." Traditionally this has been a day for reviewing the advances made by organized labor. It has been a day for commemorating the achievements made in the spread of collective bargaining, the raising of living standards and the improvement of working conditions.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- Dr. Edgar Douglas Adrian, noted Professor of Physiology at Cambridge University, who was the first physiologist to photograph the human brain at work, was recovering today from painful injuries he received yesterday while mountaineering with his wife in the Lake District.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 6 (Reuter) -- General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock's assault on Stalingrad has made no progress for the past twenty-four hours, according to reports received here. Berlin, after saying that the city would fall this week-end, now speaks or "fantastic difficulties" presented by the Russian defenses.

Marjorie Lawrence, the Australian soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, whose legs became paralyzed fourteen months ago, resumed her professional career yesterday afternoon when she sang from a wheel chair as the guest artist on "The Pause That Refreshes" program, which was broadcast by WABC from Liederkranz Hall, 111 East Fifty-eighth Street.

One does not have to venture very far by car these days to realize that the warnings both of official Washington and of the automobile and tire experts have fallen on many ears which are stone-deaf. All sorts of drivers continue to exceed the speed regulations. On almost any of the city's avenues taxicabs whiz by, often empty -- bound, one may suppose from the not-for-hire sign which they display, to a favorite hackstand.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 6 -- While the steel industry continued last week to roll out as much steel as possible consistent with available quantities of pig iron and scrap, interest for the most part centered on the change in personnel in the iron and steel branch of the War Production Board.

DENVER, Sept. 6 (AP) -- An ailing John Kimbrough was just a little bit better than the healthiest friend or foe on the field as he drove the Western Army All-Stars to victory over the Chicago Cardinals, 16 to 10, in a great football show today.
Broadway is counting on three openings for next week -- one drama and two vaudeville shows. Unless there are last-minute scratches, here is the schedule:

Driving six runs home in the third inning, the Department of Sanitation baseball team subdued the Fire Department nine in free-hitting game at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. The half-dozen tallies gave the Sanitation representatives a top-heavy lead, and a one-sided battle loomed.

If you want to take the fun out of a soldier's holiday, make him stand in line. "Show a soldier a line of people and tell him they're handing out $20 gold pieces on the front end and he'll walk away," declared Private Hubert L. Wright of Coldwater, Mich., as he stood watching long queues lined up before Times Square theatres yesterday afternoon.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Concentration of priority rating authority in Washington, as announced by Donald M. Nelson, chief of the War Production Board, "is hailed by the steel industry as a constructive proposal to eliminate much of the confusion which has prevailed," the magazine Steel reported today.
In the Aug. 31 issue of THE TIMES there is an article attributed to Senator George on the proposed spending tax. I wish to point out an important inequality in the tax as explained there.
CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Guns, ammunition and blasting powder found in the home of William Bernard Wernecke and on his farm near Wadsworth were displayed today by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents.

The pursuit planes, the bombers, the tanks, the jeeps and the other weapons are new and some of them startlingly so. But the human qualities that succeed in the making of war haven't changed at all. It is comforting to see how the old virtues of character have come back into good repute under war's stern necessities.
WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, Sept. 6 -- A battle has been fought and won.

The Rev. Dr. Robert Russell Wicks, dean of the Princeton University Chapel, in a sermon yesterday at the Riverside Church, characterized as hypocritical that attitude of self-righteousness expressed in the belief that "God is only on our side of the war."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- From their namesake cities, towns and villages in the United States to a dozen captured and embattled cities in Europe will go by short wave the Labor Day greetings of free American workers. The messages, assembled for broadcast in the several respective languages by the Office of War Information, will reach the length and breadth of Europe.

MOSCOW, Monday, Sept. 7 -- A reinforced Red Army pushed back German lines northwest of Stalingrad and continued to hold firm southwest of the beleaguered Volga city, but made "a fighting retreat to new positions" around the Black Sea naval base of Novorossiisk, the Soviet High Command announced today.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- The average British working man's eagerness for the establishment of a second front, and his preparedness to do his bit in that gigantic undertaking by giving his utmost in turning out the necessary materials, will be summed up this week at the annual convention of the Trades Union Congress which will get down to business at Blackpool beginning tomorrow.

LONDON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- Competent air observers here declared today a "second front in the air," concentrated in Western Europe during the next three months, could assure eventual Allied victory if the present American-British policy of dispersal of strength over scattered world fronts was abandoned.

Mayor La Guardia devoted most of his weekly radio "Talk to the People" yesterday to criticism of Federal war agencies and methods. The Army's dimout requirements for the city, he charged, were excessive, but would, nevertheless, be strictly enforced.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- The Yankees took two more important strides toward that pennant today as they thrashed the Senators in both ends of a double-header while 20,000 Washington mourners looked on helplessly.

Residents of the metropolitan area have responded enthusiastically to Mayor La Guardia's invitation to park their cars without cost, under police supervision, at subway terminals and in eighteen mid-Manhattan streets, a survey by police traffic commanders disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Fears that the government's anti-inflation campaign might lower prices for hogs, which are selling at 128 per cent of parity, and thereby limit the amount of corn fed to livestock, became effective yesterday as a price-making influence in the corn market on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Four prominent Catholic leaders today issued a joint statement calling upon the return of American social work to the "fundamental religious concept that gave it birth" and deplored what they termed as a movement to make the traditional service of private social work agencies a direct function of government.

A new era in missionary work will be opened shortly when a Chinese citizen is chosen to be Episcopal Bishop of China, the Right Rev. Alfred A. Gilman, Bishop of Hankow, China, declared yesterday in the morning sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 6 -- Annabella, French film actress who has been inactive since 1939, will return to the screen in "Project 47," a Commando story which will go before the cameras on Thursday at Twentieth Century-Fox, the studio has announced.

BILLINGS, Mont., Sept. 6 -- Montana Democrats endorsed Senators Wheeler and Murray in a fifteen-plank platform yesterday calling for fair distribution of the burdens of war, strong opposition to monopoly, aid to small business and post-war relinquishment by the Federal Government of its emergency powers.

Declaring that genuine charity is of supreme importance for the promotion of human happiness, the Rev. Michael J. Deacy pointed out in his sermon yesterday morning at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral that "charity will never be true charity unless it takes justice into constant account."
Isn't it about time that tenants received comparable consideration for deduction in their income-tax returns and also in the proposed spending tax, for payments of rent?

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- Bankers, college professors and students rallied here today and yesterday in an effort to assist the canning companies in handling and saving the big crop of tomatoes grown in the Rochester zone.

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 7 -- Large formations of United States bombers, both the heavy Flying Fortresses and the two-motored Bostons, carried out destructive raids over Nazi-occupied Northern France in daylight yesterday, despite adverse weather conditions, and hammered targets of Meaulte, near Albert and at Abbeville and St. Omer.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 6 -- A federated international government, patterned broadly after that of the United States, will have to be worked out for the "truly new world" that will shape up after the military defeat of the Axis, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler declared here today in his sixteenth annual address at the Parrish Memorial Art Museum.

The first phase of the Battle of Egypt has ended in a German repulse. It is a repulse so abrupt that it may pave the way to British victory. One week to the day after he launched an attack which had all the aspect of a major offensive to seize the Nile Valley, Marshal Rommel is back where he started, with all his gains lost and his armored strength considerably depleted.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- The wheat market is feeling the effect of lack of hedging pressure against cash grain, and prices moved irregularly upward last week with the September showing the most strength. Cash grain, however, led the advance, and while the September contract gained 1 1/8 cents, the cash article advanced 1 1/2 cents on the future contract.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Sept. 6 -- General Agustin P. Justo, former President of Argentina, who offered his services to Brazil "to defend liberty against tyranny," received a tumultuous welcome from Rio de Janeiro today when he arrived in the private plane of President Getulio Vargas.

Expressing appreciation of labor's contribution to the war, Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, in a Labor Day message predicted yesterday that, with labor sharing more in the fruits of production, workers would participate increasingly in ownership and that the progress of labor into a share in management would follow as a natural result.

Japan's naval spokesman is a certain Captain Hideo Hiraide. His function is to broadcast Japanese victories to the Japanese people. He does not retail these victories; he wholesales them. In the early months of the war his job was easy and pleasant. Japanese victories were real and substantial.
TUNBRIDGE WELLS, England, Sept. 6 -- A proposal that Britain subsidize babies to combat the falling birth rate came here today from Major Randolph Churchill, son of the Prime Minister.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., Sept. 67 -- Tom Strafaci of Shore View and his host, W. F. Zentler, put together a great best-ball score of 62 to bring about a tie for first place in the Leewood Golf Club's 54-hole medal play member-guest tournament today.

Little Miss Pigtail, who lives in a fashion world of her own, need have no fears that mother will surpass her in the parade of non-priority togs. Manufacturers have prepared for the Winter market a natty collection for the junior miss.

While bass fishermen took advantage of the holiday week-end to try near-by lakes, the New York A. C. Anglers have announced that they will do some fishing for large mouth bass at one of the Bear Mountain lakes when the season opens there on Sept. 15.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- The corn crop has entered the final lap in its annual race with the first killing frost and under a severe handicap, as the plant is far from maturity in many sections, and at least two weeks of hot and dry weather regarded as needed to put the bulk of the acreage out of the way of prospective damage.

LONDON, Sept. 6 -- It has been made clear again by official remarks that while the Government is not exactly complacent about the huge wartime increase in the note circulation of the Bank of England, it is by no means alarmed. It is disappointed, however, that renewed expansion in the amount of 1,400,000 last week followed a decline from the August holiday peak, which thus continued for only the brief space of a fortnight.

Henry McAlpin Schley, construction manager of Rockefeller Center, has been appointed assistant to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, to coordinate the management of physical facilities and services, it was announced yesterday.
Labor Day accident fatalities trailed far behind those of last year as the three-day holiday neared the close of its second day.

OSSINING, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- Seventeen young priests entrained as missionaries to the lowland jungles of Northern Bolivia's Pando district late this afternoon after impressive outdoor ceremonies here in the cloister at Maryknoll, headquarters of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America. Unable because of the war to travel to the Orient, they will constitute the first Maryknoll mission in South America.

The Rev. Ralph Beryl Nesbitt, associate pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, declared in a sermon yesterday that honest toil builds in the personality such values as discipline, dignity, self-confidence and trustworthiness.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- Oats held wfithin narrow price limits in trading last week on the Board of Trade, but September acted tight, due to lack of deliveries of cash grain on future contracts, and finished % cent a bushel higher. The distant months were off to /o cent.

LONDON, Sept. 6 (Reuter) -- The Royal Navy has a hearty respect for the women of Russia and feels that they realize what the "war effort" means. This was illustrated by a couple of incidents that occurred on a recent convoy to Russia, it was revealed today.

ALBANY, Sept. 6 -- Dean Alfange, American Labor party nominee for Governor, declared here this afternoon that support of his candidacy was the only way organized labor and liberal groups in the State could show their loyalty on election day to "our great President and Commander in Chief, Franklin D. Roosevelt," and their determination to carry the war effort to ultimate victory.

LONDON, Sept 6 (AP) -- Messages of encouragement to Yugoslavs, Norwegians and Luxembourgers were broadcast from Britain today, urging them to continue resistance to the Germans and promising retribution for the Nazis at the end of the war.

An offer to purchase all outstanding debentures of the Associated Mortgage Companies, Inc., amounting to $7,439,670 in face value, has been made by the United States Fidelity and Guaranty Company of Baltimore, Md., at $50 flat for each $100 of face value.

Why are New York City apartment-house owners disregarding all their pledges to abide by the OPA rent control warnings, and instead are raising rents on every side? This applies as well to apartment hotels, some of whose owners are trying to hide behind the so-called Inn Keepers' Law of New York State.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- As President Roosevelt put the finishing touches to a sweeping anti-inflation program today, several Senators served notice that any step to sweep aside by decree the statutory safeguards for farm prices would precipitate a grave break between the Executive and Congress.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6 -- James M. Landis, director of the Office of Civilian Defense, said today that "this is a tough war and it's going to get tougher," and warned against the overemphasizing of minor victories and the minimizing of major defeats.

A review of the present economic situation in Sweden was broadcast yesterday from Stockholm and recorded here by the short-wave listening station of the Columbia Broadcasting System. It dealt chiefly with the country's wood and iron industries. Excerpts from the record follow:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 -- Rules to guide the average citizen in helping the war against spies, saboteurs and a potential fifth column have been formulated by J. Edgar Hoover, head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the nation's chief spy hunter.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 6 -- Replacing the seventy-two-year-old Danbury Fair, which was canceled this year at the request of the Office of Defense Transportation, a one-week commercial agricultural exposition opened today with an estimated attendance of 25,000, only 5,000 fewer than attended the opening day of the fair last year.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Braves executed the first triple play seen at Shibe Park in 14 years today as they defeated the Phils, 13 to 3 and 7 to 3, to extend the Phils' losing streak to 11 games.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 6 -- State police of the Riverhead substation today sent out a nine-State teletype alarm containing a description of the fourteen pieces of jewelry, valued at $55,000, stolen Thursday from the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Magowan on Cooper's Neck Lane, Southampton.

Paving the way for President Roosevelt's expected wage program, Mayor La Guardia, Sidney Hillman and other labor leaders called yesterday on organized labor to make its sacrifices along with those being made by men in the armed forces and demanded that war production be continued without the loss of a single hour, regardless of anything else.

Camouflaged as a "colonization plan," the Nazis are setting out on a large scheme for the protection of Germanism on the Reich's eastern borders. In an effort to create ramparts in foreign-populated areas, the plan, calling for complete elimination of alien elements, follows the usual Nazi pattern of ruthless subjugation.

Any realistic discussion of wages must take into consideration the fact that 7,500,000 American workers still receive 40 cents an hour or less, L. Metcalfe Walling, administrator of the United States Department of Labor's newly consolidated wage and hour and public contracts divisions, declared in a Labor Day statement given out yesterday.

Soldiers, sailors -- almost any man between the ages of 20 and 45 -- and a whole lot of war-plant workers with no draft problems in sight are eyed by bankers as shaky credit risks, according to Wide World, even though the experience with service men so far has caused little loss to lenders.

OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 6 -- Society in record numbers crowded the ringside today at the Helping Hand Horse Show, a threefold charity event, held here in the show ring on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Emanuel on Cedar Swamp Road.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 6 -- Sixty-one starting craft today in the seventieth annual Fall regatta of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, which was the sixteenth of the Sound championship season, had all they could do to get around the courses, so lifeless were the conditions.
CAIRO, Sept. 6 (AP) -- A joint Headquarters-Royal Air Force communique:

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 6 -- With news of the withdrawal of Axis forces beyond the British Eighth Army's minefields, which they crossed on the first day of their advance, it became certain today that the first phase of the present battle had resulted in a defeat for General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel.

VICHY, France, Sept. 6 -- Authorities announced tonight that French patrols thwarted an attempted landing by six Britons on the Mediterranean coast near the Spanish border early yesterday, capturing an officer and routing his companions after a brisk gun battle.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 6 (AP) -- Jersey City and Newark divided a double-header before 10,460 today, the Little Giants taking the opener, 3 to 1, and the Bears the seven-inning nightcap, 3 to 0.
BOSTON, Sept. 6 (AP) -- The Red Sox took an 8-7 decision over the Athletics today in a loosely played game.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- William F. Zentler of Leewood and his guest from Shoreview, Tommy Strafaci, ended a three-day battle with Joseph L. Pittori of Hickory and his host, J. Austin Lyons Jr., to win the Leewood Golf Club's member-guest handicap tournament today with a 54-hole best-ball score of 196.

The Communist party in the State decided yesterday to fill only one of the four vacancies on its State ticket, nominating Benjamin J. Davis Jr., Negro leader and New York County Chairman of the party, as a candidate for Representative at Large.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 7 -- Fifteen years ago the late Henri de Jouvenel, then French High Commissioner in Syria and Lebanon, paid an official visit to Jerusalem to the High Commissioner in Palestine, the late Field Marshal Viscount Herbert Charles Onslow Plumer.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Sept. 7 -- Brazil, at war with the powers seeking to destroy freedom, celebrated today the 120th anniversary of her independence.

LONDON, Sept. 7 (Reuter) -- The International Sugar Agreement of 1937, which expired at the end of August after a scheduled five-year life, apparently is being extended unchanged. It is understood that all non-enemy signatories have decided to continue the system in its present form, except the Government of India, which has reportedly decided against rejoining, and even this is not yet considered a definite defection.

To meet the ever-increasing need for volunteers in child care, the American Women's Voluntary Services will give a new series of courses to prepare women to serve in child health stations, day nurseries and play schools, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Nathan Straus, director of the A.W.V.S. department of instruction for Greater New York.

CAIRO, Africa, Sept. 7 (U.P.) -- British patrols mopped up Axis stragglers on the east side of the mine-studded Egyptian front tonight and pushed the main body of General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's Nazi Africa Corps back west beyond the starting line of its ill-fated offensive at some points.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Sept. 7 -Successfully avoiding the snares and pitfalls that generally lie in wake for medal winners, Dr. Charles Robinson and his guestpartner, Wesley Cotterell of Cherry Valley, today annexed top honors in the annual Wheatley Hills' member-guest tournament.

The Garden City Publishing division of Doubleday, Doran introduces today its New Home Library, a venture that has been ten years in preparation and which, has cost, it is said, $350,000 in research and editorial planning. The library consists of a varied list of reprints and new books especially written for the series.

Before Aqueduct's greatest crowd of 40,224, Pictor, a homebred from William L. Brann's Maryland Farm, hammered his way to victory in a nose thriller in the $11,400 Aqueduct Handicap yesterday. The result was in doubt until the judges examined the photograph, but the son of Challenger II was decisively best, for he was impeded twice before he jammed his way between horses to earn $7,900.

Both newspapers and magazines, which had been lagging in linage until the last month or so, are expected to enjoy a substantial increase this month over August and one comparing favorably with September of last year, according to publishers.

FIRST there was Bill Shirer. Then there was Harry Flannery. Now comes Howard K. Smith, third in the line of succession as Berlin correspondent of the Columbia Broadcasting System. Mr. Smith crossed the border into Switzerland on Dec. 7, 1941, and in his "Last Train From Berlin"* he gives us the sequel to Mr. Flannery's sequel to Mr. Shirer's original "Berlin Diary."

CINCINNATI, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Bucky Walters, after nine attempts frustrated by weak hitting behind him, finally won his thirteenth game of the year today, beating the Cubs, 3 to 1. His Reds couldn't produce for Johnny Vander Meer, however, and the Cubs won the nightcap of the double-header, 5 to 3.

In one of the most enthralling matches the tournament ever has provided Frederick R. (Ted) Schroeder Jr. of Glendale, Calif., volleyed down the superb resistance of Frank Parker of Hollywood, Calif., yesterday to win the men's national amateur tennis championship at Forest Hills.

The Treasury deserves the gratitude of the country for the boldness and imagination of its plan to tax spending. It is the most effective and equitable scheme that has been offered so far by any of the Finance Ministries of the nations at war.

On the night of Sept. 7, 1940, planes from Goering's Luftwaffe reported to number 700 bombed London in what Berlin described as the heaviest air raid in history. They killed 306 persons and wounded 1,300. It was one of those frantic blows which were to knock England out of the war and destroy the British Empire.

While many slept soundly through the eleven-minute air raid alarm in the metropolitan area yesterday morning, most New Yorkers tumbled out of bed, many put on their lights and few were sufficiently awake to know what was afoot until it was all over.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The National Grange took issue tonight with President Roosevelt's message to Congress asking that legislation be adopted before Oct. 1 to keep farm prices at parity or he would do it by Executive action, but a newer farm organization, the National Farmers Union, gave him unqualified support.

I have just returned from a four months' stay on the farm in the West Virginia hills. My association with the farmers there stunned me into the realization of the importance and the problems of those men. They are bewildered at the nation's unconcern and the treatment meted out to them.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 7 -- Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce's effort to win a Republican Congressional nomination further complicated political affairs in Connecticut tonight by producing a new candidate for Governor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7 -- Asserting that "wildcat strikes" caused 222 tie-ups in essential war industries in July alone, Vice Admiral John W. Greenslade, commander of the Western sea frontier, advised the unions today to remedy this condition in the interest of the future of organized labor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UP) -- A "majority" of the Senate Finance Committee appear to favor a sales tax to raise additional war revenue, Senator George, chairman, said tonight prior to a showdown vote tomorrow on various tax proposals affecting individuals.

THE victory of the Western detachment of the All-Army football team over the Chicago Cardinals at Denver must have been sweet to Major Wallace Wade, commanding officer of that military task force, sweet to Major Wade and bitter to Jimmy Conzelman, coach of the Cardinals.

Some of the many thousands who have been hauled in and out of New York City this past week-end may have thought they were riding in railway cars reclaimed from the earlier episodes of some Pageant of Transportation. The distinguishing feature of American railway transportation at the moment, however, is not the use of elderly cars but the handling of a record-breaking movement of soldiers and civilians without confusion.

Duane Jones, president of the Duane Jones Advertising Agency, has leased a penthouse apartment in 30 Sutton Place through Frances R. Jaffin, who also rented an apartment in 1040 Park Avenue to Clifford Spitzer of Honolulu and an apartment in 15 West Eighty-first Street to Manuel Sidney.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A communique:

Both fresh and salt water anglers seized the Labor Day week-end as an opportunity, perhaps the last on their programs for a long while, to couple two days of fishing. Judging by reports received from many miles outside of the metropolitan area, it was a fisherman's holiday for a large number of those who were not at work.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Wartime powers of the government were invoked today to stabilize the labor supply in the non-ferrous metals and lumber industries in twelve Western States.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 7 -- America's most famous Pekingese added further honors to his almost innumerable victories tonight. Champion Che Le of Matson's Catawba, owned by Mrs. James M. Austin of Old Westbury, L.I., and handled by Mrs. Ruth Sayres, was named best in show among 521 dogs benched at the Fair Grounds in the fifty-ninth annual show of the Danbury Agricultural Society.

Mayor La Guardia, Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore, Assemblyman Robert J. Crews and Major Irving V.A. Huie, city WPA administrator, will speak at the opening of a new playground and the dedication of a memorial flagpole at Park Avenue and Floyd Street, Brooklyn, at 4 P.M. today.
MOSCOW, Sept. 7 (AP) -- A Soviet information bureau communique:

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 8 -- General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock attacked Stalingrad yesterday on a new line, west of the city, and made some progress against stiff Red Army resistance. A Soviet communique issued today says, in announcing the shift in the battle, that Soviet troops in one western sector withdrew to new positions after they had repelled four German attacks.

BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 7 (U.P.) -- Frank Wolstencroft, president of the Trades Union Congress, which opened its annual conference here today, bitterly assailed persons who charged that the workers were not carrying their load in Britain's war effort.
VICTORY, N.Y., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Thirty men have left Victory to enter the armed forces and this town dedicated a service flag today in their honor.
The following is the text of President Roosevelt's radio address to the country last night, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Nearly all of Labor Day's dozen matinees benefited from the large influx of week-end visitors to Broadway. Five of the current shows failed to give afternoon performances. A house-to-house survey disclosed that five attractions -- four of them musical -- enjoyed standee trade, three more had capacity houses, three were not far away from the sell-out mark, and only one had scanty attendance.
CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Kansas City won the American Association pennant today after one of the most rousing stretch races in history.

EL PASO, Texas, Sept. 7 -- A colorful celebration of Labor Day took place today in El Paso and Cuidad Juarez featured by the marching of labor men and military groups over the international bridges and through the streets of both cities.

LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Encouraged by the Egyptian and Russian war news the stock markets were firm today. Oils, industrials and South African gold mines were features. Although business was small prices were higher in practically all sections.

Once again the President has stated with admirable clarity and force the nature of our inflation problem and the principles which must govern its solution. Once again he has left vague and shadowy the precise means whereby he proposes to solve it. He has, in effect, repeated his message and speech of April 27, but with one important change in viewpoint.

OTTAWA, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Ontario Paper Company at Thorold, Ont., will be allotted 10,500 horsepower, "which, combined with their own, should permit operation of at least two machines," Labor Minister Humphrey Mitchell said in a telegram to Mayor W.A. Hutt of Thorold, released here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Wartime continuance of athletic programs in the armed services -- including those which pit crack All-Star Army and Navy teams against professional outfits -- found general approval today in Congressional quarters.

In each of two September primaries appears one of those curious recurrent figures of whom the kindest thing one can say is that they are eccentric comedians or "variety" performers on the political stage.
