The proposed spendings tax has the merits of both a sales tax and further increases in the income tax, while having the defects of neither, Randolph E. Paul, Treasury general counsel, said yesterday in defending the Treasury Department's latest tax measure.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- The war has created a serious situation for the squirrels, chipmunks and birds of Bear Mountain State Park. So many persons have been unable to go far for their vacations that they have been crowding through the park, eating the apples from the deserted orchards on which the animals have depended for years.

As a couple of enlisted men in the Royal Navy who have had the good fortune to spend a few weeks in New York we would like to express our heartfelt thanks to Americans who have treated us so royally during our stay here.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Washington power in the final quarter broke up what had been a brilliant aerial duel between the Redskins' Sammy Baugh and Cecil Isbell of the Green Bay Packers, and the Skins took a 28-7 decision tonight before an estimated crowd of 55,000.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 7 (AP) -- A strong Chinese offensive in the Central China Province of Anhwei has liberated twenty-five villages in twenty days and still is gaining ground, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

BOSTON, Sept. 7 -- Behind some robust hitting, including Captain Dolph Camilli's twenty-second home run, the Dodgers took today's opener from the Braves, 11 -- 4, but Bobo Newsom let them down in the nightcap and Jim Tobin hurled Boston to a 5-3 victory.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 7 -- New German-Hungarian commercial negotiations started today at noon in Budapest a few hours after the arrival there of the Reich Minister of Commerce, Dr. Walther Funk, and of the chief German commercial negotiator, Dr. Karl Clodius, whose double task it is to dampen the Hungarian antagonism to Rumania and obtain as much Hungarian foodstuffs for the Reich as possible.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 7 -- It is generally believed abroad that, if the Hindus and Moslems of India could get together and present the British with a united program, the British would have to bow gracefully, turn over the government to the Indians and go.

VICHY, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The pro-Axis government of Pierre Laval protested energetically to the United States today because American Flying Fortresses and Bostons had bombed cities in occupied France, held by Nazi troops and important to the German war effort.
Forty-four women between the ages of 20 and 30 took their oaths here yesterday as officer candidates for the Waves.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 7 -- The pre-tourney favorites, Neil White of the host club and Richard E. Callaghan, unattached, of New York City were defeated in the final round of the sixth annual Tamarack Country Club member-guest handicap golf tournament today by Martin O. Johnsen of Tamarack and Douglas Ford, New York State junior title holder of Green Valley, 1 up.

OMAHA, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Nebraska Power Company and the Kansas Gas and Electric Company were linked today in a new 154,000 volt transmission line which stretches 270 miles from Omaha to Midian, Kan. The interconnection also meant the pooling of power in thirty-one States.

LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 8 (AP) -- German nuisance raiders dropped flares in the London area just before midnight during a short air raid alarm, but heavy anti-aircraft fire drove off the planes before any bombs were dropped. Nazi planes also were reported over East Anglia early today.

DETROIT, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Harlond Clift belted five straight hits -- a triple, two doubles and two singles -- and drove in all three runs today as the Browns blanked the Tigers, 3 to 0, to divide a double-header before 21,075 spectators. Al Benton needed assistance in pitching Detroit to a 5-to-3 decision in the opener.

PLATTSBURG, N. Y., Sept. 7 -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., on a non-political visit to Clinton County, was guest at a luncheon at noon, the function being non-partisan. The sixty guests represented every phase of professional and business life.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, Sept. 7 -- The enemy force that fought a delaying, rearguard action in the southern sector while the main body of the German Africa Corps was withdrawing under British pressure appears to have "thickened" during the last twenty-four hours.

BUFFALO, Sept. 7 -- In a thousand and one chemical laboratories throughout America chemists are discovering new continents of matter at such a rapid pace under the pressure of war that "the world of 1940 has already become an antiquity," Dr. Charles M.A. Stine said tonight at the opening general session of the American Chemical Society's meeting.

Not even war can rob us of life's permanent interests. People are still interested in the seasons and the weather, as the letters to editors will attest. People are still interested in the English language. They continue to be offended by sloppy pronunciation and write letters to the papers about it.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 7 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, extended his new "get tough" attitude to the field of labor today and predicted that we are going to lose the war "unless we very quickly develop and use the overwhelming strength free men have when they are completely united and completely in earnest."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- It is understood here that the Netherlands Government, now studying the views of its Far Eastern officials and colonial experts regarding proposed far-reaching changes in the colonial system, soon will outline its views of the post-war status of the Netherlands East Indies and the other colonies, subject to a kind of imperial conference in which all parts of the Netherlands domains will be represented.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The second-place Red Sox breezed into Griffith Stadium today and beat the Senators, 9 to 7. Weather prevented a second game. A double-header will be played tomorrow.
Mrs. Frederick W. Drury and Miss Frances Sands Drury have returned to 18 East Sixtieth Street from Great Barrington, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Wider use of brick and tile in construction was urged today by the War Production Board, which estimates that a saving of at least 2,000,000,000 board feet of lumber is possible by increased utilization of brick and tile and another 100,000,000 to 150,000,000 feet can be saved by using more gypsum board.

NEW BERN, N.C., Sept. 7 -- Colonel Frank B. Goettge of the United States Marine Corps is reported missing in action in the Pacific war zone, according to word received here by friends of Mrs. Goettge, who has been notified to this effect by the Navy Department, it was learned here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The United States and Great Britain, confident that Soviet Russia will hold out despite serious setbacks, have made vital military decisions designed to put their armies on the offensive against Germany at one or more of a dozen different points in Europe, President Roosevelt told the country and the world by radio tonight.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, reiterated today the pledge of labor to abandon strikes for the duration of the war and called on workers of the nation to keep production going at the highest rate of efficiency, so that America may get the munitions necessary to win an early victory.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- In the House about sixty-five members-less than one-sixth of the membership -- listened to the reading of President Roosevelt's message today by Alney E. Chaffee, a clerk. fost Democrats and a few Republicans applauded at the end.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 7 -- If the Germans succeed in capturing Stalingrad the next move is likely to be a drive on Leningrad, according to persons closely in touch with well-informed neutral military circles in Berlin and Budapest.

Americans have not shown their usual hospitality to one foreigner transplanted to their shores. The eggplant is a vegetable of ancient and distinguished lineage, tracing its family history back to India, where it grows in wild profusion. The Arabs and Chinese long ago cannily recognized its worth, and set about cultivating it in the ninth century.

The parents of 50,000 children who are expected to register for the first time in the city's elementary schools, beginning tomorrow and continuing through Friday, were urged yesterday by Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins and School Superintendent John E. Wade to provide thorough medical and dental examinations for the children before the opening of school next Monday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 7 -- amount has signed Joel McCrea play the male lead opposite Claudette Colbert in "So Proudly Hail," a story of the exploits of the Army nurses in the siege of Bataan Mark Sandrich will produce and direct the picture and he and Allan Scott are writing the scenario.

The railroads, buses and the subways bore the brunt yesterday of transporting what was pretty strictly a pedestrian throng of Labor Day holidaymakers. By contrast, the bridges and tunnels leading into the city carried a flow of vehicular traffic that was less than that of a normal weekday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Lowering of the draft age from 20 to 18, which would make from 2,500,000 to 3,250,000 youths subject to military service, was proposed today in a bill introduced by Representative Wadsworth, author of the original draft act.
STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, Sept. 7 -- For the ninth year in succession the people of the Weirton Steel Company have staged a Labor Day pageant.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 -- American-made planes have bested enemy craft five to one wherever they have fought in the past month, Lieut. Gen. George H. Brett, just returned from command of Allied air forces in the Southwest Pacific, declared here today.

ALBANY, Sept. 7 -- Solidarity between the nation's production workers and "white collar" workers in their fight for victory, was asserted by R.J. Thomas, president of the C.I.O.'s United Automobile Workers, in an address here today before 200 delegates at the fourth annual national convention of the United Office and Professional Workers, a C.I.O. affiliate.

RENO, Nev., Sept. 7 -- Mrs Bridget McBurney Sargent of Cedarhurst, L. I., killed herself in her hotel room today, twenty-four hours before she was to have begun suit for divorce against her husband, Charles S. Sargent Jr.

Major Gen. Jean Knox, director of the Auxiliary Territorial Service of Great Britain, the organization of "women soldiers" who assist in servicing the anti-aircraft guns of England, arrived last night at La Guardia Field on an American Export Line Flying Ace.

From German broadcasts recorded in New York yesterday The Associated Press said the German High Command reported the repulse of a British attack along the central sector of the Alamein front in Egypt. Axis airmen were said to have carried out successful raids on British artillery positions, tank and armored vehicle concentrations and an airport.

Total shipments of hosiery in July dropped off to 11,250,861 dozen pairs from the 12,889,370 dozen pairs shipped in the corresponding month of last year, a decrease of 12.7 per cent according to a report by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

CAIRO, Sept. 7 -- Enemy air activity increased on the Alamein front yesterday, formations of as many as fifteen Stukas, escorted by similar numbers of Messerschmitts, being sent over on numerous occasions, it was announced today.
Philadelphia, Sept. 7 -- Dr. Geyelin was a member of a prominent Philadelphia family and a pioneer in the development of ini sulin t_eatment for diabetes.

The silence of sorrow and the power of pride filled an apartment at 222 Seaman Avenue last night as President Roosevelt awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor to a young lieutenant who was reported "missing in action" after the Coral Sea battles.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 7 (U.P.) -- Major Gen. Georg von Bismarck, commander of the German Twenty-first Armored Division, has been killed in action on the Egyptian front in the fighting that resulted in the defeat of General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel in the first phase of the Fall offensive, German prisoners said today.

Labor in the nation's shipyards spent its traditional holiday at work yesterday, setting a record of 223 ships launched or begun. The metropolitan area about New York contributed its share, while in a lunch-hour speech to the workers in the busy Navy Yard in Brooklyn Rear Admiral E.J. Marquart, congratulating the men, described the achievements since Pearl Harbor as a "staggering total almost beyond the belief of one's own eyes."
BUFFALO, Sept. 7 (AP) -- A warhawk pursuit plane, christened "Iron Eagle," was presented to the Army Air Forces today as a Labor Day gift from the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen.
LONDON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (U.P.) -- Robert Brennan, Eire's Minister to the United States, today said that recent reports of demonstrations against American troops in Ireland had been "grossly exaggerated" by those who are jealous of the traditional good feeling between the people of Ireland and America.

It is a fortunate accident that some Army or Navy flier got off his announced course early Monday morning and brought about an alert. Usually these alerts have been heralded several days ahead, and one could almost sniff the night when they were due.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7 -- Coming back after a humiliating first-game setback, in which the Pirates scored eleven runs in the sixth inning after two were out, the Cardinals matched steps with the pace-setting Dodgers today by taking the second game, 6 to 4.
LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 8 (Reuter) -- In a leading editorial devoted to President Roosevelt's call to Congress for measures to stabilize the cost of living, The London Times today said:

The Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, admitted yesterday in an address at exercises opening the university's school year that he had been wrong in espousing the isolationist cause before this country entered the war.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, Sept. 8 -- The Japanese have forced back Allied troops in the Kokoda-Myola area in New Guinea and now are in contact with our defense positions which are along the Owen Stanley range of mountains.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- Marriage, a 6-year-old gelding who ran in cheap $1,000 claiming races only two years ago, upset the famed Alsab in the $32,800 Washington Park Handicap today, stunning a holiday crowd of 35,000.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7 -- A new-type landing ship for tanks, the largest war vessel ever built at an inland shipyard, slid down the Dravo Corporation ways into the Ohio River this afternoon amid the cheers of 4,000 workmen and high ranking Army and Navy officers.

CHATHAM, N.Y., Sept. 7 -Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, continued his informal political tour today, visiting the Columbia County Fair with his 10-year-old son, Thomas E. Dewey Jr., in the afternoon, and later conferring with the Republican chairmen of Columbia, Albany and Rensselaer Counties.

Wholesale reorders improved last week, particularly in the apparel divisions, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Five-year-old Muriel De Pasquale almost missed the bus and a birthday party back at her home at 235 Smith Avenue, Kingston, N.Y., when she wandered away from her mother and her aunt yesterday afternoon while they were shopping along Ninth Avenue.

"Bomber cloth" is making its initial civilian appearance as a home-furnishings fabric. Only one New England mill is now able to produce more of this cloth than is needed for war contracts, and the surplus will be available in the drapery yard-goods departments of two New York stores next week.

PROVIDENCE, Sept. 7 -- Formation of the Silver Users Emergency Committee, which will enlist public opinion throughout the country in a campaign to force Congress "to bring silver out of government hoarding vaults and into productive use," was announced here today by William G. Thurber of Tilden Thurber, chairman of the committee.

PEARL RIVER, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- A swashbuckling young man with apparently unlimited funds at his disposal, who spent a gay week-end at the Blue Hill Country Club here, was being sought tonight by State police throughout Southern Rockland County on charges of having stolen two New York automobiles and a quantity of clothing and golf equipment from the club.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -- A confidential report on defenses in Alaska and the Aleutian Islands was given to the Senate Military Affairs Committee today in a closed session lasting ninety minutes.

A spokesman for "Automobile Old-Timers" recently addressed a letter to Mr. Ickes, saying "The gasoline supply of 30,000,000 motor vehicle owners must be rationed." His statement is characteristic of an astonishing misconception of the causes of the gasoline and fuel oil shortage in the East.

WANAQUE, N.J., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Herbert Titus, 42 years old, of Haskell, a guard at the vital Wanaque Reservoir, was injured slightly early today in a shotgun battle with two unidentified men near one of the small dams in the backwoods of the reservoir property.

Rounding the final turn with all cylinders roaring, the Yankees squared away into the home stretch of their American League pennant drive yesterday by walloping the Athletics in both ends of the double-header at the Stadium and then heading West with the cheers of 32,278 spectators ringing in their ears.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 7 (AP) -- Newark forced Jersey City into a third-place deadlock with Syracuse today by defeating the Little Giants, 3 to 1 and 7 to 5, to close the regular International League season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) -Nominees for seven Senate, fifty-five House, and eight Governor's seats will be chosen this week at primaries and conventions in eleven States, with greatest interest centered on the outcome of Senatorial contests in Minnesota and Colorado, House races in Washington and Connecticut, and a Governorship contest in Georgia.

German and Rumanian troops gained further ground in violent fighting on the Stalingrad front, the German High Command announced yesterday, according to German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York.

Tallulah Bankhead, whose last screen appearance was in "Faithless" in 1932, will be one of the several stars who will appear in Sol Lesser's production. "Stage Door Canteen." All profits from the film will be turned over to the famous recreation center, which is operated in New York by the American Theatre Wing. . . . Alma Carroll, Columbia starlet, will have her first leading role in that studio's "Prairie Thunder," opposite Russel Hayden.

LONDON, Tuesday, Sept. 8 -- The United States Flying Fortresses yesterday bombed shipyards at Rotterdam and rail yards at Utrecht in the Netherlands and more than paid back the Nazis for the enemy's destruction of two Fortress planes Sunday by shooting down, with the aid of Allied fighter escorts, at least twelve Nazi planes at the cost of one Allied fighter.

An appeal to the "leisure class woman" to contribute her time and talent to the hospitals of New York by serving as a nurse's aide was made yesterday by Mrs. William Rothholz, volunteer chairman of the nurses' aide service for the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross.

Federal Government price control is waging a more successful battle against inflation than was fought in the corresponding period of the first World War, the Office of War Information asserted yesterday. "Inflationary forces," said the office, "so briskly at work during World War I, are even more active today," but are being more effectively combated.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 7 -- Bertil Svahnstroem, Berlin correspondent of the Stockholm Tidningen, has been invited to leave the Reich, it was learned today. Mr. Svahnstroem is the third Swedish correspondent to attract the disfavor of the German Propaganda authorities this year.

OMAHA, Sept. 7 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, predicted today that American workers would accept the sacrifices involved in President Roosevelt's new program for wage stabilization and farm price control "for their own ultimate good and the nation's welfare."

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 7 -- Twenty-five thousand persons today attended Labor Day ceremonies at Seaside Park at which a Vought-Sikorsky Corsair fighter plane bought by the workers of this arms production center was presented to the Navy.

Advanced training for women in chemical engineering and metallurgy, leading to a degree of Master of Arts, will be started at Columbia University "to prepare women for the increasingly important place they will occupy in the engineering sciences," it was announced yesterday by Dean George B. Pegram of the graduate faculties.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7 -- New depths were found by the Phils at Shibe Park today with the aid of the Giants. By conquering Hans Lobert's harassed band in both ends of a double-header, Mel Ott's team swept the Phils to their thirteenth straight defeat, a new back-sliding mark for the National League season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The Navy authorized today the immediate probationary commissioning of an unlimited number of private pilots between the ages of 19 and 32 years, inclusive, who are not eligible for regular commissions as naval aviators because of marital status, minor physical defects or age.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The Office of Defense Transportation moved today to get more service from available tank cars by extending its tank car permit system and shifting the burden of the Eastward long-haul petroleum movement to larger cars.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 7 -- Income from State tax collections throughout the nation has increased a quarter of a billion dollars annually each year for the last three years and the upward trend is expected to continue in spite of the fall in gasoline and motor vehicle tax revenues, Dr. Mabel L. Walker reported today before the Governmental Research Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Several small Japanese detachments attempting landings on the swampy western reaches of Guadalcanal Island, in the Solomons have suffered heavy losses in attacks by United States planes, it was announced by the Navy tonight.

While the detinning plant handling New York's tin cans is ready to take care of unprocessed or "green" cans, this is a purely local situation that does not apply to the other communities throughout New York State and New Jersey, George Sutherland, Regional Salvage Manager for the War Production Board, declared yesterday.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The German Army, turned back or held on the northwestern and southwestern approaches to Stalingrad, has attacked frontally and driven a wedge into one sector west of the Volga city, the Russian High Command announced today.
AN EAST COAST PORT, Sept. 7 -- The heroic story of the American Volunteer Group's air battles against the Japanese was related here today when several score A.V.G. fliers arrived from the Far East.
WASHINGTON, Sept 7 -- Captive and beleaguered cities of Europe received Labor Day greetings by short-wave radio today from "namesake" cities and towns in the United States.

Two taxpayers occupied by the Safeway Stores, Inc., the one-story building at 553 West Side Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., and the one-story building at 101 North Broadway, South Amboy, have been bought for investment by the Cranston Realty Corporation.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 7 (AP) -- Showing more stamina than usual, the King Ranch's Salto, a 3-year-old son of Neddie, won the $10,000 added Jersey Handicap before a record crowd of 37,647 at Garden State Park today. Salto, with Warren Mehrtens up, not only led throughout the mile and a furlong, but set a new track record of 1:49 4/5.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 7 (AP) -- C.C. Van Meter's 2-year-old Ogma more than doubled his earnings for ten previous starts today when he won the James H. Connors' Memorial Stake by a length from Harry Barnett's Medid before a holiday crowd of almost 40,000 at Narragansett Park.

BASEL, Switzerland, Sept. 7 (AP) -- The Bank for International Settlements said today that financial and commercial cooperation in the peace arrangement to come must be extensive if the world is to avoid the errors which proved so harmful in 1918.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 7 -- Plans have been completed for the annual rummage sale in behalf of the Southampton Fresh Air Home for Crippled Children, to be held Thursday afternoon in the auditorium of the parochial school in Hill Street.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- With the fifty-fifth annual Fall regatta today, the Larchmont Yacht Club figures reached a total of exactly 1,300 starting craft for the season. That included eighty-six this afternoon. The top mark was 177 during a special regatta on Aug. 1.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 7 -- Plans have been completed for the annual rummage sale in behalf of the Southampton Fresh Air Home for Crippled Children, to be held Thursday afternoon in the auditorium of the parochial school in Hill Street.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- With the fifty-fifth annual Fall regatta today, the Larchmont Yacht Club figures reached a total of exactly 1,300 starting craft for the season. That included eighty-six this afternoon. The top mark was 177 during a special regatta on Aug. 1.

That play Moss Hart has been mulling over at his Bucks County estate turns out to be a dramatization of Howard Melvin Fast's novel "The Unvanquished." According to Charles Duell of the publishing firm of Duell, Sloan Pearce, Mr. Fast's story, in which George Washington is the central character, has sold 120,000 copies since publication last June.

After a closed hearing in his chambers, Supreme Court Justice Kenneth O'Brien reserved decision yesterday in the suit to determine whether State Senator Charles Muzzicato must remain as American Labor candidate for re-election to the Senate while running at the same time as Republican candidate for representative at large.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chairman, ruled today that it would be "entirely proper" for war workers of the Jewish faith to remain at home to observe the approaching Jewish holidays. In response to a letter written him by Dr. Israel Goldstein of New York City, president of the Synagogue Council of America, Mr. Nelson wrote:

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 8 -- Darrell Clingman, sensational apprentice jockey, drove home three winners at Garden State Park today, including Robert Curran's Flashalong in the mile and sixteenth Penns Grove Purse, before a crowd of 6,686.

Gowns for the woman who has given up her pre-war leisure were shown yesterday by Bloomingdale's. The dressy daytime frock, street-length dinner gowns and simple evening ensembles for both formal or informal wear answered the need for all-occasion use.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Senate Finance Committee, after about five minutes of formal consideration, rejected today, 12 to 0, the Treasury's proposal of a tax on spending, for which Secretary Morgenthau issued a special appeal Saturday, and focused favorable attention on a new "Victory Tax" instead.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The nation's cotton farmers, assisted by unusually favorable weather, are growing more pounds of lint cotton to the acre than ever before, it was indicated today by a Department of Agriculture forecast that 23,273,000 acres for harvest would yield 14,028,000 bales this year.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Another step in the promotion of good-will between United States and British troops was taken today with an announcement by Brendan Bracken, Minister of Information, that his Ministry has taken full charge of all British arrangements for entertaining members of the United States forces in Britain.

LONDON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Many Catholic leaders in unoccupied France are sheltering children of Jews, and their defiance of orders to surrender them has brought about an open rift between the Vichy government and priests, the Fighting French Press Service said today.

The United States commented on the Nazi submarine campaign on Labor Day by launching 174 ships, mostly naval vessels, but including a number of cargo carriers, and laying down the keels for forty-nine more. We are producing the means with which to sink or drive away the undersea commerce raiders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Commodity Credit Corporation announced today prices that refiners are to pay for crude cottonseed, peanut and soy bean oil under terms of a contract designed to facilitate processing of this year's record production.

So much had been published on the predicted overflow of visitors to this city on Labor Day that groups of pickpockets from other cities, including Pittsburgh, Boston, Philadelphia and Newark, hied themselves here in advance in anticipation of a harvest.

DETROIT, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Browns put together five straight singles for three runs in the fifth inning today and these, combined with Walter Judnich's homer in the fourth and Steve Sundra's four-hit pitching, gave St. Louis a 4-to-1 victory over the Tigers and an even break for their twenty-two games this season.

In your editorial "Yanks on Parade," in your issue of Sept. 4, you state that the first parade of American units in London during the last war was on May 11, 1918. As a member of the Fourteenth Engineers in World War I, I would like to point out that this date is inaccurate approximately by nine months.

Leaders of Catholic social action in the Western Hemisphere are striving to "stem the tide of destruction and despotism afflicting society" and are seeking "the positive and far-sighted tasks of social reconstruction in the midst of the world conflict," Mgr. Michael J. Ready, director of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, declared yesterday at the opening session of the Inter-American Seminar in this city.

BUFFALO, Sept. 8 -- Experiments on animals showing that the normal span of life could be stretched out considerably by the ingestion of a diet low in calories and high in the quality of its nutritional elements, proteins, minerals and vitamins, were described here today before the semi-annual meeting of the American Chemical Society.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 8 -- Mrs. Alice W. Parsons, who disappeared mysteriously from her home in Stony Brook on June 9, 1937, is still listed as missing and it is not known whether she is alive or dead, according to papers filed today in the Suffolk County Surrogate's Court here.

Thirteen disloyal United States citizens of German origin were deprived of their acquired citizenship yesterday by Federal Judge Edward A. Conger, after seven had failed to oppose denaturalization proceedings, five had consented to this action and one actually requested denaturalization.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8 -- The Federal Government moved against an asserted $12,000,000 lottery combination operating in three countries of the Americas today on the basis of indictments returned by the San Francisco grand jury.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 7 (Delayed) -- Wendell L. Willkie told Allied correspondents and forty Turkish journalists today that "Rommel was stopped cold and hurled back" by the superior generalship of Lieut. Gen. Bernard L. Montgomery, commander of the British Eighth Army, and the powerful combination of Allied air and ground striking force.

Judging by the size of the squad that departed for Bear Mountain Inn yesterday afternoon, C.C.N.Y., less familiarly known as the College of the City of New York, definitely is not one of those institutions of learning at which an accusing finger can be pointed by educators when they talk about over-emphasis of football.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Sept. 9 -- Massed German tanks, infantry and planes have made a frontal assault on Stalingrad from the west and have forced the Russians back to new defensive positions, the Soviet High Command announced today.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill reported to the House of Commons today on his journeyings since the House recessed. He left the members speechless. What had been planned for a two-day debate wound up quickly to the general satisfaction.

The enlargement both in values and volume in the stock market yesterday was the best since mid-August as traders returned to activity in greater numbers. Sales of 399,130 shares on the Stock Exchange against 309,270 on last Friday were helped by two special offerings aggregating 32,800 shares. Extreme additions in the share list exceeded 2 points with the average advance at approximately a point.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 8 -- With Costa Rica's gasoline ration for this month only three gallons, public interest was aroused here by announcement of the discovery of a formula for adding alcohol and reportedly increasing mileage by 35 per cent over that obtained in the use of pure gasoline.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- War Secretary Sir James Grigg made a statement in the House of Commons today on the total number of British prisoners of war from the three fighting services, placing the figure at 77,190 -- with several reservations.

Brooding because his wife had divorced him, John Zareko, 64 years old, of 710 New York Avenue, Union City, N.J., went to the home of his son at 108-58 Sixty-eighth Avenue, Queens, yesterday, and shot him and his mother-in-law with a .38 caliber revolver.

The President's proposals, in his message to Congress and in his fireside chat, must be considered from two aspects, the economic and the political. These two aspects, however, cannot be entirely separated. For the President implies that the differences in economic policy between himself and Congress may be so vital that he is justified in overriding the Congress, if necessary, in order that his own policy may prevail.

Designed as a practical work outfit for all women, the new "Home Front Uniform" for Bundles for America volunteers, was officially adopted yesterday by Mrs. Wales Latham, president, and shown at national headquarters, 681 Fifth Avenue.

NEWARK, Ohio, Sept. 8 (AP) -- An Army bomber with a broken wing hedge-hopped over the business district and plunged into a downtown apartment building today, killing all six occupants and a woman who chanced to be passing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Post-war credits under the Victory Tax plan would be represented by noninterest, nonnegotiable bonds issued at the end of the tax year. The bonds would be cashed in intallments after the war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Office of Defense Transportation will assume complete control Nov. 15 over every form of commercial motorized transport, from trucks to taxicabs, through an order which requires all owners to obtain certificates of war necessity in order to operate their vehicles.

The national amateur tennis championships will be carried on for the duration, if possible, to develop young players in a long-range plan to recapture the Davis Cup from Australia, tennis officials said yesterday.

The United States may have to aid in the manning of vessels of United Nations Allies who lack labor reserves, according to Marshall E. Dimock, head of the recruitment and manning office of the War Shipping Administration.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- The prediction that the transit systems of the nation will carry 18,000,000,000 passengers in 1942, breaking all records, was made here today by Charles Gordon, managing director of the American Transit Association.

It took a Labor Day in wartime to prove what everybody must have guessed -- that railroad engineers, bus chauffeurs and airplane pilots are safer drivers than the millions of car owners who in past years congested our holiday highways, and that roads are safer when fewer cars are on them.

VINELAND, N.J., Sept. 8 -- Employes of the Kimble Glass Company, the East's largest medicinal glass manufacturing concern, went on strike today, paralyzing the plant in the midst of work on Army and Navy orders.

Shipments of oil burners last month were down at least 75 per cent from the August, 1941, level, manufacturers estimated yesterday. The decline in deliveries to dealers along the Eastern seaboard was said to be much greater than the national average, reflecting the increasing seriousness of the fuel shortage in this area and the inability of oil suppliers to take on new accounts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Should a serious attack, threatening to defeat the farm prices legislation demanded by the President in his anti-inflation message yesterday, be made in Congress on his announcement that he will act himself if the law is not forthcoming by Oct. 1, plenty of support for his position can be produced from the archives.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Showing a great burst of speed inside the eighth pole, the Paragon Stable's Liste won the Swansea Purse today at Narragansett Park.

MONTREAL, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Pulp and Paper Administration of the Dominion's Wartime Prices and Trade Board continued its studies today preparatory to early announcement of allocation of newsprint making to mills in areas less pinched for manpower and electricity.
LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Prime Minister Churchill's statement to the war situation made in the House of Commons today follows:

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Addressing the House of Commons today, Prime Minister Churchill complimented General Sir Claude Auchinleck highly as "an officer of the greatest distinction and character" although he removed him from the command in the Middle East during his brief visit to Cairo when he also moved the army headquarters from Shepheard's Hotel.

Midtown manufacturing space and downtown office space figured in many of the commercial leases reported yesterday. Firms engaged in various branches of the apparel industry were listed as lessees in many of the midtown rentals.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Sept. 9 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

One more hurdle in the way of completion of the long-delayed tax bill has been cleared by the Senate Finance Committee's rejection of the Treasury's "spending tax" plan. It was remarkable that such a complex and extreme proposal should have been brought forward at this late moment in the face of the obvious need for speed in completing the tax program.

The War Production Board's action limiting future use of film raw stock to the eleven established Hollywood production companies has brought together for the first time the majority of the 2,000 small independent producers, distributors, exchange operators, exhibitors and film laboratory owners who view the WPB order as their "death warrant."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Farm price figures compiled by the Department of Agriculture showed today that major livestock and dairy products were selling above parity prices -- 137 per cent of that figure in the case of beef cattle -- whereas leading grains and cotton had not yet reached the theoretical fair price.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Washington overcame Boston in a hitting lest today, 15 -- 11. The Senators collected eighteen hits off Oscar Judd, Charlie Wagner, Mace Brown and Mike Ryba. The Red Sox got seventeen off Ray Scarborough and Alex Carrasquel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Congressional machinery was set in motion today in response to President Roosevelt's ultimatum that he would act under his war powers unless legislative authorization for inflation controls in agriculture was adopted by Oct. 1.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The Army will send on tour within a few days a grimly realistic "show" demonstrating types of damage that may be expected in an air raid and the officially approved methods of combatting this damage.

The gist of President Roosevelt's little Labor Day lecture on inflation was given in a brief Washington forecast the night before. Item number 1 is thus summed up: "Money, by itself, has no value. You cannot eat it or wear it. The only value of money is what you can buy with it."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- A warning was issued today to converters of finished piece goods that they must make refunds of any overcharges they may make while awaiting rulings on petitions filed with the Office of Price Administration.

A mural encircling the rotunda of the Seaplane Terminal Building of La Guardia Field now serves as a cheerful greeting for overseas passengers. James Brooks, a WPA non-relief employe, finished his project last Thursday, after three years of work.

ALBANY, Sept. 8 -- Governor Lehman told delegates to the annual convention of the United Office and Professional Workers (C.I.O.) that while it had become necessary in the war effort to waive certain standards, he emphasized that "in every such instance the steps that have been taken were of a purely temporary character and for the purpose of meeting specific war exigencies."

A German broadcast, recorded by The United Press in New York yesterday, reported that Colonel Nakao Yahao, Japanese Army press chief, had said that the war between Japan and the United States might last many years and would end with the complete defeat of one of them.
The second swearing in of future Waves ensigns took place yesterday at the New York office of Naval Officer Procurement, 33 Pine Street.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 8 (U.P.) -- P.S. Foo, Chinese military spokesman, said today that the Japanese faced a "very serious" problem in adjusting their air force to meet demands of all occupied areas.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Naval casualties reported to next of kin in the period Aug. 13 to 30, inclusive, totaled 437, the Navy announced tonight.

WHEN "high heaven and earth ail from the prime foundation" (to think that line was written in what now seem like delightfully piping times of peace.) the human mind and the human heart can reach a saturation point in horror, doom and crisis. We should and must and will read our newspapers, magazines and books that report and clarify the world's anguish, but courage, sanity and morale. need other fare too.

Post-Labor Day activity on the New York Stock Exchange was featured yesterday by a volume of 400,000 shares and two successful special offerings, one in Woolworth and the other in Allis-Chalmers. The day also was marked by the decision of the Stock Exchange to allow a group headed by Smith, Barney Co. to market 100,000 shares of Parke, Davis Co. common as a secondary offering.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 8 -- An employe in the Kearny, N.J., plant of the Western Electric Company was accused here today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of having "discovered" a time-bomb that he himself had planted in the main factory building purportedly to show up the company's lack of vigilance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- When speaking in English for the overseas world today, the Berlin radio described President Roosevelt's radio talk last night as a "message of despair," but the same station's broadcast in German for the home audience refrained from any such optimistic view.

LONDON. Sept. 8 -- Prime Minister Churchill and other speakers in the House of Commons and also in the House of Lords paid moving tributes today to the Duke of Kent, who was lauded on all sides for his services to his country.

BUFFALO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Drafting of single men and married men without minor children for military service before induction of those with minor dependents is urged by the New York State Catholic Central Verein.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- Renewed warnings about the vital need for increased coal output and for decreased coal consumption by householders so that war industries in Britain can have all the coal they need to keep the wheels turning at top speed were sounded today by government and labor union officials alike.

The coffins of Hitler, Hirohito and Mussolini were set up again yesterday in Times Square to receive the nails of war bond purchasers as Irene Dunne, film star, appeared and urged a crowd of 5,000 to buy bonds.

With the arrest of four men and three women, detectives of the Safe and Loft Squad believed yesterday that they had solved the disappearance, over a period of two years, of $78,000 in merchandise from shipments passing through the Railway Express Agency terminal in Long Island City.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- In a recent month the Royal Air Force made thirty attacks on Axis submarines in the Eastern Atlantic and the sighting and attacking of submarines has been intensified, the Air Ministry said today. Most of the activity is in the Bay of Biscay, where U-boats run the gauntlet to and from French coastal waters.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Japanese troops Kwangtung Province have retreated to Funkai, fifteen miles north of the important coastal city of Canton, a Chinese Army spokesman said today. The Japanese, he added, at the same time have pulled back their right and left wings in that vicinity.

Notwithstanding the scarcity of guides, many hunters participated in the rail shooting along the Connecticut River the past week. Although the birds have been coming in gradually, the wild rice and oats have just begun to ripen and most hunters expect the shooting to improve within the next ten days.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Increased opportunities for women, including women doctors, were forecast today by Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, director of the Waacs, and Lieut. Comdr. Mildred McAfee, head of the Waves.

John Simonetti's Cleo Louise passed the judges in second place in the first race, but it didn't do the filly's backers any good, for she had lost Willie Day soon after the start and finished with an empty saddle. Day, caught in a jam on the rail, came out of the saddle but seemed not seriously hurt, though he planned X-rays for a possible rib injury.

Forty-four enthusiastic dancers, 16 years of age and older, cut capers ranging from the streamlined antics of the "Jitterbug Jive" to the "Oldtimer's Waltz" last night in the competition to represent Brooklyn in the finals of the Park Department Harvest Dance Contest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The United States has forged a final link in the chain of defenses protecting the Panama Canal by establishing bases on the Galapagos Islands athwart the canal's western approaches, it was disclosed today.

Pending final clarification of the controversy over ceilings on farm products, the cotton market yesterday paid little heed to a high crop estimate of the Department of Agriculture and continued hesitant. On the New York Cotton Exchange price movements were erratic as trade and mill buying were counteracted by hedging near the close that left active months 5 to 10 points lower than Saturday's final quotations.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- Washington Park today closed a rousing race meeting during which $18,443,642 was wagered in 31 days. The daily handle averaged $594,950, a staggering increase over last year's $401,611. In 1941 the total handle for 32 days was $12,851,559.

LONDON, Sept. 8 (U.P.) -- The Yugoslav Information Bureau said today that traffic on two important railroads in Croatia had been suspended, resulting in a "complete paralysis of the main military and economic communications throughout much of Yugoslavia."

Both Democratic and Republican headquarters indicated yesterday that the speaking campaign to be conducted by John J. Bennett Jr. and Thomas E. Dewey, major party nominees for Governor, would be confined to a three-week period starting around Oct. 12.

The senior watchman of the American shore has doused his glim. Boston Light went dark Monday night, not to shine again till the war is over. First lighthouse in this country, presumably on this continent, it was set up on Little Brewster Island at the entrance of Boston Harbor in 1716.

Dimitri Shostakovich, Russian composer, has been invited to be the guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for the first two weeks in November, it was learned yesterday. The invitation was sent by Arturo Toscanini at the request of Marshall Field, president of the orchestra's board of directors.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 8 -- "State and local governments should not attempt to create surpluses and reserve funds at the present time as a hedge against a port-war depression," Dr. Thomas H. Reed, municipal consultant of New York City, told delegates to the annual conference of the Governmental Research Association here today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- Fred Annon of Metropolis and Powell Crichton Jr. of Winged Foot won the Westchester P.G.A. pro-amateur best-ball tourney over the long and difficult Fenway course today with a six-under-par 32, 33 -- 65.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 7 (Delayed) -- Wendell L. Willkie, personal representative of President Roosevelt, disclosed today that 100 of General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's 290 first-line tanks were knocked out by Allied forces in the first battle of the recent Axis offensive in Egypt.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 8 -- Chairman of the Senate Robustiano Patron Costas was officially installed today in Casa Rosada, Argentine equivalent of the White House, as acting President of Argentina during the absence of President Ramon S. Castillo, who left tonight for a visit to the northern provinces and does not expect to return for at least two weeks.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept 8 -- Bomber planes of the United States Army Air Forces joined with aircraft of the Royal Air Force yesterday in another raid on Suda Bay, Crete, and set fires that were followed by big explosions along the jetties. In addition, fires that were visible sixty miles away were set at a near-by airdrome.

A front-running victory by the Mill River Stable's Fair Call in the fifth race and disqualification of the Brookmeade Stable's Smiles from first place in the sixth featured the racing yesterday at Aqueduct, where 10,353 followed the record-breaking crowd of Labor Day and sent $672,835 through the part-mutuer machines.

In the rear of the pastry shop is a ridiculously small counter and behind the counter is a pale-green wall and beyond the wall is an oven-lined kitchen. There three busy bakers, wearing top-heavy hats and plying a trade that is nearer an art, crowd a little room to capacity.

Terms on the $3,000,000,000 of new government financing are expected to be announced before the end of this week. As usual, before deciding on an offering of securities of this magnitude, the Treasury Department has conferred with the Open Market Committee of the Federal Reserve System, the Federal Reserve Board itself, and with representatives of commercial banks and insurance companies.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- While Westchester and Putnam Counties were staging a surprise blackout and air raid mobilization tonight on orders from Major Gen. William N. Haskell, Director of Civilian Protection, at Albany, the city of Mount Vernon did not participate in the test.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 8 (U.P.) -- Gregorio Cardenas Hernandez, 27-year-old chemistry student, who "hates all women," has confessed killing four young women whose bodies were dug out of graves in the garden of his home. Police Investigator Jose Acosta Suarez said tonight.

The suggestion in the late news items to gather and destroy for their metal contents national statues and monuments is one to be dealt with cautiously. The very thought appears repulsive to the sensitive heart. One can just imagine Gettysburg National Park divested of monuments and statues, representing, as they do, freedom and democracy, ideals for which we are now at war and subscribed to and made possible by children's pennies and public subscription.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 8 -- Nothing but the blackened ruins of deserted towns and villages greet the Chinese troops who are reoccupying areas in the wake of the Japanese retreat from Kiangsi and Chekiang, according to a Chinese war correspondent's report Corpses line the streets.

The Dodgers wasted little time with the Pirates yesterday. They polished them off in a hurry before a ladies' day crowd of 17,105 at Ebbets Field, doing the job with such rapidity and facility that Frank Frisch actually was speechless.
Vinnie Rossano, 152 pounds, Red Hook, pummeled his way to a decision over Artie Dorrell, 148 3/4, of Tyler, Texas, in the star bout of eight rounds at the Queensboro Arena last night.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Sept. 9 (AP) -- A communique:

Murray W. Stand, former majority leader of the old Board of Aldermen, was sworn in by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday as Deputy City Clerk to succeed Philip A. Hines, who resigned last Thursday.

I have been rather surprised to see no reference to Tennyson's remarkable forecast in "Locksley Hall," written more than one hundred years ago, and seventy years, nearly, before the Wright brothers made their flight. Here it is:

MOSCOW, Sept. 8 -- Whether the shifting of the main fighting to the sector west of Stalingrad indicates a shortening or an extension of General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock's front was not clear from available reports here today. The increasing liveliness of the defenders in the northwestern sector at the end of last week may have forced the German commander to probe in a new direction.

Every person must begin to think of controls over civilian activities in "terms of what it takes to lick the enemy" and must give willing compliance, Price Administrator Leon Henderson asserted yesterday, declaring that "this nation -and I hate to say it -- has not yet chosen between victory and personal profit."

The British War Relief Society's efforts to obtain much-needed clothing to send to English children and adult war victims are handicapped by a widespread but mistaken belief that cargo space is unavailable for shipment of relief supplies to Britain, it was said yesterday by Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the society.

Billy Conn will have his second chance at the heavyweight championship of the world this year, after all. The Pittsburgh fighter, who came close to dethroning Joe Louis a year ago last June, was notified yesterday by the United States Army that he would be permitted to meet Louis on Oct. 12.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Leo T. Crowley, Alien Property Custodian, stated today that he has seized enemy interests in the George Ehret Breweries, Inc., of 193 Melrose Street, Brooklyn. Seizure of enemy interests in thirteen other business enterprises in the New York area was also announced, including such interests as the George Ehret Properties, Inc., 60 Broadway, Manhattan, a company organized as a real estate and mortgage management company.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 8 -- An advance force of seventy-five British seamen, the first of "several thousand" due to arrive in the next few weeks, moved into the Monterey and Berkeley Carteret Hotels on the beachfront here today.

William Power Maloney, special Federal prosecutor, who in July obtained the indictment of twenty-eight persons for conspiracy to lower the morale of the armed forces, made a sudden appearance yesterday at proceedings to remove two of the group to Washington.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Joseph M. Schenck, former chairman of the board of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, was released yesterday from the United States correctional institution here after having served four months and five days of his one year and one day sentence on his plea of guilty to a perjury charge.

GENEVA, N.Y., Sept. 8 (AP) -- This city took roughly 155 years to attain a population of 15,555, but ten miles south, the government, in less than six months has built a "sister city" where 40,000 will live.

The Tokyo radio quoted Japanese military observers last night as saying that the fall of Stalingrad was imminent, and that "an epochal degeneration of Soviet fighting power will follow," according to a Japanese broadcast recorded in New York by The Associated Press.

Mayor La Guardia agreed yesterday to recommend that the city comply with a request recently made by the Board of Higher Education to make available $100,000 needed to pay 257 teachers in City, Hunter and Brooklyn Colleges mandatory salary increments that have been denied them since 1935.

OYSTER MAY, L.I., Sept. 8 -- Mohannes, estate of Major and Mrs. Kermit Roosevelt in Cove Neck, close to Sagamore Hill, the one-time Summer White House when Major Roosevelt's father, Theodore Roosevelt, was President, was formally dedicated this afternoon to the United Seaman's Service, Inc., as a convalescent home for torpedoed merchant seamen.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- General buying developed in wheat on the Board of Trade today, traders construing the President's anti-inflation talk as bullish as it provided that grains and other agricultural products could sell at full parity prices and that floors might be put under the market.

The emphasis in the President's speech was on "toughness." Are we tough enough to meet the challenge of the "toughest war of all time"? This is what Mr. Roosevelt asked; it is what critics of the administration of the war have demanded when they have called upon the administrators to "get tough."

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- The people of the Island of Malta were praised today for their courage by speakers here, who called on persons living in the British Isles to profit from the example of those inhabiting the "unsinkable fortress" in the Mediterranean.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 -- An assertion that uncontrolled wages were the most threatening factor in the possibilities for inflation and farm prices were only a minor factor, was made today by Edward A. O'Neal, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman yesterday afternoon dedicated the new home of Cathedral College at 555 West End Avenue, the seven-story building formerly occupied by St. Agatha's Episcopal School for Girls. The structure was remodeled recently with a gift of $150,000 from the McCaddin-McQuirk Foundation and will accommodate 500 students.

Over 200,000,000 separate advertisements will appear in daily newspapers throughout the country and in a national Sunday supplement with a circulation of 7,700,000 on behalf of Tintex tints and dyes, according to Park Tilford.

Immediate effects of the recently announced WPB inventory control plan were lacking in the wholesale markets here yesterday. Activity was brisk, reflecting the accumulation of orders over the Labor Day holiday and the start of the Fall retail season, but there appeared no developments directly traceable to the WPB announcement.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- A remarkable decline in death rates for influenza and penumonia in the forty years ending with 1940 is shown in a mortality study issued today by the Bureau of the Census. The death rate stood at 202.2 per 100,000 of population in 1900 and had dropped to 70.3 in 1940, the lowest rate ever recorded for the United States.

The Brown Fence and Wire Company, which conducts a mail-order business in fencing and farm supplies, reported yesterday a net profit of $302,891 for the fiscal year ended on June 30. This is after a provision of $377,831 for Federal income and excess profits taxes and $50,000 for inventory contingencies and is equivalent to 38 cents each on 279,764 shares of common stock after annual dividend requirements on 98,364 shares of Class A stock.

DETROIT, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Western All-Army team seemingly thrives on hard work, for it tuned up for tomorrow night's charity battle with Detroit of the National Football League by ripping through a two-hour drill today that included rough-and-tumble contact work.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 8 -- American soldiers fighting on all fronts are setting an example for the Mexican Army, Foreign Minister Ezequiel Padilla declared today. He said Mexico was putting every ounce of strength into her preparations for an emergency on national territory.

For a few tense moments yesterday, fear gripped the hearts of the fashion writers. Floating around the smart salon on East Forty-ninth Street was a dread rumor. Hattie Carnegie, dictator to the sophisticate and queen among style creators, was talking in the fashion idiom of the day, it was reported.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 8 -- Haulage of freight, including war goods, between the metropolitan area and Pennsylvania and New England was held up today by a stoppage called by the drivers of two trucking companies with headquarters here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Captain Fritz Wiedemann, former German Consul General in San Francisco, who since has been stationed in Japan, and Admiral Shigetaro Shimada, the Japanese Navy Minister, were severely burned in the derailment by sabotage of the Japanese fast express train Sakura on July 3, according to a report from agents of "Euridan," Korean terrorist organization, made public today by Kilsco K. Haan, representative here of the Sino-Korean Peoples League.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 -- Guests who attended the wedding reception of Miss Katharine Drexel Van Pelt in Radnor were robbed of $10,000 worth of jewelry by a "crasher," it was disclosed today.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- The home rails and shipping issues provided the chief features in the stock markets today. Southern rose 1 1/4, Great Western 3/8, London, Midland Scottish 1/2 and London North Eastern 1/4 point.

It's a far cry from caissons to coiffures -- but there's a relation between them, all the same. For the smooth, new hair-do's that will grace feminine heads this Autumn are a direct reflection of the rubber shortage. Because the same indispensable commodity that now is needed to tread the tires of Army trucks formed a strategic part of last season's chapeaux.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 8 -- Engineers, contractors, architects and business men are streaming toward China's long-neglected hinterland as a result of the governments call for intensified economic reconstruction in the northwest.
Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday at the dedication of a new playground at Park Avenue and Floyd Street, Brooklyn, that this city had the largest post-war program of any city in the country.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 8 -- Between Church and State in France a struggle impends that may have far-reaching consequences and place Chief of State Marshal Henri Philippe Petain himself in a difficult position.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Copper companies and Army-operated facilities were included for the first time today in industrial establishments selected to receive the joint Army-Navy Production Award for outstanding performance of war work.

Registrations of out-of-town buyers in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 386, which compared with 829 in the preceding week and 1,201 in the similar period a year ago, which did not include Labor Day, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

OTTAWA, Sept. 8 -- Canada's war fortunes are so closely tied with those of the United States that the policy outlined by President Roosevelt yesterday in his message to Congress and his radio talk are being studied here with the closest interest and with general approval.
WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCES, Somewhere in England, Sept. 8 (AP) - "Just like shooting squirrels back in Arkansas."

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, Sept. 9 -- Our fighter planes bombed and strafed the Japanese invaders in the Kokoda-Myola area of New Guinea yesterday, but operations on the ground were static, it was revealed in a communique issued today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- President William Green of the A. F. of L. said his organization "supports the President's program to stabilize the cost of living for the duration of the war."

One of the largest issues of notes to be announced in several weeks was disclosed yesterday by Fresno County, California. The issue is for $1,300,000 and will mature on Dec. 31, 1942. Sealed tenders on this issue will be opened on Friday.

A new ban by James C. PetriUo, president of the American Federation of usieians, has been placed against the manufacture of electrical transcriptions intended for fuse only once on the radio, it was disclosed yesterday. There were i !immediate protests by advertisers, i advertising agencies, radio officials and transcription company executives at a special meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt.

To Howard K. Smith's "Last Train From Berlin," published yesterday, a sort of postscript is sent out by the publishers. It is a letter in which the author and radio correspondent apologizes for having had no notes when he wrote the book.

WESTBURY, L.L., Sept. 8 -- Helped by a double eagle 2 by Tom Curtis, Salisbury, at the fourth, the team of Curtis and Ernie Catropa tied at 67 with Joe Katz and R.C. MacDonald, Kissena, for top honors in the one day amateur-pro golf tourney of the Long Island P. G. A. at the Salisbury links today.
MOSCOW, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 2, the Federal Reserve System announced today: Decreases of $61,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, $153,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $498,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and an increase of $22,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

ALBANY, Sept. 8 -- Governor Lehman today gave the State's official greetings and extended the best wishes of all its citizens to the "victory bondmobile" contingent on its way to Buffalo to push effigies of Hitler, Hirohito and Mussolini over Niagara Falls.

LONDON, Sept. 8 -- During his report to the House of Commons today Prime Minister Churchill disclosed a "secret" so old and so well known here that it almost had been forgotten that it was ever a hidden fact of the war. That is that in July, before Mr. Churchill went to Cairo and Moscow, Harry L. Hopkins, General George C. Marshall and Admiral Ernest J. King visited London.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- American farmers were called upon today by the Department of Agriculture to elect farm women as well as men to county and community committees to administer the Agricultural Adjustment Administration's farm program next year.

TOMAH, Wis., Sept. 8 (AP) -- Miss Neil John Pietrangeli, a social welfare worker, and Miss Dorothy Baun, a State probation clerk, stripped of clothing and robbed of their car, were shot to death today and left lying in a wooded area near Oakdale, eight miles east of here.

German propaganda delivered a sharp attack yesterday upon neutral Sweden, a Berlin Transocean broadcast quoting German Foreign Office circles as saying that "Sweden has the honor of being at present the active central Comintern in Europe."

CHUNGKING, China. Sept. 8 (Reuter) -- It is now clear that the Japanese have halted their withdrawal in Eastern China. They are throwing reinforcements lavishly into the battle for Kinhwa, capital of Chekiang Province and last remaining "bomb Tokyo" air base in their hands.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (AP) -- The Indians defeated the White Sox, 10 to 0, today, but the second game was postponed and will be played either Sept. 24 or 25 in Cleveland, when the White Sox visit there for the last time this season.

G.A. Eastwood, president of Armour Co. of Illinois, has sent to stockholders a letter explaining that, while it is the policy of the directors to pay dividends when currently earned, they decided at their meeting on Sept. 2 to omit dividends on the company's shares pending a resumption of satisfactory earnings and improvement in the business outlook.
Commercial bank depositories of the United States Government were notified here yesterday that the Treasury Department would withdraw funds from them on Friday and Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The United States has informed Pierre Laval, French Chief of Government, through S. Pinkney Tuck, the American charge d'affaires in Vichy, that American aviators will continue to bomb German military properties in France at every opportunity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- These tables show how the proposed 5 per cent "Victory" tax would affect individuals when added to the income tax rates established in the new revenue bill as it passed the House:

LONDON, Wednesday, Sept 9 -- During daylight yesterday Bostons escorted by fighters went across the Channel in an unclouded sky and bombed docks at Havre. Later other escorted Bostons bombed docks at Cherbourg. Two British fighters were missing after these operations.

BALTIiViORE, Sept. 8 -- Representatives of thirty-four national organizations of women will meet here tomorrow to discuss with War Department officials and with each other, Army problems and the ways in which women can best cooperate with the armed services.

John Bridge, in his letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Sept. 6, disapproves of Sir Stafford Cripps's article because he devotes himself to (1) a justification of British policy in India and (2) an attempt to make Mr. Gandhi the villain of the piece.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 8 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has signed Kay Kyser and his band to appear in "Right About Face," a prize-fight story by Matt Brooks and Joseph Hoffman, which was previously announced for George Murphy, Donna Reed and Jean Rogers.

Because of the "almost complete cessation" of commercial shipping to South Africa from the Port of New York a "vast quantity" of such shipments has been accumulating in piers and warehouses here, it was learned in the trade yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The United States has informed Pierre Laval, French Chief of Government, through S. Pinkney Tuck, the American charge d'affaires in Vichy, that American aviators will continue to bomb German military properties in France at every opportunity.

WELL, it's set now. The big bout for the heavyweight championship is coming off on Oct. 12. Champion Joe Louis vs. Challenger Billy Conn. Two soldiers of the Army of the United States, Corporal Joe Louis and Private Billy Conn, will meet to dispute the supremacy of the boxing ring on Columbus Day, and every nickel above the bare expenses of staging the bout will go to Army Emergency Relief.

LONDON, Sept. 8 (AP) -- A credit agreement under which Russia may draw up to approximately 9,000,000 bushels of hard Spring wheat or flour was signed at Canada House today by representatives of the Canadian and Soviet Governments.
Joseph Durst, operator and realty dealer, of 358 Fifth Avenue, has acquired a large interest in the seventeen-story loft building at 250 West Thirty-ninth Street in a deal with Over-All Realty, Inc.

Broadway first-run theatres played to capacity over the Labor Day week-end, according to reports by the respective managements yesterday. At the Radio City Music Hall, where "The Talk of the Town" is in its second week, 120,000 persons attended for a gross of approximately $85,000 during the five-day period ended Monday night.

VICHY, France, Sept. 8 (UP) -Reports from occupied France said tonight that 162 persons were killed and more than 500 wounded in the raid on the Rouen area by United States Army Flying Fortresses Saturday. German troops, cooperating with local firemen, removed the last bodies from wrecked buildings today, it was reported.

The speaker was Steve Owen, the portly coach of the New York Football Giants. The "he" referred to was Al Blozis. The Giants had just concluded a two-and-a-half-hour workout at Baker Field yesterday as they went through their paces in preparation for Saturday's benefit game with the Eastern All-Army squad at the Polo Grounds.

Today is the tenth anniversary of the city's Independent Subway System, now known as the IND division of the unified network of subway, elevated, street car and bus lines created when transit unification was achieved.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- This city of 58,000 residents completed tonight an experiment in voluntary policing of itself for enforcement of retail price ceilings set by the Office of Price Administration.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Commander Arthur J. White, one of this war's previously undisclosed heroes and a survivor of the aircraft carrier Lexington, received the Navy Cross today during simple ceremonies at the Naval Academy.

Neither the Dodgers nor the Cardinals played yesterday, one by design and the other by accident. The Brooks had an open date while they contemplated their three-game lead and made ready for today's joust with the Cubs at Ebbets Field.

Reports in the women's apparel markets yesterday agreed that better quality merchandise was moving actively at retail. Both defense workers and those in non-defense areas were said to be stepping up their purchases by several price ranges in the belief the garments they were purchasing "must serve for the duration."

A plan designed to assure an equitable share of fuel oil to consumers during the Winter through the pooling of products, facilities and transportation of oil companies and jobbers throughout the Eastern seaboard has been presented to Secretary Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator, it became known yesterday.

BUFFALO, Sept. 9 -- Synthetic rubber at the rate of 1,000,000 tons a year will be pouring out of great plants, now being built by American industrial and chemical genius, by November, 1943, as an answer to the challenge of our enemies, the American Chemical Society was told today in the first comprehensive statement on the subject to be issued by the War Production Board.

New issues of notes aggregating $45,614,000 were sold yesterday by nine local housing authorities in various parts of the country. Sales were conducted through competitive bidding, and $42,614,000 of the notes went to the Chemical Bank and Trust Company.

With the United Service Organizations sharing in the proceeds, and a champion making what may be his last appearance in a ring for the duration, Freddie (Red) Cochrane and Fritzie Zivic will come together at Madison Square Garden tonight in a ten-round, non-title welterweight battle.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Sept. 10 -- Massed German tanks and infantry smashing in a frontal assault toward the western gates of Stalingrad forced the Red Army to give up two more populated places in the third Russian retreat in as many days, an official announcement said early today.

The program of the Legion of Decency, directed by the hierarchy of the Catholic Church for the establishment of high moral standards in motion pictures, received the approval of delegates to the Inter-American Seminar on Social Studies, which is in session this week at the Park Lane Hotel.

By a coincidence more spectacular than Hugo could have conceived, the voice of the true France this week has answered the voice of the slanderer and betrayer of France. Yesterday Jules Jeanneny, President of the French Senate, and Edouard Herriot, President of the Chamber of Deputies, flung in Vichy's teeth their reply to the decree which was supposed to wipe out the French Parliament.

GENERAL M'ARTHUR'S HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Nine United States Army Air Force officers received today Distinguished Service Crosses for "extraordinary heroism in action" on battlefronts from the Philippines to Australia.

Fort Jay on Governors Island will be the scene Oct. 7 of the first game between Samuel Reshevsky and Isaac I. Kashdan to decide the tie between them for first place in this year's national chess championship tournament, which was played at the Hotel Astor, according to an agreement signed by them yesterday.

Mr. Petrillo's conquests, like those of every dictator, only whet his appetite for further conquests. This private individual, having ordered a school band off the air, having ordered the country's musicians not to make records to be played over the radio or in public places, has now placed a ban even against the manufacture of electrical transcriptions intended for use only once on the radio.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Phil Marchildon, taking over in the ninth, notched his seventeenth victory tonight as the cellar-dwelling Athletics edged out the Indians, 5 to 4, in a thirteen-inning battle.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 9 -- Dr. Towne Nylander, who for five years was Southern California-Arizona director for the National Labor Relations Board, is now a seaman working on a merchant marine freighter in the Pacific, some of his friends said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- A spokesman for Wendell Lund, labor production director of the War Production Board, said today that, at Mr. Lund's request, Roy Reuther, former official of the United Autmobile Workers Union, had been released from the Army to resume a post under Mr. Lund as a field representative.

WASHINGTON, Sept 9 -- "Fancy" shoes will be fewer in the well-dressed family's wardrobe next year. The War Production Board, in a move designed to save leather, issued an order today prohibiting the manufacture of two-color shoes and reduced the variety of colors and styles of footwear to be made for Spring and Summer consumption in 1943. However, no limit will be put upon the production of permitted styles to fill civilian needs.

A duplex penthouse apartment in 145 West Fifty-fifth Street has been leased by Miss Mary Van Kirk, star of the Metropolitan Opera, through E. Shea Carline, broker, who also rented a duplex garden apartment in 154 East Thirty-seventh Street to Captain Ira Genet.

A carload of New Mexico carrots, worth $1,557 at current market prices, was auctioned off for $13,000 yesterday to produce dealers downtown who chose this means of contributing to the New York Bataan Relief Committee. Mark S. Yeckes, chairman of the committee, said the proceeds will be used to get supplies and medical equipment to American soldiers captured at Bataan and Corregidor.
LONDON, Sept. 9 -- Favorable war news and Prime Minister Winston Churchill's speech yesterday cheered the stock markets today. Shipping issues especially went further ahead.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- With the statement that the war is one largely of transportation, the American Transit Association, in convention here, pledged today its wholehearted cooperation with the Office of Defense Transportation and other government agencies.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Sept. 9 -- The first women anti-aircraft troops are now in training here at the radio-location wing of the artillery school, it was learned today. This move caps the long-term expansion of anti-aircraft defenses and gives women the task of operating artillery predictors.
Local boards in New York State were advised yesterday by Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, State draft director, of the "vital need of safeguarding the labor problems of expanding war industries."
Personal letter to New York women, 20-45 years of age, with better than high school education:
W. Averell Harriman's address last night on the Churchill-Stalin conference follows:

In the midst of final preparations for tonight's United Service Organizations benefit bouts at Madison Square Garden, Mike Jacobs yesterday confirmed the fact he would become a civilian consultant to the Army after the Joe Louis-Billy Conn bout on Oct. 12.

Nine members of the motor transport division of the American Women's Voluntary Services, all in the light blue uniform of the organization, were enrolled yesterday as auxiliaries in the Waac. The oath of induction was administered to them at Army Recruiting Headquarters, 39 Whitehall Street, by Second Lieutenant James L. Munson, Waac procurement adjutant.
