WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The President has publicly announced the view that his constitutional duty and power to prevent a domestic disaster, endangering our military success, supervene statutes that in his judgment invite this disaster: specifically, the 110-116 farm price parity act passed by the present Congress.

ALBANY, Sept. 9 -- The United Office and Professional Workers of America, C.I.O., adopted unanimously today a resolution condemning "the assault on the rights of minority political parties in New York State by the American Legion, which is trying to bar the Communist party from the ballot."

Luxurious trimmings, formerly confined to the formal corner of milady's wardrobe, have supplied one of the newest fashion notes of the current season. Their use on gowns for every occasion took the spotlight yesterday in Altman's Autumn collection.

For the first time since they began practice at Superior, Wis. more than a month ago, the New York Football Giants had an opportunity at Baker Field yesterday to drill with a wet ball and on a wet gridiron. So they did not neglect the chance which was offered them, working outdoors for more than an hour.

While steel output in August was the fourth largest for any month on record, the rate of production during the month was less than the average rate in the first two quarters of 1942 and 1941 and in the final quarter of 1941, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Flames swept the Navy transport Wakefield, formerly the $10,000,000 luxury liner Manhattan, as she was returning to the United States from Europe in convoy last Thursday night, the Navy disclosed yesterday. After two hours of heroic work had failed to halt the blaze, escorting warships took off 1,600 passengers and crew without the loss of a single life.

MOSCOW, Sept. 9 -- British Prime Minister Winston Churchill's statement in Parliament indicating a disagreement between himself and Premier Joseph Stalin during their conversations here was published in Moscow newspapers without comment today, but it strengthened the Russian belief -- correctly or incorrectly -- that there was little prospect of an early second front.

For the greater convenience of retailers, wholesalers and manufacturers in the metropolitan area, a New York district price office, manned by merchandising specialists and attorneys who will give information on OPA price regulations, was opened yesterday at the headquarters of Lee S. Buckingham, New York State director of the Office of Price Administration, at 535 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Federal Power Commission announced today that it had dissolved a stay of its order of June 9 requiring the Niagara Falls Power Company to charge to earned surplus more than $15,000,000 in write-ups in its accounts.

A man who until a few days ago had been known to many airplane production workers as a bus-line employe was branded as a major spy for the Nazis yesterday by P.E. Foxworth, assistant director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

A funeral service for William Morgan Kingsley, chairman of the board of the United States Trust Company of New York and a leader in educational and religious fields in this city, who died in his Summer home at Sky Top, Pa., on Monday, will be held today at 11 A.M. in the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street.

ATLANTA, Thursday, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Swinging into the home stretch with mounting votes from the cities, Attorney General Ellis Arnall overhauled Governor Talmadge early today in a sensational contest for Georgia's Gubernatorial nomination.

ON THE FRENCH FRONTIER, Sept. 9 -- The two parliamentary leaders of France, protesting against any move to draw France into war against "our allies," have warned the Vichy regime that the people will not "follow you along the path you are trying to take," advices reaching here revealed today.

With 20,000 former students and 150 faculty members of New York University now enrolled in the armed forces, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase declared yesterday that this was probably the largest representation from any college in the country.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Henry J. Kaiser, West Coast shipbuilder who has been negotiating with the government on a proposal to build cargo-carrying planes on a large scale, arrived today "to remain until a decision is reached one way or the other" on his plans.

Life insurance companies purchased $2,023,000,000 of government bonds in the first eight months of this year, bringing their holdings to more than $8,500,000,000, a new high record, Holgar J. Johnson, president of the Institute of Life Insurance, reported yesterday.

Urging that consideration of the Federal Trade Commission's proposed trade practice rules on the color fastness of textiles be postponed until after the war, Paul B. Halstead, secretary-treasurer of the Cotton Textile Institute, Inc., declared yesterday that with most cotton mills deeply engrossed in war output this is a most inappropriate time for consideration of the subject.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.L., Sept. 9 -- Race week at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club opened today under adverse conditions. The fleet of thirty-seven that sailed, for the most part within the reaches of the bay, had miserable going except for momentum.

IT'S a good thing that they gave Colonel Bob Neyland's Eastern detachment of the All-Army football team a fair time in which to run through signals on the greensward at Yale. This All-Army outfit, beginning on Saturday at the Polo Grounds, will play three games in eight days and the teams they are to meet are the Giants, the Dodgers and the Great Big Bears in that order.

LONDON, Sept. 9 (U.P.) -- Aneurin Bevan, a Laborite, rocked the House of Commons today with the most scathing attack on Winston Churchill since he became Prime Minister, charging that the war could have been won this year but "the government lacked the guts to do it."

Mr. Churchill is one of the star reporters of our time. The account he rendered to the House of Commons of his journey to Egypt and Russia was enlivened by a pen portrait of Stalin and a description of desert fighting which shows the observing eye of the man of letters as well as the appraising judgment of the statesman.

The first of a series of Statewide rallies of groups representing the United Nations will be held tonight as a group of Polish-Americans, in conjunction with the New York State war activities committee of the motion picture industry, lends its aid to the sale of bonds and stamps.
Alabama sportsmen have been discussing the merits of a good bass fisherman and they have nominated Sam DeGeorge of their State for the world's unofficial title as the best bass angler.

In his first public address since his return from attending the historic Churchill-Stalin conference in Moscow last month as President Roosevelt's personal representative. W. Averell Harriman, United States Defense Coordinator in London, declared last night that their talks had brought Prime Minister Winston Churchill and Premier Joseph Stalin closer together in a "burning hatred" of Hitler and Hitlerism that "transcends" all former political differences.

HARTFORD, Sept. 9 -- With Raymond E. Baldwin, former Governor, certain of nomination for the post he once held, it appeared tonight that the chief points of interest in the Connecticut Republican State Convention, which will convene tomorrow night in the Bushnell Memorial, will be feminine.

Mild profit-taking prevented yesterday any extension of Tuesday's rally in the stock markets, and prices closed dull and mixed. Lack of aggressive leadership was felt plainly during the morning, when scattered selling brought an easier trend in the share list, although some recuperative powers managed partly to right the situation in the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Severe curtailment of taxicab service in New York effective Sept. 20 was ordered today by Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation. The order provides:

A novel program for the conservation of wildlife ha Idaho by means of a 300-page, richly illustrated book will be carried out this Fall. The Fish and Game Department of the State, working with the Department of Education, has prepared "Wildlife of Idaho," a book scaled to the reading tastes and capacities of grade-school children.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Disagreements as to whether go vernment workmen should be paid time and a half on California's "Admission Day" disrupted work on at least four war projects in the San Francisco Bay area today.
Your editorial of Sept. 8, "Not According to Schedule," relating to the early air raid alarm of Monday morning, was well-balanced but you did not seem to me to go quite far enough.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 9 -- The United States is building the best trained and equipped army in its history, Robert P. Patterson. Under-Secretary of War, declared here today as he cited the combat record of our planes and tanks, the performance of which, he said, made it evident that part of the criticism of them came from uninformed sources.
Representatives of 250 candidates for appointment as city firemen protested yesterday to Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh on his policy of refusing appointments to men classified 3A in the draft.

The program of pre-induction and pre-flight courses that the New York City schools will offer in cooperation with the Army when the Fall term begins on Monday was authorized yesterday by unanimous vote of the Board of Education at its regular meeting.

The acquisition by the United States of a naval base in the Galapagos Islands, together with one on the coast of Ecuador, stirs up memories, some recent, some old. Strategists of both the professional and the amateur varieties have long argued for the importance of this location to the defense of the Canal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Diplomatic circles were left in the dark, so far as could be learned here today, over the disclosure that a disagreement over the conduct of the war arose between Prime Minister Winston Churchill and Premier Joseph Stalin during their conversations in Moscow last month.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 8 (Delayed) -- According to high foreign military sources in the Turkish capital tonight, General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel was stricken with a serious illness during the past five days, and his condition is so grave that he may have to be flown to Germany for treatment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Overriding bitter opposition from Southern members, the House accepted today, by a vote of 247 to 53, the long delayed soldiers' vote bill containing the Senate provision for suspending for the duration of the war the poll tax laws of eight States, so far as servicemen are concerned.

Only nineteen casualties among the eighty-seven pilots and a total personnel of 300 in the American Volunteer Corps of fliers in China and Burma were the record reported yesterday by Harvey K. Greenlaw, executive officer who was second in command to Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, leader of this disbanded contingent, known widely as "The Flying Tigers."

A general strike has been begun in the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg in protest against the recent German proclamation announcing that country had been incorporated into the Third Reich, it was announced yesterday here by Joseph Dupong, Prime Minister of the Luxembourg Government in Exile.

Sometimes -- and this happens rather frequently if you are a New Yorker by adoption -- you are overcome with homesickness, and long for the simple things of your youth. You remember, with a nostalgic pang that is more pleasant than not, the down-to-earth cooking in which your mother was accomplished -- most especially, perhaps, the "spaghetti suppers" that you savored on Sunday nights many, many years ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Interest in naval circles here today centered on the United States aerial attack on Gizo Island. The little island, which is about four miles wide by six long and heavily wooded, lies more than halfway on the route to Kieta, a Japanese-held point on Bougainville Island.

Births in New York City last week totaled 2,699, a high mark for the year so far, setting the birthrate up to the new level of 18.6 per 1,000 population, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins reported yesterday. So far this year the birthrate, which has been gradually rising since 1939 to reverse a forty-year trend, is 16.3 per 1.000 population, contrasted with 15.2 at this time last year, and 14.4 in 1940.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 9 -- An Army training plane on its way to La Guardia Field from Hartford, Conn., crashed in the heavily wooded Jockey Hollow section at 3:40 A.M. today, killing the pilot and another officer and injuring two officers, one seriously.

For the fiscal year ended on June 30, net income of $1,786,342, or $2.97 a common share, is reported by the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation, formerly the International Agricultural Corporation. The corporation is engaged, principally, in the production and sale of phosphate rock, superphosphate rock and complete or mixed fertilizers, and in the purchase and sale of fertilizer materials.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 9 -- Many rumors from France tonight testify to a general feeling of uneasiness, intensified by ever stricter censorship. There seems to be no doubt, according to reports reaching here, that the protests of Catholic prelates against the treatment of Jews are creating a difficult situation for the Vichy government.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 9 -- Robert Taylor and Susan Peters were named today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the leading roles in "Gentle Annie," a story of the Oklahoma frontier by McKinlay Cantor, which the studio purchased last January for $50,000.

BUFFALO, Sept. 9 -- Lieut. Gen. William S. Knudsen addressed the American Chemical Society at the dinner-meeting tonight on war production. He stated that airplane engine production has reached 15,000,000 horsepower per month and is still climbing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- President Roosevelt formally outlawed tonight all existing requirements for payment of double time for necessary overtime work on Sundays or holidays, by issuance of an executive order.

Complaints from various ticket brokers that "This Is the Army," one of Broadway's most successful shows, had violated the Theatre Code by having a "buy" for the first two weeks of the local engagement were denied yesterday by A.L. Berman, president of the civilian agency handling the business affairs for the Army's Emergency Relief attraction.
A High Command communique broadcast frm Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

BUFFALO, Sept. 9 -- The Francis P. Garvan Gold Medal honoring women in chemistry was presented to Dr. Florence B. Seibert of the Henry Phipps Institute of the University of Pennsylvania and the $1,000 American Chemical Society prize in pure chemistry was awarded to Dr. John Lawrence Oncley, of the Harvard Medical School, at the society's meeting today.

Service men blinded in the present war must be considered "definitely" a Federal responsibility and special services should be set up for their care, training and rehabilitation, a special committee of the American Association of Workers for the Blind declared yesterday after a meeting at the American Foundation for the Blind, 15 West Sixteenth Street.

Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding general of the Eastern Defense Command, issued a proclamation yesterday setting up 905 prohibited zones and sixty-nine restricted zones within the Eastern Military Area, which includes all of New England, New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland, the District of Columbia, Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia and most of Florida.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 9 (AP) -- Governor Lehman appointed former Democratic State Senator Jacob J. Schwartzwald of Brooklyn a justice of the New York City Court today to succeed the late Justice Edward J. Kelly.

Some of the effects of Japan's withdrawal in China are now being felt in the South Seas. The enemy, recovered from the shock of his defeats in the Solomons and at Milne Bay and apparently reinforced on the ground and in the air, has resumed his attacks both in New Guinea and in the Tulagi area.

Federal Judge Edward A. Conger signed here yesterday an order restraining Levan G. Smith and Warren Sears Crowell from further violations of the Securities Act of 1933. They had been charged, in a complaint by the Securities and Exchange Commission, with fraudulent sales of the stock of the National Bronze and Aluminum Foundry Company, of which Smith is vice president.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- Accusations that Dr. Benjamin F. Barnes, Mayor of Yonkers, was guilty of attempted bribery in offering to exchange political favors and that organized gambling flourishes "under protection" in Yonkers were held to be lacking in proof today by District Attorney Elbert T. Gallagher of Westchester County, who made a voluminous report on the charges to Governor Lehman.

Sales of war bonds and stamps which have been handled by retail establishments throughout the United States under the general direction of the Retail Advisory Committee of the United States Treasury Department will be supervised directly by the Treasury's war savings staff beginning Oct. 1 upon recommendations announced by the Retail Advisory Committee at a meeting yesterday at its headquarters in the Graybar Building.

On this page recently a reader in a very brief letter asked a seemingly pertinent question. A recent conference of college professors and theologians ended with a frank avowal of bewilderment. Our correspondent now wonders, if scholars in today's world are confused, "what is my own status?"

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 9 (AP) -- J.L. Friedman's Playfields, claimed out of her last race for $2,000, came back in the six-furlong American Legion Purse at Garden State Park today to defeat some speedy claiming sprinters and score by three and one-half lengths over the favored Skin Deep.

FORT RILEY, Kan., Sept. 9 (AP) -- With brand new sergeant stripes sewed to his uniform, Joe Louis left this cavalry training post today on the first leg of a journey that will lead to his fight with Conn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Senate Finance Committee confirmed today its tentative approval yesterday of a 5 per cent "Victory tax" to be superimposed next year on all individual incomes above $12 a week, but with credits allowed for payments on pro-war debts, insurance premiums and war bond savings.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information communique issued early today follows:

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- Great Britain's war expenditure on the fighting and supply services has risen by 500,000 daily since June, Chancellor of the Exchequer Sir Kingsley Wood informed the House of Commons today in submitting his vote of credit for 1,000,000,000, which makes the total amount of credits asked in the current fiscal year 3,000,000,000 and since the conflict opened 11,050,000,000.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- Members of the Cabinet, led by Prime Minister Churchill, Ambassadors, service chiefs, heads of exiled European governments and other dignitaries mourned the death of the Duke of Kent today at a memorial service in Westminster Abbey for the first member of the house of Windsor to be killed in active duty.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Egypt, Sept. 9 -- In this forward area, where men live underground and talk for the most part about raids they have been on during recent nights, speculating on how they have fared and discussing what lessons they have learned and what they will do next time they go out, you can see 650-foot-high Qaret el Himeimat dominating the surrounding landscape.

VINELAND, N.J., Sept. 9 -- Negotiations between a nine-member committee representing strikers and officials of the Kimble Glass Company broke down completely today, threatening to keep the plant, the East's largest producer of medicinal glassware, tied up for an indefinite period.

BOMBAY, India, Sept. 9 (U.P.) -- Hundreds of Indians, protesting Mohandas K. Gandhi's arrest a month ago, squatted or fell prone on Bombay streets today and when police fired tear gas to disperse them, sympathizers in buildings poured water from buckets to relieve the choking masses.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- A spokesman of the Fighting French here today said that Edouard Herriot, President of the French Chamber of Deputies in the Republican Parliament, and Jules Jeanneney, President of the Senate, who have protested the assumption of dictatorial powers by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain and Pierre Laval, were solid republicans who carry great weight with French public opinion.

After holding within a four-point range of the previous close during most of the session, the cotton market yesterday jumped to the day's peaks, and gains of as much as 16 points in the last quarter hour of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange, mainly through covering of short positions by local traders and New Orleans interests.

EAST ALTON, Ill., Sept. 9 (U.P.) -- A spokesman for the Western Cartridge Co. said tonight that the concern's munitions plant was carrying on only "limited operations" after a picket line set up by striking A.F.L. chemical workers had kept all but a few of the night shift workers from entering the plant.

The War Production Board will soon start to "crack down" on plants unwilling to sell their copper to the Copper Recovery Corporation for allocation to war plants. A.E. Tupper, chief of the WPB's Inventory and Requisitioning Branch, said yesterday at a press conference at the corporation's headquarters, 200 Madison Avenue.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- Canadian and British bombers last night dived into 200 to 300 new searchlights at Frankfort on the Main, pounding that vital rail junction and inland port with the loss of only seven bombers from a strong force despite frantic German attempts to prepare new defenses.
CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Mrs. A. M. Creech's Sales Talk, 7-10 favorite, won the $2,500 Inaugural Handicap today as Hawthorne, oldest of Chicago's tracks, opened a thirty-four-day meeting.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- In the House today Republicans, although caustically critical of what they called President Roosevelt's ultimatum, urged immediate action to avoid a disruptive inflationary situation.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Valdina Farms Valdina Dust today won the fourth race, a claiming event that featured the Narragansett Park card after the original feature was declared off because of the many scratches.
LONDON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

When the figures on excess reserves of New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System are announced late this afternoon it is to be expected that the total will be considerably less than the record of $265,000,000 made one week ago, what with heavy Treasury withdrawals and other factors.

OAKDALE, L.I., Sept. 9 -- With ten days of stiff preliminary training behind them and Herb Kopf's new offensive creation -- the QT formation -- assimilated, Manhattan's football force of forty players broke camp today at the La Salle Military Academy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Calls in Congress for Presidential application of inflation curbs to wages as well as prices of farm products became more pronounced today, soon after the Chief Executive was assured by House leaders that they would press for prompt drafting and passage before his Oct. 1 deadline, if possible, of the anti-inflation authority over farm prices which he demands.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- American aircraft operating in the Solomon Islands region last Sunday bombed and strafed enemy installations on the shore of Gizo Island, in the New Georgia group, without encountering resistance, the Navy reported in a communique issued this evening.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Treasury Department opened tonight short-term investments in its certificates of indebtedness and notes to small investors with an announcement of two new issues of $1,500,000,000 each to be offered later this month.
SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Sept. 9 -- General MacArthur told United States troops in the field today that all he asked of them in action was that they kill one Japanese apiece.

The projected inventory control plan of the War Production Board may prove to be a stimulus to retail advertising of certain types of goods which have not been promoted heavily this year, store executives said yesterday. Currently, stocks are heaviest in certain types of appliances and home furnishings, which have been moving slowly in the last few months, and in men's wear.

GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands, Sept. 3 (delayed) -- The biggest group of Japanese prisoners yet taken in the Pacific war was marched from concentration points on Guadalcanal today by American Marines, loaded aboard a transport and started on their journey to camps somewhere outside the immediate theatre of hostilities.
Four homes in Flushing and several others in other parts of Queens County have just passed into new hands.

According to an announcement published in your paper Sept. 3, there is to be introduced into the public school system of New York City on Sept. 14 a curriculum of study "completely geared to war effort," as proclaimed by Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sep. 9 -- British long-range-fighter pilots wrought havoc with their cannon last night when they attacked a column of Axis trucks that was moving westward on the coastal road between Matruh and Solum, apparently on the way to get more supplies for the forces in the battle area.

MOSCOW, Sept. 9 -- General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock is maintaining relentless pressure on the western and southwestern fronts of Stalingrad's defenses and stepping up its weight as new reinforcements, including Rumanians and Italians, reach him. In the western sector the enemy reported advancing with forces that outmatch the Russians both numerically and in weight of armor.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- Seizure of the capital stock of these New York concerns was announced today by Leo T. Crowley, Alien Property Custodian:

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Shouting men and women tried to mob Mexico City's student strangler today to avenge the slaying of four young women he killed while diverting their attention with test tubes and books, and tonight the police said his victims might number six or more.

LONDON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Major Gen. Carl A. Spaatz, commander of United States Army Air Forces in the European theatre, awarded the Distinguished Service Cross today to Edward T. Sconiers, 26 years old, of De Funiak Springs, Fla., and promoted him from second to first lieutenant for "extraordinary heroism during a Fortress battle with F-W-190s over the North Sea."

Together with so many other Americans, I dislike the idea of sending boys in their teens to war. However, at a time when the fate of our country, and particularly that of its youth, is so much in the balance it is hardly conceivable that sentimentality should prevail against the urging of our Army and the generally accepted fact that young men of 18 and 19 make the best soldier material.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 9 -- Pressing relentlessly on, as has long been their custom when closing in for the kill, the Yanks today opened their final tour of the west by trouncing the Browns, 8 to 3.

W. Averell Harriman spoke under dramatic circumstances last night at the opening dinner of the Russian War Relief campaign. It took no vivid imagination to hear the terrible organ music of the guns of Stalingrad as an undertone to his warm and outspoken sentences. The Russians feel sure, he told his audience, "that at some time, early they hope, we will be fighting the Germans on another front."

The massive iron grills that adorned the windows on the southeast corner of the Metropolitan Opera House since the building was erected in 1883 have been ripped out for scrap metal, the Metropolitan Opera Association announced proudly yesterday. The grill work yielded 6,200 pounds.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Sept. 10 -- Indications of vast aerial operations on the European fronts were perceptible in interruptions of radio programs from Budapest, Vienna, Prague and certain parts of Southeastern Germany about 9 o'clock last night.

LISBON, Portugal, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Neither the scenes nor the commentary of the German propaganda film, "How We Dealt With the British at Dieppe," impressed movie critics in the Portugese capital, one of whom called it "a poor show, which cannot convince even those who know little about movies."

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, Sept. 10 -- The Japanese have passed through the Gap on the New Guinea trail leading from Buna, on the north coast, to Port Moresby, on the south coast, and have reached the vicinity of the village of Efogi, it was announced today in a United Nations Headquarters communique.

A Brooklyn street cleaner, Joseph Cucinotta, was lifted out of his, prosaic duties yesterday morning, when he stumbled upon a minor arsenal of two submachine guns and ammunition neatly piled against a curb on Fifteenth Avenue, near Eighty-first Street, Brooklyn.
Sales of repossessed properties by banks featured realty trading in Manhattan yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The War Production Board today predicted that this year's domestic wartime demand for tin for cans, amounting to more than 21,000 long tons, will be cut almost in half in 1943 by a program now under way to use electrolytic tinplate and bonderized black plate in place of the hot dipped tinplate now used.

Sophie put on a big act in her Winter 1942-43 custom-made styles yesterday afternoon. The Salon Modern, at Saks Fifth Avenue, hummed with excitement recalling pre-war days. There were opulence and luxury in the items shown. The last impression was one of glorious gowns with very full skirts -- all perfectly legal, for they were of the sheer non-priority materials -- that would grace any ball.

Twenty-eight women volunteers received their pins, veils and certificates yesterday at headquarters of the New York Red Cross Chapter, 315 Lexington Avenue, upon completing a three-months course of training for the chapter's Hospital Recreational Corps, better known as the "Gray Ladies."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Heating in at least 585,624 New York homes next Winter depends on the supply of fuel oil, unless equipment has been converted for use of other fuel, figures of the 1940 housing census indicated today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 9 -- The Berlin press breaking its silence of Prime Minister Winston Churchill's declaration in the House of Commons this evening calls the Prime Minister's speech a "declaration of bankruptcy." Other headlines vary the theme with "Churchill the bankrupt before the Commons," "Arm in arm with Stalin," "Churchill falsifies the trial balance."

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Some day before this war is over you may go to your customary bus stop and board a "blown-up" sedan operated by a girl driver, or a woman may be at the controls of the street car which takes you to your office.

Liquidation of the Banco di Napoli Trust Company of New York, an Italian bank closed by the State Banking Department last Dec. 11 after the declaration of war between Italy and the United States, has been virtually completed, William R. White, State Superintendent of Banks, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- American airplanes, engaged on battle fronts literally around the world, have consistently outfought the planes ranged against them by greater margins than have ever before been recorded.

The four-story apartment and store building on a plot 91 by 80 feet at 6-8 East Hanover Street, Trenton, N.J., was sold by the Equitable Life Assurance Society to the Nalla Realty Corporation. This structure contains eighteen apartments and seven stores and is assessed for $65,000.

DETROIT, Sept. 9 (AP) -- The Detroit Lions put a stopper on high-scoring John Kimbrough, but two of his former Texas A. and M. mates, Bill Conatser and Bill Dawson, produced the pay-off punch in Western All-Army's 12-to-0 victory tonight for a two-to-one edge in its charity series with National Football League clubs.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 9 -- The Cincinatti Conservatory of Music, one of the country's oldest institutions for musical education, was forced to abandon today its regular series of radio broadcasts because of orders issued by James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians.

Loew's State will present this morning's only new film, "Lady in a Jam," a comedy starring Irene Dunne. Produced and directed by Gregory La Cava for Universal release, the picture features Patric Knowles, Ralph Bellamy, Eugene Pallette and Queenie Vassar.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) -- Rising farm prices, which President Roosevelt told Congress must be controlled, have skyrocketed cash income to farmers in his home State 44 per cent the last two years.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 9 -- The Berlin Propaganda Ministry is preparing a vast new campaign to reconcile the German home front to present sacrifices and to the idea of a difficult Winter, according to private advices from the Reich.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 9 -- It's a good thing New York is built on rock formation, for if it wasn't there'd be some awful gaps in the pavement when the Eastern All-Army squad arrives there Friday morning for its final practice brush-up prior to meeting the New York Football Giants at the Polo Grounds Saturday afternoon for the joint benefit of the Army Emergency Relief and the Tribune Fresh Air Fund.

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- Delegates attending the annual convention of the Trades Union Congress at Blackpool went on record today as favoring post-war educational reforms whereby all education would be free at publicly owned schools. There would be no government grants to religious or denominational schools, "and there should not be any place for private schools," the resolution said.

In Tuesday's primaries, Governor Stassen of Minnesota, Republican, was renominated. The man he backed to succeed him when he joins the aimed forces, Ed Thye, farmer, was ahead in a field of eight seeking the Lieutenant Governorship.

Smartly attired in light blue uniforms, twenty-five students who have been taking pre-flight aviation training courses at the Cardinal Hayes High School, Grand Concourse, the Bronx, left Grand Central Station yesterday morning for Canada where they will make a ten-day tour of Royal Canadian Air Force training schools.

Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia and Rear Admiral E.J. Marquart, commandant of the navy yard in Brooklyn, joined yesterday to dedicate the $20,363,000 Fort Greene housing development in Brooklyn as a symbol of the American way of life "that will conquer the Axis and will guarantee to every American family the minimal standards of comfort."

LONDON, Sept. 9 -- More than 500,000 tons of shipping monthly would be required to supply in Britain American forces equivalent in size to the minimum of twenty-five army divisions Germany is supposed to have in France. In addition, nearly 4,000,000 tons of shipping is necessary to get such a force here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 -- The Navy will start Friday to mail application blanks to women who wish to enlist in the Women's Reserve of the Naval Reserve, generally known as the Waves.

Brock Pemberton will present Janie," a comedy by Josephine Bentham and Herschel Williams, derived from Miss Bentham's novel the same name, at Henry Miller's Theatre tonight. The play is about life in a town near an Army camp, and is peopled mostly by teen-aged girls and boys.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 9 -- Sixty per cent of the war workers in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and in New York City who have received supplemental gasoline rations because of their status and their promise to pool their cars are failing to do so, according to a statement issued today by the Nassau County Council, Division of Transportation.

If manufacturers are to be assured of an equitable correlation between taxation and renegotiation of war contracts under the War Profits Control Act, the Treasury Department must establish beyond question its policy of regarding refunds on contracts as reducing the original contract price, a position taken in 1941, according to accountants in a bulletin issued by the American Institute of Accountants yesterday.

The capture of more heights southeast of Novorossiisk and of bitterly defended positions in the Soviet defenses of Stalingrad was reported yesterday by the German High Command, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

Rear Admiral Yates Stirling Jr., retired, has leased a nine-room apartment in 375 Park Avenue through Douglas L. Elliman Co., broker. William A. White Sons reported the renting of an apartment in 580 Park Avenue to William R. Carlisle, legal advisor of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- The Yugoslav Government today authorized the issuance of a report on the German treatment of Serbian prisoners of war, which purported to produce further evidence supporting stories that the Nazis are sadistic in their methods of handling Serbian captives.

Gagged and bound though it is, France remains the best barometer of the moral climate of Europe and the truest index of the course of Hitler's war. Whenever the struggle approaches a new turn, as when the Autumn rains in Russia herald the end of the Summer campaign, the pressure on France increases.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The War Production Board today took complete control of all long staple raw cotton imported into the country under an order which specified that no long-staple cotton will be allowed to enter the United States for consumption or be withdrawn from bonded warehouses without authorization of WPB.

Unit shipments of all dresses in the price ranges of $6.75 and above totaled 4,558,582 for the first six months of this year, compared with 4,421,963 in the same period of 1941 and 4,440,180 in 1940, according to the report issued yesterday by the United Better Dress Manufacturers Association.

Stocks of gasoline in the United States at the close of last week amounted to 80,356,000 barrels, a decrease of 475,000 from the 80,831,000 at the end of the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago, these supplies amounted to 80,366,000 barrels.

Time will be needed to give to all the details of the report of the President's special rubber committee the serious study that they merit. The report as a whole gives that impression of sensible and thorough consideration expected from its distinguished authors. What is most important, however, is the Administration's announcement that there will be no further delay in nation-wide gasoline rationing.

PLANDOME, L.I., Sept. 10 -- Miss Joanne Barr, daughter of Duncan Barr, professional at the Rye Country Club, registered a 79 today to capture the junior girls' championship of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Plandome Golf Club.

Conflicts between WPB Limitation Order No. 171 and the OPA price regulations are grinding the cosmetic industry between two millstones and it is difficult to see how the industry can operate under both, S.L. Mayham, executive secretary of the Toilet Goods Association, asserted yesterday at the annual meeting of the Associated Chain Drug Stores at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Lack of available land and of industrial opportunities precludes the settlement in the Dominican Republic of "anything like" the 100,000 refugees from Europe the republic offered to receive, but "a substantial number" might become established there and, if successfully, would demonstrate the feasibility and mutual advantage of other and larger Caribbean colonization projects, according to a survey report made public today by the Brookings Institution.

VICHY, France, Sept. 10 -- Foreign Jews and "stateless" Jews who are being concentrated in unoccupied territory are those who entered France since 1938, it was said in authorized circles here today. Families are not being separated, but on the contrary all are being sent to their places of origin, whether Poland, Czechoslavia or Austria, it is asserted.
OTTAWA, Sept. 10 (Canadian Press) -- A communique issued by Air Minister C.G. Power through R.C.A.F. Headquarters here:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- New York milk distributors, standing on a contractual right to choose their own methods of reducing mileage and saving rubber, were told by Chairman William H. Davis of the War Labor Board today their 1939 contract with the drivers' union was subject to modification in the light of war conditions, and public interest was paramount.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Forty-four aspirants to Princeton's 1942 varsity football team reported to Coach Tad Wieman for the first formal practice of the season on University Field today. Missing from the squad temporarily were four players, including Letterman John Douglas, center, because of illness, but ten freshmen made their initial appearance in varsity uniforms.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Private Eugene Roehrer, stationed at an Army camp "somewhere in Louisiana," may be worrying about how his wife, June, made out in court today when she appeared to answer a dispossess complaint, but he can rest assured that she is getting plenty of legal advice.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Sept. 11 -- As a special Russian communique broadcast early today reported destructive bombings by the Soviet Air Force through Wednesday night at Budapest, Berlin and Koenigsberg and "other towns of Central and Eastern Germany," Axis radio stations of Central Europe from the Baltic city of Stettin through Berlin, Prague and Budapest were off the air for the second night in a row from just before 11 o'clock last night.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Wesleyan University has given Dr. James L. McConaughy, president, a year's leave of absence to serve as president of the United China Relief.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- After another long conference today with Henry J. Kaiser, who has proposed building cargo planes, Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chairman, told reporters tonight that further meetings would have to be held before a final decision could be reached.

Once upon a time Germany produced a film called "The Last Laugh." It was in some ways a great picture, with its simple and poignant story of what happens to human grandeur. The king who lost his majesty in that story was a hotel doorman, but his fate would have been no more tragic, and no less, had he been an emperor.
VICHY, France, Sept. 10 -- A new overwhelming British assault on Madagascar was announced by the French Admiralty tonight.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose in August to 532,867 shares from the revised figure of 517,422 shares on July 31. Neither total included the short positions carried in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers, which were 40,731 shares on July 31 and 31.579 shares on Aug. 31.

OTTAWA, Sept. 10 (Canadian Press) -- The Dominion Government's deposits with the Bank of Canada increased $11,393,000 to $35,109,000 during the week ended yesterday, the bank reported today in its weekly statement. Notes in circulation increased $8,605,000 to $606,955,000.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 10 -- For the second time in ten days the German Foreign Office spokesman today sharply attacked the Swedish press for its "unneutral attitude."

Miss Rosemary Warburton gave a reception yesterday in the penthouse of the St. Regis for committee members assisting her with plans for the second Junior Officers Ball, which will take place on Sept. 26 in the Whitelaw Reid house, 451 Madison Avenue.

Tonight, on the occasion of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, even the solace of religious services will be denied 7,000,000 Jews under Nazi rule, already the victims of a barbarous war upon their existence, according to the Institute of Jewish Affairs, here, which made public yesterday a documented record of the Hitler attempt to extirpate the Jewish religion.

Jimmy Wilson's Cubs yesterday went far to avenge the long series of beatings they have taken from the Dodgers this season. Scoring almost at will, the Bruins walloped the champion, 10 -- 2, giving Lon Warneke his eleventh triumph and cutting the Brooks' first-place lead over the winning Cards to only two games.

BOSTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Reds were given two splendid pitching performances by Paul Derringer and Ray Starr today but they netted only one victory in their final appearances of the season against the Braves.

A medium-sized British merchant ship and a small Norwegian ship have been sunk by enemy submarines, it was announced yesterday by the Navy Department in Washington. They brought The Associated Press total of sinkings in our waters since Pearl Harbor to 462.

At one of its rare special meetings, attended by more than 500 members, the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York unanimously endorsed yesterday the Ruml pay-as-you-go plan for payment of individual income taxes and urged the Senate Finance Committee to reconsider it for inclusion in the Federal tax program for 1943.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- House Republicans took the initiative today in demanding speed in giving President Roosevelt legislative authorization to act decisively to curb inflation. Minority members of the Banking and Currency Committee, which will have charge of the legislation, urged that hearings be foregone and consideration adjourned to the House floor when measures are prepared.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 10 (AP) -- Syracuse won third place in the International League tonight by taking a play-off game from Jersey City, 2 to 0, on a one-hit pitching job by Red Barrett, who chalked up his twentieth victory of the season -- the only league hurler to reach that mark.

The Argentine mare Barrancosa, who has a partiality for mud, showed her ability yesterday at Aqueduct, when the footing was about as far as possible from a fast track. Piloted by Eddie Arcaro, who got three winners during the afternoon, the 7-year-old daughter of Alan Breck and Barandillo was easily the winner by three lengths at $6.70 for $2.

The forecasts issued yesterday by the Department of Agriculture indicate the largest yields of many crops in the nation's history. A further upward revision of 250,000,000 bushels in the corn crop since the estimate as of Aug. 1 brought the indicated production of that cereal to more than 3,000,000,000 bushels, a figure reached only a few times and some 700,000,000 bushels over the 1930-39 average.
MOSCOW, Friday, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The midnight communique:

Because of a tenchnicality, Supreme Court Justice Kenneth O'Brien denied yesterday the application of former State Senator John T. McCall to compel Senator Charles Muzzicato to remain as American Labor candidate for renomination to the Senate while running at the same time as Republican candidate for Representative-at-Large.

The Fall exhibition schedule of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, which was announced yesterday, includes a display arranged at the request of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, to be called "The Americas Cooperate."

MONTREAL, Sept. 10 (AP) -- J.A. McNeil, general manager of The Canadian Press, addressing the Canadian Authors Association tonight, said that "it is not enough for the press of North America to go all-out for victory; it must also be prepared to work now and henceforth for the peace to come.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- The stock markets were irregular today due to profit-taking but in most sections prices were reasonably well maintained. Shipping issues eased fractionally with the exception of Cunards which hardened to 19 3/8s.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Prospects for an aggregate crop production of unprecedented proportions continued to improve in the last month, the Department of Agriculture reported today in estimating that the total harvest would be 13 per cent greater than in the peak year of 1937.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Production of steel in the United States is far ahead, the best the Axis nations can do, the War Production Board's iron and steel branch stated today.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Action by Congress to authorize the drafting of youths of 18 and 19 years of age moved nearer today as Secretary Stimson declared that all physically and mentally sound youths should prepare to meet the needs of the Army and stated the War Department's intention to call to active military duty all student members of the Army enlisted reserve as they reached the draft age.

The United States Army having shown a desire for the presentation of eight plays at service camps this coming season, Bert Lytell, president of Actors Equity and head of a committee in charge of such productions, has called a meeting for next Monday to discuss the matter with USO-Camp Shows, Inc., under whose auspices the plays will be presented.

MOSCOW, Sept. 10 -- The fighting west of Stalingrad has assumed large proportions as the Germans, following up their initial successes, pour infantry through the gap forced by their tanks earlier this week. The Russians are hammered constantly by tanks and armored cars and they are yielding ground under heavy pressure.

There was something different about Lord Taylor's Autumn collection, previewed for the press yesterday. All the new and better silhouettes, trimmings and fabrics were there but it was the perfect details in styling that predominated in one of the most highly applauded showings of the season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- A recommendation that the government sanction formation of at least two convoys to bring blackstrap molasses, raw material for the manufacture of industrial alcohol, from Cuba and elsewhere in the Caribbean to storage points along the Atlantic seaboard, will be made shortly by the War Production Board, it was learned here today.

Contracts awarded last month for engineering construction throughout the country amounted to $813,077,000 and averaged $203,269,000 for each of the four weeks of the month. Figured on a weekly average basis, the August volume was 16 per cent below the average for July, but rose 53 per cent over the value recorded for the corresponding month last year, according to the Engineering News-Record.
HINSDALE, N.H., Sept. 10 -- The triple murder and suicide of four elderly persons was revealed today in a frame house in this village.

The bodies of Joseph Podubinski, 71 years old, and his wife, Victoria, 68, of 328 Hillside Avenue, Stapleton, S.I., were found side by side yesterday in a shed at the rear of their home. Bullets from two improvised guns had pierced both of them in what the police called a suicide pact.

A tire is a tire and gasoline is gasoline, whether used in a private automobile or in a taxi. New York City could use up great quantities of both these materials, the one absolutely scarce and the other locally scarce, if it made full use of its 11,700 cabs. Some restraint is doubtless necessary.

Enrollment of 942,500 pupils in the Fall term of the city's elementary schools, junior high schools and academic and vocational high schools was announced yesterday by the Board of Education as registration was concluded. The total marks a decline in registration of 20,500 from enrollment of a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The text of today's announcement on Madagascar by the State Department:

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (U.P.) -- World Heavyweight Champion Joe Louis may go to Northern Ireland for a fight, but he said today he didn't expect the battle to be in a ring with just one man as his opponent.

Fritzie Zivic, veteran campaigner from Pittsburgh, squared accounts with Freddie (Red) Cochrane of Elizabeth, N.J., now a Specialist, First Class, in the United States Navy, in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Lord Privy Seal, announced in the House of Commons today that basic pay of members of the British armed forces would be increased 20 per cent, effective Oct. 1, at a cost of 43,000,000 annually.

An eighteen-year masquerade came to an end yesterday for Osmund Westgate, 50 years old, an electrician who as "Patrick Joseph O'Brien" lived at 4848 Broadway, with his wife, Louise, and his 9-year-old son, Jimmy.

Charging that some individuals in the shoe trade "took advantage of secret information for personal gain," A.B. Cohen, vice president and general manager of the United States Shoe Corporation, Cincinnati, manufacturers of Red Cross shoes, said yesterday that complaints are being made by merchants in many sections of the country about the regulations issued on Wednesday by the shoe and leather division of the War Production Board.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Sept. 10 -- President Getulio D. Vargas, realistic in accepting the war as an unavoidable evil, is enthusiastic for Brazil to take part in the struggle, not passively but actively, Nelson A. Rockefeller, Coordinator of Commercial and Cultural Relations between the American Republics, declared yesterday after calling on the President to say goodbye before leaving Brazil.

WASHINGTON, SepL 10 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, tonight called on striking A. F. L. chemical workers at the Western Cartridge Company's plant in East Alton to return to their jobs pending consideration of the dispute by the boarch.

An acute shortage of baby carriages in retail stores will develop within sixty days unless the War Production Board increases manufacturers' production quotas, which in most cases limit output to a factory's 1940 shipments, it was ascertained yesterday.

Substantial oversubscriptions for the $3,000,000,000 of new securities offered yesterday by the United States Treasury were predicted in banking circles. It is understood that the actual volume of subscriptions received yesterday by the Treasury and the Federal Reserve Banks were not heavy but the subscription books do not close until tonight and it is customary for most of the large subscriptions to be made on the final day.

To enable the housewife to recognize "every ounce of scrap in her home," a check list naming more than 100 household and farm items containing material essential for war production has been compiled by the American Industries Salvage Committee, and will be ready for distribution next week, Frank Block, secretary of the committee, announced yesterday.

To relieve a steadily tightening money market, chiefly in New York City, the open market committee of the Federal Reserve System bought $113,881,000 of government securities in the week ended on Wednesday, it was revealed yesterday in the weekly statement of the twelve Federal Reserve Banks, released by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This was the largest weekly increase in the system's holdings in six weeks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Baruch rubber investigating committee recommended today nationwide gasoline rationing and other rigid motoring restrictions to avert "both a military and civilian collapse" resulting from the rubber shortage, and President Roosevelt, promptly approving the report as "excellent," promised that the recommendations would be put into effect "as rapidly as arrangements can be made."

STOCKCHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 10 -- Nearly 1,000 German soldiers are now being kept in Kirkenes concentration camp, in another camp in Pasvik Valley and some aboard the schoolship Soerlandet, lying off Jakofsenes, near Kirkenes, it was learned from reliable Norwegian witnesses tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- President Roosevelt received his special committee investigating the rubber situation, Bernard Baruch and Drs. Compton and Conant, and made public their report recommending nationwide gasoline rationing and other measures; his other visitors included Lord Halifax, Archibald Roosevelt, Ambassador Davis, Donald Nelson and Secretary Hull.
LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's statement in the House of Commons on the Indian situation:

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 10 -- Before any government program goes into effect for a compulsory draft of workers for war industries, the question of whether those workers are to join labor unions win have to be decided.
ATLANTA, Sept. 10 -- Final tabulation tonight of the votes cast in Georgia's Democratic primary gives Attorney General Ellis G. Arnall 261 county unit votes against 149 for Governor Eugene Talmadge.

The Transport Workers Union, which several years ago attempted to organize all the taxi drivers in New York City, is accepting completely the Office of Defense Transportation curb on cab operations here, but will oppose the suggested reduction in bus service for Manhattan, Mathias Kearns, a vice president, said yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 9 (delayed) -- The Indian capital spent a tense day today with most shops closed and the British putting up a strong show of force. That may have cowed the populace but at any rate nothing more serious happened up until dusk than some attempted processions that were quickly dispersed and some arrests.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- A warning that the transit industry must be prepared to face complete shutdown of the manufacture of vehicles was sounded today by Edward S. Pardoe, chief of the bus and electric railway section, War Production Board, in an address here before the American Transit Association.

Lou Little sent his Columbia football squad through its two roughest scrimmage sessions of the season thus far at Baker Field yesterday. A tentative first-team tried its offensive tricks against the scrubs and regularly broke through for long gains.
HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 10 -- Following is the prepared text of the keynote speech delivered tonight by Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce at the Republican State Convention:

When Eugene Talmadge, Governor of Georgia from 1933 to 1937, ran ingloriously for Senator in 1936, he babbled about "white supremacy." He was re-elected Governor in 1940. The Governor's term has been lengthened to four years. This year he proposed to inflict himself upon the State for that period.

Further attention is called to the frightful problems of being young in an amusing comedy entitled "Janie," which was acted at Henry Miller's last evening. Josephine Bentham and Herschel Williams have written it under the impression that girls in their teens are excitable and irresponsible and boys of the same age have expansive natures.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept 10 (U.P.) -- United States heavy bombers have disrupted communications and supply movements in a new daylight raid on Tobruk, and British guns have blasted Axis tanks venturing from cover on the desert front for the first time since General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel called off his recent offensive, it was announced tonight.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Declaring the problem of the second front one that should be settled only by the Allies' high military strategists, the British Trade Union Congress, representing more than 5,000,000 members of labor unions, voted down by a large majority today a resolution demanding the immediate opening of a second front.

A young Midwestern Army corporal who participated in the Commando raid on Dieppe is to be honored soon by Lord Louis Mountbatten, Chief of Combined Operations, it was said last night by Quentin Reynolds, magazine writer, when he and eight other passengers arrived at La Guardia Field on an American Export Airlines Flying Ace.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 -- Heavy profit-taking sales depressed wheat prices today on the Board of Trade and more than offset persistent buying of futures which was attributed to mills. Brokers estimated the purchases by mills at 2,000,000 bushels or more and said the buying pointed to a continuation of an active flour business.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 10 -- General J. Salvador Sanchez, chief of the Presidential General Staff, told this writer today that cooperation between Mexico and the United States was becoming more and more active under a general plan of continental defense, and disclosed that he will visit the United States at the end of this month or early in October.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Will Winter step in again as Russia's great ally? The following timetable, covering mean weather conditions in the latitudes on the Soviet front, may cast light on the Germans' chances [the numbers refer to the map]:

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 10 -- They are going to be known as the Wafs, the members of the new Women's Auxiliary Ferrying Squadron, whose headquarters were established today at the New Castle County Airport.

A new racket, through which the members of a "patriotic society" obtained sums of $25 and $50 from small storekeepers of German, Italian or Hungarian racial antecedents, in exchange for certificates attesting to their patriotism, was exposed in Queens Special Sessions Court yesterday with the arraignment of three men on charges of consiparcy to defraud, petit larceny and misleading advertising.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 10 (AP) -- After starting the current racing week by bowing by a length to the 6-year-old Marriage, a recent graduate of the $1,000 plater class, at Washington Park, Albert Sabath's famed Alsab will attempt to end it Saturday by humbling mighty Whirlaway, greatest money winner of all time, in the $25,000 added Narragansett Special.

The Office of Price Administration was described yesterday as being sympathetic to the idea of setting up trade practice rules covering the colorfastness of textiles, and was said to be leaning toward the use of descriptive labeling on merchandise to indicate conformity to such standards.

Even though no scarcity of meat existed last September at this time, prices of several cuts were higher then than they are now. We have this information, which surprised us not a little, from a spokesman for the Consumers Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 10 (U.P.) -- Allied air and naval forces under the Southwest Pacific Command have destroyed or damaged at least 477 Japanese planes and have sunk or damaged fifty-six vessels in less than five months, a review of 150 communiques issued by General Douglas MacArthur showed today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Army Air Forces today formed a Women's Auxiliary Ferrying Command, although withholding military recognition from the service.

NO one, not even a book reviewer, can read all the current novels that deal with one aspect or another of the Second World War. Romantic espionage thrillers, terrible accounts of the sufferings of the enslaved subjects of the conquering hordes and earnest efforts to portray the actual fighting on land, sea and air pour from the presses in a steady flood.

The two-story building at 327-35 East Sixty-fourth Street has been leased by J.S. Inskip, Inc., for defense work from Rolls Royce and the Bentley Service. It is 125 by 100.5 feet and formerly was occupied by the Glidden Bulck Corporation. The Cross Brown Company was the broker.

Two new films will arrive in local theatres this morning. "Scorched Earth," a feature-length documentary, will have its premiere at the Irving Place Theatre. Produced from Chinese, British and confiscated Japanese film material, the picture deals with Japanese conquest in China since the invasion of Manchuria.

Oscar C. Roesen, president, announced yesterday that the Wood Newspaper Machinery Corporation had declared a regular dividend of $1.75 a share on the prior preference stock, payable on Dec. 1 to stockholders of record of Nov. 16. The corporation also has declared a dividend of $2 on the arrears on the prior preference stock, payable on Oct. 6 to holders of record of Sept. 25.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 10 (U.P.) -- The Japanese have concentrated seventy-five of their imperial and puppet divisions in Manchukuo, Inner Mongolia and Northern China for a possible drive against Siberia if Russian resistance collapses on the European front, well-informed sources said today.

MOSCOW, Friday, Sept. 11 -German tanks and infantry smashing frontally at Stalingrad forced the Red Army to abandon three more populated places immediately west of that city in the fourth Russian retreat in as many days, the Soviet High Command announced early today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Though Mr. Baruch and his associates, Drs. Conant and Compton, wasted little space in their rubber report on the reasons for the national peril they propose to dispel by their recommendations, the document is a powerful indictment of weak, inefficient and unmanaged administration.

The stock market retreated further yesterday from the recovery of Tuesday as pivotal issues sagged a point and more. Support was absent through the greater part of the session, but the lighter tempo of trading acted as a brake on losses. Business on the Stock Exchange was the smallest in a week, with transfers of 344,993 shares, against 361,980 on Wednesday.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 10 -- The Wright Aeronautical Employes Association, an independent union, and the Wright Aeronautical Corporation have been asked voluntarily to disestablish the association on the complaint of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., that the company dominates the union, according to announcement here today by David Schatzo, field examiner of the National Labor Relations Board.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept_ 10 By Sept. 15 it is likely that some 20,000 foreign Jews will have been deported from unoccupied France to distant parts in Eastern Europe and that all protests will have proved unavailing. Such is the gist of reports received here tonight from Vichy, but the French continue to know nothing of it -that is, those who are content to read regimented newspapers and listen to official broadcasts.

Leonard B. Nethersole of 42 West 138th Street led a list of 1,694 successful candidates for the post of patrolman with a final average of 93.66 per cent, the Municipal Civil Service Commission announced yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- The existing set-up of the Ministry of Health and the so-called friendly societies dispensing public health benefits were attacked today at the closing session of the annual meeting of the British Medical Association.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 10 -- The signing of a rubber agreement between the United States and Mexico was announced this evening.

The fate of the larger woman in a fashion world dominated by fabric limitations was decided yesterday at the Autumn showing of Lane Bryant, 1 West Thirty-ninth Street. As seen in a diversified collection of forty-five garments for all-occasion wear, it is a happy one, marked by good tailoring and cautious usages of trimmings.
Mayor La Guardia welcomed delegates of the Inter-American Seminar on Social Studies at City Hall yesterday and invited them to suggest possible improvements in the city's handling of social problems.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Senate Finance Committee completed its work today on individual income tax rates by voting, 9 to 7, to lower them slightly in the bottom brackets to compensate in part for the added burden of the new "Victory Tax" and to raise them in the middle brackets to an extent calculated to produce a net revenue gain of about $33,000,000.

ALBANY, Sept. 10 -- Governor Lehman warned Mayor Hussey of Mount Vernon today that orders for blackouts must be obeyed and "we cannot permit each individual to determine whether he will obey orders from constituted authority."

Although bluefish news appears to be arriving in piecemeal fashion, nevertheless if the blue devils remain in our nearby offshore waters for any length of time they will supply a grand climax to the Fall season.

Rigid and definite are the rules that govern a schoolgirl's fashions. It is decreed that she garb herself in a skirt of plaid and a shaggy sweater at least a size too large. She shall wear a single strand of pearls, woolen ankle socks with the name tapes showing, and Bermuda shoes that seem never to have been new.

The American designer of patterns for home dressmaking took his place beside other native artists in the fields of fabrics and fashions yesterday as Macy's reviewed its long-range, greatly expanded Autumn and Winter program for home sewing.

TRENTON, Sept. 10 -- The trend of relief expenditures and relief cases in New Jersey continued downward during July, but at a slackened pace that led Charles R. Erdman Jr., State Municipal Aid Director, to conclude that the decreased relief load had "just about reached rock bottom," according to a report issued here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 -- Rohm Haas Company, Inc., in a statement today said its production of plexiglas for United States military aircraft was possible only because of the agreements which were described as a violation of anti-trust laws in an indictment returned by a Federal grand jury at Newark, N.J.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 10 -- A 2-cent overcharge for a tube of toothpaste cost the seller $50 today in what was believed to be the first conviction in the country under the triple-damage clause of the Price Control Act.
William Miller Collier, former United States Ambassador to Chile, and Mrs. Collier, who, with Mrs. George H. Mason of Auburn, N.Y., spent the Summer in Maine, have returned to the Biltmore.

GREENVILLE, S.C., Sept. 10 (AP) -- William Arthur Melton Jr., 15 years old, was in jail today in connection with the death Sept. 3 of Henry W. (Mike) Harrison Jr., 5, whose trussed body was found face down on the attic floor of a vacant house across the street from his home.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Friday, Sept. 11 (U.P.) -- The Melbourne Sun Pictorial said today in a front dispatch that the Japanese advancing across the waist of New Guinea were gradually leaving the worst terrain behind them.

Completely defeated in 1918, the German reactionaries who later called themselves National Socialists pledged to maintain that they were unbeaten on the battlefield ("Im Felde Unbesiegt") -- despite all evidence to the contrary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (U.P.) -- Joseph W. Martin Jr., Republican National Chairman, predicted tonight that his party "definitely" would carry the "Big Six" States, Massachusetts, New York, Pennsylvania, Ohio, Illinois and California, in the House, Senate and Governorship elections.

Norman S. Goetz, attorney and philanthropist, was named yesterday to head the 1942 merged appeal of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities, on behalf of 116 affiliated medical and social welfare agencies serving New York City.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 10 -- Robert Abial (Red) Rolfe, third baseman of the Yankees for eight years and former Dartmouth University baseball and basketball star, has been appointed head coach of baseball and basketball at Yale University, it was announced tonight by Ogden Miller, director of athletics.

An injunction restraining the operators of the Lycoming Hosiery Company from selling nylon stockings at prices higher than those set for manufacturers by the Office of Price Administration was entered in Federal court here yesterday by Judge Samuel Mandelbaum.

SHILLONG, India, Sept. 10 -- Rescue workers operating from India have located another group of 1,500 refugees from Burma isolated by a raging river and a difficult mountain trail near the borders of Burma, Tibet and Assam. The group reportedly includes about 100 Europeans and Anglo-Indians, 800 Indians and 600 sick and wounded troops.

ALBANY, Sept. 10 -- Following a conference of representatives of the Communist party today at which allegations were made that signers of the party's nominating petition were being "intimidated," Governor Lehman notified law-enforcement officers in Saratoga, Broome and Columbia Counties to "enforce the law."

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Prices for hogs declined 25 cents a hundredweight today as buyers, anticipating price ceilings, took advantage of a fairly sizable run to mark down all types and weights. The salable run here was 12,000 head, compared with 8,756 a week ago. At twelve principal markets 68,300 head were offered, compared with 40,800 last Thursday.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve reserve banks showed holdings of United States Government securities to be the highest on record, having increased $113,881,000 during the past week. Note circulation and total bills discounted also reached the highest of the year, while the ratio of reserve both for the system as a whole and for the New York Bank were at the lowest.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The report of the President's special committee on rubber begins by saying that the situation is "so dangerous that unless corrective measures are taken immediately this country will face both a military and civilian collapse."

Having taken over the stewardship of the annual "The Best American Short Stories," Martha Foley in a foreword to the 1942 book, published yesterday, discourses briefly on short story trends and problems. The editor, successor to the late Edward J. O'Brien, observes that in her scouting for stories through the magazines she finds that "the lifelessly plotted story with the forced happy or trick ending is dying."

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- The Royal Air Force was restricted apparently by bad weather last night to attacks on German shipping in the North Sea, while Russian bombers raided Budapest, Berlin and Koenigsberg in considerable force.

From the assembly line in the vast Stalingrad factories, said our dispatches the other day, the tanks roll off straight into battle. This must be very nearly the shortest supply line in the history of war.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 10 (U.P.) -- Wendell L. Willkie arrived today from Ankara, a few hours after he had conferred with the Turkish Premier, Shukru Saracoglu. Mr. Willkie said he was convinced that Turkey would remain neutral and would not permit Axis forces to pass through her territory.

Because they are convinced that only strenuous volunteer efforts can meet the urgent salvage problem confronting the country, the 250,000 members of Bundles for America, Inc., will henceforth work in cooperation with local salvage committees throughout the country, Mrs. Wales Latham, national president of the organization, announced yesterday.

The onrushing Cardinals whirled into the Polo Grounds at breakneck speed yesterday, bowled over the Giants, 5 to 1, and then hastened along to Ebbets Field for a two-game series today and tomorrow, buoyed up by the thought that they are within reach of tying the Dodgers for the National League lead.

Enlisted personnel in the Waves in the Third Naval District was tripled yesterday when Miss Mary Florence Woodworth of Maywood, N.J., and Miss Anne Edith Hoag of White Plains, N.Y., were sworn in as First Class Yeomen in afternoon ceremonies at Waves Headquarters, 33 Pine Street.

A joint ballet season of thirty-two performances by the Ballet Theatre and the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo is announced for the Metropolitan Opera House beginning Oct. 6 by S. Hurok. The Ballet Theatre will open the engagement and will play through Oct. 11, when it will go on a brief Eastern tour.

For the nine months ended on July 31 net profit of the Dresser Manufacturing Company and subsidiaries, makers of pipeline accessories, amounted to $1,031,478, or $3.08 a share on the outstanding stock, after taxes on income of $1,575,862.

DETROIT, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Tigers pushed over two runs in the eighth inning to nullify home runs by Ted Williams and Dom DiMaggio and defeat the Red Sox today, 5 to 4, in the final meeting between the clubs this season. Boston won fifteen of the twenty-two games.
ALBANY, Sept. 10 (U.P.) -- Selective Service Boards in New York State were ordered today to review the classification of married registrants without children.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 10 -- A world-wide conspiracy by two American and three foreign chemical concerns to monopolize the manufacture and marketing of an important plastic material that is being widely used in the war program was charged in an indictment made public here today.

HARTFORD, Sept. 10 -- Asserting that, although the National Administration had talked a "tough" war, it so far had fought a "soft" one, Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce called tonight for prosecution of the war to total victory.
MOSCOW, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Today's Soviet communique:

CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP) -- Bruce Campbell's pinch single with the bases filled in the eighth inning, driving in two runs, gave the Senators a 5-4 victory over the White Sox in the electric-light portion of their "twinight" double-header tonight after Ted Lyons had turned in his thirteenth victory for the Chicagoans in the first game, winning by 7 -- 1.
LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Today's British announcement of new operations in Madagascar follows:

Indications that about 100,000 soldier ballots will be sent out to men in the armed forces stationed within this country came yesterday from the State War Ballot Commission. This will mean, according to usually reliable sources, that about 300,000 New York State men will not vote in the November election, as the best estimates are that about 400,000 men from the State will be in the armed service by November.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Associated Transport, Inc., through its president, B.M. Seymour, today asked approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission of the sale of $900,000 of its preferred stock to four truck manufacturers and two tire manufacturers.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 10 -- There were fifty-three starters today in the second regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's race week. Sails fluttered back and forth, and it was tricky going that called for skillful helmsmanship to outguess the vagaries of the breeze while guiding craft through favorable and antagonistic swirls of the bay tide, but on the whole it was a relief to skippers and crews to get ashore dry.

In your editorial of Sept. 5 "Mr. Astor and New York" you enumerate some of the reasons why Mr. Astor is "selling many of his holdings here and replacing them with a diversified group of income-producing properties in various parts of the country." Fortunately you conclude with the constructive observation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The following table, prepared by the Treasury Department, shows proposed total income and "victory" taxes for single persons, childless married couples and married couples with two dependents under the rates adopted by the Senate Finance Committee.

Is there nothing that can be done to stop the smoking on the no-smoking cars of railroad trains? As I am one of the many who are nauseated by smoke, I carefully choose a no-smoking car in my travels, only to find, week after week, that people light up their cigarettes on these same cars.

BUFFALO, Sept. 10 -- A derivative of adrenalin which can be prepared synthetically in the laboratory in unlimited amounts has been discovered to be highly effective in reducing high blood pressure in animals, it was reported today before the semi-annual meeting of the American Chemical Society.

War with the Axis certainly should have taught us by this time not to underestimate the fighting quality of either enemy personnel or material. It would be dangerous folly at this stage to fall into a complacent attitude with regard to the weapons with which we are armed.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The Phils came from behind today to snap a 13-game losing streak with a 2-1 decision over the Pirates in an 11-inning contest. The second game of the scheduled doubleheader was called after three and a half innings of play.
