HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept 10 -- George Sanders has been suspended from salary by Twentieth Century-Fox for the second time this season because of his refusal to play an "unsympathetic" role, it was learned today. His removal from the payroll was caused by his withdrawal from "The Immortal Sergeant," a story by John Brophy about fighting in the Libyan Desert.

There were no signs at Baker Field yesterday that the Football Giants were victims being prepared for the slaughter. If majority opinion is that the huge and colorful array of All-Army stars gathered by Colonel Bob Neyland will prove too much for the Giants in their benefit game at the Polo Grounds tomorrow, the Giants don't seem to be worrying too much.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- The sensitive nose of a skunk was used at the Bear Mountain Trailside Museum, near Bear Mountain Bridge, today to trace the origin of a very bad odor, so strong that it made work in the museum's geology building practically impossible.

Trading in futures yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange was irregular. The market opened uneven, held in a narrow range most of the day and ended with net gains of 5 to 9 points. There was some covering by local traders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Women now are at work on most of the processes that go into the fabrication and assembly of an airplane, and it is estimated that 250,000 will be in the aircraft industry by the end of this year, as compared with about 2,000 a year ago, Secretary Perkins said today.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Sept. 10 -- The body of a man identified by papers in his pocket as Meyer Teplinsky, 42 years old, of 686 Rosewood Street, the Bronx, but known to the New York City police under eight other aliases, was found this afternoon a short distance off the pavement on Buckout Road, here.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 10 -- By twenty votes to one, the national committee of the Radical party, numerically the most important group in the Chamber of Deputies, has decided to support a demand for rupture of relations with Axis countries in the debate on foreign policy that, it is expected, will occur shortly.

An effort to unify all advertising and publicity campaigns here in behalf of the war effort through the War Activities Council of the Advertising Club of New York was undertaken yesterday at a luncheon at the club, when representatives of some thirty business associations of this city voted to join the council's advisory board. Each association submitted the name of a member to represent it on the advisory board.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- President Roosevelt's regulation abolishing for the duration of the war premium pay for Saturday and Sunday work, as such, in war industries, was based upon his wartime powers, and will be enforced by re-negotiation of contracts to reduce payments to contractors to whom additional sums have been allowed for such payments, it was announced at the White House today.

Bank clearings for twenty-three major cities, for the week ended on Wednesday, amounted to $5,077,265,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Since the week included the Labor Day holiday, this figure was sharply below the $6,882,635,000 reported in the preceding week and the $5,586,700,000 for last year, a six-day week.

WASHINGTON, Sept 10 -- Continued advances in prices for domestic agricultural commodities, particularly grains, cotton and dairy products, brought the general level of prices in primary markets up 2 per cent to a new high during the first week of September.

Recommendations of the President's Committee on Rubber are "sound and helpful and will aid in the final solution of the tire shortage," William J. Gottlieb, president of the Automobile Club of New York, said yesterday.
A man who tried to panhandle a loaf of bread in a Bronx bakery yesterday morning invested $683 in War Bonds yesterday afternoon.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 10 (U.P.) -- William J. Cox, Highway Commissioner, said today he would meet with a New York State delegation Tuesday at Greenwich to consider "post-war reconstruction of the Boston Post Road."

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- Early this morning British forces opened an attack against ports on the west coast of Madagascar, which lies athwart the route to the Middle East via the Cape of Good Hope. Tonight the operations, which the government made clear had been undertaken reluctantly and only after four months of vain effort to reach some understanding with Vichy to safeguard United Nations interests in the Indian Ocean, were "continuing satisfactorily."

ALTON, Ill., Sept 10 (AP) -- With more than 1,000 men of the Illinois reserve militia mobilized and standing by, the huge Western Cartridge plant at East Alton remained virtually shut down tonight by a strike of A.F.L. chemical workers and sympathizers.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10 -- The gay dash of the Yankees to clinch the American League pennant at the earliest possible moment experienced an amazing cropper today as the Browns, whose modest ambitions aim only to clinch third place, routed the world champions in the series final, 9 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Senate, with a voice vote, today completed Congressional action on the service men's absentee voting bill and sent it, with its provision for wartime suspension of poll tax laws in eight Southern States, to the President.

Two thousand persons attended a meeting last night in the Cosmopolitan Opera House, 133 West Fifty-fifth Street, and in the name of the membership of the American Federation of Labor adopted one resolution urging the immediate opening of a second front in Europe, and another urging the immediate creation of an Anglo-Soviet labor treaty wherein the workers of the United States would be represented.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Britain has found it "absolutely necessary" to undertake the full military occupation of Madagascar because of Axis penetration of parts of the island, and does so with the full approval of the United States, it was announced by the State Department today.

American citizens are entitled to get a clear picture of what is presented in the President's message to Congress, and in his fireside chat on price regulations and wage control. In his dual capacity as Chief Executive and Commander in Chief of the armed forces of the United States of America, in actual time of war, the President has broad powers.

THOSE citizens who like to see brisk competition and great athletes in action had better turn out now and take a good look at what's going on in the general field of sports because some -- no, many! -- of the topflight players aren't going to be around long where they can be seen in comfort from a grandstand or bleacher seat.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 9 (Delayed) -- Turkey is firmly anchored alongside the United Nations for the duration of the war and during the post-war reconstruction period -- militarily, politically and economically -- and Turkish Government leaders are most confident that Turkey will maintain her position as a citadel of defense in the vast theatre of war in the Near and Middle East until ultimate Allied victory.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, Sept. 11 -- The fighting between Australians and Japanese on the trail that leads from Buna to Port Moresby. New Guinea, is approximately midway between the Gap, high point of the trail, and the southernmost ridge of mountains above the rolling valley at the coastal end of which Port Moresby is situated.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 10 -- Nearly 200 delegates from all American countries gathered in the Congress Building this morning for the first session of the first Inter-American Conference on Social Security, which was opened by President Juan Antonio Rios of Chile and attended by Cabinet Ministers and other officials.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 10 (AP) -- County and municipal officials, such as prosecutors, Sheriffs, Mayors, police judges, magistrates and others, are not entitled to draft deferment by virtue of their public office, State selective service headquarters reminded New Jersey's 202 local boards today.
Intensified cooperation in the war was urged by Jewish leaders yesterday in messages for Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year 5703, which begins today at sundown.

First suggestion in the advertising field for a voluntary merger of facilities in line with the industry concentration plan of the War Production Board came yesterday from the Mail Advertising Service Association of New York City, which suggested that the program, if accomplished voluntarily, would be less painful to the industry and more satisfactory to all concerned, including the government.

VICHY, France, Sept. 10 -- No American rejection of the French protest against Anglo-American bombings of civilians in occupied France has been delivered in Vichy, it was stated in authorized circles here today. At the same time some explanations were presented with regard to the French protest, which, it was said, relates to damages to civilians and does not refer to the attacking of military objectives.
Hyman Co., a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, was dissolved on Sept. 8.
DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 11 -- The Automotive Council for War Production reports that the arms out-put of the automobile industry exceeds by 32 per cent the rate of peace output in 1941, the peak year.

After nearly a decade in which few American films have reached the Soviet public, negotiations were begun this week between Artkino, Inc., Soviet film distributors in this country, and the major producing companies here whereby the flow of American movies to Russia will be greatly increased.

Marking up by the Agricultural Department of the country's expected cotton crop, from 13,085,000 bales in August to 14,028,000 this week, took the cotton trade by surprise. The Government's September forecast was far above that published by private experts.

PLANDOME, L.I., Sept. 11 -- Invading enemy territory, young Douglas Ford, the Westchester and New York State junior champion, today aided his host, Fred Bohling, in getting a tie for the medal in the qualifying round of the annual member-guest tournament at the Plandome Golf Club.

An impressive newspaper appeal for conservation of rubber declares that we will walk barefoot in America if necessary to save rubber and win the war; and above the challenge in words is a picture showing the American citizen and his wife and the young son suiting the action to the word.

Dr. Leslie B. Moss, executive director of the Committee on Foreign Relief in the Churches, presided yesterday at a discussion of the problems involved in foreign relief for war victims. The meeting in the Hotel Commodore brought to a close a two-day conference of more than sixty church and relief agency leaders under the auspices of the Federal Council of Churches and the Foreign Missions Council of North America.

Despite widespread increases in purchasing power, less than half of the manufacturers who replied to a recent survey by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., are expecting an increase in sales volume during the latter half of 1942 over the corresponding period of 1941.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- President Roosevelt said today that an all-powerful rubber administrator would probably be named on Monday, when most of the rubber conservation measures recommended by the Baruch committee will become effective.

"Loyalty Sunday" will be observed tomorrow in many of the churches in the New York area. In virtually all houses of worship "The Star-Spangled Banner" will be sung, Monday being the anniversary of our national anthem. Most of the few churches which have been closed for the last few weeks will reopen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Senate and House leaders failed in a long joint conference today to agree on the form which legislation should take to give President Roosevelt the inflation-curbing authority for which he asked in his Labor Day message and fireside chat, and so took their problems to the White House late in the day.

The law requiring dismissal of any city employe who refuses to waive immunity before a legislative committee is constitutional and applies to teachers in the city colleges, Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter ruled yesterday.
By the simple expedient of waving a menacing bat yesterday at the Polo Grounds Hank Leiber sent the Cubs away dejectedly in their farewell visit of the 1942 campaign to Harlem.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Sept. 11 -- Five persons were killed and four others were injured, three of them critically, in two explosions at the war production plant of the Essex Specialty Company on the outskirts of this town shortly before 10 o'clock this morning.

ALTON, Ill., Sept. 11 (AP) -- The four-day strike at the Western Cartridge Company's East Alton plant was ended tonight as several thousand employes gave unanimous voice approval of an agreement to return to work at 8 o'clock tomorrow morning.

BUFFALO, Sept. 11 -- Chemical processes whereby the large quantities of waste liquids which paper mills are now dumping into our rivers can be utilized in large-scale manufacture of the rarest of sugars, recently costing more than $18,000 a pound, were described today before the semi-annual meeting of the American Chemical Society, which ended this afternoon.

Perhaps we boxing fans should be so grateful that the War Department finally is going to permit Joe Louis and Billy Conn to meet again that this little matter should not be mentioned, but just the same I cannot resist the temptation to raise a question concerning their bout scheduled for Oct. 12.

The East River Savings Bank has sold the two-family house at 7513 Eleventh Avenue, Brooklyn, to William G. Churchill, subject to a purchase money mortgage of $5,750. The building is on a plot 30 by 100 feet. Colonial Realty Company was the broker.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy, returned to Washington today from a secret 26,000-mile tour of battle zones in the Pacific to report that the Japanese will have an exceptionally difficult time if they try to recapture Guadalcanal or other conquered islands in the Solomons.
LONDON, Sept. 11 -- The stock markets continued quiet today. Gilt-edge issues were 1-16 to 1/8 lower.

An urgent appeal to income taxpayers to return the bills sent them by the Internal Revenue Department when paying the Sept. 15 installment was issued yesterday by Joseph D. Nunan Jr., Captain William J. Pedrick and Joseph T. Higgins, collectors for the First, Second and Third New York districts. The appeal, issued jointly, declared:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Indications increased tonight that Henry J. Kaiser, West Coast shipbuilder, would be authorized to construct at least one huge cargo-carrying plane as a result of his conferences with Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 11 -- A brisk wind blew clouds of dust across the Alamein front yesterday and despite an enemy attempt to break up a British patrol the night before little fighting developed. Both sides are reorganizing and reinforcing as a natural sequel to the recent battle, and they are naturally not inclined to break the lull for the time being.

A warning that buyers as well as sellers of rationed articles will be prosecuted if they fail to abide by the regulations was coupled by United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa yesterday with a story of a man who tried to evade the tire-rationing rules.

Two small Yugoslav merchant ships were sunk by enemy submarines in the Indian Ocean last month, and twenty-seven survivors have landed at an East Coast port in the United States, the Navy disclosed yesterday.

Magazine linage for September gives another encouraging indication that advertising is recovering steadily from its slump in the early part of the year. The loss for monthly magazines from a year ago was cut to about 6 per cent, whereas in early months of the year it had been as high as 15 and 16 per cent.

The Warner-Hudnut Corporation, manufacturer of cosmetics, which owns and occupies the building at 113 West Eighteenth Street running through the block to 110 West Nineteenth Street, has enlarged its holding by purchasing the adjoining five-story structure at 621 to 629 Sixth Avenue, southwest corner of Nineteenth Street, from Vincent Astor, according to a deed recorded yesterday in the Registrar's Office.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Red Sox collected Seventeen hits off Jim Bagby and two ineffective successors today to crush the Indians, 15 to 2. Southpaw Ken Chase, an old Tribe jinx, held the Indians scoreless until the second-placers piled up a 12-run margin.
LONDON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Under the caption "Question for the Navy," a correspondent, R.W.G.W., writes in your issue of Sept. 8 of. "a charming picture of an old sailing schooner gliding silently along the sea lanes, looking for submarines." This correspondent further states: "The Navy turned down the offer of hundreds of amateur yachtsmen to do similar duty.

An 83-year-old woman who suffered a scalp wound and possibly a skull fracture when she had a heart attack while walking down the stairs from her two-room apartment at 526 Ninth Avenue, near Thirty-ninth Street, was found at Bellevue Hospital last night to have a hoard of $5,365 in crisp new bills hidden in her clothing.

AT SEA WITH THE UNITED STATES FLEET, off the Solomons, Aug. 24 (Delayed) -- The greatest air victory of the war against Japan has been won by American fliers who today shot down ninety-six enemy planes in a far-flung battle over Guadalcanal Island and over our Navy Task Force. Our losses were eight pilots missing.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Sept. 12 -- Red Army troops braced today for a hold-or-die stand before Stalin-grad, beating back the million-man German assault army at one point southwest of the city and exacting a terrific toll to the west in the greatest battle of all history.
The sale of four large apartment and store buildings in New Jersey was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- In his order today to striking workers of the East Alton plant of the Western Cartridge Company to return to work, William Green, A.F.L. president, expressed confidence in "a fair and just decision" by the National War Labor Board on employe grievances against the company, which he accused of provoking the strike as a means of destroying the union.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Shipyards of the United States are building Liberty ships, the main part of the merchant ship program, at the fastest rate ever known in the history of shipbuilding, Rear Admiral Howard L. Vickery, vice chairman of the Maritime Commission, said today.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 11 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces have killed 300 Japanese and captured valuable war booty in a hit-run raid on the Japanese base at Yokow, Central Hupeh Province, and repulsed a Japanese attack on their own stronghold at near-by Tangyang, a Chinese communique said tonight.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Off the Netherland coast early today British light naval craft in action with a Nazi convoy and its escort warships blew up an enemy tanker, probably destroyed a large anti-aircraft ship and severely damaged an armed trawler and at least six motor torpedo and gun boats of the E-boat and R-boat classes, the Admiralty reported.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Clinging to its determination to win for labor unions the legal right to strike in sympathy with other unions, the British Trade Union Congress rejected today a personal appeal by Prime Minister Churchill to delay until the war is over its fight for revision of the Trades Dispute Act, passed in 1927 after the British general strike in 1926.
The Conservation Department in Albany has announced New York's season for ruffed grouse, which will be longer than usual and in some parts of the State will open earlier than in past years.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Lord Portal, Minister of Works and Planning, although giving an encouraging picture of progress made in Great Britain's salvage drive for essential raw materials, which is designed to save shipping space, warned the people of Britain yesterday that they "must use less, eat less and spend less."

DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 11 -- Syria has the right to expect the early recognition of its independent national status by the United States and other United Nations, Sheik Taj Eddin Hassani, President of the Republic of Syria, said in an interview today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UP) -- Donald M. Nelson, war production chief, tonight ordered a forty-eight-hour work week established in all lumber camps and sawmills in the Pacific Northwest, marking the first time the government has arbitrarily directed a specific industry to increase its work hours.
The Flatbush panic is on!

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- At the beginning of the long Blitz in London Mrs. Estrid Dane was an A. R. P. worker in a poor district of the city. Daily she would come in contact with mothers with sickly babies -- babies with the rickets, babies who wouldn't eat, babies who had been born with deformed bones and weak backs.

Presenting an encouraging view of the nation's transportation situation, Colonel A. B. Barber of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States told the closing session yesterday of the annual convention of the Associated Chain Drug Stores at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that, while major difficulties are noted, the general outlook is in "marvelous contrast to the transportation muddle of 1917-18."
WASHINGTON, Sept. (11) -- The Senate Finance Committee made several minor tax decisions today and Chairman George voiced the hope that all issues would be settled by tomorrow night.

Walter Mitchell Jr., economist, Dun Bradstreet Inc., will address the Brooklyn Chapter of the National Association of Cost Accountants on "Current Problems in the Relation of Government to Business" on Wednesday at the Central Branch Y.M.C.A., Brooklyn.

Rosh ha-Shanah messages from Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia and Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, expressing confidence that the Axis would be defeated and democratic principles of freedom and justice to all would dominate the world once the peace was won, were read yesterday at a ceremony in the Bellevue Hospital Synagogue.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- With record supplies of grain on hand or in prospect and intimations by the Department of Agriculture that another upturn in the possible yield of corn and soy beans might be reported next month if weather conditions are favorable, traders who have been on the bull side of the markets for several days beat a hurried retreat on the Board of Trade today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Office of Price Administration today announced the operating sections of its newly created standards division and the executives who will head them. The standards division was set up several days ago by Price Administrator Leon Henderson to provide OPA's operating divisions with the technical assistance necessary to incorporate quality definitions in price, rent and rationing regulations.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- A group of young American women fliers, all of whom are qualified pilots holding United States licenses, is performing valuable work in behalf of Britain by acting as ferry pilots between various points in this country.
ATLANTA, Sept. 10 -- Governor Talmadge has emerged from the avalanche of Arnall ballots under which he was buried and struck back at his victorious opponent.

A broad program for municipal cooperation with the Federal Government and the State in conservation of gasoline, rubber and other critical materials used in various forms of transportation was outlined yesterday by the New York City War Tr2nit Committee at an organizational meeting at Police Headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Disappearance of the "zoot suit" for the duration of the war was assured here today with an order from the War Production Board prohibiting the manufacture of the garments out of any material. The "zoot suit" includes an over-length coat and baggy trousers, and it has been made of wool.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- Despite the rebukes he had received from Governor Lehman and Lieut. Gen. William N. Haskell, State Director of Civilian Protection, Mayor William Hart Hussey of this city refused today to retreat from his position that he acted properly Tuesday night in disregarding State orders for a complete blackout of Mount Vernon during a county-wide test.

W. Kingsland Macy, Republican chairman of Suffolk County, and Myron J. Parkinson of Syracuse, newly elected Democratic chairman of Onondaga County, carried the brunt of the State political campaign here yesterday, each issuing a statement predicting gains in his home county.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 11 -- With a view to the readjustment of social security regulations throughout the Americas the first Inter-American Conference on Social Security devoted today's session to comparing the different systems operating in the twenty-two nations of the continent, including the United States and Canada.

The battle for the Volga, blasting an arc of death around the scarred city of Stalingrad, is easily the most ferocious battle of the war. The Russians cannot be finally defeated there and the Germans on the banks of that great brown river, life stream of Russia though it is, are as far from victory as ever.
HARTFORD, Sept. 11 -- Following is the text of the platform adopted today by the Connecticut Republican State Convention:

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 11 -- A strike of 400 local truck drivers helpers and platform men, who quit their jobs last Monday night, was ended tonight when representatives of their union promised conciliators that the strikers would return to work Sunday night and refer their wage grievances to the National War Labor Board.

The Rev. Charles Albert William Brocklebank, rector for the last five years of the Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, Tenth Street, west of Second Avenue, has been commissioned a chaplain of the United States Naval Reserve with rank of lieutenant and ordered to Norfolk, Va.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 11 (AP) -- With the benefit of three home runs, a triple and a double, the Browns drubbed the Senators, 10 to 4, today to keep up their hot third-place pace.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 -- Fifty-five employes -- including twenty-two business specialists -- have been dismissed by the State office of the Office of Price Administration here, it was learned today.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 11 -- Accused of having stolen and sold nearly 4,000 coupons from C gasoline ration books, two employes of the propeller division of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation in Caldwell, N.J., were arraigned here today before Federal Judge Thomas F. Meaney and released in $2,000 bond each for action of the Federal grand jury.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 1l -- Each day brings its addition to protests made in France against the persecution of Jews. Texts have to be smuggled out of the country, since publication is forbidden within it. Thus it is learned here that the Bishop of Montauban ordered the reading on Aug. 30 from all pulpits in his diocese "without comment" a pastoral letter with the following passages:

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Lord Privy Seal, dramatically intervening in the House of Commons debate about India today, disclosed the Mohandas K. Gandhi had balked acceptance of the British formula for settlement of the Indian question after other leaders of the Indian Congress had acceded to it.

GROTON, Conn., Sept. 11 (AP) -- Some 150 Representatives of the three States that permit savings banks to sell life insurance -- Massachusetts, Connecticut and New York -- gathered here tonight for a three-day conference. Their discussion turned to extending the system to the fourteen other States in which mutual savings banks operate.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- One of London's new deep air raid shelters for 8,000 persons was opened for inspection today. There are eight of these cylindrical tubes built of steel and reinforced concrete at what is considered a safe level below the existing subway stations.

DETROIT, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Athletics beat the Tigers, 5 to 4, today by making good use of their scoring opportunities off Paul (Dizzy) Trout, who retired to his seventeenth defeat when umpires chased him for making a pass at a spectator.

During the President's recent fireside chat he said that prices thirty years ago (that is, the 1909-15 period) were fair parity. Parity is the price at which, for example, a case of eggs, a bushel of potatoes or wheat or corn will now pay for the same or similar unit of labor, common, professional or political, farm machinery or other farm or family necessities, that they would pay for in the base period 1909-15.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- The storage of large quantities of whisky in populous centers of Scotland has caused anxiety among inhabitants of these centers, who are concerned over the danger from fire as a result of air raids, it was learned today.

Nine attractions will be available tomorrow evening to the Sunday theatregoer. They are "Claudia," "Ice-Capades of 1943," "I Killed the Count," "Porgy and Bess," "Ruddigore," "Sons o' Fun," "Stars on Ice," "This Is the Army" and "Tobacco Road."

DETROIT, Sept. 11 -- The billion-dollar bank credit that is being negotiated by the General Motors Corporation probably will take the form of negotiable ninety-day notes which will be eligible for rediscount at the Federal Reserve Banks, it was reported here today.
VICHY, France, Sept. 11 -- In the course of a press conference today with Pierre Laval, Chief of Government, on the question of Madagascar the following three points were brought out:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Department-store sales for the week ended Sept. 5, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, showed a gain of 25 per cent as compared with the corresponding period of last year. The increase followed a decline of 13 per cent in the week ended Aug. 29. For the latest four-week period, sales were 1 per cent higher.

Autumn, with its shortening days and chilly evenings, its relegation of carefree vacations to the realms of memory and its quickening of responsibilities, has its compensations none the less. A blazing open fire is a cheering thing. Fall clothes, priorities notwithstanding, are pretty enough to quicken a feminine pulse.

WHEN they step out on the gridiron, either detachment of this All-Army football team is All-America for a day. A glance at the roster of Colonel Bob Neyland's outfit that meets the Giants at the Polo Grounds today will prove that, with something to spare.

Only one municipal issue of $1,000,000 or more is scheduled for award next week, although twenty-three communities throughout the country will seek bids on new issues of securities. Next week's total of new municipal financing, according to The Daily Bond Buyer of New York, will amount to $3,769,753.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (U.P.) -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested two men today as accomplices of Neville Mecartney, Chicago attorney whose alleged attempts to impede operations of the armed forces were disclosed last week by J. Edgar Hoover, F.B.I. director.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- i The War Department issued today some pictorial evidence that its merged air ferry command and transport operations were doing work.

FORT DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Two hundred and forty-two officer candidates of the Waac, including Caroline T. Tupper, niece of General George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff, will be commissioned at graduation exercises tomorrow.

The Forty-eighth Street Theatre, which has been dark for the Summer, will re-open today with the American premiere of "Soliga Solberg," a Swedish comedy starring Edvard Persson. "Arbetsblocker Sverige," a short subject about Swedish workers, and "Sjung Och Le," a short dealing with the influence of swing music on the young people of Sweden, will be shown in conjunction with the feature film.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 11 -- The index of business activity in the Pittsburgh district, compiled by the bureau of business research, University of Pittsburgh, dropped approximately 1 per cent during the week ended Sept. 5. Most of the decline was caused by contra-seasonal or greater-than-seasonal decreases in coal production, carloading and department store sales.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept 11 (AP) -- Warren Wright's Whirlaway, whose golden goal has been set at a half-million, will make his second consecutive start in the $25,000- added Narragansett Special tomorrow and, according to some of the clockers, he is assured of being hard-pressed at every stage of that mile and three-sixteenths race.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 11 (AP) -- The champion Newark Bears, behind Southpaw Tommie Byrne's sparkling three-hit pitching, smothered the fourth-place Jersey City Giants, 8 to 2, today in the opening battle of the International League Governors' Cup semi-final play-off round.

The Japanese Government has protested to the United States against American allegations that Japan has violated the 1929 Geneva Convention concerning the treatment of prisoners of war, according to a Japanese wireless transmission to the United States yesterday.

PURCHASE, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- The Green Valley entry of Jerry Desio, pro, and Mike Tartaglia captured major honors in the Westchester P.G.A. one-day tournament at Old Oaks Country Club today. With a best-ball 32, 32 -- 61, on which the amateur member helped with seven strokes, Desio and Tartaglia won the pro-amateur event by one shot.

VICHY, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Total British occupation of Madagascar was regarded only as a matter of time tonight by angry Vichy officials, and pro-Axis Frenchmen demanded a "blow-for-blow" retaliation against Britain in the Mediterranean.

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill told an applauding House of Commons today that the operations undertaken against the three main objectives on the French island of Madagascar had been completed with "little opposition and light casualties." The statement coincided with an outburst in the German-controlled French press indicating, some quarters here thought, that there was less desire than when Pierre Laval first took power to conciliate the United States.

How the nation can best take advantage of its available food supply to extract the greatest nutritional value from it will be studied in several of the thirty-six graduate courses in chemistry to be given by Columbia University in the next academic year, which begins Sept. 24, Professor Arthur W. Thomas, acting head of the department, announced yesterday.

Methods of blacking out steel plants in case of an enemy air raid were described in a plan mailed yesterday to every company in the steel industry by the committee on steel plant air raid protection of the American Iron and Steel Institute.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, Sept. 12 -- The best news coming out of the New Guinea area today was that one of a flight of Flying Fortresses got a direct hit on a Japanese destroyer off Normanby Island. The ship was observed to be afire and sinking by the stern and men and rafts were seen in the water.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- After twenty-four hours in the capital R.M. Hadrath, an industrialist of Stillwater, Minn., had not found up to late today any method of giving all his war profits to the government.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- A Curtiss pursuit plane caught fire over the East Buffalo area late this afternoon and after the pilot had bailed out at high altitude plunged nose first through a building of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation airplane division.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- It may be that the Yankees are merely trying to provide the harried Dodgers with a little soothing balm. And then, again, it may be the world champions are running into a little annoying trouble themselves.

Maurice A. Shea of Shea Enterprises, Inc., theatre operator, has leased a terrace apartment in River Edge House, 33 East End Avenue, through the Herbert McLean Purdy Management Corporation which also rented an apartment to Frederick Meyer in the same building.

Although J.B. Priestley's novel, "Blackout in Gretley," has been put over to 1943 publication, the author will be represented on Harper's Fall list through a small book, heavily illustrated, called "Britain at War." It will be brought out some time this month.

The report of the Baruch committee is at once disheartening and encouraging. It is disheartening in its reminders of the record of the past: the failure to build a greater stockpile of crude rubber; "the procrastinations, indecisions, conflict of authority, clashes of personalities, and early non-use of known alcohol processes."
HAVANA, Sept. 11 -- Prime Minister Ramon Zaydin presented the government's new war program to the Senate tonight and asked for a vote of confidence. The entire Cabinet was present at the session.

GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands, Aug. 14 (AP) -- This is the story of a night patrol that was fought in the Solomons. There were four officers and twenty-one enlisted men in this group. Their mission was to penetrate Japanese territory and locate the main center of enemy resistance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Office of Price Administration today expanded the classes of textiles for which a specificed premium of 7 per cent may be charged on export sales and the list now includes practically all goods and yarns made of cotton or artificial fibers.

LONDON, Sept. 11 (U.P.) -- General Draja Mikhailovitch's Yugoslav patriot armies have made destructive raids across the borders of Italy and Bulgaria and have killed 400 Italians in a pitched battle near Banja Luka, 100 miles southeast of Zagreb, Yugoslav spokesmen said tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 11 -- "Fourth Brother," an unproduced play by Archibald Forbes which Paramount has owned for four months, will be filmed in color under the title "China," with John Farrow directing, the studio announced today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 11 -- To Hungary has been offered a dominating role in the new Europe by Dr. Walther Funk, the Reich Minister of Economy and President of the Reichsbank, according to Axis press dispatches reporting on his just concluded three-day official visit to Budapest.

WITH THE UNITED STATES MARINES, on Guadalcanal Island, Solomons, Aug. 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- The marines report that the Japanese today are using all the tricks of fighting they employed in the Philippines.

Despite the fact that a larger number of applications for admission to the Fire and Police School of the Division of Public Service Training at City College have been received this month than in previous terms since its opening two years ago, the school will not admit any additional students, it was announced yesterday by Professor Robert Jahrling, director of the division.

Events moved rapidly yesterday for Ormund Westgate, whose past transgressions finally caught up with him after eighteen years. The most heartening news came from Governor Dwight H. Green of Illinois, who indicated that he would not ask for the extradition of the 50-year-old convict, who escaped from an Illinois State prison while serving a sentence for robbery.

Civic organizations were called on yesterday by Ely Jacques Kahn, president of the Municipal Art Society, to find some solution for the plight of architects, painters and sculptors whose livelihood is endangered by the war. What the solution would be Mr. Kahn said that he himself did not know but he thought that the critical situation needed immediate public attention.

A young man who elevated himself rapidly from commercial photographer to "Army colonel," without benefit of commission, pleaded guilty in Federal court yesterday to charges of wearing a military uniform without authorization. Before his masquerade was spoiled by Army investigators, he had persuaded a Navy intelligence officer to get him a ride on a PT boat similar to those used by the Navy in moving General Douglas MacArthur out of the Philippines.

Signalized by the blowing of the shofar, or traditional ram's horn, Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year 5703, was ushered in yesterday at sundown with services in temples and synagogues in all parts of the world free from Nazi domination.

OTTAWA, Sept. 11 (Canadian Press) -- The United Nations cannot win the war until the English- speaking people unite under one leader and that leader should be President Roosevelt, Major William Duncan Herridge, former Canadian Minister to Washington, declared here today.

A handful of specialties managed yesterday to generate some extra activity with a slight lift in prices, but the main section of the stock market backed away farther from the recovery that appeared at the week's start. The extreme losses of a point suffered in the morning were reduced somewhat in the afternoon when the mild selling subsided and dullness settled over the list.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Sept. 11 -- A scripture-quoting conscientious objector was in the Warren County jail tonight for his own safekeeping after an angry group of his fellow-townsmen in Oxford, N.J., had staged a demonstration outside his home when it became known that he had failed to report for induction into the Army at Fort Dix yesterday.

Ten, with Pictor as the likely favorite, have been named for today's running of the Edgemere Handicap, which will gross close to $12,000 and doubtless attract 25,000 to the Aqueduct race course. The W.L. Brann color-bearer was a driving winner of the Aqueduct Handicap on Labor Day and is top weight with 117 for he Edgemere's nine furlongs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- President Roosevelt expressed the opinion today that it would not be necessary to draft any 18 or 19 year-old youths for military service before the first of the year.
BOSTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say of the Boston wool market tomorrow:

LONDON, Sept. 11 -- The Royal Air Force, with a "powerful" aggregation of four-motored bombers, carried out its fiftieth attack on Duesseldorf last night and left that Rhineland industrial and communications center battered and ablaze.

The Grocery Manufacturers ofI America, in cooperation with theI National Retail Dry Goods Asso-I clarion, has prepared the first com- j prehensive guidebook on the National Nutrition Program and the booklet will soon be dist'ibuted among the nation's retail grocers, Paul S. Willis, president of G. iL A., announced yesterday.

BUFFALO, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Directors of the Buffalo, Niagara and Eastern Power Corporation at a meeting today took no action with respect to dividends on either the $5 preferred or the $1.60 preferred stock.

HARTFORD, Sept. 11 -- Pledging loyal support of President Roosevelt and the National Administration in the conduct of the war, Raymond E. Baldwin of Stratford was nominated today for Governor, at the second session of the Republican State Convention.

PORT WASHINGTON, N.Y., Sept. 11 -- Fifty-five craft were out today for the third session of Race Week at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. Courses were shortened by Race Chairman R.W. Fraser, so that all finished.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (U.P) -- The War Production Board reported today that iron and steel scrap shipments to mills in July fell short by 433,000 tons, or 15 per cent, of the monthly schedule required to meet the 17,000,000-ton quota for the last six months of the year.

The announcement that the War Department has given the "go ahead" signal for the Joe Louis-Billy Conn heavyweight championship bout scheduled for Oct. 12 should prove heartening to those football devotees who are hoping to see another Army-Navy gridiron clash this Fall.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -Edouard Herriot, president of the French Chamber of Deputies, and Jules Jeanneny, president of the Senate, were praised by Secretary of State Cordell Hull at his press conference today for sending their letter of protest earlier this week to Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, chief of the French State, and Premier Pierre Laval denouncing them for establishing a dictatorship.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- In a bantering mood, President Roosevelt broke two wartime rules today as he told his press conference about a personal check on the automobile driving habits of Americans which indicated they still are driving too fast despite appeals for slower speeds as a rubber conservation measure.

The seventh annual charity battle between the New York Giants and the All-Stars will be staged on the Polo Grounds gridiron at 2:15 this afternoon, divorced from its usual collegiate trimmings and gaited entirely along martial lines.
MOSCOW, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Today's Soviet communique:

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 -- The first women bus drivers in the United States will begin operating heavy buses next Monday in Oakland, Calif., William P. St. Sure, vice president and general manager of the Key System of Oakland, told a meeting of the American Transit Association here today.

The fairness of an offer of $675,000 made by defendants for settlement of an accounting action brought by minority stockholders of the Consolidated Oil Corporation will be determined at hearings scheduled to open on Monday under an order of Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins.

While comparative figures will be affected by the shorter week due to the Labor Day holiday, retail trade here this week was active. On a day-for-day basis, sales were reported by store executives as showing a rise of 8 to 10 per cent over the corresponding days last year.

The city Health Department is commemorating the fiftieth anniversary of its laboratory, which was also the first laboratory regularly maintained for biological diagnosis by any public agency in the world.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Declaring for the first time its authority to set aside "any part" of a collective bargaining agreement, the War Labor Board set up a commission today to reduce tire mileage in the New York metropolitan milk industry.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 The American Transit Association ended its sixty-first annual meeting here today with a statement from Powell C. Groner, its president, who declared that the industry faces its greatest crisis and at the same time the greatest opportunity of its history.

JERUSALEM, Sept 11 (U.P.) -- Wendell L. Willkie said today he was greatly impressed by Palestine's war effort, especially the large number of enlistments in the armed forces and by the wartime mobilization of industry and agriculture.

Frank H. Eggers, a member of the City Commission of Jersey City, said yesterday at a hearing under the auspices of the Interstate Commerce Commission that the City Commission and the residents of Jersey City were opposed to granting an increase from 8 to 10 cents for a ride on the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company between Jersey City points and Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The final report of the American Technical Mission to India, under the chairmanship of Dr. Henry F. Grady, for improving the production in India of essential war materials is considered "constructive and timely," and some of its recommendations are already being implemented, according to a joint statement by the governments of the United States and India, made public tonight by the State Department.

The cotton futures market declined moderately near the close yesterday as hedge selling increased. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts ended 6 to 8 points under Thursday's final quotations. Trading was listless.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Cincinnati defeated the Phillies, 8 -- 5, in eleven innings today when Catcher Ray Lamanno sparked a three-run last-inning drive that broke a 5-5 tie with a home run into the left field bleachers.

No new offerings of bonds were made in the New York market this week. Even the municipal issues awarded to banks and banking houses in this city were either held for their own investment account in the case of the banks, or placed privately in the case of the banking firms.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 11 -- The new Women's Auxiliary Ferrying Squadron, formed yesterday to supplement the work of male civilian fliers in ferrying training and liaison planes from factory to field, took off with a flying start at the Newcastle Army Air Base today as five women applicants passed their ground tests for the new service.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Sept. 12 -The Student Safety Council of the University of North Carolina has started a campaign against student-owned pleasure cars. Various organizations have set up a council for the regulation of automobiles.

Everybody believed that Louie Lepetino's death was an accident, and that Ab Hamilton's was suicide; but, then, everybody believed, too, that old Christian Skaas and his handsome nephew Otto were genuine anti-Nazi refugees.

THERE are a number of very good reasons why ailing radios -- or any receiver for that matter -- should be inspected and overhauled now to be ready for the coming wartime broadcast season. Scarcities of vacuum tubes and replacement parts, even of competent servicemen, are growing more and more acute.

MR. PEGLER'S new book is another collection of his essays. Like those which were brought together in an earlier volume, "The Dissenting Opinions of Mr. Westbrook Pegler," these too appeared originally as a syndicated newspaper feature.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 12 -- The 639-foot Benjamin F. Fairless, fourth of five new freighters built for the Pittsburgh Steamship Company, will join the parade of ore carriers on the Great Lakes next week.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- General John J. Pershing, who led the Armies of the United States to victory in the First World War, will be 82 years old tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- It is the duty of all American citizens engaged in war work to vote in the elections this year, Donald M. Nelson, chief of the War Production Board, declared today. What time is required to be taken off in order to cast ballots is justified, Mr. Nelson said, because the right to vote is "what this war is all about."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Johnny Beazley, star rookie right-handed pitcher of the Cardinals, suffered a laceration of the right thumb in a scuffle with an unidentified assailant in the Pennsylvania station tonight. The team physician treated Beazley at his hotel for a minor laceration.

"THE Moon Is Down" spent nine unprofitable weeks at the Martin Beck, but began making money as soon as it took to the road. On the Leventhal circuit it grossed $8,000 in Brooklyn, $6,000 in the Bronx, $8,000 at Passaic, playing at $1 top for a week in each place.
LONDON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- A communique from the British Commander in Chief in East Africa, General Sir William Platt:
Gardeners are often at a loss as to what plants to use in shaded places -- for instance, porches, barren walls of a house, arbors or stone walls.

Axis broadcasts revealed yesterday that Japan's plans for a new "Greater East Asia Ministry" would involve a radical change as part of which the Overseas Ministry would cease to exist and the importance of the Foreign Office would be greatly reduced, The United Press reported.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Sept. 12 -- Smith College will open Monday with an entirely new theatre department under the chairmanship of the newly appointed dean, Hallie Flanagan Davis, who will act also as professor of theatre. Dean Davis will supervise program, give courses and actively participate in the production work.

The documentary film, as evidenced by its extensive use in training soldiers and civilians to meet various problems brought on by the war, will be an important factor in peace-time education, Irving Jacoby, supervisor of the City College Institute of Film Techniques, declared yesterday.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Sept. 12 -- There were four of us in the badly banged-up truck -- Captain Hiesmer Smith of the Australian Army, Tom Yardbrough, Associated Press correspondent; myself and the Australian driver, a man of about 50, named Alf.

A patriotic cabaret revue and supper dance, entitled "Incendiary Blondes," will be presented by the Artists and Writers Association, with the assistance of a special women's division, on Oct. 23 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 12 (U.P.) -- The war has ended a tradition at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, oldest engineering college in America, the secretary-treasurer, Livingston W. Houston, stating today that women students would be accepted for the first time in the school's 116 years.

THERE are thousands of professional baseball players but only 400 major leaguers, and of these really select 400 about 200 are outstanding. The real stars number considerably less. These figures plainly point out that good ball players represent a high degree of perfection in their particular profession.

THE wanton destruction of wildlife has been a shame and a tragedy in this country's annals: a shame and tragedy of which the country began some decades ago to be sensitively and practically aware. "Fading Trails" is the story of tragedy and awareness, of present condition, progress, need and hope.

It can now be put in the book that Hitler will not defeat Stalin in the year of our Lord 1942. That, of course, was what the Fuehrer planned to do. But he will not. When the Spring campaign of 1943 rolls around Russia will be in there fighting. Stalin had promised Washington and London as much and now it is plain he will be able to make good.

Narrow price variations prevailed again yesterday in the cotton futures market. Throughout the two-hour session on the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts held within an eight-point range, and they closed at the day's lows, 9 to 10 points under Friday's final quotations. Hedge selling, although not strong, offset limited trade buying in another small market.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The general index of prices of twenty-eight basic commodities in primary markets, as announced today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, advanced during the week ended Sept. 11 from 167.5 to 168.0. Except for a nominal gain in wool tops there were no increases in the index of prices of commodities controlled by government regulation.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Dr. Henry M. Wriston, president of Brown University, regards Secretary Stimson's announced intention of calling to active service college student members of the Army Enlisted Reserve as they reach the draft age as "a clear reversal of War Department policy."

Among the proposals now being considered by the Army Ordnance Department covering permissible costs in war contracts is one limiting deductions for executive salaries to $9,000 and another allowing only a 4 per cent profit after taxes, according to reports here last week.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, announced yesterday that he had requested a meeting with the New York Shipping Association and would ask that the wage scale clause of the existing contract be reopened in accordance with the agreement's provisions.

A WELL-KNOWN singer observed the other day that he had so many requests to sing at various patriotic rallies, broadcasts and other occasions that he would find it difficult to squeeze in his paying dates. He was, like all other musicians, only too eager to do what he could wherever he could be of service, and he was happy to give his spare time for any worthy cause.

HERE is a book in which a lifelong tree lover describes twenty-nine trees representative of different parts of this country, telling briefly of their growth, leaves, flowers and fruit, while the illustrator, who is also a naturalist, provides twenty-nine full-page, four-color lithographs, showing each tree in its natural setting.

OUT of the mouths of four sad young men -- almost the only survivors of the seventy-eight officers and enlisted personnel of Motor Torpedo Boat Squadron 3 -- W.L. White has fashioned an account of America's disastrous Philippine campaign that is almost unbearably painful at times, yet so engrossing that few who begin it will be able to put it down until they have finished its adventure-packed pages.

The opening of new agricultural and tourist regions in Southern Argentina and Chile through recent developments in modern highway construction is foreseen by travel authorities in Argentina and the United States.

Hope for victory over the forces of enslavement and a better world after the war and recognition of the unity of the Jews with the other defenders of humanity were voiced yesterday by rabbis in sermons which marked here the first full day of Rosh ha-Shanah and the Jewish New Year 5703.

Retail trade here was active last week, but comparison with 1941 suffered because of the short week occasioned by the Labor Day holiday, which occurred earlier last year. On a day-for-day basis, sales volume was estimated as running 8 to 10 per cent higher, but a decline was seen possible for the five-day week against six days last year.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 12 -- Another $50,000 cache was recovered today by San Francisco agents seeking concealed assets in bankruptcy of the Ariani family's first Italian State Bank of Chicago.

WOOD-RIDGE, N.J., Sept. 12 -A new aircraft engine plant so large that it soon will house its own indoor highways and work "villages" with thousands of new employes is rising here for the use of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation, data passed by the War Department showed today.

DR. DOLLARD looks at the subject of fear from virtually every angle. "When fear comes," he says, "stop (don't run) and think." What is more, he gives some constructive suggestions as to what to think about.

AN AMERICAN ARMY BASE IN NEWFOUNDLAND -- After a year and a half the American forces which were sent here to defend this North Atlantic island against possible enemy attack are becoming a definite part of the local scene and are playing an increasingly large role in the social and recreational life of the Newfoundland communities during their off hours.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Jim Tobin pitched the Braves to a 4-1 victory today in the first game of a double-header with the Pirates, but the teams were forced to settle for an eleven-inning 2-2 deadlock in the nightcap to enable the visitors to make train connections.

WEATHER clear; track fast. Captain Johnny Pingel of the All-Army football team won the toss yesterday and elected to receive. Ward Cuff of the Giants, or civilian home defense unit, kicked off and the football season at the Polo Grounds was on.
GUADALCANAL, Aug. 19 (Delayed) -- One of the most determined and effective patrol actions yet attempted against the Japanese forces remaining on Guadalcanal has just been completed.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 12 -- Taking the lead midway down the stretch and moving away easily, A.T. Simmons's Blue Swords scampered to a length victory in the Eastern Shore Handicap today to pick up a purse of $10,800.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 12 (AP) -- With two home runs by George Stirnweiss setting the pace, the champion Bears routed the fourth-place Jersey City Giants, 10 -- 3, today to take a two-game lead in the semi-final round of the Governors' Cup series in the International League.

Information was received by Leon Monosson from Paris last week that Vichy France has produced a deluge of eighty-three stamps for intended use in French possessions. Inasmuch as several of the possessions have affiliated with the Fighting French movement, it appears questionable whether the items prepared for those particular colonies will ever be actually postally used; if they are not, they may not be chronicled in future standard catalogues.

VICHY, France, Sept. 12 -- Springing up at dawn and without any warning, soldiers and police manned machine guns at strategic points in Vichy today and heavily guarded all government buildings and diplomatic hotels in mysterious manoeuvres, which the authorities dismissed as mere practice. Whatever the reason for the bristling of arms all over the city, it was noted that the guns were pointed at roads leading into Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's capital city.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 12 (UP) -- Federal Bureau of Investigation agents said today that Robert T. Bailey of Hattiesburg, Miss., a deserter from Fort Bragg, N.C., was sought in the slaying of two Wisconsin social workers.

OTTAWA, Sept. 12 -- Canada passed into her fourth year of war this week with the comforting knowledge that while the enemy's strength has been weakened by these three years of fighting, hers is still expanding and has not yet reached its peak.

NO woman likes to face a war in the wrong clothes. If it must be done, feminine heroism is equal to the sacrifice, but unless complete disaster sets in, war is, has been, and always will be a stimulus to fashion.

DODGE CITY, Kan. -- The thundering herds are on the move again in the Southwest, many of them over the trails which went into disuse with the coming of the barbed-wire farmer and the homesteader. The tourist who can manage tires and gas for motoring in the range country will find herds on the move to packing and loading centers in numbers that old-timers consider unbelievable.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 12 -- United States medium bombers again launched a heavy raid on Suda Bay, Crete, last night, but clouds obscured the results, it was reported here today. British heavy and medium bombers joined in attacking jetties and harbor installations at Tobruk, starting fires near the water distilleries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Controversy over whether Henry J. Kaiser, West Coast industrialist with a notable record of accomplishment in the production of ships for the government, can build heavy cargo planes as readily as ships reached the boiling point in the capital this week with the arrival of Mr. Kaiser for a series of conferences with Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the WPB.

BULKELEY, Kelly, Akers and Cox, survivors of Bataan, see the newspaper buyers "always grabbing from the newsstands the papers whose headlines turn every skirmish into a great victory" (see the review by Frank S. Adams on Page One of this section), and look on this as an indication of civilian smugness and complacency.

SAY, what's going on around here, anyway? Last March Mayor La Guardia and Commissioner Moss put the burlesque theatres out of business by the simple process of refusing to renew their licenses. Since that time not a tease has been stripped in this chaste neighborhood for 35 cents.

Johnson of Syracuse, Democratic nominee for Representative at Large, it was a}Lrlounced here yesterday by Miss Alice Disbrqw, associate chairman of the Democratic State Committee.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Topped by Monday's general election in Maine, next week's voting will virtually wind up the choosing of candidates for the November Congressional and State elections.

IN chemical terms an adequate diet consists of varying quantities of approximately thirty known substances (amino acids, vitamins, minerals, carbohydrates and fats), as well as several as yet unidentified substances. However, in terms of food the requirements for adequate nourishment may be summarized in a few simple statements pointing out those foods which when eaten collectively in reasonable amounts will supply the essentials.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 (AP) -An increase of $90,550 in pay was received last year by Joseph F. McMahon, salesman and department manager for R.C. Williams Co., food distributors in New York, additional annual reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission showed today.

LOS ANGELES, Calif. -- The city will again witness the gay festival on Mexican Independence Day, which falls tis year on Wednesday. The gala actually starts at 11 P. M of Tuesdays when Olivera Street hears the cry of "grito," which was raised 132 years ago at that hour by Miguel Hidalgo to launch the revolt against Spain.
Delegates to the American kennel Club will hold their quarterly meeting on Tuesday at 2 P.M. at the offices of the club in this city.

VICHY, France, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Vichy government said tonight that French troops were still holding their ground at Maevatanana, Madagascar. Fierce fighting was continuing there at 3:20 P.M., forty-two hours after the vanguard of South African troops reached there, a telegram from the French commander said.

THE later Labor Day holiday this year made it more difficult to compare trade results but retailers last week thought they saw a quickening of consumer demand beyond the usual seasonal experience. Possibly, the reaction from the buying boom early this year has about run its course along with the effects of higher income tax payments.

A new seventy-four-foot pilot house and flying bridge for use as a practical classroom for navigation students will be opened next week on the roof of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, at 25 South Street. Dedication ceremonies will be held Sept. 24 with Clarence G. Michalis, president of the board of managers of the Institute, presiding.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 12 -- A four-run uprising in the ninth inning gave the Red Sox an 8-to-6 victory over the Indians today and a sweep of a two-game series.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 12 -- Having split asunder ten days ago for one brief glimpse inside the country, a glimpse that seemed to portend a pro-Allied orientation of foreign policy, Spain quickly sealed the gap.

A GOOD many whodunits nowadays either ignore the war completely or else use it as background for a situation which involves espionage. In one of the best stories he has written the veteran John Rhode does something quite different.

MEPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 12 -- Barbara Joyce Davis, 13 years old, known as "the Helen Keller girl," will leave Memphis tomorrow to continue her struggle against the dark silence that has closed her in for more than ten years.

A most prized commodity -- news from home -- goes out regularly to the forty soldiers and sailors who have left Warner, N.H., for the camps and battlefronts of the war. It is sent by members of the Warner Women's Club in a wartime undertaking that has won high appreciation from the recipients.

THERE have been tumult and shouting about shortages, priorities, freezing and government restrictions. There have been fret and worry over whether we shall shiver in burlap this war Winter. But despite priorities and all the rest we shall get along.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 12--Referring to an announcement that President Juan Antonio Rios would leave for a visit to the United States Oct. 15, Senator Aniba Cruzat of the Radical party declared today that the Senate was "of the opinion that the President should have absolute freedom of action in dealing with Chile's international policy and the Senators have already expressed this confidence."

A good salon print deserves a good title, but few of them get it. Titling is important, however, and should be regarded as an integral part of picture-making, because the apt word or phrase will set off the subject portrayed as happily as velvet does a diamond.

LONDON, Sept. 12 (Netherlands News Agency) -- How by posing as "stupid Dutchmen" they persuaded an arrogant German Army officer to advance them the money by which they escaped to Great Britain was told today by two 18-year-old Netherlanders now training with the R.A.F.

THIS is a sincere, earnest and sympathetic story of the life of a Kansas youth in the years 1934-35. More than that it reflects, in no small measure, the attitude and the dilemma of intelligent youth throughout the country.

FORT DES MOINES, Iowa, Sept. 12 (AP) -- There is no glamor in being a woman soldier, and the thrills and adventures must remain "strictly private" property of the one who experiences them, the Waacs were told today by a British military woman.

When the 1,000,000 children and 35,000 teachers return to the New York City schools tomorrow, their long Summer vacation at an end, they will find that vast changes have taken place in the classroom. In every sense, the schools are now geared to the war effort.

SAN SALVADOR, Salvador, Sept. 12 (U.P.) -- A union of the five Central American Republics -- Guatemala, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Honduras and Costa Rica -- was proposed by the newspaper Prensa Grafica today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 12 -- "You can bend a man's arm forward up to his shoulder, but if you bend it backward, first thing you know he has two elbows. That's jiu jitsu."

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- So much has been promised for and expected of the air offensive against Germany that whatever is accomplished seems likely to be an anti-climax. That was true when the war began, and it is true now, as the British and the Americans in the West, and the Russians in the East, hammer at the key centers of Hitler-held Europe.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Sept. 12 -- The war has brought about many changes at Bowdoin College. Since Pearl Harbor Bowdoin has gone on a year-round schedule: for the first time in nearly 150 years of its history, the college will award degrees at times other than the regular commencement.

When the newly decorated Persian Room of the Plaza is formally opened for the season with a dinner and dance on the night of Sept. 22, the occasion will be a benefit for the Navy League of the United States. Plans are now being completed for the fete, of which Mrs. John Jacob Astor is chairman.

ASERIES of Victory concerts for service men will be given at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, beginning next Sunday afternoon, with a program by the Stradivarius Quartet. Concerts featuring prominent artists will be presented on alternate Sunday afternoons thereafter at the museum.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Despite the fact that within a couple of months the nation's beverage alcohol distillers will be practically all transferred from the production of alcohol and high wines to operations for the manufacture of munitions and war industrial purposes, officials of the War Production Board see no reason why a shortage of whisky and other alcoholic beverages will result.

CLEAR LAKE PARK, Calif. -- Armed with trowels, shovels, tape measures and notebooks, archaeologists led by Mark Raymond Harrington recently began digging on the shores of Borax Lake to determine whether the prehistoric camp ground there actually contains evidences of the most ancient man thus far discovered in America.

Five tons of scrap metal, including wrought iron railings, from the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and other buildings on the spacious grounds at Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street were turned over to the City Salvage Committe yesterday by Bishop William T. Manning.

There really is "something new under the sun" -- a new flower, one as streamlined and modern as the latest aircraft. While many of our flowers are as old as history itself, the Miniature Rose, so far as is known, really is "something new," as no mention has been found of it in early garden books or rose catalogues.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The National Resources Planning Board estimated today that at the right terms and prices and in the right places the country could absorb 900,000 to 1,200,000 new dwellings a year for the decade after the war and still be in need of a large volume of repairs during the same period.

IT wasn't so hard for a boy to persuade himself that he was playing a winning game against Big Bill Tilden, even if the balls were actually being served only to the side of the house: not hard, for an imaginative and lonely lad of 13, who had to amuse himself quietly after finishing his chores on a Saturday morning, because father was at work on tomorrow's sermon and must on no account be disturbed.

THE humorists on the staff of Punch do not wear cap and bells all the time, and there is a serious intent in a recent contribution to that paper A.P. Herbert. He is an M.P., we must remember, for Oxford University.

Everybody knows the apple merchant who lost ten cents on every bushel of apples, but he sold so many apples that he managed to keep going. Or did he? If he failed to make a good thing of it after all, it may have been because he didn't go into the subway construction and operation business.

A letter from President Roosevelt commending the Propeller Club of the United States for its activities encouraging a strong merchant marine, has been received by Arthur M. Tode, honorary president of the club, he announced yesterday. The President said the country was now building more vessels and completing them faster than any nation in history, and that these ships were now sailing the seven seas with supplies for the battlefronts of the world.

THE exhibition, "Road to Victory -- A Procession of Photographs of the Nation at War," current at the Museum of Modern Art and scheduled to close on Sept. 20, will be continued until Oct. 4. The entire original exhibition will then be sent on a tour of the country.

FOR about three years now I've been sitting behind a desk in a producer's outer office, and in the course of that time I have made something of a study of attitudes and approaches. I have talked to a lot of people about the problems of hunting a job, of making the right impression, of crashing the inner sanctum, of getting a reading.

"THE war and peace cannot be won unless modern geography is understood." A knowledge of geography -- modern geography -- has urgencies far more important than the mere ability to identify the place names in the day's news.
