WHEN the project known as Forty Mercer Street opened at Princeton two seasons ago it was regarded as something of an experiment. The plan was to stimulate an interest in collecting among the undergraduates by bringing them into contact with worthy examples and ideas, by means of informal lectures and through a series of illustrative exhibitions.

A HOUGHTON MIFFLIN Literary Fellowship has been awarded to Donald MacRae of Ellenburg, Wash., for a projected novel which will be a study of the American scene and of the competitive ruthlessness of individual democracy in America from the early years of the twentieth century up to Pearl Harbor.

Beneath bluish searchlight beams probing the night sky for planes lies a United States anti-aircraft defense system of staggering precision. Day and night on the Atlantic and Pacific Coasts, 90-mm. high-altitude guns and automatic weapons for close-in fire are on trigger alert to smash the enemy out of the air.

TOYING with a book and flipping its pages as he reads, hitching a chair back and forth and screwing up his face as he writes, the 7-year-old may get on a parent's nerves, but he is running true to form.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., Sept 19 -- Three persons injured in blasts at the Essex Specialty Company's plant here yesterday morning that took five lives are improving today and there are hopes for the recovery of all three.

A YUGOSLAV guerrilla marching song, with one set of words for the present fight and another for use after victory, has been smuggled into this country and will shortly be introduced here. "Awake, New Slovenia" is its title, and the two Slovenian students who wrote it hope that frequent broadcasts of the song from the United States will help to spread it in Yugoslavia, where it will be heard secretly on the radio.

The British radio said yesterday that the Royal Air Force offensive against Germany had forced Reich Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels to change his "line," the Columbia Broadcasting System's listening station reported.

Spurred by President Roosevelt's statements on Labor Day with respect to anti-inflation measures, members of Congress last week were busy studying various proposals for the stabilization of prices, but it was evident that sentiment had not crystallized on the form that such legislation would take.

FORMAL meat rationing will not go into effect for several months, but few Americans are waiting until the actual coupons are issued to cut down their consumption. Most of us welcome the request for informal self-rationing as a means of hastening final victory in the war.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 12 -- A six-point guide to saving domestic fuel has been prepared by J.W. Pauling, vice president of a heat regulatory company.

HERSHEY, Pa., Sept. 12 -- M.S. Hershey, who founded this community and transformed it from a cornfield to what some call a "Model Town," will be 85 years old tomorrow and will celebrate his birthday by giving a dinner to 820 friends of the Hershey Volunteer Fire Company.

LAST Fall, after a period of heavy air raids, the approach of Field Marshal von Bock's forces to Moscow caused all the principal theatre companies, the ballet dancers, concert artists and orchestras to evacuate the capital.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 12 (AP) -- After coming from behind to tie the score in the ninth, the Senators defeated the Browns, 7 to 6, today on Stan Spence's twelfth-inning triple with one runner on base.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 12 -- In the face of the enormously increased demand for workers by government and industry during the past eight months, the Radcliffe Appointment Bureau has been attempting to recruit alumnae with specialized training who were graduated since 1920.

"Returned to Sender by Censor" is common enough on mail sent to Nazi or Japanese occupied territory since the declaration of war. Of unusual interest, however, is a printed label imposed on a cover addressed to a small town in China that is believed to be still in the hands of the Chinese.

The Rhymer turned the tables on Pictor yesterday at Aqueduct and finished first in a driving finish for the main prize in the $11,375 Edgemere Handicap, which also avenged the defeat the Greentree horse had suffered in the Aqueduct Handicap.

IN case any one is worried, the approaching Autumn will not be a season for shiny noses and stern white lips and waveless hair. There will be plenty of cosmetics to go round. The WPB permits, by volume, as much as ever before of almost everything, with only a 10 per cent reduction in a limited list of cosmetics (largely compiled of such obscure items as eyelash dye and "plucking cream").

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Wheat futures drifted aimlessly today within a range of about 1/2 cent a bushel on the Board of Trade, with traders exercising extreme caution pending developments in Washington in regard to price control legislation. There was sufficient pressure on the market from professional operators and spreaders to give the market an easy undertone, and closing prices were unchanged to 1/4 cent lower than yesterday.

Four and a half months ago President Roosevelt in a radio address to the American people attacked the problem of inflation. His speech outlined a plan he had presented to Congress to check the rising cost of living. He pointed out that already living costs had spiraled 15 per cent in little more than a year and that the rate of increase was being accelerated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Congress has faced many a difficult problem in the last disturbed decade but probably none more complex than the one with which it has now been struggling steadily for more than six months.

The Department of Education of the University of Chicago, acting through Professor Ralph Tyler, chairman, has undertaken to serve as educational consultant to the faculty of the Dalton Schools of this city during the school year about to open, it was announced yesterday by Richardson Wood, president of the Dalton board of trustees.

WHEN Peter Haller returned to Hamilton, described in the guide books as "a clean, lively New England city," after a thirteen-year absence, in the course of which he had gained some small fame in journalistic circles, incidentally absorbing vast amounts of Scotch whisky, he found that, notwithstanding rose-tinted nostalgic memories of his natal city, it was remarkably like other places he had worked in.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 12 -Possibility of sabotage was studied today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the crash of a blazing, pilotless plane late yesterday afternoon through the roof of a building of the Curtiss-Wright airplane division, with death for twelve persons and injury for thirty-five.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- A graphic illustration of how low-speed automobile driving helps to conserve tires was found by President Roosevelt today in going over a report of the automobile and rubber industries committee of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

For the "Biography of a Poster" in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine I want to express my warmest appreciation. Not only was the story explanation of Mr. Rockwell's achievement full of information but the color reproduction seemed to me strikingly adequate.

Pretty soon now Grand Central and Penn Station will be swarming with young people on their way back to school. There will probably not be enough porters to go around and lots of girls and boys will have to carry their own bags, which therefore ought to be lightweight and also strong enough to take a kicking around.

Perry Mason faces a definite threat of disbarment before he rounds up the case of the careless kitten; and his ever-helpful secretary, Della Street, is actually arrested and tried for impeding the due processes of law.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Sept. 12 -- A moonlight garden musicale will be given here Sept. 24 on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Leeds Still- man by Miss Marjorie Lawrence, soprano, of the Metropolitan Opera, and Prince George Chavchavadze, pianist.

S.Z. SAKALL, who has almost as many pseudonyms chins, doesn't have to know what he's talking about to be a successful actor. Speaking his lines phonetically and without the slightest knowledge of English he stole large portions of his first Hollywood picture, "It's a Date," from Deanna Durbin and an impressive cast.

A SPITFIRE BASE, Somewhere in England, Sept. 12 (U.P.) -- Royal Air Force pilots have given up some of their best planes, fields and barracks to boost American morale by making United States fliers feel at home.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 12 -- Out of the great demand for trained men and women brought on by the war will likely come more adult education and a higher cultural standard in the deep South, according to professors of Tulane University.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- While the German forces have battered at Stalingrad's defenses, the Nazi radio has kept up a bombardment of its own by vilifying the Russians even as it paid an implied tribute to their staying qualities and their military power.

To make the teaching of modern languages more useful during the war and the period of reconstruction following it, City College will introduce courses in Russian and military German, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 12 -- The first impression of any one arriving fresh in India with an honest desire to find out what it's all about is sheer, overwhelming bewilderment. It is not so much the magnitude of the problems involved as the absence of a middle ground upon which one can take one's stand and calmly survey the countryside.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col. -When people stop you in the street and beg you to help clean up their crabapples you know that Autumn has come to upland Colorado. In the Front Range towns every other householder owns a crabapple tree, and the tart red fruit fails as the first gold touches the aspens and scrub oaks and the first snow whitens Pike's Peak.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 -- Skillful women chemists are not only in greater demand to replace men in the armed services but also to fill in expanded staffs in industrial plants, according to Chester M. Alter, assistant professor of chemistry at Boston University.

UNDER David Schooler, director of music of USO-Camp Shows, an experimental program of concert work has been carried on for the last few months in military and naval stations, chiefly in the New York metropolitan area.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 12 -- The Japanese soldiers in China today, according to accounts from the war areas, are no longer the same sort of fighters who came crashing into the country five years ago, intoxicated with easy conquest for the glory of their god-emperor.

THE protean complexion of Axis broadcasting is perhaps best demonstrated in the termite beam "Mexican." This rattlesnake of the air is a good example of just what Americans are fighting. Under the guise of a neutral, broadcasts containing poisonous Nazi catch phrases are sent out as coming from the Western Hemisphere.

WILLOW RUN, Mich., Sept. 12 -- "One day soon traffic will jam the air roads from Willow Run to Tokyo and Berlin, and those roads will be crowded with 4-motored B-24 bombers produced at Willow Run," said Robert F. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, in an address today at ceremonies dedicating the new system of highways to the big plant here.

The burning of the former passenger liner Manhattan at sea on Sept. 3 continued last week to be a mystery to the men who sailed on her and operated her and who knew the attention given to fire-resisting materials and safety equipment in her construction.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Without in the least wishing to appear unpatriotic, the paper box industry, both set-up and folding, is not averse to letting it be known that it would appreciate a little more business from old customers, now that the need for extreme economy is past and both paperboard inventories and box making capacities are more than ample for current orders.
LONDON, Sept. 12 (Canadian Press) -- High scores and big crowds featured play in British football leagues today.

Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh announced yesterday that seventy-seven members of the Fire Department would be advanced to higher rank tomorrow at exercises marking the induction of 200 new firemen into city service. The exercises will be held at Auxiliary Fire Headquarters, 87 Lafayette Street. Mayor La Guardia and Commissioner Walsh will address the rookie fire fighters.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Sept. 12 -- With women rapidly joining the ranks of Uncle Sam's war production front to replace eligible fighting men, Pennsylvania State College has attempted to increase the supply of women by suggesting certain curricula which will fit into the wartime needs of the nation.

A Ford Motor Company advertisement in THE TIMES of Sept. 6 begins: "On the eve of America's sixty-first Labor Day it can truthfully be said that the future welfare of the world rests squarely on the shoulders of the nation's 53,000,000 workers."

Palm Springs, Calif., reports an increasing number of inquiries for the coming season from visitors of past years. In fact, Desert Inn, one of the largest hotels in the area will open on Oct. 1, a month earlier than usual, to take care of guests requesting Fall reservations.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Lawn-making time is here; the sooner seed is sown the stronger growth before frost. . . . . Evergreens of most sorts can be transplanted advantageously at this time of year, and conditions this season, with moist soil and cool weather, are exceptionally favorable. . . . . Get big weeds before they seed; if they can't readily be pulled up they can be cut off at the roots.

Much has changed but even more has remained the same in country fairs. They have withstood geographical expansion, economic changes and quite a series of wars. This war is no exception. It looked for a while, early in the Summer, as though these rural gatherings and displays of produce would have to stop for the duration, and quite a few were canceled.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 12 -- Lehigh University students returning to the campus this Fall are finding a greater emphasis upon those activities which contribute directly to the war effort and a more exacting system of checking class attendance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (Science Service) -- Two improvements over present methods are claimed in a new system for blind landing of airplanes invented by Andrew Alford of New York, who has received United States patent No. 2,294,882.

LONDON, Sunday, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The R.A.F. disclosed something new and destructive today in its offensive against Hitler -- squadrons of night-prowling train-wreckers whose "engine-shooting sorties have put a big crimp in German internal transportation."

SANTA MARIA, Calif., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Thomas T. Weldon, deputy district attorney, said that Robert Bailey, 21 years old, an Army deserter, admitted tonight that he had been present when two Kenosha (Wis.) social workers were killed.

By making selections now and planting this Fall, the brilliance of hardy Phlox may be enjoyed next Summer. These are among the most colorful of flowers and some of the new varieties are sure to bring delight to the gardener. Liberal plantings make it possible to maintain blooms from June into September.

During the week two moves aimed at increasing the pool of man and womenpower needed to sustain our expanded aviation program were made. The first, which will train New York high school boys in elementary ground courses, will have its full effect in the not too distant future, but the second, which brings women fliers into active service with the Army's Ferrying Command, will become effective immediately.

THE endlessly fascinating pre-Raphaelites, that group of young artists and poets who in the middle of the nineteenth century began pulling the tail of the British lion, are again the subject of a biography, "The Pre-Raphaelite Tragedy" by William Gaunt, former editor of the English magazine, The Studio.

ROCK HILL, S.C., Sept. 12 -Some old ideas about what fields of college study best fit the interests and aptitudes of women are being revised at Winthrop College, the South Carolina college for women, as this school of 1700 girls adjusts itself to meet the needs of the war effort.

While working here by the window this morning I can see a British merchant ship anchored in the stream. Even in her peacetime dress of black hull, white upper works and colored funnel she would not be much to look at.
Mrs. Lawrence Lewis Gillespie has arrived from Newport and is at the Pierre before going to Hot Springs, Va.

A workshop in elementary education in which public school teachers will meet to explore pedagogical problems created by the war will be offered this semester by Queens College in cooperation with the division of elementary education of the Board of Education, Dr. Paul Klapper, president of the institution, announced today.

SINCE the Fourth of July, when "This Is the Army" began turning them away at the Broadway Theatre, there have been columns of type -- much of it, understandably enough, in emotional upper case -- in its praise, but singularly little has been written about its dancing.

Several hundred controllers, treasurers and other chief accounting executives of leading American business organizations will discuss inflation control, as well as legal and accounting aspects of the problem, at the annual meeting of the Controllers Institute of America, which opens a three-day session on Sept. 21 at the Palmer House, Chicago.

Calling attention to the increased need for war film personnel, Irving Jacoby, supervisor of the Institute of Film Techniques at City College, announces new workshop courses in the production and use of public information and training films.

HONOLULU, Sept. 12 -- Diamond Head and Waikiki were black beneath the stars tonight and armed sentries patrolled the beaches of Hawaii as "the Islands," their peacetime languor and glamor gone, began their tenth month of war.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 12 -- Republican party prospects for the Fall elections are looking up.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- "The Star-Spangled Banner" will be 128 years old on Monday and the Library of Congress will commemorate the anniversary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Determined Japanese attacks upon United States forces in the Solomon Islands in an effort to recapture positions from which the Americans drove them a month ago were reported in a Navy Department communique issued tonight.

Based on the initial results of a questionnaire recently sent to members, the Export Managers Club released yesterday a list of twenty-one steps which exporters are now required to take in handling an export transaction under wartime regulations.

A recommendation that the teaching of United States history be made mandatory in all colleges and universities in this country was made yesterday by Frederick A. Van Fleet, newly elected governor general of the General Society of Mayflower Descendants, in an address before the society meeting at the Hotel Biltmore.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 12 -- The year's "dream race" failed to develop today, when Alsab refused to tangle with Whirlaway in the $25,000 added Narragansett Special -- and he's probably lucky he didn't.

Holdings of United States Government securities by the twelve central banks of the Federal Reserve System have reached the unprecedented total of more than $3,500,000,000. And the trend from now on can be only upward, relieved now and then by a temporary lull.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 12 (U.P.) -American war supplies are now being flown from India to China over a new 600-mile night trail blazed by United States Army fliers after day transports were threatened by Burma-based Japanese planes.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A communique by General Douglas MacArthur's command:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- In order to relieve a threatened war shortage of manila and other fibers used in rope and twine, caused by Japanese seizure of the normal supply sources, probably 16,000 acres will be planted to the manila fiber plant In Panama and Costa Rica, by the end of this year, the Office of War Information said today.

Utilizing advertising as a weapon in the war effort, leaders in United States industry, in response to the program recently launched by the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, are about to begin an all-out campaign to promote their products on an industry-wide basis in the other American republics, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept 12 (AP) -- A warning that deferred draft registrants who failed to support the war effort would be reclassified immediately came today from selective service headquarters.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 12 (AP) -- An acute war-caused labor shortage threatened shutdowns for a dozen canneries and enormous losses in Indiana's bumper tomato crop today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Sharp curtailment of travel to football games and other sports events in order to conserve transportation facilities for war purposes was ordered today by Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- Reports from Madagascar tonight indicated that British forces, despite some resistance that included blocked roads and destroyed bridges, were making rapid progress toward accomplishment of their purpose -complete occupation of the island.
MOSCOW, Sept. 12 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

Many gardens nowadays can't afford such a luxury as a full-sized fruit tree. Some, indeed, are crowded by the four or five foot spread of even the smallest dwarfs. But almost any garden has room for a few espaliered fruit trees, for espaliers have only height and length; they adapt themselves to walls and fences and take up practically no space at all.

WASHINGTON, Sept 12 -- Charles T. Douds, who was regional director at Pittsburgh from 1937 to 1941, has been appointed by the National Labor Relations Board as regional director at New York, taking the place of Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick who resigned recently to take a job with the Todd Shipyards Company.

The New York Power Squadron will swing into the cold weather, off-season instructional schedule tomorrow night when the first of its elementary piloting classes will be held at the High School of Commerce, Sixty-fifth Street west of Broadway, beginning at 7:30 o'clock.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- London paid tribute today to over 450 heroic merchant seamen engaged in convoy work, including the men who had braved the dangers of voyages to Malta and Murmansk. A large gathering cheered them at a special concert in Albert Hall where a number of them sat diffidently in specially reserved boxes with their wives and families.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. French and Spanish Departments, at New Jersey College for Women has increased more than 100 per cent since 1940 while the number of students taking French and German decreased, it was announced today by Miss Esther W. Hawes, registrar.
