WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (Wide World) -- To prevent transportation bottlenecks, the railroads and the government are cooperating to keep track of all the freight cars in the country.

AT SEA WITH THE PACIFIC FLEET, Aug. 15 (Delayed) -- A week ago yesterday [Aug. 6 in New York, Aug. 7 on this side of the International Date Line] a task force of the Pacific Fleet, augmented by Australian warships and a hard-bitten contingent of United States Marines, assaulted and captured the port area of Tulagi, Japan's main base in the Solomon Islands on the edge of the Coral Sea.

A NEW fashion season is dawning, one of the most vital in the history of American design. Operating under wartime restrictions and completely freed from any foreign influence, designers have met the challenge and are creating authentic all-American styles, suited to the needs of the emergency.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- A "standsit seat," designed to increase by 25 to 40 per cent the seating capacity of buses and street cars and thus help to cope with the problem of rush hour traffic in wartime, will be tried out in Washington, beginning Sept. 21.

The volume of Argentine exports for the first eight months this year was 3,666,000 tons, as compared with 4,221,000 tons for the similar period of 1941, a decline of 13.1 per cent, according to figures issued here yesterday by the Argentine Information Bureau.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 11 (Delayed) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's statement about India brought a profound shock of disappointment to those Indian spokesmen whom this correspondent was able to reach today, but it brought equal satisfaction to British officials, whose viewpoint it completely supports.

Retail trade was good last week in the three major test markets of New York. Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors and basements were active, college shops crowded.

Joseph H. Cronin's letter in your issue of Sept. 6 seems to the amateur student of military history very well taken. Specially so the statement as to the danger of assuming that time is necessarily always on our side. Every step that our enemy is taking in Russia means plus for him and minus for us, and that might very well mean time as well as material gains.

THE fabled distress of Lysistrata and the other Athenian belles when their menfolk departed for the wars may soon be experienced, in a measure, by those modern females who dote on the cinematic fascinations of certain male movie stars. For patriotic fervor and the Selective Service Act are rushing the men of Hollywood, like all others, into war ranks these days, and rapidly the prospect is looming of movies depleted of males.

Installment sales by furniture stores last month were about 35 per cent under a year ago, principally as a result of the credit restrictions under Regulation W but also because of other factors which are curtailing trade in general, retailers said yesterday.

A favorite writer of garden stories compares a planting of Winter Aconite to "fair-haired little boys in a tumbling act." Truly the comparison is an apt one, as any one will agree after seeing the little buds just before they turn right side up and expand their golden petals to the wan sun of late February or early March.

THE spectacular emergence of General Hideki Tojo as dictator of Japan, and his proclamation of a "Holy War" against the United Nations, to last, if necessary, for a hundred years, marks another triumph for totalitarianism. With it Japan takes her place side by side with Germany and Italy as the sworn enemy of the world's democracies, ideologically as well as militarily.

The first experimental evidence that high blood pressure, the most deadly disease of civilized man, can be produced by feeding animals diet deficient in a group of vitamins of the all-important B family is reported in the Journal of Experimental Medicine, published by the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 -John B. Stetson Jr., former Ambassador to Poland and a Captain in charge of flying instruction in France during the first World War was sworn in as a Major in the Marine Corps today.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Sept. 7 -- Hundreds of engineers and thousands of laborers have begun work on various sections of the Pioneer Road that is being rushed by the United States Government to connect the completed sections of the Inter-American Highway from Texas to the Panama Canal.
MIAMI, Ariz., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Women are going to work for Arizona's copper mines.

Urging New Yorkers of high school and college age to return to school as their part of the war effort, Miss Elizabeth Roemer, counselor for Vocational Service for Juniors, who is acting as special consultant for the War Jobs Training Information Unit of the United States Employment Service, said yesterday that they can serve their country best by preparing for future use in the armed forces and industry.

I am glad that you have already called the attention of your readers to the proposal of the Federal Government to condemn a portion of the Adirondack Forest Preserve in order to construct a branch railroad.

RAVAGES of the war are less noticeable in the world of fashion than in any other sphere. There have been drastic changes in Britain's mode of living and eating habits. Industry, business and home life have been revolutionized, yet, even though rationing and shortages are making the going more difficult, fashion goes on.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept 12 -- Steps to protect several hundred million dollars' worth of American investments confiscated by Japanese in the Philippine Islands will be taken by the Philippine-American Chamber of Commerce, which filed articles of incorporation today with Paul Peck, Secretary of State of California. Headquarters will be in San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- All motorists in the non-rationed areas of the country were urged today by Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, to observe the same rules in using their cars that are enforced in the rationed Eastern area, as a means of conserving rubber tires until a national gasoline rationing plan can be put into effect.

We are indebted to the Citizens Emergency Committee on Non-Defense Expenditures for bringing to light some instances of Federal publicity that might be spared if we were going in for non-defense economy. Four days before Pearl Harbor the Navy Department released to the nation the favorite recipes of Navy officers' wives.

Reorders for all types of merchandise were heavy last week as Fall consumer purchasing hit its stride, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. It was evident, the report continued, that the inventory control announcement did not deter stores from ordering needed merchandise.

Your newspaper reports this morning that the Senate and House are split on the price-rule bill, which the country, in its present frame of mind, regards as one of the most important measures under consideration.

PLANDOME, L.I., Sept. 12 -- The combination that annexed top honors in last year's member-guest tourney at the Plandome Golf Club, Art Sullivan and F.W. Hombert of the Forest Hill Field Club in Bloomfield, N.J., had a short reign in this year's event.

HERMANN RAUSCHNING has written some of the most revealing books yet published on the nature of National Socialism, the character of the Nazi leaders, and the reasons and circumstance of their rise to power.

It was in 1845 that a man named Lansford Hastings wrote a book called "The Emigrant's Route to Oregon and California": and that book guided the ill-fated Donner party into tragedy in the Sierras in the following year. But in 1941 or thereabouts a "desert rat" rode a burro up to Simon Lash's door in Hollywood and announced that he was that same Lansford Hastings.

MILDRED JORDAN, the author of "One Red Rose Forever." has written a new novel which is subtitled "A pennsylvania Legend." It has definitely the charm of legend, founded on the real and earthy environment of a Pennsylvania Dutch farm, rich in the scent of things growing, harvested and marketed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- There is a wide and only partly explored area in the American system of constitutional government where dwell the "implied powers" of the President, particularly in time of war. Whenever a President draws upon these powers, entering what has been called "the dark continent in our jurisprudence, with undetermined boundaries," a conflict arises with the legislature or judicial branches of the government, both coordinate with Executive under the Constitution.

OUR appetite for knowledge of things Russian grows with each new heroic stand made by the Red Army and the Soviet people. Russian music has scarcely been neglected at any time, for the Russians have always known how to sing and their greatest composers, men like Mussorgsky and Tchaikovsky, who transmuted that gift of song into great works of art, are as familiar as any one in the repertory.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Russian midnight communique:

THE emphasis which the motion-picture industry has laid on "the blood and thunder" aspects of the war, at the expense of the less easily dramatized problems of the conflict, was deplored this week by the Motion Picture Bureau of the Office of War Information in a report which surveyed film production since last March 1.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 12 -- Believing that orientation work for freshmen has taken on increased importance under the wartime plan which calls for completion of a semester's study in fifteen weeks instead of the usual eighteen, Colgate University will use a continuing program during its 124th year starting this week. George Werntz Jr., director of admissions, announced today.

WITH the performance of Edmund Rubbra's Fourth symphony the unusually generous list of novelties in the season of Promenade concerts has come to an end and the last novelty has proved in some respects the most notable of all.

FOR its fourth season the Philadelphia Opera Company, under Sylvan Levin, is preparing the most ambitious schedule it has attempted during its career. This year besides its regular performances in Philadelphia the organization makes a six-week tour taking it to cities of upper New York, New England, Ohio and Michigan.

SYNTHETIC -- An anonymous chemist attending the meeting of the American Chemical Society at Buffalo last week delivered himself of his sentiments on synthetic rubber in a bit of synthetic verse, read by Professor Harry N. Holmes, president of the society, at its annual banquet, in the presence of Lieut. Gen. William S. Knudsen, Dr. Edward R. Weindlein and many other distinguished industrialists, chemists and government representatives.

PORT WASHINGTON, N.Y., Sept. 12 -- Race Week at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club ended tonight after the fourth and final contest had to be called off because of an overhead that was idle and blank in contrast to a morning atmosphere such as sailing craft require to get anywhere.

I realize that as a foreigner enjoying this country's hospitality I should abstain from discussing American propaganda methods. But I have always been an active defender of the cause of democracy, and I hope that these few comments will not be taken amiss.

Edouard Herriot, President of the French Chamber of Deputies, is a man now 70 years of age. For more than thirty years he was a prominent figure in the political life of France, three times as Premier, a position he lost once, so it was said, because he advocated payment of the war debt to the United States.

Negotiations are nearly completed for the acquisition by the Coast Guard of Travers Island, country place of the New York Athletic Club on Long Island Sound off Pelham Manor, N.Y., for use as a rest home and recreation center, it was learned last night.
CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Like the armed forces, American wartime industries will soon be able to draw upon peace-time professional men to serve as their "officers."

DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 12 -- Twenty-two classes on the program at the benefit horse show given today on the polo field of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club drew an unexpected entry of more than 350 and created great interest, especially among the junior riders.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 -- The President's successive statements on the necessity of controlling inflation are admirable as far as general principles are concerned. Any one inclined to be critical might say that he has failed to indicate how inflation is to be avoided.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Special House Committee on un-American activities has been put on the spot by the Department of Justice, its famed Federal Bureau of Investigation and by the Interdepartmental Committee on Investigations, but the House, which created it and has sustained it through nearly four turbulent years, does not seem to be much impressed.

GREENSBORO, N.C., Sept. 12 -- Observance of the fiftieth anniversary of the Woman's College of the University of North Carolina will culminate on Founder's Day, Oct. 5, in an academic celebration. Lieut. Comdr. Mildred H. McAfee of the Waves, who is president of Wellesley College, and Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president of Johns Hopkins University, will be the speakers.

To give volunteer hostesses special training in how to act, dress and converse with service men at entertainments, informal courses covering these topics will be featured as part of the Fall program at the Young Women's Christian Association.

From the Treasury's point of view, the "Victory Tax," approved by the Senate Finance Committee, should have much to commend it. It is expected to raise a revenue of $3,650,000,000; it will permit of being in large part withheld at the source of payment; it contains the principle of enforced saving; and the cost of collecting the tax should be comparatively moderate.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Sept. 12 -- As preparations are under way for the opening of the seventy-seventh year at the University of Kansas here next week, there are strong indications that the university, like hundreds of war production plants throughout the nation, has become a proving ground for its curricula.

The present emergency calls for the use of chemical nitrogen for war purposes. Because of this fact, restrictions are being placed upon its incorporation in and use in the manufacture of complete chemical fertilizers. We have become so accustomed to the use of the numerous and excellent fertilizers that the restricting order has jolted our complacency.

ATLANTA, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Dr. Howard W. Odum, president of the Commission on Interracial Cooperation, said today that he believed the results of the Gubernatorial primary in Georgia and the recent Senatorial campaign in South Carolina "shows clearly that the race issue no longer has its old-time political appeal."

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Sept. 12 -To prepare every student to be immediately useful in some way to the war effort, the War Council of Vassar College, in cooperation with the Red Cross, the State Office of Civilian Defense, and the United States Civil Service Commission, has organized ten extracurricular war service courses for the coming year.

Out of the pressing need for college-trained personnel in the present war effort has risen an insistent demand for extending opportunities for higher education. It is urged that the government and the colleges act promptly to make college available to all qualified young men and women, regardless of their financial status.
BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Sept. 12 (AP) -- An Axis submarine entered Carlisle Bay today and fired five torpedoes at vessels in the bay, in the first attack of the war on this British West Indies island.

KEYNOTER: Clare Boothe Luce, playwright, war correspondent and wife of Henry R. Luce, publisher of Time, Life and Fortune, delivered the keynote address to the Republican State Convention in Connecticut last week. She accused President Roosevelt's Administration of talking a "tough" war and fighting a "soft" one, and pledged the party to cooperation in the war effort, honest criticism of the Administration's mistakes.

WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 12 -- Miss Vivien Kellems, aspirant for the Republican nomination to Congress from Connecticut's Fourth Congressional District, today assailed her rival. Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce of Greenwich, as one whose nomination "would be a victory for those who wish to nullify our Constitution and substitute an evil internationalism for our true democracy."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The cost of living in large cities rose by 0.4 per cent between July 15 and Aug. 15, due noticeably to sharp increases for certain foods exempt from price control, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

An unidentified secret German radio station, which apparently began to go on the air only a few days ago, yesterday broadcast an appeal to German workers to "end the Hitler war" and "the whole damned Nazi filthiness." The broadcast was heard by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

DETROIT, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Bob Johnson drove in five runs for the Athletics today, but the Tigers staged a three-run seventh-inning rally to send the game into extra frames and then beat the Mackmen, 6 to 5, in the eleventh, on Don Ross's double and Barney McCosky's single.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission was asked today by the Public Service Commission of the State of New York to discontinue its proceedings in connection with the application of railroads for a 10 per cent increase in commutation fares in New York State and to vacate its order of April 13 for an investigation of the railroad's application.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Rookie Pitchers Andy Lapihuska and George Hennessey held Cincinnati to six hits today, but the Reds defeated the cellar-dwelling Phils, 4 to 1.

The Cleveland Orchestra announces that in celebration of its forthcoming twenty-fifth anniversary season it offers a prize of $1,000 for a new unpublished and unperformed orchestral work not to exceed fifteen minutes in duration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -Members of the Senate Finance Committee were told by the Treasury today that their action on the tax bill had added only $830,000,000 to the annual revenue provided in the House bill and they indicated that they might consider further changes in the levies on individuals.

NOW that Director John Huston has put on a soldier's uniform, we will have to postpone for a period our anticipation of further films from him. Uncle Sam has a job for him which is tougher than anything on the Warner lot.

War, transportation and personnel exigencies are all combining to require merchants to make the earliest start in years on Christmas sales planning, it was indicated in retail circles here last week. Merchants expect some gift buying to develop later this month, more in October and a great deal more in November than was the case last year.

SCHENECTADY, Sept. 12 -- A New Zealand mother is happy today in the knowledge that her doctor son is safe and well in an Italian prison, disclosed to her by Harold Denny, New York Times correspondent, in a broadcast over WGEO, General Electric's short-wave station.

WITH THE AMERICAN AIR FORCE FLYING FORTRESS COMMAND, Somewhere in England, Sept. 12 (AP) -- While British and United States bombers roared in the sunlight overhead, Major Gen. Carl A. Spaatz, commander of the United States air forces in Europe, personally decorated twenty-two members of Flying Fortress crews today for "extraordinary valor" in battles with the German air force.

THE deal now under discussion whereby the United Artists Distributing Corporation would acquire for release a group of completed Paramount pictures was wrapped in official silence last week. Rumor and unofficial opinion anent the unique transaction were plentiful, however.

This year's Red Badge prize-winner starts off as one of those tales where you don't know where you're at. Literally, of course, you know very well: in the smart and ordinary smooth-running resort hotel which attracts all man ner of pleasure-seeking folk to Brunswick, Ga.
CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- The Yankees, never given to dawdling along the line, or brooding overly-much over past misadventures, veered sharply about today after suffering two successive shutouts.

An emblem indicating an "active graveyard" will soon be seen in the United States. It will appear in yards that are cooperating with the country's war production effort by actively turning their junked cars into essential iron and steel scrap within sixty days.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Sept. 12 -- A new plan of student advisement is being introduced with this year's freshmen class at Elmira College. Previously the dean of the college had been the only freshman adviser, but this year eighteen faculty members will form a new advisory council.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Sept. 12 -- At the end of her third week at war Brazil can put in the credit column tighter anti-blockade measures with the aid of United Nations forces, restricting submarine activities; greater quantities of war materials leaving Brazil and reaching their destinations safely and more Allied ships arriving in Brazil to load ore and other war materials.

Adverse reports of the battle of Stalingrad are not causing any particular reaction among the British people, Harold A. Reed, a consultant to the United States Army Chief of Transportation and the Service of Supply in England, reported yesterday afternoon when he arrived at La Guardia Field aboard a transatlantic clipper.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 -- Production of steel ship plates was resumed on a capacity basis tonight in the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation's 160-inch plate mill at the Gary, Ind., works after a short-lived wildcat strike had threatened to paralyze the mill's war work.

WHEN William Bendix left New York for Hollywood about a year ago he thought he'd be right back. Metro had issued a summons for him to play the shadow-boxing barkeep in "Woman of the Year," but it was strictly a one-picture deal and Mr. Bendix wasn't taking any chances -- he left his wife and small daughter at home.

Women of seven different nationalities, whose countries are on either side of the world conflict, compose the present membership of the newly formed Allied unit of the National Security Women's Corps. Registration has been taken during the past month for the unit, being organized under the command of Mrs. Matty Freedman, an Englishwoman who has lived a number of years in New York.

IT is not difficult to obtain a good nutritious diet, one that is optimal in all respects. Neither need it be monotonous or expensive, though it may be both without careful planning. The food must be cooked so as to preserve its vitamin and mineral content, and served so that each meal constitutes an adventure in good eating.

Five members of the suppressed French Parliament, now residing in this country, endorsed yesterday the message sent earlier in the week by two of their former associates to Marshal Henri Philippe Petain and Pierre Laval, heads of the Vichy government, in protest against any move to draw France into war against "our Allies."

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 12 -- An unpretentious three-story building on this village's main street, described by State police as the "headquarters of the policy racket in Rockland County," was raided late this afternoon by ten troopers, who arrested four men on gambling charges and seized four truckloads of gambling equipment.

MOSCOW, Sept. 12 -- The Soviet press does not hide the great importance that the government attaches to retention of control of the Volga. It is now more than two months since the Soviet people were told that the giving up of further territory would reduce the country's fighting capacity and threaten centers and communications vital to Russia's continued existence.

No longer can the gourmet lightly journey to Cape Cod for clambakes, to the Southwest for barbecues, to the Midsouth for corn roasts. Gas rationing and the demands of war industry compel the food enthusiast to seek culinary delights closer to home, in many cases to be his own chef.

Is the phrase "consensus of opinion" really tautological, as your correspondent insists? The contention is that "consensus" is an agreement of opinion and that the words "of opinion" in the phrase are therefore unnecessary.

When Montaigne died, 350 years ago today, France was turbulent. Montaigne's life had been spent in a milieu of lawlessness, civil wars and religious persecution. He had witnessed the massacre of St. Bartholomew, with its disastrous effect on French scholarship.

The German Foreign Office attack last Thursday on correspondents of Swedish newspapers for an "unneutral attitude" and for "glorifying" the British Royal Air Force, was based not on articles published in Stockholm but on a report by a British news agency, it was disclosed yesterday in a dispatch from Stockholm to the American Swedish News Exchange here.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 11 (Delayed) -- After stating that the purpose of his tour was to stimulate the peoples of the Middle East and other countries to make greater contributions to the war effort, Wendell Willkie. President Roosevelt's representative, said today that America wanted not only to win the war but also to establish peace.
HERE is an analytical exposition by a brilliant young reporter of conditions within the Nazi State when Hitler declared war on the United States.

EVANSTON, Ill., Sept. 12 -- Anticipating the time when nearly all students of college age will be subject to the draft, Northwestern University has prepared a comprehensive educational program which will coordinate training in the fundamentals of military service with regular college work.
LONDON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- "Most astounding, my dear Holmes!"

Offices of the United States Employment Service in New York have selected more than 400 experienced seamen from several thousand applicants who have responded to the government's appeal for the registration of former seafarers, it was announced yesterday.

The Whittakers move next door to a crooked political boss who is much hated -- and promptly murdered. A murder next door should be no concern of the Whittakers, but it so happens that they are both department store detectives and that Mrs. Whittaker (nee Mary Carner) has already solved four murder mysteries.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Sept. 13 -The Russians have fallen back from one point southwest of Stalingrad before the massed blows of German tanks and motorized troops, but elsewhere the Soviet legions are holding their own in bitter-end fighting that has cost the Germans at least 10,000 men killed before the city in the last few days.

LONDON, Sept. 12 -- All information at hand here indicated today that another major phase of the air warfare in this theatre is in the making -- a phase in which heavily reinforced Nazi air fleets will try to "slug it out" with the Royal Air Force and the United States Army Air Forces for a final decision.

LONDON, Sept. 12 (U.P.) -This year's harvest of wheat and rye in German-occupied Europe is expected to be 15 per cent less than last year's and 25 per cent less than the 1935-38 average, reliable reports from the Continent indicated today.
MUSKEGON, Mich., Sept. 12 -- Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, told a gathering of war workers today that more than 600,000 men of our armed forces now are overseas.

Rutgers University, New Brunswick, N.J., will conduct a series of short courses beginning this Fall. Classes in fruit and vegetable growing as well as dairy farming are scheduled. Full information may be obtained by writing the university.

The Lehn Fink Products Corporation, engaged in the manufacture and sale of proprietary and toilet articles, had a net profit of $648,182 for the year ended on June 30 after deducting $695,083 for taxes, it was announced yesterday. This is equivalent to $1.62 each on 400,000 shares of common stock outstanding, excluding 3,300 shares held in the treasury.

OCEANSIDE, Calif., Sept. 12 (AP) -- In a 114-year-old ranch house, which nearly a century ago housed California's military Governor, a new military regime is preparing a lot of trouble for the Japanese.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, in a recent Sunday Magazine section of THE NEW YORK TIMES, states "* * * the two-party system * * * in the United States * * * has completely broken down." One may well question the veracity of this statement.

Freely admitting he had been drinking and "any one should have known it," a young private "A.W.O.L." from Fort Monmouth, N.J., was in the police line-up yesterday, accused of issuing a worthless check for $9,600 for three seats on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Commander John L. Beebe, U.S.N.R., former transatlantic shipmaster and later director of unlicensed personnel of the Grace Line, has been named superintendent of the Maritime Service training station on Hoffman Island, in New York Harbor.
SHOULD American industry in wartime be actively interested in the proper diet of its employes as well as in their general health?

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 12 -- Private Barthelemy G. Lachelier, 45 years old, formerly of Greenwich, Conn., and France, owes his presence at Basic Training Center No. 7, the Army Air Force's Technical Training Command here, to a suspender buckle.

LONDON, Sept. 12 (U.P.) -- Guerrilla bands in five Southeastern European countries have opened a small second front of their own by sabotaging Axis lines of communication and supply and raiding isolated outposts repeatedly, according to reports reaching London tonight.

Self-sufficient as a snail, with his home, food and cooking utensils on his back, and a pleasant destination in the woods in his mind, the week-end camping fan can still enjoy his avocation. To him the automobile has only been a defiler or the shady country roads along which he loves to walk, and an alien noise in the night.

Adapting its curriculum to the needs of civilian and military specialists, the Columbia University School of Business will emphasize during the coming year new fields of training for women, prospective draftees, and adults who wish to transfer to essential war occupations.

The foundations of democracy are built upon cooperative endeavor. Cooperation is essential not only among individuals but also among their institutions. Cooperation among schools, children's courts, health and recreation centers, together with all other agencies dealing with children, is a vital factor in the development of children for their place in our democracy.

Vice President Wallace's article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine is very intriguing. It shows Mr. Wallace's interest in his fellow-man, and exemplifies the high degree of political art developed by many in public life.

BOSTON, Sept. 12 -- Declaring that New Englanders must help meet impending shortages in some foods by maximum use of New England - grown produce, John E. Rice, chairman of the New England Council's Committee on Agriculture and Forestry, today urged housewives to take full advantage of the bumper crops being harvested throughout the region by increasing their home canning activities.

Walker Grey Matheson, 40 years old, of Washington, one of three men arrested a week ago on charges of acting as agents for Japan without having registered as such with the Secretary of State, was arraigned yesterday before United States Commissioner Edward E. Fay in Brooklyn.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Rosetown, George D. Widener's game little race mare, put on one of her strongest finishes today to beat Crispin Oglebay's Level Best and take a three-quarter-length verdict in the Vineland Handicap, mile-and-one-sixteenth closing-day feature at Garden State Park. Dark Discovery was third in the six-horse field.

In line with the complete overhauling of production schedules by the War Production Board in order to balance the entire program, government procurement services are canceling millions of dollars' worth of contracts on war goods, manufacturers reported last week.
A MINING TOWN, N.Y., Sept. 12 -- Springing out of rugged forest land into full-blown existence, this Adirondack Mountains community of miners is looking for a name.

PROFESSOR C.J. Friedrich's article in the Aug. 30 issue of THE TIMES entitled "Case Against Hate" deserves most careful scrutiny. The ideas expressed therein with great skill constitute a grave danger to our total effort, as they tend to neutralize our emotional energies and to weaken our most important weapon: the will to win.

PAN-AMERICANISM: Argentina has followed a policy of cautious neutrality toward the American nations at war with the Axis. Thus it was that when General Augustin P. Justo, one-time commander of Argentina's army, power in Argentina's Conservative party and one-time President of Argentina, arrived in Rio de Janeiro last week to place his sword at Brazil's disposal in her war against Germany and Italy, Brazilians gave him an enthusiastic reception.

FOR a long time to most Americans the Army or Navy nurse was just a pretty girl on a poster -- dressed in white, wearing a becoming cape and a merciful expression. Now she is beginning to come alive, and with the trickle of pictures and interviews from overseas the public realizes suddenly that there are American women as well as men in the combat areas all over the world.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 12 -- Bill Cox sailed Joseph Merrill's Feather to first place in the International Class race which highlighted the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club's special regatta today. The contest was one in the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club Trophy series.
The annual Metropolitan championship tournament will be held during the eight days beginning on Oct. 17 and ending Oct. 24. The complete schedule will be announced next week.

OUR squadron was one of the first to be organized almost three years ago, just after the war started. Night-fighting was an undeveloped art at that time. We had to go up night after night in Blenheims against an enemy who outnumbered us five, and often ten, to one.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 12 -- Armored with .30-caliber rifles, riot guns, sub-machine guns, gas guns and gas grenades, the New York State Guard, composed of a general headquarters staff, five brigade headquarters, twenty-two regiments, a signal company and two separate battalions, is now completing the season's field training program at Camp Smith.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 12 -- Macalester College, in the heart of the isolationist West, continues to emphasize the international aspects of modern education. On Oct. 5 and 6 the college will sponsor an institute on "Win the War: Win the Peace."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- A Navy Department communique:

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, Sept. 13 -- General Douglas MacArthur's United Nations air force administered a good smashing yesterday to Buna, the Northeastern New Guinea base for the Japanese troops that have pushed their way across the top of the Owen Stanley range in an attempt to reduce Port Moresby.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 -- Retail sales here took a sharp upward turn last week under the influence of the end of the holiday season and the reopening of schools. Major department stores registered a 19 per cent increase for the week. Smaller metropolitan houses and stores in neighboring cities reported an increase of 37 per cent over last year.
Flatbush fandom's worst fears today are a woeful reality. Those irrepressible St. Louis Cardinals are tied with Brooklyn's Dodgers for the National League lead.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Maine's State election campaign, first in the country since Pearl Harbor, neared the end tonight with major candidates of both parties pledging support to President Roosevelt's war effort, but with Republicans maintaining that this does not mean "acquiescence in everything he does."

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 12 -- Leaders of the local Republican organization controlling ten votes, the largest single bloc, in the Fourth (Fairfield County) Congressional District Convention announced tonight they would support Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce of Greenwich for the nomination at the convention here Monday noon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- Complete listings of all prices regularly quoted in March, 1942, must be given on ceiling price statements which service establishments are required to make, the Office of Price Administration warned today.

The Army football squad yesterday obeyed to the letter General MacArthur's dictum always to attack. Before a gathering of 40,000 at the Polo Grounds the Eastern contingent of Army All-Stars hammered the New York Football Giants without let-up and kept the pressure constantly on the professionals for a 16-0 victory.

DETROIT, Sept. 12 -- Analysis of 158,531 registration cards returned in the United States Employment Service survey of women for war work indicated that more than half the women would be available without outside care for children, John L. Craig, regional director, said today.

LOCUST VALEY, L.I., Sept. 12 -- Wooded lanes and dirt roads that lead from the North Shore colony to the Piping Rock Club here will be as much traveled as formal highways when the fortieth annual Piping Rock Horse Show opens its three-day program on Thursday in the famous club show ring.

"EPITAPH FOR EUROPE," as this book is called in England, summarizes the experiences of a man who left his native Hungary at the age of 18 and traveled in Europe for thirteen years, first in search of an education and a job, later as a successful journalist and translator.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 2 (Delayed by Censor) (U.P.) -- American pilots told today how they set fire to Japanese Army headquarters at Nanchang in the "biggest air show" of the war in China, while Chinese troops were giving "merry hell" to enemy forces defending the city.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept. 12 -- An all-out war effort by residents of the colony here falls directly in line with the plans now being made for a busy Autumn season. With several entertainments and sports events in prospect, many of the women are dividing their time between Red Cross work and other war relief activities, and committee meetings in the interests of various lighter diversions.

WALDO FRANK'S "Virgin Spain," written between 1921 and 1925, the drama of a great people, is reissued in a black and yellow cover by Duell, Sloan Pearce, Inc. ($3.50). Alfonso Reyes, the famous Mexican poet, diplomat and distinguished head of the Colegio de Mexico, refers to the new edition of this "symphonic history" in his able, well-balanced Introduction as the interpretation of a people and country of imponderable importance.

As the war plunges into its fourth year new legions of volunteers from Brazil and Mexico are joining women war workers in the Allied network. Representatives of Federal agencies and civilian organizations of the United States and other countries are already conferring with the authorities in these two nations, preparing information that may be useful in expediting their defense programs.

Regulations that might apply to duck hunting along the Atlantic seaboard are under consideration by various agencies, following the announcement of restricted areas by Army edict during the past week.

ELMER and Einer, two small boys, wanted a horse more than anything in the world, so all Spring and Summer they saved their money until the old sock under their mattress held $15 with which they bought "Old Kristie" from Axel Peterson.

German wireless transmissions to the United States claimed yesterday, without indicating the source of the purported news, that Japanese submarines had sunk two United States transports and that Japanese planes had inflicted heavy damage on an American battleship and a cruiser.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 12 -- Lloyd B. Graham, a former aircraft machinist, 51, is held in Monroe County jail as a conscientious objector to registering for the draft because he is opposed to anything concerning numbers and for the particular reason that his religious training forbids him to shoulder a rifle or discharge it in the direction of a human being.

In discussions of the President's Labor Day message so much stress has been placed upon his ultimatum to Congress calling for lower ceilings on farm prices and upon his promise to stabilize wages that there has been a tendency to slight the third and most important measure for combating inflation, taxation.

APPROACHING footsteps of the new season sounded on Fifty-seventh Street last week with two one-man shows and a group exhibition opening in the galleries. Pierre Matisse has placed on view canvases by a group of modern artists, and the result, if not world shaking, is at any rate a lively event.

ALBUQUERQUE, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Senator Carl Hatch and Representative Clinton P. Anderson, Democratic incumbents seemed certain of renomination as returns from today's primary election gave them growing majorities.

That the loss of Far Eastern rubber plantations was a major military calamity, Leon Henderson, Donald Nelson and a battalion of experts and Army officers drove home in pessimistic testimony delivered months ago before Congressional investigating committees. Yet we needed the BaruchCompton-Conant report to present us with a clear vision of the dire straits to which we have been reduced by that loss and with a constructive program of action.

Shades of Ace Parker: how those Dodgers come back to haunt the Giants. It wasn't the Ace who was bad news yesterday at the Polo Grounds. It was Bad News himself, Corporal George (Bad News) Cafego, now with the Coast Artillery at Fort Eustis, but formerly of Tennessee and later of Brooklyn.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Thoroughbred Club of America announced today it had selected George D. Widener of Philadelphia, president of Belmont Park, to receive its annual "Horseman of the Year" award.

Ben Fidd, the veteran retired watchman of the Chelsea piers and deep sea mariner who has sailed all the seas of the world in windjammers and steamships, visited the Battery yesterday with his grandson, Ben Fidd Jr., and became reminiscent about the difference between the grub served to the crews today and that which he ate in his early days at sea about sixty years ago.

The wide swath cut this year by Federal tax appropriations through American industry is reflected by the decline in net profits reported by 373 corporations from $942,890,095 in the first half of 1941 to $681,721,571 in the same period in 1942, a drop of 27.7 per cent.

AGNES HEWES, whose fine adventure stories with a background of European history, "Spice Ho!" "Spice and the Devil's Cave" and "Swords on the Sea," have been popular with young readers for a number of years, has caught in her latest book the adventurous quality of modern engineering.

The site of the return bout between Heavyweight Champion Joe Louis and Billy Conn will be the Yankee Stadium, it was announced yesterday by Army officials, Promoter Mike Jacobs and the committee of sports writers assisting in the production of the show.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The strategic military highway being built by United States Army engineers through Canada and the Yukon territory to Fairbanks, Alaska, may be completed by Dec. 1, far ahead of schedule, according to Senator Albert E. Chandler, Democrat, of Kentucky, chairman of a Senate Military Affairs subcommittee which recently returned from an inspection trip in Alaska.

NEW MARKET, England, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Sun Chariot, great filly owned by King George, romped home an easy winner of the classic St. Leger Stakes today and thereby established a new record for the royal stable.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The Office of Civilian Defense offered some advice today on the use of portable heaters to make up for fuel-oil shortages this Winter, saying that the "danger of fires from that source must be guarded against most carefully."

You published on Sept. 7 a story from the Solomon Islands, telling how Ensign Firebaugh's plane was shot down near Tulagi and how, after a desperate fight with the sea, he managed to drag himself up on the shore of an island. The natives, whom he took at first for cannibals, returned to him with a note saying "To aviator shot down: Make it known to me whether you are with the Allies."

AT SEA WITH THE PACIFIC FLEET, Aug. 25 (Delayed) -- After several days of minor skirmishing by sea and by land, the battle of the Solomons was resumed yesterday with a new fury as the Japanese started in in force to attempt recapture of the island bases from which American naval forces and American Marines dislodged them Aug. 7 and 8.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 12 -- Greenwich police sent out a nine-State alarm today for jewelry valued at "about $12,000," which apparently was stolen yesterday afternoon from the home here of William E. Hall, national president of the Boys Clubs of America, on Old Church Road.

EXHIBITION plans for the 1942-43 season have already been announced by a number of museums. The prize-winning United Hemisphere Posters, comprising thirty-four examples, will be assembled to form an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art -- current from Oct. 21 to Jan. 3.

When New York City's 1,000,000 children return to school tomorrow they will find that significant changes have taken place in the classroom. Working overtime throughout the Summer months, Superintendent John E. Wade and his competent staff of teachers and supervisors have revamped the school curriculum, gearing it closely to the national war program.

IN his new novel Dennis Wheatley picks up his serialized factual story of World War II and his fictional narrative of Gregory Sallust's unofficial secret service activities from the fall of France, carrying on both up to Hitler's undeclared move against his Russian "partner."

CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The war has hit the dairy farmers of !the Chicago milk shed so hard that 11,700 of them may go out of the i milk business this year, according i to Arthur H. Lauterbach, general manager of the Pure Milk Association. He explained: "

Except for a flurry of activity in rapid transit issues, the stock market marked time yesterday and final prices were firm. Trading was the dullest in a month with volume on the Stock Exchange at 116,450 shares, compared with 145,270 shares in the previous short session.

FROM the standpoint of conservation, which was the sole purpose of WPB Order L-85, the greatest accomplishment has been the hastening of the trend toward a slim silhouette. From the standpoint of fashion, the greatest achievement has been the liberation of our designing talent from the heritages of the past.

AMERICA is mobilizing more than 20,000,000 workers for war production. Ironically, America at the same time is wasting manpower equivalent to millions of men through "leaks." By "leaks" I mean losses of manpower through unnecessary social, economic or physical waste.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Sept. 12 (AP) -- Representative Hamilton Fish declared in a speech here tonight that the election of a Republican or anti-New Deal House of Representatives was "one way to stop the mad rush to collectivism and communism in America."

"THE fountain of courage today is in our beliefs, our democratic faith," writes Henry Morgenthau Jr. in the introduction to this volume. To show how this democratic faith came into being and how it worked in the lives of the men and women who made it, the Treasury Department suggested the writing of these essays.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended on Sept. 6 amounted to 246,942,000 barrels, according to data reported to the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the total of 248,364,000 barrels (revised) for the preceding week, there was a decrease of 1,422,000, comprising declines of 1,377,000 and 45,000 in stocks of domestic and foreign crude respectively.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -Selection of thirty additional industrial plants to receive the joint Army-Navy production award in recognition of outstanding performance on war work was announced today by the Under-Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson and the Under Secretary of the Navy James V. Forrestal.

Thirty-two heavy steel bicycles, said to weigh a ton and a half, were presented as salvage yesterday to Mrs. Harry H. Tracy, chairman of the Brooklyn salvage committee, by Frank Tilyou, one of the owners of Steeplechase Park, Coney Island.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 13 -- Cotton futures edged higher last week despite continued uncertainty over the Washington program and the promise of an ample crop. Hedging had failed thus far to develop in anything like a normal volume and contracts appeared to be scarce after midweek.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Sept. 14 (AP) -- A communique:
NEWPORT, Ky., Sept. 13 (U.P.) -- Arner Lindquist, 46-year-old Swedish-born engraver from Morgantown, W. Va., became the new National A.A.U. horseshoe pitching champion today.

BUFFALO, Sept. 13 -- The Chicago Cardinals, driving 63 yards for a touchdown in the first period, defeated the Cleveland Rams, 7 to 0, today in a National Football League game before 18,698 spectators in Civic Stadium.

BOSTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Lennie Merullo, Boston-born shortstop of the Cubs, set a new modern mark for errors with four in one inning today as his club and the Braves split a double-header, Boston winning the first, 11 -- 6, while the Cubs took the nightcap, 12 -- 8.

The National Bureau of Economic Research, Inc., reporting yesterday on a fifteen-month study of the problems of national war financing, declared that new taxes totaling at least $22,000,000,000 would have to be raised during the fiscal year of 1943 "if inflation is eventually to be avoided."

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- The Germans may soon find themselves in a position where they are unable to take advantage of the rich stocks of food in France simply through lack of means for transporting it to the Reich. There are men here who say that certainly will be the case before Winter is out.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 13 -- The Right Rev. Frank Du Moulin, rector of the Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown, here, for twelve years, has resigned and is retiring from the ministry because of ill health, it was learned tonight at the rectory.
MOSCOW, Monday, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information communique issued early today:

Today, 128 years ago, "The Star-Spangled Banner" was born. Bombs were bursting in the air when Francis Scott Key recorded that our flag was still there. Bombs are bursting again; the flag waves in many corners of the earth; and the national anthem is being sung and played more fervently than ever.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 13 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt marked the first anniversary of the United States military mission to the Middle East today with a message of congratulations to American forces here, and British officers joined in ceremonies honoring soldiers of both nations for bravery or distinguished service.

Singing in the shower is not a purely masculine prerogative. It is of interest, then, to note that the newest nicety in cosmetic circles is a creamy soap in a small bucket, equipped with a cord so that a woman may dangle it on her shower handle -- and gesticulate freely to emphasize her aria.

Declaring war has brought a revival of the Shinto religion in Japan and that Hitler has put "into the thinking of the German people a religious notion of devotion to the State," the Rev. Dr. J. Lane Miller in a sermon yesterday morning at Hanson Place Central Methodist Church, at St. Felix Street, Brooklyn, questioned the sincerity of many current appeals to "return to religion."

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 -- The resignation of the Rev. Dr. William W. Fleetwood as rector of All Saints Episcopal Church in Beverly Hills was announced today at the morning service. The Rev. Dr. J. Herbert Smith, associate rector of Calvary Episcopal Church, New York City, will succeed him on Nov. 1 when he will become rector emeritus.

PLANDOME, L.I., Sept. 13 -Doug Ford of Green Meadow added another trophy to his collection today when he and his partner, Fred Bohling, annexed the annual member-guest tournament at the Plandome Golf Club.

The appointment of key figures in Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr.'s campaign for the Governorship on the Democratic ticket was announced yesterday by Charles H. Silver, chairman of the Independent Citizens Committee for Bennett.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Wheat futures sold last week on the Board of Trade here at the highest prices in two months, and the price of the soft red Winter variety of that grain went into the highest ground since July, 1937, as the result of the lifting of some of the uncertainty in regard to measures to prevent inflation and control prices and a market revival in the demand for flour.
Freshness does much in determining the excellence of wheat germ -- it is, in all probability, more important than any one factor.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Legislation to "freeze" workers in vital war industries to their present jobs was discussed at the Capitol today as members of Congress returned from the hustings and fishing holes, ending several weeks of informal recess.

A train containing thirty-three tank cars full of fuel for the oil-hungry East was thundering over the Baltimore Ohio Railroad's main line near Havre de Grace, Md., when a coupling parted. A car left the track, and in steady procession the following cars piled over it in a heap.

This being the tenth anniversary of the typographers and printers, William E. Rudge Sons, New York, the firm is paying tribute to the memory and tradition personified by William Edwin Rudge, the master printer. Called "Paragraphs in Printing," it is a contribution to the graphic arts through an analysis of the work of Bruce Rogers, the typographic designer who was associated in his work with William Edwin Rudge from 1919 to 1928.

Last week, the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices returned to 107.4 from 107.2. Rises occurred in the prices of cotton, apples, corn, oats, wheat, hay, steers and hogs. These increases caused the raw materials, farm products and foodstuffs indexes to regain their losses of the previous week.

ALBANY, Sept. 13 -- Holton V. Noyes, Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, announced today that a hearing would be conducted Tuesday, Sept. 29, to consider the petition of the Hudson-Mohawk Milk Producers Bargaining Agency for an order regulating the handling of milk in that area.

SOMEWHERE IN EUROPE, Sept. 13 -- Appalled at the terrific sacrifice of manpower for every inch of ground gained on the Stalingrad front, Reichsfuehrer Hitler was reliably reported here to have called General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock back to his headquarters for a "report."

HONOLULU, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Hawaii is like a besieged fortress in the Pacific war, and residents who have dependents on the mainland must not bring them to the islands, Brig. Gen. Thomas H. Green, executive to Lieut. Gen. Delos C. Emmons, the Military Governor, warned yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- The outstanding feature of the stock markets continues to be the steady rise in industrial shares, the index having reached the highest point since March 16, 1939. This has been accompanied by stability in fixed-interest stocks, which have scarcely changed in the past few months.
MOSCOW, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

SOUTH HAVEN, Mich., Sept. 13 (AP) -- Dave Cluett, 16-year-old skipper from the Cedarhurst (L.I.) Yacht Club, today won the fourth national championship of the Lightning Class Yachting Association by winning the last two races.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 13 (AP) -- Behind brilliant two-hit pitching by Johnnie Wittig, the fourth-place Jersey City Giants crept back into the running in the International League's semi-final play-off round today by defeating the Bears, 3 to 0.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 7 two letters were published under the caption "Plight of Tenants Cited." I feel that publication of these letters calls for a citation of the plight of landlords and home owners.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 13 -- American war production has been increased by 350 per cent since Pearl Harbor, but the effect of that output has not yet been sufficient to turn the tide of the battle in our favor, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, said in an address delivered by radio to a rally of RCA-Victor workers attended by a crowd estimated at more than 50,000, in Garden State Park tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 13 -- Warner Baxter will play the role of Dr. Brooks, the psychiatrist, in the screen version of "Lady in the Dark" at Paramount if negotiations with the actor are concluded. The starting date of the picture has been postponed until December, and it is expected that Baxter will be available between appearances in Columbia's "Crime Doctor" series.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 13 (AP) -- Four officers and three enlisted men were killed in the crash of an Army bomber today a mile from the Columbia Army Air Base.

Despite the fact that its original quota of 10,000,000 books for men in the armed services has been overscribed, the Victory Book Campaign will continue, it was announced yesterday by Paul B. Badger, chairman of the board of directors.

Leases in Gracie Square Gardens, at East End Avenue and East Eighty-ninth Street, to business executives featured new lists of renters reported by managing agents over the week-end. The lists showed a continuance of the demand for rooms to be occupied about Oct. 1.

Two new series of Treasury tax savings notes, A-1945 and C-1945, were announced yesterday by Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury and will go on sale today. Sale of the old notes, A-1944 and B-1944, stopped with the close of business on Saturday.

DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 13 (U.P.) -- The five rivals of Clare Boothe Luce, playwright and author, for the Republican Congressional nomination in Connecticut's Fourth district ganged up on her today. They had a meeting in Darien and issued a statement declaring that Mrs. Luce was hand-picked and that her designation smacked of the kind of political control "that destroyed France."

PREAKNESS, N.J., Sept. 13 (AP) -- Emil Muller and Bill Samanchik of the home club fired rounds of 70 and 69 for 139 today to repeat their 1941 triumph in the ninth annual Passaic County invitation best-ball tournament at the Passaic County Park golf course.
DETROIT, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Rookie Hal White pitched the Tigers to an 8-to-0 victory over the Senators today after the Tigers had kicked away the opener, 5 to 2, by donating three runs in the ninth.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 13 -- Losing a mast apparently means little to an enthusiastic skipper in the International Class of sloops on Long Island Sound. Arthur Davis had one snap out of his craft Patricia on Wednesday, installed another, and came back today to win in the eighteenth regatta of the championship series, which was held by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Red Sox beat the White Sox, 6 to 1 and 5 to 0, today, Bill Butland taking his seventh in a row when he held Chicago to four hits in the first game. That made his record seven and one.

With the cotton trade training attention on developments in Washington in regard to settlement of the problem of inflation, activity in the local futures market slowed measurably last week. A sharp decline in values, however, followed the issuance of the Department of Agriculture's second forecast of the current crop, which was almost 1,000,000 bales above its first estimate.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Although prices of hogs here last week averaged about 40 cents a hundred-weight lower than in the preceding week, ceiling prices remained bid for lard futures on the Board of Trade and all trading in lard was at $12.90, a figure which cannot be exceeded under the price stabilization program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- If the nation's wed of transportation breaks, "the whole war effort falls apart," Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, said tonight, as he repeated over the radio his appeal for voluntary rationing of automobile use to save rubber in areas where gasoline is not rationed.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 13 -- Left stranded in the Belgian Congo and then subjected to the humiIiation of deportation, according to their complaint, Henry C. Kramer and his wife, Gertrude B. Kramer, missionaries, demand $50,000 damages in a suit filed in Superior Court against the International Church of the Four Square Gospel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Retail and wholesale trade associations of the nation were asked today by the Senate Committee on Small Business to help solve the problems confronting small business. Senator James E. Murray of Montana, chairman of the committee, addressed a letter and questionnaire to 346 trade associations, asking them to submit statements making constructive suggestions as to how the emergency now threatening the destruction of retail and wholesale concerns can best be met.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 13 (U.P.) -- Dispatches from Berlin said today that the Russians threw two pontoon bridges across the Volga at Stalingrad to move up reinforcements and that it was "rumored" they had been able to move great masses of fresh troops into the battle.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Navy Cross with two gold stars, equivalent of three Navy Crosses, and an air medal for heroism have been awarded to Lieutenant Clarence Earle Dickinson Jr.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Announcements have just been made in Berlin that Adolf Hitler has chosen three of his best generals to combat General Winter in Russia. This is only part of the preparations by Herr Hitler to keep his promise that the disaster that overtook his soldiers last Winter will not be repeated.

Women are working as mechanics in the Navy Yard in Brooklyn for the first time in its 141-year history, headquarters of the Third Naval District revealed yesterday. Shop officials said they were much pleased with the first batch of women working there and were looking forward to employment of more.
That was a mighty fine letter the two English Navy lads, Jack W. Hall and Harry J. Wookes, wrote and which appeared in your issue of Sept. 8.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Generally favorable weather conditions prevailed last week in the Corn Belt and the corn crop made considerable progress toward maturity, but two weeks more of hot and dry weather are regarded as needed to assure the safety of much of this year's harvest from frost.

The Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, warned in his sermon yesterday morning that "the church must cease being a sort of whitewashed trailer for national policies and must once again be the moral leader of our nation."
Under the weight of three Giant home runs, the Pirates bowed twice yesterday at the Polo Grounds before a crowd of 17,794.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Award of the Distinguished Flying Cross to Lieut. Col. Conrad F. Necrason of Cooperstown, N.Y., for his "coolness and courage" in a fight with the Japanese, during which his Flying Fortress and another on the same bombing mission shot down seven of fifteen attacking Japanese fighters, was announced today by the War Department.

VICHY, Sept. 13 -- All countries whether belligerents or neutrals are facing the same problems and are trying to solve them by the same methods. But it is not possible, even with rationing and price fixing, to prevent entirely a rise in prices, especially for imported articles.

For the one million New York City boys and girls who return to school today the long, delightful vacation is over. Another Summer, all too soon, has gone. This morning a million hearts will beat a trifle quicker as faces are washed a bit cleaner, hair combed neater and shoes polished brighter.

In the heat of the political dispute that has developed regarding farm price-fixing and wage price-fixing formulas, there is grave danger that Washington will lose sight of first principles. If we wish to halt inflation, it cannot be too often repeated, we must deal with its cause, not with its mere symptoms.

NEW DELHI Sept. 13 (Reuter) -- Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the Moslem League, said today that Moslems would not be prepared to enter a provisional government unless their demand for "Pakistan" (separate Moslem states) were met.
While duck hunters will be obliged to learn what restrictions may be imposed upon them because of war regulations this Fall, they should not have to worry too much about the actual duck supply.

War news cut little figure in last week's market; indeed, it was somewhat difficult to make out the actual situation, either in Russia or in Africa or in the Far East. All that seemed clear was the Russian comeback which followed each violent forward movement of the reinforced invaders.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Soldier Field became a sanctuary tonight for 120,000 persons who gathered there to pray for the men of the nation's fighting forces. The liturgical pageantry of the Roman Catholic Church was merged with patriotism as allegiance to Saviour and Flag was devoutly pledged.

Although few buyers were in town, most wholesale markets were busy last week filling mail orders, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 13 -- A gathering of Axis personages, led by Franz Keresztes-Fischer, the Hungarian Minister of Interior, who arrived four days ago, was completed in Vienna today. The Fascist party Secretary, Aldo Vidussoni, accompanied by the Italian Minister of Supplies, Renato Ricci, arrived there today.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 13 -- Gasoline rationing, harvesting and war work may be deciding factors in Maine's listless "barometer" State election, which will be held tomorrow -- eight weeks ahead of other States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Sept. 5 to 11 are given in the appended tabulation:

MOSCOW, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A Commando-style, sea-borne assault behind the enemy's far northern line was reported today from the Barents Sea by the navy newspaper Red Fleet, which credited Russian marines with destroying eleven heavy guns, several mortars, two ammunition dumps and one food depot.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Prices of corn failed last week to reflect fully the strength in wheat on the Board of Trade here, and while it was higher for a time, the market reacted quickly after the Department of Agriculture had issued a report indicating production in excess of 3,000,000,000 bushels, the third largest crop on record.
That monster pennant dirigible that the Dodgers and the Flatbush fans had seen floating over Ebbets Field since April 20 yesterday became only a punctured toy balloon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (U.P.) -- The board of governors of the Federal Reserve System announced tonight that reserve requirements of net demand deposits held by central reserve city banks in New York and Chicago will be lowered from 24 to 22 per cent, effective at the opening of business tomorrow.

LOGAN, Iowa, Sept. 13 (U.P.) -- P. K. Duvall, road building contractor home from Alaska for a vacation, complained tonight that the men building the military highway through the Northern wilderness were becoming bored with friendly bears and dispirited fish.

The Kansas City Monarchs displayed a wealth of hitting power to defeat the Homestead Grays in the third game of the Negro world series yesterday. The Monarchs came through with a total of sixteen hits, two of them home runs, to subdue the Grays by 9 to 3 at the Yankee Stadium and take a 3-to-0 edge in the series.
LONDON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A communique of the British Commander in Chief for East Africa on Madagascar operations:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Archibald MacLeish, Librarian of Congress, said tonight that Britain, in the two years since the devastating city-by-city Nazi air assaults, had been transformed from "an island of refuge for a desperate defense" into "a bridgehead for a great offensive."

VALLETTA, Malta, Sept. 13 -- General Viscount Gort, Governor and Commander in Chief at Malta, on behalf of George VI, has just presented the George Cross to the people of Malta for the island's gallant endurance during two years of almost daily enemy bombing.

Simon W. Gerson, Communist campaign manager, announced last night that attorneys for four independent organizations would support the efforts of the Communist party to stay on the ballot for the coming State election. Trial of the suit brought by American Legion members to void the Communist nominating petitions begins this morning in Schoharie before Supreme Court Justice Francis Bergan.
CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Wisconsin and Iowa will get down to the serious business of football Saturday -- the first teams the Western Conference to do so.
Six new films will open in Broadway theatres this week. The schedule follows:

HOW it is going in other regions deponent sayeth not, but in this election district there is a brisk "write-in" vote for a wide assortment of diamond favorites for the "Most Valuable Player" award in the big leagues. It's a poor player who hasn't one friend with a sheet of paper and a 3-cent stamp.

VICHY, France, Monday, Sept. 14 -- Compulsory labor for men between the ages of 18 and 50 and for unmarried women between 20 and 35 was established in France by a law published in the Journal Officiel today. All men of the ages mentioned and who are physically fit must show that they have employment that the government decides is in the "interest of the nation," the decree specifies.

Ending their ten weeks' Summer vacation, nearly 1,000,000 children will return to their classes this morning as the city school system begins its Fall term. Many far-reaching changes, they will find, have taken place since schools closed in June, making the classroom more closely geared to the needs of the Army and Navy.

Actors Equity has relinquished its jurisdictional claim over "Wine, Women and Song," opening at the Ambassador Theatre late this month, to the American Guild of Variety Artists, according to Walter N. Greaza, who is in charge of A.G.V.A. affairs. Both groups are affiliated with the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, parent body of all A.F. of L. entertainer unions.
LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Only slight opposition from French forces on Madagascar has been met in the advance of British columns toward Tananarive, the capital.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 13 -- Among Chief of Government Pierre Laval's visitors yesterday, reports from Vichy said, were a number of French naval officers. It was presumed here that he consulted them regarding the situation in Madagascar where M. Laval considers that Washington has been as provocative as London.

MOSCOW, Monday, Sept. 14 -- The Russian High Command said today that reinforced German troops had made a further advance southwest of beleaguered Stalingrad, the second German gain announced in this sector in twenty-four hours.

LONDON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- Daylight reconnaissance photographs of Duesseldorf and Karlsruhe substantiated today original R.A.F. reports of widespread damage in the latest raids on those German cities, it was authoritatively announced. Duesseldorf was raided last Thursday night and Karlsruhe the night before.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 13 -- The famed Green Bay Packer assault by air, checked for two periods, exploded for four touchdowns in the second half today for a spectacular 36-to-21 triumph over big John Kimbrough and his Western Army All-Stars in another of the series of Army Emergency Relief football games.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears conquered the Washington Redskins, 38 to 14, today by effectively bottling up Sammy Baugh's aerial thrusts and demonstrating a powerful ground attack.

SANTA MARIA, Calif., Sept. 13 -- Robert Taylor Bailey, 21-year-old Army deserter, told here today of a nine-day cross-country journey during which he kidnapped and shot to death two women welfare workers in Wisconsin.

Assurances of service to oil burner owners during the war and promise of renewed product offerings after the war will feature an extensive national newspaper advertising campaign to be launched this month by Silent Automatic Division of Timken-Detroit Axle Company.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 13 -- Married men with children face the prospect of being called for military service next year, Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, national Selective Service Director, told delegates to the twenty-fourth annual convention of the New Jersey Department of the American Legion here today.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Any attempt to gauge the extent of the movement of wheat and cotton from the United States to Britain is almost completely frustrated by the absence of import statistics, upon the publication of which there is a complete ban.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A public appeal from President Roosevelt and an offer of financial aid from Henry J. Kaiser, West Coast shipbuilder, started a campaign yesterday to establish a $5,000,000 fund for the United Seamen's Services, Inc., the USO of the American Merchant Marine.
