WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Official announcement was made today by the War Production Board of the setting up of a Smaller War Plants Division to provide machinery for the widest possible spread of war work to the smaller manufacturing plants of the country.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- British authorities interested in the health and diet of the nation have long been aware of a common practice among British women, especially working class wives and mothers, to give the lion's share of rationed foods to the men and children.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The formula for a successful marriage, as summed up by twenty-five white-haired couples who have been married for more than fifty years, is "cooperation, children and good cooking."
CLEVELAND, Sept. 13 -- Any combination of one will do it!

NASSAU, Bahamas, Sept. 8 -- The prospect that this British colony, which has flourished always without direct taxation, may soon have to institute an income tax to weather the economic dislocations caused by the war has become a subject of warm debate in civilian and parliamentary circles.

Whether Stalingrad stands or falls, its desperate defense must have a profound effect on the development of the war. If the Russians accomplish a miracle and hold out, the event could mark the turning of the tide not only in Russia but all over the world. If the city falls, the war will certainly be prolonged, though the cost of a delayed victory will be felt by Germany in all her future campaigns.

Betrayal of the French people by the Vichy government was denounced by the Rev. Dr. John A.F. Maynard, rector of the French Episcopal Church of Saint Esprit, 109 East Sixtieth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning. Dr. Maynard urged that the United States warn the men of Vichy that they would be held responsible for their acts.

LONDON, Monday, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Fighting French sources said today that Pierre Laval's plan to conscript labor in France appeared to be a camouflaged move under which workers may be sent "collectively" to Germany to work in Nazi war industries.

From now on the need for courage will be "greater than ever before in our experience," the Rev. Dr. L. Wendell Fifield, minister of the Plymouth Congregational Church of the Pilgrims at Orange and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn, declared yesterday morning from the pulpit once occupied by Henry Ward Beecher.

Emlyn Williams's "The Morning Star," a melodrama about an upper-middle-class British family under the "blitz" will open at 8:30 tonight at the Morosco. The play has been running since last December in London and had its American premiere in Philadelphia last week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 (U.P.) -- Wives of government officials, led by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, are as busy with the war effort as their husbands, and put in long hours at various war jobs in addition to running their homes and rearing their children.

" As goes Maine so goes the Union" is a proverb withdrawn from currency, but the September Maine election keeps its charm of antiquity and peculiarity. Stripped of its prophet's robes it remains a curious, rather pleasing custom. If it has ceased to be the mother of aleatory contracts, it is a survival dear to antiquarians.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 -- Large supplies of oats are available for the current crop year, but there has been only moderate hedging pressure so far on the market The movement in the Central West has been decidedly disappointing, however, resulting in only a moderate accumulation of stocks.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly "Talk to the People" that he had appointed a committee to aid owners of one-family and two-family houses in obtaining expert advice, at low cost, on all matters relating to fuel conservation and the conversion of oil burners into coal-burning equipment.

ALBANY, Sept. 13 -- Governor Lehman gave his approval today to the plan of newspapers to set aside the week of Oct. 1 as Newspaper Week. He said he believed "it is wise that they should again express during this period the duty of fairness in presenting the news.

An appeal was issued yesterday by the New York City Committee on Child Welfare of the State Charities Aid Association on behalf of seventeen Catholic, Jewish and Protestant charitable agencies, for several thousand foster homes in which dependent and neglected children of Greater New York can be cared for temporarily.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 13 -- Police here captured early this morning a young man in an Army sergeant's uniform who has confessed to seventy-five burglaries within the last three weeks in cities and towns between Philadelphia and Englewood.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Sept. 14 -- Allied bombers again dealt smashing blows at Japanese bases in New Guinea and on shipping west of this battle area yesterday, sinking at least one merchant vessel and bombing an enemy cruiser and two other merchantmen with unknown results, a communique said today.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles soared through the air lanes with ease today to defeat the Pittsburgh Steelers, 24 -- 14, in their opening National Football League game before 13,349.

The one-family dwelling at 986 Pierpont St., Rahway, N.J., has been purchased from the Fidelity Union Trust Company, trustee, by the trustees of the Second Presbyterian Church of Rahway for use as a rectory. Title has been insured by the New Jersey Realty Title Insurance Company.

Nazi puppet officials in the Netherlands and Belgium have begun to denounce Adolf Hitler's "New Order," possibly as part of a trick to lay the groundwork for a peace offensive, the Netherland Information Bureau reported last night, according to The United Press.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 13 (AP) -- George Woolf is slated to ride Whirlaway in his $25,000 match race with Alsab at Narragansett Park next Saturday and it begins to look as if Mr. Long Tail's official family finally has become convinced that Woolf suits the colt better than any jockey around.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Sept. 13 -- John J. Dempsey, who resigned as Under-Secretary of Interior to seek the Governorship, rolled up a heavy majority in New Mexico's Democratic primary and tonight received the congratulations of his opponent, Bryan G. Johnson of Albuquerque.
VICHY, France, Monday, Sept. 14 -- Following is the text of the new government decree "relative to the utilization and organization of labor":

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Increasing reports of surprises about to be sprung by the German Air Force of which the latest concerns a "strato-bomber" reported capable of operating at 40,000 feet, cause relatively little concern in aviation circles here, but there is considerable fear that the normal popular interest in new types may obscure the very factors most important in developing air power.

The Rev. John Atherton Bell, one of the youngest Protestant Episcopal rectors in the city, preached yesterday his first sermon as rector at the Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- Ordinarily when a county campaign chairman confidently predicts the election of candidates of his party, such prognostications are casually put in the "what-else-did-you-expect" class.

Comparing the "spectator type" Christian with the citizen who puts personal ease and preference before civic duty in wartime, Mgr. William A. Scully, secretary for religious education of the Archdiocese of New York, condemned both in a sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

MOSCOW, Sept. 13 -- Attacking with a violence and scale unprecedented in the hisory of warfare, the Germans have advanced nearer to Stalingrad. Last night the Russians were forced to abandon a village west of the city. Three times the Germans entered the village, only to be thrown out.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 13 -- Aviation Machinist A.W. Winchell of Webster City, Iowa, tells how he exchanged stares with a Japanese submarine crew -- at 25-yard range -- during a seventeen-day voyage on a leaking rubber life raft after his torpedo plane was forced down in the Battle of Midway.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- Since adoption of the lease-lend policy by the United States Government enabled the British Government to divert to its war industries much labor and material which had been used for the execution of export orders, Britain's civilian exports have been reduced to the minimum, satisfying solely vital requirements in the sterling area.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Sept. 13 -- Visualizing development of the St. Lawrence River-Lake Champlain-Hudson River inland waterway as a wartime measure to accelerate merchant shipping and carry it directly into the sea lanes to Europe, South America and Asia, the Champlain Valley Council, representing civic bodies of Northern New York and Vermont, went on record unanimously this afternoon as favoring immediate work on the project, which could materialize in about three years.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Houses in three up-State cities to provide living quarters for 1,050 families engaged in war work will be erected as the result of loans granted by the State, it was disclosed yesterday by Edward Weinfeld, State Commissioner of Housing. Contracts for the loans have been signed with the municipal housing authorities of Niagara Falls, Schenectady and Elmira, and work will start immediately on the new units.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 -- The Cardinals came within a hot breath of sweeping a double-header with the Phils today, but even though they had to be content with winning one game the Redbirds roared into exclusive possession of first place in the National League by a full game.

VICHY, Monday, Sept. 14 (AP) -- With reference to application of the new labor decree to the sending of French workers to Germany, a demand, which found its way into print in the Paris press, was put forward that the War Department "remobilize" the skilled workers the Army left in factories and send them to Germany.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 13 -- Three firemen were overcome by smoke and a fourth was injured today at a fire that caused $12,000 damage to two large warehouses here. The flames burned wires of the Long Island Lighting Company and the New York Telephone Company, cutting off light and telephone service for several hours in an area two miles east of here.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- An attempt to assassinate Peter Gabrovski, Bulgarian Interior Minister, and the arrest of more than 100 of the suspected plotters, have touched off a campaign of wild violence against Axis occupation forces throughout Bulgarian Macedonia, it was reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- The Senate Finance Committee appeared to be ready for a final decision tomorrow on a $9,000,000,000 tax bill, largest in the nation's history, which puts unprecedented levies on individuals and corporations.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 110.8 on Sept. 1. This compares with 110.2 a fortnight before, 110.9 a month before, 106.7 a year before and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 13 (AP) -- The Browns whipped the Athletics today, 7 to 0 and 3 to 2.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- The Germans announced tonight that a big United Nations convoy in the Atlantic was being attacked heavily. The statement came from Hitler's headquarters, the method used in announcing events of momentous importance.

Early Fall is a good time for it, and the boy need not be your own. Anybody's will do. He will preferably be between 5 and 10, and you will set off with him early in the morning, just after a good-sized breakfast of hot cakes, maple syrup and two cups of coffee.

Plans are being made for an Autumn Dance to be given by a group of debutantes of recent seasons and their young men friends in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton on Nov. 27. Miss Anne Delafield Finch, daughter of Judge Edward Ridley Finch of the State Court of Appeals and Mrs. Finch, is chairman of the committee, and Miss Anne Morgan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Junius Spencer Morgan, is vice chairman.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 12 (Delayed) -- Leading Indian newspapers today as well as further statements by Indian leaders go to confirm yesterday's impression that Prime Minister Winston Churchill's statement about India has caused much dismay and bitterness.

LONDON, Sept. 13 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 110.8 on Sept. 1. This compares with 110.2 a fortnight before, 110.9 a month before, 106.7 a year before and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Specialty Accounting Supply Manufacturers Association, Chicago, O.L. Moore, its secretary, and thirty members of the association who manufacture and sell sales books and continuous form sales records stationery, have been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to cease and desist from engaging in or continuing any agreement or understanding to restrain and elimnate competition in price in the sale of their products.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 13 -- Steel output in the country last week was unchanged in volume from the week before with operations remaining at 97 1/2 of rated capacity. Indications are that this record will not be bettered this week because of shortages of scrap metal and repairs to furnaces.

Obscured by the great actions in the foreground of the war, two events of more than passing interest took place last week in the shrouded wings of the Near Eastern theatre. One was the almost casual opening of the ninety-mile railroad between Haifa and Beirut. This does not seem very exciting in itself, but actually it represents the fulfillment of the long-frustrated dream of Arab nationalists.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13 -- Spurred by President Roosevelt's demand of last week for passage of anti-inflation legislation by Oct. 1, Senate and House Democratic leaders agreed tonight on the general form of a broad joint resolution to this end.

AT SEA WITH THE PACIFIC FLEET, Aug. 15 (Delayed) -- The Solomon Islands were so named by the Spaniard who is credited with discovering them in 1567 so that other Spaniards might think them the isles "whence Solomon fetched the gold to adorn the temple at Jerusalem" and desire to go there.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The American Junior Red Cross has justified the faith of its founders, President Roosevelt declared today in a letter to Norman H. Davis, chairman of the senior organization, marking the junior group's twenty-fifth anniversary tomorrow, which will be celebrated by more than 14,000,000 young Americans throughout the country.

LONDON, Sept. 14 (U.P.) -- Britain has asked United States officials in Vichy, who represent British interests in unoccupied France, to investigate the position of Britons in France under Vichy's new forced labor edict, which reportedly em braces all residents of the country, a Foreign Office commentator disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Following is the text of the resolution to authorize President Roosevelt to stabilize wages and farm prices which was introduced today in the Senate:

NEW DELHI, Sept. 14 (Reuter) -Sir Edward Benthall, member for the Indian War Transport Board, answering a question in the newly gathered Legislative Assembly today, detailed particulars of damage to Indian railways caused by the civil disobedience movement.

The present priority system is "about to fall apart," Paul R. Smith, regional director of the War Production Board for New York and Northern New Jersey, declared last night at a dinner of 200 members of the Greater New York Chapter of the American Society of Tool Engineers in the Hotel New Yorker.

The tentative schedules of wholesale liquor prices to be maintained under the Hollowell law during the month of October, recently filed with the State Liquor Authority, were opened for inspection yesterday and scores of manufacturers', wholesalers' and retailers' representatives inspected the lists at the SLA headquarters, 420 Lexington Avenue.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 14 -- Further broadcasting by the Eastman School of Music will not be permitted, because of the policy laid down by James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, according to Dr. Howard Hanson, director of the school.

The original quota of Wave probationary officers from the Third Naval District has been tripled, it was announced yesterday by the New York Office of Naval Officer Procurement, 33 Pine Street. Captain Kenneth G. Castleman, U.S.N., retired, head of the office, said authorization has been received from Washington to enroll 120 candidates in addition to the sixty already recommended to the Navy Department.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- Despite the great efforts, enterprise and hard work shown by British agriculture during the past two years, Britain received a warning today from Robert S. Hudson, Minister of Agriculture, that the situation called for even more effort.

CRESTON, Iowa, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, railroad detectives and other law enforcement officers tonight blocked off the area three miles east of Nodaway, Iowa, where early today twelve explosions rocked the Burlington Railroad's west bound Denver Zephyr streamline train.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Charges that unity of command was still lacking between our military and naval forces in action, that our fighter planes were inferior to those of Great Britain and Axis powers and that production for war on the home front had been mismanaged were made in the Senate today by Senator Truman, chairman of the special committee investigating the defense program.

Despite rationing and merchandise scarcities, and to some extent because of them, sales of wholesale and retail cooperatives in Scotland are likely to set a new record this year, Neil S. Beaton, president of the Scottish Cooperative Wholesale Society, said in an interview here yesterday.

VICHY, Sept. 14 -- S. Pinkney Tuck, United States Charge d'Affaires here, was received for the second time in three days today by Chief of Govenment Pierre Laval. The subject of conversation was not disclosed.

MOSCOW, Sept. 14 -- It was learned here this morning that the enemy had not succeeded in advancing in any sector of the Stalingrad front during the last twelve hours, though there was no abatement in the battle. A critical situation arising from the piercing of Soviet defenses southwest of the city was restored by the intervention of Russian tanks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 9: Increases of $433,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and $143,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, and a decrease of $677,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Behind the five-hit pitching of Hugh East, the Jersey City Giants downed the Bears, 3 to 1, today to even their International League play-off series at two victories apiece.

Occasional furniture that employs glass with vigor and practicality marks the final step in a drama of wartime conversion. Glass bricks, hailed last Spring as one solution for lamp bases -- for which metal has been completely curtailed -- transfer their service again.

" New Priorities of 1943" opens tonight at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre. This variety show, successor to "Priorities of 1942," is produced by Clifford C. Fischer and the Shuberts. The cast includes Harry Richman, Bert Wheeler, Carol Bruce, Hank Ladd, Henny Youngman, The Bricklayers, Johnny Burke, Harrison Fisher, Sally Keith, The Radio Aces, The Acromaniacs, Imogene Carpenter and Ted Adair.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 14 -- A decree issued tonight by the Ministry of the Interior orders the immediate dissolution of the Federation of German Welfare and Cultural Clubs under cover of which the German National Socialist party was still operating in Argentina.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's midnight communique:

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 14 -- German sources available here today asserted bluntly that the introduction of compulsory labor in France was intended primarily "to procure workers for Germany or for the execution of German orders.''

Primaries will be held today in Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New Jersey, Michigan and Wisconsin. Connecticut Democrats will hold a State nominating convention. In Mississippi there will be a Democratic run-off between former Senator James O. Eastland and Senator Wall Doxey. Mr. Eastland led Senator Doxey in the first primary.
The six-family apartment house at 6802 Owls Head Court, Brooklyn, was sold by Rosenberg Penn to an investing client of the Bulkley Horton Company, broker. This property overlooks Owls Head Park.
BOSTON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- A four-run eighth inning, marked by Max West's third homer of the three-game series, gave the Braves a 4-to-2 victory today over the Cubs.

Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and author of the pay-as-you-go plan of income tax payments, discussed his plan last night at special meeting of the Retail Dry Goods Association.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Frank Murphy told Louisville Bar Association members and their guests tonight that the United States was "not yet mobilized for war because of national indifference." He warned that the Allies would not "win the war without losing countless lives of our youth -- and you must steel yourselves to that."

NEW DELHI, Sept 14 -- India's Central Legislative Assembly opened its sessions today with a determined little group of young Congress Party sympathizers, including five girls, sitting on the steps of one of the main entrances to prevent the Indian members from getting in.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 14 -- The facts of Japan's military power show that this is not a war for the mere protection of national interests but a fight to prevent enslavement by a ruthless and formidable military and economic machine, Joseph C. Grew, former United States Ambassador to Japan, declared here tonight.

Any increase in commutation rates for the railroads serving New York City would be contrary to the national policy of stabilizing the cost of living, Corporation Counsel William C. Chanler declared in a memorandum submitted yesterday to the Interstate Commerce Commission urging that the applications for increased rates be discontinued or suspended for the duration of the war.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 15 (U.P.) -- The newspaper Pravda reported yesterday that German shock troops were "at Stalingrad," but were being repulsed by point-blank artillery fire and bayonet charges.

While placing himself behind the movement in the book publishing industry by which the plates of obsolete books are being destroyed for the nation's metal scrap heap, Carl Carmer, president of the Authors Guild, division of the Authors League, advocated in a letter released yesterday that the publication rights revert to an author after a book has been destroyed in type.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- Reports that Congress was discussing placing a 90 per cent of parity floor under farm commodity markets set the rye market soaring on the Board of Trade today and prices advanced around 3 1/2 cents a bushel at one time to a new high before profit-taking checked the upturn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- In a letter read in the House today, William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, said rigid control over voluntary wage increases was necessary to achieve stabilization and prevent inflation.

Confident that anti-inflation legislation would treat farm prices more liberally than had been expected last week, cotton traders sponsored yesterday fairly good buying early in the session on the New York Cotton Exchange after a mixed opening.

Appointment of independent counsel to represent the New York Harlem Railroad in an action brought by the New York Central Railroad to determine whether it should pay income and excess profits taxes for the N.Y. H. was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A gigantic new revenue bill geared to increase Treasury collections to more than $25,500,000,000 annually from corporations and 43,000,000 individual taxpayers won approval tonight of the Senate Finance Committee.

As glass containers replace cans as packages for a variety of food items, food retailers are beginning to adopt new merchandising tactics. Six hundred and twenty-five freshman, the largest entering class in the history of Columbia College, undergraduate division of the university, will start today a round of placement examinations, tours and receptions as part of the traditional Freshman Week.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- British sea and land forces with strong air support carried out a raid on the Axis base at Tobruk, Libya, last night, inflicting casualties and damage on the enemy before withdrawing, the Admiralty announced tonight.

Spirit was lacking again yesterday in the stock market, except for a fresh flurry in some of the low-priced issues. The list moved laboriously throughout the day and was only enlivened by two special offerings. Even these failed to help business, for sales on the Stock Exchange of 312,510 shares were the smallest in more than a month and compared with the Friday volume of 376,460 shares.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 15 -- The Russian lines before Stalingrad held firmly yesterday despite repeated German lunges on the western and southwestern outskirts of the imperiled Volga city, the Soviet High Command announced today.

Insurance companies were urged yesterday to promote in their advertising the availability of war damage insurance by H.C. Conick, assistant United States manager of the Royal Liverpool Group, in an address at the luncheon meeting of the Insurance Advertising Conference at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, tomorrow will name the Rubber Administrator, an appointment which was suggested by President Roosevelt's special rubber committee headed by Bernard M. Baruch.

Three transatlantic flying boats -- two Pan American clippers and an American Export Line Flying Ace -- reached La Guardia Field yesterday. One of the Pan American ships was the Pacific Clipper, which came home with its hull lined with 1,500 pounds of concrete after an adventure worthy of a place beside its spectacular flight around the globe last Winter.

Some readers may have been disturbed by THE TIMES'S recent dispatch quoting from Governor Lehman's address at the convention of CIO United Office and Professional Workers at Albany. PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 14 -- Efforts to reach a settlement without final hearing on charges that the Wright Aeronautical Corporation dominates the Wright Aeronautical Employes Association, an unaffiliated union, failed today and the matter will go before the National Labor Relations Board at New York on Thursday.

DETROIT, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Lanky Sid Hudson finally achieved his tenth victory today by pitching and batting the Senators to an 8-to-6 decision over the Tigers. Hudson tossed a three-hitter for six and one-third innings of relief work, started a two-run seventh-inning rally and drove in a run in the eighth with his third successive hit.
LONDON, Sept. 14 -- The stock markets had a quiet day, most buyers awaiting fresh news of the Russian situation. Gilt-edge issues finished the day with small losses.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- The British occupation of Madagascar -- and it is more that than conquest of the island -- is proceeding smoothly, it was announced here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- One of the first American service men whose lives were saved by blood plasma will raise the Army-Navy "E" pennant over the American Red Cross national headquarters tomorrow at ceremonies recognizing the achievement of the Red Cross Blood Donor Service in collecting blood for the nation's armed forces.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- Already knocked out as a pennant contender by the New York Yankee victory earlier in the afternoon at Cleveland, the Red Sox today dropped a 4-0 contest to the White Sox in the third game of their series.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 14 (AP) -Maine Republicans scored a clean sweep of all top offices tonight, capturing the Governorship, a United States Senatorship and three seats in the National House, in the country's first State election since it went to war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The War Production Board today delegated to the Office of Price Administration authority to ration farm machinery and equipment, with the further right to redelegate the authority to the Department of Agriculture.

The offering of common shares is being made subject to prior subscription by the common stockholders of the Community Power and Light Company and General Public Utilities, Inc.

ST. LOUIS, Sept 14 -- For the first time in 14 years, the Browns are assured of third place in the American League -- a dizzy height they clinched mathematically today with a 16-inning 5-to-4 triumph over the Athletics.

Demands for a 15-cent an hour increase in present wage scales and a substantial increase in overtime rates for longshoremen were presented to deep sea ship operators yesterday by the International Longshoremens Association at a meeting in the offices of the New York Shipping Association, 80 Broad Street.

HIS many friends of the baseball world will be glad to know that Secretary Edward Aloysius McGonigle Brannick of the Giants is feeling better now. He nearly died laughing on Sunday when the Dodgers lost a double-header and sank to second place. But the phone rang yesterday and it was Mr. Brannick himself on the other end of the line.

" Sculpture of Freedom" is the title of the show presented this year by the Sculptors Guild, Inc. Installed on the seventh floor roof terrace of the International Building, Rockefeller Center, it opened with a preview yesterday afternoon and beginning today may be visited by the public.

The proposed joint resolution now before Congress to freeze wages and farm prices is a much better one than seemed likely to be offered a few days ago. Contrary to earlier suggestions, Congress does not abdicate its plain responsibilities. It does not simply give the President a blank check, or irresponsibly dump the whole problem into his lap.

Dispatches from India assert that Prime Minister Churchill's statement last week on conditions there have disappointed the moderates on both sides of the internal quarrel. The fanatical part of the Indian population, whether Hindu or Moslem, Mr. Churchill could not hope to convince.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Sept. 14 -- Supervisor Benjamin I. Taylor of Harrison, long an opponent of the Westchester County Airport being constructed in the Purchase estate area of his township, charged today at a meeting of the County Board of Supervisors that the Federal Government intended to spend $5,000,000 on the field instead of the $1,950,000 hitherto announced.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (U.P.) -- Edward Flynn, executive vice president of the Burlington Railroad, said today that the explosions which rocked the Denver Zephyr occurred along 516 feet of track.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 14 -- A ninth-inning surge, aided materially by three Phil errors, sent four rampant Redbirds scampering across the Shibe Park plate today for a 6-3 triumph over the cellar champions that increased the Cardinals' first-place lead over the idle Dodgers to a game and a half.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Sept. 15 (U.P.) -- Allied bombers have made their second attack on Japanese ships in the Tenimber Islands, north of Australia, bombing and machine-gunning two enemy cargo vessels with "unknown results," it was announced today.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept 14 (Reuter) -Wendell L. Willkie declared the countries of the Middle East had unanimously pledged their faith in the Allied cause when he spoke at a dinner given in his honor during his visit to Baghdad.

BEFORE this war Alaska was a stepchild. Its big businesses -- salmon canning and gold mining -- were absentee-owned; its seasonal workers had the grubstake "get in and get out" psychology made famous thirty years ago in Jack London's "Burning Daylight." While the Navy and the Army boasted about our Gibraltar of the Pacific at Pearl Harbor, little or nothing was done to provide advanced bases either in the Aleutians or on the Alaskan mainland.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 14 -- With a last moment collapse of the opposition, Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, writer and playwright and wife of Henry Luce, publisher of Time, Life and Fortune, received today the Republican nomination for Representative in the Fourth Connecticut Congressional District by a vote of 84 to 2.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 14 -- The performance of American industry, business and finance in the wa "has completely confounded the enemies" of our system of free enterprise, Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, deqlared here tonight in an address at a dinner given by the St. Paul Chamber of Commerce for the governors of the Association of Stdek Exchange Firms.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 14 -The last episode of the British War Charities Film, "Forever and a Day," will go before the cameras Thursday with Herbert Marshall, Victor McLaglen and Ruth Warrick in the leading roles, it was learned today.
The first day of a school year meant more than the end of vacation to nearly 1,000,000 New York children who reported on schedule for their lessons yesterday morning.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 14 (AP) -A committee of the Hindu Mahasabha, third largest political party in India, called upon the British Government today to "take the initiative without further delay" to bring Indians into a war-like mood against the Axis.

The breaking up of a diligent but almost entirely fruitless effort to enlist the population of Harlem in a move to upset the United States Government and to help the Japanese establish a world empire for the "dark races" was announced yesterday by United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa.

" The Talk of the Town," the comedy at the Radio City Music Hall, will enter its fourth week on Thursday. . . . Because of the business done by "Somewhere I'll Find You," the Capitol has decided to retain that film for a fourth week, beginning Thursday, the management reported yesterday.

Excellent charts have just been prepared for persons involved in the science of nutrition -- either starting to study it (perhaps in a Red Cross class) or beginning to teach it to others or merely interested in it (as a housekeeper might be) from the standpoint of an amateur dietician.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- Temporary withdrawal of a warrant for the arrest of Osmund Westgate and his return to the Illinois penitentiary as an escaped convict was ordered today by Governor Dwight H. Green. Westgate was arrested in his home in New York last week after fingerprints taken in a Brooklyn war plant exposed his identity.

If the soul of Alvaro de Mendana de Neyra is marching on, it ought to be gratified by the sudden fame of his Isles of Solomon. He was a Saragossa boy who in 1565 went to see his uncle, a great swell and Viceroy of Peru. In 1567 the old gentleman, who had equipped an expedition, ordered him to go and find islands in the Pacific.
ALBANY, Sept. 24 -- The War and Navy Departments refused today to deliver "war ballots" to New York voters overseas, saying that the job "would manifestly interfere with the war effort."

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Sept. 13 (Delayed) (U.P.) --Rear Admiral William H. Standley, United States Ambassador, reported today that the five crew members of the American bomber forced down in Russian territory after participating in Major Gen. James Doolittle's raid on Tokyo, April 18, are healthy, cheerful and anxious to get American newspapers.

The resignation of Douglas P. Falconer is executive director of the Greater New York Fund to become head of the United Seamen's Service, 39 Broadway, was accepted yesterday with "deepest regret" by James G. Blaine, chairman of the board of directors of the combined drive for local charities that has taken place annually since 1938.

Once upon a time Henri Philippe Petain, Marshal of France, was known as the man who would not let the Germans pass Verdun. Subsequent testimony dimmed his glory. One does not see how it can outlive the decree to which, with the infamous Laval and other members of the Vichy Cabinet, he set his signature yesterday.

Offshore fishermen reported moderate success over the past week-end, with good catches of tuna, bonito and albacore marking the activities of Freeport's fleet. Mackerel, porgies, sea bass and blackfish continue to form a substantial part of the catch, and Captain Carl Forsberg of the Viking was among those reporting an improvement in the fishing.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Administrative actions taken today under Presidential and statutory authority indicated that Federal officials were adopting a "tougher" or, as they expressed it, a more "realistic" attitude toward putting the country on a basis of "total war."

CLEVELAND, Sept. 14 -- The end of another triumphant pennant trail came to the Yankees today as Joe McCarthy's invincible juggernaut of the diamond roiled over the Indians, 8 to 3, to remove the runner-up Red Sox from all mathematical calculation.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 14 (AP) -The second day of the seventy-six Grand Army of the Republic encampment saw registered only about a score of the eighty veterans expected at this sixth meeting on the scene of the organization's founding on Dec. 19, 1865.

British men are better fed than their ration cards would indicate. They get part of the ration of their women folks. A survey by The Lancet, famous medical journal, was summed up in a special dispatch to this paper yesterday.

Personal letter to New York women, 20-45 years old, with better than high school education:

PEARL HARBOR, Sept. 14 -- Japanese prisoners taken by the United States forces in the Solomon Islands fighting that started Aug. 7 -- of whom 450 have just arrived at an Allied port outside the battle area -- were so surprised by the humane treatment they have received that many have expressed a desire never to return to Japan, according to an announcement today by Admiral Chester W. Nimitz's Pacific Fleet headquarters.
Supporters of Thomas E. Dewey hailed yesterday the first reports from the Gallup poll on the New York State campaign as indicating the certain election of Mr. Dewey as Governor.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease of 9 per cent last week under the comparative week last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The absence of the colorful lighting effects of the last thirty-nine years failed to dim the gay spirits of Coney Island's fortieth annual Mardi Gras as 250,000 persons attended the opening night's festivities under New York's strict dimout regulations last night.

Two special offerings, one of which went rapidly, and one secondary distribution featured off-the-Exchange trading in listed securities yesterday. They included special offerings of 9,300 shares of Food Fair Stores and 3,000 shares of Underwood Elliott Fisher.

Colonel Conrad E. Snow, chief legal officer of the Army Signal Corps, presented yesterday the Army-Navy E for high achievement in the production of war equipment to the Federal Manufacturing and Engineering Corporation in a ceremony at 211 Steuben Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A statement of policy is expected from the Office of Price Administration within a week or ten days in respect to an appeal for more gasoline for traveling salesmen, but the outlook is "not too optimistic," Representative Woodrum said today.
SPOKANE, Wash., Sept. 14 (AP) -- Five officers and two enlisted men were on board the Army bomber which has been missing four days from Geiger Field, the base public relations officer said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Congress received two measures today to compete for enactment before the deadline of Oct. 1 set by President Roosevelt for statutory powers to curb inflation.

ROSLYN, L.I., Sept. 14 -- A six-foot putt by Gus Norwich, North Hills pro, on the eighteenth green for a birdie 3 gave him and Pat McGee first place in the weekly amateur-pro event of the Long Island P.G.A., with a 34, 30 -- 64 at the Shelter Rock Country Club today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 14 -- Evidence that a Japanese seaplane, possibly operating from a submarine, may have attempted to set Southern Oregon forests afire in the first air bombing of continental United States was reported by the Western Defense Command today.

Yesterday's Class C Chicklet Handicap at Aqueduct was run in two sections, which pleased Eddie Arcaro very much. Bringing Scotland Light up in the last few yards, Arcaro took the first division by a head and then came right back to put the huge Porter's Cap in front early and keep him there to win the second division with five lengths to spare.

A net profit of $1,327,179 for the year ended with June was reported yesterday by L.C. Smith Corona Typewriters, Inc., and its subsidiaries. The profit, which is equivalent to $4.52 a share on the common stock, compares with $1,035,040, or $3.46 a common share, for the preceding fiscal year.
The seven-story loft, store and apartment building at 16 East Fiftieth Street was sold by the Florma Realty Company, Inc., Abraham Harris, president, to the Loyal Realty Company, Inc.

OTTAWA, Sept. 14 (Canadian Press ) -- There is no place for industrial strikes, interunion strife or lockouts in Canada's war effort, Labor Minister Humphrey Mitchell said in an address prepared for delivery today at the annual convention of the Canadian Congress of Labor.

LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP) -- The Distinguished Service Cross and Order of the Purple Heart have been awarded to Lieut. Col. Loren Hillsinger, 34, of El Paso, Texas, who lost a leg while taking part in the Dieppe raid as a member of the staff of the chief of combined operations, Lieut. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower announced today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 14 -- The Fenway team of Herman Barron and Jim Gaynor captured first prize with 32, 31 -- 63 in the Westchester County Golf Association's best-ball tournament at the Wykagyl Country Club today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14 (AP) -- A heavy run Of cattle entered the local and other major live stock markets today and forced prlcei lower. Steers and yearlings grading medium to low choice were weak to 25 cents a hundred pounds lower. Choice kinds resisted tile dob'nturn.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 14 -- William S. Shea, treasurer of the New Rochelle National Corporation, a real estate holding company, and of the Home for the Aged of New Rochelle, walked into the District Attorney's office here this afternoon and admitted he had embezzled $25,000 from those organizations, according to Assistant District Attorney Frederick E. Weeks Jr.
With meat rationing about to start and with questions as to why there is a meat shortage arising from every quarter, I feel a farmer's view on the subject may be in order.
MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 14 -- A practice air raid alert in Nassau County between 2:32 and 2:50 P.M. today disclosed the need for more women air raid wardens for daytime civilian defense duties.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- Two petitions for modification of the Interstate Commerce Commission's order of July 13 setting up a plan of reorganization for the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad Company were filed today with the commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The text of the bill introduced in the House by Representative Steagall of Alabama to control prices, wages and other cost of living factors as an anti-inflation measure, follows:

The city of Rochester, N. Y., announced yesterday that it will sell on Friday a new issue of $2,270,000 eight-month notes. The issue will be dated Sept. 21, 1942, and will be payable on May 21, 1943. Bidders are required to name the rate of interest.

While American women want to help in the war by obtaining jobs in industry, they do not want to take the time to prepare adequately for such work, and many who are qualified are not going into war work "because they want to start at the top," it was charged yesterday by Professor Albert B. Newman, dean of the City College School of Technology.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Sept. 14 -- Gasoline rationing books and loose coupons, entitling the holders to 151,200 gallons of gasoline, were stolen over the week-end from the Perth Amboy War Price and Rationing Board offices, 215 Market Street.

LONDON, Sept. 14 -- All staff officers of the United States Army Bomber Command must accompany Flying Fortresses in raids over Germany and German-occupied territory "as soon and as often as practicable," Brig. Gen. Ira C. Eaker, chief of the command, ruled today.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 14 -- Repeating her medal winning performance of 1941, Miss Nancy McClave of the Maplewood C.C. today paced a field of sixty-three in the annual New Jersey State women's golf championship with a surprisingly high 84 over the Upper Montclair C.C. course.

Louis Weinstock, secretary-treasurer of District Council No. 9, Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers of America, A.F. of L., announced yesterday at a luncheon meeting held in the Hotel Woodstock, 127 West Forty-third Street, that thousands of members of the union will turn over one day's pay to Allied war relief agencies.
/%[r. and iVfrs. Herman D. Kountze are at Mayfair House. Mr. and Mrs. Wright Barclay have returned from the Southfield Point Club, Stamford, Conn., to 77 Park Avenue.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14 -- Beauticians and cosmeticians, whose mission is to keep the American woman glamorous, war or no war, have accepted the challenge of priorities.

Mayor La Guardia told 200 new firemen yesterday that the Fire Department was on a war footing and that orders must be strictly obeyed. At induction ceremonies in the department's auxiliary headquarters, 87 Lafayette Street, he also warned seventy-seven men being promoted that because of the war they would have to work harder and longer.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 14 -- Definitely going beyond the limits of a strictly technical gathering, the first Inter-American Conference on Social Security, meeting here today, laid the foundation for the establishment of a continent-wide policy to promote and maintain a high level of development, to increase the national wealth and share it more equitably, to improve health, nutrition, housing and general vocational education.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- The texts of messages exchanged between Lieut. Gen. Henry H. Arnold, chief of the United States Army Air Forces, and Air Chief Marshal Sir Charles Portal of the Royal Air Force were made public here today.

The sinking of four additional merchant ships and a Canadian patrol vessel was announced yesterday by naval authorities of Canada, and the United States Navy reported another cargo ship lost, as Berlin widened its claims of U-boat destruction among convoys.
MOSCOW, Sept. 14 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- President Roosevelt, reporting to Congress today that Lend-Lease goods transferred and services rendered during the last eighteen months had amounted to $5,129,000,000, warned that American war production now had "little more than passed the half-way mark" to maximum output, which could be achieved "only by stripping our civilian economy to the bone."

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sept. 14 (U.P.) -- American Army engineers, who long have boasted that they could fight all day and work all night, dropped their shovels and pitched in with rifles to help rout the Japanese at Milne Bay on New Guinea, Aug. 25 to 30, it was learned today.

Employes of the Sanitation Department will instruct householders, tenants and building superintendents regarding the change in the sanitary code requiring segregation of tin cans in separate containers for collection before there is strict enforcement, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday.

Last week Malta celebrated a patriotic festival. On Sept. 8, 1565, the Turkish veteran general, Mustapha, who had landed his troops in May, sailed away with the remnant of them. Helped by no other Christian Power, La Valette, Grand Master of the Knights of Malta, with an army greatly outnumbered, fought off the Moslems.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 14 -Close upon the heels of the withdrawing Japanese after a hundred-day battle in Chekiang and Kiangsi Provinces, rehabilitation measures are reportedly being implemented to repair the ravages of war and restore the area to peace and order.

The action of the Federal Reserve Board in further reducing reserve requirements of member banks in New York City and in Chicago, this time to 22 per cent from 24 per cent, follows by four and one-half weeks a similar reduction, effective on Aug. 20, to 24 per cent from 26 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 -- A new regulation announced today by the Office of Price Administration established methods by which manufacturers can readily determine the maximum prices that they may charge for new lines of rubber products.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,160 as against 386 in the preceding week and 1,043 in the like period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations totaled 544, which compared with 36 for last Tuesday.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- As a prelude to the second anniversary of the London Blitz, the German port of Wilhelmshaven, one of the enemy's outstanding U-boat bases, was bombed by a strong force of British raiders last night that lost only two aircraft.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 15 -- In a decision setting a precedent for the State, Vice Chancellor Alfred A. Stein today invalidated provisions of the New Jersey Fair Trade Act which conflict with Office of Price Administration regulations. Under the Fair Trade Act, minimum prices are established under blanket contract between wholesalers and retailers.

The gold braid and epaulets of high officers of the Army and Navy were much in evidence yesterday when the Greater New York branch of the American Women's Voluntary Services opened its luncheon canteen in the Green Room of the Hotel Edison, designed to give visiting service men an opportunity to entertain their women friends inexpensively.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The Red Cross will attempt to get messages to unidentified prisoners of war or military men missing in action in the Far East, it announced today, urging relatives and friends of such men to immediately file messages at their local Red Cross chapters.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Rioting that broke out at the start of Mohandas K. Gandhi's latest independence campaign may have been planned "to synchronize" with a Japanese attack on India, and another such outbreak would be a direct invitation to invasion, Sir Reginald Maxwell told the Legislative Assembly today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Joseph W. Powell, special assistant to the Secretary of the Navy, told a Congressional committee today that he was not surprised when the Higgins shipbuilding contract was canceled and said "there will be a good many other cancellations" because of shortages of critical materials.

KEARNY, N.J., Sept. 15 -- The war production pace in the yards of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company was accelerated further today by the launching of the twin destroyers, the Maddox and the Nelson, at ceremonies that did not interrupt work on other war vessels.

Gill Robb Wilson, State aviation director, and Albert W. Hawkes, Montclair industrialist, were locked in a neck-to-neck struggle in New Jersey last night for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate seat now held by Senator William H. Smatters, Democrat.

OTTAWA, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Canadian and United States manpower authorities today approved the continuation of professional sport in wartime, but said that no special consideration would be given under mobilization regulations to professional athletes.

OTTAWA, Sept. 15 -- The total cost among the Canadian forces of the stubbornly-pressed raid on Dieppe just a month ago was revealed today by Canadian National Defense headquarters as 3,350 killed, wounded and missing, of whom by far the largest proportion are missing and many may be presumed to be prisoners.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 (AP) --Representatives of two communities in Alabama charged today that the National Power and Light Company had "sought to avoid" disposing of its subsidiary, the Birmingham Electric Company, as directed under a "death sentence" order of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

While I am writing this letter the temperature outside my window is exactly 90 degrees in the sun, and yet women, and men too, are walking around in Fall and wintry-looking clothing simply because fashion decrees that Summer is over.

OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., Sept 15 (AP) -- A man identified by papers on his clothing as Lieutenant Mortimer Bishop, 80 years old, of 270 Broadway, New York, died on a Portland-New York train here tonight.

Describing post-war housing possibilities in the United States as "limitless" and emphasizing sharp gains in productive capacity and research, James L. Wick, economic analyst of Prentice-Hall, Inc., yesterday told the Sales Executives Club of New York all indications point to great prosperity following the conclusion of hostilities.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Montgomery Ward Co. reported today net income of $10,133,332, or $1.81 a common share, for the six months ended July 31. This compared with net income of $7,317,038, or $1.27 a common share, in the same 1941 period.

Optimism engendered principally by the provision for loans on agricultural crops at full-parity in the price-control bill of Representative Steagall of Alabama encouraged general buying yesterday in futures on the New York Cotton Exchange and prices rose 23 points early in the afternoon. Profit-taking halted the rise, however, and the market closed with net gains of 3 to 6 points.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Before the Senate Finance Committee recessed last night to await the drafting of its version of the current tax bill a national sales levy, linked to the Treasury's pay-as-you-go withholding tax, won the support of Chairman Walter F. George and came within two votes of carrying.

Striped bass fishing at famed Cuttyhunk Island is not expected to be affected by the coastal war regulations recently invoked. Anglers will be permitted to fish there during daylight hours, using boats operated by the Massachusetts guides, as previously, from sunrise to sunset.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday reported for July a gross income from operating activities of $16,616,393, compared with $12,038,940 in July, 1941. Net operating income was $3,334,961, against $2,129,861, while net income was $2,493,914, compared with $1,548,322.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Sept. 15 -- Paul Edwards, WPA Administrator for Puerto Rico, released today a special report to his Washington superiors on insular, unemployment. He revealed a "catastrophic economic situation, headed for complete collapse.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- A Navy Department communique:

MOSCOW, Sept. 15 -- The general assault on Stalingrad now is at its height and all sectors from the extreme right wing south of the city to the left on the northwest, the enemy is attacking in force. In most sectors the Russians have yielded ground in the last twenty-four hours, though in some cases they have recovered to counter-attack.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Appealing to the public again to turn in scrap to aid the war, President Roosevelt said today that a painstaking search of the White House residence and executive offices during the last three months had yielded five tons of metal scrap, and expressed the belief that the average American home had not yet been searched sufficiently.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Sept. 15 -- An Army fighter plane crashed into a bog eight miles northwest of here early this morning, killing its pilot and possibly a passenger. Late tonight State police and civilian defense workers were still trying to dig out the wreckage of the plane to determine whether there was more than one occupant.

Nassau County has adopted a supplement to its refunding plan authorizing the acceptance of certain additional bonds maturing in 1946 and 1947 in the principal amount of $1,200,000 as eligible for exchange for new refunding bonds, according to Lehman Brothers and the Chase National Bank, refunding agents for the county.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Three households typifying cross-sections of United States life have been among the first to receive the government's V-home certificate, awarded for participation in the nation's total war offensive, the Office of Civilian Defense announced today.

The wage and hours division of the United States Department of Labor began last night open hearings at its local offices, 165 West Forty-sixth Street, on a complaint against the Barnard-Greenberg Company, maker of caps and hats, of 511 East Seventy-second Street.

The new management of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation, declaring that it required more time to determine a course of action best calculated to protect the interests of the corporation and its stockholders, asked the Supreme Court yesterday to grant a stay of all proceedings in a $10,000,000 stockholders' accounting suit brought earlier in the year against the former officers and directors of the concern.

An interesting comment on the proposals to curb farm prices has been offered by the movement of prices in the commodity markets since President Roosevelt delivered his message to Congress calling for ceilings at "parity." In the interval of eight days cotton has gone up 10 to 20 points, wheat about 3 cents a bushel, rye better than 9 cents a bushel.
LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Although the stock markets had a quiet day the tone remained firm with gilt-edge issues maintaining their recent prices.

It has not yet been counted a crime in the United States to be a critic of the Government. If ever that day shall come we shall not greatly care whether Hitler or Hirohito has designs upon our freedom, for there will be freedom no more. Meantime some of us are greatly concerned.

The Timken-Detroit Axle Company and all domestic subsidiaries showed a net profit of $5,205,190, for the fiscal year ended on June 30, Willard F. Rockwell, chairman of the board, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.

Possibility of a strike of 15,000 truck drivers in this city apparently was averted yesterday when representatives of three local unions of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F. of L., and the Merchant Truckmen's Bureau of New York agreed to submit their dispute to arbitration.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 15 -Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate for Governor, paid an informal visit to the Nassau County Fair here this afternoon and conferred afterward with Republican leaders of Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Industrial building in New York State declined to the lowest figure in several years last month, mainly due to priorities, the State Labor Department reported today. Only sixty-nine plans aggregating $926,550 in probable cost were submitted.

As information about the fighting habits of the Japanese accumulates, we in this country can begin to understand what the Chinese have been up against all these years. Field reports from the Solomons and New Guinea tell of lone Japanese refusing quarter; of Japanese killing their own wounded to keep them from falling into the hands of the enemy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- A blueprint for the post-war world through establishment of "a just and free order for all the peoples" was drawn up today in the concluding statement of the Inter-American Seminar on Social Studies called together by the National Catholic Welfare Conference.

With their backs to the proverbial wall, the Dodgers will resume the feverish pennant fight today at Ebbets Field. Frank Frisch and his Pirates, having failed to damage the Giants over the week-end, will move into Flat-bush for single encounters today and tomorrow.

With three doctors differing widely on the physical condition of William Griffin, and the genuineness of a "heart attack" the publisher suffered on Sunday, United States Commissioner Garrett W. WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Since last Saturday night United States Marines on Guadalcanal Island, in the Solomons, have been fighting off violent attempts by Japanese land troops to recapture their positions, the Navy revealed tonight in a communique.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The War Production Board reported today that all "free" silver held by the Treasury has been assigned for use in war industry.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- Rye continued the advance today that got under way last week and prices soared 3 3/4 cents a bushel at one time to a new high level since last May before heavy profit-taking and some backspreading with other grains caused a reaction.

With Bucharest reported in flames and the installations of the Ploestri oil fields left in ruins by Russian bombers, the war is moving deeper into the Balkans. It is there that General Draja Mikhailovitch has already established a second fighting front. Both developments lend significance to a Swedish report of a revolt in Bulgarian Macedonia.

BOSTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Representative Joseph E. Casey and Mayor Roger L. Putnam of Springfield emerged tonight as the apparent Massachusetts primary winners of the Democratic Senatorial and Governorship nominations. Republican Senator Henry Cabot Lodge rolled into renomination by a mountainous majority.

THE late Guglielmo Ferrero, the celebrated Italian historian, scholar and exile, wrote history with a zestful flourish and a bland assumption of great historical learning upon his readers' part that made his books both good and difficult reading. Not even Shakespeare, who admitted that "not marble, nor the gilded monuments of princes" would outlive his powerful rhyme, was surer of his own pre-eminence.

As the chief comics of "New Priorities of 1942," which occurred at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre last evening, they bring something more than personality to a vaudeville show.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Exports from the United States in the first seven months of the year, stimulated by lease-lend shipments, rose to a total of $4,025,668,000, the Bureau of the Census reported today. This is 64 per cent above value of exports for the corresponding months of last year.

The absence of Summer clothing clearance sales indicates that clothiers are not concerned about having their money tied up in all-worsted and woolen merchandise, according to the consensus of leading merchants in this area, who estimated yesterday that the carryover to be held for sale next year will be twice as large as a year ago.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Allied air forces again smashed at Japanese bases in New Guinea, and ground patrols in the Owen Stanley Mountains were more active yesterday, but the general situation remained unchanged, a communique said today.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Wednesday, Sept. 16 (AP) -- A communique:

Mrs. John North Willys gave a luncheon yesterday in the Ritz-Carlton Garden. Among her guests were Mrs. Raymond Kent, Mrs. Arthur Genius, Mrs. Henry Anderson, Mrs. Kingore Bixby, Mrs. Earl Hines, Mrs. Edwin P. Benson, Mrs. Clement M. Keys, Mrs. Donald Pierce, Mrs. Nan du Page and Mrs. Fredric Uihlein.

Two old steam locomotives, which many years ago chugged and shrieked up and down the old Third and Second Avenue elevated lines, pulling carloads of passengers in the early days of this era of rapid transit, were sold for scrap metal yesterday by the Board of Transportation.

MONTREAL, Sept. 15 (Canadian Press) -- The go-ahead signal for continuation of professional sport in wartime was received with satisfaction tonight by members of the National Hockey League both in Canada and the United States.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 15 -- Railroads of New Jersey challenged today the right of the State Board of Tax Appeals to review the legality of assessments on railroad property for 1940 and 1941 on the ground that the valuations for those two years have been fixed by legislation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The War Labor Board was confronted today with the alternative of supporting President Roosevelt's declaration last Fall in the "captive mine" dispute that the government would not order a closed shop or of rejecting the recommendation of a split panel, the first since the WLB was created in January to propose granting of a closed shop.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 -- Nick Etten's sixth home run, made off Mort Cooper in the eighth inning to tie the score, brought only two results to the cellar dwelling Phils today -- both unhappy. They had to play fourteen innings and they lost to the front-running Cardinals, 3 -- 2. on a double by Murry Dickson to left center and a single to center by Jimmy Brown.

Although yesterday was income I tax day, and also the day for government payments of maturing r Treasury notes and of interest due ion various issues of government ,securities, the dislocation of the I money market is not confined to a single day but actually endures for more than a week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed in August totaled 925,089 bales of lint and 122,138 bales of linters, compared with 995,041 and 128,123 during July this year, and 872,035 and 130,965 during August last year.

In an effort to clear up uncertainties surrounding the renegotiation of war contracts which are claimed to be hampering war production a proposal to fix a flat rate of 6 per cent on profits after taxes for war contractors will be introduced in Congress, it was learned here yesterday.

The membership of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians has indorsed unanimously the fight of James C. Petrillo, federation president, against recorded music and voted its "fullest confidence" in his leadership, it was announced yesterday by the local.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 15 (U.P.) -- The number of Brazilian ships sunk by Axis submarines was increased to seventeen today when 116 survivors from three ships were landed here by the Spanish ship Cabo de Hornos.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 -- Charles S. Handelman, a former newsboy whose stand was just outside the old Ledger building thirty-five years ago, bought the structure at Seventh and Sansom Streets at auction today for $80,000.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Jimmy Bivins's sharp punches floored Tami Mauriello tonight in the first round of their Cleveland Arena fight. Then the Clevelander went on to hand Mauriello his first loss since the New Yorker graduated to the heavyweight ranks a year ago.

Fashions mannered to a new mode of life provided the theme yesterday for Arnold Constable's smartly presented review of Autumn costumes. Arranged in six scenes and with a romantic bridal finish, the collection included costumes for work and play in city and country.
WASHINGTON, Sept 15 -- Rear Admiral John H. Towers, Chief of the Navy Bureau of Aeronautics, was promoted today to the rank of vice admiral and assigned to the command of the Pacific Fleet Air Force.

The Fall art season may now regarded as officially begun, since four New York museums opened special exhibitions yesterday and a fifth is to open still another show on Friday. The Riverside Museum is starting its fifth year with a large and timely display of war and defense posters from the United Nations.

There would seem to be no evident reason for the disfavor in which many persons hold the squash. The cause cannot be said to be their conservative dislike for innovations, for pumpkins and such have been part of the American scene since the pre-Columbus period.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Members of the Pacific War Council, after an unusually long session today, intimated that there was general agreement that India must be used as a base for the fight against Japan.

The conviction that Japan would not relax her effort to retake her lost bases in the Solomons was confirmed last night by our Navy's communique reporting heavy fighting which began last Saturday and in which our Marines "are maintaining their positions." Our Navy has previously stated that it has been impossible to prevent small landings on Guadalcanal Island of enemy troops attempting to join the Japanese garrison which fled to the interior.

X-ray examinations are being held this week for 4,000 Hunter College girls in compliance with a recent resolution of the Board of Higher Education requiring annual X-rays and serological tests for all students in the city colleges.

Sounding what may be the theme of Tokyo's propaganda during the next phase of the war, a Japanese Government spokesman declared yesterday that Japan did not seek to conquer America but was fighting only to break Occidental control in East Asia, according to a Japanese broadcast recorded in New York by The Associated Press.

District Council No. 18, Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers of America, A.F. of L., yesterday sent a telegram to Louis Weinstock, secretary-treasurer of District Council No. 9, saying that not only would members of Council No. 9 be permitted to work on Saturday, Sept. 26, when they will turn their day's pay over to various Allied war relief agencies, but members of No. 18 will do the same thing.
MOSCOW, Sept. 15 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Sept 15 -- After an inspection tour of New Guinea, General Sir Thomas Blamey, commander in chief of all Allied land forces in the Australian region, held a large press conference today at which he gave his estimate of the Japanese New Guinea plans.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 15 -- Having run a gantlet of German bombs throughout most of the day, naval units of Great Britain's Mediterranean fleet returned to their base at Alexandria late yesterday after the Tobruk raid.

More war contracts are urgently needed in New York, not only to aid industry and employment here but also to help building owners to meet the added costs recently imposed by the War Labor Board through reductions in hours and increases in wages of building service employes, George L. Allin, president, said at the annual meeting of the Real Estate Board of New York held yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Colonel Frank S. Ross, chief of the Army Service of Supply Transportation Branch, in charge of the movement of American troops from the United States to Britain, told a press conference today that air cargo ships could be extremely useful in bringing certain types of critical armaments for troops across the Atlantic.
Several leases of large apartments in the Park Avenue section of Manhattan were announced yesterday by owners and agents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Wages already have been stabilized for three-fourths of the employes in manufacturing industries, and the pay levels at which they are working may be viewed as ceilings, William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, told the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency today as it considered legislation to give President Roosevelt statutory powers to curb inflation.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The Japanese in Burma, who in two raids upon Rangoon killed 1,102 persons last Christmas season, felt the impact of the American Army Air Forces twice in the past week.

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 15 -- Mrs. Alan Rosenberg of Lido dropped her tee shot three feet from the pin on the sixteenth green at Apawamis today and sank the putt for a 2, a birdie according to men's par and an eagle according to women's par. This was the shot which gave her the low gross honors in the one-day tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 15 -- Fearful of an enemy invasion, Mrs. A.V. Golterman, 78 years old, widow of Herman Golterman, a former New York importer, withdrew $28,757 early this year from three savings banks and hid the money in her piano only to have the sum stolen.

After a brief ownership, Frederick Brown, operator, has sold the three buildings at 233-41 Fourth Avenue and 102 East Twenty-fifth Street to an investing client of Cushman Wakefield and Robert Kaplan.

A playwriting contest which will be open only to enlisted men and non-commissioned officers in the United States Army is being sponsored by John Golden, Broadway producer, in conjunction with the Special Service Office, Second Service Command, United States Army, it was announced yesterday.
AN ALASKA ARMY BASE, Sept. 7 (AP) (Delayed) -- American fighter planes have strafed Japanese shipping and men on Kiska for the first time since that Aleutian island was occupied.

The New York Sterling Manufacturers Association will solicit the assistance of the Amalgamated Silver Workers Union to petition the government to release 125,000,000 ounces of silver for the silverware and jewelry industry for the next year in an effort to prevent a wholesale shutdown of shops, it was stated last night at a meeting of the association at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

DURHAM, N.C., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Prices were steady on the North Carolina middle tobacco belt today, indicating that the opening day average of about $40 a hundred yesterday would again be paid for flue-cured leaf that was mostly of medium grade.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Sept 16 (AP) -- The midnight communique:

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 15 -- Mrs. Charles Whitehead of Plainfield, the defending champion, hit her best scoring form of the season today and virtually breezed into the second round of the New Jersey State women's golf championship at the Upper Montclair Country Club.

PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Sept. 15 -- The Japanese are by no means "on the run" before the United Nations' new offensive in the Pacific, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, declared today in an address preceding his presentation of medals to twenty-five officers and men of the Pacific Fleet aboard a fighting ship here.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 15 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops have recaptured Wuyi, a highway center twenty-three miles southeast of the "bomb Tokyo" airbase town of Kinhwa, after killing or wounding 500 Japanese, and are in hot pursuit of the enemy, who is fleeing northward along the Mei River, it was announced tonight.

Fourteen hundred persons attended a dinner last night at the Riverside Plaza Hotel, 253 West Seventy-third Street, in honor of three members of the Soviet merchant marine, each of whom has been honored by his government with the title "Hero of the Soviet Union."

Delegates to the American Kennel Club at their quarterly meeting yesterday in the club offices in this city were surprised when the board of directors failed to present for their consideration the proposed amendment to the rules regarding those eligible to judge at dog shows.

A 17-year-old Stamford, Conn., youth confessed last night at Westport that he had raped and murdered two sisters, 7 and 8 years old, after kidnapping them near their home in Bedford Village, N.Y., Monday night, according to the police. Bodies of both the children have been found.

JERSEY CITY, Sept 15 (AP) -- Jersey City made it three straight over Newark's pennant-winning Bears today and took a 3-2 lead in their best 4 out of 7 semi-final Governors' Cup series when they defeated the Bruins, 3 to 1, before 1,757 fans.

Employes of the Mergenthaler Linotype Company and their friends filled Ryerson Street, between Flushing and Park Avenues Brooklyn, late yesterday afternoon for a formal presentation of an Army-Navy E pennant for production of ordnance for the government.

Color dominated at De Pinna's showing yesterday of its new Fall clothes. Purples, reds, greens, gold and browns held sway in everything from handsome tweed suits to dinner gowns. Clothes for the family, from youngsters of 4 to the sophisticated matron, were displayed.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Headquarters of United States Army Air Forces in the Middle East said today that the American bombers that backed up British aerial squadrons in Sunday's raid on Tobruk engaged in "one of their most extensive operations" of the Middle Eastern campaign.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 15 -- The New Jersey State-wide campaign for the collection of scrap metal and rubber was opened officially by Governor Charles Edison on the campus of Princeton University today when he accepted an old German war cannon that had been seized on the field of battle during the World War by former Princeton students.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 15 -- Six German divisions have captured the central station in Stalingrad, the military spokesman in Berlin reported this afternoon, announcing that the last phase of the battle for the city has now begun. The Soviet defenders inside the city have been split in two by the German wedge, which reached the central station in the middle of the city, according to reports received here.

The Bureau of Real Estate of the city sold at auction in its offices yesterday the site of the old First District Municipal Court at 146 Grand Street, at the corner of Lafayette Street, on a bid of $47,500.

Fine weather favored an outdoor benefit yesterday of the British War Relief Society, which sponsored a garden party in Turtle Bay Gardens, 229 East Forty-eighth Street, and a street fair in Forty-eighth Street, roped off between Third and Second Avenues, to raise money for the relief and recreation of British merchant seamen.

With taxpayers, including a corporation whose contribution was $12,000,000, rushing to pay the third installment of their Federal income taxes yesterday, the collectors reported receipts running a little better than twice the amounts taken in at this time last year.

Formation of the Lawyers Committee for the election of John J. Bennett Jr., Charles Poletti, Joseph V. O'Leary and Henry Epstein, Democratic State nominees, was announced yesterday. Daniel E. Blumenthal and James B. McNally are co-chairmen, while the honorary chairmen are James W. Gerard, Jeremiah T. Mahoney and Cornelius J. Smyth.

Clergymen are exhorting us to expend our greatest efforts to save the last home place of freedom of worship. We are told to save everything essential to war, and, as Winter approaches, especially fuel. We agree.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- The entire exportable tea crops of India, Ceylon and East Africa will be bought up by the British Food Ministry for distribution among the United Nations and neutral countries. This was recommended by the tea committee of the Combined Food Boards, on which sit representatives of the United Kingdom, the Dominions, the United States and the Soviet Union.

While the State War Ballot Commission at a meeting yesterday in Albany decided to ask reconsideration of the decision of the War and Navy Departments not to ship paper ballots abroad for use by New York State soldiers because of better use for the shipping space, the opinion here was that the only material result of the ruling was elimination of any possible suspense regarding the result in a close election.
