BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 15 -- After several days of feverish dickering the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Chamber of Deputies issued a majority report today, signed by five of its nine members, advising Congressional ratification of the recommendations signed by Argentina in Rio de Janeiro, but it failed to obtain a majority for the report advising a rupture of relations with Axis countries.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Larry Allen, Associated Press war correspondent who established the press box aboard warships and won the current Pulitzer Prize for international reporting on 100,000 miles of hazardous operations with the British Mediterranean Fleet, was reliably reported today to be a prisoner of war.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (A.P.) -- Prices of hogs were fully steady to 5 cents a hundred pounds higher today in the face of larger supplies than a week ago. Total salable receipts at the principal V'estern markets were $5,100, compared with 61,532 8. year ago.

Life insurance written in the first eight months of this year was 3.4 per cent greater than for the corresponding period of 1941, while the total for August was 19.3 per cent below the similar month a year ago, according to the report of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to the United States Department of Commerce.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- William M. Jeffers, president of the Union Pacific Railroad, was named rubber administrator tonight and put in complete charge of the entire rubber program.

Members of the Export Managers Club, impatient over the delay in obtaining official clarification of their proposal to utilize vessels of less than 1,000 tons to make shipments of essential products to near-by Latin-American countries, are planning to proceed with the project despite the lack of formal approval by the War Shipping Administration, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Although no hope was held for any immediate lessening of the war cost, which, for the United States, was nearly $9,500,000,000 during July and August alone, taxpayers still found some cause for cheer in the Federal Reserve Board's monthly financial bulletin issued today.

The revival of California's wine industry is making its mark on the publishers' lists. There have been numerous guides to the vineyards and brands of wine. Alice Tisdale Hobart made the traditions of the wine country the substance of her current novel.
CAIRO, Sept. 15 (AP) -- The British Headquarters, Royal Air Force communique:

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 15 -- Japan's last conquest, Burma, has been the first to learn that Japanese promises of independence are not worth anything, it was learned today from official British sources.

Dean Alfange, American Labor party nominee for Governor, making the first of a series of ten major campaign addresses last night, said he was the sole champion of the New Deal and all it stands for in the State election and that victory for either Thomas E. Dewey or John J. Bennett Jr. would mean a "slow strangulation" of the New Deal in its home State.
CHICAGO, Sept. 15 -- The first two games of the world series will be played Sept. 30 and Oct. 1 either in Brooklyn or St. Louis, Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis announced today.

It would seem that Edwin L. James, in his article in THE TIMES of Sept. 13, is guilty of a bit of wishful thinking. I recognize that Mr. James has behind him years of journalistic experience in Europe, and his judgment is not to be passed over lightly.

The newspapers are regularly accused of allowing their patriotism to run away with their headlines. In a mistaken zeal for public morale they exaggerate victories and play down disasters. The critics say this is a serious disservice to the country.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 15 -- Yale University students numbering about 600 are prepared to man vital posts in the event of an air attack on New Haven. They have enrolled in fourteen branches of the Air Raid Precautions Service and are studying to equip themselves as fire fighters, bomb reconnaissance experts, auxiliary police, airplane spotters and air raid wardens on a volunteer basis.

Aggressive service on the home front to match our government's policy of aggressive warfare on distant battlefields was advocated yesterday by Hugh R. Jackson of the Office of Civilian Defense as a bulwark against a war that can be lost because of the failure of civilians to mobilize for defense.

Immediate establishment of a 40-cent an hour minimum wage for some 20,000 unskilled workers in the candy and related industries will be recommended to Wage and Hour Administrator L. Metcalfe Walling, it was announced yesterday at the Hotel Astor by a special fifteen-man committee that has been conducting a survey to determine the industry's ability to increase the minimum hourly rate from 30 cents to 40 cents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- President Roosevelt indicated today that the Administration may not press for immediate construction of the St. Lawrence power and seaway project because of the war's more pressing demands for critical materials.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Samuel Kurtz, a torpedoman whose life was saved by twelve transfusions of blood plasma after he lost both legs in the torpedoing of the destroyer Kearny, today presented the Army-Navy "E" penant to Norman H. Davis, Chairman of the American Red Cross, for the achievement of that organization's blood donor service.

Declaring that the Yugoslav rebel forces fighting against the Nazi occupation of their country are "continuing to resist marvelously," Captain Ivan Kern, Minister of Transport in the refugee Yugoslav Government in London, arrived at La Guardia Field late yesterday with twelve other passengers aboard a transatlantic clipper.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) -- A house committee was told today by Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service Director, that unless the drafting of youth 18 and 19 were not started "very soon," it would be necessary to induct between 1,000,000 and 1,500,000 married men.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Taking up the task of developing a meat rationing system which will assure equitable distribution of existing meat supplies to civilians, experts in the Office of Price Administration have indicated that they will require three months in which to work out the variety of problems.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 15 -- Around 4 o'clock tomorrow afternoon Lou Little will bring his Columbia University Lions to the Bowl. Yale will be there as a reception committee. The two squads, their coaching staffs and no one else will enter, the doors will close behind them and they will have it out in a private supervised scrimmage.

The action of the Senate Finance Committee in reversing itself by cutting the normal and surtax corporate tax rate, and particularly in voting to permit utility companies to deduct preferred dividends from surtax charges, generated new life yesterday in the stock market.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The War Production Board ordered today a coupon-rationing system for fuel oil to be put into effect in seventeen Atlantic seaboard States and in thirteen Midwestern States by Oct. 1.

Even if the superstition that tried so long to make the Maine Fall election a sibyl were still doing business at the old stand, it would have been impossible to drum up much interest in that event this year. The Republicans have elected their candidates for Governor, Senator, Representative in Congress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Formation of an Emergency Group for Foreign Vegetable Oils, Fats and Oil-Bearing Materials, as part of a plan to establish a wartime association of importers in those lines, was announced jointly today by the Board of Economic Warfare and the Commodity Credit Corporation on the Department of Agriculture.

From a bit of prosaic information yesterday that the Hotel America at 151 West Forty-seventh Street would close by the end of the week came a strange story of a mother and daughter who were reported to have never left the hotel in which they lived so mysteriously for almost twenty years.

Even if the superstition that tried so long to make the Maine Fall election a sibyl were still doing business at the old stand, it would have been impossible to drum up much interest in that event this year. The Republicans have elected their candidates for Governor, Senator, Representative in Congress.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Sept. 15 -- "I expect, after studying the economic angle the of situation, that a formula will be found to transfer to Brazil many industries that under present conditions in the United States continue to work unadvantageously there," Joao Alberto Lins de Barros, former chairman of the Brazilian Trade Council, who has been appointed by President Getulio Vargas as Brazilian Trade Coordinator, declared today.

THE soldiers of the football task force will go into action again this evening. This time it's to be Colonel Neyland's detachment against the Dodgers under the lights in Baltimore. There were those behind the scenes who knew that Bob Neyland had a whale of a football team before the kick-off of their game with the Giants at the Polo Grounds.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 15 (AP) -- Colonel Robert Reese Neyland's Eastern Army All-Star footballers today completed a short tune-up for the second of their three games against professional teams before a crowd expected to top 50,000.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Sept. 16 -- Russian defenders of Stalingrad, fighting desperately against the heaviest air and tank assaults of the war, beat back a German armored spearhead southwest of the city yesterday, wiping out a new enemy advance, the Soviet High Command reported today.

In the four weeks ended last Saturday, 10,203 babies were born in New York City, a record high month for 1942 so far, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins reported yesterday. So far this year 85,174 births have been recorded here, compared with 79,131 for the corresponding thirty-six weeks of last year, and 74,015 for 1940.
CAIRO, Sept. 15 (AP) -- A communique of the Headquarters of United States Army Air Forces in the Middle East:

Coincidentally with reports from Philadelphia that the Securities and Exchange Commission plans to promulgate its new proxy rules in the first half of October, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York has adopted a resolution sweepingly condemning the proposed changes.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Sept. 15 (AP) -- Six officers received Navy Crosses and a seventh was awarded a Gold Star yesterday for heroic and distinguished service against Japanese forces in the Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Rear Admiral W.H.P. Blandy, Navy chief of ordnance, speaking at an impromptu press conference today following completion of a 26,000-mile tour of the Pacific area, said that the United States forces now hold the balance of striking power in the Southwestern Pacific.

Plans for the construction of a new public garage building, considered unusual in view of recent war restrictions on purchases and use of automobiles, were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The course of the Department of Justice in appealing from a Federal court dismissal of the anti-trust suit against the Aluminum Company of America was criticized today by Arthur V. Davis, chairman of the company's board.

LONDON, Sept. 15 -- Tonight has a special historic significance for all Britons. It is just two years ago that the Royal Air Force brought down 185 enemy planes over the fields of Kent, Surrey and Middlesex, ending Reichsfuehrer Hitler's hope of invading this island that year.

A million dollars worth of furs, ranging from $500 fox jackets to $35,000 sables, will be displayed today in the Continental Ballroom of the Hotel St. Moritz as a feature of the motion-picture industry's September War Bond drive. The furs, which will be modeled by a group of debutantes, will be furnished by the United Fur Manufacturers Association.

The Boston Metropolitan District, which is the transit authority of the city of Boston and near-by communities, announced yesterday that it would offer on Sept. 23 $8,286,000 of bonds to be dated Oct. 15, 1942, and to mature serially in one to twenty-five years.

From the two extremes of helmets for workers in war plants to glamorous evening fantasies of false hair entwined with pearls and ribbons Lilly Dache has made the duration millinery desirable and smart. Her showing yesterday noon in her penthouse apartment at 78 East Fifty-sixth Street began with headgear designed for plant workers.

Awards of twenty-nine scholarships totaling $64,600 were announced yesterday by Dr. Herbert E. Hawkes, dean of Columbia College. They include eighteen honor grants to students entering the college and eleven Pulitzer free scholarships to outstanding graduates of the city's high schools.

The arrest of two men accused of being members of a group that has stolen $436,765 in food stamps from relief offices in New York and other cities since June 5, 1941, was revealed yesterday when they were arraigned with six others, all charged with acting in concert, before United States Commissioner Cotter in Federal court.

Leonard Robert Jordan, who is in jail now on charges of sedition arising out of his attempts to create a pro-Japanese uprising in Harlem, expected to be put in a concentration camp, and he had his revenge all planned, it was revealed yesterday by United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa.

Most of us in the mid-continent oil region find it impossible to understand the psychology of Eastern people who are saying: "It isn't fair for us to be rationed on gasoline if people of other parts of the country still get what they need."

A fear that Mayor La Guardia's suggestion to young boys that they report to him if their fathers gamble and lose money to bookmakers or other gamblers might lead to "unwholesome family relationships" was expressed yesterday by James Marshall, former president of the Board of Education, and chairman of its law committee.

Despite substantial gains in department store and national advertising last month, newspaper linage in fifty cities measured by Media Records dropped 0.8 per cent below the corresponding 1941 month. The decrease for the eight months period was 6.7 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The Office of Price Administration established ceiling prices for Fall and Winter knitted underwear for manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers through two price actions announced by the agency today.

The wage and farm price stabilization formulas proposed in the Brown-Wagner joint resolution introduced in the Senate are clearly not ideal. But such virtues as they have shine brightly when compared with the provisions of the Steagall bill introduced in the House. It would be flattery to say that the Steagall bill is worthless. It is, in fact, as mischievous a document as could well be imagined.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull bluntly informed the Vichy French Government today that the United States would look upon the conscription of French labor for work in German war factories as aid to one of our enemies and "wholly inconsistent with France's obligations under international law."

Residents of Westchester County would feel insulted if a Commuters' Pacific Movement were started in their towns, with Japanese backing and a world empire of the Japanese-Commuting races as its object; and if, when the movement failed, people in Manhattan expressed surprise.

VICHY, France, Sept. 15 -- Comment that has appeared concerning the new compulsory labor law affirms the necessity of conforming to what are called the realities of France's situation, both national and international.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Sept. 15 -- Donald L. Moore, champion in 1939 and runner-up the last two years, today took a commanding lead in the opening round of the New Jersey State seniors' golf championship when he scored a 76 over the Essex Fells Country Club course.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 15 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho said today that Mexico was determined to collaborate with the democracies until final victory and appealed to all Mexicans to unite without reservation to win the war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 -- The Germans are trying hard to make the French people contribute more to their war effort and Pierre Laval's new decree conscripting French labor is only one item in the program. Other points are involved in the negotiations between Reichsfuehrer Hitler's representatives and M. Laval, negotiations initiated last April and kept more or less alive ever since.

The shoe industry is facing no profound dislocation because of government regulations conserving leather and the public need feel no apprehension about its essential needs, A.J. Spring, chief of the shoe unit of the War Production Board, told more than 3,000 shoe manufacturers, retailers and tanners at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Blair House, which for more than 100 years has been linked with stirring events in the nation's history and has been the home of one of its oldest families, is about to become its official "Guest House."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 16 -- Head Coach Lou Little of Columbia and Howie Odell of Yale today conducted a successful revival of the experiment of a practice game played during the preliminary season, Yale finishing the winner, 27 -- 7.

Duck hunters who are awaiting the opening of the season in this zone on Oct. 15, will find little of a restrictive nature in the announcement just made by Army Headquarters. However, they should be reminded that the Coast Guard also is expected to fix limitations shortly for those entering our bays and coastal areas.

The British radio reported yesterday that five Polish patriots were executed at Lodz and five in Vienna. The broadcast, recorded by the Columbia Broadcasting System, quoted a German statement, according to which "in Katowice during the last days of August there were executions of twenty-eight Poles, who had been accused of participating in Polish secret organizations."

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Jersey City, fourth-place team in the regular season, today whipped pennant-winning Newark for the fourth straight time, 6 to 2, and moved into the final round of the International League play-offs. Dave Koslo limited the Bears to nine hits.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- The fifty young fliers making up the three American Eagle Squadrons of the Royal Air Force, which have destroyed at least seventy-three enemy planes, have been transferred to the United States Army Air Forces, it was announced today at United States Army headquarters.

For months it has been apparent that there would be a shortage of fuel oil in the Atlantic seaboard States this Winter. The only question has been how to meet that shortage. In ordering a system of coupon rationing the War Production Board has made a wise decision.

A 26-year-old R.A.F. bombardier, who has bombed Germany and other German-held lands in Europe for the last two years without injury, was a victim early yesterday morning of an attack by four men who beat him and stole what funds he had as he was walking down Fifth Avenue near Forty-sixth Street.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 16 -- The Giants couldn't do it and neither could the Dodgers, but Mike Getto's Brooklyn eleven made it closer against the Eastern Army All-Stars tonight than did their interborough rivals last Saturday. Certainly the Brooks worried Colonel Bob Neyland's stalwarts more tonight in the vast Baltimore Municipal Stadium, and for concrete evidence they could point to the score.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The pitching misfortunes that have dogged rotund Eddie Smith of the White Sox from the start of the season apparently are going to stick it out to the finish. Today he lost his twentieth game, a 4-to-2 decision that the Athletics grabbed with an eighth-inning rally.

Belle d'Amour, a bay filly that began life in William Ziegler Jr.'s barn, yesterday carried the silks of Moe Slifkin to victory in the $6,175 Stony Brook Claiming Stakes at Aqueduct, where 12,372 persons wagered $936,949. Under 107 pounds, the daughter of Espino, a great stayer in his day, pounded on past the finish line a length and a half to the good as the sixth consecutive favorite bit the dust.
PORT LOUIS, Mauritius, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The text of the statement that Governor General Armand Annet of Madagascar issued at Tananarive, explaining his decision to ask armistice terms:

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At Loew's State the newcomer will be "Tish," a Metro comedy with Marjorie Main playing the title role. Featured in the film, which is founded in part on the stories by Mary Roberts Rinehart, are Lee Bowman, Zasu Pitts, Aline McMahon, Guy Kibbee and Susan Peters.

VINELAND, N.J., Sept. 16 -- Striking employes of the Kimble Glass Company have rejected today by a vote of 456 to 358 a proposal to end their nine-day old walkout and return to work tomorrow morning, despite telegrams received yesterday from union and government officials.

HAVING finished his annual tour of the minor league circuits and having left them laughing as usual, Al Schacht bobbed up at a big league ball park for a change and made an announcement in a few thousand words, more or less. Taking a loud stand, the Clown Prince of Baseball looked around him and began:

State Senator Charles Muzzicato will not be required to run in the coming election as candidate for two offices at the same time, Supreme Court Justice Benedict D. Dineen ruled yesterday. He denied an application by former Senator John T. McCall, Democratic candidate for the seat now held by Dr. Muzzicato, to declare void the latter's declination of his American Labor party renomination for the Senate.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (AP) -- The Cubs took over fifth place in the National League today by splitting a double-header with the Phils while Pittsburgh lost to Brooklyn. The Cubs won the second game, 4 to 1, after losing the opener, 3 to 1.

A petition for the establishment by the dress industry of a free school for design, to clinch for New York the title of world fashion center, has been signed by 200 dress manufacturers here, it was disclosed last night by Sidney Vlock, chairman of the American Council of Dress Manufacturers.

MOSCOW, Sept. 16 -- Urged on by Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's demands for manganese, a shortage of which is said to threaten to bring Germany's steel plants to a standstill, Nazi mountain troops are striving to penetrate the northern face of the Caucasian Mountain range.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Conscription of all for war became the cornerstone tonight for the American Legion's first national convention since the United States entered the war.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 16 -One of the nation-wide Victory Garden I-Iarvest Shows, the Greenwich Flower Show, will be held %omorrow and Friday at the Y. I%_. C. A. here. It will be the thirtyfirst snnual exhibition of tile Fairfield and restchester Horticultural Society in connection with the Greenwich Garden Club, the Hortu]us Club, Green Fingers Club and the Little Garden Club of Rye.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Third to Whirlaway in his previous start, Aonbarr proved a worthy favorite in the Mason-Dixon Handicap at Havre de Grace today. Racing in the silks of Miss Helen Hickman of Louisville, Aonbarr came through with a stretch drive that distanced the Walmac Farm's Bushwhacker by a length and a quarter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Three months and nine days seems a very long time for the American people to have to wait before being told, as the Navy told them today, of the sinking of the Yorktown, one of the seven aircraft carriers with which this country entered the war.

The first campaign conference between managers for Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. and leaders who opposed Mr. Bennett's nomination at the Democratic State convention took place yesterday, with all indications being that the organization forces which had backed Senator James M. Mead were now prepared to do their best to elect Mr. Bennett Governor.

With recommendations supplied by book critics, Pearl Buck of the East and West Association has compiled a list of books that the association is recommending to libraries, colleges, study groups and individual readers in Asiatic countries as the best to tell them "what the people of the United States are like."
Following is the text of the address by President Roosevelt and of Crown Princess Martha's reply at the ceremonies in the Washington Navy Yard yesterday, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

With many buyers personally in the wholesale markets here, purchasing by numerous smaller merchants to round out stocks of holiday merchandise has increased sharply this week, reports yesterday indicated. Confidence regarding Christmas trade prospects has grown recently and many merchants now look for sales gains over last year.

A simple chronological story of the disappearance of a 4 1/2-year-old Westchester girl from her home on Tuesday, the receipt of a "ransom note" by her family and the child's subsequent safe return was related last night by P.E. Fox-worth, assistant director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

The thirteen-story store and loft building on a plot 145 by 100 feet and the two-story taxpayer on a lot 20 by 100 feet at 214-28 West Thirty-ninth Street have been sold by the Lansdon Corporation to the 214 West Thirty-ninth Street Corporation.

TRENTON, Sept. 16 -- The war production plant of the Essex Specialty Company at Hackettstown, N.J., where five persons were killed in two explosions last Friday, has been closed by the State Labor Department, it was announced here today by Deputy Labor Commissioner C. George Krueger.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 16 -- Mexico celebrated the 132d anniversary of her independence today with the greatest military parade in her history. Forty thousand troops, led by General Abelardo Rodriguez, marched past the Presidential Palace.

Like the Lexington, the Yorktown did not carry her colors down until she had won her victory. The loss of the great carrier is a hard blow; but it was the swarm of American fliers from her decks that turned back the Japanese at Midway. The delay in the announcement of her sinking is understandable in view of vital naval operations since in progress in the Pacific.

The first charges of the operation of a sizable "black market" here in rationed articles were leveled yesterday against five men accused of a conspiracy to sell thousands of recapped tires to unauthorized buyers. Three of the defendants were held in $5,000 bail in Federal court last night, while government agents were seeking the others.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The Office of Price Administration acted today to assure more equitable geographical distribution of sugar and to ease the burden on transportation facilities.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 16 -- The public bathing beach of the Great Neck Park District at Kings Point has been taken over by the United States Government to add to the properties already acquired for the Maritime Training Academy at Elm Point, on Long Island Sound.
Lists of new apartment rentals issued yesterday by renting agents showed a good demand for suites in buildings on the East Side. Several leases were made along Park Avenue.

A good call for wolf featured the fur sale held yesterday by the New York Auction Company. About 75 per cent of the offering changed hands, the top being $16. Skunk brought a high of $3.70 on sales of 40 per cent. Only 25 per cent of the opossum was sold, these skins bringing up to $1.04.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Vice President Wallace today championed a set of "seven freedoms" for Mexicans, in a speech celebrating Mexico's Independence Day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- On the ground that the manpower shortage created by the migration of metal miners in Western States had already created "an emergency war problem of national significance," a majority of a War Labor Board mediation panel recommended today that the board depart from its "Little Steel" principle of limiting wage increases to cover the 15 per cent rise in the cost of living during the January, 1941-May, 1942, period.

The Twenty-third Street Association, meeting yesterday in the George Washington Hotel, adopted a resolution supporting the pay-as-you-go plan of Beardsley Ruml for payment of taxes on individual incomes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 16 -- Canada Lee, Negro actor who last appeared on Broadway in William Saroyan's short-lived "Across the Boards on Tomorrow Morning," is being tested in New York by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for roles in two films, the studio disclosed here today.

After an hour or so of "Show Time," which was staged at the Broadhurst last evening, you begin to understand what is wrong with most vaudeville shows. Most of them do not put George Jessel, Jack Haley, Ella Logan and the De Marcos on one bill.

A strong force of investigators will begin strict enforcement of gasoline rationing throughout the city and State this week to stamp out large-scale abuses and a recognized "black market" in "S" ration coupons, Joseph Kraeler, rationing administrator for New York County, warned last night.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 16 -- After matching cards with George L. Meredith of the home club, Peter Ladislaw of Bayside today won the Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tourney held at the Garden City Country Club, with a field of more than fifty participating.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Sept. 17 (U.P.) -- Heavy fighting has broken out anew on the southern slopes of the Owen Stanley Mountains just north of Ioribaiwa, New Guinea, a jungle village only thirty-two airline miles from the Allied stronghold of Port Moresby, it was announced today.

Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in the United States District Court in Brooklyn yesterday reserved decision on an application in behalf of Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, for a temporary injunction to restrain the Greenberg Brothers Iron and Steel Corporation of 114 North Fourth Street, Brooklyn, from charging more than the maximum price for steel set by the Office of Price Administration.

No crackpot conceived the Ruml plan for aborting the 1941 income tax payments. With a swish of the palms and not a penny passed out a year's taxes of billions will be paid. "Withheld at the source," in a manner of speaking.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- A Navy Department communique:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Hearings on the Brown-Wagner resolution to give inflation-curbing powers to the President were concluded this evening by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, with its record indicating that organized labor has had a rather definite advance understanding as to how it will fare under White House directives, while the farmers were still kept guessing.

Mr. Nelson has moved with encouraging promptness to carry out the Baruch committee's recommendation that full authority over the entire rubber program be vested in a single official. In selecting William M. Jeffers, president of the Union Pacific Railroad, to be Rubber Administrator Mr. Nelson has followed the further recommendation of the Baruch committee that this individual must be "a man of unusual capacity and power."
LONDON, Sept. 16 -- French authorities on Madagascar have requested an armistice.
Indications that Japan's war machine may be poised for another smash approaching Pearl Harbor in significance were stressed yesterday in Axis broadcasts, according to The Associated Press.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 16 -- Herbert Karl Friedrich Bahr, who was convicted here recently of conspiring to commit espionage for Germany, will apply Monday through his counsel to Federal Judge William F. Smith for return of the $1,500 that had been given to him by the Gestapo and which he had tried to smuggle into this country in a cigar box.

Although no final ruling on the price-ceiling problems of retail liquor dealers may be expected from the Office of Price Administration within the immediate future now that the Hollowell law is in full operation the agency is planning to press its "top-to-bottom" investigation of the industry's pricing practices on the basis of the initial survey begun some months ago, it was learned yesterday.
Dr. and Mrs. George Huston Bell have returned to 104 East Fortieth Street after spending the Summer at Bell-View Farms, Mount Sidney, Va.

The first service flag honoring seamen of the merchant marine as fighting men in the war against the Axis will be raised at noon today by the United States Lines at the north entrance of the company's Hudson River piers on Twenty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The Treasury announced today subscriptions to its $3,000,000,000 offering of securities last week totaled $5,629,000,000, which represented an oversubscription of $2,629,000,000.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- Although the Russian war news again had a subduing effect on the stock markets, trading and prices remained today fairly steady. The only feature of note in the day's trading was further demand for home rail junior stocks.

WASHINGTON, Sept 16 -- Though increasingly adapted to official policy -- that is, to the authorized Washington conception of how best to win the war -- American broadcasts to the outside world are still mostly composed of facts without comment.

Mayor La Guardia's proposal to have the city buy the electric power plant of the Staten Island Edison Company at a price not to exceed $16,500,000 was opposed yesterday by the directors of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, which made public a report by its committee on public utilities and law urging rejection of the plan.

DETROIT, Sept. 16 -- Mrs. Dorothy Kemp Roosevelt of Birmingham, Mich., former wife of the late G. Hall Roosevelt, brother of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, won the Democratic nomination from the 17th Congressional District in yesterday's primaries, the count showed today.

What type of fruits and vegetables women should can to provide for a family of four during the thirty weeks of Winter was outlined last night before an audience of 325 men and women interested in victory gardens by Esther C. Grayson at the New York Times Halt, Forty-fourth Street, west of Broadway.

CHARLESTON, Ill., Sept. 16 -- At least three persons were killed and an estimated fifty others injured at 3:07 P.M. (C.W.T.) today when the Southwest Limited, fast New York to St. Louis passenger train, crashed head on into a standing train composed of seventy tank cars filled with oil for the East.

Although the presence of a praying mantis for a while caused considerable perturbation among the girls, more than a hundred lower East Side junior farmers and farmerettes gathered yesterday afternoon to harvest their crops from their 100 by 100-foot Victory garden in Seward Park, East Broadway and Jefferson Street.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 -- August sales statistics released today by the National Restaurant Association indicated that while the nationwide gain over 1941 was 19 per cent, the small restaurants in non-boom towns are doing poorly.

Sentiment stirred Zoe de Salle to put her nimble fingers to the making of fifteen outfits which constitute her Fall and Winter offering. She desired to make the women she dresses look their prettiest when they are with men who are in or entering the armed service.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- A Navy Department resume of operations in the Pacific Ocean, issued today, indicated that the American Navy had lost thirty-two ships against fifty-nine Japanese vessels destroyed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- A large fleet of Army bombers and escorting fighter planes swooped down Monday on the Japanese base at Kiska, in the Aleutian Islands, blasting enemy warships and transport vessels and setting widespread fires ashore, the Navy Department reported in a communique issued this evening.
Everybody knows what must be done to cut down motor driving and save rubber. Everybody stands ready to give his views to the public. Not so many people are vocal about what is actually being done.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The government's war expenditures in August were $5,182,000,000, including Treasury disbursements and estimated Reconstruction Finance Corporation spending, the War Production Board announced today. This was 8.1 per cent more than the $4,794,000,000 spent in July and 333.3 per cent more than the $1,196,000,000 spent in August last year.

TRENTON, Sept. 16 -- The threat of Federal inquiry into his campaign expenditures hung tonight over Albert W. Hawkes of Montclair, who won the Republican nomination for United States Senator yesterday in one of New Jersey's closest primary elections.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The air arms of the United States forces have conducted heavy aggressive operations northwest of the Solomon Islands, damaging two Japanese cruisers and enemy shore installations, the Navy Department reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Rents for all living quarters in fifty-four defense-rental areas scattered over the country today were ordered reduced and stabilized on Oct. 1. The action by the Office of Price Administration will extend rent control to 189 areas of the total of 396 designated and will bring rent control to a total population of more than 50,000,000.

A realty investor has purchased from the Josh Realty Corporation the two five-story apartment houses at 1775-79 Fulton Avenue, between 174th and 175th Streets, in the East Bronx, for cash above mortgages of $60,965. The resale followed an ownership of about a year, according to Edward S. Jacobson, the broker.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Setting up of an interdepartmental committee to gather reliable data on business mortality trends was urged today by the Senate Small Business Committee in an appeal to the Bureau of the Budget for assistance in obtaining statistics vital to its program of aid for small business.

FORT HANCOCK, N.J., Sept. 16 -- Brig. Gen. Phillip S. Gage, commander of harbor defenses for the New York area, wrote a letter to a 10-year-old boy in Cleveland today to reassure him that his "unselfish contribution to our war effort" was well and happy.

PLANDOME, L.I., Sept. 16 -- Mrs. Harry McNaughton of the home club, playing from scratch, gained the low gross honors in the one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association with a score of 41, 38 -- 79 at the Plandome Golf Club today.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept 16 -- With platform and speakers pledging full support of President Roosevelt, particularly in the effort to win the war, the Connecticut Democratic State Convention today renominated Robert A. Hurley as an outstanding "wartime Governor," by acclamation, and named the rest of the State ticket without opposition.

A diligent three-year search for a fugitive in a stock swindle here ended yesterday with the arrest in Chicago of Howard Taft who had been representing himself, according to the police, as a "big-shot broker" who was a nephew of the late President William Howard Taft and a brother of Senator Robert Taft.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- Minister of Production Oliver Lyttelton, who in July predicted that the next eighty days would produce one of the gravest crises in British history, stuck to his prediction today, declaring the three weeks would bring "a breathless moment" as the war entered a new phase.

Headed by Philip Wolf, chairman, a delegation of members of the American Contractors War Advisory Committee will leave for Washington tonight to complete arrangements to take over a number of medium-sized government contracts for recently organized pools of New York and New Jersey contractors in various branches of the building industry.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- Coolly and dispassionately, 17-year-old Edward Haight accompanied the police today on a four-hour trek over forty-five miles of the hills and dales of Northern Westchester County to re-enact his Monday night kidnapping, rape and murder of Margaret Lynch, 7 years old, and her sister Helen, 8.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 16 -- Ten persons have been arrested and many others are being sought following a renewed outbreak of terrorism in Croatia, which appears to be solely directed by its organizers against "collaborating" police officials.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The large aircraft carrier Yorktown sank in the Pacific Ocean on the night of June 6-7 as the result of bomb damage on June 4 in the Battle of Midway Island and a submarine attack on June 6, during which she was struck by two torpedoes, the Navy Department announced today.

BOSTON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Massachusetts Republican and Democratic leaders began lining up support tonight for party candidates in the November election after a comparatively quiet primary in which a newcomer in State politics won the Democratic nomination for Governor and a young United States Representative carried off the Democratic Senatorial nomination.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- President Roosevelt transferred to the Royal Norwegian Navy today a 173-foot steel subchaser newly named "King Haakon VII," and warned the neutral nations of the world that the treacherous and brutal conquest of Norway ended "the concept that either remoteness from political controversy or usefulness to mankind could give any nation immunity from attack in a world where aggression spread unchecked."

Japan wants the new airfield on Guadalcanal Island. She will apparently incur any loss and run any risk in order to retake it, for it is the key to the whole Tulagi area of the Solomon Islands. If we should lose this airfield we would presumably be forced to evacuate the six other islands we have taken.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 16 -- Upsets hit the women's New Jersey golf championship today at the Upper Montclair C.C. and when the second-round firing was over the qualifying medalist and the defending champion were on the sidelines.

Seven major types of difficulties in price control and rationing were outlined last night by Walter Mitchell Jr., director of surveys for Dun Bradstreet, Inc., at the first Fall meeting of the Brooklyn chapter of the National Association of Cost Accountants at the Central Branch Y.M.C.A. He described them as:

Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, will give a series of five talks over the radio on Monday evenings during the coming campaign, with his voice being carried over the largest network ever used in a State campaign here.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Sept. 16 -- All Brazilian armed forces, including reserves, were called to serve their country in a general mobilization decree issued by President Getulio Vargas.

LONDON, Sept. 16 -- Al Jolson and Merle Oberon, screen actress and wife of director Alexander Korda, are returning to the United States as soon as possible and the show they were scheduled to give on Sunday for the American troops at the Palladium, largest London vaudeville theatre, has been called off.

SOMEWHERE IN CONNECTICUT, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Near the little shop where vulcanized rubber products first were manufactured 100 years ago, the United States Rubber Company has put into operation New England's first synthetic rubber plant.
LONDON, Sept. 16 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Apparently the Cincinnati Reds are still operating under the delusion that they can overhaul the Giants for third place. Mathematically they can, but actually it is a pretty hopeless task. However, Cincinnati vanquished the New Yorkers at the Polo Grounds yesterday, 3 to 1, and thus registered its sixth straight victory.

A speed-up fashion service for wartime working women was announced yesterday by Franklin Simon, 414 Fifth Avenue, during a preview of work-and-play styles for those who are budgeting both time and money on their victory schedule.

Declaring that "we need Russia, not only to win the war, we need Russia to build a new Europe and a new world," Pierre Cot, former French Minister of Aviation, pleaded last night for immediate help to Russia "before it is too late." He spoke at a dinner in the Park Central Hotel which opened the Fall campaign of eight Manhattan district committees for the Russian War Relief.
Rejuvenated by two days of rest and annoyed no little by what the Cardinals had been doing during that time the Dodgers roared into Ebbets Field yesterday to score a double victory.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information communique early today:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Methods by which the Office of Price Administration will ration fuel oil to consumers in thirty Eastern and Midwestern States, beginning next month, were made public today.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Virtually complete tabulation of New Hampshire's primary ballots today showed only one upset in Republican ranks after one of the quietest pre-election campaigns in years.

The Federal District Court at Wilmington, Del., on Tuesday denied a petition of the Department of Justice to vacate an antitrust consent decree now in effect between the Federal Government and the Radio Corporation of America, the company announced yesterday.

TUCSON, Ariz., Sept. 16 (U.P.) -- A searching party which reached the wreckage of a four-motored Army bomber on the side of a mountain in Eastern Arizona today found that the entire crew of eight officers and two enlisted men had been killed.
MOSCOW, Sept. 16 -- Soviet appreciation of the courage of British and American sailors in bringing supplies to Russia has been expressed in the newspaper Red Fleet.
Another set of clever disguises for lines and fabric shortages was displayed by Stein Blaine's salon yesterday at its showing of Autumn and Winter fashions.

The fuel oil supply in this area for the coming months will be so limited that the cost of converting industrial plants to coal, once regarded as an important obstacle, will no longer carry much weight, it was learned here yesterday, following announcement of the coupon-rationing plan for fuel oil.

Fuel oil distributors were swamped yesterday with orders as household users rushed to take advantage of a War Production Board order temporarily relaxing restrictions on deliveries pending the institution of a coupon rationing system beginning Oct. 1.

WITH THE PACIFIC FLEET, At Sea, June 6 (Delayed) -- The mighty "Y" is down. The aircraft carrier Yorktown, fightingest ship in the United States Navy, was sunk this morning by Japanese submarines as she lay helpless in the water miles north of Midway Atoll.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Buyers were unwilling to bid anywhere near recent prices for anything but choice cattle today, and, as a result, prices slumped as much as 40 cents a hundred pounds on some yearlings, light steers and heifers in one of the slowest trading days the market has experienced in many months.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, announced yesterday appointment of 182 persons to administrative and faculty posts at the university and affiliated units for the academic year to begin on Wednesday.

A record offer of $71,200 yesterday won for the National Broadcasting Company the exclusive radio rights for the Joe Louis-Billy Conn world heavyweight championship bout to be held for the benefit of Army Emergency Relief at the Yankee Stadium on Oct. 12.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- Preparing for the day when rationing to consumers will cover a wider range of products than it does at present, the Office of Price Administration sent to the printer today an order for the country's first "all-purpose" ration book.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Sept. 16 -- Carding 38, 35 -- 73, one over par, United States Senior Champion Ellis Knowles of Apawamis won among seventy-five members of the Westchestsr Seniors Golf Association in the annual Fall tourney at St. Andrews today.

NEW DEHLI, India, Sept. 16 -- The shadow of the Congress Party lay over the Legislative Assembly today as three members of other parties, including a spokesman for Mohammed Ali Jinnah's Moslem League, embraced the Congress doctrine of immediate independence for India.

ALBANY, Sept. 16 -- The Appellate Division today reversed a Supreme Court order keeping Communist party candidates off the Nov. 3 State ballot until the validity of nominating petitions is established.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- A National Service Act, giving the government broad controls over the nation's labor resources, was described today by Paul McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, as "inevitable" and as essential for maximum war production.
I was very happy to read that the number of taxicabs in New York City is going to be limited by the OPA. It is my belief that now is the time to revamp the traffic rules concerning taxicabs.

If the zoning of products, announced yesterday for sugar, spreads widely as a method of conserving transportation, local and regional advertising media will take on increasing importance for straight product selling, it was pointed out yesterday in agency circles.

As a means of keeping any recalcitrant landlords in line and to forestall complaints which might inspire the issuance of a formal order freezing rents for living quarters in New York, the Real Estate Board of New York, in association with taxpayers' organizations, announced yesterday the formation of a volunteer rent-control committee.
Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation made nearly seventy-five raids yesterday on the homes of enemy aliens in New York and in New Jersey, from Jersey City to Wildwood.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Gains of 1/4 to 1/2 cent a pound in wholesale butter today pushed prices to new high levels since the late Nineteen Twenties, in some cases to more than a cent above levels prevailing on Labor Day, Sept. 7, when President Roosevelt delivered his price control message to Congress.
An Army and Navy E pennant was presented yesterday to the Bell Telephone Laboratories for war production in a ceremony at the company's auditorium, 463 West Street.
MOSCOW, Sept. 16 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

DETROIT, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Michigan Republicans voting in Tuesday's primary election chose Homer Ferguson, Detroit's racket-busting circuit judge, as their candidate for the United States Senate, rejecting the bid of Gerald L.K. Smith, former Huey Long aide, for the nomination.

READING, Pa., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Racing the fastest 3-year-old trot for fillies over a half-mile track on the Grand Circuit this season, Miss Thelma, sired by Follow Up and owned by Dunbar W. Bostwick of New York, captured the Reading Fair Futurity today by winning the first two heats, each in 2.07.

The United States does not desire or intend to exercise paternalism over the rest of the world after the war, to police the world longer than necessary or maintain a world-wide relief program, according to Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire.

WHEN Wallace Carroll, European correspondent for The United Press, decided to put his first-hand impressions of wartime Russia into book form, some one suggested that he use "You Can Do Business With Stalin" for a title. The proposition was tempting, but Mr. Carroll finally resisted the impulse in favor of the more lackluster "We're in This With Russia."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 -- Reduction of the $385,000,000 Engineers Public Service Company to control of one of two sharply defined operating systems and divestiture of all interest in seven other systems was ordered today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Early yesterday morning seven vessels, loaded to capacity with yellowtail flounders, docked at the piers that are part of Fulton Fish Market. The total haul amounted to a quarter of a million pounds, according to figures assembled by the Fishery Council.

A full-length raccoon coat of beautifully blended skins, which would be resplendent in an opera setting, will go to the wars on Russia's bloody steppes when Lieutenant Liudmila Pavlichenko returns to her homeland where she is credited with killing 309 Nazis.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 16 (AP) -- Harry Barnett's Medid broke on top and stayed in front today to win the $2,500 added Wannamoisett Stakes at Narragansett Park.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Although there was nothing at stake in the matter of final standings, the third-place Browns shut out the Red Sox, 3 to 0, today on a seven-hitter by Johnny Niggeling.

Hedging increased yesterday near the end of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange and active futures declined to the day's lows and net losses of 2 to 6 points at the close. Trading was hampered somewhat by the confusion over the ultimate fate of the widely divergent anti-inflation measures introduced in Congress.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- A temporary order prohibiting the sale of new farm machinery and equipment, except as specified in a rationing system governing its release, was issued today by Secretary Wickard, effective tomorrow.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday an intensive salvage drive to collect every bit of unused scrap metal in the city. A proclamation fixed the period from Sept. 17 to Oct. 17 as "salvage month." His announcement followed a series of conferences with members of the New York City Publishers Association's salvage committee at City Hall.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Sept. 16 -- Major Gen. G.C. Kenney of the United States Army Air Forces, new commander of Allied Air Forces in the Southwest Pacific area, said today he believed that the way to fight this war, so far as the air was concerned, was to concentrate our strength on worthwhile targets.
BOSTON, Sept. 16 -- The Cardinals protected their two-game National League lead by drubbing the Braves, 6 to 2, today behind the effective nine-hit pitching of Ernie White, their ailing southpaw.

Production of crude petroleum in the United States last week averaged 3,902,450 barrels daily, an increase of 219,700 over the 3,682,750 in the previous week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Production was 164,050 barrels less than the recommendation of 4,066,500 daily by the Office of Petroleum Coordinator for September.

DETROIT, Sept. 16 -- Marvin Breuer, up to now the least successful of Joe McCarthy's imposing staff of regular starting hurlers, served notice on his boss today that he, too, finally had rounded into world series form.

A further decline in the volume of bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States and a further new low in the last twenty-five years was announced yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its regular monthly survey of the market.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Sept. 17 -- The Russians announced officially early today that German shock troops had battered into the northwestern outskirts of Stalingrad, where the Red Army and civilians were battling desperately to save that southern arsenal city, which is the gateway to Astrakhan on the Caspian Sea.

With the passing of Labor Day and the shedding of Summer clothes there arises the problem that all men must face -- laundry. How can I get my shirts washed and returned to me sans starch, sizing or cardboard fillings?
EXETER, N.H., Sept. 16 -- The Phillips Exeter Academy began its 162d session today with an enrollment of 728 boys, which is in excess of normal.

BUFFALO, Sept. 16 (AP) -- A gift of $50,000 to the Buffalo Council, Boy Scouts of America, and a $50,000 bequest to be distributed among six public welfare and educational organizations are provided in the will of Jacob F. Schoellkopf Sr., probated today in Surrogate's Court.

The Brooklyn Dodgers warmed up for their game with Pittsburgh at Ebbets Field yesterday by climbing into the stands and swapping punches with some of their fans. As a result they wound up in the Brooklyn-Queens Night Court, facing a threat -- warmly discussed by the Magistrate and counsel for both sides -- to summons Le Durocher, Mickey Owen and Dixie Walker to court on charges of assault in the midst of their pennant race.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- The War Department announced today the names of 125 additional soldiers who are missing in action.

The Youth Theatre decided yesterday to postpone the premiere of "Let Freedom Sing" from Sept. 21 to Sept. 28. The topical revue needs more work done on it. This leaves only one opening for next week -- "Vickie," which enters the Plymouth next Tuesday evening.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith once again "got in the scrap" as he turned over to a salvage committee yesterday 150 pounds of metal, including many cherished mementos such as an aluminum brown derby, a brass "key to the White House" and a German silver studded dog collar which belonged to Caesar, the Great Dane that was his constant companion during his last years as Governor of New York.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 16 -- At least twenty persons were injured just before midnight tonight in a mighty explosion at the plant of the Winchester Repeating Arms Company which shook the entire city.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Jim Bagby's five-hit pitching defeated Washington, 5 to 1, today for his sixteenth victory and ended the Indians' losing streak at six games.

Every war has its disillusionments, even for those who are to be the victors -- sometimes, above all, for them. Statesmen make mistakes. Generals and admirals miss opportunities. In parliamentary countries legislators squabble and waste time. War production never comes up to hopes.
LONDON, Sept. 16 -- The loss of two British destroyers, H.M.S. Sikh and H.M.S. Zulu, in the recent operation off the Axis-held Libyan port of Tobruk was announced today by the Admiralty.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Sept. 16 -- Don L. Moore, champion in 1939 and runner-up the past two years, seemed to have the senior New Jersey golf title safely stowed away tonight. Moore added an 82 to the 76 he scored yesterday at the Essex Fells C.C., his own course, and held a five-stroke lead over August F. Kammer of Baltusrol, champion the last two years.

Subscribers to the recent Treasury offerings of $1,500,000,000 each of 0.65 per cent certificates of indebtedness and 1 1/4 per cent notes got the allotment news yesterday. Aside from the small subscriptions, which were allotted in full, the rates of allotments were 75 per cent on the certificates and 42 per cent on the notes.

Earnings of the Arnold Constable Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries for the six months ended with July were $87,786 before provision for Federal taxes on income, compared with $20,324 on the same basis in the corresponding period last year, according to the semi-annual report of Isaac Liberman, president, mailed yesterday to stockholders.

Regarding the London dispatch in your daily of Sept. 9, "British Association Bans State Medicine," more than 80 per cent of the physicians, dentists and compounding druggists are now serving under the National Health Insurance Act. They receive from the government quarterly checks for the services given to the compulsorily insured masses of the workers of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

New Yorkers are probably too lazy or too busy to read New York guide books. So the picture in this newspaper yesterday of two steam engines built in '88 and retired after nearly twenty-five years' service on the Second and Third Avenue elevated roads may have puzzled all but the elders of the tribe.

William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, says that he would not object to a writing of the "Little Steel" formula into the proposed "anti-inflation" law. Let us hope that Congress will object. The "Little Steel" formula has done damage enough already.

On the theory that much can happen between the submission of tax proposals to the Congress and final enactment of a tax bill, utility issues were not so eagerly sought yesterday as the stock market drifted irregularly but closed slightly on the better side.

ALBANY, Sept. 16 -- Seasonal expansion in the clothing industries dominated the employment situation in August in New York State, according to Industrial Commissioner Miller. She announced today that factory employment from the middle of July to the middle of August increased 2.3 per cent, while factory payrolls rose 3.7 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Sept. 16 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, sustaining its original action and disregarding a suggestion of a Federal Circuit Court of Appeals that modification might be in order, reaffirmed today an order of expulsion of Charles C. Wright of New York from various national securities exchanges because of manipulation of the common stock of the Kinner Airplane and Motor Corporation, Ltd., on the Los Angeles Stock Exchange in September, 1935.

READING, Pa., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Breaking two world records, Little Pat, owned by the Biery Farms, Butler, Pa., raced to his sixth consecutive triumph in the $900 Free-For-All Pace, feature event on today's Grand Circuit card at the Reading Fair.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17 -- Little change was reflected in the level of business in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Industrial production gained moderately, whereas the volume of trade declined; the index of originating freight shipments remained about unchanged.

A sharp increase in excess reserves, due to the cut in reserve requirements last Monday of institutions in New York City and Chicago, and money shifts, incident to the quarterly tax period, are reflected in the weekly Federal Reserve figures, as of Wednesday, as released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 17 (UP) -- Allied airplanes and submarines have sunk twenty-four German vessels off Norway recently and tightened their blockade until the Germans cannot obtain sufficient supplies for an offensive on the Murmansk front, Norwegian sources reported today.

The confusing developments in the anti-inflation situation caused the cotton market to fluctuate narrowly yesterday. The closing quotations showed net losses of 6 to 8 points, the day's lows, as hedge selling offset limited trade buying. Volume on the New York Cotton Exchange was small.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The Petrillo ban on making transcriptions and recordings by members of his national musicians' union for use over the radio and in "juke boxes" and similar devices "threatens the continued existence" of many smaller radio stations vitally necessary to the national war effort, Elmer Davis, Director of War Information, told a Senate investigating group today.

LONDON, Sept. 17 (Netherlands News Agency) -- The German occupation authorities in the Netherlands have issued a decree banning normal trading on the Amsterdam Stock Exchange and fixing security prices at levels far below those recently prevailing, according to information reaching here today.

LONDON, Friday, Sept. 18 -- In the third heavy raid on German objectives this week and the ninth of its kind thus far this month a large number of bombers taking off from numerous bases in Britain smashed targets in the heavily defended Ruhr district and around Wiesbaden late Wednesday and early Thursday, but they did so at a cost of thirty-nine machines, according to an announcement by the Air Ministry yesterday.
The 15-cent dividend voted on Wednesday by directors of the Consolidated Coppermines Corporation represented an increase of 5 cents over the previous payment of 10 cents on June 1.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Dr. Hector Russell Carveth, 69, internationally known electro-chemist, died today of injuries suffered Tuesday when a cement tank exploded while being tested at the winery at Chateau Gay, Ltd., in Lewiston.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 17 -- Elton (Tad) Wieman is of the opinion that Princeton is going to have a better football team this season than a year ago, although the war has been brought home harder to the Tiger camp than to the great majority of college squads.
Traffic court fines for motorists caught speeding in this city will be doubled beginning next Monday, it was announced yesterday by Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 17 -- The American Stores Company, operators of some 300 super markets and retail grocery stores in Northern New Jersey, was accused here today by the New Jersey Division of the Office of Price Administration of having violated price-ceiling regulations by knowingly accepting three carloads of meat bearing, for the most part, a false grading.
Dean Alfange, American Labor party nominee for Governor, will start on Tuesday on his first up-State tour, which will take nine days and cover the northern and central parts of the State.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Secretary Morgenthau announced today that the Treasury had available 5,000,000 ounces of silver in a special category which would be sold outright at 45 cents an ounce to industrial users with high priority ratings upon recommendation of the War Production Board.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 17 -- The ideals of "freedom from want" and "freedom from fear" were evidenced as the underlying inspiration of nearly all statements made in the course of the first Inter-American Conference on Social Security, sponsored by the International Labor Office, which closed its meetings last night.

A Coast Guard patrol found a small, poorly constructed raft on a beach on the South Shore of Long Island, near the Hamptons, about 10 o'clock Wednesday night and sighted a prowler running along the beach. One shot was fired at the fleeing man, but he escaped in the darkness.

All season the Pirates were one of the favorite Dodger sparring partners at Ebbets Field, having lost nine out of ten there. But yesterday, when it counted most, the bold bad Bucs not only slapped down the Brooks, 3 -- 2, but probably delivered a fatal blow to their pennant chances.

MOSCOW, Friday, Sept. 18 -- Bayonet-wielding Russian troops wiped out hundreds of German shock troops who smashed into Stalingrad's streets yesterday, and the main conflict still rages on the northwestern outskirts of the city, where thousands of Nazis have fallen, the Russians announced early today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- In a long radio talk apparently addressed to South Africa and South America, which would be largely isolated without shipping connections with the Northern Hemisphere, Rear Admiral Luetzow, German naval spokesman, yesterday discussed what he called "our great new submarine successes against convoys in the Atlantic," and the danger they hold for the naval and military power of the United Nations.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 -- New corporate financing in July toppled to one-seventh the figure for June, with only $8,571,000 registered for account of issuers and proposed for sale, it was disclosed today in a consolidated tabulation of all securities dealings compiled and made public by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 17 -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, declared here today that the American people were united in their determination to preserve their way of life against totalitarian attacks and that they were eager and willing to serve on "the home front" as well as in the armed forces.

The Beak, hailed as one of the mightiest of jumpers when he was imported from England some time ago, made another step forward yesterday at Aqueduct when he easily captured the $2,875 Bushwick Hurdles Handicap at a mile and three-quarters.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Western Army All-Stars and the New York Giants went through light workouts with slightly altered line-ups today in preparation for their charity game Saturday night in Syracuse University's stadium.

War production plants were advised here yesterday by Richard C. Brockway, New York State director of the United States Employment Service, to inventory their personnel immediately and not to rely upon temporary deferments of essential men as evidence that such deferments will be renewed by the Selective Service system.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Executives of the petroleum industry who have been in conference for two days with the Office of the Petroleum Coordinator have agreed to pool "every physical facility" that would make it possible to deliver an additional barrel of oil to the East Coast States, Secretary Ickes said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The Cape Cod Canal, a highly important link in the system of protected waterways for use by war traffic, was blocked for a month by the wreck of a collier, the Navy Department revealed today in a statement that the obstruction has been removed.

MARINE HEADQUARTERS, Solomon Islands, Aug. 21 (Delayed) -- United States tanks and artillery have just completed the massacre of 750 Japanese at Tenaru, where the enemy made his first attempt to regain a foothold on Guadalcanal Island.

Despite wartime travel restrictions, producers of Winter sports apparel are going ahead with plans for the coming season, it was indicated here yesterday. One of the largest manufacturers of nationally advertised swim suits, who recently added ski-wear and Winter sportswear, reported it was introducing a water-repellent jacket as a result of insistent demand from retailers.

ASTORIA, Ore., Sept 17 (AP) -- Predictions that Bonneville Dam would kill the multi-million dollar Columbia River salmon industry remained debatable today, although fishermen were unloading huge catches for the third consecutive year.

A horizontal reduction in paper production is currently being considered by War Production Board officials, it was learned here yesterday, but is meeting strenuous opposition from those executives in the industry to whom the plan has been broached.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Sept. 18 (U.P.) -- Allied airmen yesterday made their ninth raid in a week on Buna, New Guinea, setting fires among dumps of supplies destined for Japanese forces carrying on "sporadic fighting" with Allied forces on the Owen Stanley Mountain approaches to Port Moresby, it was announced today. The fires were visible for twenty-five miles, the communique said.

There has been almost unanimous recognition of the desirability in principle of a withholding tax as an effective method of revenue collection and as a supplement to most of the proposed inflation controls. The objections that have been directed against this theory have chiefly been concerned with the enormous bookkeeping, administration and policing problems that have almost universally been assumed to be inevitable concomitants of any withholding tax plan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- President Roosevelt signed an Executive order transferring to the Secretary of the Interior the functions of the United States High Commissioner to the Philippines and elevated to embassy status the legations of Greece and Yugoslavia, naming Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr. to be Ambassador to both governments in exile.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The Navy today added eight Japanese ships to its list of enemy vessels destroyed or damaged in Far Eastern waters by the far-ranging submarines of the United States fleet. These brought the total of ships destroyed or damaged by submarines alone to 107. None of the ships that figured in today's announcement had been accounted for previously, the Navy stated.

A service flag honoring 316 seamen-employes of the United States Lines who have been lost in enemy action and 2,169 seamen pledged to carry on in the war as "soldiers without uniform" was dedicated yesterday at the company's Hudson River piers on Twenty-second Street.

Eleven years ago today an "incident" in Manchuria set in motion forces that led ultimately to the outbreak of the present war. Japan's seizure of Mukden on Sept. 18, 1931, was the first act of aggression on the part of the three Powers that were later to form the Axis.

Local war price and rationing boards were instructed yesterday to prepare for distribution of fuel oil rationing coupons and were informed that special instructions would be forthcoming later for computing the supplies to be allowed in individual cases.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 17 -- Weighing the chances of victory or defeat and also speculating on the probable duration of the war, Dr. Joseph Goebbels, German Propaganda Minister, in this week's issue of the publication Reich once more warns the Germans against taking too roseate a view of the military situation.

"Sherlock Holmes and the Voice of Terror." which opens at the Rialto, is this morning's sole new film. The topical melodrama, first in Universal's projected series with Basil Rathbone playing the detective and Nigel Bruce as Dr. Watson, features Evelyn Ankers, Reginald Denny, Montagu Love and Thomas Gomez.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept 17 -- Miss Margaret L. Wing of Westbury, jumping her 8-year-old chestnut gelding Right Dress, placed first today in one of the best classes on the opening program of the fortieth annual Piping Rock Horse Show.

Most of the 3,500 residents of Westerleigh, a residential community about seven miles from the north shore of Staten Island, were startled by a loud explosion about 10 o'clock yesterday morning. Rumors quickly spread through the area that an airplane had dropped a bomb that had exploded in a street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, was named today a vice chairman of the War Production Board. Donald M. Nelson, board chairman, who announced the appointment, said he was giving to Mr. Wilson "top production authority in the war program."

The weekly Federal Reserve figures released yesterday, as of Wednesday, reveal that Treasury balances on that day amounted to only $6,000,000, one of the lowest levels on record. This reflected the heavy Treasury payments on Sept. 15 in interest on debt and in retiring an issue of $342,000,000 of notes.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and other defendants won yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Benedict D. Dineen the dismissal of the complaint in a $750,000 suit brought by Morris H. Siegel and Samuel M. Siegel, insurance counselors doing business as the Policyholders Advisory Council.

A "Cavalcade of Stars" and victory dance, marking Constitution Day, were held in the Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street near Eighth Avenue, last night. In observance of the 155th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution, the celebration was for the joint benefit of the USO and the Save the Children Federation.

Individual rights and privileges relinquished in the interest of the war and the powers given the government in the emergency will be restored to the people when peace is won, Representative James W. Wadsworth told a noon-day crowd of 1,500 persons in Wall Street yesterday at exercises commemorating the 155th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution.

Mrs. Langdon Marvin, chairman of the newly organized New York City Nursing Council for War Service, Inc., declared yesterday that nurse recruiting in New York must be speeded up if the city is to carry its share of responsibilities for the care of the armed forces.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 17 -- Attendance of members of society at the opening program today of the fortieth annual Piping Rock horse show on the grounds of the Piping Rock Club included horse lovers who always attend the early classes of the three-day session to see the performance of the maiden jumpers, model hunters and open hunters that may have a chance at the final judging to win the championships.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Tex Hughson joined the twenty-game winner class today as he pitched the Red Sox to a 5-to-1 victory over the Browns. Tex has lost only six contests.

An extensive program of waterfront park and beach development after the war, intended to "restore to public use New York's greatest natural heritage," was outlined yesterday by the city Department of Parks.

OTTAWA, Sept. 17 (Canadian Press) -- The Bank of Canada in its statement today for the week ended yesterday showed that Dominion Government deposits decreased $16,940,000 to $18,169,000 in the week while notes in circulation increased $6,802,000 to $613,757,000.

DETROIT, Sept. 17 -- Just to make certain their winning touch has in no way become impaired, the Yankees bowled over the Tigers today in the series finale, 7 to 4, and hung up their 100th victory of the campaign. It marked, among other things, the eighth time the champions have reached the century mark in their thirteen pennant-winning years.

Two new ballets in addition to the three already announced have been added to the schedule of the Ballet Theatre, which is to open a joint Season of Ballet with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Metropolitan Opera House on Oct. 6.
Sales by savings banks of repossessed properties over scattered sections featured realty trading in Manhattan yesterday.
Any last, small shred of regard James H. (Jimmy) Hare, veteran news photographer and correspondent in five wars, might have held for the Japanese was destroyed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull observed today, the eleventh anniversary of the so-called Mukden incident, which preceded the Japanese attack on Manchuria, by praising the "gallant resistance" offered by the Chinese through the years that have followed.

Specialties monopolized again yesterday the activity in the stock market as the list drifted irregularly, with railroad shares the strongest group. The seemingly unbounded preference of traders for the low priced issues raised the turnover to the larget volume in a month, with transfers on the Stock Exchange at 407,650 shares, compared with 378,120 on Wednesday.

In an unprecedented interview, United States Supreme Court Justice Frank Murphy revealed last night at La Guardia Field that he is en route to Detroit to review the factories and war production work there and to attempt to aid in bringing that city's industries to a higher point of efficiency.

WASHINGTON, Sept 17 -- In an effort to end ineffectual collective bargaining negotiations between the United Steel Workers of America, C.I.O., and forty-one steel concerns the War Labor Board unanimously adopted today a resolution calling upon the companies which employ 200,000 workers, "to show cause" within ten days why the board's decision in the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation case on Aug. 26 should not apply to them.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Cubs concluded their season in the East today by jumping on the cellar-dwelling Phils for twelve hits and an 8-0 shut-out.

James G. Blaine announced last night that the staff of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, which he heads, will he expanded at once to 100,000 members to handle the intensive household salvage drive initiated by Mayor LaGuardia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- In a sweeping rejection of a panel's recommendations covering wages, union security and a proposal to narrow wage differentials between pay of General Motors Company employes and those of the Ford Motor Company, the War Labor Board decided today to give 225,000 G.M.C. employes a wage increase of 4 cents an hour to cover the 15 per cent rise in living costs between January, 1941, and May, 1942.

Demands upon the nursing profession both at home and abroad have increased with the war, and more extensive services will be required for civilian needs and the post-war period, religious, military and civic leaders declared yesterday at the beginning of a three-day session commemorating the golden jubilee of the foundation of the School of Nursing of St. Vincent's Hospital.
