Japanese broadcasts yesterday quoted Masayuki Tani, Japan's new Foreign Minister, as setting forth in his first official statement three major objectives and urging the Japanese to mare greater efforts toward realizing them. The broadcasts were recorded in New York by The Associated Press.
The nation applauds and accepts the Rubber Committee's recommendations for limiting automobile use to 5,000 miles a year and speed to 35 miles an hour, because this will assure victory.

Bearing the name of the victory that decided a long war, the Yorktown was worthy of it. She was mother of the planes that won the battle of the Midway. She had survived the severe wounds received in it. Two Japanese torpedoes gave her the mortal stroke. She went down with her colors flying. There was no perturbation among her officers and crew.

Serviceability in fur coats, whether of the sports, tailored or evening variety, was demonstrated yesterday in a fashion showing held during the luncheon hour at the Hotel Plaza by Jaeckel, Inc. For Autumn sports events, there were swagger coats, full backed, of beaver, nutria and Persian lamb, cut with deep armholes to slip on easily over woolen suits or the uniforms of war workers.

Lieut Comdr. Herbert Agar, president of Freedom House and editor of the Courier Journal of Louisville, Ky., has leased an apartment in 2 Beekman Place, Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., the agent, reported yesterday. Another outstanding lease on the East Side was made in the Beekman Mansions, 439 East Fifty-first Street, where M. Feuchtwanger rented a duplex penthouse apartment of ten rooms through John F. Hoban Company and Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc.

Long before the War Labor Board, as such, was created -- that is, when it was still the Defense Mediation Board -- it was pointed out repeatedly to it that it would save itself and the country an enormous amount of uncertainty and trouble if it publicly announced a definite body of principles on which its decisions would be based.

An increasing number of campaigns in which advertising is used to discourage the sale of a product because of shortages has been appearing lately. Now a new campaign is scheduled in which an association appeals to householders not to use the product of its industry as a substitute for another product in short supply.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Motion picture producers and distributors, during the year beginning Oct. 1, must get along with 10 to 24 per cent less film than they used in 1941, the War Production Board said today.

In an article in THE NEW YORK TIMES today entitled "Farm Production and Price Control," it is so truly stated that "To win this war it is generally recognized the United States must have a well-rounded food program, not only for the morale of civilian population but also for the soldiers in the field."

A nation-wide survey of steps already taken in communities throughout the country to deal with the question of wartime closing hours of taverns has been started by Allied Liquor Industries, Inc., it was announced yesterday. The action, it was stated, was taken in line with the organization's program of developing closer cooperation between the industry and the military and civil authorities on problems concerning the sale of alcoholic beverages to men in the armed services.

The New Opera Company has transferred the performances of its forthcoming subscription season from the Forty-fourth Street Theatre to the Broadway Theatre, according to an announcement made by Mme. Yolanda Mero-Irion, general manager of the company, at the first Fall meeting of the subscription committee held yesterday at the River Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Department store sales for the week ended Sept. 12 declined 3 per cent, compared with the corresponding period of last year, the Federa1 Reserve System reported today. The decline followed a sharp increase of 26 per cent in the week ended Sept. 5.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 17 -- So many refugees from France, mostly Jews, are arriving in Geneva Canton that the authorities have decided to organize there a camp where the refugees may be accommodated pending formalities.

There was no mystery about Elmer (The) Riddle at the Polo Grounds yesterday. For that matter, there was nothing particularly baffling about the pitching of Junior Thompson and the left-handed Clyde Shoun either. So the Giants just went off at a hitting tangent, smacked all three for a combined dozen blows and provided a sad farewell to Bill MeKechnie and his Reds in Cincinnati's last appearance of the 1942 campaign in the East.

Authorized dispatches from London to this and other newspapers leave no doubt that the Russian Government is in disagreement with the Governments of Britain and the United States as to the opening of a second front in Europe. There can be no disagreement as to the desirability of a two-front war.

OTTAWA, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Munitions Minister C.D. Howe told Canada tonight that tanker losses were "colossal" and that a new gasoline rationing plan reducing nonessential motoring by almost half would become effective Oct. 1.

Midmonth settlements and quarterly tax payments helped to swell the volume of bank clearings in the past week. The total for the twenty-three leading cities of the nation for the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $7,537,338,000, representing the third highest weekly total for the year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

LONDON, Sept. 17 (U.P.) -- German occupation authorities have started a new wave of executions in the occupied countries, it was reported tonight, as violence and sabotage, including the wrecking of two troop trains, hit a peak from France to the Balkans.

With a higher volume of business and the smallest number of van crews in many years, moving men in the New York district yesterday reported their schedules already filled for the final days of the Fall moving season.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 17 -- To prevent Edward Haight, 17-year-old confessed slayer of two Bedford Village girls, from escaping the electric chair on a possible claim of legal insanity, the Westchester County District Attorney's office began assembling today a web of evidence to convince a trial jury that the youth knew the character, quality and consequences of his actions.

The number of women's shoe styles which will be available next Spring will depend entirely upon the ingenuity of designers and manufacturers, it was declared yesterday at the women's shoe style committee session of the National Shoe Retailers Association's style conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Eggs shot ahead again this week, according to the Consumers' Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets. Grade A eggs now average 65 cents a dozen and Grade B mixed 51 cents. Both are from 20 to 25 per cent higher than they were last year at this time.
Why do so many little boys have curly heads when, too often, little girls' hair is as straight as a string? According to a gentleman-expert in these matters the reason is: scissors.

A new publishing house that will operate on a limited tentative scale at first has been set up by Franklin Watts, a book salesman well known in the trade. Mr. Watts has offices at 285 Madison Avenue, and while he will continue to cover large cities for several large publishers he is shaping up a small list of books.

Twenty-five former German-American Bund members and affiliates were brought to trial in Federal court yesterday under charges made last July 7. The group of men are accused of having conspired to counsel others to resist service under the Selective Service Act "until this law and all other laws of the country or of the States, etc., which restrict the citizenship rights of Bund members are repealed."

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- The political basis of Fighting France has been broadened further through the success of a daring plan whereby prominent Frenchmen of widely differing political faith have been brought here to serve under General Charles de Gaulle.

Spending by new "defense money" customers is producing sharp increases in apparel and accessory sales in the middle price brackets, while decreases are noted in the top and bottom ranges, Madelyn P. Coe, fashion coordinator of J.L. Hudson Company, Detroit, said yesterday at the accessories, millinery, fabrics and ready-to-wear luncheon of the Fashion Group, Inc., at the Murray Hill Hotel.

BOSTON, Sept. 17 -- After hanging on by their fingernails for eight innings, the determined Cardinals seized their first real opportunity with both fists and cut loose a five-run rally in the ninth today to pull out a 6-4 victory over the Braves and go three games up on their Dodger pennant rivals.
KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Sept. 17 (U.P.) -- Wendell L. Willki arrived today by plane from Teheran, Iran, for a two-day round of receptions and meetings with Soviet officials before leaving for Moscow.

The Universal Pictures Company, Inc., and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $1,752,346 for the thirty-nine weeks ended on Aug. 1 after all charges, including $2,780,809 provision for estimated applicable Federal income and excess profits taxes, according to the report of J. Cheerer Cowdin, chairman of the board, issued for publication today.

As a result of a fifteen-month study of the fiscal problems of total war, the National Bureau of Economic Research has reached the conclusion that we ought to raise no less than $40,000,000,000 in Federal taxes in the current fiscal year. It bases this conclusion on the expectation that the Government will spend $75,000,000,000 and declares that no more than $35,000,000,000 can safely be borrowed without inviting a serious rise in living costs.

The future of the United Motion Picture Industry appeared doubtful yesterday after the disclosure that William F. Rodgers, chairman of the organization and a vice president of Loew's, Inc., had submitted his resignation and that Warner Brothers and Paramount Pictures no longer would contribute toward the upkeep of UMPI or participate further in its activities.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Chairman Norman H. Davis of the American Red Cross announced today that because the Japanese Government had refused safe passage across the Western Pacific to a neutral vessel, it had canceled the charter of the Swedish ship Kanangoora.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 17 -- "Next year's budget will concern itself principally with measures designed to control the continued rise in prices and in the cost of living," according to Dr. T.F. Tsiang, Oberlin and Columbia University educated Director of Political Affairs in the Executive Yuan.

WITH THE BRITISH FLEET, Returning From Tobruk, Sept. 15 (Delayed) -- The British returned Tobruk yesterday and, after smashing Mediterranean version of the battle of Dieppe that raged from 3 A.M. until dawn, withdrew, leaving mighty pillars of smoke and flame swirling up from General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's supply base.

Whether married men with children would be drafted in 1943 brought no definite answer from Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, Selective Service director for New York City, when he was interviewed on a radio program yesterday afternoon.

American-built fighter planes have not yet been able to match the high-altitude work of the best British, German and Japanese fighters, but the Lockheed P-38 and the Republic P-47 "will soon be in wide-scale service, and on the basis of tests to date should amply take care of things 'upstairs,'" Major N.F. Silsbee and Major E.C. Locke of the United States Army Air Forces asserted last night in an analysis of warplanes.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 17 -- John S. Dumser, 93, of Oakland, Calif., who walked twenty-seven miles in Winter cold as a boy of 16 in an unsuccessful attempt to win his father's approval of his enlistment in the Union Army, today was chosen national commander of the Grand Army of the Republic.

ON THE FRENCH FRONTIER, Sept. 17 -- Vichy Chief of Government Pierre Laval has struck back at the Catholic Church's opposition to persecution of Jews in France by interning a church leader and warning the clergy to keep their hands off governmental affairs, it was learned today.

The large oak dining table around which Cyrus W. Field and his colleagues sat in planning the first transatlantic cable was presented at noon yesterday to the Western Union Telegraph Company Museum, 60 Hudson Street, which is devoted to early and modern apparatus of the telegraph and cable business.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- President Roosevelt and Secretary Wickard stepped vigorously into the drafting of legislation to curb inflation today to protest against the projected upward revision of the parity formula which sets farm prices.

News of a successful American raid on the Japanese invaders of the Aleutian Islands is especially welcome after a period of several weeks of silence about action on that front. The Navy reports that "a large group" of heavy bombers accompanied by pursuit planes took part in the raid; that Japanese ships were sunk and supply dumps ashore were set afire, and that none of our aircraft was lost as a result of enemy action.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 17 -- Equaling par for the Westchester Hills course with a 78, Miss Margaret Nichols of the Hudson River C.C. today showed the way to a field of twenty-four players competing in the one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Association.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 17 -- One important difference has existed in recent months between the attitude of the government and the attitude of the people so far as the war program is concerned.

Muted butterfly colors frosted with a scattering of sequins and bugle beads predominated in the showing of "chez moi" costumes yesterday afternoon at the Lentheric salon, 761 Fifth Avenue. Hand-painted patterns in pastel tones, accented by traceries of sequins and beading or rows of gilded studs, embellished the jackets, belts and bandanna sashes of woolen housecoats and dinner pajamas.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- The Vichy Government announced tonight, according to a French broadcast that was heard here, that Armand Annet, Governor General of Madagascar, had rejected the armistice terms offered yesterday by British authorities, and that Vichy forces would continue to resist the advance of British and Dominion troops "to the extreme limit."

Once more Grand Central Palace is to be taken over for the Army's wartime needs -- this time to replace Governors Island as the induction station for trainees of this area. During the last war the famous structure on Lexington Avenue between Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets served as a debarkation hospital.

Several two-family houses in Brooklyn have just passed into new ownerships. Joel Goldsmith sold to Dispina Timakos and Julia Sarris the two-story, two-family home at 891 Albany Avenue, through June Jacobs.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The 1942 primaries have counted out four incumbent Senators, all Democrats, and nineteen House members, including thirteen Democrats and six Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg of New York City was one of three new regional directors of the War Manpower Commission appointed today by Paul V. McNutt, chairman. Her post is Region 2, New York State. The others were James Bond for Texas, New Mexico and Louisiana, and Joseph A. Smith for the New England States.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept 17 -- Lester Cowan, independent film producer now with Columbia, announced today that he has signed Lillian Gish to play the leading feminine role in a new screen version of "The Late Christopher Bean," Sidney Howard's stage play.

In its fight against the city's annual toll of nearly 250,000 deaths and reported injuries in home accidents, the Greater New York Safety Council plans to send 750,000 safety inspection lists to house and apartment dwellers, it announced yesterday. In addition, 100,000 pedestrian safety leaflets soon will be issued.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 17 -- As the climax of a recent recrudescence of agitation by so-called "Nationalist" groups against those whom they call "warmongers," or people who favor closer cooperation between Argentina and the United Nations, a bomb was thrown late this afternoon against the offices of the democratic morning daily, Prensa, in one of the most crowded thoroughfares in Buenos Aires.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The country's scrap salvage drive received aid from the War Department today, in the shape of orders making Army trucks and personnel available for scrap collection.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 17 (U.P.) -- Japan has dispatched a powerful naval force, including four of her six available battleships, to the Southern Pacific, apparently for a showdown with the United States Fleet and an attempt to drive the Americans from the Solomon Islands, usually reliable sources reported tonight.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Indians gained an 11-inning 6-to-5 victory over Washington today when Sid Hudson came to the mound, allowed two hits, gave an intentional pass and then forced in the winning tally by walking pinch hitter Buster Mills.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Objecting to the use of Social Security funds to help pay for the war, Senator Vandenberg, of Michigan, introduced a resolution in the Senate today to keep the payroll tax at two per cent, divided equally between employer and employe.
HAVANA, Sept. 17 -- Sanitary conditions in Cuba, which have been growing steadily worse, during the past few weeks have been causing considerable concern here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (U.P.) -- The health of the Army training in this country is better than ever before during wartime, Secretary Stimson stated today.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Sept. 17 -- Mrs. J. Macy Willets of New York and Mrs. Charles Scribner of Far Hills, N.J., have sold their 500-acre estate, Mepal Manor, at New Marlboro, to George Costa of New York, through Wheeler Taylor, Inc., of Great Barrington, and Harrie C. Baxter of New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today that Myron C. Taylor, President Roosevelt's personal representative at the Vatican, would return to his post, despite the fact that Italy and the United States are at war.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. l7 -- Crews of Allied heavy bombers reported today hits on two vessels, one of which was set on fire, in a daylight raid yesterday on the harbor at Bengazi.
LONDON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Note circulation as reported in the weekly Bank of England condition statement today showed a decrease of 385,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The Uniform Manufacturers Exchange, Inc., 112 East Nineteenth Street, New York, and twenty-three member firms, all also located in New York, have been ordered to cease and desist from agreements, understandings and conspiracies to suppress competition in the manufacture and distribution of uniforms for bellboys, porters, doormen and others in similar employment, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

The family of Staff Sergeant Salvatore Battaglia yesterday received notification from the American Red Cross at their home at 27 Monroe Street of the posthumous award of the Distinguished Flying Cross at ceremonies in Hawaii.

Alfred E. ("Al") Smith indulged in the mild bad pun which is always permissible in a good cause. Handing over something like 150 pounds of old metal for the salvage campaign, the former Governor described himself as being once more "in the scrap."
Residential deals in various parts of Long Island constituted the bulk of the trading as reported by brokers yesterday. Three of these sales were in Rockville Centre.

THE recent clinching of another pennant by the Yankees brought hardly a ripple of excitement along the baseball front. Why should it cause excitement? Winning pennants is a habit with Yankee teams. It's the Yankee tradition. This is their thirteenth pennant in twenty-two consecutive seasons. There was no reason for dancing in the streets and joyous shouts of "Surprise! Surprise!" when they put over the clinching game the other day.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Ettore Panizza, the Metropolitan Opera's ranking permanent conductor, will not return to the Metropolitan for the coming season, it was learned yesterday. He will remain in Buenos Aires, where he has been conducting this Summer, and the report is that he is slated for an important post there at the Teatro Colon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- President Roosevelt accepted with thanks today a large American flag as the gift of 350 women seamstresses at the Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot, but rejected with obvious distaste a Japanese flag which his son, Major James Roosevelt, had helped to capture in the Marine raid on Makin Island Aug. 18.

Slimmer by an aggregate of about twenty-four pounds, the first local Waac's to return home from two months' training at Fort Des Moines, Iowa, illustrated yesterday "what the Army can do" for a woman.

As if dropping a tough game yesterday to the Pittsburgh Pirates was not enough of a blow to their morale, the Brooklyn Dodgers were confronted with added woes last night when they learned that assault charges had been filed against Dixie Walker and Mickey Owen, two of their most needed players.

OBERLIN, Ohio, Sept. 17 -- Forty members of the Oberlin College and Conservatory faculty called today upon the country's leading music schools to fight the musicians' union's ban on student musical broadcasts.

HICKAM FIELD, Omahu, Hawaii, Sept. 17 -- Major Gen. Willis H. Hale, commander of the Seventh United States Army Air Force, at a review here today presented awards honoring seventy-nine of his fliers for heroism, including combat action in the Midway battle, the bombing of Wake and the later photographic flight over Wake in which a Flying Fortress commanded by Major George Glober shot down four of six Japanese fighters and accomplished its mission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- During the week ended Sept. 16 member bank reserve balances increased $358,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from increases of $154,000,000 in reserve bank credit, $2,000,000 in gold stock and $3,000,000 in Treasury currency and decreases of $208,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks and $43, 000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, offset in part by an increase of $51,000,000 in money in circulation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Secretary Morgenthau expressed disappointment today over what he termed the inadequacies of the Senate's new tax bill, and said that the Treasury would continue to urge Congressional action to obtain more revenue to meet war expenditures, deter spending and set up incentives to save.
LONDON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The War Production Board served notice on the printing and publishing industry today that it was "face-up to the necessity for curtailing its consumption of paper and board," possibly cutting tonnage back to 1940 or 1939 levels.

Stockholders of the United States Freight Company are to meet in Dover, Del., on Sept. 25 to vote on proposals to approve the settlement of a debt owed by three other transport companies which will result in a loss of $2,387,155 and to write down the stated value of their stock from $25 to $15 a share.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Navy announced today the following casualty list, covering the period from Aug. 31 to Sept. 6, inclusive:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Simplification schedules covering saws, axes, hatchets, adzes and light hammers were issued today by the Director General for Operations, War Production Board.

MOSCOW, Sept. 17 -- Fighting of the bitterest and most savage nature is continuing in the streets of the northwestern suburbs of Stalingrad. Through clouds of dust, over the rubble of shattered masonry, grimy German shock troops are creeping in from block to block.
LONDON, Sept. 17 -- The seriousness of the position of Stalingrad still kept business on the stock markets quiet today. Giltedge issues were easier.

Onondaga County, N.Y., sold yesterday a new issue of $444,000 of refunding bonds, dated Sept. 1, 1942, and due serially from 1943 to 1963, to Barr Bros. Co., Inc., and Paul H. Davis Co. The bankers jointly bid 100.44, naming the interest rate as 1 1/2 per cent. Reoffering of the bonds will be made at prices to yield 0.40 to 1.50 per cent.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 17 -- The Moscow radio, in a series of special announcements during the regular foreign-language news broadcasts tonight, reported that the Soviet Minister to Sofia, Alexander Lavrideff, had made an energetic protest to the Bulgarian Foreign Ministry against an "act of armed banditry" on Tuesday in the Soviet consulate in Varna.

Unless the Office of Price Administration rescinds its ruling that normal export sales to the Lease-Lend Administration, British Ministry of Supply Mission and other government agencies must be considered as domestic transactions, the export industry and all its trade connections abroad will be "destroyed," W.H. Lukens, vice president of the Overseas Automotive Club, declared yesterday at a meeting of the group in the Hotel Lincoln.

Max A. Cohen, State chairman of the War Activities Committee of the Motion Picture Industry, announced yesterday that the sale of war bonds in the State this month had been $55,000,000 through Sept. 16. The figure, he said, "indicates almost certainly that the State will fall short of the industry's goal of $160,000,000 for the month and will have a difficult time realizing the official United States Treasury quota of $125,000,000."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Congressional committees are beginning to hear some blunt truths about the manpower question, truths that are overdue. Mr. McNutt, chairman of the commission empowered to deal with the labor servicing of the armed forces and the civilian population, said that government controls are inevitable.
MOSCOW, Friday, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Last midnight's communique:

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Roger Wolff turned in a two-hit performance today and the Athletics defeated the White Sox, 1 to 0, in their final appearance of the season at Comiskey Park. Only 487 persons witnessed the game.

Mayor La Guardia will administer the regular oath of allegiance prescribed by the Office of Civilian Defense to all members of the city's protective services present at the demonstration of air raid protective tactics at the Polo Grounds tonight, tomorrow night and Monday night.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed holdings of United States Government securities to be the highest on record, having increased $70,736,000 during the past week. Note circulation and gold holdings were also at the highest of the year, while ratio of reserve was at the lowest.

TRENTON, Sept. 17 -- Governor Charles Edison carried his fight for revision of New Jersey's ninety-eight-year-old Constitution to his opponents today by challenging the Legislature to let the voters decide at the coming election whether they wish to have a revised basic law for the State submitted to them in a referendum at the general election in 1943.

GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands, Sept. 7 (Delayed) -- Life has never a dull moment for the Marines on Guadalcanal, site of the important Solomons air base that was wrested from the Japanese a month ago. There are Japanese air attacks one day, followed by raids from the sea the next day, and there are night time forays by Japanese jungle snipers; such action is interspersed with duels offshore between United States dive-bombers and enemy cruisers.

I just read in your newspaper that five members of the French Parliament, now living in the United States, have given their approval to the courageous letter sent by the Presidents of the legislative bodies to Marshal Petain and Pierre Laval to oppose the usurpations of the regime against the French Constitution.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- Continued strength in agricultural markets during the week ended on Sept. 12 brought prices of farm products and foods to high levels unequaled since the Autumn of 1929. The rise in prices of farm products amounted to 0.5 per cent, and of foods, to 0.2 per cent.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Grain traders admitted today that they were completely at sea as to the possible outcome of the proposed price control legislation now before Congress and until there was definite information as to price ceilings or floors that operations in futures would probably remain curtailed.

"Don't let us ever for a moment forget that when Hitler and Mussolini have disappeared in ignominy from the world they have cursed, there will still be trout in the Beaverkill and the Wiscoy and the Kinderhook and grouse on the wooded hillsides."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Donald M. Nelson, war production chief, said today that the output of war material in 1943 would be "much bigger" than previous estimates of $60,000,000,000, and declared that the nation "now is on the big upswing of production."
TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 16 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran made the first airplane trip of his life today in Wendell L. Willkie's plane.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A communique:

Mme. Lyolene, one of the great Paris designers who has been working in New York for almost three years, showed her new Fall collection yesterday at Madame et la Jeune Fille, 30 East Fifty-fourth Street. Her collection was so dateless and so right for living today that one felt in it a complete understanding of American tastes and customs.

LONDON, Sept. 17 (U.P.) -- A million-to-one shot that severed a steel towline prevented the British destroyer Zulu from taking her disabled sister ship, the Sikh, out of the harbor of Tobruk after Monday's British raid on the Axis Libyan stronghold, the Exchange Telegraph Agency's Mediterranean Fleet correspondent reported today. He was aboard the Zulu, which was sunk en route back to the fleet's Egyptian base.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 17 -- Miss Maureen Orcutt, White Beeches C.C., and Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr., Crestmont, will meet tomorrow at the Upper Montclair Country Club in the thirty-six-hole final for the New Jersey State women's golf championship.
MOSCOW, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Today's Soviet communique:

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sept. 17 (U.P.) -- Major Gen. George C. Kenney, new Allied air commander in the Southwest Pacific, said today that his fliers had inflicted five-to-one losses on the Japanese Air Force, and that the enemy might have lost in this area alone in the past month more planes than his war plants could produce.

TRENTON, Sept. 17 -- Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Parker of Morristown, N.J., who will observe his eightieth birthday on Oct. 22, neared an all-time record for service on the bench today when he took the oath of office for his sixth seven-year term as a New Jersey Supreme Court Justice.

Owen D. Young, retired chairman of the General Electric Company, and Gerard Swope, formerly its president, were called back yesterday to their old positions for the war's duration. They will replace their successors, who have taken important posts on the War Production Board.

Annual wage increases which, according to union estimates, total about $15,000,000, and other gains accruing to some 78,000 shipyard workers under a wage stabilization plan recently approved by the National War Labor Board were put into contract form yesterday when the agreement was signed by representatives of the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O.
This letter comes to you from a country many miles away and has been written at the request of my fellow war workers, friends and neighbors.

Since the 1,000-plane British raid on the German industrial city of Cologne on May 30, constituting until that time the largest concentration of bombers over a city in the history of warfare, the Royal Air Force has carried out forty-three large-scale raids on more than a dozen German industrial cities.

So that United States "warpower" can deliver without halt its supplies and arms to our fighters, every American has the "patriotic duty" to prevent accidents as he would avoid aiding the enemy, Ned H. Dearborn. executive vice president of the National Safety Council, said yesterday.

The issues on which twenty-five former affiliates of the German-American Bund will be convicted or acquitted of having tried to obstruct this country's Selective Service program were drawn for the jury in Federal court yesterday by government and defense counsel.

Should a sales tax be seriously under consideration as part of the 1942 Revenue Act, I submit that the only sales tax which can produce substantial revenue at a very low rate -- namely, 1 per cent, is the gross sales or turnover tax, which had nation-wide consideration twenty years ago and which was then approved by business men in every part of the country.

LONDON, Sept. 18 (U.P.) -- British military intelligence is investigating an advertisement which appeared four days before the raid on Dieppe as a possible tip-off to the Germans that the raid was coming, The Daily Mirror reported today.
BOSTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Katharine Hepburn, stage and screen actress, was divorced today by her husband, Ogden Ludlow of Alexandria, Va., in Superior Court. Judge Patrick B. O'Sullivan rendered judgment for the plaintiff on the grounds of desertion.

CARTERET, N.J., Sept. 18 -- Three buildings housing war-production units of the Warner Chemical Company division of the Westvaco Chlorine Products Company, here were destroyed by fire early today, causing at least a one-day shut-down of operations at the plant.

For the fourth successive day closing prices for active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday were at the session's low levels, with hedging operations in the waning minutes again erasing earlier gains. Net losses were 5 to 9 points.

The fourth week of the Stalingrad battle has brought into the open a disagreement between Moscow on the one hand, London and Washington on the other, as to the early establishment of a second front in Europe. The dissension is more profound than its ostensible cause.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- The stock markets ended the week quietly with most sections showing minor changes. Gilt-edge issues continued dull and industrial leaders remained firm. The good spots were Cable ordinary u1 higher at u66, Courtaulds better at 39s and Celanese second preference up to 251/4s.

Guy Holcomb, reputedly forced out as chief of the small business section of the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice at the insistence of War Production Chief Donald M. Nelson, yesterday challenged the "big business boys, monopolists and Wail Street lawyers" on the WPB to an all-out "scrap" and announced that he was going to take his fight against them to the people.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 18 -- In deep contrast with the scenes of colorful pageantry and wild hilarity which have surrounded its annual meeting for the past twenty-three years, the American Legion is holding, its first wartime national convention here in an atmosphere of utmost seriousness and dignity.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Whirlaway will go from the inside and Alsab from the outside gate tomorrow when those outstanding stars of the turf are sent off in their winner-take-all match race for a $25,000 purse over Narragansett Park's mile and three-sixteenths course under scale weights.
After watching the New York Giants play the Eastern Army All-Star team last Saturday I want to predict a banner season for the Maramen.

On the technical ground that his plea of guilty was entered by his attorney and not by himself, James B. Schafer, head of the "Royal Fraternity of Master Metaphysicians," obtained yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null the right to freedom on $10,000 bail pending a hearing of his case by the Appellate Division.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., Sept. 18 -- Children in braids, with field flowers, school teachers, housewives, merchants, policemen, judges and a District Attorney crowded into St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church at Bedford Green today to attend a Mass of the Angels for Margaret Lynch, 7 years old, and her sister, Helen, 8, who were kidnapped and slain Monday night.

Those once high-flying Dodgers got a reprieve yesterday when their game with the lowly Phils was called off and the first-place Cardinals weren't scheduled to play. But a reprieve is all it was, because a "pardon" at this late date seems about as likely as Lippy Leo Durocher putting piccalilli on his dessert parfait tonight.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Sept. 19 (U.P.) -- Allied fliers yesterday made punishing attacks on Japanese supply lines leading to the Owen Stanley Mountain front, where Japanese and Australian forces are now engaged in only "minor fighting," it was announced today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 18 -- The terms of a deal by which United Artists will take over eleven finished Paramount pictures and distribute them have been agreed upon here, it was learned today, and official announcement of the contract will be made in New York next week by Edward Raftery, U. A. president, who will leave for Manhattan over the week-end.

Hundreds of New York City's taxicabs, which will be taken off the streets tomorrow night in conformance with the recent order of the Office of Defense Transportation to save gasoline and conserve tires, are expected to be pressed into service within the next ten days to help transport Long Island aircraft workers in Nassau and Suffolk Counties to and from their plants, it was revealed here yesterday.

In the issue of Sept. 6 you published a letter from Emil Havas, in which he wrote: "To me there is no difference between Rumania and Hungary. Both are satellites of Hitler, both support him with all the resources at their command."

The hoped-for return meeting between Occupation and Count Fleet, both of whom are considered championship timber, looms for this afternoon at Aqueduct, where one of the finest programs of the season is scheduled for the closing day of the meeting.

We are all wondering what our taxes will be next year, and, in some instances, how they are going to be paid by the white-collar man who does not share the increased earnings of the mechanical trades.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- An Executive order giving to William M. Jeffers, Rubber Director, full authority over the country's rubber, including conservation of present supplies and manufacture of substitutes, was issued at the White House today.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- British troops landed today on the east coast of Madagascar and occupied Tamatave, the island's principal port, following refusal of the French plenipotentiaries to accept armistice terms.

Clergymen in their sermons tomorrow in the churches of the New York area will stress the fact that the day, being the first Sunday after the opening of the public schools, marks also the beginning of a new church year and the first church year for a generation with the United States in a war.

The greater part of the estate left by Miss Ina Love Thursby, sister of the late Emma Cecilia Thursby, internationally famous concert and oratorio singer of the last quarter of the nineteenth century, will be used to further music education, according to the will filed for probate yesterday in Surrogates Court.

There are indications of a "general movement of the foundation and superstructure" of the Aquarium which would necessitate extensive and costly repairs or even rebuilding of the foundation, according to an affidavit by Richard Hyland, consulting engineer, submitted yesterday on behalf of Park Commissioner Robert Moses in opposition to the suit to restrain him from demolishing the structure.

It is now possible to get a clearer view of what passed in Moscow between Winston Churchill and Joseph Stalin regarding the "second front." The Russian and the British theses, as they confronted each other last month -- and they have not moved appreciably forward since -- can be outlined with some degree of assurance.

New Japanese utterances on relations with Russia, half-placating and half-threatening, were linked yesterday with Japan's observance of the eleventh anniversary of the so-called Mukden incident, first of the totalitarian aggressions that finally set the world at its greatest war, The Associated Press said.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- A battle cruise that lasted for 104 days and embraced the engagements in the Gilbert and Marshall Islands, at Salamaua and Lae, Tulagi, in the Coral Sea and at Midway constituted the last operation of the aircraft carrier Yorktown, which sank on the night of June 6-7, the Navy Department revealed today.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 18 -- Declaring Japan to be our most formidable enemy, "far tougher than Germany," former Ambassador Joseph C. Grew told a War Council luncheon here today that the Germans cracked in 1918 and that they would crack again, but that the Japanese would fight until they were completely crushed.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- Lean, wiry parachute troops are swelling the striking power of the United States armed forces for a blow against the Nazis with invasion exercises above the green hills of this island.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (U.P.) -- The Senate silver group presented a united front today against a bill by Senator Green of Rhode Island to permit the Treasury to sell some of its free silver to silver-using industries converting to war work.

VICHY, France, Sept. 18 -- Despite a British landing at the east coast port of Tamatave today and further progress by British troops from the west side of Madagascar. French authorities there declined to accept the British terms for surrender.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Sept. 18 -- Chipping and putting superbly despite a sodden course, Miss Maureen Orcutt of the White Beeches C.C. today regained the women's New Jersey golf championship by defeating Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont, 8 and 7, in the thirty-six-hole final.

ALBANY, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission ordered today an investigation of the Cabot Gas Corporation's proposal to discontinue pipe line delivery of natural gas from Pennsylvania to customers in New York State.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Eight manufacturing plants and three shipyards, including two Henry J. Kaiser West Coast yards, will receive honors for "outstanding contributions to the merchant shipbuilding phase of the war effort," the Maritime Commission stated today.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 18 -- The Legislative Assembly ended its discussion of the Indian situation today, leaving it as it was found, with each party represented having its say while India's largest and most important political party -- the Congress -- had nobody present.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 18 (AP) -- A quick sellout of reserved seats for the St. Louis games of the World Series if the Cardinals win the National League pennant was predicted tonight as the club's office was swamped with mail orders from local and out-of-town customers.
MOSCOW, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Today's Soviet communique:

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Sept. 18 -- Paying a brief visit to this city to check up on the Waves' physical-fitness program, Commander Gene Tunney, a leader of this program for the Navy, declared in an interview that this type of physical conditioning would mark "the turning point in medical history by American women."

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

TRENTON, Sept. 18 -- Albert W. Hawkes of Montclair, who won the Republican nomination for United States Senator in the New Jersey primaries last Tuesday, issued a statement today denying charges by Senator William H. Smathers, his Democratic opponent, that Mr. Hawkes had "bought" the nomination.

BALDWIN, L.I., Sept. 18 -- The Harold G. Baxter home here, a modest, rambling, brown-shingled, eight-room dwelling set in a grove of trees that obscure it from the street, should make a restful haven for weary merchant seamen.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 18 (U.P.) -- Heavy bombers of the Royal Australian Air Force and Royal Air Force medium bombers delivered a crushing raid on Tobruk last night, scoring a direct hit on a jetty and setting fire to a ship moored alongside, it was announced tonight.

Graduates of the School of Nursing of St. Vincent's Hospital were praised yesterday for their acceptance of duties with the armed services and counseled to follow the great traditions of their vocation at the golden jubilee exercises of that institution held yesterday in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Response from city housewives and women with leisure to the rally on Tuesday when they were urged to contribute some of their spare hours to civilian defense has spread cheer among officials of the Manhattan division of CDVO.

OTTAWA, Sept. 18 -- The combined operations assault on Dieppe cost Canada the "very heavy price" of 67 per cent of her attacking forces killed, wounded or missing, the Dominion Government disclosed today in a plain-spoken resume of this greatest Allied attack on the Nazi-held coast of Europe.

Large migrations of the unemployed from their home cities to war industry areas are not contemplated by the War Manpower Commission, it was disclosed here yesterday by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, who has just been appointed by Paul V. McNutt, chairman, as Regional Director of Region 2, embracing New York State.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Two measures to authorize and direct President Roosevelt to stabilize farm prices and industrial wages around present levels were approved late today by the Senate and House Committees on Banking and Currency.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 18 -- Members of society, who were scheduled to show horses and ponies today in the fortieth annual Piping Rock Horse Show on the show grounds of the Piping Rock Club, arrived in a mist and fog and remained to sit their mounts through a drizzling rain.

BOSTON, Sept. 18 -- New England business was told today by Leverett H. Saltonstall, Governor of Massachusetts, and by Walter H. Wheeler Jr., New England regional director of the War Production Board, that all possible speed should be made in conversion of industries from oil to coal burning equipment.

Official German military sources last night attributed the slowness of the operations at Stalingrad to the fact that the city had been "colossally fortified" and that its leaders "do not shrink from any sacrifices to postpone decisions that are in the making."

VICHY, France, Sept. 18 -- At Macon today there was an official reception for 226 French war prisoners back from Germany. They were part of the second group released under Chief of Government Pierre Laval's exchange accord in return for French workers.

The National City Bank of New York and the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company of Buffalo, bidding jointly, won yesterday the award of a new issue of $3, 000,000 of city of Buffalo refunding bonds. The banks bid 100.20, naming an interest rate of 1.80 per cent for the issue, which matures serially on Oct. 1, 1948 to 1952.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Western Army All-Stars and the Giants -- two and a quarter tons of football might -- collide tomorrow with the soldiers determined to "win for Wade" in their Army Emergency Relief series finale.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18 -- Representatives of the Aluminum Workers of America agreed tonight to abide by the War Labor Board's decision refusing a general wage increase, and thus ended the threat of a strike in the vital war production industry.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (U.P.) -- The War Department has awarded silver stars to five service men for gallantry, one of them in the first World War.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Bureau announced today that corporations returning money to the government as a result of renegotiation of contracts should refund only the amount of profits above Federal income and excess profits taxes already paid or assessed on the sum involved.

The Hotel Ansonia at Broadway and Seventy-second Street, architecturally outstanding because of its wealth of ornamental metal work, will be stripped of thousands of pounds of this strategic copper next Monday or Tuesday to aid the war program.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Evidence of another break in the none too friendly relations between the National Association of Retail Grocers and. OPA came today in the release of the contents of a telegram sent to President Roosevelt urging that the Baruch committee or some equivalent group investigate the "chaotic" conditions prevailing in the food industry.

The taste of women working in defense industries does not differ materially from their sisters in cities like New York. Mrs. Claire Lang, stylist and advertising director of Franklin Simon Co., said yesterday in an address before the accessories division of the fashion group at the Murray Hill Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 -- The Peoples Light and Power Company, Inc., in an initial voluntary step to comply with the "death sentence" clause of the Holding Company Act, applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to sell to the Federal Water and Gas Corporation its entire investment in the Mississippi Public Service Company for $420,000 in cash.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The Navy has devised a plan for distributing ballots wherever possible, to enable members of the service to vote in the November elections.

LONDON, Sept. 18 (U.P.) -- Senior officers of the former Czechoslovak Army, suspected by the Germans of being leaders in fomenting resistance and sabotage in Czechoslovakia, are being secretly executed by the Gestapo, official Czech quarters charged tonight.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Big Jack Hallett, rookie strike-out king from the International League, weakened in the ninth inning of a brilliant hurling duel with Johnny Vander Meer tonight and the Reds scored four times to beat Pittsburgh, 5 to 1.

James C. Petrillo may be performing a real public service, though not one that he intends. He may succeed in doing what no other labor leader has done. He may clarify the thinking of Congress and the Administration on at least a few points about labor legislation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 18 -There is no need of national registration of women for employment in the war industries, according to Miss Mary Anderson, director of the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor, who came here today.

The new investment market was more active this week in contrast with the dormant state of the preceding period. Five issues of bonds, one of which was the largest public utility flotation since June. were offered here for public subscription at an aggregate face value of $28, 751,930.

George F. Cassidy, representing a number of independent bus lines operating in and near Jersey City, testified yesterday that if the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company were permitted to increase its fare from 8 to 10 cents between Jersey City and Manhattan passenger traffic on the line would fall off 25 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- The Navy stated today that Secretary Knox had commended twenty-four enlisted men for service in action. Twenty were members of Motor Torpedo Boat Squadron 3 which operated in the Philippines under Lieut. Comdr. John D. Bulkeley.
Mrs. Peter A. B. Widener has come from Elkins Park. Pa., to the Savoy-Plaza.

Small bluefish are being caught in Long Island Sound by the fleet operating from Mattituck, most of the blues weighing about two pounds. Feather jigs appear to be the favorite lure. On the south tide of the island, casters at Shin-necock Inlet continue to take blues, slightly larger, from the surf, along with striped bass and weak-fish.

Yesterday Lieut. Col. Frank Murphy passed through New York in his Army uniform. Today, in civilian clothes, he is doing a job of trouble-shooting in Detroit. He knows Detroit well, having been its Mayor, and Michigan, having been its Governor. When he finishes his inquiry into industrial conditions in his home city we may expect to have more facts.

While industry will benefit from greatly expanded farm purchasing power this year, it must also be prepared for future economic readjustments created by the growing scarcity of skilled farm labor at a time when food requirements of the United Nations are of paramount importance.

LONDON, Saturday, Sept. 19 -- The Air Ministry disclosed today that the Royal Air Force had been dropping 8,000-pound bombs in recent raids on Germany. These new four-ton explosives were used against Karlsruhe Sept. 2 and Duesseldorf Sept. 10, and, according to the first official details of the damage done at both those highly important centers of war industry in Western Germany, they spread great havoc.

There is no better way for the peoples of North and South America to understand each other than by developing an intelligent understanding of thier mutual cultural heritage, according to Francis Henry Taylor, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, who arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday morning after a 20,000-mile flight through South and Central America and Mexico.

The most holy day of the Jewish year, Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, will commence at sundown tomorrow and end at sundown Monday. In synagogues and temples throughout New York thousands of faithful Jews will mark the day with prayer and meditation.

Faced with rapidly expanding wartime activities, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has leased additional office space in the vicinity of its building at 33 Liberty Street. Allan Sproul, president of the bank, made known yesterday that the bank had leased the first four floors of the office building at 51 Pine Street to house the War Savings Bond Department which the bank operates in its capacity as fiscal agent for the Federal Government.
LONDON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

The pending conversion of domestic furnaces from oil to coal and the use of millions of portable heaters for auxiliary heat -- both of which are effects of the oil shortage -have made fire protection authorities apprehensive, of a sharp increase in dwelling fires in the thirty States affected by the fuel oil rationing in the coming Winter.

William M. Jeffers, the nation's new rubber administrator, promised last night that a program would be under way by the middle of next week that would supply enough rubber for military and essential civilian needs. He stressed the word "essential."

Lady Doverdale gave a luncheon yesterday in the Ritz-Carlton Garden for Miss Lucile Thornton and Mrs. Charles H. Thieriot. Countess Hans Scherr-Thoss had in her party there Mrs. Peter H. B. Frelinghuysen Jr. and Mrs. McClure Meredith Howland. With Mrs. Vance Storrs for luncheon at the hotel were Lady Duveen, Mrs. Reginald D. Hiscoe and Mrs. Philip Corban.

Another pseudonym mystery, one that has particularly intrigued mystery novel and crime readers, has been cleared up. It is revealed that Joseph Shearing, author of crime novels that always have been rated high by American readers, is Mrs. Gabrielle Margaret Vere Campbell Long, an Englishwoman, with a list of more than 100 books to her credit under the names Marjorie Bowen (the most frequently used), John Winch, Robert Paye and George R. Preedy.

MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 18 -- A proposal that a two-day work stoppage at the Pinto Island Yard of the Alabama Drydock and Shipbuilding Company be terminated immediately with the five-cent ferry toll controversy referred to the War Labor Board for arbitration and decision was adopted here tonight at a mass meeting of the striking shipyard workers.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 18 -- Clearing the stage for the first test of the constitutionality of the "death sentence" clause of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, the Securities and Exchange Commission filed today its brief in defense of the statute with the Third Circuit Court of Appeals, where the United Gas Improvement Company challenged the measure.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Chile's Independence Day today received the attention of the Axis in the form of a congratulatory message from Adolf Hitler and lengthy short-wave broadcasts from Berlin and Tokyo expressing fears for Chile's independence.

It now turns out that the maxim concerning the advantage of consuming an apple daily is not so sound scientifically as one might suppose. Research workers at the New York State College of Home Economics at Cornell University evidently believe that the virtues of a single apple are overstated.

Unless there is a national calamity resulting from enemy action in which many millions of dollars worth of property is destroyed in the next six months, which no one expects will occur, there will be a substantial reduction in the rates charged by War Damage Corporation for insuring against damages caused by enemy action, in the opinion of experts here.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Sept. 18 -- High school boys, who master the 100-yard obstacle-studded "Commando" course, added to the Central High School physical education equipment this term, may not qualify immediately for the United States Army's new Ranger troops, but they will be much better physical specimens than their scholastic predecessors, in the opinion of Herbert Williamson, physical education instructor.

New York City Democratic leaders conferred yesterday on plans for getting out the vote for Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., nominee for Governor, and the rest of the candidates on the State ticket.

Despite the fact that business activity has been spotty throughout the country in recent weeks, with activity generally concentrated in heavy war production centers, newspaper linage does not appear to be following the same pattern, according to an analysis of linage reports by Media Records on the fifty-two cities checked.

Net income reported yesterday by the Quaker Oats Company and its wholly owned domestic and Canadian subsidiaries amounted to $4,335,812 for the fiscal year ended on June 30. The profit, which is after charges for depreciation and $2,615,496 provision for Federal and foreign income and Canadian profits taxes, is equivalent to $4.64 each on 702,000 shares of common stock after dividend requirements on the 6 per cent cumulative preferred.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Lon Warneke of the Cubs will be on the firing line against his former team-mates, the Cardinals, in the first game of the important two-game series opening at Wrigley Field tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Henry J. Kaiser, West Coast shipbuilder and advocate of the construction of large-scale cargo planes on a mass-production basis, was authorized today to proceed with the building of three such planes at once.

At least 250,000 tons of industrial scrap iron could be gathered in New York City if sufficient funds can be obtained from War Materials Inc., a new subsidiary of the Reconstruction Finance Commission, Park Commissioner Robert Moses said yesterday in his first report as director of the industrial division of the intensified salvage campaign undertaken by Mayor La Guardia and the New York City Newspaper Publishers Association.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 18 -- Mrs. Henry Obre of Brookville, won the C.K.G. Billings Memorial Trophy, donated by Mrs. W. Halsted Vander Poel, for the second year in a row at the fortieth annual Piping Rock horse show today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Following are the texts of the Senate Banking Committee's resolution to give the President inflation control authority and the House Banking Committee's bill:

The Rev. Walter E. Bentley, founder and general secretary for twenty-five years of the Actors' Church Alliance, will celebrate his golden jubillee in the ministry at the 11 A.M. service on Sunday, Sept. 27, in the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, "The Little Church Around the Corner," Twenty-ninth Street, east of Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- A second official warning to the Senate Interstate Commerce subcommittee investigating the American Federation of Musicians' ban prohibiting its members from making recordings for radio use came today from James L. Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, who said this action, ordered by James C. Petrillo, the union chief, was striking "at the heart of broadcasting."

In the Cathedral of St. John the Divine at 4 P.M. tomorrow a "service of solemn intercession for the suffering people of Yugoslavia, and of thanksgiving for their courage and steadfastness in this time of trial" will be held. A message will be read from King Peter II of Yugoslavia, who recently visited the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Sept. 12 were 244,671,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines, Department of the Interior. This represented a decrease of 2,271,000 barrels in the week, comprising one of 2,408,000 barrels in domestic stocks, but an increase of 137,000 barrels in foreign stocks.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 18 -- The finest Navy football squad since 1926 has checked out almost en masse with its fighting Marine coach, Major Swede Larson, to ride the sea and air lanes in the grimmest task ever undertaken by Uncle Sam's armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The United States today made an urgent inquiry as to whether the Japanese Government would comply with international agreements and make it possible for this government to furnish, under neutral auspices, supplementary supplies to American prisoners of war and civilian internees in Japan, the Philippine Islands and other areas under Japanese domination.

After a lapse of several sessions, the stock market gave evidence yesterday of better stability as pivotal issues returned as the backbone of the share list. Gains of about a point ran through an assortment of industrial producers. Trading on the Stock Exchange was the heaviest since Aug. 19 as transfers reached 417,470 shares, against 407,650 on Thursday.

READING, Pa., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Lucy Hanover, owned by the Hanover Shoe Farms, Hanover, Pa., and driven by Harry Thomas, won the first two heats and the trophy in the free-for-all trot on the closing day's card of the Reading Fair's Grand Circuit meeting today.

In the President's Labor Day message and in the subsequent testimony before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee it was strongly indicated that wage stabilization would be based upon the Little Steel formula promulgated by the War Labor Board last July 16.

The heavyweight championship battle between Sergeant Joe Louis and Private Billy Conn, scheduled for the Yankee Stadium the afternoon of Oct. 12, will be staged on a financial basis different from the one originally planned.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Germany, through her Charge d'Affaires, Dr. Erich Otto Meynen, asked the Argentine Government today to state publicly that none of the 130 escaped crewmen and officers of the scuttled pocket battleship Admiral Graf Spee had broken his word by fleeing internment.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 18 -- The Democratic opponent of comely Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, Republican nominee for Congress, got his first verbal lashing today from a tongue celebrated for its rapier-like deliveries. After carefully evading questions on her opinion of Representative Leroy D. Downs, incumbent from the Fourth Connecticut Congressional District, Mrs. Luce finally broke down at the end of her first press conference since her nomination and said:

Weather conditions' held back the expansion of consumer demand for early Fall merchandise in retail trade here this week. Volume up to yes. terday was estimated as run-i ning about 2 per cent behind a year ago, with sales yesterday affected by the rainstorm.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Germany, through her Charge d'Affaires, Dr. Erich Otto Meynen, asked the Argentine Government today to state publicly that none of the 130 escaped crewmen and officers of the scuttled pocket battleship Admiral Graf Spee had broken his word by fleeing internment.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 18 -- The Democratic opponent of comely Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, Republican nominee for Congress, got his first verbal lashing today from a tongue celebrated for its rapier-like deliveries. After carefully evading questions on her opinion of Representative Leroy D. Downs, incumbent from the Fourth Connecticut Congressional District, Mrs. Luce finally broke down at the end of her first press conference since her nomination and said:

Weather conditions' held back the expansion of consumer demand for early Fall merchandise in retail trade here this week. Volume up to yes. terday was estimated as run-i ning about 2 per cent behind a year ago, with sales yesterday affected by the rainstorm.

Although Cecilia Beaux was signally honored as recently as last May, when the National Institute of Arts and Letters presented to her its gold medal (a medal awarded to a painter only once in each decade), her distinguished career has come to be associated in our minds with an earlier epoch in American art.

VINELAND, N.J., Sept. 18 -- An eleven-day-old strike of 2,400 employes of the Kimble Glass Company, manufacturers of medicinal glassware for the armed services, was ended by an oral vote of the strikers at a mass meeting here today when announcement had been made that the War Labor Board "could take the matter up immediately and get action in three days" on the employes' demands for a 25-cents-an-hour wage rise over present undisclosed rates.

KUIBYSHEV, Sept. 18 (U.P.) -- Wendell L. Willkie cut down on his social engagements today and devoted himself to learning all he could about Soviet agriculture, industry and morale before going to Moscow, where he hopes to confer informally with Premier Joseph Stalin.

STRATFORD, Conn., Sept. 18 -- Rufe Watson of Washington, D. C., went through three extra rounds of perfect shooting today to annex opening honors in the North American skeet championships at the Remington Gun Club.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Last midnight's communique:
LONDON, Sept. 18 (U.P.) -- The Rome radio reported today that Italian motor torpedo boats had penetrated the roadstead of the Gibraltar naval base and sunk one merchant ship and damaged five others.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The appointment of 242 third officers of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps, including twenty-five from New York, three from New Jersey and five from Connecticut, was announced today by the War Department.

"The Loves of Edgar Allan Poe," opening at the Little Carnegie Playhous, will be today's lone film arrival. John Shepperd plays the title role in the Twentieth Century-Fox film, with Linda Darnell, Virginia Gilmore, Jane Darwell, Mary Howard, Frank Conroy, Henry Morgan and Walter Kingsford among the featured players.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The thirty States in which fuel oil will be rationed this Fall and Winter will be divided into four zones in order to take care of disparities in climate, the Office of Price Administration stated today. The OPA will use a "degree day" system to adjust allowances of fuel oil to climatic conditions in a given area within the zones.

In the Sept. 15 issue of THE TIMES an item appeared to the effect that an American journalist named Donald Day has the Finnish joined armed forces against Soviet Russia. This would seem quite normal on the surface, as Finland is supposedly a neutral country from the official American point of view, even though her armed forces are helping the Nazis fight one of our most important and gallant allies -- Soviet Russia.

A copy of the newly issued Fire Department air raid precaution regulations, together with the forms to be filled out by the owners of dwellings, showing how they have complied with these rules, was received yesterday.

The two-family house at 1002 Ocean Parkway, in Brooklyn, at the corner of Avenue J, has been sold by the Fulton Savings Bank to Max and Ray Eisenberg, subject to a first mortgage of $12,000. Joseph J. Fischer was attorney for the buyer and Wingate Cullen acted for the seller.
Manager Leo Durocher of the faltering Dodgers owes National League President Ford Frick a letter of appreciation. The latter certainly let the boisterous, squawking Durocher off easy.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Sept. 18 (AP) -- Delegates to the eighty-sixth convention of the International Typographical Union adopted a resolution today accusing A.F. Giegengack, head of the Government Printing Office, of showing bias against the I.T.U. and its policies.

The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, in its semi-annual statement of operations issued last night by Oswald W. Knauth, president, estimates its consolidated net profit at approximately $600,000 for the six months ended on Aug. 1, after adjustments for merchandise reserves and provision of $850,000 for Federal taxes.

New municipal financing on next week's calendar aggregates $10, 647,159, compared with this week's revised total of $9,039,753 and with the weekly average for the year to date of $23,504,858. A single issue, that of $8,286,000 bonds of the Boston Metropolitan District, Mass., will account for most of next week's total.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The War Labor Board rejected today a mediator's proposal that a wage increase of 6 cents a hour become effective for employes of the J.H. Williams Company of Buffalo.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Sept. 19 -- German armored forces struck deeper into the streets of northwest Stalingrad yesterday, but Russian counter-blows, backed up by reinforcements from Western Siberia, wiped out part of the gain, the Red Army reported today.

The necessity for paying out large sums at quarterly tax periods before the huge volume of tax checks can be put through for collection usually causes the Treasury to overdraw its accounts with the Federal Reserve Banks, with the principal operation taking place at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- The first action covering "war model" product was taken by the Office of Price Administration today when it fixed a ceiling price reflecting the lower cost of manufacturing of a new type of men's sweater.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Grain traders placed a bullish construction on a report that a Senate committee has approved a 90 per cent of parity floor under agricultural commodities and that government loans would be made on that basis. General buying developed in wheat and rye on the announcement, with wheat rising 1 cent a bushel and rye around 2 cents before the bulge was checked by aggressive profit-taking.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- The two former French political enemies the Leftist, Pierre Brossolette, and the Rightist, Charles Vallin, who arrived here recently after a daring escape from France, joined today in declaring emphatically that the overwhelming majority of their countrymen in both unoccupied and occupied France are secret supporters of General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Fighting French forces.

A WELL-KNOWN news commentator, apparently anxious to be the first among newcasters to give the American public "important" news, informed us recently that a commander over the Allied armies preparing to invade Europe had already been chosen.
Anent your symposium on the closed shop and David I. Ashe's comment in the Sept. 6 issue, I would like to call attention to something which seems to be forgotten.

QUEBEC, Sept. 19 -- In Canada the English are not really English and the French not really French. Both are first Canadians. English-speaking Canadians are not in love with Englishmen from England and French-speaking Canadians do not regret that their ancestors saw the French go back home after Wolfe had defeated Montcalm.

The ban on cross-hauling of sugar through the establishment of nine zones for the country by the Office of Price Administration last week provides a definite forerunner of what will happen to many other industries as transportation shortages become more acute, it was indicated in war agency circles last week.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 19 -- Three Axis merchantmen were damaged and two were probably sunk as Royal Air Force bombers and torpedo planes attacked shipping in the central and eastern Mediterranean Thursday. Light bombers did the work in the central Mediterranean, flying as low as 100 feet above the ships before releasing bombs.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Bucky Walters pitched his fiftenth victory against thirteen defeats today as the Reds downed the Pirates for the second straight time, 4 to 3.

Potential increases in retailer mortality as a result of war conditions and possible remedial steps which government may take came into sharper focus in merchandising circles last week as the Senate Committee on Small Business announced the scheduling of a series of meetings devoted to this problem, beginning Sept. 29.

MR. DOUGLAS GILBERT'S "Lost Chords" has as its subtitle "The diverting story of American popular songs." Yes, it is diverting; but as with Mr. Gilbert's diverting "American Vaudeville," published two years ago, one has misgivings that the author took an assignment rather than that he begged to cover a subject that fascinated him.

Miss Margaret E. Conrad, executive officer of the Department of Nursing of Columbia University's faculty of medicine, has been appointed director of nursing at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, it was announced yesterday by Dean Sage, president of the hospital's board of managers.
Mrs. Cameron McRae Winslow Jr. of Newport, R.I., is spending a month at the Ambassador as the guest of Mrs. Harold C. Bickford of Buffalo.

First results of the New York Stock Exchange's experiment with ten-share-unit stocks have been completely favorable. Volume has risen, now that active specialists are able to make close markets. Not only have spreads within the Exchange narrowed, but those in the over-the-counter field have closed up.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- The pennant-pursuing Cardinals had another day of rest today -- a rest they really needed -- when weather forced postponement of the first contest of their all-important two-game series with the Cubs.

Many home gardeners forego the satisfaction of growing strawberries, grapes, raspberries, asparagus, blackberries, currants, and gooseberries because they feel that they would require a great deal of their restricted space.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 19 -- Federal Bureau of Investigation agents today questioned thirty-two German and Italian aliens seized in Western Pennsylvania along with dynamite, pictures of Hitler, guns and burglar tools.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Cooperation of several government agencies with the hardwood lumber industry in solving production problems offers hope that the sawmills will catch up with the huge production demands confronting them, John W. McClure, secretary-treasurer of the National Hardwood Lumber Association, reported as the group prepared to open its two-day annual convention here on Thursday.

As Vast of its accelerated program of study -- instituted as a war measure to provide for undergraduates the opportunity to complete their college courses in three years instead of the normal four -- Princeton University added to its normal academic calendar a Summer term of nine weeks' duration.

A large, varied and valuable historical collection of American letters and manuscripts dating from the seventeenth to the nineteenth centuries has been given to the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue between 103d and 104th Streets, by Mrs. Elon Hooker.

SIX months ago the most exciting sight in any British town was an American soldier: today few sights are more familiar. Americans are strolling around in natty uniforms, clattering down the street in jeeps, roaring over the country roads in motor cycles. They are found from the Scottish moors in the north to the Downs in the extreme south, and they are found in ever-increasing numbers.

WATERVILLE, Me., Sept. 19 -- Increased emphasis on American history is being given this year at Colby College, with interest centered on American institutions, Professor William J. Wilkinson, head of the history department here, announced today.

THERE'S nothing like a new Fall hat to give a woman a sense of well-being. Somehow, just the feeling of a becoming new hat, after a Summer of hair bows and gadgety headgear, makes us want to look in a mirror again.

Chickweed is the bane of every gardener whose ground may happen to become seeded with this pest. It is a rather pretty plant, yellow-green, with rough, hairy stems and pointed leaves, which grow in opposing pairs alternately. The flowers are about half an inch in diameter, white with yellow centers.

While Stalingrad fought with its back to the wall, while the Russian press spoke with increasing insistence of the urgent need of second front aid by the Allies, a report came from London revealing serious disagreement between Russia and the two great democracies on the feasibility of an attack on Europe.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Fuel oil rationing probably will affect more than 3,000,000 homes, the Census Bureau reported today.

ON THE FRENCH FRONTIER, Sept. 19 (U.P.) -- Reports from France indicated tonight that a new major crisis has arisen in Vichy's relations with Germany with imposition by the Nazis of the harshest reprisals yet employed, including "massive" deportation to the East of non-Jewish French citizens.

Preparations to receive more than 3,000 guests in the three-day run of the forthcoming Fun Fair are being made by several committees working in the interests of the event, a series of carnival divertissements which will be held Oct. 6 to 8 in the St. Thomas Chapel Parish House, 229 East Fifty-ninth Street, under the auspices of the St. Thomas Church Branch of Bundles for America.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 19 -- In one of the longest private audiences accorded since his pontificate, Pope Pius XII shortly after 11 o'clock this morning received Myron C. Taylor, President Roosevelt's personal representative to the Vatican, for an hour and one-half in his study.
A DOZEN years ago Felix Cornell would have had an occupational picture taken before a blueprint and the other accouterments of an electrical engineer.
RICHARD G. LILLARD has written a tantalizing book about Nevada. He has the material at hand for a magnificent study, and in those areas he has chosen to treat he has done a thorough research job.

The man who commanded the Marines who defended Midway Island was in town yesterday. He is iron-gray-haired, with a colonel's eagles on his collar and a voice that remains soft even when he is talking of such events as the blasting of a Japanese bomber into so many pieces that observation reports said the enemy had released a storm of paper over the island.

STOCKTON, Calif., Sept. 19 (U.P.) -- Fifty-two British sailors who volunteered as emergency farm workers called a sit-down strike today to protest what they termed insanitary housing conditions and an abrogation of their work agreement.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- King George has started a fuel saving plan at Buckingham Palace and Windsor Castle whereby every one on the Royal staff, all guests and all servants will be allowed only five inches of water each when they take a tub bath.
