THE start of production this week on the last sequence of "Forever and a Day," long delayed British War Charities film, marked the end of free appearances by actors in charity pictures because of a new rule adopted by the Screen Actors Guild.

Hitler's war will be another Thirty Years' War, or so predicts Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, Nazi major prophet, advising the German people to get used to the idea. If he is right, the Germans are in for a bad time. That old war, lasting from 1618 to 1648, was the cruelest war in history, except, possibly, the present one.

LOOK out of a train window at night as you speed from one big town to another. Factories are ablaze with the blue-green of mercury arcs, flaming gases leap from furnaces, stock piles are bathed in light. Industry has manifestly heeded the President's demand that machines work twenty-four hours a day to produce the colossal numbers of planes, tanks, guns, forgings and the thousands of items on the priorities list.
LONDON, Sept. 19 -- Despite some efforts by French forces on Madagascar to obstruct it, the steady British advance toward the capital, Tananarive, continued yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 19 -- The Northwest Frontier Province is much quieter than the eastern and southern provinces, according to Abdul Qaiyum, one of the three Congress party members of the Central Legislative Assembly who are still out of jail.

DIRECTOR Michael Curtiz is a busy man these days. On his immediate schedule are two of the Warners' more ambitious undertakings for the current season, these being "Mission to Moscow," the book by Joseph E. Davies, former Ambassador to Russia, and "This Is the Army."

MEXICO CITY -- They got off the train at the Plaza, he in a wrinkled seersucker and she in a linen sport dress, the worse for wear and the long train trip to Mexico City. Their bags loaded down three boys. Obviously an American couple on their first good-will trip south of the border.

Reports from London last week stated that the Germans now have a high-altitude bomber to throw at England. The meager reports described it as a "sub-stratosphere" bomber capable of operating at 40,000 feet. No details, save that it is a Junkers 86-P and has a pressurized cabin and supercharged Diesel engines, were given.

MOSCOW, Sept. 19 -- While the fate of Stalingrad is being decided in bloody street battles of an intensity and savagery unsurpassed in the war, the Russians are advancing on a broad front, gradually but steadily, in the Voronezh area and are successfully resisting Col. Gen. Paul Ludwig von Kleist's tanks in the Eastern Caucasus.

Several thousand unused gasoline rationing books were stolen some time Friday night from rationing board offices in Norwalk, Conn., and Passaic, N.J., police of the two municipalities reported yesterday.

If the Army is not getting doctors fast enough, the fault lies with the Medical Advisory Service of the Selective Service Board. There should be some consistent policy of procurement and assignment, so that ultimately all young, healthy doctors enter into the armed forces, leaving civilians in the care of the older, frailer and alien physicians.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Competent witnesses before Congressional committees this week made it plain that the nation is facing a manpower crisis.

THE marching record of the British Army is held by a Commando unit that covered sixty-three miles in full marching order in a little more than sixteen hours. As the men neared the end of their grueling day their principal concern was whether they would reach their destination in time to attend a dance that evening.

New York, joining cities and villages in every State of the Union, holds its three-day Victory Garden Harvest Show in Grand Central Palace, with the doors opening for a preview at 6 P.M. tomorrow. This Victory Garden Harvest Show, staged for the benefit of the emergency needs of the families of our armed forces, is the first truly Autumn show ever held in New York.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Based on an unbroken tradition of 110 years of educational service, the Peekskill Military Academy will begin its academic year Monday with a record enrollment and with a series of innovations stressing the place of its cadets in the national war effort.

While five price-controlled foods have remained unchanged in retail price since price ceilings were put on them, five foods exempt from ceilings now cost from 24 to 46 per cent more than they did last March, a spot check made by the New York District Price Office revealed yesterday.

A map of Russian weather, published in this newspaper the other day, suggested that General Winter will not do for Hitler's enemies what legend inaccurately says he did for the enemies of Napoleon. In 1940 Britain and her friends longed for the coming of the rain and fog that would make daylight bombing difficult and invasion impossible.

Harry Lundeberg, president of the Sailors Union of the Pacific, declared yesterday that the seamen's training school established by his union a year ago was a success. The S.U.P., an affiliate of the International Transport Workers Federation, operates this training school for young American seafarers in San Francisco.

The social, economic and political changes taking place in the world today will be stressed in a series of courses dealing with the role of education in a country at war, to be offered this term by the City College School of Education, Dr. Esek Ray Mosher, dean, announced yesterday.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Establishment of a special collection of original historical and cultural New York State source materials at Cornell University was announced today by President Edmund E. Day.

The impact of the war on the development of the motion picture as a fine art will be analyzed by more than 100 students in the Hunter College evening division during the Fall semester, which begins tomorrow.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 19 -- When the Germans got the news last week that their meat ration was to be increased by just under two ounces weekly and their bread ration by five times that amount, there was no public jubilation to correspond with the glaring headlines composed by the Berlin Propaganda Ministry for the press to announce the event, say returning travelers.

THE Mutual Broadcasting System, under the guidance of the energetic Fred Weber, is beginning to pick up speed by way of preparing its Fall offerings. Although MBS bigwigs were not inclined to discuss it, the network's major acquisition was expected to be the Philadelphia Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Eugene Ormandy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Ferdinand Eberstadt, formerly a New York financial man, has been transferred from the chairmanship of the Army and Navy Munitions Board to a vice chairmanship in charge of programs and schedules for the War Production Board, Donald M. Nelson, WPB chief, said today.

Columbia University will begin its 189th academic year on Wednesday, when students and faculty will gather in the McMillin Academic Theatre at 3:30 P.M. to hear an address by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

STRATFORD, Conn., Sept. 19 -- Rufe Watson, veteran Washington skeet star, paced a strong field at the Remington Gun Club today, taking the .410 and 20-gauge events for a wide lead in the high-over-all competition in the North American skeet championships.

Defending his radio appeal of last Sunday to the city's little boys, asking them to write to him in confidence about places where their fathers gambled or bet on horses, Mayor La Guardia last night attacked the city's newspapers for printing racing news and information.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- An unusually clear example of how medical education and personnel are being geared to war is furnished in a report regarding the University of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry released today by Dr. George Packer Berry, assistant dean.

LONDON -- Right now the prison camps of Germany are in the grip of examination fever. Officers and Armies, who have been studying in their spare time for a year or more, are sitting at desks and taking examinations set by educational bodies in Great Britain.

THE BOOK MOBILIZATION, 1255 Broadway, New York City, is basing its plans for the national promotion of the "Victory Book of the Month" on Sterling North's original idea, the "Victory Book of the Week."
PULLMAN, Wash., Sept. 19 -- The fighting faculty members of Washington State College are opening up against the Axis with both barrels simultaneously.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 19 -- Mexico's problems were listed today as a shortage of essential materials for production, expansion of credit, greater exports and means of transportation, by President Manuel Avila Camacho in addressing the representatives of the Chambers of Commerce of Mexico.

PLAYGOERS in Britain today must balance the inconveniences of playgoing against the pleasures of playseeing. That the latter tip the balance easily is proved by some thirty theatres being open in London alone, with most of them playing to excellent business.

The Summer vacation conventionally ends when the August leaf is torn from the calendar. But this year many workers find their two weeks' furlough facing them in September after the Summer hotels and camps have been closed. Hence the question "What to do?" in order to get the badly needed change of environment is a constant topic of conversation.
BOSTON, Sept. 19 -- Mel Ott hit the jackpot at Braves Field today and gave the Giants a victory over Casey Stengel's crew that was measured by 7 to 6.

Special salvage collection days for the five boroughs in the city's intensified drive for scrap metal were announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia. The first collection will be made in Queens on Oct. 2 when ninety borough trucks and 400 trucks of the Department of Sanitation will go from street to street.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The new aircraft carrier Lexington will be launched next Saturday, less than five months after her namesake ship of war was sunk in the battle of the Coral Sea.

THE reading public does not usually encourage attempts by an established writer to experiment in a new genre. Not only must the cobbler stick to his last, but he must keep turning out shoes of the same pattern J.B. Priestley, however, has no reason to complain of the reception given to "Blackout in Gretley."

NATIONAL Socialist militarism, as Dr. Fried conceives of it, is neither a monstrous potion brewed unwittingly by the treaty-makers of Versailles nor a formula expressive of the average German's idea of the good society.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- To inform service men and civilian war workers absent from their homes because of the war how they can exercise their voting franchise in the Fall elections, the Office of War Information issued an eighty-page pamphlet today outlining in non-technical terms what rights of absentee voting are provided by the States.
WHAT wonderful parties those were, given in the old Dutch town of Veere by Hendrik Willem van Loon and his friend Frits and -- never to be lost sight of -- his other friend, Desiderius Erasmus!

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The admonition to Americans not to underestimate the fighting spirit of the Japanese, given in a speech at Syracuse, N.Y., yesterday, by Joseph C. Grew, former United States Ambassador in Tokyo, was promptly pounced upon by Japan's propagandists today as a theme for radio broadcasts.

Can a man or a nation be at the same time consciously selfish and consciously bent on suicide? That is the double accusation made by some of Britain's harshest critics on this question of the second front.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- In recent accounts of violent military actions the corps of reporters maintained by the independent press of the United States, Great Britain and Canada lived up to the best traditions of their dangerous craft. The eyewitness stories of the commando raid at Dieppe and of the sinking of the Yorktown included many examples of accurate, graphic reporting.

WASHINGTON, Sept 19 (Science Service) -- A novel method by which an airplane can leisurely deliver and pick up mail or other matter from the ground without landing is described in United States patent No. 2,295,537 issue to Verne R. Anderson of Tucson, Ariz.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The German sweep through the Caucasus has reached Stalingrad and choked off the river traffic of the Volga, but it would be a mistake to think that all of the military and economic lifeblood thus drained from Russia is flowing into the veins of Hitler's war machine.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- To decide this war finally the Allies must invade the Continent or Germany must invade the British Isles, and in either case the prelude is certain to be an air slugging match in which the rival air forces will strive to knock out each other.

Captain Edward Macauley, Deputy War Shipping Administrator in charge of training, announced last week the acquisition of the Inn-by-the-Sea, widely known hotel located at Pass Christian, Miss., for the Merchant Marine Cadet Corps.

MIDDLETOWN, N.J., Sept. 19 (AP) -- The pilot and lone occupant was killed late today when an Army fighter plane crashed in flames near the estate of J. Wright Brown, president of Editor and Publisher, newspaper trade magazine.

The Allied Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $879,147 in the three months ended on July 31 after a provision of $1,000,000 for Federal income and express profits taxes and other charges, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (U.P.) -- Senator Patrick McCarran of Nevada, leader of the Senate silver group, disclosed today plans to introduce legislation increasing the legal silver purchase price from 71.1 cents to $1.29 a fine ounce to step up production.

SABOTAGE is explosion, fire, and terror. Its chief practitioners are fiendishly clever men with faint foreign accents who are usually aided and abetted by slinky, scheming women with curves and charms utterly irresistible to wide-eyed Americans possessing information vital to the United States.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- The Football Giants evened the score with the Army All-Stars before a capacity crowd of 35,000 in Archbold Stadium tonight when they vanquished the Western division of the soldiers' task force, 10 to 7.

BOSTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- About 1,700 street car and bus operators in Eastern Massachusetts voted today in favor of a strike to enforce demands for higher wages and a change in working conditions, but delayed further action pending a meeting with the board of trustees of the system on Monday.

GALESBURG, Ill., Sept. 19 -- Whatever features of the current intensified program at Knox College survive the war, faculty members are agreed after its trial during the Summer quarter that at least one innovation which must certainly be permanently retained is the practice of meeting all classes five times a week, with a normal student load limited to three courses.

As colleges and universities throughout the country resume activities this week, one of the most momentous years in the history of higher education will get under way. On every campus, regardless of size, the influence of the war will be a powerful factor in shaping the curriculum.

IT is no reflection on Mr. Bendiner's insight to say that there are few facts in this book which readers of, say, this newspaper could not easily know, and that the criticism which Mr. Bendiner makes of the State Department is equally familiar.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A statement issued tonight by the Finnish Legation said that Finland "wants to cease fighting as soon as the threat to her existence has been averted and guarantees obtained for her lasting security."

MOSCOW, Sunday, Sept. 20 -- Surging back with renewed vigor, Russian soldiers fighting for the very life of Stalingrad drove the Nazis out of several streets within the city yesterday and "wiped out" about a company of German riflemen, the Red Army announced officially today.

Weather conditions exerted an adverse effect upon expansion of retail trade here last week. Estimates indicated average sales volume declined about 2 per cent under the same week of last year. Fairly high temperatures tended to check consumer interest in Fall apparel and spotty conditions developed toward the week-end.

The girls of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, who have gone to work to help shipfitters, loftsmen and welders in one of the East's most important construction and repair bases, are 200 strong now and growing. Yesterday they acquired counselors who will give them guidance and advice on any question of adjustment that may arise in their new work.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- A new kind of journalism has sprung up in occupied Holland. Heroic reporters are daily risking their lives to dig up stories that can bring them no Pulitzer Prizes, but only death sentences from the Germans.

Prime Minister Churchill and Averell Harriman, President Roosevelt's special ambassador, each made report to the public last week of their recent momentous visit to Moscow and of their talks there with the Russian Chief of State. Mr. Churchill rejoiced in the alliance between Britain, America and Russia which "Hitler has forced upon us."

The city, built by the toil of the young nation and the skill of foreign engineers, from which machines to cultivate the Russian harvests were poured out, now is a vast caldron in which two armies with burning hate grapple for a decision.
A READER of the Netherlands Nazi organ the Volk en Vaderland recently asked, "Why is the music of Tchaikovsky prohibited in Holland?"

Burdened with inventories 25 per cent larger than last year and a drop in sales of from 30 to 35 per cent, a serious credit problem has been created in the men's clothing industry, with manufacturers turning cautious on making further shipments, credit men stated yesterday.

The month of September is the most satisfactory time to seed lawns in the vicinity of New York. The experiences of many practical gardeners attest this. Grass sown in September has ample opportunity to send its roots down into the warm moist earth and to become established before the onset of hard freezing weather.

BERTRAM FOWLER writes of the terrific reconstruction problems that will confront the United Nations when the present conflict is ended. He presents these problems clearly and offers suggestions for their solutions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- With the program of rationing, ceilings and price controls now about nine months old, enforcement officials of the Office of Price Administration and the Compliance Branch of the War Production Board are intensifying their efforts to stamp out the black-market operator.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Russians announced officially today that Col. Gen. Paul Ludwig von Kleist, commander of the First German Tank Army, had been killed in fighting in the Mozdok area of the Caucasus.

Lippy Leo Durocher's fading champions walked into a 5-4 victory over the dungeon-dwelling Phils in the eleventh inning at Ebbets Field yesterday and thereby reduced the first place margin of the idle Cardinals to two and one-half games.

Commenting yesterday upon the bills in the Senate and House in Washington to prevent inflation of prices, the Uhlmann Grain Company expressed the opinion that adoption of either measure "would pretty nearly bring" organized grain exchanges "to the crossroads."

Because of activity in the low-priced shares, business on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was the largest for a Saturday since Aug. 22, but prices drifted irregularly and closed dull and mixed. Sales totaled 178,480 shares, against 116,450 for the preceding two-hour session.

IN this day good stories of contemporary farm life are all too rare in the reading diet of younger children, those of 6 to 8 or 9 who have graduated to more substantial fare than picture books. For them this story of Jobie seems emphatically right.

Miss Margaret Hickey of St. Louis, Chief of the new Women's Advisory Committee of the Manpower Commission, will be good-naturedly put "on the spot" next Thursday during a conference on "The Role of Women in the War Effort," at the Hotel Roosevelt.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 19 -- Why French labor should be conscripted at this stage for German benefit is best told by the Germans themselves. Explanations from Vichy need reading between the lines; those from the Reich are forthright.

A NEW sinking spell came over retail trade last week due to weather conditions and perhaps to the prominence given to the heavy taxation that lies ahead. Pre-Labor Day business made retailers feel quite hopeful of what the Fall would offer in trade but they have started to question prospects again.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 19 -- Following are excerpts from the prepared address of Secretary Knox before the American Legion session:

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Sept. 19 (U.P.) -- Wendell L. Willkie made theatrical history last night. He delayed the Bolshoi Theatre's traditionally prompt opening curtain for fifteen minutes and kissed the prima ballerina after the performance.

FOUR hundred years ago the first white men set foot on the soil of the present State of California. Wherefore California is entitled in September to a birthday cake with a candle for every year since 1542.

LONDON, Sept. 19 (U.P.) -- Yugoslav sources here said tonight that captured planes, operating from a secret airdrome in Serbia, were making sudden deadly attacks on Axis troop columns and occupation garrisons in Yugoslavia.

LONDON, Sept. 19 (U.P.) -- Large formations of British planes were reported today by the German Transocean News Agency to have flown over Southern Sweden in several waves last night and early this morning, but British quarters had no knowledge of any Royal Air Force operation in that area.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Moving to aid the war scrap collection drive, the American Industries Salvage Committee plans to distribute to housewives next week a check list of more than 100 household and farm items which may have been discarded by their owners. The War Production Board, in telling of the plan today, said that the discarded materials were essential to war manufacturing.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- Plans are nearing completion for the annual Clarence H. Geist Memorial Golf Tournament to be held at the Seaview Country Club, Oct. 16, 17 and 18.

SANTA FE, N.M. -- Color lights up the display which nature provides each Fall among the mounrains and valleys of Southern Colorado and Northern New Mexico -- gold, brilliant red, cobalt blue, and the deep green of pines and spruces. Scores of artists come annually to this exhibition.

MUSEUMS set the pace in the exhibition field last week with six events in five institutions. Perhaps of the widest general interest was the display of posters from the United Nations at the Riverside, where nearly 300 examples present all manner of phases of war and defense activities.

Main floor and basement trade was good in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles last week, according to the survey for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. The call for dresses, coats and suits was fairly good.

With production at capacity and prices controlled, the Federal Government pays something like 75 per cent of any wage increase granted in industry, according to Oliver F. Wadsworth, writing in The Exchange, magazine of the New York Stock Exchange.

A satisfaction peculiarly its own attaches to the growing of hardy flowering bulbs. As a class they possess a particular charm, producing flowers of remarkable beauty that are doubly welcome so early in the season. Nor is their culture difficult, for with a little planning and a wise selection of those kinds that are dependably good, the planter is assured of successful results as he can be in any gardening enterprise.
The annual New Jersey mixed pair tournament will be played next Sunday at Mosque Hall in Newark. Two sessions will be played, of which the first will begin at 2 P.M.

The death of a neurasthenic in a New York hotel may be made to look like suicide. But it isn't. And the dead man's real name is not the one under which he had been living at the hotel. Just how all this is mixed up with the Sunday-supplement ambitions of that clever young syndicate editor, Tony Young, is something for the author to think up, and then unravel, as best he may.

OUT in the Middle West farmers have a saying -- "hogs are just corn on the hoof." There's a lot of truth in that description, and if you add in roughage and grass along with grain, it holds good for cattle and other meat animals as well as for hogs. All those animals are vegetable matter on the hoof; feeds and pasture are the raw materials, and each animal is a small processing plant.

Carrying on the tradition of forebears who had served the Army Signal Corps in the past, a flight of 200 young homing pigeons added their skill to the current State campaign for war bonds and stamps yesterday by racing from New York to Albany with messages for Governor Lehman.

It would be unfair, as Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau has pointed out, to call the voluntary war bond program a "failure." The truth is that a magnificent job has been done by the volunteers throughout the country who have been pushing the sale of bonds and stamps.

BOSTON Not that the speed of traffic in downtown Boston was ever enough to scare any one, but the disappearance of motor sightseeing buses has brought to this city a renewed appreciation of a slow pace for leisure-time travel.

This is a paint year in home decoration. For paint is one commodity not very much affected by priorities, and painting is a field in which the amateur soon learns to shine. Homemakers who are having their walls freshened are working for new effects in color, since this may be the one bit of redecoration their scheme of living allows this Fall.

For several years now the amount of planting done in the late Summer and Fall has shown a definite and steady increase. This year, more than ever, the amateur will do well to take full advantage of the opportunities which Fall planting offers.

SOMEWHERE IN THE PACIFIC, Sept. 19 -- The Japanese were still driving doggedly toward new goals this week, but their progress was small in several theatres and the enemy was commencing to feel the growing strength of American striking power.

DETROIT, Sept. 19 -- There have been few times during the last six years when the over-all labor picture in the Detroit area has been quite as orderly as it is at the present time. It has been relatively free from serious or crippling strikes during 1942, the workers in the automobile and allied industries having pretty well lived up to their pledge to outlaw strikes for the duration.

WORCESTER, Mass, Sept. 19 -- Higgins Mechanical Engineering Laboratories, the major structure used for educational purposes at Worcester Polytechnic Institute, will be open for use with the start of the first semester on Thursday, Oct. 1.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 19 -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, director of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps, told delegates at the annual national convention of the American Legion Auxiliary today that total war had proved itself "no respecter of sex" and has shown that women are essential to the military tasks ahead for the country.

Appointment of Dr. Alice V. Keliher of New York University as chairman of child care development and protection for the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, Greater New York CDVO chairman.

AT length the "Flight" mural by James Brooks has been installed in the Marine Terminal at La Guardia Airport. Upon it, in the artist's studio, he and his assistants worked for nearly three years. This proves to have been time well spent.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 19 (AP) -- George McAfee and company of the Jacksonville Naval Air Station let loose a blast of football power in the third quarter to crush a stubborn but outclassed Florida team, 20 to 7, before 8,500 fans today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A Navy communique:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- A program which would force Americans to buy some $15,000,000,000 worth of government bonds annually to help finance the war and control inflation may be put before Congress after it disposes of the tax bill, it was learned today.

Announcement that United States Army engineers have surveyed one-third of a proposed railroad route to Alaska has been received enthusiastically in the Pacific Northwest, where both press and public have been apprehensive since the Japanese landings in the Aleutian Islands.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 19 -- Nominated for Governor for the ninth time at the Socialist State Convention here today, Mayor Jasper McLevy of this city opened his campaign with a bitter attack on the Republican and Democratic parties in his acceptance speech, which was broadcast tonight.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Johnny Wittig, star Jersey City right-hander, hurled 10 and one-third innings of hitless, runless baseball today but lost a heartbreaking 1-to-0 decision to Clay Lambert of Syracuse when the Chiefs pushed the only run of the game over in the thirteenth to take the opening chapter of the final series for the International League's Governors' Cup.

GUGLIELMO FERRERO'S "The Reconstruction of Europe" was published in this country just a year ago. Although it is probably the greatest single contribution to clarity in political thinking that our generation has seen, its effect has been negligible so far as one is able to ascertain.

From now until mid-October is evergreen moving time. Growth has ceased, the water requirements of the foliage have lessened and the warm soil is still favorable to root activity. Evergreens, therefore, become established sooner and experience less setback when moved at this time of year.

THINGS move fast these days. Here it is September and the climax of a big football campaign is coming up, the meeting of the Colonel Neyland detachment of the all-Army team and the Great Big Bears at Fenway Park today.

WHEN Emlyn Williams's "The Corn Is Green" was the toast of the town in the Autumn of 1940 this department cabled him a request for an article about living in London during the great bombing. At that time he was reported to be holing up in the basement of his house under the primitive conditions generally prevailing at the most frightful period in London's history.

STREAMS FROM THE SUN -- Magnetic storms that interrupt radio communications and cause magnetic needles to become jumpy may be due to holes in the ionosphere, the electrical "mirror" high above the ground which reflects radio waves back to earth. The holes are punched by streams of atomic fragments from the sun.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 17 (Delayed) -- In an effort to quell a new outburst of fierce guerrilla assaults in Yugoslavia the German High Command this week ordered the instant withdrawal of all Italian troops from Croatia and called on Elite Guard regiments and regular German armored forces along with fresh troops from the Bulgarian Fifth Army.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Twenty-three officers and men who distinguished themselves during the Coral Sea battle have received decorations for heroism in action. Nineteen of these men served on the aircraft carrier Lexington, which was sunk after inflicting heavy damage on the enemy.
MOSCOW, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Today's Soviet communique:

THERE has been some apprehension from time to time in the radio industry that there might be a serious shortage soon in receiver vacuum tubes and other replacement parts if the government does not relax the wartime ban on such products.

A series of war training courses in engineering, science and management will be offered at City College in cooperation with the United States Office of Education, beginning in October and continuing eight to sixteen weeks, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Albert B. Newman, dean of the School of Technology and regional adviser of the program in the metropolitan area.

ALTHOUGH the new season is just getting under way, our sculptors have lost no time in asserting themselves. On the seventh-floor terrace roof of the International Building, Rockefeller Center, the Sculpturs Guild is holding its annual outdoor show.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Sept. 19 -- Entrance of the United States into the war has brought an increased interest in American history and government on the part of students at Indiana University.

Ten days remain before the Oct. 1 deadline set by President Roosevelt in his demand for anti-inflation legislation from Congress; twelve days have passed since he asked for action. The President sought legislative sanction to go beyond the restrictions of the Price Control Act of last January and stabilize farm prices, promising, if this were done, to stabilize wages too.

While conceding the absolute necessity of strict wartime controls on foreign trade activities, freight forwarders here asserted last week that recent actions and rulings by government agencies seemed to have been drafted without due regard to the ultimate adverse effect upon the operations of American export trade.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A dynamic individual with the typically American record of advancement from office boy to president of a big company was busy directing the far-flung affairs of the Union Pacific system last Monday. Tuesday afternoon he was in Washington, summoned by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, to take over what the board chairman admittedly called one of the toughest jobs in the country.

Autumn is the time to plant hardy Winter bulbs to enrich the beauty of the Spring rock garden. Planted in the rock pockets and protected by a covering mulch, many different subjects will be found to be hardy and colorful.

IF Mr. and Mrs. Brown, parents of Harold Heavyside, familiarly known as Poo-Poo, hadn't sent him out of the house one busy Saturday morning they would have spared themselves some trouble but they would also have missed some unique experiences and a lot of fun, for that was the day Poo-Poo brought the dragon home.

Oswald D. Heck, Speaker of the Assembly, and Joe R. Hanley, majority leader of the State Senate, conferred here yesterday with Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor; State Chairman Edwin F. Jaeckle, and Herbert Brownell Jr., State campaign manager, on getting out the vote for the State ticket.

FROM Berlin one notes that not only broadcasting hours and programs are falling short, but propaganda stations are beginning to disappear from the air, no doubt for needed junk. Most noticeable is the disappearance of the powerful Berlin broadcaster to Spain (12.13 mc's).

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Scoring once in every quarter and carried along on the accurate right arm of Tommy Farmer, Iowa opened its football season today with a none-too-impressive 26-to-7 victory over Washington University of St. Louis.

FLAGSTAFF, Ariz., Sept. 19 -- One of the most important educational developments at Arizona State Teachers College in recent years is a long-range conservation program carried on in the training school and throughout the college. Instigated in 1937, the program is designed to teach man to make the best possible use of the many natural resources of this country.

During the first eight months of 1942 the number of dog shows held in the United States fell off between 25 and 30 per cent, while the number of field trials decreased by nearly 40 per cent. This situation is attributable, of course, to the entry of this country into the all-out world war.

YOUNG New Yorkers have returned, however reluctantly, from beach and camp, to the never-changing verities of mathematics and the ever-changing complexity of maps. And just how successfully they will cope with them is not entirely up to the youngsters themselves.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 19 -- In commemoration of the eleventh anniversary of the Mukden incident, an exhibition held here today compared the rich resources of the northeast with the rest of China by means of maps, charts and diagrams.

Reflecting uncertainty over developments in Washington with respect to anti-inflation legislation, cotton prices drifted lower yesterday in the short session on the New York Cotton Exchange. At the close, active futures contracts showed net losses of 7 to 10 points.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 19 -- Georgia had Frankie Sinkwich, and the All-America was what it took to beat the University of Kentucky, 7 -- 6, today before a gasping crowd of 10,000.

Two years ago the tide of air power turned definitely against the Axis. On Sept. 15, 1940, R.A.F. fliers shot down 185 German planes over England, ending Hitler's hope of conquering Britain from the air. That destruction of a single day did not seem then to mark the turning point.

Russian, English, Netherland and Chinese delegates to the International Student Assembly held in Washington early this month will take part in two six-week tours of American colleges under the sponsorship of the International Student Service and the National Student Federation of America, according to an announcement yesterday by Trude W. Pratt, general secretary of the Student Service.

ONE must speak about this book with high praise. It deals with very important subjects of the day and perhaps of the age: the stakes and strategy in the Middle East It is well informed and detailed, so that both the specialist and the layman can read it with profit.

With the opening of the Fall semester at Hunter College tomorrow, new officers of the student self-government association will begin the term's work by introducing a program of war activities. Doris Rhodes, recently elected president, will head all student affairs, assisted by Virginia Ryan, vice president; Doris Rubenstein, secretary, and Marion Klein, treasurer.

BOSTON, Sept. 19 -- The Eastern Army All-Stars, who for a warm-up took on and beat two other top-flight pro elevens during the week, were rated tonight an even bet against the champions of the National League -- the Chicago Bears.

LONDON, Sept. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Unbeaten Blackpool, favored by many to take the Football League's title, Northern Division, routed Bury by 11 -- 1 today for a total of twenty goals in the last two games. Last week Blackpool beat the same club, 9 -- 1.

Although it came all too late to do any good, Joe Cronin's Red Sox did manage to gain a measure of pleasure and satisfaction from their efforts yesterday as they opened their final visit of the year at the Stadium.
A High, Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

At midnight tomorrow the first two months of gasoline rationing by coupon will have been completed. The No. 1 coupons in the basic "A" books will be as worthless as cancelled postage stamps; and the No. 2 coupons for the next two-months period will become valid.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A policy of complete denial of fuel oil rations for heating apartment houses and commercial, industrial and institutional establishments which can convert to coal and fail to do so was announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

A great many people -- more this Fall season than in years past -- will be heading within the next few weeks for the mountains, the Jersey shore, New England vacation spots, the Southern resorts, New York City, a visit with the folks back home.
Water lilies at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden are now at the peak of their bloom. The huge blossoms -- in all colors and shades -- are displayed in the conservatory plaza pools.

Now that the Baruch committee's report has dispelled much of the confusion surrounding the rubber program, industrial and engineering executives who are engaged in building a great synthetic rubber industry here feel that they can proceed with confidence.

LONDON, Sept. 19 (U.P.) -- The Norwegian Government disclosed tonight that a mass protest by Norwegian workingmen has balked a coup by which Major Vidkun Quisling hoped to bring Norway into the war as an Axis satellite.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Hardy lilies grow best when kept out of the soil for the least possible time; any available now, such as Madonnas and others which seedsmen receive early, are best planted as soon as obtainable. . . . Don't let crab grass seed if you want clean lawns and borders next year; root it out, cut it, burn it off with a torch -- but don't let it go to seed.

FITZROY DAVIS is a young man who survived the Orson Welles tour in "Julius Caesar," played on the road with Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne and was among those present for the seven Broadway performances of "Good Hunting."

As Patrolmen Charles Winter and John J. Dunston of the Oak Street station passed Louis Shapiro's luncheonette at 21 Ann Street at 1 o'clock yesterday morning they noticed a dim light inside and one of the windows up.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Sept. 20 (AP) -- A communique:

"THE sermon delivered in the East Room of the Executive Mansion, April 19, 1865, at the funeral of Abraham Lincoln by the Rev. Phineas D. Gurley" is reprinted under the title "Faith in God" by the Department of History of the Office of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. by Davis Warde, Inc., of Pittsburgh.

ALTHOUGH this novel is said to be based upon the life of one of America's most colorful opera singers, no reader should look askance at it on that account. Henry Beetle Hough, who wrote "Country Editor," has imposed upon his imagination few, if any, of the restrictions which make the usual biographical novel a stilted and lifeless affair, neither good biography nor good romance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- While farm and labor groups in Congress moved to battle stations today for the protection of their interests in next week's floor fights over the final terms of the anti-inflation authorization program, the American consumer in general was put into the picture by a substitute resolution, sponsored by Senator Danaher of Connecticut.

RANDOLPH, Vt. -- Lake Champlain lights up with an arresting charm from late September to Columbus Day. In that span a southward migration of shore birds spreads along its 100-mile waterway, sprinkling the historic bays with the plover and snipe families, unfamiliar birds to all save gunners.

WHEN Howard Barlow conducts the Columbia Broadcasting Symphony at 3 this afternoon on WABC, he will be celebrating his fifteenth anniversary with the Columbia Broadcasting System. Even more important, he will be celebrating a milestone in a stimulating career that has affected not only music on the air and the public attitude toward it but the art of program-making in the concert halls as well.

The paragraph in Sack Gould's radio news column last Sunday, which took the radio drama critics to task for having neither courage nor a critical opinion, may have some basis of fact. However, let us permit those carefree gentlemen of the air waves to bear the burden of their own shame, while I stubbornly object to the aspersion cast upon the only female member of that fraternity.

Amid excitement of various kinds, including a disqualification in one stake and a dead heat in the other, the Aqueduct meeting came to an end yesterday when 23,254 persons went from one thrill to another on their way to betting $1,571,010 during the afternoon.

Most wholesale markets were busy last week, with mails heavy and many buyers in town working on immediate and Christmas needs, according to the weekly report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

LAST Monday Charles Dana Gibson celebrated his seventy-fifth birthday at his Summer home on an island off the coast of Maine. This week he will start for Cincinnati to hang a hundred or so paintings and drawings representative of a lifetime of work. The first item in the catalogue will be a drawing dated 1888, the last a painting signed in 1942.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- A sudden shift of British bomber operations to extensive overnight mine-sowing in Nazi coastal waters was followed today by the announcement that civilians would be removed from an area of England facing the North Sea and a report that the jittery Germans are evacuating Belgian families from Ostend on short notice.
There's plenty of evidence practically everywhere nowadays that the race is in no danger of dying out and that a lot of young women are interested in getting in supplies of baby things.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY IN EGYPT, Sept. 5 -- Patrol activity frequently mentioned in army communiques may suggest to many merely the filling in of space when there is nothing else to record. When no battle is joined patrol activity represents about the only ground fighting there is excepting artillery duels, with which, likely enough, it has some close connection.

Sounding a solemn note at the approach of the Jewish holy day, Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, speakers in temples and synagogues throughout the city yesterday called upon the Jews to be courageous in the face of world persecutions at the hands of the dictators.

Three leading factors are today the keys of future passenger-car design. The influences now shaping new models to be built after the war may be summed up, in order of their importance, as (1) automotive science, (2) industry practice and (3) public attitude.
OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 19 -- Progressively diminishing manpower is probably the number one problem of the farmer.

UNLIKE some dauntlessly profiled screen Apollos the name of Ray Milland did not suddenly catapult before the public eye in billboard letters six feet high. It achieved a 24-sheet immortality by slow degrees, growing in size so gradually and imperceptibly that when at last his name began to be placed above the titles of the films themselves, hardly any one -- unless it was Mr. Milland's accountant -- noticed that a star had been born.

AS the leader of the orchestra for "Stage Door Canteen," Raymond Paige is quietly reversing show-business tradition these Thursday evenings over WABC. Instead of being required to reconcile the activities of the program's guests to an existing musical aggregation, Mr. Paige is privileged to pattern the band to the needs of each week's broadcasts and tackle with authority anything from full-fledged opera to "Beat Me, Daddy, Eight to the Bar."

The opening night performance of the Rodeo at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 7 will be a benefit for the American Women's Hospital. Reserve Corps, which was organized in April, 1940, by Dr. Luvia Willard, who served overseas as a lieutenant in the Motor Corps of the American Women's Hospitals in the First World War.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- It can now be revealed that President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill held a debate early in June over the transatlantic telephone regarding use of the English language, in which both have considerable skill.

Two weeks have passed since the President called upon Congress to give him authority to control the cost of living. Ten days remain before the expiration of his ultimatum. Bills have been prepared by both branches of Congress; hearings have been held by a Senate committee; this week the issue is scheduled to be debated.
LONDON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

BESIDES the museum activities chronicled elsewhere on this page, a round dozen group and one-man exhibitions opened last week in the galleries. American art, new and old, was to the fore at the Kraushaar, Macbeth and Babcock galleries, while work principally modern European may be seen at the Buchholz and at Georgette Passedoit's.

Four transatlantic flying boats, three Clippers and a Flying Ace, arrived at the marine terminal, La Guardia Field, within the space of two and a half hours yesterday afternoon, with a total of 103 passengers, fifty-seven of them from Europe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The War Production Board acted today to make available for specified food and additional uses about 112,000,000 yards of sheetings, flannels, print cloth yarn fabrics, oshaburg cloth and tobacco cloth. The establishment of high priority ratings for orders placed by dairy supply manufacturers, textile converters and cloth merchants, the announcement said, is expected to provide an adequate supply of the commodities for their users.

Columbia and Manhattan battled for three hours yesterday in an informal scrimmage at Baker Field, with both elevens functioning best on the attack. It was the second scrimmage between the two squads and the last for the Lions, who open their season Saturday against Fort Monmouth.

IT has been nearly three hundred years since the voyageurs explored the lake country of Minnesota but it is still a land to try a youth's wits and courage and strength, as we are vividly reminded in this story of a fishing trip.

Every Army nurse who sails for duty overseas receives a bon voyage gift from the American Red Cross, which is selected and packed by volunteers at the New York chapter. The gift is a flowered ticking bag filled with a pocket-sized book, bar of chocolate, letter paper and envelopes, shoe strings, sewing kit, manicure set, lipstick and various toilet articles.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Senators defeated the Athletics in both games of a free-swinging double-header today, winning the first game by 8 to 3 and the nightcap by 11 to 9.

A.A. Alexander, supervisor of cargo clearance for the War Shipping Administration in the New York district, said last week that the condition of the port was "liquid" and that there was no congestion.

A New Yorker who returned to town after two years in Amnesia or some such place would notice changes in the street scene. Nowadays the taxi in a hurry runs through a little red cross instead of a big red light. It had better not do even that if the traffic policeman is looking.

OUT of Valley Forge came a little volume, bound in blue, which next to the Bible had more effect upon the creation of the United States of America than any other book. It was a drill manual written for the individualistic soldiers of the Continental Army by its first drillmaster, Baron von Steuben.

Some of the things children do and say for which elders think they should be "put in their place," or given "a good talking to," seem logical to the children. The 5-year-old who amiably hailed a gray-haired teacher. "Hello, Old Lady," was only doing as he was done by, as Peggy Dunn Brogan explains in Childhood Education for September.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 19 -- Veterans of the first World War enthusiastically applauded and cheered Secretary Knox, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, and Paul V. McNutt, Manpower Director, today when they joined in calling for complete national unity as an absolute essential for winning the war in speeches at the national convention of the American Legion.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The National Labor Relations Board divided two to one today in over-ruling objections of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and many coal operators to the certification of the Mine Officials' Union of America as the exclusive bargaining agency for fifty-six assistant foremen, fire bosses, weigh bosses and coal inspectors at three mines of the Union Collieries Coal Company at Oakmont, Pa.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 19 -- Wisconsin converted one of its opponent's third-period fumbles into a fourth-period touchdown today to beat a gallant Camp Grant football team, 7 to 0, before 15,000 spectators, who included hundreds of high school students and service men.

EMILY DICKINSON was elusive both as a poet and a woman. To portray her a heroine of a biographical novel is a task to confound any writer; to succeed in any degree, a notable achievement. One makes obeisance, therefore, to Laura Benet for her book, "Come Slowly Eden," which, in spite of obvious defects rooted in the subject's reserve rather than the author's limitations, captures the spirit of this rare personality.

Strongly urging the opening of a second front to relieve pressure on hard-pressed and beleagured Russian armies, Dean Alfange, American Labor party Gubernatorial candidate; Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti and prominent labor leaders yesterday called for immediate action by United Nations leaders at an open-air rally dedicating the new headquarters of Local 65 of the C.I.O. Wholesale and Warehouse Workers union at 13 Astor Place.

One of the events of each philatelic year is the issuing of the following year's Standard Postage Stamp Catalogue, which appears concurrently with the ushering in of the Fall season after the buying lethargy of Summer. The first section of the 1943 edition was released to the trade, and to collectors generally, last Tuesday by Scott Publications, Inc.

Edward P. Mulrooney, former Police Commissioner, has accepted the chairmanship of the New York City Committee of the United Seamen's Service, it was announced yesterday by Douglas P. Falconer, national executive director.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 19 -- Alsab whipped Whirlaway by the width of a whisker today in a $25,000 match race thriller that you had to see to believe.

ONE of our favorite memories of this war, we fancy, will always be a little scene we interrupted lately in a London studio. Our mind full of grave affairs, we came upon a number of motion picture executives in a huddle.

DETROIT, Sept. 19 -- An intensive scrap drive in ninety General Motors war plants from Connecticut to California has increased the country's stock-pile by a total of 531,000,000 pounds of iron, steel, copper, aluminum and other metals essential to the war effort, B.D. Kunkle, vice president in charge of manufacturing, reported today.

VICHY, Sept. 19 -- Chief of Government Pierre Laval today received extensive personal powers to dismiss government officials and even certain officials of private industry for any act of insubordination.

Members of the Police Department of New York City are "donating systematically to the transfusion supply for the armed forces," Major Gen. Robert C. Davis, executive director of the New York Red Cross, announced yesterday.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- The medal in the first member-guest handicap tournament, a four-ball best-ball affair, at the St. Andrews Golf Club today, went to Bertram T. Blake St., runner-up for the 1942 club championship, and Grant A. Peacock, who twenty-one years ago was runner-up for the metropolitan amateur crown.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Sept. 19 -- Teaching and research at Bryn Mawr College during the coming Winter will reflect the interest of faculty and students in aiding the war effort. Special research on the part of faculty members and graduate students, and new courses to train undergraduates for government service will be of importance.

With a program that is neither a war nor a peace curriculum, but which is geared to the present emergency, the New School for Social Research and the Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science will open for the Fall term on Sept. 28.

It's bitter cold in the haystack where Dick Hayes, bum extraordinary, is trying to find shelter; but the farm's big barn has been burned down. When he finally moves toward the house something swaying from a tree hits his shoulder in the darkness.

Prize awards in War Savings Bonds (maturity value) and cash totaling $500 will be paid for the sixty-four photographs making up the Salon Section of Good Photography in each issue, according to an announcement of this tri-yearly publication in its current issue, No. 9, which contains a full statement of the new policy.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- In the next to last special regatta of the season, held today by the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club out on Long Island Sound, winners were Joseph Merrill's International Feather, George Hinman's Atlantic Sagola, Phil Patron's S boat Kandahar and Adrian Iselin's Star Ace.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 19 -- Roosevelt Raceway brought its third year of harness horse racing to a successful close tonight after a season which frequently tested the resourcefulness of the Old Country Trotting Association, the sponsor.

KINGSTON, R.I., Sept. 19 -- A school of business administration will be established at Rhode Island State College, it was announced today by President Carl R. Woodward, following approval by the board of trustees. An outgrowth of the present Department of Economics, which is now a subdivision of the School of Science and Business, the new school will be the fourth major administrative unit of the college.

IN their 'teens boys and girls begin to think -- as their parents did before them -- that fathers and mothers are dear old fuss-budgets, living in the past, and they want to get out from under the family thumb.

Although some of the early birds got started yesterday, the college football season will begin in earnest this Saturday as the majority of the schools commence operations. A week later every one will have fallen into line.

Alcohol fuel instead of the more precious formulae of gasoline will be used this afternoon in an outboard regatta at East Paterson, N.J., near the Route 6 bridge. Two or three of these unique regattas were tried on near-by waterways last Spring as an emergency makeshift to obviate the necessity of using normal fuel now rationed in the East by Federal order.

Relatives of men in the armed services were advised yesterday by Randall J. LeBoeuf Jr., president of National Travelers Aid Associations, to make "no surprise visits" to men at their posts. In suggesting "ten commandments" for those visiting servicemen posts, Mr. LeBoeuf explained that its experience in 989 USO units had prompted USO Travelers Aid Service to formulate a set of rules for the guidance of visitors.

STEPHEN SPENDER'S work is a dilemma of poetry and politics which has bedeviled the best poets of our generation. What could he do or write, he asked, in 1934 when he was first published, that mattered, in a world living "under the shadow of war"?

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- Nazi plans for the establishment of a "corporative Norwegian Parliament," many of whose prospective members were to have sought the labor vote, have been foiled as a result of mass resignations from the Norwegian labor unions and employers' organizations, according to reports received here today by the Norwegian Telegraph Agency.

I believe that Mr. Churchill's recent statement on India in the Parliament will do incalculable damage to the cause of the United Nations by further aggravating the already dangerous Indian situation. With the Japanese at the very gates of India the urgent need at the moment is to break the political deadlock and rouse India's multitudes for war.

When the Renegotiation of Government Contracts provision was appended to the "Sixth Supplemental National Defense Appropriation Act of 1942," approved on April 28 (Section 403 of Public Law 528), taxation features of the measure appear not to have been taken into account.

It would be interesting and helpful if every editorial or magazine article discussing the relative virtues of American airplanes was preceded by an accurate biography of the writer revealing his special knowledge and qualifications, if any, plus any grounds for bias.

IRAN into a private the other day whom I hadn't seen for some months. The last time I had seen him we had talked about the pay raise for soldiers, then being debated. He had been quite definite about what he was going to do with his extra money.

Despite the hard-driving efforts of the nation's commercial banks, led by the big institutions in New York City, Chicago and other money centers, to increase lending to finance war industries, it begins to appear that steady contraction in lending for purely civilian consumer purposes will force eventually a continuing decline in the grand total of commercial loans.

BOULDER, Col., Sept. 19 -- To explore the impact of the war upon culture common to groups of departments, the University of Colorado will offer five new courses during the coming academic year, all under the general heading, "World Crisis."

No special restrictions will be invited upon duck hunters in the metropolitan area by the Coast Guard, it was officially announced yesterday. While many predictions were made as to regulations that might be enforced to prevent hunters with shotguns from going into our bays or marsh areas, the attitude of the Coast Guard is clear and leaves no room for conflicting interpretations.

BASE SOMEWHERE IN THE BRITISH ISLES, Sept. 19 -- Working ten or twelve hours daily and seven days weekly, 1,856 civilian workmen, all from the United States, have set up twenty-six buildings, including a huge machine shop, from the concrete flooring to the roof, in the past month at a great new United States Army Air Forces plane repair depot, it was disclosed to this correspondent today.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 19 -- Young China is becoming increasingly glider conscious, it was revealed today. Following the graduation of twenty-eight students from the Chengtu glider school last year these students were sent to the provinces to direct gliding and to give gliding lessons.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- United States Army Flying Fortresses attacked a strong Japanese naval force, which included battleships and cruisers, off the Solomon Islands last Monday (Solomons time) and scored "possible hits" on two battleships, the Navy announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A hint that the United States may seize French possessions in the Caribbean and cooperate with the British in seizing the French West African base at Dakar was given by The Army and Navy Journal today.

HARTFORD, Sept. 19 -- Two political contests, one for the Governorship between Robert A. Hurley, Democratic incumbent, and former Governor Raymond E. Baldwin, Republican, and the other between Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, Republican, and Representative LeRoy D. Downs, Democrat, for Representative in the Fourth Congressional District, are attracting wide attention both in and out of the State, because of the personalities involved.

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 19 -- Something new has been added to Creighton University's accelerated wartime study program. As a result, university officials expect to see undergraduate class "cuts" hit a new low during the current school year.

NOW the old friends are coming back, and with them some others who will be old friends in due time if they can find a public and make the grade, and so the early season airwaves suggest at once a reunion and the adventure of novelty.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Last midnight's communique: During the day of Sept. 19 our troops engaged the enemy in the area of Stalingrad and in the Mozdok area. No essential changes took place in other sectors.

Perhaps the best time to begin gardening with herbs is whenever any one will give you an herb plant or cutting or the seed from healthy plants. But if you can pick the season, September is an excellent time to plan for next year's herb garden.

BRONXVILLE, Sept. 19 -- When Sarah Lawrence College begins its fifteenth year Monday with a capacity enrollment of 291 students, every girl, as part of her contribution to the war effort, will take her turn at waiting on the tables in the dining room.

Smuggled out of Slovenia, the Yugoslav terrain which Germany and Italy conquered and divided, is evidence, released last week by Franc Snoj, Yugoslavia's Minister of State now in New York, that Germany is using postal paper to spread propaganda to the effect that the Nazi part of Slovenia is German regardless of the inhabitants' nationality.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- H.M.S. Urge, one of the smallest submarines in the British Navy, is reported missing and is presumed lost, the Admiralty disclosed today, also revealing it was a ship with a record surpassed by few.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- A work stoppage of "a few hours" ordered by the Federal Labor Union (A.F. of L.) at the General Chemical Company's Buffalo, (N.Y.) plant, the War Labor Board said, prompted its denial today of the union's request for a maintenance of union membership clause.

OXFORD, Ohio, Sept 19 -- Students returning to Western College, which began its eighty-eighth year on Sept. 15, found a variety of new courses offered in puppetry, play production, stagecraft, make-up and dramatic interpretation. These courses will be given by William Ireland Duncan and Mrs. Duncan, who have just joined the faculty.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 19 -- The Mineola Fair, which observed its 100th anniversary this year, closed tonight after a five-day exhibition which J. Alfred Valentine, president of the Queens-Nassau Agricultural Society, said was so well received a continuation of the fair next year might be deemed a certainty.

In the last few weeks there has been a "substantial improvement" in war contract awards to New York City firms, it was revealed here yesterday by George A. Sloan, City Commissioner of Commerce and chairman of the Mayor's Business Advisory Committee.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Winding up a four-month investigation of gambling conditions in the county ordered by Governor Lehman, the Rockland County May grand jury indicted today County Attorney Walter A. McDermott, Mrs. Helen Essex, town clerk of Orangetown and vice chairman of the Republican County Committee, and six other persons on charges ranging from perjury and conspiracy to contriving a lottery.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 19 -- A good-will exhibit depicting campus life and student activities at New Jersey College for Women is being flown this week to South America bearing 100th anniversary greetings to the University of Chile.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The problem of maintaining 5,000,000 trucks and more than 150,000 buses in all parts of the country in continued and more efficient operation despite rubber and gasoline restrictions is one which must be solved as an essential of the war effort, Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, declared tonight in an address over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Sept. 19 -- Beginning with the Fall term next week, the University of North Carolina, in a super speed-up program, will reduce the time required for graduation to thirty-three months, it was announced here by President Frank P. Graham.

Possibility of a shake-up in the administration of the National Nutrition Program was seen in the food trades last week in view of the apparent differences of opinion between the industry representatives on the one hand and the government leaders of the campaign on the other.

This is in answer to a letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Sept. 6, over the signature of David I. Ashe. Mr. Ashe referred to the recent symposium on the subject of the closed shop and characterized certain statements by Mr. Robertson and myself as fallacies.

All police guards of the two plants of the Todd Shipyards Corporation in Brooklyn and Hoboken have been sworn into the United States Coast Guard under a special agreement to increase security in plants engaged in urgent war tasks.

BALTIMORE, which has had a municipally supported symphony orchestra since 1916, will make a bid this season to build its orchestra into one of the major groups in the country. Heretofore the orchestra has depended solely on a civic grant of $43,000.

CONGRATULATIONS are in order all around on the Students' Dance Recitals series having found itself a new home. It will open its eighteenth season on Oct. 4, not at the Washington Irving High School, where it has held forth all these years, but in the new auditorium of the Central High School of Needle Trades at 225 West Twenty-fourth Street.
David I. Ashe, in his letter to the editor, made a statement that I would like to analyze a little more deeply than did Mr. Ashe. These are his words:

Hope of relief to thousands of sufferers from two of mankind's most baffling diseases, known respectively as migraine headaches and Meniere's disease, is held out in a new therapeutic approach to these disabling ills reported recently before the American Medical Association by Dr. Miles Atkinson of New York City.

JOSHUA CLUNK is as much of a character as Reggie Fortune, as all the H.C. Bailey fans know; and the amiable Reginald would have to confess to sharing one trait with the sly and unctuous Josh. They both have a genuine feeling for the neglected and downtrodden.

The placid green outfield of the Polo Grounds shook with exploding land mines last night and even the great steel girders of the grandstand throbbed as the Army's Chemical Warfare Service put on an unprecedented, ear-pounding show called "Action Overhead."

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Sept. 19 -- Mount Holyoke College's plan of the interdepartmental major, which enables students to cut across several different departments in selecting a major field, has been utilized to give to undergraduates an opportunity to major in American culture.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Sept. 19 -- The Iowa City naval cadets, launching crushing offensives by land and by air, handed a completely outclassed Kansas football team a terrific 61-to-0 defeat today. It was the worst setback in the fifty-three-year gridiron history of Kansas.

Wartime police precedure will be discussed at the forty-ninth annual conference of the International Association of Chiefs of Police at the Hotel Pennsylvania for three days beginning tomorrow. Mayor La Guardia will speak at the opening session tomorrow morning, as will Police Commissioner Valentine, Governor J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island and Hugh Clegg, assistant director Federal Bureau of Investigation.

ALBANY, Sept. 19 (AP) -- A further effort to reach New York voters in foreign military service will be made Tuesday in a conference of the State War Ballot Commission with Michael F. Walsh, Secretary of State.

New York University will begin its 111th academic year this week, with the curricula in its fourteen schools, colleges and divisions revised and expanded to meet wartime conditions, Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of the university, announced yesterday.

BENDIX, N.J., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Unanimous ratification of a "win-the-war" labor contract providing an average 10 per cent wage increase over present undisclosed scales for shop workers in the Bendix, Belleville and Lodi plants of Air Associates, Inc., was announced today by Local 969 of the United Aircraft Automobile, Aircraft and Agricultural Implement Workers of America (C.I.O.).

CONTRARY to custom, the music season will be launched in earnest not by some noted recitalist but with an ambitious production of a Viennese operetta, Karl Milloecker's "The Beggar Student," to be presented the coming week-end at the Cosmopolitan Opera House.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 4 -- Venezuela, for twenty-five years dependent upon unimpeded ocean transport for her necessaries and for the exportation of her petroleum, is engaged in an intensive program to return to an agrarian economy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (U.P.) -- Spokesmen for the Department of Justice said today that a civil action next month alleging anti-trust violations will be entered against six corporations engaged in the manufacture and distribution of gypsum products.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Flying Fortresses set fire to a Japanese cargo ship off New Guinea, the Allied Command reported today. The attack was geared with a continuation of heavy bombing and strafing of enemy bases at Lae and Buna, on the northeastern New Guinea coast, and Buka, in the northern Solomon Islands.

A "Recruiting for the Armed Forces" rally was held yesterday afternoon on the Mall in Central Park by 1,500 uniformed members of the National Security Women's Corps. The principal speaker was Mayor La Guardia, who praised the young business women for giving their leisure time for training and study.

DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 19 -- One of the East's leading young American-type cocker spaniels; Nonquitt Nola's Candidate, achieved his first best-in-show triumph today at the Ox Ridge Kennel Club's eighth annual all-breed exhibition at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 19 -- Demas, imported 7-year-old Vogel Jr. of Warrenton, Va., was awarded the grand championship in the hunter division at the fortieth annual Piping Rock horse show today.

THE Bost Records Company began business some weeks ago with albums devoted to songs of early America, the evolution of piano music and Latin-American songs. It has followed this ambitious start with four new albums which have either news or musical interest or both.

AUSTIN, Texas, Sept. 19 -- The 1942 Texas Longhorns look tough, fast and dangerous and the team's easy 40-to-0 victory over the Corpus Christi Naval Air Station team today should serve as a warning to all conference opponents.

With the return to the city of many members of society from Summer resorts -- where this last season the majority were actively engaged in various projects of the home front war effort -- plans are going forward here for various war relief and welfare enterprises that will enlist their support and cooperation through the Autumn and Winter months.

Promotion of John H. Towers, who has so ably headed the Bureau of Aeronautics, to be vice admiral is well deserved. His assignment to command of the Pacific Fleet Air Force will bring to that vital area the great range of practical flying experience which underlies his fine qualities of leadership.

THERE are many promising novels in the Autumn list: Conrad Richter's "Tacey Cromwell" -- long awaited by at least one reader -- a story of the old West; Eudora Welty's "The Robber Bridegroom," Nancy Hale's "The Prodigal Women." Marcia Davenport's "The Valley of Decision."

THAT organization known as USO-Camp Shows, organized about a year age to bring live entertainment to the men of the armed forces, seems to have been making a good account of itself. As the official agency designated for this purpose by the Army and Navy Departments, since last November it has been mighty busy.

IT was back in the bleak days of January, when the prospect appeared especially dark for any effective utilization of motion pictures in our national war effort, that this writer was beefing bitterly to Commander John Ford, U.S.N.R., in Washington.

Craig S. Vincent, assistant director of the domestic division of the recruitment and manning organization of the War Shipping Administration, was transferred to New York last week from Washington and named Atlantic Coast Regional Representative.
LONDON, Sept. 19 (U.P.) -- Adolf Hitler's reckless investment of blood and materiel to win control of Russia's treasures has netted him virtually no dividends. British economic experts said tonight.

Wexford Terrace, Inc., representing Bud A. Lipman and Oscar Lieberman, sold the seven-story garden-type apartments at 175-27 Wexford Terrace, corner of Dalney Road, Jamaica, L.I., to Gross-Morton, the well-known builders of one-family homes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Young Steve Juzwik, a first-year recruit from Notre Dame, and the veteran Sammy Baugh sparked the Washington Redskins to a 28-14 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers in a National Football League game before 25,000 fans today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Evidence of German-Japanese collaboration in military espionage here long before Pearl Harbor was disclosed today as the Federal Bureau of Investigation acknowledged that a Japanese agent was linked with the Nazi spy ring broken up in June, 1941, but that he escaped.

STRATFORD, Conn., Sept. 20 -- A Middlefield, Conn., apple grower took the all-bore title in the third annual North American skeet competition at the Remington Gun Club today, but had to share the spotlight with a Washington marksman who missed the chance of sweeping the four individual events by the margin of a single target.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 20 -- The estimate that more than a million gallons in gasoline ration stamps have been stolen from Connecticut Ration Board offices within the last few weeks, brought F.B.I. investigators here to assist the Detective Bureau of the city police force in tracing the gang that looted the local Ration Board of its entire stock of gasoline ration books early yesterday morning.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 20 -- Sergeant Vic Ghezzi, one-time P.G.A. champion, now stationed at Fort Monmouth, fired a 71 at the 22 other pros playing today in the Lakeville Club's pro-member tournament and none of them succeeded in matching it.

The Dodgers scored seven runs in two games with the Phils yesterday while the front-running Cardinals were getting just one in a pair with the Cubs, but the net result was the same. Both split their double-headers and Brooklyn remained two and one-half games out of first place with time running out rapidly.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- German claims, made tonight, said that a large Allied convoy carrying supplies to Russia had been shattered in an Arctic battle, but it was said here that the claims had been grossly exaggerated. The German High Command reported that of forty-five vessels attacked no fewer than thirty-eight were destroyed, plus six escorting warships.
The loneliest man in town this week-end was Warren Snyder.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, has agreed to investigate charges laid before the Senate Small Business Committee that manufacturers are discriminating against small retailers, Senator Murray, committee chairman, said today.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Following his annual custom of visiting Camp Smith here while the now Federalized 369th Infantry, Negro, New York National Guard unit of Harlem was in training on the reservation, Governor Lehman arrived in camp this afternoon and reviewed the Fifteenth Regiment of the New York State Guard, Harlem's successor to the old 369th.

[n recognition of the evolution l nf Xow York City into the style capital of tile world, the evening! session of the City College School of Business and Civic Administration. at Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street, will offer a series of fashion merchandising sessions, it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Sept. 20 -- A survey Just completed in Washington by the Citizens Bureau of Governmental Research of New York State recommends a reorganization of administrative machinery under which eighty agencies listed as now reporting directly to the President would be realigned under a War Cabinet of not more than seven members.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- While the uncertainties of the war preclude any authoritative forecasts of the ultimate strength to which the Army and Navy will grow, Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service Director, indicated today that more than 10,000,000 Americans would be under arms by the end of 1943.
VICHY, Sept. 20 -- First decrees in the application of the new compulsory labor law, which were published today, provide for a complete census of French workers.

AT AN AMERICAN BOMBER BASE IN THE MIDDLE EAST, Sept. 19 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The officers' baseball team had just licked the enlisted men 10 to 6 and over on the third base coaching line "the Chief," stood flushed and exuberant.

MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- A former metropolitan star, Grant A. Peacock, unattached, who has played practically no tournament golf for the past several seasons, had a taste of his former championship glory at the St. Andrews Golf Club today when he and his host, Bertram T. Blake Sr., won the member-guest handicap tournament.
