WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Called back to Washington after weeks of informal recess, members of Congress will begin tomorrow their attack on ways and means of blocking the threat of disastrous inflation -- a problem which President Roosevelt put up to them in a special message and a radio address thirteen days ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Brief Senatorial election campaigns without name-calling and with "honest and sincere discussion of local issues the only paramount dividing line" were urged today by Senator Joseph F. Guffey, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.

Assurances of patriotism are not convincingly reflected in continued strikes of labor on slightest pretext; in the demand of farmers to get their share of war prosperity, resulting in higher food prices; in politicians playing around with tax legislation, losing millions of revenue for the government for every day's delay, and who add other millions to cost of war production by holding up needed anti-inflation measures.

Uncertainties with regard to the drafting of new anti-inflation legislation were the dominating factors in the cotton market last week. Following a moderate up-turn in the early dealings on the announcement of the terms of the Senate bill, which indicated a higher ceiling on agricultural commodities than had been anticipated, the cotton market turned easier and the initial advance in prices was erased.

The President has recently called on the people to "strip civilian economy to the bone." We are ready and willing to do this; but the least we can expect of the President and Congress is to do their part to help us in controlling the ever-rising cost of living. I do not feel that this has been done.

In an effort to cut $3,500,000 from the school system's annual payroll the Citizens Budget Commission, Inc., issued yesterday a public protest against the practice of employing excess teachers, at full salary, to fill in for teachers who are on a sabbatical leave or long-term leave of absence.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Sept. 20 -- Labor's right to collective bargaining is at stake in this war, Governor Charles Edison of New Jersey told 3,000 local shipyard workers here today at service flag unveiling exercises of Local 15, Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Federal Reserve Board today reported a continued rise in industrial output in August and the first half of September. The rise in August brought the board's seasonally adjusted index up 3 points to 183 per cent of the 1935-39 average.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 20 -- Condemnation of the Laval Government for ordering the expulsion of alien Jews from unoccupied France and the drafting of French citizens for work in Germany was expressed this afternoon by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor.
An Admiralty and Air Ministry communique:
ABOARD A U.S. NAVY TRANSPORT PLANE, Somewhere in the Pacific, Sept. 13 (Delayed) -- You don't realize what distance means -- or "amphibious war" -- until you span the Pacific by air.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Charles (Red) Barrett's superb four-hit pitching sent Jersey City down to defeat again today, 4 to 0, as Syracuse took a 2-to-0 lead in the International League's final play-offs for the Governor's Cup.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

There is perhaps another duty to be added to the long and necessary list already formulated in Washington. It too will help win the war, or at least make the time of struggle a little less unpleasant.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- British commodity prices as measured by the Board of Trade index showed a further decline of 0.7 per cent in August compared with July. This fall is only the second to be recorded since the outbreak of the war.

In spite of unseasonably warm weather in many parts of the country, most wholesale markets experienced increased activity last week, according to the summary of activity prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

GREENCASTLE, Ind., Sept. 20 (U.P.) -- Two lieutenants and a corporal of the Army Air Corps stationed at Baer Field, Fort Wayne, Ind., were killed today when their bomber plane crashed in flames on the city's Country Club golf course.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Parker Hall and Jack Jacobs pitched two beautifully timed touchdown passes, each half the length of the Rubber Bowl, to give the Cleveland Rams a 24-to-14 National Football League triumph today over the Philadelphia Eagles.

George Szell, 45-year-old Czech conductor, has been engaged as a guest conductor for the coming season at the Metropolitan Opera House, Edward Johnson, general manager, announced yesterday. Negotiations are pending also with several other guest conductors, his announcement said.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Frankie Parker of Los Angeles, the "mechanical man" of tennis, won the men's singles title in the Pacific Southwest tournament today, defeating Francisco Segura of Eucador, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- There are at present three fights going on between the women of this country and its government. In each case the women stand a fair chance of coming out winners and getting what they are asking for -- equality of compensation for war injuries, equal status on income-tax returns and admission into the Home Guard.

Ten, including Doublrab, the sprint champion, are named for the $8,000 Fall Highweight Handicap, opening-day feature at Belmont Park today, but it is likely there will be as much interest in the reappearance of Shut Out. The Westchester Racing Association expects keen renewals of the fourteen stakes which stud the three-week meeting.

In his first sermon since his return from the Summer vacation, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, attacked the "wickedness of men in high places and in low" who are responsible for the situation in which the country finds itself today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- New measures to repeal the silver purchase acts, introduced by Representative Celler of New York brought a cry from Western members of Congress today that Eastern bankers were seeking to revise the monetary system under a cloak of wartime necessity.

VICHY, Sept. 20 -- The statement of condition of the Bank of France dated Aug. 20 shows little change in the credits accorded to the securities market. The most important variation was a decrease of 300,000,000 francs in bills discounted.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Sept. 20 -- Villanova College marked today the one hundredth anniversary of its founding as the first Roman Catholic college in Pennsylvania.

Both stocks and bonds went higher last week on somewhat larger transactions. War news was confused; apparently it had no influence on financial markets. As in the week before, resistance by the Russians -- military and civilian alike -- repeatedly halted the invading Nazis.

QUEBEC, Sept. 20 -- "The Boer War called us and we went," a hard - and - fast French-Canadian nationalist said to me. "We suspected it to be an unjust war against a free people and purely for English aggrandizement. That was what it turned out to be and most Englishmen now know it.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 20 (AP) -- A four-run rally in the fifth frame of the nightcap gained the Browns a 4-to-2 decision and an even break today after their four errors had presented the opening contest to the White Sox, 6 to 5.
Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose slightly to 107.5 from 107.4. Again, most of the activity occurred in the prices of the agricultural commodities.

Costumes that have made headlines in recent months, due to their strategic importance in the world of fashion, will make their debuts on the stage of The New York Times Hall at 240 West Forty-fourth Street Oct. 6 and 7, in the production "Fashions of the Times."

MOSCOW, Sept. 20 (Reuter) -- Wendell L. Willkie, carrying a personal message from President Roosevelt to Premier Stalin, said on his arrival in Moscow today that his two dominating impressions so far were the high morale of the Russian people, without the slightest sign of weakening anywhere in their determination to carry on toward victory, and their grim awareness of military realities.
A few days before the salmon season closed in Newfoundland, Lee Wulff, formerly of Chappaqua and now of Shushan, N.Y., sat down to jot a brief summary of his activities in the province.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Sept. 20 -- "What sacrifices are necessary, labor is willing to make" to insure victory for America and her allies in this war, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, declared tonight in an address, broadcast to the anthracite field and mainly for the attention of members of the United Mine Workers of America.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The National Police Gazette, a name to conjure with a generation ago in barber shops and other male haunts, was barred from the mails by the Postoffice Department in an order made public today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- The fiercely battling Cardinals split a double-header with the Cubs before 38,519 spectators today and retained their two-and-a-half-game lead over Brooklyn in the National League stretch drive as the Dodgers also split with Philadelphia.

The Bronx Chamber of Commerce, through its president, George F. biand, sent to the members of the Board of Estimate yesterday a letter objecting to Mayor La Guardia's proposal that the city purchase the electric power plant of the Staten Island Edison Company for about $16,000,000.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Sept. 20 -- The Salzburg Festival Players, an orchestra of thirty-three pieces under the direction of Hugo Burghauser, gave its second Open-Air Serenade here last night at Claremont, the estate of Prince George Chavchavadze.

More than 300 delegates representing 200,000 organized workers in shipbuilding and repair yards on the Atlantic, Gulf and Pacific coasts and the Great Lakes will assemble here tomorrow morning for the opening of the eighth national convention of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O.

Enjoying Boston's hospitality is the new musical comedy, "Count Me In", the run of which has been extended once more for another week, this time from Sept. 28 through Oct. 3. This should bring the offering, in which Charles Butterworth and Luella Gear appear opposite each other, to New York's Barrymore the week of Oct. 5.

Although the realization that defiance of God carries with it eventual destruction is a steadying thought for our nation today, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell warned yesterday against allowing that thought to be license for complacency and said that it must be met as a challenge for rededication to the will and service of God.

On the blood-stained pavements of Stalingrad the Russians have turned and, house by shattered house, are driving the Nazis out of some of the streets of the city. It is a breathless moment. On most of the war fronts a pause has fallen as the world watches the outcome of this greatest battle of all time.

SHILLONG, India, Sept. 12 (Delayed) -- When the time comes for the Allied armies to re-enter Burma they will receive a welcome from thousands of Burmese who have remained loyal to Great Britain and from thousands of others who are more than glad to escape from the duress and disillusion of Japan's new order.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 20 -- The twenty-fourth annual national convention of the American Legion unanimously adopted today a special resolution incorporating a declaration of war principles which it called necessary for victory.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Allied planes, continuing their now daily attacks on Japanese supply concentrations along the northern coast of New Guinea, have bombed and strafed Buna and Lae, burning five barges and a tugboat at the latter point, Southwest Pacific Headquarters reported today.

The paper industry is now working on a program designed to assure production of the amount of paper necessary to carry on the war and at the same time conserve to the fullest possible extent manpower, materials and power to the war effort, it is indicated by officials of the American Paper and Pulp Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- A measure granting the President wide powers to coordinate manpower and industry for maximum efficiency in the war effort was drafted today by Senator Hill of Alabama, the Democratic whip.

The prize award offered for the best first-hand war experience article sent to Harper's Magazine has been won by a British sailor, Bob Fairhaul, whereabouts not known at the moment. Frederick Lewis Allen, editor of the magazine announced that the winning article, "The Bomb Hit the Cruiser," was submitted by Richard G. Hubler, who spoke of himself as the collaborator with an unnamed "British seaman."

The city's drive for scrap metal gathered momentum yesterday as Mayor La Guardia appealed to school children and clergymen to help, borough directors made plans for the borough collection days next month and the New York C.I.O. pledged the aid of its thousands of members.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- Machinery for moving sixteen bascule and swing bridges and the raising of one fixed bridge on the Chicago Sanitary and Ship Canal will be provided by the Navy to facilitate it he transit of vessels built for the armed services, the Ninth Naval District Public Relations Office has announced.

The Conference of Alcoholic Beverage Industries, Inc., representing all branches of the liquor industry, is starting a test institutional advertising campaign in seven Southern States where dry activity has been most militant, according to announcement by Glenn Griswold, director of public relations.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- French patriots in Paris, defying a daylight curfew enforced by German troops, killed two Nazi Elite Guards today and unleashed a campaign of sabotage against German military depots and railways in the area, reports from the Continent said tonight.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- The Sunday Times today put seven United States planes on its list of the twelve best in the world. Peter Masefield, The Sunday Times's air correspondent, said facts and figures revealed the following planes were the best:

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 20 -- Severe measures were taken in both zones of France to prevent manifestations on the anniversary of the Battle of Valmy. It was on Sept. 20, 1792, that the troops of the French Revolution met the Prussians at Valmy and routed them. Goethe, who viewed the battle, wrote that a new era had dawned for mankind.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- The corn crop is entering the last lap of its race toward maturity, and additional ground was gained last week, although unfavorable weather prevailed in many sections of the Central West, which produces virtually all of the commercial corn of the country.

The one-story garage building on a plot 50 by 99 feet at 518-20 West Twenty-ninth Street has been sold by the Bank for Savings to the Peter Cole Realty Corporation of 270 Broadway. It is assessed at $33,500 and was sold for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $26,000 for ten years through Herbert Charles Co.

With October this city moves into Salvage Month to play its part in a great national hunt for metal for our war industries. The Mayor has set successive salvage days when all available city trucks will be concentrated in each borough for collection. It is the patriotic duty of every citizen to begin now the search for scrap to load these trucks.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- Reports are persistent in the West that ceiling prices on hog products will be raised, presumably after anti-inflation price control measures are put into effect. This has resulted in packers being less disposed to sell cash lard to either the government or the domestic trade.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- A.V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, declared in a speech in Sheffield today that the British Navy's losses in capital ships, aircraft carriers and cruisers during the last two years and a quarter had been replaced. He said that although Britain had lost a considerable number of destroyers they had been "more than replaced."

Henry Lewis Stimson is 75 today. He is adding distinction to a long and illustrious career. He is a great lawyer who combines the insight, judgment and imagination of the statesman with the qualities of the skilled and effectual administrator. As United States Attorney here in Theodore Roosevelt's day, he managed that office brilliantly.

VICHY, Sept. 20 -- The monetary market here remains unchanged, still with an overabundance of available capital. The war creates new money and it has not been found possible to absorb this money by means of taxes and thus efface the consequences attributed to inflation.
BOSTON, Sept. 20 -- The Eastern Army All-Star football team met its Waterloo today in its finale with the world champion Chicago Bears.

Lack of adequate housing for workers in production areas constitutes a threat to the war effort, Mrs. Dorothy Rosenman, chairman of the National Committee on Housing Emergency, declared yesterday in an appeal for closer cooperation between officials in Washington and those responsible for the solution of priorities problems in the field.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 20 -- The Moslems have grievances against both the Hindus and the British, Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the Moslem League, told this correspondent today in an interview during which he clarified certain aspects of Pakistan (separate Moslem States) that his opponents accused him of deliberately ignoring.
MOSCOW, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Today's Soviet communique:

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 20 -- Allied bomber planes, including day and night bombers of the United States Army Air Forces and United States-built aircraft in the service of the Royal Air Force, dropped an average of one bomb every seventy-five seconds on enemy forces during the six days of the recent Axis thrust in the area between El Alamein and the Qattara Depression.

THERE has arrived from high over the seas (Devonshire, England) a letter from Mr. Trevor Wignall, former Fleet Street sports authority. When his London apartment ("flat" was what he called it) was bombed out and London newspapers, by war shortages, were cut down to a size that left no room for full columns on sport, Mr. Wignall went down to Devonshire to live a retired life.

The Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Episcopal Church at Broadway and Wall Street, told his congregation yesterday morning that persons who remained at home must be ready to take upon themselves the same obligations as those of frontline soldiers.

President Manuel Quezon of the Philippines, attending morning mass yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Catherine of Siena, 407 East Sixty-eighth Street, heard the Very Rev. Richard M. McDermott, pastor and prior, predict in his sermon that the day would "speedily come" when the "flag of democracy and freedom" would once again fly over the islands, now held by the Japanese.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- Scattered liquidation developed last week in the corn market on the Board of Trade here. Traders paid little attention to price-control legislation, although many believe that corn ultimately will be more affected by the anti-inflation program than any other grain unless there is a radical downward revision in the price of live hogs, which would curtail feeding operations.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 20 -- Steel ingot output in the country last week advanced half a point from the week before to 98 per cent of rated capacity, but the increase was not necessarily significant inasmuch as shortages of scrap material continue at various locations.

Mayor La Guardia warned landlords yesterday that he would not allow the fuel oil shortage to be used as an excuse for not providing adequate heat for tenants "within the limits of the possibility of getting fuel."
Mayor La Guardia told a class of 161 rookie patrolmen yesterday to "sock on the jaw" any "tinhorn" gamblers that they saw on their beats.
MOSCOW, Sept. 20 (U.P.) -- Wendell L. Willkie and United States Ambassador William H. Standley arrived today by plane from Kuibyshev at an airport decorated with American and Russian flags.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 -- Operations in oats on the Board of Trade here were on a relatively small scale last week, but hedging pressure from the Northwest was lighter, and the highest prices of the week were established yesterday, the close showing gains of 3/8 to 1 cent a bushel in the week. September finished at 49 7/8 cents, December at 52 1/8 and May at 54 1/8.

MOSCOW, Sept. 20 -- Ilya Ehrenburg, in a tribute to the 116 French hostages executed in Paris on the eve of the 150th anniversary of the Battle of Valmy, expresses the faith of the Russian people in the steadfastness of the French and deplores the loss to France of her valorous army and her republican traditions. He writes:

It is admitted by every one that the United States needs more income. It cannot get enough by increasing taxes in the corporation and higher income brackets, so it is compelled to levy a tax on some broader base. A sales tax would accomplish this. It would broaden it to a universal base.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 20 -- Large units of the German and Italian labor corps are rushing construction of coastal defenses in Southwestern Yugoslavia, Albania and Northwestern Greece, and Italian troops that have been withdrawn from Croatia and Herzegovina are being moved into fresh defensive positions on the Dalmatian coast and as far south as maritime Albania and the island of Corfu, according to information divulged tonight by foreign military intelligence sources in Istanbul.

College endowment funds, which are regarded as among the best- advised investors in the country, have been steadily increasing their holdings of relatively high-return common and preferred stocks, and cutting down on the traditionally safe-and-sane bonds, which fail to give them the income that they need to carry on their educational work, according to Wide World.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 20 (AP) -- It's football time again back home and Captain Fred P. Dollenberg of Philadelphia is developing his usual case of "October ague," but this time it's for a bigger reason than touchdowns and tackles.

A German picture of street fighting in Stalingrad was given last night in a Transocean news agency dispatch broadcast from Germany. The dispatch, recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES, said that both sides were employing only a few infantrymen and that the main fighting was being done by forces with weapons heavier than those of the infantry.

NOTRE DAME, Ind., Sept. 20 -- The Rev. J. Hugh O'Donnell, C.S.C., president of the University of Notre Dame, today issued a plea to President Roosevelt to designate a day of prayer and fasting for the people of the United States to petition God to direct the nation to victory.
At least five new films will arrive on Broadway this week. The schedule follows:

A special service of solemn intercession dedicated to the people of Yugoslavia, at which Konstantin Fotitch, Yugoslav Minister to the United States, made public a peri personal message from King Peter II, was held at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

INSTABUL, Turkey, Sept. 19 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- As German Ambassador Franz von Papen left today for Berlin political quarters suggested the trip was being made because of differences between him and Nazi Foreign Minister Joachim yon Ribbentrop.

Commissioner William Hodson of the Department of Public Welfare reported yesterday to Mayor La Guardia that in an effort to reduce the relief rolls his department has referred 2,600 relief recipients to private employers in the last four weeks.
I think there should be an organization formed for girls and boys, like an emergency Red Cross society. I think children should know what to do in case of an emergency or an accident in the street.
MOSCOW, Monday, Sept. 21 (U.P.) -- Today's communique said that Soviet warships had sunk an enemy destroyer in the Black Sea. [Rumania presumably has destroyers operating in the Black Sea.]

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Pirates and Reds battled through twenty innings today, the Bucs taking the first game, 2 to 1, in thirteen innings, and the seven-inning nightcap ending in a 3-3 tie when it was called because of the Sunday law.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Converting two fumbles into touchdowns with Bud Schwenk passing for both of them, the Chicago Cardinals downed the Detroit Lions, 13 to 0, tonight. A crowd of 14,742 witnessed the National Football League opener here.

DETROIT, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Tigers and Indians, battling to finish fourth in the American League standing, divided a double bill today, the Tigers rallying to take the second game, 6 to 5, and the Tribe winning the opener, 2 to 0, behind Mel Harder's two-hit hurling.

The Ten Commandments are the onlly basis for world power and lasting peace after victory, Mgr. Bryan J. McEntegart, national secretary of the Catholic Near East Welfare Association, declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The sponsoring of gambling games, such as bingo, by churches was denounced as "brazen" and "unlawful," yesterday by the Rev. Ernest J. Mollenauer, in a sermon accepting a Christian flag presented to St. John's Lutheran Church by the Daughters of America, Council 18.

WASHINGTON Sept. 20 -- The i opening at Bay Ridge, ]d., Sept.; 24, of the second United Seaman's 'Service Home for the care and rest of torpedoed American seamen i was announced today by the War Shipping Administration.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Athletics ended their 1942 season today, a week earlier than other American League teams, by providing a double-header with Washington. The Senators won the first, 11 to 9, and the Athletics the nightcap, 2 to 1, in ten innings.

CALCUTTA, India, Sept. 20 -- In Assam, where an inhabitant scratches a meagre living out of a tiny vegetable plot or a flooded rice field, and where food variety is a rare luxury, the natives are amazed at the sight of United States soldiers scouring the countryside for vitamins.
British air attacks in Greece and Sicily were reported yesterday by the Italian High Command, according to a Rome broadcast recorded here by The Associated Press.

MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Workers at the Alabama Drydock and Shipbuilding Company voted tonight to return to work tomorrow and pay a protested five-cent ferry toll fee after an official of the War Production Board held out little hope for a removal of the charge.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 20 -- Cotton traders here spent almost all of last week trying to make up their minds which way to move on clues from Washington and the Cotton Belt, only to find price changes close to nil for the period.

The Fall rush for apartments in the city continued over the weekend, when an outstanding rental involved a large furnished suite in 1070 Park Avenue. The apartment was taken by Oivind Lorentzen, director of the Norwegian Shipping and Trade Mission, through Frances R. Jaffin, broker.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The British people, now "impatient to get to grips" with the enemy on a second front, have a new understanding of what the war is about: That "the real issue for us is whether Christianity, and all that it means, is to survive," Lord Halifax said today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 20 -- James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy, charged the youth of America with the task of "seeing to it that never again shall this nation be permitted to discard its arms and to rely upon the protocols of good faith and general statements of good-will," in dedicating here today a service flag in honor of Princeton University alumni in the armed forces.

MOSCOW, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Russian resistance to the Nazi invaders has given the British "the opportunity of striking a decisive blow." Foreign Editor Viktoroff of the newspaper Pravda said today in a radio broadcast.
LONDON, Monday, Sept. 21 -- Two big raiding parties of the Royal Air Force carried the war to Germany Saturday night.

Much progress has been made in the last week in preparing legislation to meet the President's demand for greater control over the cost of living. The Senate and House Committees on Banking and Currency have agreed on measures close enough together to make reconciliation appear easy.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 20 -- Scheduled on Tuesday morning to have a second and possibly final audience with Pope Plus XII before his return to the United States by the end of this week, Myron C. Taylor, President Roosevelt's personal envoy to the Vatican, spent today in consultation with several diplomats accredited to the Vatican.

Though the city's musical season will not start in earnest until next week, it was unofficially opened: yesterday afternoon with a recital at Town Hall. Carlo Menotti Li Favi, a Brazilian baritone of Italian parentage, was the principal artist, and Louis Teicher, 18-year-old American pianist, who was graduated from the Juilliard School of Music two years ago, was the guest artist.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 20 -- Mrs. Josephine Stephenson of the Larchmont Acres Apartments wondered today how far to go in breaking to her husband the news of the Brooklyn Dodgers' current woes. The husband, Captain Henry Stephenson, 66-year-old master of a Grace Line merchant ship, was taken captive aboard a German submarine on July 9.
The New York Victory Garden Harvest Show will open tonight in the Grand Central Palace at 6 P.M., with ceremonies scheduled for 8 P.M. dedicating the two-day exposition to the war program.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 20 -- Long Island Sound skippers and crews set sail today in the next to last championship regatta of the season, that of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club. There seemed to be much more reason to stay ashore, but to the course south of Great Captain Island went thirty craft.
Yom Kippur, most solemn day of the Jewish calendar, began at sundown last evening and was ushered in by services in temples and synagogues throughout the city.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 20 -- American screen rights to "Gaslight," an English play by Patrick Hamilton, have been bought by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer from Columbia and the property has been assigned to Arthur Hornblow for production.

Nothing of any importance was at stake in the double-header at the Stadium yesterday, but the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox gave the 24.307 spectators considerable enjoyment while breaking even in two closely-contested games.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Price increases since January, 1941, have cost the American people $9,000,000,000, and since July, 1942, alone about $920,000,000, according to a review issued today in the Economic Outlook, a publication of the C.I.O.

MOSCOW, Sept. 20 -- During the last twenty-four hours Stalingrad's defenders succeeded in driving the enemy from a number of streets in the northwestern region and improved their positions outside the city limits. Russians with bayonets drove German shock troops from a series of buildings and many German tanks were destroyed in the streets.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The income of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for the fiscal year ended on June 30 was $65,658,605, the corporation reported today. This income represented assessments of $54,154,790 paid by insured banks and $11,503,815 of interest earned, less provision for amortization of premiums.

War duties of police departments throughout the country and methods of handling any emergencies arising from the war will be discussed at the three-day meeting of the annual forty-ninth convention of the International Association of Chiefs of Police that will open this morning at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Contracts will be signed within a few days for 2,258,000 stirrup pumps for extinguishing fire bombs, the Office of Civilian Defense stated tonight. The pumps, made to government specifications, will sell for $3 to $4 each. Manufacturers have already been instructed to proceed in their production.

"ICH kaufe was ich kann; alles andere schlage ich kaput" means "I'll buy what I can and smash what I can't." It was the motto of Captain Franz von Rintelen, master sabotage and espionage agent of Imperial Germany in this country in the First World War.

Three birds with one stone is a pretty good record -- even for one of those ingenious people known as cosmeticians. But three separate accessories to beauty actually have been poured into one blue-and-white bottle by a canny, experienced woman who takes the war restrictions seriously.

The meat shortage and impending rationing do not disturb at all the residents of one section of this city -- those who live in the environs of Pell and Mott Streets. For these people -- many of them Chinese by birth and Americans by adoption -- know that simple satisfying dishes may be assembled by combining a minimum of meat with generous portions of vegetables.

ALBANY, Sept. 20 -- Organizations such as Boy Scouts, Girl[ Scouts, Campfire Girls and various t societies for the preservation of Indian rights, legends and history are asked by Governor Lehman in a proclamation designating .turday, Sept. 26, as American Indian Day, to join with citizens and commemorate the day.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Monday, Sept. 21 -- Preliminary returns today from the elections held throughout Sweden yesterday show a marked regression of the Social Democrats in favor of Conservatives and Liberals, on the one hand, and Communists, on the other.

BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Sept. 20 -- Four Army lieutenants and three privates were killed at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the crash of a transport plane near the summit of Blue Mountain, about eight miles northwest of here.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 10 -- Widespread measures to encourage industry and attract foreign and domestic capital in developing this country's resources are being taken by the Venezuelan Ministry of Development. The government is anxious to cooperate with industrialists, who will erect plants immediately.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 6 -- A formal contract for the establishment of a Peruvian steel, iron and coal industry at a cost of $15,000,000 with funds provided by the United States was signed here two days ago at the Ministry of Fuels and Public Works.
DETROIT, Sept. 20 (U.P.) -- The automotive industry prepared tonight to give up tools and dies that cost hundreds of thousands of dollars to help keep steel plants supplied with vital scrap.

TAPPAN, N.Y., Sept. 20 (AP) -- A black walnut tree, almost 250 years old, and sturdy until it was struck by lightning several years ago, will be repaired by the Association of Blauvelt Descendants so that Blauvelt children may continue to play under it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Filipo de Hostos, president of the Chamber of Commerce of Puerto Rico, appealed to the Truman committee today to investigate conditions there, warning of the "complete economic strangulation and collapse of the island" unless "heroic measures" were adopted immediately to restore ocean transportation with the United States.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Brooklyn Dodgers of the National League crushed Ken Strong's All-Stars, 35 to 3, before a crowd of 8,000 in a benefit football game at the Rutgers University Stadium today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sept. 20 (U.P.) -- General Douglas MacArthur today announced awards to three American airmen, two of whom have died in action, for bravery and heroism in flights over the Southern Pacific.

Those who travel daily on the Interborough Subway, and their number is legion, are definitely imperiling their eyesight by reading or attempting to read their newspapers in the dim light now provided by the operating company.

Warning that the compliance department of the War Production Board will deal vigorously with willful and substantial violations of priority orders, Sydney Hogerton, chief deputy regional director, yesterday urged business men to study carefully all priority orders affecting their industries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, will celebrate his seventy-fifth birthday tomorrow, and is expected to observe the milestone by carrying out a full day's work at his desk and in conference.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- Britain is facing her fourth Winter of war with a dangerously slender margin of safety in coal, it was revealed today. Little doubt exists any longer that the coming months will see either a falling off in war production or acute hardship for the people -- and possibly some of both.

Elimination of the distinction that now exists between academic and vocational high schools to provide a unified city system of secondary education is recommended in a report of a special committee appointed three years ago by the Board of Education to study the changes necessary to bring the vocational department up to date.

Small businesses face a cloudy outlook, according to the current issue of The Index, publication of the New York Trust Company, but those that survive should do well when peace return. They then should meet the greatest demand in history for many products, particularly those now unobtainable or obtainable only in small quantities, it says.

MOSCOW, Monday, Sept. 21 -- Red Army troops have recaptured several more of Stalingrad's rubble-strewn streets in savage counter-attacks that ripped more gaps in the German wall of infantrymen and tanks and left the enemy still short of his long-expected victory on the Volga.

Dr. German Arciniegas, Minister of Education of Colombia, who has been appointed Spanish-American Visiting Professor at Columbia University, yesterday blamed unrealistic writers, including North American journalists, for the public's lack of understanding of Latin America.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 -- An amended plan for reorganization and recapitalization of Southern Colorado Power Company on an all-common stock basis was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The coal industry of Britain will be controlled in future years by the Ministry brought into being through the present critical situation, Major Gwilym Lloyd George, Minister of Fuel, predicted today in Birmingham.

Ripe figs grown by an ice dealer on Staten Island, fine specimens of fruits and vegetables from commercial farms and home-grown food raised by enthusiastic amateurs were features of the New York Victory Garden Harvest Show that opened last night at Grand Central Palace.

WELL, it took the Great Big Bears to stop Colonel Bob Neyland's football task force and the Bears are just the best there is in football. The All-Army team in two detachments did better than all right. They played eight games against top competition, professional big league teams, including the champion of them all, and broke even with four victories and four defeats.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- A better tone developed in today's stock market. After a firm opening prices improved in many directions. An outstanding feature was the firmness in the Anglo-Iranian oils which were bought on what was regarded as a satisfactory report. Burmahs and other oils improved in sympathy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Senate agreed unanimously today to authorize and direct President Roosevelt to issue a general order on or before Nov. 1 stabilizing prices, wages and salaries on the basis of levels, so far as is practicable, which existed Tuesday, Sept. 15.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- James C. Petrillo and the American Federation of Musicians were accused of being conspirators engaged in organized coercion, contrary to law and the public interest, by Thurman Arnold at a hearing today before a subcommittee of the Senate.

The five-story Rockwell Apartments at 1308 Union Avenue, in the Bronx, have been sold by Rockwell Apartments, Inc., to a client of David Sallovitz, lawyer, for cash above a first mortgage of $35,000. The building occupies a plot 54 by 135 feet and contains twenty-two suites.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 -- The National Securities and Research Corporation of New York, having changed the name of a proposed issue of securities from "National Victory" Series to "International" Series and amended the prospectus to eliminate allegedly false and misleading statements, was permitted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to proceed with the offering.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Sept. 21 (U.P.) -- Thirty-seven Japanese bombers and fighters, the biggest enemy air fleet sent against a single target in New Guinea in more than a month, attacked an unidentified objective thirty-two miles northwest of Port Moresby yesterday, it was announced today.

ALBANY, Sept. 21 -- Telegrams confirming the allotments of the $100,000,000 in short-term notes sent out by State Controller O'Leary last night were received before noon today at the Controller's office and, as usual, the demand was far greater than the supply.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 -- Interrupting services on Yom Kippur, Jews of Philadelphia pledged themselves today to buy $2,000,000 of war bonds.

GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands, Sept. 7 (Delayed) -- Lieutenant Richard Ronald Amerine [Dick Amerine of University of Kansas football fame] did not have to wait long for a close look at the Japanese after flying a Marine fighter plane at Guadalcanal Island.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Although the collection of scrap iron and steel has increased in the last five months under local press and salvage committee campaigns, the threat remains, the War Production Board said today, that blast furnaces may have to curtail production this Winter because of the lack of scrap.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The Italian Count Edmondo di Robilant, dashing official of the Italian Lati airline, has confessed after several weeks of inquiry that he operated an espionage ring that has been telling the Axis about ship movements in the South Atlantic, the police announced today.

The judges of the Domestic Relations Court, of which Children's Court is a part, will meet some time soon, Presiding Justice W. Bruce Cobb said yesterday, to consider the problem of a sharp rise in the number of juvenile delinquents being brought into court.

MADRID, Tuesday, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Spanish Cabinet, in a communique issued at the end of its fourth meeting in five days, promised early today to punish "inexorably" any violence against the State within Spain and reaffirmed the anti-Communist policy that the Franco regime has followed for the last six years.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 21 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, warned the final session of the American Legion national convention today that this country would have to cut "farther and more deeply" into its civilian economy than even the British have done, except for food, in order to win the war.

The Democratic State leadership backing John J. Bennett Jr. computed yesterday the Bennett strength up-State on the basis of reports from only seven counties and announced that the results showed Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee, to be at least 100,000 votes weaker in those seven counties this year than he was in 1938.
A communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
LONDON, Sept. 21 -- An anonymous Royal Air Force bard has written a poem about the gremlins -- those queer little mythical folk who do all sorts of things to harass the American and British fliers.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Last midnight's communique:

Directors of the Engineers Public Service Company yesterday took a step which will be interpreted by many utility observers as laying the groundwork for a legal attack on the constitutionality of the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- Opening of debate in the Senate on the Price Control Bill resulted in speculators starting to even up their market position in grain. At the same time, officials of the Board of Trade issued statements asserting that the bill, in its present form, would result in regimenting farmers and ultimately leave the government as the sole buyer and seller of grain.

THOMAS WOLFE describe the beginning of adolescence as "the end of the beautiful weather." Somewhere in the early 'teens the sky and sea lose their supernatural blue, the trees become less green, the size of the landscape shrinks. One seldom notices it when it happens, but if one returns to a place that one hasn't seen since childhood the difference is tremendous.
Wartime changes, influencing the whole pattern of everyday life, were apparent yesterday at the opening of the newly decorated House of Years, at W. J. Sloane, Fifth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Brig. Gen. Ira C. Eaker, chief of the United States Bomber Command in Britain, said in an interview today that he believed Germany could be destroyed from the air and that Allied air forces would soon have enough airdromes in Britain to undertake the job.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Because of the absence of a final authority to allocate our manpower resources between industry and the armed services "the time has come when some clear decision between Army and industrial needs must be made."

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 21 -- Legislation that would place the State's vital communications and vital criminal information statistical systems under the control of New Jersey's uniformed police forces was demanded today by 300 delegates to the forty-second annual convention of the State Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.
Several penthouse and terrace suites figured in the apartment leasing activity in Manhattan as reported by brokers yesterday. Business executives and foreign diplomats were among the lessees.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 21 -- William Milne Sr. of North Hills and Joe Phillips of the Links Club combined to clip five strokes from par in the weekly amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island P.G.A. at the Salisbury links today, leading the field with 35, 32 -- 67.

In temples and synagogues throughout the city, Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, was observed yesterday in solemn rites. It was the tenth day of the seventh month, Tishri, and Jews, in accordance with the Hebraic law, "afflicted their souls."

The laxness of a German parole board in releasing Adolf Hitler from prison in Munich after his conviction for "violent and treasonable demonstrations against his government" nearly twenty years ago was suggested yesterday by J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, as one of the principal causes of the present war.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- Voters in this city of 143,000 residents will decide at the November election whether they wish to continue the proportional representation system of electing Councilmen -- a system operative here since January, 1940.

VINELAND, N.J., Sept. 21 -- At 10 A.M. tomorrow in the Labor Department building at Washington, the mediation panel of the War Labor Board will begin hearing the wage and hour claims of miscellaneous workers of the Kimble Glass Company represented by six of the nine locals and branches into which the 2,400 Kimble employes are organized.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 21 (AP) -- American airmen made twenty-three bombing raids on Japanese installations in occupied China, French Indo-China and Burma in July and August, shot down twenty-eight Japanese planes and probably six more and destroyed thirty enemy craft on the ground without the loss of a single bomber in combat.

TRENTON, Sept. 21 -- Remarking that his presence would serve "no useful purpose," Governor Charles Edison said today that he would not attend the sessions of the Democratic State convention this year. The opening session will be held here tomorrow, when the resolutions committee will be appointed to draft the platform that will be adopted a week hence.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- The social and economic system that emerges in the United States after the war will be the model on which other countries will rebuild their societies. Gustav Stolper, a leading economist in pre-Hitler Germany, predicted today.

As all unused No. 1 coupons in A gasoline rationing books became void last night, E.S. Ferguson, regional rationing executive for the Office of Price Administration, announced that a new procedure had been established for the renewal of B and C ration books.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Authoritative sources stated today that there was no basis for speculation that Finland currently was prepared to take the initiative in seeking a separate peace with Soviet Russia.

Members of society, wrapped in furs and buttoned up in tweeds, arrived early for luncheon at the Turf and Field Club, Belmont Park, yesterday afternoon, so as to be at the track before the 1:30 bell clanged to tell them the Fall meeting of the Westchester Racing Association at the park was getting off to an advanced starting time.

STOCKHOLM Sweden, Sept. 21 -- The Swedish Social Democratic party footed the bill of yesterday's municipal elections by losing seats to Right and Left for various reasons, while retaining the majority of individual votes. One conclusion to be drawn from the results is that it has shown how indifferent the Swedish people are to pressure from Berlin.

The big British raid on Munich raises the question as to how nearly the United Nations air front over Germany and German-occupied Europe constitutes an actual second front. To answer that question we would also have to answer another: How decisive is battle in the air in winning a war?

A secondary offering of 59,100 shares of Virginian Railway Company 6 per cent preferred stock by a syndicate headed by Shields Co. was heavily oversubscribed yesterday, according to an announcement by the underwriters. The stock, of $25 par value, was sold for the account of an estate at a fixed price of 28 1/8, less $1 discount to dealers.

Eight persons were injured, three of them seriously enough to require hospital treatment, at about 7 o'clock last night when a bus traveling south in Grand Avenue, Maspeth, Queens, and a trolley car moving west in Sixty-first Street were in collision at the intersection.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- In line with its "get tough" policy, the War Production Board today made public the following telegram sent by a prime contractor of tank parts to a sub-contractor who makes transmission cases, with indications that the WPB considered it more or less of a model:

Neighborhood organizations by the score were being enrolled yesterday in the metal scrap drive as Mayor La Guardia, in conference with other city officials and a committee representing the New York City Newspaper Publishers Association, agreed on collection details.

Dr. Dorothy Bird Nyswander, recently appointed regional supervisor of war public service projects in this region, has taken "all trouble" for her province. Her special function, she explained yesterday at the Federal Works Agency, 2 Lafayette Street, is to satisfy "war-induced needs in war-impacted communities."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Too many people are continuing to travel on week-ends by bus and train, Office of Defense Transportation officials said today.

One hundred officers of the Women's Field Army of the American Society for the Control of Cancer, representing a membership of 225,000 women volunteers in every State, attended yesterday the opening sessions of the first National Training School, in which the volunteers are trained in the methods for "fighting cancer with knowledge."
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 21 -- The prepared text of the address of Donald M. Nelson before the American Legion convention was as follows:
MOSCOW, Sept. 21 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 21 -- A report that the village of Amityville in Suffolk County was to receive a carload of air raid equipment while Nassau County had no government-provided air raid supplies resulted in a complaint today by Nassau County's War Council officials to the Regional Office of the Office of Civilian Defense.

EASTVIEW, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- Alejandro Almagro, self-styled Argentinian "doctor of jurisprudence," escaped from the psychopathic ward of Grasslands Hospital here shortly before 1 A.M. today by sawing through half-inch bars on the window of his room and sliding down a rope of sheets and blankets to the ground three floors below.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today extended until Aug. 31, 1943, the exemption of the General Electric Company, the Electrical Securities Corporation and the G.E. Employes Securities Corporation from the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act and granted conditionally an application by them for the right to carry out an exchange of securities.
LONDON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- An Air and Home Security Ministries communique:

Gradually the new season gains momentum, as galleries take up once more the task of bringing art before the public in a methodical sequence of exhibitions. Among the events of the present week is the formal reopening today of the Downtown Gallery, 43 East Fifty-first Street.

The sinking of two medium-sized ships, one British and the other American, by enemy submarines was announced yesterday by the Navy Department. Forty-three lives were lost when the British ship went down in the North Atlantic last March, while one man died in the sinking of the United States merchantman in early July.

More than 300 painting contractors and real estate operators have notified District Council 9 of the Painters Union they will employ full crews of painters on Saturday, designated by the union as "painters' work for victory day," it was announced yesterday by Louis Weinstock, secretary-treasurer of the Painters Union.
The Potash Company of America reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on June 30 a net income of $1,400,020 after $1,495,264 income and excess profits taxes and other charges.

The stock market held firm yesterday, but activity was so limited and diversified among specialties and low-priced issues that no light was shed on any change in trading sentiment. Sales on the Stock Exchange were 320,290 shares compared with 417,470 on last Friday.

Mayor La Guardia warned yesterday against excessive drinking during wartime, holding that the "decent people of the country" would not stand for "debauchery and reckless drinking" in the cities of the nation, especially if they became convinced that such practices were impairing the health of the men in the armed services and those on the home front and were tending to increase crime.

MOSCOW, Sept. 21 -- Although reports from the Stalingrad front stress that the situation there grows steadily more critical, the German advance now is being measured in yards. The masses of enemy forces converging on the city are gradually driving forward, but the salient pushed through in the northwest now covers less ground than it did last week-end.

VICHY, France, Sept. 21 -- Chief of Government Pierre Laval's conference today included talks with the American Charge d'Affaires, S. Pinkney Tuck, and with leading Axis diplomats, including Japanese Ambassador Takanobu Mitani, Baron Dessenyey, the Minister from Hungary, and Count Vittorio Zoppi, Italian Consul General.

With a view to teaching women to replace men weavers during the war and to use rayon and cotton yarns as substitutes during the current wool shortage, the Craft Students League of the Y.W.C.A., 745 Tenth Avenue, opened the first of a series of three courses in weaving yesterday afternoon.

Cotton futures continued to decline yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange under the leadership of the October. A combination of hedging and liquidation proved too much for a fairly good trade demand to absorb readily, and at the close the market was 12 to 15 points under Saturday's final quotations.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 22 -- The Russian High Command announced this morning, on the thirty-second day of Stalingrad's gallant stand, that hundreds more German shock troops had fallen in violent street fighting in the Volga city, where the enemy was too hard pressed to bury his dead or rescue his badly wounded.

In the first action of its kind in this district, the War Production Board yesterday moved against the illegal practice of using maintenance and repaid priority ratings to obtain materials for general production.
May I add the following remarks to your instructive article "U.S. Radio Facts Win World Trust," dealing with the short-wave broadcasts in general?

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 -- The training given to American youth in the welfare centers operated here and in other cities will make for a better and more internationally minded world when peace comes again, Mrs. Roosevelt declared tonight.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Swedish Nazis lost their only five seats, and Communists won 39, a gain of 17, in nationwide town and county council elections yesterday, a tabulation of returns showed tonight.

OTTAWA, Sept. 21 (U.P.) -- Theodore Dreiser, United States novelist, who said today that he would rather see the Germans in England than the "aristocratic, horse-riding snobs" who he contended are running Britain, was banned tonight from making speeches in Canada.
LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The known number of executions carried out by the Germans in conquered Europe is nearing the quarter million mark, the Inter-Allied Information Committee reported tonight.
BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 10 -- One needs only to pass a few hours at Lausanne in the immediate vicinity of the Hotel Royal to learn much of the present and future destiny of Spain.

DETROIT, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Tommy Bridges kept nine Chicago hits well spaced today and Don Ross and Barney McCosky belted home runs as the Tigers defeated the White Sox, 6 to 4, to keep alive Detroit hopes for a first-division spot in the final American League standings.

The Greater New York Industrial Union Council, governing body for the C.I.O. unions in the city, issued yesterday a report of its preliminary recommendations on candidates for legislative office at the coming election and announced also that it would determine its choice of candidates for State-wide office at a convention to be held in Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street, on Oct. 1.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 -- The Cardinals, who seem to have reduced the art of winning airtight ball games to an exact science, struck one blow today that really amounted to anything. It practically suffocated Onkel Franz Frisch and his Pirates, not to mention making breathing more difficult than ever in Brooklyn.

The Times Literary Supplement, London, which has been following closely in its pages the struggle in Norway between book publishers and Quisling officials, reports a new development -- a strike of authors. Thus far the attempts of Quislings to introduce "leadership" among publishers have not come off, the publishers managing to circumvent the restrictive orders in some canny or bold manner.

LONDON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Qualified British observers said today that the appearance of four new German high-performance warplanes on the world's battle fronts in the past few weeks indicated that Reich Marshal Hermann Goering had achieved a major retooling "swap over" in the German aircraft industry.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Sept. 20 (Delayed) -- A red box bound firmly in tape and suspended from two parachutes dropped gently to the earth yesterday morning in front of the Japanese headquarters at Lae. In it was a clock bearing the inscription "Made in Japan." On the tape were written several sarcastic messages.

The pressing need for women of leisure who can do the work of nurses' aides, particularly in the daytime, in the hospitals of the city, will be told this afternoon at a huge rally to be held in the Sunken Plaza at Rockefeller Center by the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office and the American Red Cross, which trains all the nurses' aides.
BERNE. Switzerland. Sept. '21Swiss newspapers tonight print this dispatch: "French g.-ndarmes have just made battues on Moht Saleve, where many Jews had sought refuge. Anumber of arrests were made."

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 21 (U.P.) -- Royal Air Force medium bombers gave the Axis Libyan port of Tobruk its daily pounding last night despite bad weather. Other bombers shot up Axis airdromes, barracks and roads near the Egyptian front lines, it was announced tonight.

MOSCOW, Sept. 21 (U.P.) -- Wendell L. Willkie said today that the Soviet war factories he had seen compared favorably with those of Detroit in skill and efficiency, that the Russians were grimly determined to see the war through and that he personally favored a second front if it was militarily feasible.

Language with its shades and overtones remains a fascinating subject. Somebody speaks of "a flying battleship weighing 140,000 pounds." It is a rather unusual form of weighing ordinary battleships. We do it in tons. It would sound odd to speak of one of the new British (surface) battleships weighing 90,000,000 pounds.

Thousands of motion picture theatres in this city and throughout the nation will observe "Free Movie Day" today as a contribution to the war bond sale campaign. The ambition of film theatre managers is to give away a million free tickets.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- A "retailer assistance" program, aimed at helping store owners reduce deliveries and eliminate "frills," is being formulated by the Office of Price Administration, it was announced here today.

Dr. William Beebe, explorer and naturalist, returned to New York yesterday from a seven-month tropical research expedition in the jungles of Venezuela. At Caripito, thirty-five miles inland from the Gulf of Paria, the expedition studied rare insects and reptiles.

Some excellent striped bass fishing at Montauk has brought satisfaction to the surfmen who are able to reach Eastern Long Island. Yesterday before many city offices were opened, Ted Gastonovic, fishing the stretch between Montauk Light and the North Bar, had taken fifteen bass.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21 (U.P.) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation, with the arrest of eighty-four Negroes and a white woman, revealed today a Japanese-inspired race-hatred and disobedience campaign on a nation-wide scale, based on the gullibility and superstition of the American Negro.

I have never had much use for rats. But I find, if put in their place, and kept there, they make a real contribution to the scientific world. Their rapid multiplication aids medical research in observing their reactions, by generations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- James Nemec, president of the West Palm Beach Junior Chamber of Commerce, told a Senate committee today that a group of Army musicians at Morrison air field were "transferred to Texas" after they played for two war-bond dances without permission from the local union.

The four-story apartment building at 920-22 Summit Avenue, in Jersey City, N.J., containing sixty-seven rooms and carrying an assessed valuation of $78,000, has been sold by the Prudential Insurance Company to the Baldwin Academy Realty Corporation through Jules E. Merson, broker Gross Gross were attorneys for the buyer.

It is a good thing now and then to recall the fact, and to emphasize it, that long before Pearl Harbor a great number of Americans recognized clearly our deep and inescapable interest in the winning of this war. The American Legion, now assembled in annual convention in Kansas City, is about as good a cross-section of American opinion as can be found, with its membership drawn impartially from all social and economic strata.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today to appropriate $2,731,154,307 more for the Navy, including $100,000,000 for arming merchant ships.

With mild confusion over some of the regulations, the order of the Office of Defense Transportation limiting the number of taxicabs in this city went into effect yesterday. Little change in the steady stream of traffic was apparent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (U.P.) -- Senator Rufus C. Holman, Republican of Oregon, proposed today a constitutional amendment which would permit Congress to deprive American-born individuals of Japanese, German or Italian ancestry of their citizenship rights.

Adrian Van Sinderen of Brooklyn was announced yesterday as the chairman of the United Republican Finance Committee for the metropolitan area in the 1942 campaign. The committee will raise funds for State and Congressional candidates in New York City and in Westchester, Suffolk and Nassau Counties.

The general contention of retail liquor dealers in this area that they are being "squeezed" in their replacement buying under the General Maximum Price Regulation was upheld yesterday by the Office of Price Administration when it was announced that the agency's special staff of investigators has just begun a study of wholesalers' and distillers' price structures to determine the basis on which adjustments should be made.
SOMEWHERE IN THE PACIFIC, Sept. 16 (Delayed) -- The Nazi capture of Novorossiisk and the investment of Stalingrad mark the end of another successful campaign for the enemy.

BOMBAY, India, Sept. 21 (U.P.)-Atobs armed with knives and guns attacked a salt factory in the Tinnevelly district of Madras ProvInce on Saturday, killing the assistant inspector, ,V. Loane, and setting fire to a shed, it was reported today.

Marked by a winning return to competition of the 3-year-old champion, Shut Out, and with a one-length victory in the $8,575 Fall Highweight Handicap for Imperatrice, the Autumn meeting at Belmont Park got under way yesterday with 21,084 race-goers present.

The German High Command announced yesterday that savage fighting continued in Stalingrad and that German forces in the Caucasus had captured two towns, Terek and Vladimirovka, on the Terek River front.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 21 -- After many days of terrific bombing, Stalingrad is still defying bombs, massed artillery and air forces. The fighting inside the city, reports from Berlin said today, continues to be chiefly embittered hand-to-hand combat.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 21 -- The Council of State -- India's equivalent to the British House of Lords -- opened its functions. It will run parallel to the Legislative Assembly and its functions also will be merely that of a forum from which expressions of sentiment will be made.

Lauding the "act of faith in the providence of God and in the stability of our country" professed by 500 students returning to the College of Arts and Sciences of St. John's University, Brooklyn, the Very Rev. Edward J. Walsh, president, urged them yesterday to capitalize their position by readying themselves not only for eventual war duty but more specifically for positions of leadership in the post-war era of reconstruction.

Charging that the Postoffice Department "has become the tool of a minority group that wants to grab control of censorship," H.H. Roswell, publisher of the National Police Gazette, declared yesterday at his office, 1560 Broadway, that he would demand an investigation by Congress of Postmaster General Walker's order barring the publication from the mails.

With Kirby Higbe blazing his fast ball by the Phils for eleven strike-outs at Ebbets Field yesterday, the Dodgers came through with a 3-1 triumph over the cellar champions. But the first-place Cardinals also won and held their two-and-one-half game lead.

The present lull in the fighting in New Guinea probably does not mean that the Japanese have been stopped; more likely it means that they are gathering strength to strike again. Every pause in the advance from Buna has been followed by a more powerful thrust forward.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Composition of a board of consultants who will serve in an advisory capacity to the Smaller War Plants Division and to the Smaller War Plants Corporation was announced today by Lou E. Holland, head of the Smaller War Plants Division and of the government-sponsored corporation.

Manufacturers in apparel, accessory and home furnishings lines have sought to protect the interests of smaller retailers in allotting goods which have become scarce because of war production requirements, according to views expressed in merchandising circles here yesterday.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease of 6 per cent last week in comparison with the same period last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 21 -- "We have one form of strength which our enemies do not possess, and that is the power of truth," Robert E. Sherwood, director of the overseas branch of the Office of War Information, said today in dedicating the new 100-kilowatt transmitter of General Electric's short-wave station, WGEO.

There has not been as much migration of workers from one section to another as had been generally imagined, it was reported yesterday at a luncheon discussion on population shifts, held by the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Sheraton.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- At the request of the Treasury, the Senate Finance Committee amended its tax bill today to permit simple affirmation instead of an oath in filing individual income tax returns.

The Brooklyn Dodgers won twice yesterday, but one victory was not recorded in the all-important won-and-lost columns that keep the Flatbush faithful informed of their heroes' standing in the National League pennant race.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 21 -- Yale University announced today, on the eve of the 166th anniversary of the death of Nathan Hale, Yale 1773, that a letter written by the patriot and seven others written to him have been given to the Yale library by George Dudley Seymour of this city.

Cliff Battles, Columbia's backfield coach, returned to Baker Field yesterday after a month's service with the Western Army All-Stars under Major Wallace Wade and helped Lou Little polish the Lion offense for the opening game against Fort Monmouth Saturday.

In an effort to prevent puncturing of existing price ceilings on various cotton textile products which form the major part of current civilian output, the Office of Price Administration is considering a "rollback" in mill quotations on some grades of cotton yarns, it was reported here yesterday in textile circles.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- President Roosevelt nominated a large number of Army, Navy and Coast Guard officers to be promoted to higher ranks.

The Tirpitz, apparently now holed up again in Trondheim Fjord, perhaps with another torpedo in her side, is the world's most formidable raider. The Bismarck, her sister ship, sunk last March after destroying the battle cruiser Hood, showed what a battle these German sea giants can put up and how hard they are to finish.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Plans for emergency action to provide medical care in communities where a shortage of physicians exists now are being prepared by the War Manpower Commission and United States Public Health Service, Paul V. McNutt announced tonight.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept 21 -- A year ago J. Neil (Skippy) Stahley joined the great exodus of Dick Harlow assistants who had heard the call to head coaching portfolios.

The Duveen Galleries, 720 Fifth Avenue, will open an exhibition of Dutch paintings by masters of the seventeenth century with a private view on Oct. 8. The show will be open to the public from Oct. 9 through Nov. 7, from 9:30 A.M. to 5 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- George Sylvester Viereck, the Nazi propagandist, who was convicted in March of failure to register fully as a German agent, failed in his plea for a new trial in the Circuit Court of Appeals today.
Apartment and rooming-house properties figured largely in the Manhattan real estate trading as represented by reports received from brokers yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Methods of "salvaging" waste light for the war effort with a paint brush were discussed today by lighting experts attending a wartime conference of the National Illuminating Society.

STRATFORD, Conn., Sept. 21 -- An Army air station combination from Luke Field, Phoenix, Ariz., paced a record field of thirty-four teams to capture the North American Army and Navy telegraphic skeet title, it was announced today. The competition was held in conjunction with the North American championships, which closed yesterday at the Remington Gun Club.

If the Government buried in a hole in the ground a great hoard of rubber or magnesium or tin or some other commodity needed for war use every one would recognize the insanity involved. But when Representative Celler remarks that the burial at West Point of 1,361,000,000 ounces of silver sorely needed by industry is "asinine and scandalous," the Western Congressmen from the silver States are up in arms.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nomination of Major Gen. Jacob L. Devers, commander of the Armored Forces of the Army, to the rank of lieutenant general, and the Senate promptly and unanimously confirmed the nomination without referrring it to a committee.

Marvin Breuer now knows how the Dodgers feel. The Yankee right-hander had victory in his grasp and a one-hit shut-out in the ninth inning at the Stadium yesterday. Then Johnny Pesky singled, Ted Williams smashed a home run and it was a tie game.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Behind the excellent four-hit pitching of Ewell Blackwell, 19-year-old Californian, the Syracuse Chiefs earned their third straight shut-out victory over the Jersey City Little Giants in MacArthur Stadium tonight, 5 to 0, before 8,500 fans.

There follows a review -- a summary of certain columns written by this department during the Summer. Briefly listed are some fairly recent "discoveries" that were useful in the past season and that may be even more so in the brisk days that lie ahead.

Otis Co. won yesterday the award of two issues of bonds of University Heights, Ohio, totaling $208,000. One issue of $100,000 of refunding bonds. Series B. due Oct. 1, 1917 to 1956. was awarded at a price of 100.46. with the interest rate named by the bank as 2 1/2 per cent.
Three residential sales by the Home Owners Loan Corporation and several other institutional deals were reported by brokers in Westchester County.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- President Roosevelt would be vested with blanket power to draft labor, industry and "all other material resources" into the war effort under terms of the bill introduced today by Senator Hill.

"Vickie," a farce based upon women's war activities on the home front, opens at 8:40 tonight at the Plymouth. Jose Ferrer and Uta Hagen have the leading roles of the distraught couple whose living room, designed by Ernest Glover, becomes the scene for all sorts of uniformed goings-on.

LONDON, Sept. 21 -- The annual report of the International Federation of Trades Unions published here today states that with the dismissal of Aristides Dimitratos as Greek Minister of Labor by Prime Minister Emmanuel Tsouderos, leader of the exiled Greek Government in London, the way is paved for restoration of a free labor policy for Greek unions, particularly two seamen's unions with headquarters at Cardiff, Wales.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 21 -- RKO has signed John Wayne to play opposite Jean Arthur in "Cheyenne," which Frank Ross, Miss Arthur's husband, will produce as the first of two pictures he has engaged to make for the studio, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The British authorities have now allowed to be published the fact that Prime Minister Churchill and Foreign Secretary Eden expressed to the President their doubts about a sentence in the joint British-American communique of June 12, 1942, simultaneously announcing agreements with Soviet Russia.

The study of the French experience in price control, published by the Brookings Institution, inevitably suggests a comparison with our own experience in price and wage control to date. The parallel is disturbingly close. Judging from French experience, the Brookings study warns us, price control will not be successful if approached from the standpoint of group interests rather than those of the entire nation.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A communique:

Two Fifth Avenue, New York, department stores yesterday celebrated anniversaries by dedicating windows that show historical events since their foundings. Arnold Constable Co., at Fortieth Street and Fifth Avenue, has nine window displays covering the concern's 117-year existence, and James McCreary Co., at Thirty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue, has devoted all of its Thirty-fourth Street windows to reviewing the 105 years it has been in business.

MIDLAND, Ont., Sept. 22 -- A picnic to celebrate the completion of a war contract at the Midland Foundry and Machine Company came to an abrupt and tragic ending last night in Georgian Bay, Lake Huron, when the party's 75-foot, twin-engined motor launch Wa-Wi-Net suddenly listed, righted itself and sank, drowning probably twenty-five of the forty-two men aboard.

The sum of $470,000, the entire residue of the estate of Mrs. Amelia S. Ehrmann, goes to create two charitable foundations, one for the benefit of indigent aged persons and the other for indigent, abandoned, neglected or handicaped children, it was shown yesterday in the estate tax appraisal filed here.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 22 -- Catholic and Protestant congregations in the Netherlands have sent a joint message to the Reich Commissar, Dr. Arthur Seyss-Inquart, protesting against the deportation of Jews to territories under the jurisdiction of the Reich.

Hesketh Pearson's "full-length portrait" of George Bernard Shaw is a completed book and comes from Harper's with the claim on the jacket to being "the most Boswellian biography since Boswell's 'Johnson.'" The author would appear to have had closer cooperation from Shaw than any previous biographer.

IT may -- or may not -- interest Franklin D. Roosevelt, Winston Churchill, Joseph Stalin and millions of citizens of the United Nations to know that Johnny Ray, the manager of Billy Conn, takes the short view of the war. That came out yesterday just before Sergeant Joseph Louis Barrow and Private William Conn signed the papers of legal agreement for their heavyweight championship bout to be staged at the Yankee Stadium Oct. 12.

The Artists' Gallery, now at 113 West Thirteenth Street, will move on Oct. 1 to 43 West Fifty-fifth Street. The opening exhibition at the new quarters is scheduled for Oct. 12. The gallery, which is entirely supported by private contributions, has worked out plans and will continue its activities during the national emergency.

" Orchestra Wives," a Twentieth Century-Fox musical featuring George Montgomery, Ann Rutherford, Cesar Romero and Glenn Miller and his orchestra, will open this morning at the Roxy. Lynn Bari, Carole Landis, Virginia Gilmore and Mary Beth Hughes appear in supporting roles.

Joseph C. Grew, former Ambassador to Tokyo, told a large contingent of American women in colorful wartime uniforms yesterday that the Japanese women "both at home and in the field are supporting their men with that same fanatical loyalty and valor" with which the men die for Emperor and country.
