WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Captain Hugh Mulzac of Brooklyn, the only Negro to hold a United States master's certificate, will command the Liberty ship Booker T. Washington when it goes into service next month, the War Shipping Administration announced today.

The atmosphere of the German-American Bund, in which George Washington was looked upon as the "national prototype" and Adolf Hitler as the "philosophical prototype,'' was recreated yesterday for a jury in Federal court, where twenty-five Bundists are on trial for conspiracy.

With nearly three and one-half months of 1942 still to go, the Republic Steel Corporation on last Sunday exceeded the total steel ingot production by the company for the entire year 1940. The company produced over 6,100,000 tons in 1940, which compares with 7,200,000 tons produced in Japan in the last prewar year for which figures are available.

HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 22 (AP) -- The young widow of a retired Binghamton (N.Y.) newspaper man told here today a story of almost a year's loss of memory and her recovery from amnesia to find herself married to a man she cannot remember.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- A probability that the pending tax bill must undergo a drastic rewriting in Congress, after the November election, was indicated today in some Capitol Hill circles as the Senate Finance Committee wrestled with the problem of working out a formula to end the controversy among government agencies over renegotiation of war contracts to recapture excessive profits.

As a climax to the motion-picture industry's war bond drive, a mock funeral of Hitler, Hirohito and Mussolini will be staged next Wednesday with an Army escort leading the procession from Times Square to the Central Park Mall, where a huge rally is expected to attract thousands of New Yorkers of foreign extraction.

As the first step in formulating a program of consumer education designed to reach every housewife in the borough, the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office held a conference yesterday afternoon at the Town Hall Club. Representatives of schools and colleges, trade unions, women's clubs, philanthropic and business organizations, government agencies and other groups were present.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 22 -- Princeton's varsity team made a strong finish to take the measure of Columbia, 25 -- 21, in their practice scrimmage under game conditions today at University Field. The Tigers flashed a formidable ground offense, but had difficulty solving the T formation Columbia employed from time to time.
The list of realty deals announced on Long Island yesterday included several residential sales in the Rockaway area. Banks and the Home Owners Loan Corporation disposed of several homes.

Paul J. Kern, former chairman of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, said last night that he had turned over to the Dewey-for-Governor campaign committee considerable data on various scandals which had been in his possession, and that he looked favorably on Mr. Dewey's candidacy for Governor, although he had not formally decided to support the G.O.P. nominee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Although some of the recent criticisms of the government's war production organization appear to be valid, the nation might well "look with a degree of tolerance on the government's truly epic efforts to organize and speed production and to harness our economic forces," Eric A. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, urged tonight.

Although the Office of Price Administration is rapidly pushing to completion its contemplated "alternate pricing" method for the food industry, there is little likelihood that the new formula will be announced before early October, it was reported in the trade yesterday.

The trustees in reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation announced yesterday arrangements for the sale of one of the system's subsidiaries, the Louisiana Public Utilities Company, Inc., for a base price of $3,000,000.

Wartime conditions have greatly enhanced the importance of the program for informative labeling of merchandise and in fact emphasizes the need of extending it, the National Consumer-Retailer Council declared in its annual report issued yesterday.

After a delay which cannot be understood by small business men, the establishment of the local division of the Smaller War Plants Corporation may get under way within a week to ten days, it was learned here yesterday. The local division is all set to go, but so far has received no directive or instructions from the Washington headquarters of the corporation, according to reports.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Arrest of a key figure in the operations of three Negro groups, eleven leaders and seventy or more members of which were rounded up by agents of the F.B.I. and local police over the week-end, was announced today.
Ninety-five couples danced out the finals of the first city-wide "harvest dance" contest of the Park Department on the Mall in Central Park before an audience of 5,000 last night.

Building plans filed in the city yesterday consisted mainly of projects growing out of war needs. They included several manufacturing and industrial buildings and storage structures in Brooklyn and Queens. The list follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Limitations on the uses of fats and oils were imposed by the War Production Board today as that agency acted to build up a reserve supply of the commodities for war requirements.

Liquor laws in New York State, which prescribe "high standards," are observed, in the main, and conditions generally are good, Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the State Liquor Authority, declared yesterday in commenting on Mayor La Guardia's demand of Monday for stricter police regulation of bars in the interest of the war program.

LAWRENCE, Mass., Sept. 22 -- The Pacific Worsted Mills, employing more than 5,000 textile workers, were awarded the Navy and Army "E" today. Officials from city, State and nation took part. It is the first worsted mill to be so honored in the United States.

The same backfield that started for the New York Giants against the Western Army All-Stars last Saturday night in Syracuse again will draw the opening assignment when the club begins its National Football League season against the Redskins in Washington on Sunday.

Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council, charged Mayor La Guardia yesterday at a Council meeting with "flagrant misuse of the tax-supported station WNYC" in telling in his Sunday broadcasts about the Mayor's Engineering Advisory Committee on Fuel.

An able correspondent of this newspaper, whose only interest is to report the news as accurately as he can, tells us that at the end of his first month in India he has found "among virtually all Indians a distrust of British promises." "They are convinced," he writes -- this is Herbert L. Matthews reporting from New Delhi -- "that the British have no intention of freeing India after the war.

In the heaviest trading in more than a month and with the enlarged business reserved almost exclusively for the low-priced railroad issues, the stock market edged forward yesterday to within striking distance of the August highs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The new plan of organization which Donald M. Nelson has finally established in the War Production Board has begun to operate amid more hopeful prophecies of success than any preceding one, including the ancestral set-ups of the Advisory Defense Commission, the Office of Production Management and the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board.
Mr. and Mrs. G. Beekman Hoppin are at the St. Regis.

In a race that matched for thrills anything the New York season has had to offer, Louis B. Mayer's bay colt King's Abbey got up to take a three-horse photo finish by a head at Belmont Park yesterday and added his name to the long list of winners of the Jerome Handicap, an event that had its seventy-third running and goes back to Jerome Park and the past century.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 22 -- Two Bayonne City Commissioners, Joseph Topoleski and James A. Mullanaphy, and the latter's deputy, Dennis Coughlin, and four truck dealers in that city were arrested this afternoon on bench warrants charging conspiracy, based on an alleged $7,100 "kickback" to the accused officials in a sale of garbage trucks to the city.
An urgent plea for 500 women volunteers to take a training course to become Girl Scout leaders was made last night by Mrs. Howard Phipps, president of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, Inc.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 22 -- The problem of what should be done about migratory workers in Monmouth County was revived here today when the April term grand jury called for immediate action to correct the living conditions of the workers, which were described as a serious threat to the health and welfare of other county residents, in a presentment handed up to Common Pleas Judge John C. Giordano.

Flag manufacturers generally are meeting in good stride the increasing demand for United States flags, service flags, flag emblems and bunting, and very few instances of gouging the public on the part of unscrupulous dealers are reported, according to a survey made yesterday.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- Qualifying the British and United States armies as "mere bystanders" in the titanic struggle now being waged on the Soviet front, the English-language weekly newspaper Moscow News, published authoritatively in Kuibyshev and widely read in the diplomatic colony, today issues a warning to politicians of the "long view" variety.

Again the premiere of "Let Freedom Sing" at the Longacre has been delayed. Last scheduled to open next week, the topical revue now has been put off to Monday night, Oct. 5. Since Aug. 2 the musical, which has the newly wedded Mitzi Green in the leading role, has been rehearsing under the direction of her husband, Joseph Pevney.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Eight more companies have been selected to receive the joint Army-Navy Production Award in recognition of outstanding performance of war work, Robert P. Patterson, Under Secretary of War, and James V. Forrestal, Under Secretary of the Navy, announced. Their names are as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Churches of all denominations will join the nation Sunday in paying tribute to the men who build and sail our Victory fleet, the Maritime Commission said today. Sunday marks the first anniversary of the launching of the first Liberty ship, the Patrick Henry.

With the Fall renting season drawing to a close, apartment house owners and their agents yesterday reported long lists of new tenants for buildings in nearly all parts of Manhattan. Park Avenue, "the Fifties" and Greenwich Village attracted a number of residents.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 22 (U.P.) -- Thirteen Indonesian soldiers led by a native sergeant inflicted 200 casualties on Japanese marines who occupied the Tenimber Islands, north of Australia, and then held the principal village against superior Japanese forces for an entire night, it was revealed today.

The Liquidation Bureau of the State Insurance Department has sold the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 54 Riverside Drive, south corner of Seventy-eighth Street, to an investing client of Jesse Barkin, lawyer, through the Kempner Realty Corporation, brokers.

Two extremes were reached in August advertising linages in newspapers of fifty-two cities, measured by Media Records, an analysis yesterday disclosed. Department store advertising for the month passed even the previous 1929 peak by 400,000 lines, while linage for financial and automotives was the lowest since the early Twenties.

Writing what appeared to be the "death warrant" of fair-trade pricing on new products, the Office of Price Administration here ruled yesterday that the Knickerbocker Liquors Corporation, distributors of Oldetyme and Schenley products, could not establish a general price level on its latest brands for the retail trade.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- With the aid of engine-room artificers, who made within forty-five minutes a surgical instrument from plans sketched by a medical officer of the battleship Rodney, a new type of operation was performed on an enlisted man from a destroyer suffering from a severe facial injury.

The greatest motion picture studio in the East, replete with memories of stars of the silent days and the first talkies, was formally dedicated yesterday as the Photographic Center of the Signal Corps, U.S.A.

DETROIT, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Wildness of two Chicago pitchers, Bill Dietrich and Jake Wade, who issued an even dozen passes, helped the Tigers to a 9-to-2 victory over the White Sox today in the final home game of the season for the Tigers.

The growing shortage of trained nurses in hospitals, due to the heavy demands of the armed forces, was discussed at a meeting of the Committee on Recruitment of Student Nurses of the National Nursing Council for War Service yesterday at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

Coach Earl Walsh sent his Fordham squad through a two-hour scrimmage on Rose Hill yesterday against the Army team from Fort Monmouth. The session, which was conducted on a game pattern with the exception of the kick-off and the fact that no score was kept, marked the first time a modern Ram eleven has scrimmaged against an outside team.

The disadvantages of the war are legion, but when it contributes, actually, to the joys of life -- that's news. And it's good news indeed to see a baker's dozen of famous accessories to beauty packaged with pristine simplicity and selling, suddenly, for $1 apiece.

BOSTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- A threatened strike of 1,700 employes of the Eastern Massachusetts Street Railway Company, set for 4 o'clock tomorrow morning, was postponed for twenty-four hours after Governor Saltonstall intervened tonight.
LONDON, Sept. 22 (Reuter) -- The first use in France of a blood test to determine a "non-Aryan race" was reported by the German news agency today, according to a Berlin broadcast.
Henry J. Kaiser, master shipbuilder who likes to move in heroic strides, moved into the New York labor market yesterday to recruit 20,000 shipyard workers for his plants on the Pacific Coast.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Paced by brilliant pitching performances by Paul Derringer and Johnny Vender Meer, the Reds today beat the Cubs twice by the same score, 4 to 1, in the final games of the National League season at Wrigley Field.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
Recent newspaper stories of overcrowded trains serve to emphasize the fact that many excellent trains are still running at well under their capacity passenger load right in the metropolitan area.

New York Conservation Department officials call attention to the comparatively mild limitations placed on duck hunters in the area extending from Connecticut to Manasquan, N.J., and including the Long Island sector of Great South Bay.

To the great "if's" of history F.B.I. Director J. Edgar Hoover added another this week. If, he said, Adolf Hitler had not been paroled for his part in the Munich Putsch of November, 1923, "then the Nazi party might never have come to power and certainly its reign of terror would have been postponed."

The Victory Fund Committee of the New York Federal Reserve District, whose function is to assist the Treasury in obtaining wide distribution of new issues of government securities, is at work on the Treasury's latest offering of tax-anticipation notes.

Once again the Congressional farm bloc is out to obstruct the nation's efforts to avert inflation. It was this group that caused the long delays in obtaining the original price-control law. It was the farm bloc's success in getting a ceiling of 110 per cent of "parity" on farm prices that had so much to do with weakening that law and bringing on the present crisis.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Sept. 23 -- The Red Army, fighting fiercely in the wreckage of Stalingrad, yielded two more streets to the battering attacks of reinforced German troops yesterday, the Soviet High Command announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Senator Brown, author of the Senate's anti-inflation bill, designed to give President Roosevelt power to stabilize the cost of living, frankly conceded tonight that the outcome over the higher parity amendment would be close and apparently was in doubt.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 22 -- Fifteen trade union representatives will begin a nine-month course at Harvard University this month, under a new trade union fellowship plan, it was announced tonight. The course will be sponsored by the Harvard Business School, the Littauer School of Public Administration and the Harvard Department of Economics.

VICHY, France, Sept. 22 -- German occupation authorities announced today the execution of seventy hostages at Bordeaux, raising to 186 the known number of Frenchmen executed within the last week in reprisal for anti-Nazi violence.

The report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation for the first eight months of this year, issued yesterday by Justin R. Whiting, president, shows a net income on a parent concern basis of $788,523, after expenses, taxes and other charges.

PANAMA, Sept. 22 -- United States companies here with branches in Colombia are much concerned over the effects of one of the most drastic laws concerning foreign business passed by any Latin-American country and which became effective in Colombia on Sept. 8.

The New York City Committee of the United Seamens Service, Inc., which held its first meeting yesterday under the chairmanship of former Police Commissioner Edward P. Mulrooney, was urged by Joseph Curran, labor leader, to act immediately to solve the lodging problem of merchant seamen.

Bolstered trade and commission-house buying that had been aroused by reports from Washington that Congress is favorably disposed toward the establishment of floors on agricultural commodities at the 90 per cent loan rate inserted in the new price-control measure, supplanting the present 85 per cent of parity loan figure, the cotton market yesterday broke a decline that had extended over the last five sessions and held moderate advances.

War conditions did not stifle yesterday the customary active bidding for a new issue of $500,000 city of Honolulu, Hawaii, 2 1/2 per cent refunding bonds, dated April 15, 1942, and due serially from 1943 to 1952. Due to communications problems, bids on these bonds were opened simultaneously in New York City and in Honolulu.

Most practical-minded Americans are willing to go along with the general thesis outlined by Thomas W. Lamont in suggesting that we "accept" Soviet Russia as an ally without bickering over that country's domestic economic and political policies.

BOMBAY, Sept. 22 (U.P.) -- Nationalist leaders increased pressure on the government today to review the independence question, pointing out that the approaching end of the monsoon season heightened the danger of invasion, but there were no indications here that Great Britain would widen her offer of limited home rule.
PRESQUE ISLE, Me., Sept. 22 -- Two officers and five enlisted men perished today in the crash of an Army plane six miles northeast of Presque Isle.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 22 -- An Army medium bomber and a freight transport operated by Eastern Air Lines for the Army were in collision on a runway at Thirty-sixth Street Airport today, killing three Army men and two civilian fliers and injuring four others.

Almost every one concerned has been trying to explain away the statement made in Washington last week by the Finnish Minister, Hjalmar J. Procope, that Finland "wants to cease fighting as soon as the threat to her existence has been averted and guarantees obtained for her lasting security."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Office of Price Administration applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission to suspend a proposed increase to 2.2 cents a mile from 1.65 cents a mile in passenger coach fares through the South.

LONDON, Sept. 22 (U.P.) -- British forces bearing down on Tananarive, the capital of Madagascar, met French defenders in a violent battle today at Mahitsy, twenty miles to the northwest, and "our artillery intervened effectively," a British East African communique announced.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 22 (AP) -- A United States Headquarters communiqe:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 -- Calling the United Corporation a "multitiered monstrosity" resting atop an empire of direct and indirect subsidiaries with a total capitalization of more than $5,000,000,000, the public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission recommended today the liquidation of the corporation.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- The increase of the population in Central Asia and Siberia, caused by evacutions from the west, has led to a drive to increase local food and industrial plant production. Much of the development is of a permanent character.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Two American merchant ships operating as part of a convoy sent into the Mediterranean for the relief of Malta were sunk at the end of a four-day running attack by Axis air, land and sea forces, the Navy announced today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 22 -- A thing of beauty may be a joy forever to a maker of verses, but not to a football coach and particularly not to Richard Cresson Harlow.

VICHY, France, Sept. 22 (U.P.) -- The Vichy government, borrowing from American advertising technique, has embarked on a high-pressure campaign to "sell" Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, 86-year-old Chief of State, to the French people by reminding them of his history and virtues at every opportunity.

Moe Jacobs, doing business as the atlas Purchasing and Sales Company, has leased the store, basement and sub-basement in 583-7 Broadway for a term of five years from Edward L. Piane and will occupy the space for the sale of office furniture and equipment. Harry G. Silverstein was the broker.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 22 -- General Marshal Fedor von Bock, German commander in chief of the Stalingrad and southeastern fronts, appears to have been recalled. Five days ago a Swedish journalist now in Stockholm saw him walking through the streets of Berlin in mufti.

In the midst of the doleful news of what the new income-tax bill holds in store, it is a comfort to learn that it will no longer be necessary to have returns notarized. New York State, quite sensibly, abandoned the practice some time ago. It adds nothing to the solemnities of the income-tax rites or to the penalties of income-tax evasion.

From the time of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor until Sept. 1, 6,800 enemy aliens were apprehended in the United States, and half of them have either been paroled or released, Edward J. Ennis, director of the Alien Enemy Control Unit, told the International Association of Chiefs of Police yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Chiefs had to go ten innings tonight before scoring their fourth straight victory over Jersey City, 9 to 8, to capture the International League Governors' Cup and qualify for the right to meet Columbus of the American Association in the little world series.

GERMANY under the Nazis is a land of fear, the world's most terrible example of what Guglielmo Ferrero called an "illegitimate government." The revolutionary clique that usurped power, fearing revolt from its enslaved subjects both at home and abroad in subjugated nations, maintains itself in power by terrorizing the population; and the people live in daily fear of the enormities of their rulers and so find revolt more and more attractive.

Sergeant Joe Louis and Private Billy Conn will meet at the risk of the sergeant's heavyweight championship on the afternoon of Oct. 12 at the Yankee Stadium. It isn't that this had not been known previously, but yesterday at the offices of the New York State Athletic Commission it became official, with the signing of contracts.
PERHAM, Me., Sept. 22 -- An Army plane crashed on the side of a wooded hill in this tiny Aroostook County community today, killing all seven of its occupants.

The Navy League of the United States, a forty-year-old organization which is now expanding its welfare activities throughout the country on behalf of men in the Navy and merchant marine and their families, was the beneficiary of a gala dinner and dance given last night in the redecorated Persian Room of the Plaza to mark the formal opening of that rendezvous for the new season.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Allied air forces continued their non-stop attacks on Japanese ground forces and communication lines in New Guinea yesterday, firing more than 34,000 rounds in low-level sweeps against Buna and the jungle track leading from Buna into the Owen Stanley Mountains, a communique said today.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- Private William J. Coleman of the Bronx, a member of the Service Battery. First Battalion, 258th Field Artillery of New York City, will receive the Soldiers Medal for heroism on Wednesday at a review of the regiment at the Pine Camp Cantonment.

Captain Dolph Camilli exploded his twenty-fifth home run of the season into Bedford Avenue off Bob Carpenter to start the twelfth inning and end yesterday's wild and woolly game at Ebbets Field, giving the Dodgers a 9-8 victory over the Giants.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 22 -- After struggling desperately with a run famine that for a time threatened their spectacular pennant dash, the Cardinals went on a scoring rampage today to take another enormous stride nearer the National League championship.

The German High Command reported yesterday that "more fortified points were taken in violent man-to-man battles and against fierce enemy resistance" in the fight for Stalingrad, and declared that Russian counter-attacks against the Nazi line north of the city had been repulsed.

TRENTON, Sept. 22 -- A bitter attack on Albert W. Hawkes of Montclair, his Republican opponent, by United States Senator William H. Smathers, who is seeking reelection, was the high spot at the opening session of the Democratic State Convention at the Stacy-Trent Hotel here today, while Mr. Hawkes, addressing the Republican convention, held simultaneously at the party's headquarters on East Hanover Street, refrained from personalities.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- The British column from Majunga has smashed eighteen miles through sporadic Vichy French resistance to Mahitsy, nineteen miles from Tananarive, the capital of Madagascar. Reports to London recounted steady British progress on this and other fronts despite extensive demolitions of roads and bridges.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Lighter than expected receipts again lifted prices of live hogs 15 to 25 cents a hundred pounds to a top of $15.10 today. The advance of 50 cents for the first two days of the week was the sharpest in some time.

In a 3-to-2 decision handed down late yesterday after argument of the case earlier in the day, the Appellate Division reversed a Supreme Court ruling and held that State Senator Charles A. Muzzicato must run in the coming election both for State Senator on the American Labor ticket and for Representative at Large on the Republican ticket.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Internal revenue collections in August were more than $200,000,000 higher than in the corresponding month a year ago, the Bureau of Internal Revenue reported today. The collections were $681,667,158, compared with $474,370,974.

Broken homes and extremely high wartime wages paid to youngsters, giving them an exaggerated value of their importance, are among the principal contributing factors blamed by social workers, actively interested in youth problems, for the growing trend in juvenile delinquency.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- The Army has decreed no fixed coiffure pattern for members of the Women's Auxiliary Army Corps and has stipulated only that the hair must be well above the collar line, according to Frank Baird, official hair stylist for the Waacs at Fort Des Moines.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 22 -- Irene Dunne and Melvyn Douglas will be co-starred by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in the forthcoming American version of "Gaslight" by Patrick Hamilton, the studio announced today. Arthur Hornblow, who will produce the film after he completes "Mary Smith, U.S.A.," will leave for New York next Tuesday to see "Angel Street," Shepard Traube's Broadway production of the English play.
MOSCOW, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Today's Soviet communique:
Is there a Civilian Defense job YOU can do? Of course there is! Just one branch alone of the volunteer war ef fort urgently needs help on NINE different types of work!

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. Sept. 22 -- Edward Haight, 17 years old since Saturday, was indicted this afternoon on two charges of kidnapping and two of first degree murder by a Westchester County grand jury convened specially to consider the slayings on Sept. 14 of Margaret Lynch, 7 years old, and her sister Helen, 8.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Although there was no significant increase in business in today's stock markets the tone was generally firm, with industrials and oils providing good features. The decline in gilt-edge issues which had been going on for some days was checked by the old war loan which advanced 1-16 point.

For the first time in modern political history the New York State Federation of Labor at a meeting yesterday failed to endorse the entire Democratic State ticket. Instead, it ignored two of the party's candidates for State office and backed a Republican for still another place.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 22 -- The right of asylum as a sovereign prerogative and not as a juridical obligation will continue to be exercised in Switzerland for humanitarian reasons within the limits of its possibilities, it was stated today by Edouard von Steiger, Federal Councilor and Chief of the Department of Justice and Police.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Swooping so low that they were dodging the chimney stacks on a power station supplying the Lille-Lens area in Northern France this morning, a force of British Boston bombers attacked that plant and a number of other enemy in stallations. Flying without benefit of fighter escort the bombers reported the success of their mission, from which two failed to return.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Last midnight's communique:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The 218 signatures necessary for a petition to discharge the House Judiciary Committee, which for months has been holding up a bill to outlaw the poll tax in national elections, were obtained today.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 22 -- The complaint that "no statesman in charge of American affairs has found it advisable to say one word of encouragement for the Indian people" was made on the floor of the Council of State this morning by P.N. Sapru, son of the well-known Indian liberal, Sir Taj Bahadur Sapru.

Management and accountants will be faced with a serious problem at the year-end, in determining what inventory valuation can properly be placed on goods frozen temporarily by government restrictions as well as upon unbal anced stocks.

A city-wide survey of vacant buildings has been undertaken by municipal officials as the preliminary step in a program calling for large-scale demolition of outmoded structures to provide a vast supply of scrap metal for war use, it was learned last night.

Net sales of the Davison Chemical Corporation and its subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended June 30 amounted to $14,416,329, an increase of $4,125,292 over the volume of the preceding year, according to the annual report announced yesterday.

An eleven-point program designed to readjust the procedure in New York City's secondary schools so that students would be better equipped to face life both in the home and in business was recommended yesterday in the second section of a report issued by the Board of Education's vocational survey committee.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- An appeal to civilians to accumulate War Savings Stamps rather than save actul coins with which to buy War Savings Bonds, will be made by the Treasury Department next week.

The early morning showing at Macy's -- it was a press breakfast held at 9:15 -- left certain definite impressions on the minds of the guest writers. The strongest was created by the riot of well-chosen and mated colors. For this the bouquets go the way of Amy Fagan, stylist for the store, who has an artist's feeling for color.

GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands, Sept. 9 (Delayed) -- The Marine formula for successful counter-attack against Japanese-held islands in the Pacific has proved its efficacy in the reoccupation of the Guadalcanal-Tulagi area of the Solomon Islands. Years of planning, training and equipping have come to fruition in the Solomons attack, and on almost every count the test of counter-invasion conditions has been met.

Judge Marcus B. Campbell held yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court that the act of Congress of July 2, 1940, giving the President the power to forbid or curtail the export from this country of articles he considered necessary to the defense of the nation, was constitutional.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Representative Vinson, chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee, presented today a graphic picture of the course of the war at sea in an official report disclosing "an almost complete" halt in Allied ship losses along the Atlantic Coast and a fivefold increase in the Navy's shipbuilding program.

Seven gold medals were awarded unexpectedly yesterday by the Horticultural Society of New York for excellence of displays by six growers exhibiting at the New York Victory Garden Harvest Show in the Grand Central Palace.

Mrs. Lytle Hull gave a luncheon yesterday at Hampshire House to launch a public appeal for $150,000 to finance the second year of the New Opera Company, of which she is president. The season opens on Nov. 3 at the Broadway Theatre.

A rather unusual discussion of the problems of Allied strategy in general and of India in particular appeared in a recent number of the London periodical Time and Tide. It took the form of a letter signed N. Bonaparte, from an address at Flat 6871, Military Division, Elysium.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- Stalingrad's defenders continue to report, appreciable successes in violent fighting outside the city's periphery, while in the built-up regions where German shock troops have established themselves for the last six days houses and streets are gradually being cleared.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- President Roosevelt had no engagements.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Light on the underground movement of resistance to the Nazis as it is carried on in Luxembourg was shed here today by Jean Vercel, who recently escaped from the Grand Duchy. He declared there was not the least doubt that 97 per cent of Luxembourgers firmly opposed Nazi rule.

Six new instrumentalists have been engaged by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra to fill the vacancies caused by the resignation of two players and the pensioning of four others. All of the new men are of American birth and three of them are still in their twenties.

The article by Edwin L. James in THE TIMES of Sept. 20 flatly states that the opening of a second front will not materialize this year, and he has carefully analyzed the reasons for postponing a military operation on such a vast scale until its chances for success are better than 50 per cent.

A rise of nearly a point and a half in the general death rate in New York City during the week ended last Saturday was due largely to the excessive heat, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins reported yesterday. The rate rose from 8.2 to 1,000 population the preceding week to 9.6 last week, the greatest increase being noted in the diseases of later life.

A fire in the forward hold of a medium-size British freighter at Pier 19, Clifton, S.I., yesterday destroyed part of the cargo. Strenuous work by firemen who responded to three alarms kept the flames from spreading to another hold containing ammunition and saved the ship.

Characterizing delays and work stoppages as "aid to our enemies," John Green, president of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, C.I.O., yesterday told the 300 delegates assembled at the union's eighth annual convention at the Hotel New Yorker that neither the nation nor its workers can afford now to engage in "the luxury of pre-war unionism as usual."

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 22 -- General Abelardo Rodriguez, commander of Gulf Coast defenses, told the writer today that the United States was not sending Mexico enough arms to enable her to prepare adequately for war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Miss Katharine Lenroot, chief of the Children's Bureau, predicted today that mothers who were not employed in war industries might be asked to open their homes for a few hours daily to care for school-age children of women at work in the factories.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Harry L. Hopkins told the National Inventors Council today that "we've got only one business at hand" and "the only important thing is whether we have people in Congress who want to win the war." "It is unimportant whether they be Republicans or Democrats," he continued.

A store that enters the second week of its existence this morning is a store with a triple personality. First of all it is a bakery, where you may buy a kugelhupf (a sugar-topped coffee cake made with raisins and nuts) or a half dozen almond wafers or a couple of fresh honey buns.

The Italian High Command said yesterday that Allied mechanized forces that had struck through the desert against Axis forces in the neighborhood of Gialo Oasis, Libya, at dawn last Wednesday had been driven off after a five-day fight. That statement was contained in a Rome broadcast that was recorded by The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- As the result of a revolt of farm forces in Congress, President Roosevelt tonight faced the danger of defeat in his efforts to prevent the inclusion in anti-inflation legislation of a provision which, in effect, would increase to 112 per cent the 100 per cent of parity at which he purposes to stabilize farm prices.

Dates and details of the seven days of New York racing with which the sport aims to send its war fund well over the original goal of $2,000,000 were announced yesterday by Herbert Bayard Swope as chairman of the Turf Committee of America.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Sept. 19 (Delayed) -- General Rafael L. Trujillo, President of the Dominican Republic, in an interview today, appealed to all non-belligerent Latin-American nations to give moral support and material backing to the United Nations' war efforts.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- Alex Watson, Hudson River Country Club pro, was unexcelled in the four events open to professionals in the weekly tournament of the Westchester P.G.A. at his home course today.

Four blocks on the upper East Side next week will be used as a proving ground to demonstrate what average urban dwellers can contribute to the nation's scrap campaign, Mrs. Wales Latham, national president for Bundles for America, announced yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Captain Thomas J. O'Connor of the State Police said tonight that the hacked and battered bodies of Charles A. Nash, attorney for the Internal Revenue Department at St. Louis, and his wife were found in an automobile tonight eight miles north of Springfield.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Friends of Chief Justice Harlan F. Stone predicted unqualifiedly today that he would continue his service as head of the Supreme Court after reaching the retirement age of 70 on Oct. 11.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Outright repeal of the law governing renegotiation of war contracts was urged today by Roscoe Seybold, vice president and controller, Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, in an address before the Controllers Institute of America.

Nearly every one at the Plymouth Theatre last evening seemed to be happily roaring at "Vickie." For S.M. Herzig, a writer of sketches for musical shows and a Hollywood word-man, has gone loudly into the vagaries of civilian war work, with special emphasis upon the vertigo of women in amateur uniforms.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 22 -- Because of the mass of information regarding freight operating costs and their relation to rate-making placed before the Interstate Commerce Commission here today as that body started a series of hearings on nation-wide freight rates, it was asserted tonight that the hearings would last at least two weeks.

In the Autumn Yale Review a letter, written in 1823, takes us back to the days of innocence. Lucretia, the young wife of Samuel F.B. Morse, writes from New Haven to her husband, who settled in New York in that year. The domestic prospect pleases. "Susan behaves very well and can read stories in Mrs. Barbauld's Lessons"; and "Charles with the aid of your hand trots about any wheres."
Warehouse operators and moving men predicted yesterday that Oct. it, the city's traditional residential moving day, would find fireproof storage space at a premium.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- A ten-point declaration of policies and principles, demanding "full and immediate utilization by the President of the most capable and efficient military and civilian leadership," was adopted tonight at an unusual conference of House Republicans.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 735, which compared with 1,160 in the preceding week and 508 in the similar peried of 1941, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 151 as against 544 for last Tuesday.

The first criminal prosecution for the operation of a "black market" in tires here ended yesterday in the freeing of two defendants when Federal Judge T. Blake Kennedy brushed aside a prosecutor's request that the defendants receive "severe punishment."

A blue air raid alert, flashed to the city at 8:49 o'clock last night, took radio broadcasters off the air for approximately forty-five minutes, resulted in a half-hour of confusion on the East Side of Manhattan, where an air raid siren was blown by mistake, and turned out thousands of civilian defense workers in New York, Westchester, Long Island and Northern New Jersey.

Dr. James E. West has been elected Chief Scout of the Boys Scouts of America, effective on or before June 1, 1943, it was announced yesterday by Walter W. Head, president, following unanimous action of the national executive board of the organization.

Al Schacht donned a Yankee uniform before yesterday's game at the Stadium with the explanation that he wanted to see what life was like with the champions. He soon found out. Atley Donald pitched a five-hitter and his mates clubbed Sid Hudson for eleven, with the result that the New Yorkers defeated the Senators, 3 to 1.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Naval and Marine Corps dive-bombers damaged a Japanese cruiser northwest of Guadalcanal in the Solomon Islands on Sunday, it was announced tonight by the Navy Department. The action raised to twenty-two the number of Japanese ships sunk or damaged since the Navy and Marine landing force struck at the Solomons on Aug. 7.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 22 (AP) -- Dean Alfange, American Labor party candidate for Governor, asserted tonight that the understanding of crime prevention was far more important than prosecution from a Governor's viewpoint.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Murray gave a dinner last night in the Viennese Room of the St. Regis for their daughter. Miss Marie Murray, and her fiance, Lieutenant Basil Harris Jr., U.S.A., and also for their son, Captain Thomas E. Murray Jr., U.S.A., to celebrate his birthday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 22 -- After two days of discussions with leading diplomatic representatives accredited to the Vatican, Myron C. Taylor, President Roosevelt's personal envoy to the Vatican, was again received in private audience by Pope Plus XII for fifty minutes just before noon today.

MOSCOW, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A new racial policy, dividing the vaguely defined Nordic race into "full-valued" and "devalued" elements, has been outlined by Adolf Hitler, the official Soviet news agency. Tass, reported today in dispatches from Stockholm, Sweden.

Like most reports on the progress of our war effort, that by Representative Vinson, chairman of the House Committee on Naval Affairs, is cast largely in the future tense. But though we cannot win today's battles with tomorrow's weapons, it is encouraging to learn that we are getting some of those weapons now.
LONDON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The East Africa Headquarters communique on Madagascar:

An end of free parking in the city's business streets, the construction of crosstown express highways in midtown and downtown Manhattan and in Brooklyn, and the investment of private capital in a string of day-parking garages are major proposals in a comprehensive plan which the Regional Plan Association is preparing to meet the city's traffic problems after the war.

Jennie Tourel, mezzo-soprano; Jacques Gerard, tenor, and Nicola Moscona, Metropolitan Opera bass, have been engaged as the soloists to appear with Arturo Toscanini when he conducts an uncut version of Berlioz's "Romeo and Juliet" with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra and its first three concerts of the season at Carnegie Hall on Oct. 7, 9 and 11.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 23 -- Confirmation that American heavy bombers attacked Rumanian oil fields as one of their initial operations in this theatre came for the first time today with the announcement of the award of the Silver Star for gallantry to Colonel Harry A. Halverson for leading his formation on this daring exploit.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Another appeal to the French people to keep clear of coastal areas, where an "offensive of the United Nations is being prepared," was made tonight by the British Broadcasting Corporation in its service to the Continent.

Praised for their courage and patriotism under Nazi persecution, the women of Poland, in a broadcast yesterday by women of America, were assured of victory for the United States and freedom for their stricken country. Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and four other prominent women were speakers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- A new move to enlist every woman in the United States in the national salvage drive got under way here this week with a special conference of a committee of business and professional women called in by the War Production Board. The conference, which was informally called "a salvage school," started on Monday and will end tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Expansion of inventory control to include grocery wholesalers and retailers has been urged upon the War Production Board by spokesmen for independent retail grocers, it was learned here today. Representatives of various retail organizations, including the National Association of Retail Grocers, are planning to press the request even over the objections of some of the WPB and Office of Price Administration officials.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23 -- Urged on by the joyous shrieks of 26,514 deliriously happy fans, the pennant-bound Cardinals advanced another stride toward their goal tonight when, behind Johnny Beazley's brilliant two-hit pitching, they conquered the redoubtable Bucky Walters and the Reds, 4 to 2.

LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 24 -- Demands for British aircraft in Russia and the Middle East were so great during the first six months of this year that exports to these and other regions were well over three times the number of planes imported from the United States and Canada, Ben Smith, parliamentary secretary for the Ministry of Aircraft Production, said early today in a broadcast on the North American service of the British radio.
Fordham held its last long practice on Rose Hill yesterday in preparation for Saturday's battle with Purdue at Lafayette, Ind., the Rams' initial test of the season.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Last midnight's communique:

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Beinecke gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Vere-Smith, Mr. and Mrs. George F. Breen, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Browning, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Von Elm, Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Hillas, Mrs. John A. Griffin, Adrial Bird and William B. Anderson.

Because Nazi persecution and brutality apparently have caused the death of all male members of his wife's family, a refugee physician received permission yesterday from Justice Edward R. Koch in Bronx Supreme Court to take his wife's maiden name to perpetuate it.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 23 -- While in Bucharest today a decree law signed by every member of the government confirmed the centralization of all legal power in the hands of Marshal Ion Antonescu as Chief of State, his nephew, Mihail, Vice Premier, was in Germany discussing the general situation with Adolf Hitler, with the result that the "cordial understanding between the two countries was confirmed," according to dispatches from Berlin.

The German propaganda minister, Dr. Joseph Goebbels, sought to whip up new fury against the Allies yesterday by declaring in print and on the radio that if Germany lost the war children would be sent abroad by the victors for twenty-five years of virtual slavery, according to The United Press.

Inventory control forms are being prepared and will be available to wholesalers and retailers within the next few days, returnable Oct. 25, but no official order is expected to be issued on stock regulation until the results of two quarterly reports have been analyzed, Reavis Cox of the Office of Civilian Supply, WPB, declared yesterday.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Coldstream Stable's Attendant accounted for the $2,500-added Nyatt Handicap for 2-year-olds in a photo finish with the Valdina Farms' Valdina Sol today at Narragansett Park.

HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Hollywood's forgetful bride who says that she cannot remember marrying her second husband told interviewers today that her first husband committed suicide in their sixteen-room home "for me."

In spite of continued heavy liquidation in the October position and more active switching out of that delivery into the distant months the cotton market mustered yesterday sufficient support on the buying side from the trade and commission houses to keep prices at gains throughout the session.

Jean Leonard Musa's attack on the legal adequacy of the indictment accusing him of failure to register as an agent of the Vichy government was sustained in part yesterday by Federal Judge John C. Knox. The court upheld the contention of Musa's assigned counsel, John W. Burke Jr., that the true bill failed to give the defendant sufficient notice of the nature of his alleged crime.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- President Roosevelt had no engagements.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in a speech read for him by Dr. Frederick Coykendall, chairman of the university's board of trustees, before 1,000 students and faculty members in the McMillin Academic Theatre, rededicated the university yesterday to the service of a world at war on the occasion of the opening of Columbia's 189th academic year.

Six men and a woman were placed on trial yesterday in the Federal Court, in Brooklyn, charged with conspiracy to smuggle platinum out of this country in violation of a Presidential proclamation of July 2, 1940. Judge Marcus B. Campbell is presiding over the proceedings and Assistant United States Attorney James D. Saver is conducting the prosecution.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Sept. 24 (U.P.) -- Volga River warships are helping to blast the Germans back from Stalingrad, whose defenders have withstood twelve more tank and infantry assaults and are driving into the flanks of the main German assault force northwest of the city, the Soviet High Command announced today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 23 -- William Dieterle today began directing four weeks of retakes for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Tennessee Johnson" formerly "The Man on America's Conscience," to make the characterization of Thaddeus Stevens, played by Lionel Barrymore, more sympathetic than it was in the original picture.

ALBANY, Sept. 23 -- The State War Ballot Commission was rebuffed again today when, after a conference between Michael F. Walsh, Secretary of State, and members of the commission, it was announced that the secretary would handle the voting of soldiers, sailors, Marines and others under the terms of the Ramsey Act.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, will start his up-State campaign on Tuesday, Oct. 13, with a night speech at Jamestown, Chautauqua County, Vincent Dailey, State campaign manager, announced yesterday.

TEANECK, N.J., Sept. 23 -- A mother of nine sons, four of them in the Army and two others preparing for induction, was making preparations here tonight to give her fifth son a rousing send-off when he leaves to join the armed forces tomorrow.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 23 -- Whether Second Lieutenant John M. Gabriel, Mayor of Garfield, has the right to serve as an Army officer at Fort Eustis, Va., and retain the office of Mayor, conducting his Mayoralty duties from the military camp, will be argued soon in court here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Senate Finance Committee handed over to a subcommittee for study today the problem of revising the method of renegotiating of war contracts.

Efforts of the War Production Board to enlist New York manufacturers of men's shirts and allied products in the production of 8,000,000 cotton khaki shirts being sought by the Philadelphia Quartermaster Corps met with indifferent success yesterday, when only sixty-five of 300 producers responded to an invitation to a meeting at the Chanin Building.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 23 -- The German Propaganda Ministry in Berlin today issued some literature for the use of the radio and press intended to explain that the Stalingrad operation was slowed up by the peculiar nature of the battlefield and also that the German losses there have been scientifically reduced to ridiculously small proportions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (U.P.) -- The State Department has issued regulations controlling international telephone calls to private parties in thirteen countries through which information might be forwarded to Axis enemies.

A chunky, unprepossessing young man was brought into Federal court yesterday and formally accused of deriving $55,000 from three men to whom he had painted a Utopian picture of a world without flat tires. The charge against the man, Pellegrino Vitale, 30 years old, of 34-07 Fifty-sixth Street, Woodside, Queens, was mail fraud.

Stocks of gasoline throughout the country at the end of last week were 80,793,000 barrels, a drop of 965,000 from the 81,758,000 barrels reported for a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago these supplies amounted to 79,195,000 barrels.

When the weekly Federal Reserve Bank figures are released late this afternoon, they probably will show a sharp decline in excess reserves of member banks in this city. One week ago the Federal Reserve Board's cut in reserve requirements here resulted in a jump of more than $400,000,000 in excess funds.

What the Dodgers did against the Phils yesterday at Ebbets Field certainly was not too little, but, all things considered, it may have been too late. Operating on the theory that where there is life there is hope, the Brooks, behind a near-perfect pitching job by Larry French, blanked the visitors, 6 -- 0, and kept alive their chance for the flag, a slim one, even though it was Brooklyn's 100th triumph of the season.

Methods of prolonging the enjoyment and benefits of a victory garden through the Winter months by proper storing of fresh fruits and vegetables were discussed last night before an audience of 200 amateur and professional gardeners by James B. Jack in The New York Times Hall, Forty-fourth Street, west of Broadway.

A sudden gust of wind, sweeping between the skyscraper walls that tower over the terrace roof of the International Building at Rockefeller Center, tore three statues from their pedestals at the Sculptors Guild's outdoor show on the roof early yesterday morning.

After a span of five days in which no new sinkings in Western Atlantic waters had been announced, the Navy disclosed yesterday the loss of two more ships to enemy submarines, with ten men known to be dead and nine-teen others missing.

Commenting the other day on William Harlowe Briggs's novel of a pioneer boyhood in Dakota, it did not escape our John Chamberlain how differently we treated childhood and pioneering in our hard-boiled recent past.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 -- The United Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a brief challenging the right of the commission to order it dissolved under the "death sentence" clause of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, here to attend the first meeting of the company's board of directors ever held outside of New York, declared today that the mills of "Big Steel" can maintain indefinitely their present high rate of production.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- The British campaign to break the backbone of resistance on Madagascar came to a dramatic end tonight when Tananarive was occupied in less than two weeks after the latest drive had opened.
PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Henry J. Kaiser, who has done an amazing job in pushing ship construction, has undertaken another seemingly impossible task.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The National War Labor Board today ordered wage increases of 3 cents to 5.5 cents an hour for 2,000 employes of ten refractory plants and clay mines of three companies. The increases were ordered partly to bring wage increases since January, 1941, up to the 15 per cent advance in living costs and in part to reduce reported wage inequalities with the steel industry and within the plants themselves.

In a letter to THE TIMES, Edward Childs Carpenter, speaking of the danger of inflation, expresses his readiness to follow our President's appeal "to strip civilian economy to the bone." But he also takes the President to task for not doing his part "to help in controlling the ever-rising cost of living."

Although we may face dark days ahead, men's clothing for this Fall will be far from somber, it was revealed yesterday at the sixth semi-annual clinic of the Retail Men's Wear Council of New York at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Plans for the planting of 300,000 acres of hemp for fiber and the construction of seventy-one mills for processing the product into line and tow fiber to be used in the manufacture of rope and twine were approved today by the War Production Board.

The powerful Allied States Association of Motion Picture Theatre Owners has signified its intention to withdraw from the United Motion Picture Industry, thus making more uncertain the future of the all-industry organization which was founded last December to promote greater harmony within the industry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Short-wave broadcasting from this country to Latin America, regarded as an important means af advancing understanding and cooperation in combating Axis activities in this hemisphere, is expected soon to be greatly enlarged in scope as a result of negotiations between the office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs and radio companies.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Buna, Japanese shore base in Northern New Guinea, has been subjected to its tenth consecutive daily attack by Allied warplanes, General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters reported today.

A syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of a new issue of $8,286,000 of Boston Metropolitan District, Mass., bonds dated Oct. 15, 1942, and due serially in varying amounts for Oct. 15, 1943 to 1967. The price paid was 93.288, with the stipulation that the bond bear interest at 1 1/4.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Senate Interstate Commerce Committee unanimously approved today a resolution by Senator Clark of Idaho calling for an investigation to determine whether the order by James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, A.F. of L., forbidding union members to play for recordings of musical programs used by radio stations and coin-operated phonographs, was in restraint of trade.
A High Command communique, broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Although he conceded that there appeared to be "justification for the suspicions" of Saul Berger, defeated for the Democratic nomination for State Senator from the Fourteenth Senatorial District, Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null denied yesterday Mr. Berger's motion for a recount of the primary vote in the district.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Anti-inflation legislation currently under debate in Congress would not vest in President Roosevelt the authority to cause an immediate halt in the advance of farm prices which started with the outbreak of war in Europe in 1939.

The President, and with him the nation, has met with a serious defeat in the fight against inflation. The House of Representatives rejected yesterday the Administration's urgent request for authority to place ceilings on farm prices at less than 110 per cent of "parity."

To find Steve Owen, coach of the New York football Giants, actually laughing as we did yesterday up at Baker Field, where he's whipping his squad of neophytes into shape for the opening league game against the Redskins at Washington on Sunday, was a revelation.

The remodeled street floor, basement and second floor at 30-32 West Thirteenth Street, comprising 22,000 square feet, have been leased by the Fiber Products Company, manufacturer of trunks and sample cases, for sales and manufacturing space. Charles E. Duross Sons were the brokers.

Dein-Bacher of the Waldorf presented his fur forecasts yesterday at luncheon on the Starlight Roof of the Warldorf-Astoria. Simple elegance was the theme of his collection, which displayed handsome pelts worked with a skill that enhanced their natural beauty.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 23 (U.P.) -- Liberator bombers of the United States Army Air Forces attacked Bengazi "in force" at dusk yesterday and British planes followed up during the night with heavy assaults on a wide front, it was revealed tonight.

John Farrow, who wrote the successful "Damien the Leper" back in 1937, has completed his "Pageant of the Popes," a one-volume history of the 260 men from Peter to Pius XII. Sheed and Ward will publish the work Oct. 14. It has been five years since Mr. Farrow started the book but he has been hindered in various ways.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 23 -- Henry Kaiser's Oregon Shipbuilding Company launched the Liberty ship Joseph N. Teal, 10,500 tons, today just ten days after her keel was laid, thereby establishing an all-time record. Her boilers were in and steam was up.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The twenty-fifth little world series starts tomorrow night. The combatants -- Columbus of the American Association and Syracuse of the International League -- finished third in the pennant fights, but breezed through the Shaughnessy play-offs, each winning four straight in the finals.

When Jan. 4 or Jan. 11 arrives there will be an exchange of "Life With Father" companies at the Empire. That is what present plans call for, according to the Oscar Serlin office. On one of the foregoing dates the Howard Lindsay-Dorothy Stickney aggregation (the mother unit)will wend its way either to Cincinnati (Jan. 4) or to Pittsburgh (Jan. 11).

After facing deportation for six years, and separation from his wife and seven children, Thomas Scarpone, 56 years old, of 617 East 182d Street, the Bronx, who received a Presidential pardon for a Federal offense and a Connecticut State pardon for a felony in that State, yesterday made final application for American citizenship.

AT AN ADVANCED BASE AIR FIELD, on a South Pacific island, Aug. 18 (delayed) -- This is an unnamed sergeant's story that he had to interrupt a cannibal feast to recruit native labor to help soldiers, sailors and marines build an air field.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 23 (U.P.) -- A production crippling strike in the smelter division of the Aluminum Company of America plant continued tonight as the strike, involving 225 men, spread to the second shift.

A tremendous increase in sales of rebuilt furniture next year, as a result of the new merchandise shortage expected by then and the increasing uncertainty of families about their future status, was predicted by leading retailers yesterday.

A benefit cocktail party will be given tomorrow afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar L. Rossin, 40 East Sixty-eighth Street, by the junior committee of Russian War Relief, Inc. The party is the first of several fetes to be sponsored by the junior group, which is to take an active part in meeting the quota of $6,000,000, the goal of the relief organization.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, told a Senate Civil Service subcommittee today that the government should be the "ideal employer" in paying its workers, and set a precedent for industry.

Paul Governali and Felix Demartini were named co-captains of the 1942 Columbia football team by special election yesterday. They succeed Captain-elect Joseph Siegal, who left college to attend Northwestern Dental School, and are Columbia's first co-captains since the Fall of 1937.
LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Out of 33,000,000 Britons between the ages of 14 and 65 more than 23,500,000 have been mobilized for full-time national service in some form.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- The fact that crockery is not so plentiful in this country as formerly and that what there is must be handled with care caused a slight hitch at a minor police court hearing today when thirty-four Chinese seamen summoned as witnesses demanded that they take oath in the style to which they are accustomed -- namely, by smashing saucers while they said:

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 23 -- Abbe Pierre, recently purchased by Mrs. Ella K. Bryson from R. Sterling Clark, made good at the first asking for his new owner in the Naval Handicap, a test of a mile and a sixteenth involving six Grade C routers.
Directors of the Anaconda Wire !and Cable Company voted yesteri day a 25-cent dividend, or half the i amount paid on July 20.

HATBORO, Pa., Sept. 23 -- A test pilot of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation, while a thick column of smoke trailed from the light attack bomber he was piloting nearly two miles above Bucks County, calmly carried on a three-way short-wave radio conversation today with the plant and a pilot in a near-by plane.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- A new page was added to British ecclesiastical history today with the inauguration of the British Council of Churches, this country's counterpart of the World Council of Churches advocated at world conferences held in Oxford and Edinburgh in 1937.

Mayor La Guardia made public yesterday two messages he had received commending his plea for moderation in the use of alcoholic beverages in wartime, made at a meeting of the International Association of Police Chiefs at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Major oil companies have been asked to increase tank-car shipments of heating oil to New England to avert "a disastrous situation," by immediate reduction of gasoline shipments to that and other parts of the Atlantic Coast area.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Votes in Congress today on the now almost toothless "anti-inflation" bill, and the atmosphere in which the votes were taken, increase the prospect that the President will have to veto the measure and act against rising prices under his implied war powers, or sign and ignore its fixed inflationary mandates.

The United Nations already are operating on four fronts, each of which is vital, and while the setting up of another front in Western Europe to relieve Russia at the earliest possible moment is urgent, no such action should be taken without adequate preparation and reasonable hope of success, Walter Nash, Minister from New Zealand and member of the Pacific War Council, declared yesterday.

The Cardinals are the hottest thing in baseball at the moment, but the Yankees hardly have been moving in the frigid zone themselves. They beat the Senators yesterday, 4 to 1, in their final regular appearance at the Stadium this season and this was their thirty-first victory in their last forty-five games.

The American Woman's Association has moved from the twenty-eight-story clubhouse it occupied since 1929, erected at a cost of $8,000,000, and is now at home in the Hotel Barclay, 111 East Forty-eighth Street. Furniture and fixtures of the association were moved last week-end, it was learned last night, to the twelve-room apartment on the fourteenth floor of the Barclay, formerly occupied by Harold Vanderbilt.
MOSCOW, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Today's Soviet communique:

The latest raid by British mechanized forces clear across the Libyan desert shows that the Allied High Command in Egypt does not intend to await the course of events or remain on the defensive. This sweep of 500 miles behind the Axis lines to the Gialo oasis deep in the hinterland hints at a great extension of the battlefront in the coming struggle for North Africa.

A group of 607 nurses' aides, said to be the largest number graduated together in the United States, received certificates last night in Erasmus Hall High School, Flatbush and Church Avenues, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The House defied President Roosevelt's "unalterable" opposition to an upward revision of farm price parity tonight, and then adopted by a vote of 284 to 96 a bill to give him statutory powers to curb inflation on that basis.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Because of the high boots they wear and the type of their helmets United States parachute troops in Britain have been taken for Nazi parachutists. What happened showed the alertness of the British Home Guards and the humor with which the Americans and British were able to bridge embarrassing situations.

The manpower problem, which is becoming difficult in the advertising and merchandising fields, will be acute in the post-war period, agency executives declared yesterday, because of the sharp decline in the training of young people for the field.

The semi-annual report of the Stewart-Warner Corporation and its subsidiaries, mailed to stockholders yesterday, shows a net profit for the six months ended with June, of $767.125 after depreciation, $6,432,174 provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes based on the contemplated laws and $250,000 for the contingencies.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Belittling German boasts of having sunk thirty-eight of forty-five ships, the British Admiralty in a communique today announced "the great majority" of an important convoy of United States, British and Russian merchant ships carry ing huge quantities of war materials had reached north Russian ports after an engagement with Nazi submarines and bomber planes on the Arctic supply route.

The Women's Naval Reserve began yesterday to interview applicants to fill the first quota of 255 enlisted women in the Third Naval District. The interviews were held at 33 Pine Street. An appeal to women to do "man-sized" jobs in the organization, popularly known as the Waves, as storekeepers and radio operators, was made.
Although the duck season will not open generally in this State until Oct. 15, it will get under way officially in three up-State counties on Saturday.
QUEBEC, Sept. 23 (U.P.) -- Frelighsburg will remain plain Frelighsburg and not Lidice as far as its most prominent resident, Premier Adelard Godbout of Quebec, is concerned.

A meeting of German-American Bund leaders, at which Gerhard Wilhelm Kunze led his subordinate fuehrers in deciding that the Selective Service Act was designed to eliminate German culture from the United States, was described yesterday in Federal court.

Despite the many striking impressions made on the large pattern of today's writing by talented newcomers, despite vogues and even cults in reading and the not infrequent poor performances of the writers of reputation, the American reading public stands by the American writers whose record is solid, well-deserved and sustained.

City College will open today for its ninety-sixth academic year with close to 15,000 students registered in three divisions of the college, a decline of about 5,000 from last year. The units to convene today are the day session with a registration of 7,500, the evening session with 7,000 and the division of public service training with 300.

A need for continuance of private charities during the war was stressed yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore at which the women's division of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities opened a joint 1942 campaign for funds.

The stock market bridged yesterday a two-month gap as the creeping advance of the last few sessions broadened into a full fledged rally. Stirred by the continued heavy demand for railroad issues, the rest of the list took on surprising life and additions throughout the market averaged a point, with much better gains in individual instances.

Available production of percale sheets and pillow cases for civilian use will be considerably curtailed for the balance of the year, and probably into 1943, while in the volume-selling muslin types the outlook is made uncertain by lack of definite knowledge regarding the extent of government requirements.

THE steam engine and the mass-production factory have changed the external conditions of human life, even if they haven't changed man as a bundle of hopes and desires that are fired by the motive pattern of free will. From this platitudinous observation, which is obvious enough to fully nine-tenths of the population in Western countries, our social theorists proceed to completely nonsensical conclusions.

Ten thousand tons of high-grade scrap metal may be obtained from cemeteries of all denominations in the metropolitan area as a result of the cooperation of the Association of Cemetery Officials in the current salvage campaign, the salvage committee of the New York City Publishers Association announced last night at City Hall.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 23 -- Mexico's production of strategic materials has increased considerably since this country entered the war, it was stated in both Mexican and American circles today.

Kent Miller's Elkridge captured the $3,925 Broad Hollow Steeplechase Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park, but there was so much interest in the victorious return to competition of Colonel Maxwell Howard's Party Buster in another race that the colt was sent to the post the favorite in a field of thirteen, even though he had been absent a year and a half.

THERE certainly is a fast-growing alliance on the field of sport. Practically every event on the calendar is being tied up in some way with the war effort. The campaign of the All-Army football squad is over, but now come the gridiron representatives of the four big Navy preflight schools to take part in the Autumnal scrimmaging.

HONOLULU, Sept. 23 -- The story of three duels between giant bombers over the Solomon Islands, in two of which an American 20-ton Flying Fortress shot down its adversary, a Japanese four-engine Kawanishi flying boat, and in the third of which a Japanese bomber fled to safety in the clouds, was told at United States Army Air Force headquarters here today.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Thursday, Sept. 24 (AP) -- A communique:
In this world of conflicting emotions while feeling is running high, the word "liberal" is suffering unfairly. Who are the liberals?

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- For home owners pondering the problem of converting fuel oil burners to coal this question-and-answer summary was furnished by the War Production Board today, covering questions frequently asked:

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Sept. 22 (Delayed) -- "Now we are cooking with gas," said an officer of the United States Army Air Forces today. So far as the air war in New Guinea is concerned, the officer certainly told the truth.

The International Association of Chiefs of Police closed yesterday a three-day convention in the Hotel Pennsylvania with adoption of two resolutions, one urging the members to give "emergency attention" to enforcement of the national conservation program, particularly the speed limit of 35 miles an hour to save rubber and vehicles, and the other advocating that police departments aid in the salvage of scrap.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Every ton of steel produced by the United States Steel Corporation in the Chicago district is going into the war effort, Irving S. Olds, chairman of the company's board of directors, reported today.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 23 -- The Independent Mine Officials Union of America, through its president, John McAlpine, outlined today a program under which it proposes to demand bargaining agency rights at all coal production operations in the United States.

MOSCOW, Sept. 23 -- The powerful Russian force engaged in a counter-offensive for Stalingrad's relief is gradually driving the enemy back on a broad front northwest of the city. Latest reports indicate that the Germans are counter-attacking strongly but without regaining any ground yielded during the last few days.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A warning that the United States will face a food shortage unless it acts quickly to solve the critical farm labor problem was laid before the House Agriculture Committee today by Secretary Wickard.

Evidence that there are few limits to man's ingenuity was given in Brooklyn Felony Court yesterday when Joseph L. Reed, 43-year-old house painter who lives at a Mills Hotel at 160 Bleecker Street, was arraigned before Magistrate John F.X. Masterson charged with breaking into Local Draft Board 174 at 7718 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, and taking two draft cards beginning with the letter "S."

The Interstate Commission on Crime opened its eighth annual session yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania with government officials and other speakers emphasizing the need for more legislation to eliminate prostitution and a strict control of venereal diseases that would expedite the nation's war program.

Because of an acute shortage of marine radio operators, accentuated by the many new freighter launchings to meet wartime needs, the American Communications Association announced yesterday that a campaign is being inaugurated in the Metropolitan area to recruit 500 men for training in this service to man merchant vessels.

Enlistment of workers for the shipyard plants of Henry J. Kaiser on the Pacific Coast continued here yesterday as 3,000 applicants swamped offices of the United States Employment Service in Manhattan and Brooklyn, where applications were re ceived and checked and the men sent to the Kaiser recruiting station at 381 Fourth Avenue for final examination and selection.

ST. LOUIS, Thursday, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Captain Leonard Murphy of the St. Louis detective force said today that Robert Nash, 27-year-old electrician, had confessed orally to the hatchet slaying of his middle-aged parents, Charles A. Nash, 56, and Eleanor M. Nash, 49.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 23 -- The only feasible solution to India's problems is a return to personal autocratic rulers, the Maharaj-Rana of Dholpur, Sir Udai Bhan Singh Lokindra Bahadur, told this correspondent at luncheon today.
