HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 23 -- In the natural order of things, Dartmouth College this Fall would have had one of the stand-out football teams of the East.

Larry MacPhail's resignation as president and general manager of the Dodgers was accepted last night by the Brooklyn board of directors, effective at the end of the current season. MacPhail's decision to relinquish these positions was prompted not by any dissension between him and the board, it was said, but because he hopes to report to the Army by the end of this week.

The ten-point declaration of principles which the House Republicans have issued on the subject of war aims and peace aims is a major political document. In it the Administration Democrats will find reservations and implications with which they will not agree. One or two of the Republican points are debatable for other than partisan reasons.
LONDON, Sept. 23 (U.P.) -- Reports from the Netherlands today said German authorities were strengthening coastal defenses and fighting a rising tide of sabotage.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Efforts of the Senate farm bloc to raise parity prices on agricultural products by including the costs of farm labor and reports that sufficient votes had been mustered to insure adoption of the amendment to the price-control bill were construed by wheat traders today as bullish on that grain.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 23 -- Raymond J. Whitney, suspended as City Manager of Yonkers by the Common Council on Aug. 25, filed a demand for a hearing today on the charges made against him and indicated that he would fight to be reinstated by characterizing the charges as "trivial" and "unworthy of serious consideration."
The New York Central Railroad moved 111,891 loaded freight cars last week, a record for the company, F.E. Williamson, president, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- Senator Harry S. Truman, who recently charged that American fighter planes were "inferior" to those of Britain and the Axis, said after a conference with Army Air Force officers today that he was convinced our aircraft quality was "definitely on the mend."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Finnish Legation today denied Soviet charges that Finnish units have been sent to the Russian front and are fighting in the elbow of the Don. There might be some Finnish volunteers in German ranks, it was said, but no Finnish units.
I would like to make a suggestion to the kindly ladies who knit comforts for the various organizations that look after the men of the merchant navy.

Alman Harrington, 23-year-old electrician's helper, whose four small children were returned to him by a Supreme Court order, died at 4:30 P.M. yesterday at the home of his grandmother, Mrs. Mary Malloy, at 1860 Patterson Avenue, the Bronx, after lingering between life and death since June 23, when he was shot in the spine by his 21-year-old wife Anna.

Medieval architects, whose work he so much admired, were largely anonymous. It was his merit and good fortune to leave enduring monuments as his remembrancers. The Cathedral of St. John the Divine he transformed from Romanesque to Gothic.

Triangle Publications has sold the five-story brick loft building at 112 Fourth Avenue to Ida Belle Lathrop through Joseph P. Day, broker. Assessed at $42,000, the property is on a plot 27 by 116 feet and is in the same block as Grace Church, at the corner of East Tenth Street.

On the lower East Side is a tremendous market, featuring everything from soup greens to anchovies, including a well-stocked dairy counter. This store-within-a-store boasts, in addition to milk, butter and eggs, 190 varieties of cheese. A large number of these cheeses are imported; many are domestic, made in this country by adopted Americans and refugees who received their training on the other side.

Arrangements have been completed for the Holy Name Society patriotic rally and holy hour at Yankee Stadium on Sunday afternoon, it was announced yesterday by Mgr. Joseph A. McCaffrey, spiritual director of the New York Archdiocesan Union of the Holy Name Society and pastor of Holy Cross Church.

Americans have been thinking of France in terms of Vichy French and Fighting French. Our attention has been divided between the France that works with Germany and the France that joins its old allies in open war against the common enemy. As active forces, both these groups are small.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Most sections of the stock markets were cheered slightly today by the better news coming from Russia. Gilt-edge stocks rose 1/16 to 1/8 under the leadership of the 3 1/2 per cent War Loan, which changed hands at 106 1/16 in anticipation of the half-yearly deduction of interest from the price on Oct. 26.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- Members of the Controllers' Institute of America were told today by Ellsworth C. Alvord, Washington attorney and authority on Federal taxation, that both the Treasury tax program and the revenue bill as passed by the lower House "will have substantially no effect in the fight on inflation, and will seriously interfere with war production."

Net income of the Standard Gas and Electric Company for the twelve months ended on June 30, as reported yesterday by Leo T. Crowley, chairman, amounted to $918,690, after expenses, taxes and other charges. This compared with $1,004,396 in the twelve months to June 30, 1941. For the first sixth months of this year, net income was $225,291, against $379,107 in the same period a year ago.

The law's strong arm went to work yesterday in the city's war drive to make the dimout safer and to help save the nation's vital rubber in automobile tires. On the first day of "double" fines for speeding, the law penalized 119 drivers $10 or more each.

Fatal cancer is most frequently located in the stomach and cancer of that organ occurs "two or three times" as often in the Japanese as in white races, Dr. George T. Pack, attending surgeon at Memorial Hospital, declared yesterday in a talk before 150 officers of the Women's Field Army of the American Society for the Control of Cancer, who are completing a two weeks' course here.
An eleven-year-old murder mystery appeared solved yesterday when the office of District Attorney Frank Hogan announced that a remorseful convict in Dannemora Prison had confessed the crime.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 23 -- While Allied planes, warships and landing parties were raiding Tobruk the night of Sept. 13-14, British mobile columns attacked Bengazi, which is 200 miles west of Tobruk, and the road junction of Barce, which is fifty miles northeast of Bengazi.

BOSTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A threatened strike of 1,700 employes of the Eastern Massachusetts Street Railway, which serves seventy-two communities, was "called off" tonight as workers and management agreed to submit their dispute to the State Board of Arbitration.
The War Department's revival of the regulation requiring officers and men to exchange salutes on all occasions is not relished by either the rank or the file.

War bond pledges exceeding $2,000,000 were given last night at a dinner at the Hotel Biltmore attended by 250 guests of Generoso Pope, contractor and publisher of Italian language newspapers, who is chairman of the War Savings Committee of Americans of Italian Extraction.

The Women's National Radio Committee, together with the National Information Bureau of Women's War Activities, an affiliate, whose functions are to act as an information exchange and coordinating office among women's organizations engaged in voluntary war activities, yesterday held a luncheon meeting of sixteen of the twenty-four voluntary services at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 23 -- Members of the Interstate Commerce Commission turned to a study of controversial North-South freight rate differentials today as a possible month-long hearing entered its second day here.

Three new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall the new comer will be "Tales of Manhattan," a five-episode drama, directed by Julien Duvivier, produced by Boris Morros and S.P. Eagle and released by Twentieth Century-Fox.

Alexander Fraser, president of the Shell Oil Company, has leased a large apartment in 300 Park Avenue through Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers, who also leased suites in 444 Park Avenue to Midd Buda Baker; in 101 West Fifty-fifth Street to Paul Stewart, and in 47 East Forty-ninth Street to Marvin De Witt Rae.

MAIMI, Fla., Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Miami Daily News said today that the richest purses offered for horse racing in Florida would be reduced drastically, at least for the coming season, because of wartime conditions.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A joint British. Headquarters-R.A. F. communique:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -The Census Bureau reported today that cotton of this year's growth ginned to Sept. 16 totaled 2,075,168 running bales, counting round as half bales and excluding lintcrs. compared with 2,091.389 bales a year ago and 1,805,025 bales two years ago.

LONDON, Sept. 23 (U.P.) -- A Japanese Imperial Headquarters communique heard by radio here today said that a United States cruiser of the Northampton class had been "seriously damaged" on Aug. 31 when a Japanese submarine made a surprise attack in Nazan Bay of Atka Island in the Aleutians.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration imposed specific price control tonight over about one-fourth of the entire two and one-half billion dollar printing and publishing industry, but exempted the neighborhood printshop and the publishers of books, newspapers and periodicals.

TRENTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- New Jersey men married prior to October, 1940, start of the Selective Service program, will not be called in the draft next month, Lieut. Col. Edgar N. Bloomer said today, because the State's October quota was overly large in proportion to those of many other States.

The principal aims motivating the three publications of the armed services in their efforts to reach the enlisted man were described in detail yesterday by their respective editors at a luncheon of the Overseas Press Club, at the Hotel Belmont-Plaza.

MOSCOW, Sept. 22 -- A front dispatch to a Finnish newspaper acknowledges, despite a previous official denial, that Finnish troops are participating in the German attempt to capture Stalingrad, it was revealed today.
CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A joint British. Headquarters-R.A. F. communique:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -The Census Bureau reported today that cotton of this year's growth ginned to Sept. 16 totaled 2,075,168 running bales, counting round as half bales and excluding lintcrs. compared with 2,091.389 bales a year ago and 1,805,025 bales two years ago.

LONDON, Sept. 23 (U.P.) -- A Japanese Imperial Headquarters communique heard by radio here today said that a United States cruiser of the Northampton class had been "seriously damaged" on Aug. 31 when a Japanese submarine made a surprise attack in Nazan Bay of Atka Island in the Aleutians.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission eliminated today from its "death sentence" action against the Niagara Hudson Power Company any consideration of a prohibition oil the payment of dividends by two of the corporation's subsidiaries, the Buffalo, Niagara Eastern Power Company and the Niagara Falls Power Company.

With its last exhibits of fruit going under the auctioneer's hammer to aid the relief funds of the Army and the Navy, the New York Victory Garden Harvest Show closed last night at Grand Central Palace.

A Maroon squad of thirty-three players started west from Grand Central Terminal last night to open Fordham's fifty-fourth football season with the hardest opening-day assignment in years facing them tomorrow in Lafayette, Ind.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 - Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, today announced reductions in manufacturers' ceiling prices for carded cotton sales yarns, base material for all of the more common grades of cotton fabrics. The action was taken to prevent increases in prices which consumers must pay for cotton goods.

For the first time in New York County and, it is believed, in the State, a husband and wife sat yesterday in Supreme Court on the same jury -- a jury in which there were seven women to five men. They were chosen as jurors No. 2 and No. 3 for the trial of a $50,000 negligence action before Justice Peter Schmuck.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Axis broadcasts to Europe in the last twenty-four hours have sought to divert attention from Stalingrad and to direct it toward the Caucasian front, notably Terek, while they devoted even more time and effort to an attempt to widen the gap between Russia and the Western democracies by arguing that the United States and Britain had no intention of aiding Russia.
The address of Assistant Secretary of the Navy Ralph A. Bard yesterday follows:

Engineering construction awards for the current week amount to $147,699,000, about 28 per cent below the figure for last week and 10 per cent under the corresponding period in 1941, according to a survey made by Engineering News-Record.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The War Production Board added new zest today to the newspaper-directed scrap drive by offering awards of plaques and pennants to States and counties piling up the biggest heaps of material for the blast furnaces.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- Edward Haight, 17-year-old confessed slayer of Margaret Lynch, 7 years old, and her sister, Helen, 8, was arraigned today in Westchester County Court on indictments accusing him of the kidnapping and first degree murder of the girls.

It is now reported that about 20,000 gasoline ration books were stolen in Norwalk, Conn., last week. If the perpetrators succeed in disposing of their loot this means that about $800,000 worth of gasoline, or approximately 4,000,000 gallons, will find its way into the tanks of persons illegally entitled to it.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 24 --Despite the pressure of the farm bloc in Congress to take the teeth out of the price-control bill, the farmers of the country continue to be ready to accept farm-price control along lines laid down by President Roosevelt in his Labor Day broadcast.

Under the impact of new Treasury financing and the quarterly tax-period shifts of funds, excess reserves of member banks of the entire Federal Reserve System fell $1,010,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $2,030,000,000, and excess reserves of New York City member banks dropped $415,000,000 to $210,000,000.
MOSCOW, Friday Sept. 25 (AP) -- The midnight communique:

Five thousand homes for war workers, 3,500 of them in the Fort Greene Houses near the Brooklyn Navy Yard, others under construction or contracted for in North and South Tonawanda, Niagara Falls, Schenectady and Elmira, are the contribution of New York State's housing program to the present emergency.

After a temporary curtailment of advertising, the joint committee representing the Pan-American Coffee Bureau and the National Coffee Association will resume advertising next month with an extensive campaign designed to acquaint the public with the facts about coffee and to maintain its leadership as the national beverage.

Under the heaviest trading of the year the stock market challenged yesterday its July highs as the extension of the week's recovery added fractions to 2 points to prices. Except for a session last February, the day's activity was the most inclusive so far this year as both speculative and investment buying came into the market at the opening in such force as to start trading off in blocks of 1,000 to 5,000 shares.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Indians' fourth-place lead over Detroit was slashed to half a game today by the White Sox, who won a twin bill, 3 to 1 and 4 to 2.

In October a selection from the works of "the greatest living American writers" is to be published. It is surprising to find that there are only ninety-three of these eminences. To pick them out the publishers impaneled a jury of subscribers to certain magazines, booksellers, librarians, book reviewers, and so on.

Though girls attending the City College day session, at 139th Street and Convent Avenue, no longer have the priority on men which they once enjoyed when there were about 1,000 boys to a girl, four women freshmen who started classes yesterday with 6,000 male students expressed themselves as satisfied with the diminished ratio which now allots them each only about 400 men.

Wall Street is joining today with the American Women's Voluntary Services in a monster block party with the double purpose of selling war bonds and raising money to pay for more ambulances for the undersupplied financial district. Broad Street from Wall to Beaver is to be roped off all day and from 4 to 8 P.M. the double block will be the scene of the largest rally ever held there.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 24 -- Betty Huttton was named today by Paramount to play Texas Guinan in "The Smoothest Gal in Town," a life story of the night club queen of the Nineteen Twenties written by Claude Binyon. Alan Ladd will play the male lead in the film, which will go before the cameras after Miss Hutton completes a role in "The Miracle of Morgan's Creek," Preston Sturges's next production for Paramount.
VICHY, France, Sept. 24 -- The occupation of Tananarive, the capital of Madagascar, by British forces was confirmed in an official communique issued here tonight.
Your editorial of Sept. 17, "When Britain Stood Alone" does you great honor. I read it with no little emotion.
The first gun has been fired by the Westchester Sportsmen's Legislative Council in a new drive for the enactment of various conservation measures.

The immediate opening of a second front to aid Russia was demanded by speakers at a meeting yesterday afternoon in the north section of Union Square, under the auspices of the New York State Committee of the Communist party.
LONDON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Even after Pearl Harbor, but before they took steps toward the formal, outward dissolution of the German-American Bund, the leaders of that organization made preparations to continue their movement in other forms, according to testimony given yesterday in Federal court

An aggressive policy for the drug industry in meeting the problems generated by the war economy was outlined yesterday by Fred J. Griffiths, secretary of the National Association of Chain Stores, at the war merchandising clinic of the Federal Wholesale Druggists Association at the Hotel Biltmore. Holding it was a mistake for business to don sackcloth because of the difficulties it faces, Mr. Griffiths urged a "heads-up" policy.

Twenty-five mail bags of election ballots, to be sent to New Yorkers in the armed services in the United States, were prepared for shipment to various camps yesterday by the Board of Elections, 400 Broome Street Edward McGowan, secretary of the board, revealed that 20,000 applications for ballots had been received from New York State citizens in the armed forces.

LAUGHING Larry MacPhail gave the fans, the players and his fellow-magnates in baseball many a laugh while he was bossing the Dodgers, but he didn't leave 'em laughing. For one thing, he said good-bye to baseball to go into the Army. That's no laughing matter; not if a man can read and has been following the war news arriving from all directions.

NANUET, N.Y., Sept. 24 -Eight youthful inmates of the Rockland State Hospital here escaped last night, armed themselves with six revolvers and two rifles stolen from a local gunsmith and disturbed the night rest of several hundred residents in the vicinity before they were recaptured by police this morning.
MOSCOW, Sept. 24 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

The featherweight championship of the world will be at stake tonight when Chalky Wright, Los Angeles veteran, seeks to defend the title against Lulu Costantino of the East Side in a fifteen-round clash at Madison Square Garden. The meeting will be the second between the pair, Wright having defeated his New York rival in an over-the-weight clash of eight rounds last Spring.
LONDON. Sept. 24 -- British troops are in possession of Tananative, capital of Madagascar, but the tricolor of France flies everywhere on the island where it is normally flown.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Sept. 24 -- Vice Chancellor Maja Leon Barry signed today a decree in a civil action permitting Mrs. Mary Gunther of Asbury Park and William T. Decker of Newark to levy upon any property they might find held in the name of J. Clarence Carr for the satisfaction of claims they have against his wife, Mrs. Amelia Carr, now in prison for swindling large sums from New Jersey residents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- While government officials dealing with manpower problems agreed today that a critical labor shortage was the main deterrent to increased non-ferrous metal production, spokesmen for twenty-nine Western zinc, copper and lead mining and smelting companies opposed the wage increase suggested by a panel of the War Labor Board.

We can only guess what Wendell Willkie and Joseph Stalin talked about as they sat together while the terrible battle for Stalingrad thundered in the background. We do not know what they thought of each other -- the big, breezy, casual, open-faced American and the short, compact, strong-armed and wary-eyed chief of the Soviet Government.

Henri Bendel presented Young-Timers fashions and furs yesterday at luncheon in the newly decorated Persian Room of the Hotel Plaza. The aim of the show was to demonstrate that smart clothes and fur coats may be had at moderate prices.

Final plans have been completed for the second Junior Officers Ball to be held tomorrow night in the Whitelaw Reid mansion, 451 Madison Avenue, under the sponsorship of the Committee for American War Work of the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies.
Investment buying of housing properties formed the bulk of realty trading in Manhattan yesterday.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 24 -- A 39-year-old German was sent to Ellis Island today as "a dangerous enemy alien" after the Federal Bureau of Investigation here had discovered that he maintained a small bank account in Mexico City and had a considerable amount of photographic equipment in his home in Union City, N.J.

Lewis J. Valentine today begins his ninth year as Commissioner of the largest police force in the country, holding the distinction of having that title longer than any other in the history of the city's Police Department. Marking the occasion, Mr. Valentine departed from a rigid custom and consented to a press interview yesterday.

DICKERSON, Md., Sept. 24 -- Toiling rescue crews tonight had removed twelve bodies from the twisted wreckage of two passenger trains and a fast freight in which twenty persons were believed to have died.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Sept. 25 (U.P.) -- Allied heavy bombers probably sank an 8,000-ton Japanese cargo ship with a direct hit yesterday in the harbor of Rabaul, New Britain, while medium bombers were pounding Buka, northernmost of the Solomon Islands, for the fifth time in nine days, it was announced today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 24 -- When the late John Buchan wrote "The Thirty-Nine Steps" he, of course, did not refer to the bucolic surroundings in which the Brooklyn Football Dodgers find themselves. Anyway, the Dodgers would have had no place in that spy story of the last war.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden predicted today that "at the appointed hour" Yugoslav military resistance will lead to the bursting of the entire Balkans into revolt against Adolf Hitler.

Probable extension of future government requirements in both cotton and rayon textiles, to keep pace with more rapid "wastage" of supplies that usually accompanies transition from defensive to far-flung offensive military campaigns, is expected to reduce civilian supplies of most types of fabrics used in women's and children's undergarments.

HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Finnish Information Bureau tonight issued a communique branding as "false and foundationless" foreign reports that the Finnish Legation in Washington had intimated Finland was ready for a separate peace with the Soviet Union.

The War Shipping Administration is anxious to have its cargo war-risk policies meet the needs of the importing industry and will act on all valid requests for adjustment when such requests are submitted to its Advisory Committee of Underwriters through legitimate trade associations, Henry C. Thorn member of the advisory group and chairman of the rate and underwriting committee of the American Cargo War Risk Reinsurance Exchange, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The government asked all civilians today to make a voluntary cut in their normal meat consumption to not more than two and a half pounds of beef, veal, pork, lamb or mutton per person per week, and at the same time implemented the request by cutting meat deliveries into retail channels by an average of 21 per cent.

MOSCOW, Sept. 24 -- Wendell L. Willkie will take back to President Roosevelt a deep and disturbing impression of Russian dissatisfaction over the failure of the Western Allies to establish a second front in Europe. That was obvious here today after Mr. Willkie's Kremlin audience with Joseph Stalin.

ALBANY, Sept. 24 (AP) -- A 25 per cent reduction in New York's 1942 Summer resort business was attributed by the State Division of Commerce today to gasoline and tire rationing and other wartime touring difficulties.
AT UNITED NATION HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Sept. 25 -- A communique:

With practice sessions cut to one a day with the opening of classes yesterday, Columbia's football squad took its last heavy workout at Baker Field in preparation for tomorrow's opener against Fort Monmouth.

Directors of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation passed yesterday the dividends on the corporation's first and second 5 per cent preferred stocks, normally payable on Nov. 1. They also elected Earle J. Machold as president of the corporation to succeed the late Alfred H. Schoellkopf. Mr. Machold also was made a director.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Sept. 24 -- All important coal mines in the Waikato region are being brought under government control for the duration of the war as part of a government plan to smooth out production difficulties, the Minister of Mines, P. C. Webb, announced last night.

One four-run burst in the sixth inning at Ebbets Field yesterday was enough to send the Dodgers away to a 5-3 triumph over the Braves and keep the Brooks in the National League pennant race. But they stayed in only by the thinnest thread of a mathematical chance.

Axis submarines have sunk two medium-sized cargo ships in the North Atlantic, it was announced yesterday by the Navy Department. These losses brought The Associated Press's total of sinkings in western Atlantic waters since Pearl Harbor to 475.

The Cincinnati Museum is celebrating Charles Dana Gibson's seventy-fifth birthday this month with a retrospective exhibition of that artist's work. The show opens on Monday evening with a preview at the museum and to the public the next day.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 24 -- A new United States Army tank-repair depot that was begun four months ago on a barren strip of desert and is still under construction turned out its first rebuilt tank today. The British Commander in Chief in the Middle East, General Sir Harold R. L. G. Alexander, drove the machine out.

Burdened with problems domestic and financial, service men and members of their families are making their ways to the legal advice bureau set up for them by the, New York Women's Bar Association in headquarters of the American Women's Voluntary Services, 11 West Fifty-seventh Street.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 24 -- A protest against the United States Treasury Department's decision to charge import duties on Christmas presents sent by soldiers to their families was made in today's issue of The C.B.I. Roundup, the United States Army weekly publication for China, Burma and India.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Fighting French fighter group Normandie composed of pilots who have battled Axis forces in the skies over France, Britain and the Middle East, will operate in Russia as a French unit under the general command of the Soviet Air Forces, it was announced today by the Fighting France delegation in Washington.

A long war will mean the end of "luxury medical care," even for those who can afford it, according to Dr. Samuel Binkley, medical director of the American Society for the Control of Cancer. He spoke at a session of the first national training school for officers of the Women's Field Army, the lay educational arm of the cancer society, yesterday at clinical lectures in the Memorial Hospital, 444 East Sixty-eighth Street.

The use of the civilian defense organization to combat the large increase in crime which he expects after the war was suggested yesterday to the members of the Interstate Commission on Crime by William J. Ellis, Commissioner of Institutions and Agencies of New Jersey.

FORT RILEY, Kan., Sept. 24 --Ten members of the Women's Auxiliary Army Corps, most of whom have had previous experience in some phase of food handling, are learning how the Army does it by taking the mess officers' course at the service command school for bakery cooks here.
LONDON, Sept. 24 -- "Damn well go and silence that machinegun post."

Robert A. Lovett, assistant Secretary of War for Air, told 200 leading bankers and financiers yesterday that he would rather "have Russia on my side" than to depend on the "complacent and illusory theory that we are bound to win because treasure and time are on our side."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- A "ration-banking" plan under which business men could transfer ration credits through special bank accounts in the same way in which they transfer money by check has been worked out by the Office of Price Administration.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 24 -- It has happened about once in a blue moon that a secondary school football coach has made the jump in one fell swoop into the big time of a major college portfolio.

A Yale Review anthology will be published Oct. 13, the editing work of Wilbur L. Cross and Helen MacAfee. The two have worked through the reviews of thirty years, a task that resulted, Dr. Cross says, in "an embarrassment of riches."

Ralph A. Bard, Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Labor Relations, yesterday told the convention of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers at the Hotel New Yorker that this country was losing the war and that "we should damn well understand it" if the nation is to avoid disaster.

Final plans for the four-block test scrap drive that Bundles for America will conduct as an experiment in advance of the city-wide collection scheduled for next month were completed yesterday at a meeting in the Hotel Ambassador.

MOSCOW, Sept. 24 -- The Russian writer and playwright Konstantine Simonoff, now in Stalingrad, contributes to the army newspaper Red Star today a remarkable dispatch from the city. He describes the battle area as a forty-mile belt along the Volga bend, consisting of Stalingrad itself and clusters of satellite villages, settlements and partly built-up districts. At right angles to the river run several deep ravines.

The growing trend in juvenile delinquency and the possible steps to combat it were discussed yesterday afternoon when representatives of city-wide agencies working on recruiting, training and placement of volunteers in child-care met in the Board of Estimate chamber at City Hall with Dr. Alice V. Kiliher, newly appointed chairman of Child Care, Development and Protection for the Greater New York Civilian Defense Office.

Millions of pounds of steel scrap awaits only a picking up on Long Island. I refer to the use of old steel rails which are cut to approximately six-foot lengths and driven into the ground close together along the right-of-way and at stations to form a picket fence.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Sept. 24 (Wide World) -- Only one person in a thousand escapes malnutrition, according to the conclusion of a survey published today by the Ellen H. Richards Institute at the Pennsylvania State College.

LONDON, Sept. 24 (U.P.) -- Private advices received here today said Adolf Hitler had asked Italy, Bulgaria, Rumania and Hungary to send six more divisions -- about 100,000 troops -- into Yugoslavia to guard Axis supply lines to Russia and North Africa and to combat guerrillas and saboteurs.

A nation has that form of government which it wants and is governed or ruled by the sort of government which it wants. Every one of us is responsible for our government and is to blame for its mistakes.

Coach Steve Owen must be pretty well satisfied with the eleven men who started for the Giants in the winning game ver the Western Army All-Stars last Saturday, because he is sending the same combination against the Redskins in the National Football League opener in Washington on Sunday.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Cannon Ball, G. H. Benham's trotter, beat a classy field, including five Hambletonian money winners, in the $2,500 stake for 3-year-olds at the Delaware Grand Circuit meeting today.

Women's role in the war, its limitations through prejudices, its scope in response to supply and demand and its post-war adjustment, were subjected to clinical and experienced reviews yesterday as 200 women business, professional, government and club leaders met for an all-day conference in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, went on a handshaking tour of Brooklyn last night, in territory which in the past has rolled up large Democratic majorities, and received an extremely cordial reception.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Loss of the destroyer Jarvis and a small auxiliary transport, the Little, with indicated deaths of between 250 and 275 men as a result of action in the Solomon Islands was announced by the Navy today.

WASHINGTON, Sept 24 -- The death of Lieutenant George Houk Mead Jr., Marine Corps, during the offensive against the Japanese in the Solomon Islands on Aug. 19 was announced by the Navy Department today. Lieutenant Mead was a son of George H. Mead, a member of the National War Labor Board and president of the Mead Corporation of Dayton, Ohio.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 24 -- President Juan Antonio Rios declared at a press conference today that no agreements of any kind would be signed by him during his visit to the United States, explaining that his announced trip, on which he expected to start Oct. 15, was merely the result of an invitation -- much esteemed by Chile -- that President Roosevelt had extended and that the trip would be carried out with absolute freedom.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- A call for "full production from now on" in the country's coal mines came today from Harold L. Ickes, in his capacity of solid fuels coordinator, as he called producers and union representatives to Washington to discuss longer working hours.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 24 Asserting that American colleges were facing "very great" challenges today, President Franklin D. Roosevelt, in a message read here today, warned that victory without "a worthy and permanent peace" would be futile.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 24 -- The Westchester County Golf Association and the Westchester division of the Metropolitan P.G.A. joined hands to stage a gala wartime championship tournament at the Metropolis Country Club today. At sunset, Paul Runyan of Metropolis was acclaimed the Westchester open champion, and the Winged Foot team of Craig Wood, pro, and George Dawson received the Westchester pro-amateur title.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Senate Finance Committee voted today to recommend that the Social Security payroll tax be "frozen'' for 1943 at the present level of 1 per cent on the employer and 1 per cent on the employe. It rejected a proposal to tax "excess profits" of individuals.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Department store sales showed a gain of 5 per cent during the week ended Sept. 19 as compared with the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. This gain followed a decrease of 3 per cent in the preceding week. Sales for the latest four-week period increased 3 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Agriculture Department economists estimated today that the parity price formula proposed in the House version of the anti-inflation legislation would increase present parity prices about 12 per cent.

Walter A. Mungeer, an assessor in the Tax Department since 1917, yeas sworn in at City Hall by Mayor La Guardia yesterday as a member of the Tax Commission to succeed Joseph Lilly, who resigned in June to join the Army Air Corps intelligence service.

It is to be hoped that one of the silliest and most useless officials -- the notary public -- will soon go the way of the dodo without even bothering to have his exit notarized. There is hope for this public reform because the United States Treasury, following New York State, has at last recognized the needlessness of having an income tax return notarized.
LONDON, Sept. 24 -- The Nazis claimed a further toll of United Nations shipping on the Arctic supply route in broadcasts today that London again dismissed as greatly exaggerated.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt dropped in at Arnold Constable's for fifteen minutes yesterday to try on a new two-piece dress in the presence of reporters and photographers.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept, 24 (UP) -- Clayton Lambert, tall righthander, handcuffed the defending champion Columbus Redbirds with five hits tonight as the Syracuse Chiefs, International League playoff champions, defeated the American Association play-off winners, 6 to 1, in the opening contest of the twenty-fifth little world series.

VICHY, France, Sept. 24 -- Skilled French workers will be officially asked to volunteer their, services in Germany, but they will have no legal obligations to accept and no coercion will be exerted upon them, it was stressed in authorized circles here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Senate struggle over a farm parity formula in its anti-inflation bill seemed to be moving toward compromise late today after Senator Brown of Michigan, who was in charge of the measure, warned that "the Congress of the United States and the President are headed for a collision."

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 24 -- No one in France is supposed to know of the third British broadcast to coastal populations announcing the preparation of another landing on French soil. In both zones of France press and radio ignore it, but private advices make it clear that the thousands who listen clandestinely to London have noted the warning to leave the coastal zone.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 24 -- The stock of Mrs. Clare Booth Luce of Greenwich, Republican candidate for Congress, went up today after the Socialist party here named David Mansell, Stamford architect, who lives in Old Greenwich, as their Congressional candidate.

Mrs. Anna Harrington, 21 years old, whose 23-year-old husband, Alman, died Wednesday from a bullet wound inflicted by her on June 23, was arrested yesterday at the home of her parents, 111-22 Witoff Street, Queens Village, and formally charged with homicide.

Louis Calhern and Dorothy Gish yesterday signed contracts with Herman Shumlin for the featured roles in "The Great Big Doorstep." This is the dramatization by Frances Goodrich and Albert Hackett of E.P. O'Donnell's novel of the same name.

Mme. Wellington Koo, wife of the Chinese Ambassador to Great Britain, and other members of a special advisory committee which she heads met at luncheon yesterday at Hampshire House to further plans for an exhibit of modern design based on centuries-old Chinese culture.

Considerable quantities of inexpensive blossoms are available in this week's retail market, despite a not-too-rosy state of affairs. The most conspicuous are the dahlias which arrive -- about 9,000 of them daily -- from Long Island and New Jersey. Plump, pink ones are called Jersey Beauties, while the diminutive white variety are named Jean Kerr.

CHANDLER, Ariz., Sept. 24 (U.P.) -- Two twin-engined Army training bombers were in collision over a bombing target about six miles southeast of Florence, Ariz., today, killing four flying officers and four bombardier cadets.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Alaska Highway will be ready for use about Dec. 1, Secretary Stimson said today, and traffic is expected to move steadily over its 1,600 miles until Spring thaws make it impassable in April and May.

Hiring of men for the Pacific Coast shipyards of Henry J. Kaiser was halted until further notice last night on orders of Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, acting at the request of Mr. Kaiser's agents, Who have been enlisting New York workers since Tuesday.

BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, British West Indies, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Seventeen American men, women and children of missionary families have reached safety here after drifting on a raft from their torpedoed ship for nearly three weeks, every day of which they prayed and sang hymns led by children.
MOSCOW, Sept. 24 -- Rear Admiral Boddam-Whetham, commodore of a great convoy of British, Russian and American ships that recently arrived at Northern Russian ports, is now in Moscow.

"Desperate Journey," a Warner Brothers topical adventure starring Errol Flynn and Ronald Reagan, will open this morning at the Strand. Among the players in the supporting cast are Nancy Coleman, Raymond Massey, Arthur Kennedy, Alan Hale and Albert Basserman.
Having third place clinched and facing nothing more formidable than the Phils, Manager Mel Ott tried a couple of experiments at the Polo Grounds yesterday with moderate success.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- An audience of notables sat on a wooden knoll on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Davies today and heard the Soviets' battle against the Axis extolled by Vice President Wallace, Secretary Jones, Associate Justice Jackson of the Supreme Court and members of the Senate and House.

Although sales of the Masonite Corporation in its fiscal year which ended with August rose to $17,306,209 from $13,109,030 the year before, the net profit declined, largely because of increased taxes, according to the preliminary report of the company announced yesterday.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Dr. Hermann Rauschning, a former confident of Adolf Hitler, testified today in prosecution efforts to prove that nine Friends of Progress defendants followed the policy laid down by the German Fuehrer for political conquest of the United States.

The five-cent piece which Out of is called a nickel because Their it is made of nickel is Name henceforth to be made of copper. The one-cent piece, which is frequently and affectionately called a copper because it is made of copper, is henceforth to be made of something else, not yet determined.

ALL the world may be a stage; but the stage has always been a remote and foreign country inhabited by natives as strange and exotic as Buriat Mongols or Andaman Islanders to most of the world. Behind the scenes, backstage and curtain call are romantic, glamorous terms to the average citizen, largely because they refer to a life of which he knows so little by actual experience and so much by tinseled falsification.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Rhode Island WPA Symphony Orchestra has become a sacrifice to the war effort, because many of its musicians are playing a new tune -- the swelling symphony of war industry jobs.

A new issue of $40,000,000 of New York City revenue bills was allotted yesterday by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick to a group of about seventeen Wall Street banks and investment houses. The bills are dated Sept. 25 and will be payable Nov. 4. The interest rate is 0.55 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24 -The right of the Securities and Exchange Commission to require complete reorganization of an operating company if such action is in line with an equitable distribution of the voting power of the concern has just been affirmed by a Federal district court, the commission learned today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 - Reasons for the telegram sent President Roosevelt urging an investigation by the Baruch committee of the "chaos" in the food industry are due for disclosure on Oct. 6 when representatives of the National Association of Retail Grocers ap-

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 24 -- Berlin is hinting today that Italian and German motor torpedo boats are being shipped by canal from the Black Sea to the Caspian Sea for an attack against the Soviet fleet there.

PORT HURON, Mich., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Theodore Dreiser, American novelist who was barred from making public speeches or statements in Canada this week because of remarks which the Canadian Government said were anti-British, described himself here today as "the No. 1 victim of the four freedoms."

If Mrs. John D. Hertz hasn't the Futurity favorite in Count Fleet, a brown son of her own Reigh Count, then 12,248 persons who were at Belmont Park yesterday will be greatly surprised. Under top weight of 122 pounds, Count Fleet dashed six furlongs in 1:10 3-5 and won very decisively from a dozen other first-flight 2-year-olds.
LONDON, Sept. 24 -- The news from Madagascar and the continued resistance of the Russians at Stalingrad had a heartening effect on today's stock markets, where all sections were cheerful.

A bit of feudalism in modern clothes, speaking cultivated English, stepped into the sunlight of New Delhi the other day for an interview with our correspondent, Herbert L. Matthews. His name and titles, as given in the resulting dispatch, are the Maharaj-Rana of Dholpur, Sir Udai Bhan Singh Lokindra Bahadur.

Declaring that the Democratic party had been strangled by the New Deal and had become the party of collectivism and national socialism, Samuel B. Pettingill, chairman of the finance committee of the Republican National Committee, appealed yesterday to Jeffersonian Democrats to join with Republicans in electing an anti-New Deal Congress and obtain greater efficiency in carrying the war to victory.
Leases of large apartments in buildings on the East Side featured the rush for apartments in Manhattan yesterday.
LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Lord Woolton, Food Minister, warned Britain today that leaner days were coming when he addressed a large meeting in Edinburgh.

Reflecting enormous check clearances incidental to the quarterly tax payment period, bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday rose to the highest volume of the year, according to figures announced yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, charged yesterday that the Office of Defense Transportation was responsible for a situation that is keeping upward of 7,200 tons of potential prime scrap metal from reaching the nation's blast furnaces where it is needed urgently for steel making.

TORONTO, Sept 24 (U.P.) -- The management committee of the National Hockey League completed two closed sessions today, but the league president, Frank Calder, declined to reveal the nature of the discussions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Charleston, S.C., with an increase of 49 per cent in department stores sales in August, as compared with the same month a year ago, led all cities, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Next among the leaders were Vallejo and Napa, Calif., with a rise of 39 per cent.

The President asked Congress for price ceilings at "parity" rather than 110 per cent of parity; he proposed a floor under farm prices; he suggested that calculations of parity should include the cost of labor. Under the leadership of the farm bloc, the House gave him technically what he asked for -- and completely destroyed his program.

WASHINGTON, Sept 24 (U.P.) -Secretary Stimson said today that he was personally investigating "shocking" details of the coming heavyweight title fight that will permit Sergeant Joe Louis and Corporal Billy Conn to get a $135,451 cut of the gate so they can pay off their debts.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 24 -- William H. Brettman, 54 years old, of Greenwich, Conn., former vice president of the Putnam Trust Company, there, who had pleaded guilty to a charge of embezzling $5,000 from the Greenwich Chapter, American Red Cross, of which he was treasurer, was fined $300 and given a six-month suspended jail sentence by Judge Kennett Wynne in Superior Court, here, today.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Sept. 24 -- Lieut. Comdr. Mildred H. McAfee, director of the Women's Reserve of the Navy, will visit the Naval Training School at Smith College Wednesday to address the first graduating class, when about one hundred and twenty probationary officers will be graduated and will be assigned to active duty.

The large two-story and basement industrial building occupying a block on West Fordham Road at Cedar Avenue, in the Bronx, built originally by the late Albert J. Schwarzler for use as an ice manufacturing plant, has been acquired by a client of J.P. McCann, broker, from the Bank of the Manhattan Company.

Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt presented yesterday to the New York Public Library branch at 104 West 136th Street the original manuscript of President Roosevelt's "Atlantic Charter" radio address of Feb. 23, 1942.

After an interval of more than one week, the Treasury announced yesterday that it would make withdrawals from its accounts with commercial bank depositaries on next Tuesday. For the entire country the withdrawals will amount to $122,990,000, of which $61,869,000 will be withdrawn from banks in the New York district.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- President Roosevelt's anti-inflation program is being sabotaged through Congressional failure to pass an adequate and fair tax bill and through lack of effective price control, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, charged in a letter sent to C.I.O. affiliates today.

The new pilot house and flying bridge atop the Seamen's Church Institute was formally dedicated yesterday afternoon before an audience of 100. The seventy-four-foot structure, literally the highest navigation bridge in the world, 212 feet above sea level, will serve as a classroom for navigation students preparing for the merchant marine, Coast Guard, Navy and Air Force.

VICHY, Sept. 24 -- More than one-third of the French merchant fleet has been lost or destroyed since 1938, it is declared in an article published in The Merchant Marine Journal by a French engineer, Christian La Neuville.

MOSCOW, Sept. 24 -- Maintaining its heavy pressure on the northern face of the Germans' Volga salient, the Red Army was reported today to have held its ground through the night in the region of the city. Recent German penetrations have been deeper than heretofore, but the enemy attacks in all sectors were reported held.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date. Holdings of United States Government securities decreased $177,883,000 during the week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The War Department, in compliance with the new Soldiers Voting Law, has started overseas large quantities 'of the "request cards" which soldiers must fill out to obtain ballots, Secretary Stimson said today.

Claims and counter-claims concerning President Roosevelt's attitude toward the inclusion of a new parity formula, which would raise the parity figure approximately 12 per cent, in the House Price-Control Bill, were felt keenly yesterday in the cotton market. Price movements on the New York Cotton Exchange were consequently erratic, with early advances of as much as 18 points erased and final net losses being 8 to 15 points.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -Representative Martin J. Kennedy of New York has protested to the House that new rules proposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission governing stockholders' proxies for corporate meetings would place an increased burden on corporations in preparing financial reports.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Smashing through clouds pierced by lightning bolts, four-engined heavy British bombers flew out into clear moonlight last night over the German submarine yards at the Baltic port of Flensburg and delivered a heavy attack.

MOSCOW, Friday, Sept. 25 -- The Red Army cracked German lines northwest of Stalingrad yesterday for the second time in two days in an incredible burst of offensive power springing from the smoking depths of a still unconquered city now in its second month of siege.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 24 -- Details of atrocities committed by Congress party sympathizers were given for the first time in the Legislative Assembly this morning by Sir Sultan Ahmed, Law Member of the Viceroy's Council, answering charges by K. C. Neogy of excesses by soldiers and police in repressing disorders.
OTTAWA, Sept. 24 (Canadian Press) -- The weekly communique: of the Royal Canadian Air Force:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- Representative Dies, chairman of the Special House Committee on un-American Activities, today placed in the Congressional Record the names of nineteen Federal officials and employes who, he declared, were leaders of an organization which he said Attorney General Biddle himself had indicated was affiliated with and controlled by the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -Charging the War Production Board with having failed to make full use of small plants which have been brought together in pools, the Senate Small Business Committee today pointed out that of the 500 pools that have been organized 300 have been dissolved for lack of work.

Support of the candidates on the Democratic State ticket was urged yesterday by Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, wife of the President, without mentioning Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., nominee for Governor, by name.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 24 (U.P.) --Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service director, declared today that he was opposed "at present" to using the draft as a weapon against strikes in war plants.

Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, commanding the Army's Service of Supply, in an address last night before the National Industrial Conference at the Waldorf-Astoria urged that all special economic and other groups lay aside their competitive interests during the war, in the face of a common danger.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- The French National Committee, executive organization of the Fighting French forces, has assumed responsibility for the upkeep of the house and grounds where Napoleon lived and died in exile on the British island of St. Helena, it was announced here today.

On Tuesday the House Republicans resolved that "Our national peril must not be exploited by any individual or group for special gains or advancement.'' A fine, ringing statement. On Wednesday these same Republicans knifed the President's price-control bill and gave the farm bloc a new chance to exploit the nation's peril for the special gains and advancement of a politically powerful group.

Even though Fall is here, Summer still lingers in the vegetable stalls. Favorable weather last week -- warmth coupled with moisture -- was kind to the crops and as a result the stands are piled high. That this profusion will be short-lived is emphasized by a representative of the Consumers Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets.

The report of the National Power and Light Company and subsidiaries for the year ended on Aug. 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after expenses and charges of $4,580,437. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 56 cents a share on the company's outstanding common stock and compares with a net of $8,600,879, or $1.27 a common share, in the twelve months to Aug. 31, 1941.

"We must be willing to die for our country if we are to win the war," Commander John Joseph (Gene) Tunney told 400 members and guests of the Rotary Club at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

Last week the reserve ratio was 25.9 per cent; two weeks ago, 25.6. Highest ratio of the year to date was 34 per cent on April 22; lowest was 7.2 on April 15. Lowest in 1941 was 5 per cent, on April 17, a low record.

The only original employe of Saks-Thirty-fourth Street who is still in service and one of the store first day customers were rewarded yesterday in commemoration of the fortieth anniversary of the Saks establishment.

BOSTON, Sept. 24 -- Postmaster General Frank C. Walker warned tonight that this country was in grave peril and that "blood and sacrifice and suffering and privation shall be the lot of America before victory shall come to us."

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- Wheat futures, after an advance of around 1 cent a bushel in the early trading today, turned reactionary and the May declined 1 5/8 cents from the early top. Closing sales on the Board of Trade were near the bottom for the day with losses of 1/4 to 3/8 cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- When Senator Brown of Michigan was imploring the Senate today not to force the grave national issue of executive. versus legislative powers he read one of several excerpts from recent statutes which reveal how Congress weakened its own case in advance.

Last week the reserve ratio was 25.9 per cent; two weeks ago, 25.6. Highest ratio of the year to date was 34 per cent on April 22; lowest was 7.2 on April 15. Lowest in 1941 was 5 per cent, on April 17, a low record.

The only original employe of Saks-Thirty-fourth Street who is still in service and one of the store first day customers were rewarded yesterday in commemoration of the fortieth anniversary of the Saks establishment.

BOSTON, Sept. 24 -- Postmaster General Frank C. Walker warned tonight that this country was in grave peril and that "blood and sacrifice and suffering and privation shall be the lot of America before victory shall come to us."

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 -- Wheat futures, after an advance of around 1 cent a bushel in the early trading today, turned reactionary and the May declined 1 5/8 cents from the early top. Closing sales on the Board of Trade were near the bottom for the day with losses of 1/4 to 3/8 cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- When Senator Brown of Michigan was imploring the Senate today not to force the grave national issue of executive. versus legislative powers he read one of several excerpts from recent statutes which reveal how Congress weakened its own case in advance.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- Retail trade circles here studied with decided interest a report by Walter A. Foy, regional business consultant for the United States Department of Commerce at Chicago, in which he asserted that the "only request" of Seventh District retailers was that the regulations of the OPA concerning price ceilings "be such that they are allowed to stay in business."
So Leo Durocher's hunch-managing has finally boomeranged in his face! It's about time!

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Globe the newcomer will be "Manila Calling," a Twentieth Century-Fox action drama featuring Lloyd Nolan, Carole Landis and James Gleason. Among the supporting players are Cornel Wilde, Martin Kosleck and Harold Huber. ...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- After a day of energetic campaigning, Senate Administration leaders not only said that they had enough votes tonight to reject the farm group's proposal for new and higher farm parity prices, but predicted the speedy passage of a bill empowering the President to stabilize wages, salaries and prices.

The theft of seventy-four gasoline ration books from the uptown Manhattan OPA office was reported yesterday to police of the Wadsworth Avenue station. The books, most of them S, had disappeared Thursday night from a supply room in the Office of Price Administration unit, which occupies the second floor of the building at 1130 St. Nicholas Avenue.

A vast women's army, organized to battle cancer, took another step forward yesterday when eighty officers of the Women's Field Army of the American Society for the Control of Cancer received diplomas and certificates after an intensive course of study and returned to their homes in all parts of the country to organize other women in this work and pass along their knowledge.

Chalky Wright did the unexpected at Madison Square Garden last night. Given little chance to defend his world featherweight championship successfully against youthful Charley (Lulu) Costantino of the East Side, the Los Angeles veteran confounded the 5-to-8 odds against him by defeating his challenger in a fifteen-round fight.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- The British Government's first venture into the women's fashion business has created a tempest in a teapot. The disagreement is about the utility dress and suit models shown in the last few days in London which were the first women's clothes designed and produced entirely under official direction.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- When formal meat rationing is instituted, around the first of the year, civilians will probably be introduced to "the point system" of rationing rather than "the coupon system" now applied to the distribution of sugar.

Churches of all faiths will join the nation tomorrow in paying tribute to the men who build and sail our ships, the day being the first anniversary of the launching of the first Liberty ship, the Patrick Henry. The churches also will observe the opening of annual "Religious Education Week" as proclaimed by Governor Lehman.

Wall Street saw yesterday two new records and a "first" in connection with the sale of special offerings on the New York Stock Exchange. An offering of 22,000 shares of stock of Sears, Roebuck Co. at 54 1/4 by Goldman, Sachs Co. had both the greatest dollar value and the greatest number of purchasers of any special offering.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Coupon rationing of gasoline on a national scale was ordered tonight by William M. Jeffers, rubber director.

Employment at plants of the General Motors Corporation in the United States set a high record in the week ended on Sept. 15, with about 313,000 persons on the payrolls, compared with 291,808 employed in June, 1941, the previous high mark, the company announced yesterday.

The "Keys to Victory" campaign to collect 100,000,000 old keys in order to make available for the United States Navy about 12,000,000 pounds of urgently needed nickel silver was endorsed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, who presented a metal "key to the city" to Lieutenant (j.g.) Grace Cheney of the Waves at City Hall ceremonies.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (U.P.)--Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told a gathering of school children today that some of them may be fighting in the war before it is over.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Sept. 19 totaled 244,294,000 barrels, according to data reported to the Bureau of Mines, Department of the Interior. Compared with the preceding week, this represents a decrease of 377,000 barrels, comprising decreases of 366,000 and 11,000 barrels in stocks of domestic and foreign crude, respectively.

An attendance of 100,000 is forecast by those in charge of arrangements for the patriotic rally and "Holy Hour" aiming for "A Just Peace Through Victory" to be held from 3 P.M. to 6 P.M. tomorrow in the Yankee Stadium under the auspices of the Archdiocesan Union of the Holy Name Society.

Little Nancy Zilboorg's letter in THE TIMES of Sept. 21 shows that she has a good understanding of the purpose of First Aid. Up to now the American Red Cross runs only four groups: Junior Group, age 12-17; Standard Group, age 17 and over; Advanced Course for holders of a Standard Certificate; Instructor Courses.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Sept. 26 (AP) -- A communique:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 -Georgetown defeated Temple tonight, 7 -- 0. It was the season's opener for both teams and a crowd of 22,000 persons, which half-filled Temple Stadium, appreciated the smoothness with which the Hoyas did the job, but the majority of the spectators, those who were aware of the facts, might have left the place muttering "I told you so," even though the Owls were regarded as the favorite.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Sept. 26 -- Aggressive United Nations patrols fighting in heavy rain have forced the Japanese to fall back from outposts in the Owen Stanley Mountains above Port Moresby in New Guinea, while dive-bombers have demolished one end of a vital suspension bridge on the Japanese supply route, General Douglas MacArthur reported today.

New bond financing this week was on a reduced scale and, unlike the diversified offerings of the week before, was limited to the tax exempt field. Three bond issues aggregating $11,696,000 were offered for public subscription, against five last week totaling $28,751,930. In this week of 1941 nine issues were floated for $23,811,000.

DETROIT, Sept. 25 -- Giving the keynote speech at the State Republican Convention this afternoon, Representative Martin, Republican national chairman, promised that the Republican party would give every ounce of support to winning the war, but warned that it would maintain an attitude of constructive criticism toward the administration.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- The month-long battle for Stalingrad has seriously disrupted Germany's plans for smashing the military and economic structure of the Soviet Union this year and has limited the operations of the German armies in Southern Russia to minor objectives for the rest of 1942, British military observers declared today.

With swift, dexterous fingers, five young blind people, employed by the American Mica Works Company, 47 and 49 West Street, are engaged in a vital war industry, sorting small pieces of mineral silicate into thicknesses varying as little as .001 to .005 inch.

A special assemblage of the ranking officers of the Police Department, gathered hurriedly by Commissioner Valentine in the line-up room at Headquarters, was told yesterday by Mayor La Guardia: "I want all forms of gambling wiped out.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- The steps of St. Paul's Cathedral today were turned into a stage on which an anthology in praise of Great Britain, composed from the works of famous British poets and musicians, was presented. Among the artists were Dame Sybil Thorndike, Leslie Howard, Eric Portman, Henry Ainley and Mary Cleare, supported by the combined Guards' bands under the direction of Sir Henry Wood, and a massed choir of 300 voices.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Representatives of fifteen non-operating railroad unions demanded today a wage increase of 20 cents an hour and a union shop for 900,000 employes of the Class I railroads.

LONDON, Saturday, Sept. 26 -- Royal Air Force bombers raided Oslo, capital of Norway, yesterday afternoon for the first time in more than a year and reports from Stockholm, Sweden, said their bombs landed near a university building where the Axis puppet Premier, Major Vidkun Quisling, was making a speech.

Twelve, including Whirlaway, have been named for today's mile and half of the $10,000 Manhattan Handicap, big feature at Belmont Park, where 25,000 are expected to attend on the initial Saturday of the Fall meeting. Ben Jones, trainer of the Warren Wright flyer, who is the world's leading money-winning horse, was a bit doubtful yesterday on the matter of a rider.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 25 -- Few programs the nation's history have ever received such widespread favorable reaction from the people as the handling of the Selective Service draft.

The silliest spectacle we have seen in a long time is that of American Communists, who until June 22 of last year were doing all they could to injure this country's defenses and stab Britain in the back, holding a mass meeting in Union Square to demand that the military strategy of the United Nations be changed to suit the party line.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 -- The government is planning to finance production of synthetic scrap iron by a direct reduction process to augment inadequate supplies of war-vital steel scrap, according to E.S. Harman, production manager of the Loftus Engineering Company.

A voluntary program to curtail production of wood pulp for paper and to divert logs to more essential uses has been undertaken in the Puget Sound area, it was learned here yesterday. This reduction in paper pulp will have no immediate effect on paper production, inasmuch as wood pulp stocks are very heavy, but eventually when the current supply is exhausted paper mills will begin to feel the pinch.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 25 (AP) -- A strike of 500 C.I.O. smelter workers was voted off today, but the 200 employed on the 3 P.M. shift did not return to their war jobs at the plant of the Aluminum Company of America.

Without benefit of starting blocks, the football season bursts away in full stride today as the majority of the nation's college elevens swing into action. By next week the handful of laggards will have joined the parade.

Reflecting the changed situation in the automobile field as the result of tire and gasoline rationing and the halting of sales of cars for civilian use, the Bishop-Nash Corporation has leased from the Commodore Biltmore Company the four-story building at 323-33 East Forty-fourth Street and will use it for the storage of automobiles and as a service station.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 25 -- Piqued by foreign criticism of German failure to force a decision at Stalingrad, Berlin military commentators now contend that the "strategic decision" has been reached and that the fighting is merely a type of mobile war over a field of ruins.
Joan Field, violin, and Bernhard Weiser, piano, will be the participants in the Victory concert today, at 5:30 P.M., in the New York Public Library.

Freight and passenger traffic on the Boston Maine and Maine Central railroads continues in heavy volume, E.S. French, president of the companies, said yesterday in Washington. Passenger traffic is 100 per cent above last year, he continued, expressing concern whether there would be enough locomotives to meet next Winter's demands.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 25 -Syracuse used forty-five players while rolling up a 58-6 score against Clarkson under the lights of Archbold Stadium tonight. Dick Whitesell and Tommy Maines, veteran backs, scored two touchdowns apiece to lead the scoring parade.

DETROIT, Sept. 25 -- Telegrams were sent to members of the United States Senate today by the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., asserting that the farm group's parity plan was a threat to victory and "opens the flood gates of inflation."
Recently I read that Tom Pettit, the doughty court tennis champion of fifty years ago, was still in active charge of the lawn tennis courts at the Newport Casino.

HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Candidates of the Communist party will return to the State ballot Nov. 3 after an absence of four years, it was virtually assured today as a Supreme Court justice dismissed an American Legion action to bar them.

Now that the complete manuscript of a new book of stories by Isak Dinesen (Baroness Karen Blixen of Rungstedlund, Denmark) has reached this country, certain details about its transit are available. Writing in Nazi-controlled Denmark, the author of "Seven Gothic Tales" and "Out of Africa" completed eight stories.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Columbus Red Birds pulled up even with Syracuse at 1 -- all in the little world series tonight, taking the second game by a 3-2 count in a tight pitching battle.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25 -- The National League's torrid pennant race continued tonight as a "war of nerves" on this Western sector when the news was flashed that the Dodgers, by turning back the Braves in extra innings, were still hanging on by a slender mathematical thread with a chance of plunging the race into a deadlock when the final flag falls Sunday night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- A complete reversal of Army Nurse Corps tradition was announced today when the War Department ordered that no nurse would be permitted to resign from the service because of marriage. It had been a rule of the corps since its founding that no married nurses would be accepted in the corps and that all who married on duty must resign.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Following is the text of the letter sent by farm organization leaders tto Senators Thomas of Oklahoma and Hatch concerning the inflation bill:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainright and an estimated 6,000 other American defenders of Bataan and Corregidor were reported today to be war captives of the Japanese in a prison camp at Tarlac, north of Manila, in the Philippines.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 25 -- Most of the Italian enemy aliens arrested during Federal Bureau of Investigation raids in forty-two New Jersey communities yesterday maintained today that they had been forced to become members of fascist organizations under threat of having harm visited upon their relatives in Italy, E.E. Conroy, agent in charge of the local F.B.I. office, disclosed.

OTTAWA, Sept. 25 -- Thirteen leaders of the Communist party in Canada, including Tim Buck of Toronto, the general secretary of the party, surrendered today to the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and were taken to Don jail in Toronto on charges of being members of the Communist party.

EVERY soldier presumably knows the ins and outs of the technical subject called "the power and limitation of weapons." But to civilians who are given to all-out enthusiasms for single arms, such as the airplane or the battleship, the subject is often a closed book. Every one must know at least one friend who spends his leisure hours "fighting the ships with Jane" to the exclusion of any concern for infantry, artillery, tanks and airplanes.

COLGATE vs. St. Lawrence. -- At last report the government seemed willing to sidetrack the St. Lawrence waterway project for the duration. Figuring that Colgate is willing to abide by government wishes, the Red ,Raiders should sidetrack St. Lawrence without any fear of encountering a filibuster. One vote for Colgate.

BALBOA, C.Z., Sept. 25 -- Secretary Knox, in an interview at headquarters of the Fifteenth Naval District today, stressed cooperation between the Army and Navy and emphasized that Secretary Stimson and he were in complete agreement on that question.
ROCHESTER, Sept. 25 -- Republican leaders from eight counties included in the seventh judicial district met today with Edwin F. Jaeckle, Republican State Chairman.

Twenty-one thousand newspaper and press association employes have left their jobs to engage in work directly connected with the war, according to an announcement made yesterday in the national Newspaper Week issue of Editor Publisher, which deals with wartime services of the United States press.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 25 -- The first demonstration of the teeth in the new Swiss law against espionage of Aug. 4 of this year was given by the Eighth Divisional Court sitting in Berne today when it condemned to death two of twelve defendants, including two women and two foreigners, for "having established a service of political information directed against foreign States" and "for violation of military secrets of Switzerland.
Perhaps this is merely reopening an old wound, so to speak, but there is one aspect of professional football that still alienates me, and I know many other sports fans who have the same viewpoint.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The President's War Relief Control Board today prohibited further Army or Navy relief benefit shows or solicitation of funds after Nov. 15 unless organized by the services and participated in by service personnel.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Antoine Delfosse, former Belgian Minister of Communications who recently escaped from the Continent, declared today that morale remained high in Belgium and that "acts of sabotage are increasing daily" despite the "desperate" food situation, with many dying from starvation.

Alan Haywood, national organizing director of the C.I.O., told delegates to the eighth national convention of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O., at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday that they must see to it that there was no repetition of widespread unemployment after the war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- By radio, through the press and in numerous speeches, the Nazis in the last few days have been busily publicizing within Europe their contention that the suffering imposed by the war -- which they admit outran their time schedule -- is justified because the "European question" is at last being solved.

Metal scrap is as good an illustration as can be found of a commodity that is worse than useless in the wrong place and absolutely essential in the right place. In condemned buildings, in obsolete street railway tracks, even in the railings around family plots in cemeteries, it must these days offend our sense of fitness.
THE TIMES of Sept. 21 carried a letter from Joseph C. Fink suggesting that banks announce their willingness to hold war bonds for purchasers.

Brilliant sunshine streamed, through the bedroom window of the apartment on the tenth floor at 300 West 108th Street late yesterday afternoon. Sunbeams played on a wide variety of plant life -- more than 150 -- and the room was full of fragrance from the assortment of Fall flowers.

If one could take it in isolation, one might say that the speech of Ralph A. Bard, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, makes certain questionable and certain excellent points. But one must take it in conjunction with statements made by other Administration officials. So considered, it adds to the sense of confusion about some of the Administration's policies.

One form of print that represents sheer waste of paper, ink and the labor of good men in the Typographical Union is the literature of the deadly parallel. It is now being actively employed to show what fools men are in forecasting the future -- if they happen to be your opponents.
BOSTON, Sept. 25 -- Two of the big-name college football players of the year are to be found here at Chestnut Hill on the Boston College squad.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25 -- Wendell L. Willkie spent all the daylight hours yesterday within a few miles of Rzhev and within sound of ceaseless cannonading. Standing beside captured German redoubts where the dead still lay, he saw wounded men carried back from the street-fighting in the city less than five miles away and talked with a group of German prisoners.

Irving Bacheller, the novelist, will be 83 years old today. In connection with the event, Dr. A. J. Hanna, Professor of History at Rollins College, Winter Park, Fla., announced yesterday that many friends of Mr. Bacheller are now contributing toward the endowment at Rollins of an Irving Bacheller Professorship of Creative Writing.

The report of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and certain of its subsidiaries, primarily those operating in the Western Hemisphere, for the first half of this year, released yesterday by Sosthenes Behn, president, shows a consolidated net income of $333,556, contrasted with a net loss of $14,704 in the six months to June 30, 1941.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Secretary Stimson today canceled the heavyweight championship fight scheduled for Oct. 12 between Sergeant Joe Louis and Corporal Billy Conn.
