LONDON, Sept. 25 -- The National Association of School-masters added its voice today to steadily increasing clamor -- hitherto voiced principally by the laboring section of the British public -- for the abolition of "public" schools, which in this country are equivalent to exclusive, private preparatory schools in the United States.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- The British Admiralty in a detailed account of the convoy battle starting Sept. 12 and continuing through Sept. 15 said today that at least 40 German aircraft -- and that is based on certainties -- had been shot down and at least two U-boats were definitely known to have been destroyed.

In a call to presidents of all local branches, Mrs. Charles E. Heming, president of the New York State League of Women Voters, asked them yesterday to arouse their communities to the crisis arising from the influence of pressure groups on Congress.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Lillydale set a record for fillies in winning the 3-year-old Pacing Stake at the final session of the Delaware Grand Circuit meeting today.
TORONTO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The National Hockey League's board of governors today suspended the Brooklyn American franchise for a year and limited the Stanley Cup play-offs to four clubs.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- A fashionably dressed gray-haired clubwoman parked her automobile today in front of the Gramatan Hotel here, hoisted a smudgy spare tire and wheel from a rear compartment and trundled them into the hotel, across thick carpets and past surprised hotel guests.

RIVERHEAD, L.I, Sept. 25 -- A blackout and practice air raid drill was conducted throughout Suffolk County tonight on orders received from the State Director of Civilian Protection. The red signal was flashed at 9:06 P.M., followed by the sounding of sirens and locomotive whistles warning the county's population of 200,000 that the test was in progress.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 25 (U.P.) -- British and American bombers have sunk forty Axis merchant vessels totaling 60,000 tons in the Mediterranean since June, a Royal Air Force senior officer said today. He estimated forty Axis ships had been damaged.
HAVANA, Sept. 25 -- The Cuban Senate early this morning approved modifications in the obligatory military service law "in totality."

MOSCOW, Saturday, Sept. 26 -- Russian troops fighting amid the tumbled walls of Stalingrad captured "a valuable position" yesterday and killed 1,500 Germans northwest of the city, where Soviet gains have threatened the Nazis' flank, it was reported today.

In an effort to hasten the demolition of useless buildings in this city for salvage, Park Commissioner Moses will submit to the Federal Government next Wednesday detailed reports on several types of buildings that may be scrapped.
LONDON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 25 (U.P.) -- Chinese transportation experts, returning from the northwest, said today that two substitute supply routes for the lost Burma Road were in "full readiness" to handle the bulk of American goods for Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's armies.
James J. Connelly, 37 years old, of 66 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, may not be the most successful burglar around town, but he proved yesterday he was the most photogenic.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Communist party cannot intervene in Harry Bridges's habeas corpus hearing in Federal court, Judge Martin I. Welsh ruled today.

Concerning the problem of juvenile delinquency, which shows a 14 per cent increase, according to a news item in THE TIMES, I venture to say that this increase is due not directly but indirectly to war conditions, My conclusion is based on the well-founded theory that at least 50 per cent, if not much more, of juvenile offenders originate from group-playing on the streets.

Employes of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., whose twenty-fifth, thirtieth, thirty-fifth, fortieth or forty-fifth anniversaries with the firm are occurring this month were entertained at luncheon yesterday by Percy S. Straus, chairman of the board of the department store, marking his own forty-fifth anniversary with the firm.

To spend 3 or 4 cents for a pound of white potatoes is to make an investment that pays dividends. In return one receives a food so nourishing that it provides, when combined with a bit of milk and butter, each of the nutriments now thought necessary to sustain health and promote happiness.

GREENPORT, L.I., Sept. 25 -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic candidate for Governor, made a whirlwind handshaking tour of seven of the ten townships in Suffolk County today and was enthusiastically received at stops along the 125-mile route by party members and officials of the American Legion, of which Mr. Bennett was State Commander in 1929.

TRENTON, Sept. 25 -- Schools in New Jersey industrial areas and places of business in all the more populous districts of the State were called on to stagger their opening and closing hours to alleviate bus and trolley-car congestion in an executive order issued here today by Governor Charles Edison.

As a prelude to its nation-wide Fall campaign to collect clothing for needy youngsters among 400 school systems, the Save the Children Federation will hold open house at its new workroom, 45 University Place, from 4 to 6 P.M. on Tuesday.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- German raiders confined their attention last night to one district on the southwest coast which a German communique today said was Falmouth. There they met lively opposition, with the result that few bombs were dropped, little damage done and no casualties reported.
Local college football makes its 1942 debut this afternoon when Columbia faces an Army team from Fort Monmouth at Baker Field in an Army Emergency Relief Fund game. Starting time is 2:30 P.M.

BOSTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Lieut. Comdr. John S. Thach, commanding officer of Fighting Squadron 3 on the aircraft carrier Lexington, was presented today with the Distinguished Service Medal and a Gold Star, to be worn with his previously awarded Navy Cross, for his heroic actions in the Pacific war theatre.

Disregarding announcements that no more applicants for work in the Henry J. Kaiser Company shipyards at Portland, Ore., would be interviewed for a week at the United States Employment Service Office, 44 East Twenty-third Street, more than 100 applicants appeared there before 8 o'clock yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The City Bank Farmers Trust Company of New York City today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to modify its plan of reorganization for the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad by increasing the amount of common stock and allocating the increased amount to the general mortgage bonds so that their holders will receive at least five shares of new common stock for each $1,000 of claim on the general mortgage bonds.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Traveling by jeep over muddy roads, Wendell L. Willkie returned a little worse for wear today from a trip to the central front where he witnessed a thundering artillery duel in the Rzhev sector and heard from embattled Red Army men the now familiar query: "How about a second front?"

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- A War Production Board order setting up a schedule of deliveries for canned fruits and vegetables was issued today and goes into effect tomorrow. Under the order three shipment periods are set up through the 1942-43 season, with the first running to Nov. 30 next, the second from Dec. 1 to March 31, 1943, and the third from April 1 on.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 25 -- Negotiations have just been concluded between the occupying authority of Alsace (Gauleiter Joseph Buerckel) and the German Government for a revaluation of the "Alsatian franc" -- an arbitrary monetary unit about to be set up -- designed to "bolster" Alsatian-French loyalty to the new order, it was disclosed here today.

On the eve of the final five days of the September war bond drive the Treasury Department announced yesterday that the national sales Thursday were $41,521,000, of which the New York district provided more than $5,000,000.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 25 -- Al Tolley of the Garden City Country Club and Ray Billows of the Dutchess Club in Poughkeepsie once again proved themselves an excellent host-guest combination.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 25 (AP) -Sixteen hits, including Wally Moses' two-run homer, gave the White Sox an 8-1 victory over Cleveland today and a sweep of the three-game series, plunging the Indians into a fourth-place tie with the idle Tigers.

Operations of the American Ship Building Company in the fiscal year ended on June 30, last, resulted in a net profit of $543,912 after providing $2,300,000 for Federal income and excess profits taxes and $500,000 for post-war adjustments and other contingencies, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The War Labor Board sent a request today to Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, to instruct officials of the steel union at the Gary plant of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation to correct a statement in a handbill which indicated that the board's decision in the case required that "every eligible employe must now join the union."

A campaign to recruit 10,000 Red Cross volunteer nurses' aides among women who borrow books from public libraries or private lending libraries was launched yesterday at a "readers' conference" in the Board of Estimate chamber at City Hall, under the direction of Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich, vice chairman of the CDVO and chairman of the recruiting drive.

Following declines in three successive months, new orders received by furniture manufacturers in August rose 5 per cent compared with the 1941 level and showed a contraseasonal increase of 13 per cent over the preceding month, Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants, reported yesterday.

The problem of the high cost of food cannot be solved without considering the position of the farmer. Apart from the costs of farm implements, seeds, fertilizer, taxes, interest, clothing and purchased foods, the farmer's main cash outlay is for labor.

How many of us knew that in the little island, ten miles by eight, where the first Napoleon died, Longwood, place of his captivity, was still a French enclave and possession? After 1651 the island belonged to the British East India Company, to whose control it passed again after Napoleon's death in 1821.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Larry Allen, Associated Press correspondent who fell into enemy hands in the British Commando raid on Tobruk on Sept. 13, floored his Axis captors by demanding an interview with General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel, the German agency D.N.B. disclosed today in a broadcast from Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Administration assertions that sufficient Senate votes had been mustered to pass a compromise on the farm group's demands for a new and higher parity formula in the anti-inflation bill ran head-on today into a fresh application of pressure by the "Big Four" among agricultural organizations representing millions of voters.

As the result of a study undertaken by the Board of Education because of the wartime shortage of trade teachers, modification of eligibility rules for such teachers is suggested in a survey of vocational training made public yesterday by James Marshall, co-chairman of the survey committee.

In the first step of a broad-scale effort to build an organization specializing in advertising and giving service to the advertising field, the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Department of Commerce has appointed an industrial specialist in advertising in the department, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- The stock markets remained cheerful today. The usual Friday atmosphere being livened up with a "flutter" in Mexican Eagles. A total of 25,000 shares were put on the market in blocks of 10,000, 5,000 and 10,000 but were readily absorbed, the price losing only a few pence.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- A Navy communique:

TRENTON, Sept. 25 -- Despite Governor Edison's insistent demand for early revision of the State Constitution, both major parties ignored the issue in their tentative platforms for 1942, made public here today. Thus the prospects that the question of revising the ninety-eight-year-old Constitution will be placed before the voters in the November election appear remote.

The police here sent out a nineState alarm last night for liss Adelaide Reckford, 40 years old, daughter of the late Louis J. Reckford, president of the American Lead Pencil Company, who disappeared late Wednesday night after attending the theatre witt, friends.

Father Divine, Harlem cult leader, through his attorney, asked the Appellate Division yesterday to reverse an order of Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin, issued last June, ordering the cult leader to pay $100 a week toward satisfaction of an unpaid judgment for $5,949 obtained against him two and a half years ago by Mrs. Verinda Brown, a former "angel" of Father Divine's "kingdom."

To many Americans it must come as almost the biggest surprise of our wartime economy to discover that there is an actual food shortage. Beneath all the talk of "doing without" and "lowered living standards" there has been a lurking skepticism. People have accepted a shortage of tires, of oil and gasoline on the Eastern coast, of certain imported commodities, but have said that, of course, there would always be plenty of food.

"This Is the Army," the show that Irving Berlin wrote, and its all-soldier cast will leave town after this evening's performance at the Broadway Theatre. Originally scheduled for but a month's local run, its stay was twice extended, so that the final performance will be its 112th.

LONDON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The German-controlled Paris radio said tonight that "the Allies are blockading Dakar" on the French West African coast "and they will attack it soon." A political commentator identifying himself as Jean Azema made the statement.

The Dodgers didn't leave Flat-bush fans laughing when they said good-bye to Ebbets Field for the regular season yesterday, but they did leave them still hoping. For Leo Durocher's 102-game winners won't be eliminated in the dying stages of the National League pennant race unless they lose to the Phils or the Cardinals beat the Cubs today.

The stock market continued yesterday its forward push for the fourth successive session despite the obstacle of profit-taking and the usual week-end evening-up operations. Gains generally were confined to fractions, and in most cases the high marks were not maintained to the close of the market, although there were scattered additions of more than a point.

Eleven educational, religious and charitable institutions are to share in the estate of Mrs. Jennie V. McKeever, widow of Edward J. McKeever, former part owner and president of the Brooklyn National League Baseball Club, according to her will, filed yesterday in the Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn.

German troops captured additional fortified positions in bitter fighting in the streets of Stalingrad Thursday and beat off Soviet counter-attacks launched from the north, the Nazi High Command declared yesterday, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (Wide World) -- Sufficient leather and shoes are on hand or in prospect to meet all essential requirements through 1943, in spite of growing demands of the armed forces and lend-lease, says J.G. Schnitzer, specialist of the Department of Commerce.
At a recent meeting of the New Jersey League of Surf Anglers it was decided that there should be no abatement in the campaign to "make the striped bass a gam fish."

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- President Roosevelt hailed today as a promise of ultimate victory over the Axis the record of American shipyards during the first year of the "Victory Fleet" program, in which 488 ships, totaling 5,450,000 deadweight tons, were delivered and the average construction time of a Liberty Ship was cut from 241.8 days to 70 days.
MOSCOW, Sept. 25 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:
As a subscriber to THE TIMES, I consider it my duty to write in regard to the article on the Louis-Conn fight appearing on your pages last Saturday.

Gustave Kotanyi's production of Karl Milloecker's three-act operetta "The Beggar Student" attracted a large and enthusiastic audience to the Cosmopolitan Opera House last night. The performance boasted vitality and animation.

Baseball in Brooklyn exploded yesterday with a mighty charge by 20,000 school chlidren who, in a near riot, swept over 100 patrolmen and numbers of guards in an uninterrupted march into Ebbets Field for the Dodgers' last home game of the season.

LONDON, Sept. 25 (U.P.) -- Adolf Hitler is seriously disturbed by increasing resistance to his new order in the Balkans and has demanded that Ante Pavelitch, puppet ruler of Croatia, mobilize additional troops to track down guerrilla forces, private advices from the Continent said tonight.
Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, predicted yesterday that his pay-as-you-go income tax plan would become a "definite legislative reality" this year.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today that proceedings under both sections of the "death sentence" clause be instituted against the Community Gas and Power Company; its subholding company, the American Gas and Power Company, and their subsidiaries.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 25 (AP) -Texas Christian University's football fortunes soared belatedly to victory today on the good right arm of Emery Nix as the Horned Frogs nosed out the University of California at Los Angeles, 7 -- 6.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25 -- Attacking on a broad front, the Russian counter-offensive northwest of Stalingrad is continuing to make gradual progress and is containing important German forces, according to reports available here today. The difficulties are great, for the Germans spare no effort to fortify the flank of their Stalingrad salient, and their pillboxes and redoubts are placed densely in the steppe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- By Oct. 1 Secretary Perkins will sign an order excepting 1,500,000 building trades workers from President Roosevelt's ban outlawing time and a half for overtime when the work falls on Saturday and Sunday within the forty-hour week.

Only three new issues of bonds, all in the tax-exempt field, were offered publicly this week, with the principal interest centered on an issue of $8,286,000 of 1 1/4 per cent bonds of the Boston Metropolitan District. The week's total offerings were $11,696,000, which compared with $28,751,930 for five issues the week before.

Hal Schumacher crowned his last pitching start of the 1942 campaign at the Polo Grounds yesterday with victory over the Phillies. Then the Phillies crowned the pitching debut of Hank Leiber in a manner that could easily have been foretold.

Cooler weather aided retail trade here this week, particularly so far as Fall apparel was concerned. Department store volume was estimated at about 1 or 2 per cent above the comparative week last year. Home furnishings generally continued quiet.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Justice Department said today that forty-seven members of a $1,000,000 lottery ring planning to distribute hundreds of thousands of world series baseball tickets had been seized by the Federal Bureau of Investigation agents operating in thirty-three cities.

Members of the club who have gone into the country's fighting service are remembered in the Yankees' division of their world series swag. Provision is made in the distribution even for the old bat boy and the old clubhouse boy.

Although delays in merchandise shipments are being encountered by retailers, the transportation situation generally is much more favorable than was anticipated earlier, reports in retail traffic circles here indicated yesterday. Optimism was expressed that conditions next month, ordinarily the peak of the year, would continue on the good side.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- The controversy in the Senate whether the 1909-14 formula is to be followed in arriving at parity prices for agricultural products or whether the cost of farm labor shall be added caused wheat traders to hesitate today in making commitments in the market.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 25 -- The late Will James's last book, "The Saga of the American Cowboy," which the author wrote for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, but which the studio did not buy, has been acquired from the author's estate by Harry Sherman, United Artists producer.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- London naval circles were untroubled today over announcements made almost simultaneously in Berlin and Tokyo to the effect that Japanese submarines were operating in the Atlantic in cooperation with German U-boats.

A marked lack of euthusiasm about business possibilities during the last half of this year was noted in a survey conducted by Dun Bradstreet covering 1,200 wholesale distributors and 10,000 retailers, according to the findings which were announced yesterday.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- In a move to reduce the volume of government publicity, Elmer Davis, head of the Office of War Information, made permanent today for the war duration the recent elimination of 239 pamphlets, handouts and releases and ordered the curtailment of 284 others.

It was good to read George Hartnett's letter in THE TIMES last Saturday in which he tactfully ridiculed the recent announcement made by Joseph B. Eastman, Director of the Office of Defense Transportation, concerning the curtailment of travel to football games.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Army bombers have scored three hits on Japanese transports in the Western Solomons area, the Navy Department reported in a communique today.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Sept. 25 -- Principles of operation adopted by the Inter-American Coffee Board, an official body the members of which are appointed by fifteen Western Hemisphere countries including the United States, were outlined by Paul Daniels of the State Department, chairman of the board, before 300 delegates to the National Coffee Association convention here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Working to counteract Axis propaganda, the Office of War Information spoon will begin sending to New York City a daily analysis and interpretation of this material. From a central point in the metropolis the Gervice will be available to newspapers and radio stations, many of which have agreed to avail themselves of it.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 25 -About sixty miles short of their objective -- their first game of the year -- Fordham's football forces rested here tonight in the Severin Hotel and will move on tomorrow to Lafayette and their game with Purdue.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- The National Association of Food Chains heard from A.G. Hoffman, director, food price division of OPA, that food distributors will shortly be given relief from price squeezes on about ten groups of food commodities, and from Brunson Mac Chesney, assistant general counsel of OPA, that the price control group wants a bigger enforcement staff and power to seize goods from dealers and consumers, where acquired in violation of the law.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Sept. 25 -- The continued recount of votes in the recent primary election in the Tenth New Jersey Congressional District gave Mayor William H. Williams of Belleville a new gain of ten today, making a total of twenty since the start of the recount yesterday and reducing the margin of the victor, Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., to 76 votes. Both men are Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Diversion of some existing shipbuilding facilities from the construction of Liberty cargo ships to tankers was announced today by the Maritime Commission. The rapidly increasing production of these ships, together with the expanded program for turbine production, made the diversion possible, the statement said.

ROCKVILLE, Md., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Workers removed two more bodies today from the wreckage of the three-train crack-up on the Baltimore Ohio Railroad near Dickerson, Md., bringing the total known dead to fourteen, of whom six have been identified definitely and three tentatively.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Federal Government is contributing to the nation-wide drive not only scrap metal in the cellars and attics of public buildings but the buildings themselves. The first to be razed is the old Federal Court House and Postoffice Building in Louisville, Ky.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 25 (AP) -- A gnat-sized fighting craft, capable of mass production at the rate of 3,000 a month, has been approved by a civilian committee of the National Boat Builders' Association and is soon to be tested by the Navy.

OTTAWA, Sept. 25 -- At Uplands air field near here Governor Herbert H. Lehman of New York State today had what he himself described as "the moving experience" of pinning a pilot's wings on his own son, Peter Gerald Lehman, and of saluting him together with fifty-three other airmen graduated into the Royal Canadian Air Force.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Contention that women industrial workers are less competent than men because of physical inferiority, and therefore are entitled to less pay, was set aside today by the War Labor Board in a decision ordering the Brown Sharpe Manufacturing Company of Providence to introduce the principle of equal pay for equal work for their 7,600 workers.

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Croatia, which obtained an independent status from the Nazis, is now combating a widespread revolt against the German oppressors and the Pavelitch regime. Because of their failure to collaborate with the Nazis six leading members of Croat parties have been arrested at Zagreb, the capital of Croatia, according to news reaching Yugoslavs in London today.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Japanese are having serious trouble in Kiangsi Province with the Chinese troops of their puppet Nanking regime, and one puppet commander has been executed by the Japanese, the Chinese High Command said tonight in a special communique.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Office of Price Administration said today that fuel oil deliveries to domestic consumers in the oil-rationing area must be cut 33 1-3 per cent below their normal Winter consumption, instead of 25 per cent as originally indicated, because of the oil transportation shortage.

Trading on the New fork Cotton Exchange was rather heavy again yesterday, but prices of active futures 'held within a comparatively narrow range as continued liquidation in the October and fairly active hedging were met by equally strong trade demand.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The new standards division of the Office of Price Administration is working in high gear to prevent evasion of the price ceilings through the lowering of quality of goods.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- New York City's discarded elevated railroad cars should not be junked for war scrap because they represent an "irreplacable" reservoir of transportation equipment that will become increasingly valuable as the war continues, Joseph B. Eastman, Director of the Office of Defense Transportation, said today.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 25 -About sixty miles short of their objective -- their first game of the year -- Fordham's football forces rested here tonight in the Severin Hotel and will move on tomorrow to Lafayette and their game with Purdue.

A serious case of involuntary sabotage will soon be referred to the women of the nation to be solved. Every day accidents are claiming valuable war workers and adding to the strain on medical facilities. As two out of every three such mishaps are non-industrial, much of the blame centers on the home.

Through Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard the government last week asked all civilians to limit their consumption of meat to two and a half pounds a person per week. The voluntary scheme -- it will be replaced by compulsory rationing as soon as some 128,000,000 books of coupons can be printed -- was reinforced by a War Production Board order cutting meat deliveries into retail channels by an average of 21 per cent.

Many wholesale markets are now tightening up and delivery dates have been extended further, Kirby, Block Co. reported yesterday in its weekly market review prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES. Actual shortages, it was said, are now making their appearance in many lines.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Sweden has learned from the fate of Norway and Denmark the value of her democratic institutions, and has built up her armed forces and her independence to a point that has angered the Germans.

Within about ten days 186 Frenchmen have faced German firing squads. No such wholesale executions had been reported for nearly a year. Obviously, the German military government of France, or the Gestapo which last Spring drew to itself a good deal of the police work, deems it necessary to awaken in the French masses a keener sense of Nazi ruthlessness.

In housing projects, community centers and public schools throughout the country, members of the Association of Junior Leagues of America have given 1,063 performances of children's plays during the past year.

In a drive to raise funds for a dozen military and civilian relief organizations, 12,000 members of New York District Council 9 of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, A.F. of L., raised more than $50,000 here yesterday by contributing a full day's pay to the drive.

Dr. Harry Noble Wright, named by the Board of Higher Education to be the sixth president of City College since its founding ninety-six years ago, will assume his office officially on Wednesday morning when he will be installed before representatives of 200 universities in this country and abroad, and officials of the city, State and nation.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Tennessee's highly favored Volunteers shared a furious fourth quarter air battle with South Carolina today, but the game ended in a scoreless tie. A crowd estimated at 14,000 saw the upset.

THE little world of the hospital can be very interesting, in fiction and out, and this one has a generous share of absorbing detail. Dr. Peter Mason was the strong, honest, hard working head of the hospital. His colleague, Dr. Josef Boehner, from Vienna, was an expert surgeon, a bold lover and a scandal in the hospital.
Mrs. Phineas Shaw Sprague and Miss Lucy Sprague have arrived at the Weylin from Scarboro, Me.

Arrangements are now being made for the second edition of the Piccadilly Arcade which will open, on Nov. 10, a sale of donated family treasures at the British War Relief Society's shop at 6 East Fifty-seventh Street. Mrs. William Armour and Mrs. Evander B. Schley, chairmen of the collection committee for the sale, will be guests of honor at a luncheon Tuesday at the Piccadilly Snack Bar.

ONE dozen Beaujolais, one dozen Chambolle-Musigny 1923 (Burgundy), one dozen Beychevelle 1933 (Claret), one dozen Lignorelles 1934 (Chablis), six bottles Niersteiner Domthal 1935 (Hock), six of pale Golden Sherry and three of the finest Madeira of great age, twenty years in bottle.

The point-count system of hand valuation has never been as popular as the quick-trick or honor-trick method. Any bridge player thinks in terms of "tricks"; beginner or expert, he cannot be persuaded to do otherwise. Nevertheless there are many expert players who deem the point-count method the more accurate, and who use it especially for no-trump valuation.

WITH the brisk winds of Fall there has come the usual turnout of hopefuls of all ages who want to get into the business of radio. Just what their chances are may be gleaned from statistics prepared by Wynn Wright, NBC production manager, and his able aide, Betty Shay.

An archaeological "dig" and a pagan curse provide the scene and "atmosphere" for this murder tale: a conventional story, and certainly not a distinguished one, but we have read worse. In this variation on the hidden-city theme the researches of Cleve Davis in New Mexico are hampered much less by the curse which seems to be already active than by the idiosyncrasies of the people in his own party.

WILLIAM MARSHALL RUSH writes about animals from experience, not from books. He spent more than twenty years as a forest ranger and several years as a wildlife specialist on assignment in various States.

Liquor wholesalers, unless they are willing to chance a continual delay in holiday orders by retailers, must comply with the demand of the Office of Price Administration that its questionnaires surveying the industry's price structure be returned not later than Tuesday, despite the difficulties involved, it was learned yesterday.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 26 -- To be best of all other dogs of the same bred is something. To be best of all other dogs of related breeds 153 times is something else again. Topping that with being best in show twenty-nine times just about places the stamp of perfection on an individual specimen.

Prices generally higher than had been expected were paid for some of the classics at the auctioning on Wednesday through yesterday of the first section of the collection of the late Colonel E.H.R. Green. Hugh C. Barr, who handled the sale at 38 Park Row, and Walter S. Scott, the auctioneer, said they were surprised at some of the bids made, in the light of the world situation.

HERBERT COREY, veteran correspondent of the first World War, is pleased with the way the Army is going about the business of winning this one -- so pleased that he has written a thick book to support his prediction that when the time is ripe, this Army too will reach its goal.

THREE wartime plays having developed into notable successes, our theatre managers have come to the not unnatural conclusion that there is a fashion for this sort of thing. Accordingly, we now have had three more -- one which gently died, one which flopped dismally and the last of which, "Men in Shadow," by Mary Hayley Bell, has only just been put on.

The Hotel Ansonia, at Seventy-third Street and Broadway in uptown Manhattan, was a symbol last week of the greatest salvage drive yet conducted in New York City. From the roofs and cornices of the sixteen-story structure, famous for forty years for ornamental metal work, wreckers were lowering tons of copper decorations to the street.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 26 -- Corny Shields, with his International Class sloop Aileen, today won the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club Trophy for the second year in succession.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Clemson and Virginia Military Institute, which had touted offenses and uncertain defenses, played in reverse today to a scoreless deadlock which showed the 1,500 spectators virtually no offensive fireworks.

American and English furniture, early American glass, as well as silver and rugs, will be sold at auction on Friday and Saturday afternoons at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

EARLY in the war estimate was heard frequently that mechanized warfare takes eighteen men in industry to keep one soldier going at the front. According to this formula, therefore, 5,000,000 men in military service would mean 90,000,000 working on war supply and service.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Prebendary Wilson Carlile, who founded the Church Army fifty-five years ago, was known to thousands as the "Archbishop of the Gutter." Until two months ago he traveled throughout the country holding services for homeless men and women.

Word came from Willemstad last week that Curacao's promised air-mail series in fifteen values will be placed in use on Oct. 20. Printed in London, these items will replace the current air stamps, which will be withdrawn from circulation on the same date.

COMFOUND it, no Sunday article again! The desk has gone. It was here a minute ago. But this is the biannual moving day when we leave one apartment that has become unsuitable for another that will have become unsuitable two years hence if, indeed, it has not already become a little unsuitable in the weeks since we signed the lease.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Coach Bill Alexander pulled the blanket off his dark-horse Georgia Tech football team today, giving opposing scouts many worries as Sophomore Eddie Prokop and Freshman Clint Castleberry passed and ran Auburn into submission, 15 -- 0, before 10,000 spectators.

WHEREAS Joseph Quincy Adams's admirably documented "Shakespearean Playhouses." published in 1917, concerned itself with the external history of all Elizabethan theatres, John Cranford Adams now centers his similarly able researches upon the Globe, giving us what his publishers aptly describe as "the first attempt at a complete and unified reconstruction" of Shakespeare's theatre and stage.

The present parity crisis in Congress was laid to "a coalition of big-farmer lobbyists and certain big business interests" in a statement and resolutions adopted yesterday at the end of a Conference on Taxation and Inflation, assembled in the Hotel Commodore by the New York Chapter of the National Lawyers Guild.

Paul Governali pitched with the deadly accuracy of a Tiny Bonham yesterday and Columbia hence had no trouble with the Fort Monmouth eleven as the football season opened at Baker Field before several thousand spectators. Paul tossed strikes for five of the Lion touchdowns as the Light Blue routed the soldiers, 39 to 0.

CORDELE, Ga., Sept. 26 -- A traveler through the coastal plains region of the South this Fall will see fields dotted with dirty brown witch-like stacks where cotton fields once gleamed white in the sunlight. From Virginia through to Texas you will find them, in small patches and in vast expanses stretching as far as the eye can reach.

ISTANBUL, Sept. 26 -- The systematic, punishing Allied bombings of military objectives and population centers in the Balkans and Southeastern Europe are shaking these unhappy Axis satellite nations to their shaky foundations.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Golden Avalanche of Marquette University rolled over the Kansas Jayhawkers for touchdowns in the second and third periods today to score a 14-to-0 football victory.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (U.P.) -Senator Norris said tonight that the Baruch rubber committee had done an "absolutely inexcusable" act in appointing a "prejudiced" chemist, Dr. Ernest A. Hauser, to assist in its study of the country's rubber problems.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Senator Andrews of Florida has received word that the Office of Price Administration has refused special allowances of gasoline to Northerners to permit them to go to Florida for the Winter.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Colgate University's Washington Study Group will spend 40 per cent of its time this Fall on the activities of Congress in a new course and seminar on "Legislative Process," Dr. Paul S. Jacobsen, associate professor of political science, announced before leaving for the nation's capital with the ten honor juniors forming the group.

BONNEVILLE, Ore. -- After five years of anxious waiting, naturalists and Indians and sportsmen in the Pacific Northwest now agree that the $7,022,000 fish ladders at Bonneville Dam have saved the famous Columbia River chinook salmon runs.

Fall colors are flashing across the hills and mountains of Vermont -- reds, yellows and browns -- creeping down from the northern border to the Champlain Valley where colors remain vivid until Oct. 15. Records show that there is little variation in time of appearance of the radiant hues from year to year.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 26 -- The Irish of Notre Dame and Wisconsin's Badgers cashed in once apiece out of numerous scoring opportunities today and settled for a 7-all draw in a football thriller at Camp Randall.

LAURITZ MELCHIOR, who has recorded extensively for Victor, has now shifted to the Columbia label. In his initial releases for the rival company he is heard on two 12-inch singles in excerpts from Tristan und Isolde, Rienzi and Otello.

Last Fall at a circus I took a picture of a clown holding a parasol. I developed the negative in one of the popular fine-grain developers. The lighting on the subject had been contrasty, and I believed that a soft-working fine-grain developer would produce the correct contrast.

Charles H. Zearfoss, who has been in charge of the foreign division of the recruitment and manning organization of the War Shipping Administration in New York, has been transferred to Washington to handle United Nations manning problems in the organization's national headquarters, it was announced last week.

KANSAS CITY in the Eighteen Eighties was a boom town. Something less than a third of its present settled size, it was growing like a weed and the sky looked like the limit. Real estate subdivisions sprawled across the dusty plains.

BARNESVILLE, Ga., Sept. 26 -- Beneath the gayety and enthusiasm of the cotton-picking holiday in which nearly half of this town's population joined this week there was a deeper note that has already echoed through the State.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Little Geneva College mixed a surprisingly strong attack with the breaks to overpower Carnegie Tech's de-emphasized eleven, 26 -- 0, today in the first game of the season for both teams before a crowd of 4,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- When President Roosevelt requested Congress in his Labor Day message to grant statutory powers to curb farm prices, he turned politics loose in two-score States in an election year, and with it one of the most effective lobbies Washington knows, went into action.

WITH a roster of eighteen artists, the Downtown Gallery reopens for the new season. This group show will continue until Oct. 10. Oils, water-colors and gouaches are chiefly in evidence, but sculpture is furnished by William Zorach and William Steig; and one of the painters, Karl Zerbe, has done a very attractive large still-life in encaustic.

The New York Botanical Garden, Bronx Park, is repeating last year's successful course of instruction on "Planting the Home Grounds." Owing to wartime restrictions on travel, home-owners are giving more thought to planning and developing their gardens, and this course is intended to provide the needed practical guidance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- In a major reorganization of the War Production Board which was unheralded save for his pledge to "get tough," Chairman Donald M. Nelson was well advanced today in efforts to liquidate two major problems of one agency, the faltering flow of materials and friction with the armed services.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Joe Louis-Billy Conn heavyweight boxing match is definitely off, a War Department spokesman said tonight, denying that Secretary Stimson would reconsider his order if the entire net proceeds went to charity, as originally planned.

Mounting at a record-breaking pace under the impetus of war shipments, air express is giving an upward slant to airline revenues and showing signs of becoming a major factor in balancing losses in passenger revenues as a result of reduced schedules, according to a survey by United Air Lines.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 26 -- The Finns are war-weary. That is the sum total of all reports that have drifted back here from Finland these last weeks. The Finns are just now fighting inflation even harder than they are the Russians.

A maniac with "an insatiable hunger for human heads" is roaming the streets of a Mid-western city, sending out brazen warnings of his intentions and striking where he will. And when Ash Rivers comes to town he soon has reason to wonder whether the murders are most closely connected with corrupt politics, real estate deals, or the innocent pastimes of a puppet show.

URBANA-CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Sept. 26 -- Unless planning is done now America will be educationally as unprepared for victory when it comes as it was for war when that came, in the opinion of 300 representatives of Illinois educational, civic, labor and governmental groups meeting at the University of Illinois to look ahead at the schools' problems of post-war reconstruction.

ROSE FRANKEN'S "Claudia," that play about an emotionally immature young bride with a mother complex, which has been entertaining New York audiences for a considerable time, opened here the other night under the auspices of Lee Ephraim and immediately gave promise of enjoying a long run in London.

Stricter wartime control of international communications and their cessation in many instances has caused a diminution in illicit world traffic in narcotics, according to a report section of the work of the League of Nations for the year ended in May, made public yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Like a bunch of kids running through a forest, Ohio State University's light but speedy Bucks breezed through and around the Armoraiders from Fort Knox today to win the season's opener, 59 to 0.

Debutantes of the new season have organized a committee to assist with details of the colorful cabaret revue and supper dance entitled "Incendiary Blondes," which will be presented in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Oct. 23 to aid the American Theatre Wing War Service, Inc., and its many war relief activities.

It is moose-calling time in the northland. In the country of great forests, rushing rivers and countless lakes and ponds. Summer's green has turned to flaming reds, royal purples and golds. The year-round greens of the firs, spruces, pines and hemlocks make the deep background for the highlights of frost-flamed deciduous leaves.

The article by Paul V. McNutt in the Magazine of Sept. 13 interests me. "Our habit of discrimination against the aged may yet cost us much production," he says. Already it has caused untold misery among the worthiest class of workers.

OTTAWA, Kan., Sept. 26 -- Believing that college students are capable of making their own designs for education, Ottawa University, under leadership of Dr. Andrew B. Martin, has departed from standardized educational procedure and adopted a practically applied system of individual training.

THE team of two collaborators responsible, under the collective pseudonym of "Manning Coles." for several of the best spy yarns of recent years has gone in, now, for fiction of a somewhat different and, by reason of that difference, more ambitious sort.

MOSCOW, Sept. 26 -- At the close of ten days packed with conferences, conversations and inspections, Wendell L. Willkie has convinced himself that the best way America can help to win the war is by establishing a real second front in Europe with Great Britain at the earliest possible moment military leaders will approve.

Retail trade was active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Demand for coats, suits and dresses was good and that for millinery brisk.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Mel Harder and Les Fleming combined today to give the Indians a 3-to-0 victory over Detroit and at least a tie with the Tigers for fourth place for the season.

Built by Army railway operating battalions, the fifty-mile Claiborne Polk Military Railway in Louisiana is now in service, connecting Camp Polk and Camp Claiborne, and providing a testing and training ground for the Railway Military Service.

Members of the junior post-debutante and debutante committees organized in the interests of the fourth annual benefit White Elephant Cocktail Party and Tea Dance will meet Tuesday afternoon at the Stork Club to make final arrangements for the party, which will take place Oct. 15 in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre.

Safety inspection required by States to insure good mechanical condition of motor vehicles is diminishing today. MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Drawn by two unhurried horses, a haywagon, carrying thirty boys and girls, mostly from Middletown High School, moved slowly along Route 17 just before midnight last night. The old-fashioned tunes that will always be sung on hayrides floated into the moonlit night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations and the "Big Four" railroad brotherhoods are working to prevent being excluded from the Anglo-American Labor Committee which is still exclusively composed of the British Trade Union Congress and the American Federation of Labor.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Duke University's Rose Bowl eleven of last January opened the 1942 campaign with a none too impressive 21-0 triumph over Davidson College in a Southern Conference game before 2,500 spectators today.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Engineering a smashing two-column sweep that went around strongly-fortified Japanese positions for gains of 60 and 40 miles, Chinese troops in Chekiang province have driven to the gates of Chuki and laid siege to Chenghsien, communications centers below Hangchow, frontline dispatches said today.

A compost heap is truly the gardener's bank and pays good dividends. But there's a science in making and maintaining a compost heap so that one gets the highest yield. With the chances good that fertilizer will be more scarce, even rationed, it behooves the home gardener to use the compost heap to the greatest possible advantage.

Perennial plants, because of their hardiness, dependability and variation, are a necessary part of every garden. No other group lends itself so well to making constant garden pictures. Fall is the ideal time for planting and transplanting many of these subjects, for it is then that proper space may be allotted to them, whole borders may be made or remade and plants put in will be well established by Spring.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 26 -- Princeton opened its football season today by registering a 20-6 triumph over the Lakehurst Naval Air Station team.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Superlatives are often used in describing the Berkshire Hills of Western Massachusetts in October. It is a delightful season to visit this region of hills and valleys, fields and forests, lakes and streams, a region rich in history and tradition.

Hitler had declared before the Reichstag that he did not want to wage a war against women and children.

A crowd of 3,000 saw the games, the only ones on tap for the opening of the New York City schoolboy season.

CREDIT the Rialto Theatre in Times Square with the nicest gesture of the week by contributing to the USO $1,200 as a result of the two-week engagement at the theatre of "The World at War." The donation represented the amount the theatre normally would have paid to a distributor in rental charges were not the government-made feature, dealing with world events of the last decade, being made available without cost to theatres.

Nation-wide gasoline rationing, which has been ordered to go into effect about Nov. 22 to conserve automobile tires, may result in cutting the over-all consumption of gasoline as much as 33 1-3 per cent from the peak level in 1941, when consumption amounted to 660,000,000 barrels.

The 450th anniversary of Columbus's discovery of America will be observed in a three-day Institute of Inter-American Affairs to be held beginning Oct. 10 at Co-Columbia University the National Broadcasting Company studios and the Museum of Modern Art.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (Science Service) -- A rubber-like material that can be made from soybean or other vegetable proteins is described in United States patent No. 2,296,464, granted to Robert Brown of New York City. The inventor claims that his material is more elastic than natural rubber and has great strength.

Wives of Army officers are assisting in the arrangements for the series of style showings entitled "Fashions of the Times," to be held Oct. 6 and 7 at the New York Times Hall, for the benefit of the Army Emergency Relief Fund.

A record enrollment in United States history, government and related courses dealing with American ideals and traditions has taken place this Fall at Yeshiva College, Professor Jacob I. Hartstein, registrar and secretary of the faculty, announced yesterday.

The isolation of a new vitamin from lemon peel which, preliminary experiments have shown, exerts a beneficial effect upon the state of the capillaries (small blood vessels), decreasing their fragility and preventing localized hemorrhages, is announced in the current issue of Science by Drs. Cecil Z. Wawra and J. Leyden Webb, School of Medicine, University of Southern California.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 -- Southern California, generally rated in pre-season reckoning as one of the two best football teams on the Pacific Coast, took a sound beating today at the hands of Tulane, 27 to 13.
VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Sept. 26 -- Rallying through the air in the final period, the Valley Stream Central High eleven defeated Sewanhaka of Floral Park, 13 -- 6, today.

Wild asters line the roadside, now that October creeps upon us, rivals of the slowly fading goldenrod. Hardy fellows, they are, star flowers indeed, brilliant and profuse as the stars in the Autumn skies. And varied as those stars, with blossoms large and small, white and lavender and aspiring purple, blossoms lavishly petaled, blossoms parsimonious as a pauper.

IN the swiftly gathering gloom of a chill Spring evening in 1939 a dun-colored Yugoslav Army staff car, speeding northward from Belgrade, came to a sudden halt as the chauffeur jammed on his brakes near the outskirts of the Northern Yugoslav city of Novisad. The beam of the headlamps caught khaki-clad figures of young men and boys in a marching column blocking the highway.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The convoy that the Germans boasted they had virtually destroyed delivered the "largest total of munitions yet transported in a single voyage from Britain and the United States." Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden disclosed tonight in an address to his constituents at Leamington.

The Board of Transportation voted yesterday to turn over to Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore for the city's salvage scrap pile 2,972 tons of the city-owned trolley tracks on abandoned lines that have been replaced with buses. THE New York College of Music is registering students, Mondays through Thursdays from 10 A.M. to 8 P.M., and Fridays and Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Class instruction begins Saturday.
SELINSGROVE, Pa., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Flashing a strong running attack, the University of Buffalo pushed across a touchdown in each of the first three periods to defeat Susquehanna, 19 -- 0, today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 26 -- Held scoreless for fifty-two minutes by Harvard's scrappy and almost entirely new, young eleven, the Naval Aviation Cadets from the North Carolina Pre-Flight School rushed over two touchdowns in quick succession for a 13-0 victory on Soldiers Field today.

An appeal for funds to purchase Christmas packages for men in the Navy and the merchant marine will be launched on the afternoon of Oct. 6 at the Autumn opening of the Navy League Shop, 746 Madison Avenue. Mrs. Winthrop Bowen is in charge of arrangements.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 26 -- Democrats of Fairfield County, which comprises the Fourth Congressional District, today renominated Representative Leroy D. Downs, South Norwalk publisher, by acclamation. He will be opposed in the Nov. 3 election by Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce of Greenwich, Republican nominee; David Mansell of Old Greenwich, Socialist candidate, and Lester Barlow of Stamford, the bomb inventor, as an independent Republican.

I used to read the Garden Page of THE TIMES every Sunday and try to remember the suggestions made. But when the time came to use a process or a list I seldom could recall the details. Saving the pages did little good, as after they had accumulated for a few months it was necessary to read so many items before finding the one I wanted that I would usually not bother.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- When President Roosevelt called in his Labor Day message for statutory authority to cut from 110 per cent to 100 per cent of established parity the ceilings on farm prices in the interest of inflation control, he turned politics loose in at least thirty-seven of the forty-eight States of the Union, the politics accentuated, as Capitol Hill developments have shown, by the fact that this is an election year.

THERE is tremendous satisfaction in reading a book that holds one not with plot alone and the characterization of the actors important to it with the magnetism of the author's mind. Anne Bridge's new novel, "Frontier Passage," is such a book.

WHAT may revolutionize radio's coverage of the war is a new program entitled "Freedom's Firing Line," which, when fully developed, is expected to bring to American homes an eyewitness, first-hand account of our armed forces in action on the world's battlefronts.

STERILIZED AIR -- The possibility of sterilizing the air in schools, theatres, subways and other public gathering places to prevent the spread of influenza, colds and similar infectious bacterial diseases has been reported by both English and American scientists.

"WHERE a man calls himself by a name which is not his name. he tells a falsehood." Louis Adamic has taken this grim sentence from a judgment by Lord Esher and put it as a motto over the first chapter of his new book, in which he discusses, in his usual lively and stimulating manner, the implications that the problem of personal names has for the American melting pot today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Chairman Dies announced tonight that the House committee investigating un-American activities would issue a report within two or three weeks listing ninety-three organizations within the United States as "Nazi front" groups.

Immediately after returning from Washington yesterday, Harold R. Moskovit, State president of the Affiliated Young Democrats, endorsed Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, and the remainder of the State ticket.

The diversified welfare activities of the Opportunity Shop at 46 West Forty-seventh Street will benefit from the normal opening of the Wedgwood Room of the Waldorf-Astoria on the night of Oct. 9 for its Autumn and Winter season.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Sept. 26 -- The Philadelphia Museum School of Industrial Art has changed its degree course in teacher education from a five-year to a four-year program and has added two-special industrial courses to its evening programs to meet the demands of the war upon the nation's artists.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 26 -- Ray Billows, Poughkeepsie's golf ambassador, probably has missed many short putts in his career, but perhaps none quite so short as the one he failed to make in the Garden City Country Club member-guest tournament today. Nor any that proved so costly.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- A poll of the Senate indicated tonight that the Administration had a better than even chance to defeat the farm group's attempts to write a higher farm parity price formula into the pending anti-inflation bill.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- National rationing of gasoline by coupons probably will go into effect about Nov. 22, Leon Henderson, the Price Administrator, made known today.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Sept. 27 -- Soviet troops pushed onward into German positions northwest of the smoking city of Stalingrad yesterday, the Russians announced today as the Red Army's official organ declared "there now is a chance to hold and repulse the Fascists," who have been battering at the Volga River city for more than a month.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 26 -- Big Bill Daley stepped into the shoes of an All-America half-back today to score four touchdowns and lead Minnesota's Big Ten champions in a 50-7 rout of a de-emphasized Pittsburgh team.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Sept. 26 -- Iowa chased the Nebraska football jinx today as the surprising Hawk-yes crushed the Cornhuskers, 27 to 0, for their first victory in nine games with the Big Six Conference team.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (U.P.) -- One of the longest grand jury investigations of record was at an end today. A special Federal grand jury which undertook a comprehensive study of subversive activities a year ago was disbanded late yesterday by Federal Judge Thomas J. Bailey.

A funeral service was held yesterday for Alman Harrington, the 23-year-old father who died Wednesday of a gunshot wound inflicted by his wife several months ago, and whose four children were returned to him, by a Supreme Court order, to brighten his last hours.

Francis B. Laughlin, deputy surveyor of customs in New York, has been appointed assistant surveyor to succeed Milton P. Jackson, who retired several weeks ago, it was announced yesterday by Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port. Mr. Laughlin has been acting assistant surveyor for six weeks and will receive the full title on the first of the month. He is 43 years old.

While shoe production is starting to decline, leaders of the industry and government officials expressed complete confidence yesterday that military, civilian and lend-lease requirements can be met. PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -- The "Jacksonville formula" of the Securities and Exchange Commission for reorganizing financially distressed corporations appears likely now to be brought to the attention of Congress for possible legislation to bring the scheme within reach of any company, whether within the purview of the SEC or outside it.

SANTA FE, N.M. -- A suggestion of the kind of big game hunting that may be enjoyed in the Southwest is to be had from the windows of transcontinental trains traversing New Mexico, when an antelope startled by the locomotive whistle takes off across country like a pursuit plane getting under way.
LONDON, Sept. 26 (Canadian Press) -- West Ham United and Chelsea moved to a first-place tie with Arsenal in the southern section of the English Football League today.

Moore, U.S.N.R., former transatlantic ship master of the United States Lines, has been appointed to command the training ship Empire State of the United States Maritime Service, it was announced yesterday by Captain Edward A. Macauley, deputy administrator of the War Shipping Administration in charge of the national Merchant Marine training program.

The annual report of the Eureka Vacuum Cleaner Company covering operations in the year ended on July 31, which was issued yesterday, shows a net profit of $421,842, equal to $2.09 a share on 209,919 shares of common stock. The boy had a sense of humor; moreover, a catch in his voice as he sang the sob ballads of the day made a hit with the soldiers.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Columbus Redbirds won an error-spotted 4-3 game from the Syracuse Chiefs tonight to take a 2-1 lead in the twenty-fifth little world series. Right-hander George (Red) Munger dealt the International League play-off winners only seven scattered hits.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 -- In sharp contrast to conditions prevailing during the World War, when wartime antipathy to all things German caused a heavy decline in the teaching of that language in many American schools and colleges, the demand for courses in German at Simmons College this year is the greatest in the history of the institution.

LONDON, Sept. 26 (U.P.) -- Masayuki Tani, newly appointed Japanese Foreign Minister, speaking today on the eve of the second anniversary of the signing of the tripartite Axis agreement, said that Japan planned no changes in her policy toward Russia, despite developments in the European war.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Henry J. Kaiser declared today that steel was the real bottleneck in the country's war production schedule.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Sept. 26 -- Randolph-Macon Woman's College, entering its fiftieth session, has turned its back on experimental education and has transferred emphasis in its curricula to such fundamentals as mathematics and pure science, a rigid measure designed to prepare the 650 young women in its student body better to meet conditions in a post-war world.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Norway's German-occupied capital of Oslo was reported tonight on the verge of a state of siege after Norwegian patriots and Royal Air Force bombers had combined to spread fire and havoc in the elaborate settings of a convention of the Quisling Nazi puppet party.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Close followers of the radio war deduce from recent German broadcasts that Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda, is losing his grip. For Dr. Goebbels's pose of serene confidence, the ideal one for the propagandist, is no longer possible, and on the radio and in the press Nazi propaganda lately has become increasingly defensive, with fewer boasts and more warnings of impending perils facing Germany.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday that he had given his commanding officers twenty days "to investigate, take appropriate action and report results" on the list of 244 places that Mayor La Guardia delivered to him alleging violations of the gambling laws within the city.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 26 -- The William and Mary College football team spoiled the opening game of the Naval Academy's season today, turning back the mid-shipmen, 3 to 0, before 12,000 spectators in Thompson Stadium. It was the seventeenth game between the schools and the second victory of the series for the Indians.

FIRST a hickory leaf here and there, twirling down by itself, in the dog-days, foretells the American Autumn. A sumac, waving a painted frond, adds its promise. An aspen, among dark needle forests, fires up with tremulous gold. And by that time there are asters like a rime of frost across the boggy pastures and goldenrod is bobbing underneath a freight of restless bees all under the oaks in the highwood.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -- Still stubborn about the matter, the Dodgers today ran roughshod over the Phils for an 8 -- 3 triumph, stretched their winning streak to seven games and, with the enforced idleness of the Cardinals, put over the decision in the National League flag race until tomorrow, last day of the regular season.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 26 -- According to reports from resident missionaries in Kiangsi Province, relief and rehabilitation are urgently needed. Cities and villages along the line of enemy advances and retreats have been ravaged, crops have been utterly ruined, and dysentery and malaria are rampant.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26 -- The National League pennant race continued in a state of suspended animation along its Western front today as the Cardinals, unable to play their game with the Cubs because of weather conditions, satidly in their clubhouse, while the Dodgers, by defeating the Phils in Philadelphia, kept alive their mathematical chance of throwing the race into a deadlock.

This is a pleasant collection of stories for the bedside table in the guest room. If the guest has read some of them in the Saturday Evening Post, he will find others not printed before, and he might even like to glance again at those he had read.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 26 -- The shadow of Japan lies over India today, and whenever and wherever the Indian situation is discussed people bring in Japan to help their argument along. The trouble is that it is an argument that works both ways.

President Roosevelt will formally launch the 1942 campaign of the Community Mobilization for Human Needs with a radio address over the four major networks on Monday night, Oct. 5, it was announced yesterday.

Edward I. Greene, general manager of the National Better Business Bureau, declared yesterday that a survey conducted by his organization of civilian defense experts and fire-fighting authorities had revealed that water was the "most satisfactory" agent for householders to use in combatting incendiary bombs and the fires they cause.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 26 -- Although not the first plan of its type to be put into effect, Princeton University's program of study in American civilization has, during its first six months of operation, surpassed all others in comprehensiveness, according to Professor Willard Thorp, chairman of the committee in charge of the program.

PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Sept. 26 -- Standing on a fighting ship of the Pacific Fleet before thirty-six airmen who were being decorated for bravery in air battles against the Japanese, Vice Admiral William F. Halsey Jr., senior task force commander of the Pacific Fleet, declared today that while the Fleet Air Arm has demonstrated its superiority to that of the enemy, the hardest fighting was yet to come.

FAR more than American citizens generally realize, the fortunes of our Republic turn upon the relations of the civil government to the armed forces and upon relations within and between the branches of these forces.

WHAT kind of adults are studying music nowadays? Rudolf Jankel, director of the Metropolitan Music School, provides a partial answer in an analysis of some of the school's students. Dr. Wallingford Riegger's composition class, for example, includes a psychologist, an oculist, a wrestler, a high school student and a commercial photographer, all of whom entered the school to study either harmony or an instrument and found they had a bent for composing.
In banking and in business, in railroad stations and hotels, in plants and in department stores women during the past year have assumed an increasingly important role in the national wartime scene.

AS a man currently under suspension for the third time by his home studio, George Sanders, erstwhile Saint and Falcon and gentleman adventurer extraordinary, last week seemed in remarkably frivolous spirits.

We are beginning to face a shortage of lamps, especially lamps with metal bases. Now is the time, therefore, to enlist the ingenuity of the home decorator, amateur or professional, in a return to the old American custom of "fixing up" something to help out on the home front for the duration.

Because of the absence from their voting residences of men in the armed services and in war production plants, the women's vote at the coming election has attained greater importance than at any other time since adoption of the suffrage amendment.

Chopin: Concerto No. 1 in E minor. Edward Kilenyi, piano, and Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra conducted by Dimitri Mitropoulos (Columbia M-515, four 12-inch records). Mr. Kilenyi, now in the United States Army, made a batch of records before going into the service, and this is the first of a new set of his releases.

ON THE FRENCH FRONTIER, Sept. 26 (U.P.) -- Advices from France tonight reported spreading unrest, violence and uneasiness, marked by half a dozen bomb explosions along the Riviera, spreading food riots and sudden reinforcements of guards at the Portalet Fortress, where Paul Reynaud and Georges Mandel are imprisoned.

FOR more than a hundred years Blair House has been the home of an American family. It has had its place in history, housing men who have had their part in the affairs of the country and affording a setting for conferences that shaped the destiny of men and the policies of the Republic.

After a three-month investigation of charges that the market in a bond issue of the Wisconsin Central Railroad had been "rigged," Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. began suit in Supreme Court yesterday to put out of business the over-the-counter securities concern of Hanson Hanson of 25 Broadway, as well as its two partners and a specialist salesman.

This time he is especially interested because his cousin, Ian Maclean, is accused of having murdered his wife, Adela, and the evidence against him is so overwhelmingly conclusive as to leave little hope of his escaping the gas chamber.

THE fifth column has assumed such importance as a modern method and menace that we are prone to forget that organized disloyalty on the home front is not a new factor in wartime. The Copperheads of the Civil War were not merely disaffected individuals.

STORRS, Conn., Sept. 26 -- The University of Connecticut has "enlisted for the duration," in the words of President A. N. Jorgensen, but despite wartime conditions it is continuing this year the rapid expansion of services and growth of enrollment that began with his inauguration seven years ago.

The fresh vegetables that have been enjoyed during the Summer need not become merely a pleasant memory, but may, by means of storage, be kept to provide food all through Winter. How that conservation is a major consideration, storing is an important operation for the victory gardener.

BOYS and girls, and indeed readers of any age who are curious to know what is behind this modern every-day magic of music and voices on the air, will find their questions answered with admirable simplicity and clarity in "All About Broadcasting."
