ONE of the early season announcements of more than usual interest confirms the merger of the Schaeffer and the Mortimer Brandt Galleries. Both dealers have been identified with international art affairs, their clients including many of the well-known museums and private collectors in Europe and the United States.

Enrollment of women volunteers in war work and civilian defense activities throughout the metropolitan area, which has been steadily mounting as the war progresses, is now estimated as approximating 230,000 ten months after Pearl Harbor.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The neutral position of Eire long has constituted a threat to the war effort and since the United States entered the war and began gradually building up considerable armed forces in Ulster and in North Ireland, that danger has been magnified.

Although the vacation rush has subsided, railroad travel in and out of the city yesterday was about 50 per cent greater than at this time last year, railroad officials said. The long distance bus lines, on the other hand, reported a considerable slack in travel and spokesmen said they believed this was in line with the request of the Office of Defense Transportation urging that unessential travel be curtailed.

BEAR MOUNTAIN PARK -- These are days of green and gold up here in the heart of the Hudson Highlands -- with a liberal sprinkling of scarlet, orange, purple and assorted Fall colors thrown in for good measure.

Because of the war, this year's National Horse Show will be curtailed from the usual eight days to one, with an afternoon and evening session. Saturday, Nov. 7, and will be held at the Riding and Polo Club, 7 West Sixty-sixth Street, instead of in Madison Square Garden.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 26 -- The prospect that large numbers of American college men will not only see military service abroad but will aso be needed in the international field after the war has led the Committee on Defense Instruction at Dartmouth College to urge undergraduates to give more serious consideration to the foreign studies open to them.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Impressively large numbers of British and American parachute troops and British air borne forces today were spilled from the sky in widespread areas of these isles in a big training operation. The manoeuvres are intended to test not only the ability of the growing air armies to operate on a large scale but also the British home defenses against an enemy attack like the one that captured Crete.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- The food industry has proved again that it can move price depressing storage stocks or surpluses into consumer channels through a cooperative sales campaign. Domestic movement of cheese, according to preliminary figures released here today by the joint committee of milk producers and cheese manufacturers and distributors, ran 25 per cent ahead of 1941 during August.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The people of Europe tonight were called on by the Earl of Selborne, Minister for Economic Warfare, to help the war effort of the United Nations by a vast slow-down on the Nazis' railroad system and by withholding nickel, especially coins, because the enemy is believed seriously short of this metal.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Britain's newest bomber made its debut in yesterday afternoon's attack on the Nazi Gestapo headquarters in Oslo, the Air Ministry announced today, making public for the first time the existence of these planes which are faster than Germany's Focke-Wulf fighter yet carry an effective bomb load.

The epic battle line hemming Stalingrad against the Volga was last week, as it has been for a month, the critical point in the fight against the Nazi aggressor. Half a million Germans and perhaps an equal number of Russians were pitted along an undulating forty miles of pillboxes, minefields, fortified rubble and barricaded streets.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The Archbishop of Canterbury, speaking before 6,000 persons in Albert Hall today, condemned modern society's emphasis on the profit motive and advocated a limiting of bank credit to the amount deposited by clients and declared that further credit should be a function of "public authority."

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Behind the dedication and formal opening this week-end of a new student observatory at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute is an idea originating four years ago among a small group of students whose hobby was amateur astronomy.

GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands, Sept. 19 (Delayed) -- United States Marines, strengthened by supplies and reinforcements brought in by a strong task force, tightened their grip on the southeastern Solomons today. From Aug. 7, when yelling Marines charged up Guadalcanal's sandy beaches, until about six days ago, when fanatic Japanese soldiers, shouting "American Marine, you die!"

It grows dark around Norway's North Cape in September. The long days of a brief Summer close down suddenly, the ever-lengthening nights set in, the season of lashing rain and snow storms, of fog and roaring winds begins. In a year of peace the last tourist steamer to tread the spectacular fjords would have been gone a month since, leaving a bleak ocean to the fishermen and an occasional mail vessel.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Alert, bruising line play gave Louisiana State's Bayou Bengals a traveling ticket for its shifty backs through vaunted Texas A. and M. tonight and the Tigers defeated the Southwest Conference defending champions, 16 -- 7, before 25,000 fans.

THE dramatic movements of human history are nowhere so abundant as in the strife of religious movements. Out of the endless controversies over theological minutiae and the parade of rites that sometimes seem incredible in their triviality, there come the moral spectacles of tyranny and martyrdom, brute force and toleration, frenzy and sanity.

Chairmen and co-chairmen of 2500 volunteer workers in the 1942 campaign of the women's division of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities were announced yesterday by George Z. Medalie, president of the New York organization, and Hugh Grant Straus, president of the Brooklyn group.
The tightest pennant race in the National League since 1934 comes down to its final day today with interest at fever heat and confusion on all sides.

"GOLF IS A FRIENDLY GAME" is a gladsome little book devoted wholeheartedly and gayly to demonstrating the grouches, rancors and enmities the game engenders. Mr. Gallico is very careful, however, to arrange that, from the skirmish and battle lines on the fairways and greens, the smoke clears for a bright and happy ending.

QUINCY, Mass., Sept. 26 -- The aircraft carrier Lexington, fifth of a distinguished line of naval vessels, slid down the ways here today to keep a rendezvous somewhere at sea some time with the Japanese who sank her predecessor in the Coral Sea.

THE first book of lyrics by Jose Garcia Villa, a young poet-scholar from the Philippines, is an astonishing discovery in poetry. Everything that Mr. Villa writes seems to be his own, as if he had really invented the language of feeling.

German-Americans in Yorkville and vicinity will hold a War Bond rally at 5 P.M. today on East Eighty-sixth Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues, with orchestras from five well-known restaurants furnishing music for the occasion.

ONE of the latest of the many tributes to Daniel Berkeley Updike which followed upon his death last Christmas week appears in the current issue of Direct Advertising, published in Boston. It is by George Parker Winship, who had already written an eloquent appreciation and estimate in another trade journal, The Publishers' Weekly, last February.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- American women will have to get along with one new bob-pin or hairpin next year for every four they could buy last year, the War Production Board warned today.

A drastic revision in the type and quality of United States history courses now offered on the secondary level throughout the country is needed immediately, if the high school students are to receive an adequate background in American culture and the democratic heritage, Professor Samuel McKee Jr. of Columbia University warned yesterday.

ONE day in the late Winter twenty half-frozen survivors of a torpedoed tanker were landed at an East coast port, and the women of the community were ready with efficient voluntary organization to take care of them.

Retail trade here was favored by cooler weather last week and apparel sales particularly were benefited. Department store volume was estimated as about 1 to 2 per cent ahead of the comparative week last year. Furniture was quiet. Specialty store gains were larger.

FOR the promotion and sale of war bonds and stamps the New York City WPA Symphony Orchestra will give four concerts at 5:45 P.M., on Oct. 11, 18 and 25, and Nov. 1, in Carnegie Hall, under the auspices of Mayor La Guardia and the New York City WPA War Services Section, Music Unit, in behalf of the United States Treasury Department.

IT was a happy thought to put together in a small attractive volume, just right to slip into a pocket and carry on a picnic or a journey, some fifty odd jokes. The idea grew out of a sure knowledge of young people, for, thinking back, most adults will recall a time when a funny story was an exquisite joy to laugh over one's self and to pass on to one's companions.
PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 26 -- James A. Farley's reputation as an election forecaster will be put to an acid test this November.
All America has taken the Miniver family to its heart, so it was with great interest I read Jan Struther's article on Mr. Miniver in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The United States will attain this month its goal of launching three merchant ships a day, Maritime Commission sources disclosed tonight in connection with the anniversary of the launching of the first Liberty ship a year ago tomorrow.

TWO photoplays dealing with women in aviation are currently occupying the attention of RKO. One is an almost documentary biography of Amy Johnson Mollison, "Wings and the Woman," starring Anna Neagle and produced in England by Herbert Wilcox; the other is a romantic tale about an American aviatrix who is not Amelia Earhart, the studio says.

"Sinbad the Sailor" and "The Big Bad Wolf," two new fairytale fun cartoons, are announced by Castle Films for home projection. Available in 8mm and 16mm silent versions as well as 16mm sound, the films may be had in color or black-and-white.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Sept. 26 -- Donald Roberts and Ray Kilthau of Oakland, winners of the medal with a 72, led the way into the semi-finals of the second annual North Hempstead Country Club member-guest golf tournament today.

The Andrew Furuseth Club at 30 East Thirty-seventh Street will be opened on Wednesday under the sponsorship of the United Seamen's Service. Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator, and Mayor La Guardia are expected to speak at the dedication ceremony.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 26 -- More than 3,000 opium dens are scattered around Hankow and its immediate vicinity, according to a Chinese who escaped from Hankow early in July. He reported that the puppet Hankow municipal government had established an "Opium Suppression Bureau" that serves as an opium sales agency.
American youth ran riot at the Polo Grounds yesterday and cost the Giants a bail game after Mel Ott's band practically had it sewed up in the satchel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Politicians agree today, a little more than six weeks before the November general elections, that continued Democratic control of both the House of Representatives and the Senate is probable, if not certain.

SHORT-WAVE "pirate transmitters," unlicensed broadcasters of unknown location, are cropping up as fast as mushrooms. More than half of them remain in operation, others vanish like ghosts, and many appear on the air, disappear without ceremony and return days or weeks later.

Ethelbert Smith, in reply to a question how he thought the war was going, replied without a moment's hesitation that he had given it up. Given it up? The interviewer gasped and went pale under his tan as they do in the romantic novels.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 26 -- Sparkling sprints by Meryll Frost, coupled with flashes of crisp and effective blocking at opportune moments, gave a slick band of Dartmouth Indians a surprising 17-to-6 football victory over Holy Cross at Fitton Field today.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Sept. 26 (AP) -- A seven-touchdown scoring bombardment carried Illinois to a 46-to-0 opening day victory over South Dakota today to inaugurate the career of Ray Eliot as IIlini coach.

Last Tuesday marked the formal opening of the All-Day Neighborhood Schools, a project which, school officials expect, will change the entire educational system of New York, from the first grade through high school. Public School 33 in Chelsea, and Public School 194 in Harlem will open their doors from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M., to take care of the children of women war workers.
Columbia University will conduct a series of field trips and lectures on gardening, beginning this Fall. Information may be obtained from the Department of Public Information.

PAINTINGS by the late George Pearse Ennis make up the first exhibition of the season at the Sixtieth Street Gallery. The Maine Coast, New England fishermen at their tasks and the Austrian Alps figure as subjects.

The Federal authorities, in an effort to end trafficking in used postage stamps from which cancellation marks had been so efficiently removed as to make the stamps appear to be unused copies, introduced photographic machinery in presenting the government's evidence in the recent trial of a New York dealer.

Dr. Stine, speaking to the recent American Chemical Society meeting at Buffalo, and quoted in your issue of Sept. 8, seems to have fallen into error in saying the war is hastening progress in chemistry.

Record-smashing performances in a day of unusual racing were rather commonplace yesterday at Belmont Park, where 25,320 persons saw Whirlaway beaten by Bolingbroke in 2:27 3-5, a new American standard for a mile and a half. Townsend B. Martin's Saratoga Cup winner lowered the Belmont mark by four-fifths of a second.

THE citizens were sitting around in Flatbush yesterday waiting for news from Philadelphia and St. Louis. It was the death watch of the Dodger rooters. They were waiting with sad eyes and locked lips and strained faces, clinging to just one thin ray of hope that there might be life in the National League pennant race yet.

The first nova, or exploding star, to appear in the heavens in many months has been discovered in the constellation Cygnus by Dr. Fritz Zwicky in observations from Mount Palomar, Calif., it was announced by the Harvard University Observatory, American clearing house for cosmic information.

Schools educate students for what they are to do. The older students of this generation must fight a war, the younger ones build a lasting peace. The trends in education are therefore pointed to these objectives. Many of the trends imposed by the world crisis are temporary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Nearly two-thirds of about 300 judges who make up the Federal courts, ranging from the Supreme Court downward, have been appointed to their present posts by President Roosevelt, according to figures obtained at the Department of Justice.

Wall Street's best recovery week since July ended yesterday on a note of uncertainty. Prices on the New York Stock Exchange closed fractionally easier and dull, but trading was the largest for a Saturday since March 7 with a volume of 226,825 shares, against 178,480 on the preceding Saturday.

War has shattered the routines of the last quarter of a century in women's club groups which have swung whole-heartedly into support of a multitude of activities which focus on support of the nation's anti-Axis program. On the eve of the season of 1942-1943, even a brief look backward reveals the sharp contrast between peacetime objectives and the intensity that now characterizes the club scene.

A booklet entitled "Emblems of Unity and Freedom" has been published by the Metropolitan Museum of Art, in connection with the museum's current exhibition of the same emblems of American patriotism as illustrated in the booklet.

BUFFALO, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Edwin F. Jaeckle, State Republican chairman, following a series of five up-State regional campaign strategy conferences, said today that reports indicated "a tremendous Republican trend."

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Home Secretary Herbert Morrison called on British labor today to hold itself in readiness to lead a post-war drive for the retention of the State-planned economic measures that have been adopted as expedients for the successful prosecution of the war.

Few of the people of Norway can have heard the broadcast of President Roosevelt's presentation of the sub chaser Haakon to the Norwegian Navy, for radio permits in that country, once numbering half a million, are now reduced to 7,100.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 26 (AP) -- A.J. Sackett's Tola Rose took the lead at the start and held it throughout today to win the $13,350 Havre de Grace Handicap, feature of the closing-day program.

"Butt-End Charlie," the British call him, and his is a lonely job. He is the gunner who mans the "stinger" in the rear of the big bombing planes, the sharpshooter who "keeps flies off the horse's back." Riding backward in his tiny plexiglass-walled cubicle, six miles a minute, be squints through his gunsight at a dark speck swooping down from the blue.

In answer to Puerto Rico's desperate plea for increased shipping, Herbert E. Gaston, Acting Secretary of the Treasury, signed an order last week relaxing shipping laws affecting the island. Under the new order certain vessels of foreign registry will be permitted to stop at Puerto Rican ports to load and discharge cargo.

EDITOR KALTENBORN'S book is made up of answers to the most recent questions he has been asked by patrons of the newsreel theatres. They embrace such subjects as the effects of anti-strike legislation, the handicapping of war effort through partisan politics at Washington, women's war activities, the possibility of a post-war depression, and the various strategic phases of the war itself.

An unparalleled opportunity for women to demonstrate their ability in the field of finance and banking exists today, Miss Henrietta J. Fuchs, newly elected president of the Association of Bank Women, declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the national organization of women bank executives.

THE reader will search in vain in this book and in its index for the name of Josef Vissarionovitch Djugashvilli, by which the title character was originally known. This fact is an index to the kind of book it is.

ONE of the more restless of the arts, even if it does not always seem so, the radio now and then makes what appears to be an honest effort to escape the well-worn categories, and even when it does not entirely succeed you would be less than grateful if you did not welcome the attempt.

With their president general, Mrs. William H. Pouch, as their principal guest and speaker, the State organizations of the Daughters of the American Revolution in Yew York and Connecticut will hold annual conferences this week with discussions which are expected to set the programs for their members in the coming season.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 26 -Jacques Benoist-Mechin, who was ousted as a Secretary of State today, came to the fore before the war with a history of the German Army which was highly praised in Berlin. He was taken prisoner during the war and on his release became an out-and-out "collaborationist" and received a government post calling for liaison with the German authorities.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The quota of new adult bicycles for rationing in October has been set at 88,000 by the Office of Price Administration. The September quota was 90,000.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Allied bombers have destroyed a small Japanese transport off the Trobriand Islands, east of New Guinea, and heavily bombed two other ships near Rabaul, New Britain, a communique said today.
BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 26 -University of California's Bears worked hard today for a skimpy 6-0 victory over St. Mary's College in the traditional season football opener.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Responding enthusiastically to intensive field training here at Camp Smith for the last four months, the New York State Guard is now rated by Governor Lehman, Commander in Chief, and Major General William Ottman, commanding general, as fully capable of meeting any State situation that may arise.

The United States Public Health Service has agreed to grant scholarships to New York University for the training of public health nurses, it was announced yesterday by Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase.

Women's coat manufacturers were advised to prepare for a potential reduction in volume and more drastic government policies and regulations by Joseph L. Dubow, executive director of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association, at a series of group meetings held late last week at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

The most disturbing factor which persistently oozes through current censored news is obvious disagreement among the United Nations in the matter of the conduct of the war. Three recent incidents point to this unfortunate conclusion. The first is the manifest Soviet bitterness at the failure of Anglo-American forces to open a second front.

The need for American colleges to expand their student guidance programs to meet problems caused by the war emergency was stressed last week by Dr. Harry Noble Wright, who will be inaugurated Wednesday as the sixth president of City College.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Wake Forest's two-year domination over the University of North Carolina ended today when Hugh Cox, a fleet-footed back, scored the touchdown that gave the Tar Heels a 6-0 victory before more than 9,000 fans.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Sept. 26 -- A drastic revision of the work offered in geology and geography by Bucknell University provides an illustration of the way one liberal arts college is overhauling the curricula of all departments to meet the exigencies of the wartime emergency.

THE Monterey Peninsula, California's garden spot, which claims such artistic citizens as John Steinbeck, Robinson Jeffers and Salvadore Dali, was taken over recently by the Nazis. The invasion was accomplished without disturbing the serenity of this ancient neighborhood, for the Nazis were recruits from Central Casting and their commanding officers were featured players from Hollywood.

GREENCASTLE, Ind., Sept. 26 (AP) -- The University of Rochester of Rochester, N.Y., unleased a tricky succession of spinners and reverses today to defeat DePauw University, 25 to 0, marring the Tigers' opener on the gridiron.

Anybody who wants to send a Christmas present to a boy in any overseas Army or Navy post had better get moving now. The postal authorities say you should send your gift between Oct. 1 and Nov. 1 if you want to be sure it arrives in time.

As the opening gun in a drive to compel motorists to display appropriate windshield ration stickers, the local Office of Price Administration issued summonses yesterday to twenty-four motorists in the metropolitan area to appear to answer to charges of violating rationing regulations.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Sept. 26 -- Fordham and Purdue matched touchdown forward passes today and Fordham won, two to one. Twice the Maroon stabbed through the air to scores and once the Boilermakers came through in the same way, so the scoreboard in Ross-Ade Stadium blinked Fordham 14, Purdue 7 as 20,000 started home after the final play.

With aid to retailers in cutting expenses of operation under the General Maximum Price Regulation as the announced objective, the meeting of retail executives called for next Tuesday and Wednesday in Washington by the OPA and the ODT will probably chart the way to further long-range curtailment of retail services in the war economy, according to views here last week.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Henceforth no coal or coke will be used Sundays and Wednesdays by any unit of the Eastern Command of the British Army, the War Office has announced. Gas and electricity likewise are forbidden on these days, according to authorities who are attempting to build up stocks against the Winter emergency.
EVANSTON, Ill., Sept. 26 -- Striking on the ground and through the air, Bernie Bierman's Iowa Naval Pre-Flight team built its attack on Bill Schatzer today to defeat Northwestern, 20 to 12.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -- Pennsylvania's football team, rated among the powers in Eastern collegiate circles, overmatched itself today and the opening of the sixty-sixth Red and Blue season resulted in a 14-6 setback for Coach George Munger's men.

Greece has not only made "a total sacrifice of her prosperity at home," and is still fighting in the Middle East with her forces, but she has given approximately 1,800,000 gross tons of shipping to the allied cause. Of this tonnage, representing 460 vessels, about 60 per cent has been lost.

Harold Clurman, founder and managing director for the last decade of the Group Theatre, and Stella Adler, a former member of the acting company of the organization, will be married this afternoon at the home of Mr. Clurman's parents, 1519 Fifty-second Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The job of dispensing information about the war effort and war aims of the United States to domestic and foreign publicity mediums has become one of Washington's major industries. It involves the employment of more than 4,000 persons and expenditures that exceed $1,000,000 and may be nearer $2,000,000 a month.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Trading in wheat futures was at a virtual standstill today on the Board of Trade as brokers awaited developments in anti-inflation legislation in Washington. While few operators regard the proposed ceiling prices as of much importance as a price-making figure, they are awaiting passage of the bill to determine the loan rates on wheat.

Eight enemy aliens, four Italians, three Germans and one Japanese, were seized here in raids ended yesterday, according to P.E. Foxworth, agent in charge of the local Federal Bureau of Investigation office.

The all-out effort being made by members of society to advance war relief projects and welfare enterprises on the home front is exemplified currently by the Autumn campaigns for funds which now are receiving the active cooperation and support of women representing three generations.

WHEN Ettore Panizza decided, for personal reasons, that he could not return from Buenos Aires to resume his post as conductor at the Metropolitan Opera, another difficult problem was tossed into the management's lap at a time when the theatre was swarming with troubles.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Sept. 26 -- The Coast Guard Academy defeated Wesleyan University today, 14 -- 6, in the 1942 football opener for both teams. It was the second victory in the eight-year-old series for the cadets, who have lost five and tied one.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- It is no wonder that Mrs. John Doe, whose husband has already been called into the Army through the Selective Service System, is confused when she reads a pronouncement from Washington that the induction of childless married men will begin in December or January.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 26 -- Rhode Island State's fast, well-drilled eleven overwhelmed the University of Vermont, 70 to 13, in the opening football game of the season today.

A new and much simplified technique of curing chronic infection of the tear sac, a troublesome condition resulting in constant "tearing," was demonstrated recently before the American Medical Association by Dr. David J. Morgenstern of Brooklyn, Assistant Attending in Otolaryngology at the New York Post-Graduate Medical School and Hospital.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Sept. 26 (AP) -- With Quarterback Tommy Mont firing aerials like baseballs, University of Maryland's Old Liners unveiled the tricky T-formation for the first time today and completely dazzled the University of Connecticut for a 34-0 victory before an estimated crowd of 6,000.

Distribution in the wartime economy and in the post-war readjustment period will be discussed by speakers at the Boston Conference on Distribution to be held on Oct. 5 and 6 at the Hotel Stattler in that city. At the luncheon session on the opening day, Wayne C. Taylor, Under-Secretary of Commerce, will analyze "Distribution's Place in Wartime Economy," while Harold Butler, British Minister to the United States, will talk on "War and Industry in Britain.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Ideal time for planting or transplanting peonies: provide big holes, well enriched deep down, because a peony plant "stays set" for many, many years. The crown, however, should be covered only two inches deep. . . . Bleeding-heart, another long-lived old favorite worth a place in any garden, is also best moved at this time.

The picture of Army Nurse Corps nurses on your Sept. 13 cover and the article, "Our Nurses on the World's Fronts," do a fine job of calling attention to the important work these women are doing. There are a few small factual inaccuracies in the article, however.

Nine new players will report to the New York Yankees' training camp next Spring as a result of purchases announced by the American League champions yesterday. Seven of the players were acquired from the Newark club and two from Kansas City.
IN this pleasant little story Martha Wenger, of the author's "Little Amish Schoolhouse," and her family move from their Lancaster County farm in Pennsylvania to the new Amish colony in Maryland.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- A Lafayette Leopard with teeth made Cornell earn an opening day football victory at Schoellkopf Field today. The count was 20 -- 16 as the Big Red renewed its rivalry with the club from Easton, Pa., after a lapse of twenty-three years.

MOSCOW'S musical Winter season has begun. This year there was not the usual Summer break, and opera, ballet and concerts continue to be patronized by people who were denied holidays. A concert devoted to Tchaikovsky's "1812 Overture" and symphonies by Borodin and Mussorgsky were followed by another featuring Shostakovich's Seventh symphony to mark the opening of the new season.

VULGARITY is not an uncommon phenomenon, but its appearance as a theme in fiction, in a very specific sense, is more rare than one would suppose. Mr. Kahler has attempted the treatment of the theme in his new novel in a big way, and in a large measure the attempt comes off.

MOSCOW'S musical Winter season has begun. This year there was not the usual Summer break, and opera, ballet and concerts continue to be patronized by people who were denied holidays. A concert devoted to Tchaikovsky's "1812 Overture" and symphonies by Borodin and Mussorgsky were followed by another featuring Shostakovich's Seventh symphony to mark the opening of the new season.

VULGARITY is not an uncommon phenomenon, but its appearance as a theme in fiction, in a very specific sense, is more rare than one would suppose. Mr. Kahler has attempted the treatment of the theme in his new novel in a big way, and in a large measure the attempt comes off.

THE question, How can we provide enough scrap to meet the war needs? becomes narrowed down, in the special province this page serves, to the subsidiary question, What can art do to aid the scrap pile?

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Clipping one-fifth of a second from the track record for a mile and a furlong set by Stagehand in the same race four years ago, the Valdina Farms' Valdina Orphan won the $10,000 added Governor's Handicap as the forty-two-day meeting came to an end today at Narragansett Park.

Activity in the cotton market continued yesterday, with trade price-fixing against purchases in the open market by the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation raising quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange to gains of as much as 16 points before hedge selling leveled the list almost to Friday's close.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 26 -- Another sign of the times as 1942-1943 Fall semester classes get under way at Marquette University is the announcement by the Rev. Raphael C. McCarthy, president, of the abolishment of the requirement for a one-year hospital internship by students in the Marquette School of Medicine before they receive their Doctor of Medicine degrees.
TOLEDO, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Fire, fed by crude oil and gasoline, swept three vessels at the Hocking Valley Railroad piers here today resulting in injuries to twelve men and damage estimated at $110,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Treasury's request this week that civilians accumulate War Savings Stamps rather than coins drew attention to the fact that the penny is by far the most popular coin. The Mint during the last calendar year turned out 1,108,099,100 of the coins, which compares with a 1938 production of 191,866,734.

There was tension last week on Washington's Capitol Hill. Not since the fight on the Supreme Court bill of 1937 had the mood of Congress been so serious. In both houses groups of men, in revolt against the President's demand that Congress curb rising farm prices by Oct. 1, seemed determined, instead, to encourage the upward trend.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Sept. 26 -- Theodore Backe, 17-year-old amateur tennis champion, has been missing since Thursday from his home here following a disagreement with his father over the youth's choice of a college, the Bay Shore police reported today.

Fuel savings as high as 30 per cent have resulted from adoption of a set of conservation rules by industrial plants, it was reported yesterday by Minneapolis-Honey-well Regulator Company, maker of precision equipment.

KATHERINE WIGMORE EYRE, whose appealing little tale "Lottie's Valentine" has been enjoyed by many young readers, has written in "Susan's Safe Harbor" a warmhearted, unforced story of a little girl whose family went to live on Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 23 (Delayed) -- American servicemen on furlough from Middle East combat bases are touring the Holy Land and getting to know its problems. Many Americans have been surprised to find amid spots mentioned in the Bible men and women farmers from American cities who are pooling their farm products in the common war effort.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 26 -- Fairfield County, for years the Mecca of city folk with a taste for suburban-rural life, will become "sheep country" in earnest if a project conceived by Le Roy M. Chapman, County Farm Bureau agent, materializes.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Daniel J. Tobin, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and Chauffeurs, who went to England last month at tile request of President Roosevelt to investigate labor problems there, set forth the results of his investigations in a nation-wide broadcast tonight.

HAMILTON, Sept. 26 -- After holding Colgate scoreless during the first quarter, St. Lawrence's inexperienced football team succumbed to the power of Andy Kerr's Red Raiders, who launched their campaign with a 49-0 triumph today.

MOSCOW, Sept. 26 -- An impetuous young Russian who participated in some of the grimmest battles on the eastern front paid Wendell Willkie the highest compliment a Russian Communist can pay any foreigner. When he heard of the frank, open-hearted way the President's envoy had behaved with the Volga farmers and factory workers and of his democratic, exuberant naturalness he said, "He's just like Stalin."

I think much harm is being done by the controversy regarding our national anthem, "The Star-Spangled Banner." It is surprising to read comments about the unsuitability of the music arrangement in its originally approved key of B-flat major. Some of the objections have been voiced by people who should be better informed.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Sept. 27 (AP) -- communique:

PANAMA, Sept. 26 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller, United States Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, at a press conference here today after a visit to South America, expressed gratification over the impressions he had received with reference to the cooperation of Latin-American allies in the war against the Axis.

FACTS are often unpleasant, and quite naturally many of us dislike having to face or to acknowledge them. The facts about our home-heating oil outlook obviously come under the heading of things unpleasant, notwithstanding which no citizen can longer afford to ignore them.

VICHY, France, Sept. 26 -- Chief of Government Pierre Laval, in a conference with representatives of the French and foreign press this evening, said his government was solid and would continue its task to the end. He stressed that each time he left Vichy rumors started behind him, and when he left Paris the same thing happened there.

ANY book dealing with the noisy struggle between the late Brig. Gen. William (Billy) Mitchell and the United States War Department during the first half of the Nineteen Twenties is bound to bring up at least two things.
Although the off-shore fishing has been spotty during the past week, some satisfactory catches of bonito and albacore were reported from the boats sailing out of South Shore Long Island ports.

THE year of 1795 finds Peter Dickoe, torn from the quiet life of a young Cambridge scholar, a very green lieutenant of marines aboard His Majesty's thirty-six-gun frigate Pegasus. The war with France has been going badly, the rabble citizen armies and navies of the Revolution having upset all expert predictions by not only refusing to collapse but actually taking the initiative.

IN reading Virginia Woolf at her very best -- which includes "Mrs. Dalloway," "To the Lighthouse," "The Waves" and certain of her essays in her two Common Readers as well as the present volume -- it is necessary to dust off and repolish that tarnished, dented, much abused word that has become a piece of kitchenware in criticism, "genius."
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 -- Pennantville, viewed so admiringly and confidently as their certain destination by the Dodgers a little more than a month ago, today became only a dissolving mirage.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 112.0 on Sept. 15. This compares with 110.8 a fortnight before, 110.2 a month before, 106.9 a year before and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 27 -- The new laboratories of the Radio Corporation of America, planned in peacetime as the world's foremost radio research center at a cost of almost $2,000,000, were dedicated publicly here today to war work and were closed immediately to the public for the duration of the conflict.

The first series of aviation textbooks aimed at "air conditioning" the youth of America rather than leaving them merely "air minded" has been released by the Macmillan Company. Fourteen texts, two teachers' manuals and a guide make up the series, which will be used in many of the 28,000 American secondary schools giving pre-flight aviation courses.

The foreign commerce of the United States is now being "needlessly handicapped, if not irreparably damaged," as a result of present governmental methods of controlling foreign trade, Neal Dow Becker, president of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, asserted in a special statement released today.

With President Roosevelt expected to make some statement regarding his attitude toward the candidacy of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, late this week, political leaders speculated yesterday on how the President might word such an announcement, as the phrasing may have an important bearing on the course of the campaign.

Surely there is no one in this country so blindly addicted to protective tariffs that he wishes to compel soldiers' wives, sweethearts, mothers, children, aunts, uncles and favorite cousins to pay duty on gifts sent from overseas stations. Yet this is what they will have to do if the letter of the law is enforced.

MOSCOW, Sept. 27 (U.P.) -- Holding high his glass of vodka, Premier Joseph Stalin gave a toast to President Roosevelt last night at a Continued on Page Two "most cordial" dinner honoring Wendell L. Willkie in the huge Kremlin banquet hall.

Experts in the old-fashioned skill of preserving are advised that the season for Concord grapes is relatively brief. Supplies, which will taper off shortly, are now at their peak, and price show a range of 75 to 95 cents for a generous basket holding about eight quarts.

At the conclusion of his bill of "Anton Chekhov Sketches," which was put on over the week-end at the Barbizon-Plaza, Michael Chekhov and George Shdanoff acted "I Forgot." It was a very sensible thing to do. For the Anton Chekhov vaudeville and the acting of Anton's nephew. Michael, are about as funny as anything you can shake a jester's wand at in this year of practically no grace at all.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 27 -- According to the German economic periodical Deutsche Volkswirt, received here today, a second group of 4,000 industrial plants in France are to be closed because "they are not operating in a rational manner."

The Rev. Norris L. Tibbetts, in his first sermon yesterday since he became associate pastor of the Riverside Church, spoke on "What Is Significant Now," and declared that one sign of a mature personality is the ability to determine what is significant.

A high wind accompanied by a driving rain struck the city yesterday afternoon and last night, uprooting trees, blowing down signs and smashing plate glass windows in many places. A man was killed and a woman injured when they were struck by automobiles during the height of the storm.
Penthouse apartments were among the lists of suites reported leased to new tenants over the week-end. The late rush for rooms included several leases of large apartments.

A proposal that ten one-way crosstown connecting Third and Ninth Avenues between Fourteenth and Fifty-ninth Streets be designated as "express streets" and kept completely free of parked vehicles during rush hours was advanced yesterday by the Regional Plan Association as part of its program for handling post-war automotive traffic in Manhattan.

GEORGETOWN, Barbados, British West Indies, Sept. 27 (U.P.) -- Seventeen survivors from an unidentified ship told today how they had drifted for nineteen days before being picked up by an Allied destroyer that at first shelled them, mistaking the raft for an enemy submarine.
LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Various public speakers today denounced Britain's delay in attempting to establish a second European front.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears came from behind in the final period today to power their way to a 44-to-28 victory over the Green Bay Packers in the opening National Football League game here before a crowd of 22,000.

The group of Allerton Hotels has extended its chain of properties by leasing from Vincent Astor the eight-story Club Hotel at 317 West Forty-fifth Street, a building containing 165 sleeping rooms, reception room, lounge, library and dining room.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Present prosperity of agricultural industry provides occasion to begin an abandonment of reliance on subsidies, according to the current issue of the Guaranty Survey, publication of the Guaranty Trust Company. In a study of the effect of war on the farmers, it points out that President Roosevelt's demand for tighter control over the elements in the price structure has nevertheless been met by Congressional action to loosen control over the prices of farm commodities.

Man's failure to apply to spiritual problems the same reasoning with which he meets the problems of material life is the cause of the present war, the Rev. Robert E. Woods declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

No definite trend developed in trading in cotton futures last week as the market responded erratically to conflicting reports from Washington on the price-control issue. There was a rather strong undertone to trade buying and an equally potent current of hedging and liquidation of the October position in advance of first-notice date, but both appeared almost simultaneously and price changes for the week were slight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The War Production Board has issued an order prohibiting the manufacture or sale of blackout and dimout lighting fixtures which do not conform to specifications of the War Department, Navy Department and the Maritime Commission, it was announced today.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- The manner in which Stalingrad still withstands Germany's mightiest individual effort of the war fills the City with amazed admiration. Not long ago the battle was regarded as hopeless for the Russians and there was gloomy contemplation of all that the loss of that city would mean to Russia's future war effort.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 26 (Delayed) -- Japan is like a boa constrictor that has swallowed a goat and now has to go away somewhere to digest it, General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, British Commander in Chief in India, told American and British newspaper men at a dinner given in his honor tonight.
A change in the conservation law of the State at the last session of the Legislature has made it possible for the Conservation Department to set the open season on grouse in New York.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27 -- Sweeping inexorably on toward their goal, the Cardinals, on this, the final day of the championship season, brought to a triumphant close their spectacular seven-week pennant drive by clinching the National League flag with a smashing victory over the Cubs in the first game of the afternoon's double-header.

DETROIT, Sept. 27 -- The voluntary registration of women for war work in Southeastern Michigan has resulted in the establishment of a "reservoir of potential employables" amounting to 141,000 women, it was announced here today by John L. Craig, chairman of the Michigan Unemployment Compensation Commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The Giants failed to make a first down in their battle with the Redskins before a gathering of 34,700 in Griffith Stadium today, but the New Yorkers were waiting both times opportunity knocked. So two long plays were turned into as many touchdowns for a 14-7 upset victory over the Capital Braves.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Announcement of the appointment of Edward J. Ennis to the new post of Administrator of Foreign Travel Control in the Department of Justice was made today by Attorney General Biddle.

"Wine, Women and Song," now described as a variety show, opens tonight at 8:40 at the Ambassador. Margie Hart and Jimmy Savo are co-starred. Supporting them are the Wesson Brothers, Pinky Lee, Herbie Faye, Marian Miller, Isabelle Brown, Noel Toy, Don Ritz Favorettes, Murray Briscoe, Evelyn Farney, Ruth Mason, Billy and Buster Burnell and Murray White.

DUBLIN, Sept. 26 -- Joseph Cardinal MacRory, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Armagh, said today at Cavan, Eire, that he found it "exceedingly hard to be patient" when he thought of "my own corner of my country overrun by British and United States soldiers against the will of the nation."

BALTIMORE, Sept. 27 (U.P.) -- Victory Fleet day ceremonies were held today at the yard of the Bethlehem-Fairfield Shipbuilding Company, where the first Liberty ship, the Patrick Henry, went down the ways a year ago today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Further evidence of the danger of inflation inherent in the nation's war-swollen income was provided today by a report of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation revealing that on June 30 deposits in the 13,399 insured commercial banks amounted to $71,162,000,000, or 8 per cent more than a year before.

After all charges, provision for Federal taxes of $3,671,362 and a contingency reserve of $250,000, consolidated net profit of McKesson Robbins, Inc. for the first half of 1942 was $1,360,995, according to the report issued yesterday by W.J. Murray Jr., president.

The decision of the War Production Board to allow, reasonable expenditures for advertising in cost-plus contracts for the government eliminates the last barrier that has been holding back many contractors from even small advertising campaigns.

The Rev. Dale DeWitt, regional director for the Middle Atlantic States, American Unitarian Association, preaching yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Eightieth Street and Lexington Avenue, on "Perspectives for This Period," asserted that the scenery of human life today is again the portrayal of a crisis of desperation, with an accompanying need for vision and hope.

Members of uniformed women's volunteer defense organizations in New York City will have important roles in the household collection of scrap on the five-borough salvage days beginning next Friday in Queens.

ABOARD A UNITED STATES NAVY TROOP TRANSPORT, in the Southwest Pacific, Sept. 13 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- On a tiny, insignificant-looking island somewhere in this general vicinity American ingenuity and drive have created an airfield in the jungles that for striking power probably is unequaled in this part of the world.

VICHY, Sept. 27 -- The statement of conditions of the Bank of France dated Aug. 27 shows, as Usual, that variations due to normal operations on the securities markets have only a slight influence, in comparison with those of the Treasury and the German occupation fund.

Wendell Willkie has opened a new international debate on the burning question of the second front. The statement he issued before leaving Moscow to cross the jagged land mass of Asia on his flight to Chungking was evidently written out to prevent misunderstanding.
MOSCOW, Sept. 27 (AP) -A Soviet comminique:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- All affiliates of the Congress of Industrial Organizations were urged today by Philip Murray, C.I.O. president, to undertake intensive scrap-metal collection drives at once.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 27 -- Richard Arlen and Chester Morris will be co-starred by Paramount in "Aerial Gunner," a story by Maxwell Shane which William Pine and William Thomas will produce for the studio. Most of the picture will be filmed on location at an Army aerial gunnery school, according to the producers.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 27 -- The position of the Catholic Church in Mexico and its attitude toward the war were explained today by Archbishop Luis M. Martinez, who told the writer that conditions had improved under the present regime and that the clergy had issued directives to all Catholics to cooperate loyally with the government.

A nine-room dwelling on a plot 40 by 100 feet at 524 Beach 133d Street, Belle Harbor, L. I., has been purchased for cash by Patrick J. Dawe from the Southold Savings Bank. It is assessed at $6,800 and was sold through John J. Brennan, broker.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Striving to meet the Presidentially set deadline of Oct. 1 for new price-control legislation, the Senate will resume its struggle over the farm group's demands for higher "parity" prices tomorrow, with the outcome of this fight expected to be the chief subject before Congress this week.

Within the next year or two American women probably will be subject to some sort of conscription, as are their British sisters, according to Virginia C. Gildersleeve, Dean of Barnard College, in her annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, made public today.

Members of New York's own "Fighting Seventy-seventh Division" celebrated their twenty-fifth anniversary yesterday afternoon in a drizzle on the Central Park Mall that failed to dampen the ardor of the veterans of the first World War or the laudatory quality of the praise heaped upon them by civic and military leaders.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 27 -- With collections of scrap iron and steel running high, but still to prove that they will prevent serious curtailment in steel production next Winter and with the manpower situation looming as problem No. 1 in the coming months, executives of the steel industry whose prime slogan is to "win the war first," were heartened somewhat last week by reports coming out of Washington.

GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands, Sept. 19 (Delayed) -- The tops of coconut palms are clipped off by shellfire; slit trenches and bomb and shell craters are everywhere, but the "pagoda" is still untouched and the flag still flies over the American conquests in the Southeastern Solomons.

Spokesmen for Germany, Italy and Japan celebrated the second anniversary of the conclusion of the tripartite pact, linking their countries, in speeches and in an exchange of decorations, according to broadcasts from Berlin, Rome and Tokyo recorded by The United Press and Reuter, and by THE NEW YORK TIMES in Berne, Switzerland.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- Trading in oats on the Board of Trade was restricted last week, but there was little pressure to sell, and sufficient commission house buying developed to bring about a higher level of prices. Net gains for the week were 1/4 cent a bushel, with December closing yesterday at 52 3/8 cents maid May at 54 3/8.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The Federal Power Commission took a hand today in the price-stabilization effort, ordering utility companies not to pass war taxes on to consumers.

Boston players carried off the major league batting championships in the season which ended yesterday, with Ted Williams, Red Sox slugger, retaining the American League crown and Ernie Lombardi taking the senior circuit title, according to The Associated Press.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- The stock market has ended a good week in excellent style. Once again there is a feeling of expectancy that something big and stimulating is about to happen. There, however, are more positive reasons for market cheerfulness than just the idea that we are about to witness portentious events.

VICHY, France, Sept. 27 -- Following the ousting yesterday of Jacques Benoist-Mechin as a Secretary of State, the Journal Officiel announced today that the decree naming State Secretaries attached to Chief of Government Pierre Laval had been amended to read that those Secretaries are Fernand de Brinon, Ambassador of France, and Admiral Charles Platon.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- Operators in the market for provisions continue to express the belief that a revision in the ceiling prices on hog products is simply a matter of time, and extreme confidence is expressed in some quarters that the market will be adjusted to be more in line with the ceiling price expected to be placed on hogs.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 27 -- Dr. Eliseo Arango, Commissioner of Corporations, considers that Article 7 of Law 13 of 1942, which requires all companies and firms to have Colombian agents or representatives, is inconvenient and not in harmony with the American policy of cooperation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- About $6,000,000 worth of war contracts have gone to small business in the last fortnight through the efforts of the War Production Board's Smaller War Plant Division, WPB said today.

Freedom in fellowship is the answer to the question of church leaders, "What should the church stress as the immediate will of God for our generation?" the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the Union Theological Seminary, said yesterday in a sermon at the James Memorial Chapel, Broadway and 120th Street.

GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands, Sept. 16 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- United States Army, Navy and Marine fliers have shot down 127 Japanese planes, sunk two Japanese ships, badly damaged five others, sunk sixteen small boats and wrecked enemy ground installations in countless bombing and strafing operations since swinging into action last month.
Another contingent of workers enrolled by representatives of the Henry J. Kaiser Company for employment in its Pacific Coast shipyards left Pennsylvania Station at 3:05 P.M. yesterday.

Hundreds of thousands of American women who signed the consumer's pledge -- "I will waste nothing, I will take care of what I have" -- already have learned innumerable tricks of adapting and freshening up both household articles and garments that are not new, yet too good to dispose of entirely.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission is giving serious consideration to the advisability of invalidating requirements of minimum capital recently voted by the National Association of Securities Dealers and substituting a rule of its own establishing such standards for the whole over-the-counter field, it was learned today.

The large store at 1480 Broadway, between Forty-second and Forty-third Streets, formerly occupied by London Character Shoes, has been leased by Lane Photographers, Inc. through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc. The latter recently leased the store at the northeast corner of Broadway and Forty-third Street to the shoe concern.

VICHY, Sept. 27 -- The control established by the authorities over operations on the Bourse was exercised last week with the same severity as in the preceding week. No rise in stock values was permitted.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- Broadcasting to the United States tonight, Ambassador John G. Winant read a message from Prime Minister Churchill saluting the United States shipbuilding program, which the Premier termed "a victory fleet."

ST. JOHNS, Nfld., Sept. 27 (U.P) -- Mayor La Guardia of New York, chairman of the American section of the United States-Canadian Joint Defense Board, conferred for three hours today with the Newfoundland Commissioners and the American and Canadian military and naval commanders here.

ALBANY, Sept. 27 -- Giving a detailed account of his stewardship as chairman of the State War Council, Governor Lehman, inaugurating a weekly series of radio broadcasts over station WMCA on "New York State at War," said tonight that no other State had a better record of civilian defense.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- Seldom have weather conditions been so unfavorable for the corn crop as during the last week, but neither this nor the debate in Washington over parities and ceiling prices had any effect as a price-making influence on that grain.

IN a baseball setting, the Yankees do everything in championship style. They have the lofty touch, even when it comes to an off-the-field matter like cutting up their world series melon. When the Yankee players met recently in the Bronx clubhouse to decide the allotment of shares in the Yankee end of the post-season purse, they didn't forget anybody.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- Congressional debate as to what shall constitute parity prices on agricultural products to be used as ceiling levels under anti-inflation legislation had it he effect last week of lifting the wheat market into the highest ground since last May, but the volume of business fell off materially, as brokers and professional operators went to the sidelines to await developments.

Faced with Mayor La Guardia's order that they clean up gambling in the city or face a departmental shake-up, the police continued their drive against gambling, arresting more than 100 persons in various sections of the city Saturday night and throughout yesterday for bookmaking, horse race betting and policy game participation.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 26 (Delayed) (AP) -- Long-range American-made B-24 four-motored Consolidated bombers, each packing bomb loads ranging up to four tons, in the past two weeks have carried the war straight home to the capitals of Croatia, Hungary, Rumania and Bulgaria.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- Ships formerly operated on the Great Lakes are now being converted for wartime use as ocean shipping at yards in New Orleans, Mobile, Ala., and Galveston, Texas, the War Shipping Administration discloses.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Reds lost two games to the Pirates today to end the season in fourth place, squarely on the .500 mark, their lowest percentage since Bill McKechnie became manager, in 1938. The scores were 8 to 7 in 12 innings and 7 to 4.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 27 -- The Joseph N. Teal, the record-breaking ship launched in ten days by a Henry J. Kaiser yard, was delivered last night to the Maritime Commission, less than fourteen days after laying of the keel.

Need for a central pool to coordinate all information on child care, not only for wartime but for the peace to come, was emphasized yesterday at the first session of a two-day conference held by the National Association for Nursery Education at the Mills School, 66 Fifth Avenue.

A call for a great spiritual revival to defeat the forces of darkness represented by the Axis nations was sounded by religious and lay leaders from several parts of the globe. The addresses were rebroadcast here over the NBC network as part of the nation-wide Religious Education Week sponsored by the International Council of Religious Education.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 -- Manager Leo Durocher revealed the Dodgers' division of the second-place world series money, as voted by the players. The spoils were split forty-four ways, including thirty-one full shares, eleven half shares and two quarter shares.

With the Yankee Stadium transformed into a great outdoor cathedral, 25,000 Catholics attended yesterday a patriotic service under auspices of the Archdiocesan Union of the Holy Name Society at which Archbishop Francis J. Spellman led them in a pledge of "total devotion to the cause of America."

DETROIT, Sept. 27 (AP) -- With Indian Jack Jacobs pitching two touchdown passes, the Cleveland Rams smashed a five-year jinx today to whip the Detroit Lions, 14 to 0, in a National Football League game before 14,646 spectators. It was Cleveland's first victory on Detroit soil since joining the league.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose to 107.8 from 107.5. Agricultural commodity price changes dominated the list. The farm products group index rose to a new high point of 105.3, mainly because of increases in the prices of livestock and potatoes.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 27 -- For the second day in succession a toy dog was named as the best of all breeds in a major show today.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27 -- "This is easily the happiest moment of my life," said smiling Billy Southworth as congratulations were showered upon him in a crowded dressing room following the Cards pennant-clinching game today.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 27 -- Cotton futures were erratic, nervous and rather active last week, but for the second straight period they failed to move far in either direction as Washington swayed commitment-makers with hither-and-yon reports on trends of the anti-inflation picture.

MOSCOW, Sept. 27 -- Premier Joseph Stalin placed Wendell L. Willkie at his right hand at the head of the banquet table last night, when Russia showed that despite the grave hours she is passing through she remained faithful to the ancient traditions of hospitality to honored guests from abroad.

There is something about the scent of mothballs as they tumble out of last Winter's tweeds that seems to spin the average woman into a frenzy of activity. In other Autumns this new enthusiasm would manifest itself in a bridge luncheon, the reorganization of a wardrobe, the disorganization of a dining-room:

Martin Popper, secretary of the National Lawyers Guild, announced yesterday that the group, which staged here on Saturday a conference against inflation, had sent a telegram, incorporating the results of the conference, to the President and all principal Congressional leaders.

The employment in war industries of women with young children so long as women without children are available was protested yesterday by the Social Service Commission of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, which urged rectors of parishes to ask employers of war labor to use only girls and women without children.

This will be a crucial week in the war against inflation. But it still seems overwhelmingly probable that this week's battle is one that inflation will win. For many of those in key positions who talk as if they were the enemies of inflation are really its allies. Under the pretense of delivering it a knock-out blow they are preparing to send it substantial lend-lease aid.

A situation now exists in the high schools of New York State that is, to put it mildly, anomalous. We are in the midst of war and yet our schools do not seem to recognize that fact. We should be stressing mathematics, natural science and foreign languages.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Officials here whose duty is to be informed about occupied Europe express apprehension lest the strain of the coming fourth Winter of war, accentuated by privation and long deferred hope, may lead subjected Europeans to despair of deliverance unless their confidence is sustained by some new evidence from the democratic side.

PEORIA, Ill., Sept. 27 -- Rural life leaders of the various denominations will be feted at the annual convention of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference, to be held here for four days beginning next Saturday.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Allied bombers yesterday again pounded the bases and lines of supply for the strong Japanese force striking across the New Guinea mountains toward Port Moresby, the Allied command announced today, while the situation on the ground there was declared to be unchanged.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Sept. 27 (U.P.) -- Four crew members of an American bomber shot down within three miles of a Japanese airdrome have reached safety after a two weeks' jungle hike that wore out their shoes and took ten pounds from each man, it was learned today.

Partly, no doubt, because of continued Russian resistance to the invading Nazis, last week's financial markets, both for stocks and bonds, advanced with some rapidity. On Thursday, trading in stocks was the largest of the year. Steel production tended upward, though with general output unchanged at 98 per cent of capacity.

Even in this land of plenty we must produce more food; Secretary Wickard said so the other day. The chief of our Agriculture Department is of the opinion that we will have to find some way of dealing with a food shortage unless farm production can be stepped up. Unprecedented exports face us.

VICHY, France, Sept. 27 -- Hundreds of American citizens were rounded up in the occupied zone by the French police during the week-end and turned over to German authorities, who interned some of them in the monkey house of the Bois de Boulogne Zoo in Paris, reports from that city said tonight.

MOSCOW, Monday, Sept. 28 -- The Russians drove the Germans from a number of buildings in one sector of battle-scarred Stalingrad yesterday and continued operations northwest of the Volga city against the German left flank, it was announced in the midnight communique.

WITH THE AMERICAN AIR FORCES, in China, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Resuming their air offensive against the Japanese after a lapse of nearly a month, the American air force in China strafed troop columns in Southwest Yunnan Province yesterday after having made another of their attacks on Hanoi in French Indo-China the day before, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today.

The second reduction in the last month on cargo war risk rates was announced yesterday by marine underwriters here as a result of the drop in Atlantic sinkings due to the improved methods of convoying and other protection.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 27 -- Collection of scrap in Newark today far exceeded expectations, it was said tonight by Edward J. Maier, chairman of the local salvage committee. Beginning at 8 A.M. and continuing far into the night collectors manning 126 trucks gathered 2,300 tons of metal.
MOSCOW, Sept. 27 -- The smashing of the German timetable by the firm defense of Stalingrad is seen by George Alexandroff, propaganda chief of the Communist party, in today's Pravda.

"THE sea really has no history; it is always the same." This being obviously so, a writer who admits it as Emil Ludwig does and still persists in writing a 635-page history of a sea soon exhausts the material to be found in climate, marine geography, coast lines, etc., and must proceed to nations and civilizations, great men and great events, that have a connection, no matter how remote, with the given body of water.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- An agreement by the United States and Great Britain for partition of world areas in which each will exclusively buy fats, oils and oil seeds for all United Nations' use was announced today by the Combined Food Board composed of representatives of the two countries.
One would have thought that mankind had enough to bear at this moment without getting word from London that an unpublished Sherlock Holmes story, found in an old trunk, would not be made public.

MOSCOW, Sept. 27 -- After holding the Germans for several days in the Stalingrad region and ousting them from many buildings and streets, the Russians were forced to yield some ground in the latter part of yesterday. The noon communique states that in one sector the Germans penetrated farther into the city and were fiercely engaged. The enemy's losses are reported to be high.
Wholesale demand continued strong in most markets last week, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORE TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Lean Jim Bagby clinched sole possession of fourth place for the Indians by beating the Tigers today, 8 to 0, in the last game of the season. Had Detroit won, the two teams would have tied for fourth, as they did last year.

DETROIT, Sept. 27 -- Walter P. Reuther, vice president of the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.), recommending adoption of the new contract between the union and General Motors Corporation, told delegates representing workers in about ninety plants yesterday that the new agreement carried economic gains totaling $69,000,000 for 254,000 workers.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- The failure of the German U-boat fleet drastically to reduce the flow of troops and materiel from the United States to Britain and the consequent strategic importance of these islands as a base for Continental operations in 1943, is expected to force the German High Command to resume intensive night bombing of Britain once the Russian front is consolidated, it was indicated today.

GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands, Sept. 17 (Delayed) -- The potency of air power has been strikingly revealed since the United States Marines' occupation of the Guadalcanal-Tulagi area on Aug. 7. American fighters, scout bomber, reconnaissance and ground-attack planes have been a factor that might be rated as high as 50 per cent, if not higher, in the defense of this area.

The Rev. Dr. Donald B. Aldrich, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street, announced yesterday in his sermon that he had been commissioned as a chaplain in the Navy and would leave today for active duty.
MOSCOW, Monday Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Soviet Midnight communique:

Two huge war bond rallies here yesterday resulted in the sale of nearly $500,000 in bonds and stamps, raising the total for September in the State to nearly $94,000,000, with three days of the month remaining.

The weather prevented the scheduled double-header between the Giants and the Braves at the Polo Grounds yesterday, erasing the formal closing of the club's first championship season under the leadership of the popular Mel Ott.

The Chinese counter-offensive appears to have been brought to halt just short of consummation. Two weeks ago the Chinese were at the gates of Kinhwa, the only large air base on the eastern coast they had not yet retaken from the Japanese, and were approaching Canton, the largest port in the South, within striking distance of Hong Kong.

Expressing support for the Federal Trade Commission's efforts to establish color-fastness standards for the American textile industry, Botany Worsted Mills, Passaic, N.J., has submitted to the commission proposed rules covering apparel woolens, worsteds and yarns for men's and women's wear.

Fifteen young Negro singers, three pianists, a violinist; and two mixed choruses were presented yesterday afternoon at Town Hall in the third annual "Stars of Tomorrow" program, sponsored jointly by W.C. Handy and the women's council of the New York Urban League.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Sept. 28 (AP) -- A communique:

Dr. Charles Henry Duncan, 76 years old, originator of the Duncan method of treating and preventing infectious diseases, who was decorated by the French Government, died yesterday morning in Polyclinic Hospital after shooting himself early Saturday morning.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 27 -- Young Doug Ford of Green Valley added another war bond to his collection today as a result of his victory in another member-guest tournament.

LONDON, Sept. 27 (Reuter) -- An alarming food situation is developing in Hong Kong and Shanghai, according to accounts reaching the Independent French News Agency's correspondent at Durban, South Africa.

BOSTON, Sept. 27 -- The Yankees twice were overtaken by the Red Sox before the world champions were beaten, 7 to 6, as Tex Hughson landed his twenty-second decision of the campaign which ended today. As a result Boston won the season series from New York, 12 to 10.

BUFFALO, Sept. 27 -- Held scoreless only in the final period, the Brooklyn Football Dodgers overwhelmed the Philadelphia Eagles, 35 -- 14, before 5,682 persons at Civic Stadium today in probably the most impressive National Football League opening in Flatbush history.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- President Roosevelt send word to the mothers of the nation today that America is fighting for victory so that in the future "no more mothers, wives or sweethearts may need to grieve for loved ones sacrificed in war."

A special committee of the Allied Printing Trades Council of Greater New York, of which Vincent J. Ferris is chairman and which has been named to oppose the re-election of State Controller Joseph V. O'Leary, candidate on the Democratic and American Labor party tickets, declared yesterday that one reason why the New York State Federation of Labor did not endorse Mr. O'Leary was because of his discrimination against New York State workers and union labor.

Only two new films are scheduled to arrive this week on Broadway. They are "Panama Hattie," a Metro picturization of the stage musical success, featuring Red Skelton, Ann Sothern, Ben Blue, Virginia O'Brien Rags Raglund and Dan Dailey Jr., opening Thursday at the Capitol, and "The Falcon's Brother," a mystery melodrama with George Sanders, Jane Randolph and Tom Conway, arriving the same day at the Palace, with the second-run "Footlight Serenade."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Joining in the observance of Victory Fleet Day on the anniversary of the launching of the first Liberty cargo ship, Sir Arthur Salter, British member of the Joint Merchant Shipping Board, declared in a radio address that the United Nations together were now producing new cargo ships at a rate which offsets sinkings by Axis submarines.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, announced yesterday that the two national labor organizations will cooperate with community chests throughout the country in encouraging labor contributions to the nation's war relief chests.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 27 -- Delegates from C.I.O. unions in the Fourth Congressional District, comprising Fairfield County, voted today at a meeting here to endorse Representative Leroy D. Downs, South Norwalk publisher, for re-election. Mr. Downs's leading opponent is Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce of Greenwich, Republican nominee.

From London the Inter-Allied Information Committee set up by the exiled Governments reports that the number of known victims of Nazi executions has now reached the almost incredible figure of 207,373. Even this figure is good only for the day it was issued. Every morning German firing squads revise it upward.

The effect of the war shortage of rubber and gasoline hit home hard on the first full day of competition of the 1942 college football season. The opening day crowds on Saturday were well under the normal turnouts.

An appeal for immediate action on the question of India's independence was requested yesterday by a group of fifty-five prominent Americans who issued a statement urging President Roosevelt and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek to use their influence to bring about a resumption of the conferences on the Indian problem.

A delayed dispatch to THE TIMES from Hanson W. Baldwin reveals clearly why our offensive in the South Pacific, begun almost two months ago in the Solomon Islands, still hangs fire. We have not yet consolidated our gains, and even now hold only a beach-head on Guadalcanal, most important of the four islands on which our Marines landed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The Census Bureau brought the encouraging word today that although there were 22,000,000 white people in the country at the time of the 1940 census who were brought up speaking foreign languages, English is being learned to an increasing extent by the children of recent immigrants.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 28 -- A conflict of an interesting rather than a serious character between the legislative and judicial branches of the Argentine State broke out today when the Chamber of Deputies refused to carry out a ruling handed down by the Court of Appeals ordering the release of two police officers whose arrest the Chamber ordered last week and who are still detained in the Congress building.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 28 -- James M. Barrie's play "The Old Lady Shows Her Medals" will be filmed in England by David E. Rose, Paramount's British managing director, the studio here announced today. The play was first picturized in 1930 under the title "Seven Days' Leave," with Gary Cooper and Beryl Mercer.

The American public is being shown many photographs of the damage United Nations fliers have recently done to German and German-occupied cities. It is a grim business. Our fliers specialize on factories, railroad yards, docks and military installations, but dwelling places also get hit.

Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., through the Cross Brown Company, brokers, has sold the four-story loft building, on a plot 100 by 100 feet, at 234-40 East Thirty-ninth Street to the East Thirty-ninth Street Company, Inc., and the five-story store and basement warehouse at 225-31 East Thirty-eighth Street to the Fuch's Trucking Corporation.

What with heavy shifts of funds to out-of-town points and heavy Treasury calls scheduled for this week, reserve positions of the New York City banks are being pulled down, with some banks actually deficient in reserves. As a result the banks short of reserves are borrowing from institutions better supplied, with the net result that the market for "Federal funds" is exceedingly active.

Complaints by business men of "globs of blood-red polish spattering over a notebook" have caused secretaries in many of the highest paid positions to shift back from liquid nail polish to powder polish, abandoning a vogue that has been in effect for more than a decade, Ethel A. Rollinson, instructor in office procedure at Columbia University, said yesterday in an interview.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28 -- Drawing a comparison of the world series contenders with the idea of venturing a forecast on the outcome is usually a hazardous task at best.
