And when there is added in a most striking degree that intangible factor known as the "human equation," the task becomes practically impossible.

Members of the First General Hospital, Bellevue overseas unit, were honored at a reception given last night under the joint auspices of the Catholic, Protestant and Jewish chaplains of Bellevue Hospital in the medical board room of the institution.

In your issue of Sept. 23 you have an item on flag makers and the demand for flags. This is a splendid article -- something that the country really needs, because our statistics show that only 25 per cent of the householders and apartment dwellers own and display a flag every day.
BOSTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Hubert Fauntleroy Julian, "the Black Eagle of Harlem," gained a new distinction today -- United States citizenship.

The first of thirty-eight Harlem food dealers to be brought to trial under recent indictments for frauds in food stamps was convicted yesterday in Federal court. He was Ramon Torres of 1320 Fifth Avenue, and the charges against him were in nine counts, each of which carries a maximum sentence of ten years' imprisonment and $10,000 fine.

Our largest and most important rubber reserve consists of the tires on the cars of the 27,000,000 motorists of the nation. For many months it has been apparent that we could not continue indefinitely to allow this rubber to be burned up in needless driving. It has been equally obvious that the most effective and direct method of conserving the rubber needed for essential transportation was the limitation of driving through nation-wide gasoline rationing.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 28 -Quartermaster General Stephen H. Barlow, Republiean, was exonerated by an all-Republiean Senate investigating eommittee today of blame in connection with food purehases for the State's Executive cottage at Sea Girt during itz oceupancy by Governor Charles Edison, Democrat, in August and September of last year.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

An exhibition of posters by members of the junior auxiliary of the American Women's Voluntary Services is being held, through this week, at the American-British Art Center, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street. These were designed by girls between the ages of 13 and 15, and all or most of whom have had no art training.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- An intensive drive to organize the women of the nation by neighborhoods, towns and counties for thorough cooperation in the national salvage campaign has already gotten under way as nine members of a special War Production Board committee and three women from the board's conservation division left the city to start the organization work.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A joint communique by the French National Committee and the government of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics was issued today in the interests of common cooperation between the two groups in the conduct of the war against Reichsfuehrer Hitler.

AMERICAN AIR FORCE BASE IN CHINA, Sept. 28 (U.P.) -- American planes based in China can play a vital offensive role in the Pacific because any damage they inflict on Japanese communications will have "a drastic effect on the war elsewhere in a very short time," Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, commander of United States aviation in China, said today.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 28 (AP) -- The year's leading money-winning trotters, The Ambassador and Volo Song, have their last chance of the season to increase their earnings at the seventieth Lexington trots to be held here Sept. 30 through Oct. 8.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- Negotiations for the sale by Westchester County of 140 acres of park and parkway lands as right of way for the new power line that will carry surplus electricity from New York City to up-State armament plants were announced here today by Herbert C. Gerlach, County Executive.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A strong force of United States bomber and pursuit planes, joined for the first known time by Canadian aircraft, raided the Japanese stronghold on Kiska in the Aleutian Islands last Friday, destroyed seven planes, damaged a transport or cargo ship, strafed two submarines and hit shore installations, the Navy Department announced tonight.

Reports of Junior League activities in wartime were given to the board of directors of the Association of Junior Leagues of America at the opening session yesterday of the board's annual Fall meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Sept. 28 -- Diversion of sorely needed men from war plants to combat fronts through a "chaotic draft situation" is imperiling production and facing the nation with "the very serious question of whether we are not trying to draft a larger army than we can produce for," Dr. Henry N. Davis, president of Stevens Institute of Technology, declared today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Favoring a narrowing of wage rates between farm and industrial labor to enable farmers to retain their work forces, Paul V. McNutt, Director of the War Manpower Commission, admitted today in testimony before the House Agriculture Committee that farm prices would have to be raised to accomplish this objective.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 28 -- The pressure of American opinion and Washington's diplomacy behind the scenes to bring about settlement of the Indian problem is being keenly felt here at the seat of government. Indian opinion also is gradually becoming aware of this attitude, although apparently to a lesser extent.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28 -- The battles northwest of Stalingrad have now become, in scale and ferocity, greater than any fought previously during the Summer campaign. The Russians, in great strength, are daily killing Germans by the thousands.

To argue as THE TIMES does that "because Russia is not in this war to save us" we do not have to open a Western front is to be blind to the realities of the present day. Assistant Secretary Bard's speech calling attention to the perilous position of the country is indicative of the extent to which our fate is dependent on the fight in Russia.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 28 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho arrived at Veracruz today to attempt to pacify the various political factions that are fighting for local political supremacy.

LONDON, Sept. 28 (Reuter) -- The German radio this afternoon relayed a German military spokesman's statement about the submarine attack on an Atlantic convoy reported today by Adolf Hitler's headquarters.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -Edward R. Burke, former Senator from Nebraska, said tonight that he had not decided whether to seek a term in the Senate as an independent.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 28 -- Any chance that the voters would be able to express at the general election in November their wishes as to submission of a revised State Constitution for adoption or rejection a year hence was ended today when the Legislature recessed until Nov. 16 without action.

A recent piece in London Punch has given this department much satisfaction. Our grief over the failures of American propaganda abroad and information services at home has never been too bitter. We have never attached much importance to information or propaganda designed to "condition" the plain people of the world, whether our own or in foreign countries.

A revival of D.W. Griffith's "Hearts of the World" will open today at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. Third in the theatre's series of silent film classic revivals, the picture stars Lillian and Dorothy Gish and its supporting cast includes Robert Harron, Noel Coward and George Fawcett.

Representatives of five employer associations and of the Joint Board of the Dressmakers Union, an affiliate of the International Ladies Garment Workers, met last night at the Hotel New Yorker, the employers expressing disapproval of the union's demand for an upward "equalization of wages" for 85,000 dressmakers in the metropolitan area to meet the increased cost of living.

The 6-year-old girl who was picked up by the police as a lost child in Grand Central Terminal on Sept. 19 was identified by her foster parents at Bellevue Hospital yesterday as Gertrude Louise Miller, daughter of a New Haven woman, to whom the foster parents had returned the child on Sept. 6.

SCRANTON, Pa., Sept. 28 -- About 200 soldiers, sailors and marines came to the center of the hard coal fields today to urge the mine workers to increase coal production. The miners and the men of the armed forces became real pals and when they parted each he did not need to worry about the other doing his part.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- When three facts are recalled it is easy to understand why Mr. Willkie's statement in Moscow concerning "a real second front in Europe" provoked uneasiness and a good deal of private criticism in Washington.

A new chapter will be added to wartime millinery fashion history when, on Tuesday, Oct. 6, the curtain rises on Fashions of the Times, the fashion production that will be given by THE NEW YORK TIMES in Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

The report of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and its subsidiaries, announced yesterday for the first eight months of 1942, shows a net income of $2,121,251 after Federal income and excess profits taxes, subsidiary preferred dividends and other charges.

ALBANY, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Dr. Warren W. Knox, State Director of Secondary Education, was named today director of New York's high school "Victory Corps" in the nation-wide program to bring school children into the war effort.

ALBANY, Sept. 28 -- Only about 300 prisoners in two New York institutions, Clinton and Auburn, are actively engaged in producing material for the war effort. Commissioner Lyons hopes, however, that several contracts now under consideration will come through shortly, when it will be possible to use the work of about 2,000 prisoners.

BEFORE the world series stars come to bat there's just time to point to a somewhat scrambled situation in football. Because of war conditions, there's a lot of double talk going on now in the football huddles. The confusion in speech centers around the service teams that are engaged in the current block-and-tackle campaign.

One man was shot and wounded critically by two young thugs at 10 o'clock last night in the hold-up and robbery of the New Victory grocery store at 2366 Eighth Avenue, at 127th Street. In attempting to prevent the escape of the men after they had robbed the cash register of an undetermined sum of money, Bert Ogilvie, 32 years old, the proprietor, was shot near the heart.
LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The newest weapon in the armory of the Allied air forces, the Royal Air Force's Mosquito bomber, is expected to increase the weight and range of daylight attacks on Germany.
TACOMA, Wash., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Bob Johnson, outfielder for the Athletics, arrived home today and told newspaper men he had played his last game for the Philadelphia club.

A shake-up in the Manchukuoan Government, including appointment of a new Foreign Minister and elevation of the commander of the First Army Division to a Cabinet post, was announced yesterday by Domei in a Hsinking dispatch, The Associated Press reported.

A net estate of $1,830,328 was left by Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt, former New York society leader, when she died on April 20, 1940, it was shown yesterday in the estate tax appraisal filed here. The estate passes principally to a daughter and three grandchildren.

As a typical housewife I regularly toss things into the waste basket which could be used in the salvage drive. But it is not practical to drive three miles to the gas station with a leaky hot-water bottle, nor is it reasonable to call a salvage truck for one defunct hoe. As my house is small, junk becomes a nuisance and out it goes to the garbage man.
Republican State leaders, after conferring with leaders of the counties in the metropolitan area yesterday, predicted victory for all nominees on the State ticket headed by Thomas E. Dewey.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Chinese forces have inflicted considerable casualties upon Japanese forces striking west, southwest and southeast from Kinhwa, the capital of coastal Chekiang Province, the High Command announced today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 28 -- Mayor Thomas D. Taggart, in a radio address tonight, said that he would call upon Governor Charles Edison for the aid of the State Police if Director of Public Safety William S. Cuthbert did not "keep organized vice and its resultant corruption from returning to Atlantic City."

Before the season has headed into October, some of the best college football names already have known defeat or the disappointment of a tie score, and a good many more will join them in their misery by the end of the week.
WABASH, Ind., Sept. 28 -- Orville Richard Babcock, 29, a truck driver, was sentenced to two to fourteen years in the reformatory today all because of a drunken spree.

Faced with a drastic steel shortage that will reduce the mount of farm machinery and parts available next year to less than one-half of that manufactured in 1940, farmers must become "farmer-mechanics" to make the machinery they have now last as long as possible, a "war conference" of agricultural engineers was told yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Sept. 28 -- Carrying eleven passengers and four crewmen, a Panair Do Brasil plane -- a subsidiary of the Pan American Airways -- on the run between Rio de Janeiro and Porto Alegre, crashed early today six miles southwest of Sao Paulo, killing all on board.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -The time and talents of thousands of government employes are being wasted by the agencies where they work because of poor supervision, the Civil Service Commission reported to Congress today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Sept. 29 -- Veteran Australian troops, launching their offensive with an "over-the-top charge" against Japanese barricades, have begun infiltration and flanking attacks against enemy "defensive positions" in the Owen Stanley Mountains of New Guinea and "are making progress," it was announced today.

Establishment of a central agency to coordinate child care information was recommended yesterday at the closing session of the two-day conference held by the National Association for Nursery Education at the Mills School, 66 Fifth Avenue.

UTICA, Sept. 28 -- Dean Alfange, American Labor party nominee for Governor, speaking tonight over a State-wide radio network from a dinner meeting here, pledged himself to a complete program of post-war planning and veterans' rehabilitation.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Mr. Stalin and I had been in lively conversation for some two hours. Among the subjects which we discussed was Russian industrial production. I was telling him of my visit to Russian factories and some comparisons I had made with American industrial organization and production.

With much of its activity being held in abeyance until the outcome of voting on compromise amendments to the price-control measure is known, the cotton market yesterday progressed through a sluggish session. Late hedge sales depressed prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange to the day's lows and to net losses of 8 to 15 points after quotations had hovered in the vicinity of the previous close most of the session.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (U.P.) -- Congressional sources revealed tonight that President Roosevelt will soon ask for another $3,000,000,000 to supply naval planes. The request will swell to $12,000,000,000 the total asked or appropriated for naval aviation since early in 1940.

RENO, Nev., Sept. 28 -- The circumstances under which Judge William D. Hatton of Tonopah, sitting in Carson City on Saturday, granted a divorce to Mrs. May de Forest Payne, a music authority, from Oliver H. Payne of New York City caused worried discussion among lawyers today.

Small food retailers, having an annual business volume of less than $20,000, should be exempted from the necessity of filing wartime government reports and the observance of price regulations, the National American Wholesale Grocers Association suggested yesterday in a six-point program submitted to Senator James E. Murray, chairman of the Special Committee to Study the Problems of American Small Business.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A Navy Department communique:
ALBANY, Sept. 28 (AP) -- A house-to-house hunt for 35,000 inactive nurses is being conducted by the State Nursing Council to meet a shortage of military and civilian nurses in the State.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- Mrs. Elizabeth Dilling, author of "The Red Network," indicted in Washington with twenty-seven others on charges of sedition and conspiracy, was ordered today to stand trial in Washington. She had sought, through her attorney, to stay the removal order.

Net sales of the Carpenter Steel Company for the fiscal year ended with June reached a new high at $24,758,175, representing an increase of 50.1 per cent over the $16,489,180 volume of the previous year, according to the annual report of J.H. Parker, president, issued yesterday.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease last week of 6 per cent under the comparative week last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

LONDON, Sept. 28 (U.P.) -- Eleven British fighter planes were lost Saturday afternoon from a sweep of Northwestern France that was abandoned "because of heavy clouds and severe icing," the Air Ministry announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A committee of engineers and scientists has been named to determine the manner in which the projected Office of Technical Development of the War Production Board shall be set up, it was announced today.

The gallery of Contemporary Arts, Inc., at 106 East Fifty-seventh Street, opened for the season last night despite the absence of electric light. About 300 guests viewed the exhibit with the aid of candles and flashlights.
GOLDEN, Col., Sept. 28 (AP) -- A soldier's tenacious fingertip grip on a narrow ledge, 100 feet above a rocky chasm floor, saved his life last night.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, dedicating here today a tablet containing the names of Glens Falls citizens now in the armed forces, called for a crushing and complete victory in the present conflict so that the peace may be based on firm foundations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Walter S. Gifford of New York, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, has accepted appointment as chairman of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund, Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross, said today.

Heavy steel bars that once confined some of New York's worst scoundrels to cells in the old Tombs prison are rapidly being added to New York's growing metal scrap pile, it was disclosed yesterday. The heavy grilled windows that barred escape from the famous prison and the spikes that decorated the top of its outer walls are also being sold for scrap.

IN August, 1940, Virginia Woolf sat in a darkened house in London, meditating upon the queer experience of "listening to the zoom of a hornet which may at any moment sting you to death." Young men were fighting miles up in the air, and being a woman seemed useless by comparison. Being a thinking woman seemed even worse than useless.

Coach Earl Walsh sent the Fordham football squad through a light workout yesterday afternoon on Fordham Field. Strenuous work for Saturday's engagement with Tennessee at Knoxville will commence today. A scrimmage is planned for tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Government experts believe the deficit between Eastern petroleum needs under current rationing plans and the quantity of oil now being supplied to that area can be wiped out before the end of this year.

SOMEWHERE IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, Sept. 21 (Delayed) -- The whistling of the "Marine Corps Hymn" and "Reveille" by Japanese soldiers in an attempt to deceive their opponents is the latest strategem of the enemy in the jungles of Guadalcanal, in the Solomon Islands.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- In a special announcement from Adolf Hitler's headquarters the Nazis said today that their U-boats had fought a running battle against a North Atlantic convoy loaded with United States troops bound for Britain and managed to sink three large transports and one destroyer and damage two other ships.

While the impact of the war economy upon the drug industry indicates declining volume and changes in methods of doing business, every effort should be made to retain the small retailer and wholesaler as essential elements in the merchandising picture, Lee Wilson Hutchings, president of the National Wholesale Druggists Association, said yesterday in an address at the opening of the two-day convention of the organization at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The story of how a Catalina flying boat of the United States Navy sank a submarine, then made sure that its crew of fifty-one was rescued by one boat, and taken prisoner by another, was revealed for the first time today.

MOSCOW, Sept. 27 (Delayed) -- Wendell L. Willkie said today that Russia could not be conquered, but he warned that there was a growing sense of impatience, almost disillusionment, in the Soviet Union over the lack of a second front.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 28 -- An urgent appeal for $60,000 has been made to the American Advisory Committee at Chungking for the immediate relief of over 40,000 inhabitants of Eastern Shensi Province who were rendered homeless and destitute by the Yellow River flood in August, it was disclosed today.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28 -- The Cardinals may be the toast of the National League and the pride of St. Louis, but to themselves the new champions were just another ball club today with an open date in the schedule.

Officials of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations in this city have accepted membership on the executive staff of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, James G. Blaine, CDVO chairman, announced yesterday.

War Production Board plans for stripping department stores, hotels, office buildings and theatres of all or part of their air conditioning equipment for use in war plants were disclosed here yesterday by Lessing J. Rosenwald, director of its conservation division, as eleven department stores, including three of New York's largest, voluntarily agreed to surrender as much of their facilities as the government needed for war use.

Frederic R. Coudert Jr., Republican State Senator from the Seventeenth District, opened his campaign for re-election last night by defying the Communists, who have made him a principal campaign issue Mr. Coudert declared that the same Communists who now attack him as an agent of Laval had, before the invasion of Russia by Germany, charged him with being a warmonger.

The lines of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad from Philadelphia to the terminals in Chicago and St. Louis are to be divided into eastern, central and western regions, instead of into eastern and western regions, as at present, C.W. Van Horn, vice president of operation and maintenance, announced yesterday.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Granting 257 divorces in a four-hour session, Judge A.L. Franklin declared that "if this is a sample of civilization, we are in a dickens of a fix."

It was not the policy of the German-American Bunds leaders to resist the Selective Service Act except for a test case, which was intended to establish what they considered their rights. William Luedtke, former Bund secretary, testified in Federal Court yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- President Roosvelt accepts the decisions of the military leaders and makes no military proposals of his own, according to information received today from an authoritative source close to the White House.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The revival of diplomatic and political discussion on the second front while the flower of the German Army is assaulting Stalingrad with blind fury is capped by a calm, logical editorial to be published in The Times of London tomorrow advocating a second front as the only means to complete victory and stressing the necessity of speed in launching such operation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Greater use of prison industries and prisoner manpower was urged today by Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chairman, who noted that prisons are producing at only one-third their capacity and using less than 10 per cent of their inmates in commodity output.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- A careful survey of corporation income tax reports made on C.P.A. audits showed that 97 per cent were filed before the March 15 deadline and that in the balance of the cases, good reasons usually existed for the delay, Walter A.M. Cooper, chairman of the committee on Federal taxation, American Institute of Accountants. said here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- An order which would cut off production by many of the country's principal gold mines was reported tonight to be near issuance by the War Production Board, for the primary purpose of diverting mining manpower to the production of critically needed copper, lead and zinc.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Secretary Morgenthau announced today that the Treasury would borrow approximately $4,000,000,000 in October, the largest single financing operation since the World War. He will confer with officials of the Federal Reserve Board tomorrow and will make public details of the financing early in the month.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The population of the continental United States, which has been roughly computed as 130,000,000, was actually 133,965,000 on Jan. 1, according to preliminary estimates by the Census Bureau. This total did not take into account the number of soldiers who had gone abroad, or, as the Census Bureau puts it, "the post-censal movements of the armed forces away from continental United States."

Belmont Park's Autumn meeting moved into its second week with a seven-race card yesterday that cleared the decks for today's Lawrence Realization Stakes and Valorous Purse. Despite the fact that Shut Out and Alsab will not have their anticipated duel, the Realization, in its Golden Jubilee running, stands out, with Mrs. Albert Sabath's colt a strong favorite.

The third contingent of workers recruited here for the Kaiser shipyards on the Pacific Coast left yesterday from the Central Railroad of New Jersey station at Jersey City. There were 314 aboard. The train left at 2 P.M. About a hundred friends and relatives were at the station to bid the workers farewell.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28 -- In a grim speech picturing the war so far as a series of defeats for the United Nations, Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, commanding the Services of Supply, said tonight that unless Americans lost their "smug sense of complacency" their independence would also be lost.

The Twin State Gas and Electric Company announced yesterday the omission of the Oct. 1 quarterly dividend on its 7 per cent prior lien preferred stock, interrupting an unbroken payment record extending over twenty-three years.
The executive committee of the National Ski Association of America has voted to cancel this year's convention of the directors. No meetings are planned for the duration.

Campaigns to "clean up gambling" are perhaps as old as cities themselves. None will ever wholly succeed. As long as one horse, one dog or one cootie may or may not run faster than another, as long as coins have two different sides, as long as the manufacture of dice and cards is not illegal, and as long as the State is glad to take its cut off the pari-mutuel machine there will be gambling.

Two short plays open tonight at the Belasco under the sponsorship of Eddie Dowling. They are "Hello Out There," a one-acter by William Saroyan, which serves as a curtain raiser to Gilbert Keith Chesterton's twenty-nine-year-old comedy, "Magic," that was first seen on Broadway in 1917.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- United States planes in the Solomon Islands, joining alike in defensive and offensive operations against the Japanese forces there, shot down forty-two airplanes in four days while damaging three others, and registered bomb hits on two cruisers, a large transport and a seaplane tender, the Navy announced late today.

In a further pause after the strong rally of last week, the stock market achieved yesterday only a minor consolidation of its recovery gains. Except for some scattered instances, the net additions on the day were minor fractions, with a slackening of activity acting as a natural restriction on any full-fledged furtherance of the upturn.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters was Osias Nacht, managing director of the Charles Lee Company, who leased an apartment in 912 Fifth Avenue through Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc., brokers, and Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., agents.
DETROIT, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Reports that Detroit is divided on the war effort are exaggerated, Associate Justice Frank Murphy of the Supreme Court said today, adding:

The vital part of athletics in pre-flight training of naval aviation cadets was described to the Football Writers Association yesterday at Toots Shor's restaurant by Commander Tom Hamilton, who originated the plan now in effect at the four cadet centers.

With government health posters everywhere advocating the inclusion of whole grains in the daily diet, the American housekeeper has come to realize that certain cereals are invaluable for keeping her family in tip-top physical condition.

LONDON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The International Tin Committee, which has regulated most of the world's output of this metal under a sevennation agreement, today virtually threw open the production floodgates for countries still under United Nations control.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 28 -- Senator Norris, long-time independent Senator from Nebraska, accepted today petitions signed by 16,000 persons putting him in nomination to succeed himself in the November election.

ST. JOHNS, Nfld., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Mayor La Guardia of New York, who came here with the Canadian-United Joint Defense Board, said today he was impressed with the camaraderie and cooperation of Canadian, American and Newfoundland forces serving together in this continental outpost.

College students were urged yesterday by Newbold Morris, president of the City Council and Acting Mayor in the absence of Mayor La Guardia, to "inject some wickedness into their thinking, because it takes wickedness to beat the enemy."

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Statements like those of Wendell Willkie and General Sir Archibald P. Wavell regarding a second front have inspired considerable comment here about the continued dispersal of American planes, men and equipment in many theatres.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- Dan Galgano of Woodway and Charles De Lucca of Hummocks won the Westchester County Golf Association pro-amateur best ball tournament today after matching cards with Paul Runyan of Metropolis, newly crowned Westchester open champion and his amateur partner Dolph Jarrett of the home club.

Four years ago Sept. 30 throngs of men and women, many with grim, tearstained faces, stood before the government buildings at the Hradcany, the seat of the ancient Bohemian kings in Prague, listening to the counsels of their leaders to have patience, to remain calm, when the announcement was made of the result of the Munich conference.

The city of Yonkers, N.Y., has awarded a new issue of $600,000 of tax anticipation notes to the First National Bank of Boston. The notes are dated Sept. 28, 1942, and are payable on March 1, 1943. The bank bid an 0.75 per cent basis for the issue.

A survey of butchers and restaurants in this city shows that meat buying and meat eating already have fallen into a pattern of voluntary rationing such as Secretary Wickard has suggested to be started on Thursday.

VICHY, Sept. 28 -- A message sent today by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State, through the Governor-General, praised the population of Madagascar for its resistance to the British and expressed his confidence that the island would remain French.

Completion of the unprecedented deal whereby the United Artists Corporation will purchase distribution rights to twenty-two Paramount feature pictures was announced jointly yesterday by Barney Balaban, president of Paramount Pictures, Inc., and Edward C. Raftery, president of U.A.

The National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters and the Mutual Casualty Insurance Rating Bureau announced yesterday that they had recommended to State authorities reductions in rates for bodily injury liability insurance applying to private passenger automobiles in the rate-regulated Eastern States under their jurisdiction where gasoline rationing was in effect.

Domenico Trombetta, who until last Dec. 13 edited and published the "Fascist Propaganda Weekly," Il Grido della Stirpe, was divested yesterday of his United States citizenship and, reverting to his Italian nationality, was seized by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as a dangerous enemy alien.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- A sudden change in the character of the reports regarding the Senate farm bloc being able to include farm wages in a new formula to arrive at parity prices started a general selling movement in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today.

The two-family house at 1704 Avenue H. Brooklyn, was sold by the Church Extensions of Mission of the Methodist Church to A. Goldman for occupancy. Sale was for cash above a mortgage of $7,500. Friedberg Co. were the brokers.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28 -- Vice Admiral Arseny Golovko who, at 36 years of age heads the Soviet naval forces in northern waters, stated to the Moscow press today that in fifteen months submarines under his command had sunk over 700,000 tons of enemy shipping.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Ted Lyons, 41-year-old veteran pitcher for the Chicago White Sox, enlisted as a private in the Marine Corps today and was placed on inactive duty pending action on his application for a commission.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 23 -- Although the American Red Cross supplies shipped aboard the French freighter, Mount Everest, arrived at Marseille on Sept. 16, no mention of the distribution of the milk and children's clothing which formed the greater part of the cargo has appeared in the French local papers received here, it was revealed today.

Two-family dwellings in Newark, N.J., have been sold through Michael A. Stavitsky Co., brokers, at 724-726 Eighth Street, to Gabriele DiEdoardo for the Amalgamated Building and Loan Association; also 10 Boylan Street to Donald S. Azzarello for the same owner, and 453-,544 Seventh Street to Michael D'Orio for the Fidelity Union Trust Company.

That gifted young Long Island tennis player who fled to the West because his father objected to the youth's preference of a college temporarily fortunate in players of that game to the paternal choice, is a rather engaging specimen of his kind. When collegians were few the son went meekly to his father's college or that picked by his father if his father was sheepskinless.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 28 -- At a convocation beginning the 177th year of Rutgers University here today, Robert C. Clothier, the president, dedicated the resources of the university to the war. "Education as usual," he said, was "out."
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 28 -- William A. Coker's young black and tan Doberman pinscher, Franklin D. Maredgar, C.D.X., was the lone passer among the seven dogs taking the annual tracking tests of the Westbury Kennel Association today on the J.S. Phipps estate.
If you want to be popular with the moving man, don't overload your bureau drawers with pictures, linens and bric-a-brac and then blame the mover for damage done.
MOSCOW, Sept. 28 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

CLEVELAND, Sept. 28 (U.P.) -- Production of cutting tools needed for the manufacture of rifle and bombsight parts at the plant of the Cowles Tool Company was completely halted tonight by a wildcat strike of 175 employes.
Duck hunters south of Manasquan, N.J., have been inquiring about regulations that may be established by the Coast Guard of the Fourth Naval District effecting that area.

OTTAWA, Sept. 28 -- "What we need and what we are doing are developing the greatest possible activity on all fronts," Clement R. Attlee. British Dominions Secretary and former labor leader, declared here today in reply to a question regarding the possibility of opening a second front in Europe as urged by Wendell L. Willkie in Moscow.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Sept. 27 (Delayed) -- Captain Paul Cool of Pontiac, Mich., did not eat any breakfast this morning. He was too elated to eat for the very good reason that a 500-pound bomb, dropped from his Flying Fortress, hit a 15,000-ton Japanese cargo vessel amidship in Rabaul Harbor at dawn today.
Colonel and Mrs. Arthur W. Little will return to Mayfair House tomorrow from White Sulphur Springs, W.Va.
Buffalo Joe McCarthy last night marshaled his seventh pennant-winning Yankee team on an 8 o'clock train at Grand Central Terminal and headed for St. Louis to meet the so-called "amazing" Cardinals.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- Most sections of the stock market started the week with a firm tone, the exception being the rayon group. Profit-taking caused a sharp setback in Courtaulds, while Celanese second preference was marked down.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission ruled today that the Koppers Company was a holding company and denied the applications of three subsidiaries that they be declared not a part of the Koppers system.

Was there ever such a pennant race in baseball history? Two fighting teams, each with more than 100 victories to its credit, slugged it out to the last rainy Sunday in September. If the Dodgers lost, it was not for want of trying. In the homestretch drive the Red Birds from St. Louis had a little too much for them.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Sept. 29 -- Two German infantry divisions and 150 tanks, thrown into the faltering assault on Stalingrad, crashed through Russian lines on the northwestern outskirts of the city yesterday, the Russian High Command announced in a communique issued last midnight.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Byron Price, director of the Office of Censorship, told the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association today that publishers "have done a good job" of handling war news under censorship but they "have done a poor job of informing the people why some information has to be withheld."

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 28 -- Clipping five strokes from par, Dave Seaman of South Bay and Al Brosch of Bethpage took the honors with 35, 33 -- 68 in the one-day amateur-pro tournament of the Long Island P.G.A. at the Hempstead Golf Club today.

Once again it appears that the long-promised novel by Katherine Anne Porter, her first, is off for a while. Heard about each literary season, announced by the publisher and then postponed, this first full-length work by the author of "Pale Horse, Pale Rider" and other stories is not mentioned in the latest statement of the plans of Harcourt, Brace for the Fall.

Mayor La Guardia's drive against gambling in the city received additional impetus yesterday when Magistrate Charles Solomon, sitting in the Flatbush Court, Brooklyn, advocated from the bench a change in the penal law that would give the city's magistrates "absolute and final jurisdiction" over all gambling cases.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 28 (UP) -- The Negro must be given his full rights as a citizen as promised by the Constitution, the Most Rev. Bernard J. Sheil, auxiliary Bishop of Chicago, said today at the annual conference of Catholic Charities.

Herbert E. Smith was elected yesterday president of the United States Rubber Company, according to an announcement by F.B. Davis Jr. chairman and chief executive officer of the company. Mr. Smith also was elected chairman of the executive committee and a member of the finance committee.

The structure containing twenty apartments and eleven stores at 59-69 Glen Street, Glen Cove, L.I., was sold by the Nassau-Suffolk Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company to the Glen Street Realty Company through the Lewis Land Corporation, brokers.

The establishment of fixed profit ceilings for all war manufacturers would be a deterrent to production and to the search for manufacturing economies, according to a statement sent yesterday to stockholders by the Auto-Ordnance Corporation, manufacturer of Thompson submachine guns, more commonly known as "tommy guns."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Driving of private passenger cars in the seventeen States affected by the coupon rationing plan for curbing the use of gasoline has fallen off nearly 60 per cent, according to an estimate by the Office of Price Administration.

It is not yet sufficiently understood that even the mildest farm "parity" formula is inflationary. It is inflationary because it is relative. No matter how high the absolute level of farm prices already is, the formula provides that they must go still higher if other prices rise.

The Empire Gas and Fuel Company announced yesterday that holders of more than 85 per cent of the publicly owned preferred shares of the utility had executed agreements to exchange their holdings for new 3 1/2 per cent sinking fund debentures under a recapitalization plan launched Aug. 3 and that, therefore, the plan had become operative.

The current upswing in the sale of piece goods by stores throughout the country as a result of the swing to home sewing is bringing about a sharp increase in retail advertising of yard goods, retailers reported yesterday. In addition to spending more money on their piece goods department in newspapers, stores are also increasing their budgets for interior and window display, it was said.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The heating season in thirty States where fuel oil is to be rationed starting Thursday will be divided into five periods so that home consumers of heating oil can budget their rations accurately, the Office of Price Administration made known today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Columbus Redbirds moved nearer their second consecutive little world series championship tonight when, helped by six Syracuse errors, they routed the Chiefs 10-5 in the fourth game of the twenty-fifth annual minor league classic.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 -- The extensive proposed changes in proxy rules destined to place control of corporations more securely in the hands of their stockholders are to be made a subject of joint discussion between representatives of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the financial industry, it was learned today.

Let us forget the second front for a moment. There is no question that we all want it. From Moscow through London to New York there is only one ground for difference of opinion: when and where it ought to be, and whether the decision shall be partly a political one or wholly strategic. Let us forget

VICHY, France, Sept. 28 (U.P.) -- A round-up of Americans in occupied France was ordered because of the arrest of German citizens in Brazil and because of the scarcity of Brazilians and other Allied nationals in the occupied area, it was understood tonight.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration announced tonight that the government would subsidize excess cost of transporting Pennsylvania anthracite to some New England areas.

The regional office of the OPA will rely on facts and figures disclosed by studies made by the Bureau of Labor Statistics rather than on "pressure" which might be exerted by either landlords or tenants in determining whether or not a price ceiling should be placed on rents in this area, Maurice L. Stone, new regional rent administrator of the OPA, said yesterday.

LAUREL, Md., Sept. 28 -- Encouraged by reports of a reasonably successful meeting at Havre de Grace, Laurel Park officials today completed preparations for tomorrow's opening of a 25-day meeting. The feature of the inaugural card is the $7,500-added Capital Handicap, a six furlong dash for older horses.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Indicating that the Senate fight over the anti-inflation bill might be waged beyond the deadline of Thursday set by President Roosevelt, Senator Thomas, Oklahoma farm leader, challenged Administration forces tonight to bring his amendment for a new and higher price-fixing parity to an immediate vote.

Further experiments in strip-teasing at respectable prices are studiously conducted in "Wine, Women and Song," which was put on at the Ambassador last evening. Margie Hart, the red-haired houri of the late departed burlesque, drops nearly everything and gets down to the old business toward closing time.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 28 -- A reshuffle of the German High Command at both flanks of the Eastern Front appears to have taken place.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The heating season in thirty States where fuel oil is to be rationed starting Thursday will be divided into five periods so that home consumers of heating oil can budget their rations accurately, the Office of Price Administration made known today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Columbus Redbirds moved nearer their second consecutive little world series championship tonight when, helped by six Syracuse errors, they routed the Chiefs 10-5 in the fourth game of the twenty-fifth annual minor league classic.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- In a statement addressed to the people of Nebraska, Senator Norris said today that despite his desire to return to private life, he had consented to become a candidate for re-election, adding:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The war effort is being impeded by attempts of the Office of Price Administration to control munitions prices, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, told a Senate Finance subcommittee today. He asked that the OPA be eliminated from the price-control field so far as war materiel was concerned and hinted that an agreement with the OPA to that effect was in the making.

American labor, represented jointly by the American Federation of Labor, the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the Railway Brotherhoods, yesterday sent greetings to the workers of Luxembourg, congratulating them upon their recent general strike against the Nazi occupation forces in their country and calling upon the workers of Europe to intensify their sabotage of the Nazi war machine.
MOSCOW, Sept. 29 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Sept. 30 -- The Germans continued to punch at the northwestern fringe of Stalingrad yesterday, but gained no ground. Wave after wave of Nazi infantry, supported by planes and tanks, charged against the Russians' wall of fire.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Living standards must go down to 1932-33 levels to enable the United States to make good on its production commitments to the rest of the world, Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, warned a committee of fifty retailers, assembled at a conference here to consider curtailment of many peacetime services offered by stores.

Dimitri Shostakovich will not come to this country to conduct the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, it was announced yesterday, and he has also declined to come as a piano soloist. He declined the first invitation because of lack of conducting experience, and the second because he is "extremely busy" with a new symphonic work.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Here in the peaceful, bucolic valley of the Chenango, remote from the rush and congestion of the metropolis, the war has made its strong impress and its mark upon Colgate football.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today to appropriate $2,862,000,000 more for Navy planes, bringing to $5,593,154,308 the total funds requested for the Navy in two weeks. On Sept. 17 the President asked Congress to approve a supplemental estimate of $2,731,154,308, including $960,000,000 for the Bureau of Aeronautics for unspecified purposes.

Directors of the Bush Terminal Company won from Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter yesterday a ruling upholding the constitutionality of retroactive provisions of a 1941 State law which assesed against corporations the expenses incurred by directors in successfully defending themselves against accounting suits.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Asserting that the public was "losing patience with the conduct of the war," Frank E. Gannett, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee, urged his party tonight to demand "a centralized or unified" command for the nation's fighting forces.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29 -- Primed for their thirteenth world series in twenty-one years, looking confidently toward what they expect to be their seventh Fall conquest under the leadership of Joe McCarthy, the Yankees arrived tonight an hour late, to aggravate an already acute housing situation.
Manhattan's first-string operatives got a preview of the offensive tactics Muhlenberg will probably employ against them in the opening game at the Polo Grounds on Saturday.

Joey Peralta, 136, Tamaqua, Pa., won a clean-cut decision from Cleo Shans, 133, Los Angeles, in the feature ten-round bout at the opening of the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night, before 3,000 fans.
LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Problems arising from the unsettling effect of the war upon families and homes are today receiving greater attention from agencies of the government and the church.

In your issue of Sept. 22 you published a letter from Oscar Frankl, emphasizing the importance of arranging German-language broadcasts to counteract the influence on Americans of German descent of the Nazi shortwave broadcasts.
The law stepped in yesterday in an attempt to straighten out the tangled affairs of 6-year-old Gertrude Louise Miller, left in Grand Central Station on Sept. 19.

In the twenty-second annual report of the Motor Wheel Corporation issued to stockholders yesterday, H.F. Harper, president, revealed that the net operating profit of $4,988,594 before Federal taxes for the year ended on June 30 set a new record in earnings.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Office of War Information today listed Admiral William D. Leahy, in his position as Chief of Staff to the Commander in Chief of the United States Army and Navy, as the ranking American officer on the Combined Chiefs of Staff of the United States and Great Britain.

Since the start of the war in 1939, the trend in the advertising field has been definitely away from cooperative advertising by manufacturers with retailers. But in at least one important case this trend has been definitely reversed, with the Goodall Company, makers of Palm Beach suits, going back to cooperative advertising after a lapse of a year.
Hugh Gibson, former United States Ambassador to Brazil, and Mrs. Gibson have arrived from Washington, and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's midnight communique:

The Barber Asphalt Corporation yesterday notified stockholders of a special meeting on Oct. 21 to obtain approval of the company's shipbuilding activities for the Navy and certain changes being made in the concern's plant.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 29 -- A commission of oil experts headed by E.L. De Golyer left for Washington this morning by plane, having completed an exhaustive survey of Mexican oil fields and plants to ascertain what equipment was needed to rehabilitate the industry.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Sept. 26 (Delayed) -- Australians who are attempting to push back Japanese units that have thrust toward Port Moresby through the Owen Stanley Mountains today came up against the most ambitious Japanese defensive works they have yet encountered.

Formation of a trade association comprising the leading American and Canadian fur auction companies, the first of its kind in the fur industry, is under way, it was reported yesterday by Maurice Cantor, head of the New York Fur Auction Company, who has been elected chairman of the organization. The association, as yet unnamed, will held an organizational meeting shortly.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Agriculture Department reported today that the general level of farm prices remained at 107 per cent of parity between mid-August and mid-September.

The plan for fuel oil rationing runs into one obvious difficulty not encountered in rationing gasoline. We knew that automobile speed and mileage could be cut down. We do not know how much fuel oil will be needed to keep rationed homes at the predetermined temperature of 65 degrees, because we do not know how cold it is going to be.

Five prophetic costumes, each the work of an individual designer outstanding in the American couture, will lend stimulus and inspiration to the panoramic presentation "Fashions of the Times," on Oct. 6 and 7. Based on sheer fantasy yet incorporating the same chic that will characterize the contemporary ensembles in this novel style review, the five costumes will appear in a single scene, projecting women's post-war activities and attitudes.

MAYWOOD, N.J., Sept. 29 -- Mrs. Isabelle DuBois, 32 years old. and two of her children, Adele, 2, and Molison, 8 months old, were found dead of gas poisoning late this afternoon on the kitchen floor of their home at 889 Lincoln Avenue, here.

While the German-American Bund leaders in Los Angeles allegedly were urging Americans of German origin to resist military service and to prepare for the time when they would "take over," the Navy intelligence division in that city was being kept informed of their activities, it was revealed yesterday.

Brooklyn's touring Football Dodgers, having spent a delightful week-end at Buffalo, where they got off to a flying start in the National Football League at the expense of the Philadelphia Eagles, moved into Ebbets Field yesterday, to remain until Friday. The next stop will be Detroit, where on Sunday they have a date with the Lions.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- With traders awaiting the result of the Senate vote on the proposed new formula for determining parity prices, operations in the wheat pit were on a small scale today and prices held within a range of 1/2 cent a bushel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- An important item of news, which for many days has been continuous in character but which the press and the radio have been forbidden to relate or even mention, will soon be released to the American people. When the release comes, the undercover controversy that has accompanied the act of censorship will also be made known.

Replies to a questionnaire sent out by the National Retail Dry Goods Association indicate that 99.4 per cent of its member stores are complying with all OPA price regulations, it was stated yesterday by Lew Hahn, general manager of the association.

Every phase of the advertising field has been drawn into the war effort, it was made known yesterday when representatives of twenty-five organizations and committees reported on their programs to the War Activities Council of the Advertising Club of New York at a luncheon meeting at the club's headquarters. The council has become the clearing house for all local advertising campaigns in connection with the war effort and for local participation in national campaigns.

Consumer speculation about wartime bedding gets its first clear-cut answer this week. A new bedspring made of wood and steel brings home "paper" regulations which now cover the manufacture of all types of mattresses and bedsprings.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 -- In the first decision of its kind by any Federal court, the Third Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that a corporation taking a discount in an exchange of bonds for stock may class that discount as a deductable loss on income tax reports and amortize it yearly during the life of the bond issue.

The idea of replacing "inferior" European products with "superior" American products has never been "sold properly" in the Latin-American market, Arthur A. Kron, secretary of the Association of Export Advertising Agencies, declared yesterday at a meeting of the Export Managers Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

New in a city store this week is an old favorite of nursery suppers restyled in becoming fashion -- peanut butter that has been flavored with chocolate. Haling from Hollywood, this spread comes in a neat jar that holds a bit more than a pound and costs 49 cents.

Year after year this time, a few days one way or the other, brings back into the paper a handsome elderly gentleman. He is one of the few national figures harking back to the first decade of the century. In the world series pictures yesterday Judge Landis looks more and more like Andrew Jackson.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- A conference of bituminous coal operators and miners, convened today by Harold L. Ickes, Solid Fuels Coordinator, adjourned to Oct. 21 after failure to agree on his injunction "to provide at once for increasing the hours of labor in the mines beyond the present thirty-five hour week limitation."

An 18-year-old Japanese girl, born and educated in this country and who has declared her intentions of remaining an American citizen when she reaches her majority, has been denied permission by the Board of Higher Education to enter Hunter College because her parents are living in Japan.

LAUREL, Md., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Joe Ray, a winner at Havre de Grace only last Saturday, captured the $6,800 purse of the Capital Handicap, opening day feature at Laurel, as he nosed out the favorite, Challamore, in a thrilling stretch duel today.

Four King's Scouts, whose rank is the highest in British Scouting, and who are known as the "Blitz Scouts" because of their courageous work during air raids over their home communities, returned to New York yesterday after a six-weeks' tour of the United States that included stops in thirty-three cities from coast to coast.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The War Department opposed today Senator George's bill for a 5 per cent limit on war profits on the grounds that it would lower the incentive for all-out war production and actually tend to increase manufacturing costs.

A WORLD series is all new to these Cardinal players. The Yankees are old hands at it. But that doesn't mean that the new boys at the game are beaten before they start. There's one notable thing about Billy Southworth's players when they take the field; they pass the pepper. They lost plenty of games during the National League season, but never a single one for lack of trying.

H.S. Schaeffer and Mortimer Brandt, prominent local art dealers, have joined forces, establishing a firm called Schaeffer Brandt, Inc. It occupies the former Schaeffer Gallery at 61 East Fifty-seventh Street, which, however, has been enlarged by inclusion of space on the same floor that was previously occupied by the Marie Harriman Gallery.

Fordham's football players went through an intensive two-hour practice yesterday on Fordham Field in which both the offensive and defensive mechanics of the Rams' game came in for an overhauling. A scrimmage is scheduled for this afternoon, the last full-length practice before the Rams depart tomorrow night for Knoxville and the meeting with Tennessee on Saturday.

A minimum wage rate of 40 cents an hour in the printing, publishing and graphic arts industry was recommended yesterday to L. Metcalfe Walling, administrator of the Wage and Hour Division of the Department of Labor, by an industry committee appointed by Mr. Walling. The recommendation concluded a two-day session of the committee at the Hotel Astor.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The Air Ministry and the Ministry of Agriculture are finding this tight little isle too tight. An agricultural debate in the House of Commons today revealed that the two departments are competing for the last reserve of arable land -- England's great parks and playing fields.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill issued a warning against loose talk in connection with continental invasion plans in the House of Commons today as a high British Army officer broadcast told the French that an Allied offensive "is in the making."

A severe food shortage may become the dominant issue in this country if farmers do not get the chance to hire agricultural labor at reasonable cost, Dr. R.E. Corbett, director of the Maryland Agricultural Experiment Station, told the closing session of the two-day war conference of the North Atlantic section of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers yesterday at the Belmont Plaza Hotel.

HONOLULU, Sept. 29 -- Referring to a United Press story from New York on Sept. 28 that the government employment service is recruiting laborers in New York City for Hawaii projects, offering transportation, a one-year contract, for a forty-eight-hour week at $35 weekly pay, which "is equal in purchasing power to about $52 in New York," the Honolulu Advertiser will print an editorial tomorrow entitled "Somebody's Being Kidded."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- A bill to permit aliens serving in the armed forces to obtain American citizenship without showing that they were legally admitted to the United States was introduced today by Representative Dickstein of New York, chairman of the Immigration and Naturalization Committee.

LONDON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Distinguished Flying Crosses have been awarded to two Americans, Flying Officer Sam Alfred Mauriello, 34 years of age, of New York, and Acting Warrant Officer Leonard A. Johnson, 28 years of age, of St. Paul, Minn., the Royal Air Force announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Senate, by a vote of 48 to 48, today put into the anti-inflation bill the Thomas-Hatch amendment for a new and higher farm price parity which, the Administration holds, would add $3,500,000,000 a year to the country's food bill and increase the cost of living by 5 per cent.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29 -- Stating that fifty-seven wildcat strikes had occurred at Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation operations in the last year, causing a loss of 59,863 man hours at war production plants, the management of that concern has suggested that the War Labor Board impose fines amounting to $1 a day, on workers responsible for such unauthorized walkouts as a means of curbing the "activities of these irresponsibles."

TRENTON, Sept. 29 -- Last-minute efforts by Governor Charles Edison, Democrat, and Senator Roy V. Wright of Essex County, Republican, to put their respective State conventions on record for early revision of New Jersey's ninety-eight-year-old Constitution proved fruitless today.

A study of publishers' final plans for Fall and early Winter reveals large lists, perhaps about the same size on the whole as last Fall, but it is also apparent that a large number of books previously announced will not be along for the season.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, Sept. 29 -- Tragedy tinged the scene as members of three Royal Air Force Eagle Squadrons -- the first American fliers to get into action against Adolf Hitler in Blitz days -- entered the Air Forces of their own country with impressive ceremonies here today.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- For a considerable time it would be wise for India to maintain "a position with the free partners of the British Commonwealth," declared Leopold S. Amery, Secretary of State for India, at a luncheon today at Caxton Hall, Westminster.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Advertising by war manufacturers to keep their peacetime activities before the public will be recognized as a legitimate deduction for tax purposes by the Bureau of Internal Revenue, according to an official statement of policy today by Commissioner Guy T. Helvering.

Senator Norris's consent to become a candidate for re-election is welcome news. Sole Independent in the Senate, he will be opposed in the State primary by inconsiderable candidates, party or petition. His former Democratic junior colleague, Mr. Burke, hasn't yet made up his mind.

L. Wade Childress, president of the Laclede Gas Light Company, announced yesterday the filing of amendments to the company's plan of reorganization with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Public Service Commission of Missouri.

CHICAGO. Sept. 29 (AP) -- Live hogs Managed to hold their gains today despite heavier than expected receipts and a top of $15.40, highest in twenty-two years, again was paid for choice butchers. White current levels were high enough to lure many light hogs to market, livestock men said the practical assurance that prices would not sag during the Winter served to hold such animals on the farms for profitable feeding.

The New York and Suburban Federal Savings and Loan Association will formally open its new offices at 2438 Broadway, at the corner of Ninetieth Street, tomorrow at 2 P.M., Hugh J. Smallen, president of the association, announced yesterday.

Charles Evans Hughes Jr., son of the former Chief Justice and himself an active worker for good government in the city, yesterday was named chairman of the Citizens Committee for the Election of Thomas E. Dewey as Governor.

After fairly active hedge selling and trade buying early in the session the cotton market turned quiet yesterday in late dealings. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures closed 6 points lower to 7 points higher than Monday's final quotations.

Railway operating unions recently concluded negotiations with the managements here on proposed increases in pay without reaching an agreement. It was then announced that the subject would be referred to the system of adjudication provided by law for railway labor controversies.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Sir Samuel Joseph was elected Lord Mayor of London for the coming year in bomb-scarred Guildhall today. His election came as a surprise, as he was second on the list of qualified Aldermen to Sir Frank Pollitzer, who two years ago yielded in favor of a younger man. Sir Frank is 73 and Sir Samuel 54.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Major Gwilym Lloyd George, Minister of Fuel, told the House of Commons today that 18,957 men had been released since Jan. 3 from the Royal Air Force, the army and industry to return to work in the coal mines. He estimated that about 8,000 juveniles had started work in the coal industry in the same period.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 29 (U.P.) -- Royal Air Force medium bombers last night raided Tobruk for the second time in twenty-four hours, setting fires among gasoline stores near the harbor. South African light bombers attacked three Axis coastal landing bases.

Some professionals have taken hold of a short play by Saroyan, and the results are stunning. The play is "Hello, Out There," and the professionals are Eddie Dowling and Julie Haydon, who put it on at the Belasco last evening. Only about a month ago Saroyan was staging two of his own plays at the same theatre, and the results were unprofessional and shattering.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Thousands of miles away in the Southwest Pacific United States soldiers and sailors will be listening when the world series starts in St. Louis tomorrow. Short-wave radio transmission will carry the story of the baseball classic to the service men in Australia and the Pacific islands.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Red Army, killing more than 2,200 Germans, beat off all of the main Nazi blows at Stalingrad yesterday, the Soviet High Command announced today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -Her6 is the roU-call by whicA the Senate adopted the ThomasHatck amendment to the antiinflation bill, providing for the recognition of all labor costs in establishing farm rice ceilings:

Even on the premise that the President should not have delivered his ultimatum, which expires tonight, to suspend on his own responsibility part of an act of Congress, it is in the obvious interests of all concerned that a clash should be averted on this issue. The President, in urging a more reasonable ceiling on farm prices, is more nearly in the right than Congress.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 29 -- Vern Haugland's battle for survival in the jungle -- the story of an Associated Press war correspondent who wandered for forty-three days in the mountainous wilderness of New Guinea, into which he parachuted from a storm-whipped Army plane, and out of which he came delirious, exhausted but alive -- is told in his diary.

In the fortieth start of his sensational career Alsab, bay son of Good Goods, pushed his earnings past the $300,000 mark to a total of $306,365 by capturing the $11,550 Lawrence Realization Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park before 13,188 persons. Mrs. Albert Sabath's colt now has won twenty-two races, including several of the country's classics.

VICHY, Sept. 29 (U.P.) -- An estimated 1,400 Americans have been arrested in occupied France since last Thursday and interned by the German authorities under conditions "as good as could be expected," the United States Embassy announced today.

Drug stores in the metropolitan area are adopting a policy of early closing in an effort to save fuel and electric current, Joseph Spivak, executive secretary of the New York Retail Druggists Association, 220 West Forty-second Street announced yesterday.

To break down malicious rumors harmful to the nation's morale, a "rumor clinic" similar to that conducted in Boston by Professor D.W. Allport of Harvard University has been established by students in the Psychology Club of the Washington Square College of Arts and Science of New York University.

MONTREAL, Sept. 29 (CP) -- Mayor La Guardia of New York and Colonel Biggar of Ottawa, chairmen of the Canada-United States Joint Defense Board, said tonight after their arrival with other members of the board by plane from Newfoundland, where they toured defense posts, that "everything we saw boasts well for us and disastrously for our enemies."
A number of leases for quarters in buildings on Park and Fifth Avenues were included in the contracts for residential space reported yesterday by brokers handling that type of business.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Columbus Redbirds -- roaring back for four straight triumphs -- successfully defended their little world series championship tonight by defeating the Syracuse Chiefs, 4-2, to take the twenty-fifth annual minor league classic.

UNITED STATES NAVY OPERATIONS BASE, Solomon Islands, Sept. 13 (Delayed) (U.P.) -Seaman Robert James Canavan, 20 years of age, former Chicago drugstore delivery boy, swam for nineteen hours in the South Pacific to bring back the story of how a Japanese cruiser sank an American patrol boat and methodically machine-gunned to death all five of his shipmates.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Sept. 29 -- By 67 votes to 64 the Chamber of Deputies this evening, after more than five hours of debate, approved a motion calling upon the government to break relations immediately with Germany, Italy and Japan.

An unexpected dividend of $2.50 a share for the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe made the stock the feature of the trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The stock rose 2 7/8 points on a volume of 22,900 shares to a new high price for the year.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Orphans Court today ruled against the titled next of kin of Mrs. Emily Barton Pendleton, daughter of Francis Barton, scientist and linguist, and awarded $180,000 from her estate to the Jefferson Medical College Hospital.

Household scrap metal collections in highly urban districts can average ten pounds per capita, it has indicated yesterday in first day results of the intensive drive conducted by Bundles for America, Inc., in a four-block sample district on the upper East Side.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 29 -- Total victory and quick victory over Hitlerism and Japanese despotism and a complete annihilation of everything left behind by these systems are the only way to assure anything decent, democratic and pleasant, such as recreation, in the world to come, said Dr. Reinhold Schairer, exiled German educator and visiting professor at New York University, before the War Recreation Congress here tonight.

George Van Gorder, regional vice president of McKesson Robbins, Inc., was elected president of the National Wholesale Druggists Association at the conclusion yesterday of the annual convention of the organization at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Mr. Van Gorder succeeds Lee Wilson Hutchins of Grand Rapids, Mich.

DES MOINES, Sept. 29 -- Speaking today to the National Farmers Union, M. Clifford Townsend, Agricultural Conservation Administrator, declared that the union was supporting "100 per cent" the President's program to fight the high cost of living.
Sponsors of an appeal for $1,000.000 to meet the war needs of the Presbyterian Church were announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Stuart Nye Hutchison, the moderator.

The murky lighting that has prevailed in IRT and BMT subway trains since the Spring dimout regulations will be improved immediately with the installation of new lamps that will double the present amount of light, bringing the illumination in the cars up to a little better than half the normal light.

The Hollywood Theatre will continue as a Broadway first-run house under a continuous performance, popular price policy following completion of the present two-a- day engagement of "Yankee Doodle Dandy" on Oct. 18, Warner Brothers announced yesterday.

Civilian workers and employers were criticized yesterday for failing to realize how fully the nation's manpower must be mobilized to win the war by Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, who warned that it may even be necessary for school children to spend only half a day in school and then devote "four or five hours a day to farm work or doing something else useful."

Buyer Registrations Up Registrations of buyers in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,050, as against 735 in the preceding week and 653 in the same period of last year according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Mrs. Skinker Matthews gave a luncheon yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton for Donna Ann Marie del Drago. Others in the party were Mrs. Robert Morris Phillips, Mrs. Charles H. Goddard, Mrs. Allan Wallace and Mrs. Stuart N. McNamara.

The day-by-day story of the fight for Stalingrad has made the war more real to distant places than any engagement since the conflict began. When the two greatest land armies in the world are locked in battles for streets and houses, the very narrowness of the frame in which the terrific action is crowded gives the picture an unequaled clarity.

The Museum of Modern Art placed on view yesterday afternoon several recent accessions: work by Degas, Derain, Modigliani, Berard, Rubin, Eric Isenburger and the sculptor Jacques Lipchitz, who is here represented by the second version of his bronze "Rape of Europa" and by a study, in pastel and gouache, for the fourth version of the same theme.

The large store in the commercial building at 469 Seventh Avenue, at the southeast corner of Thirty-sixth Street, has been leased for a long term by Loft Candy Corporation for a new unit in its chain of retail restaurant, soft drink and candy stores. Henry Shapiro Co. and Albert M. Greenfield Co. were the brokers. The lessor was the Raybar Realty Corporation.

The maximum fine of $500 was imposed on Wilson Co., Inc., meat packers, by Magistrate William Klapp in the Municipal Term Court yesterday on his conviction of the concern for selling last July 11 in its branch at 46 Tenth Avenue 180 pounds of "moldy, slimy and foul-smelling" frozen turkeys.

John C. Wood, vice president of B. Altman Co., has been appointed an expert consultant with the Army Specialist Corps and will take up his duties early next week. He will be stationed in Washington and will devote full time to his new post.

Estimates of the probable vote in the coming Congressional elections, made by the American Institute of Public Opinion and published in our news columns today, indicate that only 30,000,000 citizens will vote in November, as compared with nearly 50,000,000 in the Presidential elections of 1940.

Manufacturers of special types of food products for the Army will find a ready marked for them not only in this country but in other countries of the world, when the war is over, Colonel R.A. Isker, chief of the Subsistence Research Laboratory, Chicago Quartermaster Depot, yesterday told the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The newly created Program Coordination Division set up within the War Production Board is to be directed by Donald D. Davis, president of General Mills Company, Minneapolis, it was announced today.

A deal with Tammany Hall by the left wing of the American Labor party was charged yesterday by a number of American Labor party trade union leaders as they repudiated one of the judicial nominations made by the A.L.P. in the First Judicial District.

A counter-attack against the Japanese seems to be making definite progress both in New Guinea and in the Solomons. In New Guinea, on the mountain ridges back of Port Moresby, it has reached the stage where the threat to that Allied base has been reduced.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission rejected today a motion that it stay proceedings looking toward divestiture by the United Gas Improvement Company of its holdings in the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey.

Orders that will eventually eliminate the ordinary seamen of the merchant marine who lack formal training have been issued in Washington by the War Shipping Administration and the bureau of merchant marine inspection of the United States Coast Guard, it was disclosed here yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 29 -- Fifteen men, including a Newark traffic patrolman, were under arrest here today after the police had broken up a black market in stolen gasoline-rationing coupons that had threatened to sabotage the gasoline-allotment system in this area.

Bill Hutchinson, star back at Dartmouth from 1937 to 1939, has signed a contract to play with the New York Football Giants, John V. Mara, president, announced yesterday. Hutchinson, a product of James Monroe High, will work with the Maramen today at the Polo Grounds and will make his debut as a Giant against the Steelers at Pittsburgh on Sunday.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Sept. 30 -- Allied troops captured Ioribaiwa ridge in the Owen Stanley Mountains of New Guinea yesterday, General Douglas MacArthur announced today. The advance, started along the mountain front above Port Moresby late last week, continues, the communique said. The enemy was retiring toward Naoro, ten miles to the north of Ioribaiwa, abandoning quantities of equipment in his retreat.

VICHY, France, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The detention of many heads of French families as war prisoners in Germany is having the effect of increasing the legal rights and responsibilities of women, it was revealed today.
German military quarters said yesterday that "the last phase in the struggle for buildings" has started in Stalingrad, according to Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 -- Corporate integration proceedings under the "death sentence" clause of the Public Utility Holding Company Act were instituted today against the New England Gas and Electric Association by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
