CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Members of the American Institute of Accountants were assured today by Joseph I. Lubin, chairman of the WPB committee for the review of data requests, that requests for information from corporations would in the future be kept as simple and as free from duplication as possible, and were warned that even under these conditions some changes in corporate accounting methods might be necessary.

Lieut. Gen. Somervell, an able and devoted soldier, head of the Services of Supply, is the latest high authority to lecture the American people on the score of their alleged "complacency." In a speech at St. Louis reported yesterday he declared that we have been losing all the major battles, and to this he added: "We've lost all our rubber.

The United States Trust Company has sold to Paul S. Hitlin, operator and builder, the two five-story apartment houses with stores at the southeast corner of Amsterdam Avenue and Seventy-eighth Street, known as 371-75 Amsterdam Avenue and 170 West Seventy-eighth Street, for cash above a first mortgage of $99,000 due in September, 1949, with interest at the rate of 3 per cent.

War Bond sales for Monday reached a record day's total of $60,265,000, bringing the total for the month so far to $700,023,000 in the drive to sell a billion dollars worth of bonds this month, according to word received from Washington yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 29 -- Governor Spessard Holland of Florida urged a "prompt decision" in the three-year-old nation-wide freight rate case when he appeared as a witness today in hearings conducted by the Interstate Commerce Commission here.
The "heaviest moving season in a decade" was reported yesterday by various van operators and warehousemen as the Fall transfer of New York families to new residences approached its peak.

" What happened to the Dodgers could also happen to us." Thomas J. Curran. New York County Republican chairman, told members of the Republican County Committee last night in warning against over-confidence in the result on next Election Day.

A proposal, made to Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, that college and high school students be used to relieve the shortage of farm labor, met varying responses yesterday in colleges in the metropolitan area.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Enemy aircraft, sneaking in singly or in pairs, today dropped bombs on several places in Southeastern and Western England, causing a number of casualties. The most serious disaster occurred in a town inland somewhat from the south coast, where a direct hit was obtained on a boys' school.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Marian Anderson, Negro contralto, has been invited by the Daughters of the American Revolution to appear at the first of a series of war relief concerts to be given in Constitution Hall for which the use of the auditorium will be contributed by the national society.

Before a crowd of goggle-eyed children, whose expressions indicated that they expected a ghost to be stirred up by the workmen at any moment, the mysterious and dilapidated Collyer mansion at 2078 Fifth Avenue was started on the road to repair and respectability yesterday, but without the baring of any of its reputed secrets.

As a result of my experience from 1921 to 1936 in reporting upon domestic relations bills as a member of a committee on legislation of one of the bar associations, I am of the opinion that Mayor La Guardia should receive the complete and wholehearted support of the citizens of the State in his war upon the gamblers.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 29 -- The city commissioners of this militarized resort will go to Washington within the next ten days to appeal for government help for losses in operating revenue and increased municipal expense resulting from Army occupation of the beach front hotels.

VICHY, France, Sept. 29 -- About 1,000 American men, as well as 400 women, many of them married to French citizens, have been arrested in Paris and other parts of occupied France in the last few days, according to reports in the hands of the United States Embassy today.

TRENTON, Sept. 29 -- Governor Charles Edison went indirectly to the aid of his political arch-enemy, Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, today when he signed a bill hastily passed by the Legislature yesterday to halt the exodus of large corporations from Hudson County following the Governor's appointment of a new county tax board.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- One by one the lean gray shapes of destroyers that had escorted the war's greatest supply convoy to Russia are slipping into the mist-shrouded ports of the north after a great victory over the air and sea forces of the enemy along the sea route to Murmansk.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Lieutenant Commander John S. Thach, decorated three times for his exploits as leader of a squadron of Navy fighter planes in the Pacific, declared today that only carrier-based airpower could clear the way for invasion and defeat of Japan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- State Department officials said tonight that they had no knowledge of any protest filed with the French Foreign Office at Vichy against the arrest of some 1,400 American citizens in occupied France. They declined to discuss procedure that might be taken.

The cry "India must be free!" rang through Town Hall last night to the accompaniment of the vociferous approval of more than 2,000 persons who jammed the meeting place. A special detail of police, called when the hall filled to capacity, turned away hundreds of persons.

The United States Maritime Service has sworn in 460 prospective licensed officers in the last two days and will take in another group of 160 today, it was announced yesterday by the recruiting office at 45 Broadway.

Reflecting a volume of traffic swelled by the war to its largest extent in years, the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway announced a dividend of $2.50 on its common stock yesterday, which compared to a payment of $1.50 authorized on Sept. 1, last.
I am very much obliged to you for the opportunity to comment on the editorial of Aug. 9, in which you attack my article "Epitaph of a System" in The New Statesman of July 11.

A formula for estimating the number of gallons of fuel oil that can be saved by the use of storm windows on homes and apartment houses in the city was announced yesterday by the Regional News Bureau of the Office of War Information.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- There was less activity in the stock markets today, most buyers holding back pending the receipt of fresh war news. Many short-term operators decided to take their profits, but the selling was well absorbed and the net price movements were small.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 29 -- Arturo de Cordova, Latin American movie idol, president in Mexico of what compares to Hollywood's Screen Actors' Guild, and currently playing Augustin in "For Whom the Bell Tolls," at Paramount, has been selected by Cecil B. De Mille at that studio to take the leading role in "Rurales," projected Mexican-background film.

Nathan Straus, former Administrator of the United States Housing Authority, accepted yesterday a vice chairmanship of the Independent Citizens Committee for the Election of John J. Bennett Jr., Charles Poletti, Henry Epstein and Joseph V. O'Leary, the Democratic State ticket, and issued a statement here calling for the election of those candidates.

IT would be easily possible today to read much of the best current fiction and remain unaware that the English language is a noble instrument, beautiful, grand, infinitely suggestive. The simple declarative sentence, the rapid rhythm of a machine gun rather than that of the wind or the sea or an organ, a spare, nervous, colloquial style, these are the fashionable literary modes of our time.

The return of cooler weather last week brought the general death rate in New York City down to normal for the season, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins reported yesterday. The death rate last week was 8.7 per 1,000 population, compared with 9.6 the previous week.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Navy disclosed today that more than 2,301 officers and men of the American merchant marine were dead or missing as a result of enemy actions in the war at sea.

The fifteen-story Belmont Plaza Hotel, formerly the Montclair, occupying the block front on the east side of Lexington Avenue between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets, was bid in at auction by the Bowery Savings Bank, as plaintiff, at $500 above a mortgage of $2,747,533 and interest of about $82,426, in a foreclosure action against the Belmont Plaza Corporation and other defendants to satisfy a mortgage judgment of about $155,000.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 29 -- The Council of State concluded its session today, defeating a resolution calling for modification of restrictions on the press and censorship of news.

In defiance of the fuel shortage and that malicious wind which has been sending shivers up unconditioned spines these last few days, a small salon announces that it will keep you warm-as-toast while it makes you beautiful.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Men's rubber boots and rubber work shoes, excluding most ordinary rubber footwear, were ordered "frozen" in the hands of retailers and other distributors at midnight tonight by the Office of Price Administration as it prepared to impose its first rationing order affecting the field of apparel.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 -- A registration statement covering the proposed issuance of 240,584 shares of $1 par common stock of the Southern Union Gas Company, to be offered at $1.50 a share to produce $360,876, was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

ALBANY, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Fenton Ward Burnside, 21, of Johnson City, and Theodore M. De Groff, 33, of Granville, both declaring they are ministers of the Jehova's Witnesses sect, were convicted in Federal district court today of violating the Selective Service Act.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Sept. 29 -- The famed Lido Club here, mecca of pleasure hunters in more peaceful days, was officially placed in commission as a Navy receiving station for seagoing crews today at ceremonies attended by Rear Admiral Edward J. Marquart, commandant of the Third Naval District, and other ranking Navy officers.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29 -- Amid a festive atmosphere not unlike New York's last gay New Year's Eve for the duration, major league baseball stood poised tonight to go all out in making what may prove its last wartime world series a smashing success.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday that his men had arrested 645 persons on various gambling charges in forty-eight hours after Mayor La Guardia threatened, in a talk to high police officials at Police Headquarters last Friday, to "clean them up if they did not clean up gambling."

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 29 (AP) -- United States Army Air Force bombers with fighter escort made two attacks yesterday on Japanese installations in Wanting and Tengyueh, in southwest Yunnan Province, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- The principal railway of Madagascar and the last important port on the southwest coast are in British hands, according to a communique issued by the East African headquarters today.

Whether sail yachting should be carried on during the Winter or not was decided last night at a meeting of the owners of Class B dinghies, held in the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street. With a record presented over the Summer of those who have learned wind and tide with the operation of boats, and who are serving in the Navy or Coast Guard, it was decided to carry on.

In the first two days of a campaign to obtain typewriters needed for the Army and Navy from business houses in New York, agents of the War Production Board have obtained offers of 2,300 machines, it was announced last night. About 75,000 are needed.

The Maternity Center Association, of which Mrs. Shepard Krech is president, has chosen for its annual benefit theatre party the performance of "Count Me In!" the new musical comedy starring Charles Butterworth and Luella Gear, on the night of Oct. 13 at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Sept. 29 -- Frank Knox, United States Secretary of Navy, arrived here this afternoon after a flight from Natal in a Navy bomber. He was met by Brazilian and American naval and military authorities. A naval unit dressed in red tunics, white trousers and white helmets presented arms, and a band played the American anthem.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

" Strip for Action," a new comedy from the typewriters of Howard Lindsay and Russel McKinley Crouse, opens tonight at the National under the sponsorship of the authors and Oscar Serlin, the same trio who were responsible for "Life With Father."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Government economists told Senators today that it would be better to provide for the orderly wartime liquidation of many small wholesale and retail businesses than to permit them to continue "profitless competition."

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 29 -- On the basis of evidence now at hand, the American Institute of Public Opinion expects a national turnout of approximately 30,000,000 voters in the coming Congressional elections.

ALASKA DEFENSE COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Sept. 28 (Delayed) (UP) -- United States and Canadian airmen, in their first joint attack on the Aleutians, blasted Japanese planes, submarines and cargo ships in Kiska Harbor last Friday without losing a plane, it was revealed today.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- For carrying Henry Cotton, golfer and Royal Air Force member, 175 miles each way between Berkhamsted and Leeds, thus violating the gasoline rationing regulations, Frank Denham, a taxi driver of Bramley, was fined 40 today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Sept. 29 (Reuter) -- Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's troops, trying to relieve Stalingrad from the north, were reported from Moscow tonight to have reached the Don below Kachalino, one of the Germans' main bridgeheads over the river.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 29 -- Miss Grace Amory of Cedar Creek and Miss Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches, won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's best-ball tournament over the Cherry Valley course today with a 41, 37 -- 78.

Connecticut duck hunters have been advised that they must secure a special waterfowl permit if they plan to spend any shooting days on their side of Long Island Sound. Although these permits are not required by New Yorkers across the water on Long Island, Connecticut has been divided into three zones in which hunters must apply for these cards.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Orders for the pooling of petroleum supplies and terminal facilities of companies serving the Atlantic seaboard were issued today by Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator, as a means of increasing oil deliveries.

Methods and materials developed during wartime "will have a profound influence upon the physical aspect of the post-war world," Dr. Leopold Arnaud, dean of the School of Architecture of Columbia University, predicts in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, for the year ended June, 1942, made public yesterday.
RENO, Nev., Sept. 29 -- Harrison Tweed, New York lawyer, filed suit for divorce today from Mrs. Blanche Oelrichs Tweed, poet and playwright, whose pen name is Michael Strange. The charge was cruelty.

As the pace of war spending mounts the Treasury's financing problem mounts with it. From the level of $2,000,000,000 last January expenditures have been stepped up to $5,000,000,000 this month and should reach $6,000,000,000 a month by the year's end.

That any woman with a pre-war corset under lock and key in her bureau drawer is going to be the envy of the surrounding countryside is incontestable. The corset manufacturers, however, have done their best this season, and the results, now in the New York stores, are admirable, considering the difficulties under which they were produced.

Knowledge that the man she had planned to marry already had a wife and child was too much for Mrs. Bernice T. Rose, 27 years old, who was found dead in her bed yesterday morning at the Prince George Hotel, 14 East Twenty-eighth Street, with several empty bottles of sleeping tablets lying near-by.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Urging that the government train all British men in the use of arms, Lord Mottistone in the House of Lords today contended that there were millions in Great Britain who did not know it was their duty to attack the enemy if he attempted any invasion and to obey the commands of the military.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- War production in the United States lagged in August some 14 per cent behind the forecasts and "unheard of efforts" will be necessary to push the production curve for the final quarter of 1942 as high as it must go, Donald Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, asserted today in his third formal report.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 29 (AP) -- The United Nations "have not overcome the ideas of the antidemocratic propagandists which threaten to destroy the American dream," the State Congress of Parents and Teachers was warned tonight.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 29 -- Divorce legislation, patterned after English law, was recommended by a select committee reporting to the Assembly today, with divorce grounds cited as adultery, desertion for at least three years, persistent cruelty and insanity.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Rhode Island Republicans, through their convention keynoter, Fred B. Perkins, called today for a unified command of the United Nations military forces and demanded that "the United Nations become a fact and not a lyric phrase."

The Norges Bank, the central bank of Norway, which moved its head office to London at the time of the German invasion of Norway in the Spring of 1940, announced here yesterday the appointment of Hallvard Hillestad as its representative in New York for the United States, Canada and certain Central and South American countries.
MOSCOW, Sept. 30 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

FT. BELVOIR, Va., Sept. 30 (U.P.) -- Bellowing field commanders are obsolete in America's modern army, Lieut. Gen. Lesley J. McNair, commanding general of the Army ground forces, told 440 graduates of the Engineer Officer Candidate School here today.

Although the volume of trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month increased to the second largest of the year, or since January, the total was the smallest for a corresponding month in twenty-four years, or since 1918.
Following is the text of Reichsfuehrer Hitler's address in Berlin yesterday, as recorded and translated by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Problems and achievements were the keynotes of the discussions yesterday at the all-day meeting of the Regional Institute of the Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress, held in the Hotel Lincoln, Eighth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street.

A new section of northern Stalingrad has been taken by storm, the German High Command reported yesterday. The communique, quoted in Berlin broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press, said the Russians lost thirty-four tanks "in the course of unsuccessful relief attacks."

I have just sent a letter to Mayor La Guardia concerning the danger which inheres in the regular sounding of sirens at noon on Saturdays. It is my contention that if Hitler or Hirohito were planning an air raid they could catch the entire city unawares and with its entire defense set-up down by merely scheduling it for Saturday at noon when the sirens mean nothing but a weekly exercise.
An apartment building in the Yorkville section, a private home in Eighty-second Street, and tenement houses on the lower East Side have just passed into new ownerships.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Unless the House stands by its high new parity formula for fixing farm prices, the President will soon have a direction from Congress to set ceilings on agricultural products and to stabilize wages and salaries as barriers to runaway war inflation.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- An investigation of railway passenger and freight rates was begun by a Federal grand jury in Chicago today as similar inquiries were opened by Federal juries in eight other cities. The Chicago jurors, who heard representatives of seven railroads and the Illinois Freight Association, have been directed to inquire into the possibility of collusive practices in determining charges for transporting various classes of freight, according to Federal authorities.

Opinions about the second front are bound to be influenced by the question whether one is thinking of a second front to save Stalingrad or a second front to save Russia. It may well be that a second front in the West is justified if the object is to stop the Germans in their present advance, at any cost.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 30 -- Adolf Hitler, in a seventy-minute address to the nation from the Berlin Sportpalast on the occasion of the opening of the tenth Winter help collection, told the world today that he would take Stalingrad and that for the coming year he had a "simple program," as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The August level of employment in non-agricultural establishments was 37,789,000, exceeding all previous levels, it was announced today by Secretary Perkins. This figure was 2,332,000 above that of August, 1941, and 555,000 greater than in July, 1942.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 30 (AP) -- A prediction that John J. Bennett Jr. will be elected Governor of New York "beyond a shadow of doubt and in a very substantial manner" came today from James A. Farley, State Democratic chairman.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 30 -- Wide publicity is given here to an advertisement printed Monday in THE NEW YORK TIMES, urging that President Roosevelt and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek "use their good offices" to bring Indian and British leaders together for further discussions.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Oct. 1 -Doubling their tank strength by bringing a fresh division into the northwestern regions of Stalingrad that they seized last Sunday, the Germans resumed their advance in the city yesterday after having been stemmed for sixty hours.

CHUNGKING, China, Sept. 30 -- A tempest in a rice bowl is being raised by irate women functionaries over the recent adoption by the Supreme National Defense Council of a ruling governing rice allowances for government employes.

Apparel will probably play a more important part than ever before in the pre-holiday selling, according to the consensus of ready-to-wear merchandise executives obtained in a survey by the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board, it was announced yesterday by F. Nathan Wolf, executive secretary.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Sept. 30 -- Trim and military in their new gold-braided blue uniforms, the first women officers of the United States Navy were graduated from the Smith College Training School of the Waves this morning following a brief review on the green in front of Faunce Hall on the college campus.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y. Sept. 30 -- The Palisades Interstate Park Commission has purchased 541 acres of land near the northern tip of the park for development after the war as a recreational area, according to announcement made here today by A.K. Morgan, chief engineer and general manager of the commission.
SALEM, N.H., Sept. 30 (AP) -- John R. Macomber's Side Arm, the 3-5 favorite, won the Munroe Memorial Handicap by a length and a quarter today at Rockingham Park. The time was 1:46.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Senate, after eight days of bitter controversy over farm group demands and with both sides yielding to a cross-fire of compromises, adopted its anti-inflation bill by a vote of 80 to 0 tonight, just five hours before the deadline of Oct. 1 set by President Roosevelt twenty-three days ago.

The New York City contribution to the nation-wide drive to obtain 75,000 typewriters needed in the armed forces yesterday topped 3,000 machines, according to a statement by H.M. Brundage, WPB regional deputy director in charge of the drive.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Wendell Willkie's call for a second front was attacked in the House today by Representative Rankin, Democrat, of Mississippi, and Representative Hoffman, Republican, of Michigan. Each tried to hand over the former Republican Presidential candidate to the other's party.

Cotton textile production will set a new all-time production record of approximately 12,500,000,000 square yards during 1942, it was predicted here yesterday by the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York. Such volume, according to W. Ray Bell, president, would exceed by more than 1,000,000,000 square yards the War Production Board's estimate for last year of 11,328,000,000, and is 4,000,000,000 square yards more than the average annual pre-war output from 1935 to 1939 inclusive.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 -- Three hat manufacturing concerns and eighteen of their officers and other individuals were fined $23,000 in the Federal District Court here today following pleas of nolo contendere to charges of conspiracy with a labor union to bid collusively for contracts for the manufacture of Army field hats.

Negotiations on the union's request for wage readjustments affecting 20,000 employes in 125 hotels in this city will begin this morning at the Hotel Chelsea, 222 West Twenty-third Street, between representatives of the Hotel Association of New York and the New York Hotel Trades Council, A.F. of L.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- A prediction made last night by Frank E. Gannett, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee, that the Republican party would win control of the House in the November elections was countered today by Representative Johnson of Oklahoma with this statement:

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 -- The Army and Navy production "E" pennant was hoisted today at the Inglewood plant of North American Aviation, Inc., in the presence of military and plant officials and thousands of workers.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 30 -- The theft of 252 C gasoline ration books from a shipment consigned to the Newark Rationing Board was disclosed here today by the police as they continued their investigation into the activities of a ring under arrest on charges of disposing of thousands of stolen gasoline coupons.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- The wheat market made an immediate response today to the announcement that the Senate had adopted a compromise agreement as to the formula to be used in determining the parity price on agricultural products.

A spokesman for the Quarter-master Depot in Philadelphia reported last night that the invitations for bids on 8,000,000 cotton khaki shirts were oversubscribed. An unofficial check made before the bids could be analyzed indicated that the depot was assured of its requirements.

NOW General Somervell tells us that we have lost everything except our complacency. Last week the Assistant Secretary of the Navy announced that we are losing the war and chastised the American people for their smugness. Similar statements have come from other Army, Navy and government heads obviously okayed by the Office of War Information or whatever agency must approve such statements from officials.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- The time is past when the British Foreign Office issued comments on Adolf Hitler's speeches. None was forthcoming tonight, but the general impression of observers here was that Herr Hitler was showing more concern over the home front than usual, with his forensics against reactionaries and saboteurs and his reminders to civilians that however hard their lot that of the soldier is harder.

W.L. Hemingway, president of the Mercantile-Commerce Bank and Trust Company of St. Louis, was elected yesterday president of the American Bankers Association by its executive council at the concluding session of a two-day meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

ALBANY, Sept. 30 -- The Board of Regents has moved to increase the scope and quality of the program of physical training and education in the public schools of the State in line with war physical training needs, it was announced today by Commissioner Stoddard.

What was described as the first effort on the part of any industry to provide immediate emergency relief to families of employes enrolled in the armed services has been launched by the dress industry of this city under the direction of the American Council of Dress Manufacturers, Inc., headed by Sidney Vlock.

The last pillar of the Second Avenue Elevated structure was taken from the street bed at Fifty-fourth Street and trucked away at sundown last evening, as a crowd stood by and Edgar J. Nathan, Borough President of Manhattan, gave the signal from the platform of a crane.

Disappearance of consumer's goods from retail and wholesale shelves will be more and more obvious from now on, as the tempo of the war program increases, according to the monthly survey of business in the October issue of the magazine Banking, official publication of the American Bankers Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Following is the vote by which the Senate adopted a compromise amendment directing that price ceilings on farm products shall reflect increases in labor and other costs since Jan. 1, 1941:

Estimating that government war expenditures in September were approximately $5,400,000,000, equivalent to an annual rate of nearly $65,000,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York points out in its monthly review, issued yesterday, that the annual figure is within striking distance of the $67,000,000,000 rate forecast for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1943, in the revised budget estimates presented last April.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Treasury is expected to ask Congress soon for authorization to mint any new denomination of coin, under the value of $1, which wartime developments may make necessary. Included in the same legislation would be authorization for the substitution of non-critical materials for copper, nickel, zinc or tin in the composition of the proposed new coins and possibly some existing ones.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 30 -- Lieutenant John M. Gabriel is Mayor of Garfield, regardless of his Army duties, according to a ruling in Trenton today by Supreme Court Justice Joseph L. Bodine. Ordering the name of Councilman John Frank Jr. stricken from the Nov. 3 ballots as an uncontested candidate for Mayor, Justice Bodine declared no vacancy exists for the office of Mayor.

Four men, arrested in an investigation of an estimated $200,000 in thefts of jewelry and other articles from the Railway Express Agency terminal in Long Island City, were brought to Police Headquarters last night and booked on charges of grand larceny.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- A bill providing for post-war construction of a 25,000-mile nationwide network of military superhighways at a cost of $10,000,000,000 was introduced in the House today by Representative Wene of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Despite the protest of the Office of Price Administration, the Interstate Commerce Commission refused late today to suspend its order on Aug. 1 allowing the petition of Southern Railroads to increase their basic fares in coaches from 1.65 cents a mile to the uniform fare of 2.2 cents in coaches now in effect in other parts of the country.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Mrs. Gilbert Cooper gave a luncheon yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for Mrs. Vernam Foster, Mrs. Arthur C. Payne, Mrs. Edward Spelthoff and Mrs. William W. Willock Jr. A luncheon was given there by Mrs. Henry P. Kraft for Mrs. J. Thomas Russell and the Misses Edna and Dorothy Kraft.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's midnight communique:

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30 -- There was nothing disappointing or disillusioning today about the opening of the first world series held at Sportsman's Park in eight years, the first war-time series in twenty-four years -- unless it was the Cardinals.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sept. 30 -- That the Axis powers are prisoners of their success is the conclusion drawn by foreign observers analyzing Adolf Hitler's address. At this time last year the Reichsfuehrer's theme was "wait until we launch our Spring offensive"; today his military aims are to hold what he thinks should be held and to attack only when there is absolute necessity.

Bonds called before maturity for payment in September totaled $28,761,000, the smallest amount for any month since May, 1938, when the total was $25,083,000, and the smallest total for any September since 1933, when $25,794,000 was retired.

LONDON, Sept. 30 (U.P.) -- Private advices reaching London today said Alois Gruber, assistant chief of the German Elite Guard in Czechoslovakia, has been killed in a clash with "underground agents." No other details were available, though the Germans were said to have admitted Gruber's death while fighting "enemies of the Reich in the protectorate."

The battle between the farm bloc and the Administration is farcical because the parity reduction sought by the President is too small to have much effect either way. Parity prices today are not pegged to any period but are fluid, free to ascend with industrial costs and wages, thus irrevocably but logically contributing to the certain inflationary spiral.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 30 -- Despite the lull in major fighting on the Western Desert front, weeks of rearming and reinforcing since the latest German thrust have worked a profound change in the psychology of the Allied forces. The men of the British Eighth Army, the Royal Air Force and the United States Army Air Forces are no longer thinking defensively.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- A great new wave of sabotage and opposition to German domination, encouraged by an "underground" chain of newspapers, is sweeping Belgium, according to information just received here by the exiled Belgian Government.

The Turkish people favor the cause of the United Nations but will defend their liberty against "any aggression," the spokesman for a visiting group of five Turkish journalists said yesterday on their arrival aboard a Pan American Airways Clipper at La Guardia Field.

The concerted gasp of a courtroom audience brought a man, accustomed to the snappy ceremonials of German-American Bund meetings, back to reality yesterday. Lowering his hand quickly from the Nazi salute he had given automatically when asked to raise his hand, he woke up to the fact that he was a witness at the trial in Federal court of twenty-five former Bund leaders accused of conspiracy to foment resistance to the Selective Service Act.

Samuel Levy former borough president of Manhattan, has purchased as a long-range investment the property at the northwest corner of Sixth Avenue and Fifty-sixth Street, a plot of about 12,000 square feet improved with six two-story and four-story buildings. The deal was negotiated through Horace S. Ely Co. and Nathan Miller.

The City of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, has remitted to its special agents here funds for the payment of interest for the six months ended on Oct. 1, 1940, on its five-year 6 per cent external gold bonds, due April 1, 1933, at the rate of $4.1925 for each $1,000 bond.

The old Dwight mansion at 123d Street and Fifth Avenue will be opened as a music center for Harlem children if the city accepts the gift of the property from the owners, Justice Stephen S. Jackson of the Children's Court and director of the Juvenile Welfare Council announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Colonel R. Ernest Dupuy, former chief of the planning and liaison branch of the War Department Bureau of Public Relations, became chief of the news division tonight with completion of reorganization of the publicity set-up in the department here.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 29 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- Turkey, principal source of chrome for American and British war industries, has contracted to send 45,000 tons to the Krupp Armament Company in exchange for German arms, it was reported authoritatively today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Oct. 1. -- The capture by Allied forces of Naoro, a jungle hamlet in the Owen Stanley Mountains, and a continued advance northward across New Guinea were reported officially today. The head quarters communique said that the Japanese were retiring ahead of the Allied advance and that, as a result, no contact had been made with the main body of enemy troops.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society has sold the eighteen-story loft building at 147 West Thirty-fifth Street, on a plot 66.8 by 98.9 feet, between Broadway and Seventh Avenue, to the Kaufman-Thirty-fifth Street Corporation, headed by Samuel Kaufman. Michael E. Lipset Co. were the brokers.

A LONG time ago Hamilton Basso wrote a sunny novel called "Cinnamon Seed" about the scene of his youth in Louisiana. Later books by Mr. Basso have had their good qualities, but none of them seemed effortless and joyful in comparison to his first. The thinking that went into them sometimes showed in the structure; the characters occasionally pointed the moral a little too strongly to adorn the tale.

AT SEA OFF THE SOLOMON ISLANDS, Sept. 15 (delayed) -- Twenty-six-year-old Captain Marion E. Carl of Hubbard, Ore., second-ranking marine ace on Guadalcanal, returned to his base yesterday after having been missing five days.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The subcommittee of the Senate Finance Committee, which has been studying legislation proposed for the limitation of war profits, completed hearings today amid predictions that such legislation was dead for the present session.

With more than 100 friends of Yugoslavia and nationals and members of its government-in-exile present to mark the opening of a $2,000,000 relief drive, Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, ripped from the wall of the former German Railway Offices at 11 West Fifty-seventh Street yesterday afternoon a map of North Germany and replaced it with a picture of General Draja Mikhailovitch, leader of the Chetniks.

In an article entitled "What Our Navy Learned in the Pacific," Admiral Thomas C. Hart, former commander of the United States Asiatic Fleet and now a member of the Navy's General Board, says in this week's Saturday Evening Post that the United States lost two big opportunities in the early days of the war against Japan.
Apartment leasing continued brisk on the eve of the city's annual moving day, with rentals well scattered throughout Manhattan.

To the extent that we must have governmental price or wage fixing, prices and wages should be fixed, not primarily in the interests of any particular group but primarily in the interests of the whole country. This is a principle that ought to be beyond dispute.

Special skills of the financial community are to be used to help the war program according to an announcement yesterday by the New York Institute of Finance. The institute, in cooperation with the Association of Stock Exchange Firms and the New York Stock Exchange is to put on a series of military courses, open to the general public.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Recognizing that, as a surplus-producing nation, Canada is third in importance only to the United States and Great Britain, membership on the Combined Production and Resources Board is to be accorded to the Dominion.

St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church, at 127th Street and Fifth Avenue, long maintained by white pew-holders in a Harlem neighborhood, will become a free church next Sunday, encouraging all residents of the vicinity to attend its services, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Senator Taft of Ohio disagreed with Mr. Nelson's proposal for a new board on the ground that providing funds for members of a group containing 1,800,000 retailers was a "hopeless" one and that such a board would be confronted with the problem of "where to draw the line" in permitting "border line" cases to continue in business.

Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, left last midnight on his second "informal" up-State campaign trip through Genesee, Wyoming, Cattaraugus, Allegany, Steuben, Chemung, Schuyler and Tompkins Counties. He was accompanied by Joe R. Hanley, majority leader of the State Senate.

LONDON. Sept. 30 -- Viscount Simon. Lord Chancellor, assured the House of Lords today that the British Government's domestic policy was designed to preserve and develop collective bargaining machinery and to impress on employers and workers their responsibility therein both for the welfare of the State and the outcome of the war effort.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Oct. 1 (AP) -- From the Caucasus to Leningrad the Red Army offered a deep, hardened front today, and in the Kalinin sector northwest of Moscow the Soviet offensive forces continued to inch westward.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The office of Brig. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Federal Works Administrator, said today that engineering work has begun on a post-war highway building program to cost nearly $500,000,000.

Seven regular members of last season's New York Rangers of the National Hockey League have joined the Canadian or United States armed forces, President Lester Patrick announced last night, according to The Canadian Press.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Secretary Perkins gave exemption today to 1,500,000 unionized building trades workers from the ban against week-end premium pay set by President Roosevelt on Sept. 9. She also issued a sixty-clay stay to about 100,000 ship repair workers, who will adjust overtime practices in ship repair work to the terms of the President's order.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 30 -- Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr. emerged victorious today by a plurality of 52 votes in a recount that had been initiated by his opponent, Mayor William H. Williams of Belleville, N.J., for the Republican nomination in the Tenth Congressional District. Mr. Hartley's original plurality in the primary election on Sept. 15 had been 96 votes.

John S. Fleek, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, announced yesterday the principal speakers for the association's War Finance Conference to be held here on Oct. 19 and 20 at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Mr. Fleek, who is a partner of Hayden. Miller Co., of Cleveland, stated that special emphasis will be given the subject of distribution of government securities.

WASHINGTON. Sept. 30 -- Formation of a interdepartmental committee to work with the newly formed standards division of the Office of Price Administration was announced today. Dr. Faith Williams, Chief of the Cost-of-Living Division of the Department of Labor, will serve as chairman.

LONDON, Sept. 30 (U.P.) -- Responsible British quarters asserted that Adolf Hitler's speech today was probably his weakest since the war began and offered the Nazis nothing except a promise to capture Stalingrad "some time" and an unconvincing guarantee that Germany never would capitulate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The creation of a War Liabilities Adjustment Board to facilitate the use of all productive enterprises in the war effort and to assure to small business concerns the opportunity to re-enter a competitive economy after the war ends was suggested to the Senate Small Business Committee today by Donald M. Nelson, Chairman of the War Production Board.

New York's fashion dominance is now established. Caught off balance by the catastrophic collapse of France, the ranking American designers, on whom the ermine of style leadership descended, were discovered leaning comfortably against the bolster they had always known -- the Parisian couture.

VICHY, France, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The French announced tonight that the British column advancing into the south of Madagascar from Tananarive was nearing Antsirabe after having captured Ambatolampy and pushed on about thirty miles beyond.

"The Pirate," S.N. Behrman's comedy starring Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, which was due here Oct. 26, will not arrive at the Martin Beck until Wednesday, Nov. 11. The play opened at Madison. Wis., on Sept. 14, and then moved to Milwaukee for the second half of that week.

New financing for eleven local housing authorities aggregating $22,269,000 was announced yesterday for award through competitive bidding on Oct. 14. The issues range in size from $10,500,000 for the Pittsburgh Pa., Housing Authority to $40,000 for the Housing Authority of Twin Falls, Idaho.
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- The House of Commons voted 215 to 9 today to approve a second reading of a bill to prolong its life another year.

For four and one-half hours last night the rafters of Madison Square Garden shook from the applause of more than 20,000 spectators. The occasion was the Army Emergency Relief show, "We're All in It," in which entertainers from the radio, the screen and Broadway took part.

The homely white cabbage that is the Victory Food Special until Oct. 10 deserves more respect than it usually receives, for it belongs to a most distinguished family. Members of the clan, seventy in number, include broccoli and Brussels sprouts, cauliflower and kale.

Orders tying up $232,500 due to the corporate owners of railroad lines leased and operated by the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad Company were issued yesterday by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe as the government moved to collect $2,400,000 of income taxes assessed against the railroad.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Two naval transports, one of medium size and one a small converted destroyer, were lost in action in the Solomon Islands, the Navy Department announced today.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Enemy raiders, taking advantage of a cloud cover, widened their hit-run tactics over southeastern coastal districts of Great Britain today. Patrolling British fighters brought down three of them, one near the English coast, a second near Cape Griz Nez, France, and a third off the Netherlands.

New York made its contribution yesterday to the "Forty-eight State Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag and to the Constitution" in ceremonies held in the office of Council President Newbold Morris at City Hall. In the presence of Mr. Morris and officials representing New Jersey and Connecticut a star representing New York was sewn onto the blue field of an American flag that already bore stars representing Illinois, Delaware, Pennsylvania and New Jersey.

An exhibition of war paintings, "The Story of a French Soldier Told in Pictures," was opened with a pi view yesterday afternoon at the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, Inc., 451 Madison Avenue.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 30 -- The four-weeks-old strike of newspaper delivery workers that halted publication of this city's two daily and one Sunday newspapers was settled today when representatives of management and union spokesmen reached an agreement described as "mutually satisfactory."
An Army-Navy E pennant was presented yesterday to the blood donor service of the New York Red Cross Chapter at ceremonies outside the new donor center at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

Declaring that the influence of newspapers would be a dominant factor this Winter in building up scrap piles, Iron Age in its weekly review says that observers who had been lukewarm over the probable results of the national campaign to collect iron and steel scrap were being forced to take a new view of the scrap situation.

A net profit of $475,638 for the nine months ended with August was reported yesterday by the American Central Manufacturing Corporation. The company at one time was the Auburn Automobile Company. It makes a light delivery car and a variety of kitchen equipment items.

The New York Telephone Company yesterday reported that some 115,000 calls were made to its Time Bureau, MEridian 7-1212, during the first world series game and in the following hour, when time announcements carried the final score.

James B. Slimmon, vice president and secretary of the Aetna Life Insurance Company, was elected president of the Life Office Management Association at the annual meeting yesterday in the Hotel New Yorker. Edmund Fitzgerald, vice president of the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company, was elected vice president of the association.

ALBANY, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Bases of two movie projectors used by Franklin D. Roosevelt when Governor went on the curb in front of New York's Executive Mansion today as Governor Lehman instructed State departments to ransack corners of storerooms for scrap.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Sales by independent retailers increased 9 per cent in August over July, but were 2 per cent less than in August, 1941, it was announced today by J.C. Capt, director of the census.

FORCED to follow the first part of the world series at a considerable distance, this observer lent an attentive ear to what the wild air waves were saying. The Dodgers didn't get into the series but their genial Red Barber made it at the microphone. Stout fella, Red. Confident of a clear account, this listener settled back to enjoy the game.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 30 -- Leaders of Newark's scrap-collection campaign, which has so far yielded nearly 5,000 tons of metal, expressed the belief today that the city had established a national record for such a drive.

The stock market maintained yesterday an irregular course, and a creeping decline through most of the session was halted by buying in the final fifteen minutes of trading. Business showed a further contraction from the pace of last week as the closing day of September saw sales on the Stock Exchange at 341,880 shares, smallest in more than a week, against Tuesday's total of 426,830.

The Board of Economic Warfare is anxious to cooperate with private importers and there is a possibility that its arrangement, by which fats and oils traders will be permitted to handle government shipments, may be extended to other industry groups, J.B. Hutson, president of the Commodity Credit Corporation, indicated yesterday at an organization meeting of the Emergency Group for Foreign Vegetable Oils, Fats and Oil-bearing Materials at the Federal Reserve Bank auditorium, 33 Liberty Street.

Mrs. Marion duPont Scott's Caddie, lightly regarded in a field that included several topnotch steeplechasers, was the easiest sort of winner yesterday at Belmont Park of the $6,125 Brook Steeplechase Handicap at two miles and a half.

The new month will see the publishers pushing their hopefuls out into the stream at an ever-increasing rate. The following are a few of the new titles, selected from the several hundred that will make their appearance in the next few weeks:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Owners of small manufacturing plants who can prove that their establishments can help the war effort will have no difficulty in obtaining loans from the $150,000,000 fund which Congress turned over to the Smaller War Plants Corporation, according to a statement of policy issued today.

LONDON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The steadily increasing effectiveness of the Allies' anti-submarine campaign is reaching a point where pack attacks by U-boats and even bombing by shore-based planes can be coped with successfully, authoritative British sources said today.

An hour of scrimmage in which the Fordham varsity worked on defense against the scrubs, who employed Tennessee formations, featured yesterday's practice on Rose Hill. It was the last hard workout in preparation for the meeting with the Volunteers on Saturday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- A year ago Ossie Solem had the football world buzzing with his reversed center formation, designed to give greater lateral range to the quick-opening play for which the Chicago Bears and Clark Shaughnessy's 1940 Stanford eleven had created a vogue in operating to a "T."

La Marquise Chocolateur, a subsidiary of Rosemarie de Paris, formerly a leading candy manufacturer in Paris and now doing business in New York, leased from the Oceanic Investing Corporation the store at 553 Fifth Avenue through Tankoos, Smith Co., brokers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- Motor vehicle fatalities in the country in August totaled 2,310, a record-breaking reduction of 40 per cent from a high mark of 3,860 for that month recorded last year, the National Safety Council reported today.
SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Sept. 29 (Delayed) -- Things are looking much brighter hereabouts.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- A Navy communique:

The statement of Commissioner of Internal Revenue Helvering on the deductibility of advertising expense on corporate income tax returns is "of inestimable aid to business in allaying fears and permitting sound planning," Paul B. West, president of the Association of National Advertisers, declared yesterday.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue has confirmed in more official form some of the main points with respect to the position of advertising in wartime that were previously set forth in correspondence with the Association of National Advertisers. Although the new statement by Commissioner Guy T. Helvering does not go beyond what was previously indicated, it lends strength to a point that is important enough to deserve emphasizing.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 30 -- Mrs. R.M. Torgerson of Lakeville, metropolitan and Long Island champion, and Mrs. Charles Leichner of Fresh Meadow won the Women's Long Island Golf Association's best-ball tournament over the Cherry Valley course today.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- The tobacco shares were a good feature in today's stock markets on a statement by the Chancellor of the Exchequer that net receipts from tobacco duties in the three months following the imposition of higher rates were approximately 30,000,000 more than in the same period last year.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- The executive committee of the American Institute of Accountants, meeting here this afternoon as a part of the fifty-fifth annual convention of the association, went formally on record in favor of an amended renegotiation procedure on war contracts in preference to the fixed percentage of profits proposed as an alternative.

Gasoline stocks in the United States at the close of last week were 80,550,000 barrels, a decline of 332,000 from the 80,882,000 a week earlier, the American Petroleum Institute announced yesterday. A year ago, these supplies amounted to 80,005,000 barrels.

ALBANY, Sept. 30 (AP) -- In a 3-2 decision which dissenting members termed "an abuse of discretion," the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court today directed reversal of a $5,000 award won by a Bolton Landing golf caddy against William A. Julian, United States Treasurer, unless the boy agreed to accept $2,500.

Perry E. Hall, executive manager of the New York Victory Fund Committee, announced yesterday that the committee, in its campaign to help the United States Treasury sell the new series of tax-anticipation notes, had begun a drive to enlist the aid of certified public accountants.
Larger public utility and municipal financing in September raised the month's total of new securities offered here for public subscription well above the August figure.

NYACK, N.Y., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Dean Alfange, American Labor party candidate for Governor, charged tonight that the Republic Steel Corporation has brought the "brutalizing tradition of the infamous company towns" to New York State.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Labor-management committees to accelerate production have been organized at ninety-one soft-coal mines, Donald M. Nelson, chief of the War Production Board, said today.

Mrs. Ruth Miller Gootkin, 22 years old, and her father, Charles R. Miller, 50, entered not guilty pleas yesterday when arraigned in Felony Court on suspicion of abandoning the woman's 6-year-old daughter, Gertrude Louise, a week ago in the Grand Central Terminal. James D.C. Murray appeared as their lawyer.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 30 -- Robert Preston has been definitely set for the leading role in "Salute for Three," a Stage Door Canteen story being made by Paramount, the studio announced today. Production, which will get under way next week, is expected to be Preston's last, as he is awaiting induction into the Army.

"Panama Hattie," the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer film version of the Broadway musical, will open this morning at the Capitol. Red Skelton, Ann Sothern, "Rags" Ragsland, Ben Blue, Marsha Hunt, Dan Dailey Jr., Virginia O'Brien and Alan Mowbray are among the film's featured players.

As the first phase in an extended program of nursing recruitment the New York City Nursing Council for War Service, 654 Madison Avenue, will send out shortly questionnaires to all "inactive" nurses found on the last ten years' State registry lists in Albany.
MOSCOW, Sept. 30 (Reuter) -- A tremendous battle, which may prove decisive, is raging for possession of Stalingrad's factory belt in the city's northwestern suburbs.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30 -- They looked weary and solemn the Yankees who came trooping off the field at Sportsman's Park today, after having downed the Cardinals in the first game of the world series.
The cotton market was quiet yesterday with quotations moving within a thirteen-point range. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures closed 4 to 8 points higher than on Tuesday.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Oct. 1 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- A quiet investigation into the quality of American-built Army aircraft was reported authoritatively today to have left a House military subcommittee well satisfied with both the performance and protection of the planes.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- If American youth has softened and is being "mollycoddled," the chief responsibility lies with parents and schools, the State Congress of Parents and Teachers was told today by Lewis A. Froman, dean of Millard Fillmore College, University of Buffalo.

An employer who makes restitution to his employes for overtime wages they should have received earlier cannot cite such restitution as a claim for exemption from liability for damages to which the workers are entitled under Section 16(b) of the Fair Labor Standards Act, Federal Judge Edward A. Conger held yesterday.
A recent letter in THE TIMES needs some refutation. The point at issue is the new stress laid on the social sciences in our high schools.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30 (U.P.) -- President Sam Breadon of the Cardinals announced tonight that Billy Southworth, who piloted the club to its first National League pennant in eight years, had signed a contract to manage the Cards in 1943.

Fuel oil rationing became effective officially today in New York and twenty-nine other States under orders from the War Production Board even though all details of eligibility and allowances have not yet been officially announced nor ration coupons distributed.

United Artists will deliver thirty feature films, including six "Hop along Cassidy" Westerns and eight "streamlined" Hal Roach comedies, to theatres during the 1942-43 season, Gradwell L. Sears, vice president in charge of distribution, announced at the company's sales convention at the Blackstone Hotel in Chicago.

A Japanese "student" who has been in this country since 1930 and was currently engaged in reading Hitler's "Mein Kampf" was among nineteen persons rounded up by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on Tuesday, it was announced yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration accused twenty-five concerns today of violating Federal price ceilings on steel, and obtained a temporary injunction.

Sixty-nine seamen, most of them Lascars, are believed to have lost their lives in the sinking of a medium-sized United Nations vessel that was announced yesterday by the Navy Department. Thirty-five men are known to have been killed when two torpedoes crashed into the ship in the South Atlantic early in August, while thirty-four others are missing.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Volarion, owned by L.E. Greer and driven by J.F. Cartnall, both of Newark, Ohio, won the forty-sixth trotting of the Walnut Hall Cup today at the opening of the Lexington meeting, last of the Grand Circuit season.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 30 (U.P.) -- British medium bomber planes have attacked an Italian merchant ship in the Ionian Sea, damaging it so badly that it had to be beached, and British torpedo planes have scored a direct hit amidships of an enemy destroyer off Cape Spartivento, Italy, it was announced today.

While labor conditions in the shipbuilding industry are "essentially sound," the pirating of workers among the shipyards, an increasing turnover rate, and absenteeism are trends that must be checked to prevent confusion rising as a manpower shortage approaches, Paul R. Porter, chairman of the War Production Board shipbuilding stabilization committee, declared yesterday.

LAUREL, Md., Sept. 30 -- H.P. Metcalf's Star Copy, a 3-year-old daughter of Trae Call, drove to a length-and-a-half victory in the Salem Purse today. Placed under pressure in midstretch, Star Copy answered Ferril Zufelt's urging to dispose of Christopher T. Chenery's Coosa.

The Schenley Distillers Corporation has recently acquired a new plant in Arizona and is obtaining another distillery in Montana, and both will be added to the list of twelve plants now producing alcohol for war needs, Lewis S. Rosentiel, chairman, announced yesterday following a meeting of the organization's board of directors.

The American people have been warned frequently of late that their complacency is losing the war. They have been sternly reminded that so far they have won no victories, and in the large sense it is true. But if this implies that Herr Hitler is winning, apparently he gets little comfort out of his successes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- For the first time in the experience of the War Production Board raw material authorizations for both military and civilian production have been balanced in advance against the estimated supply of materials, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the WPB, said today.

The Utah Power and Light Company, a unit in the Electric Bond and Share Company system, is expected to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission in the next week or so a comprehensive plan of recapitalization. The major aim of the plan will be to effect a refunding of the company's outstanding debt, approximately $45,000,000 of which falls due in 1944.
CAIRO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- A joint British Headquarters-Royal Air Force communique:

The Andrew Furuseth Club, the first clubhouse for seafarers opened by the United Seamen's Service, Inc., was dedicated yesterday afternoon at 30 East Thirty-seventh Street in the presence of several hundred seamen, shipping men and city and Federal officials.
According to reports from Maine, where the waterfowl season opened last Saturday, duck hunters have been scoring heavily.

A concentrated effort to bring out a large number of up-State women for registration for the November elections was the first job taken on by members of the women's Democratic campaign committee yesterday as they formally opened their headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore.

With a last-minute surge of bond buying as September drew to a close, the nation appeared last night to have filled the Treasury Department's monthly war bond sales quota for the first time in five months, the War Activities Committee of the Motion Picture Industry announced.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- Dr. Howard Pillsbury, superintendent of schools in Schenectady, told the State Congress of Parents and Teachers today that morale was "three times as valuable in war as material," and asserted that education was the most valuable factor in creating this morale.

Associate Justice Felix Frankfurter of the United States Supreme Court, in an address here yesterday, said the day was not far off when our economic problems could be solved and then relegated to "a back seat" so that the world might turn its attention to "real problems -- the problems of life and of human relations, of creation and behavior and religion."
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30 -- The play-by-play description of the first game of the world series at Sportsman's Park today follows:

OTTAWA, Sept. 30 -- It was officially announced today that compulsory military service had been extended to include youths of 19 and to make liable for service every male of military age of any other than enemy nationality. Until now only British subjects had been liable to call-up in Canada.

Mismanagement will be the keyword of the coming campaign, Representative Joseph C. Baldwin told members of the New York Young Republican Club and the Young Women's Republican Club of New York, Inc., last night at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street.

Mobilization and training of enough additional women workers to halt the high and rising labor turnover in industry, which is becoming a serious production problem. was urged yesterday in a report by the National Industrial Conference Board.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Hundreds of cargo planes are being built to swell the air fleets, already performing a "modern miracle of transportation" in carrying men and materials to far-flung battle fronts, the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America said tonight in a statement.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The United States Government is rushing a supply of newly engraved Brazilian banknotes here by plane to help overcome the currency shortage, which was one of the reasons for the eight-day bank holiday decreed late last night.
Mayor La Guardia's anti-gambling crusade was lauded by Magistrate Morris Rothenberg in the Bronx yesterday as he fined a housewife $100 and held a widow in $500 bail on gambling charges.

Salvage campaigns are under way in about 15,000 of the 26,000 industrial plants of New York City and are beginning to produce substantial quantities of scrap metal and other reclaimable materials needed desperately to provide the equipment and munitions required to win the war, the Greater New York Industrial Salvage Committee, headed by Rolland J. Hamilton, disclosed last night.

RARITAN TOWNSHIP, N.J., Sept. 30 (AP) -Thirteen-year-old Kenneth Reed died tonight of bullet wounds which Police Chief Charles Grandjean said were inflicted by his brother, Dennis, 10, with a small-caliber rifle at their home in New Dover Road.

LONDON, Sept. 30 (U.P.) -- In connection with the problem of opening an offensive front while holding half a dozen other fronts around the world against Axis attack, strong support for a new drive in Egypt has developed. Observers point out that a threat to General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's hold on North Africa would bring Axis reinforcements rushing there from Russia and probably from Western Europe as well.

New York and other East Coast cities need a unified system of air raid warnings, which is now lacking, and "more and more and more" drilling of the protective forces to obtain the precision of operation which is necessary for maximum safety, James M. Landis, national director of the Office of Civilian Defense, said yesterday.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 30 -- War activities of the Daughters of the American Revolution were outlined by Mrs. William H. Pouch of New York City, president general, at the opening of the annual State meeting here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept 30 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads estimated today that operating revenues of Class I railroads in August totaled $683,806,778, compared with $493,674,008 in August last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Retailers gathered here for a two-day discussion of ways and means for eliminating peacetime "frills" from the services which stores offer consumers for the duration, turned over a list of detailed proposals for the consideration of the Office of Price Administration at the close of the sessions tonight.

Assurances that Brazil will continue its cooperation with the United Nations in the conduct of the war against the Axis powers were given yesterday by representatives of that government at a luncheon held under the auspices of the American Brazilian Association in the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-fourth Street.

Referring to reports that 300,000 retailers will close their doors next year, Lew Hahn, general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, declared yesterday at Washington, in interesting itself in retailers' wartime problems, "is unfortunately taking an undertaker's attitude."

The National Association of Manufacturers issued a statement yesterday challenging the assertion of William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, in an address before the American Management Association here Tuesday that a recent pamphlet published by the N.A.M. had exaggerated the number and importance of strikes in war industries.

TORONTO, Sept. 30 -- Rear Admiral Ben Moreell, chief of the United States Bureau of Yards and Docks, told American labor leaders today that although the people cannot live without labor they can live without labor unions and "they will damn well live without them here if all of us don't get in there and pitch."

Arraignment in Magistrates Court yesterday of twelve alleged violators of the Multiple Dwelling Fireproofing Law was said to indicate that the lives of hundreds of thousands of persons living in converted private residences in this city were in peril from fire hazards because of Federal priorities on materials needed by contractors to comply with the law.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The White Sox' mastery over the Cubs in Chicago city series competition continued today in the opening game of the 1942 meeting as Ted Lyons hurled the American League team to a 3-to-0 victory.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill officially announced in the House of Commons today that the United Nations losses at Dieppe were "very heavy and went up to nearly half the total force," although their air support was "faultless."

Arraignment in Magistrates Court yesterday of twelve alleged violators of the Multiple Dwelling Fireproofing Law was said to indicate that the lives of hundreds of thousands of persons living in converted private residences in this city were in peril from fire hazards because of Federal priorities on materials needed by contractors to comply with the law.

John P. Bowditch was elected president of the Sportsmanship Brotherhood yesterday to succeed the late Devereaux Milburn at a directors' meeting at the Hotel McAlpin. Mr. Bowditch is vice president and secretary of the Delaware Steeplechase and Racing Association of Wilmington, Del.

Crisp as white sails is the swagger hat of the enlisted Waves' uniform -- its main distinction from the officers' uniform also designed by Mainbocher. At a press preview yesterday in Third Naval District headquarters at 90 Church Street, a blonde, blue-eyed model exhibited the jaunty enlisted women's outfit, and launched ripples of applause.

A series of important steps to obtain food priorities for industrial workers on the home front, analogous to Army rationing, will be taken by the New York State Department of Labor next week, it was announced yesterday by Commissioner Frieda S. Miller.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- In banning recorded or "canned" music, James C. Petrillo and his American Federation of Musicians seek to determine what music the public should and should not hear, the government charged today in its anti-trust suit against the union leader and his organization.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 1 -- Walter Wanger today announced that his next film at Universal, to follow "We've Never Been Licked," will be a dramatization of the Women's Auxiliary Ferrying Squadron, tentatively titled "The W.A.F.S."

PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Oct. 1 -- The 24-year-old George F. Elliott was the only transport sunk of the original invasion fleet that captured the Southern Solomon Islands in the first United Nations South Pacific offensive, it is possible to reveal today.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 1 -- Colonel Henry B. Barry, commandant of the Army's quartermaster depot, here, announced today that construction work on a new quartermaster depot at Somerville, N.J. was "rapidly nearing completion."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- President Roosevelt looked the same when he received the newspaper correspondents late today to give them a report of his transcontinental tour as when he left the capital two weeks ago tonight.
Louise Barnes Gallagher, an outstanding American designer, and Jeanne Tete, milliner, presented a joint fashion show of costumes and hats at luncheon yesterday in the Persian Room of the Hotel Plaza.

At a meeting of the Metropolitan Opera Guild yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Pierre, Lucrezia Bori, chairman, announced that Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, Mrs. Albert Leeds Stillman of Plainfield, N.J., and Mrs. R. Eugene Burger, had been elected to the board of directors.

One industry which will sharply increase its advertising expenditures in 1943 is the hearing aid field, which has attracted a number of new manufacturers and intends to promote its products more vigorously because they are practically priority-proof. In the past, hearing aids have been marketed on a restricted, specialty basis, but in the future they will be promoted aggressively.

Leases of large apartments in buildings on Fifth and Park Avenues featured renting activity in the city yesterday. An entire floor consisting of twelve rooms and four baths in 635 Park Avenue was taken by Lieut. Alfred Harrison, U.S. Navy, through Douglas L. Elliman Co.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 1 -- With Newark's refuse collection halted by a strike of employes in the Department of Public Works, Theodore Miller, Deputy Director of the Division, asserted this evening that if the walk-out continued he would start hiring replacements tomorrow morning and provide them with police guards.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- A vivacious 20-year-old French girl who has just reached Britain after a daring trip from the Channel island of Guernsey in a nine-foot fishing boat added a fresh chapter today to the steadily lengthening saga of those who have made heroic escapes from German captors to join the struggle against the Axis powers.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 1 (AP) -- President Ramon S. Castillo informed the Chamber of Deputies tonight that he would "take note" of its recommendation that Argentina break relations with the Axis, but he indicated he would do nothing about it at this time.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Blighted city areas offer a challenge to public bodies, investment groups, the building industry and others, second only to the successful prosecution of the war itself, it was charged today in a statement read at the conference on wartime mortgage finance of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America.

The four-story store and loft building at 989 Eighth Avenue, at the southwest corner of Fifty-eighth Street, has been sold by the Ben-Dor Realty Company to an investor through the office of Huberth Huberth. The plot is 25 by 100 feet and the property is assessed at $190,000.

The sale of war bonds in New York State under the Treasury Department's September program has reached a total of more than $130,000,000 or $5,000,000 above the State goal for the month, Richard C. Patterson Jr., chairman of the New York War Savings Staff, announced last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Failure of Congress to modernize its procedures and to equip itself with expert advisory staffs are the reasons why it is in low repute with the people, Representative Dirksen of Illinois told the House today.

MOSCOW, Oct. 1 -- The Russians reported slight German gains in the most critical Stalingrad sectors today, but success in their counter-attacks south and southwest of the city. Between the Don and the Volga, on the Germans' left flank, the Red Army continues to force the enemy gradually southward.

VICHY, Oct. 1 (U.P.) -- The Paris press today saw a threat of American aggression in reports of the arrival of United States troops in de Gaulle-controlled Gabon, the Belgian Congo, the Gold Coast, Liberia and British Nigeria.

ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Maybe the Cornell coaches are color blind, but they maintain that the Big Red team is an astigmatic misnomer. As they see it, it should be known as the Big Green (meaning no offense to Dartmouth), and they don't think it is as big in the line as it ought to be.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The men of the Navy "are fighting only as free men fight," and "we are seeing the fruits of that determination," Secretary Knox, who is on a tour of South America, said today in a statement issued by the Navy Department in anticipation of the celebration of Navy Day on Oct. 27.
Frederick E. Halser, president of the New York State Chamber of Commerce, announced yesterday that the following New York banks had been elected as corporate members of the chamber:

Dr. George Wittkowsky, an English instructor at City College since 1936, was found dead yesterday morning in the headquarters of Sector 3. Air Raid Warden Service, 119 Washington Place, where he had reported the previous evening for all-night duty. He was found lying face down on the floor: a broken rope, the other end of which was dangling from a pipe on the ceiling, was around his neck.

Bank clearings of $7,934,443,000 for the week ended on Wednesday were slightly under those of the previous week's record volume for the year, but were 16.4 per cent above the $6,814,086,000 recorded in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the report yesterday of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- An unofficial recapitulation of war appropriations since Pearl Harbor showed today that the total will reach about $140,000,000,000 before the end of the first year.

Translated into the medium of fashion, an animated portrait of New York will unfold across the stage of the New York Times Hall next Tuesday and Wednesday afternoon and evening. The nuances, the sharp contrasts of the daily drama in America's greatest metropolis have been distilled into the scenes of the production, "Fashions of the Times," to capture the spirit of an era.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Sept. 28 (delayed) (AP) -- President Roose velt rode down what is perhaps the longest straight bomber assembly line in the country here today to wind up his Texas portion of a transcontinental scrutiny of America at war.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Jimmy Thornburg, sensational 17 year-old apprentice jocket from Indiana, who rode twenty-seven winners at the recent Havre de Grace meeting, was reported in a serious condition tonight at a Washington hospital as the result of injuries suffered in a four-horse spill in the third race at Laurel.

The Central Trades and Labor Council, representing about 500 member unions of the American Federation of Labor, endorsed last night the candidacy of Attorney John J. Bennett Jr. for the Governorship, after a storm meeting at which he was accused of failure to support President Roosevelt's war policies and of sympathy for Franco Sapin and anti-labor bias.

Appointment of a "czar" with over-all control of foreign trade activities during the present emergency was urged yesterday at a mass meeting of importers and exporters, sponsored by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York at the Hotel Commodore.

Ray Robinson, the Harlem welterweight who has won all thirty-five of his professional ring battles, will invade the middleweight ranks tonight when he opposes Jack La Motta of the Bronx in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden.
