Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date. Holdings of United States Government securities increased $172,223,000 during the week.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Oct. 1 -- Four regular members of the Opposition resigned from the War Administration today after their party's decision that its representatives be withdrawn because of a difference over the handling of the Waikato coal strike.

VICHY, France, Oct. 1 -- Evacuation of "surplus" European women and children from Dakar has been ordered by Governor General Pierre Boisson, it is announced in a dispatch from the French West African colony. "The Governor General has de cided to prepare methodically the evacuation of surplus women and children," the dispatch said. "The city presently is overpopulated and it is evident that the presence of families is liable to make the authorities' task harder.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- A charge that President Roosevelt's two-weeks trip to the Pacific Coast was made largely for political purposes rather than for the inspection of war projects was made on the House floor today by Representative Halleck, Republican of Indiana.

ALBANY, Oct 1 (AP) -- The State War Ballot Commission accused the War Department today of "denying" full suffrage to New York voters in overseas service by refusing to transport State ballots for the Nov. 3 election.

President Roosevelt's recent ultimatum setting the deadline for Congress to act on the anti-inflation bill, and warning that if it failed to do so he would act himself, was "the most serious assault upon the Constitution since the Civil War," Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, declared yesterday.

Albert Bein has arrived from Hollywood with plans for a Broadway production of his own new play. Last Spring, when he completed it, he called the work "The Turning Point." Now it is known as "That Greece May Live Again" and also as "Thermopylae, 1942."

Although trade interest was stirred yesterday by reports that John David, Inc., men's clothiers and furnishers, was entering the women's wear field, the organization yesterday denied any such intention. However, it was learned that clothiers in other sections of the country have been giving serious consideration to such a program.

Despite heavy buying of government securities by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in the open market to relieve the selling pressure, excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City fell $120,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, it was revealed yesterday.
New Jersey places the value of the fish and game liberated in the State for the past year at $436,453.27, while the receipts from hunting and fishing licenses amounted to $413,453.
The Big Realty Corporation has completed the assemblage of an industrial plot of 40,000 square feet on the east side of Osborn Street, 400 feet south of Newport Avenue, in Brooklyn.

Despite its logic, learning and lucidity I cannot conceive of any good end being served by the publication of Professor Laski's letter of Sept. 17. That is not to express disagreement with much of his reasoning or to cast any doubt on his sincerity or the validity of some of his conclusions.

The impossibility of sending allied merchant vessels into the Mediterranean except with the most powerful escort and the peril involved in getting through to Malta even strong convoys were outlined yesterday by Commander Anthony Kimmins of the Royal Navy, who has participated in convoy battles on the routes to Murmansk, Russia, as well as Malta.

The keenness of Mrs. Anne Castiglione, 22 years old, resulted yesterday in William Gable, 24, a robber known to the police as "the Black Cat," being remanded to the Tombs in default of $1,000 bail by Magistrate Edward C. Maguire in the Felony Court for the action of the grand jury on a burglary charge.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 1 -- First-hand testimony on the British Royal Air Force daylight raid against Oslo last Friday was brought here by an eyewitness who has arrived from the Norwegian capital. It establishes that while seven bombs hit in the target area, destroying some buildings and killing both Germans and Norwegians, no high Gestapo official appears to have been killed, nor did the Gestapo headquarters receive any more than superficial damage.

Heralded by President Roosevelt as the American people's "strong right arm in war as in peace," the free press of the United States yesterday opened its celebration of National Newspaper Week, dedicated this year to the theme that "American newspapers go all-out for victory."

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- At the halfway point of a circuit of the nation, President Roosevelt visited the San Francisco Bay area today, got a look at a submarine that had sent nine Japanese ships to the bottom of the Pacific and met a wounded Marine who killed thirty-six Japs at Tulagi.

QUINCY, Mass., Oct. 1 -- Only 108 days after its keel was laid, the destroyer Nields slid into the water from the Fore River yard of the Bethlehem Steel Company this afternoon. It marked the shortest time by two months in which a destroyer was built at the Quincy yards.

In a warning addressed to the neutral States of Europe, Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels declared yesterday that "whoever wants to have a share in the advantage of the new Europe must shoulder also a part of the sacrifices and burdens," according to a German broadcast reported by The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Senator Vandenberg of Michigan criticized in the Senate today a recent statement of Secretary Morgenthau denouncing an attempt by the Senate Finance Committee to "freeze" social security taxes at their present rates.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1 -- The National League's amazing young Cardinals put on another of their electrifying finishes today as the second game of the 1942 world series unraveled itself.
LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The British interpreted Hitler's speech of yesterday as meaning the German armies were going on the defensive to meet the threat of an Allied second front.

An answer to a complaint issued by the Federal Trade Commission was filed yesterday by Philip Morris Co., in which it denied the commission's allegations and declared that the complaint did not correctly state the substance of the company's advertising claims for its products.

" The Falcon's Brother," latest release in the RKO mystery series, will open this morning at the Palace. George Sanders again portrays the title role in the melodrama, with Jane Randolph, Tom Conway and Don Barclay in supporting roles.

BEAZLEY against Bonham, just as advertised. There is no dark deceit in this series. Old inhabitants will remember when Connie Mack kept Empty Ehmke in hiding for two weeks before the 1929 world series between the Athletics and the Cubs, warmed up Lefty Grove in plain sight for the first game and then suddenly produced a Red Hot Howard (Ehmke) from under the stands to baffle the Cubs completely.
CHICAGO, Oct 1 (AP) -- The White Sex made it two in a row in the Chicago City series today when they whipped the Cubs at Wrigley Field, 9 to 5, before a small gathering of 3,320.

WASHINGTON, Oct 1 -- President Roosevelt's order of Sept. 9 abolishing premium overtime for Saturday and Sunday work falling within the forty-hour week was reported today to be facing a breakdown as a result of the insistence of some unions that they be included within the exemption given to 1,500,000 American Federation of Labor building-trade mechanics by Secretary Perkins.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- President Roosevelt returned from an unannounced two weeks tour of war production centers and reported at a press conference that production is 94 to 95 per cent of his objectives.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct 1 -- For the last twenty-one years the county clerks of Essex County, all Republicans, have unfailingly drawn first place for their party on the general-election ballot, much to the chagrin of the Democrats, who have repeatedly voiced suspicions that they had been foiled by the black arts.

NANCY HALE'S clever short stories long have been one of the star attractions in The New Yorker. Her first full-length novel is clever too, brilliantly clever, hard, pitiless, rather clinical in its exhaustive dissection and display of human frailty and human cussedness. She calls it "The Prodigal Women"* and is prodigal herself of her own time and effort.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 1 -- The British Eighth Army broke the stalemate on the front in Egypt yesterday, routing Axis forces from positions in the center of the line south of the region of El Alamein and repulsing enemy counter attacks, it was announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- September's record of war production is subject to the same criticism as that of August, when output fell 14 per cent behind forecasts for that month, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, told reporters today. The same "spottiness" in results with which he found fault in August, he added, were apparent in September output.

It is not a net, it is not a pin -- yet it keeps your wayward tresses better disciplined than a combination of the two. Elastic-plastic is its name, and it has no bit of priority material in its make-up. Its price is 25 cents.

The first of the Cotillion Room luncheon fashion presentations at the Hotel Pierre opened with a timely theme yesterday -- furs for Winter. Gunther was the exhibitor. These are the type of coats that women will wear over their new L-85 regulated dresses and suits.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The United States has agreed through an exchange of notes to the imposing by Canada of a liability to compulsory military service on United States citizens living in Canada.

Two investigations centered on the activities of George L. Fecke, involving the promotion of a series of organizations the most prominent of which was the proposed Park Avenue Canteen for service men, were under way yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- For the first time since it was created last January the War Labor Board today disapproved a wage increase negotiated by employers and employes in the normal collective bargaining procedure.

It would be no great exaggeration to say that during the last few days 100,000,000 Americans have been keeping a secret from the other 30,000,000. This secret was knowledge of the fact that the President was traveling somewhere in the Far West and the Middle West, visiting war factories, shipyards and Army and Navy bases.

MOSCOW, Oct. 1 -- The killing of 1,860 Germans by five Russian snipers in two months was reported here yesterday. Today the role of snipers in Stalingrad is stressed and the latest Soviet news reels contains close-up shots of Germans pinked off by an Asiatic sniper on the northwestern front.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- After applauding a message in which Prime Minister Winston Churchill emphasized the importance of postwar planning now, the Central Council of the National Union of Conservative Unionist Associations decided at a meeting in Caxton Hall today to hold the party conference next March for the first time since 1937.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 1 (U.P.) -- A Negro American soldier was stabbed to death and a white American soldier suffered serious gunshot wounds last night when United States military police had to use force to break up a brawl outside a pub in the village of Antrim, it was revealed today.

A college president these days must have almost as much sense of responsibility as a general commanding a division of troops in action. Dr. Harry Noble Wright, who on Wednesday received the scroll and seal which promoted him from the acting presidency to the official presidency of City College, measures up to the obligation.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Oct. 1 -- Interest in "synthetic" construction materials will help to stimulate experiments and may serve to develop some improvements, but steel construction long has proved itself and no substitute will be found for it in post-war construction programs, V.G. Iden, secretary of the American Institute of Steel Construction, reported today to the twentieth annual convention of that organization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Maximum prices for forty-five imported spices and spice seeds were fixed today by the Office of Price Administration. The dollars-and-cents prices established by OPA leave only twelve of the forty-five products at previous levels and cuts prices on the remainder 1 to 50 cents a pound below last March's levels.

Grace Zaring Stone, the novelist who hid for several years behind the pseudonym "Ethel Vance" while her anti-Nazi novel "Escape" sold in the hundreds of thousands, may become permanently reincarnated as Ethel Vance. The pseudonym was originally an expedient to protect her daughter, living in Europe at the time the novel was published.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- American shipyards turned out ninety-three cargo vessels of all types in September, almost as many as they did in all of 1941. The month's tonnage was 1,009,800 deadweight. So far this year 460 vessels totaling 5,101,956 tons have been produced.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1 -- The play-by-play description of the second game of the world series at Sportsman's Park today follows:

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1 -- Neither Joe McCarthy, manager of the Yankees, nor Billy Southworth, Cardinal leader, was in a position tonight to name his starting pitcher for the third world series game, to be played in the Yankee Stadium on Saturday.

ALBANY, Oct. 1 -- On the eve of the nation-wide drive for scrap materials Governor Lehman in a radio address to the boys and girls of New York State today impressed upon his hearers the necessity for acting now.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 -- A "flight recorder" instrument electrically jotting down data on new aircraft to speed their testing and simplify the test pilot's hazardous job was announced here today by the Brown Instrument Company.

Collection of every available piece of movable household scrap metal in Queens for remanufacture into ships, guns, tanks and munitions gets under way today. Borough President James A. Burke, who has general charge of the collection, predicted last night that at least 10,000 tons would be received.

LONDON, Oct. 1 (U.P.) -- Some allied experts believed, on the basis of Hitler's speech last night, that he already has thrown his personal prestige into a propaganda effort to undermine the confidence of occupied countries in the power of the United States.

The will of Conde Nast, president of Conde Nast Publications, Inc., filed yesterday for probate in Surrogate's Court, leaves his entire estate to his three children in equal shares. The bequests are subject, however, to a possible charge against the estate to make up any deficiency in a guaranteed annual income of $10,000 payable to Mr. Nast's first wife, now Mrs. Clarisse Coudert Onativia, of Millbrook, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- An obvious contradiction between the provisions of the Agricultural Marketing Act authorizing the Secretary of Agriculture to fix milk prices and the requirements of the General Maximum Price Regulation Act would have to be reconciled if President Roosevelt's desire to prevent price inflation were to be realized, it was said today by an Agriculture Department spokesman.

ABOARD ROOSEVELT EN ROUTE TO WEST COAST, Sept. 19 (Delayed) (AP) -- President Roosevelt made a tri-State morning-to-midnight inspection of vital Midwestern war establishments today, seeing sailors training for service on fighting ships, men and machines turning out massive propulsion equipment for those ships, and the manufacturing of small arms and ammunition to help defend them.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 1 -- Two stake records were broken today by pacers on a lightning-fast track and a trotter paid $238 in the $2 mutuels in winning a heat at the second day of the Lexington Grand Circuit meeting.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Protests by two New Jersey landlords against price ceilings were rejected today by Leon Henderson, price administrator, in his first rulings on such cases.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, terming the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation a "sick company in need of a surgeon's ministrations," asked the Third Circuit Court of Appeals today to affirm the commission's order requiring the company to reduce its capitalization to an all-common-stock basis.

In one of the largest "all cash" realty transactions reported recently in Manhattan, art investing syndicate headed by Samuel Wasserman of Wasserman, Behr Shagan, and including former Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan, has purchased from Museum Estates, Inc., the twelve buildings comprising virtually all of the block bounded by Nassau, Spruce, William and Frankfort Streets.

OTTAWA, Oct. 1 -- The rhythm of Canada's production of essential war weapons for which she has contracted is threatened by the decision that the United States "has found it necessary to reduce substantially the allotment of steel to Canada for the next three months."

LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The German-controlled Paris press opened a campaign today to bring France into a military alliance with the Axis and clear the way for German aid in the "defense" of the French African Empire.
MOSCOW, Oct. 1 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:

The sixteen-story loft and store building at 21-27 West Forty-sixth Street will be offered at auction today by the I. Lincoln Seide Company in an action brought by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company against the 21 West Forty-sixth Street Corporation on a claim of $694,400.

To listen to Coach Lou Little, Maine's Black Bears have Columbia's Lions up a tree. The Columbia mentor professes to be none too confident about tomorrow's appointment with the Orono team at Baker Field.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (U.P.) -- Thirty-five Washington newspaper men, representing as many newspapers or bureaus, have protested to President Roosevelt against his refusal to take them on his cross-country tour.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., Oct. 1 -- The Maritime Commission's "M" pennant for excellence in production, coveted by factories and shipyards employing as many as 40,000 men, will fly tomorrow from the private home of a United States postoffice truck driver, the award of his diligence in turning out spokes for ship steering wheels in his spare time.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- President Roosevelt was critical today of delays in Congress on authorization to promote his anti-inflation program as the legislative branch let the Chief Executive's deadline pass and set out to finish its job if possible only one day late.

The German High Command said yesterday that several more wedges had been driven into the northern section of Stalingrad and reported the destruction of ninety-eight tanks, mostly British and American-made, that led a strong Soviet counter-thrust farther north.

Sad tidings emanate from the Department of Agriculture, which reports that these last frosty mornings, when all of New York City was shivering under Summer blankets, have killed the local crop of outdoor flowers. No more dahlias or bright gladioluses will be forthcoming from Long Island flower beds, where the curtain has fallen on open-air gardening.

HORNELL, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, shook hands today through five western and southern tier counties, visiting thirteen villages and three cities in an informal 150-mile tour of this predominantly Republican section.

UVALDE, Texas, Sept. 27 (Delayed) (AP) -- President Roosevelt and John N. Garner, whose political trails ran parallel for eight years and then swerved widely apart, met today for the first time since the third term began and chatted boisterously for six minutes.

Asserting that sterner measures must be adopted if the multiplying inflationary pressures are to be successfully combated, the National City Bank in the October issue of its monthly bank letter, warns that the controls will work only if they deal with causes as well as consequences.

The railway shares returned yesterday as the dominant trading medium on the New York Stock Exchange and duplicated the highs previously set this year, adding approximately 3 points to reach their peaks, while the rest of the market made an irregular and less spectacular climb.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Department store sales increased by 5 per cent in the week ended Sept. 26 as compared with the previous week, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. A similar increase was reported last week. For the latest four-week period, sales were 8 per cent higher.
LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

Despite the increased promotional efforts that have been planned for National Furniture Week, which will start tomorrow and continue through next Saturday, retailers will be satisfied if they can come within 10 per cent of the volume during the 1941 event, they said yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1 -- The Cardinals, who are riding into the East tonight, today confounded those who thought they would be affected by a defeatist attitude after their setback in the opening game. They were buoyed by the victory scored over the Yankees in a manner typical of the ball the club had played in its mad clash on the National League pennant.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- In remarking today that Adolf Hitler's speech yesterday contained less than the usual "boasts and bombast" and indicated that "he is desperately preparing his people for still greater hardships," Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, expressed what appeared to be the prevailing view here in military as well as political circles.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- British light naval forces, patrolling off Terschelling last night, intercepted a strongly escorted enemy convoy that included six supply ships. During the ensuing fight a British torpedo hit a medium-sized supply ship, which blew up.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Allied troops are continuing to make progress in the Owen Stanley mountain area of New Guinea, without meeting any Japanese opposition, the Allied command reported today.

An appeal for constructive ideals in this period of destruction, which he termed "the keynote of the modern world," was made yesterday by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman at the annual "Red Mass" under the auspices of the Guild of Catholic Lawyers in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Andrew, Duane Street and Cardinal Hayes Place.

A capacity attendance thronged the Iridium Room of the St. Regis last night for its formal opening for the new season. The occasion was marked by a gala dinner dance in aid of the Musicians Emergency Fund under that patronage of Mrs. Lytle Hull.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 1 -- The extraordinary effect which the Baruch committee report had on public opinion is revealed in a study just completed by the institute.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 1 (Reuter) -- Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's relief offensive northwest of Stalingrad is gathering momentum. On both sides of the Don elbow the Red Army is furiously battering forward in an attempt to cut off German communications and compel the Germans to detach troops from the city.

A six-acre site in Manhattan which was assembled originally for the erection of a low-rent housing project has been turned instead to more 'urgent war uses. The United States Coast Guard, it was learned last night, has leased "for the duration" the land acquired last year by the New York City Housing Authority along the east side of Tenth Avenue from Twenty-fifth to Twenty-seventh Street.

Hedge selling became fairly active in late dealings in yesterday's cotton market, offsetting a comparatively strong undercurrent of trade buying that had sprung both from news of a 5 per cent rise in the loan rate for agricultural commodities and from the appeal of Senator John Bankhead to farmers, urging them to retain their cotton until the market price approaches the 21 cents a pound level.

The Chase National Bank, in its quarterly condition statement, as of Sept. 30, reported yesterday that total deposits were $3,628,465,592 and total resources $3,899,955,952. Both are new record highs. The deposit figure compares with $3,595,451,031 on June 30 last and with $3,587,562,419 on Sept. 30, 1941, and with total resources of $3,869,463,740 and $3,856,798,580 respectively on these dates.

Whether the corset and brassiere industry will seek relief from its unexpected inclusion under the provisions of Maximum Price Regulation No. 220 instead of the General Maximum Price Regulation will be decided after a thorough study of Regulation 220, it was stated yesterday by Melvin Kleeblatt, of Blumberg Kleeblatt, counsel for the Corset and Brassiere Association of America, following a meeting of the board of the organization at the Empire State Club.

Nine men were arrested yesterday in raids on a fifth-floor suite of offices at 126 Liberty Street and in apartments in an eighty-five-family house at 834 Penfield Street, the Bronx, in what the police called a "million-dollar-a-year wire service for poolroom bookmakers and other gamblers on horse racing in New York, New Jersey, Westchester and Nassau County."

Challenging the authority of the Securities and Exchange Commission to proceed with its plan to regulate the sale of municipal bonds, Lyle H. Boren, member of Congress from Oklahoma, in a communication to Ganson Purcell, chairman of the SEC, released here yesterday, charged that the plan is "contrary to the obvious intent of Congress."
LONDON, Oct. 1 -- The stock markets continued firm again today. The recent steady rise in the home rails continued, with Great Western gaining 1/2 and Southern deferred 3/8.

With supporters of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, expecting that President Roosevelt will make some kind of a statement for him today or tomorrow in Washington, Mr. Bennett's itinerary for his third up-State trip was announced yesterday at his campaign headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Sir Kingsley Wood, Chancellor of the Exchequer, stated today in the House of Commons that the Bank of England would not modify its relations with the Bank for International Settlements at Basle or withdraw its representatives.

DETROIT, Sept. 18 (Delayed) (AP) -- President Roosevelt began a tour of America's war plants and military encampments today with a look at the Chrysler tank arsenal, where a 32-ton mass of mechanized metal churned through a watery morass and crunched to a stop not ten feet from him.

Parasang, almost as moody a racer as his sire, Halcyon, was a surprise winner of the $8,950 Vosburgh Handicap, sprinting feature yesterday at Belmont, which saw both Devil Diver and Doublrab go down to defeat. Many had supposed that victory in the seven-furlong dash lay between these two, but at the finish over a fast track it was Parasang by a length and a half, with Devil Diver a well-beaten second.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- The august House of Lords today heard slim young Lord Lovat, hero of the Commando raids on Dieppe, the Lofoten Islands and Boulogne, verbally rake plump 56-year-old Lord Strabolgi for publishing abroad an article entitled "What's Wrong With the British Army?"

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Questions relating to the government's policy with regard to the complicated problem of India occupied the minds of members of Parliament today. Sir Stafford Cripps took the lead in advocating a second reading as soon as possible of the bill introduced yesterday by Leopold S. Amery, Secretary of State for India, dealing with provincial rather than Central Indian Government proposals.

WASHINGTON, Oct- 1 (AP) -- The small business man was pictured by Elmer Davis, war information director, today as bewildered by the complexity of wartime regulations, but eager to make patriotic sacrifices.

Lost in the verbiage of Hitler's latest speech is a remarkable passage which has received less attention than it deserves. The program he announced for this year -- "to hold everything that must be held * * * and let the others attack" -- has been generally interpreted as a turn from the offensive to the defensive.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- With the Nazis using up every ounce of their coal to keep the wheels of their war production factories turning, householders in Germany and in German-occupied European countries will have to go very short on coal for heating and cooking purposes this Winter, according to officials of the Ministry of Economic Warfare here.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- Abruptly reversing the stand it had taken a little more than a month ago, the Yonkers Common Council voted unanimously this afternoon to dismiss charges of laxity in office against Raymond J. Whitney, suspended City Manager.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Byron Price, director of censorship, said tonight that the press and radio demonstrated their patriotism and proved "the workability of voluntary censorship" by keeping President Roosevelt's inspection trip a secret.

Progress in world problems of major importance during the between-the-wars "entr'acte" may be 'infinitesimal, but on the minor point of "women in uniform" New York's veteran tailors are agreed that the women of this war are infinitely superior to their trail-blazing mothers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (U.P.) -- Housewives will pay slightly higher prices for all canned vegetables, some cereals and other foods, under a proposal to be announced this week by the Office of Price Administration.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 1 -- long-term public works program designed to ease Bermuda over the slack labor period, already noticeable to a small degree and expected to intensify next year, has been proposed by the Governor's economic advisory committee at an overall cost of 900,000.

I have remarked with surprise the careless reporting in the press, which amounts to misrepresentation, of the speeches made at the meeting held Tuesday evening under the auspices of the India League of America. The lumping together of a few words chosen at random out of context and the inevitable false impression thus created may be ignored in the hasty writing of reporters.

The optimism and confidence of the American people about the outcome of the war are the most striking characteristics observed by Antonio Arias Bernal, noted 29-year-old Mexican cartoonist, who has come to New York at the invitation of the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs to paint a series of war posters and illustrations for circulation in Latin America.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Professional speculators were inclined today to regard the passage of the Price Control Bill by the Senate as mildly bullish, but the implications contained in the measure failed to bring any outside buying of consequence into the grain market.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Older men have been increasing in the ranks of industry as the war has progressed, but the Census Bureau finds that substantial relief from the manpower shortage cannot be obtained from the older male groups.

The National City Bank of New York in its statement of condition as of Sept. 30, which includes domestic and foreign branches, reported yesterday depositis of $2,959,691,932, compared with $2,917,113,053 on June 30, last, and with $2,897,061,411 on Sept. 30, 1941.
ATHOL, Idaho, Sept. 21 (Delayed) (AP) -- A thousand men of the Navy, stationed high above sea level in the Rocky Mountains, received a visit from President Roosevelt today.

For the second time in as many weeks, Fordham's football forces climbed aboard Pullmans last night, bound for action on a foreign gridiron. Last night, at 6:55, a squad of thirty-three players with officials and coaches left Pennsylvania Station, headed for Knoxville and tomorrow's engagement with Tennessee.

Bellevue Hospital, which has been a source of unusual news for years, ran true to form yesterday when John Cosgrove, 69-year-old porter, startled his fellow-employes by producing a receipt for a $10,000 War Bond while they were waiting to learn who was the winner of a $25 War Bond.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Here is some of the Congressional comment on President Roosevelt's trip:

In your issue of Sept. 30 there is a most interesting report on a bill introduced by Representative Dickstein aiming at the simplification of the naturalization process for aliens in the Army. Mr. Dickstein is certainly right in his statement that if any enemy alien should be captured by the Axis he would be shot as a spy instead of being treated as a prisoner of war.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 1 -- Gifts totaling $954,501 were received by Princeton University from 9,320 contributors during the fiscal year ending June 30, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, announced today. The gifts, the majority of which came from Princeton alumni, were divided into three general classes -- the annual giving program, donations for specific purposes and premiums on life insurance policies naming the university as beneficiary.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- During the week ended Sept. 30 member bank reserve balances decreased $294,000,000. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $189,000,000 in money in circulation, $176,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, $113,000,000 in nonmember deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts and $18,000,000 in Treasury cash, offset in part by increases of $193,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit, $5,000,000 in Treasury currency and $4,000,000 in gold stock.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Oct. 1 -- "Shoulder to shoulder on land, on the sea and in the air we will fight Tojo and his fellow-saber-rattlers, Mussolini of Italy and Hitler of Germany, in the war imposed upon us by the treacherous blow at Pearl Harbor," declared United States Navy Secretary Frank Knox tonight at a banquet given for him by Admiral Aristides Guilhem, Brazilian Navy Minister.

Supremely confident that their attack, which was stalled last week in Washington mud, is about due to roll, the New York Football Giants finished their work at the Polo Grounds yesterday and will depart today for Pittsburgh and a game with the Steelers at Forbes Field on Sunday.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- The forty-sixth annual convention of the State Congress of Parents and Teachers closed today with an address by Rev. Dutton S. Peterson, Assemblyman from Schuyler County, who declared that distrust was an emotional thing eating at the structure of democracy, and added:

The House of Commons has just voted by 215 to 9 to approve a second reading of a bill to prolong its life another year. The incident calls attention to a striking contrast between the British system and our own in this respect.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (U.P.) -- Medical experts assured home owners affected by fuel oil rationing today that the human body can take it and temperatures may be lowered 10 degrees from the "comfort" toward the "discomfort" zone without causing ill effects.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 1 -- One person was fatally shot and several bystanders were more or less seriously injured in last Sunday's scuffles in Copenhagen between Danish Quislingists on leave from the German front in the East and a hostile crowd, the Copenhagen correspondent of Dagens Nyheter declares today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- President Roosevelt returned today from a two-week, 8,754-mile inspection tour of war-production centers in twenty-four States and reported to a special press conference that munitions output was about 94 to 95 per cent of his objectives.

The Christian church faces the responsibility of making contributions to "the new order, which is to be a people's order," Dr. Elmer G. Homrighausen of Princeton Theological Seminary declared yesterday morning at the opening session of the annual conference of ministers, church workers and parents at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

While the Germans gnaw their way house by house into Stalingrad the battle is now sweeping with almost equal intensity northwest of the city across the steppes between the Volga and the Don. In the city the Russians have lost the initiative; they can only defend themselves with desperate courage against ceaseless Nazi assaults.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Sept. 30 (Delayed) -- The slow and cautious advance of Australian units on the main Port Moresby-Buna trail, which leads over the high mountains of Central New Guinea, continues.

An English music hall party sponsored by Bundles for Britain, Inc., marked the formal opening of the Cotillion Room of the Pierre last night and inaugurated the Autumn drive of the organization, which supports sixty-two unendowed hospitals in Great Britain, many of which have been bombed.

Commercial bank depositaries for the Treasury were notified late yesterday of another triple call, effective on next Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. This follows by a few days the announcement of Treasury withdrawals from its war loan accounts with these banks, effective yesterday, today and tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- A suggestion by Donald M. Nelson that the auto industry find a use in the war-production effort for special-purpose machinery which was packed away in grease when production lines were broken up for the duration of the war, or turn the machines into scrap, brought a critical response from members of the industry today.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. l -- The newspaper Universal charges the Ministry of Communications with corruption, inefficiency and favoritism, which it asserts are responsible for the sad state of Mexico's railway system.

LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- A high record was established for note circulation as reported in the Bank of England's weekly condition statement issued today. The increase amounted to 6,273,000 to a total of 838,029,000. The bank's reserve reflected an almost similar decrease.

ABOARD ROOSEVELT TRAIN EN ROUTE THROUGH THE SOUTH, Sept. 29 (Delayed) (AP) -- While a company band played "Hall to the Chief" the Higginses showed President Roosevelt today how they build fighting boats upside down or in a loft 72 feet above ground with equal facility.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- An end to unjustified charges of war profiteering and a more equitable tax system in which everybody will pay a share of the war costs were advocated here today by George S. Olive, newly elected president of the American Institute of Accountants, as its convention drew to a close.

We see that Army and Navy are in need of 75,000 writing machines and are asking large business houses to sell 20 per cent of their typewriters. If the supply from these wholesale sources should fall short, the government might look in another direction.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Football games and other sports events, including the present baseball world series, races and circuses, will be affected by an order issued today by the Office of Defense Transportation, freezing as of Sept. 26 all railway passenger schedules.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Immediate occupation of all French possessions "in the American sphere of civilization" was advocated today in the Senate by Senator James M. Mead of New York, in retaliation for the arrest of United States civilians in France.
MOSCOW, Friday, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Last midnight's communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Continued advances in primary market prices for domestic agricultural products, largely grains, livestock and dairy products, in the week ended on Sept. 26 again brought the Bureau of Labor Statistics comprehensive price index up 0.1 per cent to 99.4 per cent of the 1926 level.

The report of the Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Aug. 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after expenses, taxes and other charges, of $3,405,579. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 60 cents a share on the company's outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $4,737,544, or $1.29 a share, for the twelve months to Aug. 31, 1941.

Engineering construction awards during September amounted to $712,709,000, the highest valuation for September ever reported by the Engineering News-Record in its monthly national tabulation of building activity.

Nine British tars with their dungarees in their duffle bags left Grand Central Terminal yesterday for points near Albany, where they will pick apples for democracy and get better acquainted with the American people and rural customs.

Gerhard Wilhelm Kunze, former national leader of the German-American Bund, told members of that organization that they should avoid military service and evade work in war plants if they could, according to testimony in Federal court yesterday.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Engineers at the Wright Aeronautical Corporation laboratories announced today they had created polar climate in a New Jersey test cell designed to prepare aircraft engines for use this Winter in Iceland and other "iceboxes" of the world.

Eggs -- at a time when they could most effectively substitute for meat -- are the highest they have been in almost a decade. In fact, both Grade A white and Grade B mixed eggs advanced again this week, according to the Consumers' Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets.
We are forced to travel on a limited amount of gasoline and every one using gasoline is required to conserve it. But how does this apply to New York City?

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Twelve members of the Women's Advisory Committee of the War Manpower Commission, met today in an executive session devoted to the study of manpower problems and the government agencies now working in that field.

MOSCOW, Friday, Oct. 2 -- A German siege army of 300,000 men advanced slightly in the northwestern outskirts of imperiled Stalingrad yesterday, but was forced out of another locality south of the city, the Soviet High Command announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Steps preliminary to the rationing of meat to civilians were taken by the Office of Price Administration today in an order limiting the quantities of meat which slaughterers might deliver for civilian consumption.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- A check for $10,000 in United States money was recently presented by General Chiang Kai-shek to J.B. Powell, former editor of The China Weekly Review, it was stated here today by those in charge of the fund collected for Mr. Powell, long a prisoner of the Japanese.

The third annual report of Northrop Aircraft, Inc., issued yesterday to stockholders, disclosed an increase of 870 per cent in sales to $32,983,762 for the fiscal year ended on July 31, from the $3,407,704 volume of the preceding fiscal year.

NORTH PELHAM, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- Raymond S. Deck, writer on nature subjects and former assistant curator of the Brooklyn Museum, was found dead with a bullet wound in his chest tonight in a bedroom of his home at 68 High-brook Avenue, here.

Although I realize that the canceled Louis-Conn bout is now a dead issue, I think that the public is entitled to receive more information concerning the details which compelled Secretary of War Stimson to call off the whole affair.

CHICAGO, Oct 2 -- The Mortgage Bankers Association of America ended its convention here today by listening to addresses on the war by Senator Harold H. Burton of Ohio and William T. Foster, president of the Pollak Foundation for Economic Research, and electing officers.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 2 -- That Adolf Hitler sent Rudolf Hess to Britain as his personal envoy, to propose to the British a tie-up with the Tripartite Alliance against Soviet Russia, has been admitted for the first time by a Nazi source.

Ted Groh's letter appearing in THE TIMES last Saturday in regard to the wanton shooting of wild animals and birds would seem to evidence a certain humanitarian trait which, in view of the editorial note, is somewhat out of step with the trend of the times, to perpetrate a poor play on words.

Charging that the Democratic party no longer exists as a national organization but has been swallowed up by the New Deal, Samuel B. Pettengill, chairman of the Republican national finance committee, declared last night at a rally at the Women's National Republican Club that the political division today is between Americanism and collectivism.

Several sales of Brooklyn apartment, industrial and residential parcels were reported yesterday by the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn. The apartment at 18 St. Mark's Avenue was purchased by a client of Leon Kaufman. The bank also sold the industrial property at 416-20 Flushing Avenue, at the corner of Skillman Street, but the name of the buyer was not revealed.

The Van Atta homestead and farm in Hampton Township, Sussex County, N.J., held by that family for about sixty years, has been purchased by Charles C. Ort, realty broker, who will divide the land and develop it into small farms and Summer homes.

Cynical New Yorkers passing the Y.W.C.A. building at Lexington Avenue and Fifty-third Street yesterday during the noor hour received a rude jolt. A spanking new, khaki-colored mobile canteen truck was drawn up at the curb and nine uniformed women were inviting all comers to have a snack "on the house."

Netherland sources revealed yesterday that Nazi occupation authorities in Holland, striving to overcome the cold hostility of the population, had organized parades with Storm Troopers using chocolate bars to lure the children.
We must make a memorandum of it, and carry it around in the vest pocket wherever we go: "Whatever you do, don't be complacent."

OTTAWA, Oct 2 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Col. Cecil C. I. Merritt, 33 years of age, of Vancouver, B.C., commander of the South Saskatchewan Regiment, who was captured in the Dieppe raid, received the Victoria Cross today, the first Canadian to receive the British Empire's highest decoration in the present war.

NEW DELHI, India, Saturday, Oct. 3 (U.P.) -- Police gunfire killed one man and wounded at least three yesterday in breaking up a crowd of 2,000 persons demonstrating in the streets of the Old Delhi in observance of the seventy-third birthday of Mohandas K. Gandhi, imprisoned leader of the All-India Congress and the Indian independence movement.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 2 -- Twentieth Century-Fox today announced the purchase of "Only the Stars Are Neutral," Quentin Reynolds's non-fiction best seller, for a reported $100,000. Reynolds will work on the preparation of the film and appear briefly in its prologue.
NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 2 -- Refuse collection here remained virtually stalled today as a two-day-old strike of employes in the Department of Public Works developed some disturbances.

Major league baseball lost approximately 840,000 paying fans during the last season, a drop of about 8 per cent from the 1941 attendance total, but the figures fail to show evidence of a first-class losing trend, according to a survey by The Associated Press.

Thomas J. Ryan, who insists he is a "legitimate business man," while the police charge he is "king of the wire service racket" in the United States, with a million-dollar yearly income from selling horse-racing information to bookmakers and others, was held in $10,000 bail by Magistrate Charles Ramsgate in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday.

No new bond issues were offered here for public subscription this week, marking the third period of such inactivity since the beginning of August. Last week three issues of bonds totaling $11,696,000 were marketed and in this week a year ago, ten issues aggregating $15,991,000 were sold.

Three documents reach me from Italy at the same time. Through one we see the horrors of the Fascist administration; through another its tricks and lies; while the third is one of the many symptoms of the general reactions of the Italian nation against fascism.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Families with children less than 4 years old will receive a fuel oil allowance of fifty to 125 gallons, depending on the heating zone, in addition to the basic ration under the fuel plan.

LONDON, Saturday, Oct. 3 -- A big force of United States Flying Fortresses, accompanied by American, British, Dominion and other Allied fighter planes, smashed through a strong German fighter screen and bombed the enemy's aircraft factories at Meaulte, near Albert, in Northern France, and the Nazis' airfield at St. Omer late yesterday afternoon in one of the war's largest daylight operations.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., Oct. 2 -- This little South Shore residential community turned out en masse this afternoon to honor a fellow-townsman who became the first individual winner of the Maritime Commission's "M" award and the "Victory Fleet" pennant for his outstanding spare-time war production work.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Georgetown University scored a 14-6 victory over a favored University of Mississippi eleven tonight.

The resignation of Samuel Zahn as chairman of the board of governors of the New York Dress Institute, created under joint labor-manufacturer auspices to promote this city as the style center of the world, was made known here yesterday.

"Eyes of the Underworld," a Universal action drama, which arrives at the Rialto, will be this morning's lone film newcomer. Richard Dix, Wendy Barrie, Lon Chaney Jr., Billy Lee, Don Porter and Lloyd Corrigan head the film's cast.

The New York City Cancer Clinic, which, when it opened nineteen years ago, was the first of its kind in the city and the largest in the country, will end its existence today by order of Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals.

That builder of powerhouse elevens, Bernie Bierman, may have done far too sound a job with his Minnesota team in pre-war years, a discovery he may make today when his Iowa Pre-Flight squad clashes with the Golden Gophers in the day's feature.

Queens residents and storekeepers donated scrap metal to the salvage drive being sponsored by New York City newspapers in such quantities yesterday that collection facilities were taxed to the limit and arrangements were made for some further collections today.

It is with lingering amazement that I read the sports pages this week and see that the Yankees, not the Red Sox, are playing the Cardinals in the World Series, because, as between the Red Sox and the Yankees, the Sox are clearly the better team.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The bodies of twenty-two persons, including three women, were recovered today from the burned wreckage of an Army transport plane which crashed yesterday in the mountains northwest of Coamo.
CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 2 -- In a special broadcast to America this morning Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, head of the China Air Task Force, said:

LONDON, Oct. 2 (UP) -- German occupation forces have begun preparation for large-scale anti-invasion manoeuvres with 500,000 troops along the European coast from Norway to the Spanish frontier and have placed new restrictions on coastal populations in Norway, Belgium and the Netherlands, private advices reaching London said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Henry H. Arnold, chief of the Army Air Forces, returned to the capital today after a quick tour of the Pacific war zone and Australia and a record-breaking flight from Brisbane, Australia, to San Francisco.

Counsel fees are likely to absorb most of the money recovered by the trustees of the Reynolds Investing Company, according to the current report by Samuel S. Rodman, president of the Reynolds Realization Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Use of nickel was restricted by the War Production Board today to implements of war and other products certified by the Army-Navy Munitions Board to be essential in the successful prosecution of the war. This tightening of control over nickel is contained in a revision of Conservation Order M-6-b.

Apparently the victim of muggers, Private Edwin Berkowitz, 22 years old, attached to the Medical Division at Fort Monmouth, N.J., was found slain at 7:30 A.M. yesterday in the basement areaway of the rectory of Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal Church, 114th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue.

On his return from an eight-day up-State tour Dean Alfange, American Labor party nominee for Governor, declared yesterday in an interview at party headquarters that the result of this year's State election would determine the type of Presidential candidates of the major parties in 1944.

Local Democratic leaders yesterday reiterated previously published reports that President Roosevelt would endorse Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., whose nomination for Governor he opposed. Such an announcement by the President is expected by Mr. Bennett's supporters before the close of the New York City registration period next week.

A Washington dispatch reports from the Bureau of Census that the homicides of 1940 were 8,208, "compared with 12,124 in 1933." The latter figures are new. "Statistical Abstract of the United States 1941" issued by the Bureau of Census enumerated the homicides of 1900, 1919, 1920, 1930, 1936, 1937, 1938, 1939, but intentionally or thoughtfully left out the year of tribulation.

The action of the Federal Reserve Board yesterday in cutting reserve requirements of banks in New York and Chicago from 22 per cent against demand deposits to 20 per cent brings the banks of these central reserve cities in line with the banks in reserve cities.

A committee assigned to the task of seeing that every newspaper plant in the metropolitan district contributes every bit of scrap metal that it can spare to the salvage drive was appointed yesterday at a luncheon meeting of newspaper executives in the Hotel Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Americans filed a total of 74,778,159 income tax returns last year on 1940 income, an increase of 91.5 per cent, the Treasury reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 -- David M. Wood, a member of the municipal law firm of Thompson, Wood Hoffman of New York and president of the Municipal Bond Club of New York, told members of the Philadelphia Municipal Bond Club at a luncheon meeting here today that the proposed rule X-15C1-10 of the Securities and Exchange Commission which give that agency supervisory powers over the sale of municipal bonds, is "regulation at its worst."

After moving narrowly and near the previous close for most of the session, the cotton market weakened yesterday in the final minutes with the appearance of more active hedging and ended the day at the lows, 7 to 9 points under Thursday's closing quotations.

While retail trade was active here this week, comparison with the last of the "beat-the-tax" buying just prior to Oct. 1 last year pulled down the comparative sales figures sharply. The appointment by the National War Labor Board of a three-man commission to consider the dispute between milk distributors and the Milk Drivers Union in this city over the conservation of gasoline and rubber was revealed here yesterday.
ON THE FRENCH FRONTIER, Oct. 2 (U.P.) -- Edouard Herriot, elder statesman of the Third Republic, is interned at his family estate near Lyon under the surveillance of ten police inspectors.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 2 (AP) -- The "almost superhuman efforts" of three enlisted men in cutting loose a raft from a flooded and sinking patrol bomber saved the lives of thirteen officers and men after a forced landing at sea, the Navy reports.

In an effort to prevent profiteering in poultry, fish and dairy products as a result of the reduction in the amount of meat for civilian consumption, the City Department of Markets said yesterday that it would watch price fluctuations with a sharp eye and "fix the blame for any unwarranted increases."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- President Roosevelt signed the anti-inflation bill after conferring with officials and advisers. His callers included Secretary Stimson, General George C. Marshall, Admiral Ernest J. King and James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- For the third time since Aug. 19 the Federal Reserve Board today reduced deposit reserve requirements of banks in New York and Chicago to increase the supply of investment funds in those cities.
LONDON, Oct. 2 -- The markets ended the week on a cheerful note with a number of bright features in the industrial section. Several gilt-edge issues rallied 1-16 point.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- Fears that farmers would not be given 90 per cent of parity loans on wheat and corn prevailed today as members of the House and Senate entered a conference to adjust the differences between the price-control bills passed by the two Houses.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, concluding a two-day informal handshaking tour of the western and southern parts of the State tonight, stated in brief speeches throughout the day that the Republican party, in the State and nation, had "a duty" to preserve democratic principles at home while American boys were fighting on battlefronts all over the world to defend democracy from totalitarian attack.

It is not necessary at this time to curtail mail service in New York, as a recent reader suggested. From London on Thursday night came two discouraging items of news relating to India. One was the statement made by Leopold S. Amery, Secretary of State for India, that an Indian mob had killed the crew of a British plane which crashed near Behar on Sept. 5.

ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 2 (AP) -- In a rip-roaring comeback, the Georgia Navy Pre-Flight School tonight scored twice in the final period to earn a 14-14 tie with the North Carolina Navy Pre-Flight eleven before 7,500 fans.

In the most enthusiastic session of the year to date, and with volume near the million-share mark, the stock market scored yesterday its best rise since the mid-September rally. Widest gains, which ran to around 2 points, were reserved for the steels and rails, but the market was outstanding because of the over-all strength throughout the list.

Squared at a victory apiece, the 1942 world series moves to New York today when, at 1:30 o'clock, the Yankees and Cardinals clash in the third game before what promises to be a record-smashing crowd of 70,000 in the Stadium.

WEST POINT, Oct. 2 -- As a result of President Roosevelt having signed into law today a bill cutting the West Point course from four to three years, the military academy said that it would graduate its class of '43 Jan. 19, five months ahead of time, and the class of '44 on June 1, a year early.
Ray Robinson added another victim to his long list last night when he defeated Jack La Motta of the Bronx in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden.

Employes in the steel industry in August averaged 647,000, compared with 655,000 in July, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. In August last year approximately 654,000 employes were at work in the industry. Steel company payrolls in August amounted to $118,718,000, compared with $120,671,000 in July and $112,757,000 in August, 1941.

Mayor La Guardia and other members of the Canadian-United States Permanent Joint Defense Board made a place for a young American sailor in the Navy plane on which they left Newfoundland Tuesday morning, to rush the youth to the bedside of his wife and a new-born baby girl but, according to a dispatch from the sailor's home town last night, he has not reached there yet.

VICHY, France, Oct 2 (U.P.) -- German authorities today tightened their control over French civilians on the west coast, particularly the northwest section embracing their most powerful fortifications and the main invasion ports facing England.

The Army is setting a good example to the civilian population on food conservation, Miss Mary I. Barber, food consultant to the War Department, revealed yesterday. Beginning in December, Miss Barber announced, for the first time in American history master menus issued by the Quartermaster Corps will indicate coffee for only one meal a day.

Despite the sharp drop in men's furnishings sales, clothiers report that their post exchange sections have been holding total volume up relatively close to the levels of last year. It was reported by large stores here yesterday that their furnishings business was not off more than 20 per cent, while their clothing sales were down as much as 40 per cent.
Mr. and Mrs. Griswold Thompson have returned from The Shooting Box, Suffern, N.Y., where they passed the Summer, and are at 375 Park Avenue for the Winter.

James F. Faiman, assistant vice president of the Consolidated Edison Company, was elected yesterI day a trustee of the FIatbush Saviings Bank. He is president of the New York Society of Professional :Engineers.

War advertising campaigns, covering such projects as drawing additional men and women into war industries, conservation of power, meat rationing and automotive conservation, are now being prepared, the Advertising Council, Inc., reported yesterday in a survey of its first six months' work.

The Brooklyn Tablet published yesterday on its editorial page a retraction of three articles reflecting on the character of Lawrence A. Fernsworth, former correspondent in Spain for THE NEW YORK TIMES and The Times of London. With the publication of the retraction, Mr. Fernsworth withdrew a suit for $100,000 for libel he brought against The Tablet.

VICHY, France, Oct. 2 -- France's National Council, created a year ago by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain to frame the new Constitution and to give advisory opinions on governmental questions, has been scrapped and will be reorganized upon an entirely new basis, it was announced today.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- The running of convoys to Russia has placed a new strain on British shipyards, already overburdened with their tasks of filling naval and merchant building programs. One instance of how this has had a bad effect among the workers became known here today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Johnny Humphries, the White Sox "night watchman," shaded Claude Passeau, 3 to 2, before 20,819 fans at Comiskey Park tonight, the American Leaguers making it three victories in as many games in their annual city series with the Cubs.

With a largesse that characterized the new order on the Cardinals under the leadership of Billy Southworth, the National League pennant winners provided twenty-eight full shares in the division of their world series money, win or lose.

Two boys, one 16 years old and the other 19, were held yesterday in the murder of Irwin Goodman, 40-year-old mathematics teacher at the William J. Gaynor Junior High School in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, who was found dead on the school stairs shortly before 11 A.M.

In arguing against the decision of the Senate Finance Committee to postpone the increase in Social Security taxes scheduled to take effect next Jan. 1, the Treasury can marshal some strong points. LONDON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The designer of the famous Hurricane fighting plane, one of Britain's leading air weapons, has fathered another fighter, the Typhoon, which was pictured today as superior even to the celebrated Spitfire.

The training of "welfare aides" to meet the wartime shortage of child welfare workers was recommended yesterday by Leonard W. Mayo, president of the Child Welfare League of America, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

The exhibition of paintings by Dutch masters which is to open at the Duveen Galleries, 720 Fifth Avenue, with a private view on Thursday afternoon, has been insured for $5,000,000 by the Netherlands Information Bureau, which arranged for the exhibition.

Toys that many children would still find useful, flatirons still in serviceable condition and many other articles still able to serve the purpose for which they were made were deposited considerable quantities on the scrap piles of Queens yesterday as residents competed with each other to make a good showing in the salvage drive.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Successful attacks on twelve more Japanese ships in operations by Navy submarines and Army bombers were announced today in two Navy communiques. Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway at the head of Wall Street, will establish tomorrow a special "War Service" to be held at 3:30 P.M. each Sunday "for the duration," it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Parish. The "War Service" will follow immediately after evensong.

"World-Wide Communion Sunday" will be observed tomorrow in the Protestant churches of the New York area. War conditions will give added significance this year to what has become an annual observance. "All professing Christians are urged to heed the call of our Lord this day and come penitently, reverently and lovingly to His table," says the current weekly calendar, of the First Presbyterian Church.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- Louis Barbaro, young Hummocks pro, was a triple winner in the Westchester P.G.A. one-day tournament held at the Vernon Hills Country Club today. Scoring 33,-34 -- 67, four below par, on his own card, Barbaro took the individual pro event by a stroke and was in a position to head the field in both the pro-amateur and pro pro-best-ball competitions.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company reported as of Sept. 30 total deposits of $1,290,816,880 and total assets of $1,395,990,279, compared, respectively, with $1,231,547,590 and $1,337,117,489 on June 30. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $349,057,483, against $361,252,663; holdings of United States Government securities to $725,892,057, against $660,455,500, and loans and bills purchased to $223,829,734, against $220,128,756.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Administration's policy toward the enemies of the United States, which appeared to some to require clarification in view of some recent utterances, was described today by Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information, as involving neither threats of destruction of nations or peoples nor undue or premature reliance upon potential friends who may exist on the other side of the fighting lines.
