AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Oct. 3 -- Australian troops have advanced northward beyond the New Guinea village of Menari, forty-six miles from Port Moresby, and still have not re-established contact with the retreating Japanese, General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced today.

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- A mild-mannered youngster with a shock of black hair -- Corporal Franklin M. Koons of Swea City, Iowa -- has received the British Army's Military Medal for "conspicuous gallantry and admirable leadership" in the raid on Dieppe headquarters, the European Theatre Operations Headquarters of the United States Army announced today.
Institutional sales of small apartment buildings formed the bulk of the realty trading reported by brokers in Manhattan yesterday.

TRENTON, Oct. 2 -- The principle of the closed shop for governmental employes is "incompatible with any sound policy of labor relations in the government service," a violation of the merit system and "contrary to the public welfare," the Committee on State-Employe Relations declared in a six-page report to Governor Edison made public today.

WITH THE UNITED STATES BOMBER COMMAND, Somewhere in England, Saturday, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The powerful Flying Fortress flight yesterday, led by Colonel Ronald Walker of Spokane, Wash., shot Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's prize Yellow Nose squadron and other crack Focke-Wulf 190 fighter units full of holes.

Miss Madeleine Carroll, actress, has joined the staff of the United Seamen's Service as director of entertainment for clubs and rest homes that the organization is establishing throughout the world for officers and men of the American merchant marine, it was announced yesterday by Douglas P. Falconer, national executive director.

Officials at the local draft board in Long Island City where William Patrick Hitler, British-born nephew of Fuehrer Adolf, registered as an alien two years ago, revealed yesterday that Army officials to whom they referred his questionnaire had rejected him finally and definitely for military service.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- The frozen foods industry has been requested by the Army's Quartermaster Corps to produce approximately 50,000,000 pounds of frozen vegetables from the 1943 crop for consumption by America's fighting men in the continental United States.

The hoped-for return meeting between Whirlaway and Alsab will take place today at Belmont Park, where both are scheduled to start in the two miles of the Jockey Club Gold Cup, a race that will gross above $27,000 and be a grueling test that should set all doubts at rest as to which is the better colt.

The New York Conservation Department finds that there is some confusion regarding the hours during which hunters may legally take wildlife, and in an effort to clarify any misunderstandings Acting Commissioner John T. Gibbs has issued an explanatory statement.

The Ex-Cell-O Corporation reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Aug. 31 a net profit of $2,523,572 after allowing $10,994,288 as reserve for Federal income and excess profits taxes in accordance with provisions on the Senate Revenue Act for 1942.

CHUNGKING, Oct. 2 (UP) -- Wendell L. Willkie clamped down a self-imposed silence on second front talk today when he arrived in Chungking after playing a cat and mouse game with Japanese fighter planes trying to intercept his Army transport.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. B.L. Montgomery announced today that his Eighth Army was preparing for the "next round" as the end of Summer brought conviction among observers that the coming Autumn and Winter would see a renewal of fierce, full-scale fighting over the brown, rocky ridges of North Africa.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A 17-yard forward pass from Gene Hubka to Angelo Sparagna, plus Sid Beshunsky's extra point from placement, gave Temple a 7-to-6 football victory over Virginia Military Institute before 15,000 fans at Temple Stadium tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- President Roosevelt tonight signed and wrote into law the anti-inflation program which Congress had completed only three hours before.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Senate Finance Committee formally reported the wartime tax bill today seven months after it was presented. It was estimated by Senator George, the chairman, to be capable of producing more than $8,000,000,000 in new revenue to swell the Federal income to about $25,000,000,000.
MOSCOW, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:

The Missouri Pacific Railroad Company is to petition the courts for authority to use $23,000,000 of its funds to repay the principal and interest of its loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, T.C. Davis, chairman of the executive committee, said yesterday.

The $100,000 campaign to promote the printing and graphic arts industries, which has been held up more than two months pending approval by the War Production Board, will go into operation soon, it was announced yesterday. Approval by Washington was obtained after the aims of the drive were revised to eliminate any suggestion of selfishness on the part of the participants.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Volo Song, the top juvenile trotter of the year, cracked two marks today in capturing the rich National Stake at the third day of the Lexington Grand Circuit meeting.

The Missouri Pacific Railroad Company is to petition the courts for authority to use $23,000,000 of its funds to repay the principal and interest of its loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, T.C. Davis, chairman of the executive committee, said yesterday.

The $100,000 campaign to promote the printing and graphic arts industries, which has been held up more than two months pending approval by the War Production Board, will go into operation soon, it was announced yesterday. Approval by Washington was obtained after the aims of the drive were revised to eliminate any suggestion of selfishness on the part of the participants.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Volo Song, the top juvenile trotter of the year, cracked two marks today in capturing the rich National Stake at the third day of the Lexington Grand Circuit meeting.

Father Divine, Harlem cult leader, yesterday lost his fight in the Appellate Division to reverse an order of Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin directing him to pay $100 a week to satisfy an unpaid $5,949 judgment obtained more than two years ago by Mrs. Verinda Brown, a former "angel."
Mrs. Edward F. Albee, widow of the theatre executive, has leased a twelve-room air-conditioned apartment in 1115 Fifth Avenue through William B. May Company Real Estate, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Conversion of the nation's distilled spirits industry to the production of industrial alcohol will be completed next Thursday, the War Production Board said today.

THAT brace of salty range detectives, Rainbow Ripley and Grumpy Gibbs, had been highly successful in eliminating rustlers and such like pests, but here was something new under the sun the like of which they had never tackled before.

The Greek Maritime Union, the United States representative of Greek seamen serving in the war, took issue yesterday with statements contained in a review of Greek merchant marine activities issued a week ago by Andre Michalopoulos, Greek Minister of Information, in Washington.

"SHE'S like a cake of soap in a bathtub when we hit rough weather," the seaman said, his feet widespread as he balanced himself to the roll of the sub-chaser. "But it would make up for all the discomfort and the weeks of waiting if only we could sight a submarine for about thirty seconds."

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- A hope that the future will see "none of that spirit of competitive exploitation which has so often marred international relations in the past" was voiced today by Sir Stafford Cripps, Lord Privy Seal, when he spoke at a rally of the United Aid to China Fund, at which the Archbishop of Canterbury presided.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UP) -- President Roosevelt's $75,000-a-year salary will undoubtedly be adjusted to conform with the $25,000 net salary limit sought, in his new stabilization directive, a White House secretary said today.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 3 (AP) -- With an air attack that had the Iowa State backs completely befuddled, and holding complete control along the forward wall, Nebraska launched its Big Six football title drive today with a 26-0 victory.

WHEN Arturo Toscanini comes to the podium of Carnegie Hall Wednesday night he will launch a season of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra comparable in its gala character to that of last year, which celebrated the centennial of the founding of the Philharmonic Society.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 3 -- The Bowdoin Polar Bears had a lucky fourth quarter today to score three touchdowns and defeated Wesleyan, 18 to 0.

The annual duplicate season is opening in New York's bridge clubs, many of which discontinue their duplicate games during the Summer. Of the two principal membership clubs at which duplicate is played, the Cavendish Club had the first of its games last week and will continue them on Wednesday nights; the Regency Club will hold the first of its regular Tuesday night games day after tomorrow.

By the end of 1943 "air transport will approach parity with wartime ocean shipping," according to a statement issued from Washington last week by the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America. The chamber based the statement on information from Army Air Force commanders.

AT a time when Raymond Daniell and other well-informed London correspondents are bringing into the open the serious disagreement between Russia on the one hand and Great Britain and the United States on the other over the opening of a second front, this stimulating and provocative book on our relations with the Soviet Union has especial interest.

YOU can serve your weekly roast of beef or your leg of lamb cold instead of hot. If you do that, it can be carved in thinner slices and it will last longer. You can take your bath in a third or less of the water that you usually splash around in. You can take a roomer, or even two roomers, though you have never had strangers living in your house before.

In a move to prevent deterioration of new passenger-cars and trucks held in the national reserve, the OPA machinery section explained yesterday what kinds of rust-inhibiting oil must be used to meet Office of Price Administration and War Production Board requirements.

A SOUTH ENGLAND VILLAGE, Oct. 3 -- This village that mourned its dead at the Battle of Agincourt in 1415 buried today twenty-four of its schoolboys, who were part of every villager's hopes for England's future, in a ceremony of magnificent simple grandeur.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 3 -- Brown opened its season by defeating Rhode Island State, 28 -- 0, before 9,000 persons today. After a scoreless first period Brown gathered momentum and scored once in the second period, twice in the third and once in the last.

HAROLD NICOLSON was lecturing recently to the Yugoslav Club in London on "The Approach to English Literature." His task was to convey to a foreign audience, consisting mainly of soldiers and civil servants, a true impression of a literature which depends largely for its effect upon association and suggestion, and which therefore does not easily evoke the proper response in people trained in other habits of mind and language.

Not only is the health of the people of Great Britain satisfactory, despite the war, but in the case of many individuals it has been improved by the diet enforced by rationing. Dr. William M. Fraser, medical officer of health of Liverpool and Professor of Hygiene at the University of Liverpool, declared yesterday afternoon when he arrived at the marine terminal at La Guardia Field aboard a transatlantic Flying Ace with five other passengers.
LUMBERTON, N.C., Oct. 3 (AP) -- A gasoline tank truck exploded today after it was in collision with a Queen City Trailways bus and at least eleven persons lost their lives in the inferno.

Appointment of chairmen of the professional, trade and other groups taking part in the 1942 merged campaign of the New York and Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities was announced yesterday by George Z. Medalie, president of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City, and Hugh Grant Straus, president of the Brooklyn federation.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 3 (AP) -- A great Auburn team ripped the glitter off Tulane today, forced the Green Wave into constant goal line defense and wound up victor, 27 to 13, before 30,000 spectators.

The Propeller Club of the United States, which will hold its sixteenth annual convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on Oct. 15 and 16 in conjunction with the annual American Merchant Marine Conference, announced yesterday that the convention would have the largest attendance thus far, with more than 2,500 members, delegates and guests already registered.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 3 -- In a dazzling display of gridiron pyrotechnics featured by two lightning-fast backfields, Ohio State defeated Indiana today, 32 to 21, before 48,227 fans in the season's inaugural Western Conference game.

Retail trade was active here last week as consumers increased their purchases of seasonal merchandise. However, sharp declines in comparison with a year ago were noted for many stores. In the 1941 week "beat-the-tax" buying reached its climax just before Oct. 1, resulting in extremely high sales figures.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 3 -- Wartime need for a wider appreciation of American history has prompted a change in the approach to that subject as taught in the freshman year at Princeton University, it was disclosed today by President Harold W. Dodds.

OSTENSIBLY "The Lieutenant's Lady" is another novel in the succession of Bess Streeter Aldrich's popular and well-loved romances. Actually it has less the air of a novel than of a work of non-fiction. Not Mrs. Aldrich but chance and the hardships of the American frontier shaped the course of this romance which took place three-quarters of a century ago.

As a reminder to New Yorkers to mail Christmas gifts early to American troops overseas and to choose war bonds as the safest gifts, since they can be reissued if lost in transit, a Christmas tree was dedicated yesterday in front of the Hotel Paris, West End Avenue and Ninety-seventh Street, by Bruce Smith, associate State administrator of the War Savings Staff.

THIS is a personal story, with a physical background stretching from the River Don in Russia across Siberia, down through Mongolia and Northwestern China to the lofty, inhospitable Altyn Tagh, first step to the Kunlun ranges bordering Tibet.

HISTORY was being made in Alaska long before the days of "Seward's folly" and the Klondike gold rush, the salmon fisheries and the fog-hidden warfare of today. The Russians were there first. The late eighteenth and early nineteenth century exploitation and colonization of Kodiak, Sitka and other points is recounted in lively and scholarly detail by Hector Chevigny in his biography of Baranov, "Lord of Alaska."

IT is really too bad that Hollywood has not done more with the short story than it has -- that is, with the "single-incident" genus of story material which packs its inherent wallop in an unexpected pay-off or "twist." Heaven knows, on many occasions the film folks have labored manfully to stretch a short-story idea into feature-picture length.

WHEN Maxwell Anderson, the eminent playwright, bought me a steak at the Rainbow Grill in Fayetteville, N.C., some months ago I did not think he planned to use either me or the grill in a play called "The Eve of St. Mark."
MINNA CITRON is resuming private instruction at her studio, 32 Union Square, this Winter in drawing and painting in all media, including maroger.

With many voters absent from their voting residences because of the war, leaders of all political parties have made plans for more than usual efforts to get as large a registration as possible during the registration period, which will begin tomorrow in New York City and on Friday in the rest of the State.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 3 -- The old football master, Lieut. Col. Bernie Bierman, came back home today to teach his star pupil, Dr. George Hauser, one more lesson, but it was only by the narrowest of margins that he did so, as his Iowa Seahawks triumphed over Minnesota, 7 -- 6, before a crowd of 37,500.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 3 -- The expected happened in Harvard's old stadium today, but only as regards the score. Pennsylvania's veteran and highly favored football squad turned back the Crimson, 19 to 7, but if the Cantabs had held on to the ball in the first half they might have had a tie and none of the 20,000 in the stands, predominantly Harvard, could have felt he hadn't received his full money's worth.

UNDER circumstances of drama unprecedented in the long history of movie premieres, "We Are the Marines," the March of Time's latest full-length feature, will have its first showing some time this month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The labor sections of President Roosevelt's economic control order today removed, for the first time in American history, the freedom of employers and trade unions to negotiate wage contracts without recourse to government.

AN interesting exception to run-of-the-mine historical novels is this romance of colonial and revolutionary times in North Carolina, for the author has given at least as much attention to the complexities of local politics as to the fortunes of her main characters.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The users of fuel oil will not be required to stand in line at registration places to qualify themselves for supplies this Winter under the rationing plan now in technical effect, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 3 -- Forty basic University of Michigan R.O.T.C. students, commanded by three cadet officers, moved into the bare-walled military barracks of a student dormitory Tuesday, prepared to live through the semester under a strict military supervision that mill require special passes even for dates.

The second annual exhibition of prints selected from the Brooklyn Museum's permanent collection of salon photographs is currently on view in the entrance gallery, first floor of the museum, Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, where it will be displayed through Nov. 29.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- Offering a post-graduate course in explosives safety, a unique school -- the only one of its kind in the nation -- is sending safety experts from Chicago to munitions plants throughout the country to save lives and property so vital to the American war effort.

The growing production of the United States and Great Britain and the hardier morale among the free peoples of the United Nations are two factors that should help to bring final victory over the Axis powers, Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador, declared yesterday at the annual forum of the Foreign Policy Association.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 3 (AP) -- North Carolina found an ace in the form of Clay Croom today and defeated the University of South Carolina, 18-6 before 12,000 persons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The modern battleship, frequently compared adversely with the bomber as a weapon in warfare, really complements the bomber in a new type of balanced warfare at sea. Rear Admiral G.J. Rowcliff, member of the Navy's General Board, stated in an article published in the United States News.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 3 (AP) -Syracuse overcame Boston University at football tonight, 25 -- 0, before a crowd of about 10,000. The Orange made sixteen first downs to Boston's four, and ground out 226 yards by rushing. The Terriers, who never seriously threatened to score, gained only fourteen yards on the ground and completed only two of eleven passes for 16.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Great Lakes Bluejackets, pride of Uncle Sam's seagoing forces back in '18, returned to the football glory road today with a smashing 25 to 0 victory over Iowa's previously undefeated Hawkeyes.

EVEN if the Office of War Information justly finds some faults in Hollywood's treatment of war problems, the screen has avoided, in recent months, one heretofore popular delusion -- namely, that the only notable excitement in the life of a military man comes when he falls in love with another military man's girl and then saves the life of the other at the sacrifice of his own.

AN AMERICAN ARMY BASE, in the Aleutian Islands, Sept. (Delayed) -- The United States Army, starting a campaign to oust Japanese troops from the Western Aleutian Islands, has occupied this island within fighter-plane range of Japanese-occupied Kiska.

The annual Pulaski Memorial Day parade, under the auspices of the General Pulaski Memorial Committee of Metropolitan New York, will begin at 1:15 P.M. today. Following the parade, a Polish War Bond rally will be held on the Mall in Central Park.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Oct. 3 -- Concern was expressed here today by Dr. J.F. Zimmerman, president of the University of New Mexico, at the decreased enrollment among colleges in the West. He warned that the country would need college-trained men and women during the years of post-war reconstruction.

AN exhibition of Dutch paintings by masters of the seventeenth century will be formally opened by His Excellency, Dr. Alexander Loudon, at a private view to be held at the Duveen Galleries on Thursday afternoon, Oct. 8.

Kentucky's 150th anniversary of Statehood is being celebrated this year with pageants, fairs and with formal sessions at historic sites throughout the State. Illustrious sons of Kentucky who have given distinguished service to their homeland in past decades are being honored in county festivals.

Mrs. Arthur Ballantine will give a tea Wednesday in her apartment at River House, at which Miss Mary Lee Allison will speak on "The Revival of Colonial Industries at Stratford Plantation." Stratford Hall, situated in Westmoreland County, Virginia, is the historic home of the Lee family and is owned and maintained by the Robert E. Lee Memorial Foundation, Inc. Mrs. Charles W. Kellogg is the foundation's director for New York.

IF Bruno Walter is a Mozart expert, Lily Pons has not appeared, at least at the Metropolitan Opera House, in that composer's works. They collaborate in an album of Mozart Arias (Columbia M-518, three 10-inch records), and the result, from an artistic point of view, is rather mixed.

TUESDAY evening sees the opening of the Hurok "Season of Ballet" at the Metropolitan Opera House, with the Ballet Theatre in residence for the first seven of its scheduled twenty-one performances. Departing on Oct. 12 for a ten-day tour of near-by cities including Boston, it will leave the local field to the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, which will hold forth through Oct. 20.
WHEN Toscanini opens the season of the Philharmonic with Berlioz's "Romeo and Juliet" on Oct. 7, New Yorkers will be enabled to hear this large-scale choral symphony for the first time since 1882.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Al Pick, an obscure guard on Northwestern's bench for two years, had his big moment today. With the Wildcats and Texas in a scoreless deadlock for 3 1/2 periods, the West Bend, Wis., senior came in to kick a field goal from the 19-yard line and bring Northwestern a 3-to-0 triumph before 43,000 limp spectators in Dyche Stadium.

MARCY, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- A crash heard in the vicinity this week was of a bottleneck breaking. It started to split as the streamlined doors of the first NYA girls' resident center in the field of aviation mechanics in the country swung open to meet the labor shortage in aircraft repair.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- A big force of heavy British bombers visited the Rhineland again last night and left great fires blazing among German factories.

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 3 -- Within twenty-five years the country will face an accelerating decline in population so serious that unless it becomes a major purpose of national policy to maintain the family unit as an institution for the transmission of race, wealth and culture it will make little difference who wins this war, in the opinion of Dr. O.E. Baker, Professor of Economic Geography at the University of Maryland.

There was a reminiscent tone on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, for volume was 445,920 shares in the two-hour session, and activity on the floor resembled that of earlier, happier days. The turnover, accompanied by a solid upward movement which extended gains by fractions to a point and sent stocks to the high levels of the current movement, was the best since Jan. 3, when investors were straightening out year-end tax transactions.

Fashions of the future, based on new synthetic fabrics, as yet not released for general consumption, will be on display Tuesday, when "Fashions of THE TIMES" opens at the New York Times Hall. 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Viscount Wolmer, 30-year-old heir of the Earl of Selborne and captain in a British infantry regiment, was killed on the field of manoeuvers yesterday when a live artillery shell exploded in the middle of his platoon.
A FORWARD step in the democracy of fashion is seen in the interest of some of New York's ace designers in the war plant workers.

In furtherance of the New Opera Company's drive to raise the $150,000 required to finance its second season, a Committee of Endorsement is being formed, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Lytle Hull, president. The partly completed committee is headed by officers of the armed forces, State and city officials and leaders of war service organizations.

LONDON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Two hundred and seventeen Croats were reported today by Reuter to have been executed for the death of a German shot during a parade by the German minority of a Croatian village. Croatia is an Axis puppet State, a part of Yugoslavia.

Fall Rose Garden Day will be held at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden at 3:30 P.M. on Thursday. Members of the Garden and guests are invited to view the roses which are now at the peak of their Fall bloom.

THE third annual presentation of works of art by American artists, acquired by the Louise Caldwell Murdock Trust, will be made to the Wichita (Kan.) Art Museum early next month. The purchases, selected by Elizabeth S. Navas, trustee of the Murdock Trust, include six oils, four water-colors and two pieces of sculpture.

DETROIT, Oct. 3 (AP) -- C.E. Wilson, president of the General Motors Corporation, made public today a letter to the War Labor Board advising it that "due to the 'all-out' war in which our country is engaged" the corporation would comply with recent directive orders.
The recent order of the New York City Police Department calling for the registering of all those using rifle ranges within the metropolis is meeting the opposition of sportsmen.

AT a moment when emotions are deeply stirred we have these two books on India. Major Yeats-Brown is the Bengal Lancer who crashed the studios of Hollywood. He visualizes the India that is in his blood -- her races and religions, wealth and poverty, traditions and aspirations -- as a "pageant," gorgeous and grim, that rises above and spreads beyond dialectical immediacies.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 3 -- Piles of iron ore on docks in the Lower Great Lakes and in furnace yards at the first of next year will be large enough to keep steel mills operating at capacity for eight months, shippers estimated today.

IN his books Stephen Meader always contrives to put into a natural and authentic setting the elements of suspense and excitement which young readers from 12 to 15 find highly satisfactory. The scene of this, his latest story, is laid in the New Jersey Pine Barrens, where the 15-year-old hero, Ted Winslow, helps round up a gang of Nazi fifth columnists who are threatening the safety of Fort Dix.

MOSCOW, Oct. 3 -- The Red Army defending Stalingrad did not need Adolf Hitler's confirmation that Stalingrad was the Wehrmacht's major objective. Some thirty of Hitler's divisions are engaged in a direct assault on a forty-mile front at Stalingrad, while the total number of the enemy involved in the whole Don-Volga salient is credibly estimated at a million.

Before a Congressional committee, at meetings of industrial manager, in the halls of schools and colleges, the nation last week debated how best to use its 130,000,000 people in war work. Men were pouring out of civilian life into the Army; there will be more than 10,000,000 of them in uniform by the end of next year.

ANGELA THIRKELL is frank to say that English county families are a pretty dull lot. And then she proceeds to write about them in so delightful, humorous and well-bred a manner as to make them thoroughly enchanting.

WHAT happened on Outlaw Island is something that District Attorney Jerry Carver would like very much to know. The facts that he is able to glean are that Mrs. Margot Van Pelt arrived at the island, was not seen to leave it and has not been seen since that time.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- Striking with a fury that established a twelve-point lead in as many minutes and crippled Walt Kretz, Cornell's big ace, on the third scrimmage of the game, Colgate defeated the Big Red on Schoellkopf Field today before a crowd of 12,000. The score was 18 to 6.

Dean Alfange, American Labor party nominee for Governor, making his first speech here yesterday since his recent return from a 1,200-mile up-State campaign tour, declared he was convinced the two major political parties would suffer a "resounding political reversal" on election day and that he and his entire State ticket would be swept into office.

Among the patients in the contagious ward of the hospital where Norma Gale is a student nurse is a woman who insists that she has scarlet fever, although the doctors are sure that it is nothing worse than German measles, and who is given to singing "John Brown's Body" at odd hours to the annoyance of the other patients.

MEXICO, D.F., Oct. 3 -- Women of Mexico have watched the war mobilization of the women of Russia, England and the United States -- watched and waited until their country went to war. Now, five months after Mexico joined the United Nations against the Axis, the women of Mexico are applying the lessons they learned in a burst of activity that has startled many observers.

Because of the tremendous stocks of wool held in this country, all branches of the men's clothing industry, from wool growers to retailers, joined in the assertion last week that an immediate review of the situation should be conducted by the War Production Board to eliminate conservation orders, which have disrupted various branches of the market since early this year.

Eight recommendations for night driving of automobiles during blackouts to reduce accidents and prevent interference with military and other official movements were made public yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, director of the Office of Civilian Defense in the Second Region.

In 28,000 high schools throughout the country, teachers, principals and superintendents are now engaged in organizing the 6,500,000 secondary students into Victory Corps more adequately to utilize the youth in the war effort. Every boy and girl of high school age will be mobilized for duty on the civilian front.

A government-sponsored program to select high school students who show promise in engineering and to finance them through college must be adopted immediately if the nation's war effort is not to suffer from an acute shortage of engineers, Dean Thorndike Saville of the New York University College of Engineering declared yesterday.

As part of the observation of National Newspaper Week, which opened Thursday and will continue until next Thursday, three outstanding religious leaders have issued statements praising the American press for its work in promoting the principles of religion.

Retail trade was active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- President Roosevelt appointed Associate Justice James F. Byrnes of the Supreme Court today to be Director of Economic Stabilization, clothed him with sweeping authority to control civilian purchasing power, created a board to help him coordinate and command the war upon inflationary living costs, and ordered the immediate stabilization of farm prices, urban and rural rents, wages and salaries paid in industry.

The sophomores and the newfangled QT formation that Manhattan's football forces are basing their hopes on this season both came through in spectacular fashion in their first test under fire to the consternation of a hapless Muhlenberg eleven at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Michigans mighty Wolveriness held scoreless for forty minutes by an underdog Michigan State football team, ran to three quick touchdowns in the second half today, to win, 20 to 0, for their most decisive victory in ten years of the intrastate series.
WEBSTER GROVES, Mo., Oct. 3 -- Special scholarships have been made available to Latin-American and Canadian students at Webster College, it was announced today by Dr. George F. Donovan, president.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 -- A series of new and timely courses, world-wide in scope, will be presented by Temple University during the Fall semester, it was announced today by Dr. Robert L. Johnson, president.

Whirlaway and Occupation won at Belmont Park yesterday in a sweep of favorites that saw thoroughbred racing reach one of its highest peaks, even as the shadow of war deepened over the future of the sport.

An unbelievable amount of action is crowded into this story of Jessamine and her admirers. She lived on a huge North Carolina plantation with her ancient Aunt Ellen, who ruled her superintendent and her mills with the proverbial rod.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Mixing deception with speed, Duquesne University's slick ball handlers rolled up their fifteenth straight football victory by crushing Holy Cross, 25 -- 0, before a crowd of 12,000 today.

Sam Breadon, president and owner of the Cardinals, said last night that he had given the Dodgers' management permission to discuss the club's vacancies with Branch Rickey, general manager of the Cardinals, The Associated Press reported.

Herrick, the company's director of personnel, who announced several weeks ago that women would be accepted and trained to replace skilled men workers taken by military services.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Yankees and the Cardinals shoud have no trouble getting back to St. Louis next week on regularly scheduled trains if the fortunes of baseball extend the world series beyond five games, the Office of Defense Transportation said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 -- A plan for outright divestment of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company from the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation holding company system was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, closing a long and bitter legal battle.

Establishment of a department of religion at Columbia College is now being considered, Dr. Herbert E. Hawkes, dean of the college, said yesterday in his annual report to the president of the university, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler. However, both the dean and the Rev. Stephen F. Bayne Jr., university chaplain, declared that the question was entirely open and that at least a year would be required before a decision could be reached.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 3 -- The Virginia General Assembly, meeting in special session this week, enacted legislation which achieves the double purpose of putting to work millions of dollars in idle State funds, through the purchase of Federal bonds, and of gradually paying off the State debt of $18,500,000 with the interest on those bonds.

ONE of the interesting facts about William Burke, Southern Methodist missionary in China, was that he went to school with Charlie Soon. who later, having added a "g" to his name, became the father of two girls who were to marry, respectively, Sun Yat-sen and Chiang Kai-shek, and of an almost equally famous son. T.V. Soong.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- Bear hunts and a series of squirrel hunts have been announced for this section beginning this week. A maximum of 100 men a day will be permitted to hunt squirrels on the Pisgah National Forest game preserve from tomorrow to Oct. 24.

PRICE and wage ceilings are nothing new on the American scene. Back in 1777, in the Revolutionary War, prices were galloping skyward, there was general consternation at the wages demanded by "mechaniks" and laborers, and State Legislatures passed acts "For the Prevention of Monopoly and Oppression" which empowered towns to impose maximum prices on commodities and limit wages.

NEARLY forty years of distinguished, unremitting service in the Army of the United States lay behind the generalship of the heartbreaking, inspiring defense of Bataan and Corregidor. During those tense weeks America gratefully discovered its No. 1 hero of this war and wanted, as is its unfailing custom, to know all about him.

On the exposed cones of our New England mountains, at sea level along the North Atlantic coast, and characteristically at low elevations to the northward in Newfoundland, Labrador and Greenland, the Mountain or Three-toothed Cinquefoil (Potentilla tridentata) often grows in considerable abundance.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Vanderbilt Commodores, unleashing a smooth-working attack which struck alternately through the air and on the ground, marched to an almost effortless 26-0 victory over Purdue before 18,000 surprised spectators today.

Evander Childs High, rated one of the strongest teams in the city, displayed abundant power in defeating Commerce by 20 -- 0 before a crowd of 4,000 in the opener of the schoolboy football double-header at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Oct. 3 -- Co-eds are taking over the Bureau of Municipal Research at Kalamazoo College. Since 1934, when the bureau was started through the mutual efforts of Dr. R.C. Cornell, head of the Department of Political Science, and City Manager E.C. Rutz, the personnel has been drawn entirely from among the men of the campus.

SOME people are born out of time and out of place and, try as they may, never win through to a place, a time, where they belong. With dignity and restraint, in fact, almost too much restraint, Klaus Mann traces the outlines of disinheritance.

A service men's lounge, said to be the largest of its type in the country, will be opened Oct. 14 in Grand Central Terminal, it was announced yesterday by Donald S. Stralem, president of the Travelers Aid Society of New York, sponsor of the project.
LANCASTER, Pa., Oct. 3 -- Under its new coach, Richard W. Barker, Franklin and Marshall College overwhelmed Fort Hamilton today, 59 to 0, before 4,000 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The none-too-good news from the war production front emphasized this week to many experts and observers why Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chairman, must be tougher if the United Nations are to come through to an early victory in what President Roosevelt himself-has described as the toughest of all wars in the history of the world.
TWO American ladies engage our attention today, both young in one sense, but immensely old in another. Claudia is the first.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Oct. 2 (Delayed) -- Exactly what the Japanese are up to in New Guinea appeared uncertain tonight, and the Australian forces who have been thrusting the enemy back along the Port Moresby-Buna trail operated with the utmost caution.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- To help students understand more fully the workings of American democracy and to prepare young women to fill today's urgent need for government employes, a public administration course has been established at Elmira College.

With gardens being revamped and more space given to vegetable plots, many gardeners are interested in getting the greatest possible returns from the smallest areas in their ornamental plantings. Right here the rock garden fits into the picture perfectly.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- A warning by Walter M. Dear, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, and publisher of The Jersey Journal of Jersey City, that newspapers could not "surrender the right of a free press to condemn and criticize where we consider the circustances justified," was repeated in the House during National Newspaper Week.

THERE was hot stuff at the Yankee Stadium yesterday and most of it was pitching. Spud Chandler and Ernie White, the opposing pitchers, really were hot. The pitching was too good for the hitters and too bad for the spectators. It spoiled the fun. The batters might as well have been carted to the plate in tumbrils for the execution.

Ninety-one enemy aliens were seized in raids in New York City, Westchester and Nassau last week. P.E. Foxworth, agent in charge of the local Federal Bureau of Investigation office, announced yesterday.
POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- The Pocono resorts remaining open through the Fall are making plans for Columbus Day week-end -- a holiday that always brings large crowds of visitors.

THE eighty-third annual Worcester Music Festival will be held this week in Worcester, Mass. Participants will include the Worcester Festival Chorus and Orchestra, conducted by Albert Stoessel, and numerous vocal and instrumental soloists.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 3 -- The Naval Academy football team mixed power, splendid backfield work, alertness in intercepting passes and capitalizing on opponent's errors today to defeat the University of Virginia, 35 to 0, before 16,000 spectators in Thompson Stadrum.

In an effort to help teachers develop leadership traits in their students, an in-service course, sponsored by the Board of Education for instructors in the city schools from the fifth year through high school, was begun last Wednesday by Mrs. Sabra Holbrook, executive director of Youthbuilders, Inc., at the Straubenmiller Textile High School.

WAKE FOREST, N.C., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Duke University's remnants of Rose Bowl glory were trampled into the dust today when Wake Forest outclassed the favorites and won a Southern Conference football game, 20 -- 7, before a crowd of 7,010.

Obviously, if you failed to consume the two and a half pounds a week now prescribed there is no need to change your dietary habits.

Representatives of sixty-five scrap iron dealers and 1,000 organized employes in the city's scrap industry yesterday signed a "scrap for victory" labor contract which outlaws strikes and work stoppages and sets up an emergency labor-management council to make all the tricks of the trade available to the various agencies cooperating in the salvage drive.

Twelve thousand persons gathered at Belden Point, City Island, yesterday, watched a demonstration of torpedo bombing and strafing by Grumman Avenger and Wildcat fighting planes as they dived in sham attack on speeding torpedo boats and heard Rear Admiral James M. Irish and twenty United Nations heroes emphasize the great need for the minesweepers, invasion barges, "crash" boats and other patrol craft produced in the district.

Indicating an investigation into the flare-up between Frankie Crosetti, Yankee third baseman, and Umpire Bill Summers at third base in the ninth inning of yesterday's third world series game came the information that Summers had been summoned last night by Kenesaw Mountain Landis, baseball's commissioner, for a report on the incident.

AN elderly housewife sitting on the porch of her home in a New England town adjusts her spectacles and stares at the notice in a local paper. She thinks of her sailor son from whom she has not heard in months and wonders -- with fear.

LONDON, Oct. 3 (Canadian Press) -- Blackpool's high-scoring team registered its sixth successive victory to remain in front in the English Football League's Northern Section today. The only unbeaten and untied team in Britain, Blackpool downed Stockport by 6 -- 2, increasing its goal total for the season to forty.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 3 -Overwhelming ground superiority, with Ralph Hill's 72-yard touchdown dash as the high spot, netted Army's football forces a 14-to-0 triumph over a stubborn Lafayette eleven before 7,000 in the season's opener at Michie Stadium today.

Although the pay-as-you-go tax plan suggested by Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the New York Federal Reserve Bank and treasurer of R.H. Macy Co., possesses in itself a great deal of merit, it would more fully justify itself if used in combination with a plan which would make feasible the adoption of a system of withholding at a substantial rate of tax without double taxation.

TYLERTOWN, Miss., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Secretary Wickard said here today that agriculture in wartime must be limited to "producing only the farm products which are absolutely essential" and predicted the time "when the lot of farmers will seem hard -- much harder than it is now."
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 3 (AP) -- A world's record for 3-year-old pacers was equaled today by Lilydale in winning the Geers, feature of the fourth day of the Lexington Grand Circuit meeting.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- Twenty-eight classes were judged during the opening sessions of the annual horse show of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today. The exhibition will continue tomorrow afternoon.

The current auctioning of part of the collection of the late Colonel E.H.R. Green, at seven public sales lasting through November, seems to reflect an unprecedented interest in philately during wartime. The initial offering, through H.C. Barr on Sept. 23-26, clearly indicated, observers said last week, a tremendous amount of absorption power.

ON THE FRENCH FRONTIER, Oct. 3 (U.P.) -- Reports from France tell of spreading violence and repressive measures, including deportation of 6,000 persons from Paris, a round-up of thousands of hostages, the arrest of seventeen alleged British agents and the turning over to the Gestapo of seven prominent anti-Nazi Germans.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The War Production Board today limited the production of heavy forged hand tools in a new schedule which states that such tools which do not conform to the size, type, grade, finish, weight and standards established by Limitation Order L-157 may not be produced except on approval of WPB.

AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 3 -- University of Texas students in every department will be required after this year to have six hours, or a full year, of American history for graduation, by unanimous action of the Board of Regents here.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 3 -- Very Snooty, from the Brookmeade Stable, led most of the way today to win the fifteenth Richard Johnson Stakes, picking up a purse of $5,650.
ELMIRA -- In Elmira the Mark Twain legend is growing. Plans are afoot for a Mark Twain Association to perpetuate the memory of the city's share in the life of the great humorist.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 3 -General Field Marshal Erwin Rommel, who has been consulting with Adolf Hitler in Berlin and at Herr Hitler's field headquarters, told German and foreign newspaper men today that the war in North Africa was being fought under trying conditions by Germany and her Italian ally.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Able Seaman Jimmy Dean has developed a useful knack of leaving ships just before they are sunk. He has done it seven times since the war started. The best known of his late vessels were the battleship Royal Oak, the minesweeper Rajputana and the battleship Prince of Wales.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 3 (AP) -- American bombers and fighters were reported by the United States Army Air Forces Headquarters here today to have left areas of destruction at Japanese bases in Upper Burma and the adjoining Chinese province of Yunnan during sorties Sunday and Monday.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 3 -- Georgia Tech, sending out a group of speedy backs, one a freshman, punched holes in the Notre Dame line and filled the air with passes to win, 13 to 6, today. It was the first Irish defeat in eleven games and the second Tech victory over Notre Dame in thirteen years.

MOSCOW, Oct. 3 -- Major Gen. Nikolai Zhuravleff, writing in the Moscow News of the situation around Mozdok in the Caucasus, declares the fighting is extremely tense and complicated, but is likely to continue on a furious scale for some time.

OTTAWA, Oct. 3 -- The sober analysis of the facts of the Dieppe raid, as presented in the frank account issued ten days ago by the Canadian Defense Ministry and supplemented by Prime Minister Churchill's statement in the House of Commons this past week, has brought a much deeper realization in Canada than there has been until now of how hard the road to victory will be.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Telling Europe that trainloads of food from the Ukraine have just reached Berlin, Nazi broadcasters interpret this novel spectacle not only as proof of the material utility of recent conquests but as a tangible sign of the long-promised new era of plenty into which Europe is to be led by Nazi military might and organizing skill.

GRACE MOORE is of the opinion that 20 per cent is too much for an artist to be obliged to pay a concert manager. She thinks there should be a "revolution," and this season is acting as her own manager. She is highly pleased with the results.

The Swiss postal administration has made available advance illustrations of this year's "Pro Juventute" (For Youth) semi-postal anti-tuberculosis series: 5-centimes plus 5c green, 10c plus 5c brown and yellow, 20c plus 5c red and yellow, 30c plus 10c blue.

This being a day and age wherein wonders never cease, it remained for the largest world series crowd on record to see diamond history made at the Yankee Stadium yesterday as the 1942 wartime classic came sweeping into New York.

Proposals for using physically and mentally handicapped persons in the war and post-war emergencies were submitted yesterday to the United States Office of Education Wartime Commission at the end of a two-day conference in which educators and administrators specializing in these fields joined in discussion with executives of Federal departments and commissions.

New York City's labor unions in the A.F. of L. and the C.I.O., having combined their forces to collect waste material for the nation's scrap pile, leaders of both groups reported yesterday an enthusiastic response from their members that was expected to bring thousands of tons of scrap metal in the current salvage drive.

ALBANY, Oct. 3 -- Contracts for more than 4,000,000 gallons of gasoline went today to the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company and the Sinclair Refining Company as New York began mass buying to give its communities the benefit of State-contract prices.

MORE DUST STORMS -- The Egyptian desert is now having dust storms at the rate of one a week, an increase of more than tenfold over the average before 1940, according to a report by Dr. H. Heywood of the Imperial College of Science and Technology, in the British scientific journal Nature.

A patriotic tribute will be paid to the U.S. Coast Guard by Bundles for America on the night of Oct. 14 when a dinner dance and entertainment will be given in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador. The occasion will be a pre-opening of the Trianon Room for its late Autumn and Winter season.

HOUSE ARREST: Edouard Herriot, three times Premier of France, is seventy years old but an undaunted Republican still. Three weeks ago he was co-author of an open letter addressed to Marshal Petain, chief of the Vichy State, protesting the abandonment of Parliament and moves to draw France into war at Germany's side.

A new treatment for celiac disease, a malady of infants and children which sometimes proves fatal, is announced in the current issue of the Journal of Pediatrics, official organ of the American Academy of Pediatrics. The new treatment eliminates the banana diet which hitherto has been required to save the victims' lives, so that infants and children need no longer die because of the current banana shortage.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Before a crowd of 15,000, taking advantage of the last day of special trains to Rockingham Park, K.D. Smith's Charitable won the Lost River Handicap today to pay $29.20 for $2.

BOSTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Boston College swung from the heels in the first two minutes today and West Virginia never did recover as the Eagles went on to humble the Mountaineers, 33 -- 0, in an impressive 1942 gridiron debut before a crowd of 18,000.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 3 -- Wendell L. Willkie's vigorous and engaging manner served him well today as he went to work, as he put it, "to further foster Chinese-American friendship while finding out some facts."

HARTSVILLE, S.C., Oct. 3 -- Designed to contribute to the literary renaissance of the South, and in particular to promote intelligently appreciative interest in creative writing and literature among Southern college and high school students, the Coker Literary Festival was held here this week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Army and Navy Journal, which often reflects opinion in the armed services, declared today that it was fortunate that Wendell Willkie had ceased to be "the personal representative" of President Roosevelt, else he might be demanding in Chungking "with some semblance of authority that a second front be established immediately in proximity to Japan."

THE deal whereby United Artists would acquire a group of Paramount pictures was finalized last week. Twenty-two films, in finished and unfinished form, are involved in the agreement and will be turned over to United Artists for distribution this season and in 1943-44.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- Major Gen. Francis B. Wilby, superintendent of the Military Academy, announced today the appointment of Cadet James E. Kelleher of San Antonio as first captain of the Corps of Cadets. Kelleher, an end on the football team, was acting first captain for the Summer.

Mrs. Paul Garrett will give a large cocktail party on Oct. 20 at the Stork Club as one of the Autumn projects of the New Opera Company to raise funds for the purchase of seats for service men for performances of the company during its 1942 season.

October is the month to send Christmas presents to the men in the armed forces abroad. If you mail them later they may not arrive in time. Remember, too, that there are certain "don'ts" to be observed. Army and Navy remind you that stale cakes, cookies reduced to crumbs and spoiled fruit do not make for a merry holiday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The President's statement to his homecoming press conference that he deplores the "we-are-losing-the-war" speeches which some of his highest-placed subordinates made during his absence spotlights a corner of the disorganization and confusion that attend the direction of the war program by Washington.

All tipster sheets on the races and the numbers or policy games must be removed from the city's newsstands, it was announced yesterday by Commissioner Paul Moss of the Department of Licenses in a statement backing up Mayor La Guardia's anti-gambling crusade.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Acting promptly in compliance with a directive by President Roosevelt under the new price control legislation which became law yesterday, Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, today placed emergency price ceilings, effective Monday, on virtually all food items hitherto exempt from price control.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 -- On the defensive for the first time since Congress passed the "death sentence" clause, the Securities and Exchange Commission will go into the Third Circuit Court of Appeals here on Tuesday to do battle with the United Gas Improvement Company on the question of the constitutionality of that all-important part of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935.

WASHINGTON, Oct.3 -- The War Labor Board today allowed a wage increase of four cents an hour to 90,000 Chrysler Corporation employes who had sought a 12 1/2-cent raise. The decision also set forth a definition of "pay inequalities" significant in connection with the discretionary duties imposed on the board under President Roosevelt's new anti-inflation order.

The Children's Village, historic colony school at Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., will observe its ninety-first Autumn since its founding in 1851 with a benefit theatre party here on the night of Nov. 17. The Village Board of Directors has taken over the entire Martin Beck Theatre for that night for the performance of the S.N. Behrman comedy, "The Pirate," starring Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne.

New Yorkers celebrated the opening of the Croton Aqueduct 100 years ago this month. A venerable print shows the parade passing the fountain of Croton water playing at the corner of City Hall Park where the old post-office was afterward built.

Captain Thomas Blau, U.S.N.R., recently named commandant of the United States Maritime Service, has returned from sea duty in war zones to take up his new post in Washington, the War Shipping Administration announced yesterday. One of the best known men in the shipping industry, the captain has had nearly fifty years of seafaring and shipping experience, although he is not yet 60 years old.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- A self-governing community, complete with police, fire and health services, has been established by nearly 3,000 American civilians interned by the Japanese at Manila, the Office of War Information said today.
PITTSBURGH, OCT. 3 -- Pitt's Golden Panthers, flashing old Pitt power at times, surprised by trouncing Southern Methodist, 20 -- 7, today before a crowd of 15,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Positions in the Andreanof group of islands in the Aleutians have been occupied, without opposition, by American Army troops with naval support, the Navy announced today. The movement took place "recently," and Army aircraft, including Flying Fortresses and pursuit planes, now are operating from airfields in the islands, it was stated.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 3 (U.P.) -- Thomas A. Sharp, 59 years old, past president of the New York State Association of Local Insurance Agents, was in the Monroe County Jail today in lieu of $50,000 bail, to await action by the Grand Jury on Oct. 19 on charges of first degree grand larceny in connection with an alleged insurance fraud involving $255,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Campaigning for their second consecutive undefeated football season, the University of Delaware Blue Hens swamped Drexel today, 40 to 0. It was Delaware's second victory of the season. They are now unbeaten in fourteen games.

NEWS from conquered Europe reaches us so rarely that your account of Sept. 20 of musical life in the Netherlands under Nazi rule takes on a special significance. Too few such stories have appeared in our press. Yet the facts are available in neutral countries and at the receiving end of underground networks here and in England.
A world series crowd record was broken at the Yankee Stadium yesterday and a most worthy cause was aided.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 3 -- Appointment of Dr. Marjorie Carpenter as full-time coordinator of war activities at Stephens College for women, here, was announced today by Dr. James Madison Wood, president, as the school opened its 110th academic sessions.

A "bicycle-cade" to expedite the collection of rummage is one of the timely projects adopted by committees now completing arrangements for the fourth annual White Elephant Cocktail Party and Tea Dance to be given on Oct. 15 in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre by the junior division of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee, an affiliate of the State Charities Aid Association.

LIFU is a new and welcome addition to Eleanor Lattimore's gallery of Chinese children. Inquisitive and engaging, he is a child of wartime China, for even in his remote village shut in behind the mountains the war is felt, and most frequently Lifu's questions were of when his soldier father would come home.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses, appointed by Mayor La Guardia as coordinator for the collection of heavy scrap metal in the current newspaper drive, made the following statement yesterday:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- President Roosevelt's appointment of James Francis Byrnes as commander in the battle against inflation makes the South Carolina jurist, who has resigned as an Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court to take the post, one of the most powerful men in the country, after the Chief Executive himself, in the opinion of observers of events.

Preliminary plans for the series of two Mayfair Assemblies to be held later in the season are now being drawn up by two committees of young women of society under the supervision of Miss Clementine Miller, sponsor of the dances. The assemblies are attended by invitation and subscription only and are designed for the entertainment of debutantes of this season and former years and student officers of the armed forces.

Van Courtlandt Short, assistant passenger traffic manager of the United States Lines for the last six years, has been commissioned as a major in the Army Transport Service and will report for duty this week at the New York Port of Embarkation.

GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands, Sept. 21 (Delayed) -- It is becoming increasingly evident that the Allied-Japanese war is being brought to a focus in the Guadalcanal-Tulagi area of the Solomons. From here the Japanese attack on Port Moresby seems diversionary and designed to forestall offensive moves by General Douglas MacArthur while the major Japanese efforts are devoted to counter-offensive action in the Solomons area.
The war will broaden the observance of Fire Prevention Week, proclaimed by President Roosevelt, beginning today, according to an announcement yesterday by the National Board of Fire Underwriters.

A large attendance of members of society is anticipated for the tea and formal invitation preview to be given Thursday afternoon at the Duveen Galleries, 720 Fifth Avenue, to initiate the exhibition of Great Dutch Masters to be held there as a benefit jointly for the Greater New York unit of the American Women's Voluntary Services and the Queen Wilhelmina Fund. The exhibition will be open to the public weekdays from Friday through Nov. 7.

German claims that an undersea "wolf pack" sank three large American troop transports en route to England have been officially denounced by London as untrue. Berlin probably combined wishful thinking with a quest for information. Meanwhile the second reduction in marine insurance rates within a month coincides with the news that in the last week of September only five merchant ships were sunk in the Western Atlantic.
Your article on California pertinent to the fourth centennial of its discovery by Juan Rodriquez Cabrillo, Portuguese explorer in the service of Spain, was most interesting and excellently written.

While President Roosevelt was completing his "confidential" tour of the United States last week the American people were being treated to a series of lectures by generals, admirals, assistant secretaries and heads of agencies. These gentlemen pounded on the table, summoned up a mysterious character known as "We" and damned that character for being overconfident, complacent, not yet awake, or unwilling to make sacrifices.

UNTIL World War II began to make demands upon the nation's manpower, forestry was generally regarded as a profession strictly reserved for men. Today the United States Forest Service is recruiting women for such jobs as tree planting, weeding, fire lookout duty and even for fighting fires.

Reichsfuehrer Hitler's speech in the Berlin Sportpalast last Wednesday showed that he was "clearly on the defensive, not only on the field of battle, but also on the home front," Rabbi Louis I. Newman declared yesterday in Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The resignation of Associate Justice Byrnes from the Supreme Court to become economic stabilization director opened the way today for President Roosevelt to make his eighth appointment to the high tribunal.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 3 -- Out of the throes of Indian travail a new figure has arisen and he holds in his hands more power for good or evil than any single Indian politician. It is that tall, thin, exasperatingly deliberate man who seems to be taking pleasure in keeping the world guessing -- Mohammed Ali Jinnah.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 3 -- Trailing 7 -- 6 at the end of the first half, the Rutgers eleven rallied to score three touchdowns in the last two periods for a 27-to-20 victory over Vermont today.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- United States and British Marines have just completed, "somewhere in England," five-day battle exercises that were so strenuous that Colonel W.I. Jordan. Senior United States Marine Corps officer on the scene, declared:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (Science Service) -- Among 851 United States patents issued this week is one for a bomb sight, patent No. 2,297,132, issued to Romeo A Bossi of Newton Center, Mass.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

OMAHA, Oct. 3 -- Parliamentary jockeying and debate on the President's anti-inflation legislation didn't do much toward clarifying the farmers' understanding of the necessities of the situation. If anything, it only contributed to the confusion over the never-too-clearly understood parity price formula.
INSPIRING light is thrown on the muted struggle for freedom in the countries now dominated by Germany.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 3 -- Just as the Swedes were settling back comfortably for the Winter to enjoy the breathing spell which that season usually grants to those few remaining European neutral countries which otherwise have to be constantly on their guard against aggression, Adolf Hitler gave them something to think about while hibernating.

It is nothing new to find a dignitary of the church condemning the operations of the credit system. In older days the Christian was forbidden to take interest; in modern times the defects of our debtor-creditor money system have been a frequent target of ecclesiastical rebuke.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- A formal protest to President Roosevelt by thirty-three Washington correspondents against the censorship which cut off news of his recent tour of the country, had not been answered tonight and indications were that it was being officially ignored.

WASHINGTON, Oct 3 (AP) -- Two soldiers, who rescued a third man from a wrecked and burning bomber at Memphis each received the Soldier's Medal for heroism today from the War Department. They were Corporal George Barnes of Augusta, Ga., now stationed at Hensley Field, Texas, and Sergeant Ernest L. Kilgore of Hapeville Ga., also at Hensley Field.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Every important war in history has had marked effects on the population trends of the nations engaging in them, and that this is to be true for the United States as a result of its entry into the present war already has been shown by the figures thus far recorded.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Although the United States has always been the world's largest copper producer and has more than doubled its production since 1938, while increasing its imports, the problem of getting sufficient metal for military requirements is "black" and urgent need exists for conservation of existing supplies, substitution of other materials where possible and the gathering of copper scrap.

EAGLES: On an airfield somewhere in England a column of blue-clad R.A.F. pilots last week passed in review for the last time before their British commander. They were members of the three Eagle squadrons of American volunteers.

A group of 434 workers from this area, recruited for the Henry J. Kaiser Company shipyards on it the West Coast, left Jersey City yesterday afternoon at 2:20 o'clock aboard a fifteen-car special train bound for Portland, Ore.

Beneficial effects in the treatment of tuberculosis By means of a diet low in carbohydrates and high in proteins are reported in the September issue of The American Review of Tuberculosis by Dr. Benjamin P. Sandler, now a lieutenant in the Navy Medical Corps, and Dr. Rudolph Berke, now a first lieutenant in the Army Medical Corps.

IT has been assumed for many months now that American troops overseas have been receiving via short-wave radio the pick of our radio entertainment. The biggest names of the show business have volunteered gladly to put together the justly famed program known as "Command Performance.

Miss Widdemer's new novel should satisfy, even delight, her readers, for it fits easily into the shelf with her other stories of young love. This one is about a young girl with a butterfly mother and an iron grandfather. Angela at 13 had the possibilities of growing in either direction, with the chances on developing strength and independence.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Oct. 4 -- Resurgent Soviet counter-drives inside Stalingrad and northwest and south of the Volga city broke German offensive power and regained position after position, the Russians announced today, but in one sector north of the city the Nazis hammered their way into a populated place.

VICHY, France, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Belatedly breaking its silence after the news had been published abroad, Vichy announced today that Edouard Herriot had been placed under residential surveillance by the police because the government did not like his attitude."

Mayor La Guardia wrote a letter last Monday to Mrs. Richard Washburn Child, in which he expressed the hope that the organizers of the Park Avenue Canteen would work out some arrangement with the New York City Recreation Committee so the canteen "would come in line with the general scope and purpose of the committee," it was disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The text of the White House statement on anti-inflation was as follows:

IN another and a more quiet day, this record that Peter Gray has set down of two years (1937-39) on the Greek island of Poros would seem a gentle, affectionate and pastoral account. And so it is now, but now it is also something more.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The demand upon our transport system, to which the Office of Defense Transportation testified this week in its order freezing railway passenger schedules, draws attention to the importance of our inland waterways and their barge lines.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- Signing of the price-control bill last night by the President and today's announcement of provisions of the bill, which failed to mention government loans on wheat and corn, resulted today in liquidation of contracts in the grain markets on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The growing importance of the Near East in the war was emphasized by implication today when Sumner Welles. Acting Secretary of State, gave high words of praise to Syria and Lebanon and to Turkey.

THE 3A lists are suddenly beginning to dwindle so that more and more women are joining the ranks of Army and Navy wives. Mrs. Gorham's diverting and practical "So Your Husband's Gone to War!" fits the moment.

IT was women's corsets that sent Charles D. Brower into the Arctic regions of Alaska in 1883. With bone from a single whale bringing as high as $11,000. Alaska was a place for both adventure and profit. Now, after almost four decades in the Far North.

CHICAGO, Oct 3. -- Commercial banks in the United States are sounder and better equipped to handle war and post-war problems than they were in the First World War, Rand, McNally Co. reported today in announcing the final 1942 edition of the Rand McNally Bankers Directory.

As an event in this season's Town Hall Endowment Series a special concert will be given Wednesday night, Dec. 9, in celebration of the twentieth anniversary of the League of Composers. Works are being written for the occasion by Louis Gruenberg, Frederick Jacobi, Bohuslav Martinu, Walter Piston and Arnold Schoenberg, which will be performed by the Budapest String Quartet; Povla Frijsh, Ruth Freeman, flute, and Celius Dougherty and Vincenz Rusicka, duo-pianists.

Motorists who fail to display gasoline ration stickers on their cars were threatened yesterday with loss of their ration books as the Office of Price Administration disclosed that 1,000 violations had been detected here in one week.

With the tourist business in Provincetown, Mass., cut to a fraction of its normal volume, John W. Gregory, whose etching studies of the Cape-end town have hitherto made his shop on Louis Ferreira Square one of the tourist sights, has turned to his camera hobby for help.

For seventy minutes last Wednesday the Fuehrer spoke to 10,000 hand-picked Nazis in Berlin's Sportspalast, and the allied world scanned his lines for signs of what might be happening to the German war effort. The occasion was the opening of the annual Winter relief campaign.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 3 -- After several weeks of futile attempts to make a pro-Government coalition in the Chamber of Deputies accept debate on foreign politics, the Opposition at last succeeded on Tuesday of this week in forcing a vote on the vital question of whether or not Argentina should break relations immediately with the Axis countries.

LISTENING to "Joe and Mabel" on WEAF last Sunday night, a good many others must have felt, as I did, more than a little sad at the announcement that this was its last performance and must have hoped that it will not be too long before the story of the Brooklyn taxi driver and his girl friend returns to the air.

IN Ireland the passage of time is an impertinence, or better than that, the very hands of the clock seem to deny their ability to move around the dial. The sight of blackbirds circling a gray stone tower on a chill late Summer evening is far less static, yet their ritual seems to embrace ten centuries of human history, centuries of war and famine, of uncertain conquest and dubious peace.

The stalwart and ever beautiful cattails always come first to mind and to the actual vision when considering wet land material for Winter decorative purposes. The common inland sort is Typha latifolia; near the coast grows T. angustifolia, of slenderer leaves and flower head.

The National Gallery of Art in Washington has received as gifts two portraits by outstanding American artists. The first. a portrait of George Washington by Rembrandt Peale. was given by George V. Davison of this city. The second, a portrait of Captain Warren Delano by Charles Loring Elliott, was presented by the Warren Delano Estate through Frederic A. Delano.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Quietly, almost imperceptibly, the United States is moving into a wartime economy of rationing under which eventually scores of items familiar to the everyday existence of Americans will come under Federal control.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Oct. 3 - A New Zealand election loomed today when the opposition leader, Sidney G. Holland, declared that the basis for postponement of a national vote had disappeared when the Opposition quit the coalition administration.

The opposition of Lou E. Holland, Smaller War Plants Corporation head, added to that of other War Production Board officials, has practically killed the Stanley plan to help small manufacturers obtain subcontracts, despite the fact that it has worked successfuly in Chicago, reports here last week indicated.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 3 -- George W. Norris, seeking re-election as an independent to a sixth term in the United States Senate, probably faces the most critical campaign, or at any rate the next to the most critical, in his forty years of public life.

Presenting the parent's point of view in a recent address, Mrs. Bess B. Lane, educational director of the United Parents Associations, said that one of the difficulties in bringing up children nowadays was "a general feeling of rush, hurry and confusion."

FOURTEEN performances will be given in San Francisco by the San Francisco Opera Association during its forthcoming twentieth season, which will open next Friday night with Verdi's "Aida." The regular series, composed of ten performances, will close Oct. 30.

SOME time ago Pearl S. Buck, as president of The East and West Association, wrote to a selected list of book critics asking for assistance in compiling a list of the books, written by Americans, which would best present a living picture of the United States to the peoples of the Near and Far East.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 3 -- Yale inaugurated its 1942 football campaign by trouncing Lehigh today. After encountering obstinate opposition in the first half, the Eli athletes found things to their complete satisfaction in the second, and succeeded in turning what started out to be a close tussle into a rout.

ONCE before Emil Ludwig wrote about the Mediterranean, but then he painted the langorous beauties of Capri, the timeless siestas of Palermo, the crowded bazaars of Stambul and the quiet grace of Olympia.
There is a good deal to recommend this bit of nonsense. It has a pretty little mystery, for one thing, and a diverting assortment of characters assembled at a second-rate hotel in Florida.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Oct. 4 -- Scrambling in aggressive pursuit of the Japanese along the upward trail of the Owen Stanley Range, Australian bush soldiers scored a six-mile advance up a precipitous 1,200-foot ridge and have reached Efogi, only seven miles from the entrance to the gap through the mountain backbone, it was announced today.

Washington is about to feel the effect of rising desire among millions of women for action on the consumer front. Evidence of their interest is a recommendation for informative labeling to link price and quality that is being sent to Administrator Leon Henderson by the National Council of Women and the American Association of University Women.

The word "hardship" will get a strenuous workout in 1943 and should end the year with an accumulation of new definitions because of the impact of new taxes on men in the armed services. Family men with good incomes are being drafted or are accepting commissions.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Dave Schreiner, All-America end, racked up three touchdowns today to pace Wisconsin to a 35-to-7 victory over Marquette in the eighteenth renewal of the team's intrastate series.
AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 3 -- Amherst defeated the Springfield College eleven, 27 to 19, on Pratt Field today.

British and American women in this country have become "allies" in making plans for British seamen in the United States and American sailors away from home to enjoy an equally merry Christmas, to judge by a meeting held yesterday afternoon at Bundles for America, Inc., headquarters.

In the annual report of the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts one looks first for the result of the substantial filling of the long-standing vacancies in judgeships that had been an obstacle to the transaction of business in the preceding fiscal year. Then ten district judgeships and one circuit judgeship were vacant. Now one circuit and five district judgeships are vacant.

Lack of information concerning registration procedures will be no excuse for not voting this Fall, according to Miss Anna Lord Strauss, president of the New York City League of Women Voters. Following weeks of intensive nonpartisan campaigning on sending well-qualified persons to Congress, the league is setting up eleven information booths in the five boroughs this week to answer questions which may be hampering a potential voter.
