THE community of interests between the Vatican and the democracies is emphasized again by recent conferences between Pope Pius XII and Myron C. Taylor, President Roosevelt's special envoy to the Vatican.

Following reports of flagrant violations of the consumer credit rulings under Regulation W by many of the smaller stores constituting the "outer fringe" of retailing, the Federal Reserve Board has decided on a program of stricter enforcement and plans to clamp down, possibly by making examples of a few violators, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- A broad program was announced by Attorney General Biddle today to revoke the naturalization of all former leaders and officials of the German-American Bund whose citizenship was obtained by false representations.

ONCE again the American Artists Group comes forward with its portfolio of Christmas cards, and once again it is a pleasure to recommend these cards to the public. As in previous years, since the excellent plan was adopted, the cards offered as holiday greetings contain reproductions of paintings or prints by American artists.

Until 1929 there were in Atlanta five undergraduate institutions and two professional schools, all providing higher education for Negro youth. Atlanta University, a co-educational institution, founded in 1867, was developed under the auspices of the American Missionary Association.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 3 -- The Williams eleven apparently forgot to read the scrip and didn't discover until the game was over that it was supposed to be an easy Princeton victim in Palmer Stadium today. The Purple, scoring thrice on long runs, upset the sons of old Nassau for the first time in the history of the series, 19 to 7, before the startled gaze of a gathering of 8,000.

YOUTH, by common consent, is the period of romantic daring, of eager readiness to explore the unknown, of impavid response to the challenge of experience that seems, so understandably, allegiant to no bounds. Youth is protean and splendid and venturesome and ardent and free.

A pair of frightened, rumpled and subdued boys appeared at 11:30 o'clock yesterday morning in the Brooklyn Felony Court and were arraigned on a charge of murder. Whimpering between their guards, in sharp contrast with their appearance at their arrest Friday, they twitched nervously as Detective Godfrey Dellano of the Stagg Street station read an affidavit charging them with killing Irwin Goodman, 39-year-old school teacher of 1565 East Sixteenth Street, Brooklyn.

For the first time since Carl Hubbell beat them in the opening game of 1936, the Yankees found themselves trailing in a world series when southpaw Ernie White shut them out at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. This was the first world series whitewashing of the Bombers since Jesse Haines, also a Cardinal, blanked them in 1926.
WHEN he was told that he was being called the MacArthur of China, General Joseph Stilwell smiled in embarrassment and said, "Shucks, I'm just a boy from the country."
NEW WILMINGTON, Pa., Oct. 3 -- Now beginning its ninetieth year, Westminster College is demonstrating its answer to the current question, "What can the small liberal arts college do in wartime?"

Business continued active in all markets, with a fair representation of buyers in town for short buying trips, according to the weekly report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. Novelty glassware items, dolls and stuffed animals were ordered in considerable quantities for holiday selling, as well as rain capes and coats, soldier kits, boxed stationery and musical powder boxes.

A UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCES BASE, Somewhere in England, Oct. 3 -- American flying men told today how a formation of six Flying Fortresses fought off thirty-five crack German fighter planes over France yesterday, destroying a record-breaking total of thirteen -- and possibly twelve more -- in a ten-minute duel at 25,000 feet. It was probably the biggest bag of fighters ever scored by a bombing formation.

The WPB order and the reporting form covering the first stage of the inventory regulation program are likely to be issued within the next two weeks, Dr. Eaton V.W. Read, chief of the wholesale and retail policy section of the Office of Civilian Supply and chairman of the Wholesale and Retail Inventory Policy Committee, said in an interview here last week.

WHILE the air bristles, these Autumn days and nights, with what are known as major programs (coast to coast), have a thought for the small local station. Because few people do have a thought for it -- or so it often seems. The networks are busy with their own affairs and those of their affiliates.

What will Bertha Cool do, now that her partner, Donald Lam, has enlisted in the Navy? This story gives the answer to that question. She does very badly indeed until she learns that Donald is not so far away but that he can be reached by telegrams.

While seventy city trucks were still adding their loads to the Queens household scrap pile -- which surpassed all expectations by reaching 33,729,000 pounds -- the Department of Purchase moved quickly yesterday to start part of the vast collection of metal on its way to the war fronts.

The seventeenth annual rodeo, which has acquired the timely title "World Series of Western Sports," will open for a nineteen-day stay at Madison Square Garden Wednesday night when 200 cowboys and cowgirls will compete for purses totaling $60,000.

THAT wily African great-great-granddaddy of Br'er Rabbit has popped up again. At least Mr. Bemelmans claims his story is based on an old African folktale and certainly his Rosebud is as tricky and ingenious as Uncle Remus's practical joker.

Given a chance, the yield of fruit trees will outstrip any other crop in actual value for the household. The dwarf type of fruit tree, for economy of space and attractiveness, merits a place in every Victory garden. It needs no patriotic urge to realize their 100 per cent dividends on the space they occupy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- A change of seasons is descending upon the warring world. On some fronts Winter's cold will bring fighting almost to a halt. On others the bonds of tropic heat and monsoon rains that have held armies in their camps will he loosed.

THAT the physical pleasures of marriage do not decrease, but rather increase, with the passing of the years is the main theme of Margaret Flint's new novel, "Enduring Riches." The heroine and central character, Judith Squire, is one of those unfortunate women who have no women friends whatsoever, and are interested in men only as possible lovers or hus bands.
The nation's doctors and hospitals were urged yesterday to freeze their fees at current levels for the duration of the war to help combat inflation.

HONOLULU, Oct. 3 -- The Solomons campaign will end its second month next week with sporadic but bitter land, sea and air fighting still raging from the unexplored wilderness of New Guinea to the green jungles of the Southern Solomons.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 3 -- The Dartmouth Indians found in Miami University of Oxford, Ohio, the breather they had expected when they rolled over the outclassed Midwesterners, 58 -- 7, on Memorial Field today.

MR. Drueker's "End of Economic Man" was a brilliant essay on the sources and portent of Hitlerism. This grave new book grows out of the conviction that only the United States can give form and significance to the free society which may some time be within reach, if the battle against tyranny is won.

The Bronx Zoo, along with other major attractions on the New York subway circuit, is all set for the Fall and Winter crop of out-of-town visitors. Among new sights -- certainly unique among things to see in the nation's largest city -- is a completely equipped farm.

HAIFA, Palestine, Oct. 2 (Delayed) -- Vessels of the Swedish Red Cross have been carrying out a "mercy service" in taking wheat from Canada to Greece. Three ships are said to have arrived at Piraeus in mid-August and two others in mid-September.

As the date for the National Foreign Trade Convention nears, with approximately 1,200 importers and exporters due to gather in Boston on Wednesday to hear Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles and other government officials discuss the outlook for their industry, the foreign trade community here pressed its campaign for reorganization of government methods in handling wartime controls on their operations.

There will be a reunited and independent Poland after the war, Mayor La Guardia predicted yesterday at exercises held in City Hall Plaza, where he turned over to Jan Ciechanowski, Free Poland's ambassador to the United States, ten fully equipped ambulances for the use of Polish forces.

The rising purchasing power of a growing army of employed women, both in war industries and in civilian jobs where they are replacing men, is introducing new twists into the economic picture of the country. As restrictions on consumer markets increase, these new wielders of weekly pay checks are finding other ways of investing surplus income.

Opera Is Presented by Salmaggi Company at Brooklyn Academy Mussorgsky's historical opera, "Boris Godunoff," was performed by the Salmaggi Opera Company last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Although the troupe's repertoire is largely confined to works of the Italian school and its clientele consists of devotees of Italian operatic music, the presentation of the Russian masterpiece attracted an enthusiastic near capacity audience including many standees.

The hunters are out in some sections of the East, starting on a season radically different in several respects from the pre-war Fall of last year. Heretofore a hunter thought mostly about his guns and hunting dogs; now he must think about defense zones and wartime regulations.

KINGSTON, R.I., Oct. 3 -- An enlarged and lengthened program for the preparation of teachers has been adopted at Rhode Island State College enabling students who complete it to receive both the Bachelor of Science and the Bachelor of Education degrees.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 3 -- Fordham scored first and last in today's intersectional game with Tennessee, but in between the Vols registered six touchdowns to give the Rams one of the worst beatings they ever have received, and certainly the worst since the Maroon has been at the top in national football.
In his own field, which is chemistry. Dr. Percival Sambourne appears to be competent and possibly

IN "A Room of One's Own" Virginia Woolf expressed the need of the artist for privacy and independence; in "Butter With My Bread" another Englishwoman, known as Olga Petrova to American theatre audiences of twenty years ago, points up this need through her own experiences.

Seeing is believing -- at least for most people -- and demonstration makes clear the instructions for blacking out your home; the "on paper" complications melt away when a perfectly protected interior is inspected. Gimbels has set up a group of rooms on the ninth floor in order to clarify the blackout situation for the householder.

CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., Oct. 3 -- President Paul Swain Havens of Wilson College today called upon American colleges and universities to maintain their faith in liberal education and to appraise carefully the results of acceleration and other war-created educational experiments.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 3 (AP) -- A 79-yard touchdown by Earl (Sparky) Brown in the third period gave Penn State a 14-to-7 triumph over Bucknell before an opening game crowd of 10,000 today.

Completion of a plan to correlate classroom projects for 180,000 pupils who will see at least 120 performances of a patriotic play in scores of cities throughout the country was announced yesterday by Dorothy L. McFadden, president of Junior Programs, Inc., a nonprofit organization.

Holding that there could never be any appeasement of the Axis and that this country must "win the war totally or we will lose our freedom totally," Governor Lehman called last night upon all Americans to rededicate themselves to their beliefs in their religion and their country in order to gain strength in the final drive to victory over totalitarian aggression.

S.K. Ratcliffe, visiting British lecturer, told members of the Community Church in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, yesterday morning, that the presence of thousands of American troops in the British Isles had revealed to both British and Americans how little they knew of each other.

Holdings of government obligations by the Guaranty Trust Company of New York have risen almost $328,000,000 in the last year, according to the quarterly report released for publication today. On Sept. 30 the bank held government obligations amounting to $1,485,418,916, against $1,306,319,483 a quarter earlier and $1,157,552,026 a year earlier.

Following the fairly substantial gain in August, advertising linage of eight New York newspapers slipped back last month, according to a compilation based on Media Records figures. With only one of the five classifications registering increases the decline for September was 3.7 per cent from the like 1941 month.

MOSCOW, Oct. 4 -- Russian troops have made gains on the edge of a German-held factory region on the northwestern fringe of Stalingrad, and German infantry forces attempting to capture a dominating height still are meeting with failure, according to today's Russian reports.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Paul A. Porter, deputy price administrator, said today that the Office of Price Administration, to carry on its broadened duties, would have to get more money than Congress voted in the mid-Summer budget debates.
TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 4 (AP) -A State-wide study to determine the necessity of a child care program to aid mothers employed in war industries had the approval of the State Board of Education today.

Striving to cut through the "welter of words" from government agencies that have left householders still uncertain on how much fuel oil they can expect this Winter, members of the American Society of Heating and Ventilating Engineers have worked out the amount for three houses of the same size but differing in heating efficiency.

SOMEWHERE IN EASTERN INDIA, Oct. 2 (Delayed) -- Chinese troops who came out of Burma two months ago tattered, exhausted and malaria-ridden are going back through Burma one of these days as a trained, powerful fighting force.

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 4 -- The American farmer is no wartime profiteer, and in seeking a fair price for his products is asking no more than justice for his expenditure of labor and money on his farm, the Most Rev. A.J. Muench, Bishop of Fargo, N.D., declared today in his presidential address at the convention of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Senator Danaher, Connecticut Republican, denounced today the Victory Tax, with its 5 per cent levy on gross income, asserting that it would entirely disregard the individual's capacity to pay.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- American girls who have come to Great Britain for the Red Cross all say they have learned more about their countrymen in the few months they have seen them at Army camps, hospitals and Red Cross clubs over here than they ever would have in normal surroundings at home.

SOMEWHERE IN SUSSEX, Oct. 4 -- In a small agricultural and cattle-market village here there is an important war factory. It is a symbol of this country's patriotism at its best. It is a plant -- so little, yet so large in its implications -run by 150 volunteer workers.

In some general introductory remarks to "The Epic of Latin American Literature," published today, Arturo Torres-Rioseco declares that Latin-American literature is today entering its golden age. He sees the days of simple imitation ended and says Spanish-American and Brazilian writers have realized "that only an earthborn conscience could save them from superficial and artificial thinking."
AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Two Army Air Force boards today opened an investigation into the crash of a medium bomber which killed all seven crew member near the Akron Airport.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 4 -- Archbishop Victor Sanabria Martinez, in response to a request from anti-totalitarian organizations to state his attitude on the world conflict, replied that he was anti-totalitarian and anti-Communist but was pro-Russian.

WASHINGTON, Oct4 -- All Federal departments and agencies have been asked in a letter from the Senate Small Business Committee to report in two weeks detailed information concerning their activities in connection with the problems of small business, Senator Murray, committee chairman, said today.

Edward F. Barrett, president of the Long Island Lighting Company, announced yesterday that the company's first mortgage 4 per cent bonds, series C, D and E, aggregating $29,961,000, will be redeemed on Friday at par, plus premiums.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the recital by Miss Jean Watson, contralto, to be given on Oct. 20 at the Town Hall for the benefit of the Maple Leaf Club for Service Men of the United Nations. Women active in the plans for the event will meet on Thursday to discuss further arrangements for the event, which is headed by Mrs. Duncan Fraser.

Asking continuing prayers for a true understanding of the sanctity and indissolubility of the marriage bond, the Rev. Thomas Lester Graham, preaching yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, warned against hasty marriages "in the present time of crisis."
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Major Gen. Harold L. George said today that because of good planning by the Army's General Staff the Air Transport Command was operating the world's largest airline.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- In order to relieve retailers of certain hardships involved in pricing Fall and Winter commodities according to regulations issued under order No. 210, the Office of Price Administration issued today an amendment allowing the pricing of seasonal items under less rigid regulations.

There is one point of agreement in the statement made yesterday by Joseph Stalin and the speech delivered last week by Adolf Hitler. It is a very important point, so important to the Germans that Hermann Goering was called out of the shadows in which he has lived lately to drive it home in the address he made as cheer leader at the Autumn festival in Berlin.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Oct. 4 -They came from Nebraska. They lived in a cottage on a small ranch in the sand-hill country. They had to haul their own water and bathe in a washtub, and when they went to "town" it was to Kilgore, where the population might have been 250.

In the first statement he has made to the foreign press since the war began, Joseph Stalin told the Moscow correspondent of The Associated Press yesterday that the possibility of a second front occupied a place of first-rate importance in Soviet estimates of the present war situation.

Three sullen Puerto Rican youths admitted after twelve hours of questioning yesterday that they had lured Private Edwin Berkowitz to a church areaway early Friday, mugged him and then stabbed him to death.

CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Australian offensive in New Guinea, in which Japanese forces have been driven twenty miles back, up the trail to Efogi in the Owen Stanley range, was described today by Prime Minister John Curtin as essentially a holding operation.
Two postcards, one from Montana and the other from Brooklyn, bring varying messages.
A parade sponsored by the General Pulaski Memorial Committee and commemorating Pulaski Day was staged yesterday on Fifth Avenue from Thirty-fifth to Fifty-sixth Streets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- American Zionists placed themselves on record today as opposing reported moves to establish a binational State in Palestine rather than the all-Jewish State already supported by the organization.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 4 -- The Senate has modified Article 7 Law 13, which requires foreign and domestic companies to be represented here by Colombian nationals, to permit foreign representatives in addition to Colombians.
VICHY, France, Oct. 4 (U.P.) -- The French Government today issued new regulations to protect and placate workers drafted for German war industries.
Voluntary razing of all canopies in front of apartment houses, night clubs and cafes was proposed yesterday by Edgar J. Nathan Jr., Manhattan Borough President.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Green Bay capitalized on fumbles tonight to register a pair of touchdowns in the last quarter and take a 17-to-13 National Football League victory over the Chicago Cardinals before 25,000.

In the battle of inflation we have finally emerged from the period of "phony war." Out of the hot confusion and debate of recent weeks Congress has rallied to produce a bill which gives the President practically what he asked for, and, in some respects, much more than he asked.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Ten members of the disbanded Flying Tigers, including Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, have won British military decorations for gallantry during operations in Burma.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 4 -Yugoslav official circles and Allied diplomatic and military sources in Turkey that are in communication with General Draja Mikhailovitch denounced tonight as "false and preposterous" a report said to have been published by The New York Daily Worker, Communist organ, charging that the Yugoslav War Minister and generalissimo of the patriot armies in Yugoslavia had made terms with the Axis.

The Young Women's Christian Association is beginning a campaign in behalf of the white collar workers of this country whose wages are making a notably poor showing against rising living costs. Miss Julia White, president of the National Council of Business and Professional Women, Y.W.C.A., announced yesterday that a letter had been sent to President Roosevelt requesting that a section dealing specifically with white collar workers be added to the War Labor Board.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Army will take over from Pan American air ferries the direct operation of the aerial plane delivery service from the United States to American and Allied forces in the Middle East.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 4 -Walter Hart, co-author of "The Primrose Path" and producer-director of other Broadway plays, has been signed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as a writer-director. His first chore will be the direction of a short subject, "Blackout," based on "Talk in a Blackout," by Louis Adamic.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- With price-control legislation now an actuality and the measures designed to check inflation already making themselves felt, the provision trade is waiting for an official announcement that will settle the question of ceiling prices on live hogs and hog products.

Events today: Elizabeth Hipple, piano recital, Town Hall, 8:30 P.M.; Ruth Kemper, first lecture in a course on creative listening, the Art Workshop, 116 East Sixteenth Street, 7; Wilbur A. Luyster, lecture on the Galin-Paris-Cheve method of sight-singing, 1425 Broadway, 4 and 8 P.M.

Declaring that his crusade against "tinhorn gamblers" was "going on very satisfactorily," Mayor La Guardia revealed yesterday that the Legal Aid Society, 11 Park Place, was ready to act as unpaid counsel for poor families that had lost money to bookmakers on horse races and desired to sue for its recovery, as provided by the Penal Code.

Timed for publication on the first day for registration in New York City, the expected statement of President Roosevelt in support of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, was issued yesterday at the White House.

Representatives of the eight Eastern aircraft companies that last week organized the Aircraft War Production Council, Inc., East Coast, will meet next Monday at the Glenn L. Martin plant in Baltimore, it was announced yesterday by G.W. Vaughan, president of the new organization.

DETROIT, Oct. 4 -- At no time during the game did the Brooklyn Football Dodgers perform as a unit against the Detroit Lions at Briggs Stadium today, but Mike Getto's men notched their second straight National Football League decision anyway, this one by a 28-7 margin.

MOSCOW, Monday, Oct. 5 -- The Russians held their ground stubbornly against incessant German attacks in the battered city of Stalingrad yesterday, said a communique issued today, and maintained the initiative northwest of the city, where the Red Army's advances in the last few days were reported to be threatening the entire German position.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Beaten by the White Sox in the first three games, the Cubs came back to take the fourth contest of Chicago's city series, 5 to 3, behind Hiram Bithorn's eight-hit pitching today and thus keep the annual four-out-of-seven rivalry alive.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- The size of this year's crops of corn and soy beans cannot be known definitely until reports of husking and threshing show whether recent frosts did as much damage to those commodities as is feared, authorities say.

If the Cardinals win the world series -- and they were 5 to 18 betting favorites last night -- each player's share will be $6,192.50, the biggest payday in history for a series in which the players did not "cut" into the broadcasting rights, The Associated Press reported.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- Whether the futures markets for grain and other commodities will be able to continue to perform their normal functions under the government's new price-freezing program will depend on the use that is made of the President's discretionary power over price floors and ceilings, officials of Chicago's two major futures markets -- the Board of Trade and the Mercantile Exchange -- said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- American combat planes already have proved themselves to be "more than a match" for any of the aircraft that now are pitted against them, the aviation subcommittee of the House Military Affairs Committee, announced today in a report following a two-week investigation of charges that this country's fighter ships are "inferior" to some of those of Germany and Japan.

On the average, both stocks and bonds went higher last week, on largely increased trading. Railway stock average rose to the highest since last autumn; domestic bond averages went above the year's previous highest. The cause for this strength was varied.

IF civilization in its so-called higher manifestations -- swarming cities, mammoth industries, unemployment, insecurity, wars and rumors of wars -- engendered a greater feeling of peace and fulfillment among its frantic citizens, perhaps we would not have had for so many years so many literary exaltations of peasant life and primitive peoples.

MOSCOW, Oct. 4 -- In a personal letter to Henry C. Cassidy, representative of The Associated Press here, Premier Joseph Stalin stated last night that Allied aid had "so far been little effective" compared with the aid the Soviet was giving to the Allies by draw ing on itself the main enemy force and that the second-front possibility played a paramount part in Soviet estimates of the current situation.

Morton Cooper, Cardinal ace, once again failed to overcome the Yankees, although the Redbirds staged a six-run assault against young Hank Borowy in the fourth inning at the Yankee Stadium yesterday and won, 9 -- 6, after a three-run homer by King Kong Keller had driven Cooper out in the sixth and led to a 6-6 tie in that frame.

Ten men were killed and eight others were injured when an airplane with thirty-seven persons on board crashed at Botwood, Nfld., late Saturday afternoon, it was disclosed yesterday at the headquarters of the Eastern Defense Command and the First Army in this city. Two of the occupants of the plane were women, but both apparently escaped injury.

Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard called on all Americans yesterday to conserve "every pound of this year's abundant food production," because "if we use more than we need this Fall and Winter we will be hungry a few months later."

Western Hemisphere defenses are now far stronger than they ever have been in the past, Nelson Rockefeller, Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, declared yesterday in a broadcast report on his recently completed tour of inspection in South America.

TORONTO, Oct. 4 -- The American Federation of Labor will put its weight fully behind the anti-inflation program outlined by President Roosevelt in his Executive order creating the Office of Economic Stabilization, William Green, president of the federation, said today.

The Ecole Libre des Hautes Etudes in the New School for Social Research, under the acting presidency of Jacques Maritain, French philosopher, which was founded last January by French and Belgian scholars resident in this country, will open its second term today.

Means for coping with war-stimulated traffic will be discussed on Friday by R.B. White, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, at a meeting of the Atlantic States Shippers Advisory Board in Baltimore. It is estimated that carloadings may increase 8.4 per cent in the region covered by the board in the last three months of the year, compared with the same period last year.
"The Yankees aren't beaten yet. Not by a darned sight."

Dr. George S. Counts, State chairman of the American Labor party: Alex Rose, State secretary, and Andrew R. Armstrong, State treasurer, issued yesterday an appeal to all voters to register during the week for the election.
One of the great peacetime pleasures of living out of the city was that the commuter could, if he went about it right, be alone for an hour, more or less, on his trips in and out on the train.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Charley O'Rourke and Sid Luckman pitched touchdown passes to Ray McLean to lead the Chicago Bears' steamroller to a 21-to-7 conquest of the Cleveland Rams today.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 4 -Miss Ruth Allen, 23 years old, today became the first woman to win the horseshoe pitching championship tournament of Long Island, held by the Long Island State Park Commission at the Hempstead Lake State Park.

The USO War Fund Campaign has now received contributions of $19,031,173, Prescott S. Bush, national campaign chairman, announced yesterday, pointing out that this represents 96.8 per cent of the quotas that were accepted for Spring and Summer campaigns.

At least one member of Congress is alive to the need of reforming that body from within to retain its usefulness, prestige and influence during the war. Representative Dirksen of Illinois has introduced a resolution for a joint House and Senate committee on post-war reconstruction.

Until yesterday, few of the neighbors knew the name of the frail boy who lived at 33-54 Ninety-ninth Street, Corona, Queens. To them he was "The Gambler," a blond, freckle-faced youngster who was adept with dice or cards.

Private William F. Sittinger, 31 years old, killed with two companions Saturday when a medium Army bomber crashed near Oklahoma City, was the first casualty among the more than 200 employes of THE NEW YORK TIMES who have entered the armed services.

Developments in Washington relative to control of prices occupied the attention of the cotton trade last week, restricting activity in the market and holding price movements within a comparatively narrow range. After losing 16 to 22 points through Friday, the market rallied moderately on Saturday but did not regain all the lost ground.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- The United States and Britain are about to conclude a new trade agreement with Portugal, it was learned here today. This is one of several signs that Britain's relations with the few remaining neutrals are improving because of increasing evidence that Adolf Hitler's timetable in the East is Itgging while the power of the United Nations grows.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Warning that Britain may expect more devastating fire raids than she had ever experienced if Germany is able to free enough planes from the Russian front, Miss Ellen Wilkinson, Parliamentary Secretary of the Minister of Home Security, explained to a Coventry audience today why the government had called women for fire guard duty.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 4 -A warning to United States soldiers that they must not allow the cheapness and plentifulness of Indian servants to undermine traditional American self-reliance is contained in Roundup, the weekly twelve-page newspaper now published here for American expeditionary forces in India and China.
Is it not a fact that we have in the highest ranks of National Government what amounts to a fifth column of the greatest effectiveness?

A program designed to help small stores survive wartime merchandise shortages and at the same time maintain the sales contacts developed before gasoline rationing necessitated fewer salesmen's visits has been adopted by Butler Brothers, dry goods wholesalers, it was announced here yesterday by Q.P. Witte, general manager of the firm's local branch.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's speech in the Sportpalast, boastful and bombastic in tone though it was, betrayed the Nazis' fears of British bombing and waxing American strength and made two promises virtually impossible to fulfill, it was noted here tonight.

GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands, Sept. 22 (Delayed) -- Hit-and-run naval warfare, a kind of guerrilla warfare of the sea in which the protagonists are Japanese warships and American planes and shore batteries here, is a constant factor of the military situation on Guadalcanal and Tulagi.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 (AP) -- A 35-yard forward pass from Sammy Baugh to Andy Farkas, followed by a one-yard line buck by Farkas, gave the Washington Redskins a last-quarter touchdown and a 14-to-10 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles in a National Football League game at Shibe Park today.
Following are excerpts from yesterday's speech by Reich Marshal Hermann Goering, recorded from radio broadcasts heard in this country:
It couldn't have happened other than in wartime.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The President's Committee on Fair Employment will hear and examine complaints relating to the employment of Negroes in the railway industry at a three-day hearing here December 7, 8 and 9, it was said today by Dr. Malcolm S. MacLean, committee chairman.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- Men in the grain trade here maintain that there is no inflation of prices in the grain markets. They cite a report issued last week by the Department of Agriculture indicating that, on the basis of parity prices for agricultural products, grain farmers are not receiving their fair share of the national income.
MOSCOW, Monday, Oct. 5 (AP) -The Soviet midnight Communique:

Speaking from radio station WLIB, Norman Thomas criticized yesterday the refusal of a deferment from the draft for Coleman B. Cheney, Socialist candidate for Governor, to enable him to speak in the campaign.
Because of Army regulations there will be no illuminated outdoor Christmas trees during dimout periods in the city this year, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly radio talk.
The President's executive order placing limitations on the payment of salaries appears to have been too broadly interpreted.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- What stock exchange dealers describe as a broad and impressive advance occurred in the security markets last week, although the expression "impressive" is distinctly limited in its meaning and applies only in comparison with previous wartime experience.

Samuel Seabury and ten other persons prominent in the civic, philanthropic and religious affairs of New York City have been appointed vice chairmen of the Citizens Committee for Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, Herbert Brownell Jr., State campaign manager, announced yesterday.

The last piece of iron from the Sixth Avenue elevated railroad -- and probably the first to go into the war -- will go to the steel mill by way of the hotel salvage campaign. It is a forty-pound beribboned souvenir that has hung for three years in the office of John J. Woelfle, general manager of the Hotel McAlpin and chairman of the salvage committee.

Millions of women will have to replace men in industry to maintain the nation's productivity, President Roosevelt has declared in a letter to Dr. Minnie L. Maffett, president of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs.

CAIRO, Egypt., Sept. 23 -- The tendency of a few American periodicals to cast aspersions on all American-built warplanes because of obvious altitude deficiencies of some of the fighters does not take into account the indisputably fine performance of United States heavy and medium bombers in the Mediterranean theatre, it was stated here today.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Joseph Stalin's reiteration of the importance Russians place on the opening of a second front and his declaration that, compared with the part Russia has played in fighting fascism, the United Nations' help has been "little effective" caused some amazement here.

Argentina has just celebrated the hundredth anniversary of the birth of Dr. Jose C. Paz, who founded in 1869 La Prensa, now by common consent one of the greatest newspapers of the world. He was a boy of 17 on a farm in the province of Santa Fe when the Confederation was at war With his native province.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Monday, Oct. 5 (U.P.) -- Australian ground forces in New Guinea have pushed beyond Efogi, forty-four airline miles from Port Moresby, and are continuing their advance toward the gap in the Owen Stanley Mountains through which the enemy poured southward last month in an abortive drive on the great Allied base, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Clashes between Greek peasants and Italian occupation troops are still continuing in many parts of Greece, according to a statement issued today by the Greek Office of Information.
THEY murdered a couple of pitchers in the Bronx yesterday. There were about 70,000 witnesses to the crime. The police have a clue and nothing at all will be done about it.

Military occupation of the Andreanof Islands in the Aleutians marks the end of our toleration of the Japanese invaders on Kiska, Attu and Agattu and the beginning of active preparation to expel them from American soil. The threat that the Japanese might march island by island to the continent may be dismissed.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 4 -Republicans and Democrats, having nominated for the first time in State political history a joint slate of State Senate nominees at conventions here last night, prepared today to join forces on Thursday with identical nominees for the House of Representatives in Hartford.

Foghorn Clancy came to town yesterday. That meant only one thing: the rodeo was officially here also, 600 head of wild horses, Brahma steers, wild bulls, the Brahma calf, "the most vicious domestic animal in the world," and, above all, Hell's Angel, the "wildest bronc in capitvity."
Those incredible Redbirds of St. Louis are flying higher than ever in the baseball heavens.

LONDON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Germans are "on the road to winning themselves to death," General Waldyslaw Sikorski, Prime Minister of the Polish Government-in-Exile, said today in a Pulaski Day broadcast to the United States.

The demands and irritations incident to the signing of a lease may prevent the enjoyment of the lease itself as a chronicle of the times. I do not refer to the legal terms or phrasing, but to the contract between landlord and tenant.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Although the White House has indicated that President Roosevelt will limit his salary to a net of $25,000 a year after payment of taxes, insurance and fixed obligations, it was the consensus of legal opinion here tonight that such action would be voluntary and not absolutely required under his executive order of yesterday stabilizing the cost of living.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- A show that will run as long as the war went on the boards for its own clientele tonight at the old Belasco Theatre. It is playing to a house exclusively military except for one civilian each night who will pay a $100 minimum fee.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 4 -- Fifty member-guest teams played in the Fenway Golf Club's new invitation tournament today, two posting best-ball scores of 69 to tie for top honors. James Gaynor and his guest from Split Rock, B.L. Kahn, jointly carded 34, 35, while William Shields of Fenway and Domenick Strafaci of Shoreview had 36, 33.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Sam Wood, one of Hollywood's leading director-producers, has formed his own independent producing unit and has acquired screen rights to "The Land Is Bright," the George S. Kaufman-Edna Ferber drama, for his first production.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4 -- Reports reaching this and other steel centers indicate that while collections of scrap metal have become increasingly larger as a result of newspaper publicity and a greater consciousness on the part of the public toward the absolute need for this material, steel experts have warned that no letup can be afforded because of the need for scrap in the nation's open-hearth furnaces next Winter and next Spring.

Nine men of a group of ten arrested in the Bronx late Saturday night as the result of a raid on a dice game were discharged yesterday by Magistrate Samuel Orr. The tenth, Carmine Facchiano, 33 years old, of 762 Courtlandt Avenue, the Bronx, was released in $500 bail for hearing on Thursday on a charge of maintaining a room for gambling purposes.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4 -- Having upset the Washington Redskins last week, the New York Giants were upset in turn by the Pittsburgh Steelers in a National Football League game before a surprised gathering of almost 10,000 at Forbes Field today.
LONDON, Oct. 4 -- A British column in Madagascar, pushing seventy miles south from Tananarive, the capital, has occupied the railway town of Antsirabe, it was announced here today.

Several million tons of high-grade steel scrap can be obtained through the junking of "standby" machinery and equipment in industrial establishments, Robert W. Wolcott, president of the Lukens Steel Company of Coatesville, Pa., and chairman of the American Industries Salvage Committee, said yesterday.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 4 -Neutral travelers arriving in Istanbul during the past few days from Sofia reported that Bulgaria is maintaining an army of approximately 400,000, but that tile army is now largely without armored equipment, which has been requisitioned by the Germans.
MOSCOW, Oct. 4 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- War workers in crowded industrial centers who are living in tents, shacks and similar dwellings will have real roofs of one kind or another over their heads by Christmas under the accelerated program of the Federal Public Housing Authority planned for them by Herbert Emmerich, Commissioner, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Leon Henderson announced tonight that a sweeping order opening the way for extension of government rent control to all parts of the country would be issued tomorrow in compliance with President Roosevelt's new cost-of-living program.

Appointment of an advisory committee of zoologists from other institutions to Columbia University's department of zoology, which this year is celebrating its fiftieth anniversary, was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 4 -Residents of this fashionable community, the scene before the war of many social functions, will play a new role next week-end -that of host to a battalion of the New York Guard, it was revealed here today.

Zara Nelsova, 24-year-old Canadian 'cellist of Russian parentage, made her American debut last night in Town Hall. The talented player, who was already before the public at the age of 5, went to London in 1928 to continue her studies, and it was there that she first appeared as a mature artist with leading orchestras and in recital.

A decline of 12.1 per cent in total shipments of all types of hosiery during August, which amounted to 12,118,397 dozen pairs compared with 13,785,394 dozen pairs in the like month last year, was reported by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

CLINTON, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- "A group of people in prominent positions in the government apparently believe that in the war effort there is no place for the small liberal arts college," President W.H. Cowley said today as Hamilton College opened for its 131st year.

The executive committee of the Fellowship of Reconciliation desires to express its appreciation of the great service which has been rendered by THE NEW YORK TIMES to the nation in connection with the very urgent problem of establishing an understanding between the people of this country and the peoples of the Orient, by sending Herbert L. Matthews to India, and by publishing his very comprehensive and objective reports on the situation there.

Spurred by accelerated retail business in most parts of the country, particularly in war production areas, wholesale markets reached a new peak of Fall activity last week with the arrival of cooler weather, according to weekly reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

"Let Freedom Sing," a topical revue, will be offered this evening at the Longacre by the Youth Theatre. Mitzi Green has the leading role and Berni Gould, Lee Sullivan, Betty Garrett, Phil Leeds and Mordecai Bauman are featured. The music and lyrics are mostly the work of Harold J. Rome, but Marc Blitzstein, Earl Robinson, Lou Cooper, Roslyn Harvey, Lewis Allen, Walter Kent and Hy Zaret also have contributed words and tunes.

VICHY, Oct. 4 -- As was decided recently in Germany, it has been decided in Holland that all holders of stock purchased since Jan. 1, 1942, must declare these shares. They may be ordered either to sell them on the Bourse or cede them to the Bank of the Netherlands, which will buy them at the lowest rates quoted in March, which are much below present levels.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Tomorrow's London Times leads its widely read letter column with a protest by Ahmet Emin Yalman, editor of Vatan, Istanbul journal, against an appeal for a Christian brotherhood of nations after the war. Mr. Yalman and a group of his fellow-countrymen are just rounding off an official tour of British war factories and defense establishments.
There's no such thing as a woman who's too busy to be beautiful! So says the inventor of a lightninglike business called the "jiffy hairdo," and he has evidence to prove his point.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 4 -- Two hundred footsore and weary members of the New Jersey State Guard, including a sprinkling of physicians, lawyers and other professional men over 40 years old, returned here tonight from two-day manoeuvres at West Milford, N.J., between Greenwood Lake and the Wanaque Reservoir.

Members of the armed forces were remembered with prayers at a "war service" initiated at Trinity Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street, yesterday afternoon. The service will be repeated each Sunday during the war.

The Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers, pastor of the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle at Fifty-sixth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that "we will never get anywhere with this business of Christianity if every time we have a decision to make we come up against the argument that we have a right to look out for ourselves."

ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, Oct. 4 (U.P.) -- The Legislative Assembly has voted to ask Congress to authorize a Resident Commissioner for the islands, and a plenary session yesterday unanimously recommended William H. King, former Senator from Utah, for the office.
"This fashion show is going to be different," Mayor La Guardia assured the people of the City of New York in his weekly talk yesterday.

An unfurnished apartment in the building at 555 Park Avenue has been leased by John Royal, executive vice president of the National Broadcasting Company, through William A. White Sons, as brokers, and Douglas L. Elliman Co., agents.

An order requiring the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation in Long Island City to remove from its job application forms the question about a prospective employe's religion has been served on the company, it was disclosed yesterday by Industrial Commissioner Frieda S. Miller, who is also chairman of the committee on discrimination in employment of the State War Council.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- The markets for oats and rye on the Board of Trade dipped last week as the bill in Congress for price control made no provision for mandatory loans on these grains. Scattered liquidation developed in rye and prices dropped around 3 cents a bushel from the finish of the preceding week before the break was checked.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, Oct. 4 -- Fathers and mothers went into action here today as neighbors, for cooperative wartime care of their children. On a half-acre lot they had cleared themselves on a sunny southern slope in view of the Hudson, these Westchester parents dug post holes for a swing, hammered and sawed, leveled and rolled ground.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 4 -Wendell L. Willkie was visibly impressed by a chorus of 10-year-old Chinese war orphans at a tea party given in his honor this afternoon by Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of the Generalissimo and honorary chairman of the China Chapter of the United China Relief.

BOSTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Boston Symphony, sole major nonunion orchestra in the country, disclosed today that it had been negotiating with James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, A.F.L., concerning union recognition, but that certain barriers remained to be overcome before an agreement could be reached.

VICHY, Oct. 4 -- The statement of condition of the Bank of France dated Sept. 3 shows no important changes in the credits accorded the securities markets. Bills discounted declined by 249,000,000 francs, while advances on ninety-day bonds increased 352,000,000.

In order to relieve the congestion in the Washington offices of the War Production Board, business men should file their appeals for relief from restrictive orders through the agency's regional branches, H.M. Brundage, deputy regional director in charge of priorities and materials in the New York office, declared yesterday.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Churches have been used as the tools of liquor propagandists in discrediting the successes of prohibition, Dr. George Barton Cutten, retiring president of Colgate University, declared today before the convention of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union.

The other day General Hershey reprimanded those civilians who have not left jobs in unessential industries for employment in war industries. It seems to me that in this respect one angle has been overlooked.

The President's announcement yesterday that he will vote for Mr. Bennett is the first important development of the State campaign. Mr. Roosevelt did not wait until the last moment, as some had predicted he would wait, before stating his position. He did not limit himself, as others had predicted, to a bare statement that he would vote the Democratic ticket.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The negligence and carelessness which lead to fires in homes and factories in wartime constitute sabotage, James M. Landis, director of the Office of Civilian Defense, declared today in a radio address marking the opening of Fire Prevention Week.

The millions of pounds of scrap metal that New Yorkers are contributing to the current salvage campaign sponsored by the newspapers will help strengthen the city's civilian defenses in addition to supplying war materials to the battlefronts, Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday.

Samuel Okin, a stockholder of the Electric Bond and Share Company, who is circularizing other stockholders, asking them not to sign any proxy for the management and to revoke the same if they have signed it, said yesterday that a statement in a published report with respect to the action of the Securities and Exchange Commission to restrain him was incorrect.

Three months after it was repossessed in a foreclosure action, the Hotel Chelsea, an outstanding property in the Chelsea section, has been sold by the Bank for Savings to the Chelsea Hotel Corporation. The eleven-and-one-half-story building occupies a plot 175 by 98.9 feet at 216 to 228 West Twenty-third Street and contains 319 rooms, 176 baths and seven stores.

In an appeal for national unity, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of the Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, told members of his congregation yesterday morning that "we must bridle the greeds of men as well as bring the dictators to judgment." Dr. Sockman said:

Make up your mind to serve better breakfasts from now on. Cram nourishment into the first meal of the day; make it interesting, varied, fitted to the needs of your household. And watch the effect. Dispositions improve, efficiency mounts, the morning becomes the time when you work hardest and best.
The announcer's voice came over he amplifier in the press box on he mezzanine deck, loud, clear, distinct.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- Corn prices dipped last week to the lowest levels on the current downturn under scattered liquidation, the December contract selling at 84 1/2 cents a bushel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- With the new anti-inflation legislation finally disposed of, the Senate will pass on this week to consideration of the second great war problem placed before it in recent months, that of additional taxes. It will take up a bill to increase revenues to a total next year of about $25,000,000,000, or nearly one-fourth of the expected national income.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Twenty-eight of the Long Island Sound yachts, their championship over, competed today in a post-season regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club. It was the first competition of the total point series which will continue next week-end.

American women are "ready to roll up their sleeves and go to work," in the opinion of Mrs. Elsie Stapleton, budget adviser at the Gimbel Brothers department store, which maintains a free budget guide bureau to aid families and individuals.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- The conformation hunter championship, concluding the Sleepy Hollow Country Club's two-day horse show, given for the benefit of Army Emergency Relief, went to the imported brown gelding Dalchoolin today.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose to 108.2 from 107.8. The prices of agricultural commodities such as eggs, butter, livestock, and potatoes continued to rise, as they have been doing for the past month.

Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau made known yesterday that details of the $4,000,000,000 October government financing will be announced on Thursday. This financing, of course, is in addition to the weekly Treasury bill offerings and the refunding of the issue of $1,507,000,000 of Treasury certificates of indebtedness due on Nov. 1.

In order to avoid "difficulty and trouble," exporters were warned by the Department of Commerce yesterday that they must "check and re-check" all foreign accounts. Cases continue to be reported, the announcement pointed out, wherein exporters have had to divert shipments and reconsign stocks or effect their return because the consignee was placed on the proclaimed list of blocked nationals after shipment was made.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 5 -- Reports that Cary Grant will enlist in the Army Air Forces were confirmed today with an announcement by RKO that "Bundles for Freedom," in which Grant will star, has been moved up on the studio's program to Oct. 12 to permit the actor to complete his role before his projected enlistment.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 5 -- There was a one-week break in German-Danish relations following King Christian's seventy-second birthday, on Sept. 26, according to tonight's edition of Aftontidningen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Acting Secretary of State Sumner Welles told his press conference today that the American Government would give every possible assistance to the armies of Soviet Russia with the greatest possible speed.

Liquor wholesalers completed their filing of November price schedules with the State Liquor Authority yesterday without benefit of the anticipated industry-wide "adjustment" by the Office of Price Administration. In view of the urgency with which the Federal agency handled the recent survey of the wholesalers, and the intimations that it was anxious to make a decision before prices were filed for the holiday period, some "last-minute" action had been expected.

Terming the enterprise a "particularly contemptible form of war profiteering." Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora granted yesterday an application by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. to annul the corporate existence of the American-Canadian Ambulance Corps, Inc.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease last week of 5 per cent from the comparative week last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the week ended Sept. 26 the bank had reported a decline of 6 per cent.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 5 -- Internal struggles between "pro-Norwegian" and pro-German members of the Quisling Nasjonal Samling has led to an open break at Trondheim, where three Quisling trade union officials have been summarily dismissed from the party, it was learned here today.
Mrs. George A. Gordon, wife of the former United States Minister to the Netherlands, has come to the Ambassador from Washington.

Late yesterday afternoon the Federal Reserve Bank of New York notified member banks in the Second Federal Reserve District that the Treasury would make further withdrawals this week from commercial bank depositories, effective on Friday and Saturday. Last week other Treasury calls were announced, effective yesterday, today and tomorrow.

Mayor La Guardia's drive on "tinhorn" gamblers, in which it had already been announced that "tipsters" sheets would be barred from newsstands in the city, was widened yesterday to place the seal of official disapproval on The Morning Telegraph, 109-year-old newspaper devoted largely to racing information, and The Daily Racing Form.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Oct. 6 -- Australian jungle troops, still without opposition, have cleaned up the area around Kagi, last village south of the mile-high gap in the Owen Stanley Mountains of New Guinea, and are continuing toward the gap, a communique said today.

Save for the President himself, no man in our history has ever held as great powers as have been conferred upon Associate Justice James F. Byrnes as Director of Economic Stabilization. Under the terms of the executive order of Oct. 3, Mr. Byrnes is given the ultimate authority to control "civilian purchasing power, prices, rents, wages, salaries, profits, rationing, subsidies and all related matters."

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- There is increasing anxiety here over what is widely interpreted as Vichy's increasing subjugation by German industry. Adolf Hitler is playing the French stooges against each other and getting each to vie in showing who is the most willing to obey orders.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $733,202,130 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price per share of all listed stocks on Sept. 30 was $24.20, compared with $23.70 at the end of August.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Oct 4 (Delayed) -- There is still no contact between the Australians and the main Japanese force in area just below the Owen Stanley range. Latest reports tonight were that the Australians were working eastward from Efogi along a trail that leads to Myola. Advance units are still trying to find the enemy, the report added.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- A Navy communique:

Every burned-out American factory or warehouse is as effective a contribution to victory for the Axis as though it had been destroyed by an enemy bomb. Except at Dutch Harbor, no bombs have fallen on the farms or cities of this continent, but since Pearl Harbor there has been a fire in the United States every two minutes.

Kurt Wolff, founder and former director of the large pre-Hitler German publishing house of Kurt Wolff Verlag, Munich, has set up a firm here with the imprint of Pantheon Books. Mr. Wolff introduced several American writers to his country, including Sinclair Lewis and John Erskine.

Colonel Clifford Palmer Bradley of 4411 Greenwich Parkway, Washington, one of the passengers aboard the airplane that crashed at Botwood. Nfld., late Saturday, died Sunday night, headquarters of the Eastern Defense Command and First Amy announced last night.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- A jury was selected in Supreme Court here today to hear evidence in a broker's suit to collect $433,333 in commissions on the alleged grounds that Commodore Edgar F. Luckenbach agreed to sell his fleet of twenty-two steamships and freighters for $13,000,000 in 1939 but reneged and raised his price to $26,000,000 when war broke out.

The annual season of ballet under the direction of S. Hurok will open tonight at the Metropolitan Opera House with the first of a series of performances by the Ballet Theatre, newly returned from a Summer in Mexico City.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The possibility that price ceilings might be placed on livestock under the anti-inflation program was a factor, livestock men said, in a drop of 25 to 35 cents a hundredweight in hog prices late today. The late hog top slumped to $15.40. compared with $15.70 early today and last Friday.

Willie Klein of Wheatley Hills, two-time holder of the title, took a one-stroke lead in the first round of the Metropolitan P.G.A. championship by carding two under par 34, 34 -- 68 over the Fresh Meadow Country Club links yesterday.

The sixteen-family apartment i house at 201 Claremont Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., has been sold by the Security Building and Loan i Association to the Epstein Coni struction Company through Paul Weisbart, Inc. Howard R. Cruse represented the seller and Harold Epstein the buyer.

In a little room on the fifth floor of a downtown office building is a shop that has been planned particularly for those with a taste for Southern cooking. As a matter of fact, it is not a shop at all in the usual sense of the word, for there are no counters, no cash registers, no great display of wares.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- There were several good features in the industrials, home rails and oils seen in today's generally cheerful stock market The demand for the home rails found the markets short of stock and prices in consequence went well ahead.

VICHY, France, Oct. 5 -- The first group of French workers to be designated for service in Germany left Paris this morning on their way to take over a German plant. Groups are being forced to go, it is understood, from one factory after another in the Paris region.

Mayor La Guardia formally commissioned the five borough commanders of the City Patrol Corps as colonels yesterday at City Hall and at the same time commissioned Mrs. Georgianna W. Carson as a major to command the women's division of the corps.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 5 -- Wait A Bit, owned by William Ziegler Jr., and ridden by Jockey V. Nodarse, responded when turned loose to win the Uplands Purse, featuring the Laurel program today. The 4-year-old son of Espino and Hi-Nelli beat five others of his age over a mile and 70 yards while carrying top weight of 115 pounds.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 5 -- Wendell L. Willkie today held important conferences, visited three of China's "refugee" universities, made plans to go to the Chinese-Japanese front and kissed another girl.
A well sustained interest in Brooklyn homes is being noticed ruby brokers in many sections. Small houses of the medium price type are in strong demand.

An offer of wage increases for 45,000 members of the International Longshoreman's Association was disclosed jointly yesterday by Joseph P. Ryan, president of the organization, and representatives of steamship operators. The proposed wage scale would affect workers from New England to Hampton Roads, Va.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (U.P.) -- Big United States Army bombers, in a determined bid to drive the Japanese out of the Western Aleutian Islands, are subjecting the enemy to "continual fire" in almost daily raids on Kiska, the Navy disclosed today
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 5 -- All is in readiness for the arrival tomorrow of about 900 Waves, whose coming will mark the official opening of the United States Naval Training School at Smith College.

IT'S lucky that there were nearly 70,000 witnesses to the tragedy in the Bronx yesterday or the facts would be hard to believe. The clattering Cardinals, scampering through the dripping fog that enveloped the field, beat the great Yankee team for the fourth straight time and pulled down the curtain on an astonishing series.

OTTAWA, Oct. 5 -- The adoption of price and wage ceilings by the United States guarantees maintenance of the system adopted here nearly a year ago and is regarded by Canadian authorities as assurance against inflation.

Slow learners, who constitute 20 per cent of the elementary school population, will receive special attention this year, under a statement of policy submitted to elementary school superintendents yesterday by Deputy Superintendent of Schools Stephen F. Bayne.

Yesterday's session of the Supreme Court, beginning its new term, was mostly formal, as usual, and in part memorial. A flood of cases must have accumulated in the vacation of four months. The estimated number, 450, is necessarily provisional. Public as well as legal interest awaits with eagerness the full statement of the reasons for the denial in July of the petitions of the seven Nazi saboteurs for writs of habeas corpus.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Motion pictures, music, athletic and canteen facilities will be carried by "clubmobiles" to American troops on duty at isolated posts in the British Isles, under a plan announced today by Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross.

Samuel Patt, 40-year-old dress worker and father of three children, of 3244 White Plains Avenue, the Bronx, worked out a system in his spare time and between jobs whereby he received home relief, unemployment insurance payments and registered under his own name and his brother's name for social security.

Hitler has successively predicted the fall of Leningrad, Moscow and Stalingrad. All of them still stand. They are the three cities the Russians have said the enemy would never take. After forty-three days of desperate battle Hitler has not destroyed the defense of Stalingrad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Senator Downey of California said today that he would offer as a substitute for the Senate Finance Committee's 5 per cent Victory tax a 10 per cent compulsory savings levy on earnings above $100 a month -- rebatable to taxpayers after the war.
The same chord was struck by all the coaches at the Football Writers Association luncheon at Toots Shor's restaurant yesterday. Their teams are young, eager and inexperienced.

MOSCOW, Oct. 5 -- The Ambassadors of the United States and Britain evidently will ask the Russian Government to clarify certain phrases of the letter in which Premier Stalin declared that a second front was in the first rank of importance to the Soviet Union and in which he called upon Russia's allies to "fulfill their obligations fully and on time."

LONDON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill will be called upon for an early explanation of the meaning of Premier Stalin's request yesterday that the Allies fulfill their obligations to Russia "on time," the London Star said tonight.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- Attorney-General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, making his first campaign address tonight, charged that the past policy of the Republican party in New York State in reference to water power developing was responsible for a power shortage which was now hampering the war effort.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FLYING FORTRESS COMMAND, Somewhere in England, Oct. 5 -- Picture yourself in a Flying Fortress more than five miles above France in this predicament, after the attack on the Meaulte plant:

Racing appeared to take its train cancellation in stride at Belmont Park yesterday, just as the elimination of buses last July at Empire City went past with hardly more than a ripple. With 9,391 persons present on an overcast Monday, the public pool ran to $766,771, both of which are figures that compare very favorably with days when there were no restrictions regarding transportation.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would support the candidacy of Dean Alfange, American Labor party nominee for Governor, and that he intended to give the Laborite candidate "what help I can properly" in the campaign.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Members of the American Meat Institute were told today by George A. Schmidt, chairman, that the Institute must continue its meat promotion campaign despite record-breaking military and lend-lease requirements "as an instrument of good will" and as an influence in rebuilding civilian demand for meat after the war.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique:

Brought up to date and streamlined, "Rain" will be sent on the road, commencing early next month, with Lenore Ulric portraying one of the best-known characters of the modern theatre -- the energetic Sadie Thompson. This was announced yesterday by Margaret Hewes, who will sponsor the revival of the John Colton-Clemence Randolph play, probably in association with an unnamed partner.
LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Twenty-five London policemen are spending their spare time showing United States soldiers, sailors and marines the sights of London at 25 cents "a throw," it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Two Senators, one a Republican and the other a Democrat, criticized today a declaration by Marshall Field that The Associated Press is a "monopoly" and as such a "distinct threat to my nation's future."

LONDON, Oct. 5 (U.P.) -- In connection with the summary of R.A.F. operations for September, it was noted that the Flying Fortress and Boston bombers of the United States Army Air Forces attacked targets in occupied territory on three days.

The day's news includes items of chief interest to the hunter and target shooter. Here in New York one direct move against the Police Department order for the registering of firearms by club sportsmen using ranges within the city is the mass meeting that has been called for Friday evening by the Long Island Rifle and Pistol Association.

David Loeb, president of AcGinhis Restaurant, Inc., has ]eased a penthouse suite at the Warwick Hotel. 65 West Fifty-fourth Street. formerly occupied by ][arion Davies. the actre. R. Fabricant was the broker.

GREENSBORO, N.C., Oct. 5 -Dean Virginia Gildersleeve of Barnard College, as a speaker at the convocation luncheon of the Woman's College of the University of North Carolina, pleaded with the leaders of women's liberal arts colleges today to keep them at work on the central job of well-grounded leadership training and to avoid going too far afield in practical war training, for which the colleges were not fitted.

MOSCOW, Oct. 5 -- The newspaper Pravda states that September production broke the record for the production of war material. Many hundreds of factories topped their quotas and produced more planes, tanks, guns, mortars and small arms in the third quarter of the year than in any similar period.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- United States Army bombers based on a new site in the Andreanof group of the Aleutian Islands have kept the Japanese at Kiska under "continual fire" in recent days, the Navy said in a communique today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 5 (AP) -- Stamford and Middletown, biggest prizes at stake in municipal elections held in eighty-four of Connecticut's 169 communities, elected Republican Mayors today, both of whom ousted Democratic incumbents.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 5 -- Ralph S. Healy, chief of staff of Air Raid Precautions of the Nassau County Office of Civilian Defense, announced today his resignation, along with his staff of eight section heads.

Several tons of scrap metal, at the Twelfth Regiment Armory, Sixty-second Street and Columbus Avenue, were turned over yesterday to war scrap collectors at the request of Colonel Louis E. Jallade, commanding the regiment. The lot included five German light trench mortars captured in the first World War by the Fifty-second Pioneer Infantry.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Complete faith in General Draja Mikhailovitch and in his steadfast resistance to the Axis powers and his wisdom in handling quarrelsome elements among his own people were expressed here today by the Yugoslav Government in reply to statements published in the United States accusing him of making terms with the Axis.

Following individual appeals for relief under Order M-126, the War Production Board yesterday granted to several luggage manufacturers an extension of forty-five days during which they will be permitted, without restriction, to use up their inventories of steel wardrobe fixtures, frames and stays.
The strongest college football teams in the East at this time appear to be Boston College, Pennsylvania, Duquesne, Dartmouth, Colgate, Army and Georgetown.

A gloomy haze hung over the Yankee Stadium yesterday as the once mighty Bronx Bombers went down to their first world series defeat since 1926 before the irrepressible young Cardinals, who soared to victory on the wings of a ninth-inning home run by Whitey Kurowski.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- An overall rent ceiling, broad enough to cover the entire country and to protect all districts, rural or urban, was invoked today by the Office of Price Administration. The ceiling under the law is to go into effect Dec. 5 in the additional areas subject to today's order.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Cubs, losers of the first three games of the annual city series, defeated the White Sox, 2 to 1, in ten innings before 5,963 tonight to score a second straight victory and keep the 1942 competition alive.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 5 -- Joining its voice with other protests from religious bodies in France against the continued persecution of Jews in both zones, the National Council of the Reformed Church of France ordered a message read in all pulpits throughout the country before yesterday's sermons.

The machine age in the New York Stock Clearing Corporation has come to an end. The business machines that kept the clearing records started to leave the Stock Exchange building on Oct. 1 and more are scheduled to go this week.

TRENTON, Oct. 5 -- Removal of the registered offices of many corporations from Jersey City to Flemington and other municipalities to escape higher taxation of personal property does not concern Governor Charles Edison, he said today, so long as they do not leave New Jersey.

Plans for salvaging, at a cost of $2,723,000, some 49,330 tons of scrap metal through demolition of buildings, railroad bridges and street car tracks in New York City have been submitted to War Materials, Inc., by Park Commissioner Robert Moses, who released his proposals yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's speech yesterday, even more than Adolf Hitler's last Wednesday, was "the first real sign in three years of a substantial weakening of Nazi morale," said a high official here today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Grain traders placed a bearish construction on an order of the Office of Price Administration issued late Saturday freezing flour prices at the highest level of the preceding five days. As a ceiling price had been placed on wheat feeds recently, traders regarded tile latest regulation as placing a definite brake on any possible upturn in the market and general selling developed.

Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Hospitals Commissioner, held yesterday, after hearing an appeal, to his decision to close the New York Cancer Clinic at 124 East Fifty-ninth Street at the end of this week because it was more practical to treat the clinic's patients in other city institutions.

FORT GEORGE G. MEADE. Md., Oct. 5 (AP) -- A false death report attributed to possible fifth columnists was disclosed today by the Fort Meade Public Relations Office, which said the parents of a New York soldier had been informed that their son was killed here.

Will you allow an Englishman, who is also a member of the British Labor party, to say how extremely puzzling he finds the letter from Harold Laski which appeared in your columns a day or two since? Among other propositions Mr. Laski lays down these:

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- After Raymond J. Whitney had plunged the local city government into confusion today by offering his resignation as City Manager and then "repudiating" it, the Yonkers Common Council met tonight and voted to hold a special meeting tomorrow evening in an effort to straighten out the tangle.

MORAL earnestness and the ability to analyze don't usually go hand in hand. But Herbert Agar's "A Time for Greatness"* is just one more proof of the old adage that there are exceptions to all rules. Mr. Agar jumps from eloquent lay preaching to witty aphorism, and from aphorism to canny, cold discussion of the fundamental political and social principles that make for freedom.

Do five million men in the Army, Navy and Air Force drink more coffee than the same five million men at home in peacetime? For the coffee shortage in town two reasons are given -- a lack of ships and coffee demand in the armed forces.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 5 -- Wage increases for 500,000 miners commensurate with the rise in the cost of living will be demanded by the United Mine Workers of America when current agreements expire in April, John L. Lewis, president, announced today on the eve of the opening of the union's biennial convention here.
A sellout well in advance of its initial performance, "Fashions of the Times" will open this afternoon to a capacity house for a two-day run at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Three Axis supply ships, whose arrival would have been vital to the campaign in Egypt, have been torpedoed, two of them sunk, the Admiralty announced tonight in revealing another chapter of the sea war, which is as important to the campaign in the Middle East as any action fought on land
PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 5 -- To relieve the shortage of farm workers, Secretary Wickard advocated today a great migration of farm families from marginal soil to land which can be worked more productively.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Oct. 6 -- The Germans have started another drive in the northwestern suburbs of Stalingrad, hurling three infantry divisions, 100 tanks and many dive-bombers against the Soviet defenders, who "repulsed numerous enemy attacks," the Russian High Command reported today.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- The new international tin agreement appears to conflict with the spirit of the Atlantic Charter's fourth article, a study of the white paper published by the Foreign Office discloses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- At his homecoming press conference last week the President said that management and labor are doing a "magnificent job in war production," estimated that the armament program is at 94% or 95% of total "efficiency," and reproved those who he said are disposed to stress the minus %5 or %6 over the impressive plus.
