NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 5 -- While hostilities on the main Assam-Burma front are still hanging fire, both sides are sparring at either end of the Assam-China supply bridgehead, where there is a possibility that United States air freighters and Japanese interceptors may play hide and seek within sight of Himalayan snow caps.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 5 (AP) -- Baruna, the Munyon and Downing entry, won the feature race of an all-claiming card at Rockingham Park today. About 4,000 persons were at the track on its first day without special train service from Boston.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Despite a 10 per cent decrease predicted for the consumer supply of some manufactured dairy products and the possibility of a decrease in the consumer supply of eggs, there will be enough high protein foods supplementing rationed meat to maintain the country's health standards in the next twelve months, the Departments of Agriculture and the Interior said today.

Two Dodger baseball players, four fans and two Ebbets Field ushers appeared yesterday in Flatbush Court to answer a welter of counter-charges of assault and disorderly conduct. The charges were withdrawn and mutual forgiveness substituted.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Treasury is making arrangements to sell about 5,000,000 ounces of silver to industrial users, Representative McCormack, House majority leader, said today.
The thirtieth annual International Flower Show, scheduled for next March, became a war casualty yesterday.

Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, appealed last night to all voters of the State "as just plain Americans, regardless of party" to preserve the democratic principles of free elections on the home front by registering for the Fall election, thus signifying their intention to vote their convictions, as free men.

Events tonight: Victor Laderoute, song recital, Barbizon Recital Hall, 8:30; Mary Burns, song recital, Studio Club, 210 East Seventy-seventh Street, 8:30; lecture-recital on "Jazz" by Robert Goffin and Leonard Feather, Louis Prima, trumpeter, guest artist, New School for Social Research, 8:20.
Although the Yankees lost the world series, they carried off the lion's share of the records set or equaled during the five-game tussle with the Cardinals, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

A noisy chorus of pounding mallets and driving hammers is due to emerge tonight from the fifth-floor workshop of the Y.W.C.A. at Fiftieth Street and Tenth Avenue, where a record group of feminine novitiates will tackle the art of reupholstering under the direction of Miss Tilly Barning, professional upholsterer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The general language of President Roosevelt's Economic Stabilization Order raised a number of grave problems today as the National War Labor Board was flooded with inquiries on how employers and employes, about to reach agreement on wage advances, can make certain that they comply with the principles of the order, which requires Federal control of all wage changes.

SOMEWHERE IN EASTERN INDIA, Oct. 3 (Delayed) -- Here is a story that can be told now of the retreat from Burma, how the last Chinese division got out after hardships incomparably greater than those suffered by other units.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve System announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 30: Increases of $655,000,000 in holdings of Treasury notes and $894,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and decreases of $228,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $383,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and $268,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Secretary Morgenthau said today that a new tax bill to yield $6,000,000,000 more revenue would be presented to Congress "as soon as they will receive us." This would be in addition to the $8,000,000,000 measure which the Senate will take under consideration tomorrow.
Suspension of construction on the $80,000,000 Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel for the duration was recommended yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses to conserve strategic metals.

LONDON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The German radio broadcast claims of a great Japanese naval victory over the United States forces in the Solomon Islands, but all other sources -- including the Tokyo radio -- failed today to substantiate the Nazi report.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Produce futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange went into sharp declines in early trading today, reflecting week-end price control developments. Brokers attributed the active liquidation particularly to Price Administrator Henderson's sixty-day emergency ceiling on butter, eggs, onions, potatoes and other commodities formerly virtually exempt from price regulation.

MOSCOW, Oct. 5 -- A German air offensive on the Leningrad front is proving to be extremely costly. Nearly 100 German planes have been destroyed in the air during the last three days, and thirty-six are reported to have been wrecked in attacks on German fields.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- The first sedition indictments to be returned by the special sedition grand jury impaneled in April were brought into the Federal court of Judge John P. Barnes today. They named Newell Mecartney, a Chicago lawyer, and Elmer Hartzel and Elmer W. Soller, said to be his aides, as seditionists and conspirators.

Seven young American singers, including James Melton, tenor; four foreign singers and two conductors have been engaged for the Metropolitan Opera's forthcoming season, General Manager Edward Johnson announced yesterday in his annual press conference outlining the season's plans.

The Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse today will begin a revival of the Soviet film drama, "End of St. Petersburg." The picture, which depicts the rise of the Russian revolution and which was released in 1928, is the fourth film in the theatre's series of silent classic revivals.

A total of 168,092 voters registered yesterday in New York City as poll books were opened for the first time this year. This represented a drop of 89,437 from the first day's registration for last year's municipal election and a decline of 70,456 from the first day total for the last Gubernatorial election in 1938.

Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, personnel director of the Todd Shipyards Corporation, interviewed yesterday seventy women anxious to become shipyard workers. This group was the first called from 3,500 who had applied by letter to the company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Marines who captured positions on Guadalcanal, in the Solomon Islands, Aug. 7 still are fighting constant engagements with the Japanese there, the Navy reported this evening.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 5 -- John Swan, 26-year-old Negro theatre porter, who was released from the Army a month ago as unfit for service, was being held here tonight, charged with the slaying of Miss Marian Oliver, pretty 20-year-old orphan, whose nude beaten body was found early this morning in a weed-grown yard behind the Opera House, a motion picture theatre at 20 Liberty Street.

The National Foundation for Infantfie Paralysis has leased for executive offices a large part of the fourteenth floor in the Canadian Pacific Iuilding, 342 ]kfadison Avenue, through the Herbert McLean Purdy Management ' Corporation, agent.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5 -- In a resurgence of the fundamentalistmodernist dispute which created a split in the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A. in 1936, the Rev. Herbert J. Anderson, 35-year-old former pastor of the Arch Street Presbyterian Church, was dropped from the rolls of the Presbytery of Philadelphia today at his own request.

Under increased liquidation and hedging, presumably attributable to the uncertainties regarding the ultimate ceiling levels for agricultural commodities, the cotton market yesterday experienced its sharpest decline in more than a month as it closed at the day's lows and net losses of 19 to 25 points, equal to 95 cents to $1.25 a bale.

Marian Anderson has accepted the invitation of the Daughters of the American Revolution to sing at Constitution Hall in Washington for a war relief agency, provided that there be no segregation in the audience and that the appearance be a precedent for future ones in her annual tours, it was learned yesterday.

Because of the high prices which have prevailed for most of the "uncontrolled" foods, the action of Price Administrator Leon Henderson in extending ceilings to include the majority of such items is not likely to cause any sequeeze, trade factors asserted yesterday.

In the ninth inning of yesterday's fifth game of the 1942 world series, with a crowd of 69,052 looking on while two fine hurlers, old Red Ruffing and young Johnny Beazley, were locked in a 2-all tie, George (Whitey) Kurowski, a youngster just one year out of the minors, bashed a home run into the densely packed stands of the Yankee Stadium.

The fight against the poll tax as a prerequisite for voting took a new turn yesterday when Senator O'Mahoney of Wyoming introduced a constitutional amendment to outlaw it in Federal elections. Since only eight States now raise this barrier against indigent or careless citizens, Senator O'Mahoney believes the amendment could be ratified in short order.

A hundred representatives of leading community activities in the Yorkville section attended the opening ceremonies yesterday afternoon of a new consumer center at 1391 Lexington Avenue. Founded by the war activities committee of the New York section, National Council of Jewish Women, under the chairmanship of Mrs. Irving M. Engel, it was named Consumer Council 1 of the Yorkville Defense Council.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Progress toward devising a program for war-time college education to meet present military requirements and future technical demands was reported today by Dr. Edward Elliott, director of professional and technical personnel for the War Manpower Commission.
Small buildings in various partsi of Manhattan formed the bulk of i trading as reported by brokers l starting the new business week.
They broke up the Yankees yesterday. They have been yelling to "break up the Yankees" for the past two years. They did it yesterday.
Net profit for the first half of 1942 was estimated yesterday by the Cerro de Pasco Copper Corporation at $1,015,000 after income taxes and other charges.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Office of Price Administration today announced a method by which individual adjustments can be made for sellers of men's and boys' tailored clothing who are affected by the "highest price line" rule.
Exploring new fields for the salvage of scrap metal, Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn yesterday disclosed that he had not overlooked either the polls or college campuses.

OPA may recognize that increases in wages and raw materials are "important evidence" to support a manufacturer's request for higher price ceilings, but it does not automatically mean corresponding unit cost increases in finished products. Only actual operating experience can be accepted as conclusive evidence.

Because of the high prices which have prevailed for most of the "uncontrolled" foods, the action of Price Administrator Leon Henderson in extending ceilings to include the majority of such items is not likely to cause any sequeeze, trade factors asserted yesterday.

In the ninth inning of yesterday's fifth game of the 1942 world series, with a crowd of 69,052 looking on while two fine hurlers, old Red Ruffing and young Johnny Beazley, were locked in a 2-all tie, George (Whitey) Kurowski, a youngster just one year out of the minors, bashed a home run into the densely packed stands of the Yankee Stadium.

The fight against the poll tax as a prerequisite for voting took a new turn yesterday when Senator O'Mahoney of Wyoming introduced a constitutional amendment to outlaw it in Federal elections. Since only eight States now raise this barrier against indigent or careless citizens, Senator O'Mahoney believes the amendment could be ratified in short order.

A PACIFIC NORTHWEST PORT, Oct. 5 -- Five Japanese prisoners of war, the first to reach the Pacific Northwest and possibly the first to reach the Continental United States, were landed recently at a Pacific Northwest port, it was disclosed tonight.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 5 -- Byron Price, director of censorship, replied tonight to the criticism of the government's action in bringing about the suppression of news of President Roosevelt's recent tour of war production areas by declaring that "the public will applaud overwhelmingly what their newspapers did" in withholding the news at the request of the authorities.

Several debutantes of this season headed by Miss Dudley Kenyon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alden H. Kenyon, are aiding in furthering the success of the dinner and supper dance to be held on Friday night at the formal opening for this season of the Wedgwood Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Opportunity Shop.

LONDON, Tuesday, Oct. 6 (U.P.) -- The London Times urged in an editorial today that the Viceroy's Council in New Delhi be completely "Indianized" as an immediate step toward ending the deadlock in India and to show the world at the same time that Britain is ready and willing for a settlement.
Harold P. Wade has been appointed general manager of Adel Precision Products Corporation, Burbank, Calif.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today ignored the plea of the railroads operating in New York State, and postponed indefintely a hearing on whether increases in intrastate fares which the commission authorized last February should be allowed to go into effect.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- President Roosevelt opened the 1942 Community Mobilization for Human Needs tonight with the declaration that "we must transform some of our new buying power into giving power as we face redoubled needs on every hand at home and abroad; and prepare to pull our belts tighter for the hard fight ahead."

Procedure to be followed by the eighteen banks in four up-State counties that were recently selected by the Office of Price Administration as the "proving ground" for the new national ration banking plan is explained by the New York State Bankers Association in the current issue of its weekly publication, The New York State Banker.
LONDON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- A British communique on Madagascar:
MOSCOW, Oct. 5 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 5 -- A rousing reception is planned tomorrow at Union Station for the triumphant Cardinals when they return from blasting the best Yankee pitchers and routing the American League standard-bearers from their position as world baseball champions.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Lord Halifax, the British Ambassador, declared today that if the Allied peoples "keep their resolution burning as fiercely as the German resolution they need have no doubt about the results" of the war.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Tuesday, Oct. 6 -- A communique:

Facing the task of shifting New York's seventy-six voluntary hospitals to a war footing so that any emergency may be met successfully, the United Hospital Fund announced yesterday that its sixty-fourth annual appeal would begin next Tuesday.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Evidence from the Royal Air Force raids over Germany last month that the Nazis had heavily strengthened their Ruhr anti-aircraft defenses led to an expression of hope here today that the United States might go in for the production of Lancaster bombers for the Anglo-American air offensive.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Curtailed civilian consumption of a larger number of essential foods will be proposed by Secretary Wickard to assure adequate supplies for American armed forces and to bolster the supplies of our Allies, the Secretary said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- James Francis Byrnes, whom President Roosevelt has drafted to become Director of Economic Stabilization, was honored in the Supreme Court today when Chief Justice Stone praised the sense of public duty impelling the South Carolinian to leave the post of associate justice.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 5 -- Confidence in the eventual victory of the United Nations over the forces of totalitarianism marked keynote addresses opening the annual convention today of the American Federation of Labor.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Mrs. Elizabeth K. Dilling, author indicted on charges of undermining morale of the armed forces, was ordered removed to Washington for trial today by Federal Judge William H. Holly, who immediately stayed his order by allowing an appeal to the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

BOSTON, Oct. 5 -- President Roosevelt gave assurance today that the "government will do everything that it can to see that the products available for civilian needs are allocated in an orderly and equitable fashion."
HAVANA, Oct. 2 -- Banco de los Colonos, first of its kind in the island, has been organized by a group of cane planters as a means of aiding planters in financing the sugar crop.

Forty-seven women went back to school yesterday to prepare themselves for one of the most vital jobs on the home front. In a ten-week course conducted by the Child Study Association of America, they will be trained to work as volunteers in day nurseries, in kindergartens and with school recreation programs.

In the interesting letter from J.W. Connolly in THE TIMES of Oct. 4 reference was made to the fact that of the last nine heating seasons five were warmer than normal and four were colder. Mr. Connolly therefore draws the inference that by the law of averages this Winter should be colder than usual.

The Ballet Theatre, fresh from a Summer in Mexico, opened its annual season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night with an all-Tchaikovsky program, which, in spite of what one might be tempted to presuppose from that, contained a full-fledged novelty.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1.010, as against 1.050 in the preceding week and 707 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 512, which compared with 387 for last Tuesday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 6 -- The Yale-Princeton football game, originally scheduled for Palmer Stadium here, will be played instead at Baker Field, Columbia University's gridiron in New York City, it was announced tonight by Asa S. Bushnell, acting director of athletics at Princeton.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The net income, including government payments, of farm operators in the United States in 1942 was estimated tonight by the United States Department of Agriculture at $9,785,000,000.

Four local restaurant associations representing nearly 600 New York City eating establishments, including the most expensive night clubs as well as modest "bean houses," and the City Hotel Association, embracing most of the city's, hotels, advocated yesterday a weekly "meatless day" as an alternative to meat rationing in restaurants.

Eugene W. Stetson, president of the Guaranty Trust Company, was elected yesterday chairman of the Clearing House Committee at the annual meeting of the New York Clearing House Association. Herbert P. Howell, chairman of the Commercial National Bank and Trust Company, was re-elected president of the association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Although 1932 was a depression year, while in 1941 the war had stimulated business to feverish activity, the property tax yield of $4,500,000,000 in 1941 was about 5 per cent less than the property taxes collected in 1932, the Bureau of the Census reported today.

AT SEA WITH PACIFIC FLEET -- Jerry (which isn't his real name but will have to do) is the pilot of an American cruiser plane, used for anti-submarine patrol and for control of battery fire in a surface contact with the enemy or bombardment of shore positions.
BRAZIL, Ind., Oct. 6 (UP) -- Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Commissioner, wrote a letter for President Roosevelt today telling children what they should do about the war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Certain powers of the Sacred Roman Rota, supreme court of the Catholic Church, regarding pending matrimonial cases, have been conferred by Pope Pius XII on the Apostolic Delegate to the United States, it was learned here today.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York will open its 101st season at Carnegie Hall tonight, Arturo Toscanini will lead the orchestra in an all-Berlioz program consisting of the "Roman Carnival" Overture and the dramatic symphony, "Romeo and Juliet."

Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, in an address here yesterday called on shippers and carriers to "get the utmost possible work" out of the nation's railroads, declaring that transportation must meet unforeseen emergencies in a war that would strain national resources as never before.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- In order to clear up some of the confusion in the public mind on the application of the voluntary meat rationing program requested by Secretary Wickard two weeks ago, the Food Requirements Committee has drawn up a list of questions and answers for the guidance of consumers.

Arthur Bradley Campbell gave a luncheon yesterday at the formal opening of the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for this season. His guests included Mr. and Mrs. Le Ray Berdeau, Mr. and Mrs. Blaine Webb and Mrs. Arthur Woolley-Hart. Another luncheon there was given by Mrs. George Washington Kavanaugh for Lady Decies and the latter's son, John Dahlgren.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission was accused today in the Third Circuit Court of Appeals of violating the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935 by following "unconstitutional and unstatutory procedure" in its administration of the "death sentence" clause.

Mayor La Guardia's ban on the newsstand sale of "tipster" sheets was attacked from two sides yesterday and received at least a temporary legal setback. Meanwhile, the Mayor indicated that he would modify the ban as affecting The Morning Telegraph, 109-year-old newspaper devoted largely to racing information, on the ground that it receives press service news and would be treated "the same as other newspapers."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Americans are now spending $227,000,000 a day on the war, have provided through their government over $13,000,000,000 of new war plants, are working more than five hours a week longer in their factories and being paid on the average 85 cents an hour to do so.

Nine local housing authorities in various parts of the country announced yesterday new note issues aggregating $65,031,000 for award through competitive bidding. Of these, six issues totaling $58,066,000 will come up for award on Oct. 16, and three totaling $6,965,000, on Oct. 21.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 6 -- Less than twelve hours after a German proclamation of a state of emergency in Trondheim, Norway, and the surrounding province, a German military court sentenced ten prominent and innocent Norwegians to death, and this evening the victims were executed by a firing squad.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Oct. 3 (Delayed) (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur, in an unprecedented action, today pinned the United States Army's Silver Star award on Vern Haugland, Associated Press war correspondent who fought his way out of a New Guinea jungle after being lost for forty-three days when forced to bail out of an Army plane.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Senate today tentatively approved individual income tax rates which would impose upon individual taxpayers the highest levy in the country's history. Normal and surtaxes call for a total rate of 19 per cent on the first dollar of taxable income, with the levy graduated up to 88 per cent on a surtax net income in excess of $200,000.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 6 (AP) -- United States Ambassador Jefferson Caffery and Foreign Minister Oswaldo Aranha signed accords today concerning the placement of Brazil's exportable surplus of coffee, cocoa and Brazil nuts on the United States market.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Amid the grave military aspects of the war, both revealed and unrevealed, the encouraging fact can be set down that some of the severest critics of the industrial home front are becoming convinced that the new War Production Board organization has a full potential of effectiveness.

Members of the interstate commission on the Delaware River basin asked the support of the New York City Board of Water Supply yesterday for legislation "to promote interstate cooperation for the use, conservation and protection of the water resources in the Delaware River basin."

Mediation efforts have failed to effect a settlement of the strike against J.S. Bache Co., brokerage house, called on Friday by Local 20,940 of the American Federation of Office Employes, A.F. of L., it was announced yesterday by Jules S. Freund, executive secretary of the New York State Mediation Board.

The Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service, founded by Lillian D. Wald in 1893, is completing this year its first half century of service. Its original two nurses, doing what they could to help sick people in a tiny area, have been succeeded by 275, on call and going rounds from sixteen centers in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens.
MOSCOW, Oct. 6 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- A strong movement by the Japanese to land reinforcements for their troops on Guadalcanal Island, in the Solomons, on Saturday night [Solomons time] cost them a severely damaged heavy cruiser, the Navy Department reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- President Roosevelt announced today that he would make a radio address to the nation probably within ten days. He said, in answer to questions, that the speech would deal with a variety of subjects but would not be a review of the war, nor a report on his tour of war plants and armed forces' establishments from coast to coast.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Plans for converting the sugar refineries which will be closed down under the program for concentration of production into units for the production of industrial alcohol or of a low grade of edible molasses are under study by War Production Board specialists, it was learned here today.

LONDON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Two American fliers were decorated by the British today, Eagle Pilot Officer William Henry Baker, 22 years old, of Temple, Texas, receiving the Distinguished Flying Cross and Flight Sergeant William Thomas Bent, 26, Glen White, W. Va., of the Royal Canadian Air Force, receiving the Distinguished Flying Medal.
New York is a wonderful city and New Yorkers are the kindest, friendliest people they've ever met, was the consensus of 111 sailors who have just finished a three-day furlough here.

A map reveals the close link between the fighting now going on in New Guinea and in the Solomon Islands. The eastern end of New Guinea and the Southern Solomons form the base of a triangle of which New Britain, with its strong Japanese base at Rabaul, is the apex.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- A precedent-establishing measure to permit States and local governments to tax land acquired by the Federal Government for military purposes after January, 1940, drew stiff opposition today from the War, Navy and Treasury departments.

LONDON, Wednesday, Oct. 7 -- A strong force of British and Canadian bomber planes braved "appalling weather" Monday night to attack objectives in Western Germany. Ten planes were lost, which was not heavy for the force employed. The German official news agency said the target was Essen.

Lou Little is working hard these evenings to round the Columbia Lions into shape for Brown, which comes to town on Saturday to meet the Light Blue eleven. Little calls Brown at least the third best of the present "Ivy Leaguers," ranking them alongside Dartmouth and a shade behind Pennsylvania.
The seven-room house on a plot 55 by 100 feet at 144-07 Thirty-third Avenue, Flushing, L.I., was sold by G. Dresselhouse to Mrs. Mary Foley through the Halleran Agency, brokers.

Fordham's football players, still battered from the going over they received at the hands of Tennessee last Saturday, began earnest preparation yesterday on Rose Hill for the game Saturday with North Carolina in the Polo Grounds.

Members of the City Council split yesterday on the question of opening city employment to non-citizens as the Council passed a local law permitting aliens who hold first papers to work as attendants and helpers in the city hospitals.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Maxie Shapiro, a wild-swinging jolter from New York, a 5-to-1 underdog in the betting, won a terrific upset ten-round decision over Philadelphia's Bob Montgomery before a crowd of 9,000 at the Arena tonight.

DETROIT, Oct. 6 -- Its record in cutting assembly time of the Bofors anti-aircraft cannon from 450 hours each to fourteen hours, today brought government recognition in the form of the Army-Navy "E" flag to more than 45,000 employes of the Chrysler Corporation.

New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System, it appeared yesterday, had managed to retain most of the $460,000,000 of excess reserves that they had at the close of business on Saturday. Although the Treasury withdrew funds here yesterday, these withdrawals apparently were offset fully by Treasury disbursements in this area on account of war contracts.

Mildred Borst, one of four former showgirls to whom the late William Guggenheim, retired industrialist and amateur poet, left an estate later revealed as having little value, started suit in Supreme Court yesterday to recover 11,000 shares of stock of the Minas Geraes Iron Company of Brazil from the industrialist's widow, Mrs. Aimee Guggenheim.

The function of a wartime tax bill can be simply stated. It is to raise the maximum amount of revenue that can be raised short of the point at which taxes begin to impair production. The objective of such a bill is not primarily to pay for the cost of the war, although that is important.

Once upon a time there was a purely imaginary sailor in an entirely hypothetical shipwreck who struck out for the shore, which was three miles away. He covered all but one-tenth of 1 per cent of the distance.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- Miss Kathleen Byrne of Rye won low gross honors today in the next to the last one-day tournament on the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association schedule when she toured the hilly south course of the Westchester Country Club in 41, 41 -- 82.

The leading editorial in THE TIMES of Oct. 4 brings into the open a situation which has annoyed, not to say angered, many civilians on the New England coast all Summer. Day after day enormous planes float low over us; we hear constant rumors that German submarines are immediately offshore and that dead Germans have been washed ashore.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 6 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, pledged for the union and himself today unequivocal support of the nation's war efforts and lashed out at those who question his loyalty because of his isolationist position before Pearl Harbor.

The Young Men's Christian Association, operating in sixty-one countries of the world and with a total membership of 2,000,000 persons, will begin observance of founder's week next Sunday. It will be the ninety-eighth anniversary of the establishment of the movement by Sir George Williams in England.
CHUNGKING, Wednesday, Oct. 7 -- Following is the text of the statement issued today by Wendell L. Wllikie:
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 7 (U.P.) -- The midnight communique of the Soviet High Command:

LONDON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Rome radio broadcast a special communique today claiming that a United States battleship of the 33,000-ton Mississippi type "was seen sinking" after an Italian submarine shot four torpedoes into its bow 330 miles southeast of Freetown, West Africa.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At Loew's Criterion the newcomer will be "Wings and the Woman," Herbert Wilcox's production for RKO dramatizing the career of the late Amy Johnson Mollison. Anna Neagle plays the aviatrix and Robert Newton portrays James Mollison.

TORONTO, Oct. 6 -- A cordial message from President Roosevelt thanking the members of the American Federation of Labor for their efforts to increase war production was read to the delegates at the annual convention of the federation today by George Meany, secretary-treasurer.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 6 -- President James B. Conant of Harvard University told members of the entering Harvard College freshman class that they had only "a relatively few months" of college life ahead of them before they would be called into the service of their country, and the problem they faced was how to use them.

A reception and tea marked the Autumn opening yesterday afternoon of the Navy League Shop at 746 Madison Avenue. The occasion served also to inaugurate an appeal for funds to buy Christmas packages for men in the United States Navy and Merchant Marine.

Craig Wood, the national open champion, distanced a small but select field to the tune of nine strokes to win the seventeenth annual Metropolitan P.G.A. title at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Flushing yesterday.

An exhibition consisting of 100 posters by well-known artists and cartoonists, work contributed to a new national organization, "The Walls Have Ears," has been installed just inside the entrance of the Museum of Science and Industry and will be open to the public after 8 o'clock this evening.

The bitter battle of Stalingrad -- a sanguinary epic of defensive fighting -- continued its no-decision course yesterday, and in the far-flung theatres of the Pacific sporadic fighting on land, at sea and in the air marked the campaign of the Solomons and the campaign of the Aleutians.

Undeterred by Congressional investigations or Department of Justice prosecutions, Petrillo marches on, telling the American people what they can and cannot hear. It is a rare day on which he does not think of some new suppression. The weekly rebroadcast of Jack Benny's radio program to the Pacific Coast has been canceled because of the fight by Petrillo's union against transcriptions.
LONDON, Oct. 6 -- After yesterday's busy session, wherein brokers had their most active day in more than two years, business today was smaller, but many prices improved again.

Decreeing closed toes, flat heels, ankle straps and bright colors, American shoe designers participating in The New York Times Fashion showing yesterday promised style and comfort for war-working women. Bright-hued stockings of wool and cotton were worn with these sturdy shoes.

LONDON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- A German firing squad executed ten persons in the Trondheim area tonight as German authorities enforced martial law along the Norwegian coast in an effort to stamp out the spirit of rebellion, which appeared to be spreading in the Scandinavian countries, radio reports from Norway said.

OTTAWA, Oct. 6 (Canadian Press) -- The Supreme Court of Canada decided today that the Dominion has no power to impose a tax on insurance premiums paid to companies which are not authorized under the laws of the Dominion to transact insurance business in Canada.

ANDRE MAUROIS, who has written biographies of so many flamboyant and spectacular personages, Shelley, Byron, Disraeli, Chateaubriand, has no such colorful hero for his current book. "I Remember, I Remember"* is an autobiography, the record of a full, interesting and successful life, but by no means a psychological study of a bizarre and theatrical personality.
War restrictions on all types of construction work not directly associated with military and naval activity continue to keep building projects in New York down to a minimum.

Although stripped of a world championship which it had come to regard as much its very own as the City Hall, New York somehow seemed to bear up remarkably well yesterday following the shock of having seen its proud Yankees trampled underfoot by a band of hungry and hustling Cardinals in one of the most remarkable world series struggles in many years.
I wish to commend the politeness and the consideration of several air wardens and policemen in connection with the Pulaski Day parade in Fifth Avenue Sunday afternoon.

AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, received an enthusiastic reception from Cayuga County Democrats at a meeting here tonight, after a day in which he received two assurances of support.

The probability that the pension fund benefits accruing to the widow and children of Irwin Goodman, slain mathematics teacher at William J. Gaynor High School in Brooklyn, will amount to not more than $3,500, was conceded yesterday by members of the Teachers' Retirement Board.

Urging that military authorities send engineering and science students, who would be taken into the Army if the draft law is revised to include 18 and 19 year old boys, back to college to complete their training, Dr. Albert B. Newman, dean of the City College School of Technology, warned 1,000 members of the college's freshman class yesterday that unless this procedure were followed the nation's supply of engineers would seriously be endangered.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 6 (AP) -- An estimated 25,000 wildly cheering baseball fans jammed into and around Union Station late today to welcome home the world champion Cardinals, who went to New York the underdogs last week and. . . . Well, you know what they did to the Yankees in the last four games of the world series.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Office of Price Administration, which will handle the rationing of fuel oil, made public today the application form which householders will be asked to fill out when applying for fuel oil rations this month. The form contains thirty-five questions spread over four pages.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- As the United States, Great Britain and Soviet Russia signed today a new protocol covering uninterrupted and increased military aid to Russia, President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill declined firmly to be led into any public discussion of second-front plans or Russia's dissatisfaction with the aid given her thus far by her Allies among the United Nations.

Registration for this year's election made a slight gain yesterday, but the total for the first two days continued to trail the two-day totals of recent general election years by a wide margin. When the books were closed last night the number of persons registered for the two-day period this year was 388,146.

CHUNGKING, China, Wednesday, Oct. 7 -- Wendell L. Willkie today combined a vigorous demand for an "all-out" offensive everywhere by the United Nations with a plea for immediate "ironclad" guarantees by the democracies against the continuance of Western imperialism, particularly in Asia.

The first showing of the second traveling exhibition of enlarged photographs of garden sculpture, work by members of the National Sculpture Society, will open with a private view and reception this evening at the National Arts Club. A.F. Brinckerhoff will speak at 8:45 o'clock on "Sculpture Out of Doors."

BOSTON, Oct. 6 -- The United Nations are steadily advancing toward combined planning of distribution of munitions, raw materials and foodstuffs, and in the effective organization of shipping, Sir Louis Beale, head of the British Supply Council in North America, told the concluding session today of the Boston Conference on Distribution.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Unless steps are taken immediately to remedy dislocation of food distribution and to readjust price ceilings, the nation is heading into "something approaching actual hunger" within the next eighteen months, the Senate Small Business Committee was told today by Miss Rose Marie Kiefer, spokesman for more than 60,000 independent grocers throughout the country.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- A Navy Department communique:

The readers' advisers service of the New York Public Library has assembled in the current issue of the Branch Library Book News a "books for the dimout" directory. It is a listing for those "who turn to their reading lamps when the city lights are dimmed."

Home handicrafts were the foundation of American business in the early days of this country and are well worth supporting and encouraging. Richardson Wright, editor of House and Garden, said yesterday at the annual luncheon of the New York and New Jersey Divivisions of the Women's National Council of Farm and Garden Association in the Hotel New Weston.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Income payments to individuals in the United States were nearly one-fourth greater in August last than in August, 1941. Seasonally corrected they showed a 3.3 point rise in the Commerce Department index as compared with July, which had recorded a 3.1 point rise over June.

Accused of injuring seven Negroes, including five women, in a free-for-all battle in a Harlem tenement, which police attributed to growing ill-feeling over mugging attacks and the fatal stabbing of a soldier last Friday, four youths were held yesterday in $1,000 bail each in Felony court on felonious assault charges.

" Calls to the Colors" was the apt name Walter Florell gave the fashion showing of his hats at luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. This opened the series of Salon d'Elegance fashion luncheons to be held at the Ritz every Tuesday during the Winter season.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Oct. 6 -- In connection with the war loan of 3,000,000 contos [approximately $150,000,000] announced yesterday, the government decreed today that every resident of Brazil must subscribe to bonds to an amount equal to his last income tax.

Maxwell Anderson's new play, "The Eve of St. Mark," opens tonight at the Cort under the sponsorship of the Playwrights Company. Dedicated to his nephew, Sergeant Lee Chambers -- "one of the first to go, one of the first to die, that we may keep this earth for free men" -- Mr. Anderson's play is the first serious dramatic work directly inspired by America's participation in the war.
Women in uniform have become an integral part of the American wartime scene, and a well-tailored uniform hangs beside frivolous finery in many a feminine closet.

VICHY, France, Oct. 6 (U.P.) -- At least ten high officials of the Vichy Labor Ministry have resigned in protest against the government's forced-labor policies. They include several members of the staff of Secretary of State for Labor Hubert Lagardelle.

Despite brisk trade buying and hedge selling in the cotton futures market yesterday, quotations held within a comparatively tight range as orders on both sides seemed to enter the ring simultaneously. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts ended the session near the lows at net losses of 1 to 7 points.

In an effort to assure equitable distribution of dwindling supplies of sheets and pillow cases, retailers may have to limit quantities sold to individual customers within the very near future, textile merchants reported yesterday. Otherwise, it was said, stores may find themselves unable to function adequately during January "white sales," when consumer stocks are normally replenished.
Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt has closed her place in Newport and returned to 640 Fifth Avenue.

YONKERS, N. Y., Oct. 6 -- The Yonkers Common Council tonight elected former Mayor William A. Walsh to the post of City Manager to succeed Raymond J. Whitney, who was reinstated on Oct. 1 after being suspended last August on charges of failing to suppress gambling and selling usable city equipment for junk.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The Allies' coordinated land and air offensive against the Japanese in New Guinea continues in full course and still without major opposition, the Southwest Pacific command announced today.

Joseph Hilton Smyth, 40 years old, of Old Lyme, Conn.; Walker Grey Matheson, 40, Washington, and Irvine Harvey Williams, 38, of Wilton, Conn., were indicted yesterday by the Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on charges of having acted as agents for Japan without registering with the Department of State.

An adjustment movement settled yesterday over the stock market in the wake of the strong recovery drive, and after successfully fording a period of profit-taking the list closed mixed. It was apparent that traders were searching for laggards in the Fall upturn and considerable attention was paid the utilities, which constituted the bulk of the business.

It is easy to urge other people to sell their jewels or their junk for the common good. Robert Moses, as director of the Newspaper Publishers' Scrap Metal Committee, has been doing something like this. Nothing, from a frying pan to a fourteen-story building, is sacred to Mr. Moses if it seems more useful as scrap.

IT was confusing while it was happening, but it's easy to look back and see what really went on in the world series. Those Cardinals were poison to the Yankees. It was a complicated case of arsenic and old ivory.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- The American Meat Institute was told before adjournment of its thirty-seventh annual convention today that, because of labor shortages, other impediments and the record livestock production and demand for meats in 1943, it may be necessary for the government to control the marketings of hogs to handle the situation efficiently.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 7 -- The violent new German offensive against Stalingrad, which earlier reports described as surpassing in fierceness anything seen in the Volga battle, made very little progress yesterday and all but one tank were destroyed of a group of twelve that broke ahead in the region of an industrial settlement.

A two-day meeting, the purpose of which will be to convey essential information required for better understanding of key war projects affecting marketing and advertising practices, will be held here Nov. 11 and 12 by the Association of National Advertisers, Inc.

According to those who have recently visited Maine's big waterfowl shooting area at Merrymeeting Bay, the best duck hunting is still to come. Most veterans estimate that it will be well along toward the middle of the month before the ice on inland marshes and waterways drives the birds down to tidewater.

TRENTON, Oct. 6 -- Governor Charles Edison, aroused over what he called the Legislature's haphazard preparation of some measures rushed through under suspension of the rules, indicated today he would refuse to sign such bills in the future.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Despite food rationing and fewer physicians, dentists and pharmacists, the "stubborn good health" of the people of England and Wales continues, Health Minister Ernest Brown declared in presenting his report for the year ended last March.
The twelve-story loft building on a plot 52.8 by 64 feet at 584-90 Eighth Avenue was sold by David S. Meister, operator, to a client of Smith Isaacs, attorneys.
LONDON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

Small furniture retailers who are doubtful of their ability to survive during the war should give serious consideration to the advisability of closing their doors immediately while they still have some equity in their business. Maurice M. Friedman, executive director of the New York Furniture Merchants Association, told members last night at a meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The increasing importance of the widespread work of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service was brought out yesterday afternoon as a drive for $400,000 for the service opened at organization headquarters, 262 Madison Avenue. Former Governer Alfred E. Smith and Johannes Steel were among the speakers who addressed 150 men and women.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- President Roosevelt was assured today by Dr. Wei Tao-ming, the new Chinese Ambassador, that the Chinese Government and people would continue to do "their full part in this global struggle for the preservation of civilization, and when victory comes will gladly share in the heavy responsibility of fashioning a just and lasting peace."

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Persistent guerrilla warfare in Subcarpathian Ruthenia, so far hushed up by the Hungarian military authorities, is confirmed in an official statement by the Hungarian commissioner at Uzhorod, according to information reaching Czech circles in London.

The lead in per capita scrap metal collection was conceded to New York City's least populous Borough of Richmond last night shortly after Mayor La Guardia and other officials had met with 200 leading citizens at City Hall to map Manhattan's scrap metal campaign on Oct. 15.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 6 -- John Swan, 24-year-old Negro porter at the Opera House Theatre here, re-enacted for police today the slaying of Marian Oliver, 20, of 70 Louis Street in the loung of the movie in which he confessed battering her to death with his hands.

There is no reason why women's clothes cannot continue to be attractive, smart and comfortable even though the country is at war and materials will become increasingly difficult to obtain, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday at the premiere of "Fashions of the Times."

More than nineteen centuries have gone by since Judas Iscariot betrayed his Master. He has not been forgotten. More than a century and a half have passed since Benedict Arnold sold his country for place and pay. He has not been forgotten. More than two years have elapsed since Quisling betrayed Norway.

VICHY, France, Oct. 6 -- After numerous conferences dealing with recruiting of French labor for Germany, Pierre Laval, the Vichy Chief of Government, addressed a delegation of Breton Mayors today and urged them to help the government in the "present grave situation."

With bronco riding, steer wrestling and calf roping, the seventeenth annual World's Championship Rodeo will open tonight in in Madison Square Garden to run through Oct. 25, with matinees Saturdays and Sundays and Columbus Day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The inclusion of two consumer representatives on the Economic Stabilization Board, the anti-inflation agency set up last week-end, was urged upon President Roosevelt today by the American Association of University Women.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 7 (U.P.) -- A Russian Army rolling down the Don-Volga corridor to the relief of besieged Stalingrad advanced in two sectors again yesterday, killing 670 Germans and fighting its way to the outskirts of an inhabited locality, the Soviet High Command announced today.
BUFFALO, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The body of James F. Nuno, composer of Mexico's national anthem, was disinterred today from Forest Lawn Cemetery, where it has lain thirty-four years.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- City Attorney Francis E. Dorsey has announced that the City of Saratoga Springs will own the large United States Hotel here unless the United States Hotel Company pays its 1939 taxes, with accumulated interest and penalties, within thirty days.

Inception of the production known as "Fashions of the Times" dates back to the day the pavements of Paris echoed to the rumble of German tanks, the tread of German boots. For on that June day of 1940, when Paris surrendered, the domination of the fashion world which the French capital had exercised for centuries, ceased forthwith.

The demand for Park Avenue suites continued yesterday, according to reports from brokers. Frances R. Jaffin negotiated a lease for a seven-room furnished duplex in 829 Park Avenue to Professor Albert Hahn, a furnished apartment in 785 Park Avenue to Mrs. Walter Lowell through Clover, Hollyday Co. and an apartment in 969 Park Avenue to Mrs. H. Grubel through Bing Bing.
SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Bombers of General Douglas MacArthur's command smashed through savage Japanese opposition yesterday to pound Rabaul, New Britain, and Japanese ships at sea.

A short Paragraph in THE TIMES announces that five of seven Japanese candidates for public office were successful in Hawaiian primary elections, one of them winning outright his election to a county office, and another assured of election to the Territorial House of Representatives from Kauai Island.

OTTAWA, Oct. 6 (Canadian Press) -- Justice Minister Louis St. Laurent today announced the "conditional release" of Tim Buck, secretary of the Communist party in Canada, and sixteen other persons who surrendered to police a few days ago after having been sought since 1940.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The White Sox won the Chicago city series for the eighth straight time tonight when Johnny Humphries held the Cubs to five hits at Comiskey Park and the American Leaguers took a 4-to-1 victory, their fourth in six games.

LONDON, Wednesday, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The Germans have plundered the food stocks of occupied countries to such an extent that many which formerly exported food now are existing on a starvation diet, the Inter-Allied Information Committee declared today.
LONDON, Oct. 6 -- British military observers evince a reasoned optimism over the entire Russian strategical situation today that was absent from instructed opinion here a month ago.

Dr. Frank Kingdon, president of the Union for Democratic Action, announced yesterday that he would support the candidacy of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, and contended that President Roosevelt't recent endorsement of Mr. Bennett was a "clear call for all liberals and New Dealers to work for his election."
In a letter to THE TIMES Count Sforza reports the contents of three documents, which, as he says, reached him from Italy.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 6 -- Mehendranath N. Roy, a former terrorist and member of the Moscow Comintern, now head of India's Radical Democratic party, denied in an interview this morning that he was pro-British.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Soviet Premier Joseph Stalin's letter to an American newspaper man declaring a second front in the West the best way the Allies could aid Russia had its repercussions in the House of Commons this afternon. Prime Minister Churchill refused, how-even, to be lured into debate about whose move it was "at this period, which is certainly significant."

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Woman's Christian Temperance Union called today on the President and Congress "to prohibit, as an essential war measure, the manufacture, sale, transportation, importation and exportation of all alcoholic liquors for beverage purposes."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill amending the Hatch act to assure to teachers in schools and colleges the right to participate in political activities. The Senate first adopted the measure in June and will be required to act again because of minor amendments.

Lawyers Trust Company The Lawyers Trust Company reported as of Sept. 30 total deposits of $45,525,864 and total assets of $49,742,403, compared, respectively, with $43,525,507 and $47,748,307 on June 30. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $12,841,840, against $15,304,485; holdings of United States Government securities to $22,834,736, against $18,332,679, and loans and discounts to $8,628,663, against $8,588,201.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Trading in grain futures and in flour has been brought to a virtual standstill by the price-ceiling order issued on Monday by the Office of Price Administration and sent officials of the Board of Trade to Washington this afternoon in an effort to obtain immediate clarification of the order.

The Citizens Union endorsed thirteen candidates for the State Legislature from New York and Bronx Counties -- four for the Senate and nine for the Assembly -- in its nonpartisan recommendations made public yesterday. Seven were Republicans and six were Democrats.

Her service as an air raid warden led yesterday to the arraignment of a girl who described herself as Miss Judith Martin, 22 years old, a beauty shop worker, before Magistrate Harry G. Andrews in the Felony Court as a fugitive from Bethlehem, Pa., on a robbery charge

An item in the Oct. 1 issue of THE TIMES quotes an announcement by the Bureau of the Census that in 1940 the homicide rate of the United States was 6.2 per 100,000 population, as compared with 1.2 in 1900. This statement requires correction and elaboration.

Tea stocks on hand in the United States are sufficient to meet present restricted demands for fro msix to seven months, and the prospect for continuing additional imports from India and Ceylon are definitely good, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin Wood, managing director of the Tea Bureau.
First editions of "Fashions of the Times" went to press yesterday, to enthusiastic comment from capacity houses at both afternoon and evening performances.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- "This is a nation on wheels, and it must be kept on wheels." William M. Jeffers, rubber director, said tonight in a talk over the National Broadcasting Company. Any restrictions imposed on motorists should be regarded as a plan, he asserted, "whereby we can keep automobiles operating, rather than to restrict their use."

When N.Y.U. decided to give up football one of those hit hardest was little Johnny Williams. After seventeen years as trainer of Violet squads Williams suddenly was out of a job, a job at which he had spent half his lifetime. However, a man with Johnny's capabilities, who had helped doctor the arms of such baseball notables as Lefty Gomez. Tony Lazzeri and others, did not remain unemployed long.

LONDON, Wednesday, Oct. 7 (U.P.) -- Production Minister Oliver Lyttelton said today that the war "now is entering another phase" and that the Allies must redouble their efforts "to be ready for whatever the future may bring."

Captain Ivan Afanasieff, a merchant ship commander who was recently awarded the highest honor given by his country, the title of Hero of the Soviet Union, yesterday accepted from the producer, John Golden, a gift of $2,000 for the Russian War Relief Fund.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Men will not be withdrawn from the fighting services to return to their former occupation of mining coal, nor will there be rationing of fuel, the Government stated today in concluding the House of Commons debate on the coal shortage.

MOSCOW, Oct. 6 -- United States Ambassador William H. Standley saw Premier Joseph Stalin tonight before making final preparations to leave on a flight to Washington, where he will confer with President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull on closer military collaboration between the United States and the Soviet Union.

T.C. Davis, chairman of the executive committee of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, said yesterday that the company would ask the Federal court in St. Louis on Friday to authorize the payment by the company of $5,850,000 owed to banks in this city.

BOSTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- President Roosevelt said today in a letter to Senator Lodge that he shared the Senator's view that governmental control and direction of the problem of petroleum supply should be centralized in a single agency, but added that he did not think new legislation in this field was necessary at this time.

Every war front is of prime importance to those who are fighting on that front. To the Americans in the Solomons the Pacific is the main battleground, and the same is true of the Russians on the Volga, the Chinese in China, the British guarding the Channel, the Allied forces in Egypt.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 6 -- The majority of Americans are so well satisfied with the work of the Baruch committee, which investigated the rubber situation, that they believe this committee, or one like it, should be set to work studying other pressing national problems.

At least seventeen seamen were killed in a running gun battle between their ship and an Axis submarine, and twenty-three others who escaped in a lifeboat are missing and presumed dead, it was disclosed yesterday after the Navy had announced the loss of the vessel, a medium-sized merchantman of United States registry.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Public utility companies were advised today by Robert H. O'Brien, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to set their financial houses in order during the war by utilizing excess cash accumulating from depreciation accruals and other internal sources.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 6 -- Harry Eddington, former head of production at RKO, will return to the studio this month to produce one picture, it was announced today. The deal includes an option by which the studio may convert into a term contract after the one picture is completed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. George H. Brett of Menlo Park, Calif., until recently commander of Allied air forces in the Southwest Pacific and deputy commander under General Douglas MacArthur, received the Distinguished Flying Cross today for his "courage and tenacity of purpose" in frequent flights over hostile territory.

Day by day and meal by meal, cheddar or "store" cheese is climbing to the top of the list of important American foods. High in protein value, it is an excellent substitute for meat and its appreciable vitamin A content (night blindness preventive) makes it a satisfactory supplement to butter, now exceedingly expensive.

While reserving decision on the Securities and Exchange Commission's suit to restrain Samuel Okin, a stockholder, from further seeking to influence other stockholders of the Electric Bond and Share Company in the matter of proxies, Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum urged yesterday that the two parties to the suit seek some agreement.

Commissioner William H. Friedman of the New York City Tunnel Authority yesterday challenged Park Commissioner Robert Moses on several aspects of his argument for halting construction of the $80,000,000 Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel for the duration to save strategic metals.

An intensified drive to eliminate the "grotesque" tax on alcohol used in non-beverage products is understood to have been undertaken this week by commercial and industrial users. It was reported in the trade yesterday that various leaders in the flavoring extract and other industrial fields which use large quantities of alcohol will review their arguments with government agencies and legislative leaders.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 6 -- The Waves descended on Smith College today to begin training for commissions in the women's reserve of the United States Naval Reserve. The women were seriously purposed from the moment they stepped off the train, anxious to don their uniforms and become an integral part of our country's war effort.

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 6 -- Pleas for leniency for farmers in the matters of selective service and gasoline rationing were asked in resolutions adopted today at the closing session of the four-day National Catholic Rural Life Conference here.

Our British sisters may not possess the Hollywood brand of glamour, but they do have that rare commodity known as charm. There is, for example, Mrs. Miniver -- who so entranced the village station master with her spontaneous loveliness that he chose her name for his beautiful rose.
The committee chairmen who will lead the sixty-fourth annual United Hospital Fund campaign for $1,383,729, which begins Tuesday, were announced yesterday by William S. Paley, chairman of the drive.

With a first-degree murder indictment hanging over her, Mrs. Anna Harrington, who is being held without bail for the fatal shooting of her 23-year-old husband, Alman, will appear in Bronx Supreme Court Friday, according to her attorney, Kalman Sklar, to fight for custody of her four small children. Her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Mirra of 111-22 Wittoff Street, Queens Village, have applied to the court to take charge of the children.

Charging the General Electric Company, the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company and others with having reduced their prices on incandescent lamps in a move to drive independent lamp manufacturers out of business, eleven companies have filed a petition to intervene in the government's anti-trust suit against those manufacturers through the Jewel Incandescent Lamp Company, petitioner, in the District Court of the United States for the District of New Jersey.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 6 -- A six-day strike of workers in the Department of Public Works, which had crippled refuse collection, ended this afternoon after the National War Labor Board intervened for the first time in a labor dispute between a municipality and its employes, and assumed jurisdiction over the matter.

CHUNGKING, Oct. 6 (U.P.) -- A Chinese Government spokesman, commenting on Wendell L. Willkie's visit, said today that he had brought "tremendous inspiration to the people and army of China" and had strengthened "already close" Chinese-American bonds.

A well-rounded picture of what New York can offer in fashions for all was presented yesterday afternoon in THE NEW YORK TIMES'S production "Fashions of the Times." Every item selected was entered on the program because it had a definite fashion significance.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- A warning to gas appliance manufacturers to be prepared to meet post-war competition of an entirely new character was sounded today by John A. Robertshaw, following his re-election as chairman of the manufacturers' section of the American Gas Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- President Roosevelt held his press conference; his visitors included Senator Lucas, Roan Waring, National Commanader of the American Legion, the Greek Ambassador, the Chinese Ambassador and Secretary Ickes.

The increasing importance of women in the war production program was emphasized yesterday by A. Dexter Hinckley, director of the Engineering, Science and Management War Training classes at Columbia University, who reported that industries were offering employment to women even before they started their studies.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 6 -- The regimentation of Italian law under purely fascist principles along lines recently adopted by Reichsfuehrer Hitler, when he made the Ministry of Justice directly responsible to him personally, was heralded today in an article by Giovanni Giuriati, former party secretary, appearing in Premier Mussolini's newspaper Popolo d'Italia.

VICHY, France, Oct. 6 -- Antsirabe, the administrative capital of Madagascar, has fallen before the British drive, it was announced here today in a communique that tells also of the machine-gunning of the automobile in which the French Governor, General Armand Annet, was visiting the front.

The National Association of Angling and Casting Clubs is recommending a standard measurement for fly lines and leaders, which, one spokesman says, he hopes will become standard universally and thus end "the confusion that exists today."
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

License Commissioner Paul Moss said yesterday that he would not try to contest an injunction brought by The Morning Telegraph, 109-year-old newspaper that features racing information, to restrain interference with its sale, but said he would oppose the injunction as it applied to tipster sheets.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- The government seized the opportunity during a debate in the House of Lords today on punishment of war criminals to repudiate formally "Vansittartism," as the tenet that all Germans share their leaders' culability has come to be known.

TRENTON, Oct. 7 -- The question of whether the intangible assets of the Duke Power Company, a public utilities corporation, are taxable in New Jersey was argued here today before the State Supreme Court. The company is registered in New Jersey but operates only in the Carolinas.
As dazzling as the diamonds that form part of its opulence is the collection of old jewelry shown yesterday in the office of Mrs. Floyd B. Odlum, chairman of the board of Bonwit Teller.

Samuel Reshevsky defeated Isaac I. Kashdan after thirty-five moves last night in the first game of their match of fourteen to decide the United States chess championship. They tied for first place in the national tournament last April. The play-off series was opened at Fort Jay on Governors Island.

The rodeo thundered into Madison Square Garden last night for the seventeenth consecutive year. Cowboys hurtled through space and wrestled wild Brahma steers; there was swirling dust behind pounding hoofs; and, in keeping with the vogue of the day, the rodeo had undergone some streamlining.

Now that the freshman football player has come into his own in many of the colleges, it may not be amiss to repeat a story overheard on a recent trip. It's a timely little tale and proves, if nothing more, that anything can happen to a freshman, and what happened to the hero of this episode belongs under the heading of "It's a Shame!"

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Representative John E. Rankin of Mississippi today renewed his attack on Wendell L. Willkie, asserting in a brief speech on the House floor that "Mr. Marco Polo Willkie has already caused more embarrassment to the Allies than any man abroad."

LONDON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Authorized quarters here reported today that the ruthless German reprisals were touched off by a plot to sabotage the Trondheim naval base, nest of German raiders that prey on Allied convoys.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Donald Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, tonight said the American people were responding admirably to the current metal scrap and urged patience with local boards and collectors in getting the material to processing channels.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 7 -- The State League of Women Voters began its convention here today by issuing a broadside with the theme, "Use Your Ballots as Bullets." Winning the war and maintaining democracy afterward were emphasized as objectives for America.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Evidence that Channel Islanders are being rounded up and shipped off to Germany for forced labor was gathered by a British raiding party that went ashore on the tiny Island of Sark Saturday night and brought back a prisoner, it was revealed tonight in a communique issued by Lord Louis Mountbatten's Combined Operations Headquarters.

Clothiers here believe that business can be improved if store management will adopt smaller mark-ups. It was disclosed yesterday that one large store in the city enjoyed a successful sale of men's clothing recently by offering values which were about 7 per cent below its regular mark-up.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Cornell reviewed its passing game in a long dummy scrimmage against the freshmen tonight to prepare for Army. Georgie Armbruster connected often with various receivers on his passers. Running well after suffering a leg injury in mid-September was Sam Pierce, wingback, who alternated with Charley Robinson on the varsity.

Contributions totaling $23,016 toward the $200,000 sought by the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York for its 1943 activities were announced at a breakfast in the Hotel Pierre yesterday, opening the drive.

GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- A solemn warning that the people must carry on democracy at home, through the use of the ballot, lest the soldiers abroad and the world at large picture us as slipping away from democracy, was sounded today by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor.

American home furnishings pay tribute to the arts of Old China in an exhibit which opens today at Bloomingdale's, Fifty-ninth Street and Lexington Avenue. New fabric and furniture designs directly inspired from a collection of Chinese antiques, have been assembled side by side in a salute to our ally in the Pacific.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 7 -- While the Germans are applying all their nerve war methods to scare the Danes into submission by the threat of occupation, a Danish committee of nine is considering in Copenhagen the requests advanced by Germany.

LONDON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The subject of American Flying Fortresses came up in the House of Commons today when the Air Secretary, Sir Archibald Sinclair, in giving a clear indication of the great num ber of planes constantly being thrown at the Continent, announced the loss of 1,082 British bombers in the first nine months of this year in the European theatre.

I respectfully suggest that you refer to your own newspaper files for actual facts concerning the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel. Your editorial today is inaccurate and misleading. The Brooklyn- Battery Tunnel is by no means "Mr. Moses' cherished jewel."

VICHY, France, Oct. 7 (U.P.) -- Seventeen French civilians have been shot at Lille for carrying arms and for "bolshevist" activity, it was announced today as the Germans in Paris investigated the bombing of another pro-Axis French Popular party meeting in which one person was killed and thirty-eight injured.

Irregularity prevailed yesterday in the stock market, but the list was generally calm despite a sharp fall in gold issues. The Senate's rejection of a 50 per cent combined normal and surtax rate on corporations and the retention of the 40 per cent level helped to steady stocks in the late dealings.

A dinner dance under the patronage of Mrs. Vincent Astor was given last night in the new Maisonette of the St. Regis for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York. The fete served formally to open the rendezvous for the season.

Attack may be the best method of defense, but Earl Walsh, this year's head coach at Fordham, apparently believes that it must be well founded. Yesterday, on the Rose Hill campus, the quiet-spoken successor to Jimmy Crowley, now in the Navy, spent most of the Ram practice period on defense against North Carolina plays.

An examination of officials of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., as to the former financial dealings of the concern with the city of Rome, Italy, was asked yesterday in Supreme Court by Frederick Schneider of 551 Fifth Avenue in connection with a suit to recover $12,000 from Rome us the value of bonds of the city held by him.

HAVANA, Oct. 7 -- The Bureau of Investigation of Enemy Activities, which will operate in connection with the United States Federal Bureau of Investigation and the secret services of other Allied nations, was opened here today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 7 -- Flying despite cloudy and rainy weather, which for the first time in months has become a factor in the desert air battle, Royal Air Force planes staged a series of crippling raids yesterday against Axis air bases, motor transport and battle area installations.

Somebody with imagination had the naming of one of the Maritime Commission's new 10,500-ton freighters launched day before yesterday at South Portland, Me. It is called the Herman Melville. Five thousand miles from Herman Melville's particular sector in the Eastern South Seas many of Melville's countrymen are now active in the Solomon Islands.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Three hundred members of the First Port Security Regiment, United States Coast Guard, who completed a training tour at Camp Smith, here, today, were reviewed this afternoon by Rear Admiral Stanley V. Parker, district officer of the Coast Guard for New York City.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Senate defeated after a brief but spirited debate today a proposal to put a larger tax burden on corporations.

Three milliners who last Spring constituted the millinery fashion inspiration group contributed six hats to the "Fashion of the Times" production at the NEW YORK TIMES Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street. They were their top-flight designs for the mid-season.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's midnight communique:

The American Broadcasters Association, formed in opposition to the National Association of Broadcasters, will have its initial organizational meeting today at the Hotel Ambassador, it was announced yesterday by John Shepard 3d of Boston. Temporary officers and directors will be elected.
A hearty welcoming kiss was bestowed by Thomas E. Dewey yesterday on the cheek of Mrs. Mary Brooks Picken.

The Board of Transportation began last night the installation of the new "silver bowl" type of lamp in subway cars on the I.R.T. division a few hours after receiving a consignment of 14,000 of the new bulbs, which will replace those of the "black mask" type now in use as a result of Army dimout requirements.

Although registering another small gain yesterday, registration of voters in New York City continued to lag behind the figures for recent comparable years. At the closing of books last night, the total for the three days this year was 664,647, indicating the lightest vote since 1935.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- A group of Long Island business men today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to exclude the Long Island Railroad Company from its investigation into rates and fares within New York State.

If "Fashions of the Times" have been headline news, it is not only because styles, even in wartime, and perhaps especially in wartime, are a matter of wide public interest. Special causes, as Mayor La Guardia says, have given fashion a new and added momentum in this city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Two innovations will characterize a new money offering of $4,000,000,000 of 2 per cent bonds and 1 1/2 per cent notes announced tonight by the Treasury for tomorrow and Friday. The proportionate amount of bonds and notes to be issued will not be fixed in advance, but left for determination by the relative amount of subscriptions received.

A check for $12,500 was presented to General Manager Edward Johnson of the Metropolitan Opera Association yesterday afternoon as the Metropolitan Opera Guild's contribution toward the new production of Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor," which will be given this season.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 7 -- Fifteen more Norwegian men were shot tonight by German firing squads in Trondheim. This brings the known total to twenty-five victims in forty-eight hours in the new reign of terror instituted by the Germans in Norway.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The United States is planning to admit French refugee children whose parents have been sent back to Germany from France, Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, said today. This will be done within the limits of existing immigration legislation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Considerably fewer than half of the nation's non-agricultural workers come under the President's ban on double-time pay for Sunday work, the Labor Department said today after Secretary Perkins ruled that the order applied only to war industries.

In the shadow of gas tanks along the East River, nearly 600 boys and girls gathered yesterday on three square blocks of land they had cultivated during the Spring and Summer and celebrated Harvest Day.

Price-fixing by mills, stimulated by an announcement that the government would enter the open market again next week to negotiate another large purchasing order of better-grade cotton for lend-lease purposes, yesterday kept futures moderately above the previous close.

MOSCOW, Oct. 7 -- All day yesterday the Germans kept up a series of heavy blows, struck at short intervals, in the central sector of a factory district in Stalingrad, where on Sunday they had succeeded in making appreciable progress, only to be hurled out of their positions during the night in fighting of particular bloodiness. But, as on Monday, yesterday's fighting brought the Germans no success.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- In view of two recent public statements from abroad it is in order to review some of the causes of the complaint that was voiced in them.
