NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Five corporations and fourteen individuals pleaded innocent today to Federal indictments charging them with conspiracy in restraint of trade in plastics.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (U.P.) -- A.J. McAndless, president of the American Life Convention, predicted today that skilled workers will benefit most from a war-prompted adjustment of national income that will mean a virtual end to luxurious and extravagant living by those formerly wealthy.

Declaring that the chances are "distinctly good" for starting 1943 on a pay-as-you-go income tax basis, Beardsley Ruml, treasurer of R.H. Macy Co. and chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said yesterday at a luncheon of the Young Men's Board of Trade at the Commodore Hotel that he thought the popularity of such a plan was increasing from week to week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- August shipments of foodstuffs to the United Nations under lend-lease totaled 391,397,810 pounds, the Department of Agriculture announced today. By "shipment" the agency means delivery at docks in the United States and not actually delivered abroad. No figures on the amount which had been delivered overseas are available.

Despite some criticism of "meatless Fridays" 125 eating houses, members of the Restaurant Owners Guild, will not put meat dishes on their menus tomorrow. To this limited extent New York will have its first meatless day of this war.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- A stalemate has developed in the grain markets. Wheat and corn futures on the Board of Trade fluctuated today within a range of 3/4 cent a bushel, but the business was limited. Traders refused to expand their operations pending developments in regard to price control.
MOSCOW, Oct. 7 (AP) -- A Soviet information bureau communique:

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 7 (AP) -- E.K. Bryson's Joe Ray, winner of the Capital Handicap here last week, came back with blinding speed and accounted for first money in the Wye Mill Handicap, featuring today's program.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 7 -- Heavy contact work was the order on University Field today, as Head Coach Tad Wieman put his varsity through a stiff session on blocking and kicking. The Tigers have only two more practice sessions in which to mold a team capable of checking Navy's fiery squad in Yankee Stadium at New York Saturday.

Three books don't necessarily make a trend, but they might be the beginning of one. With one book on Washington, W.M. Kiplinger's, still high on the best seller lists, with David Lawrence's "Diary of a Washington Correspondent" just published and with Marquis Childs's "I Write From Washington" due next week from Harper there could grow up a correspondents' literature to rival the foreign correspondents' books.

Mrs. Charles C. Auchincloss and Mrs. Marshall Field are co-chairmen of the executive board of the Officers Service Committee, under whose auspices the first in a series of Sunday tea dances for officers of the United Nations will be held on Sunday afternoon in the Grill Room of the Plaza.

Max Levenson, 50 years old, an unemployed fur salesman who recently had been rejected for service in the merchant marine, ended his life last night by jumping from the roof of a penthouse on the 18-story apartment building at 101 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn.
LONDON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- A combined operations headquarters communique:

Wendell Willkie did a little in his statement to a press conference in Chungking yesterday to clear up the mystery surrounding his role in his present world tour. He has been commissioned, he said, to do certain things for President Roosevelt. In doing them he acts as the President's representative.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Dr. Melchoir Palyi, one-time economic adviser to the Reichsbank and the Deutsche Bank in Berlin, said today that September marked the turning point of the war in favor of the Allies and that the Allied victory would be achieved in "about a year."

Nearly 1,000 persons were disappointed yesterday in efforts to obtain seats for the second and closing day's run of "Fashions of the Times" at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street. Approximately 2,000 persons in all viewed the revue at its four matinee and evening showings, but it was impossible to accommodate the additional hundreds who telephoned or telegraphed last-minute requests for reservations.

OTTAWA, Oct. 7 -- Although the changes in the Canadian Cabinet announced last night affect only what are technically minor ministries, they have been welcomed because of the selection of Major Gen. L.R. LaFleche, Ernest Bertrand and Alphonse Fournier to represent Quebec Province in the government.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 7 -- The Philadelphia Company was accused today in United States District Court here by the city of Pittsburgh of blocking reorganization of the bankrupt Pittsburgh Railways Company, which has been in the hands of trustees four and a half years.

The hundred and first season of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra opened last night in Carnegie Hall, and under the best possible musical auspices. Arturo Toscanini, as guest leader, had returned to his rightful place at the conductor's stand.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS OF THE SECOND ARMY, Lebanon, Tenn., Oct. 7 -- In the process of educating this Army, from privates to general officers, one of the most significant manoeuvres held thus far will be launched here tomorrow.

Although retail shoe sales in this section of the country can only be called fair, manufacturers and buyers reported yesterday that September activity in out-of-town establishments showed a decided spurt over the previous month. Increases in business were placed as high as 37 per cent by some chain organizations whose figures will be released this week.

Borrowed for a day from their wartime role of serving the armed forces in their fight for victory, those miracles of the chemist's laboratory, known currently as "frozen fabrics," provided one of the most breath-taking episodes of "Fashions of the Times."

Two five-story apartment houses on a plot 106 by 147 feet at 850 and 854 East 175th Street, the Bronx, have been purchased by Henry Goelet, the operator, from the 850-4 East l75th Street Corporation for cash over mortgages amounting to $107,000.

Brooklyn's 1,400 miles of sidewalks were piled dangerously high with scrap metal last night. Danger to the enemies of this country lay in the barricades of bedsprings, baby carriages and other discarded household items, which, beginning at 7 A.M. today, will be loaded on city trucks and started on their journey to the war factories.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 7 -- An innocent looking dispatch filed through a Santiago company to Havana, reading "Kindest regards to mother and my little daughter," gave the Chilean police the missing clue to a vast Nazi spy ring operating in Latin-American countries, it was revealed today in connection with the arrest of three leaders of the local espionage organization.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 7 -- The projected remake of Victor Hugo's "Les Miserables," which has been on Twentieth Century-Fox's program for more than a year, was added to William Perlberg's production schedule today, and the studio named Mary Anderson, recruit from Broadway, to play Cosette with Laird Cregar as Javert.

Following is the text of the United States warning to the people of occupied France, which was broadcast by four international stations of the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company and by the British radio:
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 7 (AP) -- It was all over -- the season, the series and the shouting -- as the world champion Cardinals left for their homes today to join in the nation's war effort.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 7 -- Fighting mad at having been fined $1,000 for sending an agent to Georgia to recruit Negro laborers for his scrap business here, Samuel B. Freedman sent telegrams tonight to President Roosevelt, Donald Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, and New Jersey members of Congress charging that the South was "still fighting the Civil War."

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (U.P.) -- Coming restrictions in America's dining-out habits will make for a healthier nation, Sidney Hoedemaker of Los Angeles, president of the National Restaurant Association, said today.
A serious lag in the recruitment of workers for war jobs in Hawaii was attributed yesterday to a misunderstanding of the wages being offered and living costs and conditions at the Pacific base.
CAIRO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- A British headquarters communique:

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 7 (U.P.) -- Chinese leaders today hailed Wendell L. Willkie's call for an Allied world offensive and declared that his statement on the world situation compare with President Woodrow Wilson's Fourteen Points in thoroughness and sincerity.

Speaking in the Grand Ball Room of the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn, scene of the Democratic State Convention, Dean Alfange, American Labor party nominee for Governor, last night denounced those individuals and groups who sought to foment racial and religious predjudice as guilty of a special and venal kind of treason and a menace to national unity and the effort to prosecute a total war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Office of Price Administration, in establishing price ceilings for pork and other products in April, unwittingly gave the large packing companies a competitive advantage over the small ones, J.K. Galbraith, Deputy Administrator, said today before a Senate committee.

"Tales of Manhattan" today will begin the third week of its engagement at the Radio City Music Hall. . . . "Panama Hattie," the Metro musical at the Capitol, starts its second week today. . . . "The Pride of the Yankees" will enter its thirteenth week today at the Astor. . . .
Pushing preparations for its first major test of the season against Brown here Saturday, Columbia tested its offense thoroughly at Baker Field yesterday.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Clifford Sutter defeated Farnham Warriner, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 0, in the second round of the thirtieth annual Fall Tennis tourney of the Virginia Hot Springs Golf and Tennis Club which got under way today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Instructions which will guide Price Adjustment Boards in determining the circumstances under which advertising expenses may be figured as allowable costs in war contracts were made public today by WPB Chairman Donald M. Nelson.
Acknowledged as vital on the production front, the factory worker came into her own on the fashion front in "Fashions of the Times."

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- British fighters answered the only call for help sent from the Repulse and Prince of Wales when they were sunk by Japanese bombers off Malaya, a Royal Air Force commentator declared today in answer to Rear Admiral Thomas C. Hart's allegation in The Saturday Evening Post that fighters were "a half hour away" from the scene of battle and failed to aid the battlecruiser and battleship.

Precious stone jewelry from the estate of Miss J. Alice Maxwell, Rockville, Conn., and from other private sources was sold at auction yesterday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., for $45,482.

Faced with the possibility of more acute shortages than they had expected, retail liquor dealers this week started a purchasing spree and threw orders at wholesalers in such large quantities that the latter were forced to adopt rationing programs, reports yesterday indicated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- President Roosevelt is canvassing the field for a successor to the post left vacant by the resignation of James Francis Byrnes from the Supreme Court. When Mr. Byrnes resigned Saturday to become Director of Economic Stabilization, it said in some quarters that considerable time might elapse before a new associate justice was chosen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The government moved forward today on four fronts in the fight against inflation, including highly significant action designed to keep down the prices of meat, poultry, eggs and other dairy products.

CAIRO, Egypt, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Royal Air Force medium bombers raided iM[aleme airdrome, on Crete, last night, concentrating the attack on parked aircraft and leaving at least three planes burning, according to a British announcement tonight.

Cottesmore, aided by the hazards of the course, scored the easiest sort of victory yesterday at Belmont Park in the $17,450 Grand National Steeplechase Handicap, richest race of its kind in the country. The margin for the G.H. (Pete) Bostwick color-bearer was eight lengths at the end of three miles, after Mandingham had lost his rider and Elkridge and Invader had fallen.
SALEM, N.H., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Leading all the way, Blue Warrior, won the Eddie Hurley Memorial Stake, named for the former Boston newspaper man, at Rockingham Park today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Army Nurse Corps now has more than 16,000 members, it was disclosed for the first time today by Major Henry W. Longfellow of the Army Medical Department in testimony before the House Military Affairs Committee.

"Count Me In," a new musical comedy by Walter Kerr and Leo Brady, embellished with songs by Ann Ronell, will be presented this evening at the Barrymore by the Shuberts and Olsen and Johnson, in association with Richard W. Krakeur and W. Horace Schmidlapp.

The Federal rule that finders of rationing cards or stamps or booklets must turn them in to an official ration board within five days was cited for the first time here yesterday. It was made the basis of a charge against Bernardino Arias, 39-year-old filling station operator of Yonkers.

The General American Investors Company, Inc., reported yesterday that its net assets applicable to the preferred and common stock on Sept. 30 totaled $17,372,826, an increase of $1,592,641 for the first nine months of this year. They were equal to $263.22 a share of preferred stock.

Several luncheon parties were given yesterday in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. J. Henry Alexandre gave a luncheon there for Mrs. Lyttleton Fox, Mrs. James N. Hill, Mrs. Charles C. Auchincloss, Mrs. Duncan A. Holmes, Mrs. Charles Harding of Boston, Mrs. George F. Baker, Mrs. Alan L. Corey, Mrs. John C. Fremont, Mrs. Harold W. Brooks and Miss Dorothy Kane.

Randolph Paul, general counsel for the Treasury Department, told a dinner meeting of the New York chapter of the American Statistical Association at the Hotel Woodstock last night the reasons why he favors collection at the source of the net income tax and supports the spendings tax, but opposes the sales tax, the tax on increased income of individuals and the Ruml plan.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Prices of hogs advanced 15 to 20 cents a hundredweight today for the first time this week, topping at $15.50. The day's report of the livestock markets by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

Helmut Leiner, a 35-year-old German gardener who has been in the United States since 1929, was accused of treason by a Federal grand jury yesterday as a result of his dealings with Edward John Kerling, one of the eight Nazi saboteurs landed in this country last Summer by German submarines.

The large exhibition of paintings by seventeenth century Dutch masters will open with a private view at 4 o'clock this afternoon in the Duveen Galleries, 720 Fifth Avenue, and to the public tomorrow morning. It is being held under the patronage of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Her Royal Highness, Princess Juliana, and has been arranged as a joint benefit for the American Women's Voluntary Services and the Queen Wilhelmina Fund.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- President Roosevelt declared today that the United States would insist upon the successful close of the war that the "war criminals" who had been guilty of barbarism against the civilian populations in enemy occupied countries be surrendered to the United Nations for punishment.

R. Hoe Co., printing press manufacturers, reported yesterday for the quarter ended on June 30 a net profit of $204,585 after all charges including reserves and estimated normal Federal and excess profits taxes.

Fourteen debutantes appeared yesterday in District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office for questioning in the investigation Assistant District Attorney Herman T. Stichman, head of the Frauds Bureau, is conducting into the Park Avenue Canteen project for service men.

Frank Koch, 40 years old, dismissed member of the New York Fire Department, described by Charles N. Cohen, Assistant District Attorney of Brooklyn, as vital to the solution of the hold-up killing of Fireman Thomas Hitter in Brooklyn nearly four years ago, was held in $50,000 ball until Oct. 23 when arraigned yesterday afternoon in Queens County Court on a charge of having abandoned his wife, Florence, and their son, Frank, 15, in Queens.

Harry Collins of 558 Madison Avenue showed his Winter collection of custom-made clothes yesterday at a fashion luncheon in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Every style shown was keyed to the tempo of today, with simple lines, skillfully executed, to give an air of distinction.

EACH September twelve or fifteen mature journalists set their suitcases down in the Harvard Yard at Cambridge and prepare to spend a year loafing and inviting their souls. The Nieman Foundation provides them with enough money; Harvard gives them the run of lecture hall and library, class room and study. There is no formalism to the Nieman scheme, no rules, no "projects."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Apparent abandonment by the Japanese of the Aleutian islands of Attu and Agattu was reported by the Navy Department today. The enemy's withdrawal, it was added, seemed to have taken place several weeks ago.

Shortage of raw materials and failure of the Office of Price Administration to approve prices have brought about almost a complete collapse in the so-called Victory model program for the stove industry, the first of the concentration-of-industry plans adopted by WPB, it was learned here yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 7 -- The right of the National War Labor Board to intervene in a dispute involving municipal employes was challenged this evening by Joseph M. Byrne, Director of Public Works, here, when he notified the board of his refusal to submit to its assumption of jurisdiction over a labor controversy in his department.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 7 -- Transformation from civilian to military life has begun for 900 Waves on their first day at the Naval Training School at Smith College. The officer candidates were kept busy drilling, having medical examinations and receiving uniforms.

Those who follow development on the subject of silver must have been interested in the career of a recent item of news. It concerns "arrangements" which the Treasury is making to sell 5,000,000 ounces or its silver to industrial users. That isn't a large amount, contrasted with the 3,000,000,000 ounces or so locked up in the Government vaults and kept back from use in our industries by our silver laws.

On Sunday two million members of the Y.M.C.A. around the world celebrate the birthday of Sir George Williams, founder of the organization ninety-eight years ago. Founder's Day has a special significance for the Y.M.C.A. this year. The organization finds itself plunged deep in its fourth great war.

Edward White Hubbard, 49 years old, a resident of the Yale Club, who had formerly worked in various capacities in Wall Street, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by jumping from a sixth-floor window at the Pickwick Arms Hotel, 230 East Fifty-first Street, to a rear courtyard.

An encouraging response to a new wartime program for the detection of tuberculosis among the personnel of 400 nurseries and nursery schools in this city was reported yesterday by Dr. Leona Baumgartner, director of the bureau of child hygiene of the Department of Health.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Oct. 8 -- The Red Army continued its drive against the German left flank northwest of Stalingrad yesterday and held all positions inside the battle-scarred city against the huge mass of men and tanks the Germans have thrown into the battle, the Soviet midnight communique said today.

Net asset value of the capital stock of the Lehman Corporation on Sept. 30, last, valuing assets at market quotations, amounted to $26.92 a share on the 1,982,377 shares of stock outstanding, according to the report of Robert Lehman, president, isued for publication today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Charges that retailer-owned wholesale establishments have been discriminated against by the Office of Price Administration in establishing mark-ups which may be used in cases where retailers and wholesalers are "squeezed" by the March ceilings, were made by grocer-spokesmen here today.

We have stopped counting the days of Stalingrad's resistance to the most desperate assault of the war. We cannot count the dead. Premier Stalin has bluntly reminded us that the time for help is very short. The newspaper Pravda publishes a cartoon depicting a clock pointing to half past eleven and a calendar of the year 1942 showing that the month is October.

WITH UNITED STATES FORCES, in China, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Wendell L. Willkie traded information with officers and men at an American Army air base today after winding up his Chungking visit with a declaration that he was speaking for himself when he made statements such as his Moscow call for a second front.

There is certainly no debate among thoughtful men concerning the extraordinary heroism of the Russian resistance, its great importance to the cause of the United Nations, and the strategic advisability of the second front if and when it is possible.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Mrs. Walter A. Reynolds of Knollwood and her club-mate, Mrs. Ruth Young, took a three-stroke lead in the first round of the 36-hole best-ball tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association over the Apawamis Country Club course with a fine 42, 40 -- 82 today.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- After a quiet start the stock markets became more active, but profit-taking continued and prices as a consequence were held in check. Some sections of the market saw rises, the chief of these being the foreign rails, where there were many gains up to 10s.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Allied ground offensive through the Owen Stanley Mountains of New Guinea has been slowed by the difficulties of the terrain, a communique said today. The official war bulletin from Southwest Pacific headquarters explained the slackening pace of the ten-day advance with the comment:

TORONTO, Oct. 7 -- Many peace-time standards as to hours and conditions of labor will have to be suspended and labor's no-strike pledge, excellent as it is, will have to be bettered, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, told the convention of the American Federation of Labor today.

The Ballet Theatre offered a bang-up program at the Metropolitan Opera House last night with Antony Tudor's "Pillar of Fire," probably the most important ballet of the day, in its first presentation of the season, and Alicia Markova, certainly the greatest of classic ballerinas, in all the remaining ballets of the evening. More than this not even the greediest of balletomanes could ask.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- While the War Production Board will announce tomorrow the shutting down of gold production in the United States to make men and materials available for the production of metals more vitally needed for the war, the purchase of gold by the Treasury is not to be discontinued, it was learned today.

Characterizing the claim of the American Labor party to speak for organized labor as "nonsensical," Thomas Murtha, president of the Central Trades and Labor Council, A.F. of L., expressed belief yesterday that the majority of labor union members in the State would vote for Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor.
VICHY, France, Oct. 7 -- French railway schedules have been curtailed again to save fuel and to economize in the use of rolling stock, which is greatly in demand.

Many of us have turned in precious heirlooms for scrap -- treasured brass and copper, to say nothing of needed aluminum pots and metal lamps. May husband actually feels guilty because he withheld a piece of pipe we soon may be needing on the place, and which would be impossible for us to replace.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Osnabrueck, important railway center in the Ruhr and one of the most congested cities of Germany, with its 90,000 residents crammed into four square miles of streets, was raided heavily last night by a strong force of the Royal Air Force. Six British aircraft were lost.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 -- Lack of manpower in the Securities and Exchange Commission and the various corporations in the United States, resulting from the war, may force the commission to hold in abeyance a plan to institute new rules by Oct. 15 covering information to be contained in proxies for the annual meetings of corporations, which will start in large numbers after Jan. 1, it was learned today.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Reports reached London today that Nazi authorities in German-occupied Norway are in a constant state of nerves, their fears arising from a belief that United Nations forces may invade Norway any minute.

Thomas E. Dewey will leave tomorrow afternoon for a two-day trip through six counties in the northern part of the State. He will attend a dinner in Glens Falls tomorrow night and will go later to Schenectady.

Sixty-four Brewster Blasters -- a type of dive bomber which is being sent to the fighting fronts today -- could be built from scrap aluminum gathered in the last thirty days at the Long Island City plants of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation, C.A. Van Dusen, president and general manager, reported yesterday to the Metropolitan New York Salvage Committee.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Plans for the formation of the United Church of America on lines of the United Church of Canada were made public today by the Rev. Dr. Louis W. Goebel, president of the Evangelical and Reformed Churches of America.

Reports on the Eagles indicate that the Giants are in for a tough afternoon at the Polo Grounds on Sunday, when they start their home season. Coach Steve Owen did not sugar coat his warning to the players before yesterday's workout.

IT seems that shocking things were perpetrated on the gridiron while this observer and a few others were gazing at world series baseball. Williams beat Princeton for the first time in their football rivalry. Well, there has to be a first time for everything, but the Williams rooters should have sent at least a small word of warning.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 7 -- The last petunia of the season wanly persisted in a flower pot outside the $400 second-hand trailer of Harry and Leah Bradshaw of Taunton, Mass.

Complaints have been frequently voiced in the advertising field that the Federal Trade Commission issues cease and desist orders on advertising claims that have in many instances been abandoned a long time prior to the institution of action by the FTC.

AT SEA WITH THE PACIFIC FLEET, Sept. 19 (Delayed) -- The United States Marines on Guadalcanal, the big island of the Southern Solomons that was recaptured from the Japanese on Aug. 7, have been strongly reinforced.

ON THE FRENCH FRONTIER, Oct. 7 (U.P.) -- Official letters announcing that "you have been designated to work in Germany" have been sent to several hundred thousand unmarried male factory workers in occupied and unoccupied France.

Maxwell Anderson has restored to the theatre its self-respect. In "The Eve of St. Mark," which was put on at the Cort last evening, he has written a frank play about soldiers at war. Taking an American boy off an up-State farm, he has seen him through the pre-war training period and put him on a Philippine island to be expended.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Looking ahead to the transportation headaches baseball is bound to run into next year, Will Harridge, president of the American League, revealed today that the 1943 schedule would include only three long road trips, instead of four, for all clubs.

A cry of "murder" in an unoccupied sixth-floor apartment, followed by a woman's screams and a period of silence, led tenants at 34 East Fifty-first Street to the discovery yesterday of the body of Frank Trainor, 33-year-old employe of the building, in a rear court yard, and near by his wife Mary, 31, with injuries from which she died four hours later.

Steel production in the three months ended on Sept. 30 was 21,449,359 tons, the second highest for any quarterly period on record, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The previous high was in the second quarter of this year, when output was 21,531,358 tons.

At 3 A.M. yesterday William Fahey of 99 Metropolitan Oval, Parkchester, the Bronx, who was on his way to work in the navy yard, hadn't completely shaken sleep from his eyes. While he waited for a train on the IRT Westchester Square platform, he attempted to complete his nap.

Gasoline stocks throughout the country at the close of last week were 80,361,000 barrels, a decrease of 189,000 from the 80,550,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago gasoline supplies were 79,923,000 barrels.

Because of its experience in directing and financing widespread Jewish immigration, American Jewry will be charged with a large responsibility in connection with immigration on a much larger scale after the war, Dr. Jonah B. Wise of the Central Synagogue of America declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Harold Ickes, urging continued explorations for new oil fields to offset heavy military as well as civilian requirements, told a Senate Public Lands subcommittee today that the price ceilings on crude oil might have to be raised to encourage new wildcat drilling.

ALASKA DEFENSE COMMAND HEADQUARTERS, Oct. 6 (Delayed) (AP) -- American fighter pilots who never saw Japanese planes in the air before Sept. 1 have finished their first month of combat against the invaders with the remarkable average of twenty-two enemy planes downed for every American lost.

BOSTON, Oct. 7 -- Establishment of a central authority to administer the international transportation facilities of the countries of the world was suggested as a possible development of the post-war era by Wayne C. Taylor, Under-Secretary of Commerce, yesterday at the opening session of the twenty-ninth national foreign trade convention here.

An expedition by three New Jersey schoolboys bent on joining the Marines and exterminating Japanese in the South Pacific came to an unforeseen halt before dawn yesterday when Patrolman Roy Stewart intercepted their advance down Riverside Drive at 158th Street and convoyed them to the new park station near by.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 7 -- The convention of the United Mine Workers voted today to withdraw the miners organization, with a membership of 500,000, from the Congress of Industrial Organizations after the committee on officers' reports had recommended such action and John L. Lewis, president of the miners, had told the delegates that he could not continue to represent them unless the convention approved the recommendation of the committee.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 -- The telephone rang in George Munger's office at Franklin Field this morning. The young Penn football coach with the close-cropped hair and a boyish smile that never comes off lifted the receiver and the voice of Howie Odell came through.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The per capita amount of currency theoretically possessed by every man, woman and child in the United States on Sept. 30, last, was $102.04, compared with $98.32 on Aug. 31, the Treasury announced today.

Plans for mobilizing a huge army of New York City boys and girls under the age of 18 into wartime activities as "Junior Volunteers in Civilian Defense" were announced yesterday from the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office in the City Hall where, it was said, they had been worked out after months of conferences with the Board of Education and leading youth organizations.

An apartment building in the midtown section of Manhattan passed to new control yesterday with the sale by the Bankers Trust Company of the nine-story and penthouse suites at 40 West Fifty-fifth Street. It was acquired by an investor through the Charles F. Noyes Company.

Laughter was the only response of Gerhard Wilhelm Kunze and other German-American Bund leaders to a suggestion that the Bund owed a "patriotic duty" to the United States, a former member of that organization testified yesterday in Federal Court.
The strictly meat diet of the carnivorous animals at the Bronx Zoo will not be affected by a meat shortage -- at least not until horsemeat gets on the ration list.

Considerable confusion was aroused in public utility circles yesterday when it became known that the Senate Finance Committee, which is working on the 1942 tax bill, had inserted a restrictive clause in the tax proposal as applied to utility concerns.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Royal Air Force fighters "half an hour away" failed to go to the aid of the big British warships Repulse and Prince of Wales when they were attacked and sunk by Japanese airmen last December, Admiral Thomas C. Hart, former commander of Allied naval forces in the Western Pacific, asserted today.

Andre M. Embiricos notified the Greek War Relief Association yesterday that he would assign to it in behalf of his father, Maris Embiricos, all the profit from operation of the family's three ships in the last half of this year. The vessels are in the service of the British Ministry of War Transport.

Opening his campaign with a radio speech from station WABC, Solicitor General Henry Epstein, Democratic nominee for Attorney General, last night attacked Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, as a onetime isolationist who before Pearl Harbor assailed President Roosevelt as a war monger and future dictator and who now for reasons of political expediency had changed his face and form.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The War Production Board took its first step today in the steel-recovery program, involving the purchase and redistribution of millions of tons of iron and steel products, by mailing out the first 200,000 inventory certification forms to known and presumed holders of steel stocks made idle or excessive as the result of WPB orders and regulations.

The shadow of coming events seems clear in the Solomon Islands. Japanese willingness to risk a heavy cruiser and a squadron of destroyers to land a few more troops on Guadalcanal leaves no doubt that they intend to make another effort to recapture the airfield we took from them in August.
MOSCOW, Friday, Oct. 9 -- The Soviet midnight communique:

Brooklyn, long famed in song and story for its churches and baby carriages, tore up church railings yesterday and threw thousands of perambulator undercarriages along with a bewildering variety of other metal articles on its scrap piles to smash to a new record in the salvage drive sponsored by the city's newspapers.

A year ago this week the German High Command was announcing that "German troops, shoulder to shoulder with troops of allied countries, were pursuing the defeated enemy" and that "a new and vast series of battles of annihilation" had begun. This week they have spoken of "stubborn fighting," "difficult weather and terrain conditions," "stiff enemy resistance" and "inaccessible woody terrain and swamps."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- President Roosevelt personally presented to Edward F. Cheney of Yeadon, Pa., today the first Maritime Distinguished Service Medal and declared that it was "grand" that the nation now recognized that the valor of its sailors aboard merchant ships and tankers was as essential as valor on fighting ships.
VICHY, France, Oct. 8 -- In Paris today Chief of Government Pierre Laval assembled 250 employers and industrial directors and gave them his instructions on the sending of workers to Germany.

An all-American program was performed by the Henry Hadley Trio last night in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall for the benefit of the Publication Fund of the National Association of American Composers and Conductors. With this preliminary concert the association opened its tenth season.

If we hadn't seen it, we wouldn't believe it -- a stocking lotion that knits itself into a supple, porous film right on your leg! The company that makes this "weaving wonder" explains it in terms of tiny fibers of cellulose that swim in the fluid and form themselves into an elastic mesh as it dries.

With the volume of Federal contracts three times what it was a year ago, engineering construction awards for the current week total $139,855,000, an increase of 78 per cent over the corresponding week in 1941. The tripling by Federal work of the total for the 1941 week was responsible for a 98 per cent gain in public construction, according to The Engineering News-Record.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Extensive rewriting of the five-month-old law under which war contracts are renegotiated for the recapture of excessive profits was urged upon Congress today by a Senate finance subcommittee after receiving charges, through official channels, that, while it gave the government relief from a bad bargain, it was unfair to contractors upon whom responsibility is put for maximum and sustained production.
The eight-room house, assessed for $11,200, at 595 East Lincoln Avenue, Mount Vernon, N.Y., has been sold by Porter Waterman, managers, to Richard Roth Jr. through Harry D. Cole, broker.

A special train scheduled to leave today with 250 men en route to the West Coast, where they would embark for Hawaii, was canceled yesterday by Robert Merrimer, recruiting representative of the Army, as a result of the failure of men to respond to the call for war construction workers.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Oct. 7 (Delayed) -- When the Japanese landed at Gona on the north coast of New Guinea July 21 they brought with them a number of natives of New Britain, whom they used as guides and carriers. Information is now reaching here on how those natives fared.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- An effort to get the government to reopen negotiations with Mohandas K. Gandhi and All-India Congress leaders failed today when the House of Commons, by a vote of 360 to 17, rejected an attempt to block the second reading of a bill that would continue temporary arrangements for governing several provinces in India from which the All-India Congress withdrew its ministries in 1939.

" Attractive" and "glamorous" should be eliminated as essential qualifications for women seeking jobs during the war, according to Mrs. Thomas G. Evans, president of the New York City Branch of the American Association of University Women.
NEW DELHI, India, Friday, Oct. 9 (Reuter) -- A United States Army Air Forces communique issued by Brig. Gen. Clayton Bissell:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Secretary Perkins has sanctioned a 6 2-3 per cent hourly wage increase for the 40,000 employes of the Glenn L. Martin aircraft factory, Baltimore, to make up for losses resulting from the President's ban on Sunday double-time pay.

Word was received here yesterday of the death on June 13 of Mrs. Gibson Fahnestock in Manila, P.I., a few days after she had been released from the Japanese concentration camp at Santo Tomas, because of failing health.

The city of Bridgeport, Conn., announced yesterday that it would open sealed bids on Oct. 15 on $692,000 of refunding bonds, dated Oct. 15, 1942, and maturing serially from Oct. 15, 1944 to 1952. Bidders are to stipulate the rate of interest at not to exceed 2 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- A Navy communique:

A pleasant profusion of Fall fruits awaits you in the market stalls this week-end. There are red-cheeked apples to savor "as is" and greenings to convert into turnovers or tarts or pies. You will find pale golden-hued quinces for marmalade-making, great clusters of grapes of many sorts, table pears to enjoy with a bit of cheese and cooking pears to bake or stew.

Despite the fact that a halt to whisky production has been ordered, leading distilleries are continuing and in some instances expanding their advertising campaigns. Yesterday Fleischmann Distilling Corporation announced four different advertising campaigns in newspapers throughout the country.

Both houses of Congress have now approved individual normal and surtax rates which would take 19 cents out of the first taxable dollar of income. This means, for single individuals, as a practical matter, 19 cents out of the twelfth dollar of weekly pay. The House has passed an additional 5 per cent withholding tax and the Senate has before it a 5 per cent victory tax on gross income.

The collection of Anthony Blotta, well-known American designer, held the spotlight yesterday at the fashion luncheon in the Cotillion Room of the Hotel Pierre. His clothes are sold in important shops throughout the country as well as in New York City.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 8 -- In foreign circles here it is considered that the remark in the communique issued in France today, that Chief of Government Pierre Laval had given "his instructions" to employers, removes all doubt that force will be employed to assure French labor for German armament plants.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Prices of agricultural commodities increased slightly in wholesale markets last week just before the new anti-inflation bill became effective, and the Bureau of Labor Statistics comprehensive index of prices of commodities in primary markets again moved up 0.3 per cent, reaching 99.7 per cent of the 1926 average.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- Members of the National Association of Retail Druggists at the closing session of their convention here today authorized its officers to present to the Congressional Small Business Committee the war problems of the "very small retail stores" and went on record as favoring the regulation of inventories to prevent hoarding by the stores' bigger competitors and a ceiling on business rentals.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 8 -Freshman Tom Smith of Wyncote, Pa., today took over the right guard position from the veteran George Reubel, and Coach Howie Odell said it was likely that Smith would get the call against Pennsylvania here Saturday.

Registration in Greater New York was running yesterday about one-fourth lower than for a corresponding period during the last Gubernatorial campaign in 1938. The showing was a little spotty. Little Richmond led the city in its indifference. Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx were following, in that order but not far apart.
Twice in Wendell Willkie's war statement at Chungking you get the bewildered feeling of a time table in reverse. It happens frequently in statements here at home on the same subject.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Mrs. John F. Degener 3d and Mrs. Allison Choats of the Apawamis Country Club came from behind to win the 36-hole best-ball tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association when they added a par 75 to their first round 86 for 161, over their home course today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Navy carrier-based aircraft slipped into the Japanese-dominated northern area of the Solomon Islands last Monday and damaged or disrupted a sizable Japanese naval force, the Navy Department announced tonight.

Waxey Gordon, who was one of the first to discover the profitable nature of bootlegging in the prohibition era, turned up in Federal court yesterday on a charge of violating a law enacted since Gordon went to prison for breaking some of the old ones.

After watching Manhattan's squad go through its final home practice yesterday preparatory to the Jaspers' first real test of the year, against Georgetown at Washington tomorrow night, our advice to the Hoyas is to be on their toes from whistle to whistle.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Department store sales increased 2 per cent in the week ended Oct. 3 over the corresponding week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Sales for the latest four-week period also rose 2 per cent.
MOSCOW, Oct. 8 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:

Just before municipal bond men closed their desks for the day yesterday the financial news tickers brought the long-awaited word that the Senate had rejected the recommendations of its Finance Committee that the income on State and municipal securities be made subject to Federal taxation.

Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook upheld yesterday the title of the city to the unfinished Hudson Towers at West End Avenue and Seventy-second Street, the demolition of which to provide scrap for war aid has been suggested by Robert Moses, Park Commissioner.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 -- The American Utilities Service Corporation filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan providing for reorganization on an all-common-stock basis, or, if necessary, the organization of a new company, to comply with the "death sentence" clause of the Holding Company Act.

Calling upon the American people to become "rough" as well as "tough" if they want victory over "rough-tough" enemies, Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding the Eastern Defense Command and the First Army, said last night the United States must "strike ruthlessly" at the "real target" in a clear-cut program of offensive warfare.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Spring lines of corsets will be shown at a market week to be held beginning Jan. 11, 1943, according to announcement yesterday. Spring lines have usually been shown in December, heretofore, but it was felt that retailers, under present circumstances, will be better able to judge their inventory position in January.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Winning the National League pennant and the world series is all that saved the Cardinals' far-flung organization from heavy financial losses this year, President Sam Breadon said today.

Declaring that he could not provide Waldorf-Astoria service for 292 alien seamen detained at the Rikers Island penitentiary, Mayor La Guardia asked immigration officials yesterday to remove the seamen from the island by next Thursday at the latest.

The smile of a 16-year-old blond and crippled boy is stronger than the rigors of the law. Robert Ray, whose infectious smile and "educated" thumb helped him cover the distance from Shreveport, La., his home town, to New York, stood before Magistrate John D. Mason in Brooklyn Adolescents' Court yesterday charged with vagrancy, and earned a ride home -- in a train.

Your editorial on the poll tax made me bristle. You argue that the popular will of the people is being thwarted. Do you realize that the tax in Arkansas is only one dollar and only the very dregs of humanity cannot pay this small sum to vote? Certainly the pauper who cannot pay even a dollar would not vote intelligently.
A gentleman named Jerry Jerome was around the Columbia campus yesterday spreading official gloom on behalf of Coach Skip Stahley on the chances of the Brown eleven in tomorrow's game at Baker Field.

DENVER, Oct. 8 -- Robert S. Palmer, secretary of the Colorado Mining Association, declared today the War Production Board's gold mine shutdown order would release only 652 underground miners for work in copper mines, and not 20,000 men as WPB officials had first believed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -Chairman O'Mahoney of a Senate subcommittee studying means of encouraging explorations for new oil fields received today from a War Production Board official the recommendation that increased price levels be fixed for wells brought in since last Nov. 1.

AN ALASKAN BASE, Oct. 8 -Japanese camouflage shows up as pretty bad in recent pictures taken of Kiska Island by United States airmen, who are now in almost daily raids and are pushing their plane-a-day record hard.

After the war German culture will have to be "deprussianized" in order to be reborn, Dr. Alexander Loudon, Netherlands Ambassador to the United States, asserted yesterday afternoon in opening the exhibition of "Paintings by Great Dutch Masters of the Seventeenth Century" for the benefit of the Queen Wilhelmina Fund and the American Women's Voluntary Services at the Duveen Galleries, 720 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Disclosure that the Treasury Department is framing recommendations for enforcement of the President's salary-stabilization proposal, the appointment of Benjamin V. Cohen as chief counsel for the Office of Economic Stabilization, and granting by the War Labor Board of wage increases to employes of five concerns were among today's developments in the economic stabilization program.

ALBANY, Oct. 8 -- Factors working both for and against Democratic chances in rural up-State New York were apparent, even though the campaign is still young, during the three-day swing which Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, has just completed through G.O.P. territory up-State.

WITH THE PACIFIC FLEET, Sept. 27 (Delayed) -- Seven Army fliers, rescued from the South Pacific after drifting on a four-man raft for seven days, saw two other members of their B-17 bomber crew die of exposure.

A new kind of portable interior wall, which is made up and locked into place like a page of newspaper type, was announced today by the Owens-Illinois Glass Company. Neither nails nor fasteners are required, according to The Associated Press.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Stanley, the newcomer will be "In the Rear of the Enemy," a Soviet importation dealing with a Russian ski patrol trapped behind the enemy lines. The drama, which was produced in Moscow, has been equipped with English dialogue, which was recorded in London. . .

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date. Holdings of United States Government securities increased $24,681,000 during the week.

Marshal Goering's bland promise that Germans will be the last to starve is worth tons of Allied propaganda in occupied Europe. The current wave of terror in Northern Norway is partly due to sabotage in the fish canneries, whence the entire season's catch from the Bergen and Trondheim waters has been shipped to Germany.

The West, which seems to have had much the better of it this season in racing duels with the East, scored again yesterday at Belmont Park, where California's Miss Barbara fought things out so gamely near the end of the $5,000 Tambour Purse that she won by a length to return $9.30 and earn $3,250.

ALBANY, Oct. 8 -- In a five-totwo decision the Court of Appeals held this afternoon that Dr. Charles A. Muzzicato is to run only as a candidate for Representative at Largs on the Republican ticket and need not be a candidate for Senator in the Eighteenth district.

A modern shipyard built and operated by Germans at Barranquilla, Colombia, prior to the war will be put into operation by the Colombian Government to offset the Axis submarine threat if a projected shipbuilding program can be financed, Dr. Luis Carlos Baena, director of public works of the State of Atlantico, Colombia, disclosed yesterday at the Hotel Wellington in a press interview before his departure for home.
BOSTON, Oct. 8 -- Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, pledged tonight that Russia would receive "the fullest measure of every means of help."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 8 -Ten more Norwegians were sentenced to death today by the Trondheim court-martial presided over by the German Gestapo chief in Norway, Elite Guard Grupenfuehrer Wilhelm Rediess.

The Treasury's offering yesterday morning of a new issue of 2 per cent bonds due in ten years and callable after eight years, and one of 1 1/2 per cent notes due in four years and two months, was viewed by the financial community in general and by the banking fraternity in particular as a wartime task, although there was some outspoken criticism on the score that the terms might have been more generous.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Dr. Wei Tao-ming, the new Chinese Ambassador, called today for "still closer cooperation between China and the United States" in order to turn the tide in the Pacific.

WITH the Princeton-Navy football game coming up at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow, Neilson -- everybody calls him Net -- Poe, Princeton '97, settled himself back in a chair and began telling tales of old games and historical football relations between Princeton and Annapolis.

The two proposals made recently by Warner Brothers concerning the backing of Broadway shows by film companies will be considered at a three-cornered conference among the League of New York Theatres, the Dramatists Guild and representatives of the motion picture industry, it was announced yesterday by James F. Reilly, executive secretary of the league.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The country's newspapers won today a tribute from Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, for their "whole-hearted cooperation" in the work of spreading the truth about United States war aims and accomplishments.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 8 -The notion got about that the only football outfit in the country with an immunity to the war was the West Point cadet team, Army itself.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- The grain market declined again today on the Board of Trade. Scattered liquidation carried wheat and rye to new low levels in about a month. Corn and soy beans sold at their lowest prices since last December. Trading was not especially heavy, but the support was relatively slow for a time and some stop loss orders were uncovered on the way down.

Still further developing their theme of bundling launched two weeks ago at a press showing, Macy's dressed their models up in a variety of bundlers yesterday at their first public showing of the season, held in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel.

A SOUTH SEAS PORT, Sept. 14 (Delayed) -- Lieutenant, junior grade, R.B. Clark and his co-pilot, Ensign R.E. Dimmit, were tooling their big patrol bomber along, several hundred miles north of the Solomon Islands, Aug. 26, two days after the battle between United States and Japanese carriers.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8 -- Warning that time is not necessarily on the side of the United Nations, Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, said here tonight that the Axis powers had made enormous gains in strategic raw materials during the war and especially since Japan's entry into the conflict.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- The Germans had a look across the English Channel tonight when they swept two powerful searchlight beams over the water and lighted up the Kentish foreshore for a short distance. The searchlights seemed to be installed close together just south of Calais.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Miss Mary E. Wadley, former director of social service in Bellevue and Allied Hospitals of New York and founder of the first social service unit of its kind in this State, died last night at the age of 90.

Substantial buying by mills and persistent price-fixing by the trade coursed again yesterday through the cotton futures market, offsetting comparatively light hedge sales. Under this strong buying support, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange enlarged slight initial gains and closed 16 to 23 points, or 80 cents to $1.15 a bale, higher than on Wednesday.

Net sales of the Masonite Corporation for the fiscal year ended Aug. 31 amounted to $17,044,152, a new high record and an increase of $4,111,176 over the previous year's volume, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 8 -Universal today announced the purchase of "See My Lawyer," Broadway play of the 1939-40 season by Richard Maibaum and Harry Clork, as a vehicle for Bud Abbott and Lou Costello. "See My Lawyer" was produced in New York by George Abbott with Milton Berle and Paddy Hart as stars.

VICHY, France, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The United States Embassy made public today an incomplete and thus far unrevised list of American women, some with dual nationality and others only with American connections, who were reported assembled in Paris for internment at Vittel Mineral Springs Park and adjacent hotels by the Germans.

Aimed at stimulating greater purchases of war stamps and bonds by women, the War Savings staff of the Treasury Department held a special meeting yesterday in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, and outlined a six-point plan.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 8 -Teams from two of America's oldest colleges will meet in the Harvard Stadium Saturday when the William and Mary Indians from Williamsburg, Va., give battle to the Crimson.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -Cotton production prospects declined 210,000 bales in September due to unfavorable weather conditions and insect infestation, but even so a crop 28 per cent larger than a year ago was forecast today by the Department of Agriculture.

The Ballet Theatre last night paid its respects to the late Michel Fokine in a memorial program at the Metropolitan Opera House which served to introduce its new production of his "Petrushka," restaged shortly before his death, and to repeat its now well-known productions of his "Les Sylphides" and "Bluebeard."

PRINCETON, Oct. 8 -- Vice Admiral Adolphus Andrews, commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier, heads a list of five high-ranking naval officers who will watch Navy and Princeton play in New York, it was learned today.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Although there was an appreciable slackening in the volume of trading today the stock markets continued firm. The foreign railroad shares again were the main feature and many sharp rises were seen. The demand showed a shortage of stock for sale.

Arthur A. Ballantine, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, yesterday was elected president of the Greater New York Fund. Mr. Ballantine, a member of the executive committee of the fund, will succeed Thomas S. Lamont of J.P. Morgan Co., who resigned to enter the Army.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Oct. 8 -- The local scrap drive claimed its first victims here today when two small girls were burned seriously while investigating the contents of a large metal can they wanted to contribute to the community scrap pile.

A system of democratic cooperation in industry that began to function early this year as the Automotive Council for War Production reached full speed when a commission of British manufacturers arrived in Detroit. The visit put American inter-company exchange of techniques on an inter-Allied basis.

The Berlin radio declared last night that the German High Command had modified its plans to capture beleaguered Stalingrad by infantry and tank assault and had called upon its heaviest artillery to batter down the determined Russian defense of the Volga city.

Fordham's football players concluded heavy work for tomorrow's game with North Carolina at the Polo Grounds with a two-hour drill yesterday at Fordham Field. A light workout, consisting of punting and passing and a signal drill, will be held this afternoon.
A UNITED STATES OUTPOST, in the South Pacific, Sept. 12 (Delayed) -- Private First Class Eugene Oliver Moore of the Marine Corps is living on borrowed time.

Bank clearings of $7,341,582,000 reported by the principal cities of the country for the week ended on Wednesday were 7.5 per cent below the previous week's high level, but exceeded the $6,701,527,000 volume of the similar week in 1941 by 9.6 per cent, according to figures announced yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The five-story apartment house at 982 East 165th Street, Bronx, has been sold for cash subject to a first mortgage of $34,920. The seller was the 136 West 168th Street Realty Corporation and the broker was Hyman Leff. The building contains twenty apartments and eighty-five rooms and is assessed for $43,000.

R.H. Macy Co., Inc., yesterday reported for the twenty-six weeks ended on Aug. 1 a consolidated net income of $202,549 after all charges and taxes, equal to 12 cents each on the 1,656,067 common capital shares outstanding. For the similar period of 1941, the company had reported a net income of $167,682, or l0 cents a capital share.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The War Production Board today prohibited manufacturers of officers' uniforms, including shirts and pants as well as other articles of clothing, to use cloth which has been graded as "second" or which has been rejected by any government agency or department.

If "Count Me In" looks like a show it is not difficult to tell the reason why. Irene Sharaff has designed the costumes. For several years she has been imparting gaiety and electricity to musical shows by the use of design and color. But what she has done for the musical comedy that arrived at the Ethel Barrymore last evening deserves a prize.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct 8 -- A course of action to meet wartime needs was set for the League of Women Voters by speakers at the State convention here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- There has been no determination as yet of the size of the United States Army that will be necessary to win the war. Mr. McNutt, the Commissioner of Manpower, and Major Gen. Hershey, director of the Selective Service System, have suggested possible maximum figures that are millions apart.

In your paper of Oct. 6 is an item headed "Treasury to Sell Silver to Industry." The first paragraph then proceeds: "The Treasury is making arrangements to sell about 5,000,000 ounces of silver to industrial users, Representative McCormack, House majority leader, said today."

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 8 (AP) -- A Chinese Army spokesman reported today that Japan and the Japanese-sponsored Chinese regime at Nanking had signed a secret treaty whose provisions included a long-term lease for the Japanese on the island of Hainan.

The results of the Cape May (N.J.) County fishing contest have been announced and the majority of prizes have been won, as expected, by Philadelphia anglers. Director Percy H. Jackson, in charge of the competition, which ran from May 1 to Oct. 1, says that thousands of entries were received, with nineteen winners chosen for eleven species of fish designated by the contest board.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 3 were 907,607 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 9,893 cars or 1.1 per cent more than for the preceding week, 10,289 cars or 1.1 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 101,603 cars or 12.6 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

A total of 293,665 persons qualified as voters yesterday by registering in New York City for the November elections. Total registration so far this year is 958,312, about 80 per cent of the total registered in the similar four-day period of 1938, the last year in which a Governor was elected.

The veil of secrecy which has shrouded the activities of the Army's amphibious forces since their formation on May 28 was lifted yesterday with the disclosure by public relations officers of Camp Edwards, Mass., that thousands of amphibious troops and engineers based there had participated last week in the most extensive land and sea manoeuvres ever staged in this part of the country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- A Senate Agricultural subcommittee was warned in closed session today that if the United States were to hope for even a minimum sustained supply of crude rubber from Latin-American countries, existing agreements with their governments should be scrapped and renegotiated.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 -Four Marines left $500,000 in cash on the deck of the aircraft carrier Yorktown, sunk in the Battle of Midway last June, to aid sailors of the ship, officials said today.

BOSTON, Oct. 8 -- Extensive revision of governmental policy in the administration of wartime controls on export and the formation of trade committees to advise on current problems was announced today by Hector Lazo, assistant director of exports, Board of Economic Warfare.
The Board of Estimate refused yesterday to grant retirement on pension to Philip A. Hines, former first deputy city clerk, and Frederick Denkinger, former clerk in the Bronx office of the City Clerk.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 8 (Reuter) -- Prince Paul of Yugoslavia, who is in Kenya with the status of a political prisoner subject to surveillance, has arrived here after spending some months in Egypt.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- A large-scale drive to increase the country's supply of trained nurses through the recruitment of 20,000 student nurses to whom special scholarships may be made available was announced today by Mrs. John L. Whitehurst, president of the General Federation of Womens Clubs, herself a graduate nurse.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week recovered most of the drop reported in the week ended Sept. 26, according to the bureau of business research, University of Pittsburgh. Industrial production increased slightly, owing mainly to improved operations in the iron and steel industry.

MOSCOW, Oct. 8 -- In the ruins of a working-class district northwest of Stalingrad the opposing forces are still closely locked in a struggle as desperate and bloody as any fought in the built-up regions of the city. Houses, factories and workers' clubs have been ground to dust in the tense battles.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 8 (AP) -- A Navy Cross for his action against the enemy was presented to a young naval reserve flyer, Lieutenant Howard G. Benning of New York City, and letters of commendation for heroic acts and "cool and meticulous cooperation in action" were presented to two other officers and six enlisted men in ceremonies at the naval air station today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- American bombers operated by American crews carried out ninety bombing missions in a recent 110-day period of operations over Africa, the Mediterranean and adjacent combat regions, it became known today with the first official description of operations heretofore reported only piecemeal from Cairo.

Colonel Patrick Anthony Powers, U.S.A., retired, gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza. His guests included Sir George Bettesworth Piggott and Lady Piggott; Mr. and Mrs. James Cochrane, Lady Decies, Mr. and Mrs. A. Maurice Grill, Mrs. Leonard McKetterick, Mrs. Ralph W. Palmer, Sir Derwent Hall Caine, Baron Louis de Rothschild and John Vinton Dahlgren.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 8 (AP) -- With purses restored to $800, Rockingham Park went into the tenth day of its Fall meeting today and J.E. McGrath's Our Victory won the featured race of an all claiming card.

The corset industry plans no appeal against inclusion under Maximum Price Regulation No. 220, but at a conference to be held next Tuesday with local OPA officials will make several suggestions for changing the price procedural requirements as applied to new foundation garments, it was declared yesterday by Melvin Kleeblatt, counsel for the Corset and Brassiere Association of America.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- To emphasize the importance of piling Victory scrap piles high, the War Production Board, at the request of the National Scrap Metal Committee, released today the following statistics on how salvaged material can be sent to war:

OTTAWA, Oct. 8 -- Navy Minister Angus MacDonald announced tonight that a Canadian naval force of five warships cooperated with the United States force that effected the recent landing in the Aleutian Islands.

The sharp eyes of the war correspondents make the folks at home almost spectators of the events that they report. Yesterday Grant Parr, one of a number of correspondents permitted for the first time to accompany American bombers out for business, took the readers of this newspaper for a raid on Navarino Bay, famous for the naval battle that determined the independence of Greece in the Eighteen Twenties.
Don't throw household articles that are still usable into the crap metal collections.

A 19-year-old hero of two submarine attacks at sea, who won commendation from the Navy for singing songs and telling jokes to maintain high spirits in a lifeboat adrift for five days, was freed of a burglary charge in Brooklyn yesterday when authorities were moved by his modern seafaring odyssey and by the steadfastness of a 16-year-old girl who clutched two penciled romanitc notes that supported his innocence.

" Three Men on a Horse," the John Cecil Holm-George Abbott comedy that opened Jan. 30, 1935, at the Playhouse and ran for 835 performances, will be revived tonight by Alex Yokel at the Forrest with tickets for tonight's and all subsequent performances selling at a $1.65 top.

A speedy verdict of first-degree murder was returned yesterday in General Sessions against William Flynn, 23 years old, a meek-looking ex-convict, for the shooting of Claude Phelps, 65, a house painter, in the holdup of a bar on Park Avenue, near 122d Street, in the early morning of last Jan. 21.

The Brooklyn Museum opens today a loan exhibition of pre-Columbian ornaments, pottery and textiles from Peru. The material, installed in the Photography Gallery on the second floor, will remain on view through Nov. 12. All the objects in the collection were lent by Ernest Erickson.

LYNDHURST, N.J., Oct. 8 -The curiosity of Overseer of the Poor William J. Connelly over how a 64-year-old widow receiving relief funds from this township could care for sixteen dogs and nine cats and operate an automobile on A and B rationing stamps led tonight to the woman's departure from Lyndhurst at the request of the police and welfare authorities.

The speed-up in merchant shipbuilding for war cargoes has not affected the quality or efficiency of the vessels and "mothers can be assured that their sons who join the merchant marine will sail in good ships," Captain Giles C. Stedman, U.S.N.R., told a meeting of the Women's Organization for the American Merchant Marine in the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

After several months of comparative dullness, foreclosure actions in Manhattan rose in number and in dollar volume as compared with August, although they continued to be below the same month last year in the value of liens involved.

The expansion of facilities for vocational education now taking place in South America should result in a corresponding increase in the number of students seeking training in these subjects in the United States, Dr. German Arciniegas, former Minister of Education of Colombia, declared yesterday at the opening of a new counsel and guidance center of the Institute of International Education, 2 West Forty-fifth Street.
The Football Giants are approaching Sunday's home opening with the Eagles at the Polo Grounds with a far more realistic attitude than they had last week before their upset by Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Stephen Early, secretary to the President, made public today a letter to Mr. Roosevelt from thirty-three Boston newspaper men, endorsing the censorship of news of the President's recent transcontinental trip.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- National service legislation may be needed to control the country's labor force of 54,100,000 persons and its labor reserve of 30,000,000 potentially employable persons, according to Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, and Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of Near York, head of the United States branch of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, made public yesterday both his official appeal to Catholics throughout the country to support Mission Sunday on Oct. 18, and a cablegram from Pope Pius XII, invoking a blessing for those who heretofore have aided the missions with "most praiseworthy generosity and unflagging zeal."

When Private Theodore Furman learned that he and his company were to be sent overseas, he wrote a letter to Police Commissioner Valentine asking that police protection be provided for the drug store that his wife, Phyllis, and her widowed mother conducted at 63 Lorimer Street, in the Williamsburg district of Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The War Production Board today ordered gold mines to cease operations as early as possible to make manpower available for more essential mining.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Without a record vote the House passed and sent to the Senate today a supplemental war appropriation bill carrying a total of $6,236,956,621, of which 90 per cent is for the Navy. The largest item would provide for the construction of 14,611 more naval planes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The War Production Board, the armed services, the War Manpower Commission and other interested government agencies are at work on a joint "strategy of civilian production" which must be integrated with the strategical plan for actual fighting, Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman, said today.

Experience in the establishment of nucleus plants in Great Britain has shown that industry prefers the government to set up a concentration-of-production program rather than permit individual industries to prepare a voluntary scheme, Chaim Raphael of the British Information Service, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Sheraton.
LONDON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- A British Government statement on the German handcuffing of British prisoners taken at Dieppe:

UTICA, Oct. 8 (AP) -- James A. Farley, State Democratic chairman, reiterated today his belief that Thomas E. Dewey, Republican Gubernatorial candidate, will be "fortunate" to obtain an up-State plurality of 250,000 votes in the November election.
LONDON, Oct. 8 -- It was still uncertain tonight whether the Germans had carried out their threat to bind 2,500 British prisoners, mostly Canadians, captured at Dieppe.

A Federal Statutory Court reserved decision yesterday on a legal contest between the Federal Communications Commission, which is seeking to enforce extensive rules covering radio broadcasting, and the National Broadcasting Company and Columbia Broadcasting System, which have denied the commission's authority to regulate the business of broadcasting.

Apartment renting continued at a brisk pace yesterday with brokers reporting the leasing of numerous large suites. Among such was a fifteen-room apartment in 1060 Fifth Avenue leased to Donnelly Keresey, president of the Anaconda Wire and Cable Company, through William A. White Sons.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 8 -- The Convention of the United Mine Workers today ordered miners on strike in the anthracite region of Pennsylvania to return to work forthwith because their walkout was in violation of contract and instructed them to settle their grievances by negotiation.

At the request of the Writers War Board and its Lidice Lives Committee Edna St. Vincent Millay has written a long verse play entitled "The Murder of Lidice." The National Broadcasting Company plans to broadcast the play on Oct. 19 at 10:30 P.M. Frank Black is fitting the music to the script and Alexander Woollcott will introduce the program.

One of the prime objectives of the War Production Board is to assist smaller manufacturers and merchants to withstand the shock of the new war economy, H.M. Brundage, deputy regional director of WPB's priorities and materials, declared last night at a meeting of the local chapter of the National Institute of Credit at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Stimulated by encouraging war news, a fresh tinge of inflationary psychology and more lenient treatment of corporations by the framers of the tax bill, the stock market came yesterday within striking distance of the previous high levels of the year in trading that eclipsed that in any other session since the last day of 1941.

The nation's leadership, dropping all talk of "losing the war," should spread the psychology of victory -on the production line, on the battlefront and in the postwar economic struggle -- Eric A. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Union League Club at Park Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

The five-story building at 122 East Thirty-sixth Street, in the Murray Hill section, has been bought by Jacob Perlow through Jacob J. Luger, broker. It is on a lot 25 by 98.9 feet and was remodeled into two duplex apartments, one terrace apartment and one floor through.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- A coalition of Southern Democrats and Republicans adopted late today the amendment of Senator Burton of Ohio, bitterly opposed by the Administration, eliminating from the wartime tax bill a provision to tax the securities issues of States and local governments after Jan. 1.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 8 (U.P.) -Former Vice President Julio A. Roca died today. He was 69 years old. Dr. Roca had been ill with pneumonia for fifteen days.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Leasing by the Federal Government of the fourteen short-wave radio transmitters in this country for official broadcasting overseas for the duration of the war is expected to be completed next week, it was said today by Murray Brophy, chief of the Bureau of Communication facilities of the Office of War Information.
The British War Relief Society announced yesterday that preparations must be made now for a visit from Santa Claus to 100,000 war-stricken British children.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Thousands of partisans in Yugoslavia who have been opposing General Draja Mikhailovitch, the Yugoslav national military leader in guerrilla warfare against the Axis forces of occupation, have been killed by a spontaneous uprising of the people, according to reports received by the American Government.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 (AP) -The United Corporation disputed today the right of the Securities and Exchange Commission to order its dissolution under "death sentence" provisions of the Holding Company Act. Its counsel, Richard Joyce Smith, told the commission in an oral argument that dissolution was neither required nor authorized under Section 11 (B) (2) or the corporation simplification clause of the act.

LONDON, Oct. 8 (U.P.) -- Staff Sergeant Lafayette M. Shaw, 30 years old, of Greenville, S.C., was held by police today on charges of stabbing a woman in Leicester Square and wounding two constables who attempted to arrest him.

Excess reserves of the member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City, which had dropped to the lowest level in five years a week ago, recovered $370,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the weekly figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

A New York Stock Exchange membership sold yesterday at $25,000, which brought the price back to the high level for the year. A seat sold at this price in January and two at this price on the same day in June.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- President Roosevelt roared with laughter time after time today at a special performance of Irving Berlin's rollicking all-soldier show "This Is the Army," at the National Theatre.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 8 -- At the end of a Cabinet council held this evening under the chairmanship of President Ramon S. Castillo, it was announced that the Argentine Government henceforth would exercise strict supervision over all cable, wireless and telephone communications from Argentina to foreign countries in order "to prevent the transmission of news prejudicial to the national interests, particularly in matters related to national defense."

Optimistic reports on the growing strength of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, were received yesterday from two upState county chairmen, callers at the campaign headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore.

Our friends and allies, the Chinese people, celebrate today their counterpart of our own Fourth of July. This is the anniversary -- the thirty-first, it happens -- of the founding of the Chinese Republic.
