If precedent is guide, the famous "playing lion" will dance his way down Mott Street to the accompaniment of many drums.
Some confusion seems to exist with respect to the application of the President's order stabilizing wages and salaries, which apparently must await clarification by the War Labor Board.

James M. Landis, director of the Office of Civilian Defense, yesterday announced the organization of the Civil Air Patrol Cadets for young volunteer fliers. The group will parallel the Senior Civil Air Patrol, which has 60,000 members.

Staging a strong second-half comeback after being outplayed in the first half, the Horace Mann School for Boys football team opened its season yesterday by defeating Roosevelt High of Yonkers, 19 to 12, at Horace Mann Field.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Roger Touhy and Basil (The Owl) Banghart, members of a notorious gang of killers, kidnappers and bootleg operators, and three pals, all life-term prisoners, broke out of the "model" prison at Statesville, near Joliet, today in a spectacular daylight foray which resulted in the wounding of a guard.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Soviet midnight communique:

JAIPUR, India, Oct. 7 (Delayed) -- Away from New Delhi and other big cities, life becomes simpler in India, as this correspondent discovered on his first day here in the capital of one of the Rajputana States. The Congress party has made its mark, but not strongly, nor does it seem natural.

As a result of the generally poor response to the government's appeal for used typewriters needed by the Army and Navy, the Office of Price Administration may soon stop the rationing of used machines under seven years of age, thus forcing dealers and wholesalers to sell their entire stocks to the Treasury procurement department, it was learned yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia agreed yesterday to intervene in the strike of 165 employees of J.S. Bache Co., stockbrokers of 36 Wall Street, according to the American Federation of Office Employees, A.F. of L., and will confer with the employer's representatives at City Hall this morning at 9 o'clock.
MOSCOW, Oct. 9 -- British and American press reactions to Premier Joseph Stalin's replies to The Associated Press questions continued today to dominate the front pages of the central newspapers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The War Labor Board cited President Roosevelt's economic stabilization order for the first time today in rejecting a wage increase demand by a C.I.O. union.

DETROIT, Oct. 9 -- Protesting the lay-off of 400 workers who violated the plant's no-smoking rule, 2,000 Chrysler workers at the Jefferson Avenue plant walked out at 9 A.M. today, crippling the plant's production.

The mighty American frankfurter -- king of the sidelines at baseball and football games -- is one of the few meats not directly affected by our country-wide rationing. This favorite, along with other sausages, scrapple and other by-products, and tinned meats, is not included in the two-and-one-half pound allotment prescribed for civilian consumption.

Registration for this year's State election continued yesterday to lag behind the 1938 figures by about 20 per cent. A total of 335,709 voters qualified during the day, a slight increase over the previous day but 50,000 behind the same day of 1938, the last year in which a Governor was elected.

HESKETH PEARSON'S biography of Bernard Shaw, "G.B.S.: A Full Length Portrait,"* has been called "the most Boswellian biography since Boswell's 'Johnson.''' But it is more than Boswellian; it is also Shavian. Pearson has approached his subject with no reverence whatsoever, which is the way Shaw himself has approached everything and every one throughout a long lifetime.

This information concerning the origin of the mask for baseball catchers may be of interest to your readers. The mask was invented or developed by Fred Thayer, captain of Harvard's intercollegiate championship teams in 1876, 1877 and 1878.

The German High Command's communique yesterday failed to mention the Stalingrad front for the first time since the beginning of the battle there. Two days before the High Command ignored the situation inside Stalingrad, but reported on operations northwest of the city.
A few days before the Long Island Railroad stopped running race track specials, I went out to Belmont Park. I didn't do so badly, but my conscience bothered me.

Dean Alfange, American Labor party candidate for Governor, will "convince the people of this State of his sincerity and ability before the campaign is over." Mayor La Guardia predicted in a radio talk last night. The Mayor spoke under the sponsorship of the American Labor party over radio station WEAF.

It will be Whirlaway against Alsab again today, at Belmont Park, but at a longer distance, in a bigger field and with the long-tailed Calumet Farm star conceding weight to Mrs. Albert Sabath's 3-year-old. For the two miles and a quarter of the New York Handicap, expected to gross above $30,000, thirteen are named, with Whirlaway assigned 130 pounds.

Representatives of city and State hotel and restaurant associations have been invited by the Society of Restaurateurs to attend a meeting at the Crillon Restaurant, 277 Park Avenue, at 3 o'clock Monday afternoon, to discuss ways of reducing the consumption of meat by 21 per cent, Paul Henkel, president of the society, announced yesterday.

The Army will be asked to modify its dimout regulations so that salvage crews can work night and day in getting New York's victory piles of household scrap metal ready for the steel mills in the shortest possible time.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 9 -- Secretary Knox, visiting here for the first time since December, 1940, said today that Puerto Rican naval bases have been greatly improved. Mr. Knox arrived yesterday. He met reporters at noon in Rear Admiral John H. Hoover's office.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- Britain has moved to relinquish her long-established rights in China -- some of which have existed ninety-nine years -- as a gesture of gratitude for China's unwavering resistance to Japanese aggression and of realization of the importance of the Chinese Republic in the Second World War.

Every day more deeply impresses the lesson that none of the great problems raised by the war can be put in a water-tight compartment and solved in isolation. Each problem turns out to be simply one part of the over-all problem of total mobilization of the country for victory.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- A new alternative pricing method which wholesale and retail grocers may use on a selected list of items where March ceiling prices fixed under previous orders are working a hardship, was announced today by the Office of Price Administration.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses announced yesterday his resignation as director of the industrial scrap salvage drive in this city and gave lack of cooperation by Federal authorities as his reason.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The argument as to the relative flying and fighting ability of Japanese Zero fighter and American fighter planes will soon be tested by the expedient of having American fighter pilots fly a Zero and give personal reports.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Legislation to establish a Women's Reserve in the Coast Guard, the last of a series of bills authorizing the enlistment of women in the armed forces to relieve men for combat duty, was reported favorably today by the House Merchant Marine Committee.

Members of rifle and pistol clubs must record their fingerprints with the police, according to a new regulation made public yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine. In a letter to Mayor La Guardia explaining the ruling, the Commissioner intimated that it was issued as a step toward fuller investigation of persons authorized to use firearms ranges.

The War Production Board ordered yesterday a 10 per cent curtailment in paper production, including newsprint, to take effect immediately, according to reports in paper circles here. This was regarded as the first threat to continued publication of newspapers and magazines on their present scale.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Administration was rebuffed twice today by the Senate as it prepared to vote tomorrow on the greatest revenue bill in history, a measure which would increase taxes by some $8,000,000,000. At the same time, the "Victory tax" of 5 per cent on all annual incomes of $624 or more was adopted.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Oct. 10 -- Stalingrad's defenders were reported officially today to have smashed two German attempts to break through to the Volga River east of the city, but dispatches said a new threat had developed in a Nazi advance across the arid Kalmuck region toward Astrakhan and the Caspian Sea.

Asserting that "when the present conflict is over, we'll be able to reconstruct a world nearer our heart's desire," Captain Gill Robb Wilson, president of the National Aeronautic Association, said yesterday. "There must be a complete overhauling of our educational system and a complete overhauling of religious institutions" to achieve this end.

Another wave of scare buying in case goods among furniture retailers, which started quietly last week and has been gathering momentum ever since, has resulted in the withdrawal of most Southern lines as well as a few others, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Although surplus food is extinct in wartime, the Food Stamp Plan of the Agricultural Marketing Administration carries on. The plan is no longer a vehicle for saving surplus foods from waste but remains an efficient way of supplying food to the needy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Departures of "middle bracket executives" from the War Production Board have stepped up to a rate of thirty-five to fifty a week under Chairman Nelson's "get tough" policy, according to a WPB spokesman.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Oct. 10 -- Allied troops slashing through the Owen Stanley Mountains of New Guinea have made their first contact with the Japanese in twelve days in the area of the strategic gap that leads over the mountains, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Twenty-seven more industrial plants have been selected to receive the joint Army-Navy production award in recognition of outstanding performance on war contracts. Each of these firms will fly the Army-Navy production award pennant, and all employes of these companies will receive special "E" pins.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- The Germans' decision to withdraw their infantry and engineers from the bitter fighting in the streets of Stalin- grad and rely on artillery and dive- bombers to destroy the city, as announced in Berlin broadcasts yesterday, was regarded here today as an admission of the grave losses suffered by these arms and fear of Marshal Semyon Timoskenko's ability to develop his counter-at-tack on the German left flank from the north.

WITH THE UNITED STATES BOMBER COMMAND, in England, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The American-led raiders, directed by Major Gen. Carl A. Spaatz, commander of the United States Army Air Forces in the European theatre, smashed

LONDON, Saturday, Oct. 10 -- United States Flying Fortresses and Liberator bombers, assisted by an Allied fighter plane escort of more than 500 craft, carried out yesterday the biggest and most successful daylight raid of the war in this theatre -- a raid not approached since the Royal Air Force taught Goering that attacking Britain in the daytime was a costly operation.

ALBANY, Oct. 9. -- An organization of food and drug officials of the New England States, New York and New Jersey to provide protection for food and drugs in the event of enemy attacks was formed here this afternoon. H.C. Lythgoe, director of the division of food and drugs of the Massachusetts State Department of Health, was selected as chairman and Herbert Plank, of the Dairy and Food Commission of Connecticut as secretary.

The Senate is to be congratulated for the decisive vote of 75 to 9 by which it rejected Senator La Follette's proposal to raise the combined normal and surtax rate on corporations to 50 per cent, instead of the 40 per cent recommended by the Senate Finance Committee.

Dr. Ernest Eduard Loewenstein, who prior to the advent of the Nazis was a prominent jurist in Hamburg, Germany, and co-publisher of one of the largest newspapers in Austria, was killed yesterday morning by a truck as he was crossing Broadway at Sixty-sixth Street.

The order limiting the weight of steel in full-sized bedsprings to fifteen pounds after Dec. 1, issued by the War Production Board Thursday as an amendment to L-49, will have little effect on the production of coiled types, since most manufacturers withdrew them some time ago to conserve their wire for boxsprings, they said yesterday.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 9 -- If the present national scrap metal drive doesn't go hurtling over the top, it won't be because the nation's newspapers have failed to tell the people about it.

A blue air raid alert signal was flashed to control centers in New York City and near-by areas at 10:43 o'clock last night and canceled seven minutes later after an unidentified plane seen approaching from the sea was later identified as "friendly."

CINCINNATI, Oct. 9 -- Having previously withdrawn from the Congress of Industrial Organizations in response to the appeal of John L. Lewis, the convention of the United Mine Workers of America today empowered its president and executive board "to set in order" the only remaining district where strong opposition to the Lewis administration persists.

Supreme Court Justices Peter Schmuck and Bernard Botein were endorsed for election in the First Judicial District by the Citizens Union in its recommendations on candidates for judicial and county offices, made public yesterday. Justice Schmuck is running for reelection on the Democratic and Republican tickets.

VICHY, France, Oct. 9 -- The need of hastening the departure of workmen for Germany to obtain the release of war prisoners was impressed on the Cabinet today by Chief of Government Pierre Laval on his return from consultation with the German authorities in Paris.
MOSCOW, Oct. 9 (AP) -- A Soviet communique:

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 9 -- The four members of the election board of the Tenth District, Third Ward, were indicted today by the Atlantic County grand jury on charges of making a false count and report on the balloting for the Republican United States Senate nomination in the September primary and of officiating without having taken the oath of office.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Bucknell and Temple battled to a 7-7 deadlock before 18,000 fans tonight in Temple Stadium, marking the sixth stalemate in a football rivalry dating back to 1927.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- The Germans announced in a communique today that 107 British officers and 1,269 noncommissioned officers and men, all captured at Dieppe, had been placed in fetters at noon yesterday. If the British carry out their threat to manacle a like number of German captives at noon tomorrow, three times as many British prisoners will be manacled, the Germans declared.

While holiday offerings by the leading perfume and cosmetic houses will be as extensive this year as last, packages have been fundamentally changed as a result of material shortages, according to a review of the new lines by the National Association of Chain Drug Stores, issued yesterday.

ARMY vs. Cornell -- Most of the votes cast here last week might better have been thrown in the river in the dark of the moon. Chemical tests will be applied this time. After passing this Army-Cornell problem through an acid solution, one weak vote for Army.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 9 -- Frank Ross, RKO producer, announced today that "Free for All," a comedy by Robert Ardrey, will replace "Cheyenne" on his schedule and will go before the cameras on Nov. 21. Jean Arthur and John Wayne, who had been announced for the leads in "Cheyenne," will appear in "Free for All," according to the producer.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 9 -- The Japanese apparently tried to kill Wendell L. Willkie when he visited the Yellow River front yesterday. They bombed and machine- gunned a blue special coach of a train on the Lunghai railroad at Loyang, killing six persons.

Lieut. Col. Raymond P. Cook, Professor of Military Science and Tactics at City College, has been named to head the college's Reserve Officers Training Corps, which with 3,157 student cadets is the largest voluntary college unit in the nation, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 9 -- Warning against "the subtle danger" of Nazi propaganda that "the war must end in a stalemate, in some kind of a compromise," W.L. Mackenzie King, Prime Minister of Canada, told the American Federation of Labor convention today that "to attempt such a compromise would, in the end, be no less fatal to the future of the world" than the attempt at compromise which nearly destroyed the American Union.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- Through the efforts of Mrs. Charles Jones, British-born "housekeeper-at-large" here, waste fat, the ingredient that figures so largely in the manufacture of explosives, is supplying American service men all over the world with old-fashioned toilet soap.

The letter published in THE TIMES of Oct. 5 regarding unnecessary verbiage in leases is peculiarly timely because this is the season of the year in which most leases are signed. I think your correspondent is one of the very few persons who has read lease through.

John Shepard 3d of Boston, head of The Yankee Network, has been elected president of the newly-formed American Broadcasters Association, it was announced yesterday. Walter J. Datum of Milwaukee, president of FM Broadcasters, Inc., was named secretary and treasurer.

A.N. Groves of Syracuse was chosen as the new president of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards at an executive meeting of that organization yesterday in the Hotel Commodore. He will succeed George L. Long of Brooklyn.

Retail trade here showed sharp increases this week. Gains of some department stores here ranged up to 25 per cent or so over the corresponding week last year. The outstanding factor in the comparison was that it was made with fairly low sales figures of 1941 in the period immediately following the heavy "beat-the-tax" buying rush.

The book that John Steinbeck has been writing for the Army Air Forces is completed and should be along soon from Viking. After a tour of training camps and flying fields, the author has constructed the story of a bomber team. He calls it "Bombs Away."

DETROIT, Oct. 9 -- A warning has been issued to the women of Detroit that they should prepare themselves for the 70,000 jobs in war production work in local factories. William Dorn, field representative for the United States Employment Service, speaking at a city-wide conference conducted by the Y.W.C.A. and sponsored by thirty women's organizations, said:
Sales and leases involving buildings scattered over a wide area from Wooster Street to the Marble Hill section were reported yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 9 (U.P.) -- American bombers, ranging hundreds of miles over Burma, have successfully attacked Japanese barracks, an airport, bridges and railroads and a large river steamer, United States Army Air Force Headquarters announced today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- A Navy communique:

Sol Schortz's letter in THE TIMES last Saturday aroused my curiosity to such an extent that I looked up the story which appeared in THE TIMES concerning Commander Tom Hamilton's remarks on sports in the Navy pre-flight schools.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The Federal Crop Reporting Board said today that outstandingly heavy crop yields that have been in prospect for several months were now in sight but not yet "in the bag," warning that farmers were showing less assurance that the "tremendous job" of harvesting can be completed in season.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, Oct. 10 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Here is the roll-call by which the Senate adopted, 50 to 35, an amendment to the tax bill freezing social security payroll taxes for 1943 at their present levels of 1 per cent on employers and 1 per cent on employes:

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- Decrying "Roosevelt-hating" as the most primitive form of thinking, Dr. Ralph Barton Perry, Professor of Philosophy at Harvard University, urged Americans today to become world-minded citizens. Dr. Perry addressed the luncheon of the State League of Women Voters, with Mrs. Laurens H. Seeley presiding.

The subway circuit will have three major college football games today, the tastiest offering New York has had in the young season. Columbia and Brown, both unbeaten, will have it out at Baker Field at 2:30; Navy and Princeton will transplant their battle to the Yankee Stadium at 2:45 and Fordham and undefeated North Carolina will come to grips at the Polo Grounds at 2 P.M.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 9 -- Berlin tonight began to issue alibis for the German failure to capture Stalingrad. A German soldier-war correspondent, Franz Joachim Biebrach, writes from the Stalingrad front that the Germans would have taken the city long ago if the Volga River did not give the Russian artillery absolute protection as it shelled the German lines.
With the world series now red-letter history and the baseball fans satiated with the praises of the Cardinals' gang of Ty Cobbs, football pre-empts the sporting spotlight all to itself today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (U.P.) -- The Board of War Communications today established priority classifications for long-distance telephone calls, effective Nov. 1.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 9 (AP). -- Syracuse racked up its third straight football victory tonight, a 13-0 triumph over a dogged Western Reserve eleven which yielded two first-half touchdowns, then bottled up the veteran Orange backs during the final 30 minutes.

The Securities and Exchange Commission was rebuffed yesterday by Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum in its effort to prevent Samuel Okin, attorney and shareholder in the Electric Bond and Share Company, from attempting to dissuade other stockholders from giving their proxies to the management.

Directors of the Anchor Post Fence Company, meeting yesterday in Baltimore, declared dividends are payable on Nov. 1 to cent preferred and $27.50 a share on the $5 preferred stocks, covering the period from May 1, 1937, through Oct. 31, 1942.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Despairing of Federal action to realign the nation's manpower promptly enough to meet a serious labor supply problem in Minnesota dairy, livestock and mining areas, Governor Harold E. Stassen set up by executive order today an emergency program in that State designed to reduce by 20 per cent within ninety days the number of men working in non-essential industries and for government units.

WITH THE FIGHTING FRENCH SOMEWHERE IN EGYPT, Oct. 9 -- A 19-year-old American received official recognition as one of "the heroes of Bir Hacheim" at a ceremony held in a bleak stretch of the desert this morning.

In celebration of the 450th anniversary of the arrival of Columbus in the new world, the Knights of Columbus throughout the Archdiocese of New York will make Archbishop Francis J. Spellman a Fourth Degree knight at a dinner tomorrow evening in the Hotel Astor.
RAPID CITY, S.D., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Three men were killed and five suffered minor injuries early today when a Flying Fortress, four-motored bomber, crashed near the Rapid City Army air base.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- The sinking of the 4,290-ton anti-aircraft cruiser Coventry, which carried a normal complement of 400 officers and men, was announced by the Admiralty tonight. No details were given of when or where she was lost or of the number aboard.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The War Production Board today released more than 30,000,000 pounds of carpet wools, previously restricted, and gave permission to carpet mills to use the material in the manufacture of floor coverings.

For more than eighty years the Genocchio family has run a candy stand on New York Stock Exchange property. It has been a Wall Street institution, selling penny sweets to the runners, acting as unofficial police headquarters for the financial district.

Naturally no one living in New York would consider putting a bet on the ponies these days, so undoubtedly it was in an earnest effort to keep alive the sport of kings that Alex Yokel last night revived that great historical document on the subject, "Three Men on a Horse."
The present war has brought out that not alone are the streets of Hades paved with good intentions, but its walls are plastered with poor excuses.
The Avery Manufacturing Company, makers of canvas and leather products, has leased about 22,000 square feet of space in 200 Varick Street through Adams Co., Real Estate, Inc.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Probably dozens of letters on this same subject will stream into your office this week, but as a devout college gridiron fan, I cannot resist writing to tell you how fine it was to see such extensive football coverage as appeared in THE TIMES last Sunday.

George L. Fecke, 43-year-old promoter of the American War Heroes Foundation and the Park Avenue Canteen, both of which enlisted the support of some of the city's prominent men and women, was arrested yesterday and freed in $100 bail on a charge of soliciting funds for charitable purposes without a permit.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- Output of industrial electric furnaces, which are today playing a leading role in heat-treating thousands of different parts and sub-assemblies for war materials, was sixteen times greater during the first six months of 1942 than during any pre-war half-year, according to C.L. Ipsen, manager of electric heating sales for General Electric Company.

The John L. Elliot Institute of Human Relations, designed to broaden the opportunity of adults for democratic consideration of critical issues and judgment of problems created by the war, was launched formally at a dinner meeting last night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 9 -- Increased cooperation of shippers to help to meet the rising tide of traffic was urged today by Roy B. White, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, in an address before the Atlantic States Shippers advisory board.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The urgent demand for scrap iron has forced the Navy to reconsider its original decision to spare the historic battleship Oregon, James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary, announced today. Little doubt but that the ship which rounded South America on record speed in the Spanish-American War would be broken up was left by the Under-Secretary.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Oct. 9 -- The recent statement by Supply Minister John A. Beasley that attempts were now being made in Australia to develop rubber production drew attention today to successful experiments that have been carried out by the Department of Agriculture and Stock in Queensland on the obtaining of rubber from certain tropical plants.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 9 -- A terrific explosion destroying the Hermann Goering Werke-operated Fosdalen Iron Mines at Malm, in the North Troendelag district, is alleged to have been the immediate reason of the Trondheim state of emergency, according to official news received tonight from Norway.

Discovery of the chemical architecture of biotin, nature's most powerful vitamin and one of its most elusive substances, was announced last night at a meeting of the New York Section of the American Chemical Society at the Hotel Pennsylvania by Professor Vincent du Vigneaud, head of the Department of Biochemistry, Cornell University Medical College.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Plans to discontinue service of the Illinois Terminal Railroad in Central Illinois were suspended by the railroad today as Attorney General George F. Barrett obtained a temporary injunction attacking the War Production Board's action in requisitioning the branch line.

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange at the end of September was 548,365 shares of 409 issues, against 532,867 for 399 issues on Aug. 31, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Neither figure included short positions in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers, which were 30,972 at the end of September against 31,579 shares at the end of August.

LONDON, Saturday, Oct. 10 (U.P.) -- Major Vidkun Quisling, Nazi puppet Premier of Norway, was reported today to have told Reichsfuehrer Hitler that he would be unable to continue in office unless the excesses of the Gestapo torture and execution squads were checked immediately.

BOSTON, Oct. 9 -- By January the American shipbuilding industry will be producing four ships a day, despite the fact that the builders have already been told to expect the withdrawal of workers subject to military service, Rear Admiral Howard L. Vickery, vice chairman of the Maritime Commission, announced today.

Labor shortages in woolen and worsted mills stands as the principal threat to civilian supplies in the latter months of 1943, several manufacturers said yesterday. Unless the government does something to control the shifting of employes, maintenance of mills at their present efficient level will be seriously impaired, some manufacturers declared.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Oct. 3 were 241,179,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the preceding week, this represents a decrease of 1,606,000 barrels, comprising decreases of 1,530,000 and 76,000 barrels in domestic and foreign crude, respectively.
BOSTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say of the Boston wool market tomorrow:

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Oct. 7 (Delayed) -- A character from Kipling dropped in at this New Guinea base today. He is Sergeant Katue of the Papuan forces and he has killed twenty-six Japanese. Tonight he is on his way back to the jungles and mountains to kill some more.

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the first eight months of this year, issued yesterday by A.N. Williams, president, shows a net income, after expenses and charges, of $5,227,429. This was equal to $5 a share on the company's 1,045,277 capital shares and compares with $4,744,892, or $4.54 a share, in the eight months to Aug. 31, 1941.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 9 -- A big clean-up took place in Berlin three weeks ago in which more than 1,000 persons, including many women, were arrested on charges of grumbling or spreading doubts on ultimate German victory, according to news received here today from trustworthy persons through private channels.

The garish pinball machine that used to take $20,000,000 a year in nickels from gullible New Yorkers is now serving higher education as a source of supply of vital electrical and mechanical equipment that is unobtainable because of priorities, it became known yesterday.

Firmly resisting any attempt to dislodge it from its gains, the stock market broke yesterday into new high ground for the recovery in the second successive million-share session. After carrying through the bullish enthusiasm of Thursday into the opening hour, the list then settled down to digest and protect its additions.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society announced yesterday that following the recent emergency meeting of its Young People's Concerts Committee it had decided to cancel its Town Hall series of concerts for younger children this season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- An order calling for 10 per cent curtailment in production of all types of paper has been prepared by the War Production Board, but a last-minute hitch of undisclosed nature has held up its appearance, a WPB spokesman said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Ethiopia assumed the obligations of the United Nations pact through an exchange of messages between President Roosevelt and Emperor Haile Selassie. They were made public today.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The United States and Britain will undertake forthwith negotiations with China for the relinquishment of extraterritorial and related rights and privileges in that country, it was announced by the State Department tonight on the eve of the thirty-first Chinese national anniversary.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- President Roosevelt made it clear today that his abandonment of the St. Lawrence seaway and power project was purely temporary, because of war-produced steel and manpower shortages. He expressed confidence that the project will be completed to provide a water route from the Atlantic to the Great Lakes after the United Nations win the war.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS OF THE SECOND ARMY, LEBANON, Tenn., Oct. 9 -- Major Gen. William H. Simpson, commander of the XII Corps, now commanding the Blue force in the mid-Tennessee maneuvres has demonstrated that the more terrific the "blitz," the more carefully it must be prepared.

Two blond "glamour girl" burglars, who apparently have invaded another field of male activities in wartime, were at large in Staten Island last night as detectives were confronted with the fifth robbery this week believed to have been committed by two pretty young girls wearing green slacks and brown coats, hatless and with waving blond tresses.

All securities and commodity markets in the United States will be closed on Monday in observance of Columbus Day. Various livestock markets, however, will remain open. The banks in thirty-five States, including New York, will be closed.

William Bristol, 35 years old, of 354 Avenue Q, Brooklyn, yesterday obtained a summons against "John Doe" of the Trainers Turf Service, Suite 1100, 307 Fifth Avenue, on whose advice he said he had lost $35 trying to pick a horse-race winner.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, asserted here tonight that the elections held throughout the country this year would serve notice on the dictators that democracy was functioning full force in this country and would, at the same time, serve to bolster the courage of liberty-loving peoples throughout the world.

The Germans are no nearer their goal on the political than on the military front. All eyes are glued on the epic tug-of-war on the Volga and in the grim passes of the Caucasus for the reason that this action is the climax of the most decisive campaign that has yet been waged.

The assignment of conscientious objectors to work in hospitals, where the war has caused a serious shortage of nonprofessional employees, is being tried out in this and several other cities, it was revealed yesterday by Selective Service officials here.
Duck hunters will be allowed to use outboard motor boats in going to and from duck blinds on New Jersey tidal waters, according to an announcement yesterday by the State's Fish and Game Commission.

Attorney General Francis Biddle will appear as guest speaker at the free concert to be presented Monday at 8 P.M. in Carnegie Hall by Local 802 of the Musicians Union and the Philharmonic-Symphony Society in celebration of Columbus Day.

James A. Farley, Democratic State Chairman, returned yesterday from a trip up-State, confirmed in his belief that the strength of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., Democratic nominee for Governor, was growing and that the up-State plurality for Thomas E. Dewey, Republican candidate, would be hundreds of thousands less than the 616,000 he received there four years ago.

In your analytical editorial of Oct. 7, "Wartime Taxes," you state that the objective of a wartime tax bill is not primarily to pay for the war; that the primary purpose must be to minimize the danger of inflation.

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 9 -- Former Governor Alfred M. Landon of Kansas, who was the Republican Presidential candidate in 1936, called tonight for the election of Republicans in next month's Congressional and State elections in order to speed up the governmental machinery and get increased efficiency in the conduct of the war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- President Roosevelt said today that he assumed that Wendell L. Willkie, 1940 Republican Presidential nom inee, was carrying out extremely well the assignments which the President gave him when he left for the Middle East, Russia and China, as the President's personal representative on a war survey.
LONDON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- A communique from United States Army Headquarters:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The bleak and remote base on Kiska, the Aleutian island occupied by the Japanese in June, is feeling an increasing weight of American attack, against which the Japanese seem unable to offer an effective defense, it was indicated by a Navy communique issued today.

Thirteen new rentals in 205 East Eighty-second Street were reported yesterday by the Cruikshank Company as follows: Judith Brown, Katherine Osann, Frances Belverd, Elizabeth Burns, Ethel Volk, Menna Hoemann, Lawrence Lustig, Hugh F. Fitzgerald, William Sardell, Edward Manus, Peter Franzese, Jacob Calo and Charles Callahan.

In a world at war, at least one small oasis was devoted wholly to a peaceful pursuit yesterday as the semi-annual Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibition opened under the auspices of the Washington Square Association.

The president of the National Restaurant Association looks into the future and sees nothing but good resulting from simpler and shorter war meals. We agree with him on nine points in his ten-point program. The nation can get on very well with one meatless day or even two meatless days.

The Ballet Theatre and its new guest choreographer, Leonide Massine, do not seem to have got into their stride together as yet. The second result of their association was revealed last night at the Metropolitan Opera House in the form of a Mexican ballet, "Don Domingo," and the report this morning is unfortunately not a happy one.
The quarterly list of books recommended for members of the Roman Catholic Church by the Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee was released yesterday.

From lands now silent, Scandinavian design has found a new voice in furniture of American origin. A modern living room at Georg Jensen, Fifty-third Street and Fifth Avenue, marks the debut of several novel furniture pieces created by a former citizen of Denmark.

Net profit reported yesterday in the annual statement of the Royal Typewriter Company, Inc., and its domestic subsidiary amounted to $2,474,589 after Federal income and excess profits taxes, for the fiscal year ended on July 31, 1942.
LONDON, Oct. 9 -- Continued firmness was seen in today's stock markets, although prices were irregular on profit-taking, which was not fully covered by new buying.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 9 -- The Argentine Government late tonight instructed its Ambassador in Washington to protest against references to Argentina made by Acting Secretary of State Sumner Welles in a speech he delivered yesterday.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Notre Dame and Stanford, both geared to the T formation, clash tomorrow, each seeking its first victory of the season, but Frank Leahy, the Fighting Irish head coach, will not be present.

An ever so jolly small exhibition is scheduled to open, likewise thim afternoon, at the Metropolitan Museum. It consists of selected examples from the invaluable series produced by the WPA_'s Index of American Design -- this time watercolors illustrating interiors (typical though frequently composite) such as flourished between the "Elegant Eighties" and the year 1910.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 -- Counsel for the United Gas Improvement Company told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that the only interest held by the company in the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey "is its holding of stock in that corporation as an entiety."

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 9 -- A German officer who has taken part in the siege of Stalingrad from the beginning supplied the German press today with details of the Russian defense. At no time since the Germans began their attack, says this witness, have the Russians abandoned their tactics of launching counter-attacks.

Douglas Ford of Hummocks and his partner, Ted Scholes of the home club, tied J.F. Foley and Pat Callen of Lakeville for qualifying honors in the member-guest golf tournament of the North Hills Club in Douglaston, L.I., yesterday. The teams turned in identical scores of 32, 38 -- 70, one under par.

MOSCOW, Oct. 9 -- A critical situation developed in Stalingrad late yesterday when, after a series of violent attacks, the first by fifty tanks and mechanized infantry under cover of forty planes, gained ground in a factory region, which has become the fulcrum of fighting in attempts to break through to the Volga and divide the Russian armies.

In what was believed to be the smallest market in recent weeks, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday felt the impact of late hedge sales and closed at the day's low levels, 11 to 16 points under Thursday's final quotations.

OTTAWA, Oct. 9 -- The Canadian Government has informed the Swiss Consul General, in charge of German interests, that if the order for the fettering of Canadian prisoners of war in Germany is not rescinded by noon tomorrow, an equal number of German officers and men who are prisoners in Canada will be put in chains.

Count Casimir Pulaski died on Oct. 11, 1779. Two days before, galloping at the head of his two hundred horse, trying to force his way into Savannah, a grapeshot struck him in the loin. He was taken on board a ship of war. The surgeons couldn't find the bullet and he died.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 9 -- Foreign Minister Ernesto Barros Jarpa announced that a complaint had been made today to President Roosevelt, through the Chilean Embassy in Washington, regarding Acting Secretary of State Sumner Welles's statement in a speech last night that messages sent by secret Nazi radio stations in Chile were responsible for the sinking of ships abroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Having failed to knock out Russia by force, the Nazis are making renewed and furious efforts to turn her against the democracies by propaganda. To this end Axis broadcasters seek to exploit all the suspicion in Russia against the Western powers and all the dislike of communism that exists in conservative circles in Western Europe and the United States, according to recordings officially summarized here today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 9 -- Foreign Minister Ernesto Barros Jarpa announced that a complaint had been made today to President Roosevelt, through the Chilean Embassy in Washington, regarding Acting Secretary of State Sumner Welles's statement in a speech last night that messages sent by secret Nazi radio stations in Chile were responsible for the sinking of ships abroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Having failed to knock out Russia by force, the Nazis are making renewed and furious efforts to turn her against the democracies by propaganda. To this end Axis broadcasters seek to exploit all the suspicion in Russia against the Western powers and all the dislike of communism that exists in conservative circles in Western Europe and the United States, according to recordings officially summarized here today.

The opening session of a three-day Institute of Inter-American Affairs, commemorating the 450th anniversary of Columbus's discovery of America, will be held today, beginning at 10:15 A.M., in McMillin Academic Theatre, Columbia University.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Clifford Sutter of Greenwich, Conn., former Davis Cup star, won the men's singles final of the Hot Springs Fall tennis tournament today by defeating August Ganzenmuller of New York, 6 -- 4, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4.

William Merna, 40 years old, a bus driver of 2136 Amsterdam Avenue, tried in vain last night to end his troubles by killing himself and five of his six children. All were near death of gas fumes when they were discovered by neighbors.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The worker in the shipyard is performing a service just as valuable as that of the soldier in the front line, Lord Halifax, British Ambassador, declared today at the launching of two war craft at the Dravo Corporation yards.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Oct. 9 (Delayed) -- Great damage to the big Japanese base at Rabaul, New Britain, was reported by Allied fliers returning today from the record raid of the war in this region. Fires were visible for many miles after sixty tons of demolition and incendiary bombs rained on the Japanese stronghold.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- Port Chester High handed New Rochelle its second straight Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association football defeat today, 21 to 0.

RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Coming from behind in the second half with a surge of power, Coach Jim Crowley's North Carolina Navy pre-flight team downed a stubborn N.C. State Wolfpack, 19 -- 7, tonight before 10,000 thrilled fans.

Mayor La Guardia informed the Allied Printing Trades Council yesterday that he intended to wage a finish fight to ban all racing tip sheets from licensed newsstands, despite the labor organization's recent resolution condemning his course as an illegal and arbitrary attempt to hamper a free press.
ALTON, Ill., Oct. 10 (AP) -- The A.F.L. Molders Union established a picket line at the Western Cartridge Company late today, virtually halting production at the war plant.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Nazis, who for several days have been hinting broadly that there would be no second front and therefore Russia might as well come to terms with Adolf Hitler, have now made through Rumania and Hungary a direct appeal to the Russians to make a separate peace.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 9 -- Scandinavia did not have to wait long for an illustration of what was in Reichsfuehrer Hitler's mind when he proclaimed in his Sport-palast speech that in the "new Europe" there would be no place for democratic nations.

Prices on the New York Stock Exchange closed yesterday near the top levels of the year, ending the best week of 1942 on a buoyant note. Trading was the heaviest for a Saturday since Jan. 3. The volume of 455,800 shares compared with 445,920 on the preceding Saturday and with 516,840 on Jan. 3.

YOUNG creatures have a perennial interest for children, and a fledgling pelican, as she is presented by Alan Crane, is an amusing and appropriate addition to that long procession of birds and animals which has delighted so many boys and girls in the pages of picture books.

Members of the Navy League of the United States and the Military Order of the World War will give a dinner and dance on Oct. 27 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria in observance of Navy Day. Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, will be guest of honor.

Guadalcanal, described by the Marines as "the hot spot of the Pacific," again lived up to its reputation last week, while sporadic fighting continued in New Guinea, the Aleutians and on the Asiatic mainland.

HOULTON, Me., Oct. 10 -- Students of Ricker Classical Institute and Junior College will return to their books and papers Monday after three weeks in the fields of Aroostook County helping to harvest one of the largest crops of potatoes in recent years.

Patrolman Benjamin (Big Ben) Wallace, a towering Negro patrolman with five citations, arrested five Negro mugging suspects early yesterday and shot one of them who was trying to dive out the window of an apartment at 24 West 136th Street.

Travel Lines: Orlando announces that it is the only city of over 50,000 population in Florida that has not turned over any hotels or apartment houses to the armed forces. Requests from Northern residents for Winter accommodations top considerably those received at this time last year.

HERE'S fun! The Dodgers are now leading their field. It must be explained hastily that these are the football Dodgers and not the baseball Dodgers. Possibly that makes a difference in Brooklyn, but professional football is a great game, too.

RIO DE JANEIRO. A NUMBER of orchestral works by Villa-Lobos were recently presented for the first time, directed by the composer, at the Rio Municipal Theatre this Summer. The programs consisted of two orchestrations of piano works (Rudepoema and Bachianas Brasileiras, No. 4), the Third Suite of the Descobrimento do Brasil (the First Suite was given in New York last year), Choros, Nos. 6 and 9, and Choros No. 11 for piano and orchestra.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Wendell L. Willkie was homeward bound today from a fact-finding mission in thirteen countries, during which he urged speedy establishment of a second European front and increased Allied aid for China.

HERE is a book that this reviewer has read, most unusually, thrice running. First straight through. A headlong, keenly interested, present tense journey in which reader and subject were too completely identified to allow of even the brief pauses which would have made further reading superfluous.

The Wall Street banks, on which the Treasury always has relied heavily for subscriptions to the mounting issues of new government securities, have added more than $1,000,000,000 to their holdings of government obligations in the last three months, according to their statements of condition at the end of the third quarter of the year, just issued.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, will act as sponsor of a newly formed organization "to foster and promote the creative arts during the war and to plan for their increased functioning in the reconstruction to follow."

The critical material requirements of manufacturers of non-ordnance goods for the armed forces and of so-called essential civilian goods were so sharply reduced in allotments made for the fourth quarter under the Production Requirements Plan that part-time operations will become the rule for many companies, reports yesterday indicated.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 10 -- Coxswain Bob Nelson dropped back from center and calmly place-kicked the point that gave the Great Lakes Bluejackets a 7-to-6 triumph over the surprisingly ferocious Pitt Panthers, before a slim crowd of 12,315 in Cleveland Stadium today.

When the Trianon Room of the Ambassador is formally opened for the season on Wednesday night with a subscription dinner dance and entertainment under the sponsorship of Bundles for America, the occasion will be a special tribute to the United States Coast Guard.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The unit value of fuel oil ration coupons for private dwellings in the first heating period, October and November, will be ten gallons, according to the Office of Price Administration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Concern over manpower shortages in various fields of war effort took a unique turn today as evidence came out that the war agencies might have become overstaffed with civilian employes who might be serving effectively in industry and agriculture, if not in the armed forces.

The broad field of cooperation among the American republics and between the Western Hemisphere and the rest of the world was analyzed yesterday by men prominent in the political, musical and educational life of Canada, the United States, Chile and Colombia at the opening sessions of the Institute of American Affairs, which is commemorating the 450th anniver sary of Columbus's discovery of America.

A PORT SOMEWHERE IN BRITAIN, Oct. 10 -- Another convoy with thousands of United States troops has arrived. Amid the gray shapes of British warships which brought another outfit across the Atlantic one sees riding quietly at anchor the merchant vessels.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Staging the most spectacular one-man show of his brilliant football career, Virginia Military Institute's captain, Joe Muha, 210-pound triple threat from McKees Rocks, Pa., tallied three touchdowns, passed for two others and kicked two extra points in the cadets' 38-to-18 victory over the University of Virginia today.

Ten East Side youngsters, determined to pile up the biggest amount of scrap for Manhattan's drive this Thursday, defied a Department of Sanitation crew and the Rev. Victor Sperry yesterday and called off hostilities only after a fatherly police sergeant had promised them official recognition for collecting three tons of heavy metal.

To the Radio Editor: I was very much surprised and disappointed to read in the radio section of the Oct. 4 TIMES that the first two Sunday concerts of the Philharmonic this season are not to be broadcast by WABC, due to the fact that they will be conducted by Toscanini, who has been closely associated with NBC.

With the United States and Canadian Governments last week issuing orders drastically restricting gold-mining operations, another leading industry definitely has been cast into the background for the duration of the war. This decision, which probably was taken after full discussion by both governments, has thrown into the discard the old idea that gold is needed for the waging of a war.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, Sunday, Oct. 11 -- General Douglas MacArthur recently was seen at the front in New Guinea, where the Allies have been beating back the Japanese on the Port Moresby-Buna trail.

A UNITED NATIONS BASE IN WEST AFRICA, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Small, new-model German U-boats, fought to a standstill in the North Atlantic, are striking renewed blows against Allied shipping off the bulge of West Africa, apparently carrying out plans laid years in advance and with the help of pro-Nazi countries that are technically neutral.

A number of organizations are already working in high gear to see that Santa Claus in a wartime world does not exchange his pack for a duffel bag. Though toy imports are curtailed and scrap drives have taken their toll of rubber animals, tin soldiers and wire-wheeled doll carriages, substitutes are being resourcefully created.

The New York City Committee of United China Relief, under the co-chairmanship of Mrs. Robert Low Bacon and Frederick H. Wood, begins today the observance of "China Independence Week" in celebration of the thirty-first anniversary of the founding of the Chinese Republic.
"They were taken into bondage" is a statement which has come down to us from the earliest days of history as significant of the fate of a nation that has been overcome by an invader.

Although heavy reorders from stores in war-production areas taxed the delivery schedules of many wholesale markets last week, it was noted that in other areas consumer reaction affected men's wear and furniture departments, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Stores were showing interest in Spring merchandise, it was said, although many industries were not yet prepared to book business.

Many years ago Professor Franz Boas made some measurements which showed that children born of immigrants here had heads that differed in their relationship of length to breadth from the heads of immigrant children born abroad. The findings were of sensational importance because they showed that the physical characteristics of a "race" change under the influence of environment.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 10 -- Minnesota's two-year supremacy over its rivals in the Western Conference came to a stunning end today when a lowly regarded Illinois team forged a 20 to 13 decision before a riotous homecoming throng of 24,276 spectators in Memorial Stadium.

Roses are wartime plants par excellence. While this may seem an unlikely statement to gardeners brought up to believe that roses are too much trouble, experienced rose growers know that their favorite flowers will continue to give cheer for six or seven months a year despite wartime restrictions and possible neglect.

WHEREVER troops or supply ships are open to attack, the convoy system is the only method of getting them through. It was so in the last war and it is so in this one. Cargo ships unprotected by naval vessels are duck soup for submarines. That North Atlantic sinkings have decreased, not only on the route to England but also along the coast, is due to convoys.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 -- Idle clerks of the Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board, whose absence from their jobs is returning large areas of the State to prohibition aridness, rejected an offer of settlement in Pittsburgh and Philadelphia today.

EVER since her arrival increased the population of Altoona, Pa., by one, Janet Blair has been a young lady in a hurry. Even before her middy-waist days she was restlessly tapping an eager foot in a local dancing class.

THE NBC String Symphony, under Frank Black, will make its initial appearance in the first of a series of three concerts, Oct. 23, in Carnegie Hall, with Mischa Elman as soloist. The orchestra will be heard in works by Bach and Beethoven. Mr. Elman will play the Vivaldi concerto in G minor and the Mozart concerto in A.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- There was nothing wrong with one branch of the armed forces today, the football team of the United States Military Academy. Relying mainly on their air arm, the cadets turned back Cornell, 28 to 8, two of the Cornell points being a present by way of an automatic safety in the final period, when a pass from Army's center missed his backs and rolled through his own end zone.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- When England played Scotland in a charity soccer football game in Wembley Stadium today, the spectacle attracted two Kings, at least one high-ranking member of the Diplomatic Corps, Cabinet Ministers and more than 75,000 fans, including a generous sprinkling of Americans, Canadians, Australians and men from New Zealand.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- General liquidation developed today in the corn and oats futures markets on the Board of Trade following yesterday's estimate by the Department of Agriculture that the corn crop this year would set a new high record of 3,132,000,000 bushels and the announcement that record supplies of feed grains were available.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Juniata opened its football season today by coming from behind in the second half to upset Drexel, 13 to 9.

The scene on the cover -- showers of brilliant sparks flying from the torches of a crew of "burners" in an American shipyard -- might have been made at any one of a hundred places where workmen are building, converting and repairing merchant vessels to keep supplies moving across the seas.

HOLLISTON, Mass., Oct. 10 -- Facing the finest tracking layout possible and the best plotted tracks of the year, nine dogs of seven breeds competed today in the first tracking tests of the Victory Dog Training Club under the judging of one of America's pioneer obedience enthusiasts, Howard P. Claussen.
LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Reports from Canada indicated today that Britain had made good her promise to fetter a Nazi prisoner of war for each British soldier the Germans put in irons.

BENJAMIN FRANKLIN returned to Philadelphia in the Spring of 1775 after a long absence in England, where, since 1757, he had served as agent for several colonies. Everywhere he could see evidences of the vitality of his fellow-townsmen reflected not only in widespread physical improvements but also in scientific achievements and social progress. Here was, indeed, a mature people.

OLD FORGE -- "They came huntin' before them hard roads brought 'em in cars. We uster meet 'em at the train and we kin do it again," said an older guide of the Central Adirondacks when questioned regarding a would-be hunter's problem of obtaining gasoline enough to reach the mountains during deer season.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Present indications at the larger Pocono resorts are that business will continue good into November. This has been an exceptional season here. Since early Summer all the larger houses, such as the Inn at Buck Hill Falls, the Skytop Club and Pocono Manor, have been filled to capacity and there has been little change in the Fall.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- Magnus Konow, who drifted in last the first time, reversed the situation today among the International Class sloops in the opening regatta of the second week-end session of post season racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, said today that "most of the responsibility for keeping prices down rests with the women of the family."

A total of 2,135,710 voters registered in New York City for next month's Gubernatorial election, according to a tabulation completed early this morning following the close of registry books at 10:30 o'clock last night.

BOSTON, Oct. 10 -- Unless American colleges develop a program for vital, active and direct participation in the nation's all-out war effort, they are doomed to receive only secondary consideration in future war manpower plans, Professor John S. Perkins, Boston University authority on management and statistics, declared today.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10 (AP) -- A fast, alert and smartly drilled University of California at Los Angeles eleven stopped Oregon State's winning streak today, beating the defending Pacific Coast Conference and Rose Bowl champion, 30 to 7.
MOSCOW, Oct. 10 (AP) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique:

Michael Shayne of Miami is certainly one of the best of the tough sleuths, and the stories about him are tops in the tough class. It is good news, therefore, that a Michael Shayne omnibus has gathered into one volume four exciting Shayne tales.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Jack Jenkins's toe gave Venderbit University a 7-6 football victory over the University of Kentucky today and sent the Commodores off to a good start in the Southeastern Conference race.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 10 -- Conversion of the Works Progress Administration in Georgia to the war effort wherever possible has brought additional education opportunities to the State, it was disclosed here today. The adult education project is among the converted phases of WPA, and its work has expanded to the many Army posts in Georgia.
The fitful gusts of wintry wind around the city's streets these days and the occasional chilly day of the changing season have made a great many people warmth conscious.

DALLAS, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Texas pounded futilely at a rugged Oklahoma line for two periods today, then found the Sooners were too slow to halt a passing attack. So the Longhorns pitched their way to a 7-0 victory in the thirty-seventh renewal of this colorful intersectional football game.

OAKDALE, L.I., Oct. 10 -- Mike Mirabelli wound up a brilliant football career for La Salle Military Academy today in leading the cadets to a 13-7 triumph over Brown Prep. The flashy quarterback, who left for his induction center immediately after the game, was largely responsible for the La Salle triumph.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- H.D. Miser, in charge of the fuel oil section of the Geological Survey, told a Senate Public Lands subcommittee today there were big deposits of petroleum under water off the coasts of California, Texas and Louisiana, but that production in the Gulf had ceased because of submarine activity.

OF course it is natural that Andre Maurois as a boy should have wanted more than anything else to be a writer; and apparently it did not seem strange to the playmates of the rich industrialist's son in the Norman mill town.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 10 -- The Santa Clara Broncos made the foot count in football today to win a thrill-filled game from the University of California Bears, 7 to 6, before a crowd of 30,000.

This is being asked by men all over the world with increasingly serious curiosity, because Singapore and Burma, Malta and London have shown what new and possibly intolerable strains the imperial structure is being forced to endure, at the center as well as at the extremities.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 10 -- Holy Cross bounded back today after two early defeats and trampled on Fort Totten of Long Island, 60 to 0. The Crusaders outclassed the soldiers all the way and only once allowed the visitors to cross the mid-field marker.

Radio Berlin last week had an important message to broadcast. Instead, many batteries of the largest caliber siege guns would blow the last Soviet defenses apart.

COARSE GOLD is the name of the Nevada town -- like Gold Hill, for example, or Goldfield or half a dozen others -- which is the scene of this unusual Rocky Mountain Western story in which past and present and intimations of immortality are skillfully interwoven in a texture of fair and candid prose.

"COFFEE CREAM" is a story of the people and prejudices of the South -- of Mississippi in the early Nineteen Hundreds when Theodore Roosevelt was President. It plays up the conflict of prejudices between the Yankee lumber mill owners and officials and the native Southerners -- the aristocrats, the better people, the pore white trash and the Negroes (house servants and mill workers).

One of the largest entertainments of the Autumn season here will take place in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on the night of Oct. 23 when the Artists and Writers Association will present a unique supper dance and cabaret revue entitled "Incendiary Blondes."

LONDON, Oct. 10 (U.P.) -- The Norwegian Government-in-Exile charged General Wilhelm Rediess, Nazi Gestapo chief in Norway, with the death of 135 Norwegian patriots slain in the wave of terror now sweeping the country, and demanded that the United Nations execute him after the war.

AN entertaining, animated picture of San Francisco in the early Nineteen Twenties forms the background for Gertrude Atherton's new novel, "The Horn of Life." Lynn Randolph had driven an ambulance in France during three years of the first World War.

These are good days for walking in and around New York. It may be just a brief "dimout" stretch along Fifth Avenue. Possibly it is a trip of exploration through Alley Pond Park in Queens, a hike along the Palisades, a safari to Staten Island.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 10 -- Bernie Bierman's Iowa Naval Pre-Flight cadets, after trailing by 14 -- 0 in the second quarter, roared back behind a snarling, vicious line today to wallop Michigan, 26 -- 14, in a gridiron thriller.
DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 10 -- Georgia's Naval Pre-Flight School handed once powerful Duke its second consecutive defeat of the season today, 26-12, before a crowd of 7,500.

Co-Captain Stuart Goodman, 190-pound halfback, crashed through for three touchdowns in the final period that enabled Lincoln High of Brooklyn to rout the Curtis eleven, 19 to 0, at Thompson Stadium, Staten Island, yesterday. It was Lincoln's second victory of the season and the fourteenth straight in a streak that began in 1940.

BOSTON, Oct. 10 -- This is about a girl from Kokomo who registered at a Back Bay hotel to be near her sailor husband, quartered at a hotel taken over by the Navy next door, and how after three too expensive days she transformed herself from guest to elevator operator and now hopes to stay on for the duration.

Because the details of no two of these narratives are alike, the reader, and particularly the reader who is also an amateur sailor, can add them to his shelves indefinitely.

Both metropolitan elevens, New York and Brooklyn, will have their home openings today as the Giants face Philadelphia at the Polo Grounds and the Dodgers take on Pittsburgh at Ebbets Field. The local lads are favored, with the starting time for each set at 2:30 P.M.

GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands, Sept. 19 (Delayed) -- The Japanese, definitely beaten, have withdrawn after their large-scale, three-pronged attack against the Marines at Henderson Field on Sept. 12, 13 and 14. Only isolated fighting has occurred since Sept. 14, and the Marines are now patrolling widely throughout the former battle area, flushing an occasional group of Japanese.
PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Washington inched into the Pacific Coast Conference football championship picture today by turning back the University of Oregon, 15 -- 27, before 13,000.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Minister of Production Oliver Lyttelton told workers in an airplane factory in the north Midlands that growing production of the United Nations would enable them to take the initiative "soon," while P.L. Horabin, Labor Member of Parliament, attacked the Minister of production for "optimistic poppycock" about the last eighty days of the war.

Failure on the part of management to adequately acquaint new employes with principles of factory procedure is hampering expanded output in many war plants, it was pointed out here yesterday by the Labor Relations Institute, which has drafted a set of suggestions designed to help management overcome this difficulty.

THE dinner pail is emerging from partial eclipse and is finding a welcome among many who once disdained it. A stenographer in Washington, a mechanic in Detroit, an office boy in New York will tell you why. They will show you the clatter and the crowd in hot cafeterias, where hungry customers wait fifteen, twenty, thirty minutes for indifferent food.
STORRS, Conn., Oct. 10 -- Taking advantage of two pass interceptions and one fumble, Wesleyan University today defeated the University of Connecticut, 20 -- 7, before a Dad's Day crowd of 3,000.

Problems of war transport will dominate the discussions at the sixth annual meeting of the National Association of Shippers Advisory Boards to be held in the Palmer House in Chicago next Thursday and Friday. Alvin W. Vogtle of Birmingham, Ala., president of the association, will preside.

IN his review of "How War Came," Mr. Commager is on firm ground when he raises the point of inaccuracies in quoted portions of Mr. Churchill's Dunkerque and Mr. Roosevelt's Charlottesville speeches. The sentences taken from the former were derived from the version cabled to the American press.

HONOLULU, Oct. 10 -- One need only step into the street here to note increased tempo of United States preparations to meet the long awaited new Japanese thrust in the Pacific and to strike our own hard blows in the war of attrition that is fast building up from Rabaul, New Britain, to Kiska in the Aleutians.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 10 -- William L. Brann's Vincentive raced to an impressive seven-length victory in the twelfth running of the $5,000 added Maryland Futurity at Laurel Park today.

From North Carolina comes word that, judging by recent inquiries received, a considerable number of out-of-State residents are planning to spend the Winter there. Winter resort hotels are opening earlier than usual to take care of these guests.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 10 -- While the Chilean Government awaited a report from Ambassador Rodolfo Michels at Washington on a reply to the protest he transmitted against the recent speech of Acting Secretary of State Sumner Welles, Foreign Minister Ernesto Barros Jarpa conferred today with the United States and British and also the Japanese and Italian envoys here.

OF all our anniversaries, only one is celebrated throughout North and South America and yet is not observed elsewhere in the world. That is Oct. 12, which to us in the United States has always been known as Columbus Day. This year we are celebrating the 450th anniversary of Columbus's discovery of America.

THIS is the first novel that Albert Halper has written without anger, and it is by long odds his best. True, he has once again used an institution, a quality fur and millinery shop, as his mis en scene, and therefore run into familiar problems of mass-action plotting.

More than 10,000 fingerprints have been filed with the War Identification Bureau through the effort of trained members of the American Women's Hospital Reserve Corps in both New York and Queens. Narrow Mott Street was filled with 20,000 youngsters and aging Chinese yesterday as the famous "playing lion" took its fantastic way through the crooked streets of Chinatown on the shoulders of graying men in celebration of the thirty-first anniversary of the founding of the Chinese Republic.

THE title of this book is all too descriptive. Bang it on your chair-arm when you have finished, and it will ring false as a plugged quarter. But if you can stomach the first chapter, it will hold you to the end -- even if the after-effect is comparable to a morning at the reptile-house in the zoo.

Six years ago Edwin Way Teale started an insect garden in an old orchard on Long Island, He deliberately grew flowers and encouraged plants which furnish the food, the shelter and the breeding ground for American insects. There, as the seasons passed, he played host to the teeming inhabitants of a world which most of us pass unnoticed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Whatever dissatisfaction may be expressed by the Soviet Union concerning the extent of aid from the United Nations in the months ahead, the United States and Great Britain are now in a position to reply that they are doing their utmost to live up to their commitments through the protocol signed here this week providing for a continuation and intensification of the supply program.

The 450th anniversary of the discovery of America tomorrow reminds Americans that they must make every sacrifice to perpetuate those ideals upon which our democracy was founded and to extend those ideals throughout the world, rabbis declared in sermons here yesterday.

AT A DESERT AIRDROME IN EGYPT, Oct. 10 -- In a tent decorated with the Stars and Stripes, symbolizing the establishment of the United States on one of the world's main battle fronts in the Western Desert, members of a United States Army Air Force fighter squadron told the story of yesterday's air operations which resulted in damage of considerable magnitude to the enemy's African war machine.

Resources available in Great Britain for civilian production are to be concentrated increasingly in the future in the manufacture of standardized utility articles, according to data received here by the British information services. Utility clothing having proved to be a "pronounced success," the government is planning "utility" furniture, pottery, hollow ware, umbrellas, pencils, cutlery, suitcases and many other civilian articles.
In another thriller of the series between them, Alsab turned the tables on Whirlaway yesterday to capture the $30,200 New York Handicap by a nose at the end of a bitterly run two miles and a quarter.

A WEST COAST PORT, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Four men of a Navy gun crew and the chief engineer and the third mate of a coastwise tanker lost their lives in an attack on the vessel by a Japanese submarine, the Navy announced today. The thirty-eight other men aboard the tanker were saved.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Library of Congress has received as a gift the original manuscripts and typescripts of the Juvenilia of Alan Seeger, soldier-poet who was killed in the first World War.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 10 -- Exceptionally high losses of sub-alterns and fear for the morale of the army during the forthcoming Winter persuaded Reichsfuehrer Hitler to sign an ordinance today enabling any illiterate but reliable young Nazi to become an officer, it is believed in competent Stockholm circles.

WE call the season Fall, for a simple, obvious reason. It is the time of falling leaves. Summer has spent its strength. Winter still lies ahead. Between the two comes the time of fruition, the season when leaf and nut and berry achieve their height of color and maturity, bask briefly in the southward slanted sun, and return to the earth which mothered them.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Wisconsin's up-and-coming gridiron mechanics dismantled Missouri's Model T in an exciting intersectional football game today. The score of this first game between the schools was 17 to 9.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Adolf Hitler's recent speech as well as subsequent statements of his satellites are widely interpreted in the British press and to a lesser extent within the United States to mean that the Fuehrer might be preparing to go on the defensive and organize Europe in order to get the utmost profit from his conquests to date.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 -- With an aerial attack led by Charles Vaughan, former Tennessee star, and Laverne Astroth, of Illinois fame, the United States Coast Guard Training Station team of Manhattan Beach defeated Villanova in the Wildcats' opening game tonight at Shibe Park, 20 -- 13, before 15,000 spectators.

THE Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences has arranged an augmented calendar of musical events for this season forming a list of unusual extensiveness. The program includes nine series and many individual events, all to be given at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

Nearly every motorist and truck driver in the East either knows first hand of "chiseling" on gasoline rations or has done it for his own gain. Four months of rationing has established a bad record here -- one which national gasoline rationing must better.
MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Providing a minor upset, West Virginia defeated an out-classed South Carolina football squad today, 13 to 0.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 10 -- Substantially aided by penalties and pass interceptions, Colgate's unconquered, victory-rampant Red Raiders tormented the inhabitants of this peaceful New England town today by taking a gridiron thriller from Dartmouth, 27 to 19, for their third triumph of the current campaign.

GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands, Sept. 22 (Delayed) -- Extensive raiding and patrolling by United States Marine units during the last few days have established a general withdrawal of the defeated Japanese forces from the immediate vicinity of the Marine-occupied area on Guadalcanal.

THE twenty-ninth annual exhibition of oils, water-colors, sculpture and mural design by the Allied Artists of America will be held at the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, from Oct. 31 to Nov. 29. Entry blanks and circulars may be obtained from Mildred N. Kelley, assistant to the secretary, 630 Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- A "5-in-1" canned ration, including ham and eggs, and consisting mainly of canned and dehydrated foods, has been produced by the Army especially for motorized and mechanized forces. It contains three full meals for five men for one day and is prepared in a few minutes merely by heating.

The youthfulness of the run of Russian generals impressed Mr. Willkie. Timoshenko, defender of the South, is only 47. Zhukoff, who saved Moscow, is 43. FOR THE COMING WEEK: Bulb planting is in full swing; daffodils should be got into the ground at once, and others before danger of frost. . . . "Puritan Love and Marriage" and "Responsibilities of a Puritan Parent," appeared earlier this year in More Books, the bulletin of the Boston Public Library.

THE Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo will replace the Ballet Theatre tomorrow evening in the "Season of Ballet" at the Metropolitan Opera House, offering three premieres in its nine-day engagement.

THE New York musical season has started. Already two or three new musicians have given their debut recitals and a hundred or more still have the ordeal ahead.
