MOSCOW, Oct. 10 -- Stalingrad's ordeal has already lasted fifty days. On Aug. 22 General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock ordered a general assault on the city from positions across the Don and near Kotelnikov, and twenty-four hours later more than 1,000 planes attacked Stalingrad, setting three-quarters of it afire.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- French sources here denied there is any relation between the assignment of Charles Vallin, former vice president of the Croix de Feu [Righist party] to a military mission in the region of the Chad-Libyan frontier and the antagonism aroused in British Liberal circles by his association with the French National Committee.

Nearly 1,800 merchant seamen have taken advantage of the recreational facilities offered at the Andrew Furuseth Club on East Thirty-seventh Street since it was opened ten days ago by the United Seamen's Service.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- With the October moon there comes to Northern New England the most aristocratic game bird that has been sought by American gunners in the New World and by English sportsmen in the Old. The arrival of the birds is awaited with intense interest, and it isn't really the moon that brings them.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- James M. Landis, director of the Office of Civilian Defense, is forming a volunteer aviation corps for high school boys and girls, to be known as the Civil Air Patrol Cadets.

TELEVISION has been called today's thirty-million-dollar if, because that is about how much the researchers have spent to date in its development. We know little of what is now going on behind the doors of radio laboratories where tele-techniques have been stepped into high gear by the demands of a wartime America.

A series of After-Duty Cocktail Hours with dancing, to be held every other Wednesday throughout the Winter under the auspices of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, Second Regional Council, will have its inception this Wednesday afternoon in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (Wide World) -- American warplane manufacturers are expected to send new and more deadly products of their industry to the fighting fronts this Fall and Winter and a variety of new names, "Corsair," "Thunderbolt," "Helldiver," and the like, will begin to appear in reports of battle actions.

Defeat of Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., Republican candidate for re-election in the Twenty-sixth Congressional District, by Ferdinand A. Hoyt, Democratic and American Labor party candidate, was predicted yesterday by Alex Rose, State secretary of the Labor party, on the basis of reports from the Labor-party chairmen of the five Assembly districts in the Congressional district.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 10 -- Clark Shaughnessy, formerly of Stanford University, put his T-formation on display today before 15,000 as Maryland's Old Liners defeated Rutgers by a score of 27 to 13. It was the third victory in as many starts for Maryland, but there were moments when the followers of the victorious team squirmed in their seats as Rutgers held an early advantage.

Bleak winds are blowing down the steppes of Russia. Even as far south as Stalingrad German soldiers on the banks of the Don complain of the cold. Winter is on the way, marching at a measured pace the German armies have not matched. But Hermann Goering, in Berlin, says he does not fear it.

SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 10 (AP) -- A walkout of the South Portland Shipbuilding Corporation's yard spread rapidly today, with minor outbreaks of violence, until less than half the evening shift was at work.

A MAN is murdered on the stage at an opening night's performance, and the audience that sees it includes the psychiatrist-investigator, Basil Willing; yet even Dr. Willing has no idea that a murder has been committed, much less who the murderer may be.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- A 16-year-old youth who had only a theoretical knowledge of flying was fined 2 today for helping himself to a military airplane at Midlands Airfield, flying it around and then landing it to win bets of half a crown each from three other lads.

Created to help cement amicable relationships with the countries of the Pan American Union by "cultivating permanent cultural and spiritual ties" among metropolitan Catholic college students and Latin-American college students, the Inter-American Institute of St. John's University, Brooklyn, started its first year last week with a charter enrollment of fifty, Professor Joseph S. Cardinale, director, announced yesterday.

Mrs. Joseph West Dixon and Miss Margalo Gillmore head the group in charge of the sale of tickets for the benefit performance on the night of Nov. 17 of "The Skin of Our Teeth," a new play by Thornton Wilder, at a theatre yet to be announced.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 10 -- Seven years ago the world of art was a Shangri-La to Monmouth County Detective Harry Zuckerman. Today he is an authority on the subject and the inspiration for his culture is a prisoner in the county jail at Freehold charged with stealing paintings valued at $5,900.

It is increasingly apparent that the financing of the war by the Treasury is being done the "easy way," or by means of excessive bank credit expansion. This method is achieved by the almost effortless sale of Federal securities to the commercial banks, which effect pay for them by crediting the government with a deposit credit.

The second part of the collection of the late Colonel E.H.R. Green brought $25,519 when sold last week at the Collectors Club by Laurence Stryker with Walter S. Scott as auctioneer. This amount considerably exceeded the advance appraisal placed on 1,555 lots.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- A thorough investigation of the spectacular prison break yesterday by seven life-term convicts from Stateville Prison, near Joliet, was under way today under the personal supervision and direction of Governor Dwight H. Green.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Rev. Dr. Frederick Brown Harris, pastor of Foundry Methodist Church here, was elected today chaplain of the United States Senate. Fifty-fifth in the succession of chaplains and sixteenth of his denomination, he succeeds the Rev. Ze Barney T. Phillips, dean of the Washington Cathedral, who died in May.

SALESMANSIrp: At 6 A. M. last Tuesday morning Kate Smith, radio star, went on the air in a New York studio to sell war bonds. Her plan was to send forth her plea about every half. hour; her goal: $1,000,000,000. Twenty hours later, when she went off the air, she had sold $1,964,900 worth of bonds and the orders still were coming in. She got one call for a $50 bond from Tacoma, Wash.

Landscape, architectural and gardening history may be traced down through he centuries in a collection of rare old books on these subjects now on display in the Avery Library of Columbia University. Various examples of these arts in different countries are represented.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 10 -- The United Mine Workers of America has no intention of returning to the American Federation of Labor at this time, John L. Lewis, president of the union, declared today. While it would cooperate in any effort to bring about labor peace among all "bona fide" labor organizations, it would not now take the initiative in such an effort, he added.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (Science Service) -- A new version of the flying wing, one that is adapted to a smaller plane than the Northrop type, earlier patented, is the invention of David R. Davis of Los Angeles, who has received United States Patent 2,298,040.

A budget of nearly $1,500,000 for extension of the health program in Palestine has been prepared for presentation to Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, at its five day convention opening Wednesday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Darragh A. Park, vice president of the Manufacturers Trust Company and general chairman of the campaign drive of the Travelers Aid Society, appealed yesterday to industry and to the public to assist in raising $176,963.

General Draja Mikhailovitch, commander of Yugoslavia's guerrillas, is reported to have sent a message to Marshal Henri Philippe Petain. As leader of the Yugoslav people in their heroic resistance to foreign conquerors, he tried to convince the Marshal that national independence could not be won back by the methods followed in Vichy.

THE leaves are just beginning to fall here at home, the nights to grow crisp and cold. But it is time to think of Christmas. To the thousands of our boys fighting all over the world, Christmas mail will be the biggest morale booster the home front can provide. To reach its destination in time such mail must be posted early.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Scraphungry America has turned to its rural homesteads, city apartments and suburban dwellings for the materials it finds are vital to the success of its war effort. It has called on industry -- still the major source of scrap -- for greatly augmented contributions.

IN composing his fireside chat for tomorrow night President Roosevelt is offered a bewildering array of topics from which to choose. Included would be progress of the war job at home and abroad, morale, taxation, civilian controls, food, industry, small business and a host of others.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 10 -- Ezequiel Padilla, Minister of Foreign Affairs, said last night that Mexico would welcome political refugees provided "they intend to work and are disciplined."

Andre Michalopoulos, Greek Minter of Information, issued a statement last week contradicting spokesmen of the Greek Maritime Union, representing Greek seamen engaged on ships serving the United Nations' cause, Mr. Michalopoulos, in a review of the role of the Greek merchant marine in the war, made public late in September, said that Greek seamen received $125 a month and that their victualling compared favorably with those of American, British and other maritime nations.

ELIZABETH, Ill, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Production of fluorspar, vital in the processing of aluminum and steel, was tied up at two of the country's largest mines today, despite a request from the War Labor Board for striking miners to return to their jobs.

Additional air express service direct to Mexico from more than 250 United States cities is now in operation, according to an announcement last week by the Air Express division of Railway Express Agency. The new service, an extension of airline schedules to Monterrey and Mexico City, is expected to facilitate the heavy flow of vital materials between American production centers and Mexico, it was explained.

GRANVILLE, Ohio, Oct. 10 -- A citizenship major, to train students to enter governmental research and direct the economic and social reconstruction in the post-war era, has been established at Denison University, Kenneth Irving Brown, president, announced here today.

Dr. T.V. Soong, Chinese Minister for Foreign Affairs and brother-in-law of the late Sun Yatsen, founder of the Chinese-Republic, urged last night that the United Nations set up an executive council as soon as possible to establish an international organization that would function during as well as after the war.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Oct. 10 -- Held at bay through the first half, Amherst drove to a 25-0 victory over Bowdoin today, converting a blocked Bowdoin punt, two intercepted passes and a recovered fumble into touchdowns.

Evander Childs, held on even terms by the lighter Seward Park eleven through three periods, broke loose in the final quarter for a 6-0 victory in the second game of a schoolboy doubleheader yesterday at Randalls Island Stadium. A crowd of 5,000 looked on.

TORONTO, Oct. 10 -- John L. Lewis, organized labor's "enfant terrible," has again made labor history. The grim-visaged chief of the United Mine Workers, by leading his powerful organization of 500,000 men out of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, has presented all organized labor, as well as the national Administration, with a host of problems.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The crisis over manpower came, like other crises in the war program of the United States, as an expected guest for whom no adequate preparation had been made. It followed in sequence the emergencies over production, inflation, the rubber shortage and other problems that have been raised by the war and permitted to reach an acute stage before they were met.

Lebanon Valley brought a football squad to Lewisohn Stadium yesterday that was even smaller than the struggling City College team, but swamped the Lavender by 36 -- 0. Nineteen men made up the entire Flying Dutchman contingent, but they were a potent lot, who pushed over four touchdowns and a field goal in the last quarter.

FOR the timid soul who would rather stay away from the ballet, altogether than run the risk of having to pronounce the ballerinas' Russian names there are new grounds for hope, for a crop of American-born ballerinas is arising who scorn to add one synthetic ova or inska to the names they were born with.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Iowa stopped the big guns of the Camp Grant football team today and evened its series with service teams for the season by taking a 33-to-16 victory. Iowa suffered its only defeat of the season by losing to Great Lakes last week.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Oct. 10 -- Last January, in cooperation with the City-County Health Department, and with the approval of the El Paso County Medical Society, the sociology department of Colorado College entered into a working relationship on its campus whereby a Child Health Conference would be available as a teaching medium and as a place where mothers could bring their children for well-baby care.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Patriotic resistance to the Germans in Norway has increased to such an extent during the last two months that enemy efforts to exploit the country's resources and fortify its western coastline against Allied attack have been seriously hampered, ac cording to the Norwegian Government here.

MOSCOW, Oct. 10 -- The lodging of full powers of command in the hands of Red Army officers by bringing the political commissars under their control was decreed today. The measure will unify command, removing ambiguities and causes of delay.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Chile and Argentina made formal protests here today against the assertion by Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, in his speech in Boston Thursday that Axis agents were operating in those countries. Mr. Welles charged that Chile was responsible for the sinking of ships as a result of information sent by Axis agents from Chilean radio stations.

A hold-up suspect, said by the police to have attempted to rob the Worwick Luggage Shop, 1324 Sixth Avenue, between Fifty-third and Fifty-fourth Streets, twice in a little more than a week, was shot and killed in front of the shop at 8:10 o'clock last night by two detectives.

HINCKLEY, Ill., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Laverne Staid, dirt farmer, has a plan to keep a steady flow of meat going to the butcher shops. He raises four pig crops each year instead of the usual one or two. He declared that yearly production is increased 30 per cent.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 10 -- Methods of teaching visual perception developed by an Ohio State University professor of psychology are expected here to be the margin between victory and defeat in many an aerial dog-fight before the war is ended.

Although there has been less and less speculation concerning the eventual fate of the Sportsmen's Shows as the months rolled on from Dec. 7, nevertheless it now has been definitely announced that the 1943 schedule is officially canceled.

Less than 1 per cent of the estimated 500,000 men and women who take formal courses in adult education in the metropolitan area select subjects dealing with American history or government, a survey conducted by the New York Adult Education Council disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- By a vote of 77 to 0 the Senate passed today the greatest tax bill in all history and requested the House for a conference to iron out many changes from that body's version of the measure.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 10 -- Williams romped to its third straight victory today, turning back an injury-ridden Clarkson eleven, 52 -- 0. Two second-string backs, Red Nichols, and freshman Bob Zabor, led the Purple scorers with two touchdowns each.

For the first time since the outbreak of the war, the upward trend in wood pulp production and consumption has been reversed, Fred G. Stevenot, president of Puget Sound Pulp and Timber Company, reported yesterday. EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Purdue's battered football forces, twice defeated, bounded back with vengeance today to upset the highly favored Northwestern Wildcats, 7 to 6, before 33,000 spectators.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 10 -- While, according to the latest information, the German Government has not yet replied to a Danish memorandum allegedly stating the Danish attitude toward German demands, a sign that the crisis, although not ended, has become somewhat less acute, is seen in the official announcement that the Danish Free Corps will, as scheduled, leave for the Eastern Front on Tuesday.

An 80-yard march that started in the first period and reached its culmination in the second enabled Princeton to beat Navy at football in the Yankee Stadium yesterday. The middies, fighting stubbornly in an attempt to erase the touchdown resulting from this long march, made several scoring threats, but the alert Tigers held them off.

ROCHESTER, Minn., Oct. 10 (AP) -- A surprised but happy coach tuned in from a hospital bed on the last part of the Notre Dame Stanford football game today to find "the boys" scoring a 27-0 victory for the Irish.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- President Roosevelt may touch upon the manpower problem in his Monday night radio speech, it was indicated today by Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Commission chairman, after a call at the White House.

CLINTON, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- With Co-captain Milt Jannone, one of the East's leading 1941 scorers, benched for the first time in two years with injuries, his teammates rallied today to give the Hamilton College eleven a 20-7 victory over Hobart.

The past week's arrivals of new issues from abroad include Brazil's promised item commemorating the "IV Congresso Eucaristico Nacional" (Fourth National Eucharistic Congress) at Sao Paulo from Sept. 4 to 7. This is a diamond-shaped 400-reis drab olive illustrating religious insignia on a shield.

YAPHANK, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- The second game of fourteen between Samuel Reshevsky and Isaac I. Kashdan in their play-off for the United States chess championship was adjourned after forty-seven moves tonight in the Camp Upton Library.

AS a matter of fact, though described so, this isn't a Victorian novel at all; for no Victorian novelist, not even those of the Eighteen Nineties, could quite establish that over-all irony, gentle but perceptible, that plays so great a part in Anne Meredith's "The Family Man."

A new plant may cause a sensation but not always does it prove its merit over a period of years. However, when one does stand all the tests of time and weather, it is worth including even in wartime gardens. Such a plant is the new English Cottage Carnation. These carnations, of recent introduction, are hybrids obtained from the Allwood English Carnation after years of breeding and crossing with other species.

Retail trade was active in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floor and basement volume was large, with the demand for dresses, coats, suits and furs also reported good.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The tightest and most far-reaching economic controls in our history were being promulgated or drafted this week, but their net and final effect upon the life of the average citizen still is not measurable because performance must follow performance if disastrous inflation and unconscionably high living costs are to be avoided.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- President Roosevelt may touch upon the manpower problem in his Monday night radio speech, it was indicated today by Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Commission chairman, after a call at the White House.

SHOSTAKOVICH'S Seventh symphony will be played by at least ten major symphony orchestras within the next few months. Arturo Toscanini is conducting it this week with the New York Philharmonic. Serge Koussevitzky is planning to lead it in Boston and twice in New York as well as on tour.
DETROIT, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Production returned to normal today at the Chrysler Corporation's Jefferson Avenue plant after a one-day curtailment attributed to a dispute over a no-smoking rule.

The opening rally of the sixty-fourth annual United Hospital Fund campaign will be held Tuesday night at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, it was announced yesterday by William S. Paley, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System and chairman of the drive.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- Thomas E. Dewey, Republican nominee for Governor, concurred here tonight with President Roosevelt's recent statement that the proposed St. Lawrence power project be deferred until after the war because of steel and manpower shortages resulting from the war.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Sept. 28 -- United States Government restrictions on the movement of dollar currency may achieve their effect in hampering the activities of Nazi agents, but the ruling has also been a severe blow to European refugees in Latin America

The past week's arrivals of new issues from abroad include Brazil's promised item commemorating the "IV Congresso Eucaristico Nacional" (Fourth National Eucharistic Congress) at Sao Paulo from Sept. 4 to 7. This is a diamond-shaped 400-reis drab olive illustrating religious insignia on a shield.

However, when one does stand all the tests of time and weather, it is worth including even in wartime gardens. Such a plant is the new English Cottage Carnation. These carnations, of recent introduction, are hybrids obtained from the Allwood English Carnation after years of breeding and crossing with other species.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct 10 -- Forward passes featured in all three touchdowns as Vermont defeated Massachusetts State today, 13 to 6. Vermont scored in the second quarter on a 50-yard pass, Beaulieu to Lapointe, and the same combination accounted for Vermont's other touchdown on a 25-yard pass in the fourth quarter.

WATERVILLE, Me., Oct. 10 -- The Coast Guard Academy and Colby College filled the air with passes today in a wide-open game, but the Guardsmen had the edge in place-kicking and won, 14 to 12. Jack Dorsey and Charley Beyer, hard-driving backs, were the stars for the invaders.

FORT DIX, N.J., Oct. 10 -- Establishment of Fort Dix as a prohibited zone by a First Army directive has resulted in orders being issued here today barring all visitors, with a few exceptions, from the reservation's 30,000 acres, effective Thursday at 6 A.M.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, demanded under threat of "further action" by the Federal Government today that a strike of truck drivers at Minneapolis be ended at once.

The first group of 100 commissioned officers of the State Guard divisions of New York, New Jersey and Delaware completed yesterday an intensive one-week combat training course at a new school of the Second Service Command in a former camp of the Civilian Conservation Corps near Hackettstown, N.J.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Powerful Duquesne University recorded its sixteenth consecutive gridiron triumph tonight, easily winning a 33-0 decision from Kansas State. Mike Kielbasa, right halfback, led the attack as he scored two touchdowns and kicked three extra points.

Release by the War Production Board on Friday of more than 30,000,000 pounds of finer carpet wools, which until then had been frozen in the hands of manufacturers, will enable mills to maintain output at current levels until Jan. 31, when the present limitation on consumption expires, and for three to four months beyond that if the consumption quota is extended, mill executives said yesterday.

To the Radio Editor: I WAS interested in an article by Robert Tallman on your radio page on Sept. 27. I don't know and have never met Robert, but I like him very much. The reason is that, in speaking of radio ratings, he said: "As a matter of fact, nobody really believes in radio's statistical holy of holies, yet we all go on behaving as if we do."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- United States Navy and Marine Corps aviators have sunk a Japanese destroyer and damaged a Japanese cruiser and another destroyer in the course of the fighting that is proceeding in the Solomon Islands as the Japanese continue to press their efforts to land reinforcements on Guadalcanal.

A TRANSATLANTIC conflict is going on between British authorities in Washington and the War Office in London over whether "Next of Kin," the careless-talk film which has found such popular favor in England, should be released in this country.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 10 -- Mexico is ready to assist militarily any nation of the Western Hemisphere that may ask for help, President Manuel Avila Camacho asserted in an interview published in the newspaper Prensa. Mexico, he said, is now in a position to send soldiers outside national territory.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Clarence Budington Kelland, executive director of the Republican National Committee, declared tonight that "this war can be shortened and the day of victory brought nearer by the election of a Republican Congress."

BOSTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Boston College literally ran rings around a scrappy band of Clemson Tigers today, but the South Carolinians fought so strongly in the pinches that the Eagles were forced to come from behind with two second-half touchdowns to win, 14 to 7, before a crowd of 18,500 at Fenway Park.

HOWARD LANG is in town with a pocketful of money, an idea, and his report on the ownership of "Good Night Ladies," the comedy that has been a Chicago gold mine since last April. Mr. Lang, of course, is the former Hollywood agent who came to Al Rosen's rescue when Mr. Rosen couldn't find backers for the present version of the Hopwood-Andrews farce.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 10 -- An underdog William and Mary football team outplayed the Harvard eleven in almost every department of the game in the Crimson Stadium today, but had to be content with a 7-7 tie when a pair of Crimson substitutes combined to score in the first minute of the fourth quarter.
PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 10 -- There will be a Rose Bowl football game New Year's Day, but it may not be in the Rose Bowl and possibly won't be a college intersectional contest as in the past.

Unquestionably the most spectacular flowering perennials to appear this year are the new Curtis Giant Oriental Poppies. Seeing them for the first time, one is inclined to think that these magnificent flowers are an invention of an overexcited imagination.

When Sandra Cassells turned from swamis and circus riders to convicts as an outlet for her huge fortune's surplus, her friend Lee Mappin guessed there was trouble ahead. And when she established the "house with the blue door" as a convicts' refuge, minor disturbances soon were overshadowed by murder.

OFTEN a work of art has a short life and has something to say to readers only for a decade or so, or only when they are young and responsive to anything that opens new windows to their minds. But "John Brown's Body," first published fourteen years ago, has actually more to say to the generation it was first addressed to as they grow older.

Uncounted thousands of men, 20, 30, 40, 50, even 60 years old, are schoolboys again as part of their war effort. With texts under their arms, notebooks in their pockets and sometimes with a brief case loaded with pelorus, parallel rules, dividers and what-not, they are working late into the night on one or two evenings each week to learn navigation and small boat seamanship.

WITH THE UNITED STATES BOMBER COMMAND, in England, Oct. 10 (AP) -- A 19-year-old engineer-gunner of a United States Liberator who plugged a hole in a fuel line with his fingers received credit tonight for enabling his four-motored bomber to return from yesterday's Lille raid despite damage by innumerable Nazi machinegun bullets and cannon shells.

CHUNGKING, China, Oct. 10 -- The promise by the United States and Britain that they would open negotiations with China for the relinquishment of extraterritorial rights in China intensified the jubilation of Chinese in their celebration of National Day today.

BOSTON, Oct. 10 -- The outstanding development of the twenty-ninth national foreign trade convention, which has just concluded its sessions here, was the announcement of the drastically revised procedures and policies of the Board of Economic Warfare, as outlined by Hector Lazo, assistant director in charge of the office of exports, foreign traders agreed yesterday.
HAVERFORD, Pa., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Haverford had little trouble defeating Susquehanna on Walton Field today as Art Jones's passing and Dee Crabtree's run paced them to a 27-to-6 victory.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- The strike of Tyneside shipbuilders, which has been described as "the stupidest in the history of British labor," rounded out a week today with the men still refusing to work and showing no sign that they would do so Monday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Ossie Bluege, one of the finest infielders the American League has seen and for seventeen years a perfectionist at third base for the Washington baseball club, today was named to manage the Senators for the 1943 season.

PSYCHOLOGICALLY the best possible thing for Sarah, as Dr. Emily Burr told the girl's mother, would be to take care of her own room every day. The idea delighted Sarah. "But she can't," was her mother's protest. "What would the servants think?"

Senator La Follette, in his one-man minority report on the Finance Committee's revenue bill, declared: "It fails to tax heavily enough certain classes of individual and corporate incomes well able to carry a heavier share of the tax burden. * * * It places an unfair and dangerous share of the increased tax burden upon the lower-income groups."

PUBLISHERS with books hooked closely to the news (and that's a lot of publishers) are finding that they can't get quite the same happy cooperation from the book manufacturing plants that formerly was given them when a manuscript came in late and they wanted a hurry job on it.

MR. PEARSON'S portrait of Shaw will easily take its place in any series that may be called good and great biography. Whatever Shaw's reputation as dramatist or Socialist may turn out to be, his impact as a personality on his age has been a resounding historic fact; and this Mr. Pearson records accurately and indeed beautifully.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 10 -- Lafayette outscored a Soldier eleven from Fort Monmouth, 7 to 3, to open its home season today. After spotting the visitors a three-point lead, the Leopards came back to score a touchdown in the third period.

Mayor La Guardia served notice yesterday upon the scrap metal dealers that they have only "a few days" left in which to demonstrate that they can move New York's huge household scrap pile to the steel mills and processing plants without further delay.

I THINK the bravest men in the world, next to test pilots and Marine sergeants, must be anthologists of light verse. Critics are comparatively kind to novelists, biographers, even poets. "The fellow did his best and misspelled only a few words," they mutter, "so let's give him 'A' for effort."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Every motorist in the United States who obeys the speed and rationing regulations will receive enough recaps or used or new tires to keep his car rolling for essential purposes for the duration. This program was announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 10 -- With registration in its eight schools completed for the first semester, Tufts College today reported a total enrollment of 2,272 full-time students, one of the largest in the institution's long history.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 10 -- The long-expected rationing of bread and milk in Switzerland was announced yesterday by the War Ministry's Food Section. Officially the reason given is the "gradual but none-the-less extensive increase in the consumption of both commodities" -- a corollary of the scarcity of other rationed commodities.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Oct. 11 -- For the second night in succession Allied heavy bombers carried out mass attacks on the Japanese supply base at Rabaul, New Britain, dropping forty tons of explosive and incendiary bombs which set fires visible for ninety miles, a communique said today.
AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Sunday, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A communique:

Crimes committed by the Nazis will be punished as acts against the German people and the peace of the world and a speedy trial of the criminals will establish an example for the future, Gerhart H. Seger, former member of the German Reichstag and spokesman for the Association of Free Germans, Inc., said yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- It is a long way from shattered Stalingrad to the quiet house in one of the home counties where Rudolf Hess passes monotonous days under a heavy guard. But the relation between the two is becoming more evident to those who probe the mystery of the modern "Man in the Iron Mask,"

NOVELTY programs appear on the international short wave stage as the 1942 Winter season opens. Outstanding is the five-minute show put on by Catholic devotees in Germany at the risk of their lives (4:20 P.M., E.W.T., on 9.96 megacycles).
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The United States is now spending more than $6,000,000,000 a month, $5,500,000,000 of it on the war. It is getting about $1,200,000,000 in taxes and borrowing the rest.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Lou Thomas hit his ends with long passes and kicked a 35-yard field goal today to shatter Rice Institute's budding football reputation, 18 to 7, before a crowd of 25,000.

Mayor La Guardia served notice yesterday upon the scrap metal dealers that they have only "a few days" left in which to demonstrate that they can move New York's huge household scrap pile to the steel mills and processing plants without further delay.

Retail trade here was active last week and a number of stores showed gains ranging around 20 to 25 per cent over a year ago. In part, the heavy increases were due to comparison with low sales figures in 1941 in the period immediately following the end of the "beat-the-tax" buying rush.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- The drive of the National Association of Retail Druggists for better treatment of the small retailer in an area of dwindling supplies of consumer goods will probably get under way before the month is out, it was learned at headquarters here soon after this week's N.A.R.D. convention adjourned.

Plans have been completed for the three open field trial meetings for spaniels that will be held in the Eastern section of the country this Autumn. The Bath County Field Trial Association will open the season with its meeting at Hot Springs, Va.
